site_title: Shanghai: Stocks edge up at open
summary: Shanghai stocks opened slightly higher on Wednesday, with the benchmark Shanghai Composite Index rising 0.22% to 2,991.18. The move follows developments in the spread of coronavirus globally and at home, particularly a fresh outbreak in Beijing. Hong Kong was closed for a public holiday.

site_title: KrisEnergy's DBS revolving credit facility now due on Dec 31
summary: KrisEnergy's DBS revolving credit facility now due on Dec 31, 2020, after being extended by six months from June 30, 2020. The facility has outstanding principal of US$177.3 million, and Keppel Corp, which holds an indirect interest, will not be required to make a payment to DBS. The extension is part of KrisEnergy's debt restructuring plan, which Keppel will support and evaluate.

site_title: Japan business mood worsens to 11-year low on virus woes: BOJ tankan
summary: Japan's business mood worsened to an 11-year low in the second quarter, with manufacturers' sentiment index declining to minus 34 in June, down from minus 8 in March. This is the sixth straight quarter of declines and the lowest level since June 2009. Despite this, the index is expected to improve to minus 27 over the next three months. Capital expenditure plans also rose to 3.2% in the financial year to March 2021.

site_title: Tom Hanks: 'I have no idea when I will go back to work'
summary: US actor Tom Hanks said Hollywood has "no idea" when it can return to production after contracting COVID-19, describing his own recovery as "model." Hanks and wife Rita Wilson had 10 days of uncomfortable symptoms, but no life-threatening issues. Despite California giving the all-clear for filming, major Hollywood productions remain frozen, with no clear timeline for a return to work, citing financial, legal, and physical concerns.

site_title: Google buys smart glasses startup North
summary: Google acquired smart glasses startup North for an undisclosed price, reportedly around $180 million. North, based in Canada, was developing Focals glasses that respond to gestures and eye signals. The acquisition will help Google develop its ambient computing vision, where devices seamlessly integrate with users' surroundings. This move marks a renewed focus on this technology, following the limited commercial success of Google Glass.

images.alt_text: Google acquired smart glasses startup North to help the internet giant develop what it calls ambient computing. A price wasn't disclosed, but the Globe and Mail recently reported a US$180 million deal was imminent.

site_title: Europe: Stocks steady at open
summary: European stock markets opened flat on Wednesday, with London's FTSE 100 index at 6,171.20 points, following a strong second quarter. The eurozone's DAX 30 index gained 0.6% and the Paris CAC 40 dipped 0.1%. Despite this, the FTSE 100 remains down around 20% from the start of the year.

site_title: Japan's consumer mood improves in June but outlook uncertain
summary: Japan's consumer confidence index rose to 28.4 in June, up from 24.0 in May, with a reading below 50 indicating pessimism. This marks an improvement from the record low of 21.6 in April. The government noted signs of a pick-up in sentiment, but severity remained uncertain.

site_title: Olam unit obtains US$375m European revolving credit facility
summary: Olam Holdings, a subsidiary of Olam International, has secured a US$375 million European revolving credit facility with a 364-day tenor, guaranteed by Olam International. The lenders include KfW IPEX-Bank, Erste Group Bank, Intesa Sanpaolo Bank Luxembourg, ABC International Bank, Bank of Baroda, Sumitomo Mitsui Banking Corporation, and AKA Ausfuhrkredit-Gesellschaft. The facility agent is KfW IPEX-Bank. This refinancing aims to provide the company with a flexible funding option to support its operations.

site_title: Kylie Jenner's cosmetics partner sues Coty after investment
summary: Seed Beauty, the cosmetics partner of Kylie Jenner, is suing Coty, a beauty industry giant, alleging Coty stole trade secrets after investing $600 million in Jenner's company. Seed Beauty claims Coty gained access to its proprietary strategies to develop and grow cosmetics lines. This comes after Seed Beauty won an injunction preventing Kim Kardashian West from sharing trade secrets with Coty in a separate deal. The lawsuit broadens a legal battle over the Kardashian family's cosmetics empire.

site_title: Stocks to watch: Frasers Centrepoint Trust, Keppel, Sembcorp, Perennial, SPH, ESR-Reit
summary: Key developments in Singapore's stock market include Frasers Centrepoint Trust acquiring a stake in PGIM Real Estate Asia Retail Fund, Keppel Corp extending its revolving credit facility, Sembcorp Industries acquiring Veolia ES Singapore, and Perennial Real Estate Holdings selling a stake in AXA Tower to Alibaba Group. ESR-Reit secured two new tenants, while Kimly Limited acquired a coffee shop and Geo Energy Resources engaged legal advisers amid a potential dispute. Other companies, such as Mermaid Maritime and Luzhou Bio-Chem Technology, made announcements related to business units and takeovers.

site_title: Business group urges new public finance tools amid virus crisis
summary: A regional business lobby, the US-Asean Business Council, has urged Southeast Asian governments to adopt new public finance tools to ensure essential goods and payouts reach citizens during the pandemic. The council proposes trade finance, escrow accounts, and instant payment schemes to expedite delivery of essential medical supplies and protect against fraud. The report also suggests blended public-private capital structures and pandemic bonds to support small businesses and hospitals. The council is prepared to offer immediate help and collaborate on longer-term initiatives for resilience and growth.

site_title: Taiwan opens office to help people fleeing Hong Kong after China passes new security law
summary: Taiwan has opened an office to assist people fleeing Hong Kong after China's new national security law came into effect, which imposes up to life in prison for crimes of secession and subversion. The move is seen as a gesture of support for Hong Kong's pro-democracy movement, which has won widespread backing in Taiwan. Around 200 Hong Kongers have already fled to Taiwan since protests began last year, and the new office aims to provide assistance, including accommodation, to those seeking refuge. Taiwan's government has pledged to support democracy and freedom in Hong Kong.

site_title: South Korea's Moon calls for US-North Korea summit before US election
summary: South Korean President Moon Jae-in has urged US President Donald Trump and North Korean leader Kim Jong Un to meet again before the US presidential election in November. This would help resume stalled nuclear negotiations and address issues such as nuclear programs and sanctions. Moon's comments come after US Deputy Secretary of State Stephen Biegun expressed doubts about an in-person summit before the election due to the coronavirus pandemic. The two sides had previously met in 2018 and 2019, but their talks fell apart.

site_title: Biden says will not hold campaign rallies due to pandemic
summary: US Democratic presidential candidate Joe Biden announced he will not hold campaign rallies during the coronavirus pandemic, citing health concerns and government guidelines. This decision contrasts with Republican candidate Donald Trump, who has held large campaign gatherings. Biden will instead focus on virtual events, citing a record 200 million people who have watched his campaign content online. Despite this unconventional approach, Biden is currently leading in national polling and in key swing states.

site_title: Tokyo: Stocks open higher after US gains
summary: Tokyo stocks opened higher on Wednesday, driven by gains on Wall Street, despite a weak business confidence survey from Japan. The Nikkei 225 index rose 0.27% to 22,348.48, while the Topix index added 0.24% to 1,562.58. The gains follow a strong performance on US markets, where the S&P 500 and Nasdaq edged to fresh records despite ongoing tariff uncertainty.

site_title: Oil slips slightly on rising coronavirus cases, returning Libyan supplies
summary: Oil prices slipped on Tuesday as investors worried about rising coronavirus cases hurting demand, while supply could rise with a potential Libyan oil production resurgence. The Brent contract settled down 58 cents at $41.27 a barrel, and US crude fell 43 cents to $39.27 a barrel. Investors will monitor weekly inventory data for signs of demand recovery. Analysts expect oil prices to consolidate at around $40 a barrel this year, with a recovery gaining steam in the fourth quarter.

images.alt_text: Oil prices slipped on Tuesday as investors worried that rising Covid-19 cases would hurt demand while supply could rise with a potential resurgence of Libyan oil production, which has slowed to a trickle since the start of the year.

site_title: Geo Energy engages legal advisers on potential dispute related to proposed acquisition
summary: Geo Energy Resources has engaged legal advisers amid reports of a potential dispute over a proposed US$25 million acquisition of Titan Infra Energy's stake in Titan Global Energy. The dispute centers on Geo Energy's proposed coal purchase agreements with Titan Infra Energy, which was filed by the current or former ultimate controlling shareholders of Titan Infra Energy in the Jakarta courts. Geo Energy's subsidiaries, Geo Ventures Global and Geo Coal International, are also being targeted in the claim.

site_title: Broker's take: RHB upgrades Genting Singapore to 'neutral' as RWS reopens attractions
summary: RHB has upgraded Genting Singapore to 'neutral' with a new target price of S$0.73 from S$0.64, following the integrated resort operator's reopening of attractions at Resorts World Sentosa with limited capacities and safe distancing measures. Analysts expect limited sales growth in 2020, but the reopening marks a positive step towards resuming operations. Genting Singapore shares were trading flat at S$0.76, with RHB cutting its forecast earnings by 11% and profit after tax by 14% for fiscal 2021-22.

site_title: HDB resale prices rise marginally in Q2 amid Covid-19 outbreak: flash estimates
summary: HDB resale prices in Singapore rose marginally in Q2 2020, with a 0.2% increase in the resale price index to 131.8, according to flash estimates. This marks a slight recovery after prices remained flat in Q1 amid the Covid-19 outbreak. Experts attribute the stable prices to the government's stimulus package and minimal panic selling, despite a significant decline in resale volume due to the circuit breaker period.

site_title: Mnuchin sees support for crisis loans to hotels, restaurants in US
summary: US Treasury Secretary Steven Mnuchin suggests repurposing up to $140 billion in crisis loans to support restaurants, hotels, and other industries hit hard by the coronavirus pandemic. The funds, currently allocated for small businesses, are set to expire on Tuesday. Mnuchin expressed support for lawmakers to "repurpose" the money, amid concerns that expiring programs could deprive the economy of hundreds of billions of dollars in spending.

site_title: Sembcorp completes Veolia deal for S$19.2m
summary: Sembcorp Industries has completed the acquisition of Veolia ES Singapore (VESS) and its public cleaning business for S$19.2 million. The deal, internally funded and fully paid in cash, does not expect to impact Sembcorp's earnings per share or net asset value per share for the 2020 financial year. The acquisition includes contracts for public and commercial waste and recyclable collections, as well as associated properties. Regulatory approvals were met, with the Competition and Consumer Commission of Singapore clearing the deal due to sufficient competition in the relevant markets.

site_title: DBS to make second cut on Multiplier account rates this year
summary: DBS, Singapore's largest lender, will cut interest rates on its flagship deposit account, the DBS Multiplier account, starting August 1. The rate cuts will apply to account balances up to S$50,000 and will be halved for customers who meet certain transaction and income requirements. The changes are in line with a low interest rate environment and macro uncertainties, and follow similar rate cuts announced by DBS's banking peers, OCBC and Standard Chartered.

site_title: Japan's new auto sales skid 23% y-o-y in June: industry data
summary: Japan's new auto sales dropped 23% in June from the same month last year, with a total of 347,371 units sold. This decline is attributed to consumers continuing to avoid car purchases due to the coronavirus outbreak. The data comes from the Japan Automobile Dealers Association and an association for Japan's "kei" mini cars.

site_title: Singapore firms see more payment delays in Q2; retail and services post highest jumps
summary: Singapore firms experienced a rise in payment delays in Q2, with retail and services sectors posting the highest jumps. Slow payments increased to 45.78% in Q2, up 3.20 percentage points from Q1, and 8.68 percentage points year-on-year. Retail and services sectors saw the largest quarterly increases in payment delays, with retail increasing to 51.22% and services to 48.35%. The cash-flow situation for firms remains tight, prompting caution on firms' credit policies.

site_title: China must reconsider Hong Kong security law, 27 countries tell UN
summary: China's national security law in Hong Kong has been condemned by 27 countries, including Britain, France, Germany, and Japan, at the UN Human Rights Council. The countries say the law undermines Hong Kong's freedoms and must be reconsidered. The 27 nations also urged China to allow the UN rights chief access to its western Xinjiang province, citing concerns over arbitrary detention, surveillance, and human rights abuses. The statement calls for China to engage Hong Kong's people and institutions to prevent further erosion of rights and freedoms.

images.alt_text: China must reconsider its sweeping national security law imposed on Hong Kong which "undermines" the city's freedoms, 27 countries said in a joint statement on Tuesday.

site_title: Japan could reimpose state of emergency in worst-case scenario: Suga
summary: Japan's Chief Cabinet Secretary Yoshihide Suga stated that the country is not currently in a situation to declare another state of emergency due to the coronavirus, but could do so in a worst-case scenario. Despite Tokyo's recent surge in cases, Japan has had a lower rate of infection than many countries. In contrast, the US saw a record spike in new infections on Tuesday.

site_title: Australia: Shares end firmer as investors bet on fresh stimulus
summary: Australian shares rose 0.6% on their first trading day of the year, driven by hopes for fresh stimulus measures. The S&P/ASX 200 index closed at 5,934.40, despite concerns over further lockdowns in Melbourne. Gold stocks surged 4.2% and technology stocks jumped 1.6%, while healthcare stocks fell 0.8%. Investors are cautious about lockdowns, but believe the economy needs "considerable" support.

site_title: Hong Kong: Market closed for holiday on Wednesday
summary: Hong Kong's stock market is closed on Wednesday for a public holiday. The article also mentions various market developments, including a mandatory offer for PSC shares, traders brushing off new Trump threats, and companies like Singtel, Sinarmas Land, and Airalo raising funds. The S&P 500 and Nasdaq reached fresh records despite tariff uncertainty, and the STI rose 0.4% on Thursday.

site_title: Facebook frustrates advertisers as boycott over hate speech kicks off
summary: Facebook is facing a boycott by over 400 brands, including Coca-Cola and Starbucks, amid concerns over hate speech on the platform. The boycott, sparked by the death of George Floyd, calls for concrete steps to block hate speech. Despite meetings with advertisers, Facebook executives offered no new details on how they would tackle the issue. The company's CEO, Mark Zuckerberg, has agreed to meet with the boycott organizers. The boycott is unlikely to have a significant financial impact on Facebook, as the top 100 brands on the platform account for less than 20% of its ad revenue.

site_title: UK house prices fall for first time since 2012: Nationwide
summary: UK house prices fell 0.1% annually in June, the first decline since 2012, according to Nationwide. In monthly terms, prices dropped 1.4%, slightly less than May's 1.7% fall. The decline was attributed to the coronavirus shock to the economy, with mortgage approvals at a record low in May. Despite easing restrictions, the medium-term outlook remains uncertain. Nationwide's chief economist predicted a slight pick-up in activity once broader lockdown measures ease, but long-term damage to the economy is a concern. London house prices rose 2.1% annually over the second quarter.

site_title: Wirecard administrator says received inbound interest for assets
summary: Wirecard's administrator, Michael Jaffe, stated that the company has received strong inbound interest for its assets, with a large number of investors from around the world expressing interest in acquiring the core business or independent business units. This comes after Wirecard filed for insolvency last week due to a 1.9 billion euro hole in its accounts attributed to a global fraud. The administrator aims to stabilize the business operations of the company's subsidiaries, and individual unit insolvencies cannot be ruled out, while Wirecard Bank remains solvent and unaffected by the insolvency process.

site_title: Biotech firm Carmine Therapeutics inks US$900m deal with Takeda Pharmaceuticals
summary: Carmine Therapeutics, a biotech firm, has signed a US$900 million research agreement with Takeda Pharmaceuticals to discover, develop, and commercialize two rare-disease drugs using the company's novel gene therapy technology, Regent. The deal includes upfront and milestone payments, as well as tiered royalties. Carmine Therapeutics has raised over US$9.4 million in seed equity financing, led by Esco Ventures and Takeda Ventures. The technology, developed by Singaporean researchers, enables red blood cells to deliver nucleic acid drugs through extracellular vesicles, offering a potentially safer and cheaper alternative to current gene therapies.

site_title: South Korea's June factory activity shrinks for sixth month: PMI
summary: South Korea's manufacturing activity declined for the sixth consecutive month in June, according to the IHS Markit purchasing managers' index (PMI), which rose to 43.4 from 41.3 in May. The decline is attributed to the ongoing coronavirus impact on global demand and uncertainty over economic recovery. Business conditions remain weak, with many companies operating below capacity or experiencing no month-to-month improvement in production and new order volumes. Analysts have downgraded economic projections for South Korea, with the International Monetary Fund now predicting a 2.1% contraction this year.

site_title: Airbus cuts 15,000 jobs to face aviation's 'gravest crisis'
summary: Airbus plans to cut 15,000 jobs, approximately 11% of its workforce, due to the coronavirus crisis, described as the "gravest crisis" the industry has seen. The cuts will be implemented by summer 2021, with 5,000 positions to be cut in France, 5,100 in Germany, and 1,700 in Britain. The company aims to limit the social impact of the cuts and is exploring alternative measures, including voluntary departures and early retirement schemes. The aviation industry is expected to take until 2023 or later to recover from the pandemic.

site_title: Asia: Most markets up on economy hopes despite virus fears
summary: Asia markets rose on Wednesday, driven by optimism over economic recovery despite rising virus cases, with US consumer confidence beating expectations. Analysts expect trillions of dollars in government and central bank support to continue supporting equities. In the US, Anthony Fauci warned of a potential surge in daily cases unless efforts to control the pandemic improve. Despite this, markets are unlikely to rally unless a major breakthrough in a vaccine is made.

site_title: Google pushes back US office reopening plan after virus surge
summary: Google is pushing back its plan to reopen its US offices due to a surge in coronavirus cases in western and southern states. The company will keep all US offices closed until at least September 7, reversing a previous plan to reopen on July 6. This decision follows a memo from Google's vice-president of global security, Chris Rackow, stating that the US outlook must be stable before offices can reopen. The move aligns with Google's previous stance of not forcing employees to return to the office for the remainder of the year.

images.alt_text: Google is pushing back a plan to reopen its US offices after coronavirus cases surged in several western and southern states.

site_title: China's factory activity expands, but job losses quicken amid weak exports: Caixin PMI
summary: China's factory activity expanded in June, with the Caixin/Markit Manufacturing Purchasing Managers' Index rising to 51.2, the fastest pace of growth since December. However, exports remained subdued due to faltering global demand, and job losses accelerated for the sixth consecutive month. Demand remained subdued, with new export orders staying in contractionary territory. The government has rolled out easing steps, including reserve requirement cuts and targeted lending support, but a top priority remains avoiding mass unemployment, with a target to create over nine million urban jobs this year.

images.alt_text: China's factory activity grew at a faster clip in June after the government lifted coronavirus lockdown measures and ramped up support steps, but the health crisis continues to pressure exports and jobs, a private business survey showed on Wednesday.

site_title: Australia: Shares rise on stimulus hopes; New Zealand lower
summary: Australian shares rose 0.37% to 5,919.8, boosted by hopes for further stimulus measures to prop up the pandemic-hit economy, despite concerns over a second wave of coronavirus infections. The gold subindex surged 2.72% as bullion prices reached a near eight-year high. Technology stocks gained over 2% and metals and mining stocks rose 0.86%. On Wall Street, the three major indexes rose between 0.9% and 1.9%. In contrast, New Zealand's benchmark index fell 0.34% to 11,411.7.

images.alt_text: Australian shares traded higher on Wednesday, boosted by hopes for further stimulus measures to prop up a pandemic-hit economy, although gains were capped by fears of a second wave of coronavirus infections.

site_title: TransferWise gets nod to offer investment services in UK
summary: TransferWise, a London-based fintech startup, has received permission from the UK's financial watchdog to offer retail investment services in Britain. The company plans to launch its first investment product within the next year, allowing customers to invest money stored in their multi-currency accounts into affordable funds. The investment services will be protected under the Financial Services Compensation scheme, with deposits up to £85,000 (S$147,000) covered. This move expands TransferWise's offerings, following similar expansions by other fintech startups such as Betterment and Wealthfront.

site_title: Australia to lock down 300,000 in Melbourne suburbs after coronavirus spike
summary: Australia is imposing a month-long lockdown on around 300,000 people in Melbourne suburbs to contain the risk of coronavirus infection, following two weeks of double-digit rises in new cases. The restrictions, the third-strictest level, will restrict residents to home except for essential activities, and a testing blitz will be implemented to extend to half the affected population. The move comes as Victoria's cases surge, linked to staff members at hotels housing returned travellers, and authorities warn of a possible return to broader restrictions across the city.

site_title: Gold firms near 8-year peak as virus fears grow
summary: Gold prices rose near an 8-year peak on July 1, driven by concerns over the global economic impact of the coronavirus pandemic. Spot gold increased 0.1% to US$1,782.67 per ounce, while US gold futures remained steady at US$1,800.60. The surge in gold prices is attributed to the injection of funds into the global monetary system and the need for investors to find a safe-haven asset. Experts warn that if the virus surge continues, gold prices could reach US$1,800, but the risk-on sentiment and dollar's weakness may hold back the metal's price.

site_title: China to announce curbs on US media: Global Times editor
summary: China plans to announce reciprocal curbs on US media outlets in response to the US treating Chinese media outlets as foreign embassies. The move comes amid increasing tensions between the two countries, particularly over the coronavirus pandemic. China had previously expelled American journalists from three US newspapers in March. The US had also limited visas for Chinese reporters to a 90-day period with the option for extension. The reciprocal measures are expected to further sour strained relations between the world's top two economies.

images.alt_text: China will announce reciprocal curbs on US media outlets in the country, the editor in chief of the Global Times newspaper said on Twitter on Wednesday.

site_title: Magnus Energy clarifies CEO actually has indirect interest in Malaysian firm
summary: Magnus Energy's CEO Charles Madhavan has clarified that he has an indirect interest in Malaysian firm Blue Water Engineering (M) Sdn Bhd (BWEM) through a 50% stake in Blue Water Asia Pacific Group (Blue Water BVI). Two directors quit the company last month due to disagreements with Madhavan over BWEM-related matters. Magnus has terminated payments to BWEM and will continue to provide office space and admin services until MEG's winding down process is complete.

site_title: Bharti Airtel proposes to sell 25% stake in data centre unit for US$235m
summary: Bharti Airtel is proposing to sell a 25% stake in its data centre unit Nxtra Data to private equity firm The Carlyle Group for US$235 million. The transaction, subject to regulatory approvals, aims to scale up Nxtra's infrastructure and offerings across India. Nxtra has a nationwide portfolio of data centres and is building more across the country to capture growth opportunities. The deal values Nxtra at US$1.2 billion post-money, with proceeds to be used for infrastructure expansion.

site_title: Singapore private home prices down 1.1% q-o-q in Q2 2020: URA flash estimate
summary: Singapore's private home prices dropped 1.1% in Q2 2020, according to the Urban Redevelopment Authority's flash estimate. This follows a 1% drop in Q1 and a year-on-year decline of 0.3%. Non-landed property prices eased 0.6% quarter-on-quarter, while landed properties fell 2.7%. The drop is attributed to the "circuit breaker" lockdown, which led to lower transaction volumes. Experts predict a 3-6% drop in the overall private home price index for 2020, with some predicting a 5% decline.

site_title: Wanted for graft, ex-Pemex boss to be extradited to Mexico from Spain
summary: Former Pemex CEO Emilio Lozoya, 45, has agreed to be extradited from Spain to Mexico to face trial on corruption charges, including bribery and money laundering. Lozoya, a close confidant of former President Enrique Peña Nieto, has repeatedly denied wrongdoing. The extradition is seen as a boost to President Andres Manuel Lopez Obrador's efforts to crack down on corruption. Lozoya was arrested in Spain in February and had been on the run since fleeing Mexico. He faces a lengthy prison sentence if found guilty.

site_title: Goldman nears 1MDB resolution with effort to avoid guilty plea
summary: Goldman Sachs is nearing a resolution with the US Justice Department over its role in the 1MDB scandal, potentially avoiding a guilty plea. The bank's defense team, led by Karen Seymour, has appealed to the Justice Department's top officials to avoid a guilty plea. A deal could include a penalty of up to $2 billion. If Goldman escapes a guilty plea, it would be a significant victory for the bank, and Seymour may still be able to soften the blow by negotiating what details are included in a statement of facts.

site_title: Hong Kong marks handover anniversary as national security law takes effect
summary: Hong Kong marked the 23rd anniversary of its handover to Chinese rule, as a new national security law took effect, punishing crimes of secession and subversion with up to life in prison. The law, which critics fear will crush freedoms, was hailed by Hong Kong leader Carrie Lam as a necessary step to restore stability. A dozen demonstrators protested, while authorities barred an annual march, citing coronavirus restrictions. Pro-democracy activists vowed to defy the order and march later, amid concerns the legislation will erode Hong Kong's autonomy and global financial center status.

site_title: Malaysia: Shares open higher on Wednesday
summary: Malaysia's shares opened higher on Wednesday, with the FTSE Bursa Malaysia Kuala Lumpur Composite Index rising 6.79 points, or 0.45%, to 1,507.76. Volume was 203.30 million lots worth RM53.72 million. Gainers beat losers 214 to 69.

site_title: Automatic recount if difference in votes is 2% or less; special voting hour for those serving stay-home notice
summary: Singapore's General Election 2020 will be held on July 10, with automatic recounts if the difference in votes between the top candidate and any other candidate is 2% or less. Special voting arrangements have been made for those serving stay-home notice, with a designated hour between 7-8pm for them to vote. Polling stations have been increased to 1,100, and voters can use the SingPass Mobile app to access their ePoll card. The election result will be announced by the Returning Officer, and counting machines will be used to quicken the counting process.

site_title: Europe: Stocks record best quarter since March 2015 on recovery hopes
summary: Europe's pan-European Stoxx 600 closed at a 0.1% gain on Tuesday, marking its best quarter since March 2015, driven by hopes of an economic rebound despite coronavirus concerns. The index rose 12.6% in the second quarter, led by technology, mining, and real estate sectors. Despite mixed data, including a record economic contraction in the UK, investors focused on positive economic signs and unprecedented stimulus.

site_title: SGX to launch FTSE Taiwan Index futures on July 20
summary: The Singapore Exchange (SGX) will launch a futures contract on the FTSE Taiwan RIC Capped Index (FTSE Taiwan) on July 20, allowing investors to gain exposure to Taiwan's large and mid-cap stocks. The contract will provide a cost-efficient way for global investors to invest in the Taiwan stock market across different time zones. The FTSE Taiwan index covers nearly 80% of Taiwan's listed companies, offering a strong correlation with other major Taiwan benchmark indices. The launch aims to meet the rising demand for access to the Taiwan market from US and European investors.

site_title: Mask mandate could save US economic recovery: Goldman Sachs
summary: Goldman Sachs suggests a national mask mandate in the US could partially substitute for lockdowns, potentially saving the country's economic recovery by subtracting nearly 5% from US growth. According to the report, mask mandates in 125 countries resulted in a 17.3% weekly increase in coronavirus cases, compared to a 7.3% increase with a mask mandate. A national mask mandate in the US could lower daily growth in infections to 1% from 2.9%.

site_title: Japan's June factory activity extends declines for 14th month: PMI
summary: Japan's factory activity declined for the 14th consecutive month in June, according to a business survey, citing sharp reductions in output and new orders due to the coronavirus pandemic. The final PMI index rose to 40.1 from 38.4 in May, indicating a contraction. Economists expect a slim chance of a V-shape recovery, with fragile demand capacity and declining employment levels. The future output subindex showed a positive trend for the first time since February, but overall, the data points to a heavy hit to demand from the pandemic.

site_title: Investor confidence in Singapore's government fundamental to economic success: PM Lee
summary: Singaporean Prime Minister Lee Hsien Loong emphasized the importance of investor confidence in the country's government, citing its strong reputation and popular support. This confidence has attracted S$13 billion in investment commitments despite the COVID-19 pandemic. Lee highlighted the need to reinforce these fundamentals to attract more investments and jobs, particularly in creating new opportunities. He urged voters to hand the ruling People's Action Party a strong mandate to navigate the economic crisis and lead the country towards better days ahead.

site_title: ESR-Reit secures two new tenants at 8 Tuas South Lane
summary: ESR-Reit has secured two new tenants at 8 Tuas South Lane, a multi-tenanted general industrial property in Singapore. Pacific Integrated Logistics and Royal's Engineering & Trading (S) have leased 284,700 square feet, increasing the property's committed occupancy to 90.3%. The new tenants will reduce ESR-Reit's rental income exposure to Hyflux Membrane from 2.8% to 1.6% on a portfolio basis. The signings were made during the Covid-19 pandemic, as part of ESR-Reit's repositioning exercise to extract synergies before the completion of the Tuas Megaport.

site_title: Koufu plans to acquire fried food, dough product supplier for S$22m
summary: Koufu Group has proposed to acquire Deli Asia, Delisnacks, Dough Culture, and Dough Heritage for approximately S$22 million. The acquisition, funded by Koufu's internal resources, will allow the company to expand its supply of fried food and dough products, and strengthen its supply chain. The deal is expected to provide synergistic effects, improve productivity, and increase revenue streams. Koufu plans to integrate the target group's production facilities into its new headquarters, which is expected to be completed this year.

images.alt_text: Sesame balls with yellow bean paste, one of Delisnack's products.

site_title: Microsoft says to teach 25 million people digital work skills
summary: Microsoft has launched an initiative to teach 25 million people around the world digital-age work skills for free by the end of the year, with a $20 million cash grant to support nonprofit organizations and resources from GitHub and LinkedIn. The effort aims to provide digital skills training to those hardest hit by job losses, including lower-income individuals, women, and underrepresented minorities. Microsoft president Brad Smith says the initiative is a key step towards fostering a safe and successful economic recovery.

site_title: Australia home prices slip in June, but sales rebound: CoreLogic
summary: Australian home prices fell 0.7% in June, marking the second consecutive decline, but sales rebounded 29.5% after a 21.5% gain in May. Despite a drop in prices, the housing market remains resilient due to low advertised stock levels, government stimulus, and record-low mortgage rates. Clearance rates at home auctions have also rebounded, supporting economic activity and tax receipts for state governments.

images.alt_text: Australian home prices slipped for a second month in June as coronavirus lockdowns and rising unemployment cooled a once red-hot market, though a sharp rebound in sales was a positive for economic activity.

site_title: Australia to sharply increase defence spending with focus on Indo-Pacific
summary: Australia plans to increase defence spending by 40% over 10 years, focusing on the Indo-Pacific region, with a budget of A$270 billion. The move aims to acquire longer-range strike capabilities and counterbalance China's growing influence in the region. The increased spending will include 200 long-range anti-ship missiles and hypersonic missiles, but may strain relations with China, Australia's largest trading partner.

site_title: Hong Kong law 'none of your business': China to foreign critics
summary: China has dismissed international criticism of its new national security law for Hong Kong, saying it's "none of your business". Beijing officials argue the law, which critics claim will curb freedoms, was widely consulted with Hong Kong society and is only targeted at "a handful of criminals". China's State Council spokesperson, Zhang Xiaoming, criticized Western governments for interfering in Hong Kong's affairs, calling it "bandit logic". The law's passing comes after Hong Kong pro-democracy party Demosisto announced its disbandment.

site_title: Judge temporarily blocks 'tell-all' book by Trump's niece
summary: A New York judge has temporarily halted the publication of a "tell-all" book by Donald Trump's niece, Mary Trump, until a July 10 court hearing. The book, which claims Trump is "the world's most dangerous man," was initially blocked by Trump's brother, Robert, who claimed Mary was violating a non-disclosure agreement. The temporary restraining order, which prevents the book's release, will be reviewed at the court hearing. Mary's attorney vows to immediately appeal the order, calling it a prior restraint on core political speech that violates the First Amendment.

site_title: US: Stocks gain to finish banner quarter, shrugging off virus spike
summary: US stocks ended a historically strong second quarter on a positive note, closing 1.5% higher and 20% for the quarter, with the S&P 500 reaching 3,100.29. Despite a resurgence in US coronavirus cases, investors seem optimistic, with top infectious disease expert Anthony Fauci warning the country is heading in the "wrong direction" and cases could reach 100,000 a day if action isn't taken. Analysts attribute the market's resilience to local restrictions and a "momentum-driven rally."

site_title: Singapore shares open higher on Wednesday; STI up 0.8%
summary: Singapore's Straits Times Index (STI) rose 0.8% on Wednesday, reaching 2,610.35 points, driven by US gains overnight. Local banks DBS, OCBC, and UOB also rose, while Thai Beverage Public Co and Medtecs International fell. The STI's gain was largely attributed to the US market's historically strong quarter and investors' optimism about the economic recovery from the coronavirus crisis.

site_title: Tung Lok unit renews Orchard Central lease for one year
summary: Tung Lok Restaurants, a 60% owned subsidiary, has renewed the lease of its Orchard Central tenancy for a year. The two units, occupying 3,444.48 square feet, will continue to be used as the Dancing Crab restaurant premises. The estimated rental fees are S$300,000, while the estimated value of the renewal to the company is S$180,000, representing 1.2% of its latest audited net tangible assets.

site_title: Tokyo: Stocks close lower on virus worries
summary: Tokyo stocks closed lower on July 1, 2020, due to concerns over the increase in new coronavirus cases in the capital. The Nikkei 225 index fell 0.75% and the Topix index fell 1.29%. Japan's top government spokesperson warned a state of emergency could be re-issued.

site_title: US fatalities on rise with more than 1,000 deaths in 24 hours
summary: The US recorded 1,199 COVID-19 fatalities over the past 24 hours, surpassing the 1,000 death toll threshold for the first time since June 10. The country's total death toll stands at 127,322. New cases also rose to 42,528. Many US states have paused their reopening processes due to the surge in cases and deaths. Infectious disease expert Anthony Fauci warned that new cases could more than double to 100,000 per day if authorities and the public fail to take steps to suppress the pandemic.

site_title: Switzerland and UK to cooperate more closely on financial services
summary: Switzerland and the UK have signed a joint statement to deepen their cooperation in financial services, including cross-border trading in shares. The agreement aims to enable wholesale financial services access for insurance, banking, asset management, and capital market infrastructure. This move follows Britain's efforts to gain access to the EU financial market, which have been met with resistance from Brussels. Technical work will begin immediately, with a financial dialogue set to start on September 8, allowing investors to trade on each other's stock exchanges once the equivalence powers come into force in December.

site_title: Australia's Lendlease Group scraps dividend as lockdown hits earnings
summary: Australia's Lendlease Group recorded a loss in fiscal year 2020 due to Covid-19 restrictions, with a potential statutory loss of A$230-340 million. Lockdowns delayed project starts and reduced productivity, leading the company to scrap its final dividend. Lendlease cited a possible hit to earnings from the pandemic and withdrew its forecasts. The company also plans to exit its non-core business, incurring estimated restructuring costs of A$525 million.

site_title: Volkswagen, Adidas, Puma join Facebook ad boycott over hate speech
summary: German companies Volkswagen, Adidas, and Puma joined a growing advertiser boycott of Facebook over hate speech, following major brands like Levi's and Coca-Cola. Over 200 brands have paused advertising with the social media giant as part of the #StopHateForProfit campaign. The boycott, sparked by George Floyd's death, aims to pressure Facebook to remove hateful content and improve its platform. The move has already had a significant impact on Facebook's market value, with billions wiped off the company's stock.

site_title: BlackRock eyes distressed property, private debt and equity
summary: BlackRock's chief investment officer, Jim Barry, is seeking opportunities in distressed property, private debt, and equity amid a market rebound that has drained the firm's pool of cheap investable assets. With valuations for alternative assets falling 5-15% in the first quarter, Barry estimates that the firm will not spend all of its $23 billion cash war chest in 2020. BlackRock is looking at short-term lending to high-quality companies and buying assets from private-equity firms, with the goal of purchasing stakes directly in private-equity firms.

site_title: IMF sees Asia's pain persisting as virus curbs limit recovery
summary: The International Monetary Fund (IMF) predicts Asia's economic output will persistently be lower than pre-pandemic levels until 2022, with a 5% gap predicted for 2022 and potentially larger if China is excluded. Global growth is forecast to shrink 4.9% this year, down from 3% predicted in April, with Asia contracting by 1.6%. The IMF emphasizes the need for coordinated policy responses, including central bank lending and fiscal stimulus, to mitigate debt concerns and maintain sovereign credit ratings.

site_title: New York attorney general announces US$19m settlement in Harvey Weinstein lawsuits
summary: The New York Attorney General's office has announced a US$19 million settlement in two sexual misconduct lawsuits against imprisoned former Hollywood mogul Harvey Weinstein. The settlement resolves a 2018 lawsuit filed by the New York Attorney General's office and a 2017 class-action lawsuit on behalf of nine women. However, lawyers representing six women claim the deal is a "complete sellout" that doesn't require Weinstein to accept responsibility or pay out of his own pocket. The settlement will release the women from non-disclosure agreements, allowing them to speak publicly about their experiences.

site_title: BOC Aviation cancels 30 Boeing 737 MAX but backs grounded jet
summary: BOC Aviation has cancelled an order for 30 Boeing 737 MAX planes, deferring the delivery of other aircraft, amid the jet's prolonged grounding. The move is part of a compromise deal with Boeing, allowing the lessor to support the MAX and other products. BOC Aviation's CEO remains confident in the 737 MAX, stating it's not a loss of confidence. The decision is seen as a strategic move to deploy capital during a long-term downturn, rather than a loss of faith in the aircraft.

site_title: More 5G network equipment suppliers would be good for industry
summary: Nokia and Ericsson have secured significant 5G contracts, marking a shift in the global market after Huawei's setbacks due to business and security considerations. The European companies' wins have been a coup, but it's not a zero-sum game, and the industry is now likely to see multiple companies working together to build and maintain 5G networks. This could reduce fears about technology dominance and security breaches, as local governments and carriers explore partnerships with non-US companies to develop their own technology champions.

site_title: Geneva car show called off for 2021, putting to rest plan for state aid
summary: The Geneva car show foundation has cancelled plans to resume the event in 2021, citing the ongoing pandemic and difficulties for exhibitors. The decision comes after a majority of exhibitors declined to participate due to concerns over public health and financial recovery. The foundation will instead sell the show's rights to Palexpo SA, the exhibition centre that hosts the event. This decision puts to rest a controversy over state aid offered to the show's organizers.

site_title: US pending home sales post record gain in May
summary: US pending home sales surged 44.3% in May to a three-month high of 99.6, exceeding economists' median projection of a 19.3% gain. This rebound marks the residential real estate market's faster recovery than most of the economy, despite lingering health concerns and high unemployment. Mortgage rates fell to the lowest on record, stabilizing demand. The National Association of Realtors projects existing home sales to reach 4.93 million units this year, up from a previous forecast of 4.77 million.

site_title: NCMP scheme ensures 'significant opposition presence' whatever election outcome: PM Lee
summary: Prime Minister Lee Hsien Loong stated that the Non-Constituency MP (NCMP) scheme ensures a significant opposition presence in Parliament, regardless of the election outcome. The expanded scheme has increased the number of NCMPs to 12, granting them full voting rights, and is intended to prevent the opposition from being shut out. Lee emphasized the need for voters to scrutinize candidates and parties carefully and to choose those who can best serve their constituency and the country.

images.alt_text: Mr Lee said if PAP is re-elected in Ang Mo Kio GRC as well as Yio Chu Kang and Kebun Baru SMC, they could form a town council. "Then we will have five of us plus two MPs altogether - seven MPs - covering the whole of Ang Mo Kio town which was the way it was earlier when Ang Mo Kio was first opened.

site_title: HK May home prices rise at fastest pace in 13 months
summary: Hong Kong private home prices rose 1.9% in May, the fastest pace of growth in 13 months, driven by low interest rates and pent-up demand. The economy's gradual recovery and stabilisation of Covid-19 across Greater China contributed to the growth. However, property agents expect a weak economy and political tensions to weigh on prices, with no strong pickup anticipated through to the end of 2020. Bankruptcy filings in the city reached a 17-year high in May.

site_title: Customer-centric solutions will take banking into the future
summary: Customer-centric solutions are driving the future of banking, fueled by the widespread adoption of mobile devices and the internet. Fintech, the intersection of finance and technology, is rapidly reshaping the industry, with Asia at its epicenter. Singapore is a leading country in fintech innovation, with a robust landscape that is attracting investment and talent. As the industry continues to evolve, customer-centric solutions will become increasingly important, enabling banks to better serve their customers and stay competitive in a rapidly changing market.

site_title: Francis Bacon's triptych sells for US$84.6 million
summary: Francis Bacon's triptych, "Triptych Inspired by the Oresteia of Aeschylus," sold for US$84.6 million at Sotheby's digitally streamed auction in London, marking the third-highest price achieved for the artist at auction. The triptych, created in 1981, was sold to a telephone bidder in New York after a 10-minute duel with an online opponent in China. The sale surpassed the presale estimate of US$60 million, with the museum having previously tried to sell the work privately for more than US$100 million.

site_title: Money FM podcast: Investing in sustainability critical post-Covid-19
summary: Rob Kaplan, CEO of Circulate Capital, emphasizes the importance of investing in waste management value chains post-Covid-19. He highlights the critical role sustainability plays in driving long-term growth and wealth creation. Investors are encouraged to consider sustainability-focused investments to capitalize on the growing demand for environmentally friendly solutions. Kaplan's comments come as Asia drives dollar asset diversification and the global market experiences record highs.

site_title: Wells Fargo to cut dividend as top rivals maintain payouts
summary: Wells Fargo plans to cut its quarterly dividend to 20 US cents, the first major bank to do so, following the Federal Reserve's new restrictions on payouts. The move is expected, as the bank has struggled to recover from scandals and has seen its earnings plunge. The Fed capped dividends at the largest 33 banks at current levels, citing uncertainty in the economic recovery. Other major banks, including JPMorgan Chase and Goldman Sachs, have maintained their payouts.

images.alt_text: Wells Fargo will announce on July 14 how far the current payout will drop. It is expected to decline to 20 US cents.

site_title: Luzhou Bio-Chem founder launches privatisation bid
summary: Luzhou Bio-Chem Technology Limited's founder, Niu Ji Xing, has launched a voluntary conditional general offer to take the company private, valuing it at S$17.8 million. The offer price is S$0.03 per share, representing a premium of up to 150% over the company's volume-weighted average price. The move aims to provide greater management flexibility and control, as well as reduce compliance costs associated with being listed. The offer is seen as an opportunity for shareholders to exit their investment, given the stock's low trading liquidity.

site_title: Japan's May factory output slumps as economy sinks deeper in recession
summary: Japan's factory output plummeted 8.4% in May to its lowest level since the 2009 financial crisis, with the jobless rate reaching a three-year high of 2.9%. The economy is bracing for its worst postwar recession, hurt by coronavirus lockdowns and supply chain disruptions. Manufacturers expect output to rise in June and July, but the government warns of a sharp decline in industrial production, with output falling across all industries surveyed. The country is also seeing a surge in bankruptcies, with 290 firms going under since February.

site_title: Beauty World site set to catalyse area's rejuvenation
summary: A 3.22-hectare site near Beauty World MRT station in Singapore is set to be developed into a mixed-use project, with a potential sale price of S$780m to S$1.3b. The site, which can accommodate up to 96,551 sq m of GFA, is expected to feature a bus interchange, commercial and residential units, and public spaces. Developers are likely to form consortiums to bid for the site, which is envisioned to rejuvenate the Beauty World area and provide a landmark development. The project's completion is expected to coincide with the recovery of the Singapore economy, with the residential component launching for sale in 2022.

site_title: India telecom tycoon bids for SoftBank-backed OneWeb: sources
summary: Indian telecom tycoon Sunil Mittal's Bharti group has submitted a bid for bankrupt satellite firm OneWeb, backed by the UK government. The UK plans to commit $500 million to OneWeb as part of its Chapter 11 bankruptcy proceedings. The bid also attracted interest from Canada's Telesat. OneWeb's low-Earth orbit satellites provide high-speed communications and face competition from SpaceX and Amazon-linked projects. The UK's interest in OneWeb is part of its efforts to form a new national navigation system and attract foreign investment to offset its departure from the EU.

site_title: Keen fight in West Coast, with ex-PAP man facing off PAP team
summary: Dr. Tan Cheng Bock, a former PAP MP, is facing off against a PAP team in the West Coast Group Representation Constituency (GRC) election. The PAP has moved Minister Desmond Lee to the constituency, while Dr. Tan has picked a strong slate of candidates. Analysts expect a keenly-fought battle in a traditionally "safe" ward for the PAP, with Dr. Tan's experience on the ground potentially giving him an advantage. The PSP's maiden electoral outing is seen as a key test for the party.

site_title: China's June factory activity quickens, but exporters struggle
summary: China's factory activity expanded at a stronger pace in June, with the manufacturing PMI reaching 50.9, above the forecast. Production grew to 53.9, while export orders contracted but at a slower pace. Domestic demand is picking up, with a brighter outlook for the economy, but uncertainties remain due to the ongoing coronavirus crisis. The government has announced measures to bolster the economy, but the global downturn has led to patchy activity in most sectors.

site_title: Covid-19 shock has put banks under pressure on several fronts: BIS
summary: The Bank for International Settlements (BIS) expects a growing number of global insolvencies over the next 12 months due to the Covid-19 pandemic's economic crisis. The BIS warns that banks, particularly those in emerging markets, will face significant pressure as governments stop supporting businesses and employees. The organization notes that banks' balance sheets are stronger than they were during the 2008 global financial crisis, but still face vulnerabilities such as reliance on dollar funding and junk debt. The BIS advises central banks to raise interest rates to mitigate the massive size of global debt.

site_title: DPM Heng's entry raises stakes for voters in keenly fought-over East Coast GRC
summary: Deputy Prime Minister Heng Swee Keat's surprise entry into the East Coast Group Representation Constituency (GRC) election as part of the People's Action Party (PAP) team has raised the stakes for voters, with observers citing the potential consequences of a PAP victory. Heng's inclusion has turned the contest into a test of the party's strength, with former PAP MP Inderjit Singh stating that voters will be more cautious, knowing that Heng is the future PM. The GRC has a history of close contests between PAP and the Workers' Party (WP).

site_title: Container shipping set to pick up steam, but not all routes lead to recovery
summary: Container shipping is expected to recover, but not all routes will experience growth. Intra-Asia volumes are likely to lead the recovery, unlike non-main lane importing regions, according to market watchers. The global economy's emergence from lockdown is seen as a positive sign, with freight markets remaining healthy and time charter earnings weak. However, liner companies are expected to be cautious in removing capacity, and the road to recovery is expected to be slow over the second half of the year.

site_title: PIL's SS Teo steps down as SBF chairman; Workforce Singapore chair Lim Ming Yan takes over
summary: PIL managing director Teo Siong Seng, known as SS Teo, has stepped down as chairman of the Singapore Business Federation (SBF) after six years, with Workforce Singapore chairman Lim Ming Yan taking over. Teo's successor praised his leadership, citing his candour, constructive spirit, and collaborative approach. Lim vowed to work with council members and the SBF secretariat to address pressing business issues, including employment, internationalisation, and digital transformation, amid the economic fallout of the Covid-19 pandemic.

site_title: Quotation of taxable book-entry Singapore Government Bonds
summary: Singapore Government Bonds quotation as of June 30, 2020, is available. Citigroup sets a mid-2026 target of 1,150 for MSCI's global equity index. Analysts are positive on SGX earnings, raising target prices, citing a "defensive play benefiting from volatility." Meanwhile, Chinese banks face challenges from Beijing's consumer lending push. Japanese bank MUFG targets US securitization business, planning to boost headcount. The PBOC adviser suggests a 1.5 trillion yuan stimulus to counter US tariffs. Tesla expands robotaxi services to California and Arizona. FedEx partners with QuikBot for commercial robot deliveries.

site_title: Rise of the Asean Super Apps
summary: Southeast Asia is poised for significant digitalization, driven by improvements in infrastructure, mobile networks, and payments, following the COVID-19 crisis. The Asean Super App market is expected to grow from $4 billion in revenue to $23 billion by 2025, with Grab, Gojek, and Sea leading contenders. The market is driven by five key revenue drivers: ridesharing, food delivery, fintech, digital banking, and e-commerce. However, profitability remains a challenge, with ride-sharing and food delivery taking 10 and 11 years to achieve, respectively. To achieve returns on investment, Asean needs to double its investment in the sector, currently at $43 billion, to match China's $257 billion.

site_title: Bali hotels on sale at discounts as virus hits tourism
summary: Struggling hotel owners in Bali, Indonesia, are putting their properties up for sale due to the coronavirus pandemic's impact on tourism. With no tourists and no income, many hotels are being discounted, and some are even sold. The pandemic has severely affected the tourism industry, leading to a decline in bookings and revenue. This has forced hotel owners to reconsider their business models and explore alternative options, including selling their properties.

site_title: Lawyer Jeffrey Ong hit with more charges, mostly linked to Allied Tech's missing funds
summary: Lawyer Jeffrey Ong, managing partner of JLC Advisors, faces 53 charges, mostly related to Allied Tech's missing funds of over S$33 million. The new charges include 14 counts of cheating and 1 count of criminal breach of trust. Ong allegedly deceived Allied Tech into believing its escrow account had certain balance amounts, intentionally inducing the company to omit an investigation into the missing funds. The charges are punishable under the Penal Code, with potential imprisonment and fines.

site_title: Analysts mostly positive on SGX's acquisition of BidFX
summary: Analysts have expressed mostly positive views on Singapore Exchange's (SGX) acquisition of BidFX, a cloud-based FX trading platform. Analysts from CGS-CIMB, RHB, and DBS Group Research have upgraded or maintained their "buy" calls and kept their target prices unchanged. They believe BidFX will be a "potential growth driver" for SGX, contributing up to one-third of revenue in three to four years. The acquisition is expected to be earnings per share-accretive from fiscal 2021, allowing SGX to serve a wider FX community and move towards an integrated OTC FX and futures offering.

site_title: Norwegian Air scraps US$10.6b deal for Boeing 737 Max, 787 jets
summary: Norwegian Air Shuttle ASA has terminated purchase agreements for 97 jets ordered from Boeing, including 92 737 Max planes and five 787 Dreamliners. The decision, made due to restructuring efforts following the Covid-19 pandemic, includes a legal claim seeking return of pre-delivery payments and compensation for the grounded 737 Max. The aircraft are valued at at least $10.6 billion. This move affects Boeing's largest European customer and follows the company's record cancellations of 313 Max planes this year.

site_title: Grim data keeps euro, sterling under pressure
summary: Economic data released on Tuesday showed the euro and sterling under pressure due to fears of a second Covid-19 wave and sluggish consumer price growth. The euro fell to a low of $1.1199, while sterling traded at $1.2280 after a one-month low. The eurozone's underlying price pressures dropped, and the UK economy shrank by 2.2% between January and March, its worst performance since 1979. Investors are concerned about the outlook for the world's biggest economy, with US Federal Reserve chair Jerome Powell warning of uncertainty.

site_title: Boris Johnson has a new American hero
summary: British Prime Minister Boris Johnson is drawing inspiration from US President Franklin D. Roosevelt's New Deal to revamp the UK's economy. Johnson plans to invest £5 billion in infrastructure spending and has already unveiled £1 billion for school-building projects and £560 million for school renovations. He aims to reassure working-class voters that he remains committed to rebalancing the economy, echoing FDR's ability to tap into public mood and project optimism. However, critics warn that Johnson's approach may be flawed, and his government's poor handling of the Covid-19 pandemic has eroded trust in government.

site_title: Koalas may be extinct in New South Wales by 2050: report
summary: A parliamentary inquiry report warns that koalas in New South Wales may become extinct by 2050 unless the government takes immediate action to protect their habitat and species. Land clearing, urban development, and drought-fuelled bushfires have led to habitat loss and fragmentation, destroying a quarter to 81% of their habitat. The report recommends 42 measures, including a census, conservation funding, and stronger protections for habitat. The World Wide Fund for Nature urges the NSW government to rewrite land clearing laws and increase funding for farmers to conserve koala habitats.

images.alt_text: The report, commissioned by a multi-party parliamentary committee, makes 42 recommendations, including an urgent census, prioritising the protection of the animal in the planning of urban development, and increasing conservation funding.

site_title: Bentley bets on a better Bentayga
summary: Bentley has unveiled a redesigned Bentayga, its best-selling luxury car, ahead of its September sales in Singapore. The new model features a heavily updated design, a 550 horsepower engine, and improved interior features. The move is seen as a strategic bet on the car's appeal to high-net-worth individuals in the post-COVID era. Despite a pandemic-induced shutdown, Bentley's China sales have rebounded, and regional director Bernd Pichler expects strong demand for the new Flying Spur across Asia-Pacific and globally.

site_title: US sanctions on Hong Kong risk US$1.1 trillion in China funding
summary: US lawmakers have passed a bipartisan bill that targets Chinese banks doing business with officials involved in Hong Kong's security law, risking $1.1 trillion in funding from US dollar sources. China's largest banks, including Industrial & Commercial Bank of China, China Construction Bank, and Bank of China, face potentially steep fines and could be cut off from the US financial system if they knowingly do business with sanctioned officials. The bill is intended to penalize lenders, not companies, and banks will be informed of sanctioned entities before penalties are imposed.

site_title: Shell to write down up to US$22b in Q2
summary: Royal Dutch Shell Plc will write down between $15 billion and $22 billion in the second quarter due to the coronavirus crisis, impacting oil production, fuel sales, and shipments. The company expects lower oil-product sales volumes and increased gearing due to impairment charges. Despite the challenges, Shell's trading and optimisation efforts are expected to offset lower refining margins. The company is optimistic about the long-term LNG market, with CEO Ben van Beurden expecting it to recover to pre-virus levels.

site_title: Looking over the valley in equities: Capital Group
summary: Capital Group investment director Andy Budden says the recent equities rally, particularly in the technology sector, is a short-term concern, and investors should look for companies that can survive and thrive on the other side of the "valley." He highlights digital transformation sectors such as ecommerce, streaming entertainment, and cloud computing, which are experiencing significant acceleration and offer "profound growth opportunities." However, Budden also warns of value traps and cautions investors to be discerning, particularly with dividend-paying stocks, and to focus on companies with strong business fundamentals and management insights.

site_title: The battleground
summary: Singapore is gearing up for the 2020 General Election, with several key developments reported. The government has set up a centre to advance sustainable aviation in the Asian-Pacific region. Additionally, Deputy Prime Minister Gan has planned a visit to the US for trade talks. The government has also announced a new grant of up to S$100,000 for businesses hit by tariffs. Furthermore, a study suggests Singapore has the potential to become a global hub for advanced chip packaging.

site_title: No Chiam factor, but Sitoh versus Jose in Potong Pasir
summary: In the upcoming Singapore General Election, People's Action Party (PAP) incumbent MP Sitoh Yih Pin is facing a tough battle against Singapore People's Party (SPP) chairman Jose Raymond in Potong Pasir SMC. Without the "Chiam" factor, SPP is contesting for the first time, and Raymond is expected to have a challenging fight. Despite being a formidable opponent, Raymond has acknowledged Sitoh's track record and vowed to focus on new programmes to improve the town, rather than claiming the Chiam legacy.

site_title: Opposition wipeout possible if voters think NCMPs will suffice as alternative: WP
summary: The Workers' Party (WP) warns that if voters believe the Non-Constituency MP (NCMP) scheme will suffice as an alternative to the ruling party, the opposition may face a wipeout in Parliament. WP leaders say the NCMP scheme has limitations, preventing opposition MPs from sinking roots into constituencies and holding events. WP candidate Dennis Tan expressed concerns that relying solely on the NCMP scheme could lead to a "super majority" of the PAP in Parliament, making it difficult for another party to take over.

site_title: Battle for Sengkang may pit WP's youth appeal against PAP's solidity
summary: Singapore's Sengkang GRC election may pit the Workers' Party's (WP) youth appeal against the People's Action Party's (PAP) solidity. The WP has fielded three first-time candidates, while the PAP has a more experienced slate. Younger voters may relate to the WP's messaging of checks and balances, but the PAP's stability and maturity could also appeal to voters' insecurities amid the Covid-19 pandemic. The outcome remains uncertain, with the WP's online traction and e-campaigning efforts to be seen.

site_title: Cirque du Soleil files for bankruptcy protection as Covid-19 cancels shows
summary: Cirque du Soleil has filed for bankruptcy protection due to the COVID-19 pandemic, which canceled shows worldwide. The company has entered into a purchase agreement with its current shareholders from the US, Canada, and China, and will lay off 3,480 workers. Cirque du Soleil aims to rebuild operations and emerge from the US bankruptcy process with less debt, with plans to re-hire most laid-off employees once conditions allow.

site_title: Voluntary quarterly reporting has reduced visibility on listed companies' outlooks
summary: Singapore Exchange's (SGX) new risk-based approach to quarterly reporting has reduced visibility on listed companies' outlooks, making it difficult for investors and analysts to assess their financial performance. Since the transition in February, some companies have stopped providing full quarterly financial statements, opting for business updates instead. This has led to concerns about reduced transparency and increased uncertainty in assessing companies' near-term prospects. Analysts, including those from Maybank Kim Eng Securities and OCBC Credit Research, have expressed concerns about the impact on investors and the credit selection process.

site_title: China passes national security law in turning point for Hong Kong
summary: China's parliament passed national security legislation for Hong Kong on June 30, 2020, in response to last year's pro-democracy protests, which can punish crimes of secession and subversion with up to life imprisonment. The law aims to tackle subversion, terrorism, separatism, and collusion with foreign forces, and has sparked fears of crushing Hong Kong's freedoms. The US has begun eliminating Hong Kong's special status under US law, while China has vowed to retaliate, and Western governments have criticized the legislation, calling it a threat to Hong Kong's autonomy.

site_title: Singapore business loans fall further in May amid downturn
summary: Singapore business loans fell 0.7% in May to S$430.6 billion, marking the second consecutive month of decline amid the economic downturn. Loans to financial institutions and general commerce were down 2.2% and 2.7%, respectively. Consumer loans also declined, with housing and bridging loans dipping 0.1% and unsecured personal loans falling 1%. Despite a 0.6% increase in building and construction loans, the overall dip weighed down on total bank lending, which contracted for the third straight month.

site_title: Corporate digest
summary: Vividthree Holdings has canceled its proposed ordinary share placement due to sufficient working capital, while Kimly Limited has acquired a long-term leasehold coffee shop in Ang Mo Kio for S$12.9 million. Mermaid Maritime has set up a new business unit for offshore platform installation and decommissioning. Perennial Real Estate Holdings has completed the sale of a half-stake in AXA Tower to Alibaba Group's Singapore subsidiary for approximately S$45 million. SBI Offshore has ceased Mirzan Mahathir as executive non-independent chairman after a failed re-election.

site_title: Hedge funds score big gains on dividend bets that hurt banks
summary: Hedge funds have made significant gains by betting on dividend futures, which plummeted in March due to the COVID-19 pandemic but rebounded in April and May. The sell-off in dividend futures hurt banks that had issued high-yield structured products, but the funds capitalized on the opportunity, posting double-digit returns. Funds such as Ovata Capital Management, Oasis Management Co, York Capital Management, and AM Squared Ltd have returned an estimated 4.6-10% this year, bucking the 5% slump of the Bloomberg All Hedge Fund Index through May.

site_title: Fidelity, Aberdeen bet global investors will allocate more to Asia stocks
summary: Global investors are expected to allocate more to Asia stocks, driven by better local handling of coronavirus outbreaks, attractive valuations, and growth profiles of Asian economies. Fund managers at Fidelity, Aberdeen, and Capital Group predict a reversal of the global market underweight positioning in Asia equities. The MSCI Asia Pacific Index has risen 30% from its March low, but still trails the S&P 500 Index. Investors are drawn to Asia's relatively cheap valuations and the potential for less negative economic consequences compared to other regions.

site_title: 'Low Thia Khiang' effect in Hougang more palpable now than in 2015 or 2011: observers
summary: Singapore's Hougang ward, a Workers' Party (WP) stronghold, may see a stronger "Low Thia Khiang effect" in the upcoming general election, with observers noting that residents are likely to back a WP candidate. The ward has been a WP stronghold since 1991, and former WP chief Low Thia Khiang's legacy is still palpable. Despite not contesting this year, Low's influence may be stronger than in previous elections due to his continued presence in the community. The WP's rising star Dennis Tan is also fielded in the ward, which could help maintain the party's stronghold.

site_title: UK PM pushes infrastructure investment to beat Covid-19 slump
summary: UK Prime Minister Boris Johnson announced a plan to fast-track infrastructure investment and slash property planning rules to shake Britain's economy out of its coronavirus-induced crisis. The £5 billion investment will focus on hospitals, schools, and roads, and is compared to former US President Franklin D Roosevelt's "New Deal" programme. However, some have questioned the size of the investment, with Scotland's finance secretary stating it falls short of other countries' stimulus packages, and experts warn of the challenges in delivering big infrastructure projects.

site_title: India's Chinese app ban seen jolting US$1b expansion of ByteDance
summary: India's ban on 59 Chinese apps, including TikTok, has likely derailed ByteDance's $1 billion expansion plan in the country. The ban, which cites national security concerns, has sparked an uproar from users and may force companies to cut back operations, potentially leading to job losses. China's foreign ministry expressed concern over the move, which it believes violates WTO rules. The ban has also affected other Chinese companies, including Tencent, which fears potential future restrictions on its popular game PlayerUnknown's Battlegrounds.

site_title: Lemonade out of a pandemic lemon?
summary: Singapore's efforts to establish itself as a restructuring hub may gain momentum in the post-Covid environment. The country's revamped restructuring and insolvency laws, introduced in 2017, have attracted foreign companies seeking rescue financing and debt restructurings. The Insolvency, Restructuring and Dissolution Act, expected to come into force this year, will consolidate corporate and personal insolvency laws and introduce new provisions to prevent ipso facto clauses. Mediation is also gaining traction in restructuring matters, with the Singapore Convention on Mediation signed by 46 countries.

images.alt_text: Singapore boasts a world-class judiciary with an international division, is the No 1 seat for arbitration in Asia, and has a UN convention on mediation named after it.

site_title: Cut-throat competition for world-class chips: The end of Huawei?
summary: The US has imposed stricter controls on chip supplies to China, particularly to Huawei, in an effort to contain China's growing technological power. The US has banned American companies from using telecommunications equipment produced by companies posing a threat to national security, and requires manufacturers to obtain a licence before exporting semiconductors and chipsets to Huawei. The US is also pressuring countries that provide chip manufacturing equipment to China, including the Netherlands, which controls 90% of the world's semiconductor manufacturing equipment. China's largest chip manufacturer, SMIC, is seen as a key target, and the US is trying to persuade the Dutch government to cut its supply of lithography machines to SMIC.

site_title: Wirecard 'assessing' if it can continue providing Singapore services
summary: Wirecard, a German fintech, has informed Singapore regulators it is "assessing" its ability to continue providing services in Singapore following the collapse of its parent company into insolvency. The Monetary Authority of Singapore (MAS) is closely monitoring Wirecard's operations, and credit card payments and prepaid card usage may be affected if it ceases operations. Wirecard's entities in Singapore have complied with MAS's directions to hold customers' funds in segregated accounts, but Visa and Mastercard are reportedly looking to end Wirecard's access to their networks.

images.alt_text: Wirecard has told Singapore regulators it is "assessing" if it can continue providing services in the Republic - days after the the parent of the German fintech collapsed into insolvency after admitting that 1.9 billion euros (S$2.98 billion) in cash on its balance sheet is likely non-existent.

site_title: A lot at stake for Workers' Party in defending Aljunied GRC
summary: The Workers' Party faces high stakes in defending Aljunied GRC, a crucial constituency that could secure the party's influence in future elections. A win in Aljunied GRC could be a deciding factor in the party's sustainability. Political observers believe the outcome may be split between voters prioritizing safety and those focused on having opposition voices. The party's success in this constituency could have long-term implications for its overall influence in Singapore's electoral landscape.

site_title: Facebook co-founder's B Capital closes second fund at US$820m
summary: B Capital Group, co-founded by Facebook's Eduardo Saverin, has closed its second fund at US$820 million to invest in growth-stage startups globally, bringing total assets under management to US$1.44 billion. The firm invests between US$10 million and US$60 million in companies at Series B, C, and D stages, focusing on digital innovation and transformation in industries like healthcare, education, and finance. The firm has more than doubled its global team size and has made recent investments in companies like Synack and Khatabook.

site_title: DPM Heng in surprise switch as battle lines are drawn for all 93 seats
summary: Deputy Prime Minister Heng Swee Keat, formerly the anchor minister for Tampines GRC, has switched constituencies to lead the People's Action Party (PAP) team against the Workers' Party (WP) in East Coast GRC. The 9-day campaign for Singapore's General Election (GE) has begun, with 192 candidates filing their papers for 93 seats in 31 constituencies. The PAP is fielding the largest opposition slate of 24 candidates, followed by the WP with 21, in what is seen as a historic three-cornered fight in Pasir Ris-Punggol GRC.

site_title: Frasers Centrepoint Trust to raise stake in PGIM Real Estate Fund for S$197.2m
summary: Frasers Centrepoint Trust (FCT) is acquiring a 12.07% stake in PGIM Real Estate Asia Retail Fund (ARF) for S$197.2 million, increasing its interest to 36.89%. The acquisition, expected to be completed in July, will bolster FCT's presence in Singapore's suburban retail sector. FCT's pro forma gearing is expected to be 36.2% as a result, but the deal is accretive to distribution per unit. The acquisition aligns with FCT's strategy to acquire quality retail properties and enhance its presence in the suburban retail sector.

site_title: Asia's post-Covid-19 re-opening is unleashing a steep recovery
summary: Singapore is on track for a steep recovery in economic activity as it gradually lifts Covid-19 restrictions, with the country's domestic economy expected to safely restart. The region's exports have shown resilience, driven by demand from technology and pharmaceutical sectors, with countries like China, Vietnam, and Taiwan likely to see their GDP recover to pre-Covid levels within the next year. The Asia ex-Japan region is expected to return to its pre-Covid-19 GDP levels within 12 months, with China potentially recovering by Q3 2020. Key sectors such as technology and pharmaceuticals are expected to see strong growth in the wake of the pandemic, while countries heavily reliant on tourism, such as Thailand, are expected to recover later.

site_title: Is it too late to buy?
