summary: The US stock market has rebounded strongly from its March lows, with the S&P 500 now less than 5% below its year-start level. The rebound is attributed to massive central bank stimulus, particularly the US Federal Reserve's rate cuts and bond buying program. Analysts expect the Fed to maintain a dovish stance, supporting the markets. The economic recovery is unfolding, with many experts predicting a sharp but short recession, with GDP expected to recover to pre-Covid-19 levels by 2022. However, some analysts warn that investors may be over-estimating the impact of the recovery on corporate earnings, citing concerns about partial recovery in sales and increased financial leverage.

site_title: Air France to slash 7,500 jobs by end-2022: unions
summary: Air France plans to cut 7,500 jobs by the end of 2022 as part of a cost-cutting drive amid the coronavirus pandemic. Most job losses will come from non-replacement of retiring workers or voluntary departures, with layoffs possible. The airline will cut 6,500 jobs at Air France and 1,000 at its Hop! subsidiary, affecting around 41,000 full-time equivalent jobs. The move is part of a broader restructuring effort by the Air France-KLM group, which has posted significant losses and warned it may take years for operations to return to pre-pandemic levels.

site_title: S&P 500's resilience reflects corporate dynamism, why investors must diversify
summary: The S&P 500's resilience is attributed to the dynamism of the US corporate sector, with the five largest components - Microsoft, Apple, Amazon, Alphabet, and Facebook - driving growth. Despite Covid-19 turmoil, these mega-cap growth stocks have outperformed, with Amazon up 49% and Microsoft up 27%. Their digital technology platforms have enabled them to thrive in new growth areas, reflecting investors' willingness to look past current challenges. The average lifespan of S&P 500 component stocks is declining, with nearly half potentially being replaced within 10 years, emphasizing the importance of diversified exposure.

images.alt_text: The S&P500, like any other market index, isn't necessarily going to include every winning stock within its universe. And, by the time some stocks are added, they might already have seen their best days.

site_title: PAP first-timers go it alone in Marymount, Yio Chu Kang
summary: The People's Action Party (PAP) has fielded first-time candidates in Singapore's Yio Chu Kang and Marymount single-member constituencies in the upcoming general election. Yip Hon Weng, a former public servant, will face PSP's Kayla Low, while Gan Siow Huang, a former brigadier-general, will compete against PSP's Ang Yong Guan. Analysts see this move as a calculated risk, as the PAP traditionally avoids fielding new candidates in single-member constituencies. The PAP's decision may be influenced by the WP's limited spread of candidates and resources.

images.alt_text: On Nomination Day on Tuesday, the ruling party fielded Yip Hon Weng against Progress Singapore Party's (PSP) Kayla Low in the newly carved-out Yio Chu Kang SMC.

site_title: Airbus to announce job cuts after meeting with unions
summary: Airbus plans to announce its largest-ever job cuts, reportedly affecting over 10,000 positions, as the company scales back operations due to the coronavirus-induced downturn in demand. The restructuring plan comes after Airbus reduced its output by a third in April and will impact its commercial aviation, helicopters, and defense units. The company will meet with unions and labor leaders to discuss the plan, with the details to be disclosed on Tuesday evening. This move aims to cut costs and generate cash savings to navigate the prolonged downturn.

site_title: US consumer confidence up to 98.1 in June, above expectations: survey
summary: US consumer confidence rose to 98.1 in June, exceeding expectations, driven by the lifting of lockdowns to combat the coronavirus. This improvement was seen in assessments of present conditions and future expectations, but the index remains weak due to economic conditions. The Present Situation Index improved to 86.2, while the expectations index increased to 106. A moderate improvement was seen in the job market and economy, with respondents expecting business conditions to improve and jobs to be plentiful. However, the surge in coronavirus cases raises concerns about the sustainability of the recovery.

site_title: Covid-19 exposes SGX's lack of biopharmaceutical issuers
summary: Singapore Exchange (SGX) has struggled to attract biopharmaceutical firms for initial public offerings (IPOs), despite the country's position as a leading biomedical sciences hub. The exchange has a limited pool of healthcare companies, and those that do list are often early-stage and unproven. Companies like Cennerv Pharmaceuticals and iX Biopharma have failed to raise funds through IPOs due to weak demand. SGX is working to support these companies, but it faces competition from other markets, such as the US and Hong Kong, which have seen a surge in biotech listings.

images.alt_text: Singapore-based biotech Cennerv Pharmaceuticals tried twice to list on the Singapore Exchange (SGX) but was forced to withdraw its initial public offer (IPO) due to weak demand.

site_title: After pandemic, US senators want review of drug supply chain
summary: US senators, Marco Rubio and Elizabeth Warren, are introducing the US Pharmaceutical Supply Chain Review Act, which would analyze the impact of foreign influence on the US pharmaceutical supply chain. The bill aims to reduce reliance on countries like China for essential drugs and promote domestic production. The government will conduct a study on foreign investment in the US pharmaceutical industry and provide a report within a year. The move comes amid concerns about the US's over-reliance on foreign companies, particularly China, for critical drugs during the pandemic.

site_title: Post-Covid, more in West see China as major power: study
summary: A survey of French, German, and US opinion found a significant increase in perceptions of Chinese influence since the COVID-19 pandemic, with China's influence rising from 13% to 28% in France, 12% to 20% in Germany, and 6% to 14% in the US. The US is still seen as the most influential nation, but China's influence is becoming more concrete, especially on mask and medical equipment dependency. Despite this, majorities in Germany and France support tougher action on China over climate change and human rights.

site_title: EU to open borders to 'safe' countries as pandemic accelerates
summary: The European Union will reopen its borders to 15 "safe" countries, including Australia, Canada, and Japan, starting July 1, as the pandemic accelerates with over 500,000 deaths worldwide. The World Health Organization warned that the pandemic is not over, despite some progress in certain countries. The EU's decision comes as the US, Russia, and Brazil are not included in the list, and hotspots continue to surge in Latin America and the US. The list will be updated every two weeks based on the safety situation in each country.

site_title: US: S&P 500, Dow dip at open on virus fears, US-China tensions
summary: The US stock markets, including the S&P 500 and Dow Jones, opened lower on Tuesday due to coronavirus-related worries and US-China tensions. The Dow Jones fell 0.33% and the S&P 500 dropped 0.10%. Despite this, the Nasdaq Composite gained 0.01%. The downturn follows a strong quarter for the S&P 500, which is expected to be its best since 1998.

site_title: SDP's SMC strategy puts leaders in sharp fights with PAP
summary: The Singapore Democratic Party (SDP) has shifted its strategy by fielding its leaders in single-seat wards, increasing the party's chances of securing a higher share of votes and potentially entering parliament through the Non-Constituency MP scheme. SDP chairman Paul Tambyah contested Bukit Panjang SMC instead of the expected GRC, going head-to-head with PAP's Liang Eng Hwa. This tactical move is seen as a gamble to gain more seats and increase the party's representation in parliament.

site_title: Malaysia: Shares close higher on Tuesday
summary: Malaysia's FTSE Bursa Malaysia Kuala Lumpur Composite Index rose 6.54 points to 1,500.97, closing higher on Tuesday with a volume of 5.345 billion lots worth RM3.742 billion. Gainers outnumbered losers 554 to 388.

site_title: Australia to boost defence spending as China tensions rise
summary: Australia plans to increase defence spending by Aus$270 billion (S$259 billion) over the next decade, aiming to surpass 2% of GDP, amid rising tensions with China. Prime Minister Scott Morrison will deliver a policy speech highlighting the need for a stronger military presence in the Indo-Pacific. Australia will focus on building "stronger deterrence capabilities" and acquiring new capabilities, including the AGM-158C Long Range Anti-Ship Missile, while prioritizing regional defence over international operations. This shift aims to counter China's growing influence in the region and ensure Australia's ability to respond to threats.

site_title: Singapore shares rise on better economic data, STI up 0.6%
summary: Singapore shares rose 0.6% on Tuesday, driven by better-than-expected economic data and positive investor sentiment, partly due to China's June PMI data beating forecasts. The Straits Times Index (STI) ended at 2,589.91 points, with 236 advancers outpacing 193 decliners. The top-performing counter was the Singapore Exchange (SGX), which rose 3.5% to S$8.34, while Singtel edged up 0.4% to S$2.46. The boost in investor sentiment suggests a global cyclical recovery is underway, according to market strategist Stephen Innes.

site_title: Mermaid Maritime unit sets up offshore decommissioning unit
summary: Mermaid Maritime has established a new business unit, Mermaid Subsea Services (Thailand), focused on offshore platform installation and decommissioning in the Gulf of Thailand. The unit will utilize Thai personnel with 10+ years of experience and aims to cater to demand from major oil operators in Thailand. The Gulf has over 400 offshore platforms, with a quarter expected for decommissioning over the next 10 years. The new unit will deliver services of international standard using local content, making Mermaid Maritime the first Thai-owned and operated services company in the sector.

site_title: Hong Kong: Stocks finish higher
summary: Hong Kong stocks closed with gains on Tuesday, driven by a rally in New York following upbeat economic data. The Hang Seng Index rose 0.52%, while the Shanghai Composite Index and Shenzhen Composite Index also increased. Despite China passing a controversial security law, traders welcomed the economic data and remained cautious.

site_title: Temasek looks to inject up to US$100m in India's Zomato
summary: Temasek, a Singaporean state investor, is considering a US$100 million investment in Indian food delivery firm Zomato. This comes after Ant Financial's previously announced investment was delayed due to anti-China sentiment and new foreign direct investment rules. Zomato, one of India's prominent startups, has been struggling financially due to the Covid-19 pandemic. The investment is part of a larger round of funding negotiations that began last year.

site_title: Daily Debrief: What Happened Today
summary: Deputy Prime Minister Heng Swee Keat has moved to East Coast GRC, marking the first multi-cornered fight in the constituency. The move comes ahead of the July 10 General Election. Wirecard has announced it will assess its Singapore operations following its parent's insolvency filing in Germany. Singapore bank lending fell 0.6% in May, marking the third consecutive month of decline. The STI rose 0.6% to 2,589.91 points, driven by better economic data.

images.alt_text: Deputy Prime Minister Heng Swee Keat made the move from Tampines GRC to East Coast GRC where the PAP is expected to see a tough fight against the Workers' Party.

site_title: Indonesia reports US$850m in factory investments, says billions committed
summary: Indonesia's investment board announced that seven companies, worth a combined US$850 million, will relocate factories from China to the country. The investments include US$150 million from Kenda Rubber Industrial, US$90 million from Meiloon Industrial, and US$30 million from Panasonic. A total of 17 companies are interested in investing billions more, with a potential combined value of US$37 billion. The move is seen as a response to the ongoing coronavirus pandemic and US-China trade tensions, which are driving manufacturers to diversify their supply chains.

site_title: UK PM pledges 'infrastructure revolution' for virus crisis
summary: UK Prime Minister Boris Johnson announced a "programme for jobs" with a proposed $1.2 billion for school repairs and $4 billion for "shovel-ready" infrastructure projects to aid the nation's recovery from the COVID-19 crisis. The plan, dubbed an "infrastructure revolution," aims to build new homes and improve public transport, but critics say it lacks detail and is similar to previous promises made by the Conservative party. The announcement comes as the country struggles with Europe's deadliest virus outbreak and the worst economic contraction among G7 states.

site_title: Singapore gene therapy start-up clinches deal of over S$1.2b with global pharmaceutical giant
summary: Singapore-based gene therapy start-up Carmine Therapeutics has secured a deal worth over S$1.2 billion with Japanese pharmaceutical giant Takeda Pharmaceutical Company to develop and commercialize treatments for rare genetic diseases. Carmine's novel technology uses tiny particles released by red blood cells to deliver genes, offering a safer and more efficient alternative to traditional viral-based gene therapy. The partnership will help the start-up further optimize its technology and accelerate clinical trials and commercialization.

images.alt_text: A local gene therapy start-up has clinched a deal of more than S$1.2 billion with a global pharmaceutical giant to develop and eventually commercialise its treatments for rare genetic diseases.

site_title: PIL's S. S. Teo steps down as business federation chairman, Workforce Singapore chair Lim Ming Yan takes over
summary: PIL managing director S. S. Teo has stepped down as chairman of the Singapore Business Federation (SBF) after serving six years. Workforce Singapore chairman Lim Ming Yan was elected as his successor. Teo's leadership led to a "steady rise" in SBF's activities and engagement with the government and local business community. Deputy Prime Minister Heng Swee Keat commended Teo for his exemplary leadership, and Lim pledged to deliver fresh perspectives and programmes to SBF members to address issues like employment and digital transformation.

site_title: US sanctions may impact US$1.1t in China funding
summary: US lawmakers have passed a bipartisan bill that may impose steep fines on China's largest banks if they knowingly do business with sanctioned Chinese officials involved in Hong Kong's security law. The four largest state-backed lenders in China, with a combined US$1.1 trillion in dollar funding at stake, face penalties for providing accounts to officials under sanction. If imposed, the penalties could cut off banks from accessing the US financial system, and may also affect global banks with Chinese officials as customers, following previous fines on Standard Chartered and BNP Paribas.

site_title: Market Capitalisation
summary: Citigroup has set a mid-2026 target of 1,150 for MSCI's global equity index, indicating a bullish outlook on the market. Analysts have also expressed positivity on SGX's earnings, raising target prices. Meanwhile, Chinese banks are facing challenges due to Beijing's consumer lending push. Other notable news includes MUFG targeting the US securitisation market, a PBOC adviser urging a 1.5 trillion yuan stimulus package, and Tesla's expansion into robotaxi services in California and Arizona. FedEx has partnered with a Singapore startup to deploy robots for deliveries, and a mandatory offer has been made for PSC shares.

site_title: Carl Reiner, American comedy great, dead at 98
summary: Carl Reiner, a renowned American comedian and writer, has died at the age of 98. He was a driving force in American comedy, best known for creating and co-starring in the classic sitcom "The Dick Van Dyke Show." Reiner's career spanned seven decades, including work on TV shows like "Your Show of Shows" and "Caesar's Hour," as well as films like "Oh, God!" and the "Ocean's Eleven" series. He was also a prolific writer and director, earning multiple Emmy Awards for his work. Reiner is survived by three children, including director Rob Reiner.

site_title: Thai economy seen hitting bottom in Q2: central bank
summary: Thailand's economy is expected to contract by a double-digit number but less than 20% in Q2, according to the Bank of Thailand. Exports dropped 23.6% in May, but private consumption and government relief measures showed signs of improvement. The economy is forecast to shrink 8.1% this year, the largest contraction on record. The central bank expects the economy to hit its bottom in Q2, with smaller declines in the third and fourth quarters. Recent strength in the baht is seen as negative for the economy.

site_title: Bacon triptych sells for US$84.6m
summary: Francis Bacon's "Triptych Inspired by the Oresteia of Aeschylus" sold for US$84.6 million at Sotheby's, boosting the high-end art market after a months-long slump. The 1981 trio of paintings, estimated at US$60-80 million, was consigned by the Hans Rasmus Astrup foundation and will expand the Oslo-based museum's collection. The sale, part of Sotheby's marquee sales, reached US$363.2 million, setting records for artists including Helen Frankenthaler and Wifredo Lam.

site_title: Airbus slows services push amid coronavirus crisis
summary: Airbus has postponed its goal of building a $10 billion services business amid the coronavirus crisis, but is sticking with its strategy of supporting airline operations. The company has effectively dropped its goal and is restructuring its services business, re-allocating staff. Airbus is still pursuing plans to build the A321XLR, the world's longest-range narrow-body plane, with a first flight in 2022 and entry into service in 2023. The company is also prioritizing plans to expand fuel capacity and put more seats in the A350.

site_title: Brokers' take: Analysts mostly positive on SGX acquiring BidFX
summary: Analysts mostly view SGX's acquisition of BidFX as positive, citing potential growth drivers and expansion into the over-the-counter (OTC) currency market. Despite concerns over near-term earnings, analysts maintain "buy" and "fully valued" calls, with unchanged target prices of S$9.20, S$7.40, and S$8. The acquisition is seen as a step towards an integrated OTC FX and futures offering, with SGX aiming to bring together liquidity pools in both markets.

site_title: A taste of democracy: S Korea's 16-year fight for a green onion breakfast cereal
summary: A limited edition green onion-flavored cereal, Chex, was released in South Korea after 16 years of campaigning by enthusiasts. The cereal was first introduced in 2004 but was initially declared a loss by Kellogg's Korea after it was found that Chaka, the green onion flavor, had gained more votes than the chocolate flavor, Cheki. Chaka fans continued to support the cereal, leading to its eventual release. The cereal sold out within two days and has become a symbol of democracy in South Korea, with fans hailing its release as a major victory for the underdog flavor.

site_title: Singapore shares rise on better economic data, STI up 0.6%
summary: Singapore shares rose 0.6% on Tuesday, tracking Wall Street gains, as better-than-expected China's June purchasing managers index data boosted investor sentiment. The Straits Times Index (STI) ended at 2,589.91 points, with 2.34 billion shares changing hands. China's PMI rose to a three-month-high of 50.9, lending weight to the argument of a global cyclical recovery, which should boost global stock market sentiment.

site_title: BMW to source battery cells produced using renewable energy
summary: BMW has announced a contract with battery cell manufacturers to source cells produced using renewable energy. The move aims to reduce carbon emissions from electric vehicle production. By 2026, BMW's battery cell production in Germany is expected to produce 60 gigawatt hours of cells, saving around 10 million tonnes of CO2 over the next decade. This is equivalent to the annual emissions of a city with over a million inhabitants. The company's electric vehicles, including the BMW iX3 and iNEXT, will benefit from this initiative.

site_title: Luzhou Bio-Chem founder launches S$17.8m privatisation bid
summary: Luzhou Bio-Chem Technology Limited, a Mainboard-listed company, is set to become private in a deal valued at S$17.8 million. Founder and executive chairman Niu Ji Xing launched a voluntary conditional general offer via investment holding company Starnova, offering S$0.03 per share. The deal aims to provide greater management flexibility and control, and will facilitate strategic initiatives and operational changes. Luzhou has not raised funds on the Singapore Exchange since 2015, and the offer price represents a premium of up to 150% over the volume-weighted average price.

site_title: Singapore bank lending falls for third straight month in May: MAS data
summary: Singapore bank lending fell 0.6% in May from the previous month, marking the third consecutive decline amid the Covid-19 fallout. Total loans reached S$685.3 billion, down from S$689.7 billion in April, with business loans dipping 0.7% to S$430.6 billion. Consumer loans also fell 0.5% to S$254.7 billion. The decline is attributed to weakness across all segments, mainly due to the pandemic's impact.

site_title: Homebuilder Redrow to shrink London business, warns of full-year sales drop
summary: UK homebuilder Redrow is scaling back its London operations due to the impact of the coronavirus pandemic, which led to site closures in March. The company expects a full-year sales drop of over 35% and a substantial decrease in 2020 profit. Redrow will focus on high-return regional businesses and its Heritage product, with a forecasted group turnover of £1.34 billion. The company's shares fell 7% at the open to 429.8 pence, and costs associated with the London business scaling back will be reported in the June 2020 accounts.

site_title: Lower electricity bills as tariffs to fall 15% for next 3 months
summary: Singapore households can expect lower electricity bills for the next three months as tariffs decrease by an average of 15% starting July 1. The decrease translates to a reduction from 23.02 cents per kilowatt hour to 19.60 cents per kilowatt hour, resulting in a decrease of S$12 for four-room Housing Board flats. The tariff reduction is based on guidelines set by the Energy Market Authority and is a quarterly review. The decrease is expected to provide relief to households, although the exact impact on individual bills may vary.

site_title: IHG ramps up hotel reopenings, posts 76% drop in May room revenue
summary: InterContinental Hotels Group (IHG) reported a 76% drop in May room revenue due to coronavirus lockdowns. The company's comparable Revenue Per Available Room (RevPAR) is expected to fall 75% for the second quarter. However, IHG's reopening pace has accelerated, with 10% of its global estate still closed. Occupancy levels have improved to over 40% in the US, attributed to the Americas and Greater China regions. IHG's shares were down 1% despite the company having $2 billion in available liquidity.

site_title: Vividthree cancels proposed S$1.9m placement
summary: Vividthree Holdings has canceled its proposed S$1.9 million share placement due to sufficient working capital, making it unnecessary to raise funds. The company, which was spun off from mm2 Asia in 2018, initially planned to use the proceeds for strengthening its financial position and acquiring intellectual property rights. With the cancellation, Vividthree will not proceed with issuing up to 15.9 million new ordinary shares at 12.6 cents apiece.

site_title: Australia: Shares mark best quarter in nearly 11 years
summary: Australian shares rose 1.4% to 5,897.90, marking their best quarter in nearly 11 years, as the Reserve Bank of Australia played up prospects of fresh stimulus. Domestic employment continued to recover, with 30% of jobs regained since the lockdown. Despite a spike in Covid-19 cases globally, the S&P/ASX 200 index jumped 2.4% in the session, with financials stocks gaining 1.2%. The benchmark index is up nearly 17% for the quarter, its best performance since September 2009.

site_title: Europe: Stocks waver at open
summary: Europe's major stock markets wavered in cautious opening deals on Tuesday, despite rebounding share prices in Asia. London's FTSE 100 index dropped 0.3% to 6,206.92 points, while Frankfurt's DAX 30 index and Paris CAC 40 index rose 0.1% each. The focus is on US-EU trade talks, while mining and healthcare sectors prop up shares.

images.alt_text: Europe's major stock markets wavered Tuesday in cautious opening deals, despite rebounding share prices in Asia.

site_title: Malaysian gaming unlikely to bounce back fully in 2021: Report
summary: Malaysian gaming is unlikely to fully recover from the Covid-19 pandemic by 2021, with a report suggesting it could take over a year to recover even if the virus is contained. Despite plans to resume business, closed borders and safe distancing rules may limit visitor arrivals and sentiment. Genting Malaysia's gross gaming revenue is expected to improve year on year in FY2021 but not reach pre-pandemic levels. The industry's reliance on big spenders from other countries, such as Cambodia and Singapore, may also hinder recovery.

site_title: US not on EU's 'safe' travel list, diplomats say
summary: The European Union is set to unveil a "safe list" of 14 countries for non-essential travel, including Algeria, Australia, and Canada, which will support the EU travel industry and tourist destinations. The US is not included on the list, along with Russia and Brazil. China is also provisionally approved, but travel will only open if Chinese authorities allow EU visitors. The list must be approved by a qualified majority of EU countries and will act as a recommendation to EU members, who may set restrictions on travelers from other countries.

images.alt_text: The United States is not on a "safe list" of destinations for non-essential travel due to be unveiled by European Union (EU) governments later on Tuesday, three diplomats said.

site_title: Koalas may be extinct in Australia's New South Wales by 2050
summary: A parliamentary inquiry in New South Wales, Australia, warns that koalas could become extinct by 2050 due to habitat loss and fragmentation. The report attributes the decline to land clearing for agriculture, urban development, and mining, as well as a devastating drought-fuelled bushfire season. To prevent extinction, the government is urged to implement 42 recommendations, including an urgent census and increased conservation funding. If not acted upon, the report concludes that the only way children and grandchildren will see koalas in the wild in NSW is if the government takes immediate action.

site_title: Seoul: Shares end higher, mark sharpest quarterly gain in 11 years
summary: South Korean shares closed higher on Tuesday, marking the sharpest quarterly gain in nearly 11 years. The Kospi index rose 0.71% to 2,108.33, driven by upbeat data from the US and China. Contracts to buy US homes rebounded and China's factory activity expanded, beating expectations. The won closed trading 0.37% lower, but its monthly gain was 2.9% and quarterly gain was 1.2%. Foreigners were net sellers of 70.9 billion won worth of shares, while the central bank plans to provide dollar funds to local firms to stabilize the foreign exchange market.

site_title: Indian telecom tycoon bids for SoftBank-backed OneWeb
summary: Indian telecom tycoon Sunil Mittal's conglomerate Bharti Enterprises has submitted a bid for bankrupt satellite firm OneWeb, backed by the UK government. The UK government plans to commit around $500 million to OneWeb as part of its Chapter 11 bankruptcy proceedings. The bid aims to support the UK's national navigation system, which was frozen out by the European Union. OneWeb faces competition from SpaceX Starlink and other satellite projects, and the bid is part of efforts to attract fresh foreign investment to the UK.

site_title: Tim Tam maker Arnott's loses 50 jobs in first cuts since KKR buyout
summary: Arnott's, the maker of Tim Tam biscuits, is cutting 50 jobs, about 2% of its workforce, as part of its restructuring efforts following a US$2.2 billion buyout by KKR & Co Inc last year. The company cited the need to ensure its success as a stand-alone company and build capabilities to remain competitive in the market. The cuts are the first since KKR's acquisition, which aimed to improve profitability and prepare for resale in four years.

site_title: Thailand looks past pandemic to build US$9b airport city
summary: Thailand is moving forward with a $9 billion "airport city" project at U-Tapao International Airport, aiming to create a hub for logistics, tourism, and manufacturing. The 290 billion baht project, spanning 1,040 hectares, is expected to handle 60 million passengers and 3 million tons of cargo yearly. Initially set to be completed by 2024, the airport redevelopment is part of a broader plan to boost Thailand's economy and close the gap with neighboring countries.

site_title: Alaskan officials approve BP's sale of oil leases to Hilcorp
summary: Alaskan officials approved BP's $5.6 billion sale of its oil and gas leases to Hilcorp Energy Co, including interests in the Prudhoe Bay oilfield and the Trans Alaska Pipeline. The deal, which includes a revised closing date and $1.6 billion payment from future earnings, was deemed beneficial to the state despite some risk and potential liability. The lease portion of the sale could be completed on Tuesday, while approval for BP's near-half ownership in the Trans Alaska Pipeline System is still pending, with a decision expected in September.

site_title: Shell to write down as much as US$22b in wake of coronavirus
summary: Royal Dutch Shell will write down US$22 billion in asset value due to a sharp decrease in oil and gas prices amid the coronavirus pandemic. The company expects a 40% drop in fuel sales and a 10% decrease in upstream oil and gas production. Shell's shares fell 0.4% in early trading. The company also reduced its long-term oil price forecast to US$60 a barrel and its refining profit margin outlook by 30%.

site_title: Australia's top carbon polluter ties executive bonuses to emissions cuts
summary: Australia's top carbon polluter, AGL Energy Ltd, has announced a climate action plan tying executive long-term bonuses to emissions cuts. The plan, unveiled in response to investor pressure, aims to decarbonize by expanding renewable energy and increasing carbon-neutral sales. AGL will invest in emissions offset projects, but has no plans to speed up coal-fired power plant closures. Climate activists remain skeptical, citing the need for accelerated coal plant closures to meet Australia's emissions reduction goals.

site_title: GE2020: NCMP scheme is not solution for alternative voice in Parliament, says WP's Dennis Tan
summary: Workers' Party candidate Dennis Tan expressed concerns that the Non-Constituency MP (NCMP) scheme is not a viable solution for an alternative voice in Parliament, as it restricts NCMPs from holding events and sinking roots into their constituencies. Tan fears this could lead to a "super majority" of the ruling PAP in Parliament, making it difficult for another party to take over. WP chief Pritam Singh expressed confidence in the party's slate, despite the challenging Covid-19 pandemic.

site_title: Wirecard to assess Singapore services amid parent's insolvency filing in Germany
summary: Wirecard, a German fintech, has filed for insolvency in Germany amid investigations into wide-scale accounting fraud. The company's parent, Wirecard AG, admitted to having 1.9 billion euros (S$2.98 billion) in cash on its balance sheet, which is likely non-existent. Wirecard's entities in Singapore are "assessing" their ability to continue providing services, with the Monetary Authority of Singapore (MAS) closely monitoring their operations. Payments for merchants and prepaid cards issued by Wirecard may be affected if it ceases operations in Singapore.

site_title: Dubai World pays US$8.2b early to complete debt revamp
summary: Dubai World, a government-owned conglomerate, has completed a debt restructuring by making a final payment of US$8.2 billion to creditors two years ahead of schedule. The company has repaid US$18.9 billion since 2011 using funds from asset sales, dividend payments, and the delisting of DP World. The repayment marks an important milestone for Dubai World and the emirate, which is tackling its debt pile amid the economic fallout of the coronavirus pandemic.

site_title: Swedish fintech Klarna launches 'buy now, pay later' service in Spain
summary: Swedish fintech Klarna has launched its "buy now, pay later" service in Spain, allowing customers to split purchases into three interest-free instalments over 60 days. The service is available at retailers such as H&M and Sephora, with fashion brand Michael Kors set to join in July. Klarna, valued at $5.5 billion, has been expanding rapidly across Europe and the US.

site_title: TikTok denies sharing Indian user data with Chinese government
summary: TikTok has denied sharing user data with the Chinese government, amid India's national security and privacy concerns. The ban on TikTok follows 58 other Chinese apps banned in the country. The Chinese-owned company, ByteDance, maintains it complies with Indian data privacy and security requirements and has not shared user information with any foreign government.

site_title: Singapore lab cleans up chili crab to produce super supplement
summary: A Singaporean lab has developed a cleaner method to extract chitosan, a valuable substance from seafood shells, using a two-step process that reduces CO2 emissions by nearly 95%. Associate Professor Ning Yan's method, which involves heating and dissolving the shells in water, has shown promise in the lab and is now being sought to be scaled up commercially. The substance, with antibacterial and anti-fungal properties, is in high demand, with expected annual growth of 11% through 2030. The lab is in talks with a chemical company to build a facility in Vietnam to test the method on a larger scale.

site_title: Singapore PR returning from India is first imported Covid-19 case since June 14
summary: A 44-year-old Singapore permanent resident, who returned from India on June 24, tested positive for COVID-19, marking the first imported case since June 14. The patient was placed on a 14-day stay-home notice and developed symptoms during her isolation. The Ministry of Health (MOH) initially counted her as a community case but later reclassified her as an imported case. This brings the total number of community cases to five, including two Singaporeans and three work permit holders, with two suspected to be past infections.

site_title: China halts meat imports from more plants amid virus confusion
summary: China has suspended meat imports from plants in Brazil, Canada, and Germany, citing potential links to coronavirus outbreaks. The move comes as the country has been suggesting a possible connection between food and the spread of the virus, despite regulatory agencies and exporting nations denying any evidence. Customs authorities have halted imports from facilities with Covid-19 outbreaks, including a slaughterhouse in Germany where employees tested positive but later tested negative. China has asked Brazil to provide information on export plants facing outbreaks, and negotiations are underway to overturn the bans.

site_title: Samsung Heavy, Bloom Energy partner to develop zero-emissions cargo vessels
summary: Samsung Heavy Industries and Bloom Energy have partnered to develop fuel cell-powered cargo vessels that reduce carbon emissions and improve air quality. The companies plan to design and build eco-friendly vessels carrying liquefied natural gas, with the goal of replacing existing main engines and generator engines with solid oxide fuel cells. The partnership aims to meet International Maritime Organization's (IMO) goal of cutting CO2 emissions 40% by 2030 and 50% by 2050. The first design is expected to be ready by 2022, with a projected annual market for Bloom's servers on Samsung Heavy ships reaching 300 megawatts.

site_title: Hong Kong democracy figures resign after security law passed
summary: Four prominent Hong Kong democracy figures, Joshua Wong, Nathan Law, Jeffrey Ngo, and Agnes Chow, have resigned from the Demosisto party, citing Beijing's passage of a national security law that infringes on universal suffrage and human rights. The law, which outlaws acts of subversion, secession, terrorism, and foreign collusion, has sparked fears of silencing pro-democracy activists. Wong and Law, prominent figures from the 2014 student-led protests, will continue to campaign in a personal capacity, while the party may face prosecution or disqualification under the new law.

images.alt_text: Joshua Wong, Nathan Law, Jeffrey Ngo and Agnes Chow said they were ending their involvement in Demosisto, a party that has infuriated Beijing by campaigning for universal suffrage and for foreign countries to sanction China for rights abuses.

site_title: GE2020: NSP to contest PAP in Sembawang GRC
summary: The National Solidarity Party (NSP) will contest the Sembawang GRC against the ruling People's Action Party (PAP) in Singapore's 2020 General Election. The NSP team, led by secretary-general Spencer Ng, includes familiar faces from the 2015 election. The incumbent PAP team, led by Minister of Education Ong Ye Kung, boasts a diverse mix of professionals. The election comes as Singapore continues to grapple with the COVID-19 pandemic, with the PAP focusing on long-term plans and the NSP emphasizing the need for change.

site_title: Tokyo: Nikkei closes up more than 1.3%
summary: Tokyo's benchmark Nikkei index rose 1.33% to close at 22,288.14, driven by optimism over post-lockdown economic activity in the US and Europe. Investors bought on dips following Monday's declines, despite weak Japan economic data. Telecoms and investment giant SoftBank Group led gains, while Nissan and Toyota also rose. The dollar traded at 107.76 yen in Asian afternoon trade.

images.alt_text: Tokyo's benchmark Nikkei index advanced more than 1.3 per cent on Tuesday after US and European markets bounced back on optimism over post-lockdown economic activity.

site_title: GE2020: Workers' Party takes on incumbent PAP in fight for Marine Parade GRC
summary: The Workers' Party (WP) is contesting the Marine Parade Group Representation Constituency (GRC) against the incumbent People's Action Party (PAP) in the 2020 Singapore General Election. Emeritus Senior Minister Goh Chok Tong and Professor Fatimah Lateef are retiring, while Speaker of Parliament Tan Chuan-Jin, Senior Minister of State Edwin Tong, and others are joining the PAP lineup. The WP team, led by Yee Jenn Jong, promises to assess existing programs before making promises to residents, and emphasizes its sincerity and efforts to care for residents.

site_title: GE2020: PAP to face off with Red Dot United in Jurong GRC
summary: The People's Action Party (PAP) is set to face off against Red Dot United (RDU) in Singapore's Jurong Group Representation Constituency (GRC) in the 2020 General Election. Senior Minister Tharman Shanmugaratnam leads the PAP team, while RDU's team includes former Progress Singapore Party members Michelle Lee and Ravi Philemon. RDU released a 12-page charter outlining plans for policy changes in housing, healthcare, and employment. The election is seen as a tough contest for RDU, but its leaders are determined to make their voices heard.

site_title: GE2020: DPM Heng moves to East Coast GRC; first three-cornered GRC fight in Pasir Ris-Punggol
summary: Deputy Prime Minister Heng Swee Keat has moved from Tampines GRC to East Coast GRC, marking the first time a GRC will have a three-cornered fight. The PAP is expected to face a tough fight against the Workers' Party in East Coast. Meanwhile, Prime Minister Lee Hsien Loong's younger brother Lee Hsien Yang did not contest as a candidate, and two new PAP candidates, Gan Siow Huang and Yip Hon Weng, will face solo fights in single-member constituencies. The nine-day campaign for the General Election officially began on Tuesday.

site_title: GE2020: RP gives way to PSP to avoid three-cornered fight in Yio Chu Kang SMC
summary: The Reform Party (RP) has withdrawn from the Yio Chu Kang Single Member Constituency (SMC) election, allowing the Progress Singapore Party (PSP) to contest against the People's Action Party (PAP). PSP's Kayla Low will face PAP's Yip Hon Weng, who was chosen by Prime Minister Lee Hsien Loong to represent the estate. RP chairman Andy Zhu cited the risk of a three-cornered fight as the reason for the withdrawal.

site_title: SoftBank's Z Holdings sees Line merger slipping beyond October
summary: SoftBank's Z Holdings has delayed the closure of its merger with Line Corp due to regulatory approval being delayed by the coronavirus outbreak. The new timeline is expected to be later than October, with the joint tender offer now slipping beyond May to June. The deal, announced in November, aims to combine internet firms in Japan to counter US and Chinese rivals.

site_title: Chinese researchers warn of new virus in pigs with human pandemic risk
summary: Chinese researchers have identified a new flu virus in pigs that has become more infectious to humans, raising concerns of a potential pandemic. The "G4" strain of H1N1 virus, found in pigs from 2011 to 2018, has characteristics of a pandemic virus and has been detected in pig farm workers, prompting calls for close monitoring in human populations. While experts consider the risk low and no imminent threat, the study highlights the risks of viruses crossing species barriers and emphasizes the need for systematic surveillance of the issue.

site_title: GE2020: WP to contest PAP at Sengkang GRC
summary: Labour Party chief Ng Chee Meng will lead the People's Action Party's team in the newly formed Sengkang GRC, facing off against the Workers' Party. Ng, 51, was part of the PAP team that won the Pasir Ris-Punggol GRC in 2015. The WP has nominated three fresh faces: social enterprise entrepreneur Raeesah Khan, equity analyst Louis Chua, and associate professor of economics Jamus Lim. The Sengkang GRC has 120,166 voters and marks the first time the party has contested the area.

site_title: GE2020: PAP faces challenge in Chua Chu Kang GRC, Pioneer and Hong Kah North SMCs
summary: The People's Action Party (PAP) faces challenges in three Singaporean electoral districts: Chua Chu Kang GRC, Pioneer SMC, and Hong Kah North SMC. In Pioneer SMC, PAP's Patrick Tay competes against PSP's Lim Cher Hong and independent candidate Cheang Peng Wah. In Hong Kah North SMC, PAP's Amy Khor faces PSP's Gigene Wong, despite Wong's inexperience. Meanwhile, the PAP's four-member Chua Chu Kang GRC team, led by Gan Kim Yong, will compete against PSP's Francis Yuen Kin Pheng and others.

site_title: GE2020: PSP to contest PAP in Nee Soon GRC
summary: The Progress Singapore Party (PSP) will contest Nee Soon GRC in the 2020 Singapore General Election, fielding five candidates against the incumbent People's Action Party (PAP) team led by Minister for Law and Home Affairs K Shanmugam. PSP candidates include Kala Manickam, Taufik Supan, Bradley Bowyer, Damien Tay, and Sri Nallakaruppan, who will focus on key issues such as rising cost of living and safeguarding PMET jobs.

site_title: GE2020: PAP's Sun Xueling to face WP's Tan Chen Chen in Punggol West SMC
summary: Singapore's Punggol West Single Member Constituency (SMC) will go to the polls on July 10, 2020, with incumbent PAP MP Sun Xueling facing WP newcomer Tan Chen Chen. Sun, the Senior Parliamentary Secretary for Home Affairs and National Development, is defending her turf, while Tan, a 38-year-old contracts administrator, is making her first election bid. The SMC has 26,579 voters, mostly young families, and was previously part of the Pasir Ris-Punggol GRC.

site_title: UOBAM launches S-Reit income fund for Taiwan retail investors
summary: UOBAM launched the United S-Reit Income Fund, the first S-Reit fund in Taiwan, targeting retail investors. The fund allocates 60% of its portfolio to Singapore S-Reits and 40% to global Reits. It aims to provide a monthly dividend payout with a risk rating of RR4, indicating moderate to high-risk yield-driven investments. S-Reits are considered attractive investments due to their strong fundamentals and current buying opportunities. The fund's initial offering period closes on July 24.

site_title: GE2020: SDP and PAP set for rematch in Bukit Batok SMC
summary: The Singapore Democratic Party's (SDP) Chee Soon Juan, 57, is set to contest the Bukit Batok Single Member Constituency (SMC) against People's Action Party's (PAP) Murali Pillai, 52. This rematch follows their 2016 by-election contest, where Pillai won 61.21% of the vote. Chee last contested the ward in 2016 and lost. Pillai, a Senior Counsel, previously contested the 2015 General Election and lost in the Aljunied GRC.

site_title: GE2020: PAP's West Coast team led by ministers S Iswaran, Desmond Lee up against Tan Cheng Bock's PSP
summary: The People's Action Party (PAP) and the Progress Singapore Party (PSP) are set to face off in the West Coast Group Representation Constituency (GRC) in Singapore's 2020 general election. PAP's team, led by ministers S. Iswaran and Desmond Lee, will go up against PSP's team, headed by Tan Cheng Bock, a former PAP MP. The contest is seen as one of the biggest electoral battles in western Singapore, with the PSP looking to challenge the PAP's stronghold in the constituency.

site_title: GE2020: Surprise departure of Heng Swee Keat in Tampines GRC
summary: Deputy Prime Minister and Finance Minister Heng Swee Keat has left the People's Action Party (PAP) team in Tampines GRC, citing the need for him to focus on his role as DPM. Heng will lead a five-man PAP team in the East Coast GRC, while Minister for the Environment and Water Resources Masagos Zulkifli will helm the Tampines team. Masagos, a former CEO of Singtel Global Offices, expressed his commitment to supporting Heng and the team, emphasizing the importance of teamwork and accessibility to constituents.

site_title: Impossible says sausage is available to all US restaurants
summary: Impossible Foods Inc has made its meatless sausage available nationwide to all US restaurants, expanding its presence in the market. The pre-cooked sausage patties, sold through major food distributors, are now available at over 20,000 locations, including Burger King and Starbucks. This move comes as the company capitalizes on shortages of beef and pork during the pandemic, with sales of plant-based meat products surging 264% in the US. The expansion follows a partnership with Starbucks to add an Impossible breakfast sandwich to the coffee shop's US menu.

site_title: GE2020: PM Lee's PAP Ang Mo Kio team faces Reform Party challenge again
summary: Singapore's Prime Minister Lee Hsien Loong's People's Action Party (PAP) team in Ang Mo Kio GRC will face a challenge from the Reform Party (RP) in the upcoming General Election (GE) on July 10. The PAP team, led by Lee, includes five members, while the RP has six candidates. Lee emphasized that his team is taking the election seriously and will fight for every vote. He also discussed potential issues such as the balance between the local and foreign workforce, which are expected to be hot-button topics during the campaign.

site_title: GE2020: Three-way fight in Pasir Ris-Punggol GRC
summary: The Pasir Ris-Punggol Group Representation Constituency (GRC) will have a three-way fight in the upcoming Singapore General Election, with the incumbent People's Action Party (PAP) team facing off against the Singapore Democratic Alliance (SDA) and Peoples Voice (PV) parties. The PAP team, led by Senior Minister Teo Chee Hean, includes three new faces: Yeo Wan Ling, Desmond Tan, and Mohamed Sharael Mohd Taha. The SDA team, led by Desmond Lim, includes Harminder Pal Singh, Abu Mohamed, and newcomers Kelvin Ong and Kuswadi Atnawi. PV, led by Gilbert Goh, also announced its candidacy on Nomination Day.

site_title: Singapore AI startup bags US$7m in Series A round led by two US venture capitalists
summary: NextBillion.ai, a Singapore-based AI startup, has secured US$7 million in a Series A round led by Lightspeed Venture Partners and Falcon Edge Capital. The funding will be used to grow the team, product, and research and development. Founded by former Grab tech-leaders, the startup offers an AI-first maps SaaS platform for enterprises in various verticals across Asia, China, and the US. Its AI solutions cater to hyperlocal nuances in emerging and developed markets, making them suitable for global expansion.

site_title: GE2020: Marsiling-Yew Tee GRC sees PAP, SDP face-off; Kebun Baru SMC to host PAP and PSP
summary: The Marsiling-Yew Tee Group Representation Constituency (GRC) in Singapore will see a face-off between the ruling People's Action Party (PAP) and the opposition Singapore Democratic Party (SDP) in the upcoming General Election. The PAP team, led by National Development Minister Lawrence Wong, will contest against the SDP team, which includes Bryan Lim Boon Heng and Benjamin Pwee. The SDP has proposed suspending the goods and services tax until 2021 and providing retirees with a monthly income of S$500. This will be the second time the two parties have contested the GRC, with the PAP winning in 2015 with 68.73% of the valid votes.

site_title: Remdesivir, the first coronavirus drug, gets a price tag
summary: Remdesivir, the first coronavirus treatment, will be distributed in the US through September, with a fixed price of $520 per vial for private insurance and $390 per vial for government-sponsored insurance. The US will receive almost 500,000 treatment courses, while worldwide demand could potentially outstrip supplies. The pricing arrangement may serve as a template for new treatments and vaccines, and experts consider it not exorbitant compared to other promising drugs.

images.alt_text: Remdesivir, the first drug shown to be effective against the coronavirus, will be distributed under an unusual agreement with the federal government that establishes nonnegotiable prices and prioritiSes American patients, health officials announced Monday.

site_title: GE2020: Face off between PAP and WP in Hougang SMC
summary: PAP's Lee Hong Chuang is contesting the Hougang SMC seat against Workers' Party (WP) Non-Constituency MP Dennis Tan. This is Lee's second attempt at the seat, having lost to incumbent Png Eng Huat in 2015. Lee believes he has built friendships with residents and done more for the community, but acknowledges it's up to the residents to decide. Tan, who debuted as a WP candidate in 2015, is seen as a potential replacement for Png Eng Huat and has been shadowing him for years.

site_title: Lawyer Jeffrey Ong hit with another 15 charges, mostly linked to Allied Tech's missing funds
summary: Lawyer Jeffrey Ong, managing partner of JLC Advisors, faces 15 additional charges, mostly linked to Allied Tech's missing funds of over S$33 million. The charges include cheating, forgery, and criminal breach of trust, totaling 53, including earlier alleged offenses. Ong allegedly deceived Allied Tech into believing its escrow account had certain balance amounts, intentionally inducing the company to omit investigating missing funds. He also misappropriated S$250,000 from another client's escrow account.

site_title: Japan's fussy food shoppers finally go online amid pandemic
summary: Japan's notoriously fussy food shoppers have finally turned to online grocery stores amid the pandemic, with internet sales accounting for about 5% or more of total grocery sales, up from 2.5% pre-pandemic. Retailers such as Aeon Co are scrambling to meet the surge in delivery demand, with Aeon expecting online sales to grow 50% and account for 10% of sales by the end of its financial year. The shift challenges Japan's long-held belief in the importance of in-person shopping, with analysts predicting a permanent change in consumer behavior.

site_title: GE2020: Potong Pasir, MacPherson and Mountbatten SMCs set for straight fights
summary: Singapore's GE2020 election is underway, with three single-member constituencies (SMCs) - Potong Pasir, MacPherson, and Mountbatten - set for straight fights. In Potong Pasir, PAP incumbent Sitoh Yih Pin faces SPP chairman Jose Raymond, while in MacPherson, PAP's Tin Pei Ling contests against PPP's Goh Meng Seng. Mountbatten SMC's PAP MP Lim Biow Chuan faces Peoples Voice's Sivakumaran Chellappa. The SPP's manifesto for Potong Pasir, which includes programmes to support families, the elderly, and young people, will be revealed tomorrow.

site_title: GE2020: Bishan-Toa Payoh GRC see PAP and SPP face-off
summary: The Bishan-Toa Payoh Group Representation Constituency (GRC) in Singapore's upcoming General Election will see a face-off between the ruling People's Action Party (PAP) and the Singapore People's Party (SPP). The PAP's four candidates include Defence Minister Ng Eng Hen and Senior Minister Chee Hong Tat, while the SPP's four candidates include secretary-general Steve Chia and Osman Sulaiman. The SPP has launched its manifesto, calling for a reduced voting age and lower GST rates, and has vowed to run as full-time MPs if elected.

site_title: Japan calls China's reported move on Hong Kong 'regrettable'
summary: Japan's Chief Cabinet Secretary Yoshihide Suga described China's reported move to pass national security legislation for Hong Kong as "regrettable" and undermining the "one country, two systems" formula. Japan will continue to work with the US and China to address the issue, emphasizing the importance of stable relations between the two global powers for regional and global security.

site_title: GE2020: PAP to face off against Peoples Voice in Jalan Besar GRC
summary: The People's Action Party (PAP) will face off against the opposition Peoples Voice in the Jalan Besar GRC at the upcoming Singapore general election (GE2020) on July 10. PAP's four-member team, led by Manpower minister Josephine Teo, includes veteran MPs Heng Chee How and Denise Phua. The opposition's team, led by Lim Tean, includes Leong Sze Hian, Nor Azlan Bin Sulaiman, and Michael Fang Amin. This will be Teo's first time leading the constituency.

site_title: GE2020: DPM Heng Swee Keat to anchor PAP team against WP at East Coast GRC
summary: Deputy Prime Minister Heng Swee Keat will lead the People's Action Party (PAP) team against the Workers' Party (WP) in the East Coast Group Representation Constituency (GRC) in Singapore's 2020 general election. Heng replaces incumbent MP Lim Swee Say and will be joined by other PAP MPs, including Jessica Tan and Cheryl Chan. The WP slate includes familiar faces such as Abdul Shariff Aboo Kassim and Terence Tan, who previously contested in Marine Parade. The East Coast GRC has historically been a strong WP area, but the PAP has won it in the past, with Heng's nomination seen as a strategic move to counter WP's strength in the constituency.

site_title: Lululemon to buy home fitness start-up Mirror for US$500m
summary: Lululemon Athletica Inc has agreed to buy home fitness company Mirror for US$500 million, capitalizing on the surge in demand for home workout classes during the coronavirus pandemic. Mirror, which launched in 2018, is expected to reach over US$100 million in revenue this year. The deal gives Lululemon a new revenue stream and an opportunity to integrate its products into home workout classes, targeting its affluent millennial customer base. The acquisition is set to close in one to two weeks, with Mirror operating as a standalone unit.

site_title: GE2020: PAP's Gan Siow Huang and PSP's Ang Yong Guan face off in Marymount SMC
summary: In Singapore's Marymount Single Member Constituency (SMC), PAP's Gan Siow Huang and PSP's Ang Yong Guan are competing in the July 10 election. Gan, Singapore's first female brigadier-general, initially faced Bishan Toa-Payoh GRC, but switched to Marymount. Ang, a psychiatrist, is contesting under PSP for the first time. In their speeches, Gan emphasized PAP's community service, while Ang urged voters to support PSP and alternative parties to deny the PAP a two-thirds majority in the House. The candidacy was confirmed at 12:30 pm on Nomination Day.

site_title: GE2020: Battleground at Aljunied GRC heats up as WP defends turf against PAP
summary: The Workers' Party (WP) will defend Aljunied GRC against the ruling People's Action Party (PAP) at the July 10 General Election. The WP team consists of three incumbents and two former Non-Constituency MPs, while the PAP's slate includes four incumbents and two first-time candidates. This will be the battleground constituency for the election.

site_title: Chinese researchers warn of new virus in pigs with human pandemic risk
summary: Chinese researchers have identified a new flu virus in pigs, the "G4" strain of H1N1, which has the potential to become a pandemic virus. The virus has become more infectious to humans and has been found in pig farm workers, prompting calls for close monitoring in human populations. While experts say there is no imminent threat, the study highlights the risks of viruses crossing the species barrier into humans, particularly in densely populated regions. Systematic surveillance is recommended to prevent a potential pandemic.

site_title: GE2020: Tanjong Pagar GRC sees face-off between PAP and PSP
summary: The People's Action Party (PAP) will contest the Progress Singapore Party (PSP) in the Tanjong Pagar GRC, defending late Prime Minister Lee Kuan Yew's stronghold. The PAP slate includes Chan Chun Sing, Indranee Rajah, Joan Pereira, Alvin Tan, and Eric Chua, while the PSP is fielding Wendy Low, Harish Pillay, Michael Chua, Abas Kasmani, and Terrence Soon. The PSP unveiled its manifesto, calling for a reduction in foreign labor dependence and support for small businesses. The PAP aims to offer residents a choice and secure a strong mandate to lead.

site_title: Asia: Stocks rally as better economic data trump second wave fears
summary: Asian stocks rose on Tuesday as positive economic data from China and the US offset concerns about a potential second wave of COVID-19 infections. China's manufacturing and non-manufacturing indices improved, while US pending home sales surged 44% and manufacturing activity improved. The rebound in global equities has been driven by easing lockdowns and government and central bank support. However, investors remain cautious due to new virus cases in the US and strict measures in parts of China and Europe.

site_title: China smartphone giant Vivo is latest to splurge on tech tower
summary: China's No 2 smartphone brand Vivo has broken ground on a 32-storey tech tower in Shenzhen, designed by NBBJ, to house its future headquarters. The building will feature Vivo's flagship store, indoor gardens, and self-shading glass. Vivo joins fellow tech giants Tencent Holdings and ByteDance in spending big on new office space, despite economic turmoil. The tech campus boom is seen by some as a sign of an overheated economy, but NBBJ argues that China's tech giants have outgrown their old digs and are seeking space for global expansion.

site_title: Hong Kong's May home prices rise at fastest pace in 13 months
summary: Hong Kong's private home prices rose 1.9% in May, the fastest pace in 13 months, driven by low interest rates and pent-up demand. Home transaction volumes are expected to reach the highest since May 2019 in June. However, property agents predict no strong price increase through 2020 due to economic weakness and political tensions. Bankruptcy filings reached a 17-year high in May, while China's national security law imposition has sparked escape plans among residents. The luxury home segment saw a 61% increase in transactions valued over HK$50 million in May.

site_title: China crypto miner Ebang plans to start Bitcoin exchange in 2020
summary: China-based crypto mining giant Ebang International Holdings plans to launch an offshore Bitcoin exchange by 2020, aiming to expand beyond the volatile cryptocurrency market. The company's revenue is expected to grow 40% in 2020, reaching $200 million, with a potential doubling to $400 million in 2022. Ebang's new exchange will help counter Bitcoin's price fluctuations, allowing the company to diversify its business and reduce reliance on the cryptocurrency market.

images.alt_text: Chinese crypto mining giant Ebang International Holdings is planning to launch an offshore exchange for digital assets this year, hoping to expand beyond a sector that tends to boom and bust with Bitcoin prices.

site_title: Japan says coronavirus border controls in place, adding 18 countries to entry ban
summary: Japan has reaffirmed its existing border controls, keeping them in place except for humanitarian reasons. The country will add 18 countries to its entry ban, bringing the total to 129. This decision comes into effect on July 1, following a posting on the foreign ministry website on June 29.

site_title: Japan jobless rate up, available jobs in worst plunge since 1974
summary: Japan's unemployment rate rose to 2.9% in May, its third consecutive monthly increase, as the coronavirus pandemic affects the country's economy. The job market has seen a significant decline, with 120 jobs available for every 100 jobseekers, the steepest drop since the 1974 oil shock. Despite Japan's relatively low number of deaths and cases, the country is experiencing labor shortages and millions of people on precarious temporary contracts, raising concerns about the depth of the recession.

site_title: Uber makes offer to buy delivery service Postmates
summary: Uber has made a takeover offer to buy delivery service Postmates, according to three people familiar with the matter. The deal could bolster Uber's delivery business, Uber Eats, and help it compensate for the collapse of its core ride-hailing business. Postmates, a 9-year-old company, has struggled to compete with larger competitors like DoorDash and Grubhub. The takeover offer's value was not disclosed, and talks are still ongoing. The deal could also be a lifeline for Postmates, a company that confidentially filed to go public in February.

images.alt_text: Uber has made a takeover offer to buy Postmates, the upstart delivery service, according to three people familiar with the matter, as the on-demand food delivery market consolidates and Uber looks for new ways to make money.

site_title: Singapore shares rise at open after Wall Street bounce; STI up 0.8%
summary: Singapore's Straits Times Index rose 0.8% to 2,595.12 at open on Tuesday, driven by a Wall Street bounce overnight. The index saw gains from banking stocks, including DBS, UOB, and OCBC, as well as Singtel and Keppel Corp. The market is awaiting the Republic's Nomination Day, followed by the General Election on July 10.

site_title: China's parliament passes national security law for Hong Kong: Cable TV
summary: China's parliament passed a national security law for Hong Kong, setting the stage for significant changes to the city's way of life since its return to Chinese rule in 1997. The law, passed unanimously by the Standing Committee of China's National People's Congress, targets subversion, terrorism, separatism, and collusion with foreign forces. The move comes in response to last year's violent pro-democracy protests in Hong Kong. A draft of the law has yet to be published, but it will come into force as soon as it is gazetted in Hong Kong.

site_title: YouTube shuts down far-right channels over hate speech
summary: YouTube has shut down six far-right channels for violating its rules against "supremacist" content, including channels by David Duke, Stefan Molyneux, and Richard Spencer. The channels were terminated for allegedly promoting hate speech and inferiority of protected groups. Since updating its guidelines a year ago, YouTube has removed over 25,000 channels for violating hate speech policies, and has taken action against other platforms, including Reddit and Twitch, for hosting hateful content.

site_title: China's drag queens no longer content to wait in the wings
summary: China's drag culture is gaining momentum, with 18-year-old Yan Anyu, aka "Miss Cream," making his live debut in Shanghai. Attitudes toward alternative lifestyles are softening, and a small but growing drag community is stepping into the spotlight. Despite homosexuality being decriminalized in 1997, it remains a touchy topic, with the LGBT community quietly asserting itself through advocacy groups and performances. Chinese drag queens, like Yan, use their art to resist societal discrimination and express themselves freely, with online platforms and discreet events providing a space for self-expression.

site_title: A vanishing way of life in Danube Delta's natural paradise
summary: The traditional way of life in Romania's Danube Delta is disappearing due to the coronavirus pandemic and modernization. The delta, a UNESCO World Heritage site, is home to over 300 bird species and 45 freshwater fish species, but its fragile ecosystem is threatened by tourism and pollution. Residents, including fishermen and boat operators, are struggling to make a living, with many emigrating to the West. The delta's natural paradise is being replaced by purpose-built houses and motorboats, and the region's isolation during harsh winters is exacerbating the issue.

site_title: China service sector grows at fastest pace in 7 months in June: official PMI
summary: China's services sector grew at its fastest pace in 7 months in June, with the official non-manufacturing PMI rising to 54.4 from 53.6 in May. This marks the fastest growth since November 2019, suggesting consumer confidence is rapidly recovering despite increased coronavirus curbs. The services sector, which includes many smaller private companies, has been slower to recover than manufacturing, with heavy job losses and pay cuts. The official June composite PMI also rose to 54.2.

site_title: Australian employment recovering gradually from virus shock
summary: Australian employment has gradually recovered from the COVID-19 pandemic, with total payroll jobs increasing 1.0% between mid-May and mid-June, or around 30% of the jobs initially lost. The jobless rate remained steady at 5.2% before rising to 7.1% in May. Employment growth was faster for under-20s, and wages paid rose 0.2% in the week. The recovery is seen as a positive sign, but unemployment remains a concern.

images.alt_text: Australian employment is continuing to pick up gradually after the huge losses caused by coronavirus lockdowns, recovering around 30 per cent of the jobs initially shed, data showed on Tuesday.

site_title: Hong Kong: Stocks start on upbeat note
summary: Hong Kong stocks opened on an upbeat note on Tuesday, rising 0.69% or 166.96 points to 24,468.24, following a rally on Wall Street and improved Chinese factory data. The benchmark Shanghai Composite Index edged up 0.12% and the Shenzhen Composite Index rose 0.57%. Investors took cues from the US stock market, where the S&P 500 and Nasdaq reached fresh records despite tariff uncertainty.

site_title: China's June factory activity quickens to 3-month high: official PMI
summary: China's factory activity expanded at a three-month high in June, with the official PMI rising to 50.9, above expectations. This follows the government's efforts to lift lockdowns and boost investment. However, weak global demand and a mild domestic recovery are expected to weigh on growth. Analysts believe the economy remains far from full recovery, and Beijing may need to maintain easing policies.

site_title: Hatten Land to acquire 20% stake in digital asset exchange ECXX Global for US$6m
summary: Hatten Land has entered into conditional agreements to acquire a 20% stake in ECXX Global, a digital asset exchange service provider in Singapore, for US$6 million. Hatten Land's indirect wholly-owned subsidiary Hatten Technology will hold the shares, and the existing shareholders of ECXX, including CapitalX Global, have agreed to grant an option to Hatten Technology to acquire up to 31% of the company's enlarged share capital. Upon completion, Hatten Land may nominate its representatives to be appointed as directors, representing no more than one-third of ECXX's board.

site_title: US records more than 42,000 new virus cases in 24 hours: tally
summary: The US recorded over 42,000 new coronavirus infections in 24 hours, bringing the total to nearly 2.6 million, according to Johns Hopkins University. Despite this surge, daily US deaths declined to 355. Several state governors have reimposed lockdowns on businesses, but the White House attributes the rise in cases to expanded testing rather than community spread.

site_title: Malaysia: Shares open lower on Tuesday
summary: Malaysia's shares opened lower on Tuesday, with the FTSE Bursa Malaysia Kuala Lumpur Composite Index down 1.46 points, or 0.10%, to 1,492.97. This followed a positive close on Thursday, where the Straits Times Index (STI) rose 0.4% despite tariff uncertainty and split Fed views. The market was affected by various global news, including US-EU trade talks and the valuation of Airalo, which reached over $1 billion after raising $220 million in new funding.

site_title: Mirzan Mahathir not re-elected as SBI Offshore chairman
summary: Mirzan Mahathir, eldest son of former Malaysian PM Mahathir Mohamad, has ceased to be SBI Offshore's executive non-independent chairman after failing to be re-elected at the annual general meeting. He has also retired as a director, effective immediately. The company's board is discussing a smooth handover of his duties, and he may retain his services on a limited basis for ongoing matters. Mahathir was appointed chairman in 2014 and is a substantial shareholder of the company.

site_title: BlueRed Partners leads US$18m round in cyber security startup Cynet
summary: BlueRed Partners led a US$18-million Series B funding round in US-based cyber security startup Cynet, joined by Deutsche Telekom and Merlin International. Cynet, which provides an autonomous breach-protection platform, plans to use the funding to strengthen its platform and expand globally. The company has hundreds of customers worldwide and will use the fresh funding to aggressively expand its footprint. This round brings Cynet's total funding to over US$30 million.

site_title: Tokyo: Stocks open higher after US rally
summary: Tokyo stocks opened higher on Tuesday following a US rally, with the benchmark Nikkei 225 index gaining 1.55% to 22,335.41. The broader Topix index rose 1.34% to 1,569.91. The US stock market also saw gains, with the S&P 500 and Nasdaq reaching fresh records despite ongoing trade tensions. Meanwhile, an eSIM platform, Airalo, raised $220 million in funding, valuing it over $1 billion.

site_title: Stocks to watch: Keppel, SPH, IHH Healthcare, UOB, Hatten Land
summary:
Here is a 100-word or less summary of the article content:

Several Singaporean companies saw new developments that may affect trading of their securities. Keppel Corp and Singapore Press Holdings (SPH) formed a joint venture for data centre facilities, while IHH Healthcare reported a loss for the first quarter due to impairment and foreign currency translation losses. United Overseas Bank's head of digital group is departing, and Hatten Land is looking to acquire a 20% stake in ECXX Global. Ascott Residence Trust reset its distribution rate, and First Real Estate Investment Trust terminated an agreement with Lippo Karawaci. Other companies, such as The Hour Glass Group and AEM Holdings, also reported earnings.

site_title: Japan factory output slumps as economy sinks deeper in recession
summary: Japan's industrial output fell 8.4% month-on-month in May to its lowest level since the 2009 financial crisis, marking the fourth consecutive decline. The country's economy is bracing for its worst postwar recession due to the coronavirus's impact on supply chains, businesses, and consumer spending. The government's assessment of industrial production remains unchanged, describing it as "lowering sharply". Japan's economy shrunk 2.2% annually in January-March, and analysts expect a deeper slump in the current quarter.

site_title: At least 32 die in Bangladesh ferry accident
summary: At least 32 people died in a ferry accident in Bangladesh's capital Dhaka on Monday after the Morning Bird ferry capsized and sank following a collision with another ferry during the morning rush hour. One man, Suman Bapary, was found alive 13 hours later. The ferry, which had a capacity of 150 passengers, was carrying around 50 people when it sank. Authorities have blamed carelessness for the accident, which is the latest in a series of boat accidents in the country with a poor safety record.

site_title: Robotics startup Botsync bags seed funding from Wong Fong, Seeds Capital
summary: Singapore-based robotics startup Botsync has secured undisclosed seed funding from Wong Fong Industries, Seeds Capital, Angelhub, and Artesian Venture Partners. The funding will be used to scale automation solutions for the logistics and manufacturing sector, enhancing features of its robots for safer use. Botsync's robots can transport payloads of 500-1000 kg, reducing material handling costs by up to 45%. The startup plans to build technology teams in Singapore and India, aiming to help enterprises worldwide adopt automation.

site_title: Twitch, Reddit hate crackdown targets Trump, supporters
summary: Reddit banned the "r/The_Donald" forum, a popular platform for Trump supporters, as part of a crackdown on hateful posts. The platform also briefly suspended President Donald Trump's channel due to rules violations, citing his 2015 remarks on Mexicans and a recent Tulsa rally. Reddit's new policy bans promoting hate based on identity or vulnerability. The move comes amid pressure to address racial equity and comes after Reddit previously "quarantined" the forum for promoting violence.

site_title: URA launches Jalan Anak Bukit site under dual-envelope tender
summary: The Urban Redevelopment Authority (URA) has launched a 3.22-hectare commercial and residential site along Jalan Anak Bukit under a dual-envelope tender system. The site can yield about 845 private homes and generate up to 1.04 million square feet of gross floor area. URA will offer a nine-month tender period due to the ongoing Covid-19 situation, with a closing date of March 30, 2021. The site is envisioned to be a mixed-use integrated transport hub, boosting the rejuvenation of the Beauty World precinct and enhancing the commuting experience.

images.alt_text: URA has launched for sale a commercial and residential site along Jalan Anak Bukit, near Beauty World MRT Station, under a dual-envelope tender system.

site_title: Norwegian Air Shuttle cancels order for 97 Boeings
summary: Norwegian Air Shuttle has cancelled an order for 97 Boeing aircraft, including 92 737 Max and five Dreamliners, due to financial difficulties exacerbated by the coronavirus shutdowns. The grounding of its 737s caused significant losses, and the company is launching legal action to get compensation and down-payments refunded. Reliability issues with Rolls Royce engines on its 787 aircraft also contributed to losses. The announcement comes as US regulators test-flight the 737 MAX, a key step in recertifying the jet for flights.

site_title: First Reit unit serves termination notice on development agreement for Indonesia hospital
summary: A wholly-owned First Reit subsidiary, Tata Prima Indah, has served a termination notice to a Lippo Karawaci subsidiary, Saputra Karya, to scrap an agreement for the development of a hospital in Surabaya, Indonesia. The development works agreement, signed in 2015, was halted due to road subsidence that occurred in 2018. First Reit's manager cited this as the reason for terminating the agreement, and is now evaluating options and conducting feasibility studies to determine if future construction works can be done on the site.

site_title: Australia to invest more in cyber security, hire specialists
summary: Australia is investing A$1.35 billion in cyber security, including hiring 500 specialists, to combat increasing hacking attempts against the country. The funding, part of a A$15 billion investment, aims to protect the nation's economy, national security, and sovereignty. The attacks, which began in March, are believed to be carried out by a "sophisticated state-based actor", with China suspected but denied by Beijing. This investment follows previous cyber-attacks on Australian parliament and major political parties in 2019, also linked to China.

site_title: China reports 19 new Covid-19 cases, including 7 in Beijing
summary: China reported 19 new Covid-19 cases, including 7 in Beijing, on June 29. This is an increase from 12 cases the day prior. Mainland China has 83,531 confirmed cases as of June 29. The number of asymptomatic patients also rose to 4, down from 6 previously.

images.alt_text: China on Tuesday reported 19 new coronavirus cases in the mainland for June 29, up from 12 a day earlier, the health authority said.

site_title: End of the line for France's oldest nuclear plant
summary: France's oldest nuclear plant, Fessenheim, was shut down on June 29, 2020, after four decades of operation, marking the end of its 40-year lifespan. The closure, which began four months after the first reactor was taken offline, is welcomed by anti-nuclear campaigners, who had long warned of contamination risks. The site's dismantlement is expected to take until 2040, affecting the livelihoods of 2,500 people in the local community.

site_title: After deadly clash, India bans 59 Chinese mobile apps over 'security'
summary: India has banned 59 Chinese mobile apps, including TikTok and WeChat, over national security and privacy concerns, two weeks after a deadly border clash between the two nations. The move comes after complaints of data theft and user privacy violations. The apps, which have a combined user base of over half a billion, will be disallowed from being used in India. The ban is seen as a targeted move to ensure safety and sovereignty of Indian cyberspace.

site_title: Cirque du Soleil files for bankruptcy protection
summary: Cirque du Soleil files for bankruptcy protection, citing a debt of over $1 billion and zero revenues since the COVID-19 pandemic forced the closure of its shows. The company will lay off 3,480 workers and immediately re-hire most of them as conditions allow.
