A purchase agreement has been reached with current shareholders, who will provide $300 million in liquidity to support the restructuring. The company aims to emerge from the US bankruptcy process with less debt and restart operations.

site_title: US ends arms exports, China restricts visas in Hong Kong row
summary: The US has ended sensitive defense exports to Hong Kong, a move in response to China's decision to restrict visas to some Americans heading to the territory. The US had previously approved $2.4 million in defense sales to Hong Kong, but the Commerce Department is now treating the financial hub the same as China for dual-use exports. China has vowed to impose visa restrictions on American individuals deemed responsible for undermining Hong Kong's autonomy. The move is part of a tit-for-tat response to the US's national security law expected to be adopted by China, which Hong Kong activists say would destroy the city's freedoms.

site_title: More domestic flights, interstate trains as India eases virus lockdown
summary: India eases its lockdown by allowing more domestic flights and interstate train services to operate, while keeping schools shut. The country recorded 550,000 COVID-19 cases and 16,475 deaths, making it the fourth worst-hit nation. The government aims to restart activities while maintaining containment zones to limit virus spread. The new measures, including a shorter night curfew, will come into force on Wednesday and remain in place until the end of July, with further expansion of domestic flights and trains planned.

site_title: WHO to send team to China as it warns pandemic far from over
summary: The World Health Organization (WHO) is sending a team to China to investigate the origin of the novel coronavirus, six months after the outbreak. The team aims to find the source of the virus and work towards understanding how it started. WHO Director-General Tedros Adhanom Ghebreyesus warned that the pandemic is far from over, with global cases speeding up, and that unless international unity replaces division, "the worst is yet to come." The organization also emphasized the need for countries to take responsibility for measures such as contact tracing and citizens to maintain personal hygiene.

site_title: GE2020: Holland-Bukit Timah GRC, Bukit-Panjang SMC to see straight fights
summary: In the upcoming Singapore General Election, the People's Action Party (PAP) is fielding a four-man team in the Holland-Bukit Timah GRC, led by incumbent Vivian Balakrishnan, against a fresh lineup from the Singapore Democratic Party (SDP). SDP's Tan Jee Say, a former SingFirst chief, is contesting alongside James Gomez, Cheong En Min, and Alfred Tan. In another straight fight, SDP's Paul Tambyah will contest in the Bukit Panjang SMC against PAP's Liang Eng Hwa. The election is seen as challenging due to the COVID-19 pandemic's impact on jobs and incomes.

images.alt_text: PAP's team to defend seat at Holland-Bukit Timah. (from left): Christopher De Souza, Sim Ann, Vivian Balakrishnan and newcomer Edward Chia.
Another twist is SDP party chairman Paul Tambyah will contest in Bukit Panjang SMC, in a straight fight with PAP's Liang Eng Hwa, 56.

site_title: Greece says it will not allow direct flights from UK, Sweden until July 15
summary: Greek authorities have announced that direct flights from the UK and Sweden to Greece will not be allowed until July 15, citing EU guidelines on high-risk countries due to the COVID-19 pandemic. The decision affects British holidaymakers, a key market for Greece's struggling tourism sector. Greece reopened some international flights on June 15 and plans to open all others on July 1. The Greek Prime Minister stated that the process of reopening will be dynamic and subject to continuous review of the COVID-19 situation.

site_title: New Zealand to use virtual digital platforms to host Apec summit
summary: New Zealand will host the Asia Pacific Economic Cooperation (Apec) group summit next year using virtual digital platforms due to the global disruption caused by Covid-19. Foreign Minister Winston Peters stated that hosting high-level visitors from late 2020 onwards is impractical given the current environment. The decision aims to mitigate the risks associated with the pandemic and ensure a successful summit.

site_title: One Championship MMA fights to resume next month
summary: One Championship, Asia's largest MMA promotion, will resume hosting events behind closed doors in Thailand next month after a five-month break due to the coronavirus. The company has cancelled several events and cut staff by 20% but received a $70 million funding boost. Its flagship events will restart with an event without fans on July 31. The first three major bouts of the "One: No Surrender" event have been confirmed, featuring fighters such as Rodtang Jitmuangnon and Yodsanklai IWE Fairtex.

site_title: Oil rises on improving economic data but new coronavirus cases loom
summary: Oil prices rose by $1 a barrel on Monday, driven by improving economic data from Asia and Europe. Brent crude gained 1.7% to settle at $41.71 a barrel, while US crude rose 3.1% to $39.70 a barrel. However, investors remain cautious due to concerns about new coronavirus cases and the risk of a second wave of the pandemic, which has led to restrictions in some US states. The Organization of the Petroleum Exporting Countries (Opec+) extended its supply cut agreement into July, supporting the price gains.

site_title: PSP manifesto calls for less reliance on foreign labour, stronger safety net for vulnerable groups
summary: The Progress Singapore Party (PSP) has released its election manifesto, focusing on reducing reliance on foreign labor, supporting local businesses, and strengthening a safety net for vulnerable groups. The party aims to introduce quotas for Employment Passes and reduce the number of foreign Work Permit and S Pass holders. It also proposes increasing the cash portion of the Workfare Income Supplement to 80% for employees and reducing inequality through a living wage for low-wage Singaporeans. The party calls for a freeze on tax and fees for five years and stronger alternative voices in Parliament.

site_title: UK reimposes lockdown on virus-hit city of Leicester
summary: The UK has reimposed lockdown measures on the city of Leicester, with schools and non-essential shops closed, amid a spike in COVID-19 cases. This is the first large-scale lockdown in the country since easing nationwide stay-at-home orders. Prime Minister Boris Johnson's "whack-a-mole" strategy aims to control local outbreaks while easing restrictions nationwide. The measures come as the country faces a deep recession and Johnson prepares to outline a £5 billion plan to "build, build, build" and address regional inequalities.

site_title: Jobs in some international schools in danger if enrolment falls along with expat numbers
summary: International schools in Singapore face uncertainty as expat numbers and Covid-19 restrictions impact enrolment. Some schools, like Overseas Family School, struggle to secure work passes for prospective parents, while others, such as Singapore American School and Tanglin Trust School, see a decrease in waitlists due to border restrictions. Virtual classes have become a solution for schools like Global Indian International, and experts warn that remote working could lead to a decline in demand for international schools in the future.

site_title: SGX buys remaining 80% of BidFX to bridge OTC and listed FX markets
summary: SGX has agreed to purchase the remaining 80% stake in BidFX for approximately US$128 million, expanding its reach into the global FX OTC market. The acquisition, expected to complete in July, will bridge the listed and OTC markets in FX, offering a comprehensive solution for institutional investors. The deal aims to capitalize on growing demand for FX trading solutions amid increasing regulatory requirements.

site_title: US 'Golden State Killer' pleads guilty to 13 murders, confesses to almost 50 rapes
summary: Joseph James DeAngelo, 74, pleaded guilty to 13 murders and confessed to almost 50 rapes, robberies, and kidnappings in California between 1975 and 1986. The "Golden State Killer" was arrested in 2018 after DNA evidence was matched to a family genealogy database. DeAngelo, a former police officer, was initially charged with the 1978 murders of a couple but agreed to a plea deal that includes 11 consecutive life terms without parole and 15 concurrent life sentences over weapons allegations. The case drew closure for victims and families, many of whom had passed away since the crime spree.

site_title: Europe: Shares end choppy session higher after Wall Street bounce
summary: European shares ended a volatile session higher on Monday, lifted by strong gains on Wall Street and a rally in cyclical stocks. The pan-European Stoxx 600 index rose 0.4% and eurozone blue-chip stocks jumped 0.9% as improving economic data and stimulus talks boosted investor confidence. The eurozone banks were the biggest gainers, up 3.2%, while consumer stocks like Unilever and Danone fell between 0.1% and 2.6%. Despite a slowdown in market recovery, European stocks have outperformed their US counterparts in June, driven by the region's reopening and EU's proposed recovery fund.

site_title: Plunging energy prices push American shale pioneer into bankruptcy
summary: Chesapeake Energy, a US-based shale gas pioneer, filed for bankruptcy, listing assets and liabilities in the range of $10 billion to $50 billion. The company's collapse is attributed to a collapse in global energy demand due to coronavirus-induced lockdowns, which led to a 25-year low in natural-gas futures. Chesapeake's heavy debt load, acquired through aggressive expansion, ultimately became unsustainable, with the company seeking to eliminate $7 billion in debt and secure $925 million in financing.

site_title: Corporate digest
summary: ComfortDelGro Corporation will launch Singapore's fastest public commercial DC charger, the Delta Ultra Fast Charger, on July 1. The 100kW charger can charge vehicles 10 minutes faster than existing stations. MindChamps PreSchool has partnered Malek Family to expand its Australian footprint, while Ascott Residence Trust has reset its distribution rate to 3.07%. Citigroup has set a mid-2026 target of 1,150 for MSCI's global equity index.

site_title: US: Dow ends up 2.3% as stocks bounce from Friday rout
summary: US stocks rebounded on Monday, with the Dow Jones Industrial Average jumping 2.3% to 25,595.80, and the S&P 500 gaining 1.5% to 3,053.24. The recovery comes after a 2% drop on Friday due to concerns over the US economic recovery amid rising coronavirus cases. Boeing led the gains, surging 14.4% after the FAA certified the 737 MAX for return to service. Other companies, such as Facebook and Coty, also saw significant increases, while investors remain optimistic despite tariff uncertainty and mixed Fed views.

site_title: Parties, policies, personalities in focus as campaigning starts amid Covid-19
summary: Singapore's General Election (GE2020) is set to begin with Nomination Day, where all 93 seats will be contested by 200 candidates from 10 opposition parties and the ruling People's Action Party (PAP). The PAP's manifesto focuses on overcoming the Covid-19 crisis, while the Workers' Party emphasizes education and social policy. Candidates will be announced after Nomination Day, and campaigning will begin on July 10. The election marks a leadership renewal for the PAP, with several veteran politicians retiring, and the opposition seeks to gain a stronger presence in Parliament.

site_title: Builders can consider hostels for worker housing; but safe-distancing rules stay
summary: Singapore's 40 boutique hostels urge authorities to encourage foreign worker housing amid a lull in backpacker tourism due to the pandemic. Authorities are concerned about the communal-style living at hostels, which may create new infection clusters, and maintain strict safe distancing measures. The hostels propose using their premises to house foreign workers, but authorities remain cautious about the risks.

site_title: Money FM podcast: Leadership during a crisis - Amit Midha, Dell Technologies
summary: Dell Technologies President Amit Midha discusses leadership during a crisis on the Money FM podcast. He shares insights on navigating operations and leading in unprecedented times. Midha emphasizes the importance of systems leadership in managing complexity in M&As and authentic leadership in uncertain times. He also highlights the need for tracking leadership development to raise Singapore's global competitiveness. The conversation aims to provide valuable lessons for businesses and individuals in today's crisis-driven environment.

site_title: China firms behind 50% of global equity raised in H1 2020
summary: China-based companies raised $32.1 billion in equity capital globally from January to June 2020, accounting for 49.8% of worldwide offerings. This marks a record for China firms and highlights the economy's early recovery from the Covid-19 pandemic. The trend is attributed to the popularity of Shanghai's STAR Market and well-received IPOs in Hong Kong. Escalating Sino-US geopolitical tension is expected to prompt more US-listed Chinese firms to conduct secondary listings in Hong Kong or China, where funds can be raised without anti-Chinese sentiment.

site_title: Darco shareholders right to let offer lapse; should push for more accountability
summary: Darco's deputy chairman Wang Zhi's offer to buy shares at S$0.17 per share fell short of the required 50% voting rights, with only 3.9% of shareholders accepting. Despite the independent financial adviser RHT Capital's recommendation to reject the offer due to its "not fair" and "not reasonable" terms, chairman Wang Yaoyu recommended shareholders accept the offer. This move has raised concerns about the board's accountability to minority shareholders, who should continue to pressure the board for better representation.

site_title: Boeing 737 MAX test flight takes off in Seattle
summary: US regulators launched a test flight of the Boeing 737 MAX in Seattle, marking a key step in recertifying the grounded jet. The initial flight lasted several hours and will be followed by additional trips. The Federal Aviation Administration (FAA) stressed that the certification process is not over, with numerous tasks remaining, including thorough review of Boeing's work and pilot training protocols. The MAX has been grounded since March 2019 following two fatal crashes, and its return to service depends on meeting certification standards.

images.alt_text: US regulators launched a test flight of the Boeing 737 MAX on Monday, a key step in recertifying the jet that has grounded for more than a year following two fatal crashes.

site_title: IHH Healthcare reports Q1 loss of RM319.8m
summary: IHH Healthcare, a Malaysia-registered hospital operator, reported a Q1 loss of RM319.8 million (S$104.1 million) for FY2020, mainly due to impairment on an investment in India and foreign currency translation losses. Revenue was 2% lower year-on-year, and no dividends were proposed. Despite a strong balance sheet with RM5.4 billion in cash, IHH expects an impact from the Covid-19 pandemic, citing lower patient volumes and higher costs. The company expects a recovery in local patient volumes as movement restrictions ease, but warns of potential disruptions from subsequent Covid-19 outbreaks.

site_title: Real estate agents return to work as New York City reopens
summary: New York City has reopened and real estate agents have returned to work, implementing pandemic protocols to keep brokers and clients safe. Agents now conduct scheduled showings, clean before and after each visitor, and provide hand sanitizers. Virtual tours have become the norm, and in-person showings are limited to vacant or unoccupied properties. Real estate boards have issued guidelines to ensure safety, and agents are stocking up on hand sanitizers and disinfecting tools. The focus on client comfort and safety is more important than ever, and virtual walk-throughs are likely to remain a popular option in the future.

site_title: New swine flu found in China has pandemic potential
summary: Researchers in China have discovered a new type of swine flu, G4, with pandemic potential. Genetically descended from the 2009 H1N1 strain, G4 is highly infectious and replicates in human cells, causing serious symptoms. Studies show that immunity from seasonal flu does not provide protection against G4, and up to 10.4% of swine workers and 4.4% of the general population may have already been exposed. While there is no evidence of human-to-human transmission, the virus poses a concern for human adaptation and potential pandemic risk.

site_title: Federal Reserve's Powell warns US recovery depends on containing virus
summary: Federal Reserve Chair Jerome Powell stated that the US economy's recovery depends on containing the coronavirus and government support efforts. Despite the economy's rebound in May, Powell warned that keeping the virus in check remains a challenge. A full recovery is unlikely until people feel confident it's safe to reengage in activities. The Fed's programs, including lending and aid to businesses and families, remain crucial to the recovery. The path forward will also depend on government policy actions to provide relief and support the recovery.

images.alt_text: The US economy started to rebound earlier than expected, but the recovery will depend on containing the coronavirus and on government efforts to provide support, Federal Reserve Chair Jerome Powell said on Monday.

site_title: Dasin Retail Trust placement 1.2 times subscribed; purchase price for China malls unchanged
summary: Dasin Retail Trust's placement was 1.2 times subscribed at S$0.78 per unit, raising S$94 million in gross proceeds. The issue price represents a 6% discount to the volume-weighted average price of S$0.83 per unit. The placement is subject to conditions, including in-principle approval from the Singapore Exchange. The trust expects to commence trading on July 7. Despite the COVID-19 crisis, the trustee-manager remains cautiously optimistic on retail demand and expects greater interest in experiential activities when China's lockdown is lifted.

site_title: Forensic accounting probe launched into EHT sponsor Urban Commons
summary: A forensic accounting investigation has been launched by FTI Consulting into Urban Commons, the sponsor of Eagle Hospitality Trust (EHT), and its master lessees. The investigation will review financial statements, funds allocation, and rent payments. FTI will also examine whether master lessees applied funds received from hotel operations towards rents. The investigation may be extended depending on the initial outcome and findings. Meanwhile, the master lessors have issued two notices of default to the master lessees due to delinquencies in security deposits and unpaid rents.

site_title: CAD probe into Wirecard ongoing; MAS, Acra assisting
summary: Singapore's Monetary Authority of Singapore (MAS) and Accounting and Corporate Regulatory Authority (ACRA) are assisting in a probe into Wirecard's operations, following the company's admission of $2.1 billion in non-existent funds. A criminal probe into Wirecard's Singapore operations has been ongoing since February 2019. The Philippines has also launched a swift and thorough investigation, drawing up a list of entities of interest, including local firms that were partners with Wirecard. The collapse has highlighted cracks in Germany's financial oversight, with calls for reform.

site_title: Accordia Golf Trust's sponsor offers to buy golf courses for S$804.1m
summary: Accordia Golf Trust has proposed to acquire its 88 golf courses in Japan for 61.8 billion Japanese yen (S$804.1 million), representing a premium of 5.1% and 12.9% over its adjusted net asset value and adjusted net tangible assets, respectively. The proposed acquisition is conditional on unitholder approval by Sept 14 and will result in a voluntary winding up of the trust. The deal is expected to enable unitholders to realize value for their units, as the trust has historically low trading volume.

site_title: Strategies for rebound
summary: Singaporean small and medium-sized enterprises (SMEs) are sharing strategies for rebounding from the COVID-19 pandemic. Experts emphasize the importance of focusing on employee upskilling, creating new business opportunities, and leveraging digital tools to boost productivity. Companies are advised to prioritize building a strong backend support system, investing in employee training, and adapting to the new normal. Additionally, innovating in alignment with changing consumption habits and exploring unconventional revenue streams are key to sustaining commercial success post-pandemic.

site_title: IMF's difficulties from epic virus challenge have only just begun
summary: The International Monetary Fund (IMF) faces significant challenges due to the ongoing COVID-19 pandemic, which has exposed its limited resources and intersecting operations with other international financial institutions. The IMF's ability to provide liquidity support to countries in need is hindered by the complexity of the crisis, with commodity prices and tourism expected to suffer long-term shocks. The Fund may need to consider new financing instruments and debt relief measures to support countries with unsustainable finances, and its resource adequacy and quota increase are also being debated.

site_title: Airbnb peeved over home-sharing ban in Amsterdam's old town
summary: Airbnb has criticized Amsterdam's decision to ban vacation rentals in its central old town, calling it "illegal" and saying it wants to work with authorities to ensure its business survives. The ban applies to three areas within the city's canal ring and restricts rentals in other neighborhoods to groups of four or less for up to 30 days a year. Critics argue that short-term rentals have negatively impacted local quality of life, with one in 15 dwellings in Amsterdam showing up on online rental platforms. Airbnb says 95% of its listings in Amsterdam are outside the banned zone.

site_title: New Covid-19 infections weigh on markets, STI down 1.2%
summary: Singapore shares fell 1.2% on Monday due to a resurgence of Covid-19 infections, particularly in the US, and uncertainty heading into Q2 2020 results. The Straits Times Index (STI) closed at 2,574.10 points, with decliners outpacing advancers 297 to 179. Investors are likely to stay on the sidelines, and the best performer was Dairy Farm International, which rose 2%. The banking sector was also down, with DBS, UOB, and OCBC Bank falling 1.4%, 1.3%, and 1.4% respectively.

site_title: Airbus lowers output by 40% for 2 years as job cuts loom
summary: Airbus has announced a 40% reduction in production output for two years, compared to pre-crisis plans, due to the ongoing travel slump. The company's CEO, Guillaume Faury, stated that output will return to normal by 2025. The move is expected to drive significant job cuts, with industry sources predicting phased reductions of 14,000 to 20,000 jobs. Airbus has promised to announce the restructuring details by the end of July.

site_title: DBS offers transition financing with latest framework
summary: DBS Bank has launched a sustainable and transition finance framework in Singapore, making it the first bank to offer transition financing with this framework. The framework aims to evaluate the transitional qualities of economic activities and assess clients' strategies to adapt to a low-carbon economy. DBS will also introduce a taxonomy to guide clients in adapting to climate change and resource scarcity. The bank's efforts follow Singapore's move to become a global centre for green finance, with guidelines proposed by the Monetary Authority of Singapore to encourage sustainable financing.

site_title: Half of Tokyo residents oppose Olympics in 2021: poll
summary: Half of Tokyo residents oppose the 2021 Olympics, with 51.7% wanting the Games to be postponed or cancelled due to COVID-19 concerns. 46.3% want the rescheduled Olympics to proceed as planned, with 31.1% preferring a scaled-back event without spectators. Officials have warned it's impossible to postpone again, citing significant financial and logistical headaches. The poll was conducted ahead of the Tokyo gubernatorial election, where incumbent Yuriko Koike is leading her opponents.

images.alt_text: The Games are now scheduled to begin on July 23, 2021, although they will still be known as the Tokyo 2020 Olympics.

site_title: Dollar extends losses with focus on US Covid-19 cases
summary: The US dollar fell 0.3% against a basket of currencies, extending its losses to 1% this month, amid surging Covid-19 cases in the US. The global death toll reached 500,000, prompting California to close some bars. The euro rose 0.6%, its biggest daily jump in a week, and strengthened against other major currencies, including the Swiss franc and yen. Economists suggest the euro's appreciation is driven by a sustained global economic recovery, although caution remains due to the ongoing pandemic.

site_title: A clarion call for firms to go digital
summary: Singapore's ESG chairman Peter Ong emphasizes the growth opportunities for small and medium-sized enterprises (SMEs) to go digital despite the COVID-19 pandemic. Major initiatives such as the E-Commerce Booster Package, Productivity Solutions Grant, and Start Digital have been launched to drive business transformation and open new revenue streams for companies. As of June, over 6,100 SMEs have taken up the E-Commerce Booster Package, and 24,000 have adopted Start Digital solutions. Ong encourages SMEs to be nimble and open to new ideas, citing the pandemic as an unplanned event that has led to growth opportunities for those prepared to adapt.

site_title: There are reasons not to fear fiscal deficits and central bank financing
summary: Global government spending has increased significantly during the COVID-19 pandemic, with a total of almost $23 trillion in announced packages. However, the accompanying government deficits cause discomfort, with concerns about inflation, higher interest rates, and reduced funds for private sector investment. Experts argue that deficits are a problem for the private sector, not the public sector, and that they can actually increase private savings and put downward pressure on interest rates. Central banks play a key role in managing interest rates and sterilizing deficits, and government deficits can be financed without "printing money." The true danger lies in longstanding fears of deficits that can sacrifice the private sector's financial stability.

site_title: Social media is making itself felt, and may do so at the ballot box
summary: Singapore's GE2020 election is being dubbed a "social media election" due to the shift in campaigning tactics amid the Covid-19 outbreak. Candidates are utilizing online "e-rally" livestreams and airtime on national TV and radio, raising concerns about the potential for social media echo chambers and the erosion of mainstream media's ability to provide blanket coverage. Despite this, social media has already held candidates accountable, with online scrutiny leading to the withdrawal of a candidate and a candidate addressing an online barb. The impact on the ballot box remains to be seen.

site_title: Changing hands
summary: Citigroup has set a target of 1,150 for MSCI's global equity index by mid-2026. Analysts are positive on SGX earnings, raising target prices, citing a defensive play benefiting from market volatility. Meanwhile, Chinese banks face challenges from Beijing's consumer lending push. Japanese bank MUFG plans to expand its US securitisation business and boost headcount. The PBOC adviser recommends a 1.5 trillion yuan stimulus to counter US tariffs. Tesla is expanding its robotaxi services to California and Arizona. FedEx partners with QuikBot to deploy robots for deliveries in commercial areas, and Sam Goi makes a mandatory offer for the rest of PSC at S$0.40 a share.

site_title: China opens wealth tap to HK amid political crackdown
summary: China has launched the Wealth Management Connect programme, allowing two-way cross-border purchases of wealth products between Hong Kong, Macau, and southern China. The programme aims to deepen economic ties and promote financial markets opening-up, amid growing calls for democracy in Hong Kong. The move comes as lawmakers in Beijing discuss a new security law that could bar subversion and collusion with foreign forces. Authorities reassure investors that Hong Kong will remain stable, and the programme is seen as a strategic step to reinforce the city's position as a wealth management hub.

site_title: Phillip Securities to buy RHB's Singapore stockbroking business
summary: Phillip Securities has agreed to buy RHB Investment Bank's Singapore stockbroking business, RHB Securities Singapore, for an undisclosed sum based on the net tangible assets. The acquisition will integrate RHB Bank's capital markets services with its corporate banking and global markets services in Singapore, enhancing its customer experience. The move is expected to improve Phillip Securities' competitive position and distribution scale in Singapore and Asia. The transaction is subject to regulatory approvals and is expected to be completed in the third quarter of 2020.

site_title: Silicon Valley developers bet big on return to offices
summary: California real estate investors Gary Dillabough and Jeff Arrillaga are betting on San Jose, a suburb of Silicon Valley, becoming a hub for Bay Area companies to bring employees back to offices. Despite the shift to remote work, Dillabough believes companies will want workers to return, citing the need for social interaction and better-designed spaces. With over $300 million invested in properties, the duo plans to develop a denser, more vibrant downtown area, aiming to capitalize on the post-pandemic office market.

site_title: Mount Emily property launched for collective sale by tender
summary: A freehold residential property in Mount Emily Road has been launched for collective sale by tender at a guide price of S$24 million. The 515.5 sqm site can be transformed into a boutique residential development or co-living residences, with owners giving consent for the sale. Located near Mount Emily Park and the central business district, the property offers a prime location. The tender closes on August 11, with the indicative price translating to about S$1,485 per square foot.

site_title: Election digest
summary: Singapore GE2020: Overseas voting stations to be set up in 10 cities, including Beijing, London, and Tokyo, for registered Singaporean voters abroad. The Returning Officer has decided to proceed with overseas voting after consulting the Ministry of Health and Ministry of Foreign Affairs. The COVID-19 situation in these cities will be taken into consideration. Meanwhile, PAP's Henry Kwek will contest Kebun Baru, while Tan Jee Say applies to rejoin the SDP. Former MP Lee Bee Wah retires after 14 years, and the SDA proposes a 3% GST for basic items.

images.alt_text: Registered Singaporean voters living abroad can cast their votes at one of 10 overseas voting stations. These are located in Beijing, Canberra, Dubai, Hong Kong, London, New York, San Francisco, Shanghai, Tokyo and Washington.

site_title: SPH to develop, run data-centre facilities with Keppel Corp units
summary: SPH is setting up a joint venture with Keppel Corp to develop and operate data centre facilities at its Genting Lane property. SPH will hold 40% of the JV, named Memphis 1, while Keppel units will hold the remaining 60%.

site_title: Is it finally 'over' for Donald Trump?
summary: US President Donald Trump's recent moves, including his populist agenda and handling of the pandemic, are hurting the economy and his re-election bid. A recent poll shows Joe Biden leading Trump by 14 points, with Trump losing support in key electoral states. Economists agree that a combination of the pandemic, recession, and national unrest would spell electoral disaster for any incumbent president. The White House's protectionist agenda and restrictions on immigration are exacerbating economic challenges, and Trump's refusal to pursue a coherent strategy to combat the pandemic is alienating moderate voters.

site_title: Business leaders share a glimpse of the new normal
summary: Singapore business leaders shared their visions for the post-Covid-19 world, highlighting the need for virtual check-in and check-out systems, remote work, and digitalization in various industries. Experts emphasized the importance of adapting to changes and embracing new technologies to ensure business recovery. Key takeaways include enhanced hygiene protocols, job redesign, and the adoption of digitalization in sectors such as hotels, food and beverage, and education. The event also encouraged SMEs to utilize government schemes and grants to rise again.

site_title: Indonesia government nears deal with central bank on deficit funding
summary: Indonesia's central bank, Bank Indonesia, is nearing a deal with the government to buy billions of dollars of sovereign bonds at zero interest to help finance a wider deficit due to the coronavirus pandemic. The government aims to raise 397.6 trillion rupiah ($38.4 billion) in stimulus, with Bank Indonesia expected to bear the full cost of the expanded healthcare and social safety net budget. Discussions are ongoing for the central bank to buy additional bonds at 1% discount to assist micro-, small, and medium enterprises and non-SME corporates.

site_title: Oil prices extend losses as coronavirus spike cools demand hopes
summary: Oil prices fell for a second consecutive session, with Brent crude dropping 2% to $40.21 a barrel and US crude down 2% to $37.74 a barrel. The decline was driven by a surge in global coronavirus cases, leading some countries to reimpose partial lockdowns and reducing fuel demand. Despite a 9.7 million barrel per day supply cut agreement by major producers, the second wave of the pandemic is expected to cap bullish sentiment, according to economist Howie Lee.

site_title: Biolidics shares sink 22% after calling off US sales of Covid-19 test kits
summary: Biolidics shares plummeted 22% after cancelling a distribution agreement for its Covid-19 test kits in the US due to increased competition. The company will refund Aytu BioScience and withdraw its application for Emergency Use Authorization in the US. However, it plans to continue selling its test kits in other markets and has signed a non-binding agreement to jointly develop a new test kit with Aytu. The company expects no material impact on earnings per share and net tangible assets.

site_title: 'Trial by Internet' culture should not be encouraged: PM Lee
summary: Singaporean Prime Minister Lee Hsien Loong emphasized the importance of a thorough candidate selection process by the People's Action Party (PAP), stating that seeking "perfect" candidates would lead to the loss of many good ones. He also expressed confidence in the PAP's team for the Ang Mo Kio GRC, despite concerns over the online behavior of a withdrawn candidate, Ivan Lim. Lee emphasized that the GE is about addressing pressing issues like health, jobs, and the future, and that the PAP will investigate allegations against Lim after the elections.

images.alt_text: Manpower Minister Josephine Teo leading the PAP's potential Jalan Besar GRC team of Heng Chee How, Denise Phua and Wan Rizal Wan Zakariah during a morning walkabout in Beo Crescent Market and Food Centre on June 29.

site_title: Sony sees software subscription as future for data-analysing image sensors
summary: Sony aims to replicate PlayStation's success by selling software subscriptions for data-analysing image sensors. The company plans to offer software by subscription for sensors installed in security cameras and vehicles, allowing for wireless modification and replacement without disrupting the camera. This shift towards software-centric approach could provide recurring revenue and help the company address its reliance on a few smartphone manufacturers. Analysts see this move as a strategic move to increase profit growth and diversify Sony's businesses, despite potential challenges in the emerging sensor software market.

images.alt_text: "We have a solid position in the market for image sensors, which serve as a gateway for imaging data, said Sony's Hideki Somemiya.

site_title: Hour Glass Group clocks best result with S$76.2m earnings for FY2020
summary: The Hour Glass Group reported its best-ever earnings of S$76.2 million for FY2020, a 8% year-on-year increase in net profit. The company's top line grew marginally by 4% to S$749.5 million, while gross margin improved to 28.8%. A first and final dividend of two cents per share is proposed, subject to approval at the annual general meeting. The company's balance sheet remains healthy, with consolidated net assets of S$607.9 million and cash reserves of S$183.1 million.

site_title: Sovereign funds pile into venture capital investments in 2020
summary: Sovereign wealth funds have invested over $17 billion in venture capital deals in 2020, surpassing 2019's total of $15.6 billion. Despite the coronavirus outbreak, these funds continue to seek out long-term investments, particularly in emerging industries like technology. Recent deals include a $3 billion investment in Waymo and a $3 billion investment in Gojek. The investments are driven by sovereign funds' deep pockets and longer investment horizons, allowing them to invest in start-ups and potentially yield high returns.

site_title: Opera has vanished; so have the dream jobs at the Met Orchestra
summary: The Metropolitan Opera in New York has vanished, along with the dream jobs at the Met Orchestra, due to the pandemic's impact on performing arts institutions worldwide. Hugo Valverde, a French horn player, auditioned for the orchestra at 22 but faced uncertainty, symbolizing the Met's loss of joy and security. The closure of the Met marks a significant shift in the performing arts landscape, leaving many to wonder about the future of opera and classical music.

site_title: Xie Yao Quan replaces Ivan Lim in PAP's Jurong GRC slate
summary: The People's Action Party (PAP) has announced its general election team for the Jurong Group Representation Constituency (GRC), with two new faces. 35-year-old Xie Yao Quan replaces Ivan Lim, while 37-year-old Shawn Huang, a director for enterprise development at Temasek International, joins the team. No other details on the team's performance or strategy are mentioned.

images.alt_text: According to Mr Tharman (left), Mr Xie is an easy choice for Jurong because he has "been here working very hard for the last five years".

site_title: Will 'worst trade treaty' ride to Trump's rescue?
summary: The US-Mexico-Canada Agreement (USMCA) comes into effect on Wednesday, despite deep political controversy surrounding its implementation. The agreement, a revised version of the North American Free Trade Agreement (Nafta), contains multiple wins for the US, including limited opening of Canada's dairy markets. However, US Trade Representative Robert Lighthizer has threatened Canada and Mexico with potential litigation over issues such as worker rights and dairy market access, highlighting the deal's ongoing political challenges. The USMCA's success may help North America recover economically from the coronavirus recession, but its implementation poses a tightrope for President Trump to navigate during the election campaign.

site_title: Companies are using pandemic to shed weight of laggard brands
summary: European companies are reassessing and selling underperforming businesses amid the Covid-19 pandemic's economic impact. Top executives are hiring investment bankers to review portfolios and sell unwanted businesses. This strategy aims to boost profits and mitigate losses. Companies are also exploring new opportunities, such as reviving their running shoe lines, and expanding into new markets like Indonesia and Vietnam. Meanwhile, some firms, like Merck, are making significant investments, with a potential $10 billion deal for a lung therapy firm. This shift reflects the need for companies to adapt to the pandemic's economic challenges.

site_title: Covid-19 drug to cost government entities US$2,340 for 5-day course
summary: Gilead Sciences has announced a pricing model for its coronavirus-fighting drug Remdesivir, charging the US government $2,340 for a typical 5-day course of treatment. The price is $390 per vial, designed to create a one-price model for developed countries to simplify access. The company aims to ensure that the medicine reaches patients worldwide, despite having previously donated about 250,000 treatment courses. The pricing decision sets a precedent for future Covid-19 treatments.

site_title: AEM unaffected by Apple's move to drop Intel: DBS
summary: AEM Holdings is unlikely to be negatively impacted by Apple's decision to drop Intel chips for future Macs. Analysts predict Intel's focus on data-centric business will positively impact AEM, which tests logic chips and has a significant relationship with Intel. Despite Intel's shift, AEM's revenue is mostly driven by its key customer, Intel, accounting for over 90% of its revenue. DBS upgraded AEM to "buy" with a revised target price of S$3.53, citing long-term demand for data centres and server processors driven by work-from-home measures.

site_title: US pending home sales post record gain, exceed all forecasts
summary: US pending home sales surged 44.3% in May to a record high of 99.6, exceeding economists' projections of a 19.3% gain. The increase is attributed to falling mortgage rates and the easing of coronavirus lockdowns. Although the index is below the pre-pandemic high, it signals a faster-than-expected recovery in the residential real estate market. The National Association of Realtors projects existing home sales to reach 4.93 million units this year, up from a previous forecast of 4.77 million.

site_title: UK homebuilder Berkeley's founder dies, aged 72
summary: Tony Pidgley, founder and chairman of UK homebuilder Berkeley Group Holdings, has died at 72. Pidgley started Berkeley with a single house and grew the business into a FTSE 100 company, known for navigating the global financial crisis and leveraging cheap land to drive profits. Under his leadership, the company's culture and values were embedded, ensuring its continued success. Pidgley's legacy will be remembered as a shrewd property investor, and his values will continue to guide the company under new CEO Rob Perrins.

site_title: EU trade chief Hogan drops out of WTO race
summary: EU Trade Commissioner Phil Hogan has withdrawn his candidacy for the World Trade Organization (WTO) head position, citing the European Union's numerous challenges, including the coronavirus crisis, trade disputes with the US, and Brexit negotiations. Hogan stated that the EU's trade agenda requires his undivided attention, and his full involvement is necessary to address these pressing issues.

site_title: UOB's Dennis Khoo leaving to 'pursue other opportunities'
summary: Dennis Khoo, head of UOB's TMRW digital group, is leaving the bank to "pursue other opportunities" after Bloomberg reported that a ByteDance-backed consortium plans to hire him. UOB appointed Kevin Lam, current country CEO of UOB Indonesia, as the new head of TMRW digital group. Lam has held senior roles at UOB and international banks, and the bank plans to launch TMRW in several Asean markets. UOB had projected a S$10 billion market opportunity for TMRW in Asean, citing demand for complex financial instruments among young professionals.

site_title: US: Wall St opens higher on hopes of stimulus, rebound
summary: US stocks opened higher on Monday, driven by hopes of more stimulus and improving data, despite a resurgence in global coronavirus cases. The Dow Jones Industrial Average rose 0.55%, the S&P 500 gained 0.32%, and the Nasdaq Composite rose 0.15%.

site_title: Bias against women driven by people who think it doesn't exist: study
summary: Researchers found that managers who believe gender discrimination is a thing of the past are more likely to show bias against women, with a study in veterinary medicine finding that those who endorsed this idea recommended higher pay and promotion for a male candidate. The study, which involved 254 managers, found that 44.5% of respondents believed bias was a thing of the past, with 61% of men holding this view. The findings suggest that bias persists even when female representation increases, and that managers who feel confident in their objectivity are more prone to expressing bias.

site_title: Bankrupt Chesapeake plans to cut drilling further this year
summary: US shale pioneer Chesapeake Energy, bankrupt and seeking protection, plans to cut drilling to 6-8 rigs for the next two years, down from 15 rigs in 2020. The company aims to operate 7-8 rigs between 2022 and 2024. Chesapeake is currently the No 2 shale gas producer, behind EQT Corp. The reduced drilling program is a response to heavy debt and the impact of the coronavirus pandemic on energy markets.

site_title: Amazon to pay US$500m in one-time bonuses to front-line workers
summary: Amazon announced a US$500 million one-time bonus plan for its front-line employees and partners, with bonuses ranging from US$150 to US$3,000. The move comes amid scrutiny from US lawmakers and unions over Amazon's handling of the COVID-19 pandemic. The bonuses will be given to employees and partners who have worked through June. This move aims to show appreciation for their efforts during the crisis.

site_title: Malaysia: Shares close higher on Monday
summary: Malaysia's FTSE Bursa Malaysia Kuala Lumpur Composite Index rose 6.29 points to 1,494.43 on Monday, with a total volume of 6.015 billion lots worth RM3.053 billion. Losers outnumbered gainers 662 to 371.

site_title: 7 dead in attack on Pakistan Stock Exchange
summary: At least seven people were killed in an attack on the Pakistan Stock Exchange in Karachi on Monday, with two security guards and a policeman also killed in the ensuing melee. The assailants opened fire and hurled a grenade, and all four gunmen were shot dead by security forces within eight minutes. Seven others were wounded in the attack, which comes amid ongoing efforts to stabilize Karachi following a series of security operations against armed groups and militants.

site_title: Students, staff in close contact with infected student tested negative for Covid-19: Ong Ye Kung
summary: Singapore's East Spring Secondary School reported a Covid-19 case among its students, prompting the school to undergo deep cleaning and testing of 39 students and 11 staff in close contact. All tested negative, and the school remains open. Education Minister Ong Ye Kung said the school's safe management measures prevented a cluster from forming, allowing students to return to classes on Tuesday.

site_title: Singapore central bank working with police investigating Wirecard
summary: Singapore's central bank, the Monetary Authority of Singapore (MAS), is collaborating with the police to scrutinize Wirecard's collapsed operations in the city state. The investigation began in February 2019 and will focus on other possible aspects of the case. The MAS and Accounting and Corporate Regulatory Authority (ACRA) are working with the Commercial Affairs Department (CAD) to review the situation. This follows recent developments in Wirecard AG, which led to the expansion of the investigation. The MAS aims to understand the implications of the case on the Singapore financial sector.

site_title: New Covid-19 infections weigh on markets, STI down 1.2%
summary: Singapore's Straits Times Index (STI) fell 1.2% to 2,574.10 points on Monday, weighed down by a resurgence of Covid-19 infections, particularly in the US. The decline followed a risk-off sentiment, with investors staying on the sidelines ahead of Q2 2020 results and Singapore's General Election on July 10. The banking sector led the decline, with DBS, UOB, and OCBC Bank falling 1.4%, 1.3%, and 1.4% respectively.

site_title: China opens wealth tap to Hong Kong amid political crackdown
summary: China has launched the Wealth Management Connect program, allowing Hong Kong residents and people in Macau and southern China to invest in each other's wealth products. The move aims to deepen economic ties and promote financial development in the Greater Bay Area. The program, which will be handled in a "closed-loop" system, will have aggregate and individual quotas, and its formal launch date will be announced after consultation. The announcement comes amid growing calls for democracy in Hong Kong and a new security law that could bar subversion and collusion with foreign forces.

site_title: SPH to develop and run data-centre facilities with Keppel Corp units
summary: SPH is developing and operating data-centre facilities in Genting Lane under a joint venture with Keppel Corp's subsidiaries. The JV company, Memphis 1, will acquire the leasehold interest in the property for S$50 million, with TPM Pte Ltd owning a 40% stake. Completion is expected on July 17, with Keppel units contributing up to S$209 million and TPM contributing up to S$139.6 million. The deal is expected to benefit both companies, with shares of SPH and Keppel Corp closing lower following the announcement.

site_title: Coty to buy 20% stake in Kim Kardashian West's US$1b beauty line
summary: Coty Inc. has agreed to buy a 20% stake in Kim Kardashian West's US$1 billion beauty line KKW for an undisclosed amount, valuing the brand at US$1 billion. The deal is part of Coty's strategy to invest in celebrity-owned products to tap into the demand for niche brands among millennials. The partnership is expected to close in the third quarter of fiscal 2021 and will include the development of skincare, haircare, and other products for KKW. This deal comes as Coty looks to revamp its business and reduce debt.

site_title: Singtel offers insurance savings plan on Dash app
summary: Singtel has launched Dash EasyEarn, an insurance savings plan available on its Dash app. The plan has no lock-in period and allows unlimited withdrawals without penalties. It guarantees a 1.5% annual return, with an additional 0.5% for early sign-ups. The minimum initial premium is S$2,000, and the maximum is S$20,000. The plan is underwritten by Etiqa Insurance and comes with a 105% coverage in the event of death.

site_title: IHH Healthcare sinks into the red with RM319.8m loss
summary: IHH Healthcare, a Malaysia-registered hospital operator, reported a loss of RM319.8 million (S$104.3 million) for the FY2020 first quarter, due to impairment on an investment in India and foreign currency translation losses. Revenue declined 2% year-over-year, and no dividends were proposed. Despite a strong balance sheet, the company expects higher costs due to the Covid-19 pandemic and may see a prolonged impact on performance.

site_title: The Hour Glass Group clocks best performance with S$76.2m in earnings for FY2020
summary: The Hour Glass Group, a luxury watch retailer, reported its best performance to date with earnings of S$76.2 million for FY2020, a 8% year-over-year increase. Net profit rose 26% in the first half and weakened by 3% in the second half. The company's top line increased by 4% to S$749.5 million and gross margin improved to 28.8%. A first and final dividend of 2 cents per share has been proposed, pending annual general meeting approval. The retailer's balance sheet remains healthy with S$607.9 million in consolidated net assets.

site_title: Correction directions issued to two Facebook pages by Pofma Office
summary: The Protection from Online Falsehoods and Manipulation Act (Pofma) Office issued correction directions to two Facebook pages and the platform itself for false statements about cross-border travel arrangements between Singapore and Malaysia. This is the first time an alternate authority, a senior civil servant, has issued a correction direction. The directions were issued on the instruction of the alternate authority for the Minister for Foreign Affairs, highlighting the Act's flexibility in handling falsehoods.

site_title: China to impose visa restrictions on US individuals over Hong Kong
summary: China has announced visa restrictions on US individuals deemed to have "egregious conduct" on Hong Kong-related issues, mirroring US sanctions on Chinese officials curbing freedoms in the city. The move comes as China's Parliament deliberates a draft national security law for Hong Kong, which pro-democracy activists fear will tighten Beijing's control. US Secretary of State Mike Pompeo had previously imposed visa restrictions on Chinese officials, while the US Senate approved a bill that would impose mandatory sanctions on those backing efforts to restrict Hong Kong's autonomy.

site_title: Ascott Residence Trust announces 3.07% reset rate for perpetual not redeemed on first call
summary: Ascott Residence Trust (ART) has announced a 3.07% reset rate for its S$250 million perpetual issue, which was not redeemed on its first call date. This rate is lower than the initial 4.68% launch rate but higher than analyst estimates of 3%. ART's managers cited the novel coronavirus pandemic's impact on occupancies and room rates, as well as the risk of increased leverage and reduced debt headroom, in deciding not to call the issue. The trust's asset value is S$7.4 billion.

site_title: Nokia wins Taiwan Mobile 5G contract worth 400m euros
summary: Nokia has won a 5G contract worth approximately 400 million euros from Taiwan Mobile, becoming the sole supplier for the telecom operator's next-generation network. The contract, valued at around 625 million Singapore dollars, includes a three-year migration to 5G standalone. This win marks a significant deal for Nokia, which has been diversifying its chipset supply and securing 5G contracts globally.

site_title: Gilead prices Covid-19 drug candidate remdesivir at US$2,340 per patient
summary: Gilead Sciences has priced its Covid-19 drug candidate remdesivir at $2,340 per patient for a 5-day treatment in the US and some other developed countries, with $520 per vial for private insurance companies. The price is below the US$5,080 per course recommended by the Institute for Clinical and Economic Review. The US Department of Health and Human Services has secured over 500,000 treatment courses of the drug for American hospitals through September, and will manage allocation until then.

site_title: UOB's TMRW group head Dennis Khoo to leave bank
summary: UOB's TMRW group head Dennis Khoo is leaving the bank to "pursue other opportunities". Bloomberg reported that a consortium backed by ByteDance plans to hire Khoo, as ByteDance applies for a digital bank licence in Singapore. UOB appointed Kevin Lam, the current Indonesia country chief executive, as the new head of the TMRW digital group, who has held senior roles at UOB and international banks.

site_title: BP sells petrochemical arm to Ineos for US$5b
summary: BP has sold its petrochemical business to Ineos for $5 billion, aiming to strengthen its balance sheet and meet a $15 billion divestment target one year early. The deal will see 1,700 staff transferred to Ineos, with BP focusing on rebuilding its finances after taking a hit of up to $17.5 billion in the second quarter. BP CEO Bernard Looney emphasized the company's commitment to net zero carbon emissions by 2050 and minimizing uncertainty following the sale.

site_title: Construction tech Ackcio raises pre-Series A funds from Wavemaker and angel investor
summary: Singapore-based construction tech startup Ackcio has raised pre-Series A funds from Wavemaker Partners and angel investor Michael Gryseels. The undisclosed amount will help expand its presence in existing markets and new ones, particularly in North and South America. Founded in 2016, Ackcio provides wireless-monitoring solutions for industrial applications, including construction and mining projects. The funding follows a recent expansion into Canada and a contract with Changi Airport, driven by the pandemic's shift to more automated solutions.

site_title: Low-income seniors to get mobile data plans that cost as little as S$5 a month
summary: Singapore's Infocomm Media Development Authority (IMDA) has announced a national initiative to provide low-income seniors with affordable mobile data plans starting at S$5 per month for 5GB of data. Basic smartphones will be bundled with the plans, with no excess data charges and throttled surfing speeds if data limits are exceeded. The Mobile Access for Seniors scheme aims to get low-income seniors connected online and is set to launch in July.

site_title: BioNTech raises US$250m from investors including Temasek
summary: BioNTech, a German biotech firm developing a Covid-19 vaccine, has raised US$250 million from investors, including Singapore's Temasek, through a private placement. The transaction includes the purchase of US$139 million in ordinary shares and a US$112 million investment in four-year mandatory convertible notes. The funding will support BioNTech's ongoing vaccine development efforts.

site_title: UK mortgage approvals slump to new record low: BoE
summary: British mortgage approvals plummeted to a record low of 9,273 in May, down from 15,851 in April, according to Bank of England data. This marks the lowest level since comparable records began in 1997. Economists had expected a rise to 25,000 in May. The slump is attributed to the coronavirus lockdown's impact on the housing market.

site_title: Two online casinos catering to Chinese exit the Philippines
summary: Two online casinos catering to Chinese clients, Don Tences Asian Services Solutions and SC World Development Group Ltd., have exited the Philippines due to virus curbs and taxes. Over 5,000 employees will lose their jobs as the Philippine Amusement and Gaming Corp. cancels their licenses. More operators are expected to follow, with the gaming agency attributing the exit to regulatory fees and taxes. The Philippine government is considering proposals for a 5% franchise tax on online casinos and a 25% income tax on foreign workers.

site_title: Cheers! Irish pubs reopen as end of lockdown nears
summary: Ireland's 7,000 pubs reopen on Monday, ending a 15-week lockdown due to the coronavirus pandemic. Pubs serving food, restaurants, and hotels are permitted to open, with social distancing measures in place, including a maximum stay of 105 minutes. All domestic travel restrictions have been lifted, and mass gatherings of 50 indoors or 200 outdoors are allowed. The country is moving towards the final stage of its reopening plan, with the remaining restrictions set to lift on July 20.

site_title: ADO Properties to acquire control of peer Consus Real Estate
summary: ADO Properties exercised options to acquire control of Consus Real Estate, creating Europe's fourth-largest listed property firm. The deal is part of a three-way merger with Adler Real Estate, aiming for cost synergies. ADO's portfolio will grow to 14 billion euros, with 90-104 million euros in expected synergies by the end of 2021. ADO plans a 450 million euros rights issue and is expected to become a candidate for inclusion in Germany's mid-cap index. The transaction is expected to generate significant benefits for the combined entity.

site_title: China's Sinopec starts hiring for new risk management unit
summary: China's Sinopec Group has started hiring for a new commodities risk management unit, with six top management positions to be filled. The unit, Sinopec Chaoyang Risk Management, will provide financial services including hedging and inventory management for the oil and chemical sector. Launched in response to historic oil market declines earlier this year, the unit aims to mitigate risks in price fluctuations and inventory loss. Qualified candidates with at least eight years of industry experience are being sought for roles including managing director and deputy general manager positions.

site_title: Darco defends Indonesia project, says financially rewarding 'if carefully managed'
summary: Darco Water Technologies' board defended its decision to enter a proposed waste management project in Indonesia, citing it as a rare opportunity for a long-term concession project. The project, which could require up to $46 million in fresh funding, has raised concerns among minority shareholders. The board believes the project can be financially rewarding if carefully managed, with built-in downside protection from the acquisition structure. Darco has asked its business partner to negotiate with the West Java government to find a mutually beneficial solution.

site_title: Europe: Shares inch higher, Wirecard surges
summary: European shares rose 0.2% on Monday, lifted by automakers and travel companies, despite a surge in global coronavirus cases. The pan-European Stoxx 600 index gained ground, driven by the European Union's proposed $1.17 trillion recovery fund and the relative success of reopening its economy. Meanwhile, Wirecard surged 93.6% after filing for insolvency, while AMS jumped 6.6% after EU approval for its Osram acquisition.

site_title: Australia: Shares hit 2-week low as virus surge weighs
summary: Australian shares dropped 1.5% on Monday, their lowest close since June 15, amid a global surge in Covid-19 infections. The S&P/ASX 200 index fell 2.2% earlier in the session, with financials and energy stocks leading the declines. Investors are concerned about the rising death toll and new infections, with Australia reporting its biggest daily rise in over two months. The market is in a "wait-and-watch" mode, with traders preparing for potential dips in the pandemic.

site_title: Thailand to re-open bars and allow in some foreign travellers
summary: Thailand to re-open bars and allow some foreign travelers after recording five weeks without community transmission of the coronavirus. Pubs, bars, and karaoke venues will operate until midnight with safety guidelines in place. Foreigners with work permits, residency, or family ties will be allowed to enter, subject to a 14-day quarantine. Business visitors from Japan, South Korea, Singapore, China, and Hong Kong may be exempt from quarantine if they have Covid-19 test certificates.

images.alt_text: Thailand will allow pubs and bars to re-open on Wednesday and plans to let in some foreign travellers after recording five weeks without any community transmission of the coronavirus.

site_title: Daily Debrief: What Happened Today
summary: Prime Minister Lee Hsien Loong expressed confidence in the PAP candidate-selection process, stating that seeking "perfect" candidates could lead to the loss of many good ones. Accordia Golf Trust agreed to divest its Japan golf courses for S$804.1m. The Singapore Exchange (SGX) acquired the remaining 80% stake in BidFX for US$128m. A Mount Emily residential block was put up for collective sale with a S$24m guide price. The Straits Times Index (STI) fell 1.2% to 2,574.10 due to new Covid-19 infections weighing on markets.

images.alt_text: Expressing continued confidence in the People's Action Party (PAP) candidate-selection process, Prime Minister Lee Hsien Loong has said that seeking "perfect" candidates would instead result in the loss of many good candidates.

site_title: Philippines promises 'thorough' probe of Wirecard, looking at 3 local payment firms
summary: The Philippines' anti-money laundering agency will conduct a "swift and thorough" investigation into Wirecard's collapse, focusing on three local payment firms: Centurion Online Payment International, PayEasy Solutions, and ConePay International. The probe was sparked after Wirecard initially claimed it kept $2.1 billion in two Philippine banks, which has been disputed. Entities of interest have been identified, and the agency is monitoring developments to identify more individuals and entities. Philippine central bank governor Benjamin Diokno declined to comment on potential further probes.

site_title: Qatar to further ease coronavirus curbs as infections pass peak
summary: Qatar plans to further ease coronavirus curbs from July 1, allowing the limited reopening of restaurants, beaches, and parks, as infections have passed their peak and subsided. Restaurants will reopen at limited capacity, public beaches and parks will be open, and public gatherings will be limited to five people. Employees can work from office at 50% capacity. A third phase of relaxation, starting August 1, will permit flights from low-risk countries and reopen shopping malls and markets.

site_title: Airbus sees output down 40% for two years as job cuts loom
summary: Airbus is reducing its plane output by 40% for two years due to the travel slump, with CEO Guillaume Faury stating that production and deliveries will be 40% lower than pre-coronavirus plans. This move is expected to drive a restructuring of the company's workforce, with industry sources predicting phased cuts of 14,000 to 20,000 jobs. Airbus has promised to announce the restructuring plans by the end of July, with current temporary furloughs deemed insufficient. Output is expected to return to normal by 2025.

site_title: China oil titans plan joint crude buying to add market clout
summary: China's state-owned oil refining giants are in talks to form a purchasing group to buy crude oil together, increasing their market clout. The group, which includes China Petroleum & Chemical Corp, PetroChina Co, Cnooc Ltd, and Sinochem Group Co., aims to collectively issue bids for certain Russian and African grades in the spot market. This initiative has been supported by the Chinese central government and industry watchdogs, and would make the group the world's largest crude buyer, importing nearly 5 million barrels of oil daily.

site_title: Vanda Global, Marsh Singapore partner up to help firms access risk and insurance services
summary: Vanda Global Capital, a venture capital fund manager, has partnered with Marsh Singapore to provide clients with access to risk and insurance services. The agreement allows Vanda Global's portfolio companies, partners, and Marsh's existing clients to tap into insurance, risk management, and advisory services. The partnership aims to enhance Vanda Global's strategy to grow businesses sustainably and facilitate efficient access to capital in Singapore and globally. The collaboration marks the latest in Vanda Global's ecosystem of alliances and partnerships, following previous agreements with organizations such as Drew & Napier and Raffles Capital.

site_title: Seoul: Stocks tumble as virus dents recovery hopes
summary: South Korean stocks plummeted 1.93% on Monday, falling 41.17 points to 2,093.48, as investors sought safe assets amid a resurgence in global coronavirus cases. The Korean won rose, while the benchmark bond yield increased. Foreigners were net sellers of 230.4 billion won worth of shares, and the MSCI's Asia-Pacific shares index fell 0.99%. The move tracked Wall Street's fall on Friday, with some US states reconsidering their reopening plans.

site_title: Reopened stores bright spot for UK's stretched charity sector
summary: The UK's charity sector, worth billions, has seen its revenues collapse due to the coronavirus pandemic. However, the reopening of charity shops has provided a bright spot, with bargain hunters returning to stores despite social distancing measures and limited customer capacity. The sector is struggling to recover, with concerns over the impact on parent charities, and has called for the government to work more closely with the sector to support its survival.

site_title: Singapore sees broader transition to new rates benchmark next year
summary: Singapore is set to transition to its alternative benchmark rate, the Singapore Overnight Rate Average (SORA), starting next year, with key banks ready to trade SORA derivatives. The Association of Banks in Singapore (ABS) has made significant progress in this transition, with banks to pilot new SORA products in the second half of 2020 and a broader base transition expected in 2021. Existing SOR-referenced loans will also undergo a transition pathway, and an industry-standard guide to contractual provisions is expected to be finalized by the third quarter of this year.

site_title: Gold edges closer to US$1,800 as virus cases surpass 10 million
summary: Gold futures rose 0.6% to US$1,790.40 an ounce, edging closer to the 2011 record of US$1,800, amid rising coronavirus cases and stimulus measures. Demand for haven assets surged as deaths surpassed 500,000 worldwide and confirmed cases exceeded 10 million. Gold has rallied 17% this year, with Goldman Sachs forecasting a record US$2,000 an ounce in 12 months. Investors are turning to gold as a store of wealth, driven by concerns over the pandemic and trillions of dollars in stimulus.

site_title: GE quick takes: PSP, Workers' Party unveil manifestos; PAP replaces Ivan Lim
summary: Singapore is set to go to the polls on July 10, with 93 seats in 31 constituencies up for contest in the General Election. The Progress Singapore Party (PSP) has unveiled its manifesto, calling for reduced foreign labor reliance and stronger support for vulnerable groups. The Workers' Party (WP) has also released its manifesto, proposing a dedicated SME bank and redundancy insurance. Meanwhile, the ruling People's Action Party (PAP) has replaced incumbent candidate Ivan Lim in Jurong GRC with Xie Yao Quan, and added new candidates to its teams in several constituencies.

site_title: Hong Kong: Stocks start week with losses
summary: Hong Kong stocks began the week with a 1% decline, mirroring a sell-off across Asia, amid concerns over the global spread of the virus. The Hang Seng Index fell 248.71 points to 24,301.28, while the Shanghai Composite Index and Shenzhen Composite Index also dropped. The decline follows a steep drop on Wall Street, with investors worrying about the impact of new virus cases.

site_title: Australia's Ampol CEO sees growth opportunities post-Covid
summary: Australia's Ampol Ltd, the country's largest fuel supplier, sees growth opportunities post-Covid, according to its new CEO Matt Halliday. Halliday has focused on unlocking value for shareholders and has not ruled out acquisitions, including refining industry consolidation. Ampol is weighing whether to restart its Lytton refinery, which was shut for maintenance in May. The company is also exploring spinning off fuel stations into a property trust, and Halliday stated that Ampol would consider acquiring other companies if the returns can be delivered.

site_title: Vietnam grounds Pakistani pilots over licence concerns
summary: Vietnam's aviation authority has grounded all 12 Pakistani pilots working for local airlines due to concerns over "dubious" licences. The move comes after global regulators raised concerns about irregularities in pilot licences at Pakistan International Airlines. The suspension will be in effect until further notice, with Vietnam coordinating with Pakistani authorities to review the pilots' profiles. Vietnam currently has 1,260 pilots, with nearly half holding foreign citizenship.

site_title: Tencent, Primavera funding grocery app at US$3b value: sources
summary: Tencent Holdings and Primavera Capital are investing approximately US$300 million in Chinese grocery delivery app Xingsheng Youxuan, valuing the company at US$3 billion. This latest funding round triples the company's price tag from its 2019 funding round. The investment precedes an eventual initial public offering, with Tencent also backing rival Missfresh. The funding follows the pandemic's impact on the sector, with Xingsheng Youxuan benefiting from increased demand for online grocery services.

site_title: Tokyo: Nikkei closes down more than 2%
summary: Tokyo's Nikkei 225 index fell 2.30% to 21,995.04 on Monday, closing at a two-year low, due to fears of a coronavirus resurgence. The broader Topix index dropped 1.78% to 1,549.22. This decline follows a similar rout on US markets, where concerns over the virus's spread are growing.

site_title: Australian lobby touts plan for one million jobs in clean-energy sector
summary: An Australian clean-energy lobby group, Beyond Zero Emissions, has proposed a plan to create one million jobs in the sector, aiming to power a renaissance in Australian manufacturing. The plan involves fast-tracking renewable power projects, improving energy infrastructure, and using abundant wind and solar power. It could help create jobs in high-unemployment areas and provide opportunities in farming communities. The plan contrasts with the government's call for a "gas-fired" economic recovery, which has been criticized for being stacked with pro-gas executives. The plan's launch comes amid Australia's post-pandemic economic challenges.

site_title: Companies use pandemic to shed weight of laggard brands
summary: European companies are selling underperforming businesses amidst the coronavirus pandemic, with investors' profit expectations already low. Companies like Unilever, Nestle, and Total are considering sales of their struggling units, with private equity firms lining up bids. This trend is expected to continue as companies seek to bolster balance sheets and share prices. Nearly a third of companies undertaking sales are willing to increase assets on offer to get the proceeds they need to re-invest.

site_title: Rio Tinto reaches power supply deal with Mongolia for Oyu Tolgoi mine
summary: Rio Tinto has reached a power supply deal with Mongolia for its Oyu Tolgoi copper mine, with the Mongolian state building a coal-fired plant that will supply power to the mine. Construction is set to start by 2021, and the plant is expected to come on stream within the next four years. This deal replaces Rio's earlier plan to build a 300 MW coal power plant, estimated to cost $924 million. The agreement was announced as Rio Tinto flagged potential cost overruns and delays at the project due to difficult geology and coronavirus restrictions.

site_title: Indonesia to respect international law as Singapore probes companies linked to forest fires
summary: Indonesia has pledged to respect international law as Singapore investigates companies linked to 2015 land and forest fires that affected neighboring countries, particularly Malaysia and Singapore. Indonesia's Coordinating Maritime Affairs and Investment minister Luhut Pandjaitan stated that the country will adhere to the Asean Agreement on Transboundary Haze Pollution and its own laws to hold companies accountable. However, Indonesia will not automatically execute foreign verdicts or sanctions, and will instead use its own environment and forestry laws to enforce against errant companies.

site_title: UK's Ofgem proposes permanent measures to help vulnerable energy customers
summary: UK energy regulator Ofgem proposes permanent measures to support vulnerable energy customers, including those on prepayment meters. The plans, set to be implemented by the end of the year, would require suppliers to offer emergency and credit to all prepayment customers, and additional credit to those in vulnerable circumstances. The move aims to reduce the number of customers temporarily going without energy due to inability to top up meters. Around 4 million households use prepayment meters, with one in seven self-disconnecting their supply in the last 12 months.

site_title: Mount Emily residential block up for collective sale with S$24m guide price
summary: A freehold residential block in Mount Emily Road, Singapore, has been launched for collective sale at a guide price of S$24 million, translating to about S$1,485 per square foot. The property, comprising three-storey buildings, sits on a 515.5 sq m site and has an existing GFA of 1,499.3 sq m. The owners have given consent for collective sale, and the development may be strata sub-divided and expanded with a new rear extension, subject to authorities' approval. The tender closes on August 11.

images.alt_text: The indicative price translates to about S$1,485 per square foot on the existing gross floor area and all owners have given consent for the collective sale.

site_title: Durian stall in Geylang, Toa Payoh spa and Bukit Batok Thai eatery among places visited by Covid-19 patients
summary: The Ministry of Health in Singapore has released a list of locations visited by Covid-19 patients while they were still infectious, including a durian stall in Geylang, a spa in Toa Payoh, and a Thai eatery in Bukit Batok. Those who were at these places at the time should monitor their health closely for two weeks from the visit date. A total of 202 new Covid-19 cases were reported, with 196 of them being migrant workers in dormitories, bringing Singapore's total to 43,661 cases.

site_title: Jack Ma's new chieftain lays out plan to fend off Tencent
summary: Ant Group, a subsidiary of Alibaba, is transforming into an online mall offering various services, including loans and travel services, to compete with Tencent Holdings. Under new CEO Simon Hu, Ant aims to halve its reliance on financial services and increase revenue from local merchants and finance firms to 80% within five years. Hu plans to diversify Ant's business into areas like everyday consumer services, cloud offerings, and wealth management, while sharing technology and resources with other companies. The company's strategy aims to counter Tencent's dominance in China's mobile payments space.

site_title: Two new candidates join PAP team in Ang Mo Kio GRC
summary: Two new candidates, Nadia Ahmad Samdin, a lawyer, and Ng Ling Ling, a former public servant, have joined Prime Minister Lee Hsien Loong's People's Action Party (PAP) team to contest Ang Mo Kio GRC in the upcoming General Election. Incumbents Mr Lee, Gan Thiam Poh, and Darryl David will also run. The PAP team will include seven MPs in a new town council, with the goal of building a better town for all.

site_title: PSP manifesto calls for reduced foreign labour reliance, stronger safety net for vulnerable groups
summary: The Progress Singapore Party (PSP) has launched its election manifesto, focusing on reducing dependence on foreign labor, supporting local small businesses, and strengthening a safety net for vulnerable groups. Key priorities include reducing foreign labor quotas, increasing financial assistance for the unemployed, and introducing a living wage for low-wage Singaporeans. The party also calls for a freeze on tax and fees, and to exempt basic necessities from the Goods and Services Tax. Additionally, PSP proposes stronger alternative voices in Parliament and expanded presidential oversight over public appointments.

site_title: Over 3,000 people to be swabbed for Covid-19 in shelters, children's homes and special needs centres
summary: Singapore to test 3,300 staff and residents in shelters and special needs centers for Covid-19 by July 1 as part of expanded community testing efforts. Minister Desmond Lee announced the tests, which include those 13 and above with acute respiratory infections and frontline staff. The tests will complement measures to monitor health, including mask-wearing, temperature checks, and hand hygiene.
