The Ministry of Health has ramped up testing capacity to meet the increase in cases as the economy reopens.

site_title: Airbnb says Amsterdam old town home sharing ban is 'damaging'
summary: Amsterdam's city council has banned vacation rentals in its central canal ring, a UNESCO world heritage site, citing negative influences on quality of life. Airbnb has accused the move as "illegal" and "damaging" to its business. The company, however, expressed willingness to work with authorities to find long-term solutions. 95% of Airbnb's listings in Amsterdam are outside the banned zone, and the company claims the ban will disproportionately affect small businesses and residents. The city council aims to curb mass tourism and its associated nuisance.

site_title: Sony sees software subscription as future for data-analysing image sensors
summary: Sony plans to sell software subscriptions for data-analysing image sensors, a move aimed at diversifying its business and addressing its reliance on a few smartphone manufacturers. The company aims to replicate the success of PlayStation by offering software by subscription, with a focus on artificial intelligence (AI) analysis. Sony has developed the world's first image sensor with integrated AI processor and hopes customers will subscribe to its sensor software service through monthly fees or licensing. The move is seen as a competitive edge for Sony in the emerging software-centric image sensor market.

site_title: Trump denies being told about Russian bounties to kill US troops in Afghanistan
summary: US President Donald Trump denied being briefed about Russian efforts to pay bounties to Taliban-linked militants to kill US troops in Afghanistan, contradicting a New York Times report. Trump claimed he was never informed about the alleged Russian plot, despite US intelligence concluding that a Russian military unit linked to assassination attempts in Europe offered rewards for successful attacks on American and coalition soldiers. The White House and Director of National Intelligence denied the report, while Democrats called for Congress to be briefed on the matter.

site_title: Russia's opposition flounders as Putin changes constitution
summary: Russia's opposition is largely ineffective in opposing President Vladimir Putin's constitutional reforms, which aim to allow him to serve two more six-year terms after his current mandate expires in 2024. The opposition has been unable to mount a strong campaign, with many critics feeling dispirited and disheartened by the Kremlin's repression. Despite some opposition figures calling for boycotts or "no" votes, the opposition has done little to actively fight the changes, with many experts citing deep divisions and shrewd moves by the Kremlin as the main reason for the lack of opposition.

site_title: Linda Cristal, who starred in 'High Chaparral', dies at 89
summary: Linda Cristal, actress best known for her role as Victoria on the 1960s TV series "The High Chaparral," has died at 89. Cristal, born Marta Victoria Moya in Buenos Aires in 1931, had a nearly a decade-long film career in Mexico before transitioning to Hollywood, where she appeared in films such as "Comanche" and "The Alamo." She won a Golden Globe for her performance on "The High Chaparral" in 1970 and went on to guest star on various TV shows. Cristal's personal life was marked by two marriages and the loss of her parents at a young age.

site_title: Thai May factory output falls 23.2%, worse than forecast
summary: Thai May factory output fell 23.2% from a year earlier, worse than forecast, due to the impact of the coronavirus outbreak. The manufacturing production index dropped 23.19% from May 2019, with lower production of cars, petroleum, and air conditioners contributing to the decline. Capacity utilisation in May was 52.84%, down from April's revised 51.27%.

site_title: Accordia Golf Trust offered S$804.1m by sponsor to divest all its Japan golf courses
summary: Accordia Golf Trust has proposed to acquire its 88 golf courses in Japan for S$804.1 million, representing a 5.1% premium over its adjusted net asset value. The acquisition is conditional on unitholder approval by September 14. The trust will distribute the net proceeds via special distributions, with 92% paid out within 25 business days. The trustee-manager intends to undertake a voluntary winding up of the trust after the asset sale, which will cease to have any operating business.

site_title: Culture of 'trial by Internet' should not be encouraged: PM Lee
summary: Singapore Prime Minister Lee Hsien Loong expressed concerns that the "trial by Internet" culture should not be encouraged, as it may deter potential candidates from running. He defended the PAP's candidate-selection process, stating that no process is perfect and that candidates will inevitably make mistakes. Lee also denied any family disputes, focusing on the issues of the election, such as the Covid-19 crisis and jobs. He dismissed the possibility of a wipe-out in the upcoming election, citing the balance of Singapore politics and the PAP's strong performance in previous elections.

images.alt_text: Expressing continued confidence in the People's Action Party (PAP) candidate-selection process, Prime Minister Lee Hsien Loong said that seeking "perfect" candidates would instead result in the loss of many good candidates, at the introduction of the PAP's team for Ang Mo Kio group representation constituency (GRC) on Monday.

site_title: Facebook ad boycott campaign to go global, organisers say
summary: Organisers of the "Stop Hate for Profit" campaign, a global boycott of Facebook, plan to expand the campaign to Europe, urging major companies to join the boycott and increase pressure on Facebook to remove hate speech. Since its launch, over 160 US companies, including Verizon and Unilever, have signed on to pause ads on Facebook for the month of July. The campaign aims to increase global pressure on Facebook, with organisers seeking to embolden regulators in Europe to take a harder stance on the platform.

site_title: Frontline worker in battle against Covid-19 is PAP replacement for Ivan Lim in Jurong GRC
summary: The People's Action Party (PAP) has announced two new candidates for the Jurong GRC in Singapore's general election. 35-year-old Xie Yao Quan, a frontline worker in Covid-19 operations and grassroots volunteer, replaces Ivan Lim, who dropped out of the race due to online criticisms. Quan's replacement comes as the PAP is expected to field Minister Desmond Lee in West Coast GRC to shore up the team. Senior Minister Tharman Shanmugaratnam will lead the team, which faces a challenge from opposition party Red Dot United.

site_title: DBS rolls out sustainable and transition finance framework, taxonomy
summary: DBS Bank launched a sustainable and transition finance framework and taxonomy to help clients transition to a low-carbon economy. The framework evaluates the transitional qualities of economic activities and guides clients to adapt and build resilience in the face of climate change. DBS is the first Singapore bank to offer transition financing with its framework, which aims to achieve a global temperature rise below 1.5 degrees Celsius. The bank has closed over 100 sustainable finance deals worth S$12 billion and plans to expand its sustainable finance portfolio to S$25 billion by 2025.

site_title: GoBear, Mambu, CredoLab team up to accelerate Asia lending business
summary: GoBear, a financial services startup, is partnering with Mambu and CredoLab to accelerate its lending business across Asia. Mambu's cloud banking solution will form the core of GoBear's lending architecture, expanding to the Philippines this year and additional markets. CredoLab's alternative credit scoring will enable lenders to assess applicants more granularly. The partnership aims to bring access to responsible credit to the region's 296 million unbanked or underbanked population, with GoBear seeking to diversify its business and expand its presence in Asia.

site_title: Broker's take: KGI initiates coverage on Yanlord with 'outperform' on resilient China property market
summary: KGI Securities initiated coverage on Chinese property developer Yanlord Land Group with an "outperform" call and target price of S$1.30, citing a resilient China property market. The analyst believes the group's development and rental businesses will benefit from lower borrowing costs and volatility in financial markets. Yanlord shares rose 0.9% to S$1.17 on the news, despite the Covid-19 outbreak's impact on the global economy.

site_title: In Silicon Valley, developers bet big on the return to offices
summary: California real estate investors Gary Dillabough and Jeff Arrillaga are betting big on San Jose, a city in Silicon Valley, as a hub for Bay Area companies to return to offices post-pandemic. With $300 million invested in properties, they aim to densify the city with new office spaces, including a 3.8 million-square-foot complex, and push for better-designed spaces to ensure worker safety. Despite a shift towards remote work, Dillabough believes companies will want workers to return, and the city is committed to urbanization and densification, envisioning a vibrant and futuristic downtown area.

site_title: Singapore shares decline at open; STI down 0.6%
summary: Singapore stocks opened weaker on Monday, with the Straits Times Index (STI) falling 0.6% to 2,589.44 points. The decline follows a Wall Street rout on Friday, driven by concerns over a resurgence of coronavirus infections in the US. Losers outnumbered gainers 104 to 35, with banking stocks and Biolidics taking a hit. The US market also fell, with the Dow plunging 2.8% and the S&P 500 tumbling 2.4%.

site_title: Half of Tokyo residents oppose Olympics in 2021: poll
summary: A recent poll in Tokyo found that 51.7% of residents oppose holding the postponed 2020 Olympics in 2021, with 27.7% wanting the Games to be cancelled and 24% preferring a second postponement. The poll, conducted ahead of the Tokyo gubernatorial election, also showed incumbent Yuriko Koike leading her opponents. Officials have warned that it's impossible to postpone again, and even a year-long delay has created significant financial and logistical headaches. The rescheduled Olympics are set to begin on July 23, 2021, despite concerns over the coronavirus pandemic.

site_title: Halcyon Agri founding chief executive Robert Meyer retires
summary: Halcyon Agri Corporation, a natural rubber supplier, announced the retirement of founding CEO Robert Meyer and Chief Corporate Officer Pascal Demierre. David Li Xuetao, former CEO of GMG Global, takes over as CEO. The company has consolidated the natural rubber business of Sinochem International Corp, a major shareholder, and is well-positioned to navigate the challenging global environment and capitalize on emerging opportunities. The new management team will focus on the company's recovery and growth amidst the Covid-19 pandemic.

site_title: Bagged salads recalled after hundreds are sickened in the Midwest
summary: The US Centers for Disease Control and Prevention (CDC) has issued a warning about an outbreak of cyclosporiasis, an intestinal illness caused by a microscopic parasite, linked to bagged salad mixes in the Midwest. Over 200 people in eight Midwestern states have reported eating the recalled salads before getting sick, with at least 23 hospitalized. The CDC is investigating the outbreak and has recalled four different salad kits produced by Fresh Express. Cyclosporiasis can be treated with an antibiotic, but most healthy people recover on their own. The cause of the outbreak remains unknown, with officials attributing it to a "significant sanitary breakdown in the production of this food."

site_title: Malaysia: Shares open lower on Monday
summary: Malaysia's FTSE Bursa Malaysia Kuala Lumpur Composite Index dropped 7.39 points, or 0.50%, to 1,480.75 on Monday, with 218 losers beating 101 gainers. The index opened lower, following a weaker start to the week.

site_title: Australia sees biggest daily rise in Covid-19 cases in 2 months
summary: Australia's second most populous state, Victoria, reported its biggest daily rise in new coronavirus infections in over two months, with 75 cases detected in the past 24 hours. The state is considering reimposing social distancing restrictions after several weeks of fewer than 20 new cases a day. Victoria's chief health officer said the state is considering localized lockdowns to turn the outbreak around. The country's economy is also facing challenges, with the unemployment rate hitting a 19-year high of 7.1% and the government considering further stimulus measures.

site_title: Vietnam Q2 GDP growth slows to 0.36%
summary: Vietnam reported a 0.36% GDP growth in Q2, down from 6.73% in the same period last year, according to the General Statistics Office. The country's GDP in the first half of the year grew 1.81% from the previous year. This slowdown in growth is attributed to various global economic factors.

site_title: Dasin Retail Trust placement 1.2 times subscribed; China malls' purchase price unchanged
summary: DASIN Retail Trust's placement of new units was 1.2 times subscribed at S$0.78 per unit, raising S$94 million. The exercise closed on Friday, with Aqua Wealth Holdings subscribing for about 38.5 million units. The new units are expected to commence trading on July 7. The trust remains cautiously optimistic on retail demand and expects greater interest in experiential activities when the lockdown is lifted.

site_title: Australian, New Zealand dollars shackled by virus surge, set for modest monthly gains
summary: The Australian and New Zealand dollars experienced modest monthly gains due to rising risks to the global economy. A surge in coronavirus cases worldwide led to re-imposition of curbs, sapping demand for riskier assets. The Aussie rose to US$0.6881 and the kiwi to US$0.6432, both set for a 3% monthly gain. The Aussie found support around Friday's low of US$0.6841, while resistance lies around 0.6878. The Reserve Bank of Australia will deliver a speech on policy actions on Tuesday.

site_title: Battle heats up for Australia's Infigen as suitors raise bids
summary: A bidding war for Australian wind and solar firm Infigen Energy intensified, with Spain's Iberdrola raising its offer to A$856 million and Philippine conglomerate Ayala increasing its bid to match Iberdrola's initial offer. UAC Energy, a joint venture of Ayala's AC Energy and UPC Renewables Group, also revised its offer to A$0.86 per share, free of conditions. The bids signal a heated competition for Infigen Energy.

images.alt_text: A bidding war for Australian wind and solar firm Infigen Energy heated up on Monday, with Spain's Iberdrola raising its bid to A$856 million (S$818.3 million), shortly after Philippine conglomerate Ayala hiked its offer.

site_title: Asia: Markets track Wall Street drop as new virus cases spike
summary: Asian markets declined on Monday after a surge in coronavirus cases in the US and other countries prompted officials to reimpose containment measures. Bars in California reopened only to be closed again, while Texas and Florida saw large jumps in cases. The US and China are also imposing lockdowns to contain outbreaks. The US stock market dropped on Friday, and Asian markets followed suit, with Tokyo, Sydney, and Seoul falling over 1%. The European market is also concerned, as governments consider opening borders during the summer holiday season.

images.alt_text: Asian equity markets fell on Monday after a surge in coronavirus infections in several countries, including the US, prompted officials to reimpose containment measures that have fanned worries about the economic recovery.

site_title: US virus death toll at 288 in 24-hours, infections remain high: tally
summary: The US reported 288 Covid-19 deaths in 24 hours, bringing the total death toll to 125,768, with over 2.5 million cases. The country struggles to control a surge in cases, with bars in Los Angeles and six other Californian counties ordered to close again.

site_title: ComfortDelGro to roll out 'fastest' DC fast charger for EVs in Singapore from July 1
summary: ComfortDelGro will roll out Singapore's fastest public commercial DC charger, the Delta Ultra Fast Charger, on July 1. With a 100kW power output, it can charge two vehicles simultaneously, shaving around 10 minutes from full charging time. The charger can fully charge an EV in 30 minutes, with the option to charge up to two vehicles at once. This is expected to support Singapore's growing electric vehicle market.

images.alt_text: At 100 kilowatt power output, the "Delta Ultra Fast Charger" will be able to shave close to 10 minutes off the time it takes to fully charge a vehicle.

site_title: Biolidics calls off US sale of Covid-19 test kits, to develop new kit with Aytu BioScience
summary: Biolidics has called off its US sale of COVID-19 test kits, instead partnering with Aytu BioScience to develop a new test kit with broader use outside laboratory or clinical settings. The decision comes amid increased competition and the company's decision to withdraw its application to the US FDA for Emergency Use Authorization. Biolidics will refund Aytu for undelivered orders and its current test kits will no longer be available in the US market, but will continue to be distributed in other countries.

site_title: UAE suspends receiving passengers from Pakistan as of June 29 over Covid-19 fears
summary: The UAE has suspended receiving passengers from Pakistan as of June 29 due to rising Covid-19 cases in the country. The decision also affects transit flights from Pakistan. Emirates had already suspended flights from Pakistan on June 24. The UAE's General Civil Aviation Authority is awaiting the setup of a special Covid-19 lab to test passengers.

site_title: EU, Britain intensify talks on post-Brexit future
summary: The EU and Britain will hold intense five-week negotiations on a post-Brexit deal, starting Monday, with London aiming to wrap up talks quickly. The meetings will alternate weekly between Brussels and London, with British negotiator David Frost set to become Prime Minister Boris Johnson's national security adviser. Despite tempers flaring, hopes are that intensified discussions will lead to results, with London seeking a bare-bones trade deal by summer and the EU aiming for a deal by late October.

site_title: Nam Cheong unable to pay interest on loan amid 'severe' cash flow constraints
summary: Malaysian offshore support vessel builder Nam Cheong has suspended the payment of its 2% cash interest on a term loan due on June 30, citing severe cash flow constraints due to declining vessel charter rates and utilization. The company attributes its financial struggles to the COVID-19 pandemic and oil price volatility. Nam Cheong has not disclosed the loan amount, but creditors owed approximately $319.8 million opted for a 7-year term loan. The company is exploring restructuring options and plans to update creditors by August 2020.

site_title: The risk of investor-state disputes in Asean in the aftermath of Covid-19
summary: ASEAN countries face a potential wave of investor-state disputes in the aftermath of the COVID-19 pandemic, with over 2,500 investment treaties in force worldwide, including in the region. These treaties grant foreign investors broad rights against host states, including protection against nationalization and discrimination. The pandemic's impact on economic activity and the measures taken to combat it may lead to claims against governments in ASEAN, requiring them to justify their actions under international arbitration standards. ASEAN member states need to revise and update their outdated treaties to balance investor protection with public good regulations, and the region should engage in unified discussions at the UN to reform the investment treaty arbitration system.

images.alt_text: Then-Russian Prime Minister Dmitry Medvedev gave a keynote address at the ASEAN Business and Investment Summit 2019 in Thailand. Investment treaty protections apply during crises as much as at any other time. Indeed, crises seem to make certain countries become magnets for claims by foreign investors.

site_title: Hong Kong: Stocks drop at Monday's open
summary: Hong Kong stocks dropped at the open on Monday, despite a slight increase in the Hang Seng Index. Investors remain cautious due to growing signs of a second wave of infections and potential containment measures. The Shanghai Composite Index and Shenzhen Composite Index also declined.

site_title: Australian PM says reopenings of internal borders will support jobs
summary: Australian Prime Minister Scott Morrison announced that the reopening of internal borders will support jobs growth despite a fresh outbreak of COVID-19 in South Australia and Tasmania. State borders are expected to reopen in late July, with Queensland to follow. Morrison also pledged more economic stimulus, but ruled out a blanket extension of a wage subsidy scheme beyond September, instead hinting at targeted support. The Grattan Institute recommended an additional A$90 billion in stimulus programs to bring the unemployment rate down to 5% by 2022.

site_title: UK homebuilder Berkeley announces death of founder Pidgley
summary: UK homebuilder Berkeley Group Holdings Plc announced the death of its founder and chairman Tony Pidgley, who was 72. Pidgley started Berkeley with one house and grew it into a FTSE 100 company. He was known for his shrewd timing of the property cycle and navigating the global financial crisis. Under CEO Rob Perrins, Pidgley's values of ambition and quality will continue to shape the company, according to interim Chairman Glyn Barker.

site_title: China confusion leaves scrap metal stranded overseas
summary: China's delay in releasing customs codes for high-grade copper and aluminium scrap imports has left scrap metal firms abroad in confusion, with many unable to send cargoes to the country. The codes are crucial for the new system, which reclassifies scrap as a resource rather than waste, but China's State Administration for Market Regulation has yet to publish them. The delay is expected to impact the manufacturing sector, which relies on Chinese imports, and may lead to a postponement of the new system until the end of the year.

site_title: Oil falls in second straight session as virus cools demand
summary: Oil prices fell for a second consecutive session, with Brent crude dropping 66 cents to $40.36 a barrel and US crude falling 63 cents to $37.86 a barrel. The decline was driven by rising coronavirus cases in the US and other countries, leading to partial lockdowns that may hurt fuel demand. Despite Opec+ supply cuts, US crude inventories have hit all-time highs, and there is a risk that gains in prices could lead to US shale producers restarting wells.

images.alt_text: Oil prices fell for a second straight session on Monday as coronavirus cases rose in the United States and other places, leading countries to resume partial lockdowns that could hurt fuel demand.

site_title: Coronavirus deaths pass half a million: AFP tally
summary: More than half a million people have been killed by the novel coronavirus, with nearly two-thirds of those deaths occurring in the US and Europe. The official death toll stands at 500,390, with the US having the highest death toll of 125,747. The actual number of infections is likely higher due to limited testing in many countries.

site_title: Japan's May retail sales fall sharply as lockdown measures hit demand
summary: Japan's retail sales plummeted 12.3% in May from a year ago, the second consecutive month of double-digit declines, as the coronavirus pandemic and lockdown measures dampened consumer confidence. The drop is worse than forecast and raises concerns the economy could remain in recession longer than expected. The decline in spending on big-ticket items such as cars and clothing is a significant contributor. Policymakers hope a rebound in private spending will support growth, but analysts fear uncertainty over global demand and a nationwide tax hike could lead to more saving and spending less.

site_title: Taiwan opposition occupies Parliament to protest government 'tyranny'
summary: Taiwan's main opposition party, the Kuomintang (KMT), occupied the legislature overnight to protest the government's "tyranny" and President Tsai Ing-wen's nomination of a close aide to a high-level watchdog. The KMT, which lost parliamentary and presidential elections in January, blocked entry to the main chamber with chains and chairs. The ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) condemned the action, calling it a "farce." The KMT is undergoing a policy revamp to win back popular support, following setbacks including a recall vote loss in a major southern city.

site_title: Tokyo: Stocks open lower on Monday
summary: Tokyo stocks opened lower on Monday due to investors seeking to lock in profits amid concerns over a resurgence of coronavirus infections. The benchmark Nikkei 225 index fell 1.08%, and the broader Topix index declined 1.03%.

images.alt_text: Tokyo stocks opened lower on Monday as investors sought to lock in profits, disheartened by a rout on US markets as fears grow over a resurgence of coronavirus infections.

site_title: Australian regional airline Rex approves plans for big-city operations
summary: Regional Express Holdings (Rex) has approved plans to launch jet services in big cities, competing with Qantas and Virgin Australia, with a target of 5-10 jets based in Sydney and Melbourne. The airline aims to raise A$30 million through funding and regulatory approval to launch flights between Sydney, Brisbane, and Melbourne from March 1, 2021. The new services will offer affordable prices with added amenities such as baggage allowance, meals, and pre-assigned seating, and will be a hybrid model that Rex has successfully used for its regional operations.

site_title: Amazon workers in Germany to go on strike over coronavirus infections
summary: Amazon workers in Germany are set to go on strike over safety concerns following coronavirus infections at logistics centers. The strike, which will last at least 48 hours, is in response to what the labor union Verdi calls a lack of transparency from Amazon. The union claims at least 30-40 colleagues were infected, while Amazon denies the accusations. This is the latest in a long-running battle between Amazon and unions in Germany over better pay and conditions.

site_title: Great Eastern partners Doctor Anywhere on new insurance plan for gig economy workers in Singapore
summary: Great Eastern has partnered with telemedicine startup Doctor Anywhere to launch an insurance plan for gig economy workers in Singapore. The annual renewable plan, GREAT Comprehensive Care, offers hospitalisation income, personal accident coverage, and outpatient care in a single policy. The plan has two types and starts from 73 cents a day, providing up to 12 video consultations. No underwriting is required, and application can be made on the GE website. The plan aims to provide affordable and accessible protection for self-employed and gig economy workers.

site_title: EHT launches forensic accounting probe into sponsor; issues default notices to lessees
summary: EHT launches a forensic accounting probe into its sponsor, Urban Commons, amid concerns over financial statement fluctuations and rent payments. The probe, led by FTI Consulting, will review the financial statements of master lessees, which are wholly-owned by Urban Commons, and compare their funds to rent payments and other obligations. As a result, master lessors have issued default notices to the lessees for delinquencies in security deposits and unpaid rents, with some defaults also arising from hotel management agreement breaches.

site_title: SGX buys rest of BidFX for US$128m in cash
summary: SGX has agreed to purchase the remaining 80% stake in BidFX for approximately US$128 million in cash, expanding its reach into the global foreign exchange over-the-counter (OTC) market. BidFX, a cloud-based FX trading platform, was previously spun off from TradingScreen in 2017. The acquisition is expected to bring together SGX's FX futures with OTC markets, offering a unified venue for price discovery, liquidity, and transparency. The transaction is set to be completed in July, with potential for additional US$25 million payment to sellers if revenue targets are met.

site_title: MindChamps partners developer for 10 new childcare centres in Australia
summary: MindChamps PreSchool has partnered property developer Malek Family to develop 10 new childcare centres in Australia, expanding its footprint in the country. The partnership will allow MindChamps to focus on quality education and research, while the developers will handle location selection and licensing. This marks a significant expansion for MindChamps, which currently operates 23 out of 80 centres globally and generated half of its revenue in Australia in fiscal 2019.

site_title: Stocks to watch: SIA, ComfortDelGro, CapitaLand, Ascendas Reit, Halcyon Agri
summary:
Here is a 100-word or less summary of the article content:

Several Singapore-listed companies have announced significant developments that may impact their trading. Singapore Airlines (SIA) recorded a one-off charge due to the liquidation of NokScoot. The Singapore Exchange (SGX) will acquire BidFX for US$128 million. ComfortDelGro expects a net loss for the first half of 2020 due to the COVID-19 impact. CapitaLand's economic slowdown in core markets is expected to affect performance. Meanwhile, Ascendas Reit reported rent waivers, and Halcyon Agri Corp's CEO and CFO retired. Trading halts have been called for several companies, including Accordia Golf Trust, Blackgold Natural Resources, and Vallianz Holdings.

site_title: New Zealand job numbers picked up in May
summary: New Zealand's job numbers rose 0.8% in May, a slight improvement from the 1.6% decline in April, following the country's strict lockdown. The increase in filled jobs is attributed to social and economic restrictions easing in May and the government's wage subsidy schemes. Statistics New Zealand attributed the turnaround to businesses "hibernating" during the lockdown, with filled jobs including jobs paid by employers subsidized by the Covid-19 wage subsidy scheme.

site_title: Shale pioneer Chesapeake Energy files for bankruptcy
summary: Chesapeake Energy Corp, a US shale pioneer, filed for Chapter 11 bankruptcy protection on June 28, 2020, due to excessive debt and the impact of the Covid-19 pandemic on energy demand and prices. This marks the biggest US oil and gas producer to collapse this year. The bankruptcy filing comes as the energy industry struggles with declining prices and reduced demand.

site_title: Lee Hsien Yang dismisses remarks about using politics for 'personal problems'
summary: Singapore's estranged Prime Minister Lee Hsien Loong brother Lee Hsien Yang said his entrance into opposition politics was not driven by "personal problems". Yang stated he has previously spoken about personal issues without using politics, and the party's position is clear, making it unnecessary to use the party as a mouthpiece.

site_title: Filipino lawyer says he's been framed over Wirecard's missing billions
summary: A Filipino lawyer, Mark Tolentino, claims to be the victim of a "frame-up" in the Wirecard scandal, where $2.1 billion in cash was allegedly missing. Tolentino, 39, opened six euro bank accounts on behalf of a Singapore-based firm, but denied knowing the accounts were for Wirecard. He was questioned by the Philippine Justice Secretary and has not been charged with any crime. Tolentino's lawyer said he was the target of identity theft and fake news, and the Philippine government is investigating the matter.

site_title: Private leaders in the public space: More business voices needed in politics
summary: Singapore's General Election 2020 saw a notable presence of private-sector leaders among first-time candidates, which is encouraging given the country's economic challenges. However, business observers noted that there is still room for better representation in some segments, such as SMEs, among political aspirants. The presence of business leaders in politics can help tackle economic challenges posed by Covid-19, but more needs to be done to ensure diverse representation.

site_title: Los Angeles bars ordered to close again as virus spreads
summary: Los Angeles bars have been ordered to close again due to a surge in coronavirus cases, with California Governor Gavin Newsom announcing the move on Twitter. The closures, affecting seven counties, follow a nationwide trend of reimposing shutdown measures to combat the spread of the virus. The US has seen record highs in new cases, with 13.5 million people impacted in the affected counties. Health officials and state leaders have urged tougher rules and enforcement to control the spread, amid President Trump's push for a reopen economy.

site_title: Starbucks pauses social media ads as it targets 'hate speech'
summary: Starbucks has paused its social media ads to study ways to stop the spread of hate speech, joining other corporations like Unilever and Coca-Cola in the effort. The move comes amid criticism of social media platforms, particularly Facebook, for failing to eliminate racist or hate-filled posts. Starbucks, which employs racial minorities, has faced criticism over its handling of racial issues and previously closed stores for racial-diversity training after a high-profile incident in 2018. The company will continue using social media to communicate with clients and employees.

site_title: Chinese companies take record 50% of global equity raising in first half of 2020
summary: Chinese companies raised a record $32.1 billion in equity capital globally from January to June 2020, accounting for 49.8% of worldwide offerings. This marks a significant economic revival for China, which was the first to impose lockdown measures in late January. The trend is expected to continue, driven by the popularity of Shanghai's STAR Market and well-received IPOs in Hong Kong. Escalating Sino-US tensions may prompt more US-listed Chinese firms to conduct secondary listings in Hong Kong or other markets.

images.alt_text: Firms in China brought in half of equity capital raised globally this year so far, setting a record that highlights the economy's earlier revival from the Covid-19 pandemic, plus the degree to which soured US relations are turning Chinese firms homeward.

site_title: PAP candidate Tan See Leng built his whole career in the private sector
summary: Tan See Leng, a 55-year-old former managing director and CEO of IHH Healthcare, is a People's Action Party (PAP) candidate running for Marine Parade GRC. Unlike many PAP candidates, he has no military, public service, or legal background, but rather built his career in the private sector. With over 30 years of experience in the healthcare sector, Tan believes his private sector expertise will be valuable in contributing to Singapore's future. He has been tipped to take over from Emeritus Senior Minister Goh Chok Tong and has expressed support for adapting to the pandemic and making government assistance schemes accessible to those who need them.

site_title: At least 12 Filipinos missing in boat collision: media
summary: At least 12 Filipinos are missing after a collision between their fishing boat and a foreign cargo vessel off the northwest coast of the Philippines province of Occidental Mindoro on Sunday. The incident occurred 24km from Paluan town, and a strong current interrupted the search on Sunday evening. The Philippine Coast Guard resumed the search on Monday, but no one was found. This incident follows a previous collision between a Chinese fishing trawler and a Filipino boat in the South China Sea on June 9, which left President Rodrigo Duterte facing accusations of defending Beijing.

site_title: Greens gain, Macron slips in low-turnout French polls
summary: France's local elections saw the Greens gain major ground, with projections suggesting they will take key cities of Lyon, Bordeaux, and Strasbourg, and a close contest for Lille. President Emmanuel Macron's ruling party failed to make any significant impact, with abstention rates estimated at around 60%. The low turnout has raised concerns for Macron, who is rumored to be preparing for a cabinet reshuffle. Marine Le Pen's National Rally claimed victory in the southern city of Perpignan, while the Greens' biggest coup would be ousting former minister Martine Aubry as mayor of Lille.

site_title: UK's top civil servant to stand down
summary: Britain's top civil servant, Sir Mark Sedwill, announced his departure in September, citing a shift in his role to focus on Brexit negotiations. His position will be taken over by David Frost, the senior Brexit negotiator. The move could lead to reforms in the civil service, with Prime Minister Boris Johnson's adviser Dominic Cummings overseeing any changes. Sedwill's role, which also included national security adviser, will be split, allowing Frost to focus on Brexit talks. Johnson expressed confidence in Frost's ability to project influence for the UK.

site_title: China industrial firms post first monthly rise in 6 months in May
summary: China's industrial firms posted a 6% year-on-year profit rise in May, the first monthly increase in six months, indicating a strengthening economic recovery. The rebound follows a 4.3% decline in April, with key industries such as oil refinery, power, chemicals, and steel experiencing significant profit recoveries. However, demand remains sluggish amid concerns of a second wave of infections and a global recession.

site_title: Commerzbank weighs 7,000 job cuts, 400 branch closures
summary: Commerzbank is considering eliminating over 7,000 jobs and closing around 400 branches as part of a restructuring plan aimed at addressing shareholder concerns. The bank's CEO, Martin Zielke, and CFO, Bettina Orlopp, will present the cost-cutting targets to the supervisory board on Wednesday. However, the final goals have not been decided, and some executives are skeptical about the feasibility of such large-scale reductions. The plan may also shift focus from branches to digital channels, partly in response to the coronavirus crisis.

site_title: Corporate digest
summary: Ascendas Reit estimates rent waivers for tenants in Singapore due to Covid-19 to be less than S$20 million. The trust will pass through government property tax rebates and cash grants to eligible tenants. Meanwhile, SIA Engineering Company is evaluating the sustainability of its Thai-based joint-venture company due to the pandemic's impact on air traffic movement. The company will assess the viability of dissolution if its Thai airline partner NokScoot is dissolved.

site_title: WP proposes SME bank, redundancy insurance in election manifesto; unveils final four candidates
summary: The Workers' Party (WP) unveiled its election manifesto in Singapore, proposing a dedicated bank for small and medium-sized enterprises (SMEs) to finance their overseas expansion, minimum wage and redundancy insurance. The party also proposed a minimum take-home wage of $1,300, a shared parental leave scheme, and lowered the CPF Payout Eligibility Age to 60. Additionally, the WP proposed a universal buy-back scheme to tackle lease decay in public housing. The party's final four candidates were announced, including lawyer He Ting Ru and former non-constituency MPs Gerald Giam and Leon Perera.

site_title: Dow Jones' corrective recovery looks set for a greater fall
summary: The Dow Jones Industrial Average is expected to experience a greater fall after a corrective recovery, according to wave theory analysis. The index is forming a potential double-three complex pattern, which consists of a flat, any three-wave structure, and a zig-zag pattern. This pattern suggests a lack of confidence in the market and a potential sell-down, with prices potentially breaking below 25,000 and revisiting March 2020 lows.

site_title: Trump tweets - then deletes - video of fan yelling 'white power'
summary: US President Donald Trump shared a video of a man chanting "white power" in a Florida retirement community, where Trump supporters were being heckled, before deleting it amid an outcry. The phrase is considered synonymous with white supremacism and has been espoused by neo-Nazis and Ku Klux Klan members. Trump's tweet was widely criticized, with the Democratic National Committee and presumptive presidential nominee Joe Biden condemning the president's actions as a "battle for the soul of the nation." The White House later issued a statement saying Trump had not heard the chant before sharing the footage.

site_title: UK mall owner Intu collapses into administration as talks fail
summary: UK mall owner Intu Properties has collapsed into administration after failing to agree on a reprieve from lenders. The company, which owns nine top UK malls, applied to appoint administrators from KMPG, with shopping centers set to continue trading. The collapse threatens 2,500 jobs and potentially leads to the sale of its most-visited malls. Intu had warned of insolvency and was considering protecting stakeholders, with shares suspended at 70% loss. The company's debt pile of £4.5 billion (£7.74 billion) has been exacerbated by plunging store rents and the pandemic.

site_title: Money FM podcast: Working to regain trust from Singapore retail investors
summary: Singapore retail investors have lost trust in financial services, according to Chan Fook Leong, executive director of advocacy at CFA Society Singapore. Host Elliot Danker discussed this issue on the Money FM podcast. Leong emphasized the importance of trust between investors and financial professionals. Investment professionals must regain this trust by being transparent, reliable, and knowledgeable. The goal is to rebuild a strong relationship between investors and financial services in Singapore.

site_title: Under pressure Johnson launches UK public spending drive
summary: UK Prime Minister Boris Johnson is set to announce a £1 billion school-rebuilding plan, part of a major infrastructure spending programme aimed at boosting the economy. The plan, dubbed "Project Speed," will finance the first 50 projects of a 10-year school rebuilding strategy. Johnson has pledged to build new roads, schools, and hospitals to kick-start Britain's recovery from the coronavirus crisis, and has ruled out returning to austerity policies. The move comes amid growing pressure on the government over its handling of the crisis, with unemployment at almost three million and the economy contracted by 20% in April.

site_title: Huawei controversy opens field for 5G challengers worldwide
summary: Washington's push to exclude Huawei from 5G network development has prompted Japan's NEC and South Korea's Samsung to potentially fill the gap. Huawei denies spying charges, but US pressure has led Britain to reconsider its involvement in 5G infrastructure. However, excluding Huawei is challenging due to limited alternatives, with only Nokia and Ericsson currently available in Europe. Britain is exploring options with NEC and Samsung, while Washington supports the use of non-proprietary technology like Open RAN to open up opportunities for US firms. This could lead to a shift in the global 5G landscape.

site_title: Amateur traders pile into Asian stocks, making the pros nervous
summary: Amateur traders are flooding into Asian stocks, driving up market valuations and making professionals nervous. Millions of new investors, many of whom had never traded before, are buying into the market, fueled by a fear of missing out. In countries such as Japan, Singapore, and the Philippines, retail investors have opened thousands of new online brokerage accounts, with some even taking out debt to buy more shares. Experts warn that when these investors withdraw, the market could become volatile, but many amateur investors are taking a long-term view and planning to hold their shares.

site_title: Canadian detainee's wife 'disappointed' Trudeau rules out swap with China
summary: Canadian Prime Minister Justin Trudeau has ruled out a prisoner swap with China for a detained Huawei executive, citing concerns that it would put other Canadians at risk. Meng Wanzhou, Huawei's chief financial officer, is facing extradition to the US. Trudeau rejected appeals to intervene in the extradition proceedings, stating that such a move would undermine Ottawa's ability to protect Canadians abroad. The decision has left the wife of detained Canadian Michael Kovrig "disappointed."

site_title: Recovery in global economic activity could be positive for Singapore stocks
summary: Global economic activity is showing signs of recovery, potentially benefiting Singapore stocks. The US saw a 2.5 million increase in non-farm payroll employment and a decline in unemployment to 13.3% in May, with some economists attributing the turnaround to efforts to lift Covid-19 restrictions. Singapore's aggressive support measures, equivalent to 19.2% of GDP, have helped the country weather the crisis. With the market shifting from worrying about the economic slump to sizing up the potential recovery, investors may consider accumulating high-quality, cyclically-oriented stocks, particularly in Singapore.

site_title: Allianz, Korean pension service set up Asia-Pac property fund
summary: Allianz, a German insurer and asset manager, has teamed up with South Korea's National Pension Service of Korea to set up a property fund with US$2.3 billion equity in the Asia-Pacific region. The fund, Allianz Real Estate Asia-Pacific Core I (AREAP Core I), will focus on Singapore, Japan, Australia, Hong Kong, and China, investing in office, logistics, multifamily residential, and student housing sectors. With leverage, the fund will have a US$4.6 billion war chest, and its strategy is to align with secular macro trends and diversify its portfolio to build a resilient investment portfolio.

site_title: Joining forces to address domestic violence crisis
summary: The Body Shop and Expedia have partnered to raise awareness about the domestic violence crisis and call on governments to provide additional support for survivors. The partnership aims to mobilize over 20,000 employees and 30 million customers to support the cause. In Singapore, The Body Shop is working with the Ministry of Social and Family Development to train frontline staff to detect signs of family violence and refer victims to help channels. Expedia has also supported Aware's Vulnerable Women's Fund and plans to hold another fundraiser in August-September.

images.alt_text: The Body Shop is working closely with the Ministry of Social and Family Development to train frontline staff to detect signs and symptoms of family violence and refer victims to help channels.
Expedia Group employees at the Annual AWARE Gala Fundraiser 2019. The company has continued to support this annual event since 2017.

site_title: Keep focus on key issues in PAP manifesto: DPM Heng
summary: Deputy Prime Minister Heng Swee Keat emphasized that the People's Action Party (PAP) should focus on key issues in its manifesto, despite the withdrawal of candidate Ivan Lim due to online criticism. Lim, a general manager at Keppel Offshore and Marine, faced allegations of misconduct during National Service. PAP Secretary-General Lee Hsien Loong has already made his stance clear, and the party stands by its "robust and rigorous" selection process. The party will review allegations after the General Election, but for now, the focus remains on the issues at hand.

site_title: 13 tourism draws, including casinos, can reopen from Wednesday
summary: The Singapore Tourism Board (STB) announced that 13 tourism draws, including casinos, will reopen from July 1, starting with a gradual resumption of operations in Phase Two. Attractions will be restricted to 25% capacity and access to casinos will be limited to existing members and levy holders. Domestic tour operators must submit reopening proposals with safe management measures to reduce Covid-19 transmission risks. STB aims to ensure a safe and enjoyable experience for guests and visitors, with the goal of attracting local customers during the recovery period.

site_title: Milton Glaser, designer of iconic New York logo and Dylan poster, dies at 91
summary: Milton Glaser, renowned graphic designer behind iconic logos and posters, including the "I (HEART) NY" logo and Bob Dylan's 1967 poster, has died at 91. He passed away on his birthday, June 28, 2020, due to a stroke and renal failure, with his wife Shirley as his only immediate survivor. Glaser's work revolutionized American visual culture in the 1960s and 1970s with his vibrant and extroverted designs.

images.alt_text: Mr Glaser brought wit, whimsy, narrative and skilled drawing to commercial art.

site_title: Buybacks and filings slow as the quarter-end approaches
summary: Singapore stocks declined 2.8% over the last five trading sessions, with the Straits Times Index down 17.8% for the 2020 year to June 25. Share buybacks totaled S$3.2 million, led by Singapore Exchange, Hong Fok Corporation, and Global Investments. More than 80 director and substantial shareholder transactions were filed, with 12 acquisitions and 12 disposals. Key transactions include Wellpoint Pacific Holdings' acquisition of Bumitama Agri shares, Hyphens Pharma International executive director Tan Chwee Choon disposing of 1.336 million shares, and Fragrance Ltd acquiring 1.852 million shares of LHN Group.

site_title: Football: Man City will give Liverpool guard of honour, says Guardiola
summary: Manchester City manager Pep Guardiola announced that the team will give Liverpool a guard of honour when they meet at the Etihad Stadium on Thursday. This comes after Liverpool's 2-1 win over City last week, securing the Premier League title with a 23-point lead. Guardiola praised Liverpool's title-winning side, saying they "deserve" the tribute, and expressed his team's determination to come back stronger next season, already looking forward to solving the issues that led to their disappointing campaign.

site_title: 213 new Covid-19 cases in Singapore, including 11 in the community
summary: Singapore reported 213 new COVID-19 cases, bringing the total to 43,459. The majority of new cases (196) are migrant workers living in dormitories, with 11 community cases confirmed, including five work pass holders and six Singaporeans or permanent residents. The average number of new community cases has increased, prompting the Ministry of Health to remind residents to limit social gatherings and exercise caution to control the spread of the virus.

site_title: Fleeing Chinese buyers leave Hong Kong's office market lifeless
summary: Hong Kong's office market is experiencing a downturn, with only three deals in the Lippo Centre this year, a 17% drop in average price from last year. The market's decline is attributed to the city's economic funk, anti-government protests, and concerns over China's national security laws, which may lead to a loss of its status as a regional financial hub. This has resulted in a 12-year high of 5% vacancy rates in premium buildings and a potential 20% slump in office valuations.

site_title: SIAEC evaluates sustainability of Thai line maintenance JV with Nokscoot Airlines
summary: SIA Engineering Company (SIAEC) is evaluating the sustainability of its Thai-based line maintenance joint-venture company, Line Maintenance Partnership (Thailand) Company Limited (LMPT), due to the impact of the Covid-19 pandemic and depressed air traffic in Thailand. SIAEC has a 49.51% stake in LMPT, which has scaled down its investments with a minimal manning level at Don Muang International Airport. The company is also considering the potential dissolution of NokScoot, a joint venture partner, which could impact LMPT's viability.

site_title: Real estate agents return to work as New York City reopens
summary: New York City has reopened, allowing thousands of real estate agents to return to work. Agents have adopted pandemic protocols, including scheduled showings, hand sanitizers, and virtual tours, which are expected to continue. Brokerages have issued guidelines to ensure employee and client safety, including coronavirus liability forms and health screenings. Agents are eager to resume showing properties, with many having a backlog of listings. Virtual tours have become the norm, with some agencies touting them as the future of real estate.

site_title: Boris Johnson to unveil new infrastructure plan
summary: UK Prime Minister Boris Johnson will unveil a new infrastructure plan on Tuesday to boost construction and stimulate economic growth, aiming to "get Britain moving again" after the coronavirus lockdown. The plan includes measures to fast-track building projects such as hospitals, schools, and road and rail infrastructure. Johnson's government has faced criticism for its response to the crisis, but hopes the plan will revive his fortunes. The plan is seen as a way to "level up" Britain by focusing spending on traditional Labour-supporting areas, and Johnson has ruled out returning to austerity policies.

site_title: A-Reit's rent waivers to tenants in Singapore YTD amounts to less than S$20m
summary: A-Reit's rent waivers for tenants in Singapore this year amount to less than S$20 million. This includes rent waivers in addition to the government's property tax rebates and cash grants, which the trust will fully pass through to eligible tenants. SME tenants make up less than 20% of A-Reit's Singapore portfolio by gross rental income, with 88% being industrial SMEs and 12% being F&B and retail SMEs.

site_title: More US virus cases could cause second bear market wave
summary: US stocks plummeted in a volatile week amid rising Covid-19 cases in key states, jeopardizing the economic recovery. The Dow Jones Industrial Average fell 730 points, and the Russell 2000 index lost over 10% of its value since early June. Consumer spending rose 8.2% in May, but concerns about a second wave of virus spread and economic activity led to fears of a "V-shaped" recovery. The Federal Reserve is seen as a key stabilizer, but investors remain cautious, with analysts warning that the pandemic's second-order effects could affect trade relations and consumer spending.

site_title: US$ inches up; focus on surge in virus cases
summary: The US dollar edged higher in trading due to concerns over a resurgence in US Covid-19 cases, fueling doubts on a V-shaped recovery for the US economy. The CDC reported 2,414,870 US cases and 124,325 deaths, with Florida and Texas leading the surge. The dollar strengthened against the euro, while commodity-tied currencies fell. Despite a jump in consumer spending, personal income fell, validating concerns about a choppy road to recovery.

site_title: WP proposes SME bank, redundancy insurance in its manifesto
summary: The Workers' Party (WP) in Singapore has unveiled its election manifesto, focusing on key areas such as supporting small and medium-sized enterprises (SMEs), addressing the plight of professionals and seniors, and easing financial pressure on workers. The party proposes an export-import bank to finance SME growth, a redundancy insurance scheme, and a minimum take-home wage of $1,300 per month. Other proposals include reducing class sizes, lowering the voting age to 18, and introducing a shared parental leave scheme. The manifesto also addresses issues such as cost of living, commercial rents, and property concerns.

site_title: Americans hold huge pile of cash that is key to economic recovery
summary: The US Federal Reserve has pumped record amounts of cash into the financial system this year, with most funds being deposited directly into Americans' chequeing accounts. This is a significant distinction from 2008, when excess reserves accumulated in banks' accounts. The direct infusion of cash into people's pockets has the potential to boost the economy, as government stimulus matched the Fed's support. As the country slowly reopens for business, the question remains whether Americans will spend the money, which could impact economic recovery.

images.alt_text: Just like back in 2008, the Federal Reserve has pumped record amounts of cash into the financial system this year to stave off an economic collapse. But unlike in 2008, when that money mostly piled up in banks' accounts at the Fed, funds are pouring into Americans' chequeing accounts. And that's a big distinction.

site_title: Singapore and Malaysia to create rules for cross-border travel
summary: Singapore and Malaysia have agreed to establish reciprocal arrangements for essential business travel and periodic commuting, dubbed the Reciprocal Green Lane. This move will facilitate cross-border travel for business and official purposes, and allow Singapore and Malaysia residents with long-term immigration passes to periodically return to their home countries. The agreement is seen as a model for other nations and follows a call between the two countries' prime ministers.

site_title: India passes 500,000 coronavirus cases
summary: India has surpassed 500,000 confirmed coronavirus cases, with a record daily leap of 18,500 new infections. Authorities reported 15,685 deaths, bringing the total toll to 385 fatalities in 24 hours. Experts predict the pandemic will not peak in India until several more weeks, with cases potentially reaching one million by the end of July.

site_title: WP unveils fourth and final slate of candidates, with one new face
summary: The Workers' Party (WP) has unveiled its fourth and final slate of candidates for the upcoming General Election, including 54-year-old Abdul Shariff Aboo Kassim, a new face, alongside familiar names Gerald Giam, Leon Perera, and He Ting Ru. WP chairman Sylvia Lim and secretary-general Pritam Singh launched the party's "Make Your Vote Count" slogan and manifesto during a virtual press conference. The candidates' priorities include helping the vulnerable and fostering healthy debate.

site_title: Baltic Exchange Shipping Insights
summary: The Baltic Exchange Shipping Insights report for June 26-30, 2020, reveals that the capesize market has reached new highs for the year, with the 5TC market trading at $29,641. The Brazil to China C3 is trading above $20, while the west Australia to China C5 is priced at $9.723. In the panamax segment, rates continued to rise in the north Atlantic, with $13,000 agreed for an 82,000dwt delivery. The ultramax/supramax market remained positive, with rates averaging in the upper $9,000's.

site_title: Mattress unicorn Casper accused of misleading investors with IPO
summary: Casper, an online mattress retailer, has been accused of misleading investors with its initial public offering (IPO) by failing to disclose its narrowing profit margins and selling "a glut of old and outdated mattress inventory" at clearance prices. The lawsuit seeks class action status and unspecified damages. Casper's IPO raised $100 million, but the company's share price has since fallen to $8.50, valuing the company at $337.2 million, significantly lower than its private funding valuation of $1.1 billion.

site_title: Nintendo theme park in Japan won't open this summer
summary: Universal Studios Japan has decided to postpone the opening of its Nintendo-themed area, originally scheduled for this summer, due to the ongoing Covid-19 pandemic. Construction is nearly complete, and Comcast is still aiming for an opening this year, possibly with a new schedule announcement this week. The area was expected to boost visitors and raise awareness of Nintendo's game characters, and boost console and game software sales. The Tokyo Olympics, now rescheduled for 2021, was initially the target opening date.

images.alt_text: Universal Studios Japan decided to postpone an opening of the Nintendo-themed area that was originally scheduled for this summer due to the ongoing Covid-19 pandemic, people familiar with the matter said.

site_title: US dollar at crossroads as currency strategists turn bearish
summary: The US dollar is at a crucial crossroads, with currency strategists turning bearish due to the Fed's monetary policy and international debt servicing. The dollar index is 33% higher than its 2011 low, but factors such as a potential trade war, US economic depression, and high unemployment could cause a sharp decline. Analysts predict the dollar could fall to around 92 by the end of this year, 72 by end-2021, and 55 by end-2022, driven by a shift away from the dollar in international transactions and a growing Chinese economy.

site_title: How to build a stronger business magnet
summary: Singapore's ability to continue attracting strong investments in the years ahead will depend on its ability to harness its unique value on the global stage, particularly in the digital-commerce era. Experts agree that a change of attitude, better soft skills, and a focus on innovation and entrepreneurship are crucial. Singapore's stable pro-business climate, infrastructure, talent pool, and global connectivity make it an attractive destination for foreign direct investments (FDIs) and multinational corporations (MNCs). To sustain its position, Singapore must demonstrate good governance, a strong financial system, and the ability to handle investments quickly and pragmatically.

site_title: Singapore to develop and distribute vaccines fairly and quickly to all countries: PM Lee
summary: Singapore's Prime Minister Lee Hsien Loong announced the country's commitment to developing and distributing COVID-19 vaccines fairly and quickly worldwide. He emphasized the need for a coordinated global response in scientific research and government actions. Singapore plans to work with the European Commission, the World Health Organisation, and other organizations to develop and distribute vaccines. The goal is to support global initiatives such as the Access to Covid-19 Tools Accelerator and the Covid-19 Vaccine Global Access Facility. This move aims to tackle the pandemic and return to pre-COVID-19 life.

site_title: CapitaLand will be 'stronger than before'
summary: CapitaLand's CEO Lee Chee Koon says the company will emerge stronger than before from the pandemic, citing a strong balance sheet, good leaders, and effective strategies. Despite an economic slowdown in core markets, CapitaLand is incorporating digital solutions into its services and exploring investment opportunities to boost resilience. The company has committed over S$300 million in rental support and has stepped up the use of digital solutions to increase efficiency and analytics capabilities. With a diversified portfolio and a strong balance sheet, CapitaLand aims to become one of the top real estate and asset management companies in the world.

site_title: China plans to grant investment banking licences to lenders: Caixin
summary: China's securities regulator plans to grant investment banking licenses to commercial lenders, aiming to create industry behemoths amidst foreign competition. The China Securities Regulatory Commission (CSRC) may approve at least two of China's largest banks, including the Industrial and Commercial Bank of China, to conduct investment banking business on the mainland. This move follows a 2018 proposal by the Industrial and Commercial Bank of China to set up a securities unit with 100 billion yuan registered capital. The pilot scheme is part of efforts to boost domestic financial institutions and counter foreign competition.

site_title: A surreal feeling for Liverpool's supporters
summary: Liverpool clinched the English Premier League title with seven games to spare, ending 30 years of waiting for fans. The team secured the trophy after Manchester City lost to Chelsea, allowing Liverpool to maintain their lead. Liverpool defeated Crystal Palace 4-0 at an empty Anfield stadium just 24 hours prior to the title confirmation. The news brought a surreal feeling to the team's supporters, who had been eagerly awaiting the moment for months, including one fan who had secured a unique opportunity to walk Liverpool captain Jordan Henderson onto the pitch before the season was halted by the Covid-19 pandemic.

site_title: STB announces gradual reopening of tourism establishments from July
summary: The Singapore Tourism Board (STB) has announced the gradual reopening of tourism establishments from July 1, starting with 13 attractions. This follows the resumption of activities in Phase 2 after the circuit breaker. The Ministry of Trade and Industry (MTI) and STB have assessed the reopening proposals and will allow the selected attractions to reopen from July 1. Domestic tour operators can also begin submitting their applications to resume operations from June 28.

site_title: Global coronavirus cases exceed 10m
summary: Global coronavirus cases have exceeded 10 million, with over 497,000 fatalities reported, according to a Reuters tally. The milestone comes as many countries are easing lockdowns and making changes to work and social life, potentially leading to a recurring pattern of infections in the coming months. The pandemic has entered a new phase, with India and Brazil battling outbreaks, and the total number of cases continues to increase at a rate of 1-2% per day.

site_title: Lee Hsien Yang dismisses remarks about using politics for 'personal problems'
summary: Singapore's Progress Singapore Party (PSP) member Lee Hsien Yang, brother of Prime Minister Lee Hsien Loong, dismissed remarks about using politics to address personal issues. Yang, 62, stated that he has spoken about his personal problems without politics and doesn't need the party to be his mouthpiece. He also criticized the upcoming polls, citing unfair rules and restrictions on online rallies and speeches. Despite these challenges, the PSP plans to contest in nine constituencies with 24 candidates, aiming to strip away the ruling party's legislative supermajority.

site_title: Boeing 737 MAX certification flight tests to begin on Monday: sources
summary: Boeing is set to begin certification flight tests for the 737 MAX on Monday, following a preflight briefing. The three-day test campaign will involve scripted mid-air scenarios and intentionally triggering the reprogrammed stall-prevention software, known as MCAS, to ensure its robustness. The tests aim to verify the new protections added to the MCAS system, which were faulted in two crashes that killed 346 people in 2019. The FAA and Boeing declined to comment on the matter.

site_title: Philippines drops multinational rice purchase as Vietnam resumes exports
summary: The Philippines has dropped its plan to import up to 300,000 tonnes of rice from various countries due to Vietnam's resumption of rice exports. The country had planned to import under a government-to-government scheme to ensure sufficient supply during its lean harvest season. Vietnam, the Philippines' main rice supplier, had suspended exports in May to assess its local supply during the Covid-19 pandemic. The Philippines' Agriculture Secretary William Dar stated that the rice import plan was dropped as the current situation has been addressed with lifted export bans and increased rice imports.

site_title: Workers' Party introduces third batch of 5 candidates for GE2020
summary: The Workers' Party of Singapore has introduced its third batch of 5 candidates for the upcoming General Election 2020, including three first-time candidates. The candidates, including IT professional Nathaniel Koh and trained quantity surveyor Tan Chen Chen, have been volunteering for the party in the past. They will focus on issues such as pro-family policies, property prices, and support for mid-career transitions if elected.

site_title: Huawei controversy opens field for 5G challengers
summary: The US pressure to keep China's Huawei out of 5G network development has led to an opportunity for other companies like Japan's NEC and South Korea's Samsung to shine. The US claims Huawei's equipment can be used to spy for Beijing, but Huawei denies the charges. As a result, Britain has changed its stance, prompting firms to take on the challenge of developing 5G networks. This shift could benefit companies like NEC and Samsung, which are now in a position to capitalize on the growing demand for 5G technology.

images.alt_text: With growing pressure to keep China's Huawei out of 5G network development, it could be time for firms like Japan's NEC and South Korea's Samsung to shine.

site_title: GM seeks US appeals court ruling to continue legal fight with Fiat Chrysler
summary: General Motors (GM) has asked a US appeals court to allow it to continue pursuing its civil racketeering suit against Fiat Chrysler Automobiles (FCA) despite a lower court judge's criticism of the complaint. The judge had called the suit "a waste of time and resources" and ordered GM CEO Mary Barra and FCA CEO Mike Manley to negotiate a resolution by July 1. GM rejected the characterization, saying the lawsuit is aimed at holding FCA accountable for alleged bribes to secure labor agreements that put GM at a disadvantage.

site_title: US food exporters sign safety declarations in lieu of virus-free guarantees
summary: US food and feed exporters are shipping goods to China with letters assuring safety, rather than official virus-free guarantees. The Agriculture Transportation Coalition drafted these commitment statements to assure importers that shipments adhere to industry safety standards. This move follows China's request for official declarations from food exporters. The statements are meant to provide assurance, not a guarantee, and do not supersede industry safety guidelines.

site_title: Trump signs order 'protecting' monuments as crowds topple statues
summary: US President Donald Trump signed an executive order on Friday to enforce prosecution for protesters who vandalize public memorials. The move comes amid civil unrest across America following the killing of George Floyd, with protesters toppling statues of Confederate leaders. Trump announced he would skip a weekend at his New Jersey golf resort to ensure "LAW & ORDER" in Washington. The order aims to protect public monuments, but critics argue it may also restrict free speech and peaceful protests.

site_title: Malaysia palm plantations urge government to let foreign workers return
summary: Malaysian palm plantations have urged the government to allow foreign workers to return, citing a severe labor shortage that could damage the industry. The industry, which relies on 70% foreign workers, faces a worsening shortage due to thousands leaving during the Covid-19 pandemic. If the hiring freeze is not lifted, production could decline, leading to higher crude palm oil prices and a potential industry decline. The Malaysian Estate Owners' Association warned that unattended plantations could lead to severe consequences for the sector's survival and sustainability.

images.alt_text: Malaysian palm plantations have urged the government to let foreign workers return, warning of severe damage to the palm-oil industry if it is not granted an exemption from a hiring freeze.

site_title: 'The Simpsons' ends white actors voicing characters of colour
summary: The Simpsons will no longer use white actors to voice ethnic minority characters, a decision made by the show's producers. This change affects recurring characters Apu Nahasapeemapetilon and Dr. Hibbert, who were previously voiced by white actors Hank Azaria and Harry Shearer. The move comes amid a reckoning on systemic racism and discrimination in the US, following the killing of George Floyd. Producers stated that moving forward, non-white actors will voice non-white characters. This change follows a similar announcement by Family Guy actor Mike Henry, who is stepping down from voicing Cleveland Brown.

site_title: US restricts visas in latest move on Hong Kong
summary: The US has restricted visas for Chinese officials who undermined Hong Kong's autonomy, with Secretary of State Mike Pompeo saying they "eviscerated Hong Kong's freedoms." The move comes as Congress seeks tougher sanctions, with a bill to impose economic sanctions on identified violators set to be passed by the House of Representatives. The action is seen as insufficient by some, including Senator Chris Van Hollen, who called for additional sanctions.

site_title: Microsoft to permanently close all retail stores
summary: Microsoft will permanently close its over 80 retail stores, transitioning them into "experience centers" with just four locations remaining. The move, attributed to the pandemic, marks a shift to online retail operations and digital storefronts. The company will invest $450 million to cover closure costs and will rely on its digital storefronts and services such as cloud computing to drive sales. This decision follows a decline in sales at its physical stores, including its Surface business, which has struggled to gain momentum in the consumer market.

site_title: Boeing 737 MAX test flight could be as soon as next week: sources
summary: US regulators are set to undertake a test flight of Boeing's grounded 737 MAX as early as next week, according to sources. This critical step is necessary for recertifying the plane for service, which has been grounded globally since March 2019 following two deadly crashes. The exact timing remains fluid, but the test flight is a significant milestone in the plane's return to service.

images.alt_text: US regulators are getting close to undertaking a test flight of Boeing's grounded 737 MAX and could schedule the key step for as soon as next week, two sources said on Friday.

site_title: GE2020: Reform Party announces campaign slogan, manifesto
summary: The Reform Party (RP) of Singapore has announced its campaign slogan and manifesto for the upcoming general election, focusing on rebuilding the country following the economic impact of COVID-19. The party's proposals include suspending the Goods and Services Tax, increasing unemployment benefits and providing free university education. They also propose a minimum wage of $10 per hour, universal healthcare, and a higher minimum salary for employment passes. The party plans to contest 13 seats, including Ang Mo Kio GRC and two single-seat wards.

site_title: Zimbabwe suspends mobile banking, stock exchange trade
summary: Zimbabwe has suspended all mobile banking transactions and trade on the country's stock exchange, citing a need to tackle crime and economic sabotage. The move, effective immediately, aims to facilitate intrusive investigations into alleged illicit activities. The suspension affects mobile money payments, which account for over 80% of electronic payment transactions. The country is in the midst of its worst economic crisis in over a decade, with high inflation and shortages of cash, fuel, and basic goods.

site_title: New S$1.36b package rolled out to help construction firms resume work safely
summary: A new S$1.36 billion Construction Support Package has been launched to help construction companies resume work safely in Singapore. The package aims to co-fund extra costs incurred due to enhanced virus-safety measures and provide relief for costs incurred due to project delays. The fund will also cover foreign worker levy rebates and COVID-19 testing costs. The initiative is part of the Fortitude Budget, which aims to support various sectors affected by the pandemic.

site_title: Delta will warn pilots about possible furloughs, offers early retirement
summary: Delta Air Lines will send warning notices to approximately 2,500 pilots about possible furloughs due to the ongoing impact of the coronavirus pandemic on air travel demand. The airline has also reached a tentative agreement with the Air Line Pilots Association on a pilot-specific voluntary early retirement option. Delta plans to add about 1,000 flights in August but expects to remain at least two years away from a return to normal operations.

images.alt_text: Delta Air Lines said late on Friday it will soon send warning notices to about 2,500 pilots regarding possible furloughs at the airline, as the industry takes a huge blow after the coronavirus pandemic slashed air travel demand.

site_title: 'TikTok Grandma' who helped derail Trump rally will work for Biden
summary: Mary Jo Laupp, known as "TikTok Grandma," has been hired by the Biden Digital Coalition to help with online campaigning for Joe Biden's presidential election. Laupp's social media call to discourage Trump supporters from attending his rally in Tulsa, Oklahoma, resulted in a poorly-attended speech. Her TikTok video has been viewed over 2 million times and has helped build a community of pro-Biden content creators. Laupp, a 51-year-old mother of four and grandmother of six, joins the Biden campaign after previously participating in the Democratic campaign of Pete Buttigieg.

site_title: IMF approves US$5.2 b, 1-year loan programme for Egypt
summary: The IMF has approved a one-year, $5.2 billion loan program for Egypt to help alleviate the economic impact of the COVID-19 pandemic. The funding will focus on health and social spending, as well as financial stability to control inflation. The loan comes on top of the $2.8 billion in emergency aid approved last month, and will help Egypt recover from the pandemic's economic disruption. The IMF noted Egypt's strong track record of implementing economic reforms, and the loan will support job creation by the private sector.

site_title: Pakistan airline under fire in fake pilot licence scandal
summary: Pakistan's national airline, Pakistan International Airlines (PIA), is facing severe criticism after a government review found nearly a third of its pilots held fake or dubious licenses. The airline has grounded 141 pilots and initiated dismissal proceedings against 28, with subsequent criminal charges likely. The scandal comes after a crash in Karachi last month that killed 98 people, which authorities have attributed to the two pilots. The airline's reputation has plummeted, and observers question whether PIA can survive the scandal, with some predicting it will "prove the last nail in the coffin" of the struggling carrier.

site_title: UK to ease virus quarantine rules for 'low risk' countries
summary: Britain is set to ease its two-week coronavirus quarantine rule for visitors from "low risk" countries, starting July 6. The government will publish a list of countries eligible for quarantine-free entry, following discussions with France, Greece, and Spain. The new risk-assessment system will allow for safe travel routes to be established, and all passengers will be required to wear face coverings on planes and ferries. The move aims to support the tourism sector and follows criticism from airlines and travel industry groups.

site_title: Singaporeans can rely on PAP to guide nation through Covid-19 crisis: PM Lee
summary: Singapore Prime Minister Lee Hsien Loong says the ruling People's Action Party (PAP) can guide the country through the Covid-19 crisis while securing its long-term future. In the PAP's manifesto, the party outlines plans to keep Singaporeans and migrant workers safe, restart and transform the economy, and provide care and support.
