The protests have also seen a decline in momentum, with fewer participants and shorter demonstrations.

site_title: Starhill Global Reit extends appointment of property manager by 5 years
summary: Starhill Global Reit has extended the appointment of its property manager by five years, from September 20, 2020, until the same date in 2026. The property management agreements were entered into with HSBC Institutional Trust Services (Singapore) and Starhill Global Property Management. Under the agreements, Starhill Global Property Management will continue to manage the Reit's interests in Ngee Ann City and Wisma Atria.

site_title: Singapore listcos' lawyers get best practices guide for SGX RegCo submissions
summary: Singapore Exchange Regulation (SGX RegCo) and the Law Society of Singapore have jointly released a best practices guide for lawyers making submissions to the bourse operator. The guide sets out recommendations and best practices for consultations on listing rules, waiver applications, and shareholder circulars. It aims to ensure lawyers uphold legal standards and protect investors' interests. The guide also introduces an administrative measure requiring law firms' names to be listed in shareholders' circulars, promoting accountability and ownership. The guide takes effect immediately and is expected to raise the bar for professional services and law firms serving Singapore's investment community.

site_title: SoftBank's Son defends his investing decisions
summary: SoftBank Group CEO Masayoshi Son defended his investing decisions, stating the conglomerate's holdings have recovered to pre-coronavirus levels. Son used a colloquial Japanese phrase to address concerns that SoftBank was "finished" or "SoftPunku," a play on the word "puncture." This comes after the company faced significant losses due to the pandemic.

site_title: Verizon suspends advertising on Facebook, joins growing boycott
summary: Verizon Communications has suspended advertising on Facebook, joining a growing list of US companies boycotting the platform in response to Facebook's inadequate efforts to stop hate speech. The decision follows widespread support for the Stop Hate for Profit campaign, which was launched by US civil rights groups. Verizon cited the need for Facebook to create an acceptable solution to make the company comfortable with continuing advertising on the platform. This move follows similar actions by other prominent US companies, including Oracle, Grab, and PwC.

images.alt_text: Verizon Communications said on Thursday it was pausing advertising on Facebook following widespread support for a campaign that called out the social media giant for not doing enough to stop hate speech on its platforms.

site_title: Oil prices climb as US economic data lends support
summary: Oil prices rose 2% on Thursday, driven by US economic data showing a marginal improvement and a slight increase in fuel demand. Brent crude rose 74 cents to $41.05 a barrel, while US West Texas Intermediate crude rose 71 cents to $38.72. Road traffic in major cities returned to 2019 levels, according to data from TomTom. However, rising Covid-19 cases limited price gains.

site_title: Floating oil hoard off Singapore sheds light on Asian recovery
summary: A significant hoard of crude and oil products is floating off Singapore, shedding light on Asia's oil demand recovery. As of Tuesday, 82.5 million barrels of crude and oil products were parked in 67 vessels, up from 69.8 million barrels at the end of May. The fluctuating volumes are attributed to Asian buying interest countered by new shipments, indicating a complex energy market recovery in the region. China's rapid recovery has driven much of the demand, while other economies struggle to follow suit.

site_title: Space: Lounging Safely
summary: Luxury furniture retailers in Singapore have reopened with safety measures in place, including mandatory SafeEntry check-in, temperature taking, and thorough sanitization of hard and fabric surfaces. Designers and sales staff welcome customers with reduced crowds, prioritizing personal interactions and minimizing surface contact. Some stores, such as P5 and Space Furniture, have implemented discreet cleaning protocols, while others, like Xtra and atomi, have invested in UVC lamps and sterilization rooms to enhance safety.

site_title: Global housing markets ensnared by pandemic's toll on jobs: poll
summary: Global housing markets are expected to face significant challenges due to the ongoing pandemic, with high unemployment and low immigration posing major hurdles. A majority of analysts polled by Reuters predict a subdued outlook, with house prices forecast to fall in several countries, including Australia, India, Dubai, Britain, Canada, and the US. Despite fiscal and monetary stimulus, the recovery is expected to be slow and long, with over 80% of respondents predicting a gradual or slow recovery.

site_title: Federal Reserve caps bank dividend payments after pandemic analysis
summary: The US Federal Reserve announced it will cap big bank dividend payments and bar share repurchases until at least the fourth quarter, citing significant capital losses from pandemic analysis. The Fed found that lenders struggled to model the economic downturn and found aggregate loan losses could reach $700 billion under the most severe scenario. This decision aims to maintain bank capital and stability during the economic uncertainty caused by the pandemic.

images.alt_text: The US Federal Reserve announced on Thursday it will cap big bank dividend payments and bar share repurchases until at least the fourth quarter after finding lenders faced significant capital losses when tested against an economic slump caused by the coronavirus pandemic.

site_title: Nike posts surprise loss as Covid-19 hits wholesale business
summary: Nike reported its first quarterly loss in over two years due to the Covid-19 pandemic, with its wholesale business coming to a halt and resulting in a 50% fall in shipments and increased costs. The company's shares fell 4% in after-hours trading. The pandemic's impact on the footwear industry led to a decline in sales and a higher inventory. Nike's reliance on China remained despite 190% tariffs.

site_title: US: Wall Street ends choppy session higher as strength in banks offsets virus woes
summary: US stocks closed higher on Thursday as bank stocks surged ahead of annual stress test results, offsetting concerns over the COVID-19 pandemic. The S&P 500 banks sub-index rose 3.6% after regulators eased rules and investors waited for stress test results. Despite a jump in new virus cases, the Dow Jones Industrial Average rose 1.18% and the S&P 500 gained 1.10%. The market remains cautious, with investors waiting for the stress test results, which could impact dividend policies and bank flexibility.

images.alt_text: Wall Street's main indexes closed higher in choppy trading on Thursday, with bank stocks soaring ahead of annual stress test results and helping to offset investor jitters over alarming increases in new coronavirus cases.

site_title: Europe: Stocks end higher as mood improves, Lufthansa jumps
summary: European stocks closed higher, with the Stoxx 600 up 0.7% after the European Central Bank offered euro loans to backstop funding markets. Lufthansa jumped 7.1% after a top shareholder backed a government bailout. The auto-heavy DAX index gained 0.7% despite Wirecard's 71.3% slump after disclosing a financial hole. Despite upbeat euro zone business activity readings and improved German consumer morale, weekly losses remain a concern due to surging US Covid-19 cases and EU-US trade tensions.

site_title: Oil pricing agencies Platts, Argus launch new US crude benchmarks
summary: US crude pricing agencies Platts and Argus launch new benchmarks on June 26, reflecting the price of Gulf Coast-traded crude on tankers. This move comes after US crude futures plunged into negative territory in April. The new benchmarks will replace the current West Texas Intermediate (WTI) price, which is based on landlocked crude delivered at Cushing, Oklahoma. The new assessments will provide a more accurate price for crude shipped from the Gulf Coast to global markets. This shift aims to better reflect the actual market conditions for US Gulf Coast crude.

site_title: Hin Leong responds to PwC's report, says Mr Lim was unwell
summary: Hin Leong Trading's CEO, Mr. Lim, was not given a "reasonable opportunity" to respond to fraud allegations in a PwC report, his family stated. The report alleged the company misled banks, overstated assets by at least $3 billion, and used fictitious profits to hide $808 million in losses. PwC, the court-appointed interim judicial manager, filed the report with the Singapore High Court. Mr. Lim's family argued he was unwell and unable to respond to the allegations, but did not provide evidence to support this claim.

site_title: Stocks to watch: CapitaLand Mall Trust, ARA Logos, SIA, Southern Alliance Mining, Starhill Global Reit
summary:
Here's a 100-word summary of the article:

Stocks to watch include CapitaLand Mall Trust, ARA Logos, SIA, Southern Alliance Mining, and Starhill Global Reit. CapitaLand Mall Trust maintains a cautious outlook amid the Covid-19 pandemic, while ALog hopes to grow its portfolio through asset acquisitions. SIA sees an opportunity to enter the Indian market. Southern Alliance Mining debuted on the Catalist board, and Starhill Global Reit's property manager extended its contract. Other companies, such as Creative Technology, Japfa, and Yoma Strategic, also made announcements. Trading halts were called for by Dasin Retail Trust and Halcyon Agri, pending their respective announcements.

site_title: Fed balance sheet down again as currency swaps fall further
summary: The US Federal Reserve's balance sheet decreased to $7.13 trillion, marking a second consecutive week of decline, as foreign central banks reduced their use of currency swaps and US banks reduced their use of Fed repurchase agreements. The balance outstanding for foreign exchange swaps fell to $275 billion, the lowest level since March 25. The Fed's repo facilities also saw a significant decrease in usage, with $70.20 billion outstanding on Wednesday, the lowest since mid-September. The Main Street Lending Program remains idle, with no new credits extended.

site_title: US Senate backs bill to punish China over Hong Kong
summary: The US Senate passed the "Hong Kong Autonomy Act" by unanimous consent, imposing mandatory sanctions on individuals and companies backing China's efforts to restrict Hong Kong's autonomy. The bill also includes secondary sanctions on banks that do business with those backing crackdowns. The measure must now pass the House of Representatives and be signed by President Trump to become law. The legislation aims to send a clear message to Beijing that there will be consequences if it undermines Hong Kong's autonomy.

images.alt_text: Democratic Senator Chris Van Hollen, a lead sponsor, said in the Senate the legislation would send a clear message to Beijing that there would be consequences if it acts to undermine Hong Kong's autonomy.

site_title: Contactless payment options on the rise amid Covid-19 outbreak
summary: Singapore's largest bank DBS and taxi operator ComfortDelGro Taxi have partnered to allow customers to book and pay for ComfortDelGro taxi rides using DBS's PayLah! platform in-app. The move aims to encourage customers to switch to contactless payments amid the Covid-19 outbreak, making contact tracing easier. This is the latest in a series of digital banking initiatives in Singapore, following the launch of Nets Click, which allows prepaid customers to make digital top-ups and purchase data plans using Nets ATM bank cards.

site_title: US initial jobless claims higher than forecast
summary: US initial jobless claims rose above forecast for the second consecutive week, reaching 1.48 million in regular state programs, and continuing claims fell to 19.5 million. The data suggests the recovery is cooling amid a surge in coronavirus cases. Economists expect continued improvement in the labor market, with a projected 3 million jobs added to payrolls in June. Meanwhile, durable goods orders jumped 15.8% in May, while US merchandise exports sank to the lowest in over a decade.

site_title: Singapore Airlines could take India market share from Emirates, Etihad
summary: Singapore Airlines' local affiliate Vistara is poised to capture a share of the Indian market, potentially taking market share from Emirates and Etihad, as the coronavirus outbreak leads to increased demand for direct flights. Vistara's second Boeing 787 Dreamliner is set to arrive, and chief commercial officer Vinod Kannan expects demand for long-haul international travel from India to rise when travel restrictions lift. The airline will capitalize on India's restrictions on foreign airlines flying passengers to a third country, offering non-stop connections overseas.

site_title: Liverpool win Premier League title with seven games to spare
summary: Liverpool was confirmed as the Premier League champion on June 25, 2020, after Manchester City's 2-1 defeat by Chelsea. This marked the end of 30 years of hurt for the team, who last won the title in 1989-90. Liverpool now holds an unassailable 23-point lead over second-placed Manchester City with seven games remaining in the season.

site_title: Beauty: Essential Self Care
summary: Beauty services have resumed operations in Singapore after a two-and-a-half month wait, with many businesses already fully booked. To ensure safety, beauty businesses have implemented measures such as safe entry checks, social distancing, face masks, and face shields. Some businesses have also introduced digital tools, like the "Try it on Virtually" platform, to minimize physical contact. Despite health advice against close physical contact, many people are choosing to re-assimilate into society, opting for personal care services like beauty treatments.

site_title: S-E Asia must diffuse a deadly health threat
summary: South-east Asia is vulnerable to disease outbreaks due to high population density, ecological fragility, and lack of preparedness. Studies show a strong relation between air pollution and the incidence and impact of Covid-19, with cities like Jakarta and Bangkok having high levels of urban air pollution. The region should be concerned about the lethal pollution-infection interaction, especially with a second wave of Covid-19 possible. Emissions-health connections need to be prioritized in government agendas to mitigate this threat.

site_title: IMF warns markets at risk of correction
summary: The International Monetary Fund (IMF) has warned that markets for stocks and other risky assets could suffer a second downturn if the coronavirus spreads, lockdowns are reimposed, or trade tensions rise. Despite a brief rally from March's low, the IMF cautions that a correction is possible if these factors escalate.

site_title: A devastating pandemic and the geopolitical trust deficit
summary: A devastating pandemic has exposed a fragile global order, with China-US rivalry deepening due to trade wars, weakening multilateralism, and economic nationalism. China's economy is expected to grow below 2% this year, and the country is focusing on internal stability, security, and competitiveness. The China-US rivalry is becoming increasingly zero-sum, with both sides vying for dominance. A cold war between the two powers could hurt global trade, supply chains, and stability, but it is unlikely to lead to all-out war. The pandemic has accelerated the trend of countries retreating from multilateralism, leaving global challenges such as climate change and poverty unresolved.

site_title: Push for solutions for better lives has never been stronger
summary: Singapore's government has successfully leveraged digital technologies to respond to the COVID-19 pandemic, with initiatives such as the Gov.Sg WhatsApp channel, Covid-19 Chatbot, and digital platforms for mask collection and financial support. The government has also augmented its contact-tracing regime with digital tools like TraceTogether and SafeEntry. As a result, digital adoption has surged, with over 2 million users checking in/out daily via SafeEntry and over 1.1 million receiving COVID-19 updates via the Gov.Sg WhatsApp channel. The government plans to continue investing in digital capabilities to empower citizens and businesses, with a focus on humanizing front-end services and modernizing government infrastructure.

site_title: Property counters take a beating amid STI, regional markets' retreat
summary: Singapore's Straits Times Index fell 38.47 points or 1.46% to 2,590.15 on Thursday, as fears of a Covid-19 resurgence and regional markets' retreat took a toll on sentiment. Real estate companies, such as UOL Group, were the worst performers, with shares plummeting 2.86%. The only exceptions were Jardine Matheson Holdings and Jardine Strategic Holdings, which rose 0.77% and 0.87% respectively.

site_title: Goh Chok Tong, Low Thia Khiang exit politics as parties gear up for new battles
summary: Singapore's opposition parties, the Workers' Party (WP) and the People's Action Party (PAP), have announced the departure of veteran leaders Low Thia Khiang and Goh Chok Tong from active politics. Low, 63, is the longest-serving opposition parliamentarian, while Goh, 79, will not stand for the upcoming general election. WP's secretary-general Pritam Singh attributed Low's decision to refresh the party's line-up to remain relevant. The retirements are seen as a significant test for the WP, with analysts noting that Low's departure could fortify support for the opposition.

site_title: Covid-19 ushers in planting season for local farms, but costs, cheaper imports hobble prospects
summary: Singapore's local food production is expected to rise to 30% of total food needs by 2030, with the government providing S$30 million in funding for local farmers. However, challenges persist, including the need to encourage consumers to buy local produce and the high cost of farming in Singapore. Locally produced eggs, for example, are over 50% more expensive than those from Malaysia. Experts suggest exempting farmers from property taxes on manufacturing machinery and increasing demand through community events like farmers' markets to support local producers.

images.alt_text: ComCrop CEO Peter Barber and founder Allan Lim. Mr Barber said he faced administrative difficulties in setting up his farm.

site_title: Women supporting women
summary: T:>Works' Festival Of Women: N.O.W. 2020 celebrates women from all walks of life through various online art exhibitions, performances, and workshops from July 15 to August 2. Led by veteran actress and festival director Noorlinah Mohamed, the festival explores narratives of women's experiences, focusing on class, race, gender, and inequalities. The event features three key picks: a live-streamed one-woman comedy "King," a digital exhibition with interviews from over 25 women, and a radio play "The Book Of Mothers." The festival is the only women-centred visual and performing arts festival in Singapore, and all events are accessible online for free.

site_title: Heritage comfort at home
summary: Local caterer Jeremy Nguee's pop-up takeaway, Dream Shop, offers upscale interpretations of hawker food. Popular dishes include Dry Laksa ($36), featuring thick noodles with coconut milk-enriched dried shrimp rempah, and firm-textured prawns in a deep-fried ngoh hiang ($12). Other notable options include Buah Keluak Beef Rice Bowl ($38) and Gado Gado ($12), a peanut sauce-topped silken tofu dish. Meanwhile, Chef Pang Kok Keong's takeaway, Hakka Pang Delicacies, offers authentic Hakka cuisine, including chewy Hakka Noodles ($16) and savory abacus seeds ($31/kg).

site_title: Third batch of new PAP candidates includes former IMDA chief executive
summary: Deputy Prime Minister Heng Swee Keat announced the third batch of new People's Action Party (PAP) candidates for Singapore's General Election on June 25, 2020. The 26 new candidates, including former IMDA chief executive Tan Kiat How, 43-year-old lawyer Zhulkarnain Abdul Rahim, and former Parkway Holdings group chief executive Tan See Leng, have a median age of 43. The PAP has highlighted the candidates' backgrounds and experience, with some having conducted pro bono work and volunteering in community care facilities.

site_title: Izakayas crippled by coronavirus pandemic
summary: Japan's izakayas, a staple of its after-work drinking culture, are struggling to survive due to the coronavirus pandemic. With lockdown measures lifted in late May, many izakayas have seen customer numbers drop to only a third of their pre-pandemic levels. Small izakayas like Hitoshi Yaosaka's, which run 10 establishments in Tokyo, are particularly hard hit, with fewer workers commuting to nearby offices. Industry experts warn that if drinking out isn't considered welcome, izakayas may go under, potentially leading to a decline in Japan's izakaya culture.

site_title: 'Concerted effort' by PAP to ensure diversity of GE slate
summary: The People's Action Party (PAP) has made a concerted effort to increase diversity in its fifth slate of candidates for the general election. PAP organising secretary Grace Fu announced the slate, which includes candidates from different racial and ethnic backgrounds. Fu stated that the party had been in talks with some candidates before the last election, reflecting the needs of the population. This move aims to better represent Singapore's diverse population.

site_title: Election digest
summary: Singapore GE2020: The SingFirst party has been dissolved with its chief Tan Jee Say citing the need for consolidation to achieve a strong opposition. Reform Party chief Kenneth Jeyaretnam is serving a 14-day SHN, affecting his ability to submit nomination papers. People's Power Party chief Goh Meng Seng plans to contest MacPherson ward, while incumbent Tin Pei Ling of the People's Action Party is ready for a contest.

site_title: Koh Bros says its Van Holland residence 22% sold; KBEE unit spin-off gets SGX nod
summary: Koh Brothers Group (KBG) has sold 22% of its freehold luxury residence Van Holland, with 15 of 69 units sold as of Wednesday. The company expects a negative impact on its business due to the Covid-19 pandemic. Meanwhile, KBEE has received approval from the Singapore Exchange (SGX) for its proposed spin-off of Oiltek, but is reviewing the plan amid the pandemic. Both companies have implemented cost-cutting measures, including reduced dividend payments and executive director pay cuts.

site_title: PSP presents five more candidates, including two ex-military officers
summary: The Progress Singapore Party (PSP) has announced five new candidates, including two former military officers, Michael Chua and Nadarajah Loganathan, to contest in the upcoming Singapore General Election (GE2020). The candidates advocate for job opportunities for Singaporeans, support for small businesses, and greater attention to disadvantaged groups. They also criticize the current government for focusing on GDP and neglecting the needs of ordinary Singaporeans. The PSP emphasizes the importance of experience, commitment, and willingness to do what is good for the country, regardless of age.

site_title: Tencent-iflix deal signals hot market for streaming platforms
summary: Tencent has acquired the assets of struggling streaming service iflix for "tens of millions of dollars", marking a significant move into the Asian streaming market. The deal comes as the market experiences a boom amid the Covid-19 pandemic, with other players such as mm2 Asia and Gojek entering the space. However, the troubles of iflix and Singtel's failed service Hooq suggest that winning in this market is challenging, with industry experts citing the need for a sustainable model, such as advertising-driven or low subscription fees, to compete with US behemoth Netflix.

site_title: Weighing up what's success at the polls
summary: Singapore's general election is approaching, with parties needing to perform better than their 2015 campaign to be considered successful. Success will be measured by performance in key constituencies rather than overall vote share. The number of opposition MPs will also play a significant role, with the fight for Non-Constituency Member of Parliament (NCMP) slots becoming more crucial. Parties will need to do well in hotly-contested areas to be judged as successful in the upcoming election.

site_title: ARA Logos Logistics Trust eyes sponsor's portfolio for growth
summary: ARA Logos Logistics Trust, a Singaporean Reit, aims to grow its portfolio through asset acquisitions from its new sponsor Logos, which has approximately 6 million sqm of logistics space in Asia-Pacific. The trust's unit price has not recovered to pre-March levels due to the market's focus on larger, more stable-earning industrial S-Reits. To boost its unit price and enable equity capital raising, the trust will need to grow its scale and liquidity. The Reit has an investment mandate to invest in logistics properties in the Asia-Pacific region, with China remaining a key market consideration.

site_title: Five Years: The 13th Parliament
summary: Singapore's 13th Parliament marks five years since the 2015 General Election. The government has announced plans to advance sustainable aviation in Asia-Pacific and establish a centre for this purpose. The country also aims to become a global hub for advanced chip packaging, according to a study. Meanwhile, Deputy Prime Minister Gan Kim Kheng will visit the US for trade talks, and a new grant of up to S$100,000 is available for businesses affected by tariffs. The government advises graduates to be cautious but notes early data shows better employment rates.

site_title: Central Asia good expansion option for Singapore startups
summary: Singapore startups are seeking new expansion opportunities beyond South-east Asia due to the region's maturing markets. Central Asia, particularly Kazakhstan, is seen as a promising destination. The country has a growing tech scene, a well-developed infrastructure, and a large population of young, tech-savvy individuals. The government has invested in promoting STEM education and supporting startups, offering opportunities for Singapore-based companies to tap into the region's 72 million population and 3.3 billion potential market. A startup acceleration program, Kazakhstan Digital Accelerator, will be launched to nurture tech startups in the region.

site_title: US-dollar bonds winning larger share of Singapore's debt financing pie
summary: Singapore-listed companies are increasingly tapping the US dollar (USD) bond market to raise funds, driven by the more competitive credit spread in the USD market. In the first five months of this year, there were 18 USD bond issues, raising US$3.5 billion, compared to 37 SGD bond issues, which raised S$10.7 billion. The narrower spread between US Treasury bonds and corporate bonds has made it cheaper for companies to raise money from USD bonds, with many opting for larger deal sizes. Experts expect continued activity in the bond markets, particularly for longer-term deals.

site_title: MENSWEAR: Battling Covid - stylishly, of course
summary: Menswear brands have taken steps to combat the COVID-19 pandemic by implementing various safety measures and incorporating anti-viral solutions into their products. CYC Made To Measure, a menswear brand, has collaborated with a research company to apply an anti-viral solution called ViroQ to some of its products, which kills 99.99% of human coronavirus and other germs. The brand also sells ViroQ spray and masks made from high-quality fabric, designed to fit the complex structure of the nose, chin, and jawline, with a single spray coating keeping the mask virus-resistant for up to 15 washes.

site_title: Association of Banks in Singapore postpones its annual dinner
summary: The Association of Banks in Singapore (ABS) has postponed its annual dinner due to the Covid-19 crisis and safe distancing measures. The dinner, typically held in June, has been rescheduled to a later date when large-scale events are allowed. The decision comes as the Singapore government continues to implement measures to control the spread of the virus. The ABS dinner is a key event for the Singapore banking industry, where major announcements are made. Last year's dinner saw the Monetary Authority of Singapore announce plans to issue up to five new digital banking licenses.

site_title: Jetstar Asia to cut a quarter of its workforce in July
summary: Budget carrier Jetstar Asia is cutting 26% of its workforce, approximately 180 people, in July as part of "difficult but necessary decisions". The majority of affected employees will remain furloughed until the end of the year. This move comes amid the ongoing aviation industry challenges.

site_title: Amid Covid-19, breakthrough for Aussie-Indon trade deal
summary: Australia and Indonesia have finalized the Indonesia-Australia Comprehensive Economic Partnership Agreement (IA-CEPA), which will enter into force in July 2020. The agreement, 10 years in the making, aims to boost trade and investment between the two neighboring G-20 economies, with Australia expected to benefit more from the deal. Indonesia's trade and investment ties with Australia are weak, with only 2% of Australia's total trade coming from Indonesia over the past two decades. The agreement includes tariff reductions and tariff rate quotas for Australian exports to Indonesia, providing opportunities for increased trade and economic cooperation.

site_title: Covid-19 has opened a new chapter for America's workforce
summary: The US workforce, particularly low-wage service workers, has been overlooked and underprotected despite their critical role in the economy. These workers, predominantly black women and women of color, have been essential in times of stability and crisis, yet lack a strong safety net and often earn minimum wage. As the pandemic has highlighted, these workers will be crucial in the future, with home health aides and personal care aides projected to see the largest percentage increase in employment. It's time for the nation to invest in these workers, offering living-wage jobs with benefits and a federal safety net, to ensure a future where care jobs become sustainable and dignified.

site_title: Qantas to raise A$1.9b and cut 6,000 jobs to survive
summary: Qantas Airways Ltd will raise up to A$1.9 billion and cut at least 6,000 jobs to survive the coronavirus pandemic. The airline will also keep 15,000 workers furloughed, primarily tied to international operations. Qantas' entire A380 fleet, worth billions, will be grounded for at least three years. CEO Alan Joyce said the sudden reversal of fortune is "no one's fault" and the company is facing a years-long recuperation, with global airlines expected to lose over $84 billion in 2020.

images.alt_text: Qantas' entire fleet of 12 Airbus A380 superjumbos will be grounded for at least three years.

site_title: Open Tables
summary: New restaurants are set to open in Singapore as Phase 2 of the country's reopening kicks in. Tuga, a Portuguese wine shop and restaurant, opened on June 19, offering a selection of Portuguese wines and traditional Portuguese dishes. Sushi Kou, a new sushi restaurant, is expected to open soon, offering omakase-only menus at $380 and $450. Lucali BYBG, a Singapore outpost of a Brooklyn pizza joint, is set to open in July, offering its home delivery menu and brick oven pizzas. Corner House, a Michelin-starred restaurant, is reopening on July 2 with a new head chef, David Thien.

site_title: Battle lines drawn in virtual space, but fight for votes is on the ground
summary: In the lead-up to Singapore's General Election 2020, digital campaigns are expected to play a significant role, but their impact on votes remains uncertain. Experts argue that while a strong online presence can help candidates convey their message and vision, it's not a guarantee of electoral success. Physical presence, including door-to-door interactions and community engagement, is still seen as crucial in winning votes, especially among older or less digitally savvy citizens. Cyber attacks and fake news are also potential threats, but having a strong digital presence across multiple platforms is considered essential for reaching diverse demographics.

site_title: What's Up This Week
summary: The Singapore Heritage Festival has gone online for the first time in its 17-year history due to the coronavirus pandemic. The festival, running until July 5, features virtual tours, cooking demonstrations, and workshops on three areas: Tanjong Pagar, Pasir Ris, and Kallang. Meanwhile, the Motorist app now offers verified real-time data on speed traps and red-light cameras through a partnership with the Traffic Police. Hendricks Gin has launched an augmented reality game, The Cucumber Horticulturist, to promote its World Cucumber Day. The Singapore Chinese Cultural Centre has also released digital programs for the Dumpling Festival.

images.alt_text: The Singapore Heritage Festival 2020: Digital Edition is at heritagefestival.sg.

site_title: Corporate digest
summary: Singtel's Australian unit priced A$350 million in 5-year notes at 1.6% and A$500 million in 10-year notes at 2.5%. Southern Alliance Mining debuted as a Catalist-listed counter on the Singapore bourse after its IPO. Spindex Industries announced a 50-50 joint venture with Acuger Precision Corporation to expand operations in Vietnam. Pacific International Lines postponed its 2019 audited financial results due to a debt re-profiling exercise. TSH Corporation reopened two bars for dine-in services despite a 80% fall in revenue for April and May 2020. Japfa expects demand to be affected by weaker economies and reduced consumer purchasing power.

site_title: Metro H2 profit plunges 81.9% to S$11.3m on lower revenue
summary: Metro Holdings posted an 81.9% decline in net profit to S$11.3m for the half year ended March 31, 2020, due to lower sales from its retail division. Revenue fell 14.6% to S$81.5m, mainly attributed to the closure of Metro Centrepoint in October 2019 and shortened operating hours amid the Covid-19 situation. The group's property division revenue rose 42.3% to S$34.3m, driven by contributions from the sale of property rights. A final cash dividend of two Singapore cents per share was recommended for the full year.

site_title: Joey Alexander, Jazz Musician
summary: Joey Alexander, a 16-year-old jazz musician, has achieved remarkable success, recording six studio albums and earning three Grammy nominations. Despite his prodigious talent, Alexander prefers not to be called a prodigy, citing his music as thoughtful and contemplative. He has performed with renowned jazz musicians, including Wynton Marsalis, and has been invited to play at notable jazz events. Alexander's journey began with self-taught piano lessons at age 6, and he made his US debut at Jazz At Lincoln Centre at 11. He continues to compose his own material and remains focused on creating music for the audience's enjoyment.

site_title: Task force expects rise in Covid-19 cases; testing being stepped up
summary: Singapore is expected to see a rise in Covid-19 cases starting next week as the country reopens from Phase Two restrictions. The multi-ministry taskforce has ramped up testing, with daily tests ranging from 11,000 to 14,000, and plans to expand testing to include more individuals, such as students and frontline staff. The taskforce is also monitoring for large clusters, super-spreading events, and sudden spikes in cases. Despite this, Minister Lawrence Wong has expressed confidence in the country's green-lane travel arrangements with countries like China and South Korea, as long as they maintain control over the virus.

site_title: Great Eastern to pump US$70m into fintech Axiata Digital's expansion plans
summary: Great Eastern has invested US$70 million in Axiata Digital's fintech expansion plans via a new holding company, Boost Holdings. The investment will support Axiata's growing financial services business in the region. This move is part of Great Eastern's strategy to participate in Axiata's fintech expansion plans. The investment was made through Boost Holdings, which is wholly-owned by Axiata Digital.

site_title: China's banking system under stress as economy slows
summary: China's banking system is under stress as the country's economy slows, with the government urging banks to absorb losses of 1.5 trillion yuan (S$295 billion) to support small and medium enterprises. The move may weaken banks, which are already hampered by inefficient lending and slower growth. China's GDP fell 6.8% in the first quarter, and the government is increasing pressure on banks to support SMEs, potentially leading to higher non-performing loans and reduced earnings growth.

site_title: ABI Plaza said to be on the market
summary: ABI Plaza, a 12-storey freehold office building in Singapore, is on the market with an expected price tag of over S$280 million. Industry watchers anticipate strong interest in the property due to its prime location. The sale comes as the market continues to navigate post-pandemic recovery and growth.

site_title: The Joy of Dining Out Again
summary: Restaurant patrons in Singapore were finally allowed to dine out after over 10 weeks of restrictions, marking a significant milestone in the pandemic response. The experience was described as a welcome return to a night out with friends or a significant other, highlighting the benefits of dining out over takeaway food. However, the F&B industry continues to face significant challenges, with casualties mounting daily due to the ongoing pandemic. The resumption of dine-in meals is seen as a positive step, but the long-term impact on the industry remains uncertain.

site_title: Get Personal and Creative
summary: A.muse Projects, a homegrown tea company, has launched a bespoke blend service and a DIY Tea & Botanical Blending Box, allowing customers to create their own unique tea blends at home. The box contains three tea bases, three florals, two herbs, and two spices, with each blend making up 70% of the final product. The DIY kit is priced at S$45 and can be purchased from amuseprojects.com. This move aims to engage customers in the tea-making process and provide a creative outlet.

site_title: GCB in White House Park sells for nearly S$60m
summary: A freehold bungalow in White House Park, Singapore, has sold for nearly S$60 million, with market watchers estimating the price to be over S$1,600 per square foot based on its 35,290 sq ft land area. The property, located in the District 10 GCB Area, was sold via private treaty after no bids were received through a tender. The buyer, a Singaporean, plans to redevelop the site into a single mansion or subdivided into two GCB parcels.

site_title: CapitaLand rolls out tech solutions at business parks, offices in Singapore
summary: CapitaLand, a Singapore-based property giant, is rolling out digital solutions at its business parks and offices to help tenants cope with the "new normal" post-COVID-19. The company has introduced features such as staff and visitor contact tracing, near real-time data retrieval, and health and wellness surveys on its CapitaStar@Work app. Additionally, CapitaLand is onboarding F&B tenants onto its food ordering platform, Capita3Eats, and enhancing cleaning and disinfection procedures. The company is also exploring bulk purchasing of work area sanitization services and trialing disinfection technology at certain properties.

site_title: Lawsuits snarl millions in oil from Hin Leong deals
summary: Lawsuits related to trade and financing deals by Singapore's Hin Leong Trading (Pte) Ltd have resulted in millions of dollars of oil being caught in a web of disputes. Court documents and shipping data show that Hin Leong obtained financing for oil cargoes that did not exist, complicating competing claims of ownership. The issue involves millions of dollars of oil stored in tanks and ships in Asia and Europe, with multiple parties involved in the disputes. The exact amount and parties affected are not specified, but the lawsuits are expected to have significant implications for the energy and commodities markets.

site_title: Google says it will pay publishers for news content
summary: Google will pay partnered media publishers in three countries, including Germany and Brazil, for high-quality content as part of a new licensing program. The move comes after legal battles in France and Australia, where Google was ordered to pay media groups for displaying their content. The program will also offer users free access to paywalled news sites. The initiative builds on Google's 2018 Google News Initiative, a $300 million project aimed at helping news sites grow financially and tackling disinformation online.

site_title: Grocery e-tailers moving up the food chain
summary: Singapore's online grocery retailers faced significant challenges during the circuit breaker period, struggling to scale up quickly due to supply shortages and lockdowns. However, two months later, they appear to have found their footing. Tech company Infor reported robust demand for its enterprise software, highlighting the need for smooth business operations. Online grocery retailers may have finally come into their own, adapting to the pandemic's impact and emerging as a viable alternative to traditional supermarkets.

site_title: US rebuffs China, rejects links between Covid-19 and food
summary: US health and agricultural authorities have rebuffed China's demands for food-exporting companies to sign documents stating they comply with safety standards to prevent Covid-19 transmission. The US Agriculture Secretary and FDA commissioner stated that there's no evidence people can contract Covid-19 from food or food packaging. China's request comes after an outbreak in Beijing linked to imported salmon, but the country's National Health Commission has found no evidence of the virus being transmitted through food. The US is reluctant to sign the affidavit due to fear of liability, potentially delaying $36.5 billion in farm purchases under the Phase One trade deal.

site_title: Did Hong Kong's pro-democracy protesters overplay their hand?
summary: Hong Kong's pro-democracy protesters may have overplayed their hand after successfully withdrawing a contentious extradition law bill last year. The proposed legislation aimed to close a loophole for Hongkongers facing justice in Taiwan, but was met with widespread opposition due to concerns it could be used by China to suppress dissent. The protests led to Hong Kong Chief Executive Carrie Lam's apology and the bill's withdrawal, but some argue that the movement's actions may have inadvertently strengthened China's grip on the city. A year on, a sense of buyer's remorse has settled over Hong Kong's populace.

site_title: RHB upgrades SGX to 'buy' on expected rise in trading
summary: RHB upgraded its rating on the Singapore Exchange (SGX) to 'buy' from 'neutral' due to strong securities average daily value and expected trading increases. The target price was raised to S$9.20 from S$8.60. SGX shares closed at S$8.04, down 0.7% from the previous day. The upgrade is seen as a defensive play benefiting from volatility, with analysts expecting positive earnings from the bourse operator.

site_title: F&B: The new dining experience
summary: Singapore's fine dining scene has reopened under Phase 2 of the economy's reboot, with upscale restaurants such as Les Amis and Odette fully booked for lunch and dinner. To ensure safe distancing, restaurants have implemented measures like thermal imaging scanners, masked servers, and QR codes for menu scanning. However, the 10:30pm curfew on alcohol consumption has been a hindrance, with some restaurants predicting a loss of late-night seating. Despite the challenges, many chefs are optimistic about the future, with some predicting a return to pre-Covid-19 levels of business, driven by local residents and business dining.

site_title: US: Wall St opens lower on rising virus cases, elevated jobless claims
summary: US stocks opened lower on Thursday, following their worst day in two weeks, due to rising coronavirus cases and elevated jobless claims. The Dow Jones Industrial Average fell 80.72 points, the S&P 500 dropped 3.73 points, and the Nasdaq Composite fell 9.81 points. Investors were unnerved by the alarming rise in new cases and an elevated weekly jobless claims number, leading to a decline in market sentiment.

site_title: EU is 'very concerned' by delayed WTO decision on tariffs against US
summary: The European Union is "very concerned" about a delayed World Trade Organization decision on tariffs against the US over Boeing subsidies, with the EU seeking retaliatory rights. The WTO has pushed back the decision to September due to the impact of COVID-19 lockdowns. The EU wants to reach an agreement with the US to set aside the dispute, but observers believe this won't happen until the WTO awards the EU the right to impose tariffs. The US has already won the right to impose tariffs on $7.5 billion of EU goods.

site_title: ST Telemedia's first benchmark-sized SGD perpetual of the year gets sizzling reception
summary: ST Telemedia's SGD perpetual deal has received over S$2 billion in orders, with prices tightened to 4.10% from 4.375%. This follows Swiss Re's S$350 million 15-year issue at 3.125%, which drew over S$1.4 billion in orders. The market is reviving, with non-Singapore investors seeking SGD bonds, driven by the currency's status as a safe haven. DBS Bank's head of fixed income notes that the SGD market is illiquid and less transparent, but is expected to attract more foreign investors if the currency remains strong.

site_title: MAS proposes guidelines to manage environmental risk
summary: The Monetary Authority of Singapore (MAS) has proposed guidelines for banks to manage environmental risk, aiming to shape Singapore into a global centre for green finance. The guidelines, part of a set of consultation papers, require banks to incorporate environmental considerations into their strategies, business plans, and product offerings. Boards and senior management must approve environmental risk-management frameworks, and banks must assess and mitigate environmental risk at both customer and portfolio levels. The guidelines also propose disclosure requirements for banks to report their approach to managing environmental risk and its impact on the bank.

site_title: US dollar holds upper hand; recovery doubts creep in
summary: The US dollar rose 0.17% to 97.40 on the dollar index due to rising trade tensions and fears of a second coronavirus wave. This is despite being below its 2020 high of 103 in late March. The dollar's rise is seen as a safe-haven currency response to global economic uncertainty.

site_title: Saudi lender NCB weighs deal for US$15b rival Samba
summary: National Commercial Bank (NCB), Saudi Arabia's largest lender, proposed a deal to acquire Samba Financial Group for up to $15.6 billion, making it the largest banking takeover this year. The deal would see NCB issue up to 1.54 billion new shares, and the combined bank would have total assets of around $210 billion, making it the third-largest in the region. The move is part of Saudi Arabia's efforts to shore up its banking sector, which has been impacted by the coronavirus pandemic and lower oil prices.

site_title: Luxury is dead. Long live luxury
summary: Luxury brands are adapting to the pandemic by focusing on quality, customer relationships, and exclusivity. To combat the loss of customers due to social distancing measures, high-end stores are expanding their online presence, offering digital shopping experiences, and creating virtual boutiques. Some luxury brands, such as Franck Muller and Piaget, are also investing in omni-channel commerce and exploring new ways to engage with customers, including social media and email marketing. Despite challenges, luxury brands are expected to thrive as customers continue to prioritize in-person experiences and high-end products.

images.alt_text: With capacity restrictions, queues are common outside high-end stores such as Dior.
Franck Muller at MBS sees a gradual pickup.
IWC has a virtual boutique that's been visited over 10,000 times.

site_title: Global trade plunged by record during peak of virus lockdowns
summary: Global trade plummeted by a record 12% in April during the peak of the COVID-19 lockdowns, with a 16% decline compared to the same period last year. The World Trade Organization (WTO) tempered its worst-case scenario of a 32% decline, predicting a 5-20% rebound in global trade next year. The International Monetary Fund (IMF) also updated its global outlook, predicting a 4.9% slump in world GDP and an 11.9% contraction in trade this year.

site_title: Japfa hit by weaker demand for poultry in Indonesia amid Covid-19
summary: Japfa, an agri-food player, reported weaker demand for poultry in Indonesia due to the COVID-19 pandemic and reduced purchasing power. Despite this, the company expects to benefit from stronger demand for dairy in China and pork in Vietnam. Japfa's net profit for the first quarter of 2020 was US$35.5 million, a five-fold increase from the previous year. The company is well-positioned to manage the situation due to its experience and is poised to benefit from its raw milk production in China and biosecurity protocols in Vietnam.

site_title: Social issues are focus for four PAP candidates
summary: The People's Action Party (PAP) in Singapore has introduced four new candidates for the upcoming General Election, focusing on social and community issues. The candidates include Eric Chua Swee Leong, Wan Rizal Wan Zakariah, Yeo Wan Ling, and Alvin Tan Sheng Hui, who will work on issues such as education, social mobility, caregiving programs, and racial and religious harmony. The PAP will introduce the remaining 22 candidates on Friday, bringing the total to 26 candidates.

site_title: China's Huawei to build US$1.2b research facility in England
summary: China's Huawei has received planning permission to build a US$1.2 billion research and development facility in England, employing around 400 people. The facility will focus on producing optical devices for fibre-optic communication systems. This move is likely to anger US officials and some British lawmakers who oppose Huawei's involvement in Britain's 5G networks due to security concerns.

site_title: Durable goods orders in US surge by most since July 2014
summary: US durable goods orders surged 15.8% in May, the largest increase since July 2014, driven by nationwide reopenings and demand for merchandise and equipment. This surpassed economists' median estimate of a 10.5% increase. Core capital goods orders rose 2.3%, while shipments of core capital goods increased 1.8%. The rebound in orders reflects the manufacturing sector's gradual recovery, but orders remain far short of pre-pandemic levels, indicating a long path to recovery.

site_title: India says China amassed troops along border in violation of agreements
summary: India's foreign ministry accused China of amassing troops and violating bilateral agreements along their disputed Himalayan border. China deployed large numbers of troops and armaments, sparking a deadly clash last week that killed 20 Indian soldiers. The incident occurred in the Galwan Valley, where China has since added new structures near the site, contradicting India's claim that it is on their side of the Line of Actual Control. Both sides have since agreed to disengage their troops, but tensions remain elevated.

site_title: Unilever's 'Fair & Lovely' to get makeover after backlash
summary: Unilever is rebranding its "Fair & Lovely" skin lightening products, dropping the word "fair" in response to global backlash against racial prejudice. This move follows similar rebranding efforts by Johnson & Johnson and PepsiCo. The decision aims to address concerns about the promotion of skin-whitening cosmetics, particularly in South Asia. Unilever's makeover is part of a broader effort to address racial prejudice and promote inclusivity.

site_title: CMT remains cautious amid retail headwinds
summary: Capitaland Mall Trust (CMT) maintains a cautious outlook amid the Covid-19 pandemic, citing retail headwinds and economic uncertainty. The company expects shopper traffic and tenant sales to remain muted, with pressure on rental reversion and occupancy. To adapt, CMT will explore alternative leasing strategies, tap technology, and tighten operating expenses. The company has also bank facilities in place for working capital requirements and has deferred asset enhancement initiatives. Despite a 70.5% fall in distribution per unit in the first quarter, CMT's net property income rose 5.9% to S$148.3 million.

site_title: Nestle upsets Fairtrade over KitKat cocoa sourcing
summary: Nestle has announced it will source cocoa for its British KitKat chocolate wafers from Rainforest Alliance-certified producers, replacing its 10-year association with Fairtrade. The move aims to harmonize its sourcing accreditation and pay more for cocoa, with a US$400 premium and a Rainforest Alliance premium of US$180 per tonne. Fairtrade criticized the decision, claiming it would cut a lifeline for poor farmers, but Nestle said it would invest in initiatives to support farmers and pay for Fairtrade farmers to certify with Rainforest Alliance.

site_title: TSH reopens two bar outlets, expects to report loss for HY2020
summary: TSH Corporation reopened two of its five bars for dine-in services, despite the COVID-19 pandemic. The company expects to report a financial loss for HY2020, with revenue declining by over 80% in April and May 2020. However, it does not foresee material impairment to its receivables and inventories, and believes it can continue as a going concern and fulfill its obligations.

site_title: IMF warns markets at risk of correction after run-up
summary: The International Monetary Fund (IMF) warned that markets for stocks and other risky assets are at risk of a correction if the coronavirus spreads more widely, lockdowns are reimposed, or trade tensions surge. Equity markets have broadly rallied from their March low, but valuations appear "stretched" and a disconnect between market optimism and the global economy has emerged. A correction could be prompted by a deeper recession, a second wave of the virus, or increased trade tensions, with high levels of corporate debt and household debt also posing risks.

site_title: Spindex to expand operations in Vietnam through JV
summary: Spindex Industries has entered a 50-50 joint venture (JV) with Acuger Precision Corporation to expand operations in Vietnam. The JV, Spindex Acuger Precision (Hanoi) Co Ltd (VietSub), aims to manufacture and trade plastic moulds, products, and related assemblies, primarily in Vietnam. The incorporation of VietSub is expected to be completed by August 2020, enabling the group to expand manufacturing capacity, leverage its supply chain and customer base, and broaden its asset and earning base.

site_title: Macy's cuts 3,900 corporate jobs in CEO's plan to shrink company
summary: Macy's announced plans to cut approximately 3,900 corporate and management jobs in an effort to reduce costs and weather the long-term effects of the Covid-19 pandemic on the retail sector. The restructuring is expected to save the company $365 million this fiscal year and $630 million annually going forward. CEO Jeff Gennette stated that the company will be a "smaller company for the foreseeable future."

images.alt_text: Macy's will cut about 3,900 corporate and management jobs to slash costs in an effort to weather the long-term effects of the Covid-19 pandemic on the reeling retail sector.

site_title: MAS proposes guidelines for financial institutions to manage environmental risk
summary: MAS proposes guidelines for financial institutions to manage environmental risk, which could impact borrowing costs and loan limits if not implemented. The guidelines require banks, insurers, and asset managers to incorporate environmental considerations into their strategies and maintain effective oversight of environmental risk management. Key requirements include developing an environmental risk-management framework, regularly reviewing its effectiveness, and allocating adequate resources to manage environmental risk. The guidelines also propose enhanced due diligence for high-risk transactions and annual disclosure of environmental risk management approaches.

site_title: Swedish expert who doubted face masks reconsiders their use
summary: Swedish state epidemiologist Anders Tegnell has reconsidered recommending face masks, citing situations where they might be necessary, such as public transport. Tegnell previously argued against widespread mask use, citing a lack of scientific evidence. However, he now acknowledges that masks "possibly" have a role in certain situations. Sweden's hands-off approach to the pandemic has been criticized, with the country having one of the world's highest Covid mortality rates. Tegnell still advocates for social distancing measures, such as working from home and avoiding public transport.

site_title: US layoffs stay high as weak demand lingers despite businesses reopening
summary: US employers continue to lay off workers due to weak demand, despite businesses reopening. Initial jobless claims totaled 1.480 million for the week ended June 20, down from 1.540 million in the prior week. Companies are hiring but cutting jobs at a similar pace, and the economy remains in recession. Economists attribute the layoffs to a lack of demand, with some businesses choosing not to maintain their workforce. The pace of decline in jobless claims has slowed, and claims are double their peak during the 2007-09 Great Recession.

site_title: STT's first benchmark size SGD perpetual of the year gets sizzling reception
summary: Singapore Technologies Telemedia (STT) has received over $2 billion in orders for its benchmark size SGD perpetual bond, priced at 4.10% from an initial price guidance of 4.375%. The deal, which will not be callable until Year 7, follows Swiss Re's S$350 million 15-year issue at 3.125% on Wednesday. The local bond market is experiencing a revival, with SGD volume down 58% year-on-year due to the Covid-19 pandemic.

site_title: Malaysia: Shares close lower on Thursday
summary: Malaysia's shares closed lower on Thursday, with the FTSE Bursa Malaysia Kuala Lumpur Composite Index down 13.43 points to 1,489.20. Losers outnumbered gainers 728 to 253, and volume was 4.495 billion lots worth RM2.488 billion.

site_title: Covid-19 case numbers expected to rise in coming weeks; community testing efforts expanded
summary: Singapore is expected to see a rise in Covid-19 cases in the coming weeks as it enters Phase Two. The government has expanded community testing efforts, including testing individuals aged 13 and above with acute respiratory infection (ARI) and frontline staff interacting with travelers. Polyclinics and public health preparedness clinics will support the testing. The government aims to test 80% of migrant workers, with around 250,000 workers expected to have recovered or been cleared by the end of July.

site_title: Great Eastern to pump US$70m into fintech Axiata Digital's expansion plans
summary: Great Eastern invests US$70 million in Axiata Digital's fintech expansion plans through a newly created holding company Boost Holdings. The investment grants Great Eastern a 21.875% stake in Boost and will fund expansion of Axiata Digital's digital financial services business in Malaysia and the region over the next year. The expansion aims to develop Boost's merchant and customer ecosystem, enhance micro-financing and micro-insurance services, and provide better protection measures for customers and merchants.

site_title: Huawei loses out in Singapore 5G bid
summary: Singapore has chosen Nokia and Ericsson as its main 5G network providers, leaving Huawei with a minor role after US pressure due to allegations of espionage and trade secret theft. Nokia will build the main 5G infrastructure, while Ericsson will build its 5G network. Huawei won a contract to provide a smaller local network system. The government insists that no company was excluded from the selection process and that there are prospects for greater involvement in the 5G system. The 5G investments are expected to run into billions of dollars, with Singapore aiming for ultra-high-speed internet coverage by 2022 and 2025.

site_title: East Ventures hits first close of US$88m fund to seed post-pandemic startups
summary: East Ventures, a Singapore-based early-stage venture capital firm, has raised US$57 million for its first close of a US$88 million fund to seed post-pandemic startups. The firm, which has backed over 170 companies, is sector-agnostic and optimistic about the future of South-east Asia's digital economy. Managing partner Willson Cuaca believes that the pandemic has created opportunities for entrepreneurs to solve problems efficiently via technology. The fund's goal is to achieve the best-performing asset class for its investors, with a focus on quickly deploying capital to fuel startups' growth.

site_title: STI falls 1.46% in line with regional markets
summary: The Straits Times Index (STI) fell 1.46% to 2,590.15 points, mirroring regional markets' decline due to fears of a Covid-19 resurgence. The Philippine central bank unexpectedly cut its benchmark interest rate to a new low to support the domestic economy. Losers outnumbered gainers 268 to 124, with real estate companies doing the worst. Jardine Matheson rose, while Singapore eDevelopment surged due to potential Covid-related medical products.

site_title: Rainy day hastens sovereign wealth funds' refocus to home
summary: Sovereign wealth funds are shifting focus to domestic investments due to the economic impact of Covid-19. State-owned entities like Singapore's Temasek Holdings are injecting funds into their countries' economies, supporting development and managing pandemic fallout. Recent deals include Turkey's $3.1 billion injection into state banks and Temasek's $1.5 billion support for Sembcorp Marine's rights issue. This trend is expected to accelerate as funds seek to mitigate economic damage.

site_title: Wirecard files for insolvency, becoming first DAX member to fail
summary: Wirecard, a German fintech company, filed for insolvency after disclosing a $2.10 billion financial hole in its accounts. The company's shares were suspended by the Frankfurt Stock Exchange, and its CEO, Markus Braun, resigned. Wirecard becomes the first sitting member of Germany's DAX blue-chip index to go out of business, with its peak worth reaching $28 billion. The Munich prosecutor's office is investigating Braun on suspicion of misrepresenting accounts and market manipulation.

site_title: David Beckham invests in e-sports with London-based startup Guild
summary: Former England soccer captain David Beckham is investing in e-sports through London-based startup Guild Esports, taking a significant minority stake in the company. Guild Esports plans to launch player academies and teams in various e-sports arenas, including Rocket League and FIFA. Beckham will be involved in shaping the coaching program and mentoring younger athletes. The company is seeking a valuation of £100 million following a £25 million fundraising. E-sports has seen a boom during the global Covid-19 lockdown, with the global market expected to generate $1.10 billion in 2020 and $1.56 billion by 2023.

site_title: Former PM Goh Chok Tong retires from politics
summary: Former Singapore Prime Minister Goh Chok Tong has decided to retire from politics, citing a loss of energy as he approaches his 80s. In a letter to Prime Minister Lee Hsien Loong, Mr. Goh expressed gratitude for his predecessor's tribute to his "calm and steady leadership" during times of crisis. Mr. Goh has served as an MP for Marine Parade for over four decades and will not stand in the upcoming General Election.

site_title: Southern Alliance Mining to debut on Catalist board
summary: Southern Alliance Mining (SAM), a Malaysia-based iron ore producer, is set to debut as a Catalist-listed counter on the Singapore bourse on Friday. The company's initial public offering (IPO) was fully subscribed, with 76 million shares priced at S$0.25 each, generating S$19 million in application monies. The IPO comprised 56 million new shares and 20 million vendor shares, representing 15.5% of SAM's enlarged post-IPO share capital of 489 million shares.

site_title: Philippine central bank unexpectedly cuts interest rates by 50 basis points
summary: The Philippine central bank unexpectedly cut its benchmark interest rate by 50 basis points to 2.25%, its new low, to support the economy ravaged by the coronavirus. This is the fourth rate cut this year, totaling 175 basis points since February. The move was contrary to expectations of economists, with only four out of 12 forecasting a 25 basis point cut. The rate reductions aim to stimulate the economy and combat the effects of the pandemic.

site_title: WP unveils first four candidates, including Nicole Seah and Yee Jenn Jong
summary: The Workers' Party (WP) has unveiled its first four candidates for the upcoming Singapore General Election, including Nicole Seah and Yee Jenn Jong. The party plans to contest in two single-seat wards and four Group Representation Constituencies. Nicole Seah, a 33-year-old associate director, is returning to politics to promote balance in Parliament, while Yee Jenn Jong, an education entrepreneur, aims to bring competition to the ruling party. The other two candidates, Louis Chua and Muhammad Azhar Abdul Latip, are volunteers who have been involved in grassroots and parliamentary work.

site_title: ECB to provide euro loans to non euro zone central banks
summary: The European Central Bank (ECB) announced a new euro loan facility to provide liquidity to non-euro zone central banks, aiming to backstop funding markets amid the pandemic. The Eurosystem repo facility will offer euro loans against collateral until June 2021, complementing existing bilateral swap and repo lines. This move aims to support global financial stability and promote euro area economic growth.

images.alt_text: The European Central Bank will offer euro loans against collateral to central bank outside the euro area to backstop funding markets amid the coronavirus pandemic.

site_title: Gilead's remdesivir endorsed as first Covid-19 treatment in Europe
summary: The European Medicines Agency (EMA) has recommended the conditional approval of Gilead Sciences' remdesivir as the first Covid-19 treatment in Europe, for use in adults and adolescents with pneumonia requiring oxygen support. The approval follows a review of the treatment's efficacy and safety. The price of the drug in Europe is yet to be determined, with estimates ranging from $66.13 to $79.35 in India, compared to $5,080 in the US.

images.alt_text: The European healthcare regulator has recommended the conditional approval of Gilead Sciences' antiviral treatment, remdesivir, for use in Covid-19 patients, making it the first treatment to be on track to be green-lit in the continent.

site_title: US House poised for vote on Democratic police reform bill
summary: The US House of Representatives is set to vote on a Democratic police reform bill, which has been backed by the Congressional Black Caucus but opposed by President Donald Trump and Republicans in Congress. The bill aims to address issues such as police brutality, excessive force, and training to de-escalate confrontations. Despite bipartisan support for reform, the bill's passage is uncertain due to Republican opposition, which claims the legislation could undermine law enforcement. The outcome of the vote is expected to be along party lines.

site_title: New Zealand refiner to shrink, may convert to import terminal in face of competition
summary: New Zealand's only oil refinery, Marsden Point, may shut down and be converted into a fuel import terminal due to intense competition from Asian mega refineries and rising costs. Refining NZ aims to reduce operations and break even by 2021, citing a "fee floor" from key customers to protect revenue. The refinery's gross margin collapsed to $0.67 per barrel, prompting the company to consider alternative plans. A conversion to an import terminal would allow Refining NZ to focus on more competitive markets and discuss fuel security with the government.

site_title: Hong Leong Finance reopens more branches, SME centres, encourages going digital
summary: Hong Leong Finance has reopened six branches and two SME centres in Singapore, with a total of 14 branches and seven SME centres set to open by Monday. The company encourages customers to continue using digital services to minimize non-essential visits. The reopened branches and SME centres will offer safe-distancing measures, including designated ambassadors and separate queues for elderly and vulnerable customers. Customers can access fixed-deposit services through online forms and alternative payment options like PayNow and Giro.

site_title: Australia tech titans to build world's tallest 'hybrid timber' tower in Sydney
summary: Australia's tech giant Atlassian will build the world's tallest "hybrid timber" tower in Sydney, standing at 180 meters. The 40-storey building will be constructed using Mass Timber Construction, featuring a glass and steel facade with solar panels and self-shading windows. Construction is set to start in 2024 and be completed by 2025, with the tower housing 4,000 staff and forming a new tech precinct in central Sydney. The building will operate on 100% renewable energy, aiming to lower its carbon footprint.

site_title: easyJet bolsters cash by raising £419m in share sale
summary: easyJet raised £419m in a share sale, increasing its cash reserves to over £3 billion. The sale, which accounts for 15% of its existing share base, was priced at 703pence per share, a 5% discount from the previous day's closing price. The move aims to strengthen the airline's balance sheet and increase liquidity as the European aviation sector recovers from the pandemic lockdown.

site_title: Tennis: Murray confident will play at high level again
summary: Andy Murray, the former world number one, expressed confidence in returning to the highest level of tennis despite a seven-month layoff due to hip problems. Murray won his first competitive match since the Davis Cup Finals in November, beating Liam Broady, before losing to Kyle Edmund in the 'Battle of the Brits' event. Murray focused on his health, saying he's not bothered by the results and hopes his hip is okay after the match.

site_title: Royal Mail slashes management jobs as virus hits postal demand
summary: Royal Mail plans to cut 2,000 management jobs, or 40%, to streamline its business after the coronavirus outbreak accelerated a decline in letter volumes. The move aims to reduce costs by £500 million over the next two years. Despite a boost in home parcels deliveries, business-to-business mailings have slumped, and the company expects the main UK parcels division to be "materially loss-making" in fiscal 2021. The company also plans to accelerate operational changes and revisit its universal service obligation.

site_title: Lufthansa shares soar after major shareholder backs bailout plan
summary: Lufthansa shares surged 10% after major shareholder Heinz Hermann Thiele backed the airline's 9 billion euro bailout plan. Thiele, who owns 15.5% of the airline, had previously objected to the plan, but changed his stance after talks with the German government. The bailout package, which includes a 20% stake and board seats, aims to rescue the airline from the COVID-19 pandemic's impact. The move brings relief to Lufthansa, which has been struggling due to a protracted travel slump.

site_title: Daily Debrief: What Happened Today
summary: Former Singapore Prime Minister Goh Chok Tong has retired from politics, citing a loss of energy as he approaches his 80s. Singtel Optus has priced A$350m and A$500m notes for issuance on July 1. Construction firm Koh Brothers Group has sold 22% of its luxury residence Van Holland units. Circles.Life has partnered AXA Insurance to offer insurance coverage to its users. The Straits Times Index (STI) fell 1.46% to 2,590.15.

images.alt_text: IN his letter to Prime Minister Lee Hsien Loong, the former prime minister and member of parliament (MP) for Marine Parade GRC said that despite many urging him to stand for another term, he "would not have the same energy when I cross into my 80s".

site_title: Maersk heads zero-carbon drive in shipping sector with US$60m research centre
summary: AP Moller-Maersk, the world's largest container shipper, is launching a $84.2 million research centre in Denmark to develop carbon-neutral fuel and technologies, aiming to reduce emissions in the shipping industry. The centre, set to employ 100 people, will combine industry, academia, and regulator knowledge to achieve "decarbonising" the industry by 2030, in line with the shipping industry's pledge to have zero carbon emissions. Maersk aims to be carbon-neutral by 2050.

site_title: Europe: Stocks tumble on concerns over recovery
summary: European shares plummeted 1.1% on Thursday due to concerns over global economic recovery, with travel and leisure, bank, and oil and gas stocks leading the decline. A surge in coronavirus cases and worries over a fresh trade dispute between the US and EU also contributed to the downturn. However, Lufthansa shares surged after a major shareholder agreed to endorse a €9 billion state bailout, lifting the Stoxx 600 to its lowest since June 15.

site_title: Mizuho shareholders reject first climate motion put to a Japanese company
summary: Mizuho Financial Group shareholders rejected a climate motion at the bank's annual general meeting, with over 35% of votes submitted in favor. The proposal, backed by Nordic funds, aimed to rein in the bank's financing for coal projects in Asia, but fell short of the required two-thirds majority. The outcome, seen as a "strong signal" to Mizuho to exit coal finance, is similar to previous shareholder resolutions that have led banks worldwide to stop financing coal and fossil fuels.

images.alt_text: Shareholders in Mizuho Financial Group on Thursday rejected a motion for it to align its business to the Paris Agreement, the global pact to fight climate change and its effects.

site_title: Tokyo: Nikkei closes down more than 1.2%
summary: Tokyo's benchmark Nikkei index fell 1.22% to 22,259.79, closing down over 1.2% on Thursday, amidst worries over resurgent coronavirus infections and rising US virus cases. European and US stock markets also plunged, with the US government considering new taxes on European imports. The International Monetary Fund predicted the global economy would contract by 4.9% this year, hitting investor sentiment.

site_title: WP's Low Thia Khiang, Chen Show Mao, Png Eng Huat not contesting GE2020
summary: Singapore's Workers' Party (WP) leaders Low Thia Khiang, Chen Show Mao, and Png Eng Huat will not contest in the upcoming General Election (GE2020), citing the need to broaden the party's leadership base and contribute in a different capacity. The party's secretary-general, Pritam Singh, stated that the trio's decision is not a retirement, but rather a strategic move to mentor and train new leaders. The party has announced its lineup for the election, including former Non-Constituency MPs Gerald Giam and Leon Perera.

site_title: Singaporeans First party dissolves
summary: Singaporeans First party, founded by Tan Jee Say, has dissolved itself in favor of opposition unity and consolidation. The party redirected its members to other parties, including Progress Singapore Party and Singapore People's Party. Tan Jee Say stated that a strong opposition is best achieved through consolidation, and the party's dissolution is in the best interests of Singapore. Members are encouraged to join other parties that reflect their values and beliefs.

site_title: Legal tussles snarl millions in oil from Hin Leong deals
summary: Millions of dollars of oil stored in Asia and Europe have become entangled in lawsuits related to trade and financing deals by Singapore's Hin Leong Trading. Hin Leong obtained financing for non-existent oil cargoes, complicating claims of ownership. The company, under judicial management, owes $3.8 billion to 23 banks. A report found Hin Leong's total oil inventory was $212 million, less than a third of the amount owed. The sale of some inventory is planned to minimize costs, with ownership to be determined, a process expected to take significant time.

site_title: BRI Ventures launches VC fund targeting Indonesian tech startups
summary: BRI Ventures, a corporate venture capital firm under Indonesia's state-owned bank BRI, has launched a locally incorporated venture fund called Sembrani Nusantara to invest in Indonesian tech startups. The fund aims to invest $29.4 million and focuses on startups in education, agro-maritime, retail, transportation, and healthcare sectors. It prioritizes "value over valuation" and targets companies with good business fundamentals, aiming to support sustainable growth in the local economy.

site_title: PSP presents five more candidates, including two ex-military officers
summary: The Progress Singapore Party (PSP) has announced five new candidates for the 2020 Singapore General Election, including two former military officers, Michael Chua and Nadarajah Loganathan. The candidates advocate for job opportunities, support for small businesses, and attention to disadvantaged groups. They also emphasize the need for systemic changes, including a review of the Ministry of Manpower's labour force structure and increased support for the destitute elderly. PSP is contesting eight constituencies and will unveil its final six candidates on Friday.

site_title: Australia: Shares end lower as virus surge trumps recovery optimism
summary: Australian shares fell 2.5% on Thursday, snapping a four-day winning streak, as concerns about a resurgence of coronavirus cases derailed economic recovery optimism. The S&P/ASX 200 index reached its worst session since June 12, following a global surge in Covid-19 infections and a record rise in Australian cases. The global tally of Covid-19 infections surpassed 9.33 million, with the US posting its second-largest increase in cases since the crisis began.

site_title: 12 places, including 313@somerset, VivoCity and Bugis Junction, among those visited by Covid-19 patients
summary: Twelve locations in Singapore, including 313@somerset, VivoCity, and Bugis Junction, are among places visited by Covid-19 patients over 30 minutes. The Ministry of Health (MOH) is monitoring the health of individuals who visited these locations for two weeks. Five new community cases were announced, including a 50-year-old Singaporean man and four work pass holders, aged 35-42. The total number of confirmed cases in Singapore is now 42,736, with 113 new cases and 108 migrant workers in dormitories.

site_title: Some countries using virus curbs to 'silence critics', ex-leaders warn
