summary: Former leaders, Nobel laureates, and lawmakers warn that the COVID-19 pandemic has led to a surge in authoritarian behavior by governments worldwide, posing a threat to democracy. Over 80 countries have enacted emergency measures, including curfews, surveillance, and censorship, to silence critics and tighten their grip on power. The measures have diluted democratic norms, impacting political freedom and the ability of governments to handle future health emergencies. The warning comes from 500 signatories, including over 60 former leaders, who urge citizens to defend democracy and its values.

images.alt_text: For the signatories, including Fernando Henrique Cardoso, the former president of Brazil, and Jeb Bush, the former governor of Florida, a fundamental concern is that citizens begin to accept more authoritarian behaviour.

site_title: Hot stock: Yoma up 6.7% on proposed Wave Money deal
summary: Yoma Strategic's shares surged 6.7% to S$0.32 on Thursday after the company announced a proposed US$76.5 million deal to acquire a controlling stake in mobile payments firm Digital Money Myanmar (Wave Money). The deal would see Yoma Strategic take a majority stake in Wave Money, with existing shareholders including Norwegian telecommunications giant Telenor group and Yoma Strategic's wholly-owned subsidiary. The acquisition is expected to boost Yoma Strategic's presence in the mobile payments market.

site_title: DBS prices Swiss Re's S$350m 15-year notes at 3.125%
summary: DBS Bank priced Swiss Re's S$350 million 15-year subordinated notes at 3.125% per annum, with a coupon reset after the first optional redemption date and five years thereafter. The notes carry a non-call five-year feature, and mature on July 3, 2035. Over S$1.4 billion in investor interest was recorded across 85 accounts, with Singaporeans making up 75% of orders. The notes are guaranteed by Swiss Re, rated A2 by Moody's and A by S&P.

site_title: GE quick takes: Workers' Party to contest four GRCs, two SMCs; more candidates unveiled
summary: Singapore will hold its general election on July 10, with 93 seats up for contest in 31 constituencies. The Workers' Party (WP) has announced its lineup, contesting four group representation constituencies and two single-member constituencies, while the People's Action Party (PAP) has introduced three batches of new candidates. The Progress Singapore Party (PSP) has also presented five candidates, and the Peoples Voice party will contest five constituencies. The election comes as Emeritus Senior Minister Goh Chok Tong decides not to stand, and former Workers' Party chief Low Thia Khiang and two senior members have also decided not to contest.

site_title: Snapchat parent to open Singapore office later this year
summary: Snap Inc., the parent company of Snapchat, plans to open a Singapore office later this year. The move is contingent on the easing of the Covid-19 pandemic. The company has already made its first hire in Singapore, appointing Anubhav Nayyar as director of South-east Asia market development. Once the office is established, it will be part of the international markets team, led by Nana Murugesan.

images.alt_text: California-based Snap Inc, which created multimedia messaging app Snapchat, is set to open a Singapore office later this year.
Anubhav Nayyar, who is appointed director of South-east Asia market development, will be part of the international markets team.

site_title: Seoul: Shares end 2.3% lower as second wave dents risk appetite
summary: Seoul's Kospi stock market closed 2.27% lower on Thursday due to a surge in coronavirus cases and the International Monetary Fund's downgrade to global economic projections. The decline was also influenced by the government's proposal to expand capital gains taxes. Meanwhile, several US states reported record increases in Covid-19 cases, and the World Health Organization expects the global case count to reach 10 million next week.

site_title: Documentary on Hong Kong protests deletes scene after anthem law
summary: A documentary about Hong Kong's pro-democracy movement has deleted a scene featuring a dissident artist playing China's national anthem after a law was passed criminalizing "insults" to the revolutionary song. The law, which carries up to three years in jail and a fine, aims to curb artistic creativity in semi-autonomous Hong Kong. The director of the documentary, Evans Chan, removed the scene after distributors warned they might face legal problems. The move illustrates how the new law is curtailing artistic freedom in Hong Kong, where a "One Country, Two Systems" deal has allowed for autonomy for 50 years.

site_title: Wirecard whistle-blower tipped German watchdog in early 2019
summary: Germany's financial watchdog BaFin took over a year to report Wirecard for suspected market manipulation after receiving a tip-off from a whistle-blower in January 2019. The regulator initially focused on containing damage by banning investors from betting against the stock, and it wasn't until auditors weighed in earlier this year that they could investigate Wirecard. BaFin's head, Felix Mr Hufeld, apologized for the regulator's inadequate supervision, stating it was responsible for the "complete disaster" at Wirecard. The watchdog received documents from an anonymous source and had information early on casting doubt on the company, but did not disclose it until now.

site_title: PAP introduces its third batch of new candidates for GE 2020
summary: Deputy Prime Minister Heng Swee Keat has unveiled the third batch of new People's Action Party (PAP) candidates for the 2020 General Election. The four candidates come from modest backgrounds and have made significant contributions to society in areas like healthcare and digitalization. They are Ng Ling Ling, Tan See Leng, Zhulkarnain Abdul Rahim, and Tan Kiat How, who aim to serve and create a better future for Singapore.

site_title: Chuck E Cheese parent files for bankruptcy, another casualty of pandemic
summary: CEC Entertainment, the parent company of Chuck E Cheese, filed for Chapter 11 bankruptcy due to the COVID-19 pandemic's devastating impact on the entertainment industry. The company listed assets and liabilities in the range of $1 billion to $10 billion and plans to continue talks with stakeholders and restructure its balance sheet. As of June 25, 266 locations have reopened, with plans to maintain operations during the bankruptcy process. CEC Entertainment has 612 Chuck E Cheese and 122 Peter Piper Pizza venues globally.

site_title: Google tightens privacy settings for new users
summary: Google has begun auto-deleting new users' search data and location history after 18 months, a move aimed at tightening privacy settings. CEO Sundar Pichai announced the change in a blog post, citing the need to "keep less data by default." This tweak follows hefty fines levied against Google and Facebook for privacy violations. The move is part of the tech giant's efforts to boost public trust after recent privacy issues.

site_title: Association of Banks in Singapore's annual dinner set to be postponed
summary: The Association of Banks in Singapore's annual dinner, typically held in June, has been postponed due to the Covid-19 crisis and safe distancing measures. The event, where major banking announcements are made, will be rescheduled when large-scale events are allowed under government directives. The Monetary Authority of Singapore had announced plans to issue up to five new digital banking licenses, but the announcement has been delayed until the end of the year. The ABS's virtual annual general meeting will proceed as scheduled.

site_title: Banyan Tree to open farm, restaurant in Thailand with The Boutique Farmers
summary: Banyan Tree Group has formed a joint venture with Thai sustainable growers The Boutique Farmers to develop a gourmet organic farm and restaurant in Chiang Mai, Thailand. The farm, named ORI9IN, will be open to the public in October and features 350 acres of land, a community garden, and rental spaces for specific ingredients. The farm aims to focus on import substitution and lower carbon footprint, with a zero-waste kitchen and locally sourced ingredients. The project is part of Banyan Tree's efforts to champion local procurement and sustainably sourced food.

site_title: Japan confirms scrapping US missile defence system
summary: Japan has scrapped the deployment of a multibillion-dollar US anti-missile system, the Aegis Ashore, after local residents expressed concerns about the risks posed by the system. The decision reverses the government's previous suspension and comes under pressure from residents in two regions where interceptors were to be placed. The government cited concerns for public safety as the reason for the reversal, but the decision has been met with criticism from some quarters, highlighting the complexities of balancing national security with local concerns.

images.alt_text: "The National Security Council discussed this matter and reached a conclusion that the deployment of Aegis Ashore in Akita and Yamaguchi is to be rescinded," Defence Minister Taro Kono told a meeting of the ruling Liberal Democratic Party.

site_title: Asia: Equities sink as virus spikes fuel worries over reopening
summary: Asian equities plummeted as a surge in virus infections worldwide fueled concerns over a potential trade reopening. The International Monetary Fund warned of a global economic outlook, while a possible US-EU trade battle added to the downturn. Despite a 0.4% gain for the STI, investors remain cautious due to tariff uncertainty and split Federal Reserve views.

site_title: Social mobility, community issues close to hearts of 4th group of new PAP candidates
summary: The People's Action Party (PAP) has introduced four new candidates for the upcoming Singapore general election, focusing on social and community issues. The candidates, including former civil servant Eric Chua Swee Leong, Republic Polytechnic lecturer Dr Wan Rizal Wan Zakariah, social entrepreneur Yeo Wan Ling, and LinkedIn head Alvin Tan Sheng Hui, aim to address social mobility, education, caregiving, and racial harmony. The PAP will unveil the rest of its 26 new candidates on Friday, following introductory sessions on Wednesday and Thursday.

site_title: Trump admin defends defunding Covid testing in Texas, four other states
summary: The Trump administration has defended its decision to end direct funding for 13 COVID-19 testing sites in five states, including Texas, as the sites were deemed "antiquated." The sites, which were part of a 41-site program, will lose funding on June 30. US Assistant Secretary for Health Admiral Brett Giroir stated that thousands of testing options remain available and the states can use the $10 billion allocated to support testing. The decision has been met with criticism, with President Trump previously lamenting the rising US coronavirus cases and seeking to increase testing.

site_title: Broker's take: RHB upgrades SGX to 'buy' on robust trading volumes, further rises expected
summary: RHB upgraded its rating on the Singapore Exchange (SGX) to "buy" from "neutral", raising its target price to S$9.20 due to strong securities average daily value (SADV) and expected trading increases. Analyst Leng Seng Choon forecasts a 6% increase in FY21 net profit to S$415 million, driven by a 4% yield and economic recovery from COVID-19. However, a prolonged pandemic may lead to declining trading volumes.

site_title: Circles.Life makes foray into financial services with AXA Insurance tie-up
summary: Circles.Life, a Singapore-based digital telco, has partnered with AXA Insurance to offer personal accident insurance plans to its users. Existing customers can purchase the LifeSaver Personal Accident Insurance for as low as S$8 for 30 days of coverage. The insurance plan covers up to S$100,000 in accidental death or permanent disability, medical expenses, and home modification expenses. This marks Circles.Life's first foray into financial services, following a staff reduction of less than 5% in November 2019.

site_title: Virus-free Vietnam not ready to open doors to foreign tourists yet: PM
summary: Vietnam's Prime Minister Nguyen Xuan Phuc stated that the country is not ready to open its doors to foreign tourists due to concerns of a second wave of Covid-19 infections. Despite containing the outbreak with 352 cases, mostly recovered, Phuc emphasized the need for caution. The government prioritizes its citizens' safety and will not rush to open tourism. Vietnam's successful testing and quarantine program has been credited for controlling the outbreak.

site_title: Singapore law firms urged to tap government's traineeship programme
summary: Singapore's law firms are encouraged to participate in the SGUnited Traineeships Programme, which has been extended to the legal sector. The programme offers practice training contracts for law graduates, paralegals, and legal secretaries, aiming to boost employability, support professional development, and meet practice training requirements to become a Singapore Bar member.

site_title: Singtel, Nets introduce in-app payment for telco's prepaid users
summary: Singtel and Nets have introduced in-app payment for Singtel's prepaid users through Nets Click, allowing customers to make digital top-ups and purchase data plans and services directly on their mobile devices using their Nets ATM bank cards. This contactless payment option simplifies the payment process and provides a safe digital alternative, especially given the COVID-19 measures. There are no transaction fees for using Nets Click on Singtel's hi!App for top-ups, and the telco's prepaid customers can use this service after a one-time sign-up.

site_title: Shipping, aviation 2030 climate goals too weak, research finds
summary: Research by Climate Action Tracker found that shipping and aviation sectors' 2030 climate targets are too weak, with emissions on track to reach dangerous levels despite the COVID-19 pandemic. The sectors, which accounted for 5% of global emissions before the pandemic, are expected to contribute 40% by 2050. The shipping industry is likely to exceed its 2030 target, and ships powered by liquefied natural gas will not support a transition to zero CO2 emissions. The sectors' emissions are forecast to double or triple over the 2015-2050 period.

site_title: Eiffel Tower reopens with strict virus restrictions
summary: The Eiffel Tower in Paris reopened on June 25, 2020, after a three-month closure due to the coronavirus pandemic. Visitors can now ascend the stairs, but the lifts will remain closed until July 1. The top level of the tower will also remain closed. Face masks are mandatory for all visitors over 11, and limited visitor numbers will be allowed to ensure social distancing. The tower's reopening marks a gradual return to tourism in France, which has taken a hit from the pandemic.

images.alt_text: Tourists and Parisians will from Thursday again be able to admire the view of the French capital from the Eiffel Tower after a three-month closure due to the coronavirus -- but only if they take the stairs.

site_title: China taps World Bank official for US-facing finance post: sources
summary: China has appointed Yang Yingming, a World Bank official, to head the Finance Ministry's international cooperation department, focusing on US-China trade talks and G-20 coordination. Yang, who has experience in international finance, returns to China after a Phase One trade agreement with the US. The appointment reflects Beijing's efforts to maintain engagement and prevent ties from worsening amidst ongoing bilateral tensions. This move may signal a continued willingness to negotiate with the US, rather than decoupling.

site_title: Italy's 5G stumbles after a shining start
summary: Italy's 5G rollout has stalled due to high costs and bureaucratic hurdles. The country's auction in 2018 raised over $10.2 billion, but operators are facing sharp drops in profitability and difficulties in obtaining permits. The slow pace is also fueled by fake news and concerns over 5G safety. Despite this, some operators, such as Telecom Italia, have launched 5G services in select cities, with plans to expand coverage by 2025/2026. Experts suggest that the rollout could resume in 2021 if the government provides tax incentives and reduces regulatory barriers.

images.alt_text: A row over whether Chinese telecom giant Huawei, the world's largest supplier of telecom network equipment, could pose a risk to 5G security in the West has been largely absent in Italy.

site_title: Koh Bros says Van Holland units 22% sold; KBEE unit spin-off gets SGX nod
summary: Koh Brothers Group (KBG) has sold 22% of its Van Holland luxury residence units, with 15 out of 69 units sold as of Wednesday. The group expects a negative impact on its business due to the Covid-19 pandemic. Meanwhile, KBEE has received approval from the Singapore Exchange (SGX) for its proposed spin-off of Oiltek, with shares trading flat. KBG has reduced its proposed dividend to 0.25 cents, while KBEE has reduced its dividend to 0.02 cents. Both companies have implemented cost-cutting measures amid the pandemic.

site_title: SoftBank CEO says equity value back at pre-virus levels
summary: SoftBank Group CEO Masayoshi Son stated that the equity value of the group's holdings has recovered to pre-coronavirus levels. This recovery is attributed to the growth of SoftBank's stake in Alibaba Group and the successful merger of its US wireless unit with T-Mobile US. The company has undertaken a $35 billion asset sale program, allocating funds to share buybacks and increasing financial leeway. Son defended his investing reputation, saying the group's complex transactions aim to increase shareholder value.

site_title: US coronavirus infections soar to near record in 24 hours
summary: The US has seen a surge in coronavirus infections, with over 35,900 new cases reported in the past 24 hours, bringing the total to nearly 2.4 million. This marks a near-record daily level of infections, with nearly half of the 50 US states experiencing an increase in cases over the past two weeks. Additionally, 756 people have died of Covid-19 in the past 24 hours, bringing the global death toll to 121,932 in the US.

site_title: India reinforces flashpoint area as China holds ground: sources
summary: India has reinforced its presence in a flashpoint Himalayan region following China's takeover of contested territory after a deadly brawl on June 15, leaving 20 Indian soldiers dead. Indian fighter jets conducted a show of strength, and troops were deployed along the border. Despite public declarations of a pullback, both countries maintain troops in the area, with China claiming the valley as its own. Indian analysts doubt a major easing of tensions, and there is recognition on both sides that their economies need each other, despite a potential public backlash against China.

site_title: Australia: Shares fall on second virus wave fears, New Zealand drops over 1%
summary: Australian shares fell 1.8% on Thursday, marking their lowest level in over a week, due to fears of a second coronavirus wave and economic recovery. The S&P/ASX 200 index is down 10.75% this year. New Zealand's benchmark index also dropped 1.08% amid concerns over healthcare stocks. The International Monetary Fund warned of wider economic damage from the pandemic. Qantas Airways plans to axe 20% of its workforce and raise $1.3 billion to respond to the crisis.

site_title: Singapore shares fall at open, tracking Wall Street retreat; STI down 1%
summary: Singapore's Straits Times Index (STI) fell 1% or 25.05 points to 2,603.57 at 9:03am, tracking overnight losses on Wall Street. The decline was attributed to worries over resurgent coronavirus infections dampening investor optimism for economic recovery. Losers outnumbered gainers 117 to 33, with 82.8 million securities worth S$97.7 million changing hands.

site_title: Qantas to cut 6,000 jobs and raise US$1.3b due to virus outbreak
summary: Qantas Airways plans to cut at least 20% of its workforce, approximately 6,000 positions, and raise up to A$1.90 billion in equity due to the coronavirus crisis. The airline will also ground 100 aircraft for up to 12 months and retire its remaining Boeing 747 fleet six months ahead of schedule. Qantas aims to become a smaller airline in the short term, with CEO Alan Joyce agreeing to stay on until at least June 2023.

site_title: Darkened duty-free shops are fuelling a worldwide chocolate glut
summary: The global chocolate market is experiencing a glut due to a decline in duty-free sales, exacerbated by the COVID-19 pandemic and travel restrictions. With fewer airline passengers and cancelled events, chocolate sales are expected to drop, leading to a surplus of over 300,000 tons. Top chocolate makers face pressure on margins, and some analysts predict bigger declines in global grindings. The International Monetary Fund has also lowered its outlook for the world economy, signaling a further hit to cocoa consumption.

site_title: South Korea widens capital gains taxes for wealthy stock investors
summary: South Korea proposed expanding capital gains taxes to include 300,000 affluent stock investors, affecting the top 5% of all stock investors, starting in 2023. The taxes will range from 0.15% to 25% on annual capital gains exceeding 20 million won. The move aims to reduce inequality by taxing the wealthy more and general share traders less. The government plans to lower transaction taxes for retail investors to 0.15% from 0.25%. The proposal needs parliamentary approval, which is expected to pass given the ruling party's majority in the National Assembly.

site_title: EU says concerned at threat of fresh US tariffs
summary: The European Commission expressed concern over a US threat to impose up to $3.1 billion in tariffs on European imports due to a dispute over Boeing and Airbus subsidies. The US Trade Representative document listed products from France, Germany, Spain, and Britain, which could lead to "very damaging" economic consequences. The EU has threatened its own tariffs on Boeing, but the Commission sees this as an opportunity to defuse tensions, which could escalate into a larger trade war.

site_title: DBS, ComfortDelGro Taxi in strategic payments partnership
summary: DBS Bank and ComfortDelGro Taxi have partnered to enhance payment services for Singapore customers. Users can now book and pay for ComfortDelGro taxi rides on DBS's PayLah! platform in-app. The move aims to encourage customers to switch to in-app payments to help stop the spread of Covid-19.

site_title: Metro H2 profit plunges 81.9% to S$11.3m on lower revenue
summary: Metro Holdings reported a 81.9% plunge in net profit to S$11.3m for the half year ended March 31, 2020, due to lower revenue from its retail division. Revenue fell 14.6% to S$81.5m, with the retail segment experiencing a 33.9% drop in sales. The property division saw a 42.3% increase in revenue, driven by the sale of property rights. A final cash dividend of two Singapore cents per share was recommended for the full year.

site_title: Global housing markets ensnared by pandemic's high unemployment: poll
summary: A majority of analysts polled by Reuters expect major global housing markets to remain subdued due to high unemployment from the pandemic and lockdowns. The outlook is further complicated by low immigration and a slow economic rebound. Average home prices in countries such as Australia, India, and the US are forecast to fall this year and next under a worst-case scenario, with some experts predicting a 5% drop. The main risk to the housing market is unemployment, which is expected to remain above pre-Covid levels until at least 2022.

site_title: GNC files bankruptcy to manage debt with plan to sell itself
summary: GNC Holdings, a health and wellness company, filed for Chapter 11 bankruptcy protection to manage its debt load amid the coronavirus pandemic. The company plans to sell itself and close hundreds of under-performing stores, with a potential buyer and affiliate of its largest shareholder, Harbin Pharmaceutical Group Holding, agreeing to an initial bidding price of $760 million. GNC expects to confirm a standalone plan of reorganization or complete a sale by the fall, with support from lenders and stakeholders. The company will seek to close at least 800 to 1,200 stores as part of its restructuring.

site_title: Japan's izakayas, once a staple of after-work socialising, crippled by pandemic
summary: Japan's izakayas, once a staple of after-work socializing, are struggling to survive due to the pandemic. Lockdown measures have forced many establishments to halve their seating, leading to a significant decline in customer numbers. Small izakayas like those run by Hitoshi Yaosaka have seen customer numbers return to only a third of their pre-pandemic levels, with some fearing the culture may die down. The government has not given a timeframe for how long restrictions will last, and experts warn that consumption may take a long time to return to pre-pandemic levels, potentially prolonging Japan's recession.

site_title: Canada loses AAA rating as Fitch flags high debt level
summary: Canada lost its AAA debt rating due to Fitch's downgrade, citing a deteriorating fiscal position amid the coronavirus pandemic. The country's gross government debt is expected to surge to 115% of GDP this year, and Fitch warns of rising risk of federal government support for provinces. The IMF projects Canada's economy to contract by 8.4% this year.

site_title: CapitaLand rolls out tech solutions at business parks, offices in Singapore
summary: CapitaLand, a Singaporean property giant, is rolling out digital solutions at its business parks and offices to help tenants cope with the "new normal" as staff return to work in Phase Two's reopening. The CapitaStar@Work app allows for staff and visitor contact tracing, near real-time data retrieval, and health and wellness surveys. The company is also introducing contactless technology, disinfection procedures, and a food ordering platform, Capita3Eats. This move aims to provide attractive rates for bulk purchase of work area sanitisation services and enhance tenant experience.

images.alt_text: Capitaland has installed facial recognition or QR activated turnstiles at its business parks and offices to enhance contactless access and reduce touch points, while facilitating seamless and secure access in and out of buildings.

site_title: Trump administration says Huawei, Hikvision backed by Chinese military: document
summary: The Trump administration has determined that top Chinese firms, including Huawei Technologies, Hikvision, and China Mobile Communications Group, are owned or controlled by the Chinese military, according to a document. This finding lays the groundwork for new US financial sanctions. The list of 20 companies allegedly backed by the Chinese military also includes Aviation Industry Corp of China and China Telecommunications Corp. This move follows Washington's previous placement of Huawei on a trade blacklist due to national security concerns.

site_title: Stocks to watch: CapitaLand, Koh Brothers, Darco Water, Metro, Suntec Reit
summary: Key developments in the Singapore stock market on Thursday include CapitaLand rolling out digital solutions to help tenants cope with the "new normal" amid staff returns to work. Koh Brothers Group sold 22% of its luxury residence Van Holland, expecting a negative impact on its full-year financials due to the pandemic. Meanwhile, shares of Darco Water, Metro, and Suntec Reit were not mentioned in the article.

images.alt_text: The property giant on Thursday said it is rolling out digital solutions at its Singapore business parks and offices to help tenants cope with the "new normal" as their staff return to work during Phase Two of the nation's reopening. Shares of CapitaLand ended Wednesday at S$2.90, down S$0.02 or 0.7 per cent.

site_title: Tokyo: Stocks open lower on Thursday
summary: Tokyo stocks opened lower on Thursday, with the Nikkei 225 index losing 1.06% to 22,295.37, and the Topix index down 0.98% to 1,565.75. This follows European and US stock markets' decline due to concerns over resurgent coronavirus infections.

site_title: Budget carrier Jetstar Asia to cut a quarter of its mainly Singaporean workforce
summary: Jetstar Asia, a budget carrier, is cutting 26% of its workforce, approximately 180 people, in July due to the COVID-19 pandemic's impact on the aviation industry. The airline will reduce its workforce by up to 6,000 people across all roles as part of Qantas Group's post-COVID-19 recovery plan. The airline will also retire five Airbus A320 aircraft and let go of 220 pilots. Despite the cuts, Jetstar Asia remains committed to its low-cost model and is looking forward to growing passenger numbers in the future.

site_title: France plans to pare terms of work scheme designed to boost activity
summary: France is planning to modify its reduced-time work scheme, set up during the coronavirus crisis, to prevent mass permanent layoffs. The updated scheme will reduce workers' pay to 60% of normal wages from October, down from 70%, while the state will reimburse employers up to 60% of costs. A new, longer-term program will allow companies to reduce employees' work by up to 40% and receive up to 85% reimbursement. The government did not disclose the cost of the extended reduced-work scheme. Unions generally welcomed the changes, but some expressed concerns about job security.

images.alt_text: The French government laid out plans on Wednesday to rein in from October a reduced-time work scheme set up during the coronavirus crisis to prevent mass permanent layoffs.

site_title: Appeals court orders charges dropped against ex-Trump aide Flynn
summary: A US federal appeals court has ordered the charges against former White House national security advisor Michael Flynn to be dropped, a decision that has been praised by the Trump administration but criticized by Democrats as a politicized move by Attorney General Bill Barr. Flynn had pleaded guilty to lying about his Russian contacts, but Barr intervened to withdraw the charges, citing a lack of legitimacy in the investigation. The decision has sparked outrage within the justice community and has been added to a list of examples by Democrats alleging Barr is corruptly aiding Trump politically.

site_title: Australia deploys 1,000 troops to Melbourne virus outbreak
summary: Australia deploys 1,000 troops to Melbourne to help contain the country's only significant coronavirus outbreak, which has seen a spike in cases over the past week. The deployment, led by Defence Minister Linda Reynolds, aims to monitor returned international travellers, provide logistical and medical support, and alleviate community concerns. The move comes as Victoria state has seen new clusters emerge, including in large family groups and at a hotel used for quarantining returned travellers. The deployment is unprecedented in the coronavirus crisis.

site_title: Hong Kong, China: Markets closed for holiday on Thursday
summary: Hong Kong's financial markets are closed on Thursday for a public holiday. Despite this, the Straits Times Index (STI) rose 0.4% on Wednesday due to investors' positive outlook, despite US tariff uncertainty and split Federal Reserve views. In other news, Airalo, an eSIM platform, raised US$220 million in new funding, lifting its valuation past US$1 billion, and a Dutch firm is set to privatize Grand Venture Technology at S$0.94 per share.

site_title: Singtel Optus to issue A$350m, A$500m notes on July 1
summary: Singtel Optus, a subsidiary of Singapore Telecommunications, has priced two debt deals: A$350 million 5-year notes at 1.6% coupon and A$500 million 10-year notes at 2.5% coupon. The notes will mature on July 1, 2025, and July 1, 2030, respectively. The proceeds will be used for Optus' general corporate purposes. The issue is part of Optus' long-term financing strategy and extends its debt maturity profile.

site_title: Trump warns against attacking monuments as Guard troops mobilised
summary: President Donald Trump warned protesters against damaging statues of prominent figures, threatening up to 10 years in prison. The US capital's monuments are being protected by 400 National Guard troops. Trump stated that such attacks would not happen "as long as I am here." The warning comes amid ongoing protests in the US capital.

site_title: Biden leads Trump 50% to 36% in latest nationwide poll
summary: Joe Biden leads President Donald Trump 50% to 36% in a new nationwide poll, marking the largest margin Biden has seen this year. Biden's lead is seen across various demographic groups, including women, men, age, and ethnicity. Trump's only dependable lead comes from registered Republicans and white, non-college educated voters. Biden's campaign has been boosted by a recent fundraiser with former President Barack Obama, while Trump's campaign has faced controversy over his handling of the coronavirus pandemic and Black Lives Matter protests.

site_title: Malaysia: Shares open lower on Thursday
summary: Malaysia's shares opened lower on Thursday, with the FTSE Bursa Malaysia Kuala Lumpur Composite Index down 7.74 points, or 0.52%, to 1,494.89. The market saw a slight recovery in the S&P 500 and Nasdaq, which edged to fresh records despite tariff uncertainty. Meanwhile, Airalo raised US$220 million in new funding, lifting its valuation past US$1 billion, and a Dutch firm made a mandatory offer for Grand Venture Technology at S$0.94 per share.

site_title: US: Dow ends 2.7% lower as increased virus cases slow recovery
summary: US stocks plummeted on Wednesday, with the Dow Jones Industrial Average dropping 2.7% to 25,445.94, amid rising coronavirus cases in the US. Record cases in western and southern states prompted reopenings to be frozen or reversed. The S&P 500 and Nasdaq Composite Index also fell, with travel and petroleum-linked shares particularly weak. The market's vulnerability to negative news and concerns about the economy's slowdown were highlighted by analysts.

site_title: Money FM podcast: Upskilling for future jobs
summary: Prime Time with Howie Lim and finance presenter JP Ong discuss career longevity with Jaime Lim, group business leader at PeopleSearch Singapore. The conversation focuses on upskilling for future jobs, with Jaime emphasizing the importance of adapting to changing job requirements and staying relevant in the industry. The discussion highlights the need for continuous learning and professional development to ensure career success.

site_title: Relief for Lufthansa after top shareholder backs rescue deal
summary: Lufthansa's top shareholder, Heinz Hermann Thiele, has backed a 9 billion euro government rescue package, removing a potential veto that could have led to bankruptcy. The deal includes a 20% stake claim by the state and includes job cuts of 22,000 full-time positions. Lufthansa shares rose 15% in after-hours trading as investors welcomed the news. The airline's CEO, Carsten Spohr, warned that the company's future was at stake and urged investors to back the plan, which includes restructuring talks.

site_title: France reopens probe into Macron's chief of staff
summary: France has reopened a probe into President Emmanuel Macron's chief of staff, Alexis Kohler, over his alleged conflict of interest with Swiss-Italian shipping giant MSC. The initial investigation was dropped in August 2019, but a civil complaint from campaign group Anticor led investigating magistrates to take up the case. Kohler is accused of having worked on matters involving MSC's shipyard while working at the economy ministry before Macron's election in 2017. The presidency has denied Kohler did anything wrong, calling the reopening of the investigation an "automatic consequence" of the Anticor complaint.

site_title: Paris Ritz hotel items sell for quadruple the auction estimate
summary: The Paris Ritz hotel auctioned off 1,500 items, including silver, crystal, and towels, for a total of 1.7 million euros (S$2.7 million), exceeding the pre-sale estimate by four times. The auction, postponed due to the coronavirus epidemic, saw buyers from 25 countries participate, with items such as a 12-plate "Marthe service" and Christofle serving trollies selling for 45 and 58 times their estimates, respectively. This marks a significant increase from the 7.2 million euros (7 times the estimate) earned from the sale of historic furniture two years ago.

site_title: New PAP candidates to fight for low-wage earners, SMEs, sustainability
summary: The People's Action Party (PAP) has unveiled its second batch of new candidates for the upcoming Singapore general election. The candidates, including senior civil servants and grassroots volunteers, focus on issues such as low-wage workers, SMEs, sustainability, and the elderly. The PAP is introducing 26 new candidates over three days, with a focus on serving the needs of Singaporeans from diverse backgrounds. The party's vice-chairman, Masagos Zulkifli, emphasized the importance of lifelong learning and giving back to the community.

site_title: Japan's success in curbing Covid-19 cases now hampers search for cures
summary: Japan's efforts to curb COVID-19 cases have hindered the development of treatments and vaccines, as the country's slow new infections have led to a shortage of patients for clinical trials. Japan's first human trials for potential vaccines are expected to start next month, but the country's success in controlling the virus has limited the availability of participants.

site_title: Opposition parties go big on social media
summary: Opposition parties in Singapore have intensified their social media presence ahead of the General Election (GE) 2020, posting videos, livestreams, and announcements. The Workers' Party, Singapore Democratic Party, and other parties have utilized platforms like Facebook and YouTube to introduce candidates, share party ideologies, and engage with supporters. The increased online efforts come as the country navigates safe campaigning measures due to the ongoing COVID-19 pandemic.

site_title: Temasek-backed fund leads US$26m investment in Myanmar's ISP
summary: A Temasek-backed fund, Ascent Myanmar Growth Fund I, has led a $26 million minority investment in Myanmar's leading Internet service provider, Frontiir. The investment aims to improve lives, reduce inequalities, and drive economic growth in emerging markets like Myanmar. Frontiir plans to expand nationwide to bridge the country's digital divide and provide affordable digital services. The investment supports the UN Sustainable Development Goals and will also focus on enhancing gender inclusiveness and equitable access to quality education.

site_title: Corporate digest
summary: Yoma Strategic has proposed a US$76.5 million deal to acquire a controlling interest in Digital Money Myanmar (Wave Money) through its new investment holding company, Yoma MFS Holdings. KIT and Keppel Energy secured a S$700 million sustainability-linked loan from DBS Bank and OCBC Bank, linked to carbon emission targets for their jointly owned cogeneration plant. Meanwhile, Citigroup has set a mid-2026 target of 1,150 for MSCI's global equity index.

site_title: Strong earthquake strikes off eastern Japan
summary: A 5.9-magnitude earthquake struck off eastern Japan's coast on June 24, 2020, with the epicenter 41km southeast of Hasaki in Chiba prefecture. The Japan Meteorological Agency reported no tsunami risk, despite a magnitude of 6.2. The quake occurred at a depth of 25.4km.

site_title: Lab to drive innovations in building technology for post-Covid era
summary: Johnson Controls partners the Singapore Economic Development Board to establish a $50 million innovation lab focusing on artificial intelligence-based innovations for Singapore's built-environment industry. The lab aims to develop digital solutions for property owners, facilities managers, and building occupants, meeting growing demand for contactless applications. The lab is expected to employ over 100 people within four years, with a multi-pronged strategy covering research, collaboration, commercialization, and implementation.

site_title: Latest government land sales programme offers two plum sites in mature estates
summary: The Singapore government has released a list of three private residential sites for the second half of 2020, offering relief to developers amid the COVID-19 pandemic. The confirmed sites include one executive condominium in Tengah Garden Walk and two residential sites in mature estates, yielding 1,370 private residential units and 1,500 square meters of commercial space. The sites are expected to attract healthy bidding, with prices ranging from S$700-1,000 per square foot per plot ratio (psf ppr). The government aims to balance the supply of private residential units and cater to the housing needs of the population.

site_title: Europe: Stocks knocked lower by virus, tariff fears
summary: European stocks plummeted 2.8% to a one-week low, with economically sensitive sectors such as travel and leisure, automakers, and banks leading declines. The slump was fueled by a surge in coronavirus cases, US tariff fears, and concerns over fresh restrictions. The US may modify duties on EU products and weigh tariffs on products from Britain, France, and Germany. Despite some bright spots, such as Austrian sensor maker AMS rising 6%, the market's woes were exacerbated by the European Central Bank chief economist's warning that solid data may not guide the euro zone's recovery.

images.alt_text: European stocks slumped to a one week-low on Wednesday as a surge in coronavirus cases and news that US was weighing tariffs on European products dashed investors hopes of a speedy economic recovery.

site_title: Calm settles on US housing market, defying doomsayers for now
summary: The US housing market has entered a period of calm, defying doomsayers despite high unemployment. Home prices continue to rise, and lenders are seeing a surge in mortgage applications. However, many Americans are struggling to make payments, with 9.1 million borrowers missing a mortgage payment in June and 10.7 million having little to no confidence they'll pay next month. The expiration of enhanced unemployment benefits and a potential economic downturn could lead to renewed stress, with estimates suggesting 15-25% of borrowers in forbearance may default.

site_title: Parties stake out the ground in a social media-focused election
summary: Singapore's ruling party, the People's Action Party (PAP), has begun campaigning for the July 10 General Election (GE) with virtual press conferences and social media outreach, introducing 8 new candidates and showcasing a diverse lineup of 10 women. The party's candidates have median age of 43 and have been working the ground already, according to Deputy Prime Minister Heng Swee Keat. The opposition parties, including the Progress Singapore Party and the Workers' Party, are also leveraging social media to reach voters, with the WP releasing a new video highlighting its outreach efforts and activities.

site_title: China finance firms expand in world's priciest office market
summary: China's finance firms are expanding in Hong Kong's prime office market, leasing additional space in Central despite a virus-induced recession and concerns over pro-democracy protests. CMB International Capital, China Minsheng Banking, and Orient Finance Holdings increased their office space in the area, joining tech giants like Alibaba and ByteDance. The expansion contrasts with muted demand from global firms, who are reviewing office needs due to remote work. The vacancy rate in the prime business district rose to a 12-year high of 5% in May, averaging $313 per square foot.

site_title: Employers notify MOM of cost-saving moves affecting over 187,000 workers
summary: Employers in Singapore have submitted over 4,800 notifications of cost-saving measures affecting more than 187,000 employees since March 12, amid the COVID-19 pandemic. The majority of notifications came from the accommodation and food services, construction, and wholesale and retail trade sectors. Cost-saving measures included no-pay leave, salary reductions, and shorter workweeks, with most employees experiencing salary reductions of up to 25%. Employers who implemented excessive measures were intervened by the Ministry of Manpower and Tripartite Alliance for Fair and Progressive Employment Practices, resulting in some agreeing to review their measures and provide more wage support.

site_title: Wirecard's Braun dumps stock, joins rank of ex-billionaires
summary: Former Wirecard CEO Markus Braun has disposed of 5.5 million shares, leaving him with a 3% stake valued at approximately US$60 million. Braun, who was ousted as CEO after a margin call, had initially held a US$1 billion stake in the company. His actions come as part of a probe into Wirecard's accounting practices, and he surrendered to police on Monday.

site_title: Neither big nor small, music ensembles struggle in a pandemic
summary: Midsize music ensembles, with 6-30 members, face significant challenges during the pandemic. Many have cancelled concerts, leaving freelancers without guaranteed income or compensation. Despite efforts from some ensembles, such as The Crossing and International Contemporary Ensemble, to support their members, others struggle to make ends meet. Ensemble Dal Niente pays musicians a third of their fees for cancelled concerts, but acknowledges that this is insufficient for those who rely solely on freelance income. The pandemic has exposed the vulnerabilities of these ensembles, which often rely on grants, sponsorships, and donations to survive.

site_title: Waste issues in focus as food delivery surges in Singapore lockdown
summary: During Singapore's circuit breaker period from April 7 to June 1, the country saw a surge in food delivery sales, resulting in a 73% increase in delivered meals and a significant rise in plastic waste. The National Environment Agency reported a 3% increase in daily waste collected during this period. The government has taken steps to address the issue, including requiring businesses to report on packaging use and submit plans to reduce volumes or recycle by March 2022.

site_title: US states reimpose virus measures as cases spike
summary: The US is experiencing a surge in COVID-19 cases, with nearly four months since the nation's first death from the virus. States in the South and West, including Florida and Texas, are reimposing measures such as stay-at-home advice, quarantines, and mask mandates due to record-breaking daily case averages. Experts warn that the next two weeks will be critical in addressing the surges, and some officials are urging residents to stay home. The nation's death toll has surpassed 121,000, and the pandemic remains a major challenge for the world's largest economy.

images.alt_text: With coronavirus cases surging across the US South and West, officials are once again imposing tough measures, from stay-at-home advice in worst-hit states to quarantines to protect recovering areas like New York.

site_title: Weaker US dollar will hurt some companies but may give cheer to market
summary: The US dollar is expected to weaken moderately, 3-5%, as economies exit lockdowns and investors shift to riskier assets. This may benefit the local Singapore equity market but hurt companies with significant US exposure, such as electronics and plantation companies. A weaker dollar would also make imported goods more expensive for US consumers, affecting profits and exports of some Singapore-listed companies. However, a moderate USD weakening is expected to be beneficial for Asian stocks and certain sectors, including midstream food manufacturers and companies with revenue denominated in Asian currencies.

site_title: Trump-backed luxury Bali project forced to scale back
summary: A luxury Bali project backed by Donald Trump is scaling back due to reduced spending in Indonesia's economy hit by the coronavirus. PT MNC Investama, the local partner, is considering remodelling the Trump-branded hotel and residential venture to make it more affordable. The project, which was launched after a visit by Donald Trump Jr, is facing financial challenges as Indonesians hold back spending amid the economic downturn. The project's future remains uncertain as the company seeks to adapt to the changing market.

site_title: 5G to enhance enterprise digital transformation
summary: 5G technology is expected to enhance enterprise digital transformation by creating significant value and reducing costs in consumer applications. With 25% of mobile traffic in South Korea now on 5G networks, and 50 million mobile subscribers in China, 5G is becoming mainstream. Key applications include telemedicine, virtual banking, and augmented reality (AR) and virtual reality (VR) in industries such as manufacturing and healthcare. The technology is also expected to create new revenue streams for e-sports and mobile/VR gaming, and enable digital transformation in sectors like aviation, transport, and public healthcare.

site_title: A robot for every Singaporean
summary: Singapore is increasing its efforts to provide training for its workforce to adapt to automation technologies, with a focus on robotic process automation (RPA). The government and institutions of higher learning are offering RPA training programs and workshops to help students, employees, and companies improve productivity. With the RPA market growing by over 63% in 2019, Singapore aims to become a hub for digital transformation and automation. The goal is to enable a workforce that is ready for the robotic revolution, with individuals embracing digital solutions rather than fearing them.

site_title: Gold soars to near 8-year high as fears of new virus wave grow
summary: Gold prices reached a near 8-year high of $1,773 per ounce due to rising concerns over a potential new virus wave and hopes for additional stimulus measures to combat the economic impact of the pandemic. Central banks worldwide have adopted aggressive stimulus measures, keeping interest rates low, which has driven gold prices up 16% this year. The surge in gold prices is attributed to safe-haven demand, with worries about sustained economic weakness and inflation, as well as currency debasement.

site_title: Travel industry's support for community flies high amid Covid-19
summary: The travel industry has rallied to support communities affected by the COVID-19 pandemic, with over 1,000 staff members volunteering as care ambassadors and transport ambassadors for healthcare institutions. Airlines, hotels, and travel companies such as Singapore Airlines, the Singapore Hotel Association, and Expedia Group have launched various initiatives, including the "KrisPay It Forward" program, which allows customers to donate miles to support frontline workers. The industry is also focusing on enhanced hygiene and sanitation protocols, digital innovation, and exploring new opportunities for businesses.

site_title: TPG gets green light to run localised 5G
summary: Singapore's 5G rollout plans remain on track despite the coronavirus pandemic, with standalone 5G coverage expected across half of the island by end-2022 and full coverage by end-2025. The Infocomm Media Development Authority (IMDA) has granted millimetre-wave spectrum to TPG Telecom, which will roll out next-generation 5G services. However, the pandemic may cause short-term slippage in the rollout timeline, with Minister for Communications and Information S Iswaran citing the "long game" of investing in infrastructure for the long term.

images.alt_text: "We are investing in infrastructure for the long term so it's not a matter of months, it's actually a matter of more than a decade," says Mr Iswaran.

site_title: Indonesia to place funds in state banks to support economy
summary: Indonesia's finance minister, Sri Mulyani Indrawati, announced plans to shift 30 trillion rupiah (S$2.9 billion) from the central bank to four state banks to support the economy. The funds will be used to expand lending and target the real sector, with an interest rate of 80% of the central bank's benchmark rate. The move aims to counter the economic contraction caused by the coronavirus pandemic, with businesses forced to shut and lay off workers. The state banks will prioritize lending to farmers, food, and medical equipment businesses.

site_title: Guidelines for safe campaigning, political broadcasts issued
summary: The Elections Department of Singapore has issued guidelines for safe campaigning and political broadcasts ahead of the General Election. The guidelines include restrictions on physical rallies, live streaming, and interactions with the public. Candidates will have to conduct constituency political broadcasts on MediaCorp's Channel 5 from July 3 to 7, and may also use government-provided venues for live streaming. The department also advises the public to watch political broadcasts at home and avoid gathering in public to do so.

site_title: Analysts largely positive on MIT's proposed US data centres deal
summary: Mapletree Industrial Trust (MIT) has proposed acquiring the remaining 60% stake in 14 US data centers for approximately $218 million. Analysts are largely positive on the deal, with OCBC bumping up its fair value estimate to S$3.25 and Maybank Kim Eng maintaining its target price at S$2.95. The acquisition is expected to boost demand for data centers due to enterprise adoption of cloud computing and outsourcing of IT infrastructure. MIT will raise at least $350 million through a private placement of new units, with the issue price representing a 1.6% discount to its adjusted VWAP. The deal is subject to unitholder approval and will be funded with 73.8% of the gross proceeds going towards the acquisition and 24.6% towards debt repayment.

site_title: Oil tankers carrying two months of Venezuelan output stuck at sea
summary: At least 16 oil tankers carrying nearly two months' worth of Venezuelan oil are stuck at sea due to US sanctions, which are restricting global refiners from buying the crude. The tankers, carrying 18.1 million barrels of oil, are unable to unload their cargo and are incurring hefty demurrage charges. The US is tightening sanctions to cut Venezuela's oil exports and deprive the government of revenue, further exacerbating the country's economic crisis.

site_title: Cross-border ETF connectivity schemes vital to Singapore
summary: Singapore needs to establish an initiative linking its capital markets to those in South-east Asia and beyond, amid de-globalization and strategic schisms. The country can model its ETF connectivity scheme after China's successful link with Japan, which facilitates cross-border investments and reduces costs. Singapore aims to become the world's largest cross-border financial centre by 2028, with a projected cross-border wealth of US$1 trillion by 2023. Implementing ETF connectivity schemes will increase fund flows, reduce costs, and minimize information asymmetry, making Singapore a robust cross-border ETF cluster and a strategic hub in the multipolar world.

site_title: Fear of missing out? Beware agents' hype on new home sales and prices
summary: Property agents in Singapore have been exaggerating the strong sales volumes during the recent lockdown period, despite restrictions on new project launches. Agents claim developers are now more inclined to hold firm on prices, with some potentially even raising them. This contradicts expectations of a severe economic recession and rising unemployment. The hype may be driven by agents' desire to secure sales, but it is misleading buyers and could lead to financial losses.

site_title: US offers Brazil funding to buy 5G gear from Huawei rivals, says diplomat
summary: The US government, through its top diplomat in Brazil, has offered funding to help local telecom companies acquire 5G technology from non-Chinese providers, citing concerns over Huawei's reliability. Ambassador Todd Chapman stated that Ericsson, Nokia, and Samsung can provide "appropriate" 5G technology that protects information and intellectual property. The US International Development Finance Corporation will provide financing for these projects. This move comes amid US President Donald Trump's administration urging governments to shun Huawei due to spying concerns.

site_title: Japan retailers gain as sales data hints at post-outbreak rebound
summary: Japanese retailers experienced a surge in sales, with furniture depot Nitori Holdings Co. and casual fashion retailer Shimamura Co. reporting record-breaking same-store sales increases of 47% and 27%, respectively. This uptick in sales suggests a rebound in consumer spending as the COVID-19 threat subsides. These early indicators of a post-outbreak recovery could lead to a positive impact on the retail sector.

images.alt_text: Nitori saw relatively little impact on its revenue during the state of emergency, as it benefited from an increased level of spending as workers spruce up their living environments at home.

site_title: Lee Hsien Yang joins Progress Singapore Party
summary: Lee Hsien Yang, the younger brother of Singapore Prime Minister Lee Hsien Loong, has joined the Progress Singapore Party (PSP) after months of speculation. The 80-year-old PSP chief formally welcomed Yang as a member during a breakfast meeting at Tiong Bahru Market, citing the COVID-19 pandemic as the reason for the delay. This move marks a significant development for the PSP, which is led by former PAP politician Tan Cheng Bock.

site_title: Indonesia's largest taxi operator sees demand rebound as Covid-19 curbs ease
summary: Indonesia's largest taxi operator, PT Blue Bird, has seen a sharp rebound in demand for its services since authorities eased social distancing rules to revive the economy. About half of its 20,000 taxis have returned to service, prompting the operator to call more drivers to rejoin duty. Demand had plunged 80% in April due to the Covid-19 outbreak. The company expects a slow reboot to the economy, with recovery starting from August, and has postponed expanding its electric vehicle fleet until demand recovers.

images.alt_text: Blue Bird is bracing for a slow reboot to Indonesia's economy that's been ravaged by the Covid-19 outbreak.

site_title: KKR raises US$10b for biggest Asia buyout fund
summary: KKR & Co has raised over US$10 billion for its third Asia fund, surpassing a record US$10.6 billion raised by Hillhouse Capital Group in 2018. The New York-based buyout giant achieved 80% of its US$12.5 billion target within seven months of its official launch and plans to close the first round by the end of this month. This move comes as the global economy recovered from the coronavirus pandemic, with KKR benefiting from the turmoil. The fund's size will make it the largest buyout war chest ever assembled by a US private equity firm for the region.

site_title: Industry road maps see a rejig, but tech, resilience remain core
summary: Singapore's industry standards roadmap has undergone a "rejig" due to the Covid-19 pandemic, but technology and resilience will remain core priorities in the new five-year plan. The Singapore Standards Council (SSC) will focus on emerging areas like green standards, industry transformation, and smart manufacturing, while also adopting international standards for smart cards and air-conditioning. The council aims to enable companies to move into the future economy, becoming sustainable, resilient, and competitive globally.

site_title: mm2 Asia targets Q3 Singapore launch for on-demand movie streaming platform
summary: mm2 Asia, a Singapore-based film production group, plans to launch an on-demand streaming platform, Cathay CineHOME, in Singapore by the third quarter of 2020. The platform will offer movies on a pay-per-view basis, providing access to films immediately after their theatrical window or with a limited theatrical run. Cathay CineHOME will complement the Cathay Cineplexes brand of cinemas, acquired by mm2 Asia in 2017. The platform aims to cater to movie lovers who cannot attend cinemas, and the company has not yet finalized business terms with major studio and producer partners.

site_title: Combat Covid-19 with efficient allocation of resources
summary: Covid-19 is devastating developing and emerging-market countries due to lack of medical and financial capacity to combat the pandemic. Advanced economies have implemented social distancing, hand washing, and lockdowns, but poor countries face challenges such as overcrowding, scarcity of face masks and soap, and shared water sources. Enforced lockdowns can lead to penury and starvation for poor people, making it difficult for them to access basic necessities.

site_title: UK mall landlords expect worst as £2.5b rent comes due
summary: UK mall landlords face an existential threat as £2.5 billion in rent is due, with retailers collapsing into bankruptcy and little sign of replacements. Despite collecting about half of the rent owed in the second quarter, landlords may get even less this time around due to government curbs on forced payments. Landlords like Intu Properties and British Land are in crunch talks with lenders to secure waivers on debt terms. The government has banned evictions and limited landlords' abilities to force non-paying tenants into bankruptcy, but hasn't extended emergency support to property owners.

site_title: Beware market carnage if policy support is rolled back prematurely
summary: Global economies are showing signs of recovery from the pandemic, with higher production and consumer activity as economies reopen. However, experts warn that government-led stimulus packages, which have cushioned the blow from Covid-19, are not meant to last forever and may be rolled back prematurely, potentially leading to an economic shock. A W-shaped recovery, where the economy recovers from a recession but slips back into contraction, is a growing concern, with business pessimism easing but tempered by caution and expectations of a longer recession and gradual recovery.

site_title: Sanofi accelerates its timeline for Covid-19 vaccine development
summary: Sanofi has accelerated its timeline for Covid-19 vaccine development, aiming for approval from regulatory authorities by June 2021, potentially earlier than initially projected. The company and its partner GlaxoSmithKline are speeding up a vaccine development timeline after initially planning for a vaccine to be available in the latter half of 2021. A combined Phase I/II clinical trial will begin in September, and the recombinant vaccine is formulated with GSK's proprietary adjuvants to enhance the immune response.

site_title: Rise of contactless card payments in new normal
summary: Singapore is shifting towards a cashless society as the COVID-19 pandemic accelerates the adoption of contactless card payments. Research warns that physical currency and mobile phones can be vectors of infectious diseases. 91% of individuals in the Asia-Pacific region, including Singapore and Australia, prefer contactless payments due to cleanliness concerns. The government has provided up to S$250 million in incentives for retailers to adopt digital ordering systems and cashless payments, further driving the transition. This change is expected to continue as consumers and retailers strive to prevent the spread of the virus.

site_title: HDB issues S$800m notes due in 2030
summary: The Housing and Development Board (HDB) has issued S$800 million worth of 10-year notes with a fixed coupon rate of 1.265% per annum, rated Aaa by Moody's Investors Service. The notes mature on June 24, 2030, and are offered to investors through placement. The issuance is part of HDB's S$32 billion multicurrency medium-term note programme to finance development programmes and working-capital requirements.

site_title: STI dips 0.24% on fears over Covid-19 second wave
summary: The Straits Times Index (STI) dropped 0.24% to 2,628.62 on Wednesday, amid rising Covid-19 cases in Singapore and Tokyo. The STI fell 6.3 points, with losers outnumbering gainers 237 to 174. Mapletree Industrial Trust rose 4.6% following a successful private placement and acquisition of US data centres. The Singapore Exchange saw S$1.26 billion worth of securities traded.

site_title: Australia scrambles to prevent second Covid-19 wave after first death in a month
summary: Australia reported its first Covid-19 death in over a month, with a man in his 80s dying in Victoria state. 20 new cases were reported, prompting concerns of a second wave. Authorities are trying to contain outbreaks in Melbourne suburbs and have deployed military personnel to operate pop-up test centers. The state of emergency has been extended for another month, and restrictions on gatherings have been reimposed. Thousands of people have flocked to testing centers, with waiting times of up to four hours reported.

site_title: Beware second wave of coronavirus, medics warn Britain
summary: The UK's top health professionals have warned of a potential second wave of coronavirus, citing local flare-ups and a real risk of a second wave as a major concern for Prime Minister Boris Johnson as he eases lockdown restrictions. The warning comes despite a decline in infections and a report of the lowest daily increase in deaths since lockdown in mid-March. The medical community is urging preparations for a second wave to protect lives and restore the economy.

site_title: US dollar pauses as caution returns to markets
summary: The US dollar paused its two-day losing streak, remaining flat against a basket of currencies, amid caution in the markets due to the risk of a second wave of Covid-19 infections. Despite improved economic data, including a record rebound in German business confidence, analysts warned that the risk of a second wave has not been eliminated and could push the FX market back to risk aversion. The IMF released revised global growth projections, predicting a 3% decline in 2020, while spiking cases in the US and Europe are being closely watched.

site_title: Suntec launches livestream shopping to lure customers back to malls
summary: Suntec City launched Singapore's first-ever livestream shopping festival, "The Suntec Shopping Festival", on June 23-26, 2020, to attract customers back to malls amid the COVID-19 pandemic. The event featured interactive sessions with 16 stores, over 40 brands, and discount events, reaching 200,000 registered members. This move follows the rising popularity of livestream shopping in Singapore and globally, with retailers using the trend to create brand loyalty and authenticity. The festival aims to boost exposure and sales for participating retailers, with plans for future events to help mall traffic recover.

site_title: Wells Fargo signs multi-year contracts with Shell for clean energy
summary: Wells Fargo has signed multi-year contracts with Royal Dutch Shell's units to develop new utility-scale solar installations in California and the mid-Atlantic states. The agreements aim to meet the energy needs of approximately 1,200 properties and are part of Wells Fargo's efforts to progress toward its clean energy goals. The lender has been meeting its global electricity requirements with renewable energy since 2017 and is now working to set up longer-term contracts and increase on-site renewable power generation.

site_title: Infected passengers on Hong Kong flights show risks of reopening
summary: Infected passengers on Hong Kong flights have highlighted the risks of reopening borders as global airlines face over $84 billion in losses this year. Two passengers, one on Cathay Pacific and another on Cathay Dragon, were allowed to board flights despite testing positive for Covid-19. The Hong Kong health authority reported 30 new cases with a travel history during the incubation period, underscoring the challenge of controlling the pandemic while reopening borders. Airlines have been lobbying to resume flying, citing the need for stricter measures to prevent the spread of the virus.

site_title: US: Wall St slips at open on worries over rising coronavirus cases
summary: US stocks fell at the open on Wednesday due to concerns over rising coronavirus cases in several states, affecting investor sentiment. The Dow Jones, S&P 500, and Nasdaq Composite all opened lower, with the Dow losing 163.14 points and the Nasdaq falling 37.55 points. The market assessed the potential economic risks from the surge in cases, leading to a decline in investor confidence.

site_title: Chinese billionaire Wong Kwong Yu released on parole
summary: Chinese billionaire Wong Kwong Yu, founder of Gome Retail Holdings, has been released on parole after serving 10 years in prison for illegal business dealings, insider trading, and corporate bribery. He was initially sentenced to 14 years but had his sentence shortened and was scheduled for release in February 2021. The parole was granted by the Beijing No1 Intermediate People's Court until February 16, 2021.

site_title: China's debt relief to support some stressed emerging markets, says Fitch
summary: China's pledge to relieve debt burdens owed by some emerging market governments could ease near-term liquidity pressures, according to Fitch Ratings. The eligible countries include Kenya, the Maldives, Ethiopia, and others, with a significant share of their debt owed to China. China's participation in the G20 debt service suspension initiative will temporarily suspend debt repayments for 77 developing nations from May to December, potentially easing liquidity pressures for these nations.

site_title: PAP's first slate of new faces hail from diverse sectors
summary: The People's Action Party (PAP) has unveiled its first slate of 26 new candidates, with a median age of 43, in an effort to better represent Singapore's diverse society. The party aims to bring in fresh perspectives from various sectors, focusing on issues such as small and medium-sized enterprises, disadvantaged families, and youth. The move is seen as a significant attempt to increase the representation of women candidates, although the exact number is not specified. The PAP's new faces are expected to bring different interests into focus and better reflect the party's commitment to diversity.

site_title: Wirecard wins short reprieve as banks scan long-term damage
summary: Wirecard won a temporary reprieve from lenders on its 1.75 billion euros revolving credit facility, allowing it to assess its long-term viability before repayment. The company faces potential losses of about 15 lenders, including ABN Amro Bank, Commerzbank, and ING Groep, after it reported a 1.9 billion euros cash shortfall. Wirecard shares have cratered, and its CEO James Freis is under pressure to reassure business partners. The company considers selling parts of its business or swapping debt for equity as possible options. A final decision is expected soon.

site_title: Darco fields questions from minorities on disclosure and conflicts of interest
summary: Darco Water Technologies has addressed concerns from minority shareholders about its venture into Indonesia's waste-management project. The company clarified that it has not lost its direction following a surprise change in leadership and has the resources and expertise to invest in the project. Darco also addressed allegations of conflicts of interest, stating that an independent director's ties to a consultancy firm were not executive roles, but rather corporate secretarial services. The company will consolidate shareholder questions and publish answers before its upcoming annual general meeting.

site_title: Magnus Energy's independent non-executive director resigns
summary: Magnus Energy Group announced the resignation of independent non-executive director Anthony Kuek, effective immediately. Kuek relinquished his chairmanship of the nominating committee and remuneration committee, and his membership in the audit committee. The board now consists of CEO Charles Madhaven and independent director Farooq Ahmad Mann. Magnus will attempt to fill the vacant audit committee seat within two months and reconstitute the nominating and remuneration committees as soon as possible.

site_title: Surveying the new normal in shopping and other services
summary: Singapore's shopping malls have become mini-airports with stringent security measures, including temperature checks and screening, as the country reopens from the COVID-19 pandemic. Luxury boutiques and restaurants now offer sanitized services, such as glove-wearing and QR code menus. Meanwhile, young musicians and stay-at-home enthusiasts can explore new hobbies through DIY design kits, including tea-blending, terrarium-making, and pottery. The article showcases various lifestyle and entertainment options for those looking to get back into their favorite activities after a period of lockdown.

site_title: South Korea trade minister runs for WTO top job
summary: South Korea's Trade Minister Yoo Myung-hee has been nominated as the next director-general of the World Trade Organization, succeeding Brazilian diplomat Robert Azevedo who is stepping down early. The nomination closes on July 8, with Yoo being the fifth candidate in the race. This move comes as Yoo seeks to build on her experience in trade negotiations, including her efforts to establish a 'landing zone' in US trade talks. Her nomination is seen as a significant development in the ongoing search for a new WTO leader.

site_title: Swissport says to axe over 4,000 UK jobs
summary: Swissport, a UK airport services group, plans to cut over 4,000 jobs, about half its UK workforce, due to the ongoing coronavirus pandemic's impact on air travel. The company's revenue has dropped by 75% since May, with CEO Jason Holt stating that the global aviation sector faces a prolonged downturn. Airlines are expected to suffer a combined net loss of over $84 billion this year, with experts warning it could take several years to return to pre-pandemic flight numbers.

site_title: ST Group Food Industries to open 10 new F&B outlets
summary: ST Group Food Industries announced plans to open 10 new food and beverage outlets by September, expanding its operations in Australia, New Zealand, and the UK. The company, which owns international brands such as PappaRich and Gong Cha, has secured favorable lease terms and will operate five outlets directly, while five will be sub-franchisees or sub-licensees. This marks a rebound for the group after lockdown measures were eased in its key markets.

site_title: An election with plenty at stake for every political party
summary: Singapore is gearing up for a general election on July 10, with the ruling People's Action Party (PAP) contesting all 93 seats. The PAP, led by Prime Minister Lee Hsien Loong, is likely to face a strong challenge from opposition parties, including the Workers' Party, Singapore Democratic Party, and Progress Singapore Party. The election is seen as a test for the fourth-generation leaders of the PAP, who are seeking a strong mandate to chart the country's course for the next five to 10 years. The election is also significant for Lee Hsien Loong, who plans to step down as prime minister around 2022.

site_title: Biden leads Trump by 14 points in New York Times/Siena poll
summary: Joe Biden leads President Donald Trump 50-36% in a New York Times/Siena College poll, a 14-point advantage across a broad demographic range. Biden leads among women, all age groups, and ethnic groups, but trails among white, non-college educated voters. This poll result mirrors a previous CNN poll, which also showed a 14-point Biden lead. The survey of 1,337 registered voters has a margin of error of +/- 3 percentage points.

site_title: Philippines launches investigation into Wirecard's phantom billions
summary: The Philippines has launched an investigation into Wirecard's $2.1 billion accounting scandal, with former COO Jan Marsalek potentially being in the country. The Philippines' Justice Secretary Menardo Guevarra instructed state investigators to look into the case, following allegations that billions held at two Philippine banks did not exist. Marsalek was fired by Wirecard after it disclosed the scandal, and the Munich prosecutor's office is seeking his arrest due to lack of an extradition treaty between Germany and the Philippines.

site_title: North Korea suspends military action plans against South Korea
summary: North Korea has suspended military action plans against South Korea, according to a report by the KCNA news agency. The move comes after North Korean troops dismantled loudspeakers reinstalled at the fortified border, amid rising tensions over propaganda leaflets and stalled negotiations on economic sanctions. The decision to suspend military action plans is unclear, but follows North Korea's recent actions, including blowing up a liaison office and cutting off communication hotlines with the South.

site_title: IMF predicts deeper global downturn even as economies reopen
summary: The International Monetary Fund (IMF) has revised its global economic forecast, predicting a 4.9% contraction this year, a sharper decline than its previous projection of 3%. This downturn is attributed to the ongoing coronavirus pandemic, which is causing businesses to struggle and policymakers to face an uneven and protracted recovery. The IMF warns that the global economy will continue to face uncertainty until the virus dissipates or a vaccine becomes available. This revised forecast underscores the severity of the economic contraction since the Great Depression.

site_title: Darco fields disclosure and conflict-of-interest questions from minority shareholders
summary: Darco Water Technologies addressed concerns from minority shareholders regarding potential conflicts of interest and internal controls. Shareholders questioned the company's involvement in an Indonesia waste-management project and its lack of resources and expertise in the field. The company clarified that it has received funding from Emsus Co, a South Korean consultancy, and not Yunnan Water Investment Co. as previously alleged. Additionally, Darco acknowledged that an independent director, Joanna Ong Joo Mien, received a finder's fee from Qarah Consultancy, but clarified that her role was limited to corporate secretarial services.

site_title: Italy approves guarantees for US$7.1b loan to Fiat Chrysler: source
summary: Italy has approved a decree offering state guarantees for a 6.30-billion euro (S$9.90 billion) loan to Fiat Chrysler's (FCA) Italian unit, paving the way for the largest crisis loan to a European carmaker. The loan, secured by Intesa Sanpaolo, will help FCA's operations in Italy and the country's car sector. The request for state support had sparked controversy due to FCA's planned merger with PSA, but conditions and implications remain unclear.

site_title: US targets US$3.1b of EU, UK imports for new tariffs
summary: The US is considering new tariffs on $3.1 billion of EU and UK imports, including luxury goods and aircraft, as part of a 15-year-old World Trade Organization dispute over aircraft subsidies. The US Trade Representative's plan could lead to retaliatory measures from the EU, potentially harming European luxury brands and US exporters.
