The move is part of the Trump administration's "carousel retaliation" strategy, which aims to persuade the EU to agree to a settlement, but talks have stalled.

site_title: Malaysia: Shares close lower on Wednesday
summary: Malaysia's FTSE Bursa Malaysia Kuala Lumpur Composite Index closed 4.41 points lower to 1,502.63 on Wednesday, with a trading volume of 5.388 billion lots worth RM2.602 billion. Losers outnumbered gainers 556 to 409.

site_title: RBS to cut up to 90 staff in US investment-banking overhaul
summary: Royal Bank of Scotland (RBS) is set to cut up to 90 staff in its US investment-banking unit, NatWest Markets, as part of a restructuring plan. The move aims to make the business more sustainable, with CEO Alison Rose announcing plans to slash the markets business to focus on financial and risk management for corporate customers. The job cuts will be implemented at RBS's Stamford, Connecticut site, where all 400 US staff work. Employees will be delayed in their exits and continue to receive pay until September 30, 2020.

site_title: Duty Free International posts net loss of RM9.1m for Q4
summary: Duty Free International, a Malaysian multi-channel duty-free and duty-paid retail group, reported a net loss of RM9.1 million (S$3 million) for its fourth quarter ended Feb 29, 2020, due to the COVID-19 pandemic. Revenue increased 1.3% to RM169.7 million, but the group expects a challenging year ahead. Despite a net cash surplus of RM196.3 million, the group plans to reduce costs and close non-profitable outlets to mitigate the financial impact. The outlook for the coming financial year is highly uncertain due to the global economic crisis and travel restrictions.

site_title: Organisations in Asean expect to be badly hit by economic repercussions of Covid-19
summary: Businesses in ASEAN expect a significant impact from the economic repercussions of Covid-19, with 81% anticipating a decline in revenue, exceeding the global rate of 72%. A majority (61%) of ASEAN companies expect a significant impact on their annual revenue, surpassing the APAC and global rates of 51% and 50%, respectively. This is the third Korn Ferry survey, involving over 3,500 respondents from 99 countries. The survey highlights the severity of the economic downturn in the region.

images.alt_text: Office workers seen crossing Robinson Road in an empty CBD in the wake of the C19 circuit breaker at 3.15pm on 28 April 2020.

site_title: Hong Kong: Stocks close lower
summary: Hong Kong shares closed lower, with the Hang Seng Index slipping 0.50% to 24,781.58, due to concerns over a rise in coronavirus infections as lockdown restrictions ease. In contrast, the Shanghai Composite Index rose 0.30% to 2,979.55. The negative sentiment in Hong Kong was not replicated in other markets, with the S&P 500 and Nasdaq reaching fresh records in the US.

site_title: Shipments from China held for extra customs checks at Indian port: sources
summary: Customs officials at Chennai Port, one of India's largest ports, have held shipments from China for extra checks amid tensions following a border clash that killed 20 Indian soldiers. Sources say customs officers have instructed importers not to let goods from China leave the port without inspection, potentially disrupting supply chains. While there is no official government order, the increased scrutiny could have broader implications for trade between India and China.

site_title: Virus-hit meat plants from UK to Brazil stop China exports
summary: A British pork plant and a Brazilian beef unit voluntarily halted sales to China after workers tested positive for coronavirus, highlighting the risk of export disruptions. China had previously suspended poultry imports from a US Tyson Foods plant and a German abattoir. The move raises concerns about trade interruptions, with food consultant Gira suggesting some companies may have stopped sales to avoid a ban. This development follows recent outbreaks at meat plants in Europe and the Americas.

site_title: Statues of democracy leaders are disappearing in Thailand
summary: Thailand is experiencing the disappearance of statues honoring leaders of the 1932 revolution that ended absolute monarchy, which celebrated democracy. At least six monuments have been removed or renamed in the past year, with officials declining to answer questions about the removal. Historians say the disappearance reflects an ideological battle over Thailand's history, with military-royalist conservatives seeking to erase the past and promote traditional culture. Pro-democracy activists and academics argue that the removals are part of an "ideological cleansing" aimed at suppressing democratic ideals.

site_title: Australia scrambles to prevent second Covid-19 wave after first death in a month
summary: Australia reported its first COVID-19 death in over a month, with a man in his 80s dying in Victoria state, amid concerns of a second wave. The state has seen a surge in new cases, prompting authorities to extend the state of emergency and reimpose restrictions. Thousands of people have flocked to testing centers, with waiting times of up to four hours reported. Despite the spike, authorities assure that anyone who wants a test will get one, and neighboring New South Wales has vowed not to close its border with Victoria.

images.alt_text: Australia reported its first Covid-19 death in more than a month on Wednesday, as concerns about a second wave of infections saw thousands of people queue, sometimes for hours, to be tested for the virus.

site_title: UK watchdog investigates audits of London Capital & Finance
summary: The UK's Financial Reporting Council (FRC) has launched three investigations into audits of London Capital & Finance (LCF), which collapsed in 2019, affecting 11,600 investors. The audits cover 2015-2017 and will examine the financial reporting and audit practices of the firms involved. The FRC has the power to fine audit companies and ban auditors. The investigations follow a permanent ban on selling mini-bonds to retail investors by the Financial Conduct Authority (FCA).

site_title: Contactless self-check temperature kiosks to be rolled out at 70 bus interchanges and MRT stations
summary: Singapore is rolling out contactless self-check temperature kiosks at 70 bus interchanges and MRT stations as part of its SG United initiative to encourage regular temperature monitoring. The kiosks, which can detect a person's temperature with a measurement accuracy of plus or minus 0.3 deg C, are being deployed at five initial locations and will be available at all 70 locations by the third quarter of this year. The machines are not mandatory but aim to encourage the public to develop the habit of daily temperature checks and work together to keep Singapore safe.

site_title: SLB's associated company and 32RE to run co-living assets with Weave
summary: SLB Development's fund-management company 32RE and an associated company have formed a joint venture with Weave Co-Living to acquire, develop, refurbish, and operate co-living and rental accommodation assets in Singapore. The S$150 million equity joint venture will see Weave owning 80% and 32RE managing the remaining 20%. This partnership aims to diversify SLB's income stream and gain access to global investors, with the joint venture expected to deepen SLB's focus on the co-living and accommodation segment.

site_title: Thailand's central bank cuts GDP outlook, holds key rate at record low
summary: Thailand's central bank reduced its GDP forecast to a 8.1% contraction this year, the sharpest rate on record, due to the impact of curfews and border closures. Despite this, the Bank of Thailand kept its key interest rate at a record low, as businesses gradually reopen from a lockdown. The decision was widely expected, and the downgrade reflects the country's struggles with manufacturing and tourism.

site_title: Amazon's purchase of Deliveroo stake gets UK watchdog's provisional blessing again
summary: Britain's competition regulator, the CMA, has restated its provisional clearance of Amazon's 16% stake in Deliveroo, citing competition grounds. The deal, valued at US$575 million, was initially provisionally cleared in April after the CMA found Deliveroo could go out of business without Amazon's investment. The CMA has changed the basis of its approval, focusing solely on competition grounds, and will continue to monitor the deal. The provisional clearance remains in place until a final decision is made.

images.alt_text: Britain's competition regulator has restated its provisional clearance of Amazon's purchase of a 16 per cent stake in online delivery group Deliveroo but changed the basis of its approval.

site_title: Johnson & Johnson told to pay US$2.1b over cancer-causing talc powder
summary: A US court has upheld a $2.10 billion verdict against Johnson & Johnson, ruling the company liable for ovarian cancer caused by its talc powder. The Missouri Court of Appeals reduced the original $4.40 billion award by more than half, excluding plaintiffs from outside the state. The court found Johnson & Johnson knowingly sold products containing asbestos, awarding damages for the company's "knowing sale of products that caused harm." Johnson & Johnson plans to appeal the decision to the Supreme Court of Missouri.

site_title: Former Wirecard CEO Markus Braun released from custody
summary: Former Wirecard CEO Markus Braun has been released from custody after paying a 5 million euro bail. Braun was arrested on suspicion of falsifying Wirecard's accounts following the disclosure of a 2.1 billion dollar financial hole. The arrest came after Wirecard questioned whether trustees had held money on its behalf. Braun's release marks a development in the ongoing investigation into Wirecard's financial dealings.

site_title: Women, babies at risk as Covid-19 disrupts health services, World Bank warns
summary: Millions of women and children in poor countries are at risk due to the Covid-19 pandemic disrupting health services, including neonatal and maternity care, immunisations, and contraception. The World Bank's Global Financing Facility warned that the pandemic is causing a decline in essential health services, with 87% of countries reporting disruptions to health workforces and 75% experiencing shortages of key medicines. This could lead to 26 million women losing access to contraception, resulting in nearly eight million unintended pregnancies.

site_title: Sony plans to wring more revenue from chip arm via subscriptions
summary: Sony is developing subscription-based services for its semiconductor customers to increase revenue. The company aims to provide solutions, including software and support, to businesses using its sensors for applications beyond photography, such as autonomous driving and factory automation. Sony plans to offer hands-on support and customized tools, with the goal of becoming a provider of solutions to companies, similar to Amazon Web Services. The move is expected to strengthen the company's hardware sales and bring self-sustaining revenue to its semiconductor group.

site_title: Ben & Jerry's joins Facebook ad boycott over hate speech
summary: US ice-cream giant Ben & Jerry's announced it will pause all paid advertising on Facebook and Instagram in the US as of July 1, joining the "Stop the Hate for Profit" initiative. The company cited Facebook's failure to crack down on hate speech and incitements to violence. Ben & Jerry's joins other prominent brands in boycotting the social network, following similar actions by companies like Nike and Reebok. The move is supported by rights groups including the Anti-Defamation League and the NAACP.

site_title: Seoul: Shares jump as recovery hopes rise, North Korea tensions diffuse
summary: South Korean shares jumped 1.42% on Wednesday, closing at 2,161.51, as hopes for global economic recovery strengthened after US and eurozone data, and North Korea suspended military action plans. Market heavyweights Samsung Electronics and SK Hynix led gains, while the won strengthened to 1,199.4 per dollar. Foreigners were net sellers, but money and debt markets saw a rise in treasury bond futures and a fall in yields.

site_title: Indonesia to place funds in state banks to support economy
summary: Indonesia's finance minister, Sri Mulyani Indrawati, announced plans to transfer 30 trillion rupiah (S$2.96 billion) to four state banks to support the economy amid the coronavirus pandemic. The funds will be used to expand lending, targeting the real sector and applying an interest rate of 80% of the central bank's benchmark rate. The move aims to help the country's economy, which is expected to contract for the first time since 1999 in April-June. The state banks will prioritize lending to farmers, food and medical equipment businesses, and labour-intensive industries.

site_title: Tencent confirms iflix purchase; firm led by ex-Murdoch executives also submitted bid
summary: Tencent has confirmed its purchase of iflix's assets, including content, technology, and resources, to boost its WeTV streaming service. The deal aims to expand WeTV's audience base in South-east Asia, offering international, local, and original content. Iflix, which has struggled with debt, was also bid on by Crown Media, an Australian firm led by former Murdoch executives. The purchase price is reportedly several tens of millions of dollars, significantly lower than iflix's expected valuation through a public listing.

site_title: Daily Debrief: What Happened Today
summary: Singapore's Elections Department has introduced guidelines for safe campaigning and political broadcasts during the upcoming General Elections 2020. A new constituency political broadcast has been added to allow smaller parties to reach voters. The government has also set up a $50m lab to drive innovations in Singapore's built environment. Meanwhile, more than 187,000 workers have been affected by cost-saving measures, and the government land sales programme has moderated due to the Covid-19 pandemic. The Straits Times Index (STI) dipped 6.3 points on Wednesday due to fears of a second wave of Covid-19 cases.

site_title: Grab puts partnership with troubled Wirecard on hold
summary: Grab, a South-east Asian ride-hailing and payments company, has put its partnership with scandal-hit Wirecard on hold due to the German payments firm's US$2.10 billion financial hole. The partnership, announced in March, aimed to process transactions via Grab's e-wallet in Malaysia, Philippines, and Singapore. Wirecard's former boss was arrested on suspicion of falsifying accounts, and Germany's financial regulator filed a complaint against the company. Grab has paused business integration work on the partnership, pending further notice.

site_title: Probe finds procedure violations in Pakistan airliner crash, minister says
summary: Pakistan's aviation minister says an investigation into the Pakistan International Airlines Airbus A320 crash that killed 97 has found procedure violations, including pilots not following set procedures due to the coronavirus pandemic. The aircraft was "100 per cent fit" but came down 1 km short of the runway during its second attempt to land. The investigation report was presented in parliament, with the minister stating that the pilots were not "focused" during the crash.

site_title: Indonesia taxi operator Blue Bird sees demand rebound as virus curbs ease
summary: Indonesia's largest taxi operator, Blue Bird, has seen a sharp rebound in demand for its services since the easing of social distancing rules, with about half of its 20,000 taxis returning to service. Demand had plunged 80% in April, but has since recovered. The company's president director, Noni Purnomo, expects a slow reboot to Indonesia's economy, with a possible recovery by mid-2022. Blue Bird has postponed expanding its electric vehicle fleet until demand recovers. The company's shares have slumped 55% this year.

site_title: Elections Department issues guidelines on safe campaigning, political broadcasts
summary: The Elections Department of Singapore has issued guidelines on safe campaigning and political broadcasts ahead of the upcoming elections. A new constituency political broadcast has been introduced, allowing candidates from Single Member Constituencies and smaller parties to reach voters. The broadcasts will be held from July 3 to 7 on MediaCorp's Channel 5, with specific time limits for each group. This move aims to reduce the risk of transmission of COVID-19 and promote safe campaigning practices.

site_title: TPG gets green light to run localised 5G network; Singtel, StarHub-M1 confirmed as nationwide operators
summary: TPG Telecom has received the green light to deploy localized 5G networks in Singapore, despite initially losing the bid for a nationwide 5G license. The company has successfully applied for millimeter-wave spectrum and plans to roll out next-generation 5G services. Singtel, StarHub, and M1 will remain the nationwide operators.

site_title: Jack Ma dethroned as China's richest by Tencent's Pony Ma
summary: Tencent Holdings' US$40 billion surge has propelled founder Pony Ma to surpass Jack Ma as China's richest person, with a net worth of US$50 billion. Pinduoduo's more than doubling in value has also propelled founder Colin Huang to US$43 billion, pushing Hui Ka Yan of China Evergrande Group out of the top three. The coronavirus outbreak has driven the digitization of the workplace and changed consumer habits, boosting shares of internet companies and cementing tech tycoons' dominance among China's richest people.

images.alt_text: Tencent Holdings's US$40 billion surge this week and the recent ascent of Pinduoduo have reshaped the landscape of China's richest people.

site_title: Iran says it's ready for talks if US apologises over nuclear pact
summary: Iran's President Hassan Rouhani stated that the country would engage in talks with the US if Washington apologizes for exiting the 2015 nuclear deal, lifts sanctions, and compensates Iran. This comes after the US repeated calls for a new deal with Tehran, which Iran considers insincere. Iran has refused to negotiate unless the US fulfills its obligations under the original agreement. The country has scaled back its nuclear commitments in response to the US "maximum pressure" policy, which Rouhani says is reversible if European parties carry out their promises to shield Iran's economy.

site_title: STI dips on second-wave fears
summary: The Straits Times Index (STI) dropped 6.3 points or 0.24% to 2,628.62 on June 24, 2020, amid fears of a second wave of Covid-19 cases. The Singapore Exchange saw 1.7 billion securities worth S$1.26 billion change hands, with losers outnumbering gainers 237 to 174. The best-performing index constituent was Mapletree Industrial Trust, which rose 4.58% after a successful private placement. The decline was attributed to rising community cases in Singapore and Tokyo, sparking concerns of a second wave.

site_title: Huawei opens Shanghai flagship store as US pressure grows
summary: Huawei has opened its second global flagship store in Shanghai, China, as the company strengthens its brand presence in its core market amid US pressure. The 5,000-square-metre store aims to showcase Huawei's smartphones and consumer tech, despite the US government's allegations of intellectual property theft and espionage. Huawei faces stiff competition in the 5G phone segment and revenue growth has been impacted by the pandemic, with the company growing just 1.4% in the first quarter.

images.alt_text: Chinese telecom giant Huawei opened its second global flagship store in Shanghai on Wednesday, part of plans to strengthen its brand in its core Chinese consumer market as it faces headwinds overseas.

site_title: Olympus says to sell camera business to Japan Industrial Partners
summary: Olympus Corp has agreed to sell its loss-making camera business to Japan Industrial Partners. The deal aims to be finalized by September 30 and completed by December 31. This marks the end of a 84-year-old business. The exact terms of the deal have not been disclosed.

site_title: Singapore's food delivery surge during lockdown highlights waste problems
summary: During Singapore's "circuit-breaker" lockdown period, food delivery surged by 73% and takeaway food increased by almost a fifth per week, resulting in a significant rise in plastic waste. An estimated 1,334 tons of disposable containers were used, equivalent to the weight of 92 double-decker buses. The National Environment Agency reported a 3% increase in daily waste collected during the period. The government is taking steps to regulate plastic bag use, including requiring businesses to report on packaging and submit plans to reduce volumes or recycle by 2022.

site_title: AXA SmartPlan customers to get extra month of free insurance coverage
summary: AXA Insurance is offering existing and new SmartPlan customers an additional month of free insurance coverage upon renewal or new enrolment from June 1 to August 31, aiming to support corporate customers, particularly small and medium enterprises (SMEs), affected by the Covid-19 pandemic. The insurer is also providing the option to pay premiums via monthly interest-free instalments.

site_title: New Nokia CEO to take over a month earlier than planned
summary: Nokia's new CEO Pekka Lundmark will take over the company on August 1, a month earlier than planned. Lundmark will replace Rajeev Suri, who is stepping down after over a decade in charge. Lundmark's nomination was initially set for September 1. The change comes after Markus Rauramo, Lundmark's previous employer's CFO, was announced to take over as Lundmark's CEO from July 1.

site_title: Europe: Equities weaker at open
summary: European stock markets declined in opening deals on Wednesday, following a mixed Asian session, amid fading optimism over reopening economies due to rising coronavirus cases. The FTSE 100 index fell 0.6% to 6,283.88 points, while the DAX 30 index and Paris CAC 40 declined 0.3% each. Analysts attributed the decline to concerns over coronavirus news, particularly in the US and South America.

site_title: 191 new Covid-19 cases in Singapore, including 7 in the community
summary: There are 191 new Covid-19 cases in Singapore, bringing the total to 42,623. The cases include 7 in the community, comprising 2 Singaporeans, 2 work pass holders, and 3 work permit holders. The majority of cases, 184, are migrant workers living in dormitories.

site_title: Expect APAC gaming companies' leverage to stay elevated on virus-induced earnings plunge: Moody's
summary: Moody's Investors Service predicts APAC gaming companies' leverage to remain elevated due to the ongoing pandemic's impact on earnings. Nine gaming companies with APAC operations have negative outlooks, but most can withstand temporary cash burn. EBITDA is expected to fall 70% in 2020, but recover gradually in 2021. Operators in Malaysia and Australia are expected to recover sooner due to domestic customer bases, while those relying on tourism will take longer. Genting Singapore Limited has the largest liquidity buffer, while Studio City Finance's liquidity will run out in less than a year.

site_title: UK mall landlords expect worst as US$3.1b rent comes due
summary: UK mall landlords expect a poor rent collection rate as about £2.5 billion (S$4.34 billion) in rent is due, with about half collected in the previous quarter due to government restrictions on evictions and debt servicing. Landlords, including Intu Properties and British Land, are in talks with lenders to secure debt waivers, while retailers are renegotiating rent and lease terms, and pushing for turnover-based rents. The government's focus on retail jobs may not extend to property owners, potentially destabilizing the property funding ecosystem and contributing to the economic impact of the crisis.

site_title: Malaysian palm oil producers step up perks to retain foreign workers amid pandemic
summary: Malaysian palm oil producers are offering incentives, including bonuses and improved facilities, to retain foreign workers amid the COVID-19 pandemic, which has exacerbated a labor shortage in the industry. Thousands of workers, mainly from Indonesia and Bangladesh, have abandoned plantations, threatening to reduce output and exports. The industry employs nearly 337,000 foreigners, but is still short of over 37,000 field workers, which could delay harvesting and curb oil production.

site_title: Malaysia's May CPI falls 2.9% y-o-y, weaker than forecast
summary: Malaysia's consumer price index (CPI) fell 2.9% in May, weaker than forecast, marking the third consecutive month of subdued consumption. This decline is attributed to cheaper pump prices. The result contrasts with a Reuters poll's forecast of a 2.7% annual fall in May.

site_title: Oil tankers carrying two months of Venezuelan output stuck at sea
summary: At least 16 tankers carrying nearly two months worth of Venezuelan oil are stuck at sea due to US sanctions, with buyers shunning the oil to avoid falling foul of regulations. The vessels, carrying 18.1 million barrels of oil, have been at sea for over six months and have failed to unload, incurring hefty demurrage charges. The US is tightening sanctions to cut Venezuela's oil exports and deprive the government of revenue, despite the country's economic collapse.

site_title: T-Mobile shares priced at US$103 each in SoftBank sale
summary: T-Mobile US shares were sold at a price of US$103 each by SoftBank Group as part of a US$20 billion stock divestment plan. The sale price is a 4% discount to T-Mobile's closing price, with the funds to be used for a US$41 billion share buyback and debt reduction plan. This marks a major step in SoftBank's plan to sell assets and relieve pressure on the company after investments from its Vision Fund soured, impacting earnings.

images.alt_text: US wireless carrier T-Mobile US said it has priced a sale of its shares at US$103 each in a deal that will see SoftBank Group divest a portion of its stake - a major step in the Japanese conglomerate's plan to sell assets.

site_title: GE quick takes: Lee Hsien Yang joins PSP; PAP introduces new candidates
summary: Singapore will hold its election on July 10, with 93 seats in 31 constituencies up for contest. Lee Hsien Yang, brother of Prime Minister Lee Hsien Loong, has joined the Progress Singapore Party (PSP), while the PAP has introduced its first slate of four new candidates. The PSP will contest nine constituencies with 24 candidates, down from 44 initially announced. The Reform Party has withdrawn from contesting the West Coast GRC, and opposition parties are ready to compete in the polls, which could be the second election with all seats contested since independence in 2015.

site_title: Tokyo: Stocks close lower
summary: Tokyo stocks closed lower on Wednesday, with the Nikkei 225 index falling 0.07% to 22,534.32, and the Topix index dropping 0.42% to 1,580.50. The move came after the Tokyo metropolitan government confirmed 55 new coronavirus cases, the highest since the country lifted a nationwide state of emergency. The yen strengthened against the US dollar, weighing on the market. Investors struggled to find direction amid a lack of fresh clues, and exporters were mixed, with Toyota gaining and Nissan dropping.

site_title: Notifications on cost-saving measures affected over 187,000 workers: MOM
summary: The Ministry of Manpower (MOM) in Singapore reported that over 187,000 employees were affected by cost-saving measures implemented by 4,800 employers in response to the Covid-19 pandemic. The majority of employers were from sectors severely impacted by the pandemic, including accommodation and food services and construction. The top cost-saving measures included no-pay leave, salary adjustments, and shorter workweeks, with most employees experiencing salary reductions of up to 25%. MOM and the Tripartite Alliance for Fair and Progressive Employment Practices (TAFEP) will continue to guide and support employers and employees to weather the pandemic's impact.

site_title: Trump's brother seeks to block niece's unflattering memoir: report
summary: Donald Trump's brother, Robert S. Trump, has requested a restraining order to block the publication of his niece Mary Trump's memoir "Too Much and Never Enough: How My Family Created the World's Most Dangerous Man." The book, set to release on July 28, is expected to detail a "nightmare of traumas, destructive relationships and a tragic combination of neglect and abuse" within the Trump family. Robert S. Trump alleges that Mary Trump is violating a nondisclosure agreement related to the estate of their grandfather, Donald Trump's father, Fred Trump.

site_title: Tokyo expects 'large number' of new virus cases on Wednesday: governor
summary: Tokyo Governor Yuriko Koike expects a "large number" of new coronavirus cases on Wednesday due to a cluster of infections at an office, with test results adding to the seven previously found cases. Additionally, group testing in Shinjuku is expected to yield over 10 positive results.

site_title: Relaxed 'hukou' rules spark China housing rebound beyond Beijing
summary: China's property market is experiencing a rebound, driven by relaxed "hukou" rules and a gradual economic recovery. The relaxation of regional permits has boosted migration and real estate demand beyond major hubs like Beijing and Shanghai. Housing sales in cities like Hangzhou, Nanjing, and Jinan have surged, with prices rising 49-97% from 2019 monthly averages. The market's resilience is attributed to domestic demand, and experts predict a continued housing boom in Asia, potentially charting a path for the rest of the world.

site_title: Chinese banks expand in world's priciest office market
summary: Chinese banks CMB International Capital, China Minsheng Banking, and Orient Finance Holdings have expanded their office space in Hong Kong's Central hub, joining Alibaba and other mainland firms. They leased additional floors, with CMBI taking 17,000 sq ft and Minsheng signing up for 12,000 sq ft, despite muted demand from global firms amid the COVID-19 pandemic. The expansion contrasts with a 12-year high of 5% vacancy rate in the prime business district, with Hong Kong's office rents averaging US$313 per square foot, the world's costliest.

site_title: UK house price rebound from virus seen cooling by year's end
summary: The UK housing market has rebounded from the coronavirus lockdown, with house prices rising 2.4% in May compared to the same period last year. Despite this, prices are expected to grow by 3% in the third quarter before cooling towards the end of the year due to the economic impact of the virus. The increased mortgage requirements and rising unemployment will lead to reduced demand, particularly among first-time buyers.

site_title: Credit Suisse starts probe into SoftBank-linked funds
summary: Credit Suisse has launched a probe into its supply-chain finance funds, which invest in loans arranged by Lex Greensill and backed by SoftBank Vision Fund. The loans are sourced by Greensill Capital, a company also backed by SoftBank. The bank is reviewing certain aspects of the matter as standard practice. This move comes after concerns about the involvement of SoftBank and Greensill in the funds.

site_title: Australians' trust in China plummets amid rifts
summary: Australians' trust in China has plummeted, with 23% of respondents now believing Beijing acts responsibly on the world stage, down from 52% in 2018. The decline is attributed to rising confrontations between the two trading partners, including China's increasing assertiveness under President Xi Jinping and public diplomatic spats. The Lowy Institute poll also found 94% of respondents want Australia to reduce its economic dependence on China and 82% support sanctions on Chinese officials linked to human rights abuses.

images.alt_text: Recent months have seen China slap trade sanctions on Australian goods, sentence an Australian citizen to death and mock Canberra's long-standing alliance with the United States.

site_title: Gold poised to challenge US$1,800 as virus resurgence fans demand
summary: Gold futures have rallied to within 1% of the US$1,800 an ounce mark, driven by a resurgence in coronavirus cases and concerns of currency debasement and inflation. The Federal Reserve's interest rate cuts and stimulus packages have also contributed to the surge. Analysts predict gold could reach a record US$2,000 in 12 months, with holdings in bullion-backed exchange-traded funds soaring to a record. This rally has also boosted miners, with shares of Newmont and Evolution Mining increasing 36% and 43% respectively this year.

site_title: Hong Kong satirists say self-censorship already blunting dissent
summary: Hong Kong satirists and journalists claim self-censorship is already stifling dissent ahead of China's planned anti-subversion law, which will bypass the city's legislature and criminalize subversion, secession, and colluding with foreign forces. The law's implementation has sparked fears of an end to Hong Kong's liberties, with critics warning of a "major cleansing" of the city. The sudden shutdown of satirical news show "Headliner" and pressure on journalists to change their coverage of politics have become increasingly risky, with city leader Carrie Lam labeling those critical of the security law as "enemies of the people".

site_title: Japan's success in curbing Covid-19 cases now hampers search for cures
summary: Japan's efforts to combat COVID-19 have hindered clinical trials for treatments and vaccines, as the country's low number of new cases has led to a shortage of patients. Despite having a robust medical system, Japan has approved a COVID-19 therapy, Avigan, in other countries, but its regulatory approval is delayed due to the need for more patients. This shortage may force Japan to rely on data from other countries, such as Russia and India, to aid in regulatory approvals.

site_title: Government land sales programme continues to moderate given Covid-19 impact
summary: The Singapore government's land sales programme for the second half of 2020 has continued to moderate due to the Covid-19 pandemic, with a confirmed list of three private residential sites yielding 1,370 private residential units and 1,500 square meters of commercial space. This is the lowest number of units proposed since 2016. The government has calibrated the supply to avoid potential shortages, with a focus on maintaining a balance between supply and demand, and has reserved additional sites for future development if needed.

site_title: Japan car sales recovering after big fall in April, May: Nissan executive
summary: Japan's car sales are recovering after a decline in April and May due to the coronavirus impact. According to Nissan executive Asako Hoshino, demand has "recovered sharply" and is expected to return to pre-coronavirus levels if the situation persists. Nissan's Kicks SUV crossover model was launched in Japan, marking a positive step in the market's recovery. The company's sales outlook is cautiously optimistic, with Hoshino expressing confidence in the market's resilience.

site_title: Thai May exports fall 22.5% y-o-y, worse than forecast
summary: Thai exports in May fell 22.5% from the previous year, exceeding forecasts, due to lower shipments of cars and computers. However, gold shipments surged 735% year-over-year. Excluding gold, exports declined 27.8% year-on-year. This decline marks a reversal from April's surprise 2.12% increase.

site_title: PAP introduces first slate of four new candidates for General Election
summary: The People's Action Party (PAP) has introduced its first slate of four new candidates for the upcoming General Election in Singapore. The candidates include Edward Chia, Desmond Tan, Ivan Lim, and Nadia Ahmad Samdin, who have diverse backgrounds and interests. The PAP aims to build the adaptive capacity of society to overcome the Covid-19 crisis and emerge stronger. Prime Minister Lee Hsien Loong has called for an early election, citing the need for a fresh five-year mandate.

site_title: Malaysia: Shares open lower on Wednesday
summary: Malaysia's FTSE Bursa Malaysia Kuala Lumpur Composite Index opened lower on Wednesday, down 2.94 points or 0.20%, at 1,504.10. Volume reached 167.84 million lots worth RM36.09 million. Gainers outpaced losers 186-80.

site_title: Gas industry sees strong demand post-Covid, LNG shortfall by mid-decade
summary: The gas industry expects strong demand post-Covid, with LNG seen as a key fuel for backing wind and solar power, replacing coal-fired power, and producing hydrogen globally. Despite the crisis, a supply shortfall is anticipated by mid-decade due to delays in gas projects. Gas producers and buyers agree on the need for substantial investment in new projects and liquefaction. Exxon Mobil Corp's Nathan Fay emphasized the long-run outlook for gas, stating it will remain crucial for the industry's future.

site_title: Singapore Standards Council to set benchmarks in emerging areas for post-Covid economy
summary: Singapore's Singapore Standards Council (SSC) will develop benchmarks for emerging areas such as biometrics, air conditioning, and environmental sustainability to support the post-COVID economy. The council will also focus on standards for autonomous robots, self-driving vehicles, and green technologies like renewable power and sustainable food production. Plans include adopting international standards for "smart cards" and collaborating with the Building and Construction Authority on air-conditioning and mechanical ventilation standards. The move aims to strengthen business resilience and support industry transformation efforts.

site_title: With contracts cancelled and debts mounting, offshore oil drillers face another shakeout
summary: The offshore oil drilling industry is facing a second wave of bankruptcies in four years due to a historic drop in energy prices, with four of the seven largest offshore drillers seeking protection from creditors or debt restructuring talks. The sector's decline is expected to have a broad impact, with many oil producers withdrawing from projects and delaying exploration. Drillers are writing down billions of dollars on the value of their fleets, and finding new money will be difficult. Up to 200 of the 800 existing floating rigs may need to be scrapped to regain profitable lease rates, with little hope for a rebound in the next few years.

site_title: KKR raises US$10b for its biggest Asia buyout fund
summary: KKR has raised over $10 billion for its third Asia fund, surpassing its $12.5 billion target and amassing the largest buyout war chest in US private equity history for the region. The fund, which aims to close its first round by the end of June, will benefit from the global economic turmoil caused by the coronavirus and trade war. This move comes as purely Asia-focused funds have seen 45% lower fund-raising activity than the previous five-year average, and smaller funds have struggled to raise capital, with 60% meeting their targets.

site_title: Asia: Stocks touch 4-month top on dogged optimism
summary: Asian shares reached a four-month high on Wednesday, driven by optimism about the global economy's re-opening despite accelerating coronavirus cases. The MSCI Asia-Pacific index rose 0.39% to its highest level since early March. Japan's Nikkei and Chinese blue chips also gained, while European shares were supported by mining and healthcare stocks. US shares edged to fresh records despite tariff uncertainty, with the S&P 500 and Nasdaq reaching new highs.

images.alt_text: Asian shares crept to a four-month high on Wednesday as investors remained stubbornly upbeat on the outlook for a re-opening of the global economy even as cases of the coronavirus looked to be accelerating to new peaks.

site_title: Johnson Controls, EDB to set up S$50m lab to drive innovations in Singapore's built environment
summary: Johnson Controls and the Singapore Economic Development Board (EDB) are partnering to set up a S$50 million innovation lab in Singapore to drive AI-based innovations in the built environment industry. The lab, expected to open by end September, will have over 100 employees within four years, with a focus on developing digital technologies that combine building, spatial, and behavioral data with analytics and machine learning. The lab aims to create customisable, autonomous, or voice-activated solutions for property owners, facilities managers, and building occupants, and will also explore partnerships with local research organisations and property developers.

site_title: Shares of Japan retailers gain as sales data hint at post-outbreak rebound
summary: Shares in Japanese retailers surged following strong sales data from Nitori Holdings and Shimamura, indicating a post-outbreak rebound. Nitori's same-store sales jumped 47% in June, while Shimamura saw a 27% increase. The data, released after Japan lifted its coronavirus state of emergency, suggests local shoppers are regaining confidence. These early indicators of retail recovery could have a positive impact on the broader market.

site_title: Australia: Shares rise on quick rebound hopes, New Zealand up ahead of rate decision
summary: Australian shares rose 0.26% to 5,969.7, tracking a stronger Wall Street, as hopes for a quick economic recovery persisted following improved US data and upbeat regulator comments. Technology shares rose 1.18% and metals stocks 0.73% led by Afterpay and Ioneer. Gold stocks also rose 1.7%. In New Zealand, the benchmark index rose 0.66% ahead of a central bank policy decision, with expectations of a rate hold and dovish tone.

site_title: Brazil suspends WhatsApp's new payments system
summary: Brazil's central bank suspended WhatsApp's new payments system, citing concerns over competition, efficiency, and data privacy. The system, launched last week, allowed users to send money via chats, but the central bank said it was rolled out without analysis. Visa and Mastercard were ordered to halt payments and transfers via the system, with fines and sanctions possible if they don't comply. WhatsApp plans to work with local partners and regulators to address concerns, but the move is a setback for Facebook's payments ambitions.

images.alt_text: WhatsApp is reportedly the fifth-most impersonated company in phishing attacks, with a staggering 13,000 percent increase quarter-on-quarter growth in phishing URLs.

site_title: Trump administration sees no loophole in new Huawei curb
summary: The US government, under Commerce Secretary Wilbur Ross, asserts there are no loopholes in a new rule curbing global chip sales to China's Huawei, aiming to cut off its access to global supplies. The rule expands US authority to require licenses for shipments of certain foreign-made chips to Huawei. Industry lawyers and lawmakers argue the rule is overly complex, unclear, and riddled with gaps, leaving key transactions beyond the controls. The Commerce Department plans to aggressively enforce the rule and pursue any attempts to evade its intent.

site_title: mm2 Asia targets Q3 Singapore launch for on-demand movie streaming platform
summary: mm2 Asia, a film production group, plans to launch Cathay CineHOME, a pay-per-view on-demand streaming platform in Singapore, targeting Q3 2020. The platform will offer immediate access to movies after their theatrical window, complementing its Cathay Cineplexes cinemas. The service aims to cater to movie lovers unable to attend cinemas, with no intention to replace the cinema experience. The company has not finalized business terms with major studios and is focused on its digital strategy post-pandemic.

site_title: Bank of Japan has sufficient schemes to respond to pandemic: June meeting summary
summary: The Bank of Japan has sufficient schemes to respond to the pandemic, according to a June meeting summary. Board members emphasized the need to use available tools to protect businesses, jobs, and markets. The central bank can now carefully examine the effects of its measures.

site_title: Virgin Australia bondholders lodge rival proposal to US firms
summary: Virgin Australia bondholders have submitted a rival proposal to US private equity firms Bain Capital and Cyrus Capital Partners, aiming to recapitalize the struggling airline and maintain its listed status. The proposal, which would keep the airline under public ownership, was made two days after the US firms made final offers to administrator Deloitte. The bondholders' plan seeks to recoup more of their investment and provide certainty for the airline's strong operating plan.

site_title: Indonesia anti-trust agency says 7 airlines guilty over ticket prices
summary: Indonesia's anti-trust agency has found seven airlines guilty of price-fixing, but not as a cartel. The airlines, including Garuda Indonesia and Lion Group's Lion Air, were found to have followed each other's price moves in 2019, leading to inflationary pressures and impacting hospitality businesses. The agency ruled they engaged in "concerted action or parallelism." The airlines will face penalties for their actions, which affected consumers and the economy.

site_title: Wirecard clients get cold feet after 1.9b euros goes missing
summary: Wirecard, a German payments company, is facing a crisis after €1.9 billion of its funds went missing. Several business partners, including Singapore's Grab Holdings and French telecom carrier Orange, are distancing themselves from the company, citing concerns over its technology. Wirecard's licenses with major card companies, such as Mastercard and Visa, are at risk of being revoked if the missing funds are not found. Interim CEO James Freis must reassure business partners to mitigate the damage, but the company has refused to comment on the situation.

site_title: US adds 792 more deaths in 24 hours: Johns Hopkins
summary: The US reported 792 additional deaths from COVID-19 in a 24-hour period, bringing the total to 121,176 deaths out of over 2.34 million cases, according to Johns Hopkins University. Despite lifting lockdown measures in many states, a rebound in infections has been seen in 20 states, primarily in the south and west. US government health experts, led by Anthony Fauci, warned of "historic" challenges ahead and a critical two-week period to address surging infections in states like Florida and Texas.

site_title: Hong Kong: Stocks start higher
summary: Hong Kong stocks started higher on Wednesday, following a strong lead from Wall Street and Europe, as data suggested the worst of the economic pain may have passed. The Hang Seng Index rose 0.51% to 25,034.87, while the Shanghai and Shenzhen Composite Indexes also edged up. The positive trend is attributed to the end of the worst economic pain and investors' optimism about US-EU trade talks.

site_title: Singapore shares rise on global gains, election news; STI up 0.1% at open
summary: Singapore's benchmark Straits Times Index (STI) rose 0.1% at open on Wednesday, tracking global gains after Prime Minister Lee Hsien Loong called a General Election on July 10. The STI is up 2.6 points to 2,637.5, with gains outnumbering losses 77 to 28. Key stocks including Singtel, Genting Singapore, and Yoma Strategic rose, while banking stocks were mixed. Global markets, including the US, Europe, and Asia, also saw gains, with the Nasdaq Composite Index jumping to a record high.

site_title: Mapletree Industrial Trust raises S$410m from upsized placement at top end of price range
summary: Mapletree Industrial Trust (MIT) raised S$410 million through an upsized private placement at the top end of its issue price range of S$2.80 per unit. The placement, which was fully subscribed, will issue approximately 146.4 million new units. The funds will be used to partially fund the proposed acquisition of 14 US data centers and to repay debt. The trust's manager will also use the proceeds for future acquisitions and general corporate purposes.

site_title: Obama helps raise US$11m for Biden in online fundraiser
summary: Former US President Barack Obama helped raise over $11 million for White House hopeful Joe Biden during a virtual fundraiser, the most successful finance event of the campaign. Obama praised Biden's ability to heal the country and suggested a "great awakening" among Americans could help defeat incumbent President Donald Trump. The fundraiser, which featured a split-screen appearance between Obama and Biden, highlighted the power of grassroots donors and marked a significant boost for Biden's campaign.

site_title: Finland to open up for some European leisure travellers
summary: Finland plans to scrap a 14-day quarantine period for leisure travelers arriving from some European countries starting July 13, provided Covid-19 infection rates remain low. Countries qualifying for the easing of restrictions include Italy, Germany, and others, where infections have not exceeded 8 cases per 100,000 inhabitants over two weeks. The rule will remain in place for travelers from Sweden, where the infection rate is higher. The decision aims to support tourism while maintaining caution to prevent a resurgence of the virus.

site_title: Lee Hsien Yang joins Progress Singapore Party
summary: Singapore's Prime Minister Lee Hsien Loong's brother, Lee Hsien Yang, has joined the Progress Singapore Party (PSP), a new opposition party led by former PAP politician Tan Cheng Bock. Yang, 62, made the announcement after months of speculation, citing his commitment to Tan's vision for a better Singapore. The move comes ahead of the July 10 general election, in which PSP plans to contest eight constituencies, including Tanjong Pagar, where Yang's father served for nearly 60 years.

site_title: Yoma eyes controlling stake in Wave Money in US$76.5m deal
summary: Yoma Strategic has proposed a US$76.5 million deal to acquire a controlling stake in Wave Money, a mobile payments firm in Myanmar, through its new investment holding company YMFS Holdings. Yoma plans to invest up to US$25 million in YMFS, with the remaining consideration coming from a consortium of investors. The deal will give Yoma a 40.72% effective interest in Wave Money, strengthening its presence in Myanmar's financial services sector and enabling greater collaboration between Wave Money and its businesses.

site_title: SMEs, low-wage workers among concerns of 2nd batch of new PAP candidates
summary: The People's Action Party (PAP) has unveiled its second batch of new candidates for the upcoming Singapore general election, focusing on concerns of small and medium enterprises, sustainability, low-wage workers, and the elderly. Among the new candidates are senior civil servants, lawyers, and grassroots volunteers, who highlight their experience and passion for serving Singaporeans. The PAP is introducing a total of 26 new candidates over three days, with no clear indication of whether Prime Minister Lee Hsien Loong's brother Lee Hsien Yang might run as an opposition candidate.

site_title: Reserve Bank of New Zealand holds rates at all-time low
summary: The Reserve Bank of New Zealand (RBNZ) held its official cash rate at 0.25% in a widely expected move, maintaining its large-scale asset purchase program at NZ$60 billion. The Monetary Policy Committee stated it is prepared to provide additional stimulus as necessary, potentially expanding its asset purchase program and preparing for additional monetary policy tools. Economists had unanimously expected this move, citing the ongoing economic recovery in New Zealand.

site_title: Tokyo: Nikkei index opens slightly higher on Wednesday
summary: Tokyo's Nikkei 225 index opened 0.26% higher on Wednesday, driven by a stronger yen against the dollar and profit-taking, offsetting support from Wall Street rallies. The benchmark index rose 59.21 points to 22,608.26.

images.alt_text: Tokyo's key Nikkei index opened modestly higher on Wednesday as a higher yen against the dollar and profit-taking offset support from rallies on Wall Street.

site_title: Plastic 'has entered' Antarctic terrestrial food chain
summary: Scientists have found bits of polystyrene in the guts of tiny soil-dwelling organisms in Antarctica, marking the first evidence of microplastics contamination in the world's most remote land-based food systems. Researchers collected the organisms from a contaminated polystyrene foam on King George Island and detected plastic fragments through imaging techniques. The findings raise concerns about the potential risks for fragile polar ecosystems and the potential for plastic to redistribute through the soil profile and transfer to predators. This discovery highlights the widespread nature of plastic pollution.

images.alt_text: Scientists have found bits of polystyrene in the guts of tiny, soil-dwelling organisms in the Antarctic, raising concern that microplastics pollution has already "deeply" entered the world's most remote land-based food systems.

site_title: US energy laggards still not Paris compliant: analysis
summary: US-based oil and gas majors, such as ExxonMobil, Chevron, and ConocoPhillips, are failing to align their business plans with the Paris climate deal's goals, with only Chevron committing to a 1-3% reduction in overall emissions. European companies, like ENI and Repsol, are more Paris-friendly, with plans to reach "net zero" emissions by 2050. The energy industry's continued investment in new oil and gas fields poses a problem, as it contradicts the need for reduced consumption to meet Paris targets, according to market analyst Carbon Tracker.

site_title: Twitter hides 'abusive' Trump tweet targeting protestors
summary: Twitter hid a tweet from President Donald Trump, threatening to use "serious force" against protestors in the US capital, citing rules over abusive content. The move marked the first time Twitter took action against the president for an "abusive" tweet. The platform labeled the tweet as violating its standards on promoting violence and made it accessible "in the public's interest" after users could click through to read it. The action escalates a dispute between the White House and social media firms, with the president accusing them of bias against conservatives.

site_title: KIT, Keppel Energy bag S$700m sustainability-linked loan from DBS, OCBC
summary: Keppel Energy Trust (KIT) and Keppel Energy have secured a S$700 million, seven-year sustainability-linked loan from DBS Bank and OCBC Bank. The loan is tied to carbon emission targets for KIT's jointly owned gas-fired co-generation plant, with interest rates to be reduced if targets are met. The move is seen as a significant step towards reducing environmental impact and supports KIT's sustainability efforts, which include the implementation of water management and smart chemical handling systems.

images.alt_text: Kepel Infrastructure Trust (KIT) and Keppel Energy have obtained a S$700 million sustainability-linked loan from DBS Bank and OCBC Bank. The loan is linked to carbon emission targets for KIT and Keppel Energy's jointly owned gas-fired co-generation plant, Keppel Merlimau Cogen Plant.

site_title: Huawei CFO extradition hearing to stretch into 2021
summary: Huawei CFO Meng Wanzhou's extradition hearing to the US will extend into April 2021, contrary to the initial October 2020 schedule. The case, which involves allegations of bank fraud and misleading HSBC on Huawei's business dealings in Iran, has been delayed due to the coronavirus pandemic. A Canadian judge ruled in May that the case meets the standard of double criminality, and hearings on Meng's remaining claims will take place between July 2020 and April 2021. Meng has been on house arrest in Vancouver since her arrest in 2018.

site_title: Macron says EU virus package 'advancing', in talks with Dutch PM
summary: French President Emmanuel Macron said EU coronavirus recovery fund talks are "advancing" with Dutch Prime Minister Mark Rutte, a key holdout against the plan. The 750-billion-euro fund aims to support poorer southern European countries. Macron and Rutte met ahead of a July 17-18 EU summit, where leaders will try to seal a deal. France and Germany initially proposed the rescue plan, which the "frugal four" countries, including the Netherlands, oppose, citing loan conditions rather than grants. The negotiations are advancing, with Macron urging all parties to be heard.

site_title: Volkswagen explores acquisition of car rental group Europcar: sources
summary: Volkswagen is in talks to acquire car rental firm Europcar Mobility Group SA, a deal that would allow the German car maker to better capitalize on its fleet. The acquisition comes as Europcar struggles with the economic fallout of the Covid-19 pandemic. Volkswagen sold Europcar to Eurazeo SE in 2006 and has now expressed interest in acquiring the company. The talks are preliminary and a deal is not yet certain due to the financial toll of the coronavirus outbreak on Europcar.

site_title: Oil pulls back after hitting highest since early March
summary: Oil prices slipped on Tuesday after US crude inventories were expected to show a record high, pulling prices back from their highest levels since early March. Crude benchmarks declined after surprise comments from White House trade adviser Peter Navarro, which unsettled markets. Brent futures fell 1.0% to $42.63 a barrel, while US West Texas Intermediate crude fell 0.9% to $40.37. Analysts attributed the decline to technical resistance and profit taking, as US crude stocks rose to an all-time high of 539.3 million barrels.

site_title: Ukraine airline official suspended after dead puppies found on plane
summary: Ukraine International Airlines (UIA) has suspended a senior employee after 38 dead French bulldog puppies were found on one of its planes in Toronto. The investigation is ongoing to determine the cause of death. UIA has also suspended the transportation of animals on its Boeing-767s. Canada has launched its own investigation into the incident. The flight, which had 550 dogs and 89 cats, was not experiencing air pressure issues, according to the airline.

site_title: China reports 12 new coronavirus cases on the mainland
summary: China reported 12 new coronavirus cases on the mainland, down from 22 the previous day, with seven in Beijing linked to a wholesale food market. Three new imported cases and three asymptomatic cases were also reported. This marks a decline in cases compared to the previous day, indicating a possible slowing of the outbreak.

site_title: ESG investing is building resistance to layoffs
summary: ESG investing is building resistance to layoffs as companies face restructuring amid the pandemic. Despite layoffs, Banyan Tree Holdings' decision to support staff with transition packages and reskilling classes has been seen positively by investors. Research suggests that investors react negatively to layoffs, but those induced by adverse market conditions are perceived as a necessary cost-cutting measure. ESG investing is gaining traction, with social factors becoming more important and contributing to stock valuations. Companies are shifting towards a more holistic approach incorporating stakeholder interests, and regulators and the public are increasing scrutiny on companies' human capital management and employee safety.

site_title: Dell, VMware shares rise on spinoff report
summary: Dell Technologies and VMware shares rose after a report suggested Dell was considering selling its stake in VMware, estimated to be worth $50 billion. Dell shares jumped 18% and VMware rose 9% following the news. The move could help Dell reduce debt and re-energize the company, which has been struggling since its success in the PC market in the 1990s. Founder Michael Dell has been seeking to reposition the firm to compete with cloud computing rivals such as Amazon and Microsoft.

site_title: Finding the way in the new normal
summary: Multinational corporations in the region have swiftly adapted to the COVID-19 pandemic's impact, accelerating trends such as e-commerce, digital payments, and telecommuting. The pandemic is expected to lead to a 'new normal' with uncertain characteristics, requiring companies to alter their operations. As the pandemic's impact continues, countries in the region are responding with economic stimulus measures, such as interest rate cuts and trade agreements, to shield their economies from volatility and external threats, including US tariffs. The 'new normal' is likely to be a slow return to stability.

site_title: Microsoft chief says EU 'most influential' on tech rules
summary: Microsoft president Brad Smith stated that the EU is the global leader in setting rules for big tech, two years after implementing the GDPR. The EU's landmark data privacy law gives individuals more control over data and personal information, allowing regulators to fine and punish internet actors who break the rules. The GDPR has had a significant influence on other countries' data protection laws, with Smith citing the Australian law as an example. The EU's data protection rules have also been praised for enabling the development of tracing apps during the COVID-19 pandemic.

site_title: Wirecard must keep customer funds from Singapore business in banks here: MAS
summary: Wirecard, a German payments provider, must keep customer funds from its Singapore business in banks in Singapore, according to the Monetary Authority of Singapore (MAS). Wirecard's Singapore business activities are currently unlicensed, but the company has applied for a license under the Payment Services Act. The MAS has given a grace period for entities to apply for licenses. Former CEO Markus Braun was detained on suspicion of inflating the company's balance sheet and revenues, and Wirecard has admitted to a 1.9 billion euro missing amount, likely never existing.

site_title: Europe: Stocks close near 2-week high as PMI data brings cheer
summary: European stocks closed near a 2-week high on Tuesday, driven by a rebound in business activity and positive PMI data. The Stoxx 600 index rose 1.3% with cyclical sectors like banks and miners gaining ground. Euro zone stocks surged 1.6% after IHS Markit's PMI showed a historic downturn easing in June. Germany's DAX, France's CAC 40, and the UK's FTSE 100 also rose, with investors taking relief from White House trade adviser's comments on the US-China trade deal.

site_title: Abu Dhabi sells US$10b stake in pipelines to GIP-led group
summary: Abu Dhabi sold a $10.1 billion stake in its natural-gas pipelines to a consortium led by Global Infrastructure Partners. The deal values the pipelines at $20.7 billion and will bring cash into the UAE as it grapples with a 40% decline in crude prices. The 49% stake will be held by the consortium, with Abu Dhabi National Oil Co retaining the remaining shares. The deal is the largest infrastructure acquisition so far this year and underscores the appeal of energy assets in attracting foreign investment.

site_title: Money FM podcast: Signs of a sinister headache
summary: Claressa Monteiro discusses serious headaches and brain tumors with Dr. Lin Xuling, a consultant neuro-oncologist, on the Money FM podcast. Dr. Lin shares signs of a serious headache, including severe and persistent pain, confusion, and difficulty speaking or swallowing. She also explains how brain tumors can be treated, but notes that early detection is key. The conversation aims to raise awareness about brain tumors and their symptoms.

site_title: Mapletree Industrial Trust to buy remaining 60% stake in 14 data centres for US$210.9m
summary: Mapletree Industrial Trust (MIT) agreed to purchase the remaining 60% stake in 14 US data centres for approximately US$210.9 million. The acquisition is part of MIT's strategy to grow its high-tech buildings segment, increasing its assets under management to S$6.6 billion and data centre exposure to 39%. The proposed transaction is expected to enhance income stability and accretively increase distribution per unit and net asset value per unit. MIT plans to finance the acquisition through an equity fundraising and the issuance of new units.

images.alt_text: Upon completion of the deal, MIT's assets under management will increase to S$6.6 billion from S$5.9 billion as at March 31, 2020.

site_title: Pubs, restaurants and hotels to reopen on July 4 as England eases social distancing
summary: UK Prime Minister Boris Johnson announced that pubs, restaurants, and hotels can reopen in England on July 4, easing the coronavirus lockdown. The move comes after falling infection rates and a belief that a second wave is unlikely. Social distancing rules will be relaxed from two meters to one meter, with restrictions on gatherings and mask-wearing. Businesses, including hairdressers, places of worship, and leisure facilities, will reopen, while nightclubs, indoor gyms, and swimming pools remain closed.

site_title: US: Nasdaq ends at another record, extending stocks rally
summary: US stocks ended the day at record highs, with the Nasdaq Composite Index rising 0.7% to 10,131.37. The Dow Jones Industrial Average and S&P 500 also gained, despite increases in coronavirus cases in several states. Investors focused on improving economic data, including a big increase in new home sales in May. Tech stocks, including Apple, which announced plans to build its own chips, drove the rally. However, some companies, such as Spirit AeroSystems, fell after warning of potential violations of creditor agreements.

site_title: Wilmar shares jump 7.7%; company provides update on proposed listing of China unit
summary: Wilmar International shares jumped 7.7% on Tuesday after its China subsidiary, Yihai Kerry Arawana Holdings Co, submitted an updated initial public offering (IPO) prospectus to the Shenzhen Stock Exchange. The company confirmed it is still working on the proposed listing, with no assurance it will proceed. Wilmar's shares hit an intra-day high of S$4.26 before closing at S$4.18. The IPO aims to fund 13.87 billion yuan of investment projects with the IPO proceeds.

site_title: Down but not out; Changi Airport will soar again
summary: Changi Airport, one of the world's best airports, has been severely impacted by the COVID-19 pandemic, with passenger numbers plummeting by over 99%. Despite this, airport officials remain steadfast, vowing to persevere and work patiently to resume regular operations. Changi Airport has a long history, dating back to the 1940s, and has been recognized as the world's best airport over 620 times. The airport's resilience is attributed to its committed talent pool and innovative approach to managing costs. Officials are optimistic that the pandemic will eventually subside, and Changi Airport will resume its operations, playing a crucial role in Singapore's economic well-being.

images.alt_text: Changi Airport has first-class airport infrastructure and terminal facilities, managed and led by a proven team for 40 years.
(Above) Facsimile of the news clipping from The Malaya Tribune (20 August, 1948).

site_title: UBS says one-third of staff could work remotely on permanent basis
summary: UBS' chief operating officer, Sabine Keller-Busse, suggests that one-third of the bank's 70,000 employees could work remotely permanently after the pandemic. This hybrid approach would see back-office roles working remotely and trading operations in the office. Keller-Busse expects other banks to adopt similar models, reducing the need for real estate. The bank is assessing which roles will return to the office, with some requiring physical presence, such as bankers for IPOs. This shift could lead to a lesser need for office space in the longer term.

site_title: May consumer inflation negative again amid Covid-19 curbs
summary: Singapore's consumer prices showed deflation in May, with subdued spending amid the novel coronavirus pandemic. Despite emerging from a two-month quasi-lockdown, economists question whether inflation will pick up in the next six months. Food items are the exception, with prices increasing. The country's economic outlook remains uncertain, with some experts predicting better employment rates for graduates and opportunities for growth in areas like advanced chip packaging and sustainable aviation.

site_title: Yangzijiang Shipbuilding bags 4 vessel orders worth US$102m
summary: Yangzijiang Shipbuilding has secured four new vessel orders worth around US$102 million, bringing its total for 2020 to US$517 million. The orders are for two liquefied natural gas (LNG) tank carriers and two 56,000 deadweight ton bulk carriers. The vessels will feature environmental protection and energy efficiency features, with options for more LNG tank carriers. Deliveries are expected in early 2022 and March 2022, respectively. The new orders demonstrate Yangzijiang's growth in research and development capabilities, with a focus on "green" features.

site_title: Valentino sues to quit Fifth Avenue lease amid pandemic losses
summary: Luxury fashion retailer Valentino has sued its landlord, 693 Fifth Owner LLC, to exit its 15-year Manhattan lease nine years early due to pandemic-related losses. The US branch of Valentino cited the novel coronavirus outbreak, lockdowns, and a lack of consumer confidence as reasons for the suit. The Fifth Avenue location has been shut down since mid-March, and Valentino claimed it would struggle to pay rent even after the pandemic subsides. This is the latest in a string of retailers suing their landlords to re-evaluate pricey leases amid economic downturn.

site_title: Batman Forever and Lost Boys director Joel Schumacher dies at 80
summary: Joel Schumacher, director of Batman Forever and Lost Boys, has died at 80 due to cancer. A year-long battle with the disease led to his passing in New York City. Schumacher, known for his flamboyant style, directed two divisive Batman films and cult classic The Lost Boys. He began his career as a costume designer and went on to launch the careers of several young actors, including Matthew McConaughey and Colin Farrell. Schumacher will be remembered by friends and collaborators as a talented and influential filmmaker.

site_title: Trump reshuffles US ties with its Europe partners
summary: US President Donald Trump has reshuffled US ties with European partners, prioritizing countries like Poland with pro-Trump leaders over traditional allies. This shift is evident in Trump's strong relationship with Polish President Andrzej Duda and his criticism of Germany's defense spending and trade practices. Trump has accused Germany of being "delinquent" in its military spending and has announced plans to withdraw US troops from German bases. This move comes amid tensions on multiple fronts, including climate change, international trade, and the Nordstream pipeline.

site_title: Trump says border wall has 'stopped everything', including Covid-19
summary: US President Donald Trump claims the newly completed border wall has "stopped everything," including COVID-19, during a visit to Arizona. Over 322km of the wall have been built, with plans to complete at least 724km by the end of the year. Trump attributes the wall's effectiveness to advanced technology and says it has reduced human trafficking and drug smuggling, and prevented a "coronavirus catastrophe." This visit comes as the southwest US state of Arizona reports a record 3,591 COVID-19 cases and 42 deaths.

images.alt_text: President Donald Trump paid a visit to Arizona on Tuesday to mark the completion of hundreds of kilometres of the wall along the US-Mexico border, claiming it has "stopped everything" including Covid-19.

site_title: Bank of England Governor Bailey's stimulus withdrawal plan a daunting one
summary: UK Bank of England Governor Andrew Bailey is planning to shrink the central bank's balance sheet before raising interest rates, a challenging task that has never been attempted before. Bailey aims to reverse-engineer a £820 billion loan and asset hoard accumulated through quantitative easing, but experts warn it could take years to unwind. The move could lead to unwanted volatility and impact the government's ability to raise money on debt markets, raising concerns about the BOE's independence and ability to implement its plan.

site_title: Election will give new government fresh mandate to deal with pandemic fallout
summary: Singaporean Prime Minister Lee Hsien Loong announced a General Election, citing the need for a fresh mandate to address pandemic fallout. The current Cabinet will remain in charge during the election period to ensure continuity in ongoing operations against Covid-19. Lee stated that a new government will be able to focus on the national agenda and difficult decisions without the burden of a previous mandate. The election is seen as a chance for Singaporeans and the government to work together to overcome pandemic challenges.

site_title: Woolworths underpayment hits pub, liquor store staff; virus to affect annual profit
summary: Woolworths Group Ltd admitted to underpaying staff at its pubs and liquor stores division, citing a Covid-19 shutdown that hammered non-supermarket sales. This comes after similar confessions from other Australian companies. The underpayment is expected to impact the company's annual profit. The announcement follows previous revelations of underpayment at Woolworths' supermarkets.

site_title: Dubai property developer bets on quick rebound
summary: Dubai property developer Azizi Developments is hiring nearly 100 employees as it anticipates a rebound in the property market, driven by tentative resurgence in inquiries and sales. The company, which has 600 employees, is seeking to sell properties in 54 apartment buildings under construction. CEO Farhad Azizi believes the demand is coming from Dubai residents and international buyers, but sales are still half of what they were before the pandemic. The company aims to deliver 3,000 properties this year and revive an Islamic bond sale.

site_title: Hin Leong unlikely to be rehabilitated on its own: PwC
summary: Hin Leong Trading, an insolvent oil trader, is unlikely to be rehabilitated as a standalone company, according to a report by PricewaterhouseCoopers (PwC). The company overstated its assets by at least $3 billion, fabricating documents to mislead banks and conceal accumulated losses. With liabilities of $3.5 billion and assets of $257 million, PwC recommends that the Lim family, who own other companies including Ocean Tankers and Xihe Group, bring their personal assets to the table for restructuring. A court-appointed supervisor is overseeing the company's restructuring process.

site_title: Corporate digest
summary: Asian Pay Television Trust has received 474.7 million valid acceptances and excess applications for its proposed one-for-four rights issue, 1.3 times the total number of rights units offered. The renounceable non-underwritten rights issue aims to raise about S$46.2 million in gross proceeds.

site_title: Tencent sets new milestones
summary: Tencent Holdings Ltd. achieved three milestones in a single day, surpassing Alibaba Group Holding as Asia's most valuable company with a record HK$497.40 share price, doubling in value since 2018. The Shenzhen-based firm, worth US$613 billion, has captivated investors with its gaming business, payments system, and WeChat platform. However, regulatory risks from Beijing remain a concern, with China suspending operations of popular live-streaming apps backed by Tencent. Analysts have boosted their 12-month price target by 13% and Chinese investors hold a record amount of the company's shares.

site_title: Hedge funds exploit CLO weakness laid bare by corporate distress
summary: Hedge funds are exploiting weaknesses in the CLO (collateralized loan obligation) market, which is constrained by regulations designed to limit managers' participation in distressed situations. The restrictions, sparked by the coronavirus pandemic, are causing CLOs to miss out on debt restructurings, with some investors intentionally shifting value away from the structures. This is resulting in CLOs recouping less than other creditors, sometimes by as much as 30 cents on the dollar. The limitations are leaving CLO managers frustrated, with some arguing they are being pushed around by aggressive hedge funds.

site_title: Hong Kong economy gets boost from staycations, dining deals
summary: Hong Kong's economy has seen a modest boost from staycations and dining deals as social distancing restrictions ease, with some businesses experiencing a surge in demand. However, concerns remain about the long-term sustainability of this resurgence, with rising unemployment and expats leaving the city. Retail sales declined 35% in the first quarter, and tourist arrivals plummeted 99.9% in April and May. The city's battered tourism industry faces a major obstacle in recovering pre-pandemic levels, with many wondering if Chinese tourists will return even after the virus subsides.

site_title: Australia, New Zealand favourites to co-host women's football World Cup in 2023
summary: Australia and New Zealand are favored to co-host the 2023 women's FIFA World Cup, with their joint bid considered the frontrunner after scoring strongly in FIFA's evaluation report. The two countries, which have experience hosting major events, will share the tournament between 12 cities, with stadiums and ticket prices already in place. The bid has won public support from the 10-member ASEAN bloc and is seen as a compelling proposition, with a focus on promoting women's sport and social change. A decision is expected on June 25.

site_title: Geo Energy Resources may list unit in Indonesia
summary: Geo Energy Resources, a coal producer, is considering listing one of its Indonesian mining subsidiaries on the Indonesian Stock Exchange (IDX) in line with the Indonesian government's plan to support its local stock market. This move comes after the company put a previous dual listing plan on hold.

site_title: Tourism needs to adapt to survive in the new normal
summary: Tourism companies in Singapore need to adapt to survive in the new normal post-COVID-19 crisis. To do so, they should focus on outdoor activities, reduce dependence on international tourists, and develop targeted strategies for local customers. Partnerships and bundled deals can help attract repeat visitors, while adopting a lean cost structure and embracing technology can improve efficiency. Tourism companies should also prioritize long-term planning, staying open to new ideas and trends to capitalize on future opportunities. Building a strong balance sheet and prudent debt management are crucial for weathering future crises.

site_title: Saudi Arabia bars overseas arrivals to attend haj
summary: Saudi Arabia has barred overseas arrivals from attending the haj this year due to the coronavirus, limiting the pilgrimage to only Saudi citizens and residents. This marks the first year in modern times that Muslims worldwide have been denied the opportunity to perform the annual pilgrimage to Mecca. Social distancing measures will be enforced, and a limited number of participants will be allowed. The decision was made in response to the ongoing pandemic.

site_title: GE2020 battleground
summary: Singapore is gearing up for the 2020 general election (GE2020), with various government initiatives and updates on key issues.
