A new centre will be established to advance sustainable aviation in the Asia-Pacific region. Employment rates for graduates are expected to improve, with early data showing better job prospects. Deputy Prime Minister Gan Kim Kheng will visit the US for trade talks, while a new grant of up to S$100,000 is available for businesses affected by tariffs. The government is also exploring opportunities for Singapore to become a global hub for advanced chip packaging.

site_title: Banyan Tree expects net loss for H1 due to Covid-19 pandemic
summary: Banyan Tree Holdings expects a net loss for the first half of 2020 due to the ongoing impact of the Covid-19 pandemic on its hotel business. The company's hotel investment segment recorded significantly lower occupancies in April and May compared to the same period last year. This is attributed to border controls and travel restrictions imposed globally as a result of the pandemic.

site_title: Euro up on improved French PMI data
summary: The euro surged to a one-week high after improved French PMI data showed the euro zone economy easing in June, with the Flash Composite Purchasing Managers' Index (PMI) recovering to 47.5 from 31.9 in May. The news boosted euro and higher-risk currencies, including the Australian dollar, following US officials confirming the US-China trade deal remains intact. The euro rose 0.67% to US$1.1333, while the Australian dollar jumped 0.75% to US$0.6957.

site_title: Apple to build its own chips to power Mac computers, ending tie-up with Intel
summary: Apple is ending its 10-year partnership with Intel to build its own chips for Mac computers, launching the "Apple silicon" initiative. This move will enable Macs to run the same apps as iPhones, with the first new Macs shipping by the end of the year. The change will also allow for a more powerful and energy-efficient system, as well as a "common architecture" across Apple's products. This development will facilitate easier app creation for developers and enhance the user experience across Apple devices.

site_title: Opposition parties say ready to do battle in coming polls
summary: Singapore's next General Election (GE) is set for July 10, with opposition parties ready to contest. The election comes as the country has just emerged from a two-month circuit-breaker period amid concerns of a second Covid-19 wave. Opposition parties, including the Singapore People's Party, National Solidarity Party, and Progress Singapore Party, have begun preparations and introduced new candidates. The Workers' Party, the only opposition party with elected MPs, also released a slate of fresh faces. The government has announced the dissolution of Parliament, and polling is expected to take place during a time when the country is still reopening from the pandemic.

site_title: StanChart Singapore to invest extra S$5m in talent development, re-skilling
summary: Standard Chartered Singapore will invest an additional S$5 million in talent development and re-skilling, with plans to provide close to 350 traineeship and career opportunities in 2020. The bank will also ramp up its SkillsFuture@SC programme to help employees up-skill until 2022. Since launching in 2016, 20% of employees who participated in the programme have upgraded their skills and been successfully re-deployed to new roles. The investment aims to support the bank's digitalisation efforts and ensure its employees stay relevant and competitive in the changing environment.

site_title: Indonesia will not ask central bank to buy zero coupon bonds
summary: Indonesia's Finance Minister Sri Mulyani Indrawati announced that the government will not ask the central bank to buy zero coupon bonds to finance its fiscal deficit driven by pandemic-related spending. This decision comes after lawmakers pressured Bank Indonesia to expand its bond buying and purchase zero coupon government debt. The government is instead exploring other options to manage its deficit.

images.alt_text: The finance ministry and Bank Indonesia are still discussing what kind of instrument to use to help in Indonesia's response to the pandemic, Ms Indrawati said.

site_title: CFOs play crucial role in surviving Covid-19 crisis
summary: CFOs have taken on a crucial role in navigating the COVID-19 crisis, managing financial health, and organizational resilience. They must rapidly forecast and adapt to changing circumstances, reduce "data latency," and drive digital transformation. CFOs are expected to provide real-time cash positions and projections, assess risk and opportunities, and guide efforts to secure additional funding. As the crisis evolves, CFOs will be critical in guiding companies through significant changes, including remote work and digital transformations, and positioning them for recovery.

site_title: Singapore's electoral system
summary: Singapore's electoral system remains unchanged with a first-past-the-post system, where the candidate with the most votes wins the seat. The country's electoral boundaries are redrawn every 6 years. The government has not proposed any significant changes to the electoral system, despite previous calls for reform. The People's Action Party (PAP) has maintained power since 1959, with the opposition parties holding a minority of seats. The government has stated its commitment to maintaining the integrity of the electoral process.

site_title: Digital banking can be a double-edged sword
summary: The Monetary Authority of Singapore has announced that 14 digital bank applicants have progressed to the next stage of assessment for two digital full bank and three digital wholesale bank licences. Digital banking offers benefits of competition, integration, and innovation, but also increases the risk of banking fraud due to new tactics and vulnerabilities created by multi-channel services. As digital banks expand, traditional players will need to compete creatively and offer competing products, leading to increased consolidation and interoperability. However, the rise of digital banking also enables sophisticated cybercrime, with the potential to surpass the value of the international drugs trade.

site_title: S-Reits' valuations close to long-term mean, but analysts still see value in sector
summary: S-Reits have rebounded 38% from March lows, trading closer to their long-term mean valuation, according to a research report by RHB. Analysts predict acquisitions will pick up pace in the second half, driven by favorable financing and market conditions. S-Reits are expected to distribute most of their retained income, but Q2 earnings will be cautious due to rental rebates and deferrals. Industrial Reits are preferred for their resilience, while retail Reits are the least preferred sector due to structural headwinds.

site_title: Gojek cuts 9% of staff, shuts non-core verticals amid Covid-19 pressures
summary: Gojek, an Indonesian ride-hailing firm, is cutting 9% of its staff, laying off 430 employees, amid Covid-19 pressures. The company is also shutting down non-core verticals, including GoLife and GoFood Festivals. This move aims to reduce costs and focus on core operations. Gojek's decision comes as the company faces increasing competition and economic uncertainty in the region.

site_title: Hong Leong provides loans to help SMEs manage cash flow
summary: Hong Leong Finance has launched its Business Loans Campaign to provide targeted cash flow-management solutions to SMEs affected by the Covid-19 pandemic. The campaign offers collateral-free loans and fee waivers, including the Enterprise Financing Scheme-SME Working Capital Loan and the Temporary Bridging Loan Programme. The company also provides loan payment deferment relief and supports SMEs through its SME Capability Ready Programme, aiming to help them recover from the pandemic.

site_title: India starts curbing sales of Chinese goods to govt agencies
summary: India's government has instructed sellers to declare the country of origin for goods purchased via a state-run online portal, GeM, amid a boycott of Chinese goods following a border clash that killed 20 Indian soldiers. The portal will also provide a "Make in India" filter for government agencies to buy only products meeting 50% local content criteria. Industry groups welcome the move, calling for its extension to private platforms. The government plans to impose higher trade barriers and raise import duties on Chinese goods, aiming to increase total purchases to 3 trillion rupees this fiscal year.

site_title: RCEP trade deal set to be inked this year; door remains open for India
summary: Singapore and other RCEP countries plan to sign the mega-trade deal this year, despite the ongoing COVID-19 pandemic. The deal remains open for India, which withdrew in November due to unresolved issues. The countries reaffirmed their commitment to the agreement during a virtual ministerial meeting, indicating progress in negotiations.

site_title: UK carmakers seek state aid with pandemic threatening jobs
summary: UK carmakers are seeking state aid to recover from the pandemic, citing a one-in-six job risk. The Society of Motor Manufacturers and Traders (SMMT) calls for emergency funding, tax holidays, and policies to boost sales. UK production is expected to drop by a third to 920,000 cars, with annual output potentially falling to less than 850,000 vehicles by 2025. A tariff-free trade deal with the EU is seen as crucial to prevent a £40 billion drop in revenues, with production forecast to rise to 1.1 million by 2025.

site_title: To win US farm votes, Trump needs to stop bashing China
summary: US President Donald Trump's trade adviser Peter Navarro's statement that the US-China trade deal was "over" briefly sparked market concerns, but Trump later clarified that the deal was "fully intact". The Phase One trade pact, signed in January, has led to increased trade between the two economies, with China becoming America's largest trade partner. The US-China trade front has seen encouraging signs, including China boosting agricultural purchases, including soybeans, corn, and wheat. However, some US officials, known as "China hawks", may jeopardize the talks by focusing on the pandemic's impact on China's ability to meet its obligations.

site_title: STI claws back early losses on election news, ends 0.2% higher
summary: The Straits Times Index (STI) closed 0.2% higher at 2,634.92 on Tuesday, reversing early losses, following news of a General Election call by Prime Minister Lee Hsien Loong. Wilmar International led the gainers, rising 7.73% to S$4.18, after its Chinese unit spin-off prospectus was submitted for review. Jardine Matheson was the biggest loser, declining 4.29% to US$41.50. Regional markets were mostly up, with the Hang Seng and Nikkei 225 rising.

site_title: China has picked up its 'game' on trade with US: Trump adviser
summary: The US trade deal with China is intact, according to National Economic Council Director Larry Kudlow, contradicting comments made by White House trade adviser Peter Navarro that the pact was "over." China has made progress in areas such as intellectual property theft, boosting purchases of US goods by $200 billion over two years. Kudlow's comments come after Navarro's remarks caused a decline in US stock futures and risk-sensitive currencies. The Phase 1 trade deal, struck nearly two years ago, has been impacted by the coronavirus epidemic.

site_title: US new home sales rebound strongly in May
summary: US new home sales rebounded in May with a 16.6% increase to a seasonally adjusted annual rate of 676,000 units, exceeding economists' expectations. This marks a recovery from the housing market, which was impacted by the Covid-19 pandemic. The sales pace was revised down from the previously reported 623,000 units in April. The rebound is a positive sign for the broader economy.

site_title: Guidelines for investors to survive the Covid-19 economic crisis
summary: Investors can survive the Covid-19 economic crisis by understanding how each crisis impacts their portfolio companies. Different crises have varying financial and operational impacts on businesses. Companies that performed well in one crisis may not respond well to another. Investors should assess risks and critically examine the underlying reasons for buying companies. They should look for companies with a strong competitive moat, agility, adaptability, and prudent management. Examples of such companies include Nike and Visa, which can withstand economic crises due to their enduring demand and essential services.

images.alt_text: Kingsmen Creatives' Nerf Action Xperience (NAX) in Marina Square. Kingsmen Creatives' business was facing signs of stress from a changing retail landscape and tougher competition as far back as 2015. It has done well more than ten years ago as it latched on to the right trends. However, as business circumstances changed, it failed to evolve fast enough.

site_title: Amazon pledges US$2b to projects fighting climate change
summary: Amazon has pledged $2 billion to projects combating climate change through the Climate Pledge Fund, aiming to facilitate a zero-carbon economy. The fund will invest in startups and companies across multiple sectors, including transportation and energy, to reduce carbon impact and promote sustainability. The initiative follows Amazon's own efforts to cut its carbon footprint, with plans to run on 100% renewable energy by 2025 and deploy electric delivery vans. The pledge comes as climate change concerns grow, with the US administration on course to withdraw from the global climate agreement.

site_title: Accordia Golf Trust to distribute 1.2b yen reserves
summary: Accordia Golf Trust (AGT) will distribute 1.2 billion yen (S$15.7 million) in reserves, previously set aside due to the COVID-19 pandemic's impact on its golf business. The funds were initially set aside to comply with financial covenants, but the company now believes the risk of breaching these covenants has decreased. The distribution will be made after obtaining lender consent, and the trustee-manager will announce the payment date and books closure date.

site_title: Singapore goes to polls on July 10 in an election 'like no other'
summary: Singapore will hold a General Election on July 10, a public holiday, with 93 seats in 31 constituencies up for contest. The election comes despite the ongoing COVID-19 pandemic, with Prime Minister Lee Hsien Loong stating that the country is in a stable position but a "long struggle" lies ahead. Up to 12 opposition parties may join the hustings, and 2.65 million Singaporeans are expected to vote. The dissolution of the 13th Parliament and the issuance of the Writ of Election by President Halimah Yacob mark the start of the electoral process.

site_title: US business sector contraction eases in June
summary: The US business sector contracted for a fifth consecutive month in June, but at a slower pace than in previous months. The IHS Markit flash US Composite Output Index rose to 46.8, indicating a contraction in private sector output. Businesses reopened after mid-March closures, but layoffs continued, and hiring remained frozen due to weak demand. The services sector saw a slight increase, while the manufacturing sector's contraction slowed. Economists believe the recession is drawing to a close, despite ongoing challenges.

site_title: Patience wears thin on crew change issue
summary: The International Transport Workers' Federation (ITF) has urged seafarers to stop working and demand to be treated as passengers, citing the need for repatriation due to the COVID-19 pandemic. The ITF claims that seafarers have been treated as "second-class citizens" despite being hailed as "key workers" vital to the global supply chain. The International Chamber of Shipping (ICS) has acknowledged the issue, but warns that stopping work could have unintended consequences. Despite progress in some regions, such as Singapore, where 6,000 crew changes have been approved, the situation remains patchy globally, with patience wearing thin among seafarers.

site_title: Singapore Parliament dissolved ahead of General Election
summary: Singapore's Parliament was dissolved on June 23, 2020, by President Halimah Yacob, paving the way for the upcoming General Election. Nomination Day and Polling Day will be held within three months of June 23, 2020.

site_title: Europe sizzles in post-lockdown heatwave
summary: A heatwave is affecting Europe, with temperatures reaching 40°C in some areas, including Seville, Spain, and France. Nine Spanish regions are on high alert for the heat, which is expected to last until Thursday. Britain is also bracing for a heatwave, with temperatures set to reach the mid-30s, and the Nordic countries are expecting temperatures above 30 degrees. The heatwave has raised concerns about the spread of the virus, particularly among the elderly, and some countries are taking precautions to protect vulnerable populations.

site_title: Intraco disposes 41.27% stake in Dynamic Colours for S$19.5m
summary: SINGAPORE-LISTED trading firm Intraco disposed its 41.27% stake in resin-compounding company Dynamic Colours for approximately S$19.5 million. The deal values the company at S$47.2 million. The disposal is part of Intraco's strategy to reshape its portfolio with businesses in high-growth areas, offering stronger financial flexibility and enabling new investment opportunities. Intraco will convene an extraordinary general meeting to seek shareholders' ratification for the disposal.

site_title: Geo Energy Resources to potentially pursue listing on Indonesian Stock Exchange
summary: Geo Energy Resources' mining subsidiary is considering a listing on the Indonesian Stock Exchange (IDX) following amendments to the Indonesian mining law. The amended law allows miners to extend permits through a streamlined process and specifies divestment obligations for foreign investments. The company aims to widen its investor base and enhance its corporate profile by listing one of its subsidiaries on the IDX. However, it remains unclear if the divestment requirements apply to Geo Energy Resources.

site_title: Cheers as UK announces pubs reopening in England
summary: The UK has announced that pubs in England will reopen on July 4, following the easing of the coronavirus lockdown for hospitality, culture, and tourism. The move comes after three months of closures, and will allow cinemas, museums, and galleries to reopen. Restaurants, hotels, and self-catering accommodation will also reopen, with measures in place to reduce close-contact transmission of the virus. The government has set guidelines for businesses to follow, including social distancing and table service only.

site_title: Mastercard acquires Finicity with US$825m deal
summary: Mastercard has agreed to acquire Finicity for $825 million, expanding its financial data capabilities. The deal will allow banks to speed up credit decisions and improve account verification processes. Finicity's technology enables companies to share consumers' financial data, aligning with Mastercard's commitment to consumer-centric data practices. The acquisition is expected to close by the end of the year and won't be dilutive for Mastercard for more than two years. Existing Finicity shareholders may also receive an additional $160 million if performance targets are met.

site_title: Germany orders first local virus lockdowns since easing
summary: Germany has ordered its first local lockdowns since easing COVID-19 restrictions, affecting over 640,000 people in the districts of Guetersloh and Warendorf. The lockdowns come after a coronavirus outbreak at a slaughterhouse in western Germany, infecting over 1,500 workers. The measures, which include closing cinemas, museums, and schools, will remain in place until at least June 30. The developments mark a setback for Germany's efforts to reopen its borders and revive tourism.

site_title: Banyan Tree Holdings hotel business 'continues to be adversely affected'
summary: Banyan Tree Holdings reported its hotel business continues to be negatively impacted by the Covid-19 pandemic, with occupancy at 36% for the five months ended May 31, 2020, down 39 percentage points from the same period last year. Revenue per available room fell 42% to S$106. The decline is attributed to border controls and travel restrictions.

site_title: Soilbuild Construction expects adverse impact from suspension of business
summary: Soilbuild Construction Group expects adverse financial impact from suspended business activities due to the pandemic. The company suspended construction and precast activities in Singapore and Malaysia, but resumed operations in Myanmar. In Singapore, the group will continue to implement additional safety measures before resuming all activities. The group's financial performance is expected to be affected by the prolonged suspension of construction activities.

site_title: FairPrice to stop housing allowance for 1,000 Malaysian staff stuck here
summary: FairPrice Group, a Singaporean retailer, will end its housing allowance and daily allowance package for 1,000 Malaysian employees on July 9 due to financial sustainability concerns. The package, initially introduced in March to support employees affected by Malaysia's movement control order, had been extended until August 31. Employees have been asked to either relocate to Singapore or resign, with those choosing to stay on offered assistance in finding accommodation and loan options.

images.alt_text: FairPrice says it has not "actively terminated" any staff affected by Malaysia's movement control order.

site_title: Asia's economy taking centre stage post Covid: ANZ and Eurasia
summary: Asia's economy is taking center stage post-Covid-19, surpassing the US as China's largest customers, according to ANZ and Eurasia Group. In the first quarter of 2020, Asean countries absorbed 16% of Chinese merchandise exports, while the US market absorbed only 14%. Asia's recovery is expected to continue, driven by regional trade and supply chains. The report notes that domestic political instability is less pronounced in Asia, with countries like Korea, Singapore, and Vietnam responding more competently to the pandemic. This trend is likely to persist in the wake of Covid-19.

site_title: OCBC partners seven medical groups to launch healthcare app
summary: OCBC Bank has partnered seven medical groups to launch the HealthPass app, providing access to over 100 general practitioners and specialists in Singapore. The app allows video consultations and medication delivery, with a flat consultation fee of S$20 for GPs and S$100 for specialist doctors. The app also integrates with clinics, allowing patients to access their medical records and make digital payments. The launch aims to boost telehealth access and provide convenience for patients, especially those with ongoing medical needs.

images.alt_text: The healthcare app provides access to more than 100 GPs and specialists, and is available to all Singapore residents over the age of 18.

site_title: Hong Leong provides loans for SMEs with cash flow issues amid Covid-19
summary: Hong Leong Finance has launched a Business Loans Campaign to provide targeted cash flow-management solutions to SMEs affected by the Covid-19 pandemic. The campaign includes collateral-free loans, loan payment deferment relief, and financial guidance. The company aims to support local businesses, particularly small ones, with cash flow issues. The initiative is supported by the Monetary Authority of Singapore's SGD Facility and offers waivers on processing fees. The campaign will run until December 31, 2020, to help SMEs recover from the pandemic.

site_title: Daily Debrief: What Happened Today
summary: Singapore will hold a general election on July 10, 2020, with 93 seats in 31 constituencies up for grabs. Up to 2.65 million voters are expected to cast their ballots. This marks the first general election since the COVID-19 pandemic began, and it is expected to be a significant event in the country's politics. The election is also notable for being the first nomination day on June 30, where candidates can be nominated for the election.

site_title: Former Wirecard CEO detained on accusation of inflating balance sheet
summary: Former Wirecard CEO Markus Braun has been detained on accusations of inflating the company's balance sheet and revenues. Prosecutors claim 1.9 billion euros in accounts likely never existed, threatening the payments company. Braun surrendered on Monday evening and will appear before a judge on Tuesday to determine his custody. This comes after Wirecard revealed the discrepancy on Monday, which has raised concerns about the company's financial health and Braun's role in the alleged deception.

site_title: STI rises on election news
summary: The Straits Times Index (STI) rose 0.2% to 2,634.92 on Tuesday, driven by news that Prime Minister Lee Hsien Loong advised President Halimah Yacob to dissolve Parliament and issue the Writ of Election, paving the way for a General Election. Wilmar International was the largest gainer, rising 7.73% to S$4.18, while Jardine Matheson was the biggest loser, declining 4.29% to US$41.50. Regional markets were mostly up, with the Hang Seng and Shanghai Composite also rising.

site_title: Denmark's high tax consensus wobbles as Danes told to spend
summary: Opposition parties in Denmark are pushing for temporary cuts to the country's high tax regime to ensure pandemic cash handouts boost consumption instead of going to the state. Denmark has a top tax rate of 56% and is one of the countries with the heaviest tax burden. The government's plan to give 60 billion Danish crowns (S$12.6 billion) in cash handouts could encourage top taxpayers to redirect money to pension schemes rather than spending it. The issue is currently being negotiated in parliament.

site_title: Singapore maritime trade union sets aside over S$1.5m to help in crew change
summary: Singapore's maritime trade union, the Singapore Organisation of Seamen (SOS), has set aside over S$1.5 million to support seafarers during the Covid-19 pandemic. The union has partnered with Seacare Hotel to provide accommodation and meals for eligible crew members. Shipping companies participating in the Seacare Sailors' Home Scheme (SSS) will have their e-voucher entitlements doubled. The SOS is urging shipping companies to expedite crew changes and utilize the SSS e-vouchers to accommodate seafarers.

site_title: Europe: Stock markets rebound at open
summary: European stock markets rebounded at the start of trading on Tuesday, with London's FTSE 100 rising 0.4% to 6,271.85 points, Frankfurt's DAX 30 climbing 0.8% to 12,357.61 points, and Paris' CAC 40 advancing 0.6% to 4,977.55 points. The gains followed overnight increases on Wall Street and in Tokyo.

images.alt_text: European stock markets rebounded at the start of trading on Tuesday after gains on Wall Street and in Tokyo overnight.

site_title: Hong Kong: Stocks end with big gains
summary: Hong Kong stocks ended with a 1.62% gain, reaching 24,907.34, as lockdown measures are lifted worldwide, despite concerns about a second wave of infections. The Shanghai Composite Index rose 0.18%, while the Shenzhen Composite Index added 0.56%. The gains come as investors remain positive despite tariff uncertainty and split views on the Fed's future actions.

site_title: UK mall owner Intu warns of administration
summary: UK mall owner Intu Properties Plc warns that some of its shopping centers may have to close if its survival talks with creditors collapse, putting 2,500 jobs at risk. The company is seeking a 15-month loan waiver and has appointed KPMG to its contingency plan for administration. If talks fail, malls could shut temporarily due to unpaid rent. Intu has 4.5 billion pounds of debt and 600 million pounds of loans are at risk of being waived.

site_title: China soy buyers ask exporters to guarantee coronavirus-free cargoes
summary: China's soybean buyers are requesting exporters to sign letters guaranteeing their cargoes are coronavirus-free amid efforts to contain a recent spike in Beijing's coronavirus infections. This move comes after the General Administration of Customs asked overseas suppliers of meat and fruit to sign declarations ensuring the safety of their shipments. China, the world's top soybean buyer, is expected to import 94 million tonnes in the 2019/20 crop year, mostly from Brazil and the US. The request has been made by local customs authorities, but it is unclear how many exporters have signed such letters.

site_title: Polling Day on July 10, Nomination Day on June 30 for Singapore's General Election
summary: Singapore will hold its general election on July 10, with polling day declared a public holiday. Nomination Day is set for June 30, with a nine-day campaigning period without physical rallies due to the Covid-19 pandemic. Over 2.65 million registered electors will cast their vote across 31 electoral divisions. Election deposit has been set at S$13,500, and candidates must file their papers on Nomination Day.

site_title: Holding GE in the middle of pandemic not an easy decision: DPM Heng
summary: Deputy Prime Minister Heng Swee Keat said holding the General Election in the middle of the pandemic is not an easy decision, but necessary to give Singapore a fresh mandate to overcome the crisis. The election, set for July 10, will provide a strong foundation for the new government to lead the nation out of the crisis. Heng emphasized that the next few years will be critical and that the actions taken now will determine the nation's course for decades to come.

site_title: Gojek cuts 9% of staff; shutters GoLife and physical F&B verticals
summary: Indonesian ride-hailing firm Gojek is laying off 430 employees, representing 9% of its regional workforce, and shutting down non-core verticals due to financial pressure amid the Covid-19 pandemic. The company will prioritize three core verticals: payments, transport, and food delivery, following internal townhall meetings. Laid-off staff will receive a minimum of four weeks' salary, with an additional four weeks' pay for each year served. This move comes after Gojek raised an undisclosed sum from tech giants Facebook and PayPal, valuing the firm at about $10 billion.

site_title: Malaysia: Shares close lower on Tuesday
summary: Malaysia's FTSE Bursa Malaysia Kuala Lumpur Composite Index closed 4.2 points lower on Tuesday at 1,507.04. The index saw 8.746 billion lots traded worth RM2.984 billion, with 522 losers outnumbering 423 gainers.

site_title: SingHaiyi posts 64.1% fall in H2 net profit to S$4.9m
summary: SingHaiyi, a real estate group, reported a net profit of S$4.9 million for the half year ended March 31, 2020, down 64.1% from the previous year. Total revenue increased to S$44.2 million, driven by recognition of revenue from Parc Clematis and The Gazania. Earnings per share decreased to 0.117 Singapore cent. The decline in profit is attributed to a decrease in revenue from Vietnam Town.

site_title: Wirecard required to keep customer funds from Singapore business activities in banks here: MAS
summary: The Monetary Authority of Singapore (MAS) has required Wirecard to keep customer funds arising from its Singapore business activities in banks in Singapore. Wirecard's entities in Singapore are not currently licensed by MAS, but the regulator has accepted a licence application under the new Payment Services Act. This move comes as Wirecard faces scandal and financial issues globally.

site_title: Tokyo: Stocks close higher
summary: Tokyo stocks closed 0.50% higher, led by gains in high-tech shares, following rallies on Wall Street. The Nikkei 225 index rose to 22,549.05, while the Topix index advanced to 1,587.14. Investors took heart from US shares rebounding, with high-tech shares particularly benefiting from buy orders.

site_title: US: Wall St opens higher ahead of business activity data
summary: US stocks opened higher on Tuesday, with the Dow Jones rising 134.43 points, or 0.52%, and the Nasdaq Composite reaching a record high. Investors took heart from reassurances about the US-China trade deal and upbeat business activity data from Europe, which is expected to influence US surveys later. The S&P 500 also opened higher, with shares in mining and healthcare companies driving gains.

images.alt_text: Wall Street's main indexes opened higher and the Nasdaq hit a record high on Tuesday as investors took heart from reassurances that the trade deal with China was intact, while upbeat business activity data from Europe boded well for US surveys due later.

site_title: Taiwan's Foxconn eyes further India investment, sees bright outlook there
summary: Taiwan's Foxconn plans further investment in India, citing a bright outlook in the country. The world's largest contract manufacturer, which already produces smartphones for Apple and Xiaomi in India, aims to announce details in the next few months. Foxconn's chairman, Liu Young-way, views India as a promising market despite the current impact of the novel coronavirus outbreak.

site_title: Apple modifies app review process, letting developers 'challenge' guidelines
summary: Apple is modifying its app review process, allowing developers to "challenge" the guidelines governing the App Store. This change comes after developers expressed frustration over the company's ability to retain final say in reviews. Apple will no longer delay routine bug fixes over minor guideline violations, except in cases related to legal issues. The new policy aims to reduce the negative impact on customers who experience delayed bug fixes.

site_title: 48-year-old man who recovered from Covid-19 dies after fainting at temporary housing site
summary: A 48-year-old Indian migrant worker who had recovered from COVID-19 died after fainting at a temporary housing site in Singapore. He was taken to the Singapore General Hospital, where he was pronounced dead due to ischaemic heart disease. This marks Singapore's 11th death among COVID-19 patients who died from other causes. The incident highlights the ongoing health risks faced by migrant workers in Singapore.

site_title: Twenty-three-year-old to be charged with unlicensed Bitcoin dealing tied to online scams
summary: A 23-year-old Singaporean woman will be charged with unlicensed Bitcoin dealing, allegedly tied to online scams. The woman received 13 fraudulent fund transfers, totaling S$3,350, to purchase Bitcoin for a commission. The funds were proceeds of crime from victims of online scams. She does not have a licence to carry on a business of providing payment services in Singapore and faces a fine of up to S$125,000 or imprisonment for up to three years.

site_title: Indonesia won't sell zero coupon bonds to central bank: finance ministry
summary: Indonesia's Finance Minister Sri Mulyani Indrawati said the government will not ask Bank Indonesia to buy zero coupon bonds to finance a fiscal deficit driven by pandemic spending. The decision was made after lawmakers pressured the central bank to expand its bond buying. Indrawati stated that the chosen instrument must allow Bank Indonesia to share the burden while maintaining macroeconomic discipline. The decision was made after discussions with Bank Indonesia Governor Perry Warjiyo, who emphasized the need for a balance between supporting the economy and maintaining fiscal and monetary authority credibility.

site_title: PM Lee calls for General Election
summary: Prime Minister Lee Hsien Loong has called for a General Election in Singapore, citing the need for a fresh mandate to tackle the challenges posed by the Covid-19 pandemic. He announced the decision after consulting with President Halimah Yacob, who dissolved Parliament and issued the Writ of Election. The election will be held with additional precautions to ensure voter safety, including safe-distancing measures and time slots for voting. The government will continue to govern during the election period, with the Cabinet remaining in charge and various ministerial task forces continuing to lead key initiatives.

site_title: Hin Leong forged documents to mislead banks, has 'no reasonable prospect of being restructured on its own': PwC
summary: Hin Leong Trading, an insolvent oil trader, has "no reasonable prospect" of being rehabilitated as a standalone company, according to a report by PricewaterhouseCoopers (PwC). The company has liabilities of US$3.5 billion and assets of US$257 million, with forged documents used to mislead banks and conceal accumulated losses. PwC recommends that the Lim family, who own other companies including Ocean Tankers and the Xihe Group, bring their personal assets to the table for any viable restructuring. The company's oil trading business has ceased, and it is uncertain whether it can raise funds through bank loans or equity investments.

site_title: Australia: Shares edge higher as mining gains offset weak financials
summary: Australian shares rose as mining stocks offset losses in financials, despite concerns over a second coronavirus wave and US Federal Reserve stimulus. The benchmark dropped 1% earlier due to a Sino-US trade scare, but reversed after White House trade adviser Peter Navarro walked back comments and US President Donald Trump assured the trade deal was intact.

site_title: Gold slips ahead of euro PMI data, second virus wave fears cap losses
summary: Gold prices slipped 0.1% to $1,752.07 per ounce ahead of expected positive eurozone manufacturing data, but remained near its highest level in a month due to concerns over a second coronavirus wave. Economists expect the eurozone composite flash PMI to rise to 42.4 in June, supporting gold prices. The metal has gained about 15% this year due to lower interest rates and stimulus measures.

site_title: Seoul: Shares end slightly higher on Sino-US trade relief
summary: South Korean shares ended slightly higher on Tuesday, recouping earlier losses after US President Donald Trump said the US-China trade pact was "fully intact". The benchmark Kospi rose 0.21% to 2,131.24, following comments from White House adviser Peter Navarro that the trade deal was "over". Navarro later clarified that the deal continues, while Trump tweeted that it is intact. Meanwhile, South Korea reported 46 new coronavirus cases, bringing the national tally to 12,484.

images.alt_text: South Korean shares closed slightly higher on Tuesday, recouping earlier losses in the session, after US President Donald Trump said the US-China trade pact was "fully intact".

site_title: EU leaders to hold physical summit to discuss virus recovery package
summary: EU leaders will meet in Brussels on July 17 to discuss a 750-billion-euro economic recovery package, their first physical summit since the coronavirus lockdown. The two-day meeting will focus on the recovery roadmap proposed by EU Commission president Ursula von der Leyen. Capitals are still negotiating the terms of the plan, which aims to support virus recovery efforts across the bloc. The meeting will run into a Saturday, marking an unusual schedule for a summit.

site_title: Singapore, other stakeholders reaffirm plans to sign mega-trade deal this year
summary: Singapore and other RCEP stakeholders reaffirmed plans to sign the mega-trade deal this year, despite the COVID-19 pandemic. The deal, involving 15 countries, will be the largest trade pact in the world when completed. India, which previously backed out of talks, remains open to joining, according to a statement from Australia, China, Japan, South Korea, and the Association of Southeast Asian Nations (Asean). The deal's signing will signal support for the multilateral trading system and regional integration.

site_title: China-backed AIIB approves US$1b in two loans for Indonesia's virus battle
summary: The Asian Infrastructure Investment Bank (AIIB) has approved $1 billion in loans to help Indonesia combat the coronavirus pandemic. The first $750 million loan, co-financed with the Asian Development Bank, will support economic and health systems. The second $250 million loan, co-financed with the World Bank, will aid the government's immediate response to the pandemic. These loans are part of the AIIB's $10 billion funding facility to support public and private sectors in fighting the outbreak.

site_title: China's cyber watchdog punishes live-streaming sites for 'low taste'
summary: China's Cyberspace Administration of China (CAC) has penalized 10 leading live-streaming sites, including Bilibili and Huya, for spreading "low taste" content, including indecent dancing and foul language. The sites will be required to freeze updates, stop new user registrations, and revamp their platforms by a deadline. The CAC also called on the sites to punish platform supervisors and blacklist "delinquent livestreamers." This action follows a previous incident involving Sina Weibo, where users complained of censorship. The move aims to maintain the country's strict online regulations.

site_title: Scores of Volkswagen's Mexico staff test positive for coronavirus
summary: Volkswagen's Mexican unit reported that nearly 2% of its workers, around 100 employees, tested positive for coronavirus after returning to work. The company began reopening its Puebla factory after a shutdown in late March, amid Mexico's worsening pandemic. The factory will remain focused on training and preparation for manufacturing. This comes as Mexico struggles with a surge in coronavirus cases, with 4,577 new infections and 759 deaths reported on the same day. The incident highlights the challenges faced by automakers in reopening factories during the pandemic.

images.alt_text: Volkswagen AG's Mexican unit on Monday said about 2 per cent of its workers tested for coronavirus had contracted the disease at some point, underlining the challenge faced by automakers in reopening factories before the pandemic has peaked in Mexico.

site_title: Tharman reappointed as co-chair to advisory board of UN report
summary: Senior Minister Tharman Shanmugaratnam has been reappointed as co-chair to the advisory board of the Human Development Report (HDR) 2020, alongside Nobel laureate Michael Spence. The report, released this year, will discuss pressing development issues, including social vulnerabilities in the face of climate change and biodiversity loss, and the steps needed to achieve the UN Sustainable Development Goals. Tharman's co-chair last year was Professor Thomas Piketty, and the advisory board will provide intellectual advice on the report's overall vision and direction.

site_title: Twilio's Dutch rival MessageBird plans an IPO in 'gold rush'
summary: MessageBird, a Dutch software company, plans an initial public offering (IPO) after a surge in sales driven by the shift to on-demand digital businesses and cloud-based tools. The company, which helps clients manage customer inquiries, expects to grow by 50% to 300 million euros this year. MessageBird's founder and CEO, Robert Vis, says the company is on track to IPO within the next 12 months, following larger US competitor Twilio, which listed four years ago. The IPO comes as the communications-platform-as-a-service market experiences a "gold rush," with companies integrating messaging platforms into their workflows.

site_title: Tokyo Disney Resort to reopen on July 1
summary: Tokyo Disney Resort to reopen on July 1, with visitor numbers restricted due to coronavirus countermeasures. The parks will require advance bookings, temperature checks, and enforced mask-wearing. Spaced seating will also be implemented at attractions. The reopening follows the gradual reopening of businesses in the Tokyo area.

site_title: Chinese firm gets approval to begin human testing for potential coronavirus vaccine
summary: China has approved a coronavirus vaccine candidate to begin human testing, with six experimental shots currently being tested in humans. The vaccine, co-developed by Anhui Zhifei Longcom Biopharmaceutical and the Institute of Microbiology of the Chinese Academy of Sciences, has received a certificate from the National Medical Products Administration to launch clinical trials. However, none of the currently tested vaccines have passed large-scale, late-stage phase 3 clinical trials, a necessary step before entering the consumer market.

site_title: Cromwell Property gets offer for 29% stake from ARA
summary: Cromwell Property Group received a takeover bid from ARA Asset Management for 29% of its stapled securities, valued at A$0.90 per security, representing a 3.4% premium to the company's last close. The acquisition would increase ARA's stake to 52.6%.

site_title: Yangzijiang Shipbuilding bags US$102m worth of new orders
summary: Yangzijiang Shipbuilding secured US$102 million worth of new orders for four vessels, bringing the total for 2020 to US$517 million. The orders include two liquefied natural gas-tank carriers for Hong Kong's Tiger Gas and two bulk carriers for Shanghai Ganglu Shipping Co. The LNG-tank carriers will be designed with environmental protection features and will be delivered in early 2022, while the bulk carriers are slated for delivery by March 2022. This marks the second major order from Tiger Gas and allows Yangzijiang to grow its research and development capabilities.

site_title: Hallstatt, Austria's Alpine jewel, debates post-corona tourism
summary: Hallstatt, Austria, a village known for its picturesque Alpine setting, is now debating how to manage tourism after the COVID-19 pandemic led to a significant decline in international visitors. With up to 100 coaches arriving daily, locals had expressed concerns about overtourism, but the current decrease has brought a measure of serenity. The village's mayor, Alexander Scheutz, hopes the crisis will prompt a shift towards more sustainable tourism practices, prioritizing quality over quantity, and introducing an entry fee to manage visitor numbers.

site_title: UK carmakers seek state support with pandemic threatening jobs
summary: The UK automotive industry is seeking government support due to the pandemic's impact, with one in six jobs at risk. The Society of Motor Manufacturers and Traders (SMMT) calls for emergency funding, tax holidays, and policies to boost sales, citing a potential drop in production to 920,000 cars and light commercial vehicles this year. The industry faces a 40 billion-pound drop in revenues and a possible 40% decline in annual output by 2025 if Britain fails to negotiate a tariff-free trade deal with the European Union.

site_title: South Korea reports 46 new virus cases as it tackles 'second wave'
summary: South Korea reported 46 new coronavirus cases, bringing the total to 12,484, as the country battles a second wave of infections. The cases are largely concentrated in the Seoul metropolitan area, where social distancing rules were relaxed after a public holiday in May. Officials have reimposed some measures, and Seoul Mayor Park Won-soon warned that the city may return to strict social distancing if the number of infections exceeds 30 per day. South Korean President Moon Jae-in expressed confidence that the virus can still be controlled if basic disinfection rules and government guidelines are followed.

site_title: Hyundai Motor, LG Chem considering EV battery joint venture in Indonesia: source
summary: Hyundai Motor Group and LG Chem are considering establishing an electric vehicle (EV) battery cell manufacturing joint venture in Indonesia, according to a source. The investment size and capacity have not been decided. Global automakers are moving to secure EV batteries due to government subsidies and quotas to cut carbon emissions. This joint venture would be Hyundai's first battery cell joint venture, as the company tries to challenge Toyota's dominance in Indonesia. Indonesia is seen as a mid- to longer-term plan due to its limited charging infrastructure and consumers' purchasing power.

site_title: Hot stock: Wilmar up 7% at midday break, prompting SGX query
summary: The Singapore Exchange (SGX) flagged "unusual price movements" in Wilmar International's shares, which rose 7% midday, prompting a query. The company attributed the trading activity to the acceptance and posting of its subsidiary's updated prospectus for review and approval. Wilmar International stated it is not aware of any new information that might explain the trading. The company's shares are still below its 52-week high, but the unusual price movement has raised questions about potential regulatory approval for the initial public offering of its China business.

site_title: Cleantech Solar bags US$75m green loan from ING
summary: Cleantech Solar has secured a US$75 million green loan from ING Bank in Singapore to fund its expansion across South-east Asia, the largest green loan in Asia-Pacific to date. The financing will support the development of over 500 megawatts of solar power projects, benefiting leading corporates with reliable and cost-saving clean energy solutions. The deal underscores Cleantech Solar's strong portfolio and ability to deliver competitive solutions, enabling the company to accelerate its portfolio expansion in the region.

site_title: Petronas in talks to settle sales tax dispute with energy rich Malaysian state
summary: Malaysian national oil company Petronas is in talks to settle a sales tax dispute with the energy-rich Sarawak state. The dispute, which dates back to 2019, centered on Petronas' refusal to pay a 5% sales tax imposed by Sarawak. Petronas' chief quit after a disagreement with Prime Minister Muhyiddin Yassin over a settlement that would see Petronas pay RM2 billion to Sarawak. The company has agreed to withdraw its appeal and finalize the agreement, awaiting internal process completion.

site_title: Japan braces for double disaster of Covid outbreaks at flooding shelters
summary: Japan is bracing for a potential double disaster of Covid-19 outbreaks and flooding during its rainy season, which could lead to a resurgence of infections. Experts warn that crowded evacuation shelters could spark clusters of infections, threatening to reignite the disease as cases decline nationwide. The country's natural disaster evacuation plans need an overhaul to prevent this, according to experts. With Prime Minister Shinzo Abe seeking to lift restrictions, the risk of another wave of infections is a major concern.

images.alt_text: Japan natural disaster evacuation plans need an overhaul as the country heads into its rainy season, experts warned, saying crowded conditions could spark coronavirus clusters that grow into another wave of infections.

site_title: Turkey strives to revive virus-hit tourist sector
summary: Turkey is trying to revive its virus-hit tourist sector by implementing strict measures to protect tourists and staff, including social distancing, disinfectant gels, and protective face masks. The country has awarded a "safe tourism" certificate to over 500 establishments, and authorities aim to quadruple this number in the coming month. With the lifting of global restrictions, Turkey is negotiating with home countries to convince foreign tourists to visit, despite being on a list of "coronavirus risk areas" in some countries.

images.alt_text: In normal times, tourists must rise at dawn to secure a free sunbed on the beach in Antalya, a popular holiday resort in southern Turkey.

site_title: UOB's The FinLab launches digital platform for SMEs, startups in Asean
summary: United Overseas Bank's (UOB) innovation accelerator The FinLab has launched an online platform to help small and medium-sized enterprises (SMEs) and startups across the Asean region digitalise. The FinLab Online provides free membership, business transformation programmes, and access to digital solutions and technology providers. Since its launch, The FinLab has received interest from over 2,000 businesses and more than 440 SMEs and startups registered for the platform. The online platform aims to give SMEs and startups tailored support to drive business growth in the digital era.

site_title: Broker's take: RHB says S-Reits rebound 38% from March, investor interest likely to remain high
summary: S-Reits in Singapore have rebounded 38% from March lows, trading closer to their long-term mean valuations, according to a RHB research report. Analyst Vijay Natarajan attributes the rally to investor interest, low-interest rates, and liquidity returning. RHB maintains its "overweight" rating on the sector, predicting acquisitions to pick up pace in the second half as financing and market conditions improve. S-Reits are expected to distribute most of their retained income in the second half, with retail S-Reits likely to remain cautious amid fluid market conditions.

site_title: Digital habits on the rise in Southeast Asia as the new normal approaches: Mastercard study
summary: A Mastercard study found that digital habits in Southeast Asia are expected to remain long-term despite the region's easing of restrictions. 40% or more of consumers in Malaysia, Philippines, Singapore, and Thailand rely on home delivery services, and nearly half of them shop online. Cash usage decreased by 67% in Singapore, 64% in Malaysia, and 59% in Thailand since the pandemic began. Contactless payments also increased, with mobile and digital wallets seeing the greatest uptick.

images.alt_text: SimplyGo, the new payment mode for buses and trains. Commuters tap the fare gantry with their Mastercard or mobile phone. Mastercard adopted a drive into digital commerce many years before COVID-19 to maximize options andconvenience for consumers in how and where they shop and pay.

site_title: Hong Kong leader says she will appoint national security judges based on advice
summary: Hong Kong leader Carrie Lam announced she will appoint national security judges based on recommendations from a judicial body, not personally selecting them. The draft national security law, unveiled by Chinese state media, grants Beijing sweeping powers over Hong Kong's enforcement, marking the biggest change to the city's way of life since its return to Chinese rule in 1997. Lam also stated the draft law does not rule out foreign judges hearing national security cases, aiming to ease concerns over judicial independence.

site_title: Singapore core inflation stays negative for fourth month in May at -0.2%
summary: Singapore's core inflation remained negative for the fourth consecutive month in May at -0.2%, driven by a decrease in private transport costs and a slower decline in services. Food prices rose to 2.2% from 2.1% in April, while electricity and gas costs eased to -4.6% from -5.2% in the same period. Analysts expect core inflation to remain soft due to subdued economic sentiment and weak labor market conditions.

images.alt_text: Key consumer prices in Singapore continued to fall year on year in May, as core inflation stayed negative for the fourth straight month, according to data released on Tuesday.

site_title: US$4t fund holders tell Brazil to halt deforestation
summary: Investment funds managing nearly US$4 trillion in assets have issued an open letter to Brazil's government, urging them to halt Amazon deforestation. The funds, representing countries across Europe, Asia, and South America, warn that biodiversity loss and carbon emissions from deforestation pose a "systemic risk" to their portfolios. They call on President Jair Bolsonaro's administration to show "clear commitment" to reducing deforestation and protecting indigenous rights. The letter comes as Brazil's Amazon experienced a 12% increase in deforestation in May, with 829 sq km lost to deforestation, the worst May since record keeping began in 2015.

site_title: Australian regulator sues CBA and wealth unit for conflicted remuneration payment
summary: Australia's corporate regulator, ASIC, has commenced civil penalty proceedings against Commonwealth Bank of Australia (CBA) and its wealth management unit, Colonial First State Investments Ltd (CFSIL), for allegedly paying over A$22 million in conflicted remuneration for the distribution of a superannuation product between 2013 and 2019. The regulator is seeking up to A$1 million in civil penalties for each contravention. The alleged misconduct was uncovered by the Royal Commission into the financial services industry, which found widespread misconduct, including charging customers for services not rendered and deceiving regulators.

site_title: Sequoia leads extended seed round of Horizon Quantum Computing
summary: Horizon Quantum Computing, a local developer of programming tools for quantum computers, has secured an extended seed round of funding led by Sequoia Capital India, raising its total seed capital to S$4.5 million. The startup, founded in 2018, aims to use the funds to bring its technology to market and strengthen its team. Horizon's approach to quantum computing involves constructing algorithms directly from conventional source code, automatically identifying places to speed up processing. The company plans to capitalize on the emerging quantum technology, expected to have a significant impact in the future.

site_title: StanChart Singapore to invest extra S$5m in talent development, reskilling
summary: Standard Chartered Singapore is investing an additional S$5 million in talent development and reskilling initiatives, building on a two-year investment. The bank will provide 350 traineeship and career opportunities in 2020, supporting its digitalization plans. It will also participate in industry programs and ramp up its SkillsFuture@SC program, which has helped 20% of employees upgrade their skills and redeploy to new roles. The bank's CEO, Patrick Lee, emphasized the importance of keeping employees relevant and competitive in the changing environment.

site_title: Gilead targets remdesivir supply for 2 million Covid-19 patients by year-end
summary: Gilead Sciences Inc aims to supply its antiviral drug remdesivir to over 2 million Covid-19 patients by year-end, more than double its previous target of 1 million. The company plans to start trials of an inhaled version of the medicine in August, currently administered intravenously. Remdesivir has been granted emergency use authorization in the US and full approval in Japan, and Gilead has set up voluntary licensing agreements with nine generic manufacturers to increase supply.

site_title: Sanofi eyes approval of Covid-19 vaccine by first half of 2021
summary: Sanofi expects to receive approval for its Covid-19 vaccine by the first half of 2021, faster than previously anticipated. The vaccine, developed with GlaxoSmithKline, is currently in clinical trials and has demonstrated potential efficacy. Sanofi aims to produce up to 1 billion doses annually, with the capacity to supply up to 360 million doses of its mRNA vaccine. Despite competition, Sanofi's CEO believes the company's probability of success is higher than others, citing its long-established reputation in vaccine development.

site_title: Hong Kong: Stocks open higher on Tuesday
summary: Hong Kong shares opened higher on Tuesday, edging up 0.12% to 24,541.44, following a positive lead from New York. Despite a second wave of virus infections reported in several countries, investors remain cautious. The benchmark Shanghai Composite Index dipped 0.15%, while the Shenzhen Composite Index rose 0.05%.

site_title: Australia, New Zealand dollars flinch from renewed Sino-US trade fears
summary: The Australian and New Zealand dollars experienced a sudden decline on Tuesday after White House trade adviser Peter Navarro stated the US trade deal with China is "over". This sparked risk aversion, affecting global equity markets and currencies. The Aussie slipped 0.4% to US$0.6878, while the kiwi dollar dropped 0.4% to US$0.6510. Despite a positive survey of Australian businesses showing economic recovery, the Sino-US trade fears overshadowed the news, causing a 1.3% drop in S&P 500 futures.

site_title: FDA warns of potentially toxic hand sanitisers
summary: The FDA is warning consumers to avoid nine hand sanitizer products manufactured in Mexico due to potential methanol contamination. The agency tested two products, Lavar Gel and CleanCare No Germ, finding 81% and 28% methanol content, respectively. Methanol is toxic if absorbed through the skin or ingested, and the FDA advises against its use in hand sanitizers. The agency is advising consumers to stop using these products immediately and to seek alternative hand sanitizers.

site_title: Kohl's CEO says store is changing faster than ever expected
summary: Kohl's CEO Michelle Gass says the company is rapidly adapting to the post-pandemic retail landscape, with sales increasing three-quarters of what they were last year at reopened stores. The company has implemented various safety measures, including curbside pickup, Plexiglass barriers, and mask-wearing requirements. Despite a 1.4% drop in shares, Gass is confident in Kohl's ability to remain relevant, citing the success of its e-commerce efforts and the return of consumers. The company is preparing for a potentially altered holiday shopping season, with in-store pickup and curbside pickup expected to see increased popularity.

site_title: WHO urges ramped-up Covid-19 dexamethasone production
summary: The World Health Organization (WHO) has urged a rapid increase in production of the steroid dexamethasone, after British clinical trials found it had a 35% life-saving potential for critically ill coronavirus patients. The WHO is focusing on distributing the medicine to where it's needed most, with over 140 million items of personal protective equipment and oxygen concentrators already being shipped to 135 countries. Dexamethasone is an inexpensive medicine that can be produced by many manufacturers worldwide, and the WHO emphasizes its use should be limited to severe or critical disease cases under close clinical supervision.

site_title: What's gotten into the price of cheese?
summary: US cheese prices have experienced sharp swings in recent weeks, reaching record highs of $2.65 a pound in June, after plummeting to nearly 20-year lows in April. The price volatility is attributed to the pandemic's impact on supply and demand, with consumers buying more cheese and dairy farmers struggling to meet demand. The market's fluctuations are also influenced by government actions and the uncertainty facing the US economy. Despite a 165% turnaround in just two months, cheese prices remain roughly 3% below record levels.

site_title: Over 280 online merchants sign up on CapitaLand's digital platforms
summary: CapitaLand's e-commerce platforms eCapitaMall and Capita3Eats have signed over 280 online merchants, with plans to onboard 500 by the end of 2020. eCapitaMall features over 130 merchants offering 18,000 stock keeping units, while Capita3Eats has over 85 food and beverage brands. The platforms aim to support retailers in enhancing in-store customer experience and generating online sales, with a focus on leveraging CapitaLand's 1 million CapitaStar members in Singapore.

site_title: Vodafone invites pitches for US$2b tower IPO
summary: Vodafone Group Plc has invited advisers to pitch for a role on the planned initial public offering of its European towers unit, which could raise over $3 billion. The UK carrier plans to list the business as early as 2021, with Rothschild helping manage the IPO preparations. Vodafone is considering a valuation of $10 billion to $20 billion, with the IPO expected to take place soon.

images.alt_text: Vodafone Group Plc has invited advisers to pitch for a role on the planned initial public offering of its European towers unit, which could raise more than 2 billion euros (S$3.07 billion), people with knowledge of the matter said.

site_title: Singapore shares open lower on Tuesday; STI down 1.4%
summary: Singapore's Straits Times Index (STI) slipped 1.4% to 2,593.12 on Tuesday, with losers outnumbering gainers 189 to 78. Thai Beverage Public Co, Genting Singapore, and OCBC fell, while DBS and UOB rose. In contrast, Singtel gained 0.4%. The benchmark index follows a similar decline from the previous day.

site_title: Federal Reserve's Powell, Treasury's Mnuchin to testify June 30 before House panel
summary: Federal Reserve Chairman Jerome Powell and Treasury Secretary Steven Mnuchin will testify before the US House of Representatives Financial Services Committee on June 30 about the coronavirus response.

site_title: OCBC launches healthcare app with over 100 doctors, flat consultation fees
summary: OCBC Bank has launched the HealthPass app, offering access to over 100 doctors and specialists in Singapore. The app provides video consultations, medication delivery, and physical assessment appointments, with flat consultation fees of S$20 for GPs and S$100 for specialist doctors. The app integrates with healthcare partners' clinic management systems, allowing patients to access their medical records and track costs. The move aims to make telehealth more accessible and convenient for patients, particularly those without existing private coverage.

images.alt_text: The HealthPass by OCBC app integrates directly with the healthcare partners' clinic management systems. Information is accessible only by users and their doctors.

site_title: Beijing reports 13 new Covid-19 cases for June 22 vs 9 a day earlier
summary: Beijing reported 13 new COVID-19 cases on June 22, up from 9 the previous day, with 249 total cases in the city. The outbreak is linked to a wholesale food centre in southwest Beijing. The city's first case in the latest wave occurred on June 11.

images.alt_text: Beijing's municipal health authority reported on Tuesday 13 new cases of the novel coronavirus in the city for June 22, up from nine a day earlier.

site_title: Woolworths says it underpaid more staff, costs to hit annual profit
summary: Woolworths Group Ltd has admitted to underpaying thousands of employees at its ALH Hotels group, with remediation costs expected to reach A$390 million. The underpayment, which occurred in 2018 and 2019, will impact the company's full-year operating profit forecast, which is now expected to be between A$3.20 billion and A$3.25 billion. The company is also incurring additional costs to streamline its supply chain and prepare for a combination of its drinks and pubs units.

site_title: Hong Kong economy gets a boost from staycations, dining deals
summary: Hong Kong's economy is experiencing a boost from staycations and dining deals amid eased social-distancing restrictions. Despite a 99.9% decline in tourist arrivals, retail sales have seen a modest uptick, with pent-up demand among residents for food and entertainment. However, concerns remain about the city's battered tourism industry and the impact of anti-China protests on potential Chinese tourists. Smaller businesses are more optimistic about their short-term prospects, with May readings for favorable business conditions rising above 50 for the first time since 2018.

site_title: Asia: Markets rise as dealers focus on reopening over infections
summary: Asian markets rose on Tuesday as investors focused on the reopening of economies, despite concerns over a second wave of COVID-19 infections. The gains were driven by trillions of dollars in government and central bank support, as well as a V-shaped economic recovery. However, a top White House adviser's comments that the China-US trade pact was "over" sparked initial sell-offs, but markets seemed to shrug off the concerns as the lockdown-easing narrative persisted. Despite volatility, stocks continued to rise, with major markets including Hong Kong, Tokyo, and Seoul up, while Shanghai and Singapore were flat.

site_title: Australia: Shares track Wall Street higher as stimulus hopes linger
summary: Australian shares rose 0.47% to 5,972.2 on Tuesday, tracking Wall Street gains on hopes of more stimulus measures to combat the economic slump. The S&P/ASX 200 index is on track for a third straight session of gains, driven by energy stocks boosted by higher oil prices and the IHS Markit June flash composite PMI for Australia, which rose to 52.6. Retailer Woolworths Group fell 0.6% after announcing underpaid employees, while technology stocks rose 1.31% led by Apple's new product announcement.

site_title: World Bank chief calls for more private sector buy-in on G-20 debt relief
summary: World Bank President David Malpass emphasized the need for more private sector buy-in on G-20 debt relief for the world's poorest countries. As of now, 35 of 73 eligible countries are participating in the Debt Service Suspension Initiative, which will freeze debt service payments through year-end, freeing up $12 billion for health and economic strains. Malpass urged further steps to prevent economic crisis from widening poverty rates, and called for private sector creditors to boost participation, citing concerns about credit ratings and access to international capital markets.

images.alt_text: The Group of 20 major economies' debt relief initiative for the world's poorest countries has made good progress but additional relief and greater participation by private sector creditors are needed, World Bank President David Malpass said on Monday.

site_title: SoftBank to sell US$21b in T-Mobile shares
summary: SoftBank Group, a Japanese tech investment behemoth, will sell approximately US$21 billion worth of T-Mobile shares. This move aims to shore up its financial health, following an annual net loss of US$8.9 billion due to troubles with unicorn investments and market downturns caused by the coronavirus pandemic. SoftBank holds about 24% of T-Mobile shares and plans to sell up to 198.3 million shares in the transaction.

site_title: Biden campaign asks Twitter, Facebook to remove Trump posts bashing mail-in voting
summary: Democratic presidential candidate Joe Biden's campaign has asked Twitter and Facebook to remove posts by President Donald Trump that make false claims about mail-in voting. Trump tweeted that mail-in voting could lead to "baseless conspiracy theories" and undermine faith in the electoral process. The Biden campaign claims Trump's statements are meant to discourage people from voting by mail due to health concerns. Both Twitter and Facebook have stated that Trump's posts do not violate their policies and will not be removed.

site_title: Dior revives fashion shows - but with no front row
summary: Christian Dior is reviving its fashion shows, starting with an Italian catwalk display on July 22, without the traditional A-list front row due to the coronavirus crisis. The luxury brand plans to maintain its calendar of fashion weeks and produce other collections, with a mid-season "cruise" range to be streamed live. CEO Pietro Beccari aims to send a message of hope and optimism, supporting small suppliers and artisans. Dior plans to resume its Paris-based fashion show in September, potentially with a front-row audience.

site_title: Zhongmin Baihui to buy 36 tonnes of Moutai liquor
summary: Zhongmin Baihui Retail Group has agreed to purchase 36 tonnes of Moutai liquor worth 120 million yuan (S$23.6 million) from Kweichow Moutai Group. The deal includes various types of Moutai products, and the company's executive chairman, Lee Swee Keng, expressed pride in being selected for the distribution agreement. The signing ceremony involved 21 other companies, and shares of Zhongmin Baihui remained flat at 63.5 Singapore cents.

site_title: Online disruption of Trump rally highlights K-pop's political hustle
summary: K-pop fans and TikTok users disrupted Donald Trump's rally in Tulsa, Oklahoma, by reserving tickets with no intention of attending, resulting in a low turnout of 6,200 people. The campaign, which went viral on social media, highlighted K-pop's tradition of being politically engaged and socially conscious. Experts say K-pop fans are a powerful force due to their online savvy and willingness to organize and support causes, with some calling the disruption a "powerful flex" that showed the Trump campaign that their numbers can't be trusted.

site_title: Mapletree Industrial Trust to buy 60% stake in 14 data centres for US$210.9m
summary: Mapletree Industrial Trust (MIT) has agreed to purchase the remaining 60% stake in 14 US data centres for US$210.9 million, increasing its exposure to the "resilient data centres segment" and enhancing income stability. The acquisition is expected to be accretive to unitholders, with a pro forma distribution per unit (DPU) of 12.66 Singapore cents and a net asset value (NAV) of S$1.68 per unit. MIT plans to finance the acquisition through an equity fundraising and the issuance of the acquisition fee in units.

site_title: Couch dining to withstand restaurant reopenings, Jefferies says
summary: Jefferies predicts the comfort of eating at home will persist as consumers continue to save money by dining in, with 80% of consumers expecting to eat at home as much or more than before the pandemic. Analyst Rob Dickerson upgraded Conagra Brands and Campbell Soup Co to buy, citing a lift in at-home consumption for the companies' top-selling brands. In contrast, Goldman Sachs expects moderation in packaged food growth as restaurants reopen, but notes that a full reversion to pre-pandemic demand is unlikely due to crowd-avoidance behavior and higher unemployment.

site_title: China launches final satellite to complete rival to GPS
summary: China successfully launched the final satellite in its Beidou-3GEO3 system, a rival to the US GPS network, on Tuesday. The launch from the Xichang Satellite Launch Centre in southwestern Sichuan province marked a major step in China's efforts to gain market share in the lucrative geolocation sector. The launch was originally scheduled for last Tuesday but was delayed due to technical issues. This completes China's homegrown geolocation system, which aims to provide navigation and positioning services for various industries.

site_title: Malaysia: Shares open lower on Tuesday
summary: Malaysia's shares opened lower on Tuesday, with the FTSE Bursa Malaysia Kuala Lumpur Composite Index down 1.45 points, or 0.10%, to 1,509.79. Volume was 414.02 million lots worth RM125.91 million.

site_title: Tokyo: Stocks open higher, extending US rallies
summary: Tokyo stocks opened higher on Tuesday, extending US rallies, with the benchmark Nikkei 225 index up 0.85% at 22,628.00. Investors took heart from US market gains, weighing the ongoing coronavirus spread against stimulus measures. The broader Topix index advanced 0.60%.

site_title: Nam Lee buys 4 Gul Way property as new headquarters for S$18m
summary: Nam Lee Pressed Metal Industries has entered into a property sale agreement to acquire the leasehold interests in 4 Gul Way for S$18 million. The company will use the property as its new headquarters and house production facilities, citing its more accessible location and larger gross floor area compared to its current head office. The acquisition is expected to strengthen Nam Lee's operations and remain competitive. The purchase price will be funded by internal resources and bank borrowings, with completion expected within 12 weeks.

site_title: EU warns China over Hong Kong security law
summary: The European Union warned China that imposing a new security law on Hong Kong would have "very negative consequences" and undermine the territory's autonomy. EU leaders expressed "grave concern" over the law, which critics say would curb Hong Kong's freedoms. China's foreign ministry dismissed the EU's concerns, saying Hong Kong matters are a "domestic affair" and that the EU is interfering in China's internal affairs. The EU's stern message comes as Beijing shows no signs of backing down on the law, which critics say will end Hong Kong's relative freedoms and open the door to repression.

site_title: US tightens rules on four more Chinese state 'propaganda' outlets
summary: The US has reclassified four Chinese state media organizations, including China Central Television, China News Service, People's Daily, and Global Times, as foreign missions rather than media outlets, due to their propaganda nature. This decision aims to require these organizations to report on their US-based staff and real estate transactions to the State Department. The move follows the reclassification of five Chinese state media organizations in February.

images.alt_text: The State Department said it was reclassifying four outlets - China Central Television, the China News Service, the People's Daily and the Global Times - as foreign missions rather than media outlets in the United States.

site_title: Oxley inks agreements to sell retail, commercial units at former Chevron House
summary: Oxley Holdings has entered into agreements to sell retail and commercial units at the former Chevron House in Singapore for a total of S$315 million. The sales, which will be completed simultaneously on June 30, involve Siriti R Pte Ltd and Siriti C Pte Ltd. Oxley Holdings will receive deposits of S$3.15 million and pay up to 5% of the total purchase price as liability for two years. The sale will be followed by the transfer of Oxley Holdings' remaining stake in Oxley Beryl to Golden Compass.

site_title: Stocks to watch: Keppel, Oxley, Asian Pay Television Trust, ValueMax
summary: Keppel Corp, Oxley Holdings, Asian Pay Television Trust (APTT), and ValueMax Group have seen new developments that may impact their trading. Keppel Corp terminated a rig-building contract with Awilco and initiated arbitration, while Oxley Holdings entered into property sale agreements worth S$315 million. APTT received 474.7 million valid acceptances for a 1-for-4 rights issue, and ValueMax Group is unaffected by government-mandated loan repayment suspensions.

site_title: Trudeau slams 'political' detentions, after China spy charges
summary: Prime Minister Justin Trudeau condemned China's detention of two Canadians, Michael Kovrig and Michael Spavor, as "arbitrary and unacceptable" and "political in nature." The detentions come 18 months after the men were arrested in a long-running spat between the two countries. Trudeau expressed gratitude to allies for speaking out against Beijing's use of "hostage diplomacy," and said Canada will continue to pressure China to release the men. Relations between Canada and China have deteriorated, with China blocking billions of dollars' worth of Canadian agricultural exports.

site_title: Moody's lowers Brazil GDP outlook, warns of rising Covid-19 risks
summary: Moody's lowered Brazil's 2020 GDP outlook to a 6.2% decline, citing deepening uncertainty over the Covid-19 pandemic. The agency also warned of potential disruptions to consumer activity and business functioning. Brazil is the world's second-largest coronavirus hotspot, with over 1 million confirmed cases and 50,000 related deaths. Moody's revised its 2021 economic growth outlook to 3.6%, but noted this was largely due to the low 2020 growth rather than a stronger rebound.

site_title: Google adds fact-check to images
summary: Google is adding fact-check labels to images in search results to combat visually misleading information. The labels will be attached to underlying web pages of photos and videos, sourced from the ClaimReview database of independent fact-checkers. The labels will appear on Google Images and provide a summary of fact checks when users tap on the image results. This move aims to help users navigate visual media and make informed judgments, without affecting search rankings.
