site_title: UK eases lockdown further as deaths, cases slow
summary: The UK has eased its lockdown restrictions further, with fewer than 1,000 daily confirmed cases of coronavirus and a daily death toll of 15. The Health Secretary announced that restrictions for the most vulnerable will be eased, allowing them to meet outside in groups of up to six from July 6. The entire "shielding" programme will be paused from August 1, with a restart date of July 4 pencilled in for pubs and restaurants. This marks progress in the country's coronavirus outbreak, which has been the deadliest in Europe.

site_title: Asian Pay Television Trust rights issue 1.3 times subscribed
summary: Asian Pay Television Trust's (APTT) trustee-manager reported 474.7 million valid acceptances and excess applications for its proposed 1-for-4 rights issue, exceeding 1.3 times the offered 361.3 million rights units. This represents 23.2% of total rights units available, with excess applications making up 108.2%. The news follows the company's rights issue announcement.

site_title: Pandemic keeps Japan's June manufacturing activity pinned at 11-year low: PMI
summary: Japan's factory activity remained at an 11-year low in June, with the manufacturing Purchasing Managers' Index (PMI) edging down to 37.8, its lowest since March 2009. This marks the 14th consecutive month below the 50.0 threshold separating contraction from expansion. The decline is attributed to the prolonged impact of the coronavirus pandemic on export-reliant economies like Japan's. The services sector, however, saw a sharp increase in activity, with the PMI index jumping to a four-month high.

images.alt_text: Japan's factory activity remained stuck at an 11-year low in June, in a sign the coronavirus pandemic is taking a toll on manufacturers even as services-sector sentiment picks up.

site_title: Keppel FELS issues notice of termination of Awilco rig-building contract
summary: Keppel FELS has issued a notice of termination to Awilco, citing non-payment of a nearly $31.9 million instalment due on June 9. Keppel Corp claims this is a default under the contract, allowing it to terminate the agreement, retain $54 million in payments, and seek compensation. The company has commenced arbitration to enforce its rights against Awilco.

site_title: Spirit says it may breach financial covenants after deeper Boeing 737 production cut
summary: Spirit AeroSystems Holdings reported it may breach financial covenants due to Boeing's request to substantially reduce 737 production this year. The company now expects to deliver only 72 shipsets, down from 125 planned earlier. Spirit's shares fell 4% in after-hours trading. The production cut is attributed to the coronavirus crisis.

images.alt_text: Spirit AeroSystems Holdings said on Monday it was at a risk of breaching its financial covenants, as top customer Boeing has asked the aero parts maker to substantially reduce 737 production this year due to the coronavirus crisis.

site_title: New chips to bring Mac computers into iPhone ecosystem
summary: Apple announced it will design its own chips for Mac computers, ending its partnership with Intel, to create a "common architecture" allowing Macs to run iPhone and iPad apps. The first new Mac computers with Apple silicon will ship by the end of the year, offering a more powerful and energy-efficient system. This move aims to enable cross-platform development and a unified Apple product ecosystem.

site_title: Global advertising faces double-digit decline this year: report
summary: The global advertising industry is expected to decline nearly 12% this year due to the coronavirus pandemic, according to a report by ad agency GroupM. The decline, excluding US political advertising, is considered modest compared to the 2008 financial crisis. The pandemic's impact on economies is expected to be worse, but the report suggests that the advertising market's decline will be a reflection of the broader economic impact rather than a direct result of the pandemic.

images.alt_text: The global advertising industry is expected to decline nearly 12 per cent this year as the coronavirus pandemic batters businesses around the world, a report on the sector said on Monday.

site_title: Two more Trump campaign staffers positive for Covid-19
summary: US President Donald Trump's campaign staff has reported two more positive Covid-19 cases among the advance team that organized his Tulsa, Oklahoma rally. The two staffers were wearing masks during the event, but the campaign activated quarantine and contact tracing protocols. This brings the total number of positive tests to eight, following an initial six cases reported earlier. Despite health concerns, Trump went ahead with the rally, his first since the pandemic began.

site_title: New Zealand's Fonterra to pay farmers more for sustainable dairy
summary: Fonterra, New Zealand's largest dairy exporter, announced it will pay farmers up to 10 cents per kilogram of milk solids for sustainably produced dairy products starting from the June 2021 dairy season. This move aims to incentivize environmentally friendly and animal-friendly dairy production, aligning with growing consumer demand for sustainable food sources.

site_title: 'Batman Forever' and 'Lost Boys' director Schumacher dies at 80
summary: Joel Schumacher, director of 'Batman Forever' and 'The Lost Boys,' has died at 80 due to a year-long battle with cancer. Schumacher, who began as a costume designer, is best known for his flamboyant style and divisive films in the Batman franchise. Despite criticism for 'Batman & Robin,' Schumacher expressed regret in a 2017 interview, calling it a "baby" he had "murdered." He launched the careers of Matthew McConaughey and Colin Farrell, among others. Schumacher passed away quietly in New York City.

site_title: Startups exemplify how to thrive, not just survive, amid Covid-19: Jungle's Amit Anand
summary: During the COVID-19 pandemic, startups in South-east Asia demonstrated resilience and adaptability, thriving in the face of economic disruption. By innovating and pivoting their products and business models, startups such as Builder.ai and Crayon created solutions to meet the new needs of consumers and businesses. Many startups also contributed to the community by launching initiatives to support frontliners, provide mental health support, and promote hygiene and social distancing. As lockdowns ease, these startups are poised to lead the way in guiding the region into the "new normal" and driving technological maturity.

site_title: England to reopen cinemas and galleries next month
summary: Cinemas and galleries in England will reopen on July 4, as part of the government's easing of the coronavirus lockdown. Social distancing measures, including one-way systems and pre-booked tickets, will be introduced. The reopening is part of a review that may also allow hairdressers, places of worship, pubs, and restaurants to open. The death toll among Covid-19 patients has fallen to 42,647, with infection rates continuing to slow. The government is also easing restrictions on 2.2 million people considered clinically extremely vulnerable, allowing them to meet in groups from July 6.

site_title: Microsoft ends game streaming, teams up with Facebook
summary: Microsoft is ending its game streaming platform, Mixer, and teaming up with Facebook to compete with rivals like Amazon-owned Twitch. The service will be shut down on July 22, and users will be encouraged to transition to Facebook Gaming, which has 700 million monthly active users. The decision allows Microsoft to focus on other gaming efforts, including Xbox Game Pass and Project xCloud. Microsoft will work to transition the Mixer community over the next few weeks, with Phil Spencer, head of Xbox, stating that the move will enable the company to "bring that vision to life, for as many people as possible."

site_title: Trump to extend US work visa freeze to year-end: White House
summary: US President Donald Trump plans to extend a ban on new work permits for non-US citizens to the end of 2020, freeing up 525,000 jobs. The ban, which includes H1-B visas for 85,000 tech industry workers, aims to respond to soaring unemployment caused by the Covid-19 shutdown. The move is seen as a temporary measure to restructure the H1-B visa program, prioritizing foreign workers with the highest wages and skills. The administration hopes the measure will help the US economy recover ahead of the November election.

site_title: Darco minority shareholders raise disclosure, conflict of interest issues
summary: Minority shareholders of Darco Water Technologies, holding a 15% stake, have raised concerns over market misconduct and conflicts of interest amid the company's significant decline in share value. The company's non-executive deputy chairman, Robert Wang Zhi, is set to acquire control through a general offer, which minority shareholders have questioned due to lack of disclosure and potential conflicts of interest. The Monetary Authority of Singapore (MAS) is reviewing a complaint on suspected market misconduct, and the company is also facing criticism over its venture into Indonesia's waste management project.

site_title: Money FM podcast: V for S-REITs
summary: Michelle Martin discusses S-REITs with Kenny Loh, an expert in the REIT sector. The S-REIT index has experienced fluctuations, but industrial and hospitality REITs show optimism. The data REIT space is also gaining traction. Kenny Loh highlights the importance of dollar asset diversification for Asia, driven by the region's growing economy.

site_title: Aussie and Kiwi dollars lead gains; US dollar falls
summary: The Australian and New Zealand dollars rose, while the US dollar fell, as investors remained optimistic about an economic recovery despite a record increase in global COVID-19 cases. The Australian dollar gained 0.6% and the New Zealand dollar rose 0.7% against the US dollar, driven by comments from Reserve Bank of Australia governor Philip Lowe and a lack of new lockdown measures. US dollar short positions increased, indicating broader market optimism, while the euro rose 0.3% against the US dollar.

site_title: Europe: Shares hit by renewed virus fears
summary: European shares closed at a near one-week low on Monday due to renewed fears of a coronavirus resurgence in Germany and elsewhere. The pan-European Stoxx 600 index fell 0.8% as losses in the food, telecom, and oil & gas sectors led the decline. Wirecard's stock plummeted 44% after the company reported that a quarter of its assets couldn't be accounted for, and the World Health Organization reported a record increase in global coronavirus cases. The outlook for a swift economic recovery remains uncertain.

site_title: Final Virgin Australia bids a key test for ailing aviation industry
summary: Private equity firms Bain Capital LP and Cyrus Capital Partners LP have made final bids for Virgin Australia Holdings Ltd, the second-largest airline in Australia, after the government declined to step in with a bailout. The airline collapsed under A$6.8 billion of debt in April and is expected to face years of curtailed business travel. The bids, which did not disclose their value, aim to secure a sustainable recovery for the ailing aviation industry, which faces over US$84 billion in losses worldwide due to Covid-19 and related travel restrictions.

site_title: Asset managers find due diligence solution in virtual realm
summary: Asset managers in Singapore are adapting to travel bans by hosting virtual due diligence sessions with investors, replacing in-person meetings. This shift has been accelerated by the "circuit breaker" and Phase 1 periods, with firms like Gao Capital and Eastspring Investments finding it more productive for clients to discuss positions and market performance remotely. While some practices may continue after Singapore reopens, challenges remain, including integrating new staff and meeting investors in person, which can be crucial for securing investments.

site_title: A Trump win in November may not seem all that bad to Xi
summary: US Secretary of State Mike Pompeo met with Chinese diplomat Yang Jiechi in Hawaii, marking a low-profile but constructive dialogue on US-China relations. The six-hour talks, which spanned two days, were seen as a positive development despite the two countries' strained relations. The meeting was described as "constructive" by China's state news agency Xinhua, which was approved by the US. The talks are believed to be part of a new chapter in US foreign policy under President Donald Trump.

site_title: DBS initiates coverage of Valuetronics with 'hold' call
summary: DBS Group Research has initiated coverage on electronics manufacturer Valuetronics Holdings with a "hold" call and a target price of S$0.53. Despite current headwinds, including US-China trade tensions and a weak economic outlook, the research team believes the company's strong fundamentals and strategic plans to diversify out of China will allow it to tide through difficulties. Valuetronics has cash reserves of HK$1 billion, sufficient to fund a cash burn rate and support its Vietnam expansion.

site_title: Halcyon Agri plans 1-for-2 rights issue to raise S$174.7m
summary: Halcyon Agri Corp plans a renounceable non-underwritten rights issue of up to 797.5 million new shares at 22 Singapore cents apiece, offering eligible shareholders one rights share for every two existing ordinary shares. The issue aims to raise S$174.7 million to fund operating cash flows and debt servicing, strengthening the group's capital structure and reducing overall gearing. The proposed issue is a 36.2% discount to the last traded price of 34.5 cents per share.

site_title: MRT network boost delayed but 50% expansion still targeted for early 2030s: Khaw
summary: Singapore's plan to expand its rail network by 50% is delayed due to the impact of Covid-19, but Transport Minister Khaw Boon Wan aims to still achieve the target by the early 2030s.

site_title: US: Nasdaq ends at fresh record as tech leads stocks up
summary: The Nasdaq index closed at a fresh record, driven by technology stocks, including Apple's new announcements. The Dow Jones and S&P 500 also rose, with the Nasdaq Composite Index jumping 1.1% to 10,056.47. Despite concerns over coronavirus cases and US stimulus measures, investors focused on the tech sector, pushing stocks up.

site_title: Oil up above 2% on tighter supplies, eased lockdowns
summary: Oil prices rose 2% on Monday due to tighter crude supplies from major producers and easing lockdowns. Brent crude settled at $43.08 a barrel, while West Texas Intermediate (WTI) crude rose to $40.73 a barrel. The drop in US and Canadian oil rig count and the reopening of states and countries contributed to the price increase. The market also expects Opec+ to maintain coordinated production cuts, supporting oil prices. However, concerns about a potential second wave of the coronavirus kept prices from rising higher.

images.alt_text: Oil was up 2 per cent on Monday on tighter crude supplies from major producers and as coronavirus lockdowns kept easing despite a record rise in cases globally.

site_title: New licence terms for employment agencies to boost fair hiring: MOM
summary: The Ministry of Manpower (MOM) in Singapore has introduced new licence conditions for employment agencies (EAs) to boost fair hiring practices. Starting October 1, nearly 3,900 EAs must comply with fair-recruitment requirements, including briefing clients on fair employment practices, attracting Singaporean job seekers, and considering candidates based on merit. Those that fail to comply may face demerit points, licence suspension, or revocation. Selected EAs will be appointed as placement partners to help vulnerable job seekers access professional career-matching services.

images.alt_text: The new licence conditions will take effect from Oct 1, requiring nearly 3,900 EAs licensed by MOM to comply with fair-recruitment requirements set out in the Tripartite Guidelines on Fair Employment Practices; EAs must brief clients on the TGFEP fair-recruitment requirements, make reasonable efforts to attract Singaporeans for job vacancies, and consider all candidates based on merit.

site_title: Trump's reality check in campaign start
summary: US President Donald Trump's 2020 campaign got off to a poor start, with the Supreme Court rejecting his applications and embarrassing revelations from his former national security adviser, John Bolton. The president's approval ratings have plummeted, with Joe Biden leading him by 10 percentage points in the popular vote and in key electoral states. Trump's response to the coronavirus pandemic, economic downturn, and protests has been criticized as ineffective. The Supreme Court's recent rulings, including one protecting LGBTQ+ workers from workplace discrimination, further eroded his credibility. Trump's rally in Tulsa, Oklahoma, was also marred by a small turnout, highlighting his struggles to connect with supporters.

site_title: Changing hands
summary: Citigroup has set a target of 1,150 for MSCI's global equity index by mid-2026. Analysts are optimistic about SGX's earnings due to volatility, raising target prices. Meanwhile, Chinese banks face challenges from Beijing's consumer lending push. Japanese bank MUFG plans to expand its US securitization business and boost headcount. The PBOC adviser recommends a 1.5 trillion yuan stimulus to counter US tariffs. Tesla plans to expand its robotaxi services in California and Arizona. FedEx partners with Singapore startup QuikBot to deploy robots for commercial deliveries, and Sam Goi makes a mandatory offer for PSC shares.

site_title: Opportunities among the masses
summary: A commentary by Ben Paul highlights the potential for businesses to tap into the captive consumer market of the poor, who are limited by geography and have to shop in their neighborhood. This presents opportunities for local entrepreneurs to harness technology and provide goods and services at affordable prices. In contrast, the wealthy are not limited by geography and can shop globally, making them less accessible for business growth. By focusing on the poor, businesses can create jobs and stimulate the economy, shifting the national dialogue from the wealthy to the underserved.

site_title: Nintendo cools mobile ambitions after Animal Crossing success
summary: Nintendo is retreating from the mobile gaming market after disappointing results, ending a multi-year effort. The company had initially aimed to release two to three mobile titles each year, but disappointing results led to a shift in focus to its own console ecosystem. Despite a surge in Switch popularity, Nintendo's mobile ambitions have been cooled, marking a significant change in the company's gaming strategy.

site_title: SIA, SilkAir increase transit sources; Scoot to increase destinations
summary: Singapore Airlines (SIA) and SilkAir announced on June 22, 2020, that customers can transit through Singapore Changi Airport to any SIA Group network destination, including China, Hong Kong, Japan, and South Korea. Ticket sales for these new destinations will be available from June 23. This expansion builds on previous approvals for Australia and New Zealand.

site_title: Giant circle of shafts discovered close to Stonehenge
summary: Archaeologists have discovered a 2km-wide circle of deep shafts surrounding the ancient settlement of Durrington Walls, located 3km northeast of Stonehenge. The shafts, dating back 4,500 years, were found using remote sensing technology and sampling, and are believed to demonstrate the desire of Neolithic communities to record their belief systems. The discovery is considered "astonishing" and "major significance" within the UK, with researchers noting that the effort required to dig such large shafts with ancient tools is unprecedented. The site will open up new lines of investigation into the origins and meaning of Stonehenge.

site_title: Two strata office floors at GB Building for sale with S$11.9m, S$12.7m guide prices
summary: Two strata office floors at GB Building in Singapore's central business district are up for sale via expression of interest (EOI) with prices starting at S$11.9 million and S$12.7 million. The floors, located on levels 16 and 23, offer competitive pricing compared to recent transactions nearby. The sale will be open to locals and foreigners, with no additional buyer's or seller's stamp duty imposed. The EOI exercise will close on July 28, and the properties are expected to attract interest from investors, boutique real estate funds, and high net worth individuals.

site_title: Fearing second Covid-19 wave, Europe aims to train 'army' of medics
summary: Europe is preparing for a potential second wave of COVID-19 by training a "healthcare army" of medical professionals. The European Society of Intensive Care Medicine is hiring more permanent staff and retraining existing medics to handle the next wave of infections. The goal is to create a flexible workforce that can be deployed quickly to areas with shortages. Several countries, including Italy, are retraining surgeons, cardiologists, and nurses, and providing financial incentives to attract more medical students to intensive care medicine.

site_title: Nokia to cut 1,200 jobs at Alcatel-Lucent in France
summary: Nokia plans to cut 1,233 jobs at its Alcatel-Lucent subsidiary in France, reducing the workforce by a third, amid intense competition in the telecoms equipment market. This is the largest job cut at Alcatel-Lucent since its acquisition by Nokia in 2016. The move is part of global cost-cutting efforts launched in 2018 to increase operational efficiency and improve productivity. The job cuts affect research and support departments and come as Nokia's CEO Rajeev Suri steps down in September.

site_title: Over 7,600 businesses loaned about S$7.1 billion
summary: Over 7,600 Singapore businesses borrowed approximately S$7.1 billion from government-assisted schemes between March and mid-June, with 80% of loans going to micro and small enterprises. The majority of loan applications came from wholesale trade, manufacturing, and construction sectors, which were also the top sectors pre-Covid-19. The government's 90% risk share on loans until March 31, 2022, allowed businesses to access credit and use loans for both immediate needs and long-term plans.

site_title: Now is the time to reclaim the streets from the vehicles
summary: The COVID-19 pandemic presents an opportunity for cities to reclaim public space from cars and create more pedestrian-friendly and bike-friendly environments. Since the pandemic, cities worldwide have closed streets to traffic, allowing for increased cycling and walking. This shift is expected to lead to improved air quality, reduced traffic congestion, and increased economic benefits for local businesses. Cities must capitalize on this momentum by implementing permanent changes and investing in mass transit, protected bike lanes, and congestion charges to discourage unnecessary driving. This is a chance for cities to reimagine their urban spaces for the well-being of people, not just cars.

site_title: 218 new Covid-19 cases; some patients visited supermarkets in Jalan Kayu, Serangoon North and Jurong West
summary: Singapore reported 218 new COVID-19 cases, bringing the total to 42,313. The majority of cases are migrant workers in dormitories, with 648 patients discharged on Monday, leaving 200 in hospital. Three public places visited by infectious patients have been added to the list of locations for close monitoring, including two Sheng Siong supermarkets and an NTUC FairPrice outlet. The sole community case, a 33-year-old Indian national, is not linked to known cases.

images.alt_text: Two Sheng Siong supermarkets and an NTUC FairPrice outlet have been added to the list of public places visited by Covid-19 patients while they were still infectious.

site_title: 10 strategies to help your business rebound
summary: Singapore businesses are navigating the challenges of the post-COVID-19 economy, with many seeking ways to rebound. A 90-minute webinar, "Business Recovery: 10 Strategies to Set Yourself For A Rebound," will be held this Thursday, featuring discussions with business leaders and experts on strategies for recovery. The event, supported by RHB Bank and NTUC U SME, aims to provide insights and ideas for businesses to adapt to the new normal. Registration for the webinar closes at midnight today.

site_title: BOE governor signals dramatic shift towards stimulus
summary: Bank of England Governor Andrew Bailey signaled a shift in the central bank's strategy to remove emergency stimulus, emphasizing the need to reduce the institution's £700 billion balance sheet before hiking interest rates. Bailey stressed that a reduced balance sheet would provide more firepower in future crises, as the current balance sheet has swelled due to the pandemic and bond-buying program. The BOE's balance sheet is set to grow even larger, and Bailey warned that elevated balance sheets could limit the bank's ability to act in future emergencies.

site_title: Resilient supply chains come from greater connectivity: MAS chief
summary: MAS chief Ravi Menon emphasizes the importance of maintaining open markets and smooth trade flows in the post-Covid world. He suggests that countries should resist the temptation to retreat behind borders and instead focus on building resilience through greater supply diversification and redundancies in global value chains. This approach can help mitigate the vulnerabilities exposed by the pandemic, Menon said. By diversifying supply chains, countries can reduce their dependence on individual markets and create more robust and resilient economies.

images.alt_text: Mr Menon says Singapore's "fast lane" arrangement with China, launched to facilitate essential business travel between the two countries, is an example of efforts to keep global supply chains open.

site_title: Japan funds play safe by turning away from Latin American bonds
summary: Japan's funds are turning away from Latin American bonds due to concerns over the widening spread of the pandemic and rising political tensions in the region. Despite Latin American bonds returning around 7% this quarter, Japanese investors prefer safer options, citing low yields and the growing threat of COVID-19 cases in countries like Brazil and Mexico. Japanese mutual funds have been net sellers of Mexican and Brazilian bonds, and some investors are opting for Asia, citing faster recovery from the pandemic and synergies in China's recovery.

site_title: Over 500 SMEs get digital access to new markets overseas
summary: Over 500 SMEs in Singapore accessed new overseas markets through e-commerce platforms under the Grow Digital scheme despite the Covid-19 pandemic. Senior Minister of State for Trade and Industry Chee Hong Tat emphasized the need for companies to diversify revenue sources, strengthen their value proposition, and operate safely while remaining commercially viable.

site_title: US insurers eye Legionnaires' disease safeguards as buildings reopen
summary: US insurers are intensifying precautions against Legionnaires' disease outbreaks in reopened buildings, such as movie theaters, gyms, and offices, as they reopen after the pandemic-induced shutdown. Insurers, including Allianz and AXA, are scrutinizing building managers' efforts to maintain plumbing and cooling systems, and may limit coverage amounts or impose higher deductibles if systems are outdated. The disease, caused by the Legionella bacteria, can be spread through stagnant water in dormant buildings, and nearly 50,000 people have been infected between 2000 and 2015, according to the US Centers for Disease Control and Prevention.

images.alt_text: The pandemic-induced shutdown has led to an unprecedented amount of stagnant water in dormant buildings, which then become potential breeding grounds for bacteria that cause Legionnaires'.

site_title: China halts poultry imports from Tyson Foods over fears of virus transmission
summary: China has suspended imports of poultry products from a Tyson Foods plant in Arkansas due to concerns over the transmission of COVID-19. The suspension affects products already at Chinese ports or scheduled to arrive, and may have broader implications for global meat exports. The decision reverses a previous stance by Chinese officials, who had deemed food unlikely to be responsible for a recent virus outbreak in Beijing. The move could threaten US and global meat exports, particularly to China, which had previously been a key market for US poultry.

site_title: China's new low-sulphur fuel oil contract jumps in debut trade
summary: China's new low-sulphur fuel oil (LSFO) futures contract made a 16.7% debut gain on the Shanghai International Energy Exchange, rising to 9.8% higher at 2,599 yuan per tonne. The contract, which allows for sulphur content lower than 0.5%, is seen as undervalued compared to Zhoushan's spot prices and Singapore's 0.5% marine fuel prices. China aims to build a regional bunkering hub in its port of Zhoushan, seeking to challenge Singapore's dominance in the multi-billion dollar ship fuel market.

site_title: Knight Frank hires 2 property veterans in senior positions
summary: Knight Frank Singapore has appointed Alice Tan, a 17-year property veteran, as its head of consultancy, and Leonard Tay, a 15-year industry expert, as its head of research. Tan will lead the consultancy team in comprehensive real estate advisory work, while Tay will focus on tracking market trends and developing insights to drive thought leadership. The appointments aim to bolster Knight Frank's advisory arms and cater to niche market segments, with Tan and Tay bringing "excellent market knowledge and acumen" to the firm.

site_title: STI dips despite optimism for a rebound in some quarters
summary: The Straits Times Index fell 5.14 points or 0.2% to 2,629.69 on Monday, despite optimism for a sustained economic rebound, as decliners outnumbered gainers 285 to 135. Hongkong Land rose 3.46% to US$4.19, driven by positive news of a new luxury development. The index ended with 1.21 billion securities worth S$1.21 billion traded.

site_title: China eases rules for petrol-electric hybrids, giving carmakers space to meet quotas
summary: China has re-classified petrol-electric hybrid vehicles to give them more favorable treatment under new clean car rules, making it easier for carmakers to meet environment quotas. The policy change, effective from 2021, reduces negative points for petrol-electric hybrids compared to petrol-only vehicles, potentially leading to more of these vehicles being produced and replacing traditional petrol cars. This move is expected to benefit global hybrid leaders like Toyota and Honda, as well as Chinese manufacturers Geely and Guangzhou Automobile Group.

site_title: Liverpool draws at Everton, a momentary pause before its party
summary: Liverpool FC drew 0-0 against Everton in a Merseyside derby, a momentary pause before the team's push for the Premier League title. The match was intense and gritty, with both teams displaying commitment and desire despite the empty stadium. The draw may not be ideal for Liverpool, which needs five more points from eight remaining games to secure the championship. The team has grown tired of waiting, but it will tolerate the delay, focusing on the final act of the season, whenever it comes.

site_title: Wirecard says missing 1.9b euros probably 'do not exist', withdraws financial results
summary: Wirecard, a German payments company, has admitted that the 1.9 billion euros missing from its balance sheet probably do not exist, withdrawing its financial results. The company is considering a full-scale restructuring in a bid for survival, with cost reductions, a restructuring, and disposal of business units under consideration. Wirecard's shares and bonds have collapsed, its CEO has departed, and the company is renegotiating debt terms with lenders. The firm is working with investment bank Houlihan Lokey on a sustainable financing strategy.

site_title: Pandemic propels old-school bond traders towards an electronic future
summary: The COVID-19 pandemic has accelerated the shift towards electronic trading in the bond market, with record trading volumes on platforms such as MarketAxess and Tradeweb. Traders, including Russell Investments' Brandon Rasmussen, have turned to electronic trading to execute large orders due to market volatility and the inability of dealers to quote prices by phone. The trend is expected to continue, with 45% of the European fixed-income market now electronically traded, up from 38% last year. However, traditional dealer-client relationships are expected to remain a key component of the industry, particularly during times of heightened volatility.

site_title: Saudi developer Jabal Omar posts third straight quarterly loss
summary: Saudi Arabia's Jabal Omar Development, a major listed property developer, reported its third consecutive quarterly loss due to the novel coronavirus pandemic. The company posted a net loss of 217.25 million riyals in the first quarter to March 31, citing declining selling and marketing operations. The pandemic's impact on Umrah pilgrimages and travel restrictions in Mecca, where the company operates, will have a long-term negative effect on its operations, according to analysts.

site_title: China home prices to pick up, but outlook remains soft
summary: China's home prices are expected to rise 3.75% in 2020, slightly faster than initially predicted, according to a Reuters poll. Sales will remain soft due to weak consumer confidence and fears of a second coronavirus wave. The forecast is firmer than a 3.25% gain in February but down from 6.6% growth in 2019. Property transactions are expected to fall 4.5% this year, while investments are projected to rise 5%. Market curbs may be relaxed in smaller cities, but maintained or tightened in larger cities to avoid bubble risk.

site_title: Less friction with trade partners will help Australia's recovery
summary: Australia's economic recovery is expected to be aided by reduced friction with trade partners, following a successful medical response to the coronavirus pandemic. Despite keeping infections below 7,500 and 102 deaths, the economy has been severely impacted, with thousands left jobless and a projected 8% unemployment rate. The government, led by Prime Minister Scott Morrison, is now considering social welfare cuts to reduce the budget deficit, including proposals to end childcare subsidies and jobs subsidy schemes. This pragmatic approach aims to balance ideological principles with the need for economic recovery.

site_title: Nets appoints ex-Visa exec Lawrence Chan as group CEO
summary: Nets, a Singapore-based payments network, has appointed Lawrence Chan as its new group CEO, effective June 22, 2020. Chan, formerly vice-president of regional client management at Visa for the Asia-Pacific, brings a track record of strategic and operational leadership and deep global payments expertise. He succeeds Jeffrey Goh, who stepped down in 2019. The appointment aims to expand Nets' strategic growth into the digital commerce space with innovative payments solutions.

site_title: US: Wall Street opens slightly lower as virus cases mount
summary: US stocks opened slightly lower on Monday due to concerns over a resurgence in coronavirus infections, potentially hindering business activity. The Dow Jones fell 0.02%, the S&P 500 dropped 0.11%, and the Nasdaq Composite fell 0.01%.

site_title: Corporate digest
summary: Noble Group Holdings announced that shareholders of Old Noble have received over 96% of shares in Noble as part of the court-approved restructuring. However, only 88% of allocated shares have been received by shareholders who completed the allocation process. The remaining shareholders are urged to complete the process by December 19, 2020, or risk losing their entitlement to receive shares. Meanwhile, the Singapore Exchange has relaxed rules for general meetings, allowing issuers to hold them in physical locations without prior exemption.

site_title: Hotel sector needs to get creative as travellers take a break
summary: Singapore hotel operators face significant challenges as the country's borders remain closed to tourists. Despite spas and restaurants reopening under Phase 2 of the country's reopening plan, hotels are still limited to housing returnees serving stay-home notices or those traveling under essential arrangements. Occupancy rates have slumped to 40.5% in March and 41.1% in April, down from 84.3% and 85.4% in the same periods last year. Hotel operators must find new revenue generation ideas to improve their dismal numbers for the year.

site_title: Movie, pop stars line up for Covid-19 global fundraising gig
summary: International music and film stars, including Miley Cyrus, Dwayne "The Rock" Johnson, and Shakira, are set to headline a globally televised and streamed fundraising concert to help fight Covid-19. The "Global Goal: Unite For Our Future" initiative aims to raise billions of dollars for tests, treatments, and vaccines, with a focus on equitable access. The concert will coincide with a pledging summit, where world leaders, artists, and scientists will commit to helping the world end the pandemic, with a focus on marginalized communities.

site_title: Shareholders of Old Noble take up 96% of shares available to them in Noble
summary: Shareholders of Old Noble successfully registered for over 96% of the available shares in the new Noble Group Holdings, with 88% of those shares allocated to Old Noble shareholders. The new Noble entity, a supply-chain manager, has undergone significant restructuring. Shareholders must complete the remaining steps by Dec 19, 2020, to receive shares, with any unregistered shareholders no longer entitled to receive shares after that date.

site_title: BBR expects negative impact on half- and full-year results due to Covid-19
summary: Singapore construction firm BBR Holdings expects a negative impact on its half-year and full-year financial results due to the Covid-19 pandemic. The company has suspended construction activities and limited site activities to housekeeping and safety works during the circuit-breaker period. Its property development business has also been delayed, with sales launch of The Linq @ Beauty World put on hold. BBR aims to maintain liquidity and explore financing options, prioritizing cash flow management amidst the challenging business environment.

site_title: Companies must take the lead to be moral mentors in the era of Covid-19 and Black Lives Matter
summary: A 1953 book by economist Howard Rothmann Bowen coined the term "corporate social responsibility." Bowen, who was forced out of his academic position for advocating social responsibility, is credited with establishing the concept. The author argues that companies have a moral obligation to act as responsible citizens, creating social harmony through nonfinancial human incentives. This concept emphasizes the importance of companies taking the lead in promoting social responsibility, particularly in today's era of Covid-19 and Black Lives Matter.

site_title: ValueMax expects more unredeemed pledges, higher credit loss for moneylending business
summary: ValueMax Group, a pawnbroker and moneylender, expects more unredeemed pledges and higher expected lifetime credit loss for its moneylending business due to Singapore's recession. The firm will closely monitor trade receivables and take measures to minimize credit loss. It has waived interest on certain pledges and extended the validity of expired pawn tickets. ValueMax's retail operations have resumed but are expected to be negatively impacted by the economy's contraction and rising unemployment.

site_title: ECB looks to defuse German legal time bomb risking stimulus
summary: The European Central Bank (ECB) is preparing to publish a document explaining its justification for continuing quantitative easing policy, despite a German constitutional court ruling criticizing the institution's accumulation of public-sector debt. The ruling threatens to bar the Bundesbank from participating in monetary stimulus, but the ECB argues it's not answerable to national tribunals or parliaments. The bank's president, Christine Lagarde, is seeking to defuse the issue, with additional documents potentially being published to support the ECB's arguments, and a deadline for an explanation from the ECB of why the measure was proportionate set for early August.

site_title: Need for speed: Japan supercomputer is world's fastest
summary: Japan's Fugaku supercomputer, developed with government backing, has become the world's fastest, according to the Top500 rankings. Fugaku surpassed the US Summit supercomputer, with a speed of 415.53 petaflops, and is 2.8 times faster. The supercomputer, which will start full-time operation in April 2021, is already being used to simulate the spread of coronavirus droplets and develop missile technology. Its development is expected to contribute to advances in social challenges such as the pandemic.

site_title: EU presses China over trade, warns on Hong Kong law
summary: The European Union warned China on Monday to make good on its promise to open up its economy, citing "very negative consequences" if Beijing proceeds with a new security law in Hong Kong that could curtail basic rights. EU leaders also expressed concerns over disinformation about the coronavirus. The EU's chief executive and chairman, Ursula von der Leyen, spoke with Chinese Premier Li Keqiang and President Xi Jinping, highlighting the EU's challenging relationship with China.

site_title: WHO warns pandemic accelerating, as Brazil reaches 50,000 deaths and Europe eases curbs
summary: The World Health Organization (WHO) has warned that the pandemic is accelerating, with Brazil reaching 50,000 deaths and cases rising in Latin America. WHO Director-General Tedros Adhanom Ghebreyesus attributed the threat not to the virus itself, but to the lack of global solidarity and leadership. As countries ease lockdown restrictions, concerns of a second wave grow, with Australia warning against traveling to Melbourne and other regions imposing new measures. The WHO also highlighted the economic, social, and political crises caused by the pandemic, which will have long-lasting effects.

images.alt_text: Thousands of French danced and partied well into Monday for an annual music festival, the first big blow-out since the lockdown, with most revellers shunning masks and social distancing.

site_title: US existing home sales drop 9.7% in May
summary: US existing home sales declined 9.7% in May, reaching a seasonally adjusted annual rate of 3.91 million properties, compared to April. This marks the third straight monthly decline. Despite a decline in sales, median home prices rose 2.3% to $284,600, and inventory increased 6.2% from April. Analysts expect a return of buyers as states loosen lockdowns, with some predicting home sales could surpass 2019 figures in the second half of the year.

site_title: US housing set to ride out economic storm
summary: US housing prices are expected to outpace consumer price rises this year and in 2021, supported by record low mortgage rates and limited supply. A Reuters poll suggests the US housing market will remain a bright spot during the current economic downturn, driven by the novel coronavirus pandemic. Despite the economic downturn, US home prices are anticipated to defy the trend, defying predictions of a housing market collapse.

site_title: Starland says subsidiaries' frozen accounts make up a fifth of group's cash and bank balance
summary: Starland Holdings, a Chinese property developer, has disclosed that 25.39 million yuan (S$5.02 million) of its cash and bank balance in China is frozen due to bankers' actions. The frozen amount represents about a fifth of the group's total balance of 125.2 million yuan as of December 2019. Starland has reduced costs and has sufficient funds to settle obligations in China. The company has not received any notification from regulators or authorities regarding the suspension and is investigating the reason for the bank account freeze.

site_title: Thai trials of Covid-19 vaccine reach make-or-break stage
summary: Thai scientists administered a second dose of an experimental Covid-19 vaccine to 13 monkeys, aiming to determine its effectiveness for human trials by October. The vaccine has shown positive responses in previous trials, with the lead researcher calling the outcome "very impressive". The next two weeks will be crucial in deciding whether to proceed with further tests. If successful, the vaccine could be manufactured domestically and ready for next year, with doses potentially available as late as November.

site_title: SGX RegCo gives guidance on conducting general meetings in Phase 2
summary: The Singapore Exchange (SGX) has announced that companies can now hold general meetings in physical locations without needing prior notification due to Singapore's Phase 2 reopening. Issuers who had previously held meetings before September 30, 2020, must still adhere to alternative arrangements until the end of September. The Accounting and Corporate Regulatory Authority has also granted time extensions for listed companies to hold their annual general meetings. Companies are advised to follow a checklist and adopt alternative practices for shareholder meetings.

site_title: Building more sustainable small businesses for a more resilient future
summary: Singapore's small and medium-sized enterprises (SMEs) have shown resilience during the COVID-19 pandemic, with many pivoting their business models to serve their communities. As the economy recovers, SMEs are encouraged to focus on sustainability alongside growth, adopting environmentally-friendly practices and integrating values like trust and solidarity into their operations. The government offers support for digital adoption, financial planning, and employee well-being, and entrepreneurs are urged to prioritize these areas to build resilience and create positive impacts on society.

site_title: Religious events helping to spread coronavirus, WHO says
summary: The World Health Organization (WHO) warns that religious events and vulnerable settings, such as expatriate gatherings, are contributing to an increase in coronavirus cases in countries that have previously controlled the spread of the virus. The WHO's Maria Van Kerkhove and Mike Ryan reported new clusters in South Korea linked to clubs and amusement parks, and evidence suggesting the virus may have circulated in northern Italy before widespread cases were detected.

images.alt_text: Many countries that have been successful in tackling the novel coronavirus are seeing an increase in cases due to religious events and other vulnerable settings like expatriate gatherings, the World Health Organization's Maria Van Kerkhove said.

site_title: No second wave of coronavirus says White House adviser Kudlow
summary: White House economic adviser Larry Kudlow stated there is no second wave of the coronavirus pandemic, despite some flare-ups in states like Florida. He expressed confidence in the US's ability to manage the virus, citing progress since last winter. Kudlow also mentioned that the US Congress is working on a new economic relief package, known as "Phase Four," which could be reached later this summer, focusing on longer-term economic incentives.

site_title: Oil trading troubles could jack up borrowing costs
summary: A recent oil price collapse has exposed questionable practices in the Singapore oil trading industry, casting doubts on the reliability of corporate guarantees and putting pressure on smaller players. Several high-profile cases, including Hin Leong and ZenRock Commodities, have been accused of hiding losses and engaging in "dishonest" transactions. Banks have taken provisions to address these issues, but analysts warn of potential increased borrowing costs and credit losses for smaller players. Regulatory bodies, including Enterprise Singapore and the Monetary Authority of Singapore, are reviewing disclosure and lending practices to increase transparency and trust in the industry.

site_title: Morgan Stanley's post-virus stock ideas include meditation, 5G
summary: Morgan Stanley's post-virus stock ideas include investments in single-family homes, meditation and 5G technologies. The bank's analysis shows that the pandemic is accelerating trends in housing, with Invitation Homes Inc being recommended for its high-quality assets. Meditation and at-home workouts are also expected to benefit firms like WW International Inc and Peloton Interactive Inc. Additionally, the shift to remote work is expected to boost 5G technologies, with CommScope Holding Inc and Ciena Corp being well-placed to benefit.

site_title: Trump puts re-election ahead of national security: John Bolton
summary: Former US National Security Adviser John Bolton claims President Donald Trump prioritized re-election over national security, stating Trump rarely read briefings and was ignorant of global affairs. Bolton criticized Trump's diplomacy with North Korea, calling it "folly," and described Trump's summit with Russian President Vladimir Putin as a "strategic mistake." Bolton also expressed concerns about Trump's competence for office, saying he doesn't think Trump is fit to carry out the job. The book's publication has complicated Trump's re-election effort amid slumping poll numbers and a renewed national debate over policing and racism.

site_title: US Supreme Court sets limits on SEC's power to recover ill-gotten gains
summary: The US Supreme Court set limits on the Securities and Exchange Commission's (SEC) power to recover ill-gotten gains, ruling that disgorgement can only go to the net profits of a fraudulent scheme, not the total amount obtained. The 8-1 decision, authored by Justice Sonia Sotomayor, also requires disgorgement to generally go to the original investors. The ruling applies to a 2016 case involving a California couple accused of forcing foreign investors to fund a non-existent cancer treatment center.

site_title: NTUC extends seniors' discounts, price freeze on daily essentials
summary: NTUC Enterprise, the social enterprise arm of the National Trades Union Congress, has extended its S$50 million support package for Singaporeans, including a price freeze on 100 daily essentials and discounts for the elderly until December 31, 2020. The package includes estimated savings of S$17.8 million for the price freeze and S$10.4 million for seniors. NTUC has also introduced Covid-19 relief measures, including discounted groceries and school fee offsetting, and new deals for NTUC Union members.

site_title: GIC joins US$150m fundraise of fintech unicorn Checkout.com
summary: GIC, a Singaporean sovereign wealth fund, has invested in Checkout.com's US$150 million series B capital raise, led by Coatue. This investment brings Checkout.com's valuation to US$5.5 billion, tripling its previous valuation. The company plans to use the funds to strengthen its balance sheet and develop new products, such as payouts solutions. Since 2012, Checkout.com has been profitable and serves over 500 merchants, including ride-hailing players and prominent fintech startups.

site_title: Daily Debrief: What Happened Today
summary: MAS chief Ravi Menon emphasizes the importance of maintaining supply chains in the post-Covid-19 world. He suggests diversifying supply and building redundancies to build resilience. This approach is seen as a key global priority to mitigate potential disruptions. By diversifying supply chains, businesses can reduce reliance on single sources and minimize the impact of future disruptions. This strategy aims to create a more sustainable and resilient global economy.

images.alt_text: Ravi Menon, managing director of MAS said the more effective way to build resilience in a post-Covid world is through greater supply diversification and building redundancies in global value chains.

site_title: STI dips despite optimism of rebound in some quarters
summary: The Straits Times Index (STI) closed at 2,629.69, down 5.14 points or 0.2% from Friday, despite optimism for an economic recovery. Decliners outnumbered gainers 285 to 135, with real estate company Hongkong Land rising 3.46% and Singapore Exchange falling 2.05%. Regional markets were directionless, with the Hang Seng and KLCI also experiencing fluctuations. The index has lost exuberance following news of discontinued MSCI contracts and rival bourses striking similar deals.

site_title: Bank of England's Bailey says QE bond sales should precede rate rises
summary: Bank of England Governor Andrew Bailey stated that the central bank should sell government bonds to the market before raising interest rates significantly, a reversal of long-standing policy. This would help avoid large central bank holdings of government debt, which could limit the room for manoeuvre in future emergencies. Bailey's views, while personal, are likely to influence the Monetary Policy Committee's decision on future bond sales, which could mark a step towards yield curve control, keeping bond yields around a certain level rather than focusing on short-term interest rates.

images.alt_text: Bank of England Governor Andrew Bailey said on Monday that the central bank should start to sell government bonds back to the market before it raises interest rates significantly, which would represent a reversal of long-standing BoE policy.

site_title: Scoot to operate flights to eight cities by August, offers free date change on tickets
summary: Scoot, Singapore Airlines' budget carrier, will operate flights to eight cities by August, including Guangzhou, Ipoh, Kuching, Penang, Surabaya, Taipei, Hong Kong, and Perth. The airline has reinstated flights to four cities and will cancel all other June and July flights. Scoot is offering customers a one-time free date change for new bookings made between June 22 and July 31. The airline will provide more information once Singapore's green lane arrangements for essential travel are confirmed.

site_title: TiffinLabs acquires access to 1,000 delivery-enabled kitchens worldwide
summary: TiffinLabs, a food-tech firm, has acquired access to 1,000 delivery-enabled kitchens worldwide, aiming to create an international cloud kitchen network. The kitchens will open progressively worldwide, starting from the last quarter of 2020, in cities such as Chicago, London, and Singapore. TiffinLabs plans to use data analytics to identify food trends and optimize supply chains, and aims to be a global delivery business, scaling brands and menus with suppliers and delivery platforms.

site_title: India, China commanders meet after border clash
summary: India and China military commanders met in Moldo, China, to ease tensions at their disputed Himalayan border. The meeting aimed to resolve the standoff after a clash last Monday in the Galwan Valley, where 20 Indian soldiers were killed. China has not disclosed its casualties, but an Indian minister estimated around 40 Chinese soldiers may have been killed. The meeting was seen as a response to India's calls for a military and economic riposte, with some traders demanding a boycott of Chinese goods.

images.alt_text: India has deployed high altitude warfare forces along the Line of Actual Control (LAC) in northern India, after skirmishes with China broke out earlier in the month.

site_title: Malaysia: Shares close higher on Monday
summary: Malaysia's FTSE Bursa Malaysia Kuala Lumpur Composite Index rose 3.98 points to 1,511.24 on Monday, with a trading volume of 6.334 billion lots worth RM3.113 billion. Losers outnumbered gainers 549 to 434.

site_title: Saudi Jabal Omar posts third straight quarterly loss as coronavirus bites
summary: Saudi Arabia's Jabal Omar Development Co reported a third consecutive quarterly loss due to the coronavirus pandemic. The company posted a net loss of 217.25 million riyals (S$80.73 million) in its first quarter to March 31, 2020, as selling and marketing operations declined. The pandemic's impact on Umrah pilgrimage visits to Mecca and uncertainty over Haj due to Covid-19 will have a long-term negative impact on the company's operations, analysts say. Jabal Omar's shares were around 2% lower on the news, down around 30% from this year's highs.

site_title: Over 500 SMEs gain digital access to new markets overseas
summary: Over 500 small and medium-sized enterprises (SMEs) in Singapore have gained digital access to new markets overseas through e-commerce platforms under the Grow Digital scheme, despite the Covid-19 pandemic. The scheme, launched in February, aims to help SMEs access overseas opportunities without establishing a physical presence. To support SMEs, eligible businesses can receive up to 90% grant support for a multichannel e-commerce platform programme. Companies such as Yappy Pets and Nanyang Optical have benefited from the scheme, expanding their online presence and accessing new customers in Malaysia, Indonesia, and Thailand.

site_title: Hong Kong: Stocks finish lower
summary: Hong Kong stocks closed lower on June 22, 2020, due to concerns over a global rise in COVID-19 cases forcing lockdown measures. The Hang Seng Index fell 0.54% to 24,511.34.

images.alt_text: Hong Kong stocks closed in negative territory Monday as traders fret over a pick-up in virus infections across the world, forcing the reintroduction of some lockdown measures.

site_title: Australian officials warn against travel to new coronavirus hotspots
summary: Australian officials are warning residents to avoid travel to Melbourne, the country's second-largest city, due to a surge in new coronavirus cases. The cluster hotspots have recorded double-digit rises in infections, accounting for nearly 90% of the 126 cases detected nationally over the past week. Residents in these areas are advised to avoid travel outside their suburbs, and the Victorian government has threatened to reimpose social gathering restrictions. The Australian government is also urging states to remove most social distancing restrictions by the end of July to ensure the economy can continue to operate.

site_title: Money Hacks: Why insurance is good risk management during uncertain times (Ep 74)
summary: Insurance is a vital risk management tool, especially during uncertain economic times. Having insurance can protect individuals and businesses from financial losses due to unforeseen events. This is particularly crucial in today's market, where trade wars, de-dollarization, and shifting safe havens create uncertainty. Investing in insurance can provide peace of mind and financial security, allowing individuals to focus on wealth creation through productivity gains. As markets continue to rise, having a solid risk management strategy, such as insurance, is essential for long-term financial success.

site_title: ECB ready to cooperate to resolve German legal dispute
summary: The European Central Bank (ECB) is prepared to cooperate with German institutions to resolve a legal dispute that may prevent Germany from participating in the ECB's stimulus program. The dispute arose from a Constitutional Court ruling that the ECB failed to demonstrate proportionality in its asset purchases. The ECB's vice president, Luis de Guindos, stated that the bank is willing to provide necessary information and engage with German institutions if it does not threaten its independence. A decision is expected within three months.

site_title: Environmental shareholder activism comes to Japan as Mizuho faces climate resolution
summary: Environmental shareholder activists in Japan are backing a resolution to curb coal project lending at Mizuho Financial Group's annual meeting. Advisers to over $35 trillion in funds, including Institutional Shareholder Services and Glass Lewis, support the proposal. If passed, it could pressure Japanese banks to end coal lending, aligning with Japan's government and business goals. Mizuho has already committed to stopping new coal power projects, but critics argue loopholes will allow continued lending to existing projects. The resolution, if approved, would mark a significant step in Japan's transition towards cleaner energy sources.

site_title: Turkey's lonely tourist attractions face make-or-break week
summary: Turkey's tourist attractions face a make-or-break week as the government seeks to salvage the season after the coronavirus pandemic. Tourism Minister Mehmet Ersoy hopes to attract up to half of last year's 45 million arrivals, with talks on flights from Russia, Germany, and Britain expected to conclude early next week. With beaches largely empty and hotels deciding whether to open, the outcome depends on successful negotiations.

site_title: Deloitte Australia cuts 7% of its workforce due to Covid-19
summary: Deloitte Australia cuts 7% of its workforce, approximately 630 jobs, due to a 19% revenue decline in May compared to the same period last year. The company blames the decline on a government-ordered shutdown of travel and public activity caused by the COVID-19 pandemic. The move follows similar cost-cutting measures by other high-profile companies, including a 5% workforce reduction by PwC and a 200 job cut by KPMG.

site_title: Reusable cups, bags safe to use during Covid-19, Greenpeace says
summary: Reusable cups, bags are safe to use during the Covid-19 pandemic as long as basic hygiene practices are followed, according to Greenpeace USA Inc. Single-use plastic products are not inherently safer, and both can be cleaned with household disinfectants. The resurgence of disposable materials will harm the environment and undermine global efforts to curb plastic pollution. Businesses and governments should adopt reusable systems to protect the environment and workers. The pandemic has driven sales of plastic products, including 15 million tons of polystyrene produced globally annually.

site_title: US, Brazil protest Thailand's pesticide ban over impact on wheat, soy exports
summary: The US and Brazil have lodged protests with Thailand over its ban on two farm chemicals, paraquat and chlorpyrifos, citing concerns that the move could harm key agricultural exports worth over $1 billion annually. The ban, which took effect on June 1, aims to protect human health, but both countries argue that Thailand lacks new scientific evidence to justify the measure. The dispute could lead to a diplomatic showdown, with Thailand's import ban potentially adding tens of billions of dollars to costs and slashing millions of jobs.

site_title: Qantas to announce future direction soon, trying to avoid forced pilot job cuts: sources
summary: Qantas Airways plans to announce its future direction by the end of the month, aiming to avoid forced pilot job cuts. The airline's CEO, Tino La Spina, emphasized the need for flexibility from the workforce to avoid redundancies. Measures under consideration include early retirement, voluntary redundancy, and pilots agreeing to reduced pay due to the lack of flying. This comes as the airline reviews its business scope and scale due to the coronavirus outbreak, which has led to a significant decline in flying capacity.

site_title: China's new marine fuel contract seen attracting strong industry, investor interest
summary: China's new marine fuel contract, featuring low-sulphur fuel oil, is expected to attract strong industry and investor interest, despite weakened ship fuel demand due to the coronavirus pandemic. The contract, listed on the Shanghai International Energy Exchange, aims to provide a benchmark for shipping fuel and boost China's ambitions to build a bunkering hub. With 20 Chinese refineries equipped to produce low-sulphur fuel, the contract is seen as a fair chance to grow and provide pricing advantages for domestic refinery production.

site_title: Europe: Shares fall as fears of new virus wave grip investors
summary: European shares fell 1% on Monday as investors grew concerned over a potential resurgence in coronavirus cases in Germany and elsewhere. The World Health Organization reported a record increase in global cases, while Germany's Covid-19 reproduction rate jumped to 2.88. The Stoxx 600 index also fell due to losses in travel and leisure, oil and gas, and bank stocks. Separately, scandal-hit Wirecard and Lufthansa shares plummeted amid accounting and bailout concerns.

site_title: Korea's sovereign wealth fund sticks with equities, looks to US
summary: South Korea's $157 billion sovereign wealth fund, Korea Investment Corp (KIC), plans to maintain its equity holdings amid potential market shocks, including a second wave of coronavirus infections. Chairman and CEO Choi Heenam stated that if another market shock occurs, the fund may rebalance its asset allocation towards equities. The KIC is overweight on stocks versus bonds and is exploring opportunities in the US market, particularly in sectors such as environmental and digital infrastructure. The fund has invested $1 billion in environmental, social, and governance bonds and has been monitoring pandemic bonds.

site_title: NZ extends cruise ship ban, tightens rules to contain virus at border
summary: New Zealand extended its cruise ship ban and tightened rules for visitors exiting quarantine, following recent coronavirus cases linked to overseas travel. The ban, initially set to expire on June 30, will remain in place. Prime Minister Jacinda Ardern announced the extension in a news conference. The country has recorded just 22 deaths from Covid-19, but has seen a small number of new cases in recent days.

site_title: Australia: Shares end flat on fears over rising virus cases
summary: Australian shares ended flat on Monday due to fears of a second COVID-19 wave, despite gains among gold miners. The extension of Victoria's state of emergency until July 19 pressured stocks with travel and tourism exposure, including Qantas Airways and Flight Centre Travel Group, which fell over 4% each.

site_title: Halcyon Agri plans 1-for-2 rights issue to raise S$174.7m
summary: Halcyon Agri Corp is proposing a renounceable non-underwritten rights issue of up to 797.5 million new shares at 22 Singapore cents apiece, aiming to raise S$174.7 million. The issue price represents a 36.2% discount to the last traded price of 34.5 cents. The net proceeds will be used to fund operating cash flows and fixed commitments, strengthening the group's capital structure and deleveraging its balance sheet. The proposed rights issue, if fully subscribed, will provide shareholders with an opportunity to maintain their equity participation.

site_title: American Airlines seeks US$3.5b in new financing
summary: American Airlines plans to secure US$3.5 billion in new financing, including US$1.5 billion in shares and convertible senior notes, and a US$1.5 billion senior secured note and US$500 million term loan. The funds will be used to improve liquidity and enhance the airline's position amid travel restrictions caused by the coronavirus. This comes after a modest recovery in demand helped slow daily cash burn rates in June, with passenger numbers reporting record lows in April. The airline expects to use the funds for general corporate purposes and liquidity enhancement.

site_title: Two strata office floors at GB Building up for sale with S$11.9m, S$12.7m guide prices
summary: Two strata office floors at GB Building in Singapore's central business district are up for sale via expression of interest. Level 16 has an indicative price of S$11.9 million (S$2,200 psf) and Level 23 has an indicative price of S$12.7 million (S$2,350 psf). The 26-storey office development is located at 143 Cecil Street and has a three-level basement car park. The sale is exclusive to CBRE and will be available for individual or collective sale.

site_title: Thai rubber glove maker Sri Trang plans IPO to raise 14.9b baht
summary: Thai rubber glove maker Sri Trang Gloves Thailand plans to raise 14.9 billion baht (S$669.6 million) in its initial public offering (IPO), the country's largest since the coronavirus outbreak. Revenue for the three months ending in March increased 25% to 3.79 billion baht, driven by 28.7% growth in rubber glove sales and new production lines. The company's revenue was boosted by 6.2 billion pieces of gloves sold, marking a significant increase from the same period last year.

site_title: Soft underbelly in China's steel sector boom points to bumpier economic recovery
summary: China's steel sector boom, which fueled hopes for a quick economic recovery, is facing a challenge as a seasonal downturn in construction projects is expected to hit the industry. The sector's revival is driven by strong infrastructure spending, but manufacturing demand remains slow. This divergence highlights policymakers' limited options to support exports and domestic demand, suggesting a more protracted recovery for China's economy, which is struggling to recover from the coronavirus pandemic. Analysts predict a bumpier economic recovery for the world's second-largest economy.

site_title: Maker of Eskimo Pie ice cream will retire 'inappropriate' name
summary: Dreyer's Grand Ice Cream, the maker of Eskimo Pie ice cream, announced it will retire the name and character associated with the product due to its racist and culturally insensitive connotations. The company plans to have a new name by the end of the year and discontinue the character of the Eskimo, which was deemed "inappropriate" by the company. This decision follows a growing trend of companies reevaluating their brands for racial equality and cultural sensitivity.

site_title: Knight Frank Singapore hires two property veterans to head consultancy, research
summary: Knight Frank Singapore has hired Alice Tan as its head of consultancy and Leonard Tay as its head of research, effective August. Tan, with 17 years of industry experience, will lead the consultancy team, while Tay, with 15 years of experience, will focus on market tracking and insights. The appointments aim to bolster the firm's advisory arms and cater to niche market segments. The moves follow a relook at the business by group managing director Wendy Tang, who emphasized the need for tailored and personalized solutions to meet changing client needs.

images.alt_text: Knight Frank Singapore has appointed Leonard Tay as its head of research, and Alice Tan as its head of consultancy. Mr Tay has been heading the research team since May, while Ms Tan will rejoin the firm in August.

site_title: Employment agencies to get new licence conditions on fair hiring: MOM
summary: The Ministry of Manpower (MOM) in Singapore has introduced new licence conditions for employment agencies to strengthen fair hiring practices. Selected agencies that demonstrate fair hiring will become placement partners to help vulnerable job seekers access professional career-matching services. The new conditions require agencies to brief clients on fair-recruitment requirements, attract Singaporean job applicants, and consider candidates based on merit, while also preventing discriminatory hiring. Those that fail to comply may face demerit points, licence suspension, or revocation. A Human Capital Partnership (HCP) mark will be introduced to recognise agencies that demonstrate a strong commitment to fair-hiring practices.

site_title: Seoul: Shares fall on downbeat export data, fears over second virus wave
summary: South Korean shares fell 0.68% on Monday due to downbeat export data and concerns over a second Covid-19 wave. The Kospi benchmark closed at 2,126.73, with foreigners selling US$206.60 million worth of shares. The World Health Organization reported a record increase in global coronavirus cases, further weighing on the market. The country's exports contracted during the first 20 days of June, with data for the full month set to be released on July 1.

images.alt_text: South Korean shares on Monday fell as the market sentiment was dampened due to the country's downbeat export data and renewed fears over a second wave of the Covid-19 pandemic.

site_title: Singapore stocks to see 'sustained rebound' on 'imminent' economic recovery: Morgan Stanley
summary: Morgan Stanley Research predicts a "sustained rebound" in Singapore stocks as the global economy is expected to experience an "imminent V-shaped recovery". The market's focus is shifting towards a safe haven due to geopolitical and economic uncertainties in the region. Analysts forecast a 14% potential return for the MSCI Singapore Index by June 2021, driven by high and defensible dividends. Key sectors favored include banking, property, and consumer staples, with stocks such as UOB, City Developments, and Ascendas Reit expected to benefit from incremental inflows.

site_title: China's CNOOC buys two carbon-neutral LNG cargoes from Shell
summary: China's CNOOC has agreed to buy two carbon-neutral liquefied natural gas (LNG) cargoes from Shell, marking China's first gas imports of this kind. The cargoes will be offset by carbon credits from projects in China's north-west regions. CNOOC will auction the cargoes at the Shanghai exchange, following similar transactions by Shell with Japan's Tokyo Gas, South Korea's GS Energy, and Taiwan's CPC Corp. This deal demonstrates China's growing efforts to adopt carbon-neutral practices in its energy sector.

site_title: Japan's Jera to form floating wind farm JV with France's ADEME, Ideol
summary: Japan's Jera has agreed to form a joint venture with France's ADEME Investissement and Ideol to develop floating offshore wind farms. The goal is to finance at least two gigawatts of projects and establish several floating wind farms globally within the next five years. The partnership aims to accelerate the competitiveness of floating offshore wind technology, with plans to make tenders for upcoming projects in Scotland and France. The joint venture is expected to be finalized by the end of this year, with the companies believing floating offshore wind has the potential to contribute to achieving future climate goals.

site_title: Virgin Australia bondholders working on potential revival plan: source
summary: Virgin Australia Holdings bondholders are working on a potential revival plan involving a debt-to-equity swap if a sale offer is not satisfactory. The airline, which filed for voluntary administration in April, owes nearly A$7 billion to creditors. Bondholders, including FIIG Securities and The Bank of New York Mellon, aim to complete the plan before a sale, which is expected after coronavirus-related volatility subsides. The plan could impact the bidding process for the airline, with the administrator and bidders more attuned to the bondholders' interests.

site_title: Malaysia: Shares open higher on Monday
summary: Malaysia's FTSE Bursa Malaysia Kuala Lumpur Composite Index opened 0.03% higher on Monday at 1,507.66, with 348.1 million lots traded worth RM144.69 million. Losers beat gainers 238 to 191.

site_title: Covid-19 patients visited supermarkets in Jalan Kayu, Serangoon North and Jurong West
summary: Two Sheng Siong supermarkets and an NTUC FairPrice outlet in Singapore were visited by Covid-19 patients while infectious. The infected patients visited the Sheng Siong supermarket at 7 Jurong West Avenue 5 on June 9 and the NTUC FairPrice outlet at 447A Jalan Kayu on June 15. A community case was also at the Sheng Siong Supermarket at 19 Serangoon North Avenue 5 on June 19. These locations have been added to the list of public places visited by Covid-19 patients.

site_title: With digital payments on the rise, ISO 20022 compliance priority for SEA
summary: Southeast Asia's financial institutions are under pressure to adopt ISO 20022, the global standard for high-value and real-time payments, to enhance interoperability and efficiency. The COVID-19 pandemic has accelerated the shift to digital payments, with countries like Thailand and Malaysia already seeing significant growth in real-time payments adoption. However, the adoption rate varies across the region, and financial institutions must balance regulatory deadlines with their own migration timelines. Failure to comply may result in exclusion from payments networks and regional interoperability, highlighting the need for collaboration and timely migration to ISO 20022.

site_title: Nets appoints ex-Visa exec as group CEO
summary: Nets appoints Lawrence Chan as its group CEO, effective June 22. Chan, formerly Visa's Asia-Pacific vice-president, brings strategic and operational leadership expertise to the role. He replaces former CEO Jeffrey Goh, who stepped down in 2019. Chairman Ching Wei Hong stated that Nets will expand into digital commerce with new payments solutions. Chan expressed his excitement to join the team at a strategic growth stage.

site_title: Hong Kong: Stocks open down
summary: Hong Kong shares opened down on Monday, with the Hang Seng Index slipping 0.47% to 24,528.53, amid concerns over a second wave of global infections. The Shanghai and Shenzhen composite indices also remained steady.

site_title: MRT network expansion to be delayed due to Covid-19 impact: Khaw Boon Wan
summary: Singapore's rail network expansion, aiming for over 50% growth, will be delayed due to the Covid-19 pandemic. Transport Minister Khaw Boon Wan stated that the delays are caused by construction worker availability issues. Despite this, the expansion is still expected to be completed by the early 2030s.

site_title: Gold drives toward highest since 2012 on virus resurgence concern
summary: Gold prices surged to their highest level since 2012, driven by concerns over a second wave of coronavirus infections and growing uncertainty in Hong Kong after China's proposed national security law. The metal is up 15% this year, with Goldman Sachs forecasting a record $2,000 an ounce. The proposed law's potential to override Hong Kong's legal system has added to tensions with the US, supporting gold prices. Total known holdings in bullion-backed exchange-traded funds rose by almost 30 tons, with the SPDR Gold Shares seeing its largest inflow in a year.

site_title: Keeping supply chains open is one key global priority in the wake of Covid-19: MAS chief
summary: MAS chief Ravi Menon emphasizes the importance of keeping global supply chains open in the post-Covid-19 world, urging countries to resist the temptation to retreat behind borders and instead diversify and build redundancies. Insulation or in-shoring would diminish collective resilience, while maintaining open markets and trade flows is crucial for enhancing it. Menon calls for renewed commitment to keep supply chains open and coordinate actions to minimize disruption and enhance recovery, citing the need for common protocols for reopening borders and restoring air and shipping routes.

site_title: China securities regulator proposes closer cooperation with the US: Caixin
summary: China's stock market regulator, Yi Huiman, has proposed closer cooperation with the US to combat securities fraud, aiming for joint inspections and coordination. He emphasized the need for mutual trust and adequate communication between regulators to set up a law enforcement mechanism against cross-border misdeeds. This move comes amid heightened tensions between the two countries, with the US targeting Chinese firms for alleged securities law violations.
