site_title: US home-mortgage delinquencies reach highest level since 2011
summary: US home-mortgage delinquencies reached a 9-year high in May, with 4.3 million borrowers over 30 days late. This represents 8% of all US mortgages, with Mississippi, Louisiana, New York, New Jersey, and Florida leading the delinquency rates. The increase in delinquencies was smaller than the 1.6 million jump in April, but concerns remain due to the spread of new Covid-19 cases, business reopenings, and expiring benefits for jobless homeowners.

site_title: London City Airport reopens as UK slowly opens up
summary: London City Airport reopened with its first commercial flight in nearly three months, marking a step towards the UK's full emergence from its coronavirus lockdown on July 4. A short turboprop plane landed and departed from the Isle of Man, with officials expressing satisfaction. This move follows the UK's gradual reopening, with other airports and transportation services also set to resume operations.

site_title: Thai startup Synqa raises US$80m from Siam Commercial, Toyota and others
summary: Thai startup Synqa has raised US$80 million in funding from Siam Commercial Bank, Toyota, and other investors, including Sumitomo Mitsui and SMBC Venture Capital. Founded in 2013 as a payment gateway, Synqa aims to accelerate digital payments and transformation for enterprises. The Series C funding round reflects investor appetite for the digital market, following Synqa's CEO, Jun Hasegawa, stating that he sees opportunities in accelerating digital payments despite challenging times.

site_title: Broker's take: DBS initiates coverage on Valuetronics with 'hold' call
summary: DBS Group Research has initiated coverage on electronics manufacturer Valuetronics Holdings with a "hold" call and a target price of S$0.53. The analyst believes the company's strong fundamentals and strategic plans to diversify out of China will help it navigate difficulties, including US-China trade tensions and a weak economic outlook. Valuetronics' cash reserves of HK$1 billion will be useful in tiding the company through difficult times, with a new facility in Vietnam providing an alternative manufacturing site.

site_title: China eases green rules for petrol-electric hybrids, giving makers space to manoeuvre
summary: China has re-classified petrol-electric hybrid vehicles under new clean car rules, making it easier for automakers to meet environment quotas and offer more choice. The policy change, effective from 2021 to 2023, reduces negative points for petrol-electric hybrids and allows for more of these vehicles to be produced, potentially replacing traditional petrol-only cars. This move benefits companies like Toyota, Honda, and Chinese makers Geely Automobile Holdings and Guangzhou Automobile Group, as they aim to increase the proportion of new energy vehicles (NEVs) in the market, with a target of NEVs accounting for around a quarter of all vehicles sold by 2025.

site_title: Film, pop stars line up for global Covid-19 fundraising gig
summary: International music and film stars, including Miley Cyrus, Dwayne "The Rock" Johnson, and Shakira, will headline a globally televised and streamed fundraising concert on June 27, 2020, to help fight Covid-19. The "Global Goal: Unite For Our Future" event aims to raise billions of dollars for tests, treatments, and vaccines, with a focus on equitable access for marginalized communities. The concert coincides with a pledging summit, where world leaders, artists, and scientists will commit to helping the world end the pandemic.

images.alt_text: International music and film stars will headline a globally televised and streamed fundraising concert on Saturday to help fight Covid-19 as part of a joint initiative by the advocacy group Global Citizen and the European Commission.

site_title: Asia's richest man Mukesh Ambani joins club of world's 10 richest
summary: Asia's richest man, Mukesh Ambani, has entered the exclusive club of the world's top 10 richest people, with a net worth of $64.5 billion, according to the Bloomberg Billionaires Index. He overtook Larry Ellison and Francoise Bettencourt Meyers to reach the No. 9 spot, thanks to the successful investment in Reliance's digital unit, Jio Platforms. Ambani's wealth has increased substantially, despite India's worst-ever recession, highlighting the nation's deep economic divide.

site_title: Ascott members can now buy loyalty points; healthcare workers get discount
summary: Ascott Limited, a lodging business unit of CapitaLand, has launched a points purchase feature for its Ascott Star Rewards loyalty program, allowing members to buy points in advance or gift them to others. The move comes as the company's loyalty program has seen significant growth, with ASR membership tripling and direct online bookings quadrupling since its launch last year. The program now offers a 40% discount for healthcare workers booking online until December 31.

site_title: Rising Australian dollar not a problem yet, says RBA's Lowe
summary: Reserve Bank of Australia (RBA) governor Philip Lowe stated that the recent 24% appreciation of the Australian dollar is not a problem at this point, citing better health and economic outcomes from the coronavirus crisis and strong commodity prices. Lowe believes the economy has a "fantastic set of underlying fundamentals" and upgraded his estimate for employment, predicting a 10% fall in hours worked. The RBA remains prepared to implement policies to boost growth, jobs, and inflation, with interest rates expected to remain at current levels for years.

site_title: South Korea says Bolton's memoir on Trump-Kim summit is distorted
summary: South Korea has criticized former US National Security Adviser John Bolton's memoir on the Trump-Kim summit, stating that his accounts are inaccurate and distorted. According to Bolton's book, South Korean President Moon Jae-in had unrealistic expectations for unification with North Korea, which Bolton claims distorts facts. South Korea's national security adviser, Chung Eui-yong, said the publication sets a "dangerous precedent" and could damage future negotiations, as it violates the principles of diplomacy by unilaterally publishing confidential consultations.

site_title: PG&E wins final approval for its bankruptcy reorganisation
summary: PG&E has won final approval for its bankruptcy reorganisation, clearing the way for the utility company to emerge from Chapter 11 with nearly $40 billion in debt. The plan, which includes a $25.50 billion settlement for damage claims from catastrophic wildfires, will cover billions of dollars in damage claims. PG&E expects to emerge from bankruptcy in July, with the judge's confirmation allowing the company to raise $9 billion in new equity and $13 billion in debt to pay for fire-related costs.

site_title: Stocks to watch: OCBC, UOB, DBS, SPH, Sheng Siong, Soilbuild Reit
summary: Several Singaporean companies saw new developments on Monday, including OCBC Bank aiming to expand its sustainable finance portfolio to S$25 billion by 2025, UOB reopening seven more branches, and DBS being named the inaugural winner of the Digital Transformation Award. Meanwhile, Sheng Siong Group reported minimal disruption to supplies during the Covid-19 pandemic, and Soilbuild Business Space Reit obtained an S$80 million green loan to refinance its Solaris@one-north project.

site_title: China suspends imports of poultry from Tyson plant over Covid-19: customs authority
summary: China has suspended imports of poultry products from a Tyson plant in Arkansas due to a cluster of coronavirus cases at the facility. The General Administration of Customs made the decision after Tyson confirmed the cases. Tyson spokesperson Gary Mickelson stated the company is investigating the issue and works closely with US authorities to ensure food safety compliance.

site_title: Taiwan boosts domestic defence development plan with new jet
summary: Taiwan President Tsai Ing-wen oversaw the first public test flight of the locally designed and made AT-5 Brave Eagle jet trainer, part of her government's plan to boost domestic defence development. The aircraft, valued at T$68.60 billion, is the first jet made domestically since the F-CK-1 Ching-kuo fighter in over three decades. The move aims to reduce reliance on US equipment and counter China's growing military modernization efforts, with plans to take 66 units by 2026.

site_title: Foodtech startup SilverConnect closes seed funding round
summary: SilverConnect, a Singapore-based medical nutrition startup, has closed a seed funding round led by Heritas Capital Management and Seeds Capital, Enterprise Singapore's investment arm. The funding will be used to commercialize and roll out GentleFoods, a line of specialized food solutions for people with dysphagia, a condition that affects up to 40% of institutionalized older adults. GentleFoods offers ready-to-eat frozen meals with familiar local flavors, and the company aims to bring joy and nutrition to people with swallowing difficulties.

site_title: Tanks and trinkets: five things about Checkpoint Charlie
summary: Checkpoint Charlie, a border crossing between East and West Berlin during the Cold War, was removed 30 years ago on June 22, 2020. The site, initially used for prisoner swaps and foreigner crossings, has since become a tourist attraction. Authorities are considering its future. The crossing, a symbol of the division between East and West, is now a popular tourist destination, marking a significant shift from its former purpose.

site_title: Tokyo: Stocks open lower
summary: Tokyo stocks opened lower on Monday, with the Nikkei 225 index down 0.55% and the Topix index down 0.37%, as fears over increasing global virus infections outweigh hopes for business activity resumption. Investors are also eyeing economic indicators due this week.

site_title: Money FM podcast: A special interview with Mayor of Central Singapore District Denise Phua
summary: Mayor of Central Singapore District Denise Phua discussed the Community Development Council Vouchers Scheme, which helps up to 400,000 lower-income households with daily expenses while supporting local merchants and hawkers. The scheme aims to alleviate financial burdens on low-income families during the pandemic. Phua shared insights into the scheme's impact and future plans.

site_title: US housing set to ride out the pandemic's economic storm: poll
summary: US home prices are expected to rise 3% this year and next, defying the economic downturn caused by the coronavirus pandemic. The forecast is stable, despite record-low mortgage rates and a surge in unemployment, which has reached 13.3%. Housing demand is expected to bounce back, with homebuilders reporting a surge in demand in May and June. Experts attribute the resilience to the low mortgage rates and limited supply of homes.

site_title: Wirecard says missing 1.9b euros likely do not exist; withdraws results
summary: Wirecard, a German payments firm, has withdrawn its 2019 and 2020 financial results due to a missing 1.9 billion euros. The company believes the funds may not have existed, citing a "prevailing likelihood." CEO Markus Braun resigned amid the scandal, and the company is examining cost reductions and restructuring measures to ensure business continuity. The central bank of the Philippines confirmed that none of the missing funds appeared to have entered the country's financial system, further casting doubt on their existence.

images.alt_text: Wirecard said on Monday that there was a likelihood that the missing amount of 1.90 billion euros (S$2.97 billion) from its accounts simply did not exist.

site_title: NTU student among 2 Singaporean Covid-19 cases; 262 new cases
summary: A 22-year-old Nanyang Technological University student is among two new Singaporean Covid-19 cases, confirmed after symptoms appeared on Thursday. 262 new cases were reported, including 252 migrant workers in dormitories and 10 community cases. The total number of cases in Singapore is now 42,095, with 34,932 patients fully recovered. The daily average of new community cases has dropped to four, and one patient remains in critical condition in the ICU.

site_title: AMF, ESM Goh launch S$5m fund for Singapore seniors affected by Covid-19
summary: The Asian Medical Foundation (AMF) and Emeritus Senior Minister Goh Chok Tong have launched a S$5 million fund to support needy and vulnerable Singaporean seniors affected by the COVID-19 pandemic. The AMF Silver Care Fund will provide S$3.5 million in vouchers for food supplies and household items to approximately 30,000 seniors, and S$1.5 million to support pilot projects improving seniors' access to healthcare and wellbeing. The fund aims to help those with little family support, frail health, or requiring financial assistance.

site_title: Oil prices edge up on tighter supply, but demand concerns check gains
summary: Oil prices rose 9 cents to $42.28 a barrel for Brent crude, driven by tighter supplies from major producers, but gains were checked by concerns over a record rise in global coronavirus cases affecting fuel demand. US crude rose one cent to $39.76 a barrel. Last week, both contracts rose about 9% and Brent crude futures showed backwardation, indicating tightening supply.

site_title: UK remains top financial services investment pick in Europe
summary: The UK remains the top destination for foreign investment in financial services in Europe, with 40% of investors predicting increased attractiveness post-COVID-19. Despite Brexit pressures, foreign banks oversee nearly half of UK banking assets and the country has seen a smaller-than-expected exodus, with only 1,000 people moving by last September. The UK's financial sector is in a strong position to adapt to changes, according to EY's managing partner Omar Ali, who notes that London remains the dominant European city for foreign direct investment.

site_title: Brazil passes 50,000 coronavirus deaths as outbreak worsens
summary: Brazil has officially passed 50,000 coronavirus deaths, with a total of 1,085,038 confirmed cases. The country's health ministry reports the true numbers are likely higher due to a lack of widespread testing. Brazil's economy is also struggling, with rising cases and deaths eroding support for President Jair Bolsonaro. His handling of the crisis has been widely criticized, with many blaming his anti-social distancing policies and promotion of unproven remedies. The country's political instability and economic woes have raised concerns about a potential economic collapse.

site_title: Rupiah's advance in question with slowing economy, rate cuts
summary: Bank Indonesia's benchmark interest rate cut and downward economic forecast may end the rupiah's 15% surge against the dollar. Analysts predict the currency will ease in the second half of the year due to central bank support being reduced. The rupiah's rally is threatened by Indonesia's coronavirus hotspot status and potential further rate cuts.

site_title: Bungalow in Camden Park on sale for S$63m, rare artifacts not included
summary: A 15-tonne stone lion-adorned bungalow in Singapore's Camden Park is sold for S$63 million, marking one of the city-state's most expensive residential sales. The property, designed in the style of the Tang Dynasty, features centuries-old marble relics from China and a custom-designed tea room. The sale was made by Raymond Ng, executive chairman of Enviro-Hub Holdings, without including rare artifacts. The sale highlights the growing demand for luxury properties in Singapore.

site_title: Police clash with music festival attendees in Paris and Nantes
summary: French police clashed with music festival attendees in Paris and Nantes on Sunday, June 21, 2020. The clashes occurred during annual "Fete de la Musique" events, which were monitored by police to enforce social distancing measures. In Nantes, tear gas was used to disperse crowds, and residents reported bins being set on fire during a demonstration marking the anniversary of a 2019 police clash that led to a protester's death. The incidents highlighted ongoing scrutiny of policing methods in France.

site_title: AMTD, Xiaomi Finance, SMU, NUS-ISS unveil S$5m programme for digital finance leaders
summary: AMTD, Xiaomi Finance, Singapore Management University (SMU), and the National University of Singapore (NUS-ISS) have launched a S$5 million program, the AMTD-Xiaomi-SMU-ISS Digital Finance Leadership Programme, to strengthen Singapore's fintech and innovation hub. The program will cater to senior executives, fintech entrepreneurs, and policymakers from Singapore, South-east Asia, and the Greater Bay Area, focusing on digital business transformation and digital finance. The program will have two runs annually, with the first cohort set to start in November 2020, and will include a five-day executive program in Singapore, learning journeys in Hong Kong and Beijing, and curated content on topics such as new financial ecosystems and sustainability.

images.alt_text: (Top row, from left) Calvin Choi, chairman and CEO of AMTD Group; guest-of-honour Sopnendu Mohanty, chief fintech officer at the Monetary Authority of Singapore; and Shouzi Chew, senior vice-president and president of International at Xiaomi Corporation.(Second row) Lily Kong, SMU President; Tan Eng Chye, NUS President; and Khoong Chan Meng, CEO of NUS-ISS.

site_title: Water hyacinth pest chokes Iraq's vital waterways
summary: Iraq's vital waterways are being choked by the invasive water hyacinth, a South American plant introduced as a decorative species. The plant's rapid spread has blocked sunlight and oxygen, killing aquatic life and threatening fishing and agricultural livelihoods. The infestation has also damaged infrastructure, including bridges and dams, and poses a risk to the country's already strained water resources. Local authorities and fishermen are calling for action to combat the plant, while some vigilantes and environmental activists are taking matters into their own hands.

images.alt_text: The broad leaves and delicate purple flowers floating on the Euphrates look breathtaking -- but they are suffocating the waterways of Iraq, celebrated as the "land of the two rivers".

site_title: Geylang's Wing Fong Mansions, Court en bloc tenders to open on June 23
summary: Two adjacent condominiums, Wing Fong Mansions and Wing Fong Court in Geylang, will be put up for en bloc tender on June 23, with an indicative land rate of S$1,280 per square foot per plot ratio. The tenders were previously deferred due to the Covid-19 pandemic, but have now been rescheduled. Developers have expressed interest in the properties, with a potential change of use to a nursing home being explored. The combined sites span 77,214 sq ft and are zoned for commercial or institutional use.

images.alt_text: Wing Fong Court houses 88 units across eight storeys with a total strata area of about 87,791 sq ft.
Wing Fong Mansions has 130 units and eight storeys, with a total strata area of about 142,149 sq ft.

site_title: Singapore shares open lower on Monday; STI down 0.2%
summary: Singapore's Straits Times Index (STI) fell 0.2% on Monday, closing at 2,630.55 points, tracking US losses on Friday. The STI was led down by Singapore Airlines, which lost 0.5% to S$3.98, while DBS declined 0.6% and UOB fell 1.1%. However, OCBC rose 0.2% to S$9.12 after reaching its sustainable finance portfolio goal of S$10 billion. The US S&P 500 ended lower on Friday, while European shares closed higher on Friday.

site_title: China Maple Leaf agrees deal for Singapore's Canadian School
summary: China Maple Leaf Educational Systems has agreed to acquire Singapore's Canadian International School for S$680 million. The school, with 3,000 students from over 70 nationalities, will become an indirect wholly-owned subsidiary of China Maple Leaf. The deal includes paying cash and settling the school's debts. China Maple Leaf operates 104 schools globally, including in Canada and Australia, and has over 43,500 students. The acquisition marks a significant expansion for China Maple Leaf in Singapore's education sector.

site_title: Trump says he held off Xinjiang sanctions due to trade talks
summary: US President Donald Trump revealed in an interview that he delayed imposing harsher sanctions on Chinese officials responsible for a crackdown on the Uighur Muslim minority due to trade negotiations with Beijing. Trump stated that concerns about interfering with trade talks led him to hold off on Treasury sanctions, despite US officials previously considering such measures. The US had previously placed import restrictions and visa bans on Chinese officials linked to Xinjiang but had not imposed harsher sanctions.

site_title: North Korea says millions of leaflets readied against South
summary: North Korea has prepared thousands of balloons and millions of leaflets in retaliation against South Korea for anti-North leaflets floated over the border. The leaflets criticize North Korean leader Kim Jong Un over human rights abuses and nuclear ambitions. Defectors in the South send these leaflets, which have been a long-standing source of tension between the two nations. The move is seen as a "retaliatory punishment" against South Korea, escalating the already volatile situation between the two countries.

site_title: From Spam to corned beef, sales of canned meat are booming
summary: Sales of canned meat are experiencing a boom globally, with demand surging over 70% in the US and expanding at the fastest pace in years in South Korea. The trend is driven by both economic factors, such as reduced grocery bills, and a return to comfort food and nostalgia during troubled times. Canned meat makers are seeing significant sales growth, with some products expected to reach record highs, including Hormel's Spam, which has seen sales increase by over 50% in South Korea. The boom is also attributed to shortages of fresh meat supplies and the rise of convenience and affordability.

site_title: American Airlines plans to raise US$1.5b in stock, convertible notes sale
summary: American Airlines plans to raise $1.5 billion through a stock and convertible notes sale, aiming to improve liquidity amid the coronavirus pandemic. The airline expects to use the funds for general corporate purposes and to enhance its liquidity position. Goldman Sachs & Co, Citigroup, BofA Securities, and JP Morgan will act as underwriters for the offerings, set to be completed by 2025. The airline also intends to enter into a new $500 million term loan facility due 2024, following a modest recovery in demand.

site_title: Lufthansa gears up for bailout showdown with investor
summary: Lufthansa is set to negotiate with the German government over a 9-billion-euro bailout to avoid insolvency. The airline's biggest shareholder, Heinz Hermann Thiele, is expected to meet the economics minister on Monday to discuss his objections to the state-backed bailout. Lufthansa's CEO, Carsten Spohr, has stated the airline aims to avoid grounding, but the terms of the bailout remain uncertain. The airline has been severely impacted by the COVID-19 pandemic, leading to a protracted travel slump. A resolution is needed to stabilize the airline's finances and prevent insolvency.

site_title: TikTok users, K-pop fans say they helped sabotage Trump rally with false registrations
summary: TikTok users and K-pop fans are taking credit for inflating attendance expectations at President Donald Trump's Tulsa rally, with over 1 million fake registrations reported. The actual crowd was around 6,200 people, far from the 19,000-seat arena. The campaign claimed it was a "first-come-first-served" basis, but critics say the move was an attempt to deceive Trump supporters. Representative Alexandria Ocasio-Cortez attributed the success to teenagers on TikTok who flooded the campaign with fake ticket reservations, saying it was a clever tactic to trick Trump into believing more people wanted his rally.

site_title: Defaults mount for Eagle Hospitality Trust
summary: Eagle Hospitality Trust has announced multiple defaults and legal proceedings, including temporary caretaker arrangements for 11 hotels and a lawsuit from the City of Pasadena over unpaid taxes. The trust's total liabilities incurred by master lessees are estimated at US$50.7 million, up from US$44.6 million previously reported. The financial impact is expected to be approximately US$1.3 million, with over 10 hotels facing liens totaling US$8.26 million.

site_title: UK PM Johnson to announce lockdown easing plans on Tuesday
summary: UK Prime Minister Boris Johnson will announce the latest lockdown easing plans on Tuesday, including the relaxation of the two-metre social distancing rule. The government will unveil which sectors can reopen on July 4, with detailed guidance provided to ensure businesses are "Covid secure." Johnson's office also hinted at a possible change to social distancing guidelines, allowing people to be one metre apart with additional measures such as mask-wearing. The move comes as the number of Covid-19 cases continues to fall in the UK.

site_title: UMS rides semiconductor upswing
summary: Singapore-listed UMS Holdings, a primary supplier of semiconductor equipment, has renewed its contract with AMAT for another three years, with a focus on cost reduction and lean manufacturing. The company posted a 30.7% net margin in the March quarter and is expected to benefit from the rollout of 5G technology. UMS has a 70% supplier market share for Endura machines and supplies components to AMAT, with the two companies' ERP systems linked. The company plans to expand its Malaysian factory and is eyeing acquisitions in the aerospace industry, with a restored quarterly interim dividend of one Singapore cent per share.

site_title: Central banks cut dollar offers in sign of market confidence
summary: Major central banks in Europe and Asia are scaling back their dollar offers to lenders, cutting the frequency of operations from daily to three times a week starting July 1. This move indicates confidence in the market's recovery from the pandemic's economic strain. The reduced demand has helped check the rapid expansion of the Federal Reserve's balance sheet, with assets falling by $74.2 billion in the week to June 17. Central banks remain ready to adjust their dollar liquidity provision as market conditions warrant.

images.alt_text: Major central banks in Europe and Asia are scaling back their offers of dollars to lenders in a sign of confidence that the pandemic's grip on markets is loosening, even if the economic pain persists.

site_title: PT ISM raises Indofood Agri Resources stake
summary: PT Indofood Sukses Makmur Tbk (PT ISM) raised its stake in Indofood Agri Resources to 82.86% after acquiring 11,881,800 shares for S$3,439,007. This follows a previous acquisition on March 16. The acquisition increased PT ISM's interest in Indofood Agri Resources from 82.01% to 82.86%.

site_title: Explosive directional move anticipated for gold prices
summary: Gold prices are anticipated to break out of their current narrow range, with a decisive directional move expected after greater clarity on the economy. The catalyst for this move is unclear, but technical indicators such as price penetration of support or resistance levels, MACD indicator, and Average True Range (ATR) indicator will provide clues. If resistance is broken, gold could trend towards $1,839.48, while support broken could lead to a price of $1,451.55, with volatility expected to spike above $35.

site_title: Mass to mid-tier properties draw interest as showflats reopen after 10-week halt
summary: Singapore's new private home sales started strongly after showflats reopened, with mass-market and mid-tier projects attracting buyers. Over 140 units were sold across nearly 60 show galleries, mostly in luxury and mid-market projects. Developers reported pent-up demand and some projects saw sales of between five and 15 units per weekend. Not all developers reopened their showflats, but those that did reported positive responses from potential buyers. Sales have rebounded from a 58% drop in April, with June sales potentially surpassing May's numbers.

site_title: Disappointing crowd size at Trump's rally falls short of campaign's expectations
summary: US President Donald Trump's campaign rally in Tulsa, Oklahoma, drew a disappointing crowd, falling short of campaign expectations. The event, held in a safe state, was overshadowed by criticism of Trump's response to the pandemic and nationwide protests. The rally's poor showing adds to indications that Trump's re-election is uncertain, with his campaign struggling to maintain enthusiasm amid the COVID-19 pandemic and social unrest. Trump's campaign blamed protesters for the low turnout, but local authorities disputed this claim.

site_title: US dollar records small weekly gain
summary: The US dollar recorded a small weekly gain, its best in a month, due to increased demand for safe-haven assets amid fears of a second wave of coronavirus infections in the US and globally. Markets have been volatile, with concerns over global lockdowns and the impact of US tariffs.

site_title: Bankers in Sweden reveal financial perks of ethical funding
summary: Sweden's credit market is recovering, driven by increased issuance of debt earmarked for ethical projects. Green bonds, specifically, have seen a surge in sales, with $31.6 billion issued in the first five months of 2020, nearly double that of the previous year. This has attracted a wider investor base and provided a lifeline to the market, which suffered a severe crash in the wake of the COVID-19 pandemic. Issuance has rebounded quickly, with bond sales returning to near pre-pandemic levels within weeks.

site_title: Baltic Exchange Shipping Insights
summary: The Baltic Exchange Shipping Insights report for June 19, 2020, reveals a significant rally in the tanker and dry bulk market. The Capesize market surged, with the Atlantic basin reaching unexpected heights, while the Pacific Basin was largely swept up in the sentiment. Panamax rates also increased, driven by improved demand from the US Gulf and EC South America. Ultramax and Supramax rates followed suit, with increased demand from key areas. Handysize rates remained strong, particularly in the East, with mid-sized vessels fixed for transatlantic runs.

site_title: Nintendo chills mobile ambitions after Animal Crossing success
summary: Nintendo is shifting its focus away from mobile gaming after disappointing results, following a multi-year effort to release smartphone titles. The company's president initially set a goal of a $1 billion mobile business, but now says it's not necessarily looking to continue releasing many new mobile apps. Despite the success of Animal Crossing: New Horizons, Nintendo's mobile games have plummeted in sales, and the company is reassessing its focus to its console ecosystem. Nintendo's peers, such as Square Enix, have shown that cracking the smartphone market can be challenging, and the company believes its franchises shine brightest on its own consoles.

images.alt_text: Nintendo is retreating from the US$77 billion mobile gaming arena after disappointing results deflated once-lofty ambitions, ending a multiyear effort just as the market goes through an unprecedented Covid-era boom.

site_title: US stocks on knife edge over Covid-19 concerns
summary: US stocks are on a knife-edge due to concerns over Covid-19, with market indices testing key levels and pandemic updates drawing attention. The S&P 500 bounced at the 3,000 level in early June and may retest it this week, potentially falling if Thursday's jobs data shows rising unemployment. Analysts remain cautious, with Citigroup setting a mid-2026 target for the MSCI global equity index at 1,150. Meanwhile, Tesla plans to expand its robotaxi services to California and Arizona, and FedEx partners a Singapore startup to deploy robots for deliveries in commercial areas.

site_title: EU and China to seek to cool tensions at video summit
summary: The European Union and China will hold a video summit on Monday to address tensions, their first formal talks since EU accusations of disinformation about the coronavirus. European Commission President Ursula von der Leyen and President Charles Michel will meet with Chinese Premier Li Keqiang and President Xi Jinping. The EU seeks to cool tensions, but also expects China to assume its responsibilities, amid concerns over Hong Kong, climate policy, and economic openness. No joint statement is expected, and the talks come as the EU navigates its relationship with both the US and China.

site_title: Airbus targets voluntary staff cuts before wider layoffs
summary: Airbus plans to pursue voluntary job cuts before seeking forced reductions, aiming to bring down costs without inciting a political uproar in France and Germany. The European planemaker expects 12,000 to 16,000 employee reductions, with CEO Guillaume Faury warning that the crisis calls for "heart-wrenching decisions." Airbus has already raised liquidity, slashed production, and put factory workers on rolling furloughs, and will provide more detailed guidance to employees by the end of July.

site_title: Dubai ports giant prepares for worst as virus impact looms
summary: DP World, a Dubai-based ports operator, is preparing for the worst as the coronavirus pandemic continues to impact global trade, with 80% of trade transported by sea being stifled. Despite a 4% drop in trade handled by its 82 ports in the first quarter, the company's chairman, Ahmed bin Sulayem, remains focused on revenue-generating acquisitions. He warns of an L-shaped recovery, with a drop followed by a slump, unless stimulus measures are adopted, and predicts a significant decline in global trade this year.

site_title: Wreckage of global economy now looks even worse, warns IMF
summary: The International Monetary Fund (IMF) is expected to release revised global economic forecasts on Wednesday, which are likely to be more pessimistic than its earlier forecast. The IMF warned that a global contraction of 3% this year is possible due to the ongoing impact of the coronavirus pandemic. Most countries are expected to endure a recession, with both advanced and emerging market economies affected for the first time since the Great Depression of the 1930s.

site_title: Hollywood all set for big-screen gamble as US cinemas reopen
summary: Hollywood is poised to reopen its cinemas with blockbuster releases, including Russell Crowe's "Unhinged" and Christopher Nolan's "Tenet", on July 10 and July 31, respectively. However, the risk of early flops and potential "second wave" of virus cases remains a concern, with top theatre chains initially declining to mandate face masks. Analysts predict that if fresh outbreaks are traced back to screens in the US, theatres may shut down quickly. Despite these risks, studios are hoping that "Unhinged" will jump-start the recovery and set the stage for more major releases.

site_title: First batch of eight satellite career centres in heartland to help job seekers from July 1
summary: Singapore has launched its first batch of eight satellite career centres in the heartland, starting July 1, to provide career matching services and advice to job seekers. Located in Ang Mo Kio, Bedok, Bukit Batok, and other Housing Board towns, these centres will offer career coaching and guidance to residents, with plans for 24 centres across the island. The SGUnited Jobs and Skills Centres will generate over 100,000 job opportunities, and close to 100,000 job seekers can access career services online through the MyCareersFuture.sg portal.

site_title: Saudi property financing firm Amlak says sets price range for IPO
summary: Saudi Arabian real estate financing firm Amlak International has set the price range for its planned initial public offering (IPO) at 15-17 riyals per share. The company plans to float 30% of its shares in Riyadh, marking the exchange's first IPO since the coronavirus crisis. The bookbuilding for the offered shares will start on Monday and last until June 29.

site_title: 'Ring of fire' solar eclipse thrills skywatchers in Africa, Asia
summary: A "ring of fire" solar eclipse occurred on June 21, 2020, visible from a narrow band across west Africa to the Arabian Peninsula, India, and the Far East. The annular eclipse, where the Moon passes between the Earth and Sun, leaving a thin ring of sunlight visible, was seen in several countries, including Kenya, India, and Taiwan. The eclipse lasted up to 1 minute and 22 seconds, with maximum visibility in northeastern Republic of Congo and Uttarakhand, India. The event was less spectacular in Nairobi due to cloudy skies.

site_title: Breaking through to the next level
summary: Singapore's Phase Two reopening of the economy is expected to bring a welcome boost to businesses, allowing more employees to return to work in a protected environment. The phased reopening is aimed at mitigating the lingering threat of Covid-19 and will allow businesses to improve face-to-face interactions, rebuild sales pipelines, and adopt digitalization. Experts emphasize the need for businesses to adapt to the new normal, finding a balance between safety and resuming full business activities. The reopening is also expected to have a positive impact on people's wellbeing, particularly mental health, and will require collective wisdom, innovation, and pragmatism to overcome the crisis.

site_title: First batch of 8 satellite career centres in the heartland to help job seekers from July 1
summary: Singapore is launching its first batch of 8 satellite career centres in the heartland, starting July 1, to provide career matching services and advice to job seekers. Located in community clubs and other suitable locations, these centres will offer career guidance and referrals to nearest career centres for follow-ups. The centres will be part of the SGUnited Jobs and Skills Package, which aims to generate over 100,000 job opportunities and provide tailored career coaching services.

site_title: Singapore retail investors' trust in financial institutions falls
summary: Singapore retail investors' trust in financial institutions has declined by 11 percentage points to 36% over the past two years, the largest drop globally among 15 markets surveyed. The decline is attributed to disillusionment over plummeting values in certain instruments and lack of transparency among financial institutions. A survey by the CFA Institute found that 66% of respondents ranked retirement as their top investment goal, but only 52% trust their investments will provide enough wealth for a comfortable retirement.

images.alt_text: Singapore retail investors' trust in financial institutions eroded significantly over the past two years, a survey by the CFA Institute shows.

site_title: Asean consumers keen to try new digibank players: Visa survey
summary: Visa's Consumer Payment Attitudes Study found that 75% of Asean consumers are keen to try new digital banking players. Despite trusting established banks, a large majority would also consider non-financial brands or start-ups. The survey, conducted in late 2019, involved over 5,100 people across seven Asean markets. This trend suggests a growing demand for digital financial services in the region.

site_title: Private markets data providers tap rising demand in S-E Asia
summary: Private markets data providers in South-east Asia are experiencing rising demand, with more funding going to these firms as investors seek insights into the traditionally opaque space. Data providers track startup funding and VC fund-raising, creating benchmarks and deep analyses of sectors. New players have entered the market, offering more accurate data and innovative mapping methods. This growth is driven by investors' interest in discovering the next tech unicorn in the region, with the ecosystem continuing to mature.

site_title: Floatel and KrisEnergy impairments may impact MAC clause: Morgan Stanley
summary: Morgan Stanley advises Kyanite Investment Holdings on its cash partial offer for Keppel Corporation, noting potential impairments of Floatel or KrisEnergy may not trigger the MAC clause, which requires a decrease in net asset value or cumulative net profit after tax. The thresholds for MAC are a 10% decrease in net asset value (S$10.3 billion) and a 20% decrease in cumulative net profit after tax (S$556.9 million). The Offeror will make disclosures if there are any material developments or updates.

site_title: UOB reopens seven more branches on Monday; HSBC moves to new location at MBFC
summary: United Overseas Bank (UOB) is reopening seven more branches in Singapore on June 22, bringing the total to 55 branches islandwide, following the country's second phase of reopening. The branches, located in shopping malls and retail areas, will feature safe distancing measures and enhanced hygiene protocols. Meanwhile, HSBC has relocated to a new office location at Marina Bay Financial Centre Tower 2, with a focus on flexible workspace and digital services.

site_title: Amazon signals entry into alcohol delivery in India with nod in key state
summary: Amazon has secured clearance to deliver alcohol in West Bengal, India's fourth most populous state, marking its first entry into the country's multi-billion-dollar sector. The move follows Alibaba-backed Indian grocery venture BigBasket, which has also won approval to deliver alcohol in the state. Amazon's expansion into the sector is seen as a bold move to tap into a market worth $27.20 billion, as the US e-commerce giant has committed $6.50 billion in investments in India.

site_title: Wirecard's missing 1.9b euros did not enter Philippine system: central bank
summary: Wirecard AG's missing 1.9 billion euros, or $3 billion, do not appear to have entered the Philippine financial system, according to the country's central bank. None of the funds were deposited into the country's two largest banks, BDO Unibank and Bank of the Philippine Islands, despite documents suggesting otherwise. The central bank is investigating the matter, but the banks have stated they had no business relationship with Wirecard. The company's CEO quit amid a cash crunch, and its ratings have been downgraded due to accounting irregularities.

images.alt_text: Philippine banks BDO and BPI have stated that Wirecard was not their client and that they had no business relationship with the German firm.

site_title: Hedge funds cut bullish bets on US crude from near 2-year high
summary: Hedge funds cut their bullish bets on US crude to 377,173 contracts, the lowest since early August 2018, amid concerns of a spike in new coronavirus infections eroding global demand. This follows a 23,948-contract reduction from the previous week. The move comes as new cases of Covid-19 set records in US states and China reports an uptick in cases, leading to mandated mask use and a decline in oil demand. Global oil prices have been supported by Opec+ output cuts.

site_title: SDP's plans for upcoming general election starting to take shape
summary: The Singapore Democratic Party (SDP) is finalizing its plans for the upcoming general election, with several key announcements. SDP chief Chee Soon Juan will contest Bukit Batok SMC, a seat he previously won in a by-election in 2016. Other party members, including Paul Tambyah and Robin Low, are also expected to return to contested wards. The SDP's plans across the island are starting to take shape, with the party sending teams to four constituencies and planning walkabouts in the remaining one.

site_title: HK lawyers alarmed at plans for Carrie Lam to pick judges
summary: Hong Kong lawyers are alarmed by plans for Chief Executive Carrie Lam to select judges for national security cases, citing a threat to the territory's judicial independence. The move, part of China's new national security law, has been described as the "biggest shift" since Hong Kong's 1997 handover to Chinese rule. Lawyers and democracy activists fear the law will erode autonomy and curb the "separation of powers" that makes Hong Kong's judges an important check on the government.

site_title: UOB raises more than S$1.65m in its latest Covid-19 relief effort
summary: United Overseas Bank (UOB) raised over S$1.65 million in its latest Covid-19 relief effort, the UOB Heartbeat Covid-19 Relief Fund, through a global fundraising campaign across 18 markets. The funds will support frontline healthcare workers and vulnerable communities worldwide. In Singapore, the funds will support local initiatives, including producing 500,000 3D-printed face shields for healthcare workers and providing meals to frontline healthcare workers. UOB's efforts aim to drive global initiatives for 31 beneficiaries supporting frontline healthcare workers and vulnerable children and families.

site_title: Trump slams protests, defends pandemic response as Tulsa crowd underwhelms
summary: President Donald Trump held a rally in Tulsa, Oklahoma, with a smaller-than-expected crowd, despite campaign officials saying demand far outstripped the venue's capacity. Trump defended his pandemic response, claiming more testing led to identifying more cases, and criticized anti-racism protests, blaming the media and demonstrators for discouraging attendees. The event was seen as an attempt to reinvigorate his re-election campaign, which is trailing in opinion polls to former Vice-President Joe Biden. Trump also made comments about the need to protect Americans' rights to bear arms and warned of chaos in Democratic-run cities if he is not re-elected.

site_title: DBS wins Digital Transformation Award
summary: DBS Bank has been named the inaugural winner of the Digital Transformation Award in the Hackett Group's Digital Awards 2020. The bank was recognized for its use of automation, analytics, and artificial intelligence technologies to transform multiple aspects of its business, particularly during the COVID-19 pandemic. DBS's digital onboarding and transaction capabilities allowed for above-market increases in volumes, while its remote working and AI-driven contact tracing measures created safety and trust for employees. The bank's strategic use of digital technologies has enabled it to make available more than S$1.1 billion in loans to micro- and small-enterprise customers.

site_title: OCBC, riding growth wave, targets S$25b sustainable finance portfolio by 2025
summary: OCBC Bank aims to expand its sustainable finance portfolio to S$25 billion by 2025, surpassing its 2022 target of S$10 billion. The bank attributes growth momentum to increased demand for sustainable financing due to climate change awareness and reduced pollution from Covid-19. OCBC plans to diversify its portfolio by focusing on industries such as renewable energy, clean transportation, and education, with government support playing a key role. The bank has already provided green loans to companies in Australia and Malaysia, and has partnered with Axiata Group Berhad on a US$800 million sustainability-linked Islamic financing in Malaysia.

site_title: Will Phase Two of reopening spur recovery for shops, restaurants and Reits?
summary: Singapore's Phase Two reopening, which began on June 19, is expected to have a limited impact on the local economy, with many restaurants and retail shops struggling to maintain pre-pandemic levels of sales. Retailers serving wealthy consumers are more likely to exceed pre-pandemic sales, with luxury brands like The Hour Glass and Cortina Holdings poised for growth. However, the economy's recovery will depend on creating new jobs and employment opportunities to boost consumer confidence. The government has unveiled a S$2 billion package to create 40,000 jobs, 25,000 traineeships, and 30,000 skills training opportunities, but the real challenge lies in persuading employers to offer jobs to unlikely candidates and encouraging people to redefine their careers.

site_title: A run on the Catskill Mountains
summary: New Yorkers are driving up prices of pastoral houses in the Catskill Mountains as they seek fresh air, with a midcentury cottage selling for $250,000 in just eight days after its listing. The property received nine offers, all exceeding the list price, with two coming from buyers who hadn't even seen the home. The winning bid was $50,000 over the asking price, highlighting the strong demand for mountain properties.

site_title: NTU student among 2 Singaporean Covid-19 cases; 262 new cases
summary: A 22-year-old NTU student is among two new Singaporean Covid-19 cases reported, with 262 new cases confirmed, bringing the country's total to 42,095. The student was tested after showing symptoms, while the other case was detected through surveillance of dormitories. The cases include 10 community cases, 7 work pass holders, and 3 Singaporeans or permanent residents. The number of ICU patients has declined, with 1 patient remaining in critical condition, and 34,932 patients have fully recovered.

site_title: France shakes off its virus blues as cinemas, casinos set to open
summary: France is set to reopen cinemas, casinos, and stadiums on June 21, marking a return to normalcy after the COVID-19 pandemic. Cinemas will open at midnight, with 2,000 fans attending a virtual "avatar" concert by Jean-Michel Jarre. Millions of French people are also waiting for the reopening of restaurants and cafes, with casinos set to welcome gamblers from Monday. Schools will reopen for primary and secondary students up to 15 years old on Monday, and team sports will resume in stadiums on Monday without fans until July 11.

site_title: Airbus targets voluntary job cuts before any wider staff layoffs
summary: Airbus plans to pursue voluntary job cuts before seeking forced reductions, aiming to bring down costs without sparking a political uproar in France and Germany. The European planemaker is considering layoffs of 12,000 to 16,000 employees, with CEO Guillaume Faury warning of "heart-wrenching decisions" to scale back the business. Airbus has already raised liquidity, slashed production, and put factory workers on furloughs since the coronavirus spread, with the company expecting to give more detailed guidance to employees by the end of July.

site_title: Samsung denies reports of move of China display output to Vietnam
summary: Samsung denies reports that it plans to shift its China display output to Ho Chi Minh City in Vietnam, citing the reports as "groundless." The South Korean tech giant is the largest foreign investor in Vietnam with $17 billion investments. The relocation was reported by Vietnamese state media Tuoi Tre, which cited an announcement on Samsung's Vietnam website. The reports come as companies diversify supply chains beyond China amid global disruptions. Samsung has display production operations in Vietnam and has not elaborated on the matter.

site_title: Australian state extends state of emergency as coronavirus cases spike
summary: Victoria, Australia, has extended its state of emergency for four more weeks due to a spike in coronavirus infections, with 19 new cases reported on Sunday, bringing the total to 1,836 cases. The state has reimposed restrictions, including limiting visitors to households to five people and outdoor gatherings to 10. Health officials, including Deputy Chief Medical Officer Nick Coatsworth, have expressed concern but still do not recommend face mask use, citing low community transmission numbers.

site_title: Hong Kong lawyers alarmed at plans for Lam to select judges in national security trials
summary: Hong Kong's Chief Executive Carrie Lam will have the power to select judges for national security cases under a new law expected to be passed by China's parliament. This move has sparked alarm among senior lawyers, who describe it as the most serious challenge to the territory's judicial independence since the 1997 handover to Chinese rule. The Hong Kong Bar Association's chairman calls it "extraordinary" and "a threat to the independence of the judiciary." The new law is seen as eroding autonomy promised to Hong Kong under the "one country, two systems" formula, fueling fears among democracy activists and foreign governments.

site_title: Liverpool take centre stage as title countdown recommences
summary: Liverpool is set to close within one win of their first league title in 30 years when they face local rivals Everton on Sunday. The English champions-elect have a 22-point lead and need just two wins from their remaining nine games to secure the title. A Merseyside derby will take place behind closed doors, with Liverpool looking to complete the job on the field after concerns over the coronavirus pandemic suggested the season be declared null and void. A win for Liverpool could see them crowned champions as early as Monday if Manchester City lose to Burnley.

site_title: US sees 705 more virus deaths in 24 hours
summary: The US reported 705 additional coronavirus deaths in the 24 hours leading up to June 20, 2020, bringing the total to 119,086 deaths. This marks the ninth day with fewer than 1,000 daily tolls, despite the US being the hardest-hit country by the pandemic. The epicenter of the outbreak has shifted from the Northeast to the South and West, with 20 states experiencing a rebound in infections.

site_title: Wirecard's missing US$2.1b didn't enter Philippine financial system, central bank says
summary: The Bangko Sentral ng Pilipinas (BSP) stated that none of Wirecard's missing $2.1 billion appears to have entered the Philippine financial system. The BSP's governor, Benjamin Diokno, said that the country's largest lenders, BDO Unibank and Bank of the Philippine Islands (BPI), suffered no losses despite being named in connection with the missing funds. Documents purporting to show Wirecard's deposits with BDO and BPI were found to be false. The BSP is investigating the matter, but the initial report suggests no money entered the Philippines and no losses occurred.

site_title: China accuses UN human rights head of interfering
summary: China has expressed strong dissatisfaction and opposition to UN High Commissioner for Human Rights Michelle Bachelet's remarks on Hong Kong's national security law, accusing her of interfering in China's sovereignty and internal affairs. Bachelet stated that the draft law must comply with China's human rights obligations and respect international treaties on civil and political rights and economic, social and cultural rights. China urges the UN Office of High Commissioner for Human Rights to respect and support its efforts in safeguarding national security in Hong Kong and refrain from intervening in its affairs.

site_title: China charges Canadians with spying, Ottawa 'disappointed'
summary: China has formally charged two Canadians, Michael Kovrig and Michael Spavor, with spying and state secrets, amid a long-standing row between Beijing and Ottawa. The charges follow a key ruling allowing Huawei executive Meng Wanzhou to be extradited to the US, and come as relations between Canada and China have hit rock bottom. Canada's Prime Minister Justin Trudeau expressed disappointment and called for the release of the two men, who have been detained since 2018. China's foreign ministry insisted the charges are based on "clear and sufficient" evidence.

site_title: HKEX CEO says national security law won't change Hong Kong's financial role
summary: HKEX CEO Charles Li stated that China's national security law will not impact Hong Kong's role as an international financial market, despite US sanctions. Li emphasized Hong Kong's openness and internationalization, which benefits China, the US, and the world. He also mentioned that many US-listed Chinese firms will likely list on the Hong Kong exchange this year due to US political pressure.

site_title: Robinhood details possible changes to options offering after suicide by customer
summary: Robinhood is considering changes to its options trading features after a customer, Alex Kearns, 20, took his own life, believing he lost over $730,000 trading options on the platform. The company will make it harder to qualify for sophisticated options trading and improve its user interface. Robinhood is also expanding educational content for options trading and donating $250,000 to the American Foundation for Suicide Prevention. The company's co-founders expressed personal devastation over the tragedy and acknowledged the need for changes to prevent similar incidents.

site_title: Asia's deadliest roads are getting a US$2.8b makeover
summary: Thailand, the world's largest rubber producer, has launched a US$2.8 billion road safety program to turn 1 million metric tons of rubber into 12,282km of fender barriers and 1,063,651 guide posts. The program aims to absorb about a quarter of the annual harvest, potentially saving lives by reducing crash impact up to 80%. With Thailand having Asia's highest per-capita traffic fatality rate, the program could help alleviate the issue, which claims 22,500 lives annually.

site_title: 'Civil rights isn't over': Americans mark Juneteenth coast to coast
summary: Thousands of Americans marked Juneteenth with coast-to-coast marches and virtual observances, commemorating the abolition of slavery 155 years ago. The event coincided with the US's reckoning with racism, sparked by the death of George Floyd. Despite many events being cancelled due to COVID-19, activists organized street marches, car caravans, and online observances. The Juneteenth holiday blends with calls for racial justice, highlighting the ongoing struggle for civil rights in the US.

site_title: France shakes off its coronavirus blues as cinemas, casinos set to open
summary: France is reopening cinemas, casinos, and allowing outdoor gatherings as it continues to recover from the COVID-19 pandemic. Cinemas will reopen on Sunday with 2,000 capacity limit, and casinos will welcome gamblers from Monday. The country's midsummer music festival will also take place, with thousands of people attending despite social distancing measures. Other venues, such as stadiums and racetracks, will reopen on July 11 with a 5,000-person limit.

site_title: 218 new Covid-19 cases in Singapore, including 2 in the community
summary: Singapore reported 218 new COVID-19 cases, bringing the total to 41,833. Two community cases, both work pass holders, were confirmed, while the majority of cases were migrant workers living in dormitories. The average number of new daily community cases has decreased, with 33,449 patients fully recovered and 212 hospitalized. The Republic eased restrictions, allowing more business and social activities to resume, but some venues remain closed, including karaoke outlets and large cultural venues.

images.alt_text: Migrant workers living in dormitories make up the vast majority of the other cases on Saturday, said MOH.

site_title: Apple reverses course, closes some US stores in virus hotspots
summary: Apple has closed six US stores in Arizona, North Carolina, Florida, and South Carolina due to a surge in coronavirus infections. The closures, which reverse the company's recent reopening efforts, will allow Apple to implement new safety protocols. The stores will limit the number of customers who can enter, potentially causing delays. Apple's decision comes as the US experiences a rise in Covid-19 infections despite a decline in most regions.

site_title: North Korea prepares anti-South leaflets amid heightened tensions
summary: North Korea is preparing to send anti-South leaflets over its southern border, following a recent leaflet campaign by South Korean defectors. The move comes as tensions between the two countries rise, with North Korea blaming South Korean defectors for launching leaflets and threatening military action. This is the latest escalation in a decades-long leaflet campaign between the two Koreas, with both sides using balloons and other methods to send propaganda messages. The situation remains volatile, with both countries' military actions and diplomatic efforts on high alert.

site_title: Beijing tests food, parcel couriers for coronavirus as city checks widen
summary: Beijing is expanding COVID-19 testing efforts, targeting food and parcel delivery personnel, after a recent outbreak linked to a wholesale market. The city has seen over 200 locally transmitted infections since June 11 and is now testing tens of thousands of delivery personnel. Food delivery firm Meituan Dianping has confirmed all its Beijing riders will be tested, while SF Express, China's second-largest courier firm, has also begun testing its workers. The city aims to test all couriers by next week, amid concerns about contamination through packaging.

site_title: US attorney who was investigating Trump's lawyer replaced in surprise move
summary: The US Justice Department has replaced Manhattan US Attorney Geoffrey Berman with Securities and Exchange Commission chairman Jay Clayton, effective immediately. The reason for Berman's departure is unclear. Attorney General William Barr stated that Trump intends to nominate Clayton to replace Berman as head of the Southern District of New York. The office has been investigating Rudolph Giuliani, Trump's personal lawyer, and the reason for Berman's replacement is not yet publicly disclosed.

images.alt_text: In a surprise move, the US Justice Department said on Friday that it was replacing Geoffrey Berman, the US attorney in Manhattan whose office has been investigating Rudolph W Giuliani, the personal lawyer of US President Donald Trump.

site_title: Coronavirus lockdowns may be driving another virus wave: Dengue fever
summary: A surge in dengue fever cases in South-east Asia, particularly in Singapore, is linked to coronavirus lockdowns, which may have reduced outdoor activities and increased mosquito interactions with the population. As people stay indoors, stagnant water sources around homes may be breeding grounds for Aedes mosquitoes, spreading the disease. With no direct evidence, experts warn that lockdowns could have inadvertently created an environment conducive to dengue transmission, with Singapore reporting a record 165 cases per day and a possible record outbreak in the city-state's history.

site_title: Brazil surpasses one million coronavirus cases
summary: Brazil surpassed 1 million coronavirus cases, with 54,771 new infections reported, bringing the total to 1,032,913 cases and 48,954 deaths. Experts say the real numbers are likely higher due to under-testing. The country's infection curve is showing signs of flattening, but it remains a hotspot in the pandemic. President Jair Bolsonaro's handling of the pandemic has been criticized, with clashes between him and state authorities over stay-at-home measures and business closures.

site_title: Johnson & Johnson will stop selling skin-whitening lotions
summary: Johnson & Johnson will stop selling skin-whitening lotions, including Neutrogena Fine Fairness and Clear Fairness by Clean & Clear, due to criticism for promoting fairness or white skin tone. The products were sold in Asia and the Middle East but not in the US. The company will no longer produce or ship the product line, following similar announcements from other companies that have removed racist imagery from their products. The decision comes as part of Johnson & Johnson's response to the demonstrations against racism in the US.

site_title: Singapore's actions in next five to 10 years will chart nation's course 'for decades to come': DPM Heng
summary: Deputy Prime Minister Heng Swee Keat emphasized that Singapore's actions over the next five to 10 years will chart the nation's course for decades to come. He outlined three key strategies: (1) fostering a dynamic and inclusive economy by leveraging new global trends, (2) investing in infrastructure to strengthen resilience and connectivity, and (3) enhancing competitiveness through research and innovation. The government will allocate S$20 billion for research and innovation, and establish industry-led coalitions to drive growth in key areas. Heng prioritized job creation, aiming to create 100,000 jobs and training opportunities, and promised that every citizen will be part of society's progress.

site_title: Oil resumes weekly winning streak on gradual demand recovery
summary: Oil prices rose 2.3% on Friday, extending a 9.6% weekly gain, marking the seventh gain in eight weeks. The US benchmark crude futures closed at the highest level since March 6. Demand recovery and output cuts by Opec+ contributed to the price strength, with inventories in Cushing, Oklahoma, contracting every week since early May. However, a potential resurgence of the virus in China and worsening cases in the US may cloud the long-term outlook.

site_title: Hong Kong unions, students fail to get support for strikes against security law
summary: Hong Kong pro-democracy labour unions and student groups failed to garner enough support to hold strikes against the looming national security legislation, imposed by Beijing. A city-wide poll by unions showed only 8,943 union members participated out of 60,000 needed, with 95% of those voting in favor. The student group, the Secondary School Students Action Platform, also fell short of its targets. The planned law has alarmed foreign governments and democracy activists, who fear it will erode Hong Kong's autonomy. Beijing officials have sought to reassure investors that the law will target only "troublemakers."

site_title: Chinese Basketball Association league restarts after 5-month virus stoppage
summary: The Chinese Basketball Association (CBA) league resumed operations on June 20, 2020, after a 5-month hiatus due to the coronavirus pandemic. The league restarted behind closed doors, with a somber moment of silence held before the first match between Nanjing Monkey Kings and Zhejiang Guangsha Lions. The games were played without fans, in line with international sports protocols, and most teams will compete without foreign players due to travel restrictions. The resumption comes as China battles a new cluster of infections in Beijing, with 23 new domestically transmitted cases reported.

site_title: India's Modi says there was no border intrusion in deadly clash with China
summary: Indian Prime Minister Narendra Modi downplayed a deadly clash with Chinese troops in a disputed Himalayan region, stating there was no border intrusion. The clash, which left 20 Indian soldiers dead and over 70 injured, occurred in Ladakh's Galwan valley. Modi's comments contrast with his government's earlier stance, which claimed the Chinese side sought to erect a structure on the Line of Actual Control. China has returned 10 Indian soldiers captured during the battle, but tensions remain high with military-level talks ongoing.

site_title: Singapore office leasing momentum to slow on economy's easing: CGS-CIMB
summary: Singapore's office leasing momentum is expected to slow due to a weaker economy, with overall office rents forecast to decline 5-10% this year, worse than previous predictions of 0-5% drop. Analyst Lock Mun Yee attributes the decline to cautious tenants assessing the impact of COVID-19 on their businesses. A net absorption rate of 500,000-700,000 square feet is anticipated for the year, with a vacancy level of 11.3% by end-2020.

site_title: Japan PM Abe's support rebounds despite ex-justice minister's arrest
summary: Japan's Prime Minister Shinzo Abe's cabinet approval rating has rebounded to 36% despite the arrest of former justice minister Katsuyuki Kawai on vote-buying charges. The recent arrest led to a 9-point drop in support, but a poll shows that 55% of respondents welcome the government's decision to lift domestic travel curbs. However, 59% of those polled believe Abe has heavy responsibility for the scandal, and 59% doubt the Tokyo Olympics can be held next year. Japan has not seen a significant surge in coronavirus cases, with 18,000 confirmed cases and 954 deaths.

site_title: Singapore bungalow on sale for S$63m; rare artifacts extra
summary: A Singapore bungalow is on sale for S$63 million, featuring 500 Chinese artifacts and rare relics from the Tang Dynasty capital of Chang'an. The 26,000 sq ft property boasts modern touches, including a car elevator and wine cellar, and is considered a rare and prestigious asset among the affluent. As one of Singapore's priciest properties, it reflects the city-state's high-end real estate market, where "good class bungalows" are highly sought after for their scarcity and prestige status.

site_title: US: S&P 500 closes lower as Covid-19 resurgence casts a shadow on sentiment
summary: US stocks closed lower on Friday as Covid-19 resurgence cast a shadow on sentiment. The S&P 500 and Dow fell, while the Nasdaq closed modestly higher. Apple announced fresh store closures in states with rising cases, citing the virus as a concern. Despite this, the Fed warned of a challenging economic recovery and no quick fix. The S&P 500 and Dow are still shy of their all-time highs, and investors weigh the balance between Fed stimulus and the resurgence of Covid-19.

site_title: STI finishes the week down 1.86%
summary: The Straits Times Index (STI) fell 1.86% to 2,634.83 on Friday, as investors grew wary of a potential second wave of Covid-19 infections. Despite ample liquidity lifting valuations, traders remained cautious. Losers outnumbered gainers 220 to 205, with 1.8 billion securities worth S$2.31 billion traded.

site_title: ComfortDelGro in tie-up with RATP, Alstom to bid for 2 metro lines in France
summary: ComfortDelGro Corporation has partnered with RATP Dev and Alstom to bid for two metro lines in France's Greater Paris region as part of the Grand Paris Express project. The bid, if successful, will be ComfortDelGro's first overseas rail project. The company will participate through a newly set-up subsidiary and is expected to adopt a cost-plus model, assuming revenue risk for the rail line in its initial period of operations.

site_title: Fed officials signal rising caution on US economic recovery amid virus spread
summary: US Federal Reserve officials expressed caution on the swiftness of economic recovery from the novel coronavirus epidemic, warning that the unemployment rate could rise again if the disease is not brought under control. Despite nascent signs of recovery, officials, including Boston Fed president Eric Rosengren and Minneapolis Fed president Neel Kashkari, cautioned against reopening the economy too hastily. Fed officials expect a full economic healing to take years, with some predicting a second wave of the virus this fall, which could lead to higher unemployment.

site_title: Real estate agency industry urged to press on with digitalisation
summary: Minister of State for National Development and Manpower, Zaqy Mohamad, urged the real estate agency industry to continue its digitalisation efforts amidst the resumption of most property transaction activities under Phase 2. He emphasized the need to adapt to shifting consumer habits and maintain the 'human touch' while increasing productivity. Despite technical issues with SafeEntry QR codes and client address visibility on SingPass Mobile, the government is working on solutions, including an enhancement to the QR code that may enable property agents to generate it themselves.

site_title: Where do investors go in an income drought?
summary: Investors facing income droughts can explore alternative sustainable income sources amid challenges in traditional assets. Dividend cuts and historically low yields have affected various sectors, including the FTSE 100, where nearly half of the UK stock market's dividend stream has been lost. Companies like European and Australian banks have been forced to suspend or cut dividends due to regulatory requirements. In contrast, emerging markets like Asia are expected to drive dollar asset diversification and potentially provide new income opportunities.

site_title: The ABCs of high blood pressure
summary: A man, Mr. A, was diagnosed with high blood pressure and had been taking medication for over 20 years due to frequent dizzy spells. However, after his medication was stopped, his dizziness resolved, and his blood pressure returned to normal. The article highlights the importance of a thorough evaluation before diagnosing high blood pressure and hypertension, as Mr. A's case suggests that medication may not be the only solution. This emphasizes the need for personalized treatment approaches and careful consideration of symptoms before making a diagnosis.

site_title: Mike Pompeo says way US treats Hong Kong depends on how China does
summary: US Secretary of State Mike Pompeo stated that the US will treat Hong Kong as a Chinese city if China treats it as such, effectively ending Hong Kong's autonomy. Pompeo made the remarks during a Copenhagen Democracy Summit, following a meeting with China's top diplomat, Yang Jiechi. The comments come amid strained US-China relations, with Pompeo also urging European governments to speak out against China's actions. Pompeo's comments also come as the US is working to determine accountability for curbs on Hong Kong's freedoms.

site_title: Hackers planning phishing attack with fake MOM e-mails, warns cybersecurity firm
summary: Hackers plan to target Singapore businesses on June 21 with a phishing email claiming to offer additional subsidies for employees, according to cybersecurity firm Cyfirma. The email will be sent from a spoofed Ministry of Manpower account, prompting recipients to divulge personal and financial information. The hackers aim to impersonate government agencies and departments, targeting over five million people and businesses worldwide in six countries affected by the pandemic. Authorities have been notified, and an advisory has been issued to be vigilant.

site_title: Europe: Shares up for week, hopes remain for recovery plan
summary: European shares rose 0.6% on Friday, with defensive plays leading gains, as investors remained hopeful for a massive stimulus package worth 1.85 trillion euros. The proposed rescue package was discussed at a summit by video-conference, with leaders agreeing to meet in mid-July to haggle over the long-term budget. The Stoxx 600 index recovered 36% from its March lows, with traders betting on urgent action to haul coronavirus-hit economies from the deepest recession since World War Two.

site_title: Malaysia partially reopens borders to selected expats, medical tourists
summary: Malaysia has partially reopened its borders to select expats and medical tourists. Foreigners earning at least RM10,000 (S$3,264) per month can enter without immigration approval, while those with professional visit passes or resident talent passes with top management positions are also allowed entry. Malaysians can travel abroad with proof of purpose, and those traveling to Malaysia must undergo Covid-19 tests before or upon arrival. The country has also agreed to relax entry requirements for citizens of Singapore and Brunei, with reciprocal agreements to be discussed.

site_title: H1 investment in Singapore-based fintech firms up 19%
summary: Investment in Singapore-based fintech firms increased 19% year-over-year to S$462 million in the first six months of 2020, with a majority going to mid-stage companies. Banking services for SMEs and retail banking were the largest recipients of equity funding. Industry experts attribute the surge to the maturation of the fintech ecosystem, which is now five years into the Monetary Authority of Singapore's focus on fintech. This growth is expected to have a positive impact on the financial industry, with fintech firms providing value-added services and products to customers.

site_title: Suburban malls trump Orchard shops as shoppers return
summary: Suburban malls in Singapore saw better turnout than central areas as shoppers returned, with some retailers reporting increased footfall and sales. Despite initial quietness, Orchard Road began to attract crowds, particularly with Father's Day weekend approaching. Retailers predict more promotions and discounts to clear seasonal goods, drawing more consumers. Sales were up across various stores, including Courts, which saw a 200% year-on-year increase, and BHG Singapore, which saw a 22% increase in sales. However, some stores, like Uniqlo, remained closed due to safety concerns.

site_title: Emirates resumes Singapore flight services
summary: Emirates has resumed passenger flight services from Singapore to Dubai, with three weekly flights on Boeing 777-300ER aircraft. This follows the UAE government's lifting of restrictions for transit passenger services. Emirates also added 10 new cities to its scheduled flights, including Colombo and Auckland. Singapore Airlines has reinstated flights to several cities, including Adelaide, Amsterdam, and Auckland, with increased frequencies in June and July. The resumption of services aims to connect Singapore to Emirates' network of 40 destinations across the world.

site_title: Japanese investors are flooding yen into US dollar assets
summary: Japanese investors are rapidly buying US dollar assets, indicating they see little appeal in the Japanese market. The yen-US dollar basis for 30-year contracts reached its most negative level this year in late May, and remains near those levels despite the Federal Reserve's liquidity injection. This trend suggests a long-term shift in investment preferences away from Japan, with Asia expected to drive and benefit from dollar asset diversification.

images.alt_text: With the Bank of Japan predicting that negative rates will remain until 2023, there is little incentive to hold onto the yen.

site_title: No downtime for Novena Global as Lohs inject growth through M&As
summary: Novena Global Lifecare, a Singapore-based company, is expanding through a series of mergers and acquisitions. The company, founded by cousins Nelson and Terence Loh, has been using its private vehicle Dorr Global Healthcare International to acquire Catalist-listed Axington Inc. This move comes three years after the company initially sought a public listing in Taiwan. The acquisition is part of Novena Global's growth strategy, as the company continues to diversify its portfolio through strategic investments.

site_title: Political turmoil roils bonds as Malaysia's deficit risk rises
summary: Malaysia's bond market is under pressure due to rising deficit risk and political turmoil. The government's $69 billion stimulus package has been met with skepticism, and a snap election is expected to further destabilize the market. The country's sovereign rating outlook is at risk of being downgraded, with rating agencies warning of negative outlooks. Benchmark yields have increased, and foreign ownership of Malaysian bonds has declined to a 10-month low, making it harder for the authorities to attract inflows and sustain a strong recovery.

site_title: Petronas chief quit over plan to pay US$470m to Sarawak
summary: Malaysia's Petronas CEO Wan Zulkiflee Wan Ariffin quit after a disagreement with Prime Minister Muhyiddin Yassin over a plan to pay US$470 million in sales tax to Sarawak state. The payment was part of a settlement reached after Petronas fought the demand in court. Wan Zulkiflee opposed the deal, citing principles and concerns about the financial impact on Petronas and the national budget. The decision comes amid efforts to rebuild Malaysia's reputation after the 1MDB scandal.
