site_title: Ex-F1 driver Alex Zanardi 'in extremely serious condition' after bike crash
summary: Former Formula One driver Alex Zanardi, who had both legs amputated after a 2001 crash, was in an "extremely serious condition" in hospital after crashing into a truck while competing in a handbike race in Italy. He underwent emergency surgery for head and facial injuries and was transferred to intensive care. Zanardi, 53, had a long career in motor racing, winning four Paralympic gold medals and ten world championship titles, and is known for his determination and spirit.

images.alt_text: Ex-Formula One driver Alex Zanardi, who had both legs amputated in a motor racing accident almost 20 years ago before going on to become a Paralympic champion, was in an "extremely serious condition" in hospital on Friday after crashing into a truck while competing in a handbike race in Italy.

site_title: Tackling turbulence
summary: Schweizer World CEO Maren Schweizer discusses how her family's 170-year-old German business has adapted to the Covid-19 pandemic and the digital revolution. Drawing on past crises, she believes teleworking is here to stay due to efficiency gains and reduced commuting. The company has implemented a network of teams and procedures to handle crises, inspired by the aviation industry. Schweizer World is focused on digitalization, leveraging big data to understand digital business models and implement AI tools. The company has also changed its leadership structure to include external hires and promote diversity and inclusion.

site_title: Banker Tracey Woon joins SPH board as independent director
summary: Singapore Press Holdings (SPH) appointed banker Tracey Woon, 63, as an independent director, effective July 1. Woon, vice-chairman of UBS' Asia-Pacific global wealth management, brings expertise in investment banking and international capital markets. The move comes as SPH faces challenges from the coronavirus pandemic and economic uncertainty. SPH chairman Lee Boon Yang stated that Woon's experience and expertise will be valuable to the company.

site_title: Corporate digest
summary: Holding company Falcon Energy Group is set to hold a creditor vote on a compromise or scheme of arrangement due to debt issues. Meanwhile, KrisEnergy, a subsidiary of KrisEnergy, has lodged an appeal against a winding-up petition. Perennial Real Estate Holdings has appointed PricewaterhouseCoopers as its financial adviser for a potential privatisation attempt. SK Jewellery Group expects a net loss for the first half of the year, while Sen Yue Holdings' chairman has cancelled a meeting to change the board after an overnight notice from the Singapore Exchange Regulation.

site_title: Pound heads for worst week since mid-May as public debt surges
summary: The UK pound is on track for its worst week since mid-May, with a 0.2% decline against the dollar and a 0.5% drop against the euro, due to record-high government borrowing and the country's public debt exceeding economic output for the first time since 1963. This is attributed to the ongoing coronavirus pandemic's impact on the economy. The pound rose briefly on Friday after retail sales rebounded more than expected, but Brexit-related risks and the Bank of England's bond-buying programme continue to weigh on the currency.

site_title: A tidal wave of bankruptcies is coming
summary: A tidal wave of bankruptcies is expected, with experts estimating that this year will see a record number of mega-bankruptcies (US$1 billion or more in debt) and large bankruptcies (US$100 million or more in debt). The coronavirus pandemic has exposed deep-seated financial issues in many companies, and even a rebound in economic activity won't stop the wave of bankruptcies. Experts warn that the flood of petitions could swamp the system, causing irreversible economic losses and job losses, and call for reform to prevent viable small businesses from being forced to liquidate.

site_title: Reits (June 20-21, 2020)
summary: US mortgage rates have climbed for the first time in five weeks, reversing a trend of declines. This shift is expected to impact the real estate market, particularly in Singapore, where a Q3 wave of condo launches will test demand for prime projects above the S$3,000 psf benchmark. Meanwhile, Manhattan rents have reached a record high, with further increases anticipated. UK homebuyer demand has rebounded to a six-month high, and Goldman Sachs has acquired a significant portfolio of hotel and retail assets in Seoul. These developments highlight ongoing market fluctuations and changing demand.

site_title: Patchy sales on first day of showflats reopening
summary: Singapore developers experienced generally patchy sales on the first day of showflat reopenings after nearly two-and-a-half months of closure due to Covid-19 measures. Developers took a cautious approach to ensure safety, limiting showflat visits to appointment-only groups of up to five people. Sales were slower than expected, with some developers selling fewer than 10 units on the first day. Despite this, several projects saw increased interest, with some units selling for over S$3 million. Developers are now working to capitalize on pent-up demand, but some are holding firm on prices.

site_title: Things may appear changed forever but the old ways usually return quickly
summary: A second wave of COVID-19 infections has arrived, with rising new infection rates and a subsequent decline in equity markets. The virus may be seasonally recurring, requiring investors to assess long-term economic damage. Despite initial fears of a higher death toll, mortality rates have been lower than expected, leading to a significant recovery in risk assets. Governments are grappling with whether forced lockdowns are the most effective way to deal with the situation, with some, like Singapore, adopting a more pragmatic approach. The economic impact of COVID-19 may be more long-term than initially thought, with changes in behavior and demand potentially being more limited than expected.

site_title: Conference calls are the new miserable punch clock
summary: Conference calls have become a symbol of overwork and productivity expectations, mirroring the 1950s punch clock culture. As remote work arrangements continue, digital communication has escalated, with employees feeling pressure to clock in hours and present a varnish of productivity. This has led to burnout, with employees feeling like they're working long hours, even when they're not physically present in the office. Experts argue that this is a result of a lack of trust and flexibility in work arrangements, with managers using remote work as a test of loyalty, and productivity gurus blaming employees for not managing their time effectively.

site_title: Creating a circular plastic economy
summary: A proposed plastic credit scheme aims to encourage recycling and reduce the use of virgin plastic materials by creating a circular economy. The scheme, similar to carbon credits, would allocate certificates representing the right to produce virgin plastic materials, traded between industries with varying needs. This approach could preserve the value of plastic, reduce pollution, and encourage recycling. Governments could provide grants and tax benefits to incentivize infrastructure investments, and tracing capabilities would be necessary to govern the mechanism.

site_title: An uneventful week for gold after latest Fed meet
summary: Gold prices started the week on a weak note due to concerns over a resurgence of the novel coronavirus in China, but recovered after the US Federal Reserve announced tweaks to its bond buying programme, which led to a drop in the US dollar. The US dollar's decline and stimulus measures from Japan and China also supported gold prices. Despite a rally, gold prices failed to test last week's high and consolidated in the same trading range, with the benchmark Comex GC August 20 contract closing at US$1,749.20 an ounce.

site_title: Safeguarding investor outcomes
summary: Countries are addressing investor protection through a balance of regulations, enforcement, and cultural shifts. The Australia Royal Commission highlighted the need for change, but progress remains slow. In contrast, Canada and the US have separate standards for broker-dealers and registered investment advisers, while the UK has banned commissions and raised minimum qualifications. Hong Kong and Singapore have implemented regulations to reduce conflicts of interest and enhance transparency. Despite challenges, most markets have made material improvements, and a balance of regulatory measures and cultural shifts offers the best chance for ideal investor outcomes.

site_title: Without lavish tastings, Bordeaux sells itself with discounts and Zoom
summary: Bordeaux wine estates are adapting to the pandemic by selling their 2019 vintages en primeur through virtual tastings, with many offering discounts to drum up enthusiasm. Normally, top estates would host lavish tastings for merchants and journalists, but this year's events were cancelled or held with strict social distancing measures. Despite the challenges, many châteaux are reporting high-quality vintages and are offering significant price cuts, with some wines down by 30% or more. The goal is to build buying momentum without the usual pomp and circumstance, but it remains to be seen if the strategy will be enough to overcome economic headwinds.

site_title: Reopening may slow but not reverse retail decline: economists
summary: Singapore's retail sales may not experience a significant "revenge spending" surge as initially expected, according to economists. Despite a boost in sales from pent-up demand after two months of closure, consumer spending is expected to shift from grocery retailers to food services. This is based on the assumption that consumers will prioritize dining out over shopping, a trend observed in China. Economists caution that while retail sales may slow, it is unlikely to reverse the overall decline in the sector.

site_title: Average number of new daily Covid-19 cases in community falls for 5th day
summary: Singapore reported a fifth consecutive day of declining new daily Covid-19 cases in the community, with the average number of cases falling to four. Unlinked community cases also decreased from four to two over the same period. Two new dormitory clusters were reported, linked to six and three cases, respectively. A single new case was confirmed, a 21-year-old prison inmate who tested positive despite being asymptomatic. With 747 new recoveries, 33,449 patients have fully recovered from the disease, and 212 remain in hospital.

images.alt_text: The average number of new daily Covid-19 patients in the community has continued to come down from nine cases two weeks ago to four in the past week, the fifth straight day that the figure has fallen.

site_title: Hong Leong Asia extends Tasek takeover deadline to July 17
summary: Hong Leong Asia has extended its bid to acquire Malaysia-listed cement manufacturer Tasek until July 17, from the original deadline of June 23. The group, which controls 96.72% of Tasek, has received acceptances but needs to verify them. Hong Leong Asia, a subsidiary of the Hong Leong Group, is pushing to complete the takeover.

site_title: PSP cannot stop three-cornered fights in GE: Tan Cheng Bock
summary: Singapore's Progress Singapore Party (PSP) will attempt to avoid three-cornered fights in the upcoming general election (GE), but acknowledges that no party can dictate where others contest. PSP chief Tan Cheng Bock stated that the party's new status makes it challenging to claim contested areas, and they will not try to stop other parties from contesting. Meanwhile, Red Dot United, a newly registered party, has announced its intention to contest Jurong GRC, but will not do so if it leads to a three-cornered fight.

site_title: Wirecard CEO quits as search for missing US$2.1b hits dead end in the Philippines
summary: Wirecard CEO Markus Braun resigned amid allegations of fraud and a search for missing US$2.1 billion in funds. The German company is facing a looming cash crunch after its auditor, EY, refused to sign off on its accounts. Wirecard is holding emergency talks with banks to secure a financial lifeline. The company's shares have tanked following allegations that documents had been falsified by two Philippine banks. Braun had defended the company against accusations of accounting fraud, but had not identified those he suspected of wrongdoing.

site_title: Stamford Land refutes Australian news report; says it didn't breach social distancing measures
summary: Stamford Land has denied breaching social distancing guidelines at its Melbourne hotel after a security contractor tested positive for COVID-19. The company stated that the security personnel was not employed by Stamford Plaza Melbourne and that the hotel followed guidelines. The claim was made in response to an Australian news report.

site_title: BMW cuts jobs, ends self-driving project with Mercedes
summary: BMW is slashing 6,000 jobs this year and freezing a self-driving technology collaboration with Mercedes-Benz due to the coronavirus pandemic's impact on the luxury car industry. The German luxury carmaker is aiming to achieve workforce reductions through attrition and voluntary agreements. The company also announced plans to cut costs by slashing two hours of work per week and offering extra holiday time for lower pay. BMW's pre-tax profit is expected to be significantly lower than 2019's 7.10 billion euros.

site_title: Small businesses across US weigh the challenges and cost of reopening
summary: US small businesses are weighing the challenges and costs of reopening after months of closure due to the novel coronavirus. Many are taking a slow approach, with some opting for curbside rentals or reduced capacity. The cost of reopening is a significant challenge, with no relief packages including funding for safety equipment, sanitization regimens, or personal protective equipment. Businesses are also struggling with uncertain demand, with some owners considering reducing costs or even closing temporarily. Despite the uncertainty, many small businesses are cautiously reopening, with some seeing an increase in online sales and revenue.

images.alt_text: More US states are allowing restaurants, offices and retail businesses to reopen after being closed, some for as long as three months, to fight the spread of Covid-19.

site_title: Registration of HC Surgical's Julian Ong as doctor conditional for now
summary: Singapore Medical Council orders registration of surgeon Julian Ong as a doctor to be made conditional for 18 months due to a complaint filed against him. The complaint, filed in June 2018, alleges that Dr Ong and another specialist colluded to have sex with vulnerable female patients. Dr Ong's registration is conditional on compliance with restrictions, including not contacting female patients outside of medical practice or sharing patient data. A tribunal will conduct a formal inquiry into the matter.

site_title: Darco Water: Chairman's dissenting opinion raises questions
summary: Darco Water Technologies' mandatory general offer (MGO) will close on June 23. The offeror, Wang Zhi, holds a 43.8% stake, triggering the MGO. However, the independent financial adviser (IFA), RHT Capital, has advised the independent directors to recommend that shareholders reject the offer, citing it as not fair and reasonable. Chairman Wang Yaoyu has dissented, recommending acceptance, raising concerns about his financial connection with the offeror, which may impact the board's decision-making.

site_title: Putin calls Arctic fuel spill unprecedented for Russia, Greenpeace sees 100b roubles damage
summary: Russian President Vladimir Putin described the massive Arctic fuel spill as unprecedented for Russia, with estimated environmental damage of 100 billion roubles (S$2 billion). The spill, which occurred in May, released 21,000 tonnes of diesel into rivers and subsoil near Norilsk. It will take at least 10 years for biodiversity to fully return, according to the state fishing agency. Greenpeace estimates the damage at 100 billion roubles, citing a slow official response. The state environmental watchdog plans to finish its assessment by July 1.

site_title: Saving India's migrant workers
summary: Actor Sonu Sood and social worker Bunker Roy, along with others, have come together to help India's poor, starving, and hungry migrant workers. The COVID-19 pandemic led to the largest-ever migration of 40 million workers, with many not receiving pay during the lockdown. Sood's "Ghar Bhejo" initiative chartering planes to transport workers to their homes, while Roy's Barefoot College provided survival kits and aid to thousands. Meanwhile, a businessman from Andhra Pradesh, Chandrasekhar, arranged for trucks to transport workers to their destinations. These efforts have helped thousands of workers reunite with their families.

site_title: Taiwan pitches investment deal with EU to strengthen democracy
summary: Taiwan President Tsai Ing-wen has proposed signing an investment agreement with the European Union to strengthen democratic ties. The deal, which has been stalled since 2015, aims to promote economic cooperation and counterbalance the influence of China. Tsai highlighted Taiwan's strong track record in high-tech industries and its commitment to democratic values, including human rights and intellectual property. The EU has grown increasingly impatient with China on trade, and a deal with Taiwan could be a strategic move to counterbalance China's economic influence.

site_title: Sheng Siong says virus posed minimal disruption to supplies
summary: Sheng Siong Group, a Singaporean supermarket chain, reported that despite a price increase for popular household essentials, the supplies of most items remained unaffected during the coronavirus pandemic. The company expects variable costs to rise due to elevated demand and elevated demand from shoppers, but has not made major changes to its operational structure.

site_title: Putin pushes idea of Russian-backed summit to stabilise world
summary: President Vladimir Putin has called for a face-to-face summit with the leaders of the five permanent UN Security Council members to address global issues. He proposed the summit in January and received agreement in principle, but tensions with the US and other Western nations remain. The summit would discuss topics such as global economy, security, arms control, and climate change. Putin hopes the summit can proceed once coronavirus fears recede, despite strained relations with the West. The proposal is seen as highly ambitious, with some experts questioning Russia's willingness to compromise.

site_title: No Signboard may close Clarke Quay outlet amid coronavirus pandemic
summary: No Signboard Holdings, a seafood restaurant operator, may terminate the lease for its Clarke Quay outlet due to the ongoing coronavirus pandemic. The company plans to focus resources on other outlets and is in talks with its landlord about lease termination. It expects revenue and operating profits to be affected for the next 12 months, but believes it has enough resources to weather the pandemic. No Signboard will also expand its catering services. The company will adopt a cautious approach in managing its restaurants portfolio until the pandemic subsides.

site_title: Singapore Pools to resume lottery draws and outlet operations from June 22
summary: Singapore Pools will resume lottery draws and outlet operations starting June 22, with Toto lottery draws resuming on June 25 and other draws on specified dates. All other outlets, except authorized retail outlets, will remain closed. Lottery tickets purchased before April 5 are valid for upcoming draws, and prize-winning ticket validity periods will be extended by 90 days due to suspended prize payment services.

site_title: Real-estate agency industry urged to tap technology for greater productivity
summary: Singapore's real estate agency industry is urged to continue leveraging technology for greater productivity, said Minister of State for National Development and for Manpower, Zaqy Mohamad. The industry should adapt to shifting consumer habits and expectations by offering virtual viewings, saving time and maintaining the 'human touch'. Agents are allowed to conduct physical viewings in groups of up to five under Phase 2 of the reopening, but certain activities remain restricted. The industry is advised to use IT tools and solutions as much as possible, with face-to-face interactions only when necessary.

site_title: Spotify shares jump with analysts bullish on podcast moves
summary: Spotify shares jumped 7.3% on Friday, reaching record territory, following positive analyst commentary on the company's podcast deals. Analysts from Rosenblatt Securities and Monness, Crespi, Hardt raised their price targets to $275, citing attractive monetization potential and growth opportunities. The deals with high-profile podcasters like Joe Rogan and Kim Kardashian West are seen as a key factor in the company's bullish outlook, with investors buying into Spotify's podcast vision. This is the largest weekly percentage gain in the company's history, with shares more than doubling off a March low.

site_title: MOM unveils timeline to screen and clear foreign worker dorms of coronavirus
summary: The Ministry of Manpower (MOM) in Singapore has cleared nearly a quarter of the country's 323,000 migrant worker dormitory residents of the novel coronavirus, with around 75,000 residents cleared as of June 15. A timeline has been released for the clearance of individual dormitories, with 40 out of 43 purpose-built dormitories expected to be cleared by end-July. Residents will continue to be regularly tested to prevent new clusters from forming.

site_title: Food exporters to China asked to declare produce is coronavirus-free
summary: China's customs authority has asked food exporters to sign a declaration stating their produce is coronavirus-free. The declaration, seen by Reuters, aims to reduce additional testing on imported foods and make exporters responsible for ensuring product safety. The move comes after Beijing began testing imported food for the coronavirus following an outbreak in a wholesale food market. More than 30,000 samples of meat, seafood, and produce were tested between June 11-17, with all samples negative for the virus. The effectiveness of the declaration remains unclear, with some exporters expressing concerns about the added responsibility.

site_title: Winding-up petition served on KrisEnergy unit
summary: A winding-up petition was served on KrisEnergy (Gulf of Thailand) in the Cayman Islands, but the company has lodged a notice of appeal to block the petition from Rubicon Vantage International. Meanwhile, KrisEnergy's Vietnam 115 subsidiary has agreed to transfer its stake in an offshore production-sharing contract to an unnamed company for a nominal cash consideration, with the long-stop date extended to September 30. Trading in KrisEnergy shares has been suspended since August 2019 due to the company's restructuring efforts.

site_title: Divided EU seeks to agree coronavirus stimulus
summary: European Union leaders began discussing a stimulus package to help the bloc's coronavirus-ravaged economies, with a proposed 1.10 trillion euros budget and a 750 billion euros recovery fund. The aid is aimed at worst-hit nations like Italy and Spain, but differences over grants, conditional loans, and spending priorities remain. Officials expect a deal by July, with at least one or two more meetings needed to reach a final agreement.

site_title: Crisis call: Singapore business leaders on managing in the pandemic
summary: Singapore business leaders share strategies for managing operations and staying connected with staff during the pandemic. Key takeaways include the importance of crisis communication, being vulnerable and honest, and leading by example. Effective leaders should communicate regularly, create certainty and clarity, and trust their teams to handle the facts. Pay cuts and retrenchments are often necessary, but companies should be transparent and empathetic in their communication. Leaders should also prioritize staff morale, providing regular updates and reassurance about the company's strategy and future prospects. By adopting these strategies, businesses can navigate the pandemic and emerge stronger.

site_title: Neymar loses lawsuit with FC Barcelona over bonus
summary: Neymar has been ordered to pay FC Barcelona 6.7 million euros after losing a lawsuit over an unpaid bonus. The Brazilian forward claimed 43.6 million euros in the final renewal of his contract, but the court ruled in Barcelona's favor. Neymar moved to Paris St Germain in 2017 for a world record fee, but the dispute arose from the terms of his previous contract. The decision is final, with Neymar's representatives able to appeal the verdict.

site_title: Singapore fintech sector bags S$462m in funding in H1 2020
summary: Singapore's fintech sector secured S$462 million in funding during the first half of 2020, a 19% increase from the same period in 2019. The majority of this funding, S$223 million, went towards banking services for small and medium-sized enterprises, driven by payments and lending product verticals.

site_title: SK Jewellery warns of H1 2020 net loss amid virus-related revenue drop
summary: SK Jewellery Group, a Catalist-listed company, is expected to post a six-month net loss for the first half of 2020 due to the coronavirus pandemic's impact on its retail revenue. The company's stores in Singapore and Malaysia remain shut due to movement restrictions, but it plans to increase its online presence and become more competitive when the situation improves. Shareholders are advised to exercise caution when trading the company's shares.

site_title: Wirecard CEO quits as search for missing billions hits dead end in Asia
summary: Wirecard CEO Markus Braun resigned as the company faces a looming cash crunch amid allegations of $2.1 billion in missing funds. Braun had defended the company against accounting fraud accusations, but the search for the missing money hit a dead end in the Philippines. Wirecard is holding emergency talks with banks to secure a financial lifeline after its auditor refused to sign off on its accounts. The company's shares continue to tank, and Braun's departure comes as investor confidence is shattered.

site_title: Leases for commercial equipment, vehicles to be covered by temporary relief law
summary: Singapore's Ministry of Law announced that leases for commercial equipment and vehicles will be covered by a temporary relief law due to Covid-19, starting June 20. The law provides relief from specified legal actions, including repossession, for renters who cannot fulfill their contractual obligations. The relief will last until October 19, 2020, and applies to rental agreements entered before March 25, 2020. Renters are encouraged to discuss with the rental company before applying for relief or seeking an Assessor's determination.

site_title: US: Wall Street jumps at open on hopes of economic rebound
summary: US stocks jumped 1% on Friday, with the tech-heavy Nasdaq near a fresh record high, driven by hopes of a post-pandemic economic rebound. The Nasdaq opened above its all-time closing high and shares of Apple, Microsoft, and Amazon.com led the gains. Despite rising COVID-19 cases in several US states, the S&P 500 and Dow are headed for their fourth weekly rise in five. Oil prices jumped amid signs of gradual recovery in demand, and investors are optimistic about the economic outlook, with some expecting an "overshoot" in equities driven by monetary policy easing and fiscal expansions.

site_title: Soilbuild Business Space Reit snags S$80m green loan
summary: SOILBUILD Business Space Reit has secured an S$80 million green loan to refinance its Solaris@one-north project in Singapore's Fusionopolis district. The loan, from OCBC Bank and RHB Bank, marks the Reit's first green loan and supports its capital management strategy of diversifying funding sources. CEO Roy Teo stated that the loan delivers long-term value to stakeholders and creates a more sustainable future. Units closed flat following the announcement at S$0.40.

site_title: Founder of Indonesia's Bukalapak to head Telkom's digital business
summary: Indonesian e-commerce startup Bukalapak's co-founder and president Fajrin Rasyid, 34, has stepped down to become head of digital business at state-owned Telkom, following a request by State-Owned Enterprises Minister Erick Thohir. This move aims to make Telkom more profitable and reduce its dependence on mobile services. Bukalapak, valued at over $2.5 billion, now lacks a founding team member after its co-founder and CEO Achmad Zaky stepped down in January.

images.alt_text: Indonesian e-commerce startup Bukalapak said that its co-founder and president Fajrin Rasyid 34 has stepped down to become the head of digital business at state-owned PT Telekomunikasi Indonesia Tbk, (Telkom).

site_title: Europeans working with US to restructure WHO, top official says
summary: European countries, including Britain, France, Germany, and Italy, are working with the US to overhaul the World Health Organization (WHO), aiming to ensure its independence from single country influence. The reforms would involve changing the WHO's funding system to a more long-term model, with the goal of separating emergency management from any single country influence. This move comes after the US withdrew funding and announced plans to quit the WHO, citing concerns over its close ties with China during the coronavirus crisis.

site_title: Popular grocery items cost more during pandemic, but most supplies not disrupted: Sheng Siong
summary: Sheng Siong Group, a mainboard-listed supermarket chain, reported that popular grocery items experienced price increases during the pandemic, but most supplies remained unaffected. The company attributed the price hikes to exceptional increases in logistics costs. Despite this, Sheng Siong expects variable costs to rise due to elevated demand, but overall net margins may improve. The company has not made major changes to its operational structure and has diversified its supplier sources. Its e-commerce platform contributed 1-2% to revenue, but faces competition from big online players.

site_title: Daily Debrief: What Happened Today
summary: Singapore's Wee Tiong MD and shipping manager charged with falsifying papers to hide North Korea trade. Private banks plan to boost hiring in Singapore to manage Greater China offshore wealth. A temporary relief law will cover commercial equipment and vehicle leases affected by Covid-19. Frasers Property Thailand names new CEO, while ComfortDelGro partners with RATP Dev and Alstom for French metro projects. A High Court hearing for Hyflux is scheduled for July 27, and hackers plan a phishing attack targeting Singapore businesses with fake MOM emails. The STI fell 1.86% on Friday.

site_title: Samsung to relocate Chinese display production to Vietnam
summary: Samsung Electronics plans to shift most of its display production from China to its plant in southern Vietnam, citing the country's strategic location as a gateway to other South-east Asian countries. The move is part of a global trend to diversify supply chains beyond China, following disruptions caused by the novel coronavirus. Samsung already produces displays in Vietnam, with six factories and two research centers, and the relocation is expected to make Vietnam the world's leading supplier of Samsung screens.

site_title: Ipos names Rena Lee as new chief executive
summary: The Intellectual Property Office of Singapore (Ipos) has appointed Rena Lee as its new chief executive, effective August 2020. Lee, 51, succeeds Daren Tang, who is leaving to head the World Intellectual Property Organisation (Wipo) as director-general. Lee, a law graduate of the National University of Singapore, brings expertise in international law and has experience in the Attorney-General's Chambers and Ministry of Foreign Affairs. Her appointment aims to grow Ipos' robust intellectual property infrastructure, following Tang's recognition as the world's most innovative intellectual property office in 2020.

site_title: Banker Tracey Woon joins Singapore Press Holdings as independent director
summary: Singapore Press Holdings (SPH) appointed 63-year-old banker Tracey Woon as an independent director, effective July 1. Woon, who is vice-chairman of Asia-Pacific global wealth management at UBS, brings experience in investment banking and international capital markets to the role. The appointment aims to help SPH navigate challenges from the COVID-19 pandemic and global economic uncertainties. Woon will join the executive committee and risk committee, contributing to the company's investment, diversification, and strengthening efforts.

site_title: Indonesia business chamber says 6.4m jobs lost so far in pandemic
summary: Indonesia's business chamber, Kadin, reports 6.4 million jobs lost due to the pandemic, exceeding the government's worst-case scenario of 5.23 million people losing work. The textile industry has laid off 2.1 million workers, while land transportation and footwear makers have also shed significant numbers. Kadin chairman Rosan Roeslani warns of further job losses in July and August if the government doesn't provide stimulus, predicting a 6% contraction in the April-June quarter and negative growth for full-year 2020.

site_title: New digital transformation guide launched for sea-transport businesses
summary: A digital transformation guide for sea-transport businesses has been launched, aiming to help small and medium-sized enterprises develop their business strategies and digitalise their operations. The "Maritime Digitalisation Playbook" covers key areas such as port clearances, trade documentation, and financing, based on findings from a survey of over 200 maritime organisations. Developed jointly by the Maritime and Port Authority of Singapore, the Infocomm Media Development Authority, and the Singapore Shipping Association, the guide is available online and aims to help companies close their digital gaps and improve their competitiveness.

site_title: China's new marine fuel contract seen attracting strong industry, investor interest
summary: China's new marine fuel contract, featuring low-sulphur fuel oil, is expected to attract strong interest from the industry and investors, despite weakened ship fuel demand due to the coronavirus pandemic. The contract, which debuted on the Shanghai International Energy Exchange, is seen as a potential Asian benchmark for shipping fuel, with about 20 Chinese refineries equipped to produce the fuel. The contract's listing aims to boost Beijing's ambitions to build a bunkering hub in eastern China's Zhoushan port and challenge Singapore's dominance in the multi-billion dollar shipping fuel market.

site_title: Wee Tiong MD, manager charged with falsifying papers to hide North Korea trade
summary: Singapore's Wee Tiong managing director Tan Wee Beng, 43, and shipping manager Bong Hui Ping, 38, were charged with falsifying papers to hide business relationships with North Korea-linked entities. They allegedly concealed transactions between 2014 and 2017, including selling sugar to North Korean customers. Tan faces up to 10 years in jail and a fine for falsification of papers with intent to defraud. The charges come after the US Treasury placed sanctions on Wee Tiong in 2018 and the FBI accused Tan of bank fraud and money laundering in support of North Korean entities.

site_title: UK markets watchdog proposes further 3-month consumer credit payment holiday
summary: Britain's Financial Conduct Authority proposed extending a payment freeze on credit cards by three months, supporting borrowers struggling due to the coronavirus pandemic. Consumers can apply for a payment freeze or an interest-free overdraft of up to £500 until October 31. This measure aims to alleviate financial difficulties for those affected by the pandemic.

site_title: YouTube hit with discrimination suit by black video artists
summary: A federal court lawsuit accuses YouTube of discriminating against African American video makers and viewers by using computer-driven racial profiling and filtering tools to restrict content. The suit claims YouTube uses metadata and tags referencing "Black Lives Matter" and other topics to block or demonetize videos based on race, rather than content. The lawsuit seeks class action status and names YouTube, Google, and Alphabet as defendants. This comes as Google has committed to boosting non-profit advertising and supporting black artists on YouTube. The case raises concerns about algorithmic bias and content moderation.

site_title: STI finishes the week down 1.86%; iFAST rallies on digibank hopes
summary: The Straits Times Index (STI) fell 1.86% to 2,634.83 on Friday, closing at 49.8 points lower. Despite this, fintech platform iFAST Corp surged 13.91% after being shortlisted for a digital wholesale bank license. The rally in the STI has fizzled, but it's unlikely to plummet to new depths, according to UOB Kay Hian research head Adrian Loh, citing subdued inflation and aggressive monetary policies.

site_title: European investors threaten Brazil divestment over deforestation
summary: Seven major European investment firms, with over $5 billion in investments in Brazil, threaten to divest from beef producers, grains traders, and government bonds if progress is not made in addressing Amazon rainforest deforestation. The move comes after Brazil's President Jair Bolsonaro's administration weakened environmental protections and increased deforestation. The investors, including Nordea and LGIM, have expressed alarm over the government's inaction and lack of credibility, with some threatening to sell Brazilian government bonds or boycott Brazilian exports. The threat of divestment could trigger other investors to follow suit, putting pressure on the Brazilian government to take action.

images.alt_text: Seven major European investment firms told Reuters they will divest from beef producers, grains traders and even government bonds in Brazil if they do not see progress in resolving the surging destruction of the Amazon rainforest.

site_title: Seoul: Shares end week higher as recovery hopes offset ongoing pandemic worries
summary: South Korean shares ended the week higher, closing up 0.37% at 2,141.32, driven by hopes for an economic recovery despite ongoing pandemic worries and tensions with North Korea. Cyclical stocks reversed losses in the late session, while foreigners bought 55.3 billion won worth of shares. The won weakened, and bond yields rose, with the 10-year yield increasing by 0.8 basis points to 1.378%. South Korean President Moon Jae-in accepted the resignation of the minister responsible for North Korea relations amid rising tensions.

site_title: Hong Kong: Stocks close with gains
summary: Hong Kong stocks ended the week on a high note, with the Hang Seng Index rising 0.73% to 24,643.89. This follows easing of lockdown measures worldwide, which may have alleviated economic concerns. The Shanghai Composite Index and Shenzhen Composite Index also saw gains, with the latter jumping 1.19%. The market's optimism is despite ongoing US-China trade tensions, with the US and EU set to discuss trade talks.

site_title: 142 new Covid-19 cases in Singapore, including one in the community involving prison inmate
summary: Singapore reported 142 new COVID-19 cases, bringing the total to 41,615. The majority of cases are migrant workers living in dormitories, with one community case involving a prison inmate on social visit pass. The inmate had been segregated from the general population since June 6 and tested positive for COVID-19.

site_title: HSBC hits out at 'rumours' with China investment pledge
summary: HSBC Holdings has responded to "Internet rumours" in China, reaffirming its commitment to investing and supporting the Chinese economy despite growing tensions. The bank stated it has been a "steadfast backer" of China's development since 1980 and will continue to serve the mainland. Despite recent criticism, HSBC rose 0.7% in Hong Kong and has maintained a significant presence in China with over 8,000 staff across 170 outlets. The bank's China business remains a key growth area, with Asia accounting for half of its revenue in 2019.

site_title: Malaysia: Shares close higher on Friday
summary: Malaysia's FTSE Bursa Malaysia Kuala Lumpur Composite Index closed higher on Friday, rising 2.35 points to 1,507.26. The index saw 6.328 billion lots traded worth RM4.923 billion, with 610 gainers and 400 losers.

site_title: Wirecard says it cannot rule out 'fraud of considerable proportions'
summary: Wirecard, a German payments company, may be the victim of "fraud of considerable proportions" after its auditor refused to sign off its 2019 accounts due to a missing 1.90 billion euros. The company's shares dropped 60% as banks managing the trust accounts, which held a quarter of Wirecard's balance sheet, claimed the balances were spurious. CEO Markus Braun stated that Wirecard cannot rule out being the victim of fraud, amid speculation that the company's financials have been manipulated by short sellers. The company is seeking to clarify the balances in question.

site_title: Europe: Shares rise with recovery fund talks in focus
summary: European shares rose 0.5% on Friday ahead of a European Council meeting to negotiate the European Union's 750 billion euro recovery fund. The pan-European Stoxx 600 index led gains, with Frankfurt shares particularly strong. The meeting will discuss a proposal to raise debt to 1.10 trillion euros in 2021-27. Meanwhile, Germany's Lufthansa gained on signs of movement in its stalled government bailout.

site_title: Malaysia partially reopens borders to expats, medical tourists
summary: Malaysia partially reopened its borders to expats and medical tourists, allowing certain foreigners to enter without immigration approval. Those earning 10,000 ringgit (S$3,255) per month or holding professional visit passes and resident talent passes with top management positions can enter without approval. Malaysians can travel overseas by showing proof of purpose to immigration officers. The reopening follows the country's gradual lifting of lockdown measures, with COVID-19 tests and monitoring required for all travelers. Discussions are ongoing to extend the same courtesy to Malaysian citizens and others.

site_title: UK retail sales rebound in May, public debt passes 100% of GDP
summary: The UK retail sales rebounded 12% in May, exceeding economists' forecasts, but still down 13.1% from last year. Public debt surpassed 100% of GDP, a record high, due to increased government spending. Consumer confidence remains weak, and unemployment is expected to rise. The Bank of England's governor, Andrew Bailey, noted the economy is shrinking less severely than feared, but a strong rebound is not guaranteed. Household incomes will be strained when a government support scheme ends in October.

site_title: Australia: Shares pare gains on second virus wave concerns
summary: Australian shares rose 0.1% to 5,942.6 points, driven by a record 16.3% surge in May retail sales, but pared gains amid concerns over an uptick in coronavirus cases in China and US states. Risk sentiment was also dampened by US President Donald Trump's renewed threats to cut ties with China. Energy stocks rose 1.9%, while technology stocks advanced 1.84%. Despite the gains, shares of heavyweight miners BHP Group and Rio Tinto fell 1.9% and 1.4%, respectively.

site_title: Higher support of up to S$500 a year for union members aged 40 and above to upgrade skills
summary: The National Trades Union Congress (NTUC) in Singapore announced an enhancement to its Union Training Assistance Programme (UTAP) for union members aged 40 and above. Starting July 1, they can use up to S$500 a year to defray up to half of course fees, with a maximum of S$500 per year. This support complements the government's SkillsFuture Credit and aims to help middle-aged workers upgrade their skills, particularly in light of the ongoing COVID-19 pandemic and its impact on the labor market.

site_title: Red Dot United unveils mission statement and logo, sets sights on Jurong GRC
summary: Singapore's Red Dot United (RDU) political party has unveiled its mission statement and logo, aiming to contest Jurong GRC constituency. RDU will not contest the constituency if other opposition parties do so, but will represent the opposition if it remains unchallenged. The party, led by former Progress Singapore Party members, has 12 members and plans to unveil its candidates next week. RDU's entry marks a record 12 opposition parties vying for the next general election, following the party's registration on June 17.

site_title: Main Street investors bank profits on rally that Wall Street doubted
summary: Main Street investors, who have profited from the record-breaking stock market rebound, are shifting strategy, cashing out of volatile sectors and moving into safer investments. Despite Wall Street experts advising clients to re-engage with riskier assets, retail investors are prioritizing sentiment and market mood, with some achieving significant returns on their investments. Experts note that retail investors often follow the money flow and sentiment of the markets, rather than fundamental analysis.

site_title: Robinhood reviews options trading offering following suicide by customer
summary: Robinhood is reviewing its options trading offering following the death of a 20-year-old customer, Alex Kearns, who took his own life after losing an estimated $730,000 on the platform. Kearns left a note stating he had no idea what he was doing and thought ending his life would protect his family from exposure. Robinhood says it will not disclose details about Kearns' account due to respect for privacy. The company, founded in 2013, is committed to improving its platform and reviewing its options offering to determine if changes are necessary.

site_title: Private banks to boost hiring in Singapore to manage Greater China offshore wealth: sources
summary: Leading private banks, including UBS, Credit Suisse, and Julius Baer, plan to boost staff in Singapore to manage Greater China offshore wealth, expecting to benefit from rising uncertainty in Hong Kong. The banks aim to increase staff by up to a third, focusing on Singapore, as client queries from China and Hong Kong increase. This move is largely driven by the need to lock in bankers before supply runs out, as client queries from China and Hong Kong are on the rise.

site_title: Electronics strength to fuel Asean exports in post-Covid trade
summary: Vietnam, Singapore, and Malaysia are expected to experience strong export growth after the COVID-19 crisis due to their exposure to tech and pharmaceutical supply chains. According to HSBC's chief economist, these countries are less affected by pandemic-related supply-chain disruptions. This growth is attributed to the industries' resilience and the favorable trade terms with the US, which has sweetened its trade agreement with Vietnam. The three countries are likely to outperform other Asean economies in terms of export growth, driven by their electronics strength.

site_title: Seoul's unification minister resigns over North Korea tensions
summary: South Korea's Unification Minister, Kim Yeon Chul, resigned on Friday amid heightened tensions with North Korea, following the destruction of the liaison office between the two countries. The North had condemned South Korea for anti-Pyongyang leaflets and threatened to bolster its military presence. Analysts believe North Korea may be seeking to manufacture a crisis to pressure South Korea for concessions. The move comes after a series of escalating tensions, including the collapse of a 2019 summit between North and US leaders.

site_title: Japan lifts coronavirus travel curbs to help economy bounce back
summary: Japan lifted all coronavirus-related travel curbs on domestic travel, with Prime Minister Shinzo Abe urging citizens to engage in social and economic activities to boost the economy. The move comes after the end of an emergency declaration and the easing of social distancing measures. The decision aims to help Japan recover from a pandemic recession, with Abe encouraging people to go sightseeing, attend concerts, and participate in other events.

site_title: Liquor giant Moutai poised to become China's biggest stock
summary: Chinese liquor giant Kweichow Moutai is poised to become China's biggest stock by market value, surpassing Industrial & Commercial Bank of China (ICBC). Moutai's market capitalization rose to 1.808 trillion yuan, surpassing ICBC's 1.813 trillion yuan, with its stock closing up 1.9% at a record high. The distiller's steady rise is attributed to its ability to keep raising retail prices, despite the coronavirus pandemic affecting distillers globally. Moutai's Shanghai-listed stock has surged 1,350% over the past decade, making it one of China's highest-rated stocks.

site_title: Startup led by ex-Goldman Sachs HR chief launches diversity and inclusion index
summary: Eskalera, a startup led by former Goldman Sachs HR chief Dane Holmes, has launched an index to measure corporate diversity and inclusiveness. The index combines employee sentiment, company culture, and HR data to generate a score for inclusivity. Eskalera aims to provide actionable information to companies to increase diversity, following a surge in inquiries from prospective clients. The launch comes amid growing pressure on US companies to improve racial diversity and equity, with few Fortune 500 CEOs being black. Eskalera's CEO said companies must take concrete actions beyond symbolic gestures to address diversity gaps.

site_title: Frasers Property Thailand names new country CEO
summary: Frasers Property Thailand has appointed Thanapol Sirithanachai as country CEO, effective August 17. He previously led Golden Land Property Development, acquired by Frasers Property Thailand in 2019, turning its operations from loss to profit within three years. Sirithanachai will work closely with current president Sopon Racharaksa to develop a new structure for Frasers Property Thailand and drive investment strategies. He brings over 30 years of real estate experience, citing the acquisition as a competitive edge for the company.

images.alt_text: Thanapol Sirithanachai was previously the president of Golden Land Property Development, which was acquired by Frasers Property Thailand in August 2019.

site_title: Thailand aims to turn away from mass tourism and target the rich
summary: Thailand aims to shift its tourism strategy from mass tourism to high-end travel, targeting wealthy individuals seeking private and socially distanced experiences. The country plans to reopen with a limited number of arrivals, focusing on business executives and medical tourists, and will implement measures such as COVID-19 screenings and mandatory stay periods. The goal is to attract 10 million foreign arrivals this year, with a focus on luxury resorts and winter months. The strategy aims to reset the tourism sector and address issues like over-crowding and environmental destruction.

site_title: Air freight rates head back to earth as virus-driven boom cools
summary: Air freight rates, driven by demand for protective gear during the coronavirus pandemic, have peaked and are now falling, albeit still 40-50% above normal levels. This trend is concerning for airlines relying on freight revenue, as passenger revenues remain weak. Global air cargo capacity is rising as passenger flights return, but the market is becoming flooded with belly freight capacity, leading to declining rates. The International Air Transport Association estimates cargo will contribute 26% of airline industry revenue in 2020, up from 12% in 2019.

site_title: Emirates resumes Singapore flight services, expands destination network
summary: Emirates has resumed flights from Singapore to Dubai, offering three weekly flights, and expanded its destination network to include 10 new cities. The airline will also add 15 new destinations in July, bringing its total network to 40. Passengers from Singapore can now connect to any destination on Emirates' network, including the Gulf Cooperation Council, Asia-Pacific, Europe, and the Americas.

images.alt_text: Emirates has resumed flights for passengers from Singapore following the United Arab Emirates federal government's announcement on lifting restrictions for transit passenger services.

site_title: Indonesia to build pipeline from Rokan block to Dumai refinery
summary: Indonesia's state gas utility, Perusahan Gas Negara (PGN), plans to build a 367km pipeline connecting the Rokan oil block to Pertamina's Dumai refinery on the island of Sumatra. The $300 million pipeline, set to be completed by the end of next year, will transport 250,000 barrels of oil per day. This project is part of Indonesian oil and gas company PT Pertamina's plan to take over the Rokan oil block from Chevron in August next year.

site_title: Registration of HC Surgical's Julian Ong as doctor conditional for now
summary: Singaporean surgeon Julian Ong's registration as a doctor is conditional for 18 months due to a complaint filed with the Singapore Medical Council, which led to a disciplinary tribunal. Ong's private practice, HC Surgical Specialists, is a 70% subsidiary of HCSS. He faces restrictions, including not contacting female patients outside medical practice and not sharing patient data. Ong previously lost a defamation lawsuit against minority shareholder Serene Tiong, who accused him of colluding with another specialist to have sex with vulnerable female patients.

site_title: ING names veteran Steven van Rijswijk as CEO
summary: ING Groep has named veteran Steven van Rijswijk as its new CEO, replacing Ralph Hamers who is leaving to become CEO of UBS Group in July. Van Rijswijk, with over 20 years at ING, will focus on building on Hamers' strategy of developing the bank's technology platform and digital products. ING chairman Hans Wijers described van Rijswijk as having the "right combination of experience, leadership skills and deep understanding of our business."

images.alt_text: ING Groep, the largest Dutch bank, said on Friday chief risk officer Steven van Rijswijk would replace Ralph Hamers as the chief executive officer (CEO) from July 1. Mr Hamers, credited with helping ING develop its successful online banking platform, in February announced he was leaving to become CEO of Swiss bank UBS Group later this year.

site_title: Australian retail sales surge record 16.3% in May: ABS
summary: Australian retail sales surged a record 16.3% in May, rebounding from a 17.7% decline in April, as lockdown restrictions eased. This strong bounce suggests consumer spending will recover quickly from its recession, offering hope for a swift economic recovery. Household goods, clothing, and cafes saw significant increases, with sales also up 5.3% from last year to A$28.83 billion.

site_title: Tokyo: Nikkei closes higher, driven by tech shares
summary: Tokyo's benchmark Nikkei index closed 0.55% higher at 22,478.79, driven by gains in tech shares, including Tokyo Electron and Advantest. However, a second wave of coronavirus infections weighed on buying sentiment. The broader Topix index edged down 0.02% as investors bought on dips following recent declines. Japanese core consumer prices dropped 0.2% year-on-year in May, reflecting stay-home requests due to the lifted state of emergency declaration.

images.alt_text: Tokyo's benchmark Nikkei index closed marginally higher on Friday led by high-tech shares, but worries over a second wave of coronavirus infections weighed on buying sentiment.

site_title: Broker's take: CGS-CIMB expects slower Singapore office leasing momentum in Phase Two
summary: CGS-CIMB expects slower office leasing momentum in Singapore's Phase Two due to a weaker macroeconomic backdrop. Analyst Lock Mun Yee forecasts a 5-10% decline in office rents and a 500,000-700,000 sq ft net absorption rate this year. Vacancy levels are projected to reach 11.3% by end-2020, with existing buildings likely to fare better than newbuilds. Longer-term changes to the market, such as a shift to de-densify offices, are expected to occur gradually, and CGS-CIMB maintains an "overweight" call on the Singapore property sector.

site_title: Asia: Markets mixed as traders weigh conflicting issues
summary: Asian markets were mixed on Friday, weighed down by conflicting issues including easing lockdowns, improving economic data, and geopolitical tensions. Despite a strong start to the week, markets are leveling out as investors await the next major catalyst, such as a vaccine. The spread of COVID-19 in several countries, including the US, China, and India, is casting a pall over markets, while simmering tensions between the US and China, as well as between North and South Korea, add to the uncertainty.

site_title: Hong Kong: Stocks open lower on Friday
summary: Hong Kong shares opened lower on Friday, with the Hang Seng Index easing 0.37% to 24,373.36, amid concerns about a potential second wave of virus infections and the global economy. The benchmark Shanghai Composite Index remained flat, while the Shenzhen Composite Index gained 0.07%. The dip follows a tepid lead from Wall Street, where the S&P 500 and Nasdaq edged to fresh records despite tariff uncertainty.

site_title: Malaysia: Shares open lower on Friday
summary: Malaysia's shares opened lower on Friday, with the FTSE Bursa Malaysia Kuala Lumpur Composite Index down 7.04 points, or 0.47%, to 1,497.87. Volume was 140.96 million lots worth RM46 million. The decline follows a 0.4% gain for the STI on Thursday.

site_title: Japan says economy 'almost stopped worsening', raising view for first time since 2018
summary: Japan's government has raised its economic assessment for the first time since 2018, citing signs of improvement in consumer spending and business sentiment after the lifting of a state of emergency. The economy, still in an "extremely severe situation," has "almost stopped worsening," according to the June report. While exports and factory output are expected to remain subdued, the upgrade in economic assessment offers a glimmer of hope for Japan's post-pandemic recovery.

site_title: US sees nearly 700 more virus deaths in 24 hours
summary: The US reported nearly 700 additional COVID-19 deaths in the 24 hours leading up to Thursday evening, bringing the total to 118,381 deaths. This marks the eighth day with fewer than 1,000 daily tolls. Despite this, the US remains the hardest-hit country by the pandemic. The White House's chief infectious disease expert, Anthony Fauci, expressed skepticism about the need for new widespread containment measures, instead focusing on controlling areas with surging cases.

site_title: High Court hearing for Hyflux lenders to take place on July 27
summary: The Singapore High Court has scheduled a hearing on July 27 for Hyflux lenders to determine issues related to the application by an unsecured working group (UWG) to be carved out of the water treatment firm's moratorium. The UWG, comprising several major banks, had previously applied for a carve-out but was denied by the court. If approved, the UWG plans to file an application to appoint judicial managers to oversee Hyflux in place of the present management. The hearing will also determine the application by RBC Investors Services Trust Singapore to be carved out of the moratorium.

site_title: Fauci confident in vaccine efforts, predicts no more US lockdowns
summary: US government expert Anthony Fauci expressed confidence in the country's vaccine efforts, predicting no more US lockdowns are needed to control the Covid-19 outbreak. Despite a flat national daily infection rate, Fauci remains optimistic about a vaccine that would end the pandemic, citing encouraging early trial results. He stated that places experiencing a surge in cases, such as California and Texas, do not need to reissue stay-at-home orders.

site_title: Nissan plans more shift cuts at Japan car plants due to low demand: sources
summary: Nissan plans to cut more shifts at its three Japanese assembly plants due to low demand. The automaker will cancel all night shifts at two plants between June 29 and July 31, affecting approximately 1,000 workers. The moves aim to reduce production costs and adapt to the post-pandemic market. Nissan's struggles in Japan come as the company faces a drop in sales and a need to recover from the coronavirus pandemic's impact on the automotive industry.

site_title: Curtain falls on Hong Kong's oldest satirical TV show
summary: Hong Kong's oldest satirical TV show, "Headliner," will air its final episode on Friday, amid pro-democracy unrest and concerns about Beijing's anti-subversion law. The show, which ran for 31 years, has faced government ire for its irreverent skits and lampooning of public figures. The government's review of public broadcaster RTHK, which produces the show, has been criticized by Beijing loyalists as overly sympathetic to the opposition. The show's cancellation is seen as a blow to local freedoms.

site_title: Japan's deflation gathers momentum as prices extend declines
summary: Japan's core consumer prices fell 0.2% in May, marking the second straight month of declines, exacerbating deflation concerns and complicating the Bank of Japan's efforts to revive the economy. The nationwide core consumer price index, excluding volatile food prices, dropped from a year earlier, prompting BOJ policymakers to warn of stronger monetary support and closer policy coordination needed to prevent deflation. Analysts doubt the economy can rebound strongly from an expected 20% contraction in the current quarter, citing ongoing COVID-19 impacts and a state of emergency in April.

site_title: Australian dollar finds support from super-strong sales data
summary: The Australian dollar found support on Friday as strong retail sales data helped offset global concerns about the coronavirus. Sales surged 16.3% in May, the second-highest on record, suggesting consumer spending will be stronger than expected. The Aussie was steady at US$0.6855, almost unchanged for the week. The Reserve Bank of Australia remains committed to holding interest rates near zero, but the data offers hope for the economy's recovery from its first recession in three decades.

site_title: Stocks to watch: Olam, ComfortDelGro, SIIC Environment, Global Invacom, mm2 Asia
summary: Olam International secured a US$250 million sustainability-linked loan, ComfortDelGro Corporation entered a collaboration agreement for Grand Paris Express greenfield metro projects, and SIIC Environment Holdings clinched a project in China's Zhejiang province. Global Invacom Group and mm2 Asia saw unusual share price movements, while Alibaba Pictures Group received approval to delist from the Singapore Exchange mainboard. These developments may impact trading of the respective companies' securities.

site_title: Australia: Energy stocks boost shares, New Zealand up
summary: Australian shares rose 0.73% to a one-week high, driven by energy stocks tracking higher oil prices, amid hopes of a quick economic recovery. The S&P/ASX 200 index reached its highest since June 11. Energy stocks, particularly Cooper Energy, led gains, while gold stocks and miners also advanced. In New Zealand, the benchmark S&P/NZX 50 index rose 0.24% and was set to gain more than 3% for the week.

images.alt_text: Australian shares gained on Friday, hitting a more than one-week high, helped by energy stocks that tracked higher oil prices, although worries remained about a second wave of Covid-19 infections around the world.

site_title: Japan shoppers queue, crash website for Uniqlo's washable masks
summary: Japanese shoppers queued at Uniqlo stores and crashed its website on Friday as the clothing chain began selling face masks with breathable fabric, preparing for the coronavirus outbreak. The Airism masks, known for staying cool in heat and exercise, were sold in three-piece packs for 990 yen (S$12.90) plus tax. The website was inundated with requests, prompting an apology from Uniqlo. The move comes as Japan prepares for a prolonged coronavirus outbreak lasting through summer.

site_title: Online Pablo Picasso auction raises almost £5m
summary: A 10-day online auction by Sotheby's featuring almost 200 works by Pablo Picasso raised almost £5m, marking the first auction since the UK partially lifted its coronavirus lockdown rules in May 2020. The sale included 60 works from Marina Picasso's private collection.

site_title: ComfortDelGro, partners to bid for France metro projects
summary: ComfortDelGro, a Singaporean transport group, has entered into a collaboration agreement with RATP Dev and Alstom to jointly bid for the Grand Paris Express (GPE) greenfield metro projects in France. The group aims to expand its rail capabilities beyond Singapore. Through its newly set-up subsidiary ComfortDelGro Transit Pte Ltd, the company will participate in the bid for Lines 16 and 17 of the GPE project, covering 200 km of automated metro. This move is seen as a significant step in ComfortDelGro's vision to grow its rail portfolio globally.

site_title: Hackers planning phishing attack with fake MOM e-mails: cybersecurity firm
summary: Hackers plan a phishing attack targeting over five million people and businesses in six countries, including Singapore, Japan, and the US, with fake Ministry of Manpower (MOM) e-mails promising additional subsidies. The attack, planned by the Lazarus Group, aims to capitalize on governments' fiscal support to individuals and businesses during the pandemic. Cybersecurity firm Cyfirma warned of the threat, urging businesses to be cautious of spoofed e-mails.

images.alt_text: Hackers could target Singapore businesses on Sunday with a spoofed Ministry of Manpower (MOM) email promising additional subsidies for each of their employees, a cybersecurity group warned on Thursday.

site_title: Singapore family office hires seven to manage rich Asian assets
summary: Singapore-based family office Kamet Capital Partners has hired seven new staff, bringing its total headcount to 25, to manage over $1 billion in assets for wealthy Asian clients. The new recruits include a portfolio manager and analysts from Rockpool Capital and Mizuho Asset Management. Kamet's growth underscores the boom in Singapore's family-office industry, which has attracted billionaires such as James Dyson and Haidilao International Holding's Shu Ping. The firm plans to invest in a healthcare business in Thailand and is expanding its administrative team to support its growing client base.

site_title: Singapore shares open lower on Friday; STI down 0.6%
summary: Singapore stocks fell 0.6% on Friday, with the Straits Times Index (STI) slipping to 2,650.57, due to resurgent Covid-19 infections in the US and Beijing. Key losers included Singtel, Singapore Airlines, and Singapore Press Holdings, while UOB, DBS, and OCBC also declined. Meanwhile, Tokyo stocks opened higher on Friday, and US stocks finished little changed, as investors weighed jobless claims against monetary stimulus.

site_title: Oil edges up on Opec output cut compliance; pandemic still weighs
summary: Oil prices rose slightly as Opec and its allies reviewed record oil supply cuts, settling at $41.51 for Brent crude and $38.84 for US West Texas Intermediate. Despite this, concerns about additional coronavirus cases in the US and China kept prices in check. Analysts expect more Opec compliance, citing coronavirus fears.

site_title: Australia under broad cyberattack from 'state' actor: prime minister
summary: Australia's Prime Minister Scott Morrison warned that the country is under a broad cyberattack from a "state-based actor" targeting government, public services, and businesses, with suspicions falling on China. The attacks, described as "malicious" and targeting sensitive institutions, have raised alarm bells, particularly with Australia's medical facilities already under strain due to the coronavirus pandemic. Morrison declined to name the culprit, but China has previously denied involvement and warned Australia against criticizing its foreign policies.

site_title: Tiong Seng performance hit by 'circuit breaker'; says road to recovery 'long and challenging'
summary: Tiong Seng Holdings, a Singaporean construction and property developer, has reported a significant impact from the country's "circuit-breaker" measures, which temporarily ceased its construction and engineering projects, resulting in no revenue except from essential works. The company's road to recovery is described as "long and challenging," but its investments in construction technologies are expected to aid in quick mobilization of resources as operations resume. Tiong Seng has a "healthy cash position" of about S$59 million and does not expect material uncertainties concerning its debt obligations.

site_title: Tokyo: Stocks open higher on Friday
summary: Tokyo stocks opened higher on Friday, with the Nikkei 225 index up 0.68% or 152.52 points at 22,507.98. Investors weighed concerns over a second wave of coronavirus infections and financial support from central banks and governments. The broader Topix index also edged up 0.27%.

images.alt_text: Tokyo stocks opened higher on Friday in nervous trade as investors weighed worries over a second wave of coronavirus infection and financial support by central banks and governments.

site_title: PM Johnson tells Macron: Brexit talks cannot stretch into autumn
summary: British Prime Minister Boris Johnson told French President Emmanuel Macron that it's unlikely Brexit talks can be extended into autumn, according to a statement from Johnson's office. The UK and EU agreed to intensify talks in July, but Johnson emphasized that prolonged negotiations are not necessary. This move aims to avoid prolonging the negotiations, which could impact the UK's ability to move forward with other priorities.

site_title: Google giving US$1b in ads to non-profits this year
summary: Google has increased its non-profit advertising funding to $1 billion this year, a $200 million boost from last year. The additional funding will support groups addressing COVID-19 and racial injustice. This is part of Google's ongoing efforts, which also include a $275 million commitment to help black artists on YouTube and $100 million to combat systemic racism. Google's Ad Grants program, launched in 2003, provides up to $10,000 in free ads per month to non-profits.

site_title: Good Food Hunting
summary:

site_title: Singapore fintech wants to take corporate loan trading into digital future
summary: Singapore-based fintech iLex aims to transform the manual corporate loan trading market into a digital platform. With seed funding from strategic investors, the startup plans to launch its platform in October, targeting banks, hedge funds, and other financial institutions. The platform will automate loan syndication and trade execution, reducing costs and operational risks. iLex seeks to cater to both primary and secondary markets, providing insights and pricing tools to users, and has partnered with IHS Markit to facilitate multi-bookrunner syndications and analytics.

site_title: China pledges continued support but warns of liquidity hangover
summary: China's central bank governor, Yi Gang, pledged continued financial support to help the economy recover from the coronavirus pandemic. However, he warned that the monetary stimulus could add to debt risks and may need to be withdrawn at some point. China's economic fundamentals remain sound, with financial markets stable and financing costs guided lower. New loans are expected to reach a record 20 trillion yuan this year, and total social financing could increase by over 30 trillion yuan. Policymakers are balancing the need for stimulus with the risk of debt buildup.

site_title: UK says EU trade deal will be difficult if no progress before October
summary: Britain warned the EU that concluding a Brexit free trade deal by the end of the year will be difficult unless significant progress is made by October. Minister for the Cabinet Office Michael Gove stated that talks have stalled on EU fishing access, British compliance with EU rules, and customs arrangements for Northern Ireland. French President Emmanuel Macron will hold talks with Prime Minister Boris Johnson in London, aiming to intensify negotiations. A deal would require ratification by both sides, a process that could take several months.

site_title: Biden to spend US$15m campaign advertisement on racial unrest
summary: US President Joe Biden's campaign will spend $15 million on advertisements addressing racial unrest, following his recent address in Philadelphia. The ads will feature his stance on not "trafficking in fear and division," referencing President Trump's comments on the 2017 Charlottesville white supremacist rally. Additionally, the campaign will highlight essential workers during the pandemic, emphasizing the need for fair pay.

site_title: Sterling stays low despite Bank of England's bond boost
summary: The Bank of England increased its bond-buying by £100 billion to support the UK's coronavirus-hit economy, keeping its benchmark interest rate at 0.1%. Sterling briefly rose against the US dollar and euro but remained 0.4% down against both currencies. Economists expected a £100 billion increase, but some analysts, such as ING Bank, predicted a larger boost. The decision is seen as a defensive move, and uncertainty around a UK-EU trade deal is expected to continue to impact the pound.

site_title: Last-chance takeaway treats
summary: Fine dining restaurants in a major city are discontinuing their takeaway services, forcing customers to dine in instead. The decision comes as dining in resumes after a pandemic-induced hiatus. Several popular eateries have announced the end of their delivery services, leaving customers to adapt to a new reality of having to physically visit restaurants. The discontinuations are set to occur by the weekend or while supplies last.

images.alt_text: Left: Nouri collaborates with Swee Choon for this weekend; Right: Esora's Japanese pork sando; Les Amis's quiche has a buttery shortcrust pastry base.
Les Amis's quiche has a buttery shortcrust pastry base.

site_title: Olam International secures US$250m sustainability-linked loan
summary: Olam International has secured a US$250 million sustainability-linked loan with interest margins tied to key performance indicators (KPIs). The revolving-credit facility consists of tranches for one, two, and three years, and will be used for general corporate purposes. This is Olam's third sustainability-linked loan, following similar deals in 2020 and 2019. The KPIs for this facility involve Olam's support of farmers, food systems, communities, and the environment, which will be independently assessed by Ernst & Young.

site_title: Pandemic Keepsakes
summary: Krayon's new watch model, "Anywhere," is a "hyper complication" that indicates the time of sunset and sunrise anywhere in the world. The watch, launched during the pandemic, may become a collectible due to its association with a significant time in history. Krayon's founder, Remi Maillat, designed the watch with a personal "ephemeris" that tracks the positions of heavenly bodies, aiming to capture the connection between humans and nature. The watch features a new in-house hand-wound movement and comes in a 39mm white or rose gold case.

site_title: How Covid-19 is changing consumer patterns in SE-Asia
summary: Covid-19 has accelerated the shift towards online consumer behavior in South-east Asia, with digital purchases and online basket sizes increasing substantially. A study of 8,600 consumers in six countries found 30% increased online spending, while 47% reduced offline purchases. Companies that adapt quickly to these changes will thrive, with examples including Heineken Vietnam's online innovations and Grab's redeployment of drivers to deliver food and essential supplies. Flexibility and a focus on consumer needs will be key to survival in the post-pandemic landscape.

site_title: As online brokerages burgeon, MAS warns against unlicensed ones
summary: Singapore's Monetary Authority (MAS) warns investors to deal only with licensed online brokerages, as some tout lower or zero commission rates without being authorized to operate in the country. Investment platforms like eToro, which offers commission-free trading, do not have a Capital Markets Services (CMS) licence, despite being regulated by the Australian Securities and Investments Commission (ASIC). MAS strongly encourages consumers to deal with regulated entities, as they will forgo protection and face risks such as fraud. Licensed brokerages like Tiger Brokers (Singapore) and TD Ameritrade Singapore offer lower fees and are authorized by the MAS.

images.alt_text: MAS and CAD jointly launched the probe on Samtrade FX for potential offences under local securities laws.

site_title: When crisis calls
summary: Covid-19 has put small and medium-sized enterprises (SMEs) through a crisis, with business leaders adapting to managing operations from home while staying connected with employees. Experts discuss the need for leadership in uncertain times, with topics including digital transformation, investor protection, and managing complexity in mergers and acquisitions. Meanwhile, Singapore's economy is navigating the pandemic's impact, with the government moving to Phase Two and companies like DBS appointing a new COO. Leadership development is also being tracked as a key factor in Singapore's global competitiveness.

site_title: COE bidding to resume in uncertain market
summary: Singapore's Certificate of Entitlement (COE) bidding exercises will resume from July 6, with 8,737 COEs up for bidding. The accumulated quota of 19,940, suspended since April 7, will be gradually returned to the market over the next 12 months. A third of the quota, 6,494 COEs, will be returned from July to September, while the remaining 12,996 certificates will be returned from October 2020 to June 2021. The Land Transport Authority aims to ensure sufficient supply and long-term market stability.

site_title: Colgate reviewing Chinese toothpaste brand Darlie amid debate on racial inequality
summary: Colgate-Palmolive is reviewing its Chinese toothpaste brand Darlie amid a US debate on racial inequality. The brand, previously known as Darkie, features a smiling man in a top hat and a name that translates to "black person toothpaste" in Chinese. Colgate has made substantial changes to the brand's name, logo, and packaging over the years. The review comes after PepsiCo dropped its Aunt Jemima logo, prompting other brands to reassess their products. Colgate is working with its partner to further evolve the brand, including its name.

site_title: Alibaba Pictures Group plans to delist in Singapore and trade only in Hong Kong
summary: Alibaba Pictures Group, a dual-listed media company, has received approval to delist from the Singapore Exchange (SGX) mainboard.
