The shares will be traded only on the Stock Exchange of Hong Kong, citing lower trading volume and improved cost-effectiveness. The company will notify investors at least three months prior to the delisting and cover transfer fees for shareholders. The SGX is not objecting to the move as long as the company meets requirements. This move aims to increase shareholder value in the long term.

site_title: Bjorn Lee, CEO of MindFi.co
summary: Bjorn Lee, CEO of MindFi.co, credits his experience with stress-induced chest pains at 29 with leading him to start the mental wellbeing company in 2017. After a silent retreat in India, Lee meditates daily and founded MindFi, a mindfulness app with tens of thousands of users, mostly in Asia Pacific. The app offers short, habit-friendly sessions and unique features like focus mode and haptic breathing. The COVID-19 pandemic has accelerated the app's growth, with a 250% increase in users and more companies signing up for its annual subscription plans. Mindfulness has helped Lee become a more sensitive and empathetic leader and person, allowing him to manage his emotions better and recover from stressful situations faster.

site_title: China races to prevent virus second wave as outbreaks surge globally
summary: China imposed travel restrictions on nearly half a million people near Beijing to contain a fresh coronavirus outbreak, as deaths surged globally and the world economy was hit. The outbreak, linked to a wholesale market, has raised concerns of a second wave in China, with 158 cases reported in the past 24 hours. The global toll has surpassed 450,000, with rising cases in Latin America, South Asia, and the US, where daily deaths dropped below 1,000 for a seventh day.

site_title: BP raises nearly US$12b in hybrid bonds issue
summary: BP raised nearly US$12 billion in hybrid bonds, issuing US$5 billion, 4.75 billion euros, and £1.25 billion in multiple currencies. This is the company's first hybrid bond issue, allowing for less strain on its balance sheet. The fundraising comes as BP writes off up to US$17.5 billion from asset values, citing low energy demand due to the Covid-19 crisis and plans to shift to renewable energy. The company aims to reduce its debt burden and increase pressure to reduce its dividend.

site_title: US weekly jobless claims remain high as second wave of layoffs hits industries
summary: US initial jobless claims fell to 1.508 million for the week ended June 13, down from 1.566 million in the prior week. The 11th straight weekly drop pushed claims further away from a record 6.867 million in late March. Despite a record 2.5 million jobs hired in May, economists say the economy remains fragile due to weak demand and supply chain issues, with Federal Reserve Chair Jerome Powell citing "significant uncertainty" about the recovery. Economists attribute the high claims to layoffs in various industries, including manufacturing, retail, and oil and gas production.

site_title: Best World International must hold FY2019 AGM by June 29: Acra
summary: Best World International, a mainboard-listed skincare company, must hold its FY2019 Annual General Meeting (AGM) by June 29, according to the Accounting and Corporate Regulatory Authority (Acra). The company had requested more time to convene the meeting and lodge its annual return but received a final rejection. Best World will finalize its audited FY2019 financial statements and annual report after the FY2018 AGM and convene the FY2019 AGM by the deadline. The company will also pay composition amounts for the delays in holding the AGMs and lodging annual returns.

site_title: Anger surges in India over deadly border brawl with China
summary: A wave of anti-Chinese anger is sweeping India following the deaths of 20 Indian soldiers in a brawl with Chinese troops along the disputed border. The Indian government is reviewing contracts with Chinese companies, and crowds are smashing Chinese-made televisions in the street. A retired army major called for a boycott of Chinese goods, while troops are preparing for a possible escalation. Prime Minister Narendra Modi has signaled that India will not back down, but is also exploring economic and diplomatic strategies to contain China. Protests have broken out across India to boycott Chinese goods, and the Indian government is preparing to cancel a huge railway contract with a Chinese company.

site_title: Taiwan central bank cuts growth outlook, holds fire on rates
summary: Taiwan's central bank maintained its policy rate at 1.125% despite global central banks' efforts to loosen monetary settings. The bank cut its 2020 growth forecast to 1.52% due to the coronavirus pandemic's impact on the trade-reliant economy. Exports fell for a third straight month, and the central bank lowered its core inflation forecast to 0.36%. The decision was seen as a cautious move to support economic recovery, with the bank expecting stronger growth in the second half of the year.

site_title: Sen Yue independent review may have found ties between group chairman and customers
summary: Singapore Exchange Regulation (SGX RegCo) has issued a notice of compliance to Sen Yue Holdings, a waste-management group, after an independent review suggested links between the chairman and some customers. The review, conducted by Foo Kon Tan Advisory Services, raised concerns over long credit repayment periods, low or negative margins, and the collectability of debts. The audit committee must now determine whether these ties breached Catalist listing rules and establish the recoverability of outstanding accounts receivables. The committee has recommended halting trades with these customers until all investigations are completed.

site_title: STI falls 0.15%, regional markets go into profit-taking mode
summary: Singapore shares fell 0.15% on Thursday, with the Straits Times Index (STI) closing at 2,665.66 points. The decline was attributed to resurgent Covid-19 cases in the US and Beijing, prompting traders to be cautious. Medtecs International surged 16.36% to S$0.32, while Jardine Matheson rose 3.03% to US$44.56. Venture Corp rose 2.73% to S$16.16, with analysts expecting a boost from its medical-products division. Regional markets also reflected profit-taking, with the KLSE and Nikkei falling.

site_title: No mid-year bonus for civil servants for first time since 2009; year-end bonus still up in the air
summary: Singapore's government has decided not to give civil servants a mid-year bonus for the first time since 2009, citing the economic crisis caused by the COVID-19 pandemic. Senior public officers will also take a one-time pay cut, while the government is considering a year-end bonus for lower-wage workers if the economic situation improves. The decision was made in consultation with unions and takes into account the National Wages Council's recommendation to prioritize lower-wage workers.

site_title: WHO hopes for hundreds of millions of vaccine doses this year, 2 billion next year
summary: The World Health Organization (WHO) aims to produce hundreds of millions of coronavirus vaccine doses this year and 2 billion doses by the end of 2021, according to chief scientist Soumya Swaminathan. The WHO is drawing up plans to allocate doses to frontline workers, vulnerable individuals, and those in high-transmission settings. With 10 potential vaccines undergoing human trials, countries have begun making deals with pharmaceutical companies to secure doses before their effectiveness is proven. Genetic analysis shows the new coronavirus has not mutated in ways that would alter illness severity, giving hope for a successful vaccine rollout.

site_title: MG HS review: Journey to the best
summary: MG's HS is considered the best car in Singapore for under S$100,000, according to a review. The vehicle boasts a family-size SUV design with coherent styling and a storied past from the MG brand, known for its dashing roadsters. The HS is made by a carmaker with a future, making it an attractive option for those looking for a reliable and affordable vehicle. Its features and performance make it a standout in its class, with a potential to outshine competitors in the market.

site_title: Daily Debrief: What Happened Today
summary: COE bidding resumes on July 6, following the "circuit breaker" period. There will be no mid-year bonus for civil servants for the first time since 2009, but the year-end bonus is still uncertain. Singapore's general election guidelines include special constituency broadcasts and restrictions on physical rallies. The Monetary Authority of Singapore (MAS) approved 14 digital bank applicants, with 5 being full banks. The Singapore Fintech Association launched a digital platform for corporate loan market automation. The Straits Times Index (STI) fell 0.15% on Thursday.

site_title: STI falls 0.15% on Thursday; regional markets in profit-taking mode
summary: Singapore shares fell 0.15% on Thursday, with the Straits Times Index closing at 2,665.66. Regional markets also declined, with the KLSE down 1.40% and the Nikkei down 0.45%. Investors are cautious amid resurgent Covid-19 cases in the US and Beijing, and uncertainty over trade friction between the US and European countries.

site_title: OCBC branches to fully reopen over next two weeks
summary: OCBC Bank will reopen all branches over the next two weeks as Singapore continues to ease Covid-19-related restrictions. Five branches will reopen on Friday, followed by the rest of the branches over the next two weeks. Customers can resume in-person meetings with financial services staff, who will wear face masks, and can also use digital platforms for day-to-day banking needs. The bank will continue to offer virtual financial advisory services via video conferencing.

site_title: Budgeting for cyber security - count the costs
summary: A successful cyber security strategy can be measured by the absence of damaging cyber attacks, which can be difficult to quantify. To effectively budget for cyber security, organisations should attach real numbers to hypothetical situations, such as the cost of a successful breach. Conducting a comprehensive cyber security risk assessment using industry standards like ISO 27001 can help identify gaps and vulnerabilities, and inform a strategic roadmap for risk mitigation. By leveraging industry research and best practices, organisations can make more realistic and appropriate budgeting decisions to mitigate cyber risk.

site_title: Prudential sells Jackson equity stake to Apollo-backed Athene for US$500m
summary: Prudential has sold a minority stake in its US business, Jackson, to Apollo-backed Athene Holding for $500 million. The deal aims to create an independent US business and is the first phase of Prudential's plan. Athene will fully reinsure $27.6 billion of Jackson's in-force annuity portfolio, increasing the risk-based capital cover ratio by 80 percentage points. The investment is expected to close in July and Prudential will continue to evaluate other options, including a minority initial public offering.

site_title: Indian PM Modi opens coal mining to private sector
summary: Indian Prime Minister Narendra Modi has launched the auction of 41 coal mines, aiming to make India a net exporter of coal and utilizing its fourth-largest coal reserves. The move is expected to attract investments and boost production, with the government offering reduced upfront payments and relaxed payment schedules. The auction is part of a plan to spend 500 billion rupees on creating infrastructure around coal mining, with a target of gasifying 100 million tonnes of coal by 2030. The coal price will be linked to a national coal index, and bidding is expected to begin in August.

site_title: Reimagining the future of residential real estate
summary: The COVID-19 crisis has prompted a reevaluation of the future of residential real estate in Asia, particularly in Asean countries. The shift to remote work and e-commerce has led to increased adoption of PropTech, enabling virtual tours and online purchases. However, this may lead to a diminished role for real estate agencies as middlemen. Decentralization and urban dispersal could also change the demand for homes, with cities focusing on sustainable development and affordable housing. Home ownership rates in Asean countries, such as Vietnam and Singapore, are high, but affordability is a growing concern. Securitization of residential property through Reits could provide households with liquidity and risk management benefits.

site_title: Wirecard shares plunge 50% as it delays results again
summary: German payments company Wirecard delayed the publication of its 2019 annual report, causing its shares to plummet 50% as it warned the delay could trigger loan covenants. Auditor EY found insufficient evidence for 1.9 billion euros in cash balances on trust accounts, which Wirecard described as "spurious". The company cited indications that the balances were provided to deceive the auditor. The delay and resulting financial concerns have significant implications for Wirecard's financial health and future prospects.

site_title: BlackRock chief ranks China among biggest opportunities
summary: BlackRock CEO Larry Fink stated that China remains a top growth opportunity for the company despite trade tensions and the virus outbreak. Fink expressed optimism about the US-China relationship and global economic recovery, citing encouraging signs of stabilization. BlackRock is expanding in China to tap its trillion-dollar wealth market, with plans to set up wholly-owned mutual fund firms and joint ventures with local banks. The company aims to capitalize on China's fast-growing wealth management industry, which could reach $3.4 trillion in retail funds by 2023.

site_title: Temasek, CapitaLand, NTWU to pilot table separators in some food courts, canteens
summary: Temasek Foundation, CapitaLand, and the National Transport Workers Union (NTWU) are partnering to install tabletop separators in over 500 dining tables at participating outlets in Singapore, starting with Kopitiam and Food Junction in CapitaLand malls, and NTWU staff canteens for frontline transport workers. The move aims to promote social distancing during Phase Two of Singapore's reopening.

site_title: Hong Kong: Stocks finish lower
summary: Hong Kong stocks closed 0.1% lower on Thursday, following a two-day advance, as traders weighed signs of a second wave of virus infections against stimulus support. The Hang Seng Index dropped 16.47 points to 24,464.94.

site_title: Indonesia central bank makes year's 3rd rate cut, trims GDP outlook
summary: Indonesia's central bank, Bank Indonesia, cut its benchmark rate by 25 basis points to 4.25% for the third time this year, aiming to support the country's economy amid the pandemic. The move trimmed the forecast for 2020 GDP growth to 0.9-1.9% from 2.3%. Governor Perry Warjiyo pledged to keep monetary instruments "accommodative" and hinted at further easing. The decision came after the finance minister warned of recession risks, with a 3.1% contraction in the second quarter expected.

site_title: MPA to prioritise crew change for Singapore-registered ships; ease pleasure craft restrictions
summary: The Maritime and Port Authority of Singapore (MPA) has announced that it will prioritize crew changes for Singapore-registered ships, allowing them to carry out crew changes regardless of purpose, as long as they meet requirements. This move aims to address challenges faced by ships due to the Covid-19 outbreak, including expired crew contracts and repatriation of seafarers. The MPA's decision is expected to ease restrictions on pleasure craft and facilitate smoother crew changes for the shipping industry.

site_title: Malaysia: Shares close lower on Thursday
summary: Malaysia's shares closed lower on Thursday, with the FTSE Bursa Malaysia Kuala Lumpur Composite Index down 21.41 points to 1,504.91. Losers outnumbered gainers 685 to 300, with a total of 5.122 billion lots traded worth RM3.872 billion.

site_title: Hospitality startup K Hotel raises S$2m in seed funding
summary: K Hotel, a Singapore-based hospitality firm with 300 beds across six properties, raised S$2 million in seed funding led by Noel Neo, who joined as chief financial officer. The funding will be used to acquire new hospitality projects and fund expansion. K Hotel targets budget travelers and recently provided discounted-rate accommodation to stranded foreigners due to Covid-19 travel restrictions. The startup plans to raise S$5 million for its Series A round, with Neo expecting to generate attractive rates of return on investment in the recovery from the pandemic.

site_title: Germany wants to bolster EU shaken by pandemic: Merkel
summary: Germany's Chancellor Angela Merkel says the coronavirus pandemic has exposed the weakness of the European Union, emphasizing the need for solidarity and economic prosperity among its 27 member states. Merkel aims to promote these values during Germany's EU presidency, focusing on agreeing on a multi-year budget and a recovery fund to address the bloc's worst recession since World War Two, which has resulted in over 100,000 COVID-19 deaths. Merkel laments the initial "rather national and not European" response to the pandemic.

site_title: Firms must reinvent themselves so they are fit for rebound
summary: Business leaders must adapt to the post-Covid-19 world by identifying structural changes, ideating new strategies, and developing comprehensive plans to emerge stronger. The pandemic has accelerated digitalization, virtualization, and data-driven decision-making, forcing businesses to rethink their models. Key trends include virtual working, real estate reimagining, and cloud education. To thrive, Singapore and its businesses must collaborate, innovate, and adopt forward-thinking ideas, such as regulatory sandboxes, "star alliances" of locations, and redefined spaces. By embracing change, businesses can create a new normal that benefits both the organization and the economy.

site_title: Hong Kong Disneyland reopens to masked guests in scorching heat
summary: Hong Kong Disneyland reopened on June 18, 2020, with about 100 visitors under health restrictions to combat the spread of COVID-19. The park had been closed since late January, and guests were required to wear masks. The reopening comes after the city's successful early measures to control the virus, with only four reported deaths. The attendance limit for Hong Kong Disneyland was not specified, but the company had initially sold tickets at less than one-third of full capacity at Shanghai Disneyland. The reopening is part of the entertainment giant's efforts to keep visitors safe amid the pandemic.

site_title: Eiffel Tower to re-open, but visitors to take stairs
summary: The Eiffel Tower is set to re-open on June 25 after a three-month shutdown due to the Covid-19 lockdown. To minimize the risk of infection, visitors will be limited to the second level and can only access the tower via stairs, with elevators initially closed. A one-way traffic system and face coverings will also be in place. The initial visitor base is expected to be domestic, with foreign travel still recovering from pandemic restrictions. The goal is to promote safe distances and ensure a secure environment for visitors.

site_title: New coronavirus cluster in Tuas workers dormitory
summary: A new coronavirus cluster was announced in Singapore, involving a dormitory at 10 Tech Park Crescent in Tuas, with two new cases confirmed on June 18. The cluster has four cases, linked to two previous cases, and includes four community cases. The Ministry of Health reported 257 new cases, bringing the total to 41,473. Migrant workers living in dormitories account for the remaining 253 cases. The cluster's average daily community cases have decreased, with 32,702 patients fully recovered and 225 in hospital.

site_title: Thai 2020 domestic car sales could fall by 30-50% as virus hits demand
summary: Thailand's domestic car sales are expected to drop 30-50% in 2020 due to the coronavirus, according to the Federation of Thai Industries. Sales may reach 700,000 or 500,000 units if the outbreak stays under control or continues locally. The industry accounts for 10% of GDP and provides 700,000 jobs, with car production forecasted at 1-1.4 million vehicles. A decline in production would reduce revenue by 300 billion baht.

site_title: Europe: Shares lose ground on concerns of second coronavirus wave
summary: European shares declined 0.4% due to concerns over a second coronavirus wave, driven by rising cases in China and US states. Fears of a swift recovery from the pandemic-led economic slump led investors to scale back on risk. Oil and gas, miners, and healthcare sectors were among the biggest decliners, while retailers gained. Despite this, some companies, such as Zalando, saw gains after reporting optimistic sales and profit forecasts.

site_title: China approves JPMorgan as first fully foreign-owned futures company
summary: China has approved JPMorgan as the first fully foreign-owned futures company, allowing the US bank to operate independently. This move is part of China's efforts to further open up the financial market. The approval comes after Beijing scrapped caps on foreign ownership in the futures industry last year. JPMorgan will now be able to bring in more qualified foreign shareholders, marking a significant shift in the country's financial landscape.

site_title: Hong Kong's 'rebel' tycoon Jimmy Lai has no regrets
summary: Hong Kong media tycoon Jimmy Lai, known for his pro-democracy views, says he has no regrets despite facing prosecution for participating in last year's rallies and criticism from Beijing. Lai, 72, believes he will be positive in prison and is willing to fight for Hong Kong's freedom. He criticizes Beijing's proposed national security law, calling it a "death knell" for the city, and fears for the safety of his journalists. Lai's publications, Apple Daily and Next magazine, remain pro-democracy, despite the risks, and he has no plans to moderate his views.

site_title: HKEX to launch green exchange promoting sustainable investments
summary: HKEX is launching Stage, a pioneering green exchange promoting sustainable investments in Asia. The exchange will serve as a data and information hub, increasing visibility and transparency of green finance across asset classes. Initially, it will provide a database of sustainable investment options available on Hong Kong's securities markets. The move aims to promote sustainable investments and increase accessibility for investors.

site_title: India to spend US$6.6b for jobs in villages
summary: India's federal government plans to spend US$6.6 billion on a 125-day jobs program in villages, providing employment to millions of migrant workers who left cities during the coronavirus lockdown. The program aims to create rural infrastructure and will be launched in 116 districts across six states, including Uttar Pradesh and Bihar, which are scheduled for elections. This is part of India's US$265 billion economic support package, which is aimed at preventing the country's first full-year contraction in over four decades.

site_title: France to apply digital tax this year whether US returns to negotiations or not
summary: France will implement its digital tax this year, regardless of whether the US returns to negotiations on the issue or not, Finance Minister Bruno Le Maire stated. The US withdrawal from talks on global tax rules for digital companies has been described by Le Maire as a "provocation." France, along with other European countries, has enacted taxes to collect more revenue from digital companies, which they argue pay too little tax in the countries where they operate. The European countries want a deal at the OECD as soon as possible.

site_title: SoftBank invests in startup Splyt in hunt for super app
summary: SoftBank invested $19.5 million in startup Splyt, aiming to build its own super app by integrating mobility options with other services. Splyt has helped integrate ride-hailing into apps like Alipay and Grab, and SoftBank will take a significant stake in the company. This deal follows SoftBank's acquisition of Line's chat app and its own payments app PayPay, positioning the company to control top contenders for a local super app. SoftBank's head of global business division, Daichi Nozaki, will join Splyt's board of directors.

site_title: Man charged for taking part in management of 7 companies while bankrupt: SPF
summary: A 47-year-old man has been charged in court for allegedly managing seven companies, including medical clinics and suppliers, while being an undischarged bankrupt from 2004 to 2017. He is accused of violating the Companies Act by taking part in company management without permission. The charges carry penalties of up to two years imprisonment, a fine of up to SGD 10,000, or both.

site_title: Hot stock: Medtecs shares rise 12% ahead of AGM
summary: Medtecs International Corporation's shares rose 12.7% to a high of 31 Singapore cents ahead of its annual general meeting on Friday. The counter was the most heavily traded on the Singapore Exchange, with 76.3 million shares changing hands. The company reported a 16-fold increase in net profit for the first quarter, driving a surge in shares last month. Shareholders will attend the meeting electronically due to coronavirus-related safeguards.

site_title: Fitch cuts India's outlook to 'negative'
summary: Fitch downgrades India's outlook to 'negative' due to the coronavirus pandemic's impact on the economy and a high public-debt burden. This move affects the country's growth outlook for 2020, despite maintaining its rating at 'BBB-'. The downgrade is attributed to the pandemic's weakening economic growth and challenges associated with India's high public debt.

site_title: Tokyo: Stocks close down on virus worries, higher yen
summary: Tokyo stocks fell 0.45% or 100.3 points to 22,355.46, with the Topix index slipping 0.25% or 4 points to 1,583.09, due to concerns over a second coronavirus wave and a stronger yen.

site_title: Beijing residents rush to coronavirus test clinics as emergency rules expand
summary: China's capital, Beijing, has mandated coronavirus tests for hundreds of thousands of people amid a surge of 158 infections linked to a wholesale food market. Residents must obtain a negative nucleic acid test result to travel, visit attractions, or return to work in food-handling industries. The city has tested over 350,000 people, with many more expected, putting a strain on the testing system. Officials say the measures are part of a "wartime" response to the outbreak, but supplies and testing capacity are being strained, with waiting times for voluntary tests stretching to weeks or months.

site_title: Australia: Shares down nearly 1% as dismal jobs data, virus relapse weigh
summary: Australian shares fell 0.92% to 5,936.8 points, weighed down by dismal jobs data and a spike in fresh Covid-19 cases. Unemployment rate jumped to its highest in about two decades, with employment in May plunging 227,700. Investors expect a gradual economic reopening to reverse job losses, but mining and material stocks declined 1.3% amid volatility in steel prices. New Zealand's economic growth contracted 1.6% in the March quarter, and new Covid-19 cases in both countries added to the downturn.

site_title: Reaching customers directly - an investment worth making in times of supply chain disruption
summary: Manufacturers in Southeast Asia are pivoting to direct-to-consumer (DTC) sales to maintain business continuity and strengthen customer loyalty amid supply chain disruptions. Software technology is crucial in supporting these new go-to-market models, enabling manufacturers to optimize relationships, configuration, product lifecycle management, and 3D printing. Investing in technology is vital for manufacturers to stay competitive, as it allows them to adapt to changing consumer trends, build customer intimacy, and ensure business continuity in uncertain times.

site_title: Top China Parliament body to review Hong Kong security legislation
summary: China's top Parliament body is set to review a draft of national security legislation for Hong Kong, which specifies four crimes and sets out punishments. The draft defines crimes such as separatist activity, state subversion, and collusion with foreign forces, and will be reviewed during a session in Beijing. This move comes amid ongoing tensions between China and Hong Kong.

images.alt_text: The top decision-making body of China's Parliament will review a draft of national security legislation for Hong Kong during a session in Beijing that began on Thursday, the official Xinhua news agency reported.

site_title: Singapore fintech offers one-stop electronic platform for corporate loan market
summary: Singapore-based fintech iLex has developed a digital platform to automate corporate loan syndication and trade execution, aiming to enhance efficiency and liquidity in the traditionally manual and relationships-based market. The startup has secured seed funding from strategic and fintech investors in France, Hong Kong, Singapore, and the US, with the exact amount not disclosed. This move seeks to bring the corporate loan market into the digital age, potentially disrupting the current reliance on roadshows, voice calls, and Rolodexes.

site_title: Chinese interest in Australian property shrinks as diplomatic rift grows
summary: Chinese buyer enquiries for Australian homes plummeted by 65% in May, the lowest in almost three years, as diplomatic tensions between the two countries escalate. The decline coincides with Canberra's push for a coronavirus origin investigation, drawing Beijing's rebuke and threats of economic reprisals. Mainland China's real estate investment in Australia has been a significant contributor to the country's economy, but a prolonged slump could spell trouble for the sector. Economists expect the diplomatic tensions to be resolved without major economic impact, but the situation remains uncertain.

site_title: Seoul: Shares fall on second virus wave worries
summary: South Korean shares fell 0.35% on Thursday as worries about a rise in coronavirus infections in the US and China, along with tensions with North Korea, dented market sentiment. The Kospi index closed at 2,133.48 points, down 7.57 points. Foreigners were net sellers of $159.27 million worth of shares. The decline comes amid concerns about a second wave of virus infections and escalating tensions with North Korea, following Pyongyang's recent actions.

site_title: Geely Automobile steps towards mainland China listing; Hong Kong shares surge
summary: Geely Automobile, a Zhejiang-based carmaker, has approved a preliminary proposal to list new renminbi shares on mainland China's Nasdaq-like Star board, sending its Hong Kong-listed shares up 7% on Thursday. The move aims to raise funds for "business development and general working capital" and may be linked to a planned merger with sister company Volvo Cars. Geely Automobile plans to list on the Shanghai Stock Exchange's Star board without converting existing shares, and the funds raised will be used for the Volvo merger, according to analysts.

site_title: Migrant workers to stay in dorms on rest days at start of Phase Two: MOM
summary: Singapore's Ministry of Manpower (MOM) has announced that migrant workers will stay within their dormitories on rest days during Phase Two of the country's reopening, starting June 19. This decision aims to minimize the risk of cross-infections with the general community. Up to 75,000 workers are now in cleared premises, and measures are being implemented to allow workers to leave dormitories for work in a safe manner. Employers must continue to provide food and daily necessities to their employees in the dormitories.

site_title: SingPost to reopen all post offices from Friday, except at airport
summary: SingPost to reopen all post offices, except the one at Changi Airport's Terminal 2, from Friday as Singapore enters Phase Two of its "circuit-breaker" easing. The airport post office will be relocated. Safe-distancing measures will be enforced, and customers are advised to check crowd levels and use self-service options. SingPost shares were trading flat after the announcement.

images.alt_text: Singapore Post will reopen all its post offices from Friday - except the one at Changi Airport's Terminal 2 - as the nation enters Phase Two of its "circuit-breaker" easing, it said on Thursday.

site_title: COE bidding to resume from July 6
summary: COE bidding exercises will resume in Singapore starting July 6, after being suspended since April due to the Covid-19 outbreak. The first exercise will have 8,737 COE quotas, with a total of 19,490 COE quotas accumulated from April to June to be gradually returned to the market over the next 12 months. One-third of the accumulated quota will be returned from July to September, and the remaining two-thirds from October to June 2021, to ensure long-term market stability and meet orders built up during the suspension period.

site_title: China could top Japan's LNG imports in 2020 as coronavirus cuts demand
summary: China is poised to surpass Japan as the world's largest liquefied natural gas (LNG) importer, according to Rystad's head of gas research. China imported 5.6 million tonnes of LNG in May, while Japan's imports fell to an 11-year low of 4.5 million tonnes. China's LNG imports are expected to continue, driven by the country's economic recovery from the coronavirus pandemic, while Japan's economy remains sluggish. This shift could give China a significant advantage in the global LNG market.

site_title: Special constituency broadcasts included in preliminary campaigning guidelines for GE during Covid-19
summary: Singapore's Elections Department has released preliminary guidelines for campaigning in the upcoming general election, which may be held during Phase Two of the country's reopening amid the Covid-19 pandemic. Physical rallies are prohibited, but candidates will receive television airtime, including special constituency broadcasts on Channel 5. Campaigning will be restricted to groups of no more than five persons, with safety measures in place, and candidates can also use the internet to campaign subject to regulations. The guidelines aim to protect public health and ensure voters have access to campaigning messages from all parties and candidates.

site_title: Red Dot United registration approved, says it is ready to contest general election
summary: A record 12 opposition parties, including Red Dot United, have been approved to contest the next general election in Singapore. Red Dot United, formed by former Progress Singapore Party members, is ready to field candidates despite being registered just a month ago. Its secretary-general, Ravi Philemon, confirmed the party's readiness for the election, stating it is "even more ready" now that registration is complete.

site_title: Broker's take: UOB Kay Hian recommends profit-taking on SIA, downgrades to 'sell'
summary: UOB Kay Hian downgraded Singapore Airlines (SIA) to "sell" from "buy" and lowered its target price to S$3.80 from S$4.35, recommending profit-taking due to significant uncertainty over airline traffic decline and cash burn. The brokerage raised its year-on-year traffic decline estimate to 58% and increased its fiscal 2021 net loss estimate to S$1.64 billion. SIA shares were trading at S$4.09, down S$0.04 or 1% at the time of the downgrade.

site_title: Australian regulator says Google's US$2.1b Fitbit deal could harm competition
summary: Australia's antitrust regulator, the ACCC, has expressed concerns that Google's planned $2.1 billion acquisition of Fitbit may harm competition in health and online advertising markets due to the potential consolidation of user data. The deal could give Google a more comprehensive set of user data, potentially limiting entry for rivals. The regulator will announce its outcome on August 13. This move comes amid ongoing tensions between Google and the Australian government over internet company data usage rules.

site_title: China 'resolutely opposes' G-7 statement on Hong Kong security law
summary: China strongly opposed comments from G-7 foreign ministers urging it to reconsider its proposed Hong Kong national security law, which critics see as a threat to the city's freedoms and autonomy. The law aims to restore stability in Hong Kong, but Beijing's determination to introduce it remains unwavering, according to a senior Chinese official. The G-7 had called for China to "reconsider this decision" due to "grave concerns" about the law's impact on Hong Kong's rights and freedoms.

site_title: Australia, NZ dollars dented as data disappoints
summary: The Australian and New Zealand dollars declined due to disappointing job data and economic contraction. Australia lost 227,000 jobs in May, exceeding expectations, while the unemployment rate rose to 7.1%. New Zealand's economy shrank by the most in three decades in the first quarter. Economists predict a long recovery for the labor market and expect GDP to fall by 20% in Q2. Despite this, central banks have taken measures to mitigate the impact, with the RBA keeping interest rates near zero and the RBNZ cutting rates and launching a bond buying program.

site_title: IEA sets out US$3t energy sector recovery plan to spur growth, cut emissions
summary: The International Energy Agency (IEA) has set out a US$1 trillion energy sector recovery plan to spur economic growth and cut carbon emissions over the next three years. The plan, which requires a 0.7% annual investment of global GDP, aims to boost global economic growth by 1.1 percentage points a year, save or create 9 million jobs, and reduce greenhouse gas emissions by 4.5 billion tonnes. The plan integrates energy policies into government responses to the economic fallout from the coronavirus crisis, accelerating the deployment of clean energy technologies.

site_title: Trump says US will not lock down again amid rising coronavirus cases
summary: US President Donald Trump stated the country will not close businesses again due to rising coronavirus cases. Despite rising infections in 14 states, Trump and his advisors attribute the spike to increased testing. The US has already closed businesses and resulted in millions of Americans losing their jobs. Trump's comments contradict his previous emphasis on the economy, which is central to his re-election bid.

images.alt_text: President Donald Trump said on Wednesday the United States would not close businesses again as several states reported rising numbers of new coronavirus infections.

site_title: South Korea's nuclear envoy visits US as tensions flare with North Korea
summary: South Korea's chief nuclear negotiator, Lee Do-hoon, visited the US amid tensions with North Korea, following the destruction of a joint liaison office by Pyongyang. Lee met with US officials, including Deputy Secretary of State Stephen Biegun, to assess the situation and discuss responses. Tensions escalated after North Korea declared an end to dialogue with South Korea, criticizing South Korean President Moon Jae-in for failing to implement a 2018 peace accord. The visit comes as efforts to restart inter-Korean economic projects stalled due to international sanctions.

images.alt_text: South Korea's chief nuclear negotiator will hold talks with officials in Washington on Thursday amid flaring tensions with North Korea after Pyongyang blew up an inter-Korean liaison office and threatened military action.

site_title: ADB sees developing Asia barely growing in 2020 due to pandemic
summary: The Asian Development Bank (ADB) has revised its growth forecast for developing Asia in 2020 to 0.1% due to the COVID-19 pandemic's impact on economic activity. The bank maintains a 6.2% growth forecast for next year. Lockdowns and shuttered businesses have led to a freeze in domestic demand, causing significant economic contraction. The ADB's revised forecast reflects the pandemic's ongoing effects on Asian economies.

site_title: Asia: Markets drop into the red as traders take step back
summary: Asia markets dropped on Thursday as investors took a breather after a two-day rally, amid concerns about a new wave of virus infections and the impact of US presidential elections. Tokyo, Hong Kong, and Sydney fell, with Sydney losing 1.6% and Wellington down more than 1%. Analysts warn that markets may be due for a pull-back unless a major event, such as vaccine development, drives higher prices. The narrative around policy stimulus and economic data losing its sway has also contributed to the decline.

site_title: Syrup brand Aunt Jemima to get new name as PepsiCo concedes 'racial stereotype'
summary: PepsiCo has announced plans to phase out the Aunt Jemima brand, citing its origins as rooted in racially problematic tropes. The company will remove the image of a Black woman from its packaging and marketing, and the brand's name will be changed. This move comes as part of a corporate reckoning on institutionalized racism, following nationwide protests sparked by the police killing of George Floyd. Other brands, including Uncle Ben's and Mrs. Butterworth's, are also under scrutiny and may undergo similar changes.

site_title: Chinese ecommerce giant JD.com jumps 5.75% on Hong Kong debut
summary: JD.com, a Chinese e-commerce giant, made its Hong Kong debut, jumping 5.75% on its initial public offering that raised almost US$4 billion, the world's second-largest this year. The firm opened at HK$239, surpassing its listing price of HK$226.

site_title: Malaysia seeks to amend 1MDB charges against Goldman Sachs
summary: Malaysian prosecutors are seeking to amend charges against three Goldman Sachs units in the 1MDB case, alleging the bank misled investors about misappropriated funds. The US bank faces fines of over $2.7 billion and the return of $600 million in fees. The case, which has been on hold due to the pandemic, is set to resume on September 4. Goldman Sachs lawyers argue the proposed changes would be substantial, while prosecutors seek to hold the bank liable for the alleged wrongdoing.

site_title: China cental bank to keep liquidity ample, weigh policy exit strategy
summary: China's central bank governor, Yi Gang, stated that the country will maintain ample liquidity in the second half of the year. However, the bank should consider withdrawing policy measures to counter the pandemic's effects. China's economic fundamentals remain sound, and financial markets are stable. New loans are expected to reach nearly $3.94 trillion, and total social financing could increase by over $30 trillion. The People's Bank of China will not monetize fiscal deficits and will not adopt negative interest rates. The economy is expected to continue recovering, but it will take time for global supply chains to recover.

site_title: Lyft says all rides will be in electric cars by end-2030
summary: Lyft commits to making 100% of its trips in electric vehicles by the end of 2030, citing a business advantage and consumer demand for cleaner vehicles. The company aims to leverage partnerships with carmakers, policymakers, and charging networks to achieve its goal. However, it will require the cooperation of its drivers, who currently drive traditional cars. Lyft's co-founder, John Zimmer, frames the transition as an opportunity to "re-evaluate everything" and notes that electric vehicles have lower operating costs and simpler maintenance.

site_title: Facebook's deal with Jio under India antitrust review
summary: India's antitrust watchdog is reviewing Facebook's $5.7 billion investment in Reliance Industries' digital assets, which could give the US giant a foothold in the country's fast-growing internet market. The Competition Commission of India is examining whether the deal could lead to misuse of data and whether it alters the competitive landscape. The regulator is also considering new parameters for assessing mergers and acquisitions. A decision is expected within 210 days, but no timeline has been disclosed.

site_title: China says it must improve hygiene in markets after Beijing outbreak
summary: China's Communist Party has urged the government to improve hygiene standards and minimize health risks at markets, particularly after a recent coronavirus outbreak in Beijing's Xinfadi food centre, infecting over 100 people. The resurgence of Covid-19 highlights the need for urgent action to address low market hygiene standards and vulnerabilities in the food supply chain. The party's top disciplinary body emphasized the importance of sanitation and minimizing health risks to prevent wider contagion.

site_title: New US layoffs show mixed impact of small business loans
summary: US layoffs by small businesses receiving small business loans under the Paycheck Protection Programme show a mixed impact. Companies like Arrangements Abroad, which secured a $597,000 loan, laid off employees despite receiving financial assistance. The loan allowed the company to pay salaries for a couple of months but ultimately led to job losses. This highlights the challenges faced by small businesses in recovering from the coronavirus pandemic, and the need for more effective support to prevent layoffs and support business growth.

site_title: Gold steady as virus cases rise, stronger US dollar limits upside
summary: Gold prices remained steady at $1,726.69 per ounce, as investors maintained concerns over a potential economic slowdown due to rising COVID-19 cases in the US and China. The strengthening US dollar limited gold's appeal, while a rise in the dollar index held firm against its rivals. Meanwhile, the Bank of England is expected to announce a significant increase in its bond-buying program to support the economy.

site_title: Japanese banks' overseas investments hit new high despite market turbulence
summary: Japanese commercial banks' overseas investments reached a record high of 4.7 trillion yen ($61.37 billion) in the three months to March, driven by a desire to beat ultra-low returns at home and market turmoil caused by the pandemic. Lending and investment to the US accounted for nearly half of the total, with foreign bonds and mortgage-backed securities also being targeted. This move aims to offset dwindling margins at home due to years of low interest rates and lack of demand for funds.

site_title: Australia jobless rate surges to 19-year high of 7.1%
summary: Australia's unemployment rate surged to 7.1% in May, the highest in nearly two decades, as nearly 250,000 people lost their jobs due to the pandemic. Employment declined 127,000 after a record 600,000 drop in April. The participation rate dropped to 62.9% due to the government's wage subsidy scheme, leading to a lower-than-expected jobless rate. The Reserve Bank of Australia has cut interest rates to a record low to combat the economic damage caused by the pandemic, predicting a 10% unemployment rate by June and through 2021.

site_title: Florida gambles on reopening, as virus numbers rise
summary: Florida is reporting record daily coronavirus cases, but the state is reopening its economy to attract tourists, despite concerns about public health. Republican Governor Ron DeSantis aims to boost the local economy and help President Donald Trump's re-election chances. Many visitors are ignoring mask-wearing and social distancing guidelines, making it challenging to strike a balance between economic recovery and public health protection.

site_title: Alibaba, JD test virus recovery with online sales extravaganza
summary: Alibaba Group Holding and JD.com, China's two largest e-commerce companies, are testing consumer spending recovery with an 18-day online shopping extravaganza, dubbed "6.18." The event, which began on June 1, features record-breaking sales, generous subsidies, and live-streaming personalities, with Alibaba's Tmall logging 50% higher sales during the first 10 hours compared to last year. The stakes are high as the companies gauge investor appetites and assess the strength of their platforms, with JD.com's US-listed share sale also underway.

site_title: US dollar and yen gain on worries about virus and economic outlook
summary: The US dollar and yen rose against other currencies due to growing concerns over the COVID-19 pandemic and its impact on the global economy. The US dollar traded at 1.1234 euros and 0.9496 Swiss francs, while the yen edged up to 106.79 against the US dollar. The Australian and New Zealand dollars fell as data showed significant job losses and economic contraction. The British pound traded in a narrow range before a Bank of England meeting, where policymakers are expected to expand quantitative easing to address the economic outlook.

site_title: Keppel, Mitsubishi Heavy to explore hydrogen-powered plant concept for Singapore data centres
summary: Keppel Data Centres Holding and Mitsubishi Heavy Industries Asia Pacific have signed a memorandum of understanding to explore a hydrogen-powered, tri-generation plant concept for data centers in Singapore. The concept aims to meet the growing digital economy's needs in a safe, reliable, and environmentally friendly manner. The companies will study the production of hydrogen fuel using a carbon-neutral process and consider its implementation in a floating data center project in Singapore. This collaboration aligns with Keppel Data Centres' efforts to decarbonize its operations.

site_title: Winson seeks US$30.4m from Standard Chartered Singapore over Hin Leong deal
summary: Winson Oil Trading has initiated a lawsuit against Standard Chartered Bank (Singapore) for at least US$30.4 million, stemming from a diesel cargo deal with Hin Leong Trading. Winson Oil sold ultra-low sulphur diesel to Hin Leong and received a letter of credit from Standard Chartered, but the payment was not made. Winson Oil is seeking damages, interest, and costs from Standard Chartered, in addition to the outstanding payment. This case is part of several disputes between Hin Leong's counterparties and banks over payment issues arising from oil deals with the Singapore-based trader.

site_title: Hong Kong: Stocks open lower on Thursday
summary: Hong Kong stocks opened lower on Thursday, with the Hang Seng Index dipping 0.39% to 24,386.31. This follows a two-day advance. The Shanghai Composite Index and Shenzhen Composite Index also eased, with the latter down 0.08%. The decline is attributed to profit-takers following the recent market rally.

site_title: China's economic situation improving gradually, says vice-premier Liu
summary: China's Vice-Premier Liu He stated that the country's economic situation has gradually improved, with marginal progress shown in various indicators. Liu also emphasized the need for China and the US to create conditions for implementing the Phase 1 trade deal reached earlier this year. Meanwhile, other economic news includes Citigroup setting a target of 1,150 for the MSCI's global equity index by mid-2026 and Malaysia's May industrial production rising 0.3%.

site_title: Malaysia: Shares open lower on Thursday
summary: Malaysia's shares opened lower on Thursday, with the FTSE Bursa Malaysia Kuala Lumpur Composite Index down 1.91 points, or 0.13%, to 1,524.41. Volume was 344.68 million lots worth RM149.02 million. Gainers beat losers 176 to 169.

site_title: Ex-Morgan Stanley diversity officer says bank slashed her budget by 71%
summary: A former Morgan Stanley diversity officer, Marilyn Booker, claims the bank cut her budget by 71% to promote diversity and financial education, allegedly in retaliation for repeatedly pushing senior management to address racial bias. Booker, who worked at the bank for 17 years, filed a lawsuit after being let go in December. She believes the bank did improve diversity during her tenure, but was terminated for her efforts to increase diversity and address bias against black financial advisers.

site_title: Stocks to watch: Keppel, Mapletree NAC Trust, China Everbright, IReit Global, ESR-Reit
summary: Singapore stocks experienced varied movements on Thursday. Keppel Corp and Mitsubishi Heavy Industries Asia Pacific signed a memorandum of understanding for a hydrogen-powered data center concept. Mapletree North Asia Commercial Trust received a HK$45 million insurance payout for damage to its Hong Kong mall. China Everbright Water issued asset-backed securities and secured a 5-year office lease in Barcelona. IReit Global secured a 5-year office lease in Barcelona, while ESR-Reit had its Baa3 rating downgraded by Moody's Investors Service.

site_title: 14 digital bank applicants to progress to next stage of assessment: MAS
summary: The Monetary Authority of Singapore (MAS) has selected 14 out of 21 digital bank applicants to proceed to the next stage of assessment. The shortlisted applicants include Grab's and Singtel's joint venture, Sea Ltd, Razer Fintech, and a MatchMove-Singapura Finance consortium. The MAS will evaluate the applicants' value proposition, business model, and growth prospects. The central bank has asked the shortlisted applicants to review their business plans and financial projections, which will be assessed independently. The MAS aims to award digital bank licences by the end of 2020.

site_title: Singapore shares fall at Thursday's open; STI down 0.7%
summary: Singapore stocks began trading in negative territory on Thursday, with the Straits Times Index (STI) falling 18.82 points or 0.7% to 2,650.80. The decline came after Singapore's non-oil exports fell 4.5% in May, its first monthly drop this year. The market was also influenced by global equities closing lower overnight due to concerns over coronavirus cases and market valuations.

site_title: Must be glove: the Japan man obsessed with lost gloves
summary: Koji Ishii, a 39-year-old man from Tokyo, has been documenting lost gloves on the streets of Japan for over 15 years, photographing and recording details of thousands of lone gloves. He finds them in various locations, including streets, drains, and beaches, and imagines the stories behind each one. His passion has inspired a global subculture of lost glove enthusiasts, with some even sharing their own photos on social media. Ishii's obsession has also led him to notice acts of kindness, such as people picking up lost gloves, and he hopes to one day connect with others who share his fascination.

site_title: Qantas halts most international flights until October on border closure
summary: Qantas has cancelled most international flights until late October due to Australia's border closure. The airline will maintain some flights to New Zealand, but plans to add more flights if travel between Australia and other countries opens up. The Australian government has indicated the border closure is likely to extend to 2021, prompting Qantas to halt international flights until then.

site_title: New Zealand's economy shrinks by most in three decades
summary: New Zealand's economy contracted by 1.6% in the March quarter, the largest quarterly drop in 29 years, due to the initial effects of coronavirus curbs. This decline is expected to worsen in the current quarter, potentially leading to the country's first technical recession since 2010. The Reserve Bank of New Zealand is expected to hold interest rates steady, while Finance Minister Grant Robertson aims to protect jobs and support the economy's recovery through investments.

images.alt_text: New Zealand's economy shrank 1.6 per cent in the March quarter, the largest drop in 29 years and the first quarterly fall since the December 2010, as the initial effects of coronavirus curbs paralysed activity.

site_title: US pulled out of stalled talks on digital services taxes: Lighthizer
summary: US Treasury Secretary Steven Mnuchin decided to pull out of stalled talks on digital services taxes with European Union officials, citing a lack of progress. The US had proposed pausing, not ending, talks on digital taxes among OECD countries to address the COVID-19 pandemic. The move comes amid tensions with countries like France and Britain over their plans to impose digital service taxes on big tech companies. The US still believes an international regime is needed to deal with taxation, and a source suggests an agreement is possible this year.

site_title: 'That '70s Show' actor Masterson charged with multiple rapes
summary: US actor Danny Masterson, 44, has been charged with raping three women, all in their twenties, at his Hollywood Hills home between 2001 and 2003. Masterson, a Scientologist and star of 'That '70s Show' and 'The Ranch', faces a maximum sentence of 45 years to life in prison if convicted. The alleged incidents occurred "by force or fear" and Masterson's lawyers have not commented on the charges.

site_title: Singapore, Shenzhen ink MOUs for smart city initiative
summary: Singapore and Shenzhen have signed eight memoranda of understanding to deepen digital collaboration and create new market opportunities in the Guangdong-Hong Kong-Macao Greater Bay Area and South-east Asia. The move supports the Singapore-China Smart City Initiative, which aims to facilitate trusted cross-border partnerships and provide access to a larger ecosystem of buyers, sellers, and digital solution providers. The initiative includes a new SME hub operational by July 2020, with 50 SMEs in Singapore having access to a buyer base of four million in China.

site_title: US daily virus deaths drop below 1,000 for 7 days in a row
summary: The US has recorded 840 daily Covid-19 deaths for the seventh consecutive day, with the country still experiencing the most deaths worldwide. Over 117,000 deaths and 2.1 million cases have been reported. New infections have plateaued at around 20,000 per day, shifting the pandemic's focus from the northeast to the south and west, with over a dozen states reporting their highest case numbers since the start of the pandemic.

images.alt_text: The United States recorded 840 deaths from the new coronavirus in the past 24 hours, according to data from Johns Hopkins University on Wednesday, the seventh day in a row the toll has dropped below 1,000.

site_title: Tokyo: Stocks open lower on virus worries, higher yen
summary: Tokyo stocks opened lower on Thursday due to concerns over a potential second wave of Covid-19 infections, weighing on economic recovery hopes. The benchmark Nikkei 225 index fell 0.28% to 22,393.70, while the Topix index declined 0.30% to 1,582.30. A stronger yen also negatively impacted the market.

site_title: In Hawaii, US and China assess path forward from tensions
summary: US Secretary of State Mike Pompeo met with Yang Jiechi, a top Chinese official, in Hawaii, marking the first high-level meeting between the two powers since the coronavirus pandemic. The talks aim to ease rising tensions between the US and China, with Pompeo a vocal critic of China. The meeting comes ahead of the November US elections, where President Donald Trump has increasingly blamed China for the pandemic. The outcome of the talks is unclear, but the meeting represents a step towards de-escalation in strained relations between the two nations.

site_title: Australian house prices to go down under this year, no respite in sight: poll
summary: Australian house prices are expected to decline an average 5.0% nationally this year and 3.6% next year due to the ongoing impact of the coronavirus pandemic on the economy, according to a Reuters poll of 13 property market analysts. The decline is attributed to higher unemployment and lower immigration, which is expected to dampen demand for housing. The country's economy, valued at A$2.0 trillion, is likely to experience a recession after nearly three decades of continuous growth.

site_title: Brazil cuts interest rate to new low amid virus rout
summary: Brazil's central bank cut its benchmark interest rate to 2.25% amid the economic rout caused by the coronavirus pandemic, marking the eighth straight cut. The move was in line with forecasts, but economists are skeptical it will staunch losses caused by months of stay-at-home orders and business closures. The World Bank forecasts a 8% contraction for Brazil's economy this year, its worst annual recession on record. The central bank will continue to monitor the pandemic's impact and any government stimulus measures.

site_title: Study shows how quickly coronavirus spreads at home
summary: Researchers in China and the US found the novel coronavirus is twice as infectious within households as similar diseases, with a 17.1% chance of infecting a cohabitant. The virus can spread before symptoms appear, with a 39% chance of transmission before symptoms start. Isolation within households reduced Covid-19 cases by 20-50%. The study's findings suggest that public health advice to stay home only if sick may have been too late to prevent widespread transmission.

site_title: WHO halts hydroxychloroquine trials on Covid-19 patients
summary: The World Health Organization (WHO) has halted trials of hydroxychloroquine as a potential treatment for hospitalised Covid-19 patients, finding it did not reduce mortality rates. The decision comes after a review of evidence from multiple randomised clinical trials, including the Solidarity Trial and the Recovery Trial. The WHO announced the halt on its own trials, but noted that the decision does not apply to the use or evaluation of the drug as a preventative measure against the virus.

site_title: US: Stocks end mostly down on valuation worries, Dow -0.7%
summary: US stocks ended the day down, with the Dow falling 0.7% to 26,119.61, as investors expressed concerns about the market's valuation amid increased coronavirus cases. The S&P 500 lost 0.4%, while the Nasdaq Composite Index gained 0.2%. Analysts attribute the market's volatility to a still-weak economic picture and the Federal Reserve's continued support. Investor Jeremy Grantham warned of a potential stock bubble, further fueling market uncertainty.

site_title: Canadian party leader kicked out of parliament after accusing MP of racism
summary: Canadian NDP leader Jagmeet Singh was temporarily kicked out of parliament after refusing to apologize for calling a Bloc Quebecois MP a racist. Singh had made the comment during a heated argument over a motion recognizing systemic racism in the Royal Canadian Mounted Police. The House speaker ordered Singh out for the remainder of the day's sitting due to his use of unparliamentary language and refusal to apologize. Singh claimed the Bloc MP's gesture was dismissive of indigenous communities' experiences with police brutality.

site_title: Google boosts racial equity programme pledge to US$275m
summary: Google has pledged US$275 million to support racial equity initiatives, including US$175 million for black business owners, startup founders, and job seekers. The company aims to increase representation of underrepresented groups in leadership positions by 30% in the next five years. Google will establish a task force to improve recruiting, hiring, and career progress for African-American employees, and create anti-racism educational programs. The company will also build racial equality awareness into its products and support the mental health of black workers.

site_title: US dollar rises as investors take refuge
summary: The US dollar rose due to investor refuge from geopolitical risks. Record-high coronavirus infections in US states, new cases in Beijing, and clashes between Indian and Chinese troops contributed to the sentiment. Investors sought the dollar as a safe haven amid these global concerns.

site_title: Money FM podcast: Low code is the key to business agility and resilience
summary: In a recent Money FM podcast, Mark Weaser from Outsystems discussed the benefits of low-code applications in navigating the COVID-19 pandemic. Low-code enables businesses to quickly adapt and innovate, providing agility and resilience. Weaser emphasized the importance of leveraging technology to drive growth and competitiveness. Meanwhile, Singapore's SUTD has launched an office for AI and Digital Innovation, fostering Design AI skills in students.

site_title: Pompeo disparaged Trump, doubted North Korea efforts: ex-aide Bolton
summary: US Secretary of State Mike Pompeo secretly disparaged President Donald Trump and doubted his North Korea diplomacy, according to former national security advisor John Bolton in a new memoir. Bolton claims Pompeo called Trump "so full of s***" after a meeting with North Korean leader Kim Jong Un in 2018. Pompeo also expressed skepticism about Trump's diplomacy and reportedly told Bolton he was "having a cardiac arrest" in Saudi Arabia. The revelation contradicts Pompeo's public support for Trump and raises questions about their relationship.

site_title: Survival tactics to stay in the game
summary: The COVID-19 pandemic has forced many businesses to close or adapt, but some independent companies have found ways to stay afloat. Key survival tactics include being nimble, adapting to new opportunities, and innovating. Pastry chefs have also found success by offering simplified, high-end products, while a mental well-being company created an app to increase meditation accessibility. These companies demonstrate resilience and resourcefulness in the face of economic challenges.

site_title: Zimbabwe government workers get 50% pay hike in virus relief
summary: The Zimbabwean government has awarded its 300,000 civil servants a 50% pay rise and a $75 monthly non-taxable Covid-19 allowance to cushion against the pandemic's hardships. The move comes as the country battles high inflation (785.55% in May) and a virus lockdown that has affected informal traders. This is the government's response to the economic challenges faced by workers, who had earlier threatened to stop reporting for duty due to low pay. The pay hike and allowance will be effective immediately.

site_title: IReit Global bags five-year lease for office space in Barcelona property
summary: IReit Global secured a five-year lease for 3,450 square meters of office space in its Il∙lumina building in Barcelona from travel food and retail services company Areas, despite the Covid-19 lockdown. The lease, valued at an undisclosed amount, will increase Il∙lumina's occupancy rate to 86.4% and is considered one of the largest year-to-date rental transactions in Barcelona. The deal marks a pivotal moment for the Reit, following intensified leasing efforts amid the pandemic.

site_title: Europe: Shares rise for second day on hopes of more US stimulus
summary: European shares rose 0.7% on Wednesday, driven by hopes of more US stimulus and a potential global economic recovery. The Stoxx 600 index is now 15.7% below its February record high, but has rebounded since a coronavirus-fueled crash in March. The European Council will meet to discuss a 750 billion euro debt proposal, while concerns over a new Covid-19 outbreak in China and potential lockdowns weigh on investors' minds.

site_title: Oil retreats with China outbreak, increased US stockpiles dampening demand outlook
summary: Global oil prices retreated after a second wave of coronavirus cases in China and a report on increased US stockpiles. Futures in New York fell below $38 a barrel, down 6% from the previous session. The International Energy Agency (IEA) expects global oil demand to rebound in 2021 but will take two years to return to pre-pandemic levels. The decline in oil prices is attributed to concerns over China's energy consumption and the potential impact on the global demand outlook.

site_title: India, China hold talks to de-escalate deadly border tensions
summary: India and China agreed to ease tensions at their disputed Himalayan border after a deadly brawl left at least 20 Indian soldiers dead. The two nations' foreign ministers spoke by telephone, with China's Wang Yi demanding India conduct a thorough investigation and punish those responsible. India's Subrahmanyam Jaishankar warned that the incident would have a serious impact on bilateral relations, but the two sides also agreed to de-escalate tensions and implement a previously agreed disengagement.

site_title: Eduardo Cojuangco, who built San Miguel empire, dies at 85
summary: Eduardo Cojuangco, the 85-year-old chairman of San Miguel Corp, has died. Cojuangco, also known as "the Boss" and "Pac-Man" for his business acumen, passed away on Tuesday. He was the founder of the San Miguel empire.

site_title: US-European trade talks stalled over 'unsafe' American food
summary: US-European trade talks have stalled due to suspicions of poor American food standards, according to US Trade Representative Robert Lighthizer. Lighthizer dismissed concerns as "thinly veiled protectionism," but acknowledged that agriculture is a difficult issue. The US has the best agriculture in the world, he claimed, and there will be no compromise on US agricultural exports. The talks, which include Britain, have been stalled for months over issues like subsidies to Boeing and Airbus, digital taxation, and agriculture. A fair access for US agriculture is seen as a non-negotiable requirement.

site_title: Oil slides on fresh Covid-19 outbreaks, bump in crude stocks
summary: Oil prices fell on Wednesday due to concerns over fuel demand amid new Covid-19 outbreaks in China and the US. US crude inventories reached a record high, and distillate stockpiles declined. The World Health Organization announced that corticosteroid medication dexamethasone reduced death rates among severely ill Covid-19 patients. Oil prices settled down 0.6% for Brent crude and 1.1% for US West Texas Intermediate, with Brent at $40.71 a barrel and WTI at $37.96 a barrel.

site_title: Several recent GCB deals had viewings before circuit breaker
summary: Several Good Class Bungalow (GCB) transactions have occurred in Singapore despite the "circuit breaker" lockdown, with viewings done before April 7. A bungalow in Windsor Park Road was sold for S$21.25 million, or S$1,063 per square foot, and two bungalows in Oei Tiong Ham Park were also sold. The transactions demonstrate strong demand for GCB properties, highlighting their value and desirability in Singapore's luxury market.

site_title: US vows to curb China and Russia in space
summary: The US has released a new "Defence Space Strategy" aiming to curb China and Russia's control of space. The strategy highlights the threat posed by China and Russia's development of counterspace capabilities, including jamming and cyberattacks on US satellites. The US will strive to maintain superiority in space, particularly protecting GPS satellites, and is seeking help from allies like the "Five Eyes" group. China has invested billions in space, including a successful satellite missile test in 2007, while Russia is developing its Angara rocket and intercontinental ballistic missile, Sarmat, posing a significant threat to US and allied military effectiveness.

images.alt_text: The United States wants to prevent China and Russia from taking control of space and will look to allies for help, according to a new "Defence Space Strategy" unveiled by the Pentagon on Wednesday.

site_title: South Africa's Miss Universe uses platform to fight racism
summary: Zozibini Tunzi, South Africa's Miss Universe, uses her platform to fight racism, inequality, and perceptions of beauty. Tunzi drew inspiration from the 1976 Soweto Uprising, where tens of thousands of students protested against apartheid laws. She marched in the Black Lives Matter protests in New York City, highlighting the shared struggle for racial equality. Tunzi aims to challenge these issues in her native South Africa, where young people have died fighting for the same cause.

site_title: South Korea to tighten property curbs as home prices surge
summary: South Korea plans to further tighten mortgage rules and apply property market curbs to areas outside Seoul to combat rising home prices. The government will designate pockets of Gyeonggi-do province as "speculative zones" with stricter borrowing rules, including a mortgage ban on properties valued over 1.5 billion won. The median apartment price in Seoul has increased 52% since 2017, prompting the government to increase capital gains tax and other taxes on property ownership. The measures aim to curb speculative investments and slow down property price rises.

site_title: Europe's biggest tech summit will go ahead in November
summary: The Web Summit, Europe's largest tech conference, will proceed as planned in Lisbon in November, adhering to strict health protocols. The event, which attracts 70,000 participants annually, could be one of the first major international gatherings since the COVID-19 pandemic. Despite Portugal's ongoing lockdown restrictions, the conference's founder, Paddy Cosgrave, confirmed the event's continuation, citing government guidance and measures to reduce contagion risk.

site_title: US wants undersea data cable to skip Hong Kong
summary: The US Justice Department recommended that a proposed undersea data cable system, backed by Google and Facebook, bypass Hong Kong due to potential national security concerns. The Pacific Light Cable Network, which connects the US, Taiwan, and the Philippines, was planned to pass through Hong Kong, but the DoJ cited concerns that US communications traffic could be exposed to collection by Beijing. The recommendation was made following China's recent actions to remove Hong Kong's autonomy. The cable system, which could handle 120 terabytes of data per second, would instead connect the US, Taiwan, and the Philippines directly.

site_title: European car sales show signs of tepid recovery
summary: European car sales showed a tepid recovery in May, with new auto registrations falling 57% year-over-year, the worst May since 1990. While an improvement over April's 78% plunge, the industry faces uncertainty ahead, with carmakers preparing to announce second-quarter results. US customers drove sales rebound with SUV and truck purchases, while China saw car sales rise for the first time in almost a year. Sales have dropped 43% in the first five months, with forecasts predicting a decline of up to 20% in 2020.

site_title: UK and EU should double down on Brexit trade deal
summary: UK and EU leaders agreed to put more urgency into Brexit trade deal negotiations, aiming for a broad agreement by autumn with a potential ratification by December. UK Prime Minister Boris Johnson believes a deal can be achieved in July, but experts warn this is overly optimistic. The EU's chief negotiator Michel Barnier accused the UK of backtracking on commitments, and a no-deal scenario could have serious economic repercussions for both sides. A hard exit could lead to a return to negotiations in 2021, making a deal this year crucial.

site_title: Player unease as US Open to go ahead in Aug without fans
summary: The US Open tennis championships will proceed in August without spectators, despite concerns from top players. New York Governor Andrew Cuomo gave the event the green light, with the US Tennis Association (USTA) implementing safety protocols such as testing, cleaning, and social distancing. Several players, including Novak Djokovic and Rafael Nadal, have expressed reservations about playing in New York, citing safety concerns and restrictions on support staff. The tournament is set to take place from August 31 to September 13 at the USTA's Billie Jean King National Tennis Center.

site_title: Crypto exchange Binance to launch UK trading platform in summer of 2020
summary: Binance, a global blockchain company, plans to launch a UK-based cryptocurrency trading platform this summer. The platform, regulated by the UK Financial Conduct Authority, will allow investors to buy and sell digital currencies using pounds and euros. It will offer up to 65 digital assets and provide deposits and withdrawals through direct bank transfers. The launch comes amid growing institutional interest in cryptocurrencies, with a recent survey showing nearly 80% of institutional investors see the appeal of digital assets. The platform aims to engage and capture interest from a wider audience with varying risk appetites.

site_title: Mapletree Investments reports 18% drop in net profit to S$1.78b
summary: Mapletree Investments reported an 18% drop in net profit to S$1.78 billion for the fiscal year ended March 31, 2020, due to lower asset revaluation and disposal gains. However, the company delivered its highest recurring earnings in five years at S$752 million, up 5% from a year earlier. The group is exploring launching more funds or Reits, including a private fund for its European commercial portfolio. Despite the challenges posed by the Covid-19 pandemic, Mapletree remains cautiously optimistic about its prospects, with 35% of its assets under management in logistics and data centers.

site_title: Oracle expects flat sales on fewer corporate software deals
summary: Oracle Corp projects stagnant revenue in the current quarter, signaling potential flat sales due to delayed software purchases by clients in the hospitality and retail industries amid the pandemic. The company expects sales to be in a range of a 1% gain to a 1% decline year-over-year. Cloud licence and on-premise licence sales declined 22% in the period ended May 31, and profit is expected to be 84-88 US cents per share. The company's growth in cloud-based services and growing businesses may aid future sales growth.

site_title: Pan-United taps tech to supply concrete mix with fewer workers
summary: Pan-United Corp, a Singaporean concrete supplier, is leveraging technology to boost safety at construction sites during the pandemic. The company has introduced an electronic invoicing system and a smart concrete-mixing system that enables remote tweaks to the concrete mix, reducing the need for quality assessors and product technicians. Pan-United is also developing a new-generation self-compacting concrete that requires only one worker to guide the pumping pipe, increasing productivity by 75% and reducing casting time by 40%. This innovation aims to support safe distancing requirements and enhance operational efficiency for customers.

site_title: Behind the surge in stocks, markets will remain wild
summary: The global stock market has experienced a rapid rebound, with the US S&P 500 up for the year despite renewed tensions, civil strife, and the ongoing COVID-19 pandemic. The surge is attributed to the massive stimulus from central banks and fiscal support from governments, with the US Federal Reserve increasing its balance sheet by over $3 trillion. However, experts warn that this volatility is a sign of increased financial risks and that markets are likely to remain unpredictable and volatile for the rest of the year.

site_title: Asian companies must turn scale into value
summary: Asian companies face significant underperformance challenges due to the COVID-19 pandemic, despite having grown rapidly in scale over the past decade. The region's largest companies have struggled to generate economic value, with many operating in value-destroying sectors. However, there are opportunities for improvement, particularly in financial services, consumer goods, and digital innovations. Embracing digital technologies such as machine learning and artificial intelligence can unlock productivity growth and help Asian companies rise more prominently on the global stage.
