The World Health Organization has reported over 100 new confirmed cases in Beijing, and countries such as Iran, India, and Saudi Arabia have seen worrying increases in deaths and infections, adding to concerns about the long fight against Covid-19.

site_title: STI drops 70.75 points to 2,613 as lockdown fears resurface
summary: The Straits Times Index (STI) fell 70.75 points, or 2.64%, to 2,613.88 on Monday, marking its third straight day of losses, amid rising concerns of lockdowns due to new coronavirus infections in the US and China. About 1.71 billion securities worth S$1.82 billion changed hands, with losers outnumbering gainers 349 to 148. The decline was attributed to the resurgence of new cases globally, potentially derailing the anticipated rebound in global demand in the second half of the year.

site_title: Germany to buy stake in biotech firm CureVac
summary: Germany's Economy Minister Peter Altmaier announced that the country will acquire a 23% stake in biotech firm CureVac for 300 million euros, valuing the company at 1.3 billion euros. The move aims to strengthen Germany's life sciences sector and provide financial security for CureVac's vaccine development programs. The deal does not require EU approval, and the German government will have no influence over CureVac's business strategy. The investment reflects concerns about relying on overseas suppliers for healthcare products and equipment.

site_title: Trump's niece to publish book with 'harrowing' revelations: report
summary: Donald Trump's niece, Mary Trump, is set to publish a book titled "Too Much And Never Enough" on August 11, which will allegedly reveal "harrowing and salacious" stories about the president. The book will be released less than three weeks before Trump's acceptance speech at the Republican nomination for a second term. Mary Trump, 55, claims to have provided confidential tax documents to The New York Times, contradicting Trump's image of a self-made billionaire. The book's publication may be the first damaging revelation from a member of Trump's own family.

site_title: OCBC, DBS to hire over 5,000 this year, with emphasis on tech roles
summary: Singapore's two largest banks, OCBC and DBS, plan to hire over 5,000 new employees this year, with an emphasis on tech-related roles. OCBC will hire over 3,000 people, including 2,100 full-time roles and 500 traineeships, while DBS will create over 360 permanent positions and train 60 people in areas like AI and cloud computing. The hiring drive comes as the Covid-19 crisis accelerates digitalization in the sector, with global tech companies shedding jobs.

site_title: Risk-sensitive currencies recover some losses; dollar steadies
summary: The US dollar steadied on Monday after a "risk-off" sentiment eased, with commodity currencies recovering some losses. The dollar rose 0.4% overnight but then erased gains, settling at 97.12. Analysts cite fears of a second Covid-19 wave, with China re-introducing restrictions and the US reporting over 25,000 new cases. The euro was broadly flat against the dollar, while the Australian and New Zealand dollars fell. Industrial output in China rose for the second consecutive month, a positive sign for the global economy.

site_title: Women leaders may be more consultative in a crisis
summary: A study analyzing 21 countries' response to the COVID-19 pandemic found that countries led by women had significantly lower death rates, averaging 36 coronavirus-related deaths per million inhabitants compared to 214 in male-led countries. Researchers attribute this difference to the more consultative and evidence-based leadership styles of female leaders, who often recognized expertise and acted quickly, unlike male authoritarian leaders who botched the response. This suggests that women may be better equipped to handle crises, but the findings do not imply a gender gap in leadership effectiveness within the United States.

site_title: LMIRT to pay perp coupon due in June; reopens most malls
summary: LMIRT to pay its S$120 million, 6.6% perpetual securities coupon on June 19, and has deposited S$3.97 million with Citibank to satisfy the payment. The trust has reopened most of its malls, marking a positive development after the COVID-19 pandemic.

site_title: England property sales rebound after lockdown ends
summary: England property sales rebounded after the government eased coronavirus lockdown restrictions on May 13, according to Rightmove. Sales during the lockdown fell by 94%, but by June 5, they were just 3% below their level a year earlier. The average asking price for properties increased by 1.9%, and accepted prices were 98% of the asking price. This rebound is attributed to high pent-up demand and upward price pressure, with sales averaging two-thirds of their previous level over the previous three weeks.

site_title: Parts of Beijing locked down as virus outbreak gathers fresh pace
summary: China's capital, Beijing, locked down parts of the city and shut indoor sports and entertainment venues amid a growing coronavirus outbreak linked to a wholesale food market. The number of cases increased to 79, with tens of thousands targeted in a massive test and trace program. Authorities also locked down 21 housing estates and a market, with over 8,000 workers tested and sent to quarantine facilities. The outbreak highlights the enduring dangers of a second wave of the pandemic, with China reporting 177 infected individuals, its highest since early May.

site_title: Keppel's Alpha in 3-way tie-up to invest in Indonesia's logistics property sector
summary: Keppel's Alpha Investment Partners, a subsidiary of Keppel Corporation, has entered a 3-way tie-up with Manulife subsidiary Asuransi Jiwa Manulife Indonesia and Mega Manunggal Property (MMP) to invest in Indonesia's logistics property sector. The venture, valued at US$200 million, aims to acquire stakes in four logistics assets in the Greater Jakarta area, with an initial target size of US$200 million. The assets have a total net lettable area of over 163,000 square meters and an occupancy rate of over 96%.

site_title: New virtual trade show seeks to match coffee and tea buyers, sellers
summary: A virtual trade show, the Future Tea & Coffee Summit and Expo 2020, will be held from June 24-26, 2020, to match coffee and tea buyers, sellers, and facilitate online sourcing and sales. The event aims to eliminate physical interactions, utilizing ProfilePrint's digital food standard for rapid and non-destructive fingerprinting technology. The virtual expo will also feature webinars with industry leaders and discussions on new technologies and innovative solutions to address the tea and coffee industry's pressing challenges.

site_title: BOE gets negative rates advantage by watching others go first
summary: The Bank of England (BOE) is considering negative interest rates to stimulate the UK economy, but Governor Andrew Bailey is hesitant due to concerns about its impact on banks and financial stability. The UK's experience with negative rates is different from the European Central Bank's, where the policy has been criticized and reversed. Instead, the BOE may explore alternative options, such as cutting the rate on its Term Funding Scheme or implementing yield-curve control. Investors expect the BOE to add £100 billion to its bond-buying program, rather than cutting interest rates further.

site_title: Surveillance fears over TraceTogether Token unwarranted
summary: Singapore's TraceTogether Token, a contact tracing device, has sparked controversy over surveillance concerns. However, the device relies on Bluetooth proximity and does not have a GPS tracker or internet connectivity, dispelling fears of constant monitoring. The data collected can only be accessed after a user tests positive for Covid-19 and is protected under Singapore's personal data protection laws. The use of the device is not unique, as 29 countries use similar Bluetooth-based tracing methods. The government aims to control the spread of the virus to resume economic activities, prioritizing public health over individual privacy concerns.

site_title: DBS upgrades Koufu to 'buy' on expected rise in food court footfall
summary: DBS Group Research upgraded Koufu Group's rating to "buy" and raised its target price to 75 Singapore cents from 68 cents due to expected rise in food court footfall as Singapore's "circuit breaker" phase two easing permits dining in. Analysts cited the company's resilient business, strong cash flow generation, and superior net margins as key drivers. The upgrade also reflects the potential for a strong post-pandemic recovery and special dividends from the sale of existing central kitchen properties.

site_title: NAB prepared to say 'no' to more relief for customers who can't repay
summary: NAB CEO Ross McEwan warns that thousands of customers who requested loan relief due to the coronavirus pandemic may not be able to repay their loans when deferral periods end in September. NAB has already provided holiday periods of up to six months to over 772,000 business and home loans worth A$234 billion. McEwan says the bank will not hesitate to deny more assistance, citing concerns about customers going into more debt if they can't afford to pay it back. Australia's household debt-to-income ratio is above 190%, one of the highest in the developed world.

site_title: AMTD Group to take majority stake in CapBridge
summary: AMTD Group, a Hong Kong-based financial services firm, has agreed to take a majority stake in CapBridge Financial, a private capital platform, for an undisclosed sum. The partnership aims to expand CapBridge's digital assets exchange platform and tap the private market. AMTD Digital, the group's digital platform arm, will drive the collaboration, while CapBridge will bring private capital markets expertise and financial technology. The deal is subject to approval from the Monetary Authority of Singapore and closing conditions, with plans to establish a Singapore-centric Asian fintech platform to expand across South-east Asia and China.

site_title: Recovery uncertain but Gojek plans to stay the course in Singapore
summary: Gojek Singapore's ride-hailing business has been recovering gradually since the circuit breaker slump, with completed trips and booking requests rising by about 50% since June 1. Despite uncertainty about the recovery timeline, the company remains committed to growing its ride-hailing business in Singapore. Gojek's CEO has dismissed reports of a potential merger with rival Grab, citing the benefits of competition for riders and drivers. Experts are optimistic that ride-hailing will continue to be a mainstay despite social distancing measures, with demand expected to recover to pre-pandemic levels once economies reopen.

site_title: Changing hands
summary: Citigroup has set a mid-2026 target of 1,150 for MSCI's global equity index, indicating a bullish outlook for the market. Analysts also raised target prices for SGX earnings, citing a defensive play benefiting from volatility. Meanwhile, Chinese banks face challenges due to Beijing's consumer lending push. Japanese bank MUFG plans to expand its US securitisation business and boost headcount. The PBOC adviser recommends a 1.5 trillion yuan stimulus package to counter US tariffs. Tesla plans to expand its robotaxi services to California and Arizona, and FedEx partners with QuikBot to deploy robots for deliveries.

site_title: Corporate digest
summary: Synagie Corp partnered media investment group GroupM for e-commerce platform services in South-east Asia. Hatten Land expects a loss for Q4 and FY 2020 due to construction manpower crunch and reduced sales. Lum Chang Holdings won a contract to refurbish a former State Courts building. Mapletree Logistics Trust agreed to buy a warehouse in Brisbane, Australia. KrisEnergy faces a winding-up petition from creditor Rubicon Vantage International, but plans to discuss next steps.

site_title: Sweden weighing stricter bond-trading rules after funds crisis
summary: Sweden's financial watchdog is considering stricter bond-trading rules following a liquidity crisis that led to 35 fixed-income funds shutting down in March. The Financial Supervisory Authority is looking at an exemption granted to Swedish securities firms, which gave them lenient reporting obligations. The lack of transparency has prompted calls for change, with the EU discussing consolidation of bond price information. The Swedish government is also exploring ways to improve liquidity, including giving fund companies access to more tools. The move aims to create a more well-functioning market and address concerns over bond pricing transparency.

site_title: Defence alleges abuse of process in Canada arrest of Huawei executive
summary: Huawei executive Meng Wanzhou's lawyers claim Canadian police and border agents, in collusion with the FBI, abused process in her arrest on a US warrant. Defence lawyer David Martin alleges that authorities delayed her arrest to gather evidence for the FBI, allowing them to snoop through her electronic devices. The Canadian government had previously cooperated with the FBI, including storing Meng's devices in "signal-blocking" bags. Meng, daughter of Huawei's billionaire founder, is wanted in the US for fraud linked to Iran sanctions, and the case has raised concerns of a "serious political incident" between Canada, China, and the US.

images.alt_text: Lawyers for Huawei executive Meng Wanzhou on Monday accused Canadian police and border agents, in collusion with the FBI, of abuse of process in her arrest on a US warrant.

site_title: China's factory output continues rebound in May
summary: China's factory output rebounded 4.4% in May, its highest reading since December, but domestic demand and infrastructure investment contracted. The recovery remains fragile due to a potential second wave of COVID-19 in Beijing and a global economic recession. Retail sales dropped 2.8% and fixed asset investment shrank 6.3% in May. China's economy faces persistent weak demand and growing hostility from Europe and the US, with unemployment affecting small enterprises, migrant workers, and young graduates.

site_title: The Republican Party is now the Trump Party
summary: The Republican Party has undergone a significant ideological shift, transforming into a nationalist white Christian party that prioritizes government aid for favored industries. This shift began in the 1960s with the "southern strategy" aimed at persuading white Southerners to switch from the Democratic to the Republican Party. Under President Ronald Reagan, the GOP moved towards a more conservative direction, embracing protectionism and mercantilism. The current president, Donald Trump, has furthered this trend, exploiting social-economic resentments among white blue-collar workers and targeting "others" such as African-Americans and Hispanic immigrants. The party's evolution has led to a decline in its representation of African-Americans and a rise in nationalist and illiberal tendencies.

images.alt_text: The party that elected the first African-American senator in the last century - Edward Brooke in 1966 - now has very few black public figures among its leaders. It has become the nation's white party, peddling a form of "soft" racism that plays up issues of "us" and "them".

site_title: Bukit Sembawang's price cut at 8 St Thomas has some agents in a tizzy
summary: Bukit Sembawang Estate, a developer of premium homes, has cut prices by up to S$500,000 at its 8 St Thomas freehold development in District 9, Singapore. The price cuts were limited to a one-time period and saw prices slashed by S$200,000 to S$2,700 per sq ft. Despite slow sales, 12 units were sold during the offer, including bulk purchases. The developer remains positive on the long-term outlook of Singapore's property sector and has introduced a new deferred payment scheme for buyers.

site_title: Hmlet readies property listing platform, names new CFO and CTO
summary: Hmlet, a Singapore-based co-living operator, is launching a property listing platform that allows landlords to list their properties directly. The platform provides advanced analytics, tools, and services, and also offers furniture rentals and other services. The move is part of Hmlet's pivot to an asset-light model, aiming to diversify its offerings and scale. The platform is currently in beta and expected to launch in early Q3. Hmlet has also appointed new CFO Rajive Keshup and CTO Pramodh Rai to lead the company's growth strategy.

site_title: Testing for all entering Singapore; more long-term pass holders can return
summary: Singapore will require testing of all incoming travelers starting June 17, with a community testing facility to be used for swab tests a few days before the end of their 14-day stay-home notice period. Long-term pass holders, excluding those using the Singapore-China fast lane, will still need necessary approvals to enter.

site_title: IMDA chief to step down in lead-up to general election
summary: IMDA chief Tan Kiat How is set to step down on June 20, as part of the lead-up to Singapore's general election. He is expected to enter politics under the ruling People's Action Party and may contest East Coast GRC. Tan's departure is part of a wave of senior public servants leaving their posts, including Desmond Tan, Yip Hon Weng, and Ng Ling Ling. Tan will be succeeded by Lew Chuen Hong as part of a leadership renewal, and has expressed plans to leverage his experience in digital technology to contribute to the government's efforts in the post-Covid-19 era.

site_title: Turning to technology to future-proof clinical trials
summary: Singapore is turning to technology to future-proof clinical trials amid the COVID-19 pandemic, which has disrupted global supply chains and clinical trial operations. The country's Health Sciences Authority has approved over 500 ongoing clinical trials, and the government has committed S$19 billion to sustain research and innovation. To overcome challenges, clinical trials should be "virtualised" using digital tools and technologies, such as remote patient data gathering, drug supply management, and centralized platforms. A unified data platform can also enhance resilience and preparedness, allowing for seamless sharing of data and efficient collaboration across teams.

site_title: Businesses scramble to meet earlier reopening date
summary: Singapore's Phase Two reopening is set for this Friday, ahead of expected, with safe-management measures, group size, and capacity limits in place. Businesses have just three days to prepare, with some scrambling to recall workers and prepare for crowds. Despite the surprise, many are welcoming the move, but express concerns over sustaining activity and the potential for a resurgence in virus cases.

site_title: Boutique fund seeks answers from Accordia Golf Trust over move to retain profits
summary: A Singapore-based boutique fund, Hibiki Path Advisors, has expressed concerns over Accordia Golf Trust's (AGT) decision to set aside 1.56 billion yen as a reserve in the March quarter, reducing the trust's semi-annual payout by almost half. The fund argues that AGT's lack of transparency on the reserve's relevance and the large amount allocated warrants further explanation. AGT's financial advisers are evaluating a non-binding offer to acquire the trust's golf course portfolio, but the fund questions the need for the reserve and the large fees paid to professional parties.

site_title: China home prices rise most in seven months
summary: China's home prices rose 0.49% in May, the fastest pace in seven months, as the property market recovers from coronavirus shutdowns. New-home prices in 70 major cities increased, while secondary market values gained 0.24%. Demand is boosted by central bank credit support, discounts, and a surge in supply. Analysts are split on the outlook for the rest of the year, with some predicting stable prices and others warning of pressure in smaller cities.

site_title: Art dealer sues over failed Singapore freeport sale
summary: Swiss art dealer Yves Bouvier has filed a lawsuit in Singapore's High Court against a group of businessmen who allegedly agreed to buy his freeport for S$83.3 million before repeatedly delaying and reneging on the deal. The group, led by Jaime Ordonez, cited various issues, including a negative article and concerns about the freeport's infrastructure, to push back the completion date multiple times. Bouvier's lawyers claim the defendants breached the terms of the October 2019 contract, while Ordonez and his associates deny the allegations.

site_title: Asia electronics sector bucking global economic slump
summary: Asia's electronics sector is bucking the global economic slump, driven by the digitalization of economic activities amid the Covid-19 pandemic. Semiconductor exports rose in South Korea and Taiwan, while electronic-component exports grew 13.2% in Taiwan. Companies are adopting new technologies to make remote work easier, fueling demand for 5G equipment and automation tools. Analysts predict a sustainable boost, but US-China tensions and consumer spending habits may impact the sector's growth.

site_title: EU gearing up for post-virus summer holiday season
summary: The European Union is set to reopen its internal borders on Monday, allowing travel within the region after anxious months of confinement. Many Europeans are expected to stay at home and take holidays within their own countries due to the tourism industry's struggles. France and Spain are among the countries reopening, with France launching a campaign to encourage domestic tourism and Spain allowing German tourists to visit the Balearic Islands. Britain remains closed to international tourists due to a 14-day quarantine, but is considering establishing "air bridges" with countries with low virus rates.

site_title: Virus prompts Astrea IV structure's 'de-risk'
summary: Temasek-owned Azalea Group's Astrea IV Class A bonds have seen a 'de-risk' structure prompted by the coronavirus pandemic. An additional US$53 million was set aside, along with scheduled US$40 million and US$1 million, to manage the portfolio's loan-to-value ratio.

site_title: The Putin referendum will affect not just Russia, but the world
summary: Russian President Vladimir Putin's proposed constitutional change to extend his term in office until 2036 has significant implications for international economics and politics. If successful, it would allow Putin to remain in power until his 80s, potentially surpassing Joseph Stalin's 30-year rule. The move could also lead to closer ties between Russia and China, with President Xi Jinping, who has already consolidated power in China. The outcome of the referendum, scheduled for July, could inject uncertainty into Russia's outlook post-2024 and impact global relations, particularly with the US, which has been critical of Putin's actions.

site_title: UK's Johnson sees Brexit deal in July if talks momentum builds
summary: British Prime Minister Boris Johnson expressed optimism about a Brexit deal, stating that outstanding disagreements between the UK and EU are well understood and a deal could be reached in July if negotiations gain momentum. He urged the EU to increase energy in talks, saying "put a tiger in the tank." Johnson also emphasized the need to finalize the deal before the autumn and winter, as a prolonged negotiation could be seen as beneficial to the EU.

site_title: House-hunting in Sweden: An entire historic village for sale at 70m krona
summary: A historic Swedish village, Satra Brunn, is for sale at 70 million Swedish krona (S$10.4 million). The village, built in 1700, features 70 buildings, including a natural underground spring and a 19th-century deconsecrated church. The property has been owned by a group of 15 local residents since 2002 and was previously operated as a wellness retreat and holistic research center. The village is a rare example of Swedish village architecture and is considered a world heritage site. The buyer can choose to continue operating the commercial spaces, which include a conference center, restaurant, and preschool.

site_title: Phase 3 businesses resigned to waiting their turn to reopen
summary: Businesses in Singapore's Phase 3, including large-scale events and entertainment venues, will remain closed when Phase 2 begins on Friday. However, operators are taking the gradual reopening of the economy in stride, showing no surprise or concern over the decision. They are focusing on waiting for their turn to reopen, indicating a sense of patience and acceptance.

images.alt_text: Large-scale events and venues such as conferences, exhibitions, concerts and trade fairs; and entertainment venues such as bars, nightclubs, karaoke outlets, cinemas, theatres, as well as indoor and outdoor attractions will still remain shut when Phase 2 kicks in on Friday.

site_title: CMT offers more rental relief to SME tenants; CapitaLand accelerates China digitalisation push
summary: CMT offers additional rental relief of up to one month of rental or other forms of assistance for SME tenants that don't qualify for the new rental relief law. This follows the passing of amendments to the Covid-19 (Temporary Measures) Act, which waives up to two months of base rent for eligible tenants.

site_title: Saudi property firm plans first post-virus Riyadh IPO
summary: Saudi Arabian real estate financing firm Amlak International plans to float 30% of its shares in Riyadh, the kingdom's first IPO since the coronavirus crisis, as part of economic reforms to reduce reliance on oil revenues. Amlak, with assets of 3.1 billion riyals, will offer shares starting June 22, with the final offer price announced on June 30. The IPO aims to increase visibility, reduce costs, and boost profitability. Saudi retailer BinDawood Holding also plans to launch an IPO this month, following Amlak's lead in deepening the kingdom's capital markets.

site_title: Webinar, panel discussions offer strategies for post-Covid-19 business recovery
summary: A webinar, "Business Recovery: 10 Strategies To Set Yourself Up For A Rebound," will be held on June 25, discussing post-Covid-19 business recovery strategies. Experts, including Joseph Liow, dean of College of Humanities, Arts, and Social Sciences at Nanyang Technological University, will share their insights on adapting to the new normal. Two panel discussions will also take place, focusing on industry-specific recovery strategies and digital innovation. The event aims to provide tips and ideas for SMEs to navigate the economic challenges posed by the pandemic.

site_title: More chances for ICT SMEs to snag government contracts in FY2020
summary: The Singapore government plans to increase ICT spending by 30% to S$3.5 billion in FY2020, with 80% of opportunities available to small and medium-sized enterprises (SMEs). GovTech aims to uplift local SMEs' capabilities, allowing them to expand beyond Singapore and tap new markets. Seven bulk tenders will be called, implementing dynamic contracting, which allows new suppliers and requirements to be introduced during the contract period. This move is expected to help SMEs recover from the COVID-19 pandemic and capitalize on the rise in digitalization.

site_title: Improving standards for foreign workers could be a new opportunity for business
summary: Singapore companies are expanding their services to support foreign workers amid the COVID-19 pandemic. SATS, a ground handler and in-flight caterer, is feeding migrant workers in makeshift care facilities, using its kitchen expansion to produce large quantities of food. Other companies, such as Surbana Jurong and Centurion Corp, are also contributing to the effort, with some even charging below normal costs. The government has allowed these companies to prioritize profit once again, with the goal of raising standards for foreign workers and encouraging businesses to invest in new infrastructure.

site_title: US Supreme Court endorses gay, transgender worker protection
summary: The US Supreme Court delivered a 6-3 ruling, endorsing protections for gay and transgender workers under Title VII of the Civil Rights Act of 1964. The landmark decision, authored by Justice Neil Gorsuch, recognizes new worker protections in federal law, covering 28 US states lacking comprehensive measures against employment discrimination. This ruling marks the biggest moment for LGBT rights in the US since the legalization of same-sex marriage nationwide in 2015, providing significant protection against workplace bias for gay and transgender employees.

site_title: Face-to-face client meetings and more bank branches to open when financial sector moves to Phase 2: MAS
summary: The Monetary Authority of Singapore (MAS) announced that financial institutions can reopen shuttered branches and allow staff to meet customers face-to-face again, starting Friday, in line with the second phase of the country's social and economic reopening plan. Financial institutions must implement safe management measures, such as mask-wearing and contact tracing. The MAS encourages the use of digital financial services and e-payments, with staff working from home where possible.

site_title: EU imposes tariffs on Chinese makers of glass fibre fabric in China and Egypt
summary: The European Union imposed tariffs on Chinese producers of glass fibre fabric in China and Egypt, citing unfair subsidies that allowed them to sell at low prices in Europe. The EU found that companies, including Egyptian subsidiaries of state-owned China National Building Materials Group Corp, received preferential lending, land, and electricity, as well as grants and tax breaks. Tariffs of 30.0% to 99.7% will be applied, with higher rates for China-based companies and lower rates for operations in Egypt, backdated to January 22.

site_title: Businesses warned of rough road ahead despite Phase Two
summary: Singapore is moving into Phase Two of its reopening plan, allowing most businesses to resume operations on June 18. While this marks a positive step for the economy, economists warn that the recovery will be challenging and uneven, with industries such as construction and tourism facing continued pressure. The construction sector is expected to face significant pressure due to high numbers of infections among foreign workers, and projects are likely to be delayed. Economists forecast a 5% contraction in Q2, but expect the economy to recover by the end of 2021, with some sectors such as finance and manufacturing potentially offsetting slower growth in others.

site_title: Viruses don't recognise nationality
summary: The COVID-19 pandemic has resulted in a significant loss of American lives, surpassing the number of US soldiers killed in World War I and World War II. The 1918-1919 influenza pandemic, also known as the "Spanish flu," spread globally during World War I, with the US being the likely origin. Despite this, the pandemic was downplayed in the US due to wartime censorship, leading to it being dubbed "Spanish flu" instead of "American flu." This experience highlights the importance of isolating the ill and providing reliable information during infectious disease outbreaks, and serves as a warning against blaming a nationality for a disease that does not discriminate.

site_title: KrisEnergy unit could face winding-up petition; investor meeting to be held on June 19
summary: KrisEnergy's wholly-owned subsidiary, KEGOT, faces a winding-up petition in the Cayman Islands, but the petition has not yet been served. The company is seeking advice from its legal advisers and will hold a virtual investor meeting on June 19. KrisEnergy has been involved in legal proceedings since 2018 and has a moratorium blocking a British court judgment over US$2.6 million in debt. Trading in KrisEnergy shares has been suspended since August 2019. The company is in the process of restructuring its debt.

site_title: Q1 total employment dives a record 25,600, Q2 likely to be worse
summary: Singapore's employment in Q1 2020 contracted by a record 25,600, with a "significant fall" in foreign employment and a "slightly" contraction in local employment. The labour market is expected to worsen further in Q2 due to the pandemic, with economists citing the circuit breaker measures and sharp decline in global demand. Retrenchments reached 3,220 in Q1, with the re-entry rate dipping to 64% and 4,190 employees placed on short work-week or temporary layoff.

site_title: Fed launches long-awaited lending programme
summary: The US Federal Reserve launched the Main Street Lending Program, offering up to $600 billion in loans to US businesses with up to 15,000 employees or $5 billion in revenues. The program, administered by the Boston Fed, aims to provide credit to companies that may not qualify for the Paycheck Protection Program. Lenders must register immediately, and the loans must be repaid. The program has been adjusted twice to expand eligibility and offer five-year loans with deferred payments. Fed Chair Jerome Powell said supporting small and mid-sized businesses will foster a broad-based economic recovery.

site_title: OUE C-Reit prices S$100 million offering of 4% notes due 2025
summary: OUE Commercial Real Estate Investment Trust (OUE C-Reit) priced a S$100 million offering of 4% notes due 2025, to be guaranteed by DBS Trustee. The net proceeds will be used to refinance Reit borrowings. The notes will mature on June 24, 2025, with semi-annual interest payments. OUE C-Reit units closed at S$0.39, down 2.5%, before the news.

site_title: Private-sector economists see 5.8% GDP fall in 2020
summary: Private-sector economists predict Singapore's full-year GDP to decline by 5.8% in 2020, with a 11.8% year-on-year contraction in Q2, due to the Covid-19 pandemic. However, they foresee a 4.8% expansion in 2021. Manufacturing and finance sectors are expected to show improvement, while sectors like accommodation and food services, wholesale and retail trade, and construction are forecast to decline. The unemployment rate is predicted to be 3.6% by year-end, with core and headline inflation expected to come in at -0.3% and -0.7% respectively.

images.alt_text: Private-sector economists expect Singapore's full-year gross domestic product (GDP) to decline by 5.8 per cent in 2020, with an 11.8 per cent year-on-year contraction in the second quarter, according to the latest Monetary Authority of Singapore (MAS) survey of professional forecasters released on Monday.

site_title: Trump's niece to publish book with 'harrowing' revelations, report says
summary: President Donald Trump's niece, Mary Trump, will publish a book titled "Too Much And Never Enough" on August 11, revealing "harrowing and salacious" stories about him. The book will be the first time Trump has been forced to confront damaging revelations by a family member. Mary Trump, 55, was a primary source for The New York Times' coverage of Trump's finances, providing confidential tax documents. The book's release comes less than three weeks before Trump accepts the Republican nomination for a second term.

site_title: Bollywood stars attend Rajput's funeral as death sparks mental health debate
summary: Bollywood stars gathered for the funeral of actor Sushant Singh Rajput, who died at 34, sparking a national debate about mental health. Rajput was found dead in his Mumbai apartment, with police attributing his death to suicide. Stars like Shraddha Kapoor, Kriti Sanon, and Deepika Padukone attended the funeral, with Padukone tweeting about the importance of seeking help for mental illness. The young actor's death has led to an emotional discussion on social media, with many sharing their own struggles and encouraging others to reach out.

images.alt_text: Bollywood stars joined family members for the funeral Monday of actor Sushant Singh Rajput, whose death aged 34 has sent shock waves through the Indian film industry and rekindled a national debate about mental health.

site_title: US: Stocks open lower on renewed virus fears
summary: US stocks fell in opening trading on Monday following a fresh coronavirus outbreak in China and increased case counts in some US states, raising doubts about the economic recovery. The Dow Jones Industrial Average plummeted 2.7%, the S&P 500 shed 2.2%, and the Nasdaq Composite Index fell 1.6%. This move comes as investors worry about the impact of the virus on the US economy, despite recent record highs.

site_title: Singtel's AIS associate not liable for regulator's 7.22 billion baht revenue claim: Court
summary: A Thai court has ruled that Advanced Info Service Public Co (AIS), an associate of Singtel, is not liable for a 7.22 billion baht (S$324 million) revenue claim made by Thailand's National Broadcasting and Telecommunication Commission (NBTC). AIS argued that it had no revenue to submit due to falling user numbers and expenses outweighing revenues. The court has revoked the NBTC's payment order, and AIS will not have to pay the claim amount. AIS can still be appealed to the Supreme Administrative Court within 30 days.

site_title: Cargo ship calls at Singapore hub plummet to 27-year low
summary: Cargo ship arrivals in Singapore plummeted to a 27-year low in May, with 3,059 vessels calling at the port, the lowest since 1993. Marine fuel sales volumes also dropped 2% in May, with average bunker loadings falling to a five-month low. The decline is attributed to the coronavirus pandemic's impact on global trade, with shipping activity and bunkering demand remaining weak. The slump is expected to continue, with analysts predicting sluggish activity in June.

site_title: E-commerce startup iPrice appoints former COO as CEO
summary: iPrice, an e-commerce startup, has appointed Paul Brown-Kenyon as its new CEO, replacing founder David Chmelař. Brown-Kenyon, with over 20 years of experience in the Asian technology sector, will focus on scaling the company to meet growing consumer needs. The company saw a 60% increase in traffic on its websites during the pandemic, and is exploring partnerships with tech and media platforms. Heinrich M Wendel will take on additional responsibilities as chief product officer, following Brown-Kenyon's appointment.

site_title: Incoming travellers to Singapore will have to take swab tests, bear costs of test
summary: Singapore will require all incoming travelers to take a swab test starting June 17, with costs to be covered by the traveler. The test will be conducted at a community testing facility, and travelers must take private transport to the facility. Travelers from certain countries, including Australia and South Korea, will be able to serve their two-week stay-at-home notice (SHN) at home or a hotel at their own cost. The cost of the SHN facility and Covid-19 test will be borne by travelers unless they are Singaporeans or permanent residents.

site_title: Pandemic prompts 'de-risk' of Astrea IV structure to safeguard future bond redemption
summary: Temasek-owned Azalea Group has added US$53 million to the reserves accounts of its Astrea IV Class A bonds to "de-risk" the structure during the COVID-19 pandemic. This move aims to safeguard future bond redemption. The reserves now hold a balance of US$209 million, reducing the loan-to-value ratio to 42.4%. The move is a precautionary measure amid uncertainty over the pandemic's duration and economic disruption.

site_title: Singapore Exchange's SGX Bull Charge Charity Run heads online for 2020
summary: The Singapore Exchange's SGX Bull Charge Charity Run has shifted to an online virtual run due to the Covid-19 pandemic. The 17th edition will take place from Oct 30 to Nov 13, where participants can run at their own pace and space, with a mass run target of 100,000km. The event will raise funds for welfare organizations and the exchange will match contributions dollar for dollar, capped at S$1 million, and donate S$5 for each kilometre run. Last year's event raised over S$3.4 million.

site_title: Phase Two of Singapore's re-opening set for Friday
summary: Singapore is set to move into Phase Two of its reopening on Friday, June 19, with retail outlets, F&B dine-in, and personal health services allowed to resume, subject to certain guidelines and restrictions. Schools will reopen on June 29, with larger public venues such as malls and large retail outlets subject to capacity limits. Safe distancing measures, including social gatherings and business operations, will also be enforced. The move aims to ease measures while controlling the spread of COVID-19 and protecting vulnerable groups.

site_title: Hong Kong: Stocks finish sharply lower
summary: Hong Kong stocks plummeted over 2% on Monday as concerns over a potential second wave of COVID-19 infections in China and the US drove market fears. The Hang Seng Index fell 2.16% to 23,776.95, while the Shanghai Composite Index dropped 1.02%. The decline was attributed to fears that a resurgence in cases could disrupt economic recovery.

site_title: Nokia adds Broadcom as third 5G chip vendor to diversify supply
summary: Nokia has partnered with Broadcom to develop 5G chips, its third such deal following Intel and Marvell. The move aims to diversify supply and reduce costs. Nokia initially used Field Programmable Gate Arrays (FPGAs) but switched to custom chips due to high costs and supply issues. The company aims to have custom chips in over 35% of its 5G shipments by the end of this year, with a goal of 100% by 2022.

site_title: Beijing reinstates curbs as coronavirus resurfaces
summary: Beijing has reinstated coronavirus curbs after a surge of 79 cases linked to the Xinfadi market, the city's largest wholesale food market, in the past four days. The city has set up security checkpoints, closed schools and ordered mass testing, with over 8,900 people tested so far. The outbreak has raised concerns about the spread of the virus, with officials tracing the source to the market, which is more than 20 times larger than the Wuhan seafood market where the outbreak was first identified.

site_title: Hatten Land Q3 net loss widens to RM32.3 million
summary: Hatten Land, a Catalist-listed property developer, reported a widened net loss of RM32.3 million in the third quarter, down 92.4% from the same period last year. The group expects to record a loss for the fourth quarter and full year due to sales woes from the coronavirus pandemic and construction delays. Higher operating expenses and finance costs contributed to the loss, with revenue falling to RM7.24 million.

site_title: Jaguar Land Rover owner sees beginnings of recovery in China
summary: Jaguar Land Rover's Indian owner, Tata Motors, is seeing a recovery in China sales as the country gradually reopened after months of inactivity due to the coronavirus pandemic. China's economy contracted 6.8% in the first quarter but demand is reviving as factories reopened. A recovery in China is crucial for Tata Motors, which generates 74% of its revenue from Jaguar and Land Rover vehicles. This could bolster the Indian auto-maker's sales in the second half of the year.

site_title: Mapletree Logistics Trust to buy Brisbane warehouse for A$21.25 million
summary: Mapletree Logistics Trust has agreed to buy a newly-built warehouse in Brisbane for A$21.25 million, funded by debt. The 9,050 sqm property is fully leased to Decina for 10 years with annual rent escalations. The acquisition is expected to be completed by the third quarter of its financial year and is expected to provide a stable and growing income stream. The deal is seen as accretive with an initial yield of 5.4% and supports the growth of the Brisbane logistics market despite short-term challenges from the coronavirus pandemic.

site_title: Qantas budget arm Jetstar plans to exit Jetstar Pacific JV in Vietnam
summary: Qantas' low-cost arm Jetstar plans to exit its 30% stake in Vietnam-based Jetstar Pacific joint venture, a move prompted by challenges faced by the airline during the Covid-19 crisis. The airline will return to its original name, Pacific Airlines, pending government and regulatory approvals. Jetstar CEO Gareth Evans stated that the decision was made after talks with Vietnam Airlines, which holds a 70% stake in the venture. The exit is subject to approval from relevant authorities.

site_title: Salmon suppliers say China has halted imports after virus found at Beijing market
summary: China has halted imports of salmon after discovering the novel coronavirus at a Beijing wholesale market, affecting major suppliers including Norway Royal Salmon and Bakkafrost. The market's closure follows reports of the virus on chopping boards used for imported salmon. Shares in affected companies plummeted 5-7% in early trade. The halt in imports will likely have significant economic implications for Norway's salmon industry, which relies heavily on exports to China.

site_title: Malaysia: Shares close lower on Monday
summary: Malaysia's FTSE Bursa Malaysia Kuala Lumpur Composite Index closed lower on Monday, down 47.19 points to 1,498.83. The market saw 9.067 billion lots traded worth RM5.318 billion, with losers outnumbering gainers 1,107 to 159.

site_title: Relief for Paris restaurants as virus lockdown ends
summary: Paris restaurant owners celebrated the end of a three-month virus lockdown, allowing them to reopen their dining rooms. The move comes after a low 9 Covid-19 deaths in the previous 24 hours, marking the lowest figure since March. Owners, who had been limited to outdoor seating, expressed relief and eagerness to return to work, but warned that the social distancing rules would continue to impact capacity. Foreign tourists are not expected to return to pre-Covid numbers, and owners will need time to restock and rehire employees.

site_title: Lum Chang unit wins S$155.5 million contract to refurbish former State Courts building
summary: Lum Chang Holdings has won a S$155.5 million contract to refurbish the former State Courts building in Havelock Square, Singapore. The project, expected to begin on August 3 and take 28 months, involves structural strengthening, façade conservation, and new floor slabs. The contract, which includes a five-year maintenance service package, is not expected to significantly impact Lum Chang's financial results for the year. The company beat seven other bidders, including Tiong Aik Construction, to secure the contract.

site_title: Risk-sensitive currencies fall on fears of second wave; dollar rises
summary: The dollar rose against other currencies as a "risk-off" sentiment dominated markets due to fears of a second wave of Covid-19 infections. New cases were reported in Beijing and the US saw over 25,000 new cases on Saturday. The Australian and New Zealand dollars fell, while the Japanese yen and Swiss franc remained relatively stable. Analysts attribute the dollar's rise to its recent weakening, with some expecting the dollar to correct and profit from its recent decline.

site_title: Germany to buy stake in CureVac as world races for Covid-19 vaccine
summary: Germany will acquire a 23% stake in CureVac, a biotech firm working on a Covid-19 vaccine, for 300 million euros. The deal values CureVac at 1.3 billion euros. The move follows reported US attempts to acquire the company, which sparked a backlash in Berlin. The German government's decision is seen as a support for keeping CureVac German, following Interior Minister's comments on the matter.

site_title: Bitcoin drops below US$9,000 level for the first time since May
summary: Bitcoin dropped below US$9,000 for the first time since May, falling as much as 5.1% on Monday, amid growing concerns about a second wave of coronavirus infections. The decline mirrored a global sell-off in equities and rival digital currencies, with the Bloomberg Galaxy Crypto Index declining 6.5%. Experts attribute the drop to a lack of sustained rally above US$10,000, following the "halving" event that reduced the amount of cryptocurrency earned by miners.

site_title: Commerzbank to cut more jobs, branches: board member
summary: Commerzbank plans to announce significantly more branch closures and job cuts, exceeding previous announcements, as part of its cost-cutting strategy review in August. A member of the bank's supervisory board criticized Cerberus' demands for two board seats and cost cuts, calling its approach "rude and inappropriate." The bank rejected Cerberus' demands, and the job cuts are expected to be more substantial than previously announced.

site_title: 12 members of staff in close contact with student who tested positive for Covid-19 are well
summary: The Ministry of Health (MOH) in Singapore reported that 12 staff members who had been in close contact with a confirmed student patient at St Anthony's Canossian Secondary School tested negative for Covid-19. All 47 students who had been in contact with the student are also well. The MOH also reported three community Covid-19 cases, all of whom were work pass holders.

site_title: Mitsubishi Aircraft to focus on SpaceJet certification work this year
summary: Mitsubishi Aircraft Corp will focus on certifying its SpaceJet M90 this fiscal year, aiming to overcome design missteps and push back the delivery target six times. The company will prioritize improving the design and validating data from 3,900 hours of flight tests. This shift away from global development comes amid the COVID-19 pandemic, which has led to a reduced development budget and potential staff cuts. The certification is a key step towards the airworthiness of the aircraft, and the company aims to emerge from the crisis with a new operating plan.

site_title: Europe: Shares slide on fears of second coronavirus wave
summary: European shares plummeted 2.4% on Monday due to concerns of a second coronavirus wave, with China reporting a record number of new cases and underwhelming economic data. The Stoxx 600 index slipped further from its 5.7% fall last week, with the German exporter-heavy index leading declines. Global markets also fell as fears of economic damage from the health crisis resurfaced.

site_title: Australia: Shares end at three-week low; NZ drops as virus worries weigh
summary: Australian shares closed at their lowest level in three weeks on June 15, 2020, due to concerns over a resurgence of COVID-19 cases globally. The decline followed reports of new infections in Beijing and a surge in cases in the US. Investors shifted away from riskier assets, citing concerns about the effectiveness of current containment measures. The decline was also attributed to uncertainty over the US-China trade relationship.

site_title: Tokyo: Shares end lower on fears of another coronavirus wave
summary: Japanese shares plummeted 3.47% to a near-three-week low, falling below a key 200-day moving average, amid concerns of a second coronavirus wave. New cases in China and the US have deepened worries about a prolonged economic damage. The Nikkei average dropped to 21,530.95, its lowest since May 27.

site_title: 24 Hour Fitness files for bankruptcy amid onslaught of gym closures
summary: 24 Hour Fitness, a US-based fitness chain, has filed for bankruptcy amid an onslaught of gym closures due to the prolonged shutdown caused by the coronavirus outbreak. The company, which operates over 430 clubs, has filed a Chapter 11 petition in Delaware to rework its debt load. Despite efforts to restructure, negotiations with creditors ended in a stalemate, leading to the filing. The company's revenue declined 2% in the fourth quarter, partly due to customer defections to higher-end or budget-friendly options.

site_title: From seamless to touchless: the metamorphosis of retail
summary: The retail industry is undergoing a significant transformation due to the COVID-19 pandemic, with a shift towards touchless and seamless experiences. Retailers are adapting to changing consumer demands, such as increased online shopping and the need for contactless payment and delivery. To succeed, retailers must adopt digital strategies, including online platforms, mobile engagement, and immersive technologies like augmented reality. The future of retail will favor those who are digitally bold, with a focus on creating resilient supply chains and leveraging Industry 4.0 technologies.

site_title: H&M's March-May sales tumble by less than expected 50%
summary: H&M reported a 50% year-on-year decline in second-quarter sales to 28.7 billion crowns, slightly smaller than expected. The company's net sales fell due to measures to slow the COVID-19 pandemic, with 80% of stores initially closed. Local-currency sales in June were down 30% in the first 13 days, and 18% of its 5,058 stores remain closed temporarily. Despite a forecasted loss, H&M's shares were down 24% this year.

site_title: Seoul: Shares plunge on China's downbeat factory data, second virus wave worries
summary: South Korean shares plummeted 4.8% on Monday, the largest daily fall since late March, due to China's weaker-than-expected factory data and growing concerns of a second coronavirus wave. The Kospi index closed down 101.48 points, or 4.76%, at 2,030.82. This comes as the US sees a surge in new coronavirus cases and hospitalizations, with Florida and Texas among the states affected. The economic recovery remains fragile, adding to the uncertainty in the market.

site_title: Traders gear up for Hong Kong to defend dollar peg for 7th day
summary: Traders are bracing for Hong Kong's central bank to defend the local currency's peg to the US dollar for a seventh consecutive day, the longest run in five years. The Hong Kong dollar remains strong, trading at 7.7504 against the greenback, just four pips away from its technical limit. The Hong Kong Monetary Authority has intervened by selling HK$49.45 billion in local dollars since April to support the currency, which has benefited from a yield advantage over US rates and increased liquidity in the financial system.

site_title: China's patchy aviation recovery portends more pain for oil
summary: China's aviation market is experiencing a patchy recovery, with domestic flights rebounding but international flights still down 95% due to Covid-19 travel restrictions. This portends a slow recovery for airlines and refiners, as jet fuel demand remains at 70% of pre-virus levels. Global jet fuel consumption is expected to take until 2026 to fully recover, and the uneven recovery is causing headaches for refiners, including a global diesel glut and reduced refinery profits.

site_title: STI closes 2.64% lower at 2,613.88 on Monday
summary: The Straits Times Index (STI) fell 70.75 points, or 2.64%, to 2,613.88 on Monday, marking its third consecutive day of losses. The decline was attributed to rising new coronavirus infections globally, sparking fears of potential lockdowns. About 1.71 billion securities worth S$1.82 billion changed hands on the Singapore Exchange, with Synagie being the top traded stock, and Perennial Real Estate Holdings and United Overseas Bank also experiencing significant price movements. Regional markets also fell, with the Hang Seng, KLSE, Shanghai Composite, and Nikkei all declining.

site_title: From crowded tubes to pedal power, London's Covid transport challenge
summary: London's transport network has been reduced by 85% to comply with social-distancing rules, with capacity on the London Underground and buses cut in half. Commuters must now wear face coverings, and alternative modes of transport, such as cycling, walking, and boat services, are being promoted as solutions. Experts warn that even small increases in car journeys could lead to gridlock, and that good infrastructure alone may not be enough to encourage people to change their behavior and adopt alternative modes of transport.

images.alt_text: Capacity on the transport network in one of the world's biggest financial hubs has been reduced by 85 per cent to comply with social-distancing rules.

site_title: Uniqlo rolls out reusable mask line as retailers adapt to virus
summary: Uniqlo, Japan's largest retailer, is launching a reusable face mask line in response to the coronavirus pandemic. The masks, made from breathable AIRism fabric, will be sold in sets of three for 990 yen (S$12.54) and can be washed up to 20 times. Plans for international sales will be announced later. This move follows similar efforts by other large apparel makers, such as Gap and Adidas, as companies adapt to the pandemic's impact on lifestyles.

site_title: China's May factory output rises less than expected
summary: China's industrial output rose 4.4% in May, the highest reading since December, but fell short of expectations. Retail sales contracted for a fourth straight month, with a 2.8% drop, and fixed asset investment fell 6.3% year-over-year. The economy's recovery is uneven, with domestic demand recovering at a sluggish pace. China's central bank vice governor stated that more policy support is needed, and the government did not set a GDP growth target for the first time in nearly two decades.

site_title: Singapore marine fuel sales fall in May as cargo ship calls plummet
summary: Singapore's marine fuel sales declined to a three-month low of 3.925 million tonnes in May, down 2% from last year and 5% from April. Cargo ship calls plummeted to a five-year low of 3,059 ships, and average bunker loadings fell to a five-month low at 1,206 tonnes per ship. This decline is attributed to the detrimental impact of the coronavirus on global trade, with the number of ships calling at Singapore's top transhipment port being the lowest since 2015.

site_title: Indonesia's trade surplus larger than forecast as imports slump
summary: Indonesia's trade surplus exceeded forecasts in May, reaching $2.1 billion due to a 42% decline in imports, the largest in 11 months. Imports of consumer goods, raw materials, and capital goods all fell, while exports dropped 29% from a year ago, mainly due to oil and gas. The data suggests the economy is struggling, with a lower-than-expected GDP growth forecast of 2.3% this year, down from 5.3%. The trade surplus may pressure Bank Indonesia to lower borrowing costs to support growth.

site_title: Synagie to provide e-commerce services to WPP's GroupM clients in S-E Asia
summary: SYNAGIE Corporation has partnered with GroupM, a media investment group under WPP, to provide e-commerce services to GroupM's clients in South-east Asia. The partnership will leverage SYNAGIE's cloud-based platform for end-to-end e-commerce platform store management and fulfilment services. This will enable GroupM's clients to quickly set up their online presence and sell across multiple digital platforms in the region, with a focus on omnichannel planning, campaign execution, and consumer experience. The tie-up is expected to create greater integration for clients and capitalize on the growing internet economy in South-east Asia.

site_title: BP to take up to US$17.5b hit on coronavirus
summary: British energy giant BP will take a hit of between US$13 billion to US$17.5 billion in the second quarter due to sustained coronavirus fallout. The impact is expected to be driven by non-cash impairments and write-offs. BP had previously axed 10,000 jobs in response to the pandemic. The company's statement suggests the pandemic will have a prolonged impact on the global economy, potentially weakening energy demand for a sustained period.

images.alt_text: British energy giant BP revealed Monday that it will take a hit of between US$13 billion to US$17.5 billion in the second quarter on "sustained" coronavirus fallout.

site_title: Addvalue Tech to defer S$6m placement, subject to shareholders' approval
summary: Addvalue Tech, a Singapore-listed communications technology products developer, has deferred its S$6 million share placement to Rain Asia Pacific, pending shareholders' approval. The initial deadline for the listing and quotation of the placement shares has lapsed, and Rain Asia has requested a final deferment to complete the placement by June 23. The company has received a deposit of S$1.2 million from Rain Asia, demonstrating its commitment to the deal. Addvalue's board believes the deferment is in the company's best interest, as it would provide significant funding for the group's working capital and funding requirements.

site_title: Daily Debrief: What Happened Today
summary: Singapore's employment landscape contracted by 25,600 in Q1 2020, the largest quarterly decline on record. Private home sales rebounded 75.5% in May, while the private sector expects a 5.8% contraction in the economy this year. The CMT will provide additional rental relief to SME tenants, and OCBC plans to hire over 3,000 people this year. Digital bank Tonik raised US$21m in Series A funding, while the STI fell 2.64% to 2,613.88 on Monday due to rising global coronavirus infections.

images.alt_text: Singapore's employment landscape in the first quarter of 2020 performed worse than expected, with total employment declining by 25,600, the largest quarterly contraction on record.

site_title: China to handle some Hong Kong national security cases: official
summary: China will handle some national security cases in Hong Kong, a senior official stated, as Beijing prepares to unveil a new anti-subversion law. This move comes ahead of a major meeting of China's top lawmaking body and follows a year of pro-democracy protests. The enforcement of the national security law will largely fall to Hong Kong's local authorities and police, with the new law bypassing the city's legislature.

site_title: Facebook rejects call to share revenue with Australian media
summary: Facebook has rejected calls from the Australian government and news companies to share advertising revenue, suggesting it would rather cut news content from its platform. In a submission to Australia's competition watchdog, Facebook stated that news content represents a "very small fraction" of its average user's news feed. The US tech giant also threatened to boycott local news companies, implying that removing news content would not significantly impact its community metrics and revenues.

site_title: Malaysia: Shares open lower on Monday
summary: Malaysia's shares opened lower on Monday, with the FTSE Bursa Malaysia Kuala Lumpur Composite Index down 6.93 points, or 0.45%, to 1,539.09. Losers beat gainers 228 to 198. This marks a continuation of the market's volatility, as investors remain cautious amid global economic uncertainty.

site_title: Broker's take: DBS upgrades Koufu to 'buy' on expected rise in food court footfall with phase two reopening
summary: DBS Group Research upgraded Koufu Group to 'buy' from 'hold' with a target price of 75 cents, citing expected rise in food court footfall as Singapore lifts dining restrictions. Analysts raised FY20-21 earnings forecasts by a "marginal" 1-5% due to safe distancing measures. Koufu shares rose 2.3% to 67 cents. The upgrade comes ahead of phase two easing of Singapore's "circuit breaker".

site_title: Unilever to invest 1b euros in climate change fund over 10 years
summary: Unilever plans to invest €1 billion over 10 years in a climate change fund to support projects like reforestation, water preservation, and carbon sequestration. The company aims to reduce greenhouse gas emissions from all products to net-zero by 2039, 11 years ahead of the Paris Agreement deadline. This move follows existing efforts to cut emissions by 2030 and is part of a broader commitment to reduce its carbon footprint across its value chain.

site_title: Saudi Aramco cuts July crude supplies to at least 5 buyers in Asia: sources
summary: Saudi Aramco has cut July crude supplies to at least 5 buyers in Asia, mainly for medium and heavy grades, amid a deal with OPEC to keep production cuts of 9.7 million barrels per day until the end of July. The move follows signs of global demand recovering and tighter Middle East supplies. Saudi Aramco has also increased official selling prices (OSPs) to Asia, prompting at least one buyer to request a significant reduction in its contract volume. The cuts and price hikes reflect the market's response to the recovering demand and the rising crude valuation.

site_title: Trans Mountain pipeline to resume operations after oil spill
summary: The Trans Mountain pipeline in British Columbia, Canada, resumed operations after an oil spill occurred over the weekend. The spill released 940-1,195 barrels of light crude at the Sumas Pump Station in Abbotsford. The incident is attributed to a small, 1-inch diameter piece of pipe connected to the mainline. An investigation is underway, with monitoring showing no risk to the public or community. The pipeline carries 300,000 barrels of crude oil daily and was restarted on Sunday after a 2 pm local time restart. Cleanup efforts continue with local authorities and indigenous groups involved.

site_title: Crunch time for China's robot startups as pandemic brings pain and opportunities
summary: China's robot startups are facing a challenging time due to the pandemic, with revenue plummeting by a third and staff cuts reported. However, some companies are adapting by focusing on pet robots, warehouse automation, and disinfection robots. Despite this, access to funding is tight, and venture capitalists are cautious about investing. Major players in the industry, such as ABB and Yaskawa Electric Corp, are expected to weather the storm. For domestic startups, the rest of the year could be make or break, with some finding opportunities in alternative markets like Western countries and the healthcare sector.

site_title: Owner of Singapore 'Fort Knox' maximum-security vault sues over failed freeport sale
summary: Swiss art dealer Yves Bouvier is suing a group of businessmen over a failed sale of his Singapore freeport, Le Freeport, for US$60 million. The deal, agreed upon in October 2019, was repeatedly delayed and ultimately reneged on, with the defendants citing various issues each time. Bouvier's lawyers claim the defendants breached the contract and raised new issues that were not previously discussed. The lawsuit was filed in Singapore's High Court on April 15, 2020.

site_title: Beijing outbreak grows to nearly 100 cases in test for China
summary: China is battling a growing outbreak in Beijing, with nearly 100 cases reported over the weekend. The new outbreak is believed to have originated from the Xinfadi market, and officials are investigating contact with the city's largest fruit and vegetable market. Over 20 residential compounds have been locked down, and people are being tested at a sports stadium. This is the largest test of China's coronavirus containment strategy since the outbreak began in Wuhan.

site_title: Hong Kong's Disneyland to reopen on June 18 after coronavirus break
summary: Hong Kong's Disneyland theme park will reopen on June 18 with reduced visitor capacity and enhanced health measures, following a nearly five-month coronavirus closure. The park will implement social distancing measures, controlled capacity for shopping and dining, and gradually resume hotel services. The reopening comes after Hong Kong reported only a handful of new cases, with a total of 1,110 infections and four deaths.

site_title: Asia: Markets slip on fears of second virus wave
summary: Asian markets declined on Monday, extending losses from last week, due to fears of a second COVID-19 wave that could hinder economic recovery. European nations reopened, but China and the US are seeing a resurgence of cases. This has put pressure on stock markets, which have risen 50% since March, and will test their resilience.

site_title: 500 Startups invests in Malaysia fintech Curlec
summary: 500 Startups has invested in Malaysia-based fintech firm Curlec, which will use the funding to expand its operations, product development, and market growth. Founded in 2018, Curlec helps businesses collect recurring payments and manage cash flow through its technology on top of direct debit bank-to-bank payment infrastructure. Despite the Malaysia lockdown, Curlec has seen 20% month-on-month growth in transaction volumes, and managing partner Khailee Ng sees a huge opportunity for the company to grow in the subscription economy space.

site_title: Israel in talks to buy coronavirus vaccine from Moderna: YNET
summary: Israel is in advanced talks to purchase a coronavirus vaccine from Moderna Inc, which is nearing the final stage of testing. The vaccine's manufacturer, Moderna, plans to start a trial of 30,000 volunteers in July. No further details on the purchase were disclosed.

site_title: Digital bank Tonik raises US$21m in Series A funding
summary: Digital-only bank Tonik Financial has raised US$21 million in Series A funding led by Sequoia India and Point72 Ventures, with significant participation from previous investors. The funding will be used to launch Tonik's digital bank in the Philippines, with commercial operations set to begin in the third quarter. The Philippines represents a US$140 billion retail savings market, and Tonik aims to capitalize on the country's unbanked population of over 70%. The funding round follows Tonik's previous institutional round of funding in February, which raised US$6 million.

site_title: Hong Kong Exchange chairman supportive of national security law
summary: Hong Kong Exchange chairman Laura Cha expressed support for China's national security law, stating it will bring stability to the financial hub without jeopardizing its core values. The proposed legislation, which bans subversion and foreign interference, has sparked concerns about restricting freedoms and sparked street protests. Cha believes the law will create clarity and stability for businesses, and Hong Kong will remain a vital link between China and the West. The move has also forced businesses to choose sides, with HSBC backing the legislation despite criticism from its largest shareholder.

images.alt_text: Like many in Hong Kong, the chairman of the stock exchange was caught off guard when China revealed last month it would enact new security legislation in the former British colony. And like many of the city's business elite, she's supportive.

site_title: One Championship raises US$70m, announces job cuts as live shows halted by virus
summary: One Championship, Asia's largest mixed martial arts promotion, raised US$70 million and announced a 20% staff reduction due to the coronavirus pandemic, halting live shows. The organization, which has 201-500 employees, aims to "streamline operations" and has a total capital of US$346 million. This move comes after almost four months without live events.

site_title: China home prices rise most in six months as economy reopens
summary: China's home prices rose 0.49% in May, the fastest pace in six months, as the property market recovers from coronavirus shutdowns. New-home prices increased in 70 major cities, excluding state-subsidized housing, while secondary market values gained 0.24%, the fastest pace in seven months. The recovery suggests a strong demand for housing, but experts caution that the market may face challenges in the future. The data follows a rebound in the UK and other countries, indicating a global trend towards housing market recovery.

images.alt_text: China's home prices rose at the fastest pace in six months in May, as the property market continues its rapid recovery from the coronavirus shutdowns.

site_title: Australia to spend A$1.5b more on infrastructure, fast-track projects
summary: Australia is set to spend an additional A$1.5 billion on infrastructure and fast-track projects, including the expansion of BHP Group's Olympic Dam, to stimulate its ailing economy. The funds will be used for "small priority" projects identified by states and territories, and will expedite approvals for 15 projects, including an undersea electricity connection and road projects. The move aims to reduce the average 42-month approval period for projects to 21 months, as the country navigates its first recession in 30 years since the COVID-19 pandemic.

site_title: UK house prices increase amid lockdown easing: Rightmove
summary: UK house prices rose 1.9% in June compared to March, with average values reaching £337,884, according to Rightmove. The increase follows lockdown easing and buyers agreeing to pay 98% of asking price. Home movers delayed by stay-at-home measures drove website traffic to its 10 busiest days ever. Experts attribute the surge to high demand and upward price pressure, with no signs of panic selling or price dip. Despite economic recovery concerns, new housing supply is recovering, but the number of sellers decreased by over 175,000 between March and May.

site_title: Hong Kong: Stocks open sharply lower on Monday
summary: Hong Kong stocks plummeted 1.28% on Monday, with the Hang Seng Index falling to 23,991.38, amid concerns over a fresh wave of virus infections in China and the US. The Shanghai Composite Index and Shenzhen Composite Index also declined, with the latter remaining flat. Investors are fretting about the economic rebound, weighing on market sentiment.

site_title: Britain's Metro Bank in talks to buy peer-to-peer lender RateSetter: Sky News
summary: Britain's Metro Bank is in advanced talks to buy peer-to-peer lender RateSetter, one of the UK's biggest lenders. The price of the potential deal is unclear, and no guarantee exists that it will proceed. This comes amid a funding squeeze exacerbated by the Covid-19 pandemic. RateSetter was launched in the UK in 2010, connecting individual borrowers and lenders without a bank. The talks follow reports in March that RateSetter was exploring a sale or merger.

images.alt_text: Britain's Metro Bank Plc is in advanced talks to buy RateSetter, one of UK's biggest peer-to-peer lenders, Sky News reported on Sunday.

site_title: Stocks to watch: Keppel, Perennial, Lendlease Global Reit, CapitaLand, Union Gas
summary: Key companies to watch on Monday include Keppel, which partnered with several shareholders to take Perennial Real Estate private, while Lendlease Global Commercial Reit won a tender to redevelop a car park into a multi-functional event space. CapitaLand Mall Trust announced additional rental relief for small and medium enterprise tenants, and Union Gas reported steady growth in two business segments. Other notable developments include Sembcorp Industries being upgraded to "neutral" by OCBC Credit Research, and ISOTeam securing S$32.5 million in new projects.

site_title: Money FM podcast: A special interview with Minister Indranee Rajah
summary: Minister Indranee Rajah, in a special interview on Money FM's "The Breakfast Huddle," discussed the Fortitude Budget, emphasizing the need for Singapore to transform and seize new opportunities. Rajah analyzed the budget, focusing on its key initiatives and how they can benefit the nation.

site_title: Union Gas conserving funds for expansion
summary: Union Gas Holdings, a Singapore-based fuel retailer, has weathered the COVID-19 pandemic with steady growth in its two main business segments, LPG retail and diesel. The company's revenue and net profits have more than doubled since its listing in 2017, with a cash reserve of S$21 million. Despite a decline in its compressed natural gas segment, Union Gas has continued to expand its business through acquisitions, including two major LPG acquisitions in 2018. The company is now exploring opportunities for acquisition, diversification, and expansion into new markets such as hydrogen and electric vehicles.

site_title: Singapore private home sales rebound 75.5% in May
summary: Singapore's private home sales rebounded 75.5% in May, with 486 units sold, exceeding April's 277 units, despite the "circuit breaker" period. The surge in demand was driven by locals and investors, with a higher proportion of affordable homes sold. Non-landed homes bought by Singaporeans rose 81.1% to 402 units, while foreigners purchased 71.4% more units. Consultants see momentum continuing, with 155 new homes sold in the first week of June. The rebound is attributed to pent-up demand and substantial liquidity among buyers, despite the economic challenges posed by the pandemic.

site_title: Tokyo: Stocks open lower on Monday
summary: Tokyo stocks opened lower on Monday, with the Nikkei 225 index down 0.68% and the Topix index down 0.51%. Fears of a second wave of domestic coronavirus infections and anticipation of Chinese data later in the day contributed to the decline.

site_title: Visitors to UK shops remained more than 80% lower in May
summary: Visitors to UK shops saw a 81.6% decline in May compared to the same month last year due to the coronavirus lockdown. Some garden centres and homeware shops reopened during the month, showing a slight improvement from April's 84.7% decline. Non-essential stores can reopen on Monday as long as they follow social distancing rules. Despite Prime Minister Boris Johnson's optimism, BRC chief executive Helen Dickinson warns that immediate relief for retailers is unlikely due to low consumer confidence and limited store capacity.

site_title: Macquarie Infrastructure plans US$3b Asia fund: sources
summary: Macquarie Infrastructure and Real Assets (MIRA) is planning to raise about US$3 billion for a new Asia-focused infrastructure fund. The fund, targeting a first close in the third quarter, aims to invest in transportation, communications, and energy assets across the Asia-Pacific region. This would follow two similar funds that raised US$6.4 billion, building on MIRA's success in acquiring an 88% stake in data-center firm AirTrunk in April for over A$3 billion. The new fund will follow MIRA's existing infrastructure investments in Asia.

site_title: Macron says France has scored its 'first victory' against virus
summary: France President Emmanuel Macron announced that his country has achieved its "first victory" in the fight against the coronavirus pandemic. The victory marks the end of much of the lockdown, with all of mainland France entering a "green zone" of a lower state of alert starting Monday. This means cafes and restaurants in Paris can reopen in full, not just on terraces. Macron acknowledged that the fight against the virus is not finished, but expressed happiness about this milestone.

site_title: Germany's fastest aid for Europe starts now as tourists seek sun
summary: Germany is easing travel restrictions, allowing tourists to visit Europe starting Monday, as the continent's coronavirus lockdown eases. Germans, traditionally the biggest spending tourists in Italy, are expected to play a crucial role in boosting the southern economies, which rely heavily on visitors. Despite uncertainty, flight searches for trips to Spain and other destinations have increased, and some hotels are reporting tentative bookings. However, the summer tourism season is likely to be affected, with occupancy rates in Spain and Italy hovering at around 35-50% in July and August.

site_title: Singapore shares fall at Monday's open; STI down 1.5%
summary: Singapore shares fell 1.5% at the start of the week, with the Straits Times Index (STI) losing 39.27 points to 2,645.36. Decliners outnumbered advancers 101 to 65, with Singtel, ComfortDelGro, and CapitaLand Mall Trust trading lower. Local banks DBS, UOB, and OCBC Bank also declined. The decline follows a weak close for US stocks on Friday, amid concerns over rising Covid-19 cases and a grim outlook from the Federal Reserve.

site_title: Taiwan pedals faster to meet global pandemic demand for bikes
