summary: Taiwan's bike industry has seen a surge in demand due to the global pandemic, with factories racing to meet orders for bikes and struggling to find parts. The country, a leading bicycle producer, has managed to avoid mass lockdowns and is now benefiting from the boom. Giant, the world's largest bike company, has seen a "dizzying few months" with orders pouring in, particularly for affordable bikes under $1,000. Taiwanese manufacturers are diversifying away from China, with a new factory in Hungary set to benefit Europe. The pandemic has also led to a renaissance for Taiwan's bike industry, with electric bike exports reaching a record high.

site_title: UK's Johnson announces body to probe inequality amid race protests
summary: UK Prime Minister Boris Johnson announced the establishment of a commission to investigate and address inequality, following race protests across Britain. The commission will examine all aspects of inequality, including employment and health outcomes. Johnson argued that tackling the "substance" of the problem, rather than its symbols, is necessary. He also defended keeping a statue of Winston Churchill outside parliament, despite criticism from activists.

site_title: Indonesia orders firms to stagger duty hours as malls reopen
summary: Indonesian authorities have ordered companies to stagger duty hours to prevent overcrowding on public transportation during peak hours as shopping malls reopened. Employees will work either between 7am-7:30am or 10am-10:30am, with a 4-hour gap between shifts. This measure aims to reduce physical distancing challenges due to high commuter rail passenger numbers. The decision follows a review that found over 75% of commuters leave work between 5:30am and 6:30am.

site_title: AMTD to take majority stake in private capital platform CapBridge
summary: AMTD Digital will take a majority stake in private capital platform CapBridge Financial for an undisclosed sum as part of a strategic partnership to expand the digital assets exchange platform. The collaboration aims to tap the private market and digital assets exchange knowledge of CapBridge, and leverage AMTD's digital solutions platform strength. With AMTD's backing, CapBridge will develop the global private markets and digital asset space from its Singapore headquarters, with plans to build a "Singapore-centric Asian fintech platform" to expand across South-east Asia and connect with China.

site_title: English shops, attractions to reopen as virus lockdown eased
summary: English shops and outdoor attractions are set to reopen on Monday after nearly three months of lockdown, with thousands of non-essential retailers and leisure sites such as drive-in cinemas and zoos reopening. The government has eased restrictions, requiring social distancing and face coverings, and finance minister Rishi Sunak encouraged shopping to help kickstart the economy. However, the non-essential retail sector, which employs 1.3 million people, is still adapting to the new rules, with some predicting it will take time to return to normal.

site_title: 'Disinfecting non-stop' as Italy faces two new virus outbreaks
summary: Italy is experiencing two new outbreaks of COVID-19, one at a Rome squat with 15 cases and another at a hospital with 109 cases and five deaths. Authorities have taken measures to contain the outbreaks, including testing and contact tracing. The outbreaks come as Italy is cautiously relaxing measures to contain the disease, which has claimed over 34,000 lives. Health officials stress that the virus remains infectious and that vigilance is necessary to prevent further spread.

site_title: Australia aims to expand onshore fuel storage capacity, in talks with refiners
summary: Australia plans to expand onshore fuel storage capacity by developing domestic facilities to bolster emergency oil stockpiles. Energy Minister Angus Taylor announced the plan in a statement, citing the impact of the Covid-19 pandemic on fuel supply and demand. The country is currently spending A$94 million to buy crude for the US Strategic Petroleum Reserve, and the move is expected to enhance Australia's fuel reliability.

site_title: Britain records lowest daily virus toll since March
summary: Britain recorded 36 new deaths of people testing positive for Covid-19, the lowest daily toll since March 21, according to Health Secretary Matt Hancock. The total number of deaths since the start of the pandemic stands at 41,698, and the total number of people testing positive rose to 295,889. The drop in contaminations gives the government "more margin for manoeuvre" to relax social distancing rules, with the reopening of non-essential retail businesses and some leisure activities set for next month.

site_title: Warehouses in vogue amid stockpiling, surge in e-commerce
summary: Singapore's warehouse leasing activity has remained resilient in the past three months, driven by national stockpiling efforts, e-commerce growth, and safety concerns. Short-term leases ranging from six months to two years are being signed, and landlords are raising asking rents. Leasing demand for logistics/warehouse space has outperformed other segments of the Singapore industrial property market. The average occupancy for ramp-up logistics facilities has reached 98%, with forecasted growth in rents and a constrained supply pipeline for logistics properties. Market observers expect the resilient leasing activity to boost property investment interest in the sector.

site_title: Hong Kong's rich preparing for worst-case scenario
summary: Hong Kong's wealthy individuals are preparing for a worst-case scenario, with some moving millions of dollars to Singapore and applying for alternative passports. The city's high property prices are driving this trend. Meanwhile, China's economic growth is expected to slow, putting pressure on policymakers. Chinese banks are struggling with a push to increase consumer lending, while Japan's MUFG is targeting the US for securitization business. The US is also imposing tariffs, including a 35% tariff on Canada, which may prompt other countries to diversify their investments. This shift in global economic dynamics is affecting financial markets.

site_title: Baltic Exchange Shipping Insights
summary: The Baltic Exchange Shipping Insights report highlights a strong week for the Capesize market, with iron ore demand driving prices to new highs for the year. The 5TC Capesize index settled at $12,410, while voyage routes C3 and C14 saw significant increases. The Panamax market also experienced a substantial recovery, with Australian and NoPac round trips hovering around the mid-$7,000s mark. Meanwhile, the Ultramax/Supramax sector saw stronger demand from the US Gulf and Indian Ocean, with period activity returning.

site_title: Stuck at home, the world is eating less sugar
summary: Global sugar demand is expected to drop for the first time in four decades due to the COVID-19 pandemic's impact on out-of-home spending. The lockdowns of sports arenas and cinemas led to a 1.2% decline in sugar consumption, resulting in a projected 169.9 million tonnes this season. Analysts predict bigger-than-expected sugar surpluses, but global consumption is expected to rebound 3.6% next season as lockdown measures ease. The decline in demand has also affected major companies like Coca-Cola and PepsiCo, with volumes sliding 25% and revenue expected to fall.

site_title: New York governor threatens reopening rollback over street drinking
summary: New York Governor Andrew Cuomo threatened to roll back the state's phased reopening plans due to widespread violations of coronavirus lockdown guidelines. Cuomo reported 25,000 complaints of reopening violations, including large crowds, parties in the street, and businesses ignoring social distancing rules. The governor's office has been monitoring the situation closely, and any further rule-breaking could lead to a rollback of the reopening plans.

site_title: Opec gets chance to gain upper hand in long battle with shale
summary: Opec, the Organization of Petroleum Exporting Countries, is reviving its standing in the global oil market as the coronavirus crisis subsides. The cartel has reduced millions of barrels of output to prop up crude prices, which have been weakened by the pandemic. This move could lead to greater dependence on Opec's crude, potentially gaining the cartel an upper hand in its long battle with shale oil producers. Analysts see this as a strategic move to regain market share and influence in the global oil market.

site_title: Lian Beng increases its stake in SLB
summary: Lian Beng Group increased its stake in SLB Development, its Catalist-listed property developer spin-off, after acquiring 3,936,500 shares for S$468,444. This raised its total interest in SLB to 76.24%. The move comes as SLB reported a net profit of S$3.6 million in Q2 FY20, a turnaround from a net loss in the same period last year.

site_title: More aid for job loss, low income can bolster Singapore's social safety net
summary: Singapore's social safety nets, particularly those related to job loss and low income, can be strengthened, according to observers. Prime Minister Lee Hsien Loong emphasized the need to improve the social compact in a recent speech. While the country has taken emergency measures to help through the Covid-19 crisis, experts suggest bolstering support for economically vulnerable middle-class individuals. This would help balance the need for self-reliance with a more comprehensive safety net. Enhancements could include additional aid for job loss and low income, as well as targeted support for the middle class.

site_title: Britain reviewing distancing rules; may ease travel quarantine
summary: Britain's finance minister Rishi Sunak announced the country is reviewing its social distancing rules, potentially easing travel quarantine to aid the economy's recovery from the coronavirus crisis. The move, driven by progress in tackling the pandemic, could allow three-quarters of pubs to reopen. Sunak also hinted at introducing travel corridors with specific countries, aiming to reopen the economy "slowly and safely", starting with the retail sector this week. The goal is to revive the economy without risking a second wave of coronavirus cases.

site_title: Some global funds more optimistic on Singapore market than equity analysts
summary: Global funds are more optimistic about the Singapore market than analysts, citing valuations, fiscal stimulus, and the economy's reopening. Fund managers at Fidelity, Citigroup, and Bank of Singapore expect the Straits Times Index to rise 10% in the next 12 months, despite being projected at the lowest estimated return since 2018. Singapore is considered "one of the cheapest" markets in Asia, with a record-low valuation of 0.9 times book value. Global investors are seeking value plays, and the market is expected to benefit from the rotation towards cyclical and value shares.

site_title: China reports 49 more virus cases as Beijing tests thousands
summary: China reported 49 new coronavirus cases, including 36 in Beijing, where a fresh cluster linked to a wholesale food market has raised concerns of a second wave. Mass testing has begun in the area, with over 10,000 residents already tested. The National Health Commission also reported 10 imported cases and 177 total cases in China, with two severely ill patients. Authorities are tracing those who visited the market and have locked down 11 residential neighborhoods near the market.

site_title: Saudi property firm Amlak plans first post-coronavirus Riyadh IPO
summary: Saudi Arabian real estate financing firm Amlak International plans to float 30% of its shares in Riyadh, the kingdom's first initial public offering (IPO) since the coronavirus crisis. The IPO aims to deepen Saudi Arabia's capital markets and reduce its reliance on oil revenues. Amlak's assets total around 3.1 billion riyals, and the final offer price will be announced on June 30. The company expects the IPO to provide more visibility, reduce costs, and boost profitability.

site_title: High Street Centre up for collective sale with S$800m reserve price
summary: The High Street Centre, a mixed-use tower in Singapore, is up for collective sale with a reserve price of S$800 million. The site spans 5,601.9 sqm and has an allowable gross plot ratio of 7.72. Owners holding at least 80% of the strata area and share value have agreed to put it on the market with the specified price tag, allowing for commercial and hotel use. The property consultant, Cushman & Wakefield, confirmed the sale details.

site_title: SoftBank invested in Credit Suisse funds financing its bets: report
summary: SoftBank invested approximately US$500 million in Credit Suisse's supply-chain finance funds, which then invested in debt of startups backed by SoftBank's Vision Fund. This investment occurred over the past year, according to reports citing marketing documents.

site_title: Singapore Pools to resume online betting
summary: Singapore Pools announced that online sports betting will resume from June 15, while online horse wagering for overseas races will resume from June 17. The physical outlets and lottery draws remain suspended due to the government's phased approach for safe reopening. Prize payment services will also be suspended, with an announcement to be made for eligible prize-winning tickets. Customers can contact the company's customer service hotline for further queries.

site_title: OCBC to hire more than 3,000 people this year
summary: OCBC Bank plans to hire over 3,000 people in Singapore this year, with 2,100 full-time roles and 900 traineeships and internships. The positions are across various areas, including wealth management, corporate banking, and technology. The bank aims to boost disposable incomes and consumer confidence, contributing to the country's economic recovery. This move follows DBS' announcement of hiring over 2,000 people in Singapore, also focusing on technology and growth areas.

images.alt_text: OCBC said on Monday that it plans to hire over 3,000 people in Singapore this year, amid the economic and employment uncertainty due to the Covid-19 pandemic.

site_title: Quake strikes east Turkey, 1 dead
summary: A 5.7-magnitude earthquake struck Bingol province in eastern Turkey on Sunday, killing one person. A security guard was trapped under the rubble of an observation tower, but another guard was pulled out alive. Vice President Fuat Oktay and interior ministers visited the scene. This is the second major earthquake to hit Turkey in six months, following a 6.8-magnitude quake in January that killed over 40 people.

site_title: Royal Ascot lacks special feeling this year, says leading trainer Johnston
summary: Leading trainer Mark Johnston says Royal Ascot lacks its special feeling this year due to the COVID-19 pandemic, which has reduced prize money and eliminated spectators. Johnston, who has won the prestigious Ascot Gold Cup three times, expressed mixed feelings about racing at the event, describing it as "weird" without owners and staff. Despite this, he is excited about his chances of winning the Gold Cup and praised owners for keeping the racing business afloat during the pandemic.

site_title: Listed firms not in a rush to privatise despite battered share prices
summary: Local listed firms are hesitant to privatize due to battered share prices amid the COVID-19 pandemic. Despite offers for Perennial Real Estate Holdings and Elec & Eltek International Co, many players are waiting to see how the situation unfolds. Experts believe the real economic impact of the pandemic is yet to be determined, making it difficult for companies to consider privatization or mergers. Share buybacks and mergers are more likely to occur first, according to analysts, with hostile takeovers expected in the final phase of recovery.

site_title: OEL completes 51% acquisition of Chinese healthcare company
summary: OEL Holdings has completed the acquisition of a 51% stake in Shanghai Longjian Hospital Management, making it an indirect subsidiary. Shanghai Longjian, founded in Shanghai last year, focuses on hospital management, medical technology, and health consulting. Chairman Zhang Jian will lead the company alongside AJJ Health Care Management personnel, while Shanghai Longjian's founder Ye Wenzheng will continue to lead the medical team. OEL also announced a joint venture with Shanghai Suntec to manufacture and distribute medical products, with plans to launch in July and expand to Southeast Asia and the US.

site_title: Singapore's total employment in Q1 sees largest quarterly contraction on record: MOM
summary: Singapore's total employment in Q1 2020 declined by 25,600, the largest quarterly contraction on record, according to the Ministry of Manpower. This represents a 0.7% decrease, mainly due to significant cutbacks in foreign employment and sharper-than-expected declines in trade and tourism-related industries. The sharpest decline was seen in the food and beverage services sector, with 8,300 jobs lost, while the public administration and education sector saw the biggest expansion with 2,500 new jobs.

images.alt_text: Singapore's employment landscape in the first quarter of 2020 performed worse than expected, with total employment declining by 25,600, the largest quarterly contraction on record, according to the Ministry of Manpower (MOM) on Monday.

site_title: Fearless day traders could power US stock market
summary: The US stock market faces uncertainty as a second wave of the COVID-19 pandemic hits some states, prompting concerns about a potential crash. Despite this, strategists believe that fearless day traders could power the market higher, citing Google mobility data showing consumers in reopened states ignoring warnings about "second waves". The US Federal Reserve has reassured its readiness to intervene, but the labor market is expected to suffer multi-year damage. A recent selloff, the biggest since March, has raised questions about the economy's recovery and the potential for lockdowns.

site_title: How to ease premium payments but still maintain your insurance
summary: During Singapore's severe COVID-19 crisis, nearly half of working adults have lost income, forcing them to reduce or stop saving for retirement. However, maintaining insurance plans is crucial to avoid financial hardship due to death, severe illness, and disability. Some insurers offer flexible payment options, such as temporary premium deferrals or premium waivers, allowing policyholders to continue coverage while managing cash flow. These options may have conditions, but can help individuals maintain coverage without cancelling their policies.

site_title: Hotels bet on staycations to survive Covid-19
summary: The global hotel industry is relying on staycations to survive the COVID-19 pandemic. With lockdowns easing, travelers are opting for local getaways, leading to a 50% decline in guest nights in the US compared to pre-pandemic levels. Hotels in Asia, where staycations have been a successful strategy, are providing a roadmap for European and American hotels. Analysts predict that staycationers can boost US and European hotel occupancies, but experts warn that a second COVID-19 wave could cause mass cancellations. High-luxury and economy hotels are seen as more resilient, while properties centered on amenities and events are struggling.

site_title: AmEx wins clearing licence for China's 190t yuan market
summary: American Express (AmEx) has won a network clearing licence from the People's Bank of China to process local currency transactions, marking the first time a foreign payments network has been allowed to do so in the country. The approval is seen as a step forward in China's efforts to open its financial markets to foreign capital and support growth. AmEx will start clearing services within six months and will cooperate with leading Chinese mobile wallet services providers, processing both online and offline payment transactions.

site_title: Bond traders grasp grim reality of economy's long recovery slog
summary: US Treasury yields have fallen back to around 0.7% after investors reassessed the economy's slow recovery from the pandemic, contrary to expectations of a breakout higher. The Federal Reserve's pledge to keep interest rates near zero for years has contributed to the decline, with strategists predicting a slow creep higher in the months ahead. The economy is expected to show signs of recovery in areas such as retail sales and housing, but concerns about job losses and the ongoing pandemic may limit optimism.

site_title: Oil prices drop as rising US coronavirus cases stoke fears of weak fuel demand
summary: Oil prices dropped on Monday, with US oil falling 2% and Brent crude futures falling 1.7%. The decline was driven by concerns over a potential second wave of the US coronavirus, which could weigh on fuel demand recovery. Over 25,000 new cases were reported on Saturday, prompting fears of a second wave. The Organization of the Petroleum Exporting Countries (Opec) and its allies agreed to reduce supplies by 9.7 million barrels per day until end-July.

site_title: Lawmakers brand British Airways job cuts a 'national disgrace'
summary: UK lawmakers have criticized British Airways for its 12,000 job cuts, labeling the move a "national disgrace." The House of Commons transport committee stated that the airline took advantage of the Covid-19 crisis to slash headcount and weaken employment terms. The committee urged the government to penalize firms receiving taxpayer funds for making sweeping cuts, and called for a review of airport slot allocation. British Airways has since proposed offering voluntary redundancy to pilots and other staff.

site_title: Private-sector economists expect Singapore economy to contract 5.8% this year
summary: Private-sector economists predict Singapore's full-year GDP to decline by 5.8% in 2020, with a 11.8% year-on-year contraction in the second quarter. The COVID-19 pandemic has led to a significant decline in expectations, with contraction forecasts worsening for accommodation and food services, wholesale and retail trade, and construction. However, there is a possibility of recovery in 2021, with GDP growth forecast to expand 4.8%. The top downside risks include escalation in COVID-19 situation and trade tensions, while a containment of the outbreak and stronger-than-expected global economic recovery are seen as potential upside risks.

site_title: Region's online consumption boost may continue post-lockdown: Bain
summary: A report by Bain & Company and Facebook suggests that South-east Asia's online consumption boost, accelerated by the Covid-19 pandemic, may continue even as authorities relax safe-distancing measures. Digital and e-commerce growth accelerated, with 85% of respondents trying new apps, and demand for essential items increasing online. Consumers prioritize "value for money" and are more health-conscious and environmentally aware, driving shifts in traditional businesses and marketplaces.

site_title: Russia rated top best-value market by Cape ratio; Singapore is 11th
summary: Russia is rated the top best-value market by the Cape ratio, with a low valuation of 6.4, despite a dire economy and high Covid-19 infections. South Korea is second with a Cape of 11.8, followed by Austria, the Czech Republic, and China. Singapore ranks 11th with a Cape of 11.3, while the US is the most overvalued market with a Cape of 28.3, driven by the FAANG stocks. The Cape ratio is a guideline to determine overvaluation, not a timing indicator, and some developed nations have poor economic results, such as the UK.

site_title: US records 382 virus deaths in 24 hours, lowest in weeks: monitor
summary: The US recorded 382 coronavirus-related deaths in the last 24 hours, bringing its death toll to 115,729, according to Johns Hopkins University. This is the lowest 24-hour toll since mid-April. The country continues to experience around 20,000 new cases daily, with infection rates fluctuating nationwide. The administration of President Donald Trump remains optimistic about the economy, stating that a second wave of cases will not lead to a shutdown.

images.alt_text: The United States has recorded 382 coronavirus-related deaths in the last 24 hours, bringing its death toll to 115,729, according to a tally on Sunday by Johns Hopkins University.

site_title: Perennial CEO, partners make share offer to take it private
summary: Perennial's CEO, Pua Seck Guan, is partnering with substantial shareholders to take the company private. An entity called Primero Investment Holdings is offering S$0.95 cash per share for all Perennial shares, representing a 37.7% premium over the company's close on June 9. The offer is conditional upon receiving 90% acceptances, allowing Primero to delist the company. The consortium owns 82.43% of Perennial's shares, with Hopu Fund Management Company financing the remaining 17.57%.

site_title: CMT to give additional rental relief to SME tenants; CapitaLand accelerates China digitalisation push
summary: Singaporean real estate investment trust CapitaLand Mall Trust (CMT) will provide additional rental relief to small and medium enterprise (SME) tenants, on top of a new rental relief law that waives up to two months of base rent. The relief will be provided to non-qualifying tenants, with the aim of supporting businesses affected by the pandemic. Meanwhile, CapitaLand is accelerating its digitalisation push in China, with a focus on boosting online sales through its e-commerce platform, CapitaStar.

site_title: A hand up vs a handout
summary: Singapore can strengthen social support systems while maintaining self-reliance by leveraging partnerships across sectors, focusing on temporary reliefs, and providing tools and skills for individuals to thrive. Taxation must become more progressive to fund increased support. Employers can play a key role by subsidizing continuing education and training, especially in in-demand areas. The government can also improve social security, work closely with communities, and enhance social capital and solidarity. Consolidating means-tested public assistance schemes and raising payouts under existing schemes are also recommended. Ultimately, a balanced approach that encourages self-reliance while providing necessary support is crucial for Singapore's resilience.

site_title: Iran prepared to retaliate if US forces stop Venezuela-bound tankers
summary: Iran's naval forces are preparing to target US commercial vessels in the Gulf if US forces interfere with Venezuela-bound Iranian oil tankers, according to an Iranian news agency. Iran sent tankers to Venezuela in May, despite US criticism and sanctions. The US is considering imposing sanctions on dozens of foreign oil tankers for trading with Venezuela. Tensions between the US and Iran have escalated since 2018, following US President Donald Trump's withdrawal from Iran's 2015 nuclear deal and reimposition of sanctions.

site_title: Brazil's Treasury secretary expected to resign soon, source says
summary: Brazil's Treasury Secretary Mansueto Almeida is expected to resign soon, according to a source. Almeida, who has held the position for one and a half years, is expected to join a private company after his departure. No immediate comment was given by the Economy Ministry.

site_title: Hmlet readies property listing platform; names new CFO, CTO
summary: Hmlet, a Singapore-based co-living operator, is launching a property listing platform that allows landlords to list their properties directly with the startup. The platform provides advanced analytics and services, enabling better insights into property performance. Hmlet has also appointed Rajive Keshup as CFO and Pramodh Rai as CTO, aiming to diversify its offerings and scale. The platform is currently in beta and expected to launch in early Q3, with the goal of serving over 5,000 members in the Asia-Pacific by the end of the year.

site_title: Another police killing of a black man stokes US tension, debate
summary: A black man, Rayshard Brooks, was fatally shot by a white police officer in Atlanta, Georgia, sparking widespread protests and debate over racism. The incident occurred after Brooks failed a sobriety test and struggled with police, leading to a fatal confrontation. Police Chief Erika Shields resigned, and Officer Garrett Rolfe was dismissed. The death drew outrage, with lawmakers debating police reform and the "defund the police" movement. The incident is the latest in a string of police killings, including the May 25 killing of George Floyd in Minneapolis, Minnesota.

site_title: Postal staff put stamp on UK outbreak
summary: Royal Mail staff delivered 308 million fewer letters in the five weeks to May 3, down 33% on a year earlier, but saw a 31% jump in parcel deliveries during the UK's coronavirus pandemic. The company's core letters business slumped, but staff played a key role in delivering virus test-kits and helping businesses survive the economic fallout. The company's interim head, Keith Williams, has helped stabilize the company after the sudden departure of CEO Rico Back, who was accused of being slow to provide protective equipment to workers.

images.alt_text: For many customers, receiving an item that they have ordered online from the Royal Mail postmen and postwomen can really brighten up their day in these challenging times.

site_title: China's slow aviation recovery a warning to others
summary: China's domestic flight capacity has recovered to within 7% of year-earlier levels, but international capacity remains down 95% due to the ongoing COVID-19 pandemic. The country's aviation market is expected to experience a long and slow recovery, with global jet fuel consumption not expected to fully recover until 2026. Other countries emerging from lockdowns, particularly those without a large domestic base, will likely face similar challenges in rebooting international travel and aviation demand.

images.alt_text: As China's economy began to recover from novel coronavirus-induced stay-at-home orders in April, Victor Li took to the sky again.

site_title: LMIRT reopens most malls, retail spaces as Indonesia eases Covid-19 restrictions
summary: Lippo Malls Indonesia Retail Trust (LMIRT) has reopened 21 of its malls and 6 retail spaces across Indonesia with social distancing measures, following the easing of Covid-19 restrictions by the Indonesian government. Eight malls and two retail spaces in greater Jakarta reopened on June 15, while others have reopened since May 13. The trust is cautiously optimistic about mall operations recovery, with occupancy rates and future collections being its primary focus. Two remaining malls are scheduled to reopen on July 3, and one retail space on June 16.

site_title: Queen Elizabeth marks official birthday with scaled-back parade at Windsor
summary: Queen Elizabeth II marked her official birthday with a scaled-back Trooping the Colour ceremony at Windsor Castle, her first public appearance since the UK's virus lockdown. The 94-year-old monarch watched a smaller military parade from a dais, with soldiers from the Welsh Guards maintaining social distancing guidelines. The ceremony, dubbed mini-Trooping, was the first time Windsor Castle had staged an event since 1895 due to the coronavirus pandemic, which has affected the UK's worst-hit population.

site_title: Sembmarine's recapitalisation plan: Is more restructuring really afoot?
summary: Sembcorp Marine is considering a recapitalisation plan amid persistent merger speculation with Keppel Corp's offshore and marine arm. Regulators should scrutinize the situation, as both companies are controlled by Temasek Holdings. A merger could enhance competitiveness in the global offshore and marine market. However, the idea has been quietly discussed among analysts and journalists for years, with no official confirmation from the companies.

images.alt_text: On June 8, plans were unveiled to recapitalise Sembcorp Marine through a massive S$2.1 billion rights issue, and then separate it from its parent Sembcorp Industries.

site_title: Strength expected for NZD/USD pair
summary: The New Zealand dollar (NZD) is expected to gain further strength against the US dollar (USD) due to the country's virus-free status and reopening economy. The NZD/USD pair is poised to retest its year-high, driven by improving fundamentals, technical indicators, and a dovish Fed outlook. The pair's strength is also supported by a narrowing gap between short-term and long-term moving averages, a bullish signal, and a strong buying trend. Immediate resistance is expected at 0.676, while the 61.8% Fibonacci level provides support.

site_title: Asia's electronics sector booms, bucking global economic slump
summary: Asia's electronics sector is bucking the global economic slump, driven by strong demand for semiconductors, 5G equipment, and automation tools. South Korea and Taiwan's semiconductor exports rose in May, with Taiwan's electronic-component exports growing 13.2% to $10.2 billion. Companies are investing in new technologies to facilitate remote work, and governments are providing support for digital transformations. However, consumer demand remains lagging, and US-China tensions could constrain progress. Analysts expect a sustainable boost if consumers return with similar vigor and digital demand and supply continue to grow.

site_title: DBS, Lions Befrienders launch Singapore's largest-ever virtual befriending initiative
summary: DBS Bank and Lions Befrienders have launched Singapore's largest-ever virtual befriending initiative, LB Virtual Befriending@ SAC, to help alleviate social isolation and loneliness among seniors amid the COVID-19 pandemic. The 8-week program, set to start in early July, will connect 1,000 DBS employees with 1,000 senior beneficiaries through online activities such as conversations, sing-along sessions, and games. The initiative aims to reach out to Lions Befrienders' pool of 6,000 seniors and provide companionship to those in need, addressing the emotional and mental health challenges faced by seniors during the pandemic.

site_title: Hong Kong's rich are preparing for a worst-case scenario
summary: Wealthy individuals in Hong Kong are preparing for a worst-case scenario amid the city's economic and political crises. Many have moved assets to Singapore, the UK, or alternative passports, while others are opening offshore bank accounts. Private bankers report an increase in contingency planning efforts, with some clients considering emigration to countries like Australia or the US. While there's no evidence of widespread capital flight, the situation underscores the challenge for Chief Executive Carrie Lam to maintain Hong Kong's status as a magnet for Asian wealth.

site_title: Machu Picchu to sharply limit visits after July reopening in Peru
summary: Peru's Machu Picchu to limit daily visitor numbers to 675 starting July after a virus-imposed closure. To prevent COVID-19 spread, visitors will be led in groups of 7, and masks will be mandatory. This is a significant reduction from the usual 2,500 visitors. The move aims to revive the tourism industry, which has suffered losses of $3.3 billion this year. The site, a UNESCO World Heritage Site, last closed in 2010 due to a flood, and its reopening is linked to the lifting of national confinement measures in place since March 16.

site_title: Investor confidence to tide Singapore over Covid-19 crisis: Chan Chun Sing
summary: Singapore's Minister for Trade and Industry Chan Chun Sing says investor confidence remains strong due to the country's open economy, infrastructure, and stability. In the first four months of 2020, the Economic Development Board secured S$13 billion of investment commitments from companies like ExxonMobil and ST Microelectronics. Chan emphasizes the importance of Singapore's connectedness with the world, stable society, and skilled workforce in attracting investments. Despite the uncertainty caused by Covid-19, Singapore is expected to create 100,000 jobs and training opportunities in various sectors, and the government is building digital economy partnerships to boost exports.

site_title: Low Keng Huat says it can withstand short-term cash flow pressures from Covid-19
summary: Low Keng Huat, a Singapore-based builder, stated it can withstand short-term cash flow pressures due to the Covid-19 pandemic with its liquidity and bank support. The company has S$68.6 million in cash and S$194 million in unused banking lines. It plans to focus on completing development projects, optimizing operations, and reducing costs. Low Keng Huat will also maintain its F&B business and implement cost-cutting measures. The company's shares closed at S$0.39 on Friday.

site_title: Keppel's Alpha in Indonesia logistics venture with Manulife unit, Mega Manunggal Property
summary: Keppel's Alpha Investment Partners, Manulife subsidiary Asuransi Jiwa Manulife Indonesia, and Mega Manunggal Property have entered into a new venture focusing on Indonesia's logistics property sector. The venture, called Keppel-MMP Indonesia Logistics Fund, aims to raise US$200 million with an initial US$93 million in capital commitments from venture partners. This partnership will focus on developing logistics properties in Indonesia, with Manulife providing co-investment capital.

site_title: Dollar gains versus yen, Swiss franc as US stocks bounce back
summary: The US dollar rose against the Japanese yen and Swiss franc on Friday as stocks on Wall Street rebounded from their worst one-day performance in three months. The dollar surged 0.6% against the yen and 1.2% against the Swiss franc, while the euro fell 0.6% to US$1.1228. The dollar index climbed 0.5% to 97.33, driven by hopes of a post-Covid-19 global recovery and easing US-China trade tensions. Investors are now bracing for key events, including EU recovery fund discussions and the Federal Reserve chair Jerome Powell's semi-annual testimony.

site_title: Redas donates S$451,000 of vouchers to SingHealth
summary: Redas, the Real Estate Developers' Association of Singapore, donated S$451,000 in NTUC vouchers to SingHealth in appreciation of frontline healthcare staff during the Covid-19 pandemic. The donation was made with Desmond Lee, Minister for Social and Family Development, as the guest of honour. The Redas Solidarity Project Fund aims to support healthcare workers and migrant workers in the built environment sector. The donation is part of a total of S$852,000 raised by Redas members to support these workers. The gift aims to boost staff well-being and resilience during the challenging time.

site_title: Lawmakers brand British Airways job cuts a 'national disgrace'
summary: UK lawmakers criticized British Airways for planning 12,000 job cuts, calling it a "national disgrace" during the coronavirus crisis. The airline's plans to dismiss pilots and rehire them on new contracts were deemed exploitative. The House of Commons transport committee urged the government to penalize firms receiving taxpayer funds for making sweeping cuts and called for a review of airport slot allocation. British Airways responded that it's battling to survive the crisis and will retain the maximum number of jobs consistent with a shrinking travel market.

site_title: Co-working firms dangle perks as they brace for post-pandemic pressures
summary: Co-working firms in Singapore are adapting to post-pandemic pressures by offering discounts and safe-distancing measures to attract new members and retain existing ones. Many operators face increased vacancies due to members opting for downsized spaces or working from home. To address this, some firms are offering extended contract lengths, free months, and flexible lease options. Industry watchers caution that the prevailing business model of taking on long-term lease obligations may be a risk, and operators must evolve further to remain relevant. Despite this, many believe that co-working will continue to be relevant post-pandemic due to the demand for flexible workspace solutions.

site_title: China's foreigner ban leaves global businesses in limbo
summary: China's coronavirus travel ban has left global businesses and international schools in limbo, with many key employees and students stranded in their home countries. The ban, which was implemented in March, has complicated the process for key business personnel to return, requiring approval from the foreign ministry and an invitation letter. This has resulted in significant financial losses for companies, with some considering relocating permanently. International schools are also struggling, with students and teachers stranded overseas and some parents demanding refunds for tuition fees. The ban is expected to have long-term implications for China's attractiveness as a destination for international businesses and families.

site_title: Investor confidence will tide Singapore through uncertainty: Chan Chun Sing
summary: Singapore's Minister for Trade and Industry Chan Chun Sing says investor confidence in the country's open economy, infrastructure, and stability will help it navigate uncertain times. Despite uncertainty, Singapore attracted $13 billion in investment commitments from companies such as ExxonMobil and ST Microelectronics in the first four months of 2020. Chan expressed confidence in Singapore's ability to grow and thrive despite potential job losses and pay cuts.

site_title: Singapore Pools to resume online betting for sports and horse racing, outlets remain closed
summary: Singapore Pools has announced the resumption of online sports betting and horse racing from June 15 and June 17, respectively. However, physical outlets, including lottery draws, remain closed until further notice. Prize payment services are also suspended until further notice. The decision is in line with the government's phased approach to safe reopening and resumption of business activities, prioritizing customer safety and well-being.

site_title: China reports 57 new virus cases as Beijing cluster grows
summary: China reported 57 new cases of the coronavirus on June 14, the highest daily figure since April, as a cluster linked to a wholesale food market in south Beijing grew. The cases were largely local transmissions in the capital, with 36 linked to the Xinfadi market. Fresh lockdowns were imposed in 11 residential estates near the market, and city officials delayed the return of primary school students. The outbreak has raised concerns about the hygiene of the city's food supply chain, with major supermarkets removing imported salmon from their stocks.

site_title: Investors in German bonds face conundrum over Europe's safest asset
summary: Investors in German bonds face a conundrum as the debt's rally in the past week suggests yields may soon turn positive after a year below zero. However, past attempts to short the bonds have been unsuccessful, with investors instead seeking havens like bunds due to economic recovery and regional stimulus. Analysts predict higher yields due to economic growth, but investors must weigh the risks of shorting the safest asset in Europe.

site_title: Deutsche Bank says it doesn't need capital increase
summary: Deutsche Bank AG says it can overcome the economic shock from the coronavirus pandemic without a capital increase, citing its strong capital buffers and liquidity position. Despite billions in losses, management believes the bank can absorb currently foreseeable burdens without weakening its equity base excessively. The bank has increased provisions for possible credit losses to 800 million euros, but expects lower provisions for the rest of the year. Deutsche Bank's risk chief attributes the bank's resilience to the German government's aid programs and the country's strong economic position during the crisis.

site_title: Public servant arrested for allegedly leaking classified information about post 'circuit-breaker' activities
summary: A 50-year-old Singaporean public servant was arrested for allegedly leaking classified information about the post-"circuit-breaker" activities before it was officially released. The man shared the information with a private WhatsApp chat group, which was not authorised to receive the information. The offence of wrongful communication of information under the Official Secrets Act carries a fine of up to S$2,000 and imprisonment for up to two years. The police are investigating and warning that unauthorised recipients may also be liable under the Act.

site_title: More than 19,000 home renovation projects get BCA approval to resume works
summary: The Building and Construction Authority (BCA) in Singapore has approved over 19,000 suspended home renovation projects to resume work, with over 300 construction projects also cleared to resume work. Companies must assess their readiness and submit applications to the BCA, which will require regular Covid-19 testing for construction workers. The resumption of renovation work is dependent on companies' availability of manpower and supplies. The BCA is also working with construction firms to help meet the requirements for their projects to resume safely.

site_title: Taking pay cut to help FA a no-brainer, says England football boss Southgate
summary: England football boss Gareth Southgate accepted a 30% wage cut to help the Football Association (FA) mitigate the financial impact of the Covid-19 pandemic. The FA estimated a £100 million loss due to the suspension of international matches and domestic cup games. Southgate, who would have been the highest earner in the organization, felt it was a "no-brainer" to contribute to the bigger picture. He cited his inability to fulfill his full job duties and the disparity in earnings between himself and other employees as reasons for his decision.

site_title: China reports 57 new virus cases as Beijing cluster grows
summary: China reported 57 new COVID-19 cases, the highest daily figure since April, due to a growing cluster linked to a wholesale food market in south Beijing. 36 of the new cases were local transmissions, and all three dozen were linked to the Xinfadi market. Fresh lockdowns were imposed on 11 residential estates near the market, and city officials declared an "extraordinary period." The market has been closed, and officials are conducting testing on everyone who works there and those who have visited.

site_title: Venezuela's oil production plunges to lowest level since 1945
summary: Venezuela's state-run oil company PDV has lowered its production estimates to 374,000 barrels a day, the lowest level since 1945, due to US sanctions that have scared off most oil buyers. Production is 57% lower than planned output, with the Orinoco Belt bearing the brunt of the decline. The US government has threatened to sanction 50 vessels, further exacerbating the crisis. PDV has shut joint venture oil fields and production has dropped 45% in the Maracaibo basin and 79% in the Orinoco Belt.

site_title: Singapore equity analysts aren't as optimistic as global funds
summary: Singapore equity analysts remain less optimistic than global investors, despite the city-state's US$396 billion stock market being cited for its valuations, fiscal stimulus, and economic reopening. Analysts at Fidelity, Citigroup, and Bank of Singapore project a 10% increase in the Straits Times Index over the next 12 months, near its lowest estimated return since 2018. Singapore's economy is easing lockdowns and has received significant stimulus, making it "one of the cheapest" markets in Asia, according to analysts.

site_title: Indonesia's Pertamina creates four new sub-holding units
summary: Indonesia's state-owned energy company Pertamina has created four new sub-holding units to boost profitability, improve transparency, and enhance public trust. The units include an upstream unit, a refinery unit, a power and renewable energy unit, and a trading unit, which will be grouped under a single umbrella to eventually launch initial public offerings within two years. This move is part of Indonesia's effort to revamp hundreds of state companies.

site_title: 407 new Covid-19 cases in Singapore, including 9 in community
summary: Singapore reported 407 new Covid-19 cases, bringing the total to 40,604, with 9 community cases, including 4 Singaporeans and 5 work pass holders. The majority are migrant workers living in dormitories. A 73-year-old Singaporean man died from complications due to Covid-19, increasing the total number of deaths to 26. With 768 more patients discharged, 28,798 have fully recovered.

site_title: What Odette, Asia's best restaurant, has planned in post-Covid era
summary: Chef-owner Julien Royer of three-Michelin-starred Odette restaurant in Singapore predicts the fine-dining scene will shift towards shorter, more concise menus, casual carryout models, and off-premise offerings as the post-Covid era unfolds. Odette has successfully adapted to the pandemic by introducing a contactless curbside pickup service and installing air purification technologies. Royer hopes the industry will rediscover the joys of dining together, valuing quality over quantity, and preserving the unique role restaurants play in celebrating diverse cultures.

images.alt_text: Chef-owner Julien Royer of Odette: "Regardless of what lies ahead, what matters is we, as chefs and restaurateurs, do not lose sight of our passion and why we do what we do."

site_title: Germany may make property sales harder after Berlin rent freeze
summary: Germany's construction minister, Horst Seehofer, proposes a threshold of at least two-thirds of apartment building flats needing to be sold to tenants or family members for government approval to convert rental apartments into condominiums. This move aims to protect tenants from eviction and encourages property owners to keep rental properties. The plan also obliges landowners to build residential properties, and cities may require a certain number of residential buildings in developments. The measure is part of a broader effort to address Germany's housing shortage and the recent rent freeze in Berlin.

site_title: The economy is reeling. Tech giants spy opportunity.
summary: Tech giants, including Facebook, Amazon, Apple, Google, and Microsoft, are aggressively investing and acquiring companies despite the global economy's recession. The companies, which have billions of dollars in cash, are betting on growth in areas such as e-commerce, cloud computing, and artificial intelligence. Their spending spree follows a pattern of previous recessions, where companies that invested during economic downturns emerged stronger. The expansion has raised concerns over the tech giants' concentration of power and potential impact on competitors and society, with lawmakers and regulators sounding the alarm.

site_title: Sinovac's vaccine trial data suggest potential in virus defence
summary: Sinovac Biotech announced positive findings from its coronavirus vaccine trial, CoronaVac, which showed the shot is safe and elicits an immune response in human trials. The vaccine induced neutralizing antibodies in over 90% of participants, and Sinovac plans to publish its results in academic journals. The trial, conducted in China, involved 743 healthy people ages 18-59, and more data will be collected from another group. Sinovac's vaccine is among five Chinese experimental shots nearing the final stage of human testing before potential public approval.

site_title: Hong Kong democrats fear disqualifications ahead of key election
summary: Hong Kong's opposition parties fear disqualifications ahead of the key election in September due to a new national security law and other Chinese laws. Leader Alvin Yeung and other high-profile politicians have been accused of behavior that could lead to disqualification, with some already facing charges. The opposition's "35+" plan to capture more than half of the Legislative Council's seats could be complicated by the threat of mass disqualifications, which could give the government sweeping powers to block opposition figures from office.

site_title: Businessman close to Maduro arrested; Venezuela slams 'arbitrary detention'
summary: Venezuelan businessman Alex Saab, close to President Nicolas Maduro, was arrested in Cape Verde, a move Venezuela calls an "arbitrary detention" in violation of international law. Saab, a Colombian with a Venezuelan passport, won contracts to supply food to Maduro's government-run program, which US officials say was a scam. The US charged him with money laundering and sanctioned him for the deals. Venezuela's foreign ministry claims Saab acted as an "agent" of the state, while the US says he was arrested pursuant to an Interpol red notice issued for his US indictment.

site_title: 347 new Covid-19 cases in Singapore, including five in community
summary: Singapore reported 347 new COVID-19 cases, bringing the total to 40,197, with five community cases confirmed, including two Singaporeans and three work pass holders. Migrant workers in dormitories account for the majority of the cases. The community cases include six previously unlinked cases, with one being a 22-year-old woman who showed symptoms on June 5. The number of new daily community cases has increased since Singapore's phased reopening, with 25 people having died from complications due to the virus.

site_title: Pua Seck Guan and other substantial shareholders offer S$0.95 a share to take Perennial private
summary: Perennial Real Estate Holdings announced that an entity called Primero Investment Holdings is offering S$0.95 a share in cash to take the company private. The offer price represents a 37.7% premium over the company's close on June 9. Substantial shareholders, including CEO Pua Seck Guan, Kuok Khoon Hong, and Ron Sim, are partnering to make the offer. The deal aims to take Perennial private, with the offer set to be accepted by shareholders.

site_title: CVS joins Walmart in keeping multicultural beauty products out of locked cabinets
summary: CVS and Walmart have announced they will no longer keep multicultural beauty products in locked display cases, following criticism and protests over racial inequality. The change in policy comes after a customer complaint and in response to nationwide protests in the US. Both companies have a firm non-discrimination policy and have expanded their product selection to cater to communities of colour. Walgreens has also ensured multicultural products are not stored behind locked cases at its stores.

site_title: US presses on with reopening, but virus first wave lingers
summary: The US continues to reopen despite a resurgence of coronavirus cases, with over a dozen states reporting their highest daily tolls since the pandemic began. President Trump and many local officials show no signs of worry, ruling out new lockdown measures. The virus has shifted its focus to the south and west, particularly in Arizona, Texas, and Florida, which will host the Republican presidential convention in August. Many states struggle to meet White House criteria for reopening, with rising cases, dwindling hospital capacity, and insufficient testing.

site_title: Australia's largest states further ease coronavirus curbs
summary: Australia's two largest states, New South Wales and Victoria, are easing coronavirus restrictions. NSW will scrap the 50 person limit on indoor venues starting July 1, allowing them to operate with a one person per four square meter rule. Nightclubs and music festivals will be allowed to operate from August if new cases remain low. Victoria will allow indoor businesses to have up to 50 seated patrons from June 22, with all sports for children resuming. The moves come as the country seeks to revive its economy and reduce pressure on policymakers.

site_title: France unveils plan to reopen non-Schengen borders
summary: France will reopen its non-Schengen borders to countries outside the European Union zone starting July 1, following the EU's recommendation to reopen to some Balkan countries. The move, announced by the interior and foreign ministers, aims to be in harmony with the rest of the EU. The borders were closed in mid-March to curb the spread of the coronavirus pandemic.

site_title: World's first 5G networks still more patchy than powerful
summary: Despite hype, the world's first 5G networks remain patchy, with significant gaps in coverage that may leave early adopters waiting for full speed. In South Korea and China, tests showed varying results, with average speeds ranging from 800Mbps to 1.5Gbps. In Hong Kong and Tokyo, coverage was limited, with most areas lacking high-frequency airwaves necessary for top speeds. While 5G devices have been sold in millions, carriers are investing billions to expand their networks, with plans to offer more bandwidth-hungry add-ons to recoup costs.

site_title: Popular blood pressure medicines do not put patients at greater Covid-19 risk, new study finds
summary: A new study of 1.1 million patients found that popular blood pressure medicines, including ACE inhibitors and ARBs, do not increase the risk of Covid-19 or hospitalization. The study, published on Friday, analyzed electronic medical records from the US and Spain and found no clinically significant increased risk compared to other first-line hypertension treatments. The findings are reassuring for hundreds of millions of people with high blood pressure, and researchers recommend that patients continue their treatment.

site_title: Britain's Cineworld scraps US$1.65b deal to buy Cineplex
summary: Britain's Cineworld Group scrapped its $1.65 billion deal to buy Cineplex due to breaches in the merger agreement, citing the Canadian company's unwillingness to cure the issues. The deal, announced in December, would have made Cineworld North America's largest cinema operator. Cineworld terminated the Arrangement Agreement with immediate effect, citing Cineplex's breaches as the reason for the cancellation.

site_title: Amazon's business practices examined by two US states: reports
summary: US states California and Washington are investigating Amazon's business practices, focusing on how the company treats sellers in its online marketplace. California is reviewing Amazon's practices on selling its own products in competition with third-party vendors, while Washington is investigating whether Amazon makes it harder for sellers to list their products on other websites. The investigations are not in advanced stages and have not been confirmed or denied by the attorney generals' offices. This comes after the US House of Representatives Judiciary Committee called for Amazon CEO Jeff Bezos to testify about allegations of data misuse.

site_title: Brooks Brothers joins list of faded luxury facing bankruptcy
summary: Brooks Brothers, a 202-year-old luxury brand, is in talks with Authentic Brands Group and Simon Property Group to buy the company after a potential Chapter 11 filing. The retailer has struggled with declining demand due to relaxed dress codes and the pandemic, forcing it to temporarily close stores. Authentic has a history of buying struggling brands, while Simon aims to keep prime tenants in business. If a deal is reached, it would be Authentic's second major acquisition in the luxury market, following the purchase of Barneys New York.

site_title: Tokyo Olympics will be safe, governor says
summary: Tokyo Governor Yuriko Koike has pledged a "120-per cent effort" to ensure the Tokyo Olympics, postponed due to the coronavirus pandemic, can proceed safely next year. Despite admitting the event will be downsized, Koike expressed her commitment to holding the Games as a "symbol of human triumph" over the virus. However, she declined to comment on her confidence in the event's opening as planned.

site_title: 25,000 life, health insurance policyholders in S'pore apply to defer premium payments
summary: About 25,000 life and health insurance policyholders in Singapore have applied to temporarily defer premium payments for up to six months as part of industry-wide relief measures. 90% of the applications have been approved, totaling S$47.6 million in deferred premiums. Additionally, 80% of applicants who requested flexible instalment plans for general insurance policies have received approval. These measures were rolled out by the Monetary Authority of Singapore as part of relief measures amid the Covid-19 crisis.

site_title: Singapore dengue cases may hit record
summary: Singapore is on track to break its record for dengue cases, with over 1,000 cases expected this week. The country's healthcare system may face pressure due to the outbreak, which Ms. Amy Khor, Senior Minister of State for Environment and Water Resources and Health, warns should be taken seriously. The current decline in COVID-19 hospital cases makes the timing of the dengue outbreak particularly challenging.

site_title: Fiat Chrysler wins trade case over Mahindra's Jeep copy
summary: Fiat Chrysler Automobiles (FCA) has won a trade case against Mahindra & Mahindra Ltd, with the US International Trade Commission upholding a judge's finding that Mahindra's Roxor off-road vehicle copies the look of FCA's iconic Jeep Wrangler. The commission modified the judge's decision, and Mahindra has pledged to appeal. FCA claimed the Roxor is a "nearly identical copy" of its Jeep, particularly in its boxy body shape and flat-appearing vertical sides.

site_title: Warner Bros delays 'Tenet' in setback for reopening efforts
summary: Warner Bros has delayed the release of Christopher Nolan's "Tenet" by two weeks, pushing it back to July 31. This move comes as US states begin to reopen movie theaters, but there's been a lack of new films to show. The delay affects the studio's efforts to reopen theaters after the coronavirus shutdown, with the Russell Crowe road-rage picture "Unhinged" opening on July 1 instead. A 10th-anniversary edition of "Inception" will be released in theaters on July 17 to fill the gap.

site_title: New domestic cases in Beijing raise fears of new virus wave
summary: China reported 11 new coronavirus cases, including six domestic cases in Beijing, raising concerns about a resurgence. The new cases prompted Beijing officials to delay primary school student returns and suspend sporting events and group dining. This marks a departure from recent months, where most cases were overseas nationals returning home. The outbreak has brought China's domestic cases largely under control since the initial emergence in Wuhan last year.

site_title: Over 4,000 crew-change cases have been approved for seafarers during Covid-19 period: MPA
summary: The Maritime and Port Authority of Singapore (MPA) has approved over 4,000 crew-change cases for seafarers since March 2020, facilitating the disembarkation of seafarers on medical grounds and compassionate reasons. Despite the COVID-19 pandemic, MPA has continued to facilitate crew changes, including a second chartered flight on Friday, and is working with the shipping industry to develop a "safe corridor" guidebook. MPA chief executive Quah Ley Hoon said the authority will review crew-change procedures, taking into account Singapore's circumstances and the global situation.

site_title: Goldman says there's still room for gains in emerging stocks
summary: Goldman Sachs' emerging-market strategist Caesar Maasry expects gains in emerging stocks, citing a preference for cyclical assets and dollar weakness. The MSCI Emerging Markets Index has gained 30% since its four-year low in March, driven by reopening economies and better-than-forecast data. Goldman sees potential upside in Latin American markets, particularly Brazil and Mexico, with Brazilian stocks up 46% and Mexican stocks expected to rise 12%. However, longer-term growth is limited due to structural issues such as heavy debt burdens and stagnant growth.

site_title: China finalises new IPO rules for Shenzhen's ChiNext startup board
summary: China has finalized new rules for companies looking to list on Shenzhen's ChiNext startup board, streamlining the listing process and allowing market-determined IPO pricing. The reforms, modeled after Shanghai's STAR Market, will eliminate the need for China Securities Regulatory Commission approval. The move aims to make it easier for startups, particularly tech firms, to access domestic capital and reduce reliance on international venues like New York and Hong Kong. The changes are seen as a response to the trade war with the US, aimed at boosting domestic capital markets.

site_title: NEC's global battery firm cites Covid-19 for winding down
summary: NEC Energy Solutions, a global battery installer, is winding down operations due to fierce competition and the impact of the COVID-19 pandemic on finding a buyer. The Massachusetts-based company, which has struggled to turn a profit, will finish projects under development but not seek new business. The parent company, NEC Corp, had been trying to sell the business, but the pandemic made it difficult. The company's demise is attributed to the growing importance and consolidation of energy storage as a technology, with plunging prices putting pressure on profit margins.

site_title: Greece reopens for tourists, but UK flights barred for now
summary: Greece reopens for tourists, with regular international flights allowed at Athens and Thessaloniki airports starting Monday, but flights from coronavirus hotspots like Britain remain barred until July 1. The country aims to balance tourism with safety, having fared relatively well in the pandemic with fewer than 190 deaths. Non-essential travel restrictions remain in place, and quarantine measures are in place for travellers from high-risk areas.

site_title: More cooks in kitchen turn up heat in food delivery business
summary: In Singapore, online food ordering system providers are gaining traction as F&B operators seek alternatives to high commission fees charged by dominant players GrabFood, foodpanda, and Deliveroo. Since April, Oddle has seen a surge in demand, with 500 new restaurants signing up, and NinjaOS has seen 120 new restaurants subscribe to its system. These providers charge lower fees and offer customised online storefronts, making them attractive to food establishments. Some F&B operators, such as Jinjja Chicken, continue to use multiple platforms to boost brand visibility and absorb delivery fees.

site_title: Oil prices see weekly loss on virus resurgence fears
summary: Oil prices declined for the first time in six weeks due to concerns over a potential second wave of the COVID-19 pandemic, which may impact fuel demand. Oil prices fell 8% on a weekly basis, with Brent settling at $38.73 a barrel and West Texas Intermediate at $36.26 a barrel. US crude oil inventories rose to a record 538.1 million barrels, while producers cut supply, with Opec+ slashing 9.7 million barrels per day. Experts warn that if the pandemic worsens, the market will likely decline, while a decline in production could slow down the recovery in demand.

site_title: NYC hotels battered by pandemic face rift over safety rules
summary: New York City hotels, severely impacted by the pandemic, are facing a rift over safety rules as they try to reopen. Hotel owners and the Hotel Trades Council, representing 95% of hotel workers, disagree on protocols, with owners resisting increased labor expenses. The city's tourism agency projects hundreds of millions of dollars in lost hotel taxes, highlighting the importance of restarting tourism with safety measures. A proposal by the union includes measures like providing masks and hand sanitizer, but owners are concerned about increased costs, potentially leading to hotel closures or bankruptcy.

site_title: EU state aid regulators to ease bailout rules for small firms, startups
summary: EU state aid regulators plan to ease bailout rules for small firms and startups, allowing private investors to team up with EU governments to provide aid to virus-hit companies. The European Commission will amend its rules to encourage private investment and lighten the burden on state coffers. Changes will also allow state aid for pre-pandemic companies to be granted to those hit by the virus. The move aims to support start-up companies, especially innovative ones, crucial for the economic recovery of the EU. Feedback is being sought from EU countries before a final draft is decided.

site_title: Lendlease Global Reit secures S$10m tender to rejuvenate Somerset area
summary: Lendlease Global Reit has secured a S$10 million tender to redevelop a 48,200 sq ft car park near 313@somerset into a new multi-functional event space. The project, set to be operational in 2022, will include multiple event spaces, an independent cinema, hawker stalls, and a food-and-beverage attraction. The Reit will collaborate with Live Nation and The Projector to create a calendar of events, and will work with local stakeholders to use the space for curated events. The development cost is within the 10% regulatory limit on property development for Reits.

site_title: Global economy to suffer 'significant scarring': IMF
summary: The International Monetary Fund (IMF) expects the global economy to suffer "significant scarring" from the coronavirus pandemic, with growth projections likely to be worse than initially estimated. The IMF's chief economist, Gita Gopinath, cited the depth of the crisis, labour re-allocation, and changes in consumer behavior as factors pointing to scarring effects. The IMF's revised growth projections, set to be released on June 24, are expected to show a deeper contraction than initially estimated, with an anticipated rebound to 5.8% in 2021.

images.alt_text: Asia's open economies are especially vulnerable to the downturn in global trade, and external financing needs and fiscal vulnerabilities remain for emerging markets even after effective liquidity injections.

site_title: US FDA approves GSK unit's drug to treat infants and children with HIV
summary: The US FDA has approved Tivicay and Tivicay PD tablets for treating HIV-1 infection in pediatric patients at least four weeks old and weighing at least three kilograms, in combination with other antiretroviral treatments. Developed by GlaxoSmithKline's HIV division ViiV Healthcare, the approval was granted for infants and children with HIV. The drug is currently under review by the European Medicines Agency.

images.alt_text: The US Food and Drug Administration has approved a drug to treat infants and children with HIV, with the drug having been developed by drugmaker GlaxoSmithKline's HIV drugs division ViiV Healthcare, the FDA and the GSK unit said.

site_title: Airbnb partners with Brazil virus hotspot on post-pandemic tourism
summary: Airbnb partners with Sao Paulo, Brazil, to revive post-pandemic tourism, marking the first destination in Latin America to be chosen for the initiative. The partnership aims to promote Sao Paulo as a travel destination once coronavirus-related restrictions ease. Airbnb will feature exclusive content and share global data with the local government, targeting travelers who will likely use cars once the state economy reopens. This move follows Airbnb's economic impact of $2.89 billion in Brazil in 2019, and comes as the company seeks to recover from the pandemic.

site_title: Commerzbank rejects Cerberus demands for supervisory board seats
summary: Commerzbank has rejected demands from top investor Cerberus for two seats on the German bank's supervisory board, as part of a campaign calling for cost cuts and a strategy shift. Cerberus, which holds a 5% stake in the bank, had demanded the seats after more than 70 meetings with managers, citing the bank's "disastrous" performance. Commerzbank's chairman Stefan Schmittmann said the bank does not have any vacancies, and Cerberus is expected to continue its push despite the rejection.

site_title: JPMorgan's Kolanovic drops caution on stocks, says buy the dip
summary: Marko Kolanovic, JPMorgan's quant guru, has dropped his caution on stocks, advising clients to "buy the dip" due to a drop in US-China tensions. He cites the three main risks to US stocks: US-China relations, the COVID-19 pandemic, and domestic social unrest. Kolanovic predicts hedge funds and trend-following traders will increase equity exposure this summer, followed by stock pickers. He maintains a bullish stance on value stocks, particularly cyclical shares, which will benefit from an economic reopening. Kolanovic's latest note suggests the S&P 500 can reclaim its all-time high in the first half of 2021.

images.alt_text: Marko Kolanovic, who two weeks ago tempered his bullish stance on stocks because of worsening geopolitical tensions, says now is the time to move back in.

site_title: AT&T mulls selling gaming unit in US$4b deal: CNBC
summary: AT&T is considering selling its Warner Bros. video-game unit, a business that could fetch approximately US$4 billion, to help reduce its US$200 billion in debt. Activision Blizzard, Electronic Arts, and Take-Two Interactive are reportedly interested in acquiring the division, which includes popular games such as Harry Potter: Wizards Unite and Mortal Kombat 11. A sale may involve licensing Warner Bros.'s movie and show properties to the buyer, and the deal is not imminent. The sale could help AT&T cut costs and unload assets under its new CEO, John Stankey.

site_title: HK street-level shops see surge in enquiries
summary: Hong Kong street-level shops are experiencing a surge in bargain buying and leasing interest following China's imposition of national security legislation. The increased activity is seen as a sign of potential stability in the protest-hit city. Despite the rise in enquiries, no deals have been reported yet. Major realtors attribute the interest to the perceived benefits of the new laws. The development suggests that the worst may be over for Hong Kong's property market.

site_title: Europe: Shares edge higher after torrid week of losses
summary: European shares ended 0.3% higher on Friday after a week of losses, marking their worst week since the coronavirus sell-off. The Stoxx 600 index lost 5.7% for the week, with travel and leisure stocks declining amid US coronavirus concerns. Automakers, basic resources, and real estate companies rose, while oil prices dropped. Analysts predict a drawn-out economic recovery in the euro zone, with Italian stocks rising 0.4% on the day.

site_title: On valuations: it's back to basics amid Covid-19
summary: Corporate finance expert Aswath Damodaran advises investors to stick with traditional valuation tools during the Covid-19 crisis, rather than abandoning them due to uncertainty. He emphasizes the importance of going back to "first principles of valuation" and making adjustments for the pandemic. Despite the crisis, the S&P 500 Index reached a record high, suggesting that investors are finding ways to value companies amid uncertainty. Damodaran's advice is a nod to the fact that valuation fundamentals matter most during times of crisis.

site_title: Utico says it's been approached by potential partners for Hyflux deal
summary: Utico, a UAE-based utilities group, has been approached by potential partners for a deal that could value the company at up to US$1.5 billion. The interested parties are from the Gulf Cooperation Council, the UK, Singapore, and Indonesia, but Utico did not disclose the size of the stake that may be acquired. This development comes after Utico announced its intention to sell a significant portion of its shares in its Singapore arm, Hyflux, in 2020.

site_title: Understanding the trade-offs in our decisions
summary: Investors often face trade-offs in their financial decisions, including risk versus returns, concentrated versus diversified portfolios, and timing. A recent example illustrates the risks of prioritizing high returns over safety, with a 67-year-old investor losing almost his entire $800,000 portfolio due to a leveraged exchange-traded note. Diversification is key to reducing risk without sacrificing potential returns, according to Nobel Prize-winning economist Harry Markowitz. Investors must weigh the trade-offs between explosive growth and volatility, as well as the timing of their investments, to make informed decisions.

site_title: STI 0.72% lower for the day, 2.43% down for the week
summary: Singapore's Straits Times Index (STI) closed 0.72% down at 2,684.63 points, marking its second consecutive decline. The index lost 2.43% for the week. Six STI members gained, while two were flat, and the rest declined. Top Glove, a Malaysian-listed company, was a bright spot, adding 14 Singapore cents to end at S$5.70. Japan's Nikkei 225 and Hong Kong's Hang Seng index also declined, while Australia's S&P/ASX 200 index fell 1.89%.

site_title: When you have a crisis, make the best use of it
summary: SICC CEO Victor Mills states that a crisis is necessary for a business to step out of its comfort zone and change. Mills, who previously made a comment about Singaporeans having a misplaced sense of entitlement, believes the country needs a crisis to drive change over the past 15 years. He suggests that a crisis would have prompted the necessary transformation, rather than gradual change. Mills' comments reflect his perspective on the importance of adversity in driving business growth and innovation.

site_title: ISOTeam bags S$32.5m in new contracts
summary: ISOTeam, a Singapore-listed building solutions firm, secured S$32.5 million in new contracts, bringing its total for FY2020 to S$139.17 million. The contract wins are largely public-sector projects, expected to drive growth in the near term. The company's projects, set to be completed between 2020 and 2024, include mechanical and electrical projects, addition-and-alteration projects, and repair-and-redecoration projects. The news comes as Singapore's construction sector is expected to contract by 10.3% this year.

site_title: Spanish real estate heading for second crash in a decade
summary: Spain's $6 trillion home market is heading towards a second crash in a decade due to the pandemic lockdown. Experts predict a 6.5-15% drop in housing prices, with a 12% decline by year-end. The looming crash comes after the market rose 32% since 2014, with job growth and economic outlook being key factors. The Bank of Spain projects a 15% GDP shrink and a 18.1-23.6% jobless rate, correlating with higher Covid-19 infection rates and lower home prices.

site_title: Harry Elias, Eversheds Sutherland to part ways
summary: Singapore law firm Harry Elias Partnership and Eversheds Sutherland will part ways on June 30, after a three-year merger. The move comes after a review mechanism at the three-year mark, with both firms citing the need to "tread a different path." The firm's name will revert to Harry Elias Partnership, and both parties will continue to cooperate on future projects. The decision follows a report in 2017 where Harry Elias' managing partner Philip Fong stated the merger aimed to internationalize the firm's practice and compete with other legal centers.

site_title: US: Stocks end volatile session higher but down for the week
summary: US stocks ended the day higher, but down for the week, following a volatile session. The Dow Jones Industrial Average rose 1.9% to 25,605.54, while the S&P 500 and Nasdaq Composite Index gained 1.3% and 1%, respectively.
