Investors weighed rising coronavirus cases and concerns about equity valuations, despite the market's advance.

site_title: Most issuers plan to postpone IPOs to 2021
summary: The Singapore Exchange (SGX) expects a "healthy" pipeline of issuers for 2021, despite a slowdown in initial public offering (IPO) activity this year. Only five deals have raised S$698 million year-to-date, down from 11 in 2020. Reit listings have been affected, with foreign Reits facing financial and regulatory troubles. However, some analysts remain optimistic, citing the popularity of Reits as an asset class and the low interest rate environment. Companies are preparing for 2021 listings, with some expecting to list in the second half of the year.

site_title: BOS targets bigger slice of booming family offices business
summary: Bank of Singapore (BOS) aims to expand its share of the growing family office business by offering more investment products and targeting clients outside the region. Despite declining assets under management, BOS's family office segment saw a 20% increase in assets to US$104 billion. The company plans to set up an onshore presence in China, capitalizing on the country's crackdown on shadow banking. BOS competes with UBS and Credit Suisse in providing services to wealthy Asians, and CEO Bahren Shaari sees opportunities for growth in private markets, including hedge funds and real estate.

site_title: US consumer sentiment jumps most since 2016 on gain in jobs
summary: US consumer sentiment surged 6.6 points to 78.9 in early June, the largest increase since 2016, as more states reopened their economies and jobs were restored. Despite optimism about the economy's recovery, two-thirds of respondents expect unfavorable economic conditions in the year ahead due to coronavirus concerns. Inflation expectations rose to 3%, while consumer confidence in government policies declined, with a growing political divide among Republicans and independent voters.

site_title: Reits (June 13-14, 2020)
summary: Realtors in Singapore are anticipating a Q3 wave of condo launches, which may test demand for prime projects above the S$3,000 psf benchmark. Meanwhile, US mortgage rates have climbed after five straight weeks of declines, and Manhattan rents have reached a record high. In the UK, homebuyer demand has rebounded to a six-month high. In other news, Goldman Sachs has acquired 262 billion won hotel and retail assets in Seoul, and WeWork has secured new tenants at 21 Collyer Quay in Singapore after its bankruptcy. New World Group is also selling China property assets.

site_title: After the sharpest stock sell-off since March, what's next?
summary: US stocks experienced a significant sell-off, with the S&P 500 declining 5.9%, Nasdaq 5.3%, and Dow 6.9% on Thursday, marking the worst day since March 16. The decline was largely driven by sector-specific losses, particularly in energy, financials, materials, and industrials, amid concerns over second waves of infections, the equity rally running ahead of fundamentals, and increased uncertainty related to the US presidential elections. Despite this, analysts see the current consolidation as an opportunity to buy structural long-term winners and cyclical stocks, with the market not currently showing signs of systemic selling.

site_title: Did Amazon's crackdown on price-gouging worsen shortages of sanitizer, wipes?
summary: Amazon's crackdown on price-gouging during the pandemic may have led to shortages of essential items like hand sanitizer and toilet paper. The company's vague warnings about price policy violations caused merchants to pull products from the site, even if they weren't raising prices, to avoid being exiled. This resulted in lost sales and revenue for merchants, who were left playing a guessing game about what prices were deemed fair. Amazon's complex algorithms and unclear rules made it difficult to manage, and some merchants say the company's crackdown went too far, forcing them to eliminate sales of popular products.

site_title: China's street vendor push ignites debate
summary: China's premier, Li Keqiang, sparked debate about the country's prosperity by suggesting a "stall economy" to create jobs for the jobless amid the coronavirus epidemic. He highlighted the struggles of millions of young people, including a 22-year-old Beijing resident who became a street vendor after losing her job. Li's comments defied the Communist Party's usual narrative of untrammelled prosperity, citing 600 million Chinese earning only $140 a month. The idea gained traction, with cities rushing to support street vendors, but was later met with backlash, with official media reining in enthusiasm and labeling the concept "backward."

site_title: EPL's much-awaited restart promises twists and turns
summary: The English Premier League (EPL) is set to resume after a two-month hiatus due to the COVID-19 pandemic. The restart promises twists and turns, with key matches scheduled during Europe's evening prime time TV slot, potentially affecting Asian audiences. Liverpool is favored to win the title, but Manchester City's appeal against a two-year suspension from European club competitions could shake up the Champions League equation. The relegation battle is also intense, with six clubs fighting to avoid the drop. The season's outcome is uncertain, with many unresolved scenarios and potential twists ahead.

images.alt_text: Liverpool and Everton during a match played at Anfield in January this year. The two teams will play again, in the EPL, on June 22.

site_title: Two Coastal Oil ex-senior staff charged with cheating banks; reported losses amount to US$133m
summary: Two former Coastal Oil Singapore employees, Ong Ah Huat and Huang Peishi, have been charged in court for allegedly cheating eight banks in Singapore and Hong Kong, resulting in reported losses of US$133.3 million. The duo allegedly created fictitious sales contracts and invoices to obtain financing from the banks between 2017 and 2018. Ong faces 58 charges, including 44 forgery charges, while Huang faces 63 charges for similar offences. Both are offered bail, with Ong set at S$100,000 and Huang at S$50,000.

images.alt_text: The accused are Singaporeans Ong Ah Huat, 60, and Huang Peishi, 34, court documents seen by BT on Friday show.

site_title: A matter of metamorphosis
summary: Operation Dagger, a Singaporean bar, has launched the #DaggerMetamorphosis series of bottled cocktails, released in response to the COVID-19 pandemic. The series features unique concoctions, such as Beetroot, and bittergourd-based é kho qua, with a focus on adaptation and creativity. Head bartender Thomas Girard emphasizes the importance of R&D and collaborations, and notes that the pandemic has provided an opportunity to reassess the business model and find new ways to survive. The bar's delivery selection is available through online platforms, allowing fans to experience their signature drinks from home.

site_title: A gloomier assessment of the US economy by the Fed buoys gold
summary: Gold prices surged last week, buoyed by the US Federal Reserve's dovish stance on monetary policy, which projected a sluggish US economic recovery and near-zero interest rates through 2021. The weak dollar and cautious investors' appetite also supported gold, with prices reaching a weekly high of $1,754.9 an ounce. However, the rally was limited by resistance at last week's high of $1,761, and gold prices ended the week softer in Asian trade.

site_title: There really is no alternative this time
summary: The COVID-19 pandemic may be nearing its end, with the stock market's recent recovery suggesting a possible swift recovery of the economy. Long-term bond yields are higher than short-term rates, indicating a protracted recession is unlikely. However, economists caution that stock markets focus on company profits, which may not directly reflect the economic situation. Companies can boost profits by increasing revenues, raising prices, or cutting costs, but these measures may not necessarily translate to an economic recovery. As central banks provide cheap money, the concept of "There Really Is No Alternative" (TRINA) may force investors to seek solace in shares rather than other asset classes.

site_title: Maybank KE raises target price on Top Glove, positive on Malaysia glove sector
summary: Maybank KE has raised its target price on Top Glove to RM21.90, from RM20, due to the company's strong Q3 results and positive outlook for the Malaysia glove sector. Top Glove posted its highest quarterly net profit and revenue in its 29-year history, driven by a surge in demand for gloves amid the Covid-19 pandemic. The brokerage expects Top Glove to post a Q4 net profit of RM782 million and raises its EPS forecast for FY20, FY21, and FY22 by 20%, 8%, and 27%, respectively.

site_title: Local electronics firm PCI to make Singapore's virus-tracing device
summary: PCI, a Singapore-based electronics firm, won a S$6 million tender to supply 300,000 bluetooth-enabled TraceTogether Tokens, wearable devices that help identify Covid-19 carriers. The government's GovTech awarded the contract on May 14. The tokens are expected to be given to everyone in the city-state, with the goal of tracing interactions between carriers and non-carriers. The contract is part of Singapore's efforts to track the spread of Covid-19.

site_title: OCBC upgrades Sembcorp Industries to 'neutral'
summary: OCBC upgraded Sembcorp Industries (SCI) to 'neutral' from 'negative' due to the proposed separation of Sembcorp Marine (SMM) from its parent company. The separation is expected to increase SCI's return on equity to 7.9% and lower debt levels. SCI's remaining energy and urban development segments are expected to drive growth post-separation. The upgrade comes after OCBC previously noted the burden of supporting SMM on SCI debt holders, and the separation is expected to reduce SCI's leverage levels.

site_title: Hertz surges on plan to sell US$1b stock in bankruptcy
summary: Hertz Global Holdings is seeking permission to sell up to $1 billion of new shares in bankruptcy, taking advantage of a surge in its stock price. The car rental company plans to issue up to 246.78 million common shares, which may become worthless, but would provide much-needed working capital. Following a 68% surge in trading, investors are optimistic about a rebound in the economy and air travel, as well as a rise in used car prices. A hearing is set for Friday to consider the proposal.

site_title: Japan aims to launch coronavirus contact tracking app next week
summary: Japan is set to launch a coronavirus contact tracking app next week, utilizing technology from Apple and Google to detect close contacts via Bluetooth. The app will notify users who spent over 15 minutes within 1 meter of an infected individual, prompting them to seek medical consultation. The app will remain anonymous and does not collect personal data. Japan aims to curb the spread of the virus, with the app expected to increase user participation and prevent infection. The country has reported 17,300 confirmed cases and 922 deaths to date.

site_title: Over 4,000 crew-change cases approved for seafarers during Covid-19 period: MPA
summary: The Maritime and Port Authority of Singapore (MPA) has approved over 4,000 crew-change cases for seafarers since March 27, 2020, amidst the COVID-19 crisis. This includes facilitating medical treatment, compassionate reasons, and contracts that cannot be extended. MPA has also chartered flights to facilitate crew changes, with two more scheduled for this week. The authority is working with the shipping industry, unions, and government agencies to ensure safe crew changes, and will review procedures to address the ongoing pandemic.

site_title: Inside the HK$39b 'Apollo' deal to salvage Cathay Pacific
summary: Cathay Pacific Airways has secured a HK$39 billion bailout deal, code-named "Apollo", after complex negotiations with top shareholders including Swire Pacific and Air China. The airline, which had been struggling due to social unrest and the coronavirus pandemic, will receive financial assistance to stay afloat. The deal aims to support Cathay Pacific's operations and prevent the airline from going bankrupt. The terms of the deal were not disclosed, but the bailout is expected to provide a significant boost to the airline's finances.

site_title: Covid-19 puts the brakes on this year's F1 Singapore Grand Prix
summary: The Formula One Singapore Grand Prix has been cancelled for this year due to COVID-19 restrictions. The event promoter, Singapore GP, cited prohibitions on access and construction of the venue, as well as mass gatherings and international travel, as the main reasons for the cancellation. Singapore is emerging from a "circuit breaker" that began in April, bringing construction activities to a standstill, making it impossible to proceed with the event.

site_title: The city reimagined: why in design, ecology matters
summary: Cities worldwide struggle with ecological loss and risk due to density. A 60-year-old concept by Jane Jacobs highlights the need to redefine urban problems, focusing on "organised complexity" rather than isolated parts. Asian cities, such as Mumbai, face ecological crises like deforestation and water pollution. Nature-inspired solutions, like ecosystem services and green infrastructure, are gaining traction. Policies like Singapore's 30% local food goal and China's urban farming initiatives demonstrate the potential for transformation. Reimagining the city as a whole, integrating natural and human systems, is key to restoring harmony between humans and the environment.

site_title: Grounded by Covid-19, a once-busy traveller finds new way to see the world
summary: A travel writer, Sarah Khan, has been grounded by the COVID-19 pandemic and has turned to her friends to help her stay connected with the world. Through Instagram Live interviews, she has chronicled regional quirks and differences in how countries are managing the crisis. Friends from around the globe, including US expats and journalists, have shared their experiences with lockdowns, curfews, and government measures. The conversations have highlighted the universal impact of the pandemic, bridging hemispheres and time zones, and have given meaning to the unexpected time off.

site_title: Up to 400,000 lower-income households to receive vouchers under S$20m CDC scheme
summary: Deputy Prime Minister Heng Swee Keat launched a S$20 million CDC Vouchers Scheme, providing up to 400,000 lower-income Singaporean households with S$50 vouchers. The scheme aims to support vulnerable households during the COVID-19 pandemic. The vouchers were distributed in collaboration with the five mayors of Singapore. The initiative is part of the government's efforts to assist low-income families and promote community development.

site_title: Tesla at US$1,000: too much too soon for some analysts
summary: Top Wall Street brokerages Goldman Sachs and Morgan Stanley downgraded their ratings on Tesla, citing the electric carmaker's shares were overpriced. The brokerages noted increased competition in the electric vehicle industry and highlighted risks such as Sino-US trade tensions, near-term demand, and tech competition. Goldman Sachs cut its rating to "neutral" while Morgan Stanley cut its price target to $650, down from $680. The move follows Tesla's shares crossing $1,000 per share, which have jumped 360% in the last year.

site_title: Facebook's Giphy deal draws UK competition watchdog's attention
summary: Facebook's acquisition of Giphy, a popular GIF website, is being scrutinized by the UK's Competition and Markets Authority for potentially reducing competition in the UK. The deal, valued at around $400 million, allows Facebook to integrate Giphy with its Instagram app. The CMA has served Facebook with an initial enforcement order and launched an investigation, inviting comments from interested parties. Giphy has assured users that their access to the platform will remain unchanged, but the deal has raised concerns about reduced competition in the market.

site_title: Opec+ panel meeting next week will advise on policy, not decide: sources
summary: Opec+ is set to advise on its oil policy at a panel meeting next week, rather than making decisions. The group agreed to maintain a 9.7 million barrel per day production cut until the end of July, helping oil prices more than double since April. A Joint Ministerial Monitoring Committee (JMMC) will meet monthly to assess the agreement's effectiveness, advising Opec+ on potential extensions. The committee's first meeting will focus on countries that haven't delivered their share of the cutbacks, including Nigeria and Iraq.

site_title: Harry Elias parts ways with global legal giant
summary: Singapore law firm Harry Elias Partnership will part ways with global law firm Eversheds Sutherland on June 30, after a three-year merger. The decision comes after a review mechanism was included in the initial merger agreement. Managing partners Philip Fong and Stephen Kitts stated that the firms have decided to "tread a different path" and will continue cooperation in the future, albeit in a different form. The firm's name will revert to Harry Elias Partnership on July 1.

site_title: Hi-P to widen customer base and products, expand out of China to boost profit margin
summary: Contract manufacturer Hi-P International plans to diversify its customer base, widen product offerings, and expand outside of China to mitigate declining profit margins. The company aims to broaden its geographic footprint, explore merger and acquisition opportunities, and increase automation to maintain profit margins. Hi-P will also leverage its recent acquisition of SEAMCO to offer new solutions to existing and new customers, particularly in the automotive market. The move comes as the company seeks to cope with the impact of the US-China trade tensions and the Covid-19 crisis.

site_title: Malaysia: Shares close lower on Friday
summary: Malaysia's FTSE Bursa Malaysia Kuala Lumpur Composite Index closed lower on Friday at 1,546.02, down 11.23 points. Volume reached 8.032 billion lots worth RM4.771 billion. Losers outnumbered gainers 803 to 283.

site_title: Fed's Powell pledges focus on return to strong labour market
summary: US Federal Reserve Chair Jerome Powell reiterated his pledge to bring the US labor market back to its pre-coronavirus strength, particularly for minorities and the poor. The Fed's findings from 15 community outreach events highlighted the pandemic's impact on low-wage workers, with employment now 35% lower than before the crisis. Most people expressed lack of concern over low inflation, which may hinder the Fed's use of interest-rate policy to stimulate growth. The Fed remains focused on its goals, with a return to the strong labor market seen in 2019 as its top priority.

site_title: The drive to replace drivers
summary: BMW is launching its first self-driving car, the i20, which will be autonomous on highways but require human intervention in city driving. The car is based on the Vision iNext concept and will be available in 2021. BMW's Technical Product Manager Regulation Automated Driving, Armin Graeter, expects a huge demand for the technology, with managers wanting the extra time to work and others seeking to relax. However, Graeter notes that car companies must prove the technology is at least as safe as human drivers, with a 99.9993% safety rate currently achieved. The technology is expected to revolutionize transportation but may not replace human drivers on all roads, with Graeter estimating it could be beyond the 2030s or 2040s.

site_title: Thailand to lift curfew, more curbs as 'travel bubbles' targeted
summary: Thailand to lift nationwide curfew and ease restrictions starting June 15, after 18 days without local COVID-19 transmissions. The country plans to reopen to foreign visitors through "travel bubbles" with virus-controlled countries, but no target date was set. Strict social distancing rules will still be observed in public activities.

site_title: Malaysia PM paves way for year-end snap poll
summary: Malaysian Prime Minister Muhyiddin Yassin is preparing for a snap election by the end of the year, amid uncertainty over his support in Parliament. A confidence vote in May was scuttled due to limited parliamentary sessions. The opposition accused Muhyiddin of stealing power by shifting alliances, and he is now seeking a firm mandate to address the ongoing COVID-19 battle and other challenges.

site_title: Britain unveils plans to impose EU border checks in stages
summary: Britain will introduce EU border checks in stages, starting January 1, 2021, with the first six months featuring limited requirements. The move reverses an earlier plan to introduce full controls on December 31, giving companies more time to prepare for new customs systems. The checks will include record-keeping and customs declarations, with tariffs to be paid but deferred until declarations are made. Further steps will be introduced in April and July, with a full border controls system expected to be in place by then.

images.alt_text: Britain will introduce border checks with the European Union (EU) in stages from Jan 1, reversing an original plan so it can now give companies struggling with the coronavirus crisis more time to fill out forms and pay tariffs.

site_title: Up to 400,000 lower-income households to receive vouchers to spend on local businesses
summary: Up to 400,000 lower-income Singaporean households will receive S$50 vouchers to spend on local businesses, supporting local merchants and hawkers. The Community Development Council (CDC) Vouchers Scheme was launched to help households with daily expenses and boost local businesses. About 2,500 merchants have signed up, and eligible households will receive notification letters in batches between June 15 and end-July to collect their vouchers by December 31. The scheme aims to support lower-income families and promote local spending.

site_title: OCBC Research upgrades Sembcorp Industries' issuer profile
summary: OCBC Credit Research upgraded Sembcorp Industries' issuer profile to "neutral" due to a proposed two-part deal separating Sembcorp Marine from its parent company. The separation is expected to increase SCI's return on equity to 7.9% on a pro forma basis, compared to 3.5% in 2019. This credit positive outcome is a result of the separation of SMM, potentially leading to a higher return on equity for SCI.

site_title: SoftBank has spent US$2.9b buying back its own shares since March
summary: SoftBank has spent US$2.9 billion on buying back its own shares since March, exceeding its initial budget of 500 billion yen. The company has acquired 71.5 million shares as of May 31, with the goal of raising as much as 4.5 trillion yen to buy shares and slash debt. This move comes as SoftBank struggles with falling global tech valuations and a record operating loss of 1.36 trillion yen for the year ended March 31. The company's stock has gained almost 90% since announcing the plan to sell assets.

site_title: Netflix in talks to source local Indian content from Reliance affiliate Viacom18: sources
summary: US video streaming company Netflix is in talks with Viacom18, an Indian media unit of Reliance Industries, to source local content for its platform. The potential partnership aims to expand Netflix's offerings in India, where it competes with Amazon and Disney. However, a Netflix spokesperson denied the talks, and Viacom18 declined to comment. The partnership would help Network18 affiliates create shows for Netflix, enhancing its presence in the Indian market.

site_title: Daily Debrief: What Happened Today
summary: Two former Coastal Oil Singapore employees were charged with cheating eight banks in Singapore and Hong Kong of over US$340 million. The Singapore Grand Prix was cancelled due to the Covid-19 pandemic. Bank of Singapore's private banking unit plans to expand its investment products to target family offices. Utico, a utilities group, may be acquired by two parties valuing it at up to US$1.5 billion. Singapore electronics firm PCI won a government contract to manufacture contact-tracing devices. Harry Elias Partnership merged with Eversheds Sutherland, ending the merger. The STI fell 0.72% for the day and 2.43% for the week.

site_title: Hi-P to widen customer base and products, expand out of China amid macro challenges
summary: Contract manufacturer Hi-P International plans to diversify its customer base, expand product mix, and exit China to mitigate macro headwinds affecting its declining gross profit margin. The company's gross profit margin has decreased from 16.3% in FY2017 to 13.7% in FY2019. This move aims to reduce reliance on China and increase revenue.

site_title: Beijing shuts markets after second day of new Covid-19 cases
summary: Beijing has shut six major wholesale food markets after two new Covid-19 cases were reported, with the infected individuals working at a meat research center. The cases, involving two men aged 25 and 37, occurred after they visited the markets in the past 14 days. The city government has also delayed plans for students to return to school and will inspect restaurants and seafood products. The closures follow a case reported on Thursday, China's first in nearly two months.

site_title: ISOTeam bags S$32.5m in new contracts amid 'gloomy backdrop'
summary: ISOTeam, a CATALIST-listed building-solutions firm, secured S$32.5 million in new contracts, bringing its FY2020 total to S$139.17 million. The contract wins, led by public-sector projects, are seen as a "bright light" against the gloomy construction sector backdrop, which is expected to contract 10.3% this year. The group expects to maintain its order-win momentum through tender opportunities and government projects.

site_title: US: Wall Street jumps at open after previous session's rout
summary: US stocks opened sharply higher on June 12, 2020, after a one-day dive in about three months, driven by fears of a coronavirus resurgence. The Dow Jones Industrial Average rose 2.11%, the S&P 500 gained 2.30%, and the Nasdaq Composite increased 2.35%. The rally came despite uncertainty over US-EU trade talks and tariff implications.

site_title: 'Shameful' to threaten Churchill statue, says UK PM Johnson
summary: British Prime Minister Boris Johnson has condemned the threat to remove a Winston Churchill statue, calling it "absurd and shameful." Johnson defended Churchill's legacy, stating that while he made unacceptable opinions, he was a hero and deserves his memorial. The move comes as anti-racism protesters, inspired by the George Floyd protests, challenge Britain's imperialist past by targeting statues of historical figures. Johnson appealed to protesters to avoid violence and abide by social distancing rules.

site_title: Startups' valuations are climbing more slowly since Covid-19
summary: Startup valuations are slowing down after the COVID-19 pandemic, with a 60% increase in per-share stock prices in April, compared to 42% in March and 93% in average months in 2019. Internet and software companies showed funding results in line with 2019 averages, while hardware, life sciences, and other industries declined. About 70% of companies raised money saw their valuations increase, but early-stage companies faced challenges, with only one-fifth of all transactions in April.

site_title: STI 0.72% lower for the day, 2.43% down for the week
summary: Singapore's Straits Times Index (STI) closed 0.72% down at 2,684.63 points on Friday, marking a second consecutive day of decline. The index lost 2.43% for the week. Six STI members gained, while 28 lost value. Non-STI constituent Top Glove was a bright spot, adding 14 cents to S$5.70. Losers outnumbered gainers 294 to 170, with 1.74 billion shares traded. The decline follows a similar trend in Asia's key bourses, including Japan's Nikkei 225 and Hong Kong's Hang Seng index.

site_title: OCBC's private banking unit targets bigger slice of booming family offices business
summary: Bank of Singapore, OCBC's private banking unit, aims to capture a larger share of the booming family offices business by expanding investment products and targeting clients outside the region. Assets under management for this segment rose 20% to $104 billion in the year to March, driven by the market downturn. The unit competes with UBS and Credit Suisse in serving wealthy Asians and is evaluating an onshore presence in China. CEO Bahren Shaari sees a growing interest in private markets and a shift towards full-time wealth management, with opportunities for local partnerships.

site_title: Australia: Shares post biggest weekly drop in seven weeks
summary: Australian shares posted their biggest weekly drop in seven weeks, falling 2.5% on Friday, amid fears of a second COVID-19 wave and a gloomy economic outlook. The S&P/ASX 200 index closed at 5,847.8, its second straight session of losses. The US Federal Reserve's gloomy outlook and a leading health expert's warning of a potential 200,000 coronavirus deaths by September also contributed to the decline.

site_title: Singapore electronics firm wins government contract for contact-tracing devices
summary: Singaporean electronics firm PCI has won a government contract to manufacture an initial batch of wearable contact tracing devices, known as TraceTogether Token, as part of the country's efforts to contain the spread of COVID-19. The contract, worth S$6 million, will supply 300,000 dongles to the government. The devices are part of Singapore's nationwide reopening efforts, with the first batch set to be delivered in the latter half of this month. The move aims to address the slow take-up rate of a separate contact tracing phone app.

site_title: Fincy receives US$11m injection from parent GBCI Ventures
summary: Fincy, a Singapore-based fintech startup, has received a US$11 million injection from its parent company GBCI Ventures. The funding will be used to expand the company's market presence, build new headquarters, and make strategic hires. Fincy aims to use its multi-currency wallet to facilitate seamless and contactless currency exchange across Asia, with a focus on driving user acquisition and transaction volumes. The startup will also use the funds to further develop its blockchain technology and data centre network.

site_title: Seoul: Shares post biggest weekly fall since mid-March after US rout
summary: South Korean stocks plummeted 2% on Friday, marking their biggest weekly decline since mid-March, amid renewed fears of a second wave of coronavirus infections in the US. The Kospi fell 44.48 points to 2,132.30, while the Korean won weakened and bond yields rose. Analysts attribute the decline to concerns about a second wave, despite not being a confirmed fact, and investors are waiting for a potential rebound after a couple of days of losses.

site_title: US lawmakers ask Zoom to clarify China ties after it suspends accounts
summary: US lawmakers have asked Zoom Video Communications to clarify its data-collection practices and relationship with the Chinese government after suspending user accounts of three US and Hong Kong-based activists. Zoom said it was notified of the events by the Chinese government and suspended accounts in Hong Kong and the US, but has since reinstated them. The company claims it did not provide user information to China and has encrypted communications. The move has raised concerns about Zoom's ties to China, with US lawmakers calling for transparency and Senator Josh Hawley asking the company to "pick a side" between the US and China.

site_title: Hong Kong: Stocks end week with another loss
summary: Hong Kong stocks ended the week with a loss, following a decline on Wall Street due to concerns over the global economic recovery and US infections. The Hang Seng Index fell 0.73% to 24,301.38, while the Shanghai Composite Index was marginally lower. The Shenzhen Composite Index rose 0.29%. The decline follows a rally earlier this week, as investors weigh the impact of new US President Trump's threats on the stock market.

site_title: HK property enquiries up in street retail sector on stability hopes
summary: Hong Kong's street-level shops have seen a surge in bargain buying and leasing interest, with enquiries increasing by at least 50% in the three weeks following Beijing's imposition of national security legislation. Retailers hope the law will bring an end to over a year of protests, but prices remain low due to sellers' hesitation to sell at low prices. The increased activity has not yet led to a significant increase in deals, with the office sector and shopping malls still stalled.

site_title: Economists still expect a slow decline in US unemployment rate
summary: US economists expect a slow decline in the unemployment rate, with a median estimate of 13.4% in the second quarter, down 2.7 percentage points from the previous month's poll. Forecasts for the end of 2021 remain steady at 7%, while the US economy is expected to contract 5.7% in 2020, expand by 4% in 2021, and 2.8% in 2022.

site_title: UK economy shrinks by record 20.4% in April lockdown
summary: The UK economy shrank by a record 20.4% in April due to the coronavirus lockdown, with a 10.4% contraction in the three months to April. This is the lowest point of the slump before a long recovery. The services sector fell by 19%, manufacturing by 24%, and construction by nearly half. The Bank of England warns of a possible deepest recession in three centuries, with an 11.5% forecasted contraction this year.

site_title: Singapore signs digital economy partnership agreement with Chile, New Zealand
summary: Singapore signed a digital economy partnership agreement (DEPA) with Chile and New Zealand, aiming to promote interoperability and improve efficiency in digital trade. The agreement will enable Singapore businesses to trade more seamlessly with Chile and New Zealand, reducing costs and increasing trust. The partnership was signed via video conference by Singapore's Minister for Trade and Industry Chan Chun Sing and his counterparts from Chile and New Zealand, and the three countries have begun joint projects to operationalize key aspects of the agreement.

site_title: Hyflux suitor Utico says two parties eyeing its shares
summary: Two parties are eyeing Utico's shares, valuing the UAE-based utilities group at up to US$1.5 billion. The interested parties have interests in the Gulf Cooperation Council, the UK, Singapore, and Indonesia. Utico is studying the propositions, pending its rescue deal for Hyflux, which is also considering a revised offer for the Singapore water treatment firm. A group of bank lenders is seeking to put Hyflux under judicial management.

site_title: Europe: Shares edge lower as virus worries take centre stage
summary: European shares fell 0.5% on Friday, their worst one-day sell-off since March, amid concerns over the economic recovery from the pandemic. The Stoxx 600 index is on track for a 5.8% weekly loss, distancing itself from all-time highs. Rising Covid-19 cases in the US and a sober economic outlook from the US Federal Reserve contributed to the decline. However, shares of automakers and some healthcare companies gained marginally.

site_title: Gold steady as firmer US dollar offsets risk-off sentiment
summary: Gold prices remained steady at $1,727.24 per ounce, despite rising safe-haven demand due to economic projections and COVID-19 fears. A stronger US dollar offset the downward pressure, holding prices flat. Asian equities are expected to fall due to concerns over a resurgence in coronavirus infections. The US jobless claims declined, but continuing claims remain high, and the Federal Reserve announced plans to keep interest rates near zero through 2022.

site_title: Indonesia's Bank Central Asia may join loan programme for troubled banks
summary: Bank Central Asia, Indonesia's largest bank by market value, may join a government loan programme to lend to troubled banks and improve their liquidity. The programme, which is the first of its kind in Indonesia, allows healthy banks to lend to struggling ones using government-provided funds. This is a departure from past crises where the central bank provided short-term liquidity support. The move aims to address the cash crunch faced by banks due to the coronavirus pandemic.

site_title: Singapore Grand Prix taken off the grid this year
summary: The Singapore Grand Prix has been cancelled for 2020 due to restrictions on crowds and mass gatherings caused by the COVID-19 pandemic. The event's promoter, Singapore GP, cited prohibitions on access and construction at the event venue, as well as international travel restrictions, as reasons for the cancellation. Existing ticketholders can opt for automatic refunds or roll over their tickets to next year's event. The cancellation is part of a broader trend of F1 race cancellations this year, with Japan and Azerbaijan also opting out.

site_title: Hedge fund group says don't write off Hong Kong as finance hub
summary: A hedge fund industry group in Hong Kong says the city remains a finance hub despite concerns over China's national security law. At least six new hedge fund managers have set up shop in Hong Kong this year, and the city continues to attract new firms. Despite some firms seeking licenses to expand in Singapore, they are not abandoning Hong Kong. The industry group's CEO, Jack Inglis, notes that Hong Kong remains the largest centre for hedge funds in the Asia Pacific region, and many firms prefer to stay due to the local workforce and proximity to China's stock markets.

site_title: 463 new Covid-19 cases in Singapore, including 18 in community
summary: Singapore reported 463 new COVID-19 cases, bringing the total to 39,850. Of these, 18 were community cases, including 8 Singaporeans and 10 work pass holders. Migrant workers in dormitories accounted for the remaining 416 cases. The average daily community cases have increased, with 8 cases in the past week, and unlinked cases have risen from 1 to 4 over the same period. Globally, over 7.58 million people have been infected, with 423,000 deaths.

site_title: Australian state recommends approving controversial A$3.6b Santos gas project
summary: The Australian state of New South Wales has recommended approving a controversial coal seam gas project by Santos, valued at A$3.6 billion. The project aims to address an expected energy supply shortfall in 2024, deemed "critical for energy security and reliability in NSW." The recommendation was submitted to the state's Independent Planning Commission, which has 12 weeks to determine whether the project should proceed.

site_title: Saudi wealth fund 'shopping spree' belies economic pain
summary: Saudi Arabia's sovereign wealth fund has acquired around $8 billion in stakes in global companies such as Boeing and Facebook, despite the country's economic struggles. The government has implemented austerity measures, including a tripled value-added tax and reduced spending, to address a ballooning budget deficit. This move strains the "rentier" social contract, which previously provided citizens with generous subsidies and a tax-free lifestyle, highlighting the economic pain beneath the fund's "shopping spree".

site_title: Spanish real estate is heading for its second crash in a decade
summary: Spain's US$6 trillion home market is forecasted to experience its second crash in a decade due to the impact of Europe's strictest pandemic lockdown. Experts predict a 6.5-15% decline in housing prices, with a potential drop of 12% by year-end. The looming crash is attributed to the economic crisis, with some regions experiencing higher declines in asking prices. However, analysts suggest a faster recovery due to a lack of excess supply and lower indebtedness compared to the 2008 crisis.

site_title: Tokyo: Stocks close lower after Wall Street rout
summary: Tokyo stocks closed lower on Friday, following a decline in US shares due to revived worries about the coronavirus and concerns about overheating equity prices. The benchmark Nikkei fell 0.75% and the Topix index lost 1.15%. The US Dow Jones plummeted 6.9% on Thursday, with investors discouraged by rising coronavirus cases in some reopened US states. Tokyo stocks initially dropped but later pared losses as US futures pointed to a positive opening, with Sony and SoftBank Group falling 1.21% and 2.19% respectively.

site_title: Singapore launches first national standard on guidelines for e-commerce transactions
summary: Singapore has launched its first national standard, Technical Reference 76 (TR 76), on guidelines for e-commerce transactions. The standard aims to provide a checklist for online retailers and intermediaries to develop e-commerce processes and policies, ensuring clear and comprehensive information is conveyed to consumers. The TR 76 guidelines are a provisional standard developed in response to industry demand, and they will be issued for industry trials for a period of time.

site_title: US to reduce troops in Iraq 'over coming months'
summary: The US has agreed to reduce its troops in Iraq over the coming months following talks with Baghdad. The decision comes after Iraqi lawmakers demanded the withdrawal of US forces following a US drone strike that killed a top Iranian general. The US and Iraq have agreed to maintain protection of US bases, which have been targeted by pro-Iranian paramilitary groups. The reduction of US troops is seen as a result of progress in eliminating the ISIS threat, with the US reaffirming its intention not to establish permanent bases in Iraq.

images.alt_text: The United States promised Thursday to reduce troops from Iraq over the coming months after talks with Baghdad, where lawmakers have pushed for their withdrawal.

site_title: Japan's 10t yen reserve to combat pandemic sparks ire as PM Abe's 'pocket money'
summary: Japan's 10 trillion yen emergency fund to combat the coronavirus pandemic has sparked controversy, with opposition lawmakers labeling it "Shinzo Abe's pocket money" due to its unprecedented size and lack of parliamentary oversight. The fund, which is roughly equal to the country's education and defense budgets combined, was approved by parliament as part of a record $300 billion extra budget to finance an economic stimulus package of $1.1 trillion. Analysts argue the size is justified given the need to guard against a second wave of infection, but critics worry it sets a bad precedent for future spending.

site_title: ASME, SBF launch funds to support migrant workers, SMEs and employees
summary: The Association of Small and Medium Enterprises (ASME) and the Singapore Business Federation (SBF) launched the ASME-SBF Foundation Compassion Fund for Migrant Workers' Centre to raise S$500,000 for migrant workers. The fund aims to support migrant workers, SMEs, and employees, with S$300,000 from local SMEs matched by a S$200,000 grant from the SBF Foundation. ASME highlighted the economic contributions of migrant workers, echoing Singapore's forefathers' migrant worker history.

site_title: Hong Kong government rejects UK criticism of new security law as biased
summary: The Hong Kong government has rejected UK criticism of its new national security law, calling it "inaccurate and biased." The British government has criticized the law as a clear violation of China's international obligations and a breach of the "one country, two systems" formula. Hong Kong authorities insist the law will focus on "troublemakers" and will not curb freedoms or hurt investors. The exchange came as Hong Kong marked the anniversary of a major protest against the proposed bill, which would have allowed extraditions to mainland China.

site_title: Goldman Sachs is said to try to avoid pleading guilty in 1MDB scandal
summary: Goldman Sachs is attempting to negotiate with US federal prosecutors to reduce a proposed $2 billion fine and avoid a guilty plea in connection with the 1MDB scandal. The bank's lawyers have requested a review by Deputy Attorney General Jeffrey Rosen, citing the potential for a lower fine and a deferred prosecution agreement. The case involves allegations of foreign bribery, corruption, and money laundering related to the theft of billions from a Malaysian sovereign wealth fund. Goldman has consistently maintained that it was not directly involved in the scheme, with CEO David Solomon apologizing for the bank's role.

images.alt_text: Goldman Sachs is trying to get federal prosecutors to ease up on the bank for its role in a brazen scheme to loot billions of dollars from a Malaysian sovereign wealth fund.

site_title: Coastal Oil ex-employees charged with cheating Singapore, HK banks of over US$340m
summary: Two former Coastal Oil Singapore employees, Ong Ah Huat, 60, and Huang Peishi, 34, have been charged in court for allegedly cheating eight banks in Singapore and Hong Kong of over US$340 million. The banks named include DBS Bank (Hong Kong), China Merchants Bank, and OCBC (Hong Kong). The charges stem from alleged misappropriation of funds, with the court documents showing the accused employees' involvement in the scheme. The case is ongoing, with no further details provided.

site_title: Broker's take: Maybank KE raises target price on Top Glove, positive on Malaysia glove sector
summary: Maybank KE has raised its target price on Top Glove to RM21.90, from RM20, citing the company's highest quarterly net profit and revenue in its 29-year history. Top Glove's strong third-quarter results beat analysts' expectations, driven by a surge in demand for gloves amid the Covid-19 pandemic. The brokerage expects the company to post a fourth-quarter net profit of RM782 million, representing a 9.8 times increase. Maybank KE has maintained its "buy" rating on Top Glove, citing higher average selling prices and a "bullish guidance" for the months ahead.

site_title: How SMEs can be both bankable and credible
summary: Singapore's economic landscape faces bleak prospects due to the COVID-19 outbreak, with forecasts downgrading the city-state's growth numbers. SMEs are struggling to survive, with many unable to raise funding and facing cash flow management challenges. To become bankable and credible, SMEs must improve their financial management skills, digitize, and explore online sales channels. A professional financial assessment is crucial to determine financial health, evaluate credit risk, and identify financing needs. By taking concrete steps to manage cash flows and credit risk, SMEs can increase their chances of getting a loan and ensure long-term sustainability.

site_title: Japan's economy is bottoming out, eyes on recovery: finance minister
summary: Japan's economy appears to have hit bottom and is on track for a gradual recovery from the coronavirus pandemic, according to Finance Minister Taro Aso. The country's economy is expected to recover gradually, with domestic conditions and overseas developments playing a significant role. The Bank of Japan is likely to stick to its view of a gradual recovery at its upcoming rate review, with no plans to expand stimulus. This cautious optimism comes ahead of the Bank of Japan's rate review, which will provide insight into the country's economic recovery prospects.

site_title: Asia: Stocks track US rout as rally hits roadblock, second virus wave appears
summary: Asia's stock markets plummeted on Friday, tracking a rout on US stocks, as investors worried about a second wave of COVID-19 infections in the US and the economic recovery. The Dow, S&P 500, and Nasdaq all fell, with Asia's main indexes down 1-2%. Oil prices also dropped, and the dollar rallied as investors sought safe-haven status. Analysts cited profit-taking and concerns about the economic recovery, with some warning that the sell-off could be a correction or a sign of something more serious.

site_title: Australia, New Zealand: Shares a sea of red as virus fears resurface
summary: Australian and New Zealand shares plummeted on Friday, with the S&P/ASX 200 index dropping 3% for a second straight session, amid investor fears of a possible Covid-19 resurgence and the US Federal Reserve's warning of a "long road" to economic recovery. Energy and financial stocks led the losses, while mining stocks fell 2.8%. New Zealand's benchmark index also declined 2.2%, with some signs of recovery in manufacturing activity. The downturn marks the index's biggest weekly drop since April 24.

site_title: Hong Kongers withdraw HK$1.44b in pension funds in Q4, up 46% on-year
summary: Hong Kong residents withdrew a record HK$1.44 billion from their Mandatory Provident Fund accounts in Q4 2019, a 46.1% increase from the same quarter in 2018. This follows violent unrest in the city, sparked by protests over a now-withdrawn extradition bill, which evolved into calls for greater democracy. The largest quarterly withdrawal since 2014, it suggests residents are seeking a safety net amid fears of China's tightening grip on the city. The total withdrawal amount for 2019 was HK$4.85 billion, up 1.1% from 2018.

site_title: Hong Kong: Stocks plunge more than 2% at open
summary: Hong Kong stocks plummeted 2.29% at the opening of trading on Friday, following a sell-off on Wall Street due to concerns over economic recovery and a second wave of US infections. The Hang Seng Index fell to 23,920.70, while the Shanghai Composite Index dropped 1.51% to 2,876.80. The declines were attributed to worries about the economic recovery and a second wave of infections in the US.

site_title: Chinese metals giant cuts Singapore oil team after few months
summary: Amer International Group Co, a Chinese metals giant, has cut its Singapore oil team after hiring only two employees to set up an oil trading desk. The move comes as the company scales back non-copper related activity amid market volatility and a collapse of other commodities firms in Singapore. The decision follows a tumultuous period for commodities trading, with lenders becoming increasingly concerned about the highly leveraged and low-margin business.

site_title: Westpac says regulator may include more allegations in money-laundering case
summary: Westpac Banking Corp stated that AUSTRAC, the financial crime watchdog, may include more allegations in its money-laundering case against the lender. AUSTRAC requested additional information on 272 suspicious transactions for customers previously reported. Westpac previously claimed an internal investigation found child exploitation payments were due to "faults of omission" and not intentional wrongdoing.

images.alt_text: Australia's Westpac Banking Corp on Friday said it was notified by the financial crime watchdog that it may include additional allegations of wrongdoing in its case against the lender for breaching anti-money laundering laws.

site_title: Seoul: Shares tumble tracking US rout, set to post first weekly drop in a month
summary: South Korean shares tumbled 2.7% on Friday, tracking a US rout, and are poised to post the first weekly drop in a month. The Kospi index fell 58.50 points to 2,118.28, with Samsung Electronics and SK Hynix falling 3.9% and 4%, respectively. Concerns over a second wave of coronavirus infections in the US and rising cases in several states have led to investor worries, while foreign investors were net sellers of 208.1 billion won worth of South Korean shares.

site_title: Two-thirds of sponsors unsure about 2021 Olympics: poll
summary: Two-thirds of Tokyo 2020's corporate sponsors are undecided on continuing their financial support for the Games, with 65% saying they haven't made up their minds. Concerns over reduced promotional activities and potential scrapping of the event due to the coronavirus have led to uncertainty. Over 68% of respondents reported financial difficulties, and the International Olympic Committee has set aside $800 million to cover the additional costs of postponing the Games by a year, which were initially estimated to be $12.6 billion.

site_title: New Zealand says to allow entry for some maritime vessels, cruise ships still banned
summary: New Zealand has lifted most coronavirus restrictions, allowing entry to some maritime vessels with a compelling need to travel to the country. Cruise ships and leisure travelers are still banned, but cargo ships and crew members can enter with no restrictions. Exemptions have been granted to two syndicates preparing for the America's Cup. The move aims to kick-start the country's battered economy and keep shipping routes open, as most maritime journeys take over 14 days, allowing for self-isolation.

site_title: Malaysia: Shares open lower on Friday
summary: Malaysia's FTSE Bursa Malaysia Kuala Lumpur Composite Index dropped 2.69% to 1,515.30, with 41.95 points losses, on Friday. The market saw 787.77 million lots traded, with losers outperforming gainers 790 to 34. This comes as global markets continue to navigate uncertainty, with US-EU trade talks and tariff concerns.

site_title: Dynamic Italian duo
summary: Beppe De Vito, the boss of the ilLido group, has launched two new concepts: Grammi, a casual virtual trattoria-supermarket, and Braci a Casa, a one Michelin-starred Italian cooking experience at home. Grammi offers comfort and casual Italian fare, while Braci a Casa brings high-end Italian cuisine to living rooms. The launch comes after De Vito's previous offerings, catering to a wide range of Italian cooking styles.

site_title: Tokyo: Stocks open down more than 2% after Wall Street rout
summary: Tokyo stocks plummeted more than 2% on Friday, June 12, 2020, following a US stock market rout amid revived coronavirus concerns and worries about overheating equity prices. The benchmark Nikkei dropped 2.36% to 21,942.01, while the Topix index fell 2.54% to 1,548.58. This downturn occurred despite positive performances in other markets, such as Singapore's STI, which rose 0.4% on Thursday.

site_title: Zoom says China demanded shutting activists' accounts over Tiananmen event
summary: Zoom Video Communications Inc. reported that the Chinese government demanded the termination of four public meetings on its platform to commemorate the 31st anniversary of China's Tiananmen Square crackdown. The company did not provide user information or meeting content to China and refused further requests, leaving one meeting "undisturbed" as it did not have participants from mainland China. Three accounts were temporarily suspended or terminated, but later reinstated. Zoom stated it would not allow further requests from China to impact users outside the country.

site_title: Fearful Hong Kongers rush to secure limited British passports
summary: Hong Kongers are rushing to secure British National (Overseas) passports, a document that grants access to British consular services and permission to travel to the UK, amid fears of China's planned national security law. The law, which bypasses Hong Kong's legislature, has sparked concerns of mainland-style political oppression. Britain has announced plans to extend immigration rights, including a possible "path to citizenship," for those with BN(O) status, sparking both hope and fury in Beijing. Over 350,000 people currently hold BN(O) passports, with many more eligible, and a recent survey found that young Hong Kongers are particularly keen to emigrate.

site_title: Latam Airlines bondholders in talks to supply up to US$1.5b loan, sources say
summary: Latam Airlines bondholders are in talks to provide up to $1.5 billion in a debtor-in-possession loan to the airline as part of its Chapter 11 proceeding in the US. The loan, to be provided by bondholders including Blackrock, Macquarie Group, and HSBC, will be formally discussed with investment bank Moelis & Co. The exact value of the loan is expected to be within the $1 billion to $1.5 billion range.

images.alt_text: A group of bondholders of Latam Airlines Group SA is in talks to supply up to US$1.5 billion in a debtor-in-possession loan within the Chapter 11 proceeding in the United States, two people with knowledge of the matter said on Thursday.

site_title: Sony pulls back curtain on PlayStation 5 console
summary: Sony unveiled its PlayStation 5 console, highlighting its powerful hardware and action-packed games tailored for the next-generation console. The console's design features a dark tower with white sides, and two versions were shown, one with a disk slot and another without. Games showcased include Marvel's Spider-Man Miles Morales, Deathloop, and Resident Evil Village. Pricing and launch date were not revealed, but the console is set to compete with Microsoft's Xbox Series X later this year.

site_title: Accordia Golf Trust posts 585m yen distributable loss for Q4
summary: Accordia Golf Trust reported a 585 million yen distributable loss for Q4, reversing from a profit a year ago, due to higher reserved items related to the COVID-19 pandemic's impact on the business. The trust set aside 1.2 billion yen for compliance with financial covenants.

site_title: Good Food Hunting
summary: Singapore's Western food scene is highlighted in Oddle's latest series, featuring gems from Buona Vista, Queensway, and Bukit Timah. A-One Claypot House offers traditional claypot dishes like Dried Scallop Century Egg, while Boon Lay Power Nasi Lemak serves the city's best nasi lemak since 1978. Canton Paradise offers dim sum and Cantonese favorites, and Greenwood Fish Market offers sushi and seafood at great prices. Other recommended spots include Ippudo for Japanese ramen, Keng Eng Kee for home-style cooking, Peperoni Pizzeria for wood-fired pizzas, and YAYOI for Teishoku set meals.

site_title: SGX to share fundraising expertise with co-working space provider Ucommune
summary: The Singapore Exchange (SGX) has partnered with China's largest co-working space provider Ucommune to share fundraising expertise. The agreement aims to support Ucommune's global members in accessing international funding via Singapore's capital markets. As part of the partnership, SGX will provide best practices, education, and assistance to suitable companies, while Ucommune will identify companies exploring fundraising options and jointly organize roundtable meetings and roadshows to accelerate Chinese enterprises entering the international market. This partnership will provide businesses with relevant insight into investment and financing activities.

site_title: Singapore shares continue slide from Asia rout; STI down 3.4% at Friday's open
summary: Singapore's Straits Times Index (STI) fell 3.4% at Friday's open, following a dismal Asia-wide performance and a dour US Federal Reserve economic outlook. The benchmark index dropped 92.2 points to 2,611.99, with losers outnumbering gainers 238 to 28. Genting Singapore led the decline, losing 3.3% to 74.5 cents. The slide continues Singapore's recent rout, with the STI down 3.4% from Thursday's close.

site_title: Apple launches US$100m racial justice initiative
summary: Apple has launched a US$100 million racial justice initiative aimed at breaking down barriers to opportunity for minorities. The initiative, led by executive Lisa Jackson, will focus on systemic barriers to opportunity faced by communities of color, particularly black communities, through education, civil rights organizations, and minority developers. CEO Tim Cook emphasized the importance of corporate leaders to drive change and stressed that the burden of change falls on those in positions of power. The initiative will start in the US and be rolled globally over time, with the goal of achieving transformation in the company and in society.

site_title: Stocks to watch: SIA, SGX, Starhill Global Reit, Accordia Golf Trust, UOI
summary: Singapore stocks saw varied developments on Friday. Singapore Airlines landed S$10 billion in funding, improving its financial position, but analysts note headwinds persist due to lack of domestic market support and ongoing travel restrictions. Meanwhile, Singapore Exchange partnered with China's Ucommune on fundraising knowledge sharing, while Starhill Global Reit's distribution is expected to be below 90% of taxable income this year. Accordia Golf Trust reported a distributable loss, and United Overseas Insurance warned of challenging premiums amid the Covid-19 crisis.

site_title: Hyflux's next pre-trial conference likely to be on June 19 or 22
summary: Hyflux's next pre-trial conference is likely to be held on June 19 or 22, where the court will issue further directions on the water treatment firm's reorganisation process and creditor applications. A group of bank lenders, including Bangkok Bank and Standard Chartered Bank, plans to revive an application to put Hyflux under judicial management after two years of a court-sanctioned restructuring process. The lenders had previously submitted an affidavit to the court on June 12, with a redacted version to be served to other creditors by June 16.

images.alt_text: Hyflux on Thursday said its next pre-trial conference is likely to be held on June 19 or June 22, where further directions will be issued regarding the water treatment firm's main reorganisation process and applications by any of the creditors.

site_title: UK's Johnson, EU leaders to assess Brexit progress
summary: UK Prime Minister Boris Johnson will hold a conference call with EU leaders to assess progress on post-Brexit trade negotiations. The call comes as talks have stalled with just six months to go before the UK leaves the EU single market and customs union. The two sides aim to reach a free trade agreement by December 31, with the economic consequences potentially devastating if they fail. The intensified timetable will involve regular meetings in London and Brussels.

site_title: Snapchat to deliver breaking news, adds wellness features
summary: Snapchat has introduced a new "Happening Now" service to deliver breaking news to its users, partnering with major news outlets such as The Washington Post and NBC News. The company aims to reduce stress and anxiety on its platform by offering meditation tools and expanding its "Here For You" initiative. Additionally, Snapchat unveiled new features, including augmented reality visual search and personalized maps with business information, as well as gaming and entertainment features to boost usage and engagement.

site_title: Singapore, Hong Kong bourses to face off over Chinese stock futures
summary: Singapore's role as a regional equity derivatives trading centre may be curtailed after losing a major index-licensing deal to Hong Kong. Singapore Exchange (SGX) will face competition in trading Chinese stock futures, with Hong Kong Exchanges & Clearing (HKEX) working on a similar hedging tool. SGX's monopoly on offshore derivatives based on China's A shares may end, with the exchange facing challenges such as a slowdown in listings and India's decision to move trading onshore.

site_title: North Korean foreign minister voices 'despair' for ties with US, two years after summit
summary: North Korea's Foreign Minister Ri Son Gwon expressed "despair" over the country's ties with the US, two years after the historic summit between Kim Jong Un and President Donald Trump. Ri stated that despite people's desire for peace, Washington is "hell-bent on exacerbating the situation," leading to a deterioration in relations. The minister's comments suggest that hopes for improved ties have been lost, shifting to a sense of despair.

site_title: NTUC Income offers insurance coverage with bite-sized premiums
summary: NTUC Income introduces a micro-insurance model called Snack, allowing Singaporeans to pay as little as 30 Singapore cents for critical illness, personal accident, or term life coverage. Policyholders can gradually accumulate coverage with bite-sized premiums tied to daily activities. This model aims to provide accessible insurance options to a broader audience, making insurance more affordable and convenient.

site_title: Trump may try to 'steal' election or not leave office: Biden
summary: US President Joe Biden expressed concerns that President Donald Trump may try to "steal" the November election or refuse to leave office if he loses. Biden stated he believes the military would ensure a peaceful transition of power. The White House dismissed Biden's remarks as conspiracy theories, with press secretary Kayleigh McEnany calling them "ridiculous propositions." Trump has repeatedly made unfounded claims about voting and mail-in ballots, fueling concerns among Democrats.

site_title: California startup aims to monitor social distancing and face masks using drones
summary: A California startup, Airspace Systems, has released software to monitor social distancing and face-mask wearing using drones. The system analyzes video streams and identifies crowded areas and people wearing masks, generating text-based data on crowd density and mask-wearing percentages. The system does not use facial recognition and does not save images of people. Cities can decide whether to send alerts to residents or internal authorities. Critics, including the American Civil Liberties Union, raise concerns about the potential for a "nightmare vision" of machine surveillance monitoring behavior. The system aims to help cities create safer environments.

site_title: Japanese women bear brunt of recession as pandemic unravels Abe's 'Womenomics'
summary: Japanese women are bearing the brunt of the country's economic recession, with female labor participation reaching a decade-high despite lacking job security. Women make up 70% of the workforce, but many hold vulnerable part-time, contract, or temporary jobs, with 710,000 women losing jobs in April. Experts say women are "the shock absorber" of the economy, with limited access to government support and often relying on unstable employment. The economic slump, caused by the coronavirus outbreak, is expected to take time to recover from, with many women struggling to make ends meet.

site_title: Oil prices slump 8% as virus-related demand concerns resurface
summary: Oil prices plummeted 8% on Thursday, with Brent crude futures falling to $38.55 a barrel and US West Texas Intermediate (WTI) crude falling to $36.34 a barrel. The decline was driven by renewed concerns about demand destruction due to rising coronavirus cases globally, despite most states having eased restrictions. The US Federal Reserve expressed concern that fuel consumption remains 20% below typical levels, limiting demand. US crude inventories hit a record 538.1 million barrels, and the Fed warned of a prolonged period of high unemployment and interest rates near zero.

site_title: Microsoft joins rivals, bars police use of face recognition tech
summary: Microsoft joins its tech rivals in banning law enforcement use of its facial recognition technology until government regulations are in place. The company's president, Brad Smith, stated that the technology will not be sold to police in the US until there are laws grounded in human rights. This move follows similar announcements by Amazon and IBM, amid concerns over police brutality and potential discrimination against minorities. The company aims to protect human rights as the technology is deployed, and has previously implemented principles for fair and lawful surveillance.

site_title: Trump praises US police, rejecting protesters' cries of racism
summary: US President Donald Trump rejected nationwide protesters' claims of police racism, saying only a "few bad apples" are to blame for police misconduct. He offered a vague proposal to encourage officers to meet "current professional standards for the use of force." Trump is making law and order a new keystone of his reelection campaign, aiming to win a second term on November 3.

site_title: Twitter removes China, Russia and Turkey 'state-linked' accounts
summary: Twitter has removed tens of thousands of "state-linked" accounts from China, Russia, and Turkey, citing efforts to push propaganda, sow misinformation, and attack critics. The Chinese network, comprising 23,750 core accounts and 150,000 amplifier accounts, was detected using systems used to delete state-linked accounts last August. The network spread geopolitical narratives favorable to the Communist Party of China and promoted deceptive narratives on the Hong Kong protests and coronavirus pandemic. Twitter has archived the accounts for researchers, following similar actions by YouTube, Google, and Facebook.

images.alt_text: Twitter on Friday said it had removed tens of thousands of "state linked" accounts used by China, Russia and Turkey to push their own propaganda, sow misinformation or attack critics.

site_title: Money FM podcast: The Last Artisan
summary: Host Glenn van Zutphen of Money FM 89.3's Weekend Mornings podcast discussed The Last Artisan, a film directed by Craig McTurk, with award-winning author Neil Humphreys. The film showcases Haw Par Villa, a historic site in Singapore, and explores its transformation. The conversation delved into the challenges and process of directing the film, which will be aired on The Projector's online platform.

site_title: US: Stocks plunge on revived coronavirus fears, Dow -6.9%
summary: US stocks plummeted 6.9% on Thursday, with the Dow Jones Industrial Average falling 1,850 points to 25,128.17, as revived coronavirus fears and excessive equity prices led to the worst session since March. Rising case counts in reopened states, including Texas and Arizona, have investors concerned about depressing economic activity. Despite Treasury Secretary Steven Mnuchin's assurance that the government won't shut down the economy again, analysts describe equity valuations as "frothy" and warn that the market has "run into some facts."

site_title: Brazil tops 40,000 coronavirus deaths: official
summary: Brazil has surpassed 40,000 coronavirus deaths and 800,000 cases, according to the health ministry, with 1,239 new deaths reported over the last 24 hours. This puts Brazil as the third highest death toll in the world, with the US being the only country to have surpassed it. Brazil is second only to the US in total cases.

site_title: Trudeau says racism exists in all Canada institutions
summary: Canada's Prime Minister Justin Trudeau stated that systemic racism exists in all Canadian institutions, including the federal police. This contradicts RCMP Commissioner Brenda Lucki's assertion that Canada does not have systemic racism. Trudeau emphasized the need for Canadians to acknowledge their institutions' past unfair treatment of racialized and Indigenous groups. He expressed a desire to do better and not be "proud of the Canada that we built and that our ancestors built." Trudeau's comments come amid widespread protests and marches against racism and police brutality in Canada and the US.

images.alt_text: Prime Minister Justin Trudeau said on Thursday that systemic racism exists in all Canadian institutions including the federal police, after the nation's top cop balked at the notion.

site_title: Boeing contractor to halt work on 737 MAX, furlough staff
summary: Boeing contractor Spirit AeroSystems will furlough 900 workers at its Wichita factory starting Monday after being directed to pause work on 737 MAX planes due to the COVID-19 pandemic's impact on air travel. The move affects production on 16 planes scheduled for 2020 delivery. Spirit's hourly workforces in Tulsa and McAlester, Oklahoma, will also be reduced. The furlough is intended to support Boeing's delivery schedules and mitigate unnecessary production costs. The 737 MAX has been grounded since March 2019 following two deadly crashes.

images.alt_text: Spirit AeroSystems, a major contractor on the 737 MAX, will furlough staff after being directed by Boeing to pause work on the embattled plane, Spirit announced late Wednesday.

site_title: Over 95,000 employers in Singapore to receive S$450m in wage credits by June 30
summary: Singapore's Wage Credit Scheme (WCS) will provide over S$450 million in payouts to over 95,000 employers by June 30, co-funding 20% of qualifying wage increases for 800,000 employees earning up to S$5,000 monthly. Deputy Prime Minister Heng Swee Keat announced the enhancement in Budget 2020, raising co-funding levels to 20% and increasing the monthly wage ceiling to S$5,000. Employers can receive payouts directly into their bank accounts through digital payment modes.

site_title: Lebanese pound hits new low despite government efforts, sparking protests
summary: The Lebanese pound hit a record low on the black market despite government efforts to stabilize it, amid the country's worst economic turmoil in decades. The plunge is attributed to prolonged economic downturn and corruption accusations. Lebanon is in talks with the International Monetary Fund to secure billions in aid. Mass protests, sparked by economic grievances, took place in October last year.

site_title: Dusit Thani to open first Singapore resort in Oct
summary: Dusit Thani, a Thai hospitality giant, is set to open its first resort in Singapore, Dusit Thani Laguna Singapore, in October. The luxury urban resort, co-located with Laguna National Golf & Country Club, will offer direct access to two championship-calibre golf courses. The resort features 198 rooms, restaurants, three swimming pools, and a Thai-inspired spa. Room reservations can be made for stays from October 1, pending updates from the Singapore government on the economy's re-opening.

site_title: Europe: Shares run red on Federal Reserve's reality check, second-wave virus fears
summary: European shares plummeted 4.1% on Thursday, their worst day in over 11 weeks, amid a sobering economic outlook from the US Federal Reserve and concerns over a second wave of Covid-19 cases. The Fed indicated a full-fledged economic recovery would require more than just easing coronavirus curbs, while forecasting a 6.5% contraction in the US economy for 2020. Automobile stocks led losses, with Fiat Chrysler and Peugeot maker PSA falling 7.7% and 10% respectively, as worries about a second wave of infections pressured travel and leisure stocks.

site_title: US dollar shortage in March threatened to spark off another financial crisis
summary: The Monetary Authority of Singapore (MAS) recalled contingency plans for a financial crisis in March due to severe stress in global financial markets, particularly in the US corporate bond market. The MAS set up a US$60 billion swap facility with the US Federal Reserve to support dollar lending to businesses in Singapore and the region. Managing Director Ravi Menon warned that the debt build-up from the pandemic will be a major challenge, with renewed outbreaks and secondary waves of infections posing a risk to emerging markets. He emphasized the need for an exit strategy to address the growing corporate debt and potential liquidity risks.

site_title: Jump in orders from pandemic hands Top Glove record Q3 profit
summary: Top Glove, a Malaysian company, reported its highest quarterly net profit and revenue in its 29-year history, driven by a surge in demand for gloves amid the global pandemic. The company's bottom line jumped 365.7% to RM347.9 million, with revenue rising 41.9% to RM1.69 billion. Top Glove attributed the outstanding performance to "unparalleled growth in sales volume" and plans to expand its capacity to meet growing demand, with a RM3 billion capital expenditure plan to build 450 new lines.

site_title: China, US should resume timely communication: China adviser
summary: China adviser Zhu Guangyao urged timely communication with the US on trade and other issues, citing the two economies' intertwined nature. China's economy contracted 6.8% in the first quarter, and the government set a 2020 budget deficit of at least 3.6%. Cabinet advisers Liu Huan and Wang Zhaoxing predicted China's economy could rebound sharply in the third quarter, with growth potential of 5% and 3-4% for the year. China's government has pledged more spending and set a large fiscal stimulus package to support the economy.

site_title: Opportunities for real estate players despite pandemic
summary: The COVID-19 pandemic has brought about significant economic and operational changes to the real estate sector, despite its relatively slow impact. Tenants in Singapore are struggling with rental costs, leading to rent concessions and tax measures for landlords. In the medium to long-term, this could result in rental shortfalls, affecting valuations. The shift towards online shopping and work-from-home may also alter the way retailers and businesses operate, with some adopting experiential store designs and technology to complement e-commerce efforts. The sector is expected to transform and adapt to these changes, presenting opportunities for resilient and future-proof businesses.

site_title: US sees 1.54m new jobless claims as layoffs go on
summary: The US Labor Department reported 1.54 million new jobless claims last week, bringing the total to 44.2 million since mid-March. Despite a decline in weekly claims, the number remains higher than any single week of the 2008 global financial crisis. The insured unemployment rate declined to 14.4%, with 20.9 million people receiving unemployment payments. States and businesses have reopened, but activity remains restricted, leading to ongoing layoffs. The decline in continuing claims suggests some people are returning to work, but the number of weekly claims remains high.

site_title: Singapore's role on global stage hinges on it being united, strong at home: SM Teo
summary: Senior Minister Teo Chee Hean emphasized that Singapore's global standing hinges on its unity and strength at home. Despite the COVID-19 pandemic and other challenges, Singapore will continue to play a significant role in shaping the world's frameworks post-pandemic. Teo highlighted the need for collective global action to address challenges such as violent extremism, nuclear proliferation, and climate change. He stressed that Singapore's diplomats will have credibility only if the country is strong, successful, and united at home, and that building a resilient Singapore is crucial for its ability to respond effectively in a more uncertain world.

site_title: Singtel consortium to build high-performance submarine cable across East, SE-Asia
summary: Singtel, part of the Asia Direct Cable Consortium, is building a 9,400-kilometre high-performance submarine cable connecting East and South-east Asia, with completion expected by 2022. The cable, featuring multiple pairs of optical fibres, will enable high-capacity data transmission of over 140 Terabits per second, supporting advanced technologies like 5G and high-definition video. The project involves Singtel, China Telecom, SoftBank, Tata Communications, and Viettel, aiming to enhance infrastructure and support future growth.

site_title: Jazz Up The Home Work Space
summary: Designers share tips on creating a comfortable and productive home workspace. Interior designers Yeo See Wee and Dennis Cheok recommend choosing a space that suits individual needs, separating work from sleep, and using aesthetically functional furniture and lighting. Swiss furniture brand Vitra emphasizes the importance of a task chair with proper sitting position. Lighting designer Toh Yah Li suggests using natural light or soft, filtered artificial light. Adding plants, artwork, and colorful accents can also enhance the workspace.
