His campaign has faced criticism for its handling of the coronavirus pandemic, with Trump's job approval ratings also down. Despite this, the campaign believes the recent street protests have lifted pressure on Trump to avoid large gatherings, and plans to respect health precautions in the arena setting are yet to be detailed.

site_title: Just Eat Takeaway to buy Grubhub, forming food-delivery giant
summary: Just Eat Takeaway.com agreed to buy Grubhub Inc in an all-stock deal, creating the world's largest food delivery company outside China. The deal, valued at around $8.1 billion, would combine four of the world's largest profit pools in food delivery: the US, UK, Netherlands, and Germany. Just Eat Takeaway expects to close the deal in the first quarter of 2021, pending shareholder and regulatory approval. The combined company will be headquartered in Amsterdam, with Just Eat Takeaway CEO Jitse Groen owning a 10.29% stake in the new entity.

site_title: US lawmakers propose US$22.8b in aid to semiconductor industry
summary: US lawmakers have introduced a bipartisan bill providing over $22.8 billion in aid to semiconductor manufacturers, aiming to boost domestic production and counter China's growing influence. The proposal includes a 40% refundable income tax credit for equipment, $10 billion in federal funding to match state incentives, and $12 billion in research and development funding. The move comes amid concerns over China's strengthening domestic chip manufacturing industry and the US's reliance on Asian foundries, particularly Taiwan Semiconductor Manufacturing. The bill aims to spur the construction of chip factories in America, with some firms, including Intel and Apple, already relying on Asian manufacturers.

images.alt_text: A bipartisan group of US lawmakers on Wednesday introduced a bill to provide more than US$22.8 billion in aid for semiconductor manufacturers, aiming to spur the construction of chip factories in America amid a strategic technology rivalry with China.

site_title: Real estate investors taking 'barbell' approach to crisis
summary: Real estate investors are adopting a "barbell" approach to navigate the crisis, focusing on distressed assets such as malls and hotels hurt by the pandemic, as well as logistics facilities in demand as shopping shifts online. This strategy is driven by high unemployment and low interest rates, which may persist for a long time. Investors are also looking at better-quality properties with long-term leases and secure income streams.

site_title: Raising speech fears, Zoom briefly shuts account over Tiananmen
summary: Zoom temporarily shut down a US account of activists who met to commemorate China's Tiananmen Square crackdown, raising concerns over free speech on the video-meeting service. The group Humanitarian China used the paid Zoom account to connect over 250 people, including participants from inside China, to remember the 1989 bloodshed. The account was shut down without explanation, but was later restored. Zoom stated it complied with applicable laws, but the activists accused the company of being under pressure from China's communist leaders, potentially erasing memories of the Tiananmen Massacre.

site_title: Amazon stops police using its face-recognition tech
summary: Amazon has announced a one-year ban on police using its facial recognition technology, citing calls from critics and racial justice groups for stronger government regulations. The move follows repeated calls to stop providing police and immigration officials with tools that can be used to unfairly target people based on race. Amazon hopes the moratorium will give Congress time to implement rules and is ready to help if requested. The decision comes as Amazon's cloud computing unit faces growing scrutiny over the use of its technology.

site_title: Spike in black unemployment 'heartbreaking': Federal Reserve's Powell
summary: Federal Reserve Chair Jerome Powell expressed concern over the spike in unemployment for African Americans, stating it's "heartbreaking" and "unacceptable." Unemployment rates for black workers rose to 16.7% in April, while Hispanic workers saw a surge to 18.9%. Powell attributed the disparity to low-income service fields being disproportionately affected by the COVID-19 shutdowns. He vowed to use the Fed's tools to support maximum employment, acknowledging that societal and government responses are needed to address racial inequality.

site_title: Premier League clubs suffer £600m losses before virus outbreak: report
summary: Premier League clubs in the 2018/19 season incurred a combined £600 million loss despite record revenues of £5.15 billion, according to Vysyble analysis. This loss occurred before the financial impact of the coronavirus pandemic.

site_title: Twitter moves to limit sharing on unread articles
summary: Twitter is testing a new feature to limit the sharing of unread articles, aiming to slow the spread of unverified information. The feature, set to be tested on Android, asks users if they've read an article before retweeting it, giving them the option to open it first. The goal is to promote informed discussion and improve the health of conversations. This move follows Twitter's efforts to contain misinformation, which often spreads through users who fail to review details of the comments they share.

site_title: New York's luxury real estate slump to last for months
summary: New York's luxury real estate market is experiencing a slump due to the COVID-19 pandemic, with the number of luxury residential listings plummeting. The shutdown led to buyers and sellers waiting for the city to reopen, missing the spring sales season. As a result, luxury sales are expected to be slow this summer, with some listings already being delayed until the fall. The oversupply of luxury properties could suppress prices, with experts predicting a possible bounceback in the fall. Discounts of up to 10% are being seen in some luxury sales, but prices are expected to rebound in the long term.

images.alt_text: A slow summer sales season could depress prices. If that slow season is followed by a flood of inventory, prices could fall even further.

site_title: George Floyd's brother implores US Congress to act on police reform
summary: George Floyd's brother, Philonise Floyd, appeared before the US Congress, pleading for lawmakers to pass police reform legislation to reduce brutality and systemic racism. Floyd, still grieving the loss of his brother, who was killed by police in Minneapolis, demanded accountability and action to "stop the pain." Lawmakers united in expressions of sorrow, with some Republicans expressing support for reforms, while others opposed them. The proposed legislation includes measures to ban choke holds, require anti-racism training, and restrict qualified immunity. Floyd's family and lawmakers emphasized the need for comprehensive solutions to address police brutality.

images.alt_text: The brother of George Floyd, whose killing by police sparked worldwide protests against racism, made an emotional plea to the US Congress on Wednesday to "stop the pain" and pass reforms that reduce police brutality.

site_title: Developer forecasts big overhang for office sector if work-from-home spreads
summary: A leading property developer in central Europe, Futureal Group, warns of a significant overhang for the office sector if work-from-home policies continue. With 30% less desk space needed, the market may struggle. However, residential homes are expected to see a boost, with Futureal focusing on apartment development. The company predicts that prices for prime office space will be more resilient, but the shift towards home office work poses a longer-term risk to commercial real estate.

site_title: Federal Reserve warns of uncertain path for post-pandemic US economy
summary: The US Federal Reserve has projected a solid rebound for the US economy in 2021, with growth of 5% and a rate of 3.5% in 2022. However, Fed Chair Jerome Powell warned that the path of the economy is highly uncertain and that both the central bank and Congress may need to take additional steps to boost the recovery. The Fed will keep the benchmark interest rate at zero until the recovery is underway, and will continue to use its tools to ensure households and businesses have access to credit.

site_title: Europe: Shares end turbulent day lower as Federal Reserve nerves kick in
summary: European stocks ended a turbulent day lower, down 0.4% as investors awaited the US Federal Reserve's economic projections. Travel and leisure stocks declined, with Just Eat Takeaway plummeting 13.3% after an all-stock deal with Grubhub. The Fed's projections are expected to show a collapse in US output and near-zero interest rates, potentially spooking investors. Despite a broad recovery in recent weeks, caution is warranted, with investors moving quickly to price in good news.

site_title: Layoffs at Emirates continue for second day: sources
summary: Emirates continued its layoffs, with hundreds of pilots and cabin crew members being let go for the second day, amid the ongoing impact of the coronavirus pandemic. The airline had previously announced that it would take up to four years to resume flights to all 157 destinations. The redundancies are part of the airline's efforts to address a cash crunch.

site_title: Condo, HDB rental volumes may have bottomed out in May
summary: Private apartment and HDB flat rentals in Singapore may have reached a bottom in May, with volumes decreasing by 45.7% and 45.1% respectively from a year ago. Rents for private flats fell 1.4% in May, while HDB rents dropped 1.3%. Market observers expect rents to continue weakening, with leasing demand potentially dropping 2-4% this year due to economic headwinds and travel restrictions.

site_title: Money FM podcast: How boards are and should be gearing up for recovery
summary: Singaporean boards are gearing up for recovery from the economic aftermath, according to a recent Money FM podcast. Consultant Stephen Langton advises boards to focus on long-term strategic planning, rather than just reacting to short-term market fluctuations. He emphasizes the importance of effective leadership, diversity, and diversity in navigating uncertainty. Langton also suggests that companies should reassess their executive chairman roles and consider appointing a more independent board chair. By adopting these strategies, Singaporean companies can improve their resilience and competitiveness in the face of economic challenges.

site_title: Oil edges higher, even as US inventory rise revives glut worries
summary: Oil prices rebounded from earlier losses, rising 55 cents to $41.73 a barrel for Brent crude and 66 cents to $39.60 for US West Texas Intermediate. US crude inventories rose to a record high of 538.1 million barrels, reviving concerns of a persistent glut due to weak demand. Despite this, product demand rose, and the US Energy Department purchased 126,000 barrels of crude for the US strategic reserve. Analysts expect the market support to subside as the pandemic cuts demand and the equities market becomes overcooked.

site_title: Blossoming interests
summary: A growing interest in unusual plants and blooms in Singapore has led to an increase in business for online plant stores, despite nurseries closing due to circuit breaker measures. Horticulturist John Lim showcases his unique garden, featuring miniature watermelons, rainbow-colored corn, and black and white sunflowers. Meanwhile, tech startup Chope's founder-CEO, Arrif Ziaudeen, shares lessons on how technology and adaptability can help the F&B industry recover from the pandemic.

site_title: US firm Capria invests in Singapore venture debt outfit Genesis
summary: US-based global impact investment firm Capria Ventures has invested in Genesis Alternative Ventures Fund 1, a Singapore-based private venture debt fund, marking Capria's first investment in South-east Asia. The investment aims to capitalize on the growing demand for venture debt in the region, with Genesis planning to make 5-6 new investments in the coming months. Capria sees opportunities in financial services, healthcare, education, and logistics, and believes venture debt provides a flexible and efficient way for start-ups to raise capital. The investment is significant, but the exact amount was not disclosed.

site_title: Stability, resilience the bedrock of Singapore's future success
summary: Singapore's Prime Minister Lee Hsien Loong emphasized the importance of stability and resilience in the city-state's future success. Despite the challenges posed by the Covid-19 pandemic, Singapore secured S$13 billion in foreign investment and maintained strong foreign currency flows. The country's consistent ratings as the most politically-stable country in Asia and its pro-business attitude have attracted investors. Singapore's swift and comprehensive policy response to the pandemic has been praised, and the government is prioritizing policies to develop workers' capabilities, invest in digitalization, and resilient infrastructure to ensure a strong economy and community recovery.

site_title: That was beautiful, whatever it was
summary: A pianist's recital at Carnegie Hall, featuring 13 contrasting works spanning three centuries, was disrupted when the performer, Yuja Wang, altered the order of the pieces without explanation. The audience was confused, with some members complaining they felt manipulated. This experience led the author to question whether classical concerts are overly explanatory and proscriptive. A critic, Corinna da Fonseca-Wollheim, has created a series called "Beginner's Ear" that aims to present music without prior explanations, encouraging listeners to experience the music with an open mind.

site_title: Court dismisses SBI Offshore ex-CEO's claims of reputational loss against PwC
summary: A Singapore High Court judge dismissed a former SBI Offshore executive's claim that PricewaterhouseCoopers (PwC) caused him reputational loss due to its special audit of transactions. David Tan Woo Thian, the former CEO, alleged PwC acted negligently in its investigation and report, but the judge found his claims unsupported and speculative. PwC's report correctly identified discrepancies in the transactions and raised concerns about breaches of Chinese and Singaporean laws. The judge rejected Tan's "conspiracy" theory and dismissed his claims, with the case set to be heard on costs later this month.

site_title: Wing Tai Properties warns of H1 loss
summary: Wing Tai Properties, a Hong Kong associate of Singapore-listed Wing Tai Holdings, has guided for a first-half consolidated loss due to potential "adverse changes" in the fair value of its investment properties and financial instruments. The company reported a consolidated profit of HK$245.4 million in the year-ago period, citing the COVID-19 fallout and weakening economy as factors affecting its business. The group's overall financial positions remain healthy, and its consolidated first-half results are expected to be published in August.

site_title: IPC Corp says 2 of its directors being probed over Hyflux saga
summary: IPC Corp confirms that two of its independent directors, Teo Kiang Kok and Lee Joo Hai, are under investigation over Hyflux's Tuaspring project, which involves potential lapses in disclosures and accounting irregularities. The investigation is unrelated to IPC's business and operations, which will continue as normal. Both directors are deemed capable of fulfilling their duties professionally.

site_title: China's factory deflation deepens in May amid slow recovery
summary: China's factory deflation deepened to 3.7% in May, the lowest in almost four years, and consumer price gains slowed to 2.4%, missing forecasts. Demand remains weak, despite government efforts to boost consumption and encourage exports. The producer price index (PPI) decline and falling consumer inflation may provide policymakers with more space to implement policy stimulus to offset the impact of COVID-19 on the economy.

site_title: CGS-CIMB upgrades Dairy Farm to 'hold'
summary: CGS-CIMB upgraded its rating on Dairy Farm International to 'hold' from 'reduce' and raised its target price to US$5.45 due to most markets easing out of Covid-19 lockdowns. Analyst Cezzane See forecasts a higher price-to-earnings ratio of 20 times for FY2021, citing a recovery in margins. Forecasts for the company's health and beauty earnings remain unchanged due to risks from weak Hong Kong tourism. The analyst expects a recovery of Chinese tourism to Hong Kong before re-evaluating the stock. The company's FY20 dividend yield is expected to remain intact.

site_title: Mnuchin says US recovery has begun, will gain strength in Q3, Q4
summary: US Treasury Secretary Steven Mnuchin stated that the US economy has begun to recover from the coronavirus pandemic and will "improve dramatically" in the third and fourth quarters. Incoming jobs and economic data indicate the country is well-positioned for a phased reopening. Mnuchin also mentioned the progress of federal coronavirus rescue loan programs, despite initial glitches in the Paycheck Protection Program.

site_title: Australian, NZ dollars pause near highs as economies reopen
summary: The Australian and New Zealand dollars paused near their highs on Wednesday as economies reopened, driven by successful containment of the coronavirus. The Aussie dollar consolidated at US$0.6966, while the kiwi dollar steadied at US$0.6521. Consumer confidence in Australia rebounded to pre-lockdown levels, with spending on payment cards and furniture/electronics increasing. The Reserve Bank of Australia aims to keep three-year yields at 0.25%, and markets await the US Federal Reserve policy meeting.

site_title: The challenge of keeping offshore drilling secure
summary: The oil and gas industry faces significant cybersecurity challenges due to its complex systems and isolated nature. Hackers have successfully launched attacks on offshore drilling rigs, including a 2012 attack on Saudi Aramco that disabled 35,000 computers. The industry's fragmented approach, with multiple external contractors using different systems and protocols, introduces multiple vulnerabilities. To address this, rig contractors can use a single, vendor-agnostic security platform to integrate with different systems and gain visibility of potential threats. This approach can help automate the detection and flagging of anomalies, ultimately securing offshore infrastructure against malicious cyber activity.

images.alt_text: One of the biggest issues around offshore technology is its fragmented nature. Assets and infrastructure often use multiple different systems provided by different external contractors.

site_title: China Everbright Water cancels notes issue
summary: China Everbright Water has cancelled a proposed 1.2 billion yuan (S$235.5 million) first tranche issuance of medium-term notes due to "recent volatile conditions" in the Chinese bond market. The move aims to control financing costs.

site_title: Spanish property price growth hits 5-year low in Q1
summary: Spanish property prices grew at their lowest rate for five years during the first quarter of 2020, increasing by 3.2% compared to the same period in 2019. However, this growth was largely driven by new-build properties, which rose 6.1% year-on-year. In contrast, second-hand property prices rose only 2.7% year-on-year, the smallest increase since 2015. The coronavirus outbreak dampened demand for second-hand properties, but institutional buyers remained active in the new-build market. The slowdown is expected to continue in 2020.

site_title: China's air passenger decline slows in May as economy reopens
summary: China's air passenger traffic declined 52.6% in May from a year earlier to 25.83 million, with the pace of decline slowing from the previous month. The decline is attributed to the coronavirus pandemic, although the industry is showing a gradual recovery. This marks a slowdown in the decline, indicating the industry is on track for a recovery.

site_title: Chip Eng Seng to acquire S$25m industrial building at Tuas
summary: Chip Eng Seng's subsidiary CESP acquired the remaining unexpired leasehold estate in a Tuas industrial building for S$25 million, part of a diversification plan amid the Covid-19 fallout.

site_title: More home buyers sign on dotted line in May, drawn by discounts, low rates, affordability
summary: Singapore private home sales surged 74.7% in May, with 484 units sold, driven by discounts and low interest rates. Most sales (90%) were in the mass market segment, with prices ranging from S$1 million to S$2 million. The number of luxury home sales declined in May, with only 41 units sold in the core central region, compared to 102 in April. Developers launched 12 projects in 2020, with some offering discounts ranging from 1% to 10% off pre-pandemic prices. The rebound in sales suggests buyers are taking a long-term approach to property investment during the pandemic.

site_title: No 'significant impact' from Covid-19 on Melbourne project, says World Class Global
summary: World Class Global, a property developer, reported that the COVID-19 pandemic has not significantly impacted its residential development in Melbourne, Australia. Settlement rates for its Australia 108 development remain largely in line with previous stages, and construction has not been delayed due to the pandemic. The development is expected to contribute positively to the company's revenue and profitability in the 2020 financial year.

site_title: How tech firms should spur innovation without their founder
summary: A sudden, unforeseen change in leadership can dramatically impact a tech firm's innovation, with research showing a 43.8% decline in citation-weighted patent count following a founder's departure. This decline occurs even if R&D spending remains stable, attributed to a new management structure and philosophy. To mitigate this, companies should establish a structured plan, implement specific systems and cultures for innovation, and reduce employee fear of penalty for project failure. Additionally, firms should encourage entrepreneurship among regular employees, outline succession plans, and protect the CEO's lifestyle to prevent high-risk activities that could impact the company's interests.

site_title: Acrylic table shields go up at Thomson Plaza food court
summary: ComfortDelGro's advertising arm Moove Media is sponsoring acrylic shields for dining tables at Thomson Plaza food court in Singapore to provide a safe dining experience during Phase Two of the nation's reopening. The shields, made of 3mm clear acrylic, can be customized to fit different table shapes and are easy to clean and maintain. The trial, which began in Phase Two, will see 50 tables installed with shields, with the goal of expanding the initiative to other food courts if well-received by diners.

site_title: Uncertainties will cap oil price rise as economies reopen
summary: Oil prices have surged nearly doubling to above $40/barrel since hitting a multi-decade low in April, driven by supply cuts and quicker-than-expected demand recovery as economies reopen. The Opec+ coalition has implemented the largest coordinated production cut in history, 9.7 million barrels/day, to combat demand destruction from Covid-19. However, high stock levels, potential shut-in production, and uncertainty around demand recovery may cap the upside, and a monitoring committee will meet monthly to adjust the deal. Demand recovery is expected to continue, with Asia showing signs of returning demand, but a possible second wave of infections poses a risk to the market.

site_title: International funding can prevent emerging market meltdown
summary: The International Monetary Fund (IMF) estimates that emerging markets need $2.5 trillion in financing to mitigate the economic fallout of the COVID-19 pandemic. However, the IMF can only lend $1 trillion, and other countries lack access to capital markets. To address this, the IMF and other organizations are exploring alternatives, such as borrowing and lending funds, or establishing a special-purpose vehicle (SPV) to issue bonds that can be purchased by leading central banks. This could help prevent a developing-world depression and mitigate the economic impact of the pandemic on tens of millions of people.

site_title: 167 Singapore fintechs, financial institutions tap government digitalisation support
summary: 167 Singapore fintech firms and financial institutions have signed up for digitalisation grants worth S$125 million, two months after the government rolled out the support package. The grants cover up to 90% of fees for courses accredited by the Institute of Banking and Finance, benefiting close to 4,700 industry professionals. The move aims to enhance the fintech industry's digital capabilities and competitiveness in the region.

site_title: Oil down as rising US inventories reawaken supply anxiety
summary: Oil prices fell on Wednesday, with Brent crude futures dropping 1.6% to $40.51 a barrel and West Texas Intermediate futures falling 2.1% to $38.14 a barrel. The decline was driven by rising US crude inventories, which rose 8.4 million barrels, exceeding analyst expectations. The US labor market also showed signs of weakness, with layoffs falling in April but hiring hitting a record low. The news revived concerns about oversupply and falling fuel demand amid the coronavirus outbreak.

site_title: Corporate digest
summary: World Class Global, a property developer, reports that the COVID-19 pandemic has not significantly impacted the settlement rates of its residential development in Australia, with credit remaining generally available. Construction has not been delayed due to the pandemic, which is classified as an essential service in Australia. The development is expected to contribute positively to the group's revenue and profitability in FY2020. In contrast, Clearbridge Health's indirect subsidiary, PT Tirta Medika Jaya, has commenced legal proceedings against three former directors over alleged breaches of director's duties.

site_title: Britain goes record two months without coal power
summary: Britain has reached a record 60 days without burning coal for power, with the fuel's share of the power generation mix dropping from 40% to 2.5% in 2019. The UK's reliance on coal has slumped amid increased renewables and reduced demand due to the coronavirus lockdowns. The government has also announced plans to phase out coal from the energy system by October 2024, earlier than initially planned. This move is seen as a significant step towards reducing the UK's reliance on fossil fuels and becoming a world leader in phasing out coal.

site_title: US$ hits 3-month lows amid Fed easing speculation
summary: The US dollar hit a three-month low amid speculation that the Federal Reserve would ease monetary policy to curb rising bond yields. The move is driven by concerns about the Fed's intentions to hold down yields. This comes as China's GDP growth is expected to slow, putting pressure on policymakers.

site_title: Creating the Singapore advantage in Industry 4.0
summary: Singapore aims to create a domestic innovation hub for startups and entrepreneurs by investing in a National Digital Infrastructure, which would provide a competitive advantage in Industry 4.0. The proposed network would enable real-time data sharing, inter-organisational collaboration, and leveraging data as a means of communication. This would foster a cohesive and optimised ecosystem, allowing manufacturers to thrive in Singapore despite rising global competition. The initiative would also support startups focused on deep tech companies, providing access to vast data vaults and real-time data streams.

images.alt_text: Ensuring that manufacturing remains a key pillar of the economy in the future requires enhancing the strength of the sector against a growing regional and global competitive market.

site_title: Natural gas heads for record drop in global demand
summary: Global natural gas demand is expected to slump by 4% this year, the largest drop since the 2008 financial crisis, due to the Covid-19 crisis. The International Energy Agency (IEA) forecasts a 1.5% annual rise in demand to 2025, down from a previous forecast of 1.8%. The crisis will have a lasting impact on the industry, dampening growth rates and increasing uncertainties. Mature markets like Europe and North America will recover next year, while growth will come from fast-growing Asian markets.

site_title: Cathay Pacific ends lower after initial surge on HK$39b rescue plan
summary: Cathay Pacific Airways Ltd shares ended lower on Wednesday, despite a 19% surge in pre-market trading on its HK$39 billion government-backed rescue plan. The airline's shares fell 1.02% to HK$8.72, as Credit Suisse and Daiwa Securities downgraded the stock to "sell" citing concerns over dilution of minority shareholders. The plan eases liquidity concerns but the recovery outlook remains "dim" and monthly cash burn is likely to remain high.

site_title: Singapore shares trade sideways as markets await Fed meeting
summary: Singapore's Straits Times Index (STI) ended with a 0.23% gain at 2,800.57 points, mirroring regional peers' range-bound trading ahead of the Federal Reserve meeting. Japan's Nikkei 225 rose 0.15%, while South Korea's Kospi increased 0.31% and Australia's S&P/ASX 200 edged up 0.06%. However, Hong Kong and China's markets dipped lower. Investors await the Fed's decision on policy settings, with analysts questioning if it will provide fresh reasons for stocks to continue their climb.

site_title: Behind IRs' shutdowns, teams work feverishly to prepare for reopening
summary: Singapore's integrated resorts, Marina Bay Sands (MBS) and Resorts World Sentosa (RWS), remain closed due to the Covid-19 pandemic. MBS and RWS staff are busy redesigning business models and preparing for reopening. Task forces have been set up to generate fresh ideas, including designing masks and rewriting buffet experiences. The IRs will remain closed for Phase 1, expected to last until the end of June, but will reopen with new safeguards and experiences in place. Staff are undergoing online training and sanitization measures to ensure a high level of cleanliness and hygiene.

site_title: US consumer prices post third straight monthly drop
summary: US consumer prices fell 0.1% in May for a third straight month, the largest decline since December 2008, amid a recession caused by the Covid-19 pandemic. The core CPI, excluding volatile food and energy components, also dropped 0.1% in May, the first time it has fallen for three consecutive months. Underlying inflation remained weak, with the core CPI rising 1.2% in the 12 months through May, the smallest gain since March 2011.

site_title: Pandemic lockdowns pull the plug on relocations, but firms see pent-up demand
summary: Relocation businesses in Singapore have seen a record decline in demand due to the COVID-19 pandemic, with a 30-95% drop in activity in the first half of 2020. However, with countries easing lockdowns and reopening, some companies are seeing signs of recovery, particularly with the return of expatriates and the easing of border curbs. Despite the challenges, businesses are hopeful that the third quarter will bring some semblance of recovery, and some are adapting by outsourcing services and focusing on digital solutions.

site_title: Indonesia's rich pawning McLaren, Rolls-Royce as cash crunch hits home
summary: Wealthy Indonesians are pawning luxury items such as cars, watches, and jewelry due to the economic impact of the Covid-19 pandemic. As the government eases social restrictions, businesses face cash shortfalls and uncertain road to recovery. Indonesia's pawn business is being digitalized with online apps linking pawnbrokers to customers, in response to the economic downturn. The digitalization aims to provide a more accessible and convenient service for customers.

site_title: Deutsche Bank combines wealth management and international retail ops
summary: Deutsche Bank has combined its international retail and wealth management operations into a single division, dubbed the international private bank, with revenues of around 3 billion euros. The move aims to streamline operations and cut 18,000 jobs globally. Claudio de Sanctis, current head of global wealth management, will oversee the combined business. The restructuring is part of the bank's broader efforts to reduce costs and improve efficiency.

site_title: Scrutiny of audit work on Hyflux important to credibility of disclosure-based regime
summary: The Accounting and Corporate Regulatory Authority (Acra) is inspecting the audit work of KPMG for Hyflux, a Singapore-based water treatment firm, amid concerns over its bankruptcy in May 2018. KPMG signed off on Hyflux's financial statements just two months before its bankruptcy, raising questions about its audit work, particularly on Hyflux's subsidiaries that failed to submit their annual returns. Acra is scrutinizing KPMG's approach to valuing assets held for sale and its assessment of Hyflux's going concern status, which may have contributed to the company's insolvency. The investigation aims to ensure the credibility of Singapore's disclosure-based regime.

site_title: 5,500 migrant workers from 40 dorms in Singapore approved to resume work
summary: The Singapore government has approved 5,500 migrant workers from 40 dormitories to resume work, following the completion of necessary Covid-19 infection clearance. This brings the total number of cleared workers to 40,000, who can return to work pending approval. The workers will receive a "Green" AccessCode on their SGWorkpass app, indicating they are Covid-free and their employer has been granted approval to resume operations. The Ministry of Manpower outlines a three-step process for workers to return to work, including arranging staggered pick-up and drop-off timings and downloading the FWMOMCare app to record temperatures and symptoms.

site_title: Japanese lawmakers pass record Covid-19 budget
summary: Japan's lower house of parliament approved a record-breaking emergency budget of nearly $300 billion to stimulate the economy after Covid-19 tipped the country into recession. The budget includes subsidies for smaller businesses, cash handouts for medical workers, and loans for struggling businesses. The total measures, including loans and investments, amount to 40% of Japan's GDP and push the debt-to-GDP ratio to 257%. The government aims to drive the recovery, with economists predicting a 3-point increase in real 2020 GDP.

images.alt_text: Mr Abe lifted Japan's emergency declaration last month but said that it would take 'quite a long time' for the country to fully return to normal.

site_title: Repeat test of 6 infected students, staff for Covid-19 finds all negative: MOH
summary: The Ministry of Health (MOH) reported that six students and staff infected with Covid-19 have all recovered after a repeat test found them negative. The cases, from various schools, displayed mild symptoms and had low viral loads. Five have been discharged from hospital, while the sixth remains in hospital due to administrative issues. This update comes alongside 451 new cases, including 444 migrant workers in dorms and seven community cases, bringing Singapore's total to 38,965 cases and 26,523 recoveries.

site_title: US court asked to force Facebook to release Myanmar officials' data for genocide case
summary: A US court has been asked to force Facebook to release data of Myanmar officials' posts and communications related to the alleged genocide of Rohingya Muslims. The International Court of Justice, or World Court, has agreed to hear a case against Myanmar, with The Gambia backing a group of Muslim countries. Hundreds of thousands of Rohingya have fled a crackdown in Myanmar, with rights groups documenting killings and village burning. Facebook is being requested to release data of military and police officials, including commander-in-chief Min Aung Hlaing, amid allegations of spreading hate speech.

site_title: Just Eat Takeaway in advanced talks to buy Grubhub
summary: Just Eat Takeaway.com is in advanced talks to acquire Grubhub in an all-stock deal, creating the world's largest food delivery company by revenue. The deal, valued at approximately $4.30 billion, would surpass China's Meituan, the current largest global food delivery company. Experts say consolidation is long overdue in the US food delivery space, where demand is surging due to the COVID-19 pandemic. A potential Uber-Grubhub merger, which Uber is now exiting, had raised antitrust concerns, but a Just Eat Takeaway-Grubhub deal is expected to receive easy approval.

site_title: Ford to return to pre-Covid production rates in US plants by July 6: COO
summary: Ford Motor plans to resume US vehicle assembly plant production at pre-COVID rates by July 6, according to Chief Operating Officer Jim Farley. The company, along with other Detroit automakers, resumed production on May 18. This move comes as the US auto industry continues to recover from the pandemic shutdown.

site_title: Man City to learn fate on European ban in July
summary: Manchester City will learn the outcome of their appeal against a two-season ban from European competition in mid-July. The ban was handed down by UEFA for allegedly overstating sponsorship revenue to hide non-compliance with financial fair play rules between 2012 and 2016. A three-day hearing was held via video conference due to coronavirus restrictions, with both parties expressing satisfaction with the procedure. The verdict will be announced before the end of the delayed Premier League season, which is set to restart on June 17.

site_title: OECD warns global economic risks will continue
summary: The Organization for Economic Cooperation and Development (OECD) warns that the global economy will remain on a tightrope until a Covid-19 vaccine becomes widely available. Two scenarios are presented: a "single hit" outcome with a 6% contraction in 2020 and 5.2% growth in 2021, and a "double-hit" scenario with a 7.6% decline in 2020 and 2.8% growth in 2021. The OECD predicts dire and long-lasting consequences for people, firms, and governments, with unemployment expected to more than double to 11.5% by mid-2020.

site_title: IPC Corp says two of its directors being probed over Hyflux saga
summary: IPC Corp confirmed two of its independent directors, Teo Kiang Kok and Lee Joo Hai, are under investigation over Hyflux's Tuaspring project. The probe focuses on potential lapses in disclosures and possible accounting irregularities. The investigation is unrelated to IPC Corp's business, and its operations will continue normally.

site_title: Starbucks sees US$3.2b virus hit, plans new cafe format
summary: Starbucks expects a US$3.2 billion sales hit from the coronavirus pandemic, with operating income declining by up to US$2.2 billion this quarter. The company plans to accelerate its "pickup" store concept, with smaller-format locations, and expects to open 300 net new stores in the Americas this fiscal year. Despite this, Starbucks expects an adjusted loss of 55-70 cents per share and sees a recovery stretching into next year. The company's shares fell 4% on the news, with comparable sales down 43% in May in the US.

site_title: Britain asks too much of EU in Brexit talks, Barnier says
summary: Britain is seeking a trading relationship with the EU that is too similar to an EU member state, according to Michel Barnier, the EU's Brexit negotiator. This is despite the EU's concerns about the economic consequences of looser ties, which Britain left the EU on January 31 after 47 years. Barnier urged London to adjust its demands in the four months left to reach a deal, citing that Britain is demanding more than other countries like Canada and Japan in trade agreements.

site_title: France lifts pandemic response to 136b euros
summary: France has raised its coronavirus response measures to nearly 136 billion euros, accounting for 5.6% of its gross domestic product. This is the third budget revision for the year, with the government initially estimating the cost at 110 billion euros. The total mobilization is 460 billion euros, or 20% of GDP, with various financing guarantees extended to companies and European Union institutions.

site_title: Maybank sued for 'thwarting' luxury New York condo project
summary: Maybank, Malaysia's largest bank, was sued by Sharif El-Gamal, developer of a 43-story luxury condo building in Manhattan, for allegedly reneging on construction loans worth over $162 million. The lawsuit claims Maybank's actions effectively thwarted the project, causing "irreparable damage" to the contractor. El-Gamal is seeking over $245 million in damages, which he claims is the projected net sell-out value of the property. Maybank declined to comment on the lawsuit.

site_title: US mall operator Simon Property abandons US$3.6b acquisition of Taubman
summary: Simon Property Group, the largest US mall operator, is abandoning its $3.6 billion acquisition of Taubman Centers due to the impact of the Covid-19 pandemic on the retail sector. The pandemic disproportionately hurt Taubman's malls in densely populated areas with high-end retailers whose sales have shrunk. The deal, announced in February, will not be renegotiated, and shares of both companies have dropped significantly following the announcement.

site_title: China-Asean trade strengthens amid lockdowns and icy US relations
summary: China's trade focus is shifting towards Southeast Asia, with bilateral trade between China and ASEAN countries accounting for 14.7% of China's total trade volume in the first five months of 2020. This marks a significant increase, surpassing traditional trading partners the US and EU. The rise in China-ASEAN trade is attributed to China's strained relationship with the US, with some companies relocating to Asia to avoid punitive tariffs. Vietnam has seen the largest increase in trade with China, driven by technology products and lower logistics costs.

site_title: Airbnb ordered to repay apartment owner over sublets
summary: A French court ordered Airbnb to compensate an apartment owner nearly €52,000 for renting her Paris flat without permission and to pay €5,000 in legal fees. Airbnb was also required to repay €1,558 in commissions. The court deemed Airbnb a publisher due to its role in linking hosts and travelers, and held the platform responsible for the owner's harm. Airbnb plans to appeal, arguing the case concerns a private dispute. The ruling is seen as a significant decision, bringing financial responsibilities to bear on Airbnb for abuses committed on its platform.

site_title: Nato chief says on Huawei: UK review of 5G security is important
summary: Nato Secretary General Jens Stoltenberg emphasized the importance of a UK review of Huawei's role in Britain's 5G network to ensure security, amid China's increasing presence in the West. Stoltenberg noted China's growing influence in the Arctic, cyberspace, and critical infrastructure. China's foreign ministry spokesperson denied posing a threat to any country, but Stoltenberg urged the UK to design networks that protect them. This review comes as Britain reassesses relations with China following the COVID-19 outbreak and disagreements over Hong Kong.

site_title: From app to portable token: Singapore's contact tracing journey
summary: Singapore launched its contact tracing app, TraceTogether, in March 2020, drawing inspiration from a 2014 US high school project that won an international prize. The app, developed by Rohan Suri and his Stanford University teammates, was initially met with no backing but was later adopted by the Singapore government. The app's success has sparked a global rush to develop similar contact tracing apps, with several governments investing millions of dollars. However, privacy concerns remain a hurdle, and alternative solutions, such as wearable devices, are being explored.

site_title: Goldman traders gain US$1b in commodities revenue after oil slump
summary: Goldman Sachs' commodities unit generated over $1 billion in revenue through May, primarily driven by oil trading. The gains came after oil prices plummeted to historic lows in March, with US crude futures briefly falling into negative territory. The collapse was attributed to a selloff triggered by the US government's bearish stance on tariffs, which led to a surge in oil prices. Other commodities, such as natural gas, power, and precious metals, also contributed to the revenue.

site_title: Natural gas heads for record drop in global demand
summary: Global natural gas demand is expected to drop by 4% this year, the largest-ever decline, due to the coronavirus crisis. The International Energy Agency (IEA) forecasts a 1.5% annual increase in demand to 2025, down from a previous forecast of 1.8%. The crisis will have a lasting impact on the industry, dampening growth rates and increasing uncertainties, with mature markets like Europe and North America expected to recoup losses next year.

site_title: Hong Kong voters go to the polls on Sept 6
summary: Hong Kong voters will head to the polls on September 6 to choose their parliament, amidst a tumultuous period marked by economic recession and a political crisis. The government has set the nomination period from July 18 to July 31, and the current Legislative Council will end its sessions on the same day. A recent High Court ruling upheld a ban on individuals with jail terms of three months or more from running for public office for five years, including League of Social Democrats chairman Raphael Wong. The election comes amid concerns over the national security law passed by Beijing, which may impact the outcome.

site_title: China punishes microblog platform Weibo for interfering with communication
summary: China's Cyberspace Administration ordered Sina Weibo to disable some features for a week after finding it interfered with online communication and disseminated illegal information. Weibo was reprimanded for a case involving a person with the surname Jiang, although details are unclear. The punishment comes after Weibo temporarily censored content in 2018 and follows a senior Alibaba executive's demotion for a relationship with a social media influencer. Weibo did not immediately comment on the punishment, which will last for a week and includes a fine from the Beijing branch.

site_title: Tata Consultancy Services to launch digital acceleration centre in Singapore
summary: Tata Consultancy Services (TCS) plans to launch a digital acceleration centre in Singapore with support from the Economic Development Board (EDB). The centre aims to help local businesses recover from the Covid-19 pandemic by upskilling and reskilling the workforce. It will offer 100 traineeships for polytechnic and university graduates, focusing on key areas of cutting-edge technology such as cloud adoption and cybersecurity. The centre will also provide specialized skill enhancements for trainees who secure jobs at TCS. The initiative is part of TCS' efforts to support Singapore's Smart Nation ambitions.

site_title: Chip Eng Seng to acquire industrial building at Tuas
summary: Chip Eng Seng's subsidiary CESP has acquired the remaining unexpired leasehold estate in an industrial building in Tuas for a deposit of S$1 million and an option fee. The purchase price is expected to be paid in full upon completion. This acquisition comes as Singapore's construction sector is forecasted to contract by 10.3% in real terms this year due to the COVID-19 outbreak. The deal has no direct or indirect interest from Chip Eng Seng's directors or controlling shareholders.

site_title: Fintech startup Wallex raises Series A funding from BAce Capital, SMDV, Skystar
summary: Singapore-based fintech startup Wallex has raised Series A funding from BAce Capital, SMDV, and Skystar Capital. The funding, led by BAce Capital, will be used to expand into new markets and invest in core products. Wallex aims to offer services such as virtual receivable accounts and multi-currency wallets to small and medium-sized enterprises (SMEs). The startup has regulatory licenses in Singapore, Indonesia, and Hong Kong, and plans to continue hiring and partnerships to further expand its business.

site_title: US consumer prices post third straight monthly drop
summary: US consumer prices fell 0.1% in May, marking the third straight monthly drop, as demand remained subdued amid the Covid-19 pandemic. The core CPI, excluding food and energy, also dropped 0.1% in May, the first time it has declined for three consecutive months. The 12-month year-on-year gain for the core CPI was the smallest since March 2011, at 1.2%. The decline is attributed to reduced data collection due to the pandemic, leading to an increase in temporarily unavailable prices.

site_title: UK regulator gets more time for final ruling on Amazon's Deliveroo deal
summary: Britain's Competition and Markets Authority (CMA) has given itself two more months to rule on Amazon's purchase of a minority stake in online delivery group Deliveroo. The CMA launched a detailed investigation in December, citing concerns that the deal could damage competition by discouraging Amazon from re-entering the online restaurant food market. Amazon led a $575 million fundraising in Deliveroo in May last year. The CMA will take full account of representations from all interested parties before making a final ruling.

site_title: Japan MPs pass record coronavirus budget
summary: Japan's lower house of parliament approved a record-breaking emergency budget of nearly $300 billion to combat the economic impact of the coronavirus pandemic, which has tipped the country into recession. The budget, worth 31.91 trillion yen, includes subsidies for smaller businesses and cash handouts for medical workers. The move is expected to push the country's debt-to-GDP ratio up to 257% and drive the recovery, with economists predicting a 3-point increase in real 2020 GDP.

site_title: US banks prepare branches for gradual post-coronavirus re-opening
summary: US banks are preparing for the gradual reopening of their branches after the COVID-19 pandemic by installing acrylic barriers, stocking up on masks and sanitizers, and enhancing cleaning protocols. Major banks such as Bank of America, Capital One, and JPMorgan Chase are taking measures to prevent the spread of the virus, including providing masks to customers and employees. The banks faced supply chain challenges at the outset of the crisis but have since secured a steady supply of necessary materials. This is part of the country's gradual reopening efforts.

site_title: Malaysia resumes travel, haircuts and retail therapy as coronavirus curbs ease
summary: Malaysia has eased coronavirus restrictions, reopening hair salons, shopping malls, and allowing interstate travel. The country reported its lowest number of new cases in nearly three months, with 2 confirmed infections. Despite the easing of restrictions, international borders and entertainment venues remain closed. Schools are set to reopen in stages starting June 24, and travel agreements may be sought with "green bubble" countries. The easing of restrictions aims to revive Malaysia's economy, which was hard hit by the pandemic.

images.alt_text: Hair salons and shopping malls reopened, traffic jams returned and interstate travel resumed in Malaysia on Wednesday in a further easing of coronavirus restrictions to revive an economy hard hit by the pandemic.

site_title: Hong Kong: Stocks end slightly down
summary: Hong Kong stocks ended the day marginally lower, snapping a seven-day winning streak, as investors became cautious about global economic re-openings. The Hang Seng Index decreased 7.49 points to 25,049.73, while the Shanghai Composite Index dipped 0.42%.

site_title: Remdesivir approved for Covid-19 treatment in Singapore
summary: Singapore has granted conditional approval for the use of remdesivir, an antiviral drug, to treat seriously ill COVID-19 patients. The approval, granted in under three weeks, allows infectious diseases specialists to administer the drug to patients with low oxygen saturation levels or those requiring supplemental oxygen. Remdesivir is the only treatment shown to benefit COVID-19 patients in a robust clinical trial, with Singapore participating in both the US National Institute of Allergy and Infectious Diseases trial and a Gilead trial.

site_title: Singapore replaces US as India's top market for engineering exports
summary: Singapore surpassed the US as India's top market for engineering exports in April, with a 95% increase in exports to US$553 million. This surge in exports comes despite a 63.9% decline in total engineering exports to US$2.31 billion. Engineering exports to China rose 19% to US$173 million. India's engineering exports, which account for nearly a quarter of total goods exports, continue to face challenges due to the coronavirus lockdowns and weak global demand.

site_title: US: Stocks open mixed, Nasdaq up above 10,000 points
summary: The US stock market opened mixed on Wednesday, with the Nasdaq Composite Index reaching an all-time high of 10,009.95, while the Dow Jones Industrial Average slipped 0.2% to 27,230.61. The S&P 500 gained 0.1% to 3,210.79. Despite US-China trade tensions, investors are optimistic, with the Singapore Stock Exchange Index up 0.4% and Airalo raising $220 million in funding. A Federal Reserve policy announcement is expected later in the day, which may impact market sentiment.

site_title: Shares close marginally higher on Wednesday
summary: Malaysia's FTSE Bursa Malaysia Kuala Lumpur Composite Index rose 0.11 points to 1,575.27 on Wednesday, with 626 gainers outnumbering 411 losers. The index closed marginally higher after a day of trading.

site_title: Wing Tai Properties expects H1 loss
summary: Wing Tai Properties, a Hong Kong associate of Singapore-listed Wing Tai Holdings, expects a first-half consolidated loss due to an "adverse change" in the fair value of its investment properties and financial instruments. The loss is attributed to the Covid-19 fallout and weakening economy, but the group's overall financial position remains healthy. The consolidated first-half results are expected to be published in August.

site_title: South Korea acts to stop defectors sending aid, messages to North Korea
summary: South Korea plans to take legal action against two organizations that send propaganda and contraband to North Korea through defectors. The move comes after North Korea suspended communication hotlines with South Korea over the issue. Defectors in South Korea have been sending materials such as anti-North leaflets and rice into the North, prompting North Korean media to denounce them as "mongrel dogs." This led to a warning from Kim Yo Jong, the sister of North Korean leader Kim Jong Un, that South Korea's failure to stop the defectors would result in severed communication ties.

site_title: China's new bank loans fall in May, but broader credit growth quickens
summary: China's new bank loans fell to 1.48 trillion yuan in May, down from 1.70 trillion yuan in April, according to the People's Bank of China. This was higher than the 1.18 trillion yuan in the same month last year. Despite the decline, broader credit growth quickened as the central bank eases policy to stimulate the economy. Analysts had predicted a fall to 1.50 trillion yuan. The data suggests the central bank's efforts to boost the economy are having some effect, but may need further stimulus to achieve desired growth.

site_title: Daily Debrief: What Happened Today
summary: New private home sales in Singapore rebounded sharply in May, increasing 74.7% to 484 units, driven by stay-home buyers. The country replaced the US as India's top market for engineering exports, with exports rising 95% to US$553 million. Remdesivir was approved for COVID-19 treatment in Singapore, and the STI ended the day with a 0.23% gain. Meanwhile, 167 fintech firms and financial institutions signed up for digitalisation grants, and a former SBI Offshore executive had his claims against PwC dismissed by the High Court.

site_title: OECD sees deepest peace-time slump in a century
summary: The OECD has forecast the global economy to contract 6% this year due to the coronavirus pandemic, with a possible 7.6% contraction if a second wave occurs. The economy is expected to bounce back with 5.2% growth in 2021, but the US and euro area could face more severe downturns, with the US potentially contracting 7.3% this year and the euro area facing a 9.1% decline. Britain is expected to experience the worst downturn, with an 11.5% contraction this year.

site_title: Zara owner Inditex books first quarterly loss as lockdowns shut stores
summary: Inditex, the owner of Zara, reported its first quarterly loss due to the coronavirus crisis, with a net loss of 409 million euros. The company shut almost 90% of its stores in the three months from February to April, resulting in a 34% decline in sales at constant currencies. Despite this, online sales surged 95% in April. Inditex expects stores in key markets to open by the end of June and plans to invest 900 million euros annually for three years to focus on larger stores and online business.

site_title: Adidas pledges to hire more black and Latino staff
summary: German sportswear brand Adidas has pledged to invest US$20 million in the black community in the US, aiming to fill at least 30% of new US jobs with black and Latino staff. The company recognizes the black community's contribution to its success but admits it must do more to fight racism and improve company culture. This move follows Adidas' long history of partnering with prominent black athletes and celebrities, and its influence in hip-hop culture since the 1980s. The goal is to increase equity, diversity, and opportunity within the company.

site_title: Credit Suisse CEO sees things 'going in right direction'
summary: Credit Suisse CEO Thomas Gottstein expressed optimism about the bank's business conditions, citing improving trends after a tough start to the year. He noted that stress in the system eased in April and remains robust in May and June. Despite expecting bad economic data for Q2 in Europe and the US, Gottstein remains optimistic due to high client engagement in corporate and investment banking.

site_title: New private home sales rebound sharply in May, up 75% over April: OrangeTee & Tie
summary: New private home sales in Singapore rebounded sharply in May, with 484 units sold, a 74.7% increase from 277 units in April. This surge was driven by stay-home buyers seeking affordable homes despite the "circuit breaker" period and economic uncertainty. Executive condominiums also saw a 73.7% increase in sales. Despite the challenges, buyers remained optimistic, with Christine Sun, OrangeTee & Tie's head of research and consultancy, attributing the rebound to their desire for a dream home.

site_title: Brussels suggests EU open external borders from July 1
summary: The European Commission recommends EU member states to reopen their external borders to travellers from outside the bloc from July 1, suggesting a gradual and partial lifting of the ban. This decision comes as EU countries have started easing temporary restrictions on non-essential border crossings within the bloc, with a goal of restoring free travel by June 15. The move aims to ease travel restrictions while continuing to monitor the spread of the coronavirus.

site_title: Singapore fintechs, financial institutions tap govt support to digitally pivot, keep hiring
summary: Singapore's fintech industry has seen significant government support, with 167 firms signing up for a S$125 million digitalisation grants package. The grants cover up to 90% of fees for industry training, benefiting 4,700 professionals. The Monetary Authority of Singapore has allocated S$90 million for workforce training and S$35 million for digitalisation efforts. This move aims to support the industry's digital pivot and hiring amid the COVID-19 pandemic.

site_title: Australia: Shares end at 3-month high on rebound hopes; Fed in focus
summary: Australian shares ended at a three-month high, reaching 6,148.4, driven by a survey showing consumer sentiment rising for a second straight month. The country is on track to largely eradicate the coronavirus virus by July, with public health officials expressing optimism. However, gains were capped as investors await clarity on the US economy and stimulus measures from the Federal Reserve's meeting. Gold stocks surged 2% and tech stocks gained 3.1%, while shares of Harvey Norman Holdings jumped 7.3% on a special dividend announcement.

site_title: Repeat test of 6 infected students, staff for Covid-19 finds all negative, have recovered: MOH
summary: The Ministry of Health (MOH) in Singapore announced that six infected students and staff, who tested positive for Covid-19 on June 7, have all recovered and been discharged from hospital. The patients, who displayed mild symptoms, tested negative in a repeat test using new samples. This brings the total number of fully recovered patients to 26,523, accounting for 68% of the Covid-19 patients in Singapore.

site_title: STI up 0.23% as markets await FOMC meeting
summary: The Straits Times Index (STI) rose 0.23% to 2,800.57 points on Wednesday, following regional peers' range-bound trading ahead of the Federal Reserve meeting. Investors are cautious due to uncertainty, but the market is showing resilience. The best performers included United Overseas Bank, while Jardine C&C and Sembcorp Marine were among the worst performers.

site_title: Bank of Singapore hires RBS strategist as chief economist
summary: Bank of Singapore has appointed Mansoor Mohi-uddin as its chief economist, pending regulatory approval. Mohi-uddin, a former macro strategist at NatWest Markets and global head of FX strategy at UBS Investment Bank, will develop strategic views and research analysis on macroeconomic and financial environments. He will report to Jean Chia, head of portfolio management and research office, and sit on the bank's investment committee to shape asset allocation calls for clients. This move aims to enhance the bank's economic outlook and research capabilities amid market uncertainties.

site_title: Tokyo: Shares end almost flat just below 3-month high as rally loses steam
summary: Japanese shares closed nearly flat on Wednesday, ending just below a three-month high, as investors took a cautious approach amid stretched valuations and concerns about the market outlook. The Nikkei rose 0.15% to 23,124.95, while the Topix lost 0.23% to 1,624.71. Growth shares, including Takara Bio and Shin-Etsu Chemical, outperformed, while value shares underperformed.

site_title: Thailand should join Asia-Pacific trade pact talks, business group says
summary: Thailand's business group recommends joining Asia-Pacific trade pact talks in August to learn about the Comprehensive and Progressive Agreement for Trans-Pacific Partnership (CPTPP) before deciding on membership. The process of seeking membership is expected to take at least four years, and Thailand can withdraw at any stage if found unbeneficial. The commerce ministry believes membership will boost Thailand's economy, offsetting the impact of the coronavirus outbreak.

images.alt_text: Thailand should seek to participate in Asia-Pacific trade agreement negotiations in August before deciding on membership in the pact, a group of leading business associations in Thailand said on Wednesday.

site_title: Job loss: Bouncing back after 55 (Covid-19 Mental Health video series)
summary: A video series by BT offers tips for older workers over 55 who have lost their jobs due to the coronavirus crisis. Psychologist Maria Micha advises focusing on practical and emotional strategies to re-enter the workforce. Practically, workers should repackage their strengths and experience, and utilize government initiatives and free online courses for retraining. Emotionally, maintaining hope and managing anxiety and depression is crucial for creativity. By adopting these strategies, older workers can bounce back and find new employment opportunities.

site_title: SoftBank's chip technology company Arm says China JV replaces CEO
summary: Arm Ltd, a chip technology company owned by SoftBank Group, has replaced the CEO of its China joint venture, Arm China. The majority of directors voted to remove Allen Wu, who will be succeeded by co-CEOs Ken Phua and Phil Tang. The move comes as Western semiconductor companies navigate the US-China trade war, with Arm complying with US rules limiting sales to Huawei. Arm continues to supply technology to Huawei's HiSilicon unit, which is a significant source of revenue for the company. The company remains committed to its progress and vision operating as an independent company.

site_title: Federer to miss rest of tennis season after second knee op
summary: Roger Federer will miss the rest of the 2020 tennis season after undergoing a second knee procedure due to a setback during his initial rehabilitation. The 20-time Grand Slam singles champion had already undergone surgery on his right knee in February. Federer plans to take the necessary time to be 100% ready to play at his highest level and will miss his fans and the tour, but looks forward to returning in 2021.

site_title: Fintech startup Split raises seed funding from 500 Startups
summary: Split, a Singapore and Malaysia-based fintech startup, has raised an undisclosed round of seed funding led by 500 Startups and joined by other angel investors, including AccorHotels Asia Pacific's deputy CEO Louise Daley. Founded in 2018, Split provides a buy-now-pay-later solution with no interest, late fees, or charges, partnering with 70 retail outlets and businesses like Switch, Urban Republic, and Straits Wine Company. The funding is seen as a response to the economic uncertainty brought by COVID-19, with Split's co-founder stating that the service makes purchases affordable for consumers.

site_title: UBS commits to hiring 300 more in Singapore over 18 months
summary: UBS, Asia's largest wealth manager, has committed to hiring 300 new jobs in Singapore over 18 months, with an aim to tap into the government's Job Support Scheme. This addition will represent 10% of its existing workforce in the country. The bank has also set up the Singapore UBS Program for Employability and Resilience (SUPER), a program to develop "sustainable skills" for graduates and mid-career individuals, aiming to create a pipeline of financial talent and support job-seekers in the challenging job market.

site_title: NUHS, startup Bot MD launch bot that monitors Covid-19 patients in worker dorms
summary: Singapore's National University Health System (NUHS) and startup Bot MD have launched a bot, SGDormBot, to monitor Covid-19 patients in worker dorms. The multilingual platform, accessible through WhatsApp, has seen over 90% of Covid-19 patients in NUHS-managed dormitories use it to log their vital signs daily. Nearly 500 alerts have been triggered, with nearly 100 teleconsultations held, and 20 residents identified for medical reviews. The bot aims to address healthcare and manpower constraints, as well as social and cultural issues, in densely-packed dormitories.

site_title: Taiwan lifts short-selling ban early
summary: Taiwan has lifted its short-selling ban on stocks earlier than planned, citing the stabilization of its equity markets and the well-control of the coronavirus situation. The ban, which was initially set to expire on June 19, was lifted on June 10. The move is seen as a positive step for the country's financial markets, which had been affected by the coronavirus outbreak.

site_title: Tokyo: Stocks open lower on profit-taking, stronger yen
summary: Tokyo stocks opened lower on Wednesday, with the Nikkei 225 index down 0.59% and the Topix index down 0.80%. Investors took profits after a series of gains, while a stronger yen against the dollar also weighed on the market.

images.alt_text: Tokyo stocks opened lower on Wednesday, as investors continued to lock in profits after a lengthy series of gains while a firmer yen against the dollar also weighed on the market.

site_title: Europe: Banks lead stocks higher ahead of Fed's economic view
summary: European shares rose 0.8% on Wednesday, led by banks, ahead of the US Federal Reserve's economic projection. Eurozone banks gained 2.5% as the European Central Bank prepares to cope with unpaid loans due to the coronavirus crisis. Investors also moved into growth-sensitive stocks like oil firms, despite Zara owner Inditex booking its first ever loss. The Fed's remarks on the economy's health will be closely watched, with investors expecting no major policy announcements.

images.alt_text: European shares rose on Wednesday, with banks leading the gains as investors awaited the US Federal Reserve's first economic projection since the Covid-19 pandemic set off a recession in February.

site_title: Japan April core machinery orders fall 12.0% m-o-m
summary: Japan's core machinery orders fell 12.0% in April from the previous month, exceeding economists' median estimate of an 8.6% drop. This decline compares to a 17.7% drop from the same period last year. The data is considered a volatile indicator of capital spending in the coming six to nine months.

site_title: Japan wants to take lead for G-7 statement on Hong Kong: Abe
summary: Japan's Prime Minister Shinzo Abe stated that the country wants to lead the G-7 in issuing a statement on the situation in Hong Kong, where China has imposed a new security law. Japan had already released a statement on May 28 expressing serious concern and called in the Chinese ambassador. Abe emphasized Japan's commitment to the "one nation, two systems" principle in Hong Kong, and the country is seeking to take a lead in shaping the global public opinion on the matter.

site_title: ComfortDelGro unit to trial acrylic shields on foodcourt tables in Thomson Plaza
summary: ComfortDelGro's advertising arm Moove Media is sponsoring acrylic shields on dining tables in Thomson Plaza foodcourt in Singapore as part of a month-long trial to minimize Covid-19 spread. The shields, made of 3mm-thin clear acrylic, are easy to clean and maintain, and customizable to fit different table shapes and sizes. The trial is part of Singapore's reopening phase two, which is set to begin soon.

site_title: Asia: Most markets rise, focus turns to Federal Reserve meeting
summary: Asian markets rose, fueled by hopes for an economic rebound from the coronavirus crisis. Despite a record number of new global cases, European nations eased lockdown measures, with Cyprus welcoming tourists and France reopening the Eiffel Tower. The S&P 500 and Nasdaq edged to fresh records in the US, while the STI gained 0.4% on Thursday, despite tariff uncertainty and split Federal Reserve views.

site_title: Hong Kong: Stocks open higher on Wednesday
summary: Hong Kong stocks rose 0.49% on Wednesday, extending their advance for an eighth day, driven by optimism over the global economy's reopening. The Hang Seng Index reached 25,179.03, while China's Shanghai Composite Index eased 0.16%. The rally was unaffected by US President Trump's recent threats, with traders focusing on positive market sentiment and potential trade talks between the US and EU.

site_title: Hong Kong police arrest 53 during fresh pro-democracy protests
summary: Hong Kong police arrested 53 people during protests on Tuesday, marking a year of pro-democracy rallies in the former British colony. The arrests came amid heightened tensions over a proposed national security bill, with protesters fearing it will stifle freedoms. The bill's details have yet to be revealed, but authorities in Beijing and Hong Kong have downplayed concerns. Pro-democracy supporters plan further protests, citing the need to prevent the bill's passage.

site_title: Honda cyberattack halts plants in India, Brazil, Turkey
summary: Honda's plants in Turkey, Brazil, and India have halted operations due to a cyberattack affecting 11 global factories, including five in the US. The attack targeted Honda's internal servers and spread a virus through its systems. All US plants have resumed operations, with the suspension expected to have a limited impact on the company's business globally. The cyberattack comes as Honda faces a slump in sales due to the new coronavirus pandemic, with the company reporting a 25.3% fall in net profit last month.

site_title: High Court dismisses SBI Offshore ex-CEO's claims against PwC
summary: A High Court judge dismissed claims by former SBI Offshore CEO David Tan Woo Thian against PwC, stating that the accounting firm did not cause him reputational loss in its special audit of transactions. The audit was conducted in July 2016 to review SBI's acquisition and disposal of shares in a Chinese entity. The decision marks a conclusion to the former CEO's claims, although the article does not provide further details on the reasoning behind the dismissal.

site_title: Malaysia: Shares open higher on Wednesday
summary: Malaysia's FTSE Bursa Malaysia Kuala Lumpur Composite Index rose 1.25 points, or 0.08%, to 1,576.41 on Wednesday, with 108.31 million lots traded worth RM46.88 million. Gainers outpaced losers 219 to 66.

site_title: Broker's take: CGS-CIMB upgrades Dairy Farm to 'hold' as main markets ease Covid-19 lockdowns
summary: Brokerage firm CGS-CIMB upgraded Dairy Farm International to 'hold' from 'reduce' and raised its target price to US$5.45 due to easing Covid-19 lockdowns in main markets. Analyst Cezzane See forecasts a higher price-to-earnings ratio for FY21 and expects investors to 'await the recovery' as negatives have been priced in. Dairy Farm's health and beauty earnings forecasts remain unchanged, citing medium-term risks from weak Hong Kong tourist visitation. The stock is expected to maintain its FY20 dividend.

site_title: Seoul: Shares extend gains on recovery hopes; Fed in focus
summary: South Korean shares rose for the ninth consecutive session, with the KOSPI index gaining 6.77 points or 0.31% to 2,195.69, its highest close since February 19. The Korean won strengthened to its highest close in over three months, and the benchmark bond yield rose. Investors are awaiting the US Federal Reserve's economic projections and policy decision, which may impact the market's cautious stance. Despite the economic downturn caused by the coronavirus, shares of LG Chem rose 1.73% after signing a conditional contract to sell its LCD polariser business for $1.1 billion.

site_title: Airlines improvise gradual liftoff as lockdowns ease
summary: Airlines have adjusted to the post-pandemic travel landscape by adopting "flexibility" in their operations, with Lufthansa revealing it has developed new procedures in flight and route planning. The German airline had to adjust its schedule due to lockdowns, resulting in a 90% drop in passenger connections. Now, cabin crews are on standby with destinations revealed only hours before flights, and pilots use simulators to stay up-to-date. This is a far cry from the pre-pandemic era of clockwork precision.

site_title: Nintendo says 300,000 accounts breached after hack
summary: Nintendo has confirmed that 300,000 of its accounts were breached in a hack since early April, with hackers gaining access to birthdays and email addresses but not credit-card details. The initial breach in April compromised 160,000 accounts, with an additional 140,000 breaches discovered since then. Nintendo apologized for the incident and pledged to enhance security measures to prevent future breaches. The company assured that fraudulent purchases from affected accounts were minimal and vowed to reimburse victims.

site_title: Cathay Pacific plans to repay Hong Kong government over 3 to 5 years
summary: Cathay Pacific Airways plans to repay the Hong Kong government over 3 to 5 years for HK$19.5 billion (S$3.5 billion) of preference shares as part of a US$5 billion recapitalisation package. The package includes a HK$11.7 billion rights issue and aims to halve the airline's gearing levels, restoring access to equity and debt markets. The airline's share price may come under pressure due to potential 43% dilution. The Hong Kong government could gain a 6% stake in Cathay via convertible warrants.

site_title: Australian, New Zealand dollars pause near highs, economies re-open
summary: The Australian and New Zealand dollars consolidated near their recent highs, with the Aussie dollar at US$0.6966 and the kiwi dollar at US$0.6521. The currencies paused after their rallies ran out of steam, but the progress in opening their domestic economies supported sentiment. The Aussie dollar is still near its 11-month top and faces resistance at US$0.7082, while the kiwi dollar has support around US$0.6470.

site_title: Chinese firms may halt use of tankers that have transported Venezuelan oil: sources
summary: Chinese oil companies may stop chartering tankers that have visited Venezuela in the past year, citing US sanctions that could disrupt operations. The US plans to add dozens of tankers to a blacklist, aiming to choke Venezuelan oil exports and starve the socialist government of revenue. Existing sanctions have cut exports sharply, but President Maduro has held on. This move could further exacerbate the global oil market and impact China's energy operations.

site_title: Federal Reserve to consider how long to stay at zero rates at meeting
summary: US Federal Reserve policy makers will consider keeping interest rates near zero for this year and next to aid the economy's recovery from the coronavirus-induced recession. The Federal Open Market Committee is expected to keep the benchmark overnight rate in a target range of zero to 0.25% when it concludes its two-day meeting. Despite better-than-expected May unemployment data, the Fed is unlikely to signal it is exiting emergency policies to keep credit flowing, citing a slow road back to normal. The committee will release its quarterly forecasts and rate projections alongside a statement.

site_title: Who killed the Swedish PM? Suspense as probe nears end
summary: Swedish prosecutors will announce on Wednesday whether they are pressing charges or closing the investigation into the 1986 murder of Prime Minister Olof Palme. Over 10,000 people have been questioned, but no one is currently under formal suspicion. The case files span 250m of shelf space, and experts suggest the case may be closed due to the main suspects being deceased. The investigation has been botched in the past, with police failing to properly secure the crime scene, and a key suspect was convicted and later freed due to a technicality.

images.alt_text: In a highly anticipated announcement, Swedish prosecutors will reveal on Wednesday whether they are pressing charges or closing the investigation into the unsolved 1986 murder of prime minister Olof Palme.

site_title: Cathay Pacific shares soar more than 18% after bailout
summary: Cathay Pacific shares surged over 18% on Wednesday after the airline announced a major government bailout to survive the coronavirus crisis. The Hong Kong government pledged HK$39 billion (S$6.94 billion) to support the airline, including a six-per-cent share stake and two board members.
