The bulk of the capital will come from new shares issued to Aviation 2020 and a bridging loan. The airline will raise HK$11.7 billion in a rights issue and sell preference shares and warrants to the government.

images.alt_text: Cathay Pacific shares soared more than 18 per cent at the open on Wednesday morning, a day after the airline announced a major government bailout to survive the coronavirus crisis.

site_title: China's May PPI -3.7% y-o-y, CPI +2.4%
summary: China's May producer price index (PPI) fell 3.7% from a year earlier, the sharpest annual decline in over four years, as the COVID-19 pandemic continues to impact global demand. China's consumer price index (CPI) rose 2.4% from a year earlier. The country's exports contracted in May, while imports fell deeper, indicating mounting pressure on its manufacturing sector. Official surveys also showed deep contractions in export orders, underscoring persistent downward pressures on growth.

site_title: Commonwealth Bank of Australia hit with insurance class action
summary: A class action lawsuit was filed against Commonwealth Bank of Australia over the sale of worthless credit card and personal loan insurance products to customers. Slater and Gordon law firm claims customers were charged for worthless products, and the bank has not been served with legal proceedings. This lawsuit follows similar actions against Australia's three other major banks, with settlements and class actions already reached. The bank has not commented on the allegations, but will consider any claims once the lawsuit is received.

site_title: Singapore shares advance at Wednesday's open; STI up 0.5%
summary: Singapore's Straits Times Index (STI) rose 0.5% to 2,809.15 on Wednesday, rebounding from a decline on Tuesday. Gainers outnumbered losers 81 to 39, with DBS and OCBC banks gaining due to their mortgage offerings. The US Federal Reserve began its two-day meeting, causing mixed equities on Wall Street. Japan's Topix fell 0.6%, while South Korea's Kospi declined 0.3%.

site_title: Australia consumer sentiment rebounds to pre-pandemic levels: survey
summary: Australia's consumer sentiment index rose 6.3% in June, recovering to pre-pandemic levels, according to a survey by the Melbourne Institute and Westpac Bank. The index is now 7% lower than in June 2019, but optimism remains despite pessimists outnumbering optimists. The recovery is attributed to Australia's success in controlling the coronavirus and easing social restrictions. Consumer confidence in the economy over the next 12 months and 5 years also showed significant gains, with respondents expressing confidence in job security and a good time to buy major household items.

images.alt_text: A measure of Australian consumer sentiment rose for a second straight month in June to recover all of the historic loss suffered during the peak of the coronavirus lockdowns, a promising sign for spending and the economy in general.

site_title: Chinese companies put US listing plans on ice as tensions mount
summary: Chinese companies are putting off plans for US listings amid rising tensions between the US and China. The proposed US legislation, which would make it harder for some Chinese firms to debut in America, and mounting scrutiny following an accounting scandal at Luckin Coffee have led to a slowdown in interest. Chinese firms have raised $1.67 billion via US IPOs this year and are looking to raise another half billion, but many are now targeting exchanges nearer to home, with some even halving their enquiries about US listings.

site_title: Premier League clubs lost £600m in season before virus, says report
summary: Premier League clubs incurred a combined loss of £600 million in the 2018/19 season, despite record revenues of £5.15 billion, due to high wage costs and an over-reliance on TV revenues. The financial impact of the coronavirus pandemic is expected to worsen the situation, with potential losses of £330 million in rebates and £126 million in matchday income. Experts attribute the financial distress to a deeper problem with the league's financial model, rather than the pandemic itself.

site_title: NGO warns pandemic to aggravate Africa's 'neglected' crises
summary: The Norwegian Refugee Council warns that the COVID-19 pandemic is exacerbating Africa's "neglected" crises, particularly in countries like Cameroon, the Democratic Republic of Congo, and Burkina Faso. Nine of the world's 10 most neglected crises are in Africa, according to the NRC's annual report. The organization's secretary general, Jan Egeland, calls for solidarity with conflict-stricken communities to prevent the pandemic from adding to their already unbearable disasters. Africa has reported 5,354 COVID-19 deaths and 197,823 confirmed cases.

site_title: UK passes 50,000 coronavirus-related deaths
summary: The UK has surpassed 50,000 coronavirus-related deaths, according to the Office for National Statistics. This milestone marks Europe's worst toll and the second-highest in the world. The government reported 50,107 deaths, with 40,883 being confirmed cases. Despite the grim figure, Business Secretary Alok Sharma stated that infection and death rates are falling, and the UK lockdown may be eased further, with non-essential shops set to reopen on June 15.

site_title: Procurri expects 'substantially weaker' performance in H1 2020
summary: Procurri Corporation expects a "substantially weaker" performance in the first half of 2020 due to the COVID-19 pandemic and a failed sale of its third-party maintenance business to Park Place Technologies. The company had previously announced the cancellation of the transaction in January, citing challenges in finding a suitable deal structure. The expected weaker performance is attributed to these factors.

site_title: IMF approves US$5b in aid to Ukraine: statement
summary: The International Monetary Fund (IMF) has approved a US$5 billion aid package for Ukraine, with an immediate release of US$2.1 billion. The 18-month program aims to help Ukraine cope with the COVID-19 pandemic challenges. The agreement was reached in principle on May 21 and received approval from the IMF's board of directors. The aid package will support Ukraine's economic recovery and financial stability.

site_title: TikTok's Mayer pledges fake news fight in call with EU's Breton
summary: TikTok's new CEO Kevin Mayer has pledged to actively fight disinformation on the platform, according to an EU official. In a call with EU digital chief Thierry Breton, Mayer committed to addressing issues related to illegal and harmful content, including disinformation. Breton invited TikTok to join the European Union's code of conduct, which includes Google, Facebook, Twitter, and Mozilla, to combat fake news. Mayer also promised to act responsibly and take additional steps in the fight against disinformation.

site_title: Houston bids farewell to George Floyd in hometown funeral
summary: Houston held a farewell ceremony for George Floyd, a 46-year-old African American who died after being restrained by a Minneapolis police officer, sparking global protests against police brutality and racism. The ceremony, attended by politicians, civil rights activists, and celebrities, included a eulogy by Reverend Al Sharpton and a message from Democratic presidential candidate Joe Biden, who called for racial justice in America. Floyd's death has galvanized a worldwide movement, with the Minneapolis authorities pledging to dismantle and rebuild the police department and four officers involved in his arrest facing charges.

site_title: Europe demands better pandemic plan, as Moscow exits lockdown
summary: Europe's top leaders, including French President Emmanuel Macron and German Chancellor Angela Merkel, urged the European Union to develop a common approach to future pandemics after the continent's chaotic response to the coronavirus. Europe has been hit hard, with nearly 185,000 deaths, and critics say a lack of coordination led to shortages of medical equipment. Meanwhile, Moscow lifted its lockdown despite a surging epidemic, and other countries, including Cyprus and France, began to reopen their borders. The World Health Organization warned of the dangers of complacency as new cases continue to rise globally.

site_title: New coronavirus may have emerged in summer 2019: study
summary: A preliminary study by researchers at Boston University and Harvard suggests the new coronavirus may have emerged in Wuhan, China in August 2019, prior to the initial reported cases in December 2019. The study analyzed satellite images and internet searches related to Covid-19 symptoms in Wuhan, detecting a surge in hospital visits and searches for diarrhea in August 2019. The findings support the hypothesis that the virus emerged naturally in southern China and was potentially already circulating at the time of the Wuhan cluster.

site_title: China Everbright Water cancels proposed 1.2b yuan notes issue on 'volatile' market conditions
summary: China Everbright Water has cancelled a proposed 1.2 billion yuan (S$235.5 million) first tranche issuance of medium-term notes due to "volatile" market conditions. The move aims to control financing costs. The company had announced plans to issue the notes in June, with a five-year maturity and AAA rating. Shares of China Everbright Water finished Tuesday at S$0.23, down 4.2%. The company will continue to monitor market conditions and proceed with the notes issuance "according to the market environment in the future".

site_title: US: Nasdaq closes at new record high but S&P, Dow lower
summary: US stocks closed mixed on Tuesday, with the Nasdaq reaching a new record high of 9,953.75, while the Dow Jones Industrial Average fell 1.1% and the S&P 500 retreated 0.8%. Analysts attributed the losses to profit taking and the upcoming earning season, despite the Federal Reserve's monetary policy remaining unchanged. The tech-rich Nasdaq's gains were driven by its second straight daily record, but the overall US economy remains dire due to the coronavirus pandemic.

site_title: Researchers see risks in online vote system approved for 3 US states
summary: A US online voting system, OmniBallot, approved in Delaware, West Virginia, and New Jersey, is vulnerable to hacking and may compromise ballot secrecy, according to researchers from MIT and University of Michigan. The platform, used primarily for voters with disabilities and overseas military voters, lacks adequate security measures, allowing attackers to alter election results without detection. The researchers urge voters to avoid using OmniBallot and instead use mail-in ballots or print and mail a blank ballot.

site_title: Will DBS' fixed-rate mortgage move be enough to keep its lead?
summary: DBS, Singapore's largest mortgage player, is introducing fixed-rate home loans to counter the uncertain economic climate, where customers are seeking stability. The bank's fixed-rate mortgages start at 1.5% per annum for two- to five-year lock-in periods, making them attractive to borrowers. Analysts say this move could keep DBS at the top of the mortgage market, but the competition remains fierce, with other banks already revising their fixed-rate offers. The bank's head of secured lending notes that the current Sibor-linked offers are still attractive, but the risk of volatility makes fixed rates more appealing to risk-averse borrowers.

site_title: Europe: Stocks hit as cyclicals reverse gains
summary: European stocks declined 1.2% as investors turned cautious ahead of the US Federal Reserve's policy meeting. Banks, led by eurozone banks, fell 3.8% after an EU financial stability watchdog advised against dividend payments until the end of the year. Oil majors also dropped, with Royal Dutch Shell, BP, and Total falling between 3% and 4.5%. Investors await the Fed's views on economic recovery, with some expecting a cautious approach.

images.alt_text: Banks and oil companies led European stocks lower on Tuesday as investors turned wary ahead of the US Federal Reserve's policy meeting.

site_title: BTS fans raise US$1m for Black Lives Matter movement
summary: BTS fans have raised over $1 million for Black Lives Matter, the Movement for Black Lives, and other civil rights organizations, following the death of George Floyd. The fundraising effort, led by fan group One in an Army, began on June 1 and accelerated after Variety reported BTS' $1 million donation. The group encouraged fans to educate themselves on anti-black racism and to vote in local elections. BTS itself stood in solidarity, saying "we will stand together" against racial discrimination, following similar advocacy from K-pop fans worldwide.

site_title: Healthcare sector investing is on the cusp of change
summary: The healthcare sector is poised for change as it navigates the COVID-19 pandemic. Despite facing headwinds, the sector has proven resilient, with the US healthcare sector outperforming the market in recent months. However, healthcare providers have been significantly impacted by social distancing measures. Companies with potential treatments for COVID-19 have outperformed, while those with uncertain clinical trial timelines have underperformed. Long-term fundamentals, including an aging population and rising wealth in developing economies, support the sector's growth. Emerging trends in medical devices, gene-editing, and precision medicine also hold promise for investors. Active management and healthcare ETFs are recommended investment strategies for navigating the complex healthcare sector.

site_title: Covid-19 magnifies challenges to business in China: European business group
summary: A European business group reported that the COVID-19 pandemic has worsened business challenges in China, citing slowing revenue growth, regulatory obstacles, and the dominance of state-owned enterprises. Only half of European companies surveyed experienced 5% or more revenue growth in mainland China in 2019, the lowest proportion in a decade. The pandemic's impact on China's economy, which shrank by 6.8% in the first quarter, remains unclear, but trends are undeniably bleak. Regulatory obstacles and the state-owned sector's influence are expected to worsen in the next five years.

images.alt_text: The Covid-19 epidemic has exacerbated already worrisome trends to doing business in China amid slowing revenue growth, regulatory obstacles and the clout of the state-owned sector, a European business group said on Wednesday.

site_title: Corporate digest
summary: Tee International appoints Ewe Tuck Foong as its new CFO, replacing Yeo Ai Mei who was ordered to leave due to unauthorized payments. AEM Holdings also announces Leong Sook Han as its new CFO, starting June 15. Meanwhile, Standard & Poor's downgraded Singtel Optus's stand-alone credit profile to "BBB" from "BBB+" due to weaker financial performance.

site_title: Stocks to watch: DBS, OCBC, Singtel, China Everbright, Challenger, Procurri
summary:
Here is a 100-word or less summary of the article content:

Several companies saw new developments that may impact trading on Wednesday. DBS is counting on its fixed-rate home loans to draw customers, while OCBC Bank has successfully transitioned its face-to-face process to online. Singtel's credit rating was downgraded, but its shares rose 1.1% after affirmation of its issuer credit rating. China Everbright Water cancelled a proposed note issuance due to volatile market conditions. Challenger and Procurri Corporation also reported negative impacts from the COVID-19 pandemic. Trading halts were called for Perennial Real Estate Holdings and Addvalue Technologies pending their respective announcements.

site_title: Pompeo criticises HSBC for backing Hong Kong law
summary: US Secretary of State Mike Pompeo criticized HSBC for backing Beijing's security law proposal in Hong Kong, warning of businesses' overreliance on China. The move has led to HSBC being considered no longer autonomous from mainland China in US law. Other British companies, including Standard Chartered, have also backed the law, despite London's official position. Pompeo's comments follow China's rubber-stamp parliament's passage of the law, which some activists say will kill Hong Kong's freedoms.

site_title: Singapore business sentiment remains downbeat for Q3: survey
summary: Singapore business sentiment remains downbeat for Q3, with the Business Optimism Index recording -5.16 percentage points, a slight improvement from the record low of -7.88 percentage points in the second quarter. The construction sector holds the bleakest outlook, while manufacturing and financial services sectors show slight improvement. Uncertainty remains due to the threat of a second wave of infections, global social unrest, and trade tensions. Despite this, SCCB chief executive Audrey Chia notes "green shoots" in certain sectors, but predicts the overall sentiment will remain dampened in the months ahead.

site_title: France earmarks 15b euros for ailing aerospace industry
summary: The French government has announced a 15 billion euro rescue plan for the struggling aerospace industry, including export guarantees and credit relief for Airbus SE and its suppliers. The aid aims to bolster the European planemaker and its suppliers, which have been severely impacted by the Covid-19 pandemic. The plan also includes loan guarantees and a moratorium on airline loan reimbursements, and is expected to support the development of less polluting planes. The move is part of a larger stimulus package worth 40 billion euros to support the French economy.

site_title: Keppel FELS denies breaches alleged by Awilco unit in bid to terminate rig order
summary: Keppel FELS has denied allegations by Awilco unit AR1 of breaches in the construction of the Nordic Winter rig, which was set to terminate the contract on June 9. The notice came a day before a US$31.9 million payment instalment was due. Keppel FELS has rejected the termination and is considering its legal options, reserving its rights under the contract, including seeking compensation for work done to date. The dispute may impact Keppel Corp's shares, which fell 1.1% on the news.

site_title: Oil rises as production curbs offset renewed demand fear
summary: Oil prices rose on Tuesday, with Brent crude increasing 38 cents to $41.18 a barrel and West Texas Intermediate crude rising 75 cents to $38.94 a barrel. The Organization of the Petroleum Exporting Countries (Opec+) agreed to extend record production cuts until the end of July, offsetting concerns about a potential resurgence in coronavirus cases. However, Saudi Arabia, Kuwait, and the UAE refused to maintain supplemental reductions, and Libya declared force majeure on some exports, supporting the market. Despite this, analysts warn that prices may pull back due to demand uncertainty and inventory overhang.

site_title: Money FM podcast: Don't sit on back pains
summary: Claressa Monteiro from Money FM 89.3's "Workday Afternoon" podcast discussed lower back pain with Dr. Diana Chan, director of Pain Medicine at Sengkang General Hospital. Dr. Chan explained that lower back pain is caused by poor posture, muscle imbalances, and lifestyle factors. She recommended exercises and stretches to alleviate pain, as well as maintaining a healthy weight and regular exercise routine. The podcast aimed to raise awareness about lower back pain and provide listeners with practical tips to prevent and manage the condition.

site_title: German exports slump in April as coronavirus wrecks demand
summary: Germany's exports and imports declined in April, posting their biggest drops since 1990, as coronavirus lockdowns led to a significant decrease in demand. Seasonally adjusted exports fell 24% and imports slid 16.5% in April. The trade surplus shrank to 3.20 billion euros, exceeding economists' expectations. The economy is facing a deep recession, with a 6.3% expected shrinkage this year, and the government has announced a 130 billion euro stimulus package to boost domestic demand.

site_title: Anniversary protests as Hong Kong democracy movement faces triple threat
summary: Hong Kong's pro-democracy movement is facing a triple threat, with anniversary protests taking place despite authorities' crackdown, coronavirus restrictions, and a looming national security law. Demonstrators marched in defiance of authorities, marking seven months since massive protests began in June 2019, which saw up to a million people take to the streets against a bill allowing extraditions to mainland China. The movement's future remains uncertain, with ongoing arrests and a deteriorating financial situation.

site_title: AI is an important ally for businesses in a crisis
summary: Artificial intelligence (AI) is playing a crucial role in helping businesses respond to the COVID-19 pandemic and future crises. By leveraging AI's speed and data-driven capabilities, companies can boost productivity, enhance human judgement, and replace manual work. To scale AI effectively, businesses must adopt a comprehensive data management framework, align AI with business goals, and design it to meet specific business needs. Companies that successfully scale AI can achieve significant returns, including a 32% premium on key financial valuation metrics and nearly three times the return on investments.

site_title: Forestry fund roots itself deeper in Asia through Singapore
summary: New Forests Asia, a forestry investment manager, has secured a capital markets services licence in Singapore, allowing it to deal in securities and units in collective investment schemes. The move strengthens its presence in the region, where it manages $4 billion in assets, including the Tropical Asia Forest Fund, which focuses on sustainable plantation forestry in Asia. The company aims to increase its share of assets from emerging markets to at least 20% by 2030 and is in talks with Asian investors to bring in more capital to drive development in the forestry sector.

site_title: Building materials firms to lead construction recovery
summary: Analysts predict building materials companies will lead the construction sector's recovery due to accelerated infrastructure spending as economies reopen. Singapore's construction sector is expected to contract 10.3% this year, but key projects such as the Mass Rapid Transit and Deep Tunnel Sewerage System will drive growth. Analysts, including Phillip Securities and CGS-CIMB, have expressed bullish views on companies like BRC Asia and Boustead Projects, citing their dominant market share and potential for growth. However, smaller contractors and those with low margins are expected to be severely impacted.

site_title: Japan, UK aiming for early trade deal, says Tokyo
summary: Japan and the UK agreed to start talks on an early trade deal, with Japan's foreign minister welcoming Britain's interest in joining the Trans-Pacific free trade pact. Britain hopes to join the pact and trade talks with Japan are seen as a step towards that end. Japan's trade minister called for the early elimination of automobile and auto parts tariffs, while adopting high-level rules on digital trade. The talks come as the EU and British negotiators made little progress in their latest round of post-Brexit trade agreement talks.

site_title: Major currencies inch lower as traders cash in gains
summary: Major currencies declined on Tuesday as investors took profits from recent gains, with the US dollar rising against commodity currencies. The Australian dollar fell nearly 2% after China's education ministry urged students to reconsider traveling to Australia due to racist incidents. The Japanese yen rose to a one-week high, while the euro fell 0.2% to US$1.1277. The decline in currency values is attributed to market expectations of the US Federal Reserve's meeting, which may lead to a pause in risk-on trading.

site_title: Explaining the pandemic performance differential
summary: A recent analysis of the COVID-19 pandemic reveals that countries with higher sustainable economic growth scores, such as South Korea, Singapore, and Norway, have largely contained the pandemic's first wave. The Growth Environment Score (GES) index, developed by Goldman Sachs, considers factors like technological adoption, educational attainment, and rule of law, which have proven critical in rolling out effective testing, tracking, and contact-tracing protocols. The strong correlation between GES and pandemic performance suggests that sustainable-growth metrics have a bearing on the quality of a country's health system, with countries prioritizing investments in digital infrastructure, education, and healthcare likely to fare better in the post-pandemic economy.

site_title: Urban plans, business practices will have to change: Lawrence Wong
summary: Singapore's Minister for National Development Lawrence Wong has emphasized the need for urban plans and business practices to change in response to Covid-19. The government will introduce measures to cushion the impact on the construction industry, while companies will need to adopt safer delivery methods and improved ventilation systems. People's behavior and mindsets will also be crucial in adapting to the virus, with a focus on maintaining good personal hygiene and safe-distancing measures. The government plans to ease travel restrictions and re-open borders through green-lane arrangements, but mass-market travel is expected to take time.

site_title: Thailand proposes taxing foreign Internet companies
summary: Thailand has approved a draft bill requiring foreign digital service providers to pay a 7% value-added tax (VAT) on sales of digital products and services in the country, starting from July. The move is expected to generate approximately 3 billion baht in annual tax revenue. The bill applies to companies earning more than 1.8 million baht per year and affects services such as music and video streaming, gaming, and hotel booking. The bill is part of a broader push by governments worldwide to tax internet companies, with nearly 140 countries negotiating tax rules for the tech industry.

site_title: Sembcorp is right to cast off its marine unit; both entities will be the better for it
summary: Sembcorp Industries has proposed funding the bulk of Sembcorp Marine's $2.1 billion recapitalisation exercise and spinning off its marine unit, marking a long-overdue move to shed a loss-making business. The deal will see SMM repay its $1.5 billion subordinated loan to SCI by converting it into equity, while SCI will be freed from the marine unit's cyclical nature and transformed into a defensive utilities and urbanisation play. The move is seen as a positive for both firms, with SMM expected to benefit from reduced debt and more cash for working capital, and SCI poised to gain investor attention with its pivot to power generation and green energy solutions.

site_title: Tale of 2 stocks: Sembcorp jumps 37% on demerger, Sembmarine dives 27%
summary: Sembcorp Industries (SCI) and Sembcorp Marine (SMM) announced a proposed demerger, with SCI's shares jumping 36.6% and SMM's shares plummeting 27.1%. Analysts expect SCI to benefit from the separation, citing a more focused strategy on energy and urban development. However, SMM's share price is expected to face short-term pressure due to a highly dilutive rights issue. Despite this, some analysts remain optimistic on SMM's prospects, citing improved gearing and potential for further restructuring.

site_title: As many as 25,000 US stores may close in 2020, mostly in malls
summary: The COVID-19 pandemic is expected to lead to 20,000-25,000 US store closures, shattering the 2019 record of 9,800. Most closures will occur in malls, with department stores and clothing shops being heavily impacted. Retailers have been forced to rewrite their business plans due to the pandemic, with 4,000 permanent store closures planned and 15 major retailers filing for bankruptcy so far this year. The closures will have a ripple effect on malls, with anchor tenants' closures leading to further store closures.

site_title: HK's rush to attract China listings comes with a big risk
summary: Hong Kong's push to attract Chinese technology listings is raising concerns about the city's ability to support the influx of investing dollars amidst ongoing political tensions. Despite recent approvals for companies like JD.com and NetEase, investors worry that the US may retaliate against Hong Kong's listings, potentially disrupting liquidity. The city's efforts to cut settlement times for listings and introduce weighted voting rights may not be enough to attract and support all the big-name companies, potentially threatening its ambitions to catch up with London and New York.

site_title: Aqua Munda prepared to make offer to Hyflux PnP holders: Sias
summary: Aqua Munda, a special purpose vehicle, is prepared to make an offer to Hyflux PnP holders, seeking to acquire the company. The Securities Investors Association (Singapore) has assured Aqua Munda will provide details of its offer and financial capability, as well as business plans for Hyflux. Sias emphasized the importance of considering the plight of PnP holders, who have "suffered enough," and urged Aqua Munda to make a sincere offer. The offer must be made soon, as Hyflux is under moratorium until July 30, or risk liquidation and PnP holders receiving nothing.

site_title: Negative interest rate debate needs clarity to be useful
summary: Negative interest rates have sparked intense debate, with some arguing they will do more harm than good and others claiming they are no different from conventional monetary policy. Critics point to operational issues such as cash hoarding and bank net interest margins, while supporters argue that monetary policy should be geared towards supporting aggregate demand and full employment. Policymakers are cautious, but the coronavirus crisis has elevated consideration of negative rates as a possible tool. The debate lacks clarity, and economists call for a better understanding of the assumptions and challenges surrounding negative interest rates.

site_title: OCBC takes complex face-to-face wealth advisory process online
summary: OCBC and Standard Chartered Singapore have seen significant growth in digital adoption rates amid the COVID-19 pandemic. OCBC's virtual wealth advisory service has seen a 45% increase in sales in the first 10 days of its launch, while StanChart's digital adoption rates have hit "historic-high levels" with a 30% year-on-year jump in digital transactions in March 2020. Both banks report a surge in online transactions, with OCBC's digital transactions growing 40% year-on-year and StanChart's seeing a 200% increase in digital investment platforms.

images.alt_text: OCBC says it has registered a broad-based increase in the take-up of digital services, from new accounts to the sale of investments.

site_title: Singapore working to facilitate seafarer crew change
summary: Singapore has been working to facilitate seafarer crew changes during the COVID-19 pandemic. The Maritime Port Authority (MPA) has approved nearly 3,000 cases of crew changes since March 27, with chartered flights also being used to transport crews. The Singapore Crew Change Working Group has developed a guidebook outlining safe protocols for crew changes, and efforts are underway to address the 150,000-200,000 seafarers trapped onboard ships worldwide, who are experiencing mental health issues and physical exhaustion.

site_title: As art world goes online, a generation gap opens
summary: The COVID-19 pandemic has significantly impacted the global art market, with international art collectors being the main customer base supporting a US$60 billion industry. The art world has struggled to adapt to the digital era, with younger collectors more receptive to online purchases, while experienced collectors remain wary due to concerns over condition and provenance. Despite efforts to persuade collectors to spend thousands online, the industry faces a serious gap in sales figures, with online-only transactions representing just 9% of the global market's estimated US$64.1 billion sales last year.

site_title: Global economy to shrink 5.2% in 2020: World Bank
summary: The World Bank has forecast a 5.2% contraction in the global economy in 2020, the worst recession in 80 years, due to the COVID-19 pandemic. The crisis is expected to leave 70-100 million people in extreme poverty, with a risk of a second wave of outbreaks undermining the recovery. The US, Eurozone, and Japan are projected to contract by 6.1%, 9.1%, and 6.1%, respectively, while China is expected to see a modest 1% growth. The report warns of a high risk of financial crises and defaults, with a potential global recession of 8% if the pandemic lingers or rebounds.

site_title: Frasers Property bags S$350m green loan for Fernvale Lane exec condo project
summary: Frasers Property has secured a S$350 million green loan from DBS Bank, Maybank, and OCBC Bank to finance its Fernvale Lane executive condominium project in Singapore. This is Singapore's first green loan for an EC development and the group's 10th green financing initiative. The project aims to obtain a BCA Green Mark Gold Plus rating and will develop 500 units. The loan is structured according to green loan principles issued in 2018, and Frasers Property has raised around S$4 billion in green financing to date.

site_title: Protesters gather to mark 'million-people' march anniversary in Hong Kong
summary: Hundreds of protesters gathered in central Hong Kong to mark the one-year anniversary of the 'million-people' march, defying a government ban and heavy riot police presence. The gathering comes amid fears of looming national security legislation, re-igniting unrest in the global financial hub.

site_title: Navigating retail in the post-Covid-19 era: Welcome to the Paranoid Economy
summary: The COVID-19 pandemic has accelerated disruptions in the retail industry, with over 190,000 stores in the US closing due to the crisis. Established chains like Neiman Marcus, J.C. Penney, and Pier 1 Imports have filed for bankruptcy. However, discounters like Walmart, Costco, and Target have successfully transitioned to an omni-channel retail model, offering online and offline services to boost store sales. To remain competitive, retailers must be innovative, committed to hygiene, and socially distant, and seamlessly integrate online and offline shopping experiences.

site_title: As businesses reopen, we should reopen our minds too
summary: As businesses reopen, the world looks unfamiliar due to prolonged closures and new measures such as masks and social distancing. These measures may be here to stay unless a vaccine is discovered. The article highlights various economic and market trends, including dollar asset diversification, a low-profile property trust's data centre gambit, and the potential for retail investors to drive massive ETF growth in Asia and Europe. Productivity gains are key to unlocking wealth creation, and markets continue to rise despite ongoing trade tensions and de-dollarisation.

site_title: Business leaders urge Britain to use UN's sustainable goals in Covid-19 recovery plan
summary: UK business leaders urge Prime Minister Boris Johnson to embed the UN's Sustainable Development Goals (SDGs) in the country's Covid-19 recovery plan. The letter, signed by leaders like Natwest's Alison Rose and Schroders' Peter Harrison, emphasizes the importance of prioritizing health, wellbeing, and the environment alongside economic growth. They propose "coherent policies" based on the SDGs to support a low-carbon economy and address societal risks. The aim is to ensure a recovery plan leaves no one behind and prioritizes the health and wellbeing of current and future generations.

site_title: Honda halts output at some plants after cyber attack
summary: Honda has halted production at some of its factories worldwide due to a cyber-attack, affecting car and motorcycle plants in the US, Turkey, India, and South America. The disruption, which began on Monday, has been contained to internal networks and there's no indication of an information breach. Honda's Japanese operations remain unaffected, and the company is working to fix systems. The attack comes amid a rise in cyber-attacks during the coronavirus pandemic, with other industries, such as ship builders and government agencies, also experiencing disruptions.

site_title: Xiaomi-backed trading app Tiger Trade launches SGX trading
summary: Tiger Trade, a mobile and online trading application backed by Xiaomi, has launched access to the Singapore Exchange (SGX). This move comes amid an increase in trading volumes among Singapore-based retail investors during the Covid-19 pandemic. The app now offers commission rates starting from US$1.99 or S$2.80 per trade, with a promotional rate of 0.08% per trade for Singapore stocks until December 31, 2020. The launch aims to strengthen Tiger Trade's offerings for its customers, who can now invest in various financial instruments, including A-shares and futures.

site_title: TSMC secures US govt subsidies and picks site for US$12b Arizona plant
summary: Taiwan Semiconductor Manufacturing Co (TSMC) has secured US government subsidies for its $12 billion chip plant in Arizona, aiming to address national security concerns and shift high-tech manufacturing to the US. The company has picked a site for the plant and federal and state governments have agreed to help offset the higher cost of fabricating semiconductors in the US. TSMC, the main chipmaker to Apple and Huawei, will create American jobs and produce sensitive components domestically for national security reasons, with negotiations ongoing over the specifics of the incentives.

site_title: Singapore developers start to dangle discounts to move units
summary: Singapore developers are offering small discounts to move units, with concessions ranging from S$3,000 for a one-bedroom unit to S$100,000 for a terrace house. The discounts are a result of the COVID-19 pandemic, which has led to a significant decline in new private home sales, plummeting 58% in April to 277 units. Despite the economic downturn, developers remain cautious, with many having previously avoided offering discounts due to confidence in their projects' sales.

site_title: US-China tensions: Trump shouldn't add Hong Kong into the fight
summary: US President Donald Trump is considering new measures to punish China for tightening control over Hong Kong, amid rising tensions between the two nations. The Trump administration has already suspended entry to the US for Chinese scientists deemed a risk to national security and scrutinized Chinese companies listed on US markets. However, some proposed actions, such as imposing tariffs on Hong Kong imports, could harm the city's economy and backfire on its residents. The move is seen as a strategy to divert attention from the administration's pandemic response and economic downturn, and may play into the hands of Chinese nationalists.

site_title: Citi partners YMCA to support vulnerable groups in Singapore
summary: Citi Singapore has partnered with the YMCA to distribute over 45,000 meals and grocery packs to vulnerable communities, including seniors, migrant workers, and those with special needs, as part of the Covid-19-related community relief efforts. The initiative, supported by a grant of S$210,000, aims to provide food and groceries to those in need. The partnership is part of Citi's 15th Global Community Day and demonstrates the bank's commitment to serving the local community and making a difference in times of need.

site_title: Germany earmarks 500m euros for electric car charging: sources
summary: Germany plans to allocate 500 million euros from its stimulus package to support the expansion of electric vehicle charging stations, aiming to install 1 million public spots by 2030. This move addresses consumer concerns and utility company criticisms. Additionally, the ministry plans to spend an extra 1.5 billion euros on supporting domestic battery cell production, more than doubling existing funds. The remaining 500 million euros will be allocated for research and development.

site_title: HK government to lead HK$39b rescue package for Cathay Pacific
summary: Cathay Pacific Airways Ltd has secured a HK$39 billion rescue package from the Hong Kong government, led by a HK$19.5 billion preference share sale and a HK$1.95 billion warrant sale. The airline will also propose a rights issue to raise an additional HK$11.7 billion. The government will own 6.08% of Cathay and have two observers on its board. The airline will cut executives' salaries, offer unpaid leave, and consider job cuts to avoid collapse. Global air traffic may only return to 50-60% of usual levels by year-end, with the industry's debt expected to swell to US$550 billion this year.

images.alt_text: Cathay Pacific Airways Ltd became the latest global carrier to receive a lifeline to get through the coronavirus pandemic, with the chairman saying its plan to raise HK$39 billion (S$7 billion) from the Hong Kong government and shareholders was necessary to avoid collapse.

site_title: Mediacorp's former Caldecott Hill site may come to market soon
summary: Mediacorp's former Caldecott Hill campus, a 752,000 sq ft site in the Good Class Bungalow (GCB) area, may be put up for sale. The developer will need to rezone the site for residential use, pay a differential premium, and top up the lease to 99 years. Market estimates suggest the site could fetch between S$130 million to S$250 million, with a land cost ranging from S$400-550 million. The proposed development will involve building 52-65 bungalows, with each unit priced at S$9-10 million, and the developer must sell the units within five years to avoid additional buyer's stamp duty.

site_title: Boeing jet deliveries sink to just four in May
summary: Boeing delivered just four planes in May, its lowest total for the month in six decades, amid the ongoing impact of the coronavirus pandemic on airlines. This decline follows six deliveries in April and is about 87% fewer than deliveries last year. The company's adjusted net orders sank to a negative 602 airplanes due to cancellations from aircraft leasing firms, including 14 MAX jets. Despite resuming production and expecting deliveries of the MAX in the third quarter, many airlines have cancelled or deferred delivery due to the collapse in air travel.

site_title: H1 revenue will be negatively impacted: Challenger
summary: Challenger Tech, a Singapore-based consumer electronics retailer, expects revenue in the first half of FY2020 to be impacted negatively due to the closure of its physical stores amid the COVID-19 restrictions. Despite a substantial increase in online orders, the group guided for profitability in the first half, thanks to pre-circuit-breaker sales and government relief measures. The group's physical retail stores have been closed since April, and only its online tech marketplace, Hachi.tech, continues to operate. The company remains uncertain about its FY2020 outlook and will continue to manage cash flow prudently.

site_title: Chanel, Revlon, L'Oreal pivoting away from talc in some products
summary: Cosmetics companies Chanel, Revlon, and L'Oreal are removing talc from some products amid US cancer lawsuits and consumer concerns. Chanel has removed talc from a loose face powder and a talc body powder, while Revlon and L'Oreal are also making changes. The move follows negative perceptions around the mineral, with court documents showing the luxury beauty company's decision. The shift away from talc is a response to growing consumer concerns and lawsuits in the US.

site_title: Trump's failure with North Korea might come back to bite him
summary: US President Donald Trump's efforts to improve relations with North Korea through diplomacy have stalled, with the two-year-old Singapore summit showing little progress. Despite South Korean President Moon Jae-in's efforts to intensify inter-Korean relations, the US-North Korea dialogue remains stalled due to differing interpretations of "denuclearisation". The US has made concessions, including calling off joint military exercises, while North Korea has made few concrete commitments. The stalled talks may come back to bite Trump ahead of the US presidential election, with North Korea's continued nuclear development and missile tests posing a significant threat to the US homeland.

site_title: Five tips for recovering from Covid-19 panic selling
summary: The COVID-19 pandemic led to irrational, fear-driven panic selling in the markets, causing a significant collapse in early March. However, the tech-heavy Nasdaq 100 Index has since recovered to new highs, and the S&P 500 Index is now up for the year. To recover from such panic selling, experts recommend five steps: 1) analyzing one's decision-making process, 2) admitting the error, 3) acknowledging it wasn't part of a planned financial strategy, 4) understanding it's a common mistake, and 5) making a rational plan for re-investing, such as buying in a lump sum.

site_title: Resale prices for condos hold steady in May despite volume dive
summary: Resale condo prices in Singapore remained stable in May, increasing 0.1% from April, despite a 43% drop in sales volume. Only 171 units were resold, a similar number to 2009, and 80% lower than May 2019. Prices in the core central region decreased 0.2%, while the outside central region fell 0.5%. Experts predict a potential rebound in sales volume when physical viewings resume, with some predicting volumes to range between 150-300 units in June.

site_title: US: Wall Street opens lower as focus shifts to Fed meeting
summary: US stocks opened lower on Tuesday as investors became cautious ahead of a Federal Reserve meeting. The Dow Jones Industrial Average fell 0.45%, the S&P 500 dropped 0.59%, and the Nasdaq Composite declined 0.58%. The Fed meeting's views on the economic recovery could impact markets, which have seen recent gains driven by the tech-heavy Nasdaq reaching an all-time high.

site_title: S&P cuts Japan's debt outlook as spending surges during pandemic
summary: S&P Global Ratings cut Japan's debt outlook to stable from positive due to increased uncertainty over the country's fiscal health amid the coronavirus pandemic. The move comes as Japan boosts spending to support the economy, which is slipping into recession. The general government deficit is expected to remain relatively high in fiscal 2021 through 2023, and the country's public debt is among the highest in industrialized nations. The rating agency affirmed Japan's A+ long-term and A-1 short-term sovereign credit ratings.

site_title: 58 fines issued to businesses and individuals in first week of post 'circuit-breaker' phase one
summary: In Singapore, 58 fines were issued to businesses and individuals in the first week of the post 'circuit-breaker' phase one, with 5 businesses fined S$1,000 each for failing to enforce safe management measures. 53 individuals were fined S$300 each for not wearing masks, breaching social gatherings, and leaving homes for non-essential reasons. Authorities warned of further action against non-compliant businesses and individuals, citing up to S$10,000 fines and jail time under the Covid-19 (Temporary Measures) Act.

site_title: SoftBank to expand Vision Fund cuts to as many as 80 employees
summary: SoftBank's Vision Fund is planning to cut up to 80 employees, about 15% of its workforce, due to record losses of $13 billion in the last fiscal year. The cuts will disproportionately affect staff supporting portfolio companies, with around 18 positions expected to be eliminated. The move comes after the fund's managing partner, Rajeev Misra, received a significant compensation increase despite the company's losses. SoftBank's parent company, SoftBank Group, may also see staff departures, with around 30 employees seeking new jobs.

site_title: Singapore market loses steam, snaps six-session winning streak
summary: The Singapore market lost steam, snapping a six-session winning streak, with the Straits Times Index (STI) closing 0.1% down at 2,794.17. The benchmark index had opened higher but declined from mid-afternoon, despite some recovery towards the end of the session. Sembcorp Industries led the index, while Sembmarine was the most heavily traded stock. Regional markets were mixed, with Australia's ASX 200 up 2.44%, and Japan's Nikkei 225 and Jakarta Composite Index down 0.38% and 0.7%, respectively.

site_title: UK gets near-record £73b demand for new 30-year bond
summary: The UK government sold £9 billion of a new 30-year bond, part of its surge in borrowing to respond to the coronavirus crisis. Demand from investors was near-record, with £72.8 billion of orders placed in an hour, and the bond was priced to yield 0.5 basis points more than the current 30-year benchmark. The sale brings the UK's total gilt proceeds for the financial year to £143 billion, approaching the government's target of £225 billion. British domestic investors accounted for 91% of the allocation.

site_title: IMF hails Hong Kong's status as global financial hub
summary: The International Monetary Fund (IMF) has praised Hong Kong's status as a global financial hub, citing its strong financial sector and well-governed monetary system. IMF First Deputy Managing Director Geoffrey Okamoto emphasized the importance of Hong Kong to both China and the rest of the world, as the Chinese territory faces renewed pro-democracy unrest. Okamoto also discussed the impact of the coronavirus pandemic on economies, noting that policy support may need to be adjusted as countries reopen. The IMF is set to issue a revised update to its world economic outlook on June 24.

site_title: IMF looks to use existing reserve assets rather than create more
summary: The International Monetary Fund (IMF) is exploring ways to utilize existing special drawing rights (SDRs) to support countries affected by the global pandemic, rather than creating new ones. The fund's first managing director, Geoffrey Okamoto, stated that internal work is underway to determine how to replicate the impact of a proposed $500 billion SDR allocation. This approach aims to maximize the benefits of an SDR allocation using the existing stock, which was blocked by the US in April.

site_title: SocGen reviews some structured products after first quarter hit
summary: French bank Societe Generale is reviewing its market activities after a poor first quarter, with equity trading revenue wiped out due to market falls and dividend cancellations. CEO Frederic Oudea stated that the bank will not abandon its leading equity structured products franchise but will conduct a thorough review to limit risks in case of extreme market dislocation.

site_title: Singapore ranks 4th-safest place amid Covid-19 pandemic: study
summary: Singapore ranks 4th among 200 nations and territories as the safest place to live during the Covid-19 pandemic, according to a study by Deep Knowledge Group. The country excelled in quarantine efficiency, monitoring, and detection, but fared less well in government efficiency. Switzerland and Germany took top marks, acting early to contain new cases, while poorer countries like Mali, Rwanda, and South Sudan struggled. The results suggest Singapore's efforts to lift restrictions could be successful, but the pandemic is moving into a more dangerous phase, with richer countries prioritizing vaccines and poorer countries facing challenges in testing and resource mobilization.

site_title: AEM hires new chief financial officer
summary: AEM Holdings announced the hiring of Leong Sook Han as its new chief financial officer (CFO), effective June 15. With over 20 years of finance experience, Leong is expected to strengthen AEM's financial management and reporting capabilities. She previously held positions at Hong Leong Asia and Royal Phillips NV, and brings extensive experience in the electronics sector and cross-border treasury management. AEM's shares closed trading at S$3.09, down 14 Singapore cents or 4.3 percent.

site_title: A digital future for maritime education?
summary: The COVID-19 pandemic has accelerated the shift towards digital maritime education, with institutions and organizations launching online training programs and courses to support seafarers. Viking Safety Academy and Reval Safety Training have developed an e-learning platform for refresher training, while the Baltic and International Maritime Council (Bimco) and Institute of Chartered Shipbrokers (ICS) have partnered to create an online academy. The International Bunker Industry Association (IBIA) has also launched its first online bunker training course. Experts believe that the pandemic will lead to a lasting change in approach to maritime training and education, with distance learning and virtual reality becoming increasingly important.

site_title: Challenger says surge in online sales unable to offset impact from store closures
summary: Challenger Tech, a consumer electronics retailer, reported a negative impact from store closures due to the COVID-19 pandemic. Despite a surge in online sales, the group expects revenue in the first half of FY2020 to be impacted negatively. However, management expects the group to remain profitable due to pre-pandemic sales and government relief measures. The company's physical retail stores have been closed since April, while its online marketplace has continued to operate. Challenger remains uncertain about the outlook for FY2020 and will continue to manage cash flow and its balance sheet prudently.

site_title: "Home-centric consumption" to continue post-lockdowns: report
summary: A report by Bain & Company and Facebook suggests that "home-centric consumption" trends in South-east Asia, accelerated by the COVID-19 pandemic, are likely to continue even as authorities relax safe-distancing measures. The region has seen significant growth in digital and e-commerce space, with 85% of respondents trying new apps and 44% spending more on online groceries. Key consumption themes include "at home" and "contactless" habits, with 70% preparing food at home more often and 65% watching more on-demand TV.

site_title: Football: French court rejects appeal on ending Ligue 1 season, suspends relegations
summary: France's highest administrative court rejected an appeal by three Ligue 1 clubs to end the season early due to the Covid-19 crisis. The court validated the decision to end the season with 10 games remaining, resulting in Olympique Lyonnais failing to qualify for Europe and Amiens and Toulouse being relegated. However, the court suspended relegation for Amiens and Toulouse. The decision also led to a review of the Ligue 1 championship for the 2020-21 season, potentially resulting in a 22-team league.

site_title: Huawei's 5G patents means US will pay despite Trump ban
summary: The US will likely be forced to pay Huawei for its 5G patents despite the Trump administration's efforts to ban the Chinese company from the US market. A study by two research firms found that Huawei owns the most patents on next-generation 5G technology, along with other major companies such as Samsung and Ericsson. The study's findings suggest that Huawei will still receive royalties from companies that use its patents, even if the US tries to exclude it from the supply chain. This may undermine the administration's efforts to limit Huawei's influence in the 5G industry.

site_title: EU seeks tougher checks on foreign buying of European firms
summary: The European Union is set to introduce tougher checks on foreign companies buying European firms, particularly state-owned or state-backed companies, to prevent the use of unfair subsidies. EU antitrust chief Margrethe Vestager aims to tighten checks and investigate companies with foreign state-backed shareholders. This move aims to protect European industrial champions and prevent the fragmentation of the single market. Vestager will present a proposal, known as the white paper on foreign subsidies, which will specify EU interests that could be harmed by foreign subsidies.

images.alt_text: The European Union (EU) will seek tougher checks on foreign state-owned or state-backed companies buying European firms to prevent the use of unfair subsidies, the EU antitrust chief said on Tuesday, the latest move to increase protection.

site_title: Airline industry headed for US$84b loss this year: IATA
summary: The International Air Transport Association (IATA) predicts the airline industry will incur record annual losses of US$84 billion in 2020, with 2020 being the "worst year in the history of aviation." Airline passenger traffic is expected to rise 55% in 2021, but still remain 29% below 2019 levels. IATA director general Alexandre de Juniac warned of a further US$15.80 billion hit to the industry's bottom line in 2021, totaling about US$100 billion in losses due to the pandemic.

site_title: Emirates lays off pilots, cabin crew, plans thousands more job cuts: sources
summary: Emirates, one of the world's largest long-haul airlines, has laid off more pilots and cabin crew due to the global coronavirus pandemic's impact on the aviation industry. The airline plans thousands of additional job cuts as it manages a cash crunch. The Dubai government's promise of new equity will help preserve the airline's skilled workforce, allowing it to "right size its workforce in line with reduced operations." This move comes after the airline grounded passenger flights in March and operates limited services since then.

site_title: Hong Kong still most expensive city for expats: Mercer
summary: Hong Kong remains the world's most expensive city for expats for a third consecutive year, according to Mercer's annual report. The city's sky-high housing costs, driven by the strength of the US dollar, pushed it ahead of 208 other cities. Asia dominated the top 10, with Ashgabat edging Tokyo out of second place. New York rose three spots to sixth, while Singapore fell to fifth. The least expensive cities were Karachi, Bishkek, and Tunis. The survey was conducted before the COVID-19 crisis had a significant impact, but its effects may be felt in the future.

site_title: Malaysia: Shares close higher on Tuesday
summary: Malaysia's FTSE Bursa Malaysia Kuala Lumpur Composite Index rose 18.83 points to 1,575.16 on Tuesday, driven by a gain of 771 stocks over 325 losers. The market volume reached 9.097 billion lots worth RM6.206 billion.

site_title: S&P downgrades Singtel Optus' stand-alone credit rating
summary: S&P has downgraded Singtel Optus' stand-alone credit rating to "BBB" from "BBB+" due to weaker performance in FY2020. Despite the downgrade, S&P Global Ratings has affirmed Optus' "A-" issuer credit and issue-level ratings, citing alignment with Singtel's "A-" SACP. Optus contributes significantly to Singtel's revenue and Ebitda. The stable outlook on Optus mirrors Singtel's outlook.

site_title: Japan, Britain aim for swift trade deal, Tokyo says
summary: Japan and Britain agreed to start talks on an early trade deal, with Britain expressing interest in joining the Trans-Pacific free trade pact. Japanese Foreign Minister Toshimitsu Motegi welcomed British Trade Minister Liz Truss's interest, and both countries aim to secure business continuity. Britain hopes to join the Trans-Pacific pact, while Japan seeks an early elimination of automobile and auto parts tariffs in negotiations. This comes as EU-British negotiations on a post-Brexit trade agreement have stalled, with just weeks left to reach a deal.

site_title: Tiffany amends debt agreements amid LVMH deal, sales slump
summary: US luxury jeweller Tiffany & Co has amended some of its debt agreements to bolster liquidity amid a 44% slump in quarterly sales. The company, set to be acquired by LVMH for $16 billion, has ample cash on hand and is in compliance with debt covenants. Despite this, LVMH CEO Bernard Arnault is exploring ways to potentially pressure Tiffany to lower the agreed price of $135 per share. The acquisition still needs regulatory approvals, and LVMH may revisit the issue if Tiffany's financial condition deteriorates.

site_title: Daily Debrief: What Happened Today
summary: Singapore business sentiment remains downbeat for the third quarter, but improved from a record low in the previous quarter amid the economy's reopening. Analysts are optimistic about a deal between SCI and Sembmarine, which could benefit both companies. The government plans to boost spending on infocomm technology to S$3.5 billion. Keppel denies allegations of breaching a US$425 million rig deal. Resale prices for private homes held steady in May, despite a decline in sales volume. The Straits Times Index (STI) closed 0.1% down, snapping a six-session winning streak.

site_title: Thailand proposes to tax foreign internet companies
summary: Thailand has proposed a draft bill requiring foreign digital service providers to pay a 7% value-added tax (VAT) on sales of digital products and services in the country. The move aims to boost tax revenues from international tech companies, with estimates suggesting a 3 billion baht annual increase. The bill, if approved, will affect services such as music and video streaming, gaming, and hotel booking, and is seen as a response to the growing internet economy in the region. The proposal follows similar moves in Indonesia and the Philippines.

site_title: China warns students to think twice before choosing Australia due to racist incidents
summary: China has warned students to consider twice before choosing Australia for study due to recent racial incidents targeting Asians in Australia. The warning comes amid strained relations between the two countries, following China's imposition of tariffs and blocked beef imports. China's culture and tourism ministry previously advised citizens against traveling to Australia due to racial discrimination. The Australian dollar fell 1% on the education ministry's warning, amid ongoing tensions between the two nations.

site_title: EU backs Covid-19 changes to airline CO2 scheme, EU official says
summary: The European Union has backed changes to the UN's Corsia scheme, allowing airlines to potentially pollute freely for years, according to an EU official. The proposal, which aims to cap emissions from international flights, would change the baseline from 2019-2020 to 2019. This move is opposed by campaigners, who argue it would undermine efforts to reduce aviation emissions. The EU's decision comes amid the ongoing COVID-19 pandemic, which has led to a significant decline in air travel and emissions.

site_title: Indonesia eases travel rules in boost for virus-hit airlines
summary: Indonesia has eased travel rules for airlines, allowing carriers to carry more passengers while maintaining mandatory virus testing and social distancing rules. The move comes as the country recorded a daily spike in infections and follows the reopening of 136 cities. Airlines, such as Lion Air Group, will limit passenger loads to 50% of aircraft capacity, with flag carrier Garuda Indonesia limiting its load to 70%. The easing of curbs aims to revive the tourism industry, but concerns remain about the cost of testing and handling positive cases.

site_title: Malaysian prosecutors drop corruption charges against Najib ally
summary: Malaysian prosecutors have dropped all 46 corruption charges against Musa Aman, a senior figure in former premier Najib Razak's party, citing a lack of evidence. The charges, worth 403 million ringgit (S$131.3 million), related to alleged bribery in timber concession deals and money laundering. The prosecution's decision has been described as "confusing and disappointing" by the opposition, raising concerns about potential political influence in the case. Najib faces multiple corruption charges linked to the 1MDB scandal and will know the verdict of his first case in July.

site_title: Hong Kong: Stocks rise for seventh day
summary: Hong Kong stocks rose for a seventh consecutive day, driven by investor optimism over an economic rebound from the virus crisis. The Hang Seng Index climbed 1.13% to 25,057.22, while the Shanghai Composite Index rose 0.62%. The gains followed a record lead from Wall Street, with the S&P 500 and Nasdaq indices reaching fresh records.

site_title: US failed to properly oversee Chinese telecom carriers: Senate panel
summary: A US Senate report finds the US government failed to properly oversee Chinese-owned telecommunications companies for nearly two decades. The Federal Communications Commission (FCC) and an informal group, Team Telecom, are criticized for inadequate oversight of China Telecom, China Unicom, and Pacific Networks. The report urges the FCC to revoke the carriers' authorizations, citing national security threats. The FCC has issued show-cause orders, but the carriers have urged against revocation. The report calls for greater oversight and legislative authority to protect US telecommunications networks from foreign threats.

site_title: Business leaders urge Britain to use UN targets in Covid-19 recovery plan
summary: Business leaders in the UK, including Natwest's Alison Rose and Schroders' Peter Harrison, have urged Prime Minister Boris Johnson to incorporate the United Nations' Sustainable Development Goals (SDGs) into the country's Covid-19 recovery plan. The SDGs aim to end poverty, reduce inequality, and protect the environment by 2030. The leaders believe embedding the SDGs in the recovery plan will prioritize the most vulnerable and ensure a sustainable, low-carbon economy. They emphasize the need for "coherent policies" to create lasting positive change and promote the health and wellbeing of current and future generations.

site_title: Tragic yarn: India-China border spat hits global cashmere production
summary: A border dispute between India and China is threatening global cashmere production, with tens of thousands of pashmina goats dying due to restricted grazing lands. The dispute has led to the death of 85% of newborn goats, resulting in a potential shortage of the highly prized cashmere wool. The conflict is concentrated in the Ladakh region, where Indian officials claim Chinese troops have encroached on the border. The loss of pashmina goats could devastate the handicrafts industry in Kashmir, supporting thousands of people and generating up to $800 per scarf.

site_title: Robot built for Japan's ageing workforce finds coronavirus role
summary: Japan's Mira Robotics is offering its "ugo" robot, designed to support the country's aging workforce, as a tool in the fight against the coronavirus. The robot features a hand attachment that uses ultraviolet light to kill viruses on door handles and can be deployed for security, equipment inspections, and cleaning. With its remote control feature, the robot can reduce direct contact between people, and its CEO, Ken Matsui, has received inquiries from overseas, including Singapore and France. The robot costs around $1,000 a month to rent and can be operated by multiple users.

site_title: STI loses steam, snaps six-session winning streak
summary: The Straits Times Index (STI) snapped a six-session winning streak, closing 0.1% or 2.8 points down at 2,794.17 on June 9, 2020. A proposal by Sembcorp Industries to hive off its loss-making marine arm Sembcorp Marine negatively impacted the offshore and marine player's share price. In contrast, Sembcorp Industries' share price rose 36.6% after the announcement.

site_title: Shanghai renewable subsidies to support solar and offshore wind
summary: Shanghai's municipal government has extended subsidies for solar and offshore wind projects through 2021, while ending onshore wind subsidies. Solar and offshore wind projects will receive a maximum subsidy of 50 million yuan over five years. Offshore wind turbines will receive a 0.1 yuan per kilowatt-hour subsidy, while utility-scale solar projects will receive 0.3 yuan and household projects 0.15 yuan. The government aims to increase China's renewable energy generation to 28.2% by 2020.

site_title: Office, building designs will have to change to lower risk of Covid-19 spread: Lawrence Wong
summary: Singapore's urban plans and building designs will need to change to lower the risk of Covid-19 spread, said Minister for National Development Lawrence Wong. Office and building designs will require improved ventilation, air filtering systems, and contactless fittings, while companies will need to find new, safer ways to deliver products and services. The construction industry will also implement new safeguards at worksites, and the government will continue to support the industry through the Fortitude Budget. A phased reopening plan will be implemented, with conditions monitored to prevent a surge in new cases.

images.alt_text: The construction industry will have to implement new safeguards at worksites and continue its push for automation and productivity to curb its dependence on migrant workers, said Mr Wong.

site_title: Euro top currency for 'green' bonds: ECB
summary: The European Central Bank (ECB) reported that almost half of global "green bond" issuance in 2020 was in euros, with EU residents being the largest issuers. The market segment grew to $205 billion, with 45.4% denominated in euros, compared to 25.7% in dollars and 28.9% in other currencies. ECB President Christine Lagarde sees this as an opportunity for the euro to gain importance on the global stage, but notes that a taxonomy is needed to clearly mark out environmentally-friendly investments and prevent "greenwashing".

site_title: Hong Kong govt says does not intend to hold Cathay Pacific stake long-term
summary: Hong Kong's government does not intend to hold a long-term stake in Cathay Pacific Airways, which received a bailout to help it through the coronavirus pandemic. Finance Secretary Paul Chan stated that the bailout aimed to maintain Hong Kong's status as a major international aviation hub and the government has no plans to get involved in the company's operations.

images.alt_text: Hong Kong's government does not intend to hold a stake in Cathay Pacific Airways long term after leading a rescue package to help it through the coronavirus pandemic, Finance Secretary Paul Chan said on Tuesday.

site_title: Xiaomi-backed trading app Tiger Trade launches SGX trading
summary: Tiger Trade, a mobile and online trading application backed by Xiaomi and Interactive Brokers, has launched access to the Singapore Exchange (SGX). The move comes amid increased trading volumes among Singapore-based retail investors during the Covid-19 pandemic. Tiger Trade offers commission rates starting from US$1.99 or S$2.80 per trade, with a special promotion for Singapore stocks at 0.08% per trade until December 31, 2020. The platform aims to strengthen its offerings and provide users with up-to-date stock quotes, market data, and news to make informed decisions.

site_title: Seoul: Stocks end higher for eighth day on quicker recovery hopes
summary: South Korean shares closed higher for an eighth consecutive session, driven by hopes of a quicker global economic recovery. The Kospi index rose 0.21% to 2,188.92, while the benchmark bond yield fell. Samsung Electronics gained 1.1% after a court denied an arrest warrant request for its heir. The Korean won hit a three-month high, and foreigners sold 21.2 billion won worth of shares. The US Federal Reserve's meeting is expected to influence market sentiment, with investors seeking a dovish message.

site_title: Australia: Shares end at 3-month high on swift economic turnaround hopes
summary: Australian shares ended at a three-month high on Tuesday, rising 2.4% to 6,144.9, driven by hopes of a speedy economic rebound from the coronavirus-triggered slump. Financials led the gains, with top lenders Commonwealth Bank and Westpac Banking Corp rising 4.8%. Oil prices ticked up on demand recovery hopes, and global miners BHP Group and Rio Tinto surged. Despite New Zealand's benchmark index dropping 2%, the Australian market's strong performance was attributed to a recent surge in iron ore prices and easing virus-induced curbs.

site_title: Aqua Munda to make offer to Hyflux PnP holders
summary: Aqua Munda is set to make an offer to Hyflux PnP holders, following a meeting with the Securities Investors Association (Sias). Aqua Munda aims to understand the concerns of the PnP holders to factor them into its plans. The firm did not provide details of its proposed offer, but assured Sias that it will provide details of its offer and financial capability at an appropriate time. Aqua Munda's goal is to acquire Hyflux, with business plans for the company to be disclosed later.

site_title: German exports collapse in April as coronavirus wrecks demand
summary: Germany's exports and imports plummeted in April, with seasonally adjusted exports diving 24% and imports sliding 16.5%, as the coronavirus lockdown took its toll. The trade surplus shrunk to 3.20 billion euros, beating economists' expectations. A recovery may have started due to easing lockdowns, but the road ahead is uncertain, especially for foreign trade. The government has announced a 130 billion euro stimulus package to boost domestic demand, but still expects the economy to shrink by 6.3% this year.

site_title: 218 new Covid-19 cases in Singapore, including 6 in community
summary: Singapore reported 218 new COVID-19 cases on June 9, with 6 in the community, including 3 unlinked cases in the construction and marine sectors. The other 3 community cases are housemates of a previously confirmed case. 212 cases are migrant workers living in dormitories. The daily average for new community cases has increased to 9, with 34 cases linked to a new cluster at a dormitory. With 509 patients discharged, 25,868 have fully recovered, and 248 remain in hospitals or community facilities.

site_title: UK retailers report smaller drop in annual sales in May
summary: UK retailers reported a 5.9% decline in annual sales in May, less severe than the 19.1% drop in April, as Covid-19 restrictions eased and more shoppers went online. This is the second-largest decline since the survey began in 1995. Online non-food spending rose by 60% year-over-year, while supermarket sales continued to grow, and garden centres and home improvement stores rebounded with sales down only 3% year-over-year. However, restaurants and cafes reported a 70% decline in sales, largely due to takeaway and delivery services.

site_title: Europe: Stock markets mixed at open
summary: European stock markets opened mixed, with London down 0.2% and eurozone indices up 0.3-0.5%. Analysts attribute the mixed results to optimism over the lifting of COVID-19 lockdowns, but fading optimism due to lack of fresh catalysts. The Bank of France predicted a 10% French economy shrinkage this year, while Germany's exports fell 24% in April. Despite this, Wall Street finished strong, with the Nasdaq hitting a record high.

site_title: Granite to resume commercial property Deals in Europe, the US
summary: Granite Real Estate Investment Trust is resuming commercial property deals in Europe and the US, driven by growing demand for storage and warehouse space. The firm raised C$789 million through debt and equity deals and has a pipeline of asset purchases planned. While some tenants were impacted by the pandemic, Granite's business has been less affected due to its focus on industrial and logistic warehouses. The company is now poised to capitalize on the recovery of global financial markets and the shift to online shopping.

site_title: Argentina is nationalising one of world's top soy suppliers
summary: Argentina's President Alberto Fernandez has announced the nationalization of Vicentin SAIC, a major soy supplier, for 60 days to seek congressional approval to expropriate the company. The move aims to address the financial crisis of the company, which filed for bankruptcy last year, and will place Vicentin's assets in a trust managed by state-run oil company YPF SA. The nationalization has been met with opposition from the main opposition coalition, who call it "illegal and unconstitutional," and raises questions about the government's ability to attract private sector investments to lift the country's economy.

site_title: Uber's Middle East unit Careem sees recovery after 80% slump
summary: Careem, Uber's Middle East ride-hailing unit, has started to recover from a 80% slump in March and April, with business now down 50-60% from last year. The company has seen a double-digit weekly growth since early May, with its delivery business expanding significantly during the pandemic. Careem has ruled out further job cuts after reducing staff by 31% in May and plans to launch a super app this month. The company remains fully backed by Uber Technologies Inc.

site_title: Singapore working with global shipping industry to facilitate crew changes
summary: Singapore is working with the global shipping industry to facilitate safe crew changes. The Maritime Port Authority has approved nearly 3,000 cases of crew changes since March 27, with the use of "safe corridors" and chartered flights. The first chartered flight took place at Changi Airport last Saturday, with three more flights scheduled this week. This effort aims to reduce the risk of COVID-19 transmission among seafarers.

site_title: OCBC takes complex face-to-face wealth advisory process online
summary: OCBC has successfully transitioned its complex face-to-face wealth advisory process to an online platform, allowing customers to complete over 50 pages of documents and a comprehensive financial needs analysis digitally. The bank saw a 45% increase in wealth management product sales online after launching its virtual service in April, with 60% of unit trusts purchased digitally in Q1. OCBC's digital adoption has accelerated since the COVID-19 outbreak, with 80% of digitally-active customers banking on their mobile phones. The bank aims to continue this shift and provide customers with a choice in engagement mode for their financial needs.

site_title: Vietnam plans to resume flights to some virus-free countries
summary: Vietnam plans to resume flights to virus-free countries, prioritizing destinations such as Japan, South Korea, and Cambodia, after 54 days without a domestically transmitted infection. The country has contained its COVID-19 cases to 332 and reported no deaths. Flights will resume with countries that have had no new cases for 30 days, with the National Steering Committee drafting a list of "safe" countries. The resumption will be cautious, with no specific quarantine program mentioned for inbound travelers.

images.alt_text: Vietnam plans to allow a resumption of flights to and from countries that have had no cases of coronavirus for 30 days, state media cited the prime minister as saying on Tuesday, with priority destinations including Japan, South Korea and Cambodia.

site_title: Ernst & Young sued over Wirecard as accounting woes add up
summary: Ernst & Young (EY) is being sued over its work for Wirecard, a German payment processor, amid accounting woes. The lawsuit alleges EY failed to flag €1 billion in improperly booked assets on Wirecard's 2018 accounts. The suit comes after a London judge criticized EY for its treatment of a whistle-blower and as the firm faces investigations in the UK over its audit of NMC Health.
