Wirecard's headquarters were raided by Munich prosecutors as part of a market manipulation probe, with regulators reviewing whether the company gave misleading signals to markets.

site_title: UniCredit eases travel ban, starts to ramp up return to office
summary: UniCredit, a major Italian bank, has eased its travel ban and started to allow employees to return to the office. Starting June 15, essential work trips to the US, Brazil, and Russia will be permitted, with approval required from a direct manager. The bank is gradually increasing the return of its 4,000 staff in Milan and allowing business meetings on site, subject to restrictions. UniCredit's memo also outlines "Golden Rules" for staff conduct, including social distancing and frequent handwashing, as the bank navigates its post-pandemic return to normal operations.

site_title: US nod boosts China carmaker BYD's push into masks
summary: Chinese carmaker BYD Co has received US regulatory approval to sell N95 respiratory masks to California, a key market. The certification, granted by the National Institute for Occupational Safety and Health, allows the state to start receiving millions of masks from BYD, which will be distributed to healthcare workers. This approval comes as BYD expanded into protective gear due to the pandemic's impact on electric-vehicle demand. BYD's chairman Wang Chuanfu led teams in ramping up production capacity to become the world's largest mask manufacturer.

site_title: Japan's Tepco plans 2 trillion yen green power push by 2030
summary: Japan's Tepco plans to invest over 2 trillion yen (S$25.75 billion) in renewable power by 2030, aiming to boost green generation by up to 70%. The move aims to bolster the role of clean power in the country, with a focus on offshore wind and hydro generation. Tepco's renewable unit plans to develop 7 gigawatts of green power capacity in Japan and overseas, with domestic offshore wind projects expected to be the most profitable.

site_title: UK tourism group says government plans to open travel corridors from June 29
summary: The UK tourism group, Quash Quarantine, announced that travel corridors allowing unrestricted movement between Britain and some countries will open on June 29, citing assurances from senior government sources. The group, representing 500 travel and hospitality firms, is still considering legal options, including joining a challenge to the government's 14-day quarantine rule.

site_title: France earmarks US$17b for struggling aerospace industry
summary: The French government has announced a US$17 billion rescue plan for the struggling aerospace industry, including billions of euros in financial aid for suppliers hit by the Covid-19 pandemic. The package includes loan guarantees, part-time work subsidies, and funds for the development of less polluting air travel. The measures aim to bolster European plane maker Airbus SE and its hundreds of French suppliers, which have been severely impacted by the pandemic. The industry employs 300,000 people and generates 58 billion euros in annual revenue.

site_title: Goldman Sachs expects oil rally to run out of steam soon
summary: Goldman Sachs expects oil prices to pull back in the coming weeks due to uncertain demand and a large inventory overhang. The bank forecasts Brent prices to reach US$35 per barrel and US$36 for WTI crude, down from recent highs. The rebound in oil prices has been driven by a macro risk-on backdrop and policy-induced Chinese crude imports, but Goldman says fundamentals are turning bearish, with supplies expected to increase and lead to a deficit of 1.2 million barrels per day.

site_title: Chanel, Revlon, L'Oreal pivoting away from talc in some products
summary: Chanel, Revlon, and L'Oreal, major cosmetics brands, are shifting away from using talc in some products due to US cancer lawsuits and consumer concerns. Talc, which is linked to asbestos, has been removed from loose face powder and body powders by Chanel and Revlon, while L'Oreal is exploring alternatives. The moves come amid scrutiny of talc products after a Reuters investigation in 2018 reported that Johnson & Johnson knew asbestos was present in its talc and powders. Other companies, including Avon and Bausch Health, have also stopped selling talc powder or face powder due to negative publicity.

site_title: 101 Beach Road up for en bloc sale with S$90m reserve price
summary: A mixed-use development at 101 Beach Road in Singapore is up for collective sale with a reserve price of S$90 million. The six-storey building has a 999-year leasehold tenure and a gross floor area of 3,515.89 sq m. The site is near Bugis MRT Interchange and the upcoming Guoco Midtown. The Urban Redevelopment Authority has provided two development parameters, with land rates ranging from S$2,394 to S$2,848 per square foot per plot ratio. The tender will close on July 22.

site_title: Hyundai Development wants to renegotiate Asiana Airlines acquisition after debt surge
summary: Hyundai Development, a South Korean consortium, is seeking to renegotiate its acquisition of Asiana Airlines after the airline's debt surged by $3.8 billion. Asiana Airlines had an additional 2.8 trillion won of debt recognized as of end-2019 and borrowed 1.7 trillion won more, prompting Hyundai Development to call for creditor support. Despite the pandemic, Hyundai Development still wants the deal to proceed, stating that the airline's survival hinges on the transaction. Asiana Airlines declined to comment, and Korea Development Bank, its lead creditor, did not have an immediate response.

site_title: Hong Kong government to lead Cathay Pacific bailout package: SCMP
summary: Hong Kong's government will lead a HK$30 billion bailout package for Cathay Pacific Airways, providing a government loan and equity stake. The deal includes two observer seats for the government in the airline's boardroom. As part of a broader HK$40 billion capital restructuring, Cathay Pacific has grounded most of its planes due to falling demand amid the coronavirus pandemic. The airline has made an unaudited loss of HK$4.5 billion and flagged a "very bleak" outlook, but has not announced large-scale permanent job losses.

site_title: Singapore condo resales sink further but prices hold steady in 2nd month of circuit breaker: SRX
summary: Singapore condo resale prices held steady in May, with 171 units resold, a 43% decrease from April. Despite low sales volume, prices finished 0.1% higher than in April and 0.6% lower than in May 2019. Luxury apartments saw increased sales, with three units sold for over S$10 million during the circuit breaker period. Experts predict a possible jump in transaction volume when physical house viewings resume, with ERA Realty forecasting 150-300 units sold in June.

site_title: Manchester United legend Dunne dies aged 78
summary: Tony Dunne, a former Manchester United defender, has died at the age of 78. Dunne played in the team's first European Cup-winning side in 1968 and made 535 appearances for the club. He won two First Division championships and the 1962-63 FA Cup. Dunne also represented the Republic of Ireland 33 times. The news of his passing was announced by Manchester United and other clubs, including Shelbourne FC, with which he started his career.

site_title: Boxed lunches and plexiglass will welcome back Wall Street's workers
summary: Wall Street is gradually reopening its doors to employees, with thousands returning to offices starting this month. However, the return will be limited and mostly voluntary, with many workers opting to continue working remotely. Companies are implementing various safety measures, including temperature checks, face-mask sensors, and social distancing, but some firms are considering postponing reopenings until September or later due to ongoing concerns about the virus. As a result, many expect a "very gradual return" to in-person work, with only 10% to 29% of employees returning to city offices by the end of the year.

site_title: S&P cuts Japan's debt outlook as spending surges during pandemic
summary: S&P Global Ratings lowered Japan's debt outlook to stable from positive, citing increased uncertainty over the country's fiscal health due to boosted spending during the pandemic. Japan's public debt is among the highest in industrialized nations, with a general government deficit of about 16% of GDP in fiscal 2020. The ratings agency expects the fiscal deficit to remain relatively high until economic growth returns and the Covid-19 outbreak recedes. S&P affirmed Japan's A+ long-term and A-1 short-term sovereign credit ratings, but warned that a sharp increase in real interest rates could strain the government's debt dynamics.

site_title: Tokyo: Stocks off 3.5-month peak as firmer yen weighs on market
summary: Japanese stocks declined, slipping from a 3.5-month high, as a firmer yen weighed on the market. The benchmark Nikkei average fell 0.4% to 23,091.03, with carmakers and chip-related companies leading the decline. A stronger yen hurt Japanese manufacturers' profits abroad, while a Wall Street overnight rally failed to boost the market.

site_title: Austria to introduce 40-euro minimum flight price
summary: Austria's government plans to introduce a 40-euro minimum flight price to combat "social and environmental dumping" in the aviation industry. The move aims to ensure that airlines cover actual costs, rather than offering cheap tickets that harm the industry. The 40-euro price will be enforced nationwide, with Environment Minister Leonore Gewessler stating that "it will no longer be possible to offer tickets which are cheaper than the actual costs." The measure is part of a government-backed rescue package for Austrian Airlines.

site_title: Asia: Markets mixed as profit-taking offsets lockdown easing
summary: Asian markets experienced a mixed day on June 9, 2020, with Sydney and Hong Kong leading gains, while Tokyo and Seoul declined due to profit-taking. Optimism over lockdown easing and economic recovery offset concerns about a potential second wave of COVID-19 infections. Analysts warned that the road to full recovery is long and will require medical solutions, including vaccines and accurate testing. Oil markets remained supported by expectations of increased demand, but prices may plateau due to weak US demand.

site_title: Gold ticks up, moves in tight range ahead of Fed meeting
summary: Gold prices rose 0.1% to $1,696.06 per ounce, supported by a weaker US dollar. However, the metal traded in a narrow range ahead of the US Federal Reserve's two-day monetary policy meeting. Investors are cautious, as a strong employment report last week reduced expectations of negative interest rates. Market participants favor riskier assets, pushing gold's advance, and Asian stocks are expected to climb. The World Health Organization warned the Covid-19 pandemic is "far from over" with a record number of new daily infections reported.

site_title: Chanel's first digital show was a disappointment on many levels
summary: Chanel's first digital fashion show was unveiled Monday, following the COVID-19 pandemic and global protests. The collection, originally scheduled for May 7, was adapted due to lockdowns. Despite being out of the brand's control, the digital show was disappointing, with critics citing a lack of creativity and poor production quality. The show was intended to mark Virginie Viard's tenure as creative director, but its execution fell short, raising questions about the future of digital fashion shows. The collection consisted of videos, still images, clothes, and notes, which were released online.

site_title: Australian dollar scales 11-month peak, hits profit-taking
summary: The Australian and New Zealand dollars reached fresh multi-month peaks on Tuesday, with the Aussie climbing to US$0.7043 and the Kiwi reaching US$0.6580, driven by optimism for global recovery. Despite profit-taking, both currencies remain on a tear as economies reopen. Australian business activity and confidence improved in May, but job ads still suggest a weak labor market. Yields on Australian bonds have jumped 20 basis points in the past week, with the Reserve Bank of Australia seemingly comfortable with the move.

site_title: Lotte takes over Changi Airport's duty-free liquor, tobacco stores
summary: Changi Airport has welcomed Lotte Duty Free as its new key liquor and tobacco concessionaire, replacing DFS Group. Lotte will operate 18 stores across the airport, offering over 3,000 wines and spirits tax and duty-free. The new operator will introduce innovative store designs, including a high-tech tasting bar and immersive experience zones, and will initially retail on the airport's e-commerce platform before opening physical shops. The partnership is part of Changi Airport Group's efforts to transform the airport's core liquor and tobacco concession as e-commerce grows exponentially.

site_title: Australia business activity bounces from recessionary lows in May: NAB
summary: Australia's business activity showed a broad-based improvement in May, with the National Australia Bank's index of business conditions rising to -24 from -34 in April. Business confidence also improved, but remains below the long-run average. Employment remained weak, improving only slightly to -31. The economy continues to be in recessionary territory, with the Reserve Bank of Australia warning of a 10% economic contraction in the first half of the year.

site_title: Hong Kong's rush to attract China listings comes with a risk
summary: Hong Kong's push to attract Chinese technology listings faces a risk that the city's ability to absorb investing dollars will be threatened by US retaliation over Beijing's proposed security law. Despite the recent influx of mainland money, concerns persist that the city's international investor base is dwindling, and a flood of issuance could be difficult to absorb. The US has tightened its rules for Chinese tech companies, and a proposed bill could force them to stop trading in New York. Hong Kong's efforts to reform its regulatory framework and reduce settlement times for IPOs may not be enough to attract sufficient investor interest.

site_title: Honda suspends vehicle shipments after suspected cyberattack
summary: Honda Motor has temporarily halted shipments from some of its Japanese factories due to a suspected cyberattack that disrupted its internal network. The attack affected Honda's inspection systems, but production was not impacted. The company is working to fix its systems and assess the extent of the disruption, with the impact on overseas plants still unclear. Honda's spokesperson, Hidenori Takeyasu, stated that the company is probing whether the system was attacked.

site_title: Amsterdam to clean up sex-and-drugs tourism in post-virus reboot
summary: Amsterdam is working to rebalance its city center after the COVID-19 pandemic reduced tourism, revealing that locals are outnumbered by visitors. The city's mayor has proposed a plan to attract local businesses, limit permits for tourist-oriented shops, and promote residents' needs. Efforts include buying property and renting office space to companies like Adyen NV, which will bring young employees to the area. However, brothels and cannabis-selling coffee shops are resistant to changes, citing the need for tourists to support their businesses. The city aims to create a vibrant center where locals live, work, and socialize, rather than relying solely on tourists.

site_title: TSMC says could fill order gap if unable to sell chips to Huawei
summary: TSMC Chairman says the company could fill any order gap if US restrictions prevent sales to Huawei due to security concerns and trade disputes. TSMC's clients include Huawei's chip division HiSilicon, and the company has production bases in both the US and China. The US Commerce Department's proposal to amend chip export rules would restrict TSMC's sales to Huawei.

images.alt_text: Taiwan Semiconductor Manufacturing Co Ltd (TSMC) could quickly fill any order gap should US restrictions against Huawei Technologies prevent sales to the Chinese firm, the company's chairman said on Tuesday.

site_title: Macy's raises US$4.5b to shore up funds as stores reopen, shares surge
summary: Macy's has raised $4.5 billion in funding, including $3.15 billion in new borrowings against its real estate assets, to shore up funds as stores reopen after the COVID-19 pandemic. The funding gives the retailer flexibility and liquidity to steer the business, allowing it to purchase new inventory and repay debts. Shares surged 11% after the announcement, as the company navigates the fallout from store closures and lockdowns. The funds will be used to repay outstanding borrowings and modify the retailer's credit agreement.

site_title: UK labour market outlook bleakest since 1992: study
summary: The UK labour market is at its bleakest since 1992, according to a survey by ManpowerGroup, with hiring intentions down by 12% in the third quarter of 2020. This marks the worst level since the survey began in 1992. Despite this, most UK businesses expect to return to normalcy over the next 12 months, with 57% expecting to return to pre-Covid-19 hiring levels by the end of the year. The survey highlights the unprecedented disruption caused by the coronavirus pandemic, which has killed over 40,000 in Britain.

site_title: Floating dams fail to stop fuel spill in Russian Arctic, official says
summary: Russian officials have recorded massive concentrations of pollution in a Siberian river, despite installing floating dams to stop a fuel spill. The dams were deemed "ineffective" or installed too late, allowing pollution to spread. The spill, which released 21,000 tonnes of diesel, was caused by melting permafrost and has triggered a major clean-up effort. Local environmental protection specialists have detected fuel product concentrations 80-116 times the accepted levels, and four criminal cases have been opened in connection with the incident.

images.alt_text: Russian officials said Monday they had recorded massive concentrations of pollution in a Siberian river, even after authorities installed barriers to stop a fuel spill that sparked a state of emergency.

site_title: Singapore business sentiment remains downbeat but more optimism in manufacturing, financial sectors
summary: Singapore's business sentiment remains downbeat, but improved slightly in the third quarter, with a Business Optimism Index of -5.16 percentage points. The manufacturing and financial sectors show optimism, with indicators such as new orders and sales volumes turning positive. However, the construction sector remains the most pessimistic, and uncertainty remains due to ongoing global issues.

site_title: As many as 25,000 US stores may close in 2020, mostly in malls
summary: The US retail industry may see 20,000 to 25,000 store closures in 2020, mostly in malls, due to the coronavirus pandemic. This would surpass the record 9,800 closures in 2019. Department stores and clothing shops are expected to be among the hardest hit. The pandemic has forced retailers to rewrite their business strategies, leading to a ripple effect that could spell bad news for malls. Fifteen major retailers have already filed for bankruptcy this year, and Coresight Research expects another wave of bankruptcies as debt-laden retailers struggle.

site_title: Alibaba says cloud unit to recruit 5,000 staff globally this financial year
summary: Alibaba's cloud unit plans to recruit 5,000 staff globally by the end of the financial year, focusing on areas like network, database, and artificial intelligence. President Jeff Zhang stated that the digital transformation journey for businesses in China is likely to be accelerated to one year, requiring a significant investment in worldwide IT talents. This move aims to build trusted cloud technologies and services, driving the company's growth in the cloud computing market.

site_title: Chinese telecom firms urge FCC not to revoke ability to operate in US
summary: The US units of China Telecom Corp and China Unicom urged the FCC not to revoke their authorisation to provide international telecommunications services in the US, citing unfounded claims of national security concerns. The companies argued that the FCC should not revoke their rights based solely on foreign policy concerns without evidence of specific misconduct. This comes after the US Justice Department requested the FCC to act in April.

site_title: Hong Kong: Stocks extend rally at Tuesday's open
summary: Hong Kong stocks continued their rally, with the Hang Seng Index rising 0.52% to 24,906.01, following a surge on Wall Street. China's benchmark Shanghai Composite Index also edged up 0.06%. The rally marks a seventh day of gains, as investors took heart from the S&P 500's wipeout of all its losses for the year.

site_title: Online used car seller Vroom raises US$467.5m in US IPO
summary: Vroom Inc, an online used car seller, raised US$467.5 million in its initial public offering, valuing the company at US$2.48 billion. The company priced its shares at US$22, above its earlier range of US$18-US$20. This IPO follows a rebound in appetite for new stocks after the Covid-19 pandemic.

site_title: Govt to boost spending on infocomm technology to S$3.5b
summary: The Singapore government plans to spend S$3.5 billion on information and communications technology (ICT) this financial year, up from S$2.70 billion in the previous year. The investment will focus on digitalisation, including projects to respond to the COVID-19 pandemic, such as the TraceTogether application and SafeEntry system. The government will also invest in technology to accelerate Singapore's digitalisation push, including digital services for citizens and businesses, and the development of AI applications. Small and medium-sized enterprises (SMEs) will be eligible for 80% of potential ICT procurement opportunities.

site_title: Cathay Pacific, major shareholders Swire and Air China halt trading in Hong Kong
summary: Cathay Pacific Airways and its major shareholders Swire Pacific and Air China halted trading of their shares in Hong Kong on June 9, 2020, pending an announcement. The halt follows a meeting between Cathay's management and pilot unions, as well as reports of potential senior management changes. The airline has been struggling due to the coronavirus pandemic, grounding most of its planes and reporting a loss of HK$4.5 billion in January-April.

site_title: Tee International names new CFO after predecessor leaves amid probe
summary: Tee International has appointed Ewe Tuck Foong as its new chief financial officer (CFO) effective June 9, following the departure of Yeo Ai Mei in February due to her involvement in unauthorized payments. The company's former CEO, Phua Chian Kin, has also admitted to taking company funds to repay personal debts. Tee International has implemented internal control measures and tightened corporate governance since Phua's departure. Ewe Tuck Foong brings experience as CFO of HPC Holdings from 2016 to 2019.

site_title: Dubai charts a path to luxury industry's new normal
summary: Dubai's luxury tourism industry is gradually returning to normal after easing pandemic restrictions, but the new normal has resulted in a loss of its "wow" factor. Tables are now set 2 meters apart, and extravagant luxuries such as sweeping breakfast buffets and frolics in swimming pools may have to be reconsidered. Hospitality experts warn that luxury experiences are not particularly luxurious anymore, and people will want more privacy and individual experiences. The city's economy is diversifying, with a focus on retail and hospitality, and experts predict a long-term shift in global norms surrounding travel, luxury, and entertainment.

site_title: China's troubled Baoshang rescue exposes fault lines in bank reform drive
summary: China's central bank took over troubled Baoshang Bank in 2019, citing "serious credit risks," but a year later, the rescue has veered off its planned trajectory due to infighting between regulators, limited support from big state banks, and a larger role for financially stretched local governments. The bank's assets were sold to Huishang Bank, which acquired the bank's four city licenses for an estimated 106.5 billion yuan. The rescue has raised concerns about the stability of China's small lenders, which account for about a quarter of the country's assets.

site_title: Tokyo: Stocks open lower on profit-taking
summary: Tokyo stocks opened lower on Tuesday, closing down 0.21% or 49.71 points at 23,128.39, despite hopes for a global economic recovery from the coronavirus crisis. This follows six straight days of rallies. The broader Topix index also declined 0.06%. Investors locked in profits, likely due to profit-taking.

site_title: Australian job ads steady in May after record dive
summary: Australian job advertisements steadied in May, edging up 0.5% from April, after suffering a record 53.4% drop. This improvement is attributed to the gradual rollback of Covid-19 restrictions allowing businesses to reopen. Economists fear unemployment could spike towards 10% in coming months, but expect a rapid recovery from mid-year. The Reserve Bank of Australia has slashed rates to a record low and launched a bond buying program to cushion the economy.

site_title: Singapore shares clock further gains, Sembcorp jumps; STI up 0.9% at open
summary: Singapore's Straits Times Index (STI) rose 0.9% to 2,823.05, driven by gains in Sembcorp Industries (SCI) and Singapore banks. SCI jumped 30.7% after a massive recapitalization announcement, while DBS, UOB, and OCBC Bank also increased. The market followed Wall Street's strong finish, with the Nasdaq hitting a new record and the S&P 500 erasing losses for the year.

site_title: This wheel-bound unicorn is ready to sprout wings
summary: Gojek and Grab Holdings, rival ride-hailing and food delivery companies, are shifting their focus from mobility to other services such as payments, loans, and advertising. Executives believe that adding these services will increase profit and create a broader ecosystem. Recent investments from Facebook, Alphabet, and PayPal Holdings hint at Gojek's direction, as the company aims to expand its presence beyond South-east Asia. Gojek's payments business, GoPay, is expected to play a key role in this strategy, with the potential to tap into Facebook's vast user base and expand into new markets.

site_title: Wealthy havens lure homebuyers in 'mad rush' from San Francisco
summary: A surge in demand for real estate in the San Francisco Bay Area's outer suburbs and wealthy havens has occurred during the COVID-19 pandemic, with 13 bids on a $1.7 million home in Marin County and a $10.85 million estate in Napa Valley selling within hours of a buyer's tour. The trend is attributed to tech companies' long-term acceptance of remote work, making it less necessary to live close to offices, and wealthy individuals seeking more spacious areas. However, this shift may exacerbate existing divides in the region, where affordable housing is already scarce, and may not be a permanent trend if the virus is a short-term aberration.

site_title: Brokers' take: Analysts positive on SCI, Sembmarine deal; latter's share price slides
summary: Analysts are optimistic about the proposed deal between Sembcorp Industries (SCI) and Sembcorp Marine (Sembmarine), expecting it to benefit both companies. However, Sembmarine's share price is expected to face short-term pressure due to the rights issue. RHB maintains a "buy" call on Sembmarine and SCI, with raised target prices. The deal is seen as a strategic move to help Sembmarine better ride through tough business conditions and SCI to focus on its energy and urban development arms. The proposed recapitalisation and demerger are expected to improve Sembmarine's financials and provide a cleaner structure for SCI.

site_title: IBM gets out of facial recognition business
summary: IBM will no longer offer general-purpose facial recognition or analysis software, citing opposition to its use for mass surveillance, racial profiling, and human rights violations. The decision comes amid nationwide protests in the US over police brutality and racial injustice. CEO Arvind Krishna stated in a letter to Congress that IBM will not condone such uses and calls for greater transparency and accountability in policing. The move follows IBM's shift in focus towards more transparent and trustworthy technologies, aligning with its "Principles of Trust and Transparency."

site_title: Sony to unveil PS5 games in online event
summary: Sony unveiled plans to showcase PS5 games in an online event, titled "The Future of Gaming," which was postponed due to unrest in cities over police misconduct and race discrimination. The event aims to ramp up efforts for the year-end holiday season.

images.alt_text: Sony unveiled plans to showcase games tailored for its planned PlayStation 5 consoles Thursday in a sign of a ramped up effort for the year-end holiday season.

site_title: California says movie theaters can reopen by Friday with crowd limits
summary: California movie theaters can reopen by Friday with crowd limits, according to the state's health department. To operate, theaters must cap attendance at 25% of normal capacity or a maximum of 100 people, whichever is lower. This decision comes after theaters closed in mid-March to curb the coronavirus pandemic. Local officials must still approve reopening and impose additional safeguards to prevent the spread of the virus.

site_title: Hong Kong leader says city cannot tolerate any more 'chaos'
summary: Hong Kong leader Carrie Lam warned the city cannot tolerate further "chaos" amid ongoing anti-government protests. The protests, sparked by a now-withdrawn extradition bill, have revived in recent weeks, with fears over Beijing's tightening grip on the city. The protests, which began in June 2019, have plunged the city into turmoil. Lam's comments come as the city marks the first anniversary of the mass rally against the extradition bill. The protests have led to widespread unrest and calls for greater autonomy for Hong Kong.

images.alt_text: Hong Kong leader Carrie Lam said on Tuesday the Chinese-ruled city cannot afford to tolerate any more of the "chaos" that has roiled it over the past 12 months, with anti-government protests plunging the city into turmoil.

site_title: Catching up: How much further can emerging assets run?
summary: Emerging assets have partially recovered from the COVID-19 pandemic, with some $80 billion being pulled out of developing stocks and bonds in March. However, investment managers are uncertain about the sustainability of this rally, citing ongoing economic challenges. The US dollar's decline and steady decline in emerging bond yields have contributed to the growth, but investors remain cautious. With China's GDP growth expected to slow, policymakers face pressure to implement stimulus measures. Analysts forecast a 1,150 target for MSCI's global equity index by mid-2026, but the outlook remains uncertain for emerging assets.

site_title: New York, Moscow starts reopening after lockdown
summary: New York City partially reopened its economy after nearly three months of lockdown, with around 400,000 residents allowed to return to work. Retailers began offering limited in-store and curbside pickup, while construction and manufacturing resumed operations. The World Health Organization warned that the health crisis is worsening worldwide. This move comes as the US experiences a resurgence of COVID-19 cases.

site_title: US police in hot seat after years of near impunity
summary: US police face widespread criticism and calls for reform after the death of George Floyd, with communities and Congress demanding changes to address systemic racism and excessive use of lethal force. Despite 1,098 police killings in 2019, including 275 of African Americans, and a 15-year lack of felony homicide charges, police unions and laws protect officers, making prosecution rare. A nationwide movement is pushing for reforms, including defunding the police, lowering the legal threshold for prosecution, and increasing racial sensitivity training, but the challenge of 18,000 autonomous police departments across the country poses a significant hurdle.

site_title: Thousands mourn George Floyd as accused officer appears in court
summary: Thousands mourned George Floyd's coffin in Houston ahead of his funeral, drawing over 6,000 people to pay tribute to the unarmed black man whose murder sparked nationwide protests against police brutality. Derek Chauvin, the 44-year-old white officer charged with Floyd's murder, appeared in court, facing up to 40 years in prison if convicted. In response to Floyd's death, Democratic lawmakers unveiled a package of police reforms, including a bill to make it easier to prosecute officers for abuse, and knelt in silence at the US Capitol to honor Floyd's memory.

site_title: Malaysia: Shares open higher on Tuesday
summary: Malaysia's FTSE Bursa Malaysia Kuala Lumpur Composite Index rose 25.97 points, or 1.67%, to 1,582.30 on Tuesday, driven by a higher volume of 224.48 million lots worth RM133.05 million. This follows a 0.4% gain on the STI on Thursday, despite tariff uncertainty and split Fed views.

site_title: Stocks to watch: CapitaLand, Keppel, Sembcorp Industries, Sembmarine, Frasers Property
summary: Singapore stocks to watch: Sembcorp Industries and Sembmarine unveiled a massive S$2.1 billion recapitalization deal and demerger, with trading halted since last Thursday. CapitaLand further waived and potentially deferred rent for small and medium-sized enterprise tenants, impacting earnings. Keppel Corp faced a terminated offshore rig construction deal, while Frasers Property secured a S$350 million green loan. Other companies, including SingPost, Ho Bee Land, and Bonvests Holdings, reported various developments.

site_title: US recession started in February, ending 128-month expansion
summary: The US economy reached its peak and entered recession in February, ending a 128-month expansion amid the coronavirus pandemic. The National Bureau of Economic Research (NBER) defined the recession due to the unprecedented decline in employment and production. The economy contracted by 4.8% in the first quarter, with a significant drop in employment, marking the longest US expansion since 1854. This downturn was characterized by a broad decline in economic activity across the economy, meeting the NBER's criteria for a recession.

site_title: Kiwi unit up after NZ declared Covid-free
summary: New Zealand declared itself Covid-free, lifting all virus-containment measures except border controls. The New Zealand dollar strengthened to its highest in nearly four months, rising against the US dollar and Australian dollar. However, global economic recovery hopes were tempered by European industrial output plummeting and US employment data raising expectations for a quicker recovery.

site_title: Volkswagen names Ralf Brandstaetter brand chief executive
summary: Volkswagen has appointed Ralf Brandstaetter as its new brand chief executive, effective July 1. He will oversee the development of the brand towards electric vehicles, following the departure of Herbert Diess, who will focus on the entire VW group. This move comes after weeks of tension at VW, reportedly due to software problems with the ID.3 electric model. Volkswagen is shifting its focus towards "zero-emission mobility" in response to the disastrous emissions-cheating scandal.

site_title: Samsung heir avoids arrest over controversial merger
summary: A South Korean court declined to issue an arrest warrant for Lee Jae Yong, vice-chairman of Samsung Electronics, over a 2015 merger of two business units, citing insufficient probable cause. The merger was seen as a key step in his succession, but prosecutors alleged price manipulation and illegal trading. Lee is already being re-tried on charges related to a corruption scandal that brought down former President Park Geun Hye, and his release from detention was met with a brief statement from Samsung rejecting media reports of price manipulation.

site_title: Keppel denies allegations by drilling firm seeking to scrap US$425m rig deal
summary: Keppel FELS denies allegations by drilling firm Awilco Drilling that it is breaching contract terms for a $425 million offshore rig deal. Awilco claims breaches in project management, schedule, and compliance, but Keppel Corp says it rejects the allegations and will consider its legal options. The dispute comes as Awilco is set to pay its next instalment of $31.9 million, which Keppel Corp may retain if Awilco defaults. Keppel Corp has reserved its rights under the contract, including the right to seek compensation for work done to date.

site_title: Federal Reserve again expands Main Street loan programme to reach more firms
summary: The US Federal Reserve has expanded its Main Street Lending Programme to reach more companies struggling with the coronavirus shutdowns. The programme now offers loans of up to $300 million, with a minimum loan amount of $250,000, and extends loan terms to five years. The programme aims to support small and mid-sized businesses, with the goal of fostering a broad-based economic recovery. The changes are expected to improve the ability of the programme to support employment during this difficult period, according to Federal Reserve Chair Jerome Powell.

site_title: North Korea to cut communication lines to 'enemy' South: KCNA
summary: North Korea announced it will cut off all communication links with South Korea on June 9, 2020, in response to South Korean authorities cracking down on anti-Pyongyang leaflets sent over the border. The move comes amid strained inter-Korean ties, despite three summits between the two leaders in 2018. The liaison line between the two countries will be completely shut down, effective 12:00pm on June 9.

site_title: Iraq is fully committed to the Opec+ cut deal: oil minister
summary: Iraq's oil minister, Ihsan Abdul Jabbar, has reaffirmed the country's commitment to the Opec+ production cut deal, extending record output cuts of 9.7 million barrels per day into July. The deal aims to curb global supply by almost 10% amid a slump in demand due to the coronavirus pandemic. Iraq is committed to reducing its production in June and July in compliance with the agreement, with further cuts planned after the period. This move is seen as part of efforts to stabilize the global oil market.

site_title: Risk-taking billionaires offer rich reward for Credit Suisse
summary: Credit Suisse is banking on risk-taking billionaires to drive revenue growth at its wealth management division, with estimated US$400 million in additional revenues between 2020 and 2022. The division's head, Philipp Wehle, says ultra-wealthy clients are investing in higher-risk assets and building strategic positions, with some seeking to acquire undervalued companies. Despite the COVID-19 pandemic, Credit Suisse's wealth management division saw 6% growth in the first quarter, driven by increased trading activity.

site_title: Frasers Property bags S$350m green loan for Fernvale Lane exec condo project
summary: Frasers Property has secured a S$350 million green loan to finance its Fernvale Lane executive condominium project, marking Singapore's first green loan for an EC development. The loan, arranged by DBS Bank, Maybank, and OCBC Bank, will be structured according to green loan principles issued in 2018. The project, developed by Frasers Property's subsidiary Fernvale Lane, aims to obtain BCA Green Mark Gold Plus upon completion, targeting 500 units at the Fernvale Lane site near the Seletar Aerospace Hub and Punggol Digital District.

site_title: Surbana Jurong acquires urban and infrastructure protection firm
summary: Surbana Jurong, a Temasek-owned consultancy, has acquired Prostruct Consulting, an urban and infrastructure protection firm specializing in security and blast consultancy. The acquisition enhances Surbana Jurong's portfolio of built environment services, enabling it to deliver building designs with integrated security measures. This move comes as the Singapore government has enacted an Infrastructure Protection Act requiring designated buildings to integrate security measures into their designs. The combined strengths of Prostruct and Surbana Jurong will reinforce the latter's commitment to building safe, secure, and sustainable spaces.

site_title: Can a 'law-and-order' president get re-elected?
summary: US President Donald Trump has been using strong language to praise law enforcement agencies and threaten to send military troops into states to quell protests, sparking concerns about his re-election chances. The protests, sparked by the killing of a black man by a white police officer in Minneapolis, have turned violent and destructive in some cities, with many African Americans and Hispanics being disproportionately affected. Trump's actions have been criticized as divisive and authoritarian, and opinion polls suggest he is losing public support, particularly among middle-class white Americans.

site_title: SCI to hive off Sembmarine to its shareholders; latter plans S$2.1b rights
summary: Sembcorp Industries (SCI) and its marine arm Sembcorp Marine (SMM) have agreed to a S$2.1 billion recapitalization deal for SMM, including a demerger from each other with Singapore's Temasek Holdings taking a direct stake in SMM. SCI will subscribe to its S$1.5 billion pro-rata entitlement, while Temasek will backstop the remaining S$600 million rights issue. The deal aims to boost both companies' financial positions and unlock shareholder value. SMM seeks to raise funds to improve its cash position and strengthen its balance sheet, while SCI will become a focused energy and urban business.

site_title: US warns against dealing with top Iran shipper
summary: The US Treasury Department imposed sanctions on Iran's top shipping company, IRISL, and its Shanghai-based subsidiary E-Sail, citing their role in supporting Tehran's contested weapons programs. The sanctions, which came into effect on June 8, 2020, threaten unilateral action against any government, business, or person doing business with IRISL. The move is seen as a tightening of US sanctions, which aim to prevent Iran from acquiring proliferation-sensitive items. The US urges countries worldwide to investigate and take action to halt IRISL's activities.

images.alt_text: The Treasury Department said sanctions came into effect Monday against the Islamic Republic of Iran Shipping Lines, known by its acronym IRISL, as well as its Shanghai-based subsidiary E-Sail.

site_title: Japan's economy shrinks less than expected in Q1
summary: Japan's economy shrank 2.2% in the first quarter, less than the 3.4% contraction initially estimated, but still indicating a recession for the first time in 4.5 years. The country's economy contracted 0.6% on a quarter-on-quarter basis. Despite some gains in business spending, private consumption fell 0.8% due to declines in spending on services. Analysts expect the economy to suffer a 20% annualized contraction in April-June due to the coronavirus pandemic's impact globally and domestically.

site_title: Trump readying to resume his signature rallies: campaign
summary: President Donald Trump is set to resume his signature rallies in the next two weeks, his campaign announced, as the Republican seeks to recover from multiple crises ahead of the 2024 election. The rallies, which were halted in March due to the coronavirus lockdown, will feature venue ideas and measures to prevent coronavirus transmission. Trump has relied on rallies to project his brand of populist nationalism and draw large crowds, and their restart is seen as a crucial part of his reelection campaign.

site_title: Hong Kong seethes one year on, but protesters on the back foot
summary: Hong Kong marks one year since pro-democracy protests began on June 9, 2019, but a city-wide resumption of unrest is unlikely due to mass arrests, coronavirus restrictions, and a looming national security law. The protests, sparked by a bill allowing extraditions to China, left the city's reputation in tatters and a population divided. With no clear end in sight, activists are on the back foot as the city's stability and freedoms are increasingly threatened.

site_title: Jinke Properties unit gears up for US$500m HK IPO
summary: Jinke Properties Group, a Shenzhen-listed developer, is gearing up for a US$500 million initial public offering (IPO) in Hong Kong through its property management unit. CLSA and Huatai International Financial Holdings have been selected to work on the listing plans. The unit manages nearly 800 projects in 20 provinces in China, with revenue of about 2.8 billion yuan and net income of 406 million yuan. This is part of a trend of Chinese developers spinning off their property management arms, with Jinke joining others such as KWG Group Holdings and Excellence Group.

site_title: US: Wall Street leads global stock rally, with Nasdaq at record high
summary: US stocks surged on Monday, with the Nasdaq hitting a new record and the S&P 500 erasing its annual losses. The rally was driven by positive expectations of a global economic recovery and companies hit hard by lockdowns, such as United Airlines and American Airlines, seeing increased demand. Asian equities also rose, despite some European markets ending mildly negative. Analysts attribute the momentum to a "bull cycle" and "risk appetite" remaining, with the path of least resistance seen as "up".

images.alt_text: Wall Street indices powered to a strong finish on Monday, with Nasdaq hitting a new record and the S&P 500 erasing its losses for the year despite the ongoing coronavirus tumult.

site_title: Oil falls 3% despite Opec+ cuts as Gulf ends voluntary curbs
summary: Oil prices fell 3% on Monday after Opec+ nations agreed to extend output cuts, but Saudi Arabia and other Gulf producers said they would not maintain supplemental reductions. This decision came despite the group's previous agreement to cut supply by 9.7 million barrels per day in May and June to support prices. Brent crude fell to $40.80 a barrel, and US West Texas Intermediate crude fell to $38.19 a barrel. The decline in oil prices comes as the global demand remains low due to the coronavirus lockdowns.

site_title: Trust in VPN is good, but zero-trust mindset is better
summary: A growing trend towards remote work has highlighted the limitations of traditional VPNs, which often provide unsecured access to corporate resources. As more employees work from home, VPNs can become bottlenecks, leading to slow speeds and increased security risks. A zero-trust mindset, which verifies users and devices before granting access, is a more effective approach to securing remote access and protecting company data. Zero-trust solutions, such as virtual workspace platforms, utilize machine learning and multi-factor authentication to quickly detect and respond to security threats, providing a faster and more targeted reaction.

site_title: Europe: Stocks take a breather as tech, healthcare weigh
summary: European shares closed 0.3% lower on Monday, halting a recent rally, as technology and healthcare stocks declined. The Stoxx 600 index fell 0.6% due to AstraZeneca's 2.7% drop after a potential merger with Gilead Sciences. Euro zone banks jumped 2% after the European Central Bank's bigger-than-expected pandemic-related stimulus. Despite the decline, euro zone stocks have rallied 39% from March lows, and the broader European index has climbed 33%.

site_title: Money FM podcast: Singapore's reopening, new legal developments and REITs
summary: Singapore's economy slowly reopens, and investors are looking at REITs for better investments. In a Money FM podcast, host Michelle Martin discussed REITs with Gabriel Yap, chairman of GCP Global. Key takeaways include Asia's potential to drive and gain from dollar asset diversification. Meanwhile, a low-profile property trust is exploring a data centre gambit, and Ant, backed by Jack Ma, plans to add a stablecoin to its global network. Amundi expects retail investors to drive massive ETF growth in Asia and Europe.

site_title: Virus spares no one - but telco yields still offer attractive shelter
summary: Singapore's three telcos, Singtel, StarHub, and NetLink NBN Trust, have seen a -4.7% average return this year, outperforming the Straits Times Index's -11.5%. Despite poor year-on-year earnings and dividend cuts, analysts predict a 5-6% yield for Singtel and 4% for StarHub, citing the telcos' defensive nature and steady cash flows. The sector's resilience in a downturn is attributed to the essential nature of its services, with Fitch Ratings' Janice Chong stating that telcos will be more resilient than other sectors.

site_title: The pandemic is changing the role of innovation hubs
summary: The COVID-19 pandemic has significantly impacted startups, with 41% having three months or less of cash runway left and 74% experiencing revenue decline. However, innovation hubs and accelerators are playing a crucial role in supporting entrepreneurs by providing access to expert advice, collaboration, and resources. These hubs have hosted numerous webinars and virtual events to help startups navigate the crisis and have enabled agility, pivoting, and innovation. Governments are also committing funds to support promising startups, and innovation hubs will continue to play a key role in identifying and empowering long-term winners in the post-pandemic economy.

site_title: Partial award issued in arbitration over share-purchase dispute: SingPost
summary: A partial award has been issued in an arbitration filed by SingPost over a share-purchase dispute with Tan Ho Sung, relating to Famous Holdings (FHPL) and its subsidiaries. The arbitration pertains to a share-purchase agreement and shareholders' agreement. Various claims against SingPost have been dismissed in the partial award, which has been issued in this dispute.

site_title: Can GoPlay combine best of China streaming giants and Amazon Prime to beat rivals?
summary: GoPlay, a streaming service by Gojek, aims to combine the best of China's online streaming giants and Amazon Prime to succeed in Indonesia's competitive market. The service bundles content with other Gojek services, such as food and parcel delivery, and has raised US$15 million in fresh capital. GoPlay's CEO Edy Sulistyo is confident that the service can offer localised content that will attract subscribers, despite intense competition from local and international players like Netflix. The company plans to experiment with different content formats to find its unique voice and build audience stickiness.

site_title: Fed says beating pandemic is key, but how will it know things are better?
summary: The US Federal Reserve officials have agreed that containing the COVID-19 pandemic is key to lasting economic progress, but policymakers are divided on the trajectory of the pandemic and its impact on the economy. Despite a surprise job gain of over 2.5 million in May, the Fed is concerned about the potential for a second wave of infections and its effect on consumer confidence. The Fed will release its economic projections on Wednesday, which will provide insight into its views on the pandemic's trajectory and the economy's recovery.

site_title: Oil advances near US$43 after Opec+ extends production cuts
summary: Oil prices rose near US$43 a barrel after Opec+ agreed to extend production cuts by an extra month, promising stricter compliance to ensure members don't pump more than they pledged. Saudi Arabia made significant hikes to the price of its crude, with the steepest increases hitting July exports to Asia. The extension aims to shore up oil markets globally, but a sustained recovery may be hampered by deteriorating relations between Washington and Beijing, or returning US shale supply.

site_title: Joyful Ardern declares NZ virus victory
summary: New Zealand has lifted all domestic coronavirus restrictions after its final Covid-19 patient was given the all clear, with Prime Minister Jacinda Ardern declaring the country has eliminated transmission of the virus for now. The nation of 5 million has had 1,154 confirmed cases and 22 deaths, with no new infections for 17 days. Strict border controls will remain in place, but restrictions on social distancing and public gatherings are no longer needed, allowing nightclubs and theatres to reopen, and sporting events to proceed with crowds in the stands.

site_title: Russia reopens borders for its nationals to work, study and get treatment abroad
summary: Russia has reopened its borders to its nationals for work, study, and medical treatment abroad, allowing them to resume international travel since late March. Moscow will also ease restrictions, including lifting a digital pass system and self-isolation regime, starting from Tuesday. Residents can now go out for walks and restaurants and cafes in the city will reopen their summer verandas from June 16.

site_title: Tackling Covid-19 and its fallout
summary: Singapore is tackling Covid-19's fallout with various initiatives. A centre is being set up to advance sustainable aviation in Asia-Pacific. The government also announced a visit by Deputy Prime Minister Gan to the US for trade talks and a new grant of up to S$100,000 for tariff-hit businesses. Additionally, a study suggests Singapore has the potential to become a global hub for advanced chip packaging. The government is also urging graduates to future-proof their careers before a crisis strikes.

site_title: Crowds define opera. They're also keeping it from returning
summary: The Metropolitan Opera's upcoming season has been canceled due to the coronavirus pandemic, leaving opera fans without their usual experience of crowds and live performances. Opera is deeply rooted in the energy and mystique of live music, with crowds playing a crucial role in defining the art form. The Met's nearly 4,000-seat theater is usually packed for performances, and the cancellation will be a significant blow to the opera community. The pandemic's impact on the livelihoods of artists and staff is also being felt, highlighting the devastating consequences of the shutdown.

site_title: MAS interviewing EHT's current, former directors
summary: MAS is conducting a joint investigation with the Singapore Police Force's Commercial Affairs Department into suspected breaches of disclosure requirements by Eagle Hospitality Trust's (EHT) directors. The investigation, sparked by a referral from Singapore Exchange Regulation, relates to EHT's real estate investment trust (Reit) issues. Former and current directors have been or will be interviewed. The review of Far East Consortium International Limited's (FECIL) application for EHT's Reit manager is also ongoing. Trading in EHT stapled securities remains suspended.

site_title: Is the current US foreign policy on the right track?
summary: US President Donald Trump's administration has departed from the country's long-standing tradition of a moral foreign policy, instead prioritizing "America first" and limited military interventions. This departure has sparked debate over the meaning of American exceptionalism and its role in promoting liberal values and international cooperation. A recent poll shows that more than two-thirds of Americans want an outward-oriented foreign policy, but the US is struggling to balance its desire for independence with its need for global cooperation to address challenges such as climate change and pandemics.

site_title: Firms know rethinking business models needed; government support isn't forever
summary: Deputy Prime Minister Heng Swee Keat stated that business leaders in Singapore acknowledge the government's efforts to preserve jobs during the Covid-19 crisis are not sustainable forever. This comes after a meeting with the Future Economy Council and the Singapore Business Federation, who expressed a realistic view that the government cannot support companies indefinitely.

site_title: STI up a further 1.65% on stronger data from US and China
summary: Singapore's Straits Times Index (STI) rose 1.65% to 2,796.97 points, following stronger-than-expected US job numbers and a smaller-than-expected export decline in China, which boosted Asian stock markets. The STI performance was in line with regional key indices, with Japan's Nikkei 225 and Indonesia's Jakarta Composite Index also rising. United Overseas Bank (UOB) was a top performer, while Venture Corp was the worst performer.

site_title: Frustration, not fortitude, in the restaurant business
summary: Singapore's government has been providing rental reliefs to restaurants affected by the COVID-19 pandemic. However, the industry is struggling to stay afloat, and some argue that restaurants should be able to opt out of their leases without default. The concept of "frustration" in law may apply, allowing restaurants to discharge their leases prospectively. This would mean they can recover security deposits and use the rental reliefs to calculate rent for using leased premises after the time of frustration. While force majeure clauses in leases may also provide a lifeline, they are often strictly construed and may not cover unforeseen events like the pandemic.

site_title: How HK behaves now likely to affect post-2047 status: official
summary: A Chinese official, Zhang Xiaoming, suggested that Hong Kong's post-2047 status may be affected by its current behavior, particularly in relation to the city's response to Beijing's plans to impose new security laws. Pro-democracy demonstrators have taken to the streets, and Beijing sees these protests as a threat to national security. The official indicated that a stronger commitment to national security could lead to a more favorable post-2047 arrangement under the "one country, two systems" agreement. This stance suggests that Hong Kong's future autonomy may depend on its ability to balance national security concerns with its own freedoms.

site_title: Singapore has to adapt to vast changes from Covid-19
summary: Deputy Prime Minister Heng Swee Keat warned Singapore faces an "unprecedented level" of uncertainty due to the Covid-19 pandemic, which will radically change the shape of globalisation, trade, and the future of work. He predicted significant job losses, particularly in sectors like aviation, tourism, and retail, and emphasized the need for Singapore to adapt quickly to new economic models. With the country heading towards its next general election, Heng sees the election as a test of Singapore's ability to overcome the pandemic and emerge stronger, with the next 5-10 years defining the nation's future.

site_title: China cosmetic brands see rally despite global beauty downturn
summary: China's low-cost, online-savvy cosmetic brands have seen significant gains despite the global beauty downturn. Proya Cosmetics Co has surged 88% this year, reaching a record high in May, while Guangdong Marubi Biotechnology Co has risen 42%. These local brands' cheaper products and online-focused sales platforms suit the Covid-19 reality of consumers staying at home and avoiding public places. Analysts attribute their success to their mastery of live-streaming e-commerce and influencer partnerships, but question whether their short-term gains will translate to long-term success in the Chinese beauty market.

site_title: Gulf mall operators rein in expansion as retailers reel from Covid-19
summary: Mall operators in the Gulf region, including Majid Al Futtaim and Emaar Malls, are delaying new projects due to the impact of the coronavirus pandemic and low oil prices. Retailers are struggling with reduced foot traffic and liquidity issues, with some predicting a 20-40% drop in sales this year. The pandemic has accelerated the shift to online sales, with many malls offering digital platforms for shops to sell products online. Operators are revisiting timelines and adapting to the changing retail landscape, with some predicting a meaningful recovery in 18-24 months.

site_title: Airbnb, vacation-rental sites see surge in summer demand
summary: Airbnb and other vacation-rental sites are experiencing a surge in summer demand, with bookings for US listings increasing by 30% compared to the same period in 2019. The company saw a significant boost in domestic travel globally, with a 50% increase in bookings within 322km of a destination. Other companies, such as Expedia Group's Vrbo and Booking Holdings, are also seeing a jump in domestic vacation-rental reservations. The rebound is attributed to people seeking open spaces and a desire to avoid crowded areas, with hotels seeing a decline in bookings.

site_title: Anticipation and uncertainty across the Causeway
summary: Malaysia is poised for a general election, with Umno, a major partner in the ruling Perikatan Nasional coalition, indicating readiness to challenge the Pakatan Harapan coalition. Umno's goal is to prevent the Pakatan Harapan coalition from regaining a parliamentary majority. The country's economy has been severely impacted by the COVID-19 pandemic, with Prime Minister Muhyiddin Yassin's government rolling out a RM260 billion stimulus package. The situation is further complicated by the potential for illegal immigrants to pose a coronavirus risk, and the uncertainty surrounding joint projects with Singapore, including the High Speed Rail and Mass Transit lines.

site_title: Creative rallies to 1-year high after Super X-Fi online launch
summary: Creative Technology's shares surged 19.9% to a one-year high of S$3.92 after launching its Super X-Fi products in China via live-streaming. The stock closed at S$3.66, with over 2.3 million shares traded. This follows a 42.2% jump on Friday after the online launch. The Super X-Fi technology promises "holographic audio" and has been described as "mind-blowing" and "magical". CEO Sim Wong Hoo said the technology is suitable for working, learning, and playing during the pandemic.

site_title: Indonesian retailers brace for gradual recovery as stores reopen
summary: Indonesia's capital, Jakarta, has reopened retail stores, restaurants, and offices after a two-month lockdown due to the coronavirus pandemic. The city's online services, including motorcycle taxis, have also resumed. The number of visitors to dine-in restaurants and retail stores is limited to 50% capacity under a new health protocol. Retailers and food establishments expect a gradual recovery, with predicted 3-4% growth in full-year sales. The government has also announced plans to reopen the country to foreign tourism by September and domestic holidaymakers by the end of July.

site_title: Changing hands
summary: Singapore's OCBC CEO Helen Wong is retiring and will be succeeded by Tan Teck Long. Sats CEO Kerry Mok received a 30.5% pay hike to S$3.1 million. China's GDP growth is expected to slow, putting pressure on policymakers. Tesla marked its formal entry into India with a launch event in Mumbai. Citigroup has set a mid-2026 target of 1,150 for MSCI's global equity index. Analysts are optimistic about SGX earnings, raising target prices, citing a defensive play benefiting from volatility. Chinese banks are struggling due to Beijing's consumer lending push.

site_title: Elections Department spells out safe voting measures
summary: The Elections Department of Singapore has outlined measures to ensure safe voting during the upcoming general election, which could be held during the COVID-19 pandemic. The measures include reducing the number of voters in polling stations, temperature screening, and increased use of the SafeEntry app for contact tracing. Senior voters will also have a longer time frame to cast their ballots, and campaigning guidelines will be released soon, with a focus on minimizing large group gatherings. The number of polling stations will be increased to 1,100, and voters will be required to wear masks and sanitize their hands before voting.

site_title: Ho Bee Land buys two residential sites in Australia for A$23.5m
summary: Ho Bee Land, a Singaporean developer, has acquired two residential sites in Australia for a total of A$23.5 million. The sites, one in Queensland valued at A$14.5 million and another at A$9 million, are expected to yield approximately 570 and 95 residential lots, respectively. The projects are financed by internal funds and bank borrowings and are not expected to impact Ho Bee's earnings and net tangible assets per share for the financial year ending December 31, 2020.

site_title: Best World independent auditor issues disclaimer of opinion
summary: Best World International, a premium skincare products seller, has received a disclaimer of opinion from independent auditor Ernst & Young (EY) due to insufficient audit evidence on financial statements for 2018. The issue relates to matters disclosed in Note 2.1, including potential unrecorded transactions and the group's relationship with import agents and marketing agents. The independent review is ongoing, and Best World will provide clarifications in due course. Trading in the company's shares has been suspended since May 2019.

site_title: UK kicks off quarantine that will further slam airlines
summary: The UK is implementing a two-week quarantine for international arrivals, starting June 8, which airlines British Airways, EasyJet, and Ryanair have threatened to sue over, claiming it will be ineffective in curtailing Covid-19 and devastating tourism. The quarantine will impact thousands of jobs, with London's Heathrow airport warning of staff cuts if the government doesn't indicate when the rule will be relaxed. Airlines fear the move will deter bookings, while the government defends the measure as part of its strategy to avoid a second wave of infections.

site_title: Corporate digest
summary: Ascott Residence Trust (ART) will be included in the FTSE EPRA Nareit Global Real Estate Index Series starting June 22. Bonvests Holdings CEO Helen Wong is set to retire, with Tan Teck Long named as her successor. Sats CEO Kerry Mok saw a 30.5% pay hike to S$3.1 million. China's GDP growth is expected to slow, raising pressure on policymakers. Tesla marked its formal entry into India with a Mumbai launch event. Citigroup aims to reach 1,150 for MSCI's global equity index by mid-2026.

site_title: Goldman reprises Democratic tax-hike worry after stock surge
summary: Goldman Sachs strategists have revived concerns about the Democratic party's tax-hike policy platform, citing potential negative impacts on the economy. Former Vice-President Joe Biden's proposal to partially reverse the 2017 Tax Cuts and Jobs Act could reduce S&P 500 earnings estimates by $20 per share, according to Goldman. Companies with high effective tax rates, such as Boeing and Visa, are at risk from a tax-law revamp, and the chances of enacting such legislation are uncertain due to the close electoral race and difficulty in passing tax overhaul legislation.

site_title: WHO head urges world not to let up on Covid battle
summary: The World Health Organization (WHO) urged countries to continue battling the COVID-19 pandemic, despite it not having peaked in Central America. WHO Director-General Tedros Adhanom Ghebreyesus stated that the pandemic is worsening globally, with over seven million infected and 400,000 deaths. Experts emphasized the need for a comprehensive approach to prevent second peaks, with a focus on South America and Central America. The WHO warned that the pandemic is "far from over."

site_title: Online lectures here to stay, but campus classes will survive too
summary: Remote instruction is likely to remain a staple of online learning, despite initial concerns about its quality. Economies of scale favor remote courses, as fixed costs per student decrease with volume, allowing for significant improvements in quality over time. While campus classes will continue to exist, especially for specialized courses, the shift to remote learning will accelerate, driven by the Matthew Effect, where successful remote courses refine their offerings and further expand their market share. This trend is poised to increase economic prosperity but may also exacerbate inequality.

site_title: SIA slips on first day of rights shares trading; carrier secures over S$1b of credit facilities
summary: Singapore Airlines (SIA) raised over S$1 billion in credit facilities, in addition to S$8.8 billion from its recent rights issue, to tackle the challenges of the global Covid-19 outbreak. The airline secured over S$1.7 billion in liquidity, with options to raise an additional S$6.2 billion. SIA also implemented enhanced health and safety measures, including face masks, hand sanitizers, and ultra-violet light cleaning procedures, for its passengers and crew.

site_title: Singapore in talks with Malaysia about resuming cross-border work travel
summary: Singapore and Malaysia are in talks to resume cross-border work travel, with discussions focusing on protocols, industries, and testing requirements. The two countries aim to allow Malaysians to travel into Singapore for work in a safe manner, with testing and quarantine measures to be implemented. The number of people allowed to enter, industries to be prioritized, and testing protocols will be discussed with the Malaysian government.

site_title: Thailand plans extra stimulus measures to support virus-hit economy
summary: Thailand plans to introduce additional stimulus measures in the third quarter to boost domestic consumption and tourism, which have been hit by the coronavirus outbreak. The measures aim to encourage spending and follow billions of dollars of economic packages. The Bank for Agriculture and Agricultural Cooperatives will offer soft loans to help restore the farm sector. This move comes as Thailand's economy is expected to show the deepest contraction since the 1997-98 Asian financial crisis.

site_title: Democratic lawmakers unveil sweeping bill on race, police in wake of Floyd death
summary: Democratic lawmakers unveiled a sweeping bill to combat police violence and racial injustice, following George Floyd's death. The bill would limit qualified immunity for police misconduct victims and make lynching a federal hate crime. Democrats aim to pass the legislation in the House by the end of June, but its reception in the Republican-controlled Senate is uncertain. Senate Majority Leader Mitch McConnell remains noncommittal on the need for legislation.

site_title: Investors pile into African assets, unconcerned about virus spreading
summary: Investors are pouring into African assets despite the ongoing coronavirus pandemic, driven by global stimulus and a search for yield. Since May, African stock markets, currencies, and bonds have seen significant growth, with investors seemingly unconcerned about the economic and health consequences of the pandemic. This trend is attributed to unprecedented stimulus from governments and central banks worldwide, which has driven down the dollar and fueled a reawakening of investment in emerging markets.

site_title: ECB's Lagarde defends 'proportionate' bond buys against German challenge
summary: European Central Bank (ECB) President Christine Lagarde defended the bank's aggressive stimulus measures, saying they are proportionate to the risk faced by the eurozone. The ECB has been buying massive amounts of government bonds to combat the coronavirus pandemic, but Germany's constitutional court has given it three months to justify these measures. Lagarde emphasized that the ECB took into account "proportionality" and carried out a "cost-benefit analysis" when making decisions. The ECB's Pandemic Emergency Purchase Programme (PEPP) has been expanded to 1.35 trillion euros until June 2021.

site_title: CapitaLand to further waive, defer rent for SMEs, expects financial performance to be hit
summary: CapitaLand, a Singaporean property giant, will further waive and defer rent for qualifying small and medium-sized enterprise (SME) tenants amid the COVID-19 pandemic. The move is in line with the latest government regulations, which require landlords to provide additional rental relief to SMEs. The financial strain from these measures is expected to have an adverse impact on CapitaLand's financial performance this year.

site_title: Hotelier Amara Holdings expects 'severe' hit on earnings this year
summary: Hotelier Amara Holdings expects a "severe" hit on earnings this year due to global travel restrictions and safe-distancing measures. The company's hotel-room revenue is expected to be impacted, with local guests contributing only 23% of its revenue before the pandemic. Amara remains optimistic about the hotel industry's prospects over a longer horizon and plans to conserve resources to prepare for the post-pandemic recovery. The company's share price has recovered to 85% of its pre-pandemic level, and it will focus on recurring income streams through its three inter-related segments.

site_title: Singapore, France agree to keep supply chains for essential food open and connected
summary: Singapore and France have agreed to maintain open and connected supply chains for essential food supplies during the Covid-19 pandemic. The agreement, made through a joint statement by Singapore's Trade and Industry Minister Chan Chun Sing and France's Minister of Agriculture and Food Didier Guillaume, aims to ensure the flow of essential food and agricultural products for food security. Both countries will work together to facilitate partnerships and collaboration between food companies, importers, and distributors.

site_title: Saudi Arabia considers limiting haj pilgrims amid Covid-19 fears
summary: Saudi Arabia considers limiting haj pilgrims amid Covid-19 fears due to over 100,000 cases in the country. The annual haj pilgrimage, attended by 2.5 million pilgrims, may be restricted to "symbolic numbers" with age and health restrictions, and up to 20% of regular quotas. Authorities are also considering cancelling the haj, which could further pressure the government's finances hit by the pandemic and oil price decline. The move could affect the kingdom's $12 billion annual revenue from haj and umrah pilgrimages.

site_title: World Bank says coronavirus to shrink 2020 global output by 5.2%
summary: The World Bank predicts a 5.2% global economic contraction in 2020 due to the coronavirus pandemic, with advanced economies expected to shrink 7% and emerging markets to contract 2.5%. This is deeper than the IMF's April forecast of a 3% global contraction. The World Bank warns that a prolonged lockdown scenario could deepen the contraction to 8-10% in advanced economies and 5% in emerging markets, leading to a sluggish recovery in 2021. The report also estimates 70-100 million people will be pushed into extreme poverty.

site_title: Volkswagen supervisory board to discuss VW brand leadership: sources
summary: Volkswagen's supervisory board will discuss the leadership of the company's core VW brand at an extraordinary meeting. Herbert Diess, the current head of the VW brand, will retain his role as CEO of the Volkswagen Group, but faces opposition from labour leaders who control nine of the 19 seats on the supervisory board. Diess is pushing to cut costs to invest in electric and autonomous cars, and his grip on the company seems to have increased after a market manipulation probe against him was dropped. The outcome of the meeting is uncertain.

site_title: One third of 2019 Swiss investment sustainable, study finds
summary: A study by the Swiss Sustainable Finance association and the University of Zurich's Center for Sustainable Finance and Private Wealth found that approximately one-third of assets managed in Switzerland in 2019 were invested sustainably, a 62% increase from the previous year. The total value of sustainable investments reached 1.16 trillion Swiss francs, with institutional clients holding 79% of these assets. While progress has been made, industry executives acknowledge that more work is needed to establish Switzerland as a leading sustainable financial center.

site_title: A world redrawn: Isabel Allende hopes pandemic will doom patriarchy
summary: Chilean author Isabel Allende hopes the COVID-19 pandemic will lead to a new world order where men and women share equally in power, with solidarity, compassion, and hope. She believes the pandemic has exposed stark inequalities that will continue to fuel protests globally, particularly in the US. Allende, who has written extensively on feminism, envisions a post-pandemic world free from patriarchy and violence, where creativity, artists, and scientists work together to build a better future for all.

site_title: German cabinet speeds up stimulus package
summary: Germany's cabinet is speeding up the implementation of its 130 billion-euro stimulus package to support the country's economy, which has been devastated by the coronavirus pandemic. The package includes temporary cuts in value-added tax, cash handouts for parents, and incentives to buy electric cars. The cabinet aims to pass large parts of the package during an extraordinary meeting on Friday, following marathon negotiations. The move comes after record-low industrial output in April, which forced manufacturers to halt production.

site_title: ECB seeks to identify polluters in push for green finance system
summary: The European Central Bank (ECB) has submitted a proposal to the European Commission to identify companies that harm the environment, known as "brown" activities, to better manage climate-related risks in the financial system. The move aims to address a data gap in tracking sustainable and unsustainable activities. The ECB believes banks and asset managers can only play a supporting role in reducing greenhouse gas emissions, and that fiscal measures like carbon pricing are necessary to drive change. The proposal is part of the EU's push to green the financial system and become climate-neutral by the middle of the century.

site_title: India plans to hike edible oil import taxes to boost local supply: sources
summary: India is considering a tax hike on edible oil imports to boost local oilseed production, aiming to reduce its reliance on overseas purchases. The proposed 5% tax increase would curb imports of vegetable oils, including palm oil, and prop up local prices of oilseeds such as rapeseed, soybean, and ground nut. The move is part of Prime Minister Narendra Modi's push for self-reliance, with the goal of increasing oilseed production and reducing imports, which currently account for 70% of India's edible oil needs.

site_title: Japan hopes to draft G-7 joint statement on China security legislation on Hong Kong: source
summary: Japan plans to draft a joint G-7 statement on China's new security legislation for Hong Kong, following Prime Minister Shinzo Abe's concerns about the city's autonomy and freedoms. Japan decided not to join other countries in a statement criticizing China, citing "short notice" and a focus on G-7 efforts. The country has already expressed its concerns to China directly and has received no complaints. Japan's move comes amid the country's sensitive situation regarding US-China tensions over Hong Kong, with a state visit by Chinese President Xi Jinping planned for the future.

site_title: US troop plans 'shake transatlantic relationship', Merkel ally says
