summary: US President Donald Trump plans to withdraw 9,500 troops from Germany, reducing the US contingent to 25,000, according to a senior US official. The move has sparked controversy in Germany, with Defence Minister Annegret Kramp-Karrenbauer stating that US troops serve the entire security of the NATO alliance. German coordinator for transatlantic ties, Peter Beyer, described the decision as "shaking the pillars of the transatlantic relationship", citing concerns about weakening the West in the face of China. The move has strained relations between Berlin and Washington.

site_title: Spain's economy heads for recession with sharp Q2 contraction, Bank of Spain says
summary: Spain's economy is expected to contract by 16-21.8% in Q2 due to the Covid-19 pandemic, leading to a recession. The Bank of Spain forecasts a 9-11.6% overall contraction for 2020, with a more severe scenario of a 15.1% contraction possible if new infections persist. The economy is expected to start recovering in the second half of the year, but uncertainty remains due to ongoing lockdown measures.

site_title: Chinese liquor makers seek listings as investors keep spirits up
summary: Chinese liquor makers Sichuan Langjiu and Guizhou Guotai Liquor have sought listings in China, following a surge in investor enthusiasm for spirit makers. Both companies plan to use IPO proceeds for production and working capital. Industry bellwethers Kweichow Moutai and Wuliangye have scaled new highs, with Moutai's market value now second only to Industrial And Commercial Bank Of China. Analysts attribute Langjiu's profit surge to price rises and lower advertising costs, as investors expect further stimulus to boost domestic demand.

site_title: Austria strikes 450m euro bailout deal for Lufthansa unit: sources
summary: Austria has agreed to a 450 million euro bailout package for Lufthansa unit Austrian Airlines, consisting of 300 million euros in guaranteed loans and 150 million euros in grants. This is significantly smaller than the 767 million euros initially requested. The package comes after a 9-billion euro deal between Austrian's parent company Lufthansa and the German government. Lufthansa will also provide an additional 150 million euro grant.

site_title: Crane builder Yongmao expects 'significantly' lower net profit on lower revenue in China
summary: Crane builder Yongmao Holdings expects a "significantly lower" net profit in the second half of 2020 due to lower revenue in China, largely attributed to the national lockdown to combat the Covid-19 pandemic. The firm's production plants in China resumed operation on February 10 but have not been operating at optimal capacity due to new health and safety measures. Yongmao recorded a one-off obsolescence stocks adjustment and write-off, as well as higher cost of goods sold in the second half of 2020. The company's shares closed flat at S$0.93 on Monday.

site_title: US: Wall Street opens higher on economic rebound hopes
summary: US stocks opened higher on Monday, building on last week's rally, after a surprise rebound in jobs bolstered views that the US economy has weathered the Covid-19 pandemic's economic fallout. The Dow Jones rose 121.95 points, the S&P 500 opened 5.99 points higher, and the Nasdaq Composite gained 9.36 points. This follows a jobs report showing a surprise increase in employment, boosting investor confidence in the economy's recovery.

site_title: Omnisense Systems keeps its cool as fever scanner market heats up
summary: Omnisense Systems has seen a significant increase in sales of its thermal fever scanner, the Sentry MK IV Mass Fever Screening System, with orders totaling S$8 million at end-April. The company has ramped up its production capacity by five times to meet demand from reputable customers, including Changi Airport. CEO Leonard Lim credits the surge in sales to the COVID-19 pandemic, stating that the company has benefited from the situation despite not initially aiming to profit from it.

images.alt_text: Leonard Lim, founder and CEO of Omnisense Systems, prioritises the user experience and aesthetic design of his system, so users know they have a complete, well-designed product.

site_title: Competition inviting pitches from startups returns with new Covid-19 track
summary: Enterprise Singapore's Slingshot 2020 competition is now open, inviting startups to pitch their ideas for a chance to win over S$800,000 in prizes. The competition includes a new Covid-19 track, a corporate innovation platform, and a grand prize of a S$200,000 Startup SG grant and S$10,000 in cash from L'Oréal. The top 500 start-ups will connect with innovation players and stand a chance to win grants and co-innovation projects with corporates in Singapore. The competition will close on Aug 24 and the finals will take place virtually as part of the Singapore Week of Innovation and Technology from Nov 9-13.

site_title: Hong Kong: Stocks finish with small gains
summary: Hong Kong stocks finished with small gains, marking a sixth consecutive rise, following a surprise jump in US jobs creation. The Hang Seng Index increased 6.36 points to 24,776.77, while the Shanghai Composite Index rose 0.24%. Gains were capped by profit-taking.

site_title: Average GDP in Asean could bounce back to 8% by 2021: ICAEW report
summary: Economic growth in the Asean region is forecast to rebound to an average 8% in 2021, driven by recovery in Chinese import demand and global trade. The region fell into recession in the first half of 2020, but most South-east Asian economies are expected to recover in the second half. Vietnam is predicted to be the least affected, while Thailand is expected to be one of the worst hit due to its reliance on tourism. Global GDP is expected to shrink by 4.7% due to the Covid-19 pandemic.

site_title: Construction, marine and process sectors identified for Covid-19 surveillance testing
summary: Singapore to set up more Covid-19 surveillance testing centers in construction, marine, and process sectors, targeting groups with higher infection rates. The Health Promotion Board will establish regional screening centers (RSCs) in various locations, prioritizing workers in these sectors. Testing will also be expanded to individuals with acute respiratory infections, including seniors, healthcare workers, and older students. The Ministry of Health emphasizes the importance of maintaining strong infection-control measures, including safe distancing and good hygiene, to prevent transmission.

site_title: Australia says China unresponsive to its pleas to ease tensions
summary: Australia has reported that China remains unresponsive to its pleas to ease tensions between the two countries, despite weeks of requests for discussion. The tensions escalated after Australia called for an international inquiry into the origins of the novel coronavirus. China has accused Australia of playing "petty tricks" and has imposed tariffs on Australian barley and suspended beef imports. The Australian Trade Minister, Simon Birmingham, said Beijing has been ignoring Canberra's pleas, and a recent poll showed 79% of Australians backed a global coronavirus investigation.

site_title: Married couple share German ambassador role
summary: Germany's foreign ministry has appointed a married couple, Natalie Kauther and Adrian Pollmann, to share the ambassador's role in Slovenia for four years starting from August. Both 45 and 43 years old, they have been working for the ministry since 2005 and were seeking a family-friendly arrangement due to their three children. The couple will take turns holding the post, with Mr. Pollmann serving first for eight months and Ms. Kauther taking over for eight months. This unique arrangement is the first of its kind for Germany and follows a similar model used by Switzerland and France.

site_title: Bonvests Holdings sees 'significant' fall in hotel revenue amid travel curbs
summary: Bonvests Holdings reported a "significant" decline in hotel revenue amid global travel restrictions. The group's rental division has also been impacted, mainly due to the "circuit breaker" restrictions in Singapore. Despite this, Bonvests has sufficient cash holdings and undrawn credit facilities, and may leverage unencumbered hotel properties for new credit facilities. The company expects to report a loss-before-tax for the first half of FY2020 and has implemented measures to conserve cash and reduce costs.

site_title: Saudi Arabia to end voluntary cuts on top of Opec+ pact
summary: Saudi Arabia will end its voluntary 1.18 million barrel per day production cuts in July, increasing output to match its Opec quota, amid signs of global demand recovery. The move comes as the Opec+ pact extends production cuts until the end of July, curbing global supply by almost 10%. Saudi Energy Minister Prince Abdulaziz said the country will pump its Opec quota, with a portion going to domestic consumption, as crude use for power generation increases in the hot summer months. Oil prices rose after the announcement, with Brent crude down 0.3% at US$42.16 per barrel.

site_title: Arbitration over share-purchase dispute issued partial award, says SingPost
summary: SingPost announced that an arbitration panel issued a partial award in a share-purchase dispute with Tan Ho Sung over Famous Holdings (FHPL) and its subsidiaries. The Tribunal dismissed Tan's claims for damages and ruled in SingPost's favor on material accounting and computational issues. The parties will now discuss the final amount payable for the transfer of Tan's remaining shares to SingPost, with the Tribunal reserving the issue of costs for a later date.

site_title: Grab launches B2B programme to help small businesses take digital route
summary: Grab launches a B2B programme to help small businesses in South-east Asia move online and digitalise their operations. The Small Business Booster programme includes tools and initiatives to raise visibility and will roll out a self-serve merchant platform, GrabMerchant, in phases from mid-June. The platform allows business owners to optimise operations, view insights, and create ads with no upfront costs. The goal is to support small businesses and bridge the digital divide, with the potential to expand Grab's ecosystem beyond ride-hailing and capture ad spend.

site_title: Oil major BP to cut 15% of workforce
summary: BP plans to cut 15% of its workforce, approximately 10,000 jobs, as part of CEO Bernard Looney's plan to shift the oil and gas major to renewable energy. The job cuts, mostly senior office-based positions, will be completed by the end of 2020. The company aims to find $2.5 billion in cost savings through digitalisation and integration by 2021. This move is part of Looney's plan to make BP a leaner, faster-moving, and lower-carbon company.

site_title: DocDoc partners insurtech firm Kaitaiming to grow reach in China
summary: DocDoc, a Singapore-based healthtech startup, has partnered with Kaitaiming Technology to expand its reach in China. DocDoc's "doctor-discovery" service will be integrated into Kaitaiming's insurance agent application, enabling the startup to reach policy-holders of top Chinese insurance companies. The partnership aims to reduce medical care costs and complications in China, leveraging DocDoc's predictive analytics and network of over 23,000 doctors. DocDoc currently operates in eight countries and hopes to capitalize on China's massive unmet need for high-quality, affordable care.

site_title: Huawei launches UK advertising blitz ahead of security review
summary: Huawei has launched a UK advertising campaign to highlight its role in building the country's broadband and mobile networks, ahead of a potential security review that could lead to further restrictions. The company's vice president, Victor Zhang, stated that Huawei has been in Britain for 20 years, contributing to the development of 3G and 4G networks, and remains committed to helping the UK's connectivity needs.

site_title: STI up 1.65% on better data from the US and China
summary: Singapore's Straits Times Index (STI) rose 1.65% to 2,796.97 points, driven by better-than-expected job data in the US and a smaller-than-expected export decline in China. This lifted regional markets, including Jakarta's Composite Index and Japan's Nikkei 225, which also saw gains. The upward momentum continued from last week's upward trend.

site_title: Daily Debrief: What Happened Today
summary: SEMBCORP Industries and Sembcorp Marine propose a S$2.1 billion cash call and demerge to rescue the marine giant amid the pandemic. DPM Heng says COVID-19 will accelerate structural changes and the future of work. The government cannot support businesses forever, and firms must rethink their business models. ETF and securities turnover climbed in May due to economic stimulus optimism. The Elections Department lists safety measures for the general election, while SIA raises S$10 billion in liquidity and boosts health measures on flights. The STI rose 1.65% on better-than-expected US and China data.

site_title: Japan to adopt selective, rather than blanket, approach in coronavirus tests
summary: Japan will adopt a selective approach to coronavirus testing, targeting vulnerable individuals and those at high risk, rather than conducting blanket tests. The country's economy minister, Yasutoshi Nishimura, defended the approach, citing the difficulty of testing the entire population and the potential for false negatives. Japan has a daily testing capacity of over 27,000 cases, but is currently conducting around 10,000. The country has avoided a spike in infections, with around 17,200 cases and 900 deaths, compared to the US' 1.9 million cases and 110,000 deaths.

site_title: Heathrow could cut more than 2,000 jobs if quarantine continues
summary: London Heathrow airport may cut over 2,000 jobs if the UK government doesn't relax quarantine rules for incoming passengers. The airport, Europe's busiest, has eliminated a third of operating costs and management posts but may need to cut one-third of its workforce if travel restrictions persist. CEO John Holland-Kaye urged the government to provide clarity on border reopening, warning that British airports and airlines risk losing the entire summer season. The move could impact 25,000 jobs, including 76,000 people employed at the airport.

site_title: Bank of Singapore hires senior UBS banker as new global head of products
summary: Bank of Singapore has appointed veteran banker Lim Leong Guan as its new global head of products, effective immediately. Lim, who spent over two decades at UBS, will lead the bank's product strategy and expand offerings in areas like investment research and wealth planning. He brings 30 years of experience in investments and advisory services. Lim will report to CEO Bahren Shaari and join the bank's management committee.

site_title: MAS launches S$1.8m fintech innovation challenge for Covid-resilient and greener sector
summary: The Monetary Authority of Singapore (MAS) has launched a S$1.8 million competition, the MAS Global FinTech Innovation Challenge, to develop fintech solutions addressing Covid-19 and climate change. The challenge comprises the MAS FinTech Awards and the MAS Global FinTech Hackcelerator, with a total of S$1.2 million in prize money. Fintech firms, financial institutions, and solution providers worldwide are invited to submit innovative solutions. The competition aims to promote fintech for Covid-resilient and greener sectors, with a focus on Asia and globally.

site_title: Singapore's Elections Dept lists safety measures for general election
summary: Singapore's Elections Department has outlined safety measures for the upcoming general election, including reducing voter numbers and barring those with fever or respiratory symptoms from polling stations. Voters will be masked, screened for temperature, and checked for contact tracing. To minimize exposure to unwell voters, special polling stations will be set up for those on Stay-Home Notice. The number of polling stations will be increased to 1,100, with reduced voter numbers. The election must be held by April 2021, with Prime Minister Lee Hsien Loong warning of the need to learn to live with Covid-19.

site_title: Half of Singapore's new Covid-19 cases are symptomless: Lawrence Wong
summary: Singapore's co-head of the virus taskforce, Lawrence Wong, revealed that at least half of the city-state's newly discovered Covid-19 cases show no symptoms. This discovery was made as Singapore ramped up testing, with over 38,000 cases recorded. Wong emphasized the need for a cautious approach in lifting curbs due to the presence of asymptomatic cases, which can still spread the virus. Singapore's gradual reopening of schools and businesses was reinforced, with the majority of recent cases among migrant workers.

site_title: FJ Benjamin ramps up online store network
summary: FJ Benjamin ramps up its online store network after inking agreements with several global brands, including Guess, Casio, and Superdry. The company now runs online stores for five brands and is in talks with or will soon roll out online stores for at least seven other brands, including US Polo Association and Rebecca Minkoff. While the company may consider opening brick-and-mortar stores if online sales prove viable, it will not forsake its physical store network. FJ Benjamin has been impacted by the COVID-19 pandemic, with its market value falling below S$20 million and shares trading flat at S$0.02.

site_title: Firms to rethink business models because govt can't support them forever: DPM Heng
summary: Deputy Prime Minister Heng Swee Keat stated that businesses in Singapore should rethink their models as the government cannot support them forever, especially with the Jobs Support Scheme set to taper off after 10 months. He emphasized the need for businesses to adapt to structural changes such as globalization, digitalization, and a robotic revolution in the labor market, which have been accelerated by the COVID-19 pandemic.

site_title: Europe: Shares pull back from 3-month highs after rally
summary: European shares retreated 0.8% from three-month highs, reversing gains from a strong rally last week on hopes of a post-coronavirus recovery. The decline was led by personal and household goods, healthcare, and retail sectors. Oil majors Royal Dutch Shell, BP, and Total rose as crude prices climbed after major producers agreed to extend record output cuts. AstraZeneca slipped 1.8% after a potential merger with Gilead Sciences, while Wirecard dropped 4.1% amid a market manipulation probe.

site_title: Seoul: Shares gain as upbeat US jobs report fuels rebound hopes
summary: South Korean shares gained for the seventh session, with the Kospi closing up 2.42 points at 2,184.29, as upbeat US employment data boosted hopes of a swift economic recovery. The US nonfarm payrolls rose by 2.51 million jobs in May, offering a clear signal that the Covid-19 pandemic downturn was over. However, blue-chip Samsung Electronics closed lower due to Jay Lee's court appearance. Foreigners were net buyers of 7.50 billion won worth of shares, and the won strengthened against the dollar.

site_title: Ho Bee Land acquires two residential sites in Australia for A$23.5m
summary: Ho Bee Land, a MAINBOARD-LISTED developer, acquired two residential sites in Queensland, Australia, for A$23.5 million. The sites, located in Ripley and the Sunshine Coast, will yield approximately 565 residential lots. The projects are expected to be financed by internal funds and bank borrowings, with no material impact on Ho Bee's earnings and net tangible assets per share for the 2020 financial year. The announcement resulted in a 0.5% increase in Ho Bee's shares to S$2.15.

site_title: Fintech startups Ayannah, ECAPS merge; Singapore-based entity raising up to US$50m
summary: Ayannah, a Philippines-based fintech startup, has merged with ECAPS, an India-based payments company, to form Ayannah Global. The new entity, based in Singapore, aims to provide affordable digital financial services to the growing middle class in South Asia and South-east Asia. Ayannah Global plans to raise US$30-50 million in a Series B round, expanding its reach to over 10 million customers in the Philippines and India, and launching digital marketplaces and savings products in Indonesia and Vietnam.

site_title: Covid-19 to accelerate structural changes and the future of work, says DPM Heng
summary: Deputy Prime Minister Heng Swee Keat stated that the COVID-19 pandemic will accelerate structural changes globally, including the future of work and technology. The city-state needs to quickly adapt to the new economic model, which will require workers to upskill or reskill due to digitalization and changes in globalisation. Heng emphasized the importance of partnerships and collaboration in the new economic model, and believes Singapore has the capabilities to quickly adapt and emerge stronger.

site_title: Japan's service sector sentiment rises 7.6 points in May
summary: Japan's service sector sentiment index rose 7.6 points to 15.5 in May, a Cabinet Office survey showed, despite the ongoing coronavirus pandemic. This marks a significant improvement from the record low in April. The increase in sentiment is attributed to workers' confidence in current economic conditions, which rose to 15.5.

site_title: Ryanair boss says: We'll fly through UK's 'rubbish' quarantine
summary: Ryanair's CEO Michael O'Leary stated that the airline will not cancel flights to and from the UK despite a 14-day quarantine for international travelers. He believes British tourists will continue to book holidays in Europe, but European tourists will be deterred from visiting Britain, harming the domestic tourism industry. O'Leary described the quarantine as "rubbish" and plans to operate flights as usual, despite potential legal action from other airlines.

site_title: South Korea court to rule on arrest warrant for Samsung heir
summary: South Korea's court is set to rule on an arrest warrant for Samsung heir Lee Jae-yong, who is accused of involvement in a 2015 merger of two business units that helped ensure his succession. Lee, 51, is already being retried on charges related to a corruption scandal that brought down former President Park Geun-hye. Prosecutors seek an arrest warrant for Lee on suspicion of price manipulation and illegal trading, a move that could add to the difficulties faced by the Samsung group, a dominant chaebol in South Korea's economy.

site_title: LVMH-backed private equity firm hires ex-TPG veteran in Asia
summary: L Catterton, a US$20 billion consumer-focused private equity firm backed by LVMH, has hired former TPG Capital Asia partner Scott Chen to lead its operations in the region. Chen, a 19-year veteran, will help strike new deals as consumption recovers from Covid-19. The firm has invested in restaurants, bars, and retailers in Asia and plans to raise more money to do deals worldwide. Chen's hiring and internal promotions demonstrate the firm's view that growth remains in the space, with portfolio companies reporting dramatic rebounds in sales and foot traffic.

site_title: New Zealand says coronavirus 'eliminated' and life can resume without restrictions
summary: New Zealand has eliminated domestic transmission of the coronavirus and will lift all containment measures except for border controls, Prime Minister Jacinda Ardern announced. The country, which has reported 1,154 infections and 22 deaths, has gone 75 days without new cases. Ardern said New Zealand has achieved a milestone in stopping the virus's spread, but it's a sustained effort and not a point in time. The country will move to a level one national alert and resume public events, retail, and hospitality industries without social distancing norms, starting Monday.

site_title: HSBC Asia-Pacific chief risk officer to step down
summary: HSBC Asia-Pacific chief risk officer Ed Jenkins is stepping down from his role due to family reasons, effective July 1. Jenkins, who has been with HSBC for over a decade, will take a sabbatical and plans to return in October. Mark McKeown, his predecessor, will handle the role on an interim basis until Jenkins' return.

site_title: Reebok slams CrossFit in outrage over CEO's tweet
summary: Reebok ends its partnership with CrossFit Inc, citing an insensitive comment by CEO Greg Glassman regarding protests against racial injustice. The decision comes after Glassman tweeted "It's FLOYD-19," referencing the death of George Floyd. Reebok, which had been the title sponsor for the 2020 CrossFit Games, will fulfill its current contract obligation before ending the partnership. Other affiliates, including CrossFit Magnus, have also cut ties with CrossFit due to the incident.

site_title: MAS interviews Eagle Hospitality Trust's current, former directors
summary: Eagle Hospitality Trust's current and former directors have been interviewed by the Monetary Authority of Singapore (MAS) as part of a joint investigation into suspected breaches of disclosure requirements under Section 203 of the Securities and Futures Act. The investigation was triggered by a referral from Singapore Exchange Regulation (SGX RegCo) and is related to issues surrounding the trust's real estate investment trust (Reit). Trading in EHT stapled securities was voluntarily suspended on March 24. The outcome of the investigation is yet to be disclosed by MAS.

site_title: 386 new coronavirus cases in Singapore, including 2 in community
summary: Singapore reported 386 new coronavirus cases, including two community cases, on June 8, 2020. Seven new places were added to the Ministry of Health's list of places visited by infected cases. The cases are linked to known clusters, with 384 new cases among migrant workers in dormitories. The daily average for new community cases has increased, and 482 patients were discharged, bringing the total number of recovered patients to 25,359.

site_title: No limit on crowds at New Zealand Super Rugby: organisers
summary: New Zealand is set to host the first unrestricted crowd at a professional sports competition, Super Rugby Aotearoa, this weekend. The decision comes after the country's successful COVID-19 containment measures led to a lifting of domestic restrictions. New Zealand Rugby chief Mark Robinson hailed the move as a "world first," with fans allowed to attend matches in large numbers. The competition, which involves New Zealand's five teams, will be a unique event with no international matches due to border controls. The event is expected to be "special and unique," with teams and fans eager to return to action.

site_title: Norway's domestic liquor sales up 44% in May
summary: Norway's government-run wine and liquor monopoly, Vinmonopolet, reported a 44% increase in domestic liquor sales in May due to coronavirus travel restrictions preventing purchases abroad. The retailer saw overall sales rise by 28% in the January-May period. Private-sector importers, producers, and wholesalers benefited from the border closure, with Arcus stock price rallying 50% after reinstating a dividend payout. The government has maintained quarantines for most foreign travel, with some restrictions lifted for neighboring Denmark.

site_title: Investors pile into Africa unconcerned about virus spreading
summary: Investors are pouring into African assets despite concerns over the ongoing coronavirus pandemic, with seven of the 12 top-performing developing-nation bond markets in Africa, including Angola and South Africa. Despite lower infection rates and fewer deaths, African countries face significant economic challenges, with many economies expected to contract by an average of 4.5% this year. Investors are drawn to the region's high yields, but experts warn of "premature exuberance" and a potential for market pain once the current rally has run its course.

site_title: Philippines probes proliferation of fake Facebook accounts after anti-terror law protest
summary: The Philippines is investigating the proliferation of fake Facebook accounts created using the identities of students, journalists, and government officials following an anti-terror law protest. The University of the Philippines identified the accounts, which were later reported by dozens of Facebook users. Justice Secretary Menardo Guevarra has ordered an investigation, while Facebook is also investigating reports of suspicious activity. The move comes amid concerns about the bill's potential to silence critics and grant the president unprecedented power.

site_title: Tokyo: Shares at 3.5 month high as US data boosts recovery hopes
summary: Japanese stocks rose to a 3.5-month high, with the benchmark Nikkei average advancing 1.4% to 23,178.10 points, driven by a surprise increase in US employment that boosted recovery hopes. The US economy unexpectedly added 2.5 million jobs, providing evidence of a quicker-than-anticipated recovery. The yen weakened, boosting Japanese manufacturers' profits, and shares of export-oriented carmakers, such as Nissan and Mazda, jumped. Longer-term US Treasury yields surged, lifting Tokyo-listed financial stocks.

site_title: Britain starts mandatory self-quarantine for arrivals
summary: Britain has introduced a mandatory two-week self-quarantine for most arrivals from Monday, aiming to prevent a second wave of coronavirus contagion. Critics, including the aviation sector, claim the measure is "disproportionate and unfair" and will harm the tourism industry. Exemptions are made for certain groups, and authorities will conduct spot checks, with penalties for non-compliance. The measure is part of the government's gradual lockdown easing, which includes retail reopenings and limited restaurant service starting in July.

site_title: Didi Chuxing CEO says ride-sharing orders recover to pre-pandemic levels
summary: Didi Chuxing, China's largest ride-hailing company, has seen its ride-sharing orders recover to pre-pandemic levels, with peak daily orders surpassing 30 million in June. The company's bike-sharing business also saw daily orders reach 10 million. The recovery comes as most of China has reopened for business after the coronavirus outbreak. Didi aims to achieve 100 million daily orders and 800 million monthly active users globally by 2022. The company's overseas operations, including Japan, Australia, and Latin America, have also seen a recovery in orders since mid-March lows.

site_title: Alone in the Gulf, Qatar's currency escapes devaluation bets
summary: Qatar's currency, the riyal, has maintained its peg to the dollar despite regional economic downturn, with investors betting on its resilience. The nation's fiscal defenses have been strengthened, and its external balance sheet is projected to average 177% of GDP from 2021 to 2023. Qatar's sovereign credit strength and self-sufficiency have drawn investors, with its bonds outperforming those of other Gulf Cooperation Council members this year. The country's strong external balance sheet and low oil price balance are expected to mitigate the impact of economic and financial shocks.

site_title: Vietnam ratifies free trade deal with European Union
summary: Vietnam ratified a free trade agreement with the European Union, cutting or eliminating 99% of tariffs on goods traded between the two. The European Union-Vietnam Free Trade Agreement (EVFTA) will take effect in July, providing Vietnam with a post-pandemic boost and expected to boost the country's GDP and exports by 2.4% and 12% by 2030, respectively. The agreement also opens up Vietnam's services market and aligns some standards, while protecting EU food and drinks from imitations.

site_title: Gulf mall operators rein in expansion as retailers reel from Covid-19
summary: Mall operators in the Gulf region, including Majid Al Futtaim and Emaar Malls, are delaying new mega-projects due to the impact of the coronavirus pandemic and low oil prices on the retail industry. Retailers are struggling with liquidity issues and foot traffic at malls has dropped significantly, with some predicting a 20-40% drop in sales. The industry is shifting towards online sales, with many malls offering digital platforms for shops to sell products online. The sector's growth is expected to be slow, with some predicting a 20-24 month recovery period.

site_title: Indonesia's Indofood CBP to buy Pinehill company for US$3b
summary: Indonesia's Indofood CBP is set to acquire Pinehill Co, a producer of instant noodles in Africa and the Middle East, for US$3 billion. The acquisition will expand Indofood CBP's presence in fast-growing consumer markets. Pinehill Co has 12 factories with a production capacity of about 10 billion packs, primarily serving Saudi Arabia, Nigeria, Egypt, and other countries. The acquisition is expected to be finalized after a shareholders' meeting on July 15.

site_title: Dubai Islamic Bank hires banks to market dollar sukuk: document
summary: Dubai Islamic Bank (DIB) hired 10 banks to arrange a global investor call for a potential issuance of US dollar-denominated sukuk. The sukuk may be issued for five years or long five years, subject to market conditions. A benchmark issuance is planned, with DIB and the hired banks to promote the deal. The move aims to tap global investors for the sukuk, which will be denominated in US dollars.

site_title: A world redrawn: Isabel Allende hopes pandemic will doom 'patriarchy'
summary: Chilean writer Isabel Allende believes the COVID-19 pandemic has exposed deep-seated inequalities that will continue to fuel protests globally. She hopes the younger generation will build a new normal founded on gender and racial equality. Allende, known for her novel "The House of the Spirits," is working on a nonfiction book on feminism, "What Women Want." She sees the pandemic as a catalyst for change, teaching people to reevaluate priorities and recognize the interconnectedness of humanity. Allende envisions a world without the patriarchy, where solidarity, compassion, and hope guide decision-making, and humans work together to save the planet.

site_title: Alibaba-backed newspaper says Q1 revenue dropped 50%
summary: The South China Morning Post, a Hong Kong newspaper backed by Alibaba, reported a 50% drop in Q1 revenue due to reduced advertising sales amid the pandemic and social unrest. CEO Gary Liu attributed the decline to advertisers cutting budgets and expressed optimism that advertising sales may recover as the pandemic eases. The newspaper has taken steps to reduce costs, including cutting jobs and lowering executives' salaries. The media industry in Hong Kong has been severely impacted by the pandemic and recent security law changes.

site_title: Sugar shipping rush in Brazil amid Covid surge causes huge vessel logjam
summary: More than 70 ships are waiting to load sugar at Brazil's Santos port, causing a potential one-month backlog due to the surge in demand amid the Covid-19 pandemic. Brazil, which posted record sugar output, has become the primary source for the global trade, but its high number of Covid-19 cases (over 610,000) has led to loading suspensions and quarantine measures at nearby ports. This has disrupted the sugar shipping process, causing delays and potential shortages in the global market.

site_title: New Zealand says it has no active Covid-19 cases in the country
summary: New Zealand has reported no active Covid-19 cases for the first time since February 28, with the last person being monitored for coronavirus now released from isolation after being symptom-free. The country will announce later this week if it will lift all social distancing and economic restrictions.

site_title: Japan details some spending in controversial 10t yen budget reserves
summary: Japan has set aside 10 trillion yen in emergency budget reserves to prepare for a prolonged COVID-19 pandemic, with half of the funds to be spent on supporting firms and boosting medical care. Finance Minister Taro Aso made the announcement as the government presented a $1.1 trillion stimulus package to combat the pandemic. The move comes after criticism from the opposition that the government could tap the massive pool of money without parliamentary scrutiny.

site_title: Indonesian retailers brace for gradual recovery as stores reopen
summary: Indonesia's capital city Jakarta has reopened retail stores, restaurants, and offices after a two-month partial lockdown, with visitors limited to 50% capacity under new health protocols. The city aims for a gradual recovery, with malls set to reopen on June 15 and tourism sites on June 20. Economic activities are expected to resume in stages, with the government considering reopening foreign tourism as early as September and domestic holidaymakers by the end of July. Retailers and the food industry expect a gradual revival in demand, with 3-4% growth in full-year sales anticipated.

images.alt_text: Retail stores, restaurants and offices reopened in Indonesia's capital after more than two-months as authorities eased social restriction rules to jump-start an economy hit hard by the coronavirus pandemic.

site_title: Abu Dhabi to invest US$752m in Reliance Industries' digital arm
summary: Abu Dhabi Investment Authority is investing US$752 million in Reliance Industries' digital arm, Jio Platforms, acquiring a 1.16% stake. This brings total new investment in Jio Platforms to US$13 billion since April, led by Mukesh Ambani's US$65 billion digital unit. The deal supports Reliance's strategy of shifting away from oil refining towards telecommunications, e-commerce, and digital services, boosting investor confidence and pushing up Reliance shares.

site_title: Hot stock: Creative Tech rallies to 1-year high after Super X-Fi online launch
summary: Creative Tech's shares surged 19.9% to a 1-year high of S$3.92 on Monday after the company launched its Super X-Fi products in China via live-streaming. The technology promises "holographic audio" with its high-end multi-speaker system. The stock had previously closed above this level in May 2019. Following the launch, the company's shares jumped 42.2% on Friday. CEO Sim Wong Hoo attributed the product's appeal to its suitability for remote work, learning, and entertainment during the Covid-19 pandemic.

site_title: US$140b at stake for Hong Kong tycoons backing security law
summary: Hong Kong's richest people, worth $140 billion combined, are backing China's national security law despite widespread opposition. Nine billionaire leaders, including Li Ka-shing and Michael Kadoorie, have endorsed the bill, citing stability and prosperity. Critics argue the move erodes the "one country, two systems" principle that has made Hong Kong a global financial hub. The law's supporters claim it will guarantee stability, while opponents, like media tycoon Jimmy Lai, face arrest and crackdowns for opposing the measure. The move is seen as a warning to those who do not publicly support the bill.

site_title: Chinese cosmetic brands see rally despite global beauty downturn
summary: Chinese cosmetic brands, such as Proya Cosmetics Co and Guangdong Marubi Biotechnology Co, have seen significant gains despite the global beauty downturn caused by the coronavirus pandemic. Proya's shares have surged 88% this year, while Marubi's have risen 42%. These local brands are thriving due to their online-focused sales and marketing platforms, which suit the current Covid-19 reality. Analysts attribute their success to their affordable products and ability to leverage social media platforms like live-streaming e-commerce and influencer endorsements. However, some experts warn that these gains may be excessive and short-lived.

site_title: Advancing SME growth requires a suitable ecosystem
summary: Small and medium enterprises (SMEs) play a crucial role in economic growth, accounting for 52-97% of employment and 30-53% of gross domestic products in Southeast Asian economies. In Singapore, SMEs comprise 99% of all enterprises, generating 72% of employment and 47% of national GDP. However, despite their importance, SMEs face challenges in digitalization, requiring suitable ecosystems to support their growth. To address this, financial institutions like OCBC aim to provide loans to serial entrepreneurs by 2028, and specialized centers and initiatives are being established to aid SMEs in their digitalization journeys.

site_title: Broker's take: DBS says SIA Engg should be past the worst soon, upgrades to 'hold'
summary: DBS Group Research upgraded SIA Engineering to "hold" from "fully valued" with a raised target price of S$2.30, citing the signing of bilateral flight-resumption agreements and the government's enhanced Jobs Support Scheme, which should help the company maintain dividends and improve investor sentiment. DBS forecasts a 40% decline in line maintenance revenues in FY2021, before recovering in FY2022.

site_title: AF Global unit proposes disposal of 55% stake in China JV for 292.8m yuan
summary: AF Global's wholly-owned subsidiary, LC Logistics, is selling its 55% stake in a Chinese property development joint venture (JV) for 292.8 million yuan (S$57.6 million) to affiliates of the JV partner, Xuzhou Yinjian LumChang Real Estate Development. The JV is engaged in developing an integrated mixed development in China, but disputes and litigation have resulted in an "irrevocable breakdown" of the working relationship. The sale is expected to strengthen AF Global's cash flow and may lead to dividend payments.

site_title: ETF, securities turnover climb in May amid optimism over economic stimulus: SGX
summary: SGX reports that market turnover value for ETFs and securities surged 73% year-over-year in May, driven by optimism over economic stimulus and the reopening of economies. ETFs saw a 73% increase in value to S$302 million, with the SPDR Straits Times Index ETF trading nearly three times higher year-over-year. The market's positive sentiment despite the ongoing pandemic reflects growing confidence in economic recovery.

site_title: Asia: Equities build on rally as US jobs data fans recovery hopes
summary: Asia's stock markets continued their rally, with Hong Kong, Tokyo, and Shanghai rising 0.7%, 0.9%, and 0.4% respectively, amid optimism over the US economic recovery. A strong US jobs report, with 2.5 million jobs created in May, boosted investor confidence, while a decision to extend oil production cuts provided further support. Other markets, including Canada, Singapore, and Wellington, also gained ground, as countries ease lockdown measures and receive trillions of dollars in stimulus and central bank support.

site_title: Sembmarine to raise S$2.1b, demerge from parent Sembcorp
summary: Sembcorp Marine and its parent Sembcorp Industries have proposed a plan to rescue the marine giant, raising S$2.1 billion through a rights issue and demerging from each other. The plan aims to strengthen financial positions and unlock shareholder value. Sembcorp will receive S$1.5 billion from a subordinated loan, and shareholders will receive between 427 and 491 Sembmarine shares for every 100 Sembcorp shares. The demerger will enable both companies to focus on their respective industries, with Sembcorp focusing on energy and urban development and Sembmarine on engineering solutions for the offshore, marine, and energy industries.

images.alt_text: Sembmarine hopes to raise S$2.1 billion under a five-for-one renounceable rights issue at an issue price of 20 Singapore cents per share.

site_title: Surbana Jurong acquires blast testing and consultancy firm
summary: Surbana Jurong, a Temasek-owned urban and infrastructure consultancy, has acquired Prostruct Consulting, a Singapore-based firm specializing in security, blast consultancy, and testing. The acquisition enhances Surbana Jurong's portfolio of built environment services, allowing it to deliver building designs with integrated security measures. The deal comes as the Singapore government enacts an Infrastructure Protection Act, requiring designated buildings to incorporate security measures into their designs. Prostruct's expertise will now be leveraged globally, extending its reach beyond the Singapore market and reinforcing Surbana Jurong's commitment to building safe and secure spaces.

site_title: Tokyo: Stocks open higher on US rallies, cheaper yen
summary: Tokyo stocks rose on Monday, breaking through the 23,000-point mark, driven by US rallies and a cheaper yen. The Nikkei 225 index climbed 1.05% to 23,103.90, while the Topix index gained 0.86% to 1,626.25.

site_title: Best World independent auditor issues disclaimer of opinion
summary: Best World International's independent auditor, Ernst & Young (EY), has issued a disclaimer of opinion on the group's 2018 financial statements due to insufficient audit evidence. The disclaimer relates to matters raised by PricewaterhouseCoopers (PwC) during an independent review of Best World's export and franchise models in China. The independent review is ongoing, and the company will provide clarifications on key matters. The disclaimer does not raise audit issues that could impact the company's ability to continue as a going concern.

site_title: India's bodybuilders flex muscles, call for gyms to open
summary: Gym owners and trainers in several Indian cities protested against the ban on opening fitness centers due to the coronavirus pandemic, despite the government easing lockdown restrictions. The nation of 1.3 billion people will allow shopping malls, restaurants, and hotels to reopen, but gyms remain closed, causing losses for gym owners and trainers who continue to pay rent and staff salaries. The easing of restrictions comes as India records a rising number of new daily virus cases and the government seeks to revive the economy.

site_title: Sellers of sex toys capitalised on all that alone time
summary: During the COVID-19 pandemic, sales of sex toys have seen a significant surge, with big companies like Adam and Eve, Wow Tech Group, and Cotr Inc reporting a 30-200% increase in online sales. However, brick-and-mortar sex shops are struggling to adapt, with many owners citing higher prices and the inability to compete with online retailers. Some sex shops have attempted to shift their focus online, but sales remain lower than usual. The pandemic has highlighted the challenges faced by the sex industry, with owners expressing concerns about financial sustainability.

site_title: Hong Kong: Stocks start week with fresh gains
summary: Hong Kong stocks started the week with gains, with the Hang Seng Index rising 1.00% to 25,018.05. China's benchmark Shanghai Composite Index and the Shenzhen Composite Index also increased, driven by hopes for an economic recovery from lockdowns. The positive trend comes after US jobs data smashed expectations, fueling optimism about an economic rebound.

site_title: Venezuela's new gasoline system fails to end epic lines
summary: Hundreds of Venezuelans waited in miles-long lines to buy subsidized gasoline at the new dual-price system, which was launched by President Nicolas Maduro last week. The system aims to ease fuel shortages, but it caused chaos and confusion. Motorists can purchase up to 120 liters at a heavily subsidized price of 5,000 bolivares (S$0.03) per liter, and 50 US cents per liter thereafter. Despite the new system, epic lines persisted, indicating that it has failed to end the fuel shortage.

site_title: Minneapolis city council votes to dismantle police
summary: The Minneapolis city council has voted to dismantle and rebuild the police department, following the death of George Floyd in custody, sparking nationwide protests about racism in law enforcement. The decision was made with a veto-proof majority, with Council President Lisa Bender stating that the current policing system is "not reformable." The city council plans to shift police funding towards community-based strategies, with discussions on replacing the current police department to be held.

site_title: Singapore shares rise for sixth day in a row; STI up 0.8%
summary: Singapore's Straits Times Index (STI) rose 0.8% on Monday for the sixth consecutive day, driven by strong gains from Singapore banks and the start of trading for Singapore Airlines' rights shares. The STI advanced 21.8 points to 2,773.30. Banking stocks, including DBS, UOB, and OCBC, rose, while other counters like Rex International and Keppel Reit also saw gains.

site_title: Money Hacks: Fortitude and the market in Covid-19 times (Ep 73)
summary: In a recent podcast episode, "Money Hacks: Fortitude and the market in Covid-19 times," experts from OCBC Bank discuss the impact of the COVID-19 pandemic on Singapore's economy and investors. The "Fortitude Budget" introduced by Finance Minister Heng Swee Keat provided nearly S$100 billion in stimulus. Experts weigh in on the outlook for the economy, real estate investment trusts (Reits), corporate earnings, and dividend payments, emphasizing the need for investors to adapt to the changing market landscape and consider seeking advice from a qualified financial advisor.

site_title: UK shopper numbers indicate huge pent-up demand, Springboard says
summary: The UK saw a surge in shopper numbers in early June, indicating "a huge amount" of pent-up demand for physical stores as the coronavirus lockdown eases. Data from Springboard shows a 42.9% year-on-year decline in footfall in retail parks, while high streets and shopping centers saw a 70.0% decline. Despite a 73.3% decline in overall UK footfall for the May 3-30 period, some stores, like IKEA, saw monumental queues on their re-opening day.

site_title: Samsung heir appears in court for arrest warrant hearing
summary: Samsung Group heir Jay Y. Lee appeared in court for a hearing on a potential arrest warrant over accounting fraud allegations. The 51-year-old Lee did not answer questions from reporters before entering the court. The Seoul Central District Court is expected to decide whether to issue a warrant by late Monday or early Tuesday. This is Lee's latest brush with the law at South Korea's top conglomerate.

site_title: Japan's Q1 GDP shrinks less than initial estimate but still faces steep recession
summary: Japan's economy shrank 2.2% in the first quarter, less than the initial estimate of 3.4%, but still faces a steep recession due to the coronavirus crisis. The country slipped into recession for the first time in 4.5 years, with business spending expected to falter in coming months. Private consumption fell 0.8% and net exports subtracted 0.2 percentage point from GDP growth. Analysts forecast an annualised contraction of over 20% in April-June, with the economy expected to recover moderately in the latter half of the year.

site_title: Japan's economy minister warns against premature fiscal, monetary steps to stimulate demand
summary: Japan's Economy Minister Yasutoshi Nishimura warned against premature fiscal and monetary steps to stimulate demand, citing concerns of sparking another wave of coronavirus infections. He emphasized the need to protect jobs and help businesses survive the pandemic, delaying efforts to stimulate consumption and travel.

site_title: Australia says China unresponsive to its pleas to ease tensions
summary: Australia says China remains unresponsive to its pleas to ease tensions, with the two trading partners locked in a dispute over the origins of the novel coronavirus. China has accused Australia of playing "petty tricks" and has imposed tariffs on Australian barley and suspended beef imports from four of its largest meat processors. Australia's Trade Minister Simon Birmingham stated that Beijing has been ignoring Canberra's requests for a discussion, disappointing the country. The dispute has strained overall relations between the two nations, with 79% of Australians supporting a global coronavirus investigation.

site_title: Gojek streaming service GoPlay bags funding to deepen Indonesian focus
summary: GoPlay, a video streaming service under Indonesia's Gojek, has secured an undisclosed investment led by Singapore's Golden Gate Ventures and Chinese investment firm ZWC Partners. The funding round, valued at approximately $15 million, will be used to deepen GoPlay's focus on Indonesia, where it plans to tap into the country's vast 270 million population and underdeveloped film industry. The move aims to capitalize on the region's growing demand for local content, with GoPlay's CEO Edy Sulistyo stating that the service can succeed where other regional video streaming services have struggled.

site_title: New Zealand: Shares hit near 3-month high on economic recovery hopes
summary: New Zealand shares reached a nearly three-month high on Monday, driven by hopes of a quicker global economic recovery from the coronavirus pandemic. The benchmark S&P/NZX 50 index rose 1.9% following a record US employment increase, while Air New Zealand jumped 10.3% after aiming to return to "healthy profits" by 2022. Vista Group was the top percentage gainer, surging 13%, and Kathmandu Holdings added 12.3% for its fifth straight gain.

site_title: Airbnb joins vacation-rental sites seeing surge in Summer demand
summary: Airbnb has seen a surge in summer demand for vacation rentals, with bookings in the US and globally surpassing pre-pandemic levels. The company's CEO, Brian Chesky, attributes the increase to people seeking domestic escapes from their homes rather than international travel. Other companies, such as Expedia Group and Booking Holdings, are also experiencing a rebound in domestic vacation-rental reservations. The travel sector was severely impacted by the pandemic, but months of pent-up demand is driving the recovery. Airbnb plans to pursue a public market debut, despite the uncertainty of the trend's sustainability.

site_title: Realistic post-pandemic solutions for sustainable supply chains required
summary: The COVID-19 pandemic has exposed weaknesses in global supply chains, prompting a need for more resilient and flexible structures. ASEAN exporters are particularly vulnerable, relying on complex global supply chains. To address this, businesses should diversify production sources, adopt conservative inventory management, and invest in technology solutions to reduce reliance on cross-border movements. International cooperation, including trade agreements, is crucial to addressing the root causes of pandemics and promoting sustainable global supply chains. ASEAN countries should promote these solutions, rather than retreating to protectionism, to ensure a more stable and sustainable future.

site_title: Citi's rare 'sell' call on Singapore banks returns to 'buy' herd
summary: Citi Research upgraded its call on Singapore banks to "buy" from "sell", citing a V-shaped recovery in 2021. Analyst Robert Kong raised target prices for OCBC, UOB, and DBS, up 40%, 39%, and 29.8% respectively. Markets may be pricing in a recovery, with banks seen as a proxy. However, earnings in Q2 are expected to show the "true weakness of the lockdown period", with soft loan growth and weak fees. Citi's economists believe ample liquidity will prevent a financial crisis.

site_title: Oil climbs over 2% after Opec+ extends output cuts to end-July
summary: Oil prices rose 2% to their highest in three months after Opec and its allies, including Russia, agreed to extend record oil production cuts until end-July. Brent crude climbed to $43.41 a barrel, while US West Texas Intermediate crude gained 83 cents to $40.38 a barrel. The deal, which began in April, aims to withdraw almost 10% of global supplies from the market. However, compliance among Opec members remains an issue, with some producers still struggling to meet the agreement's terms.

site_title: Broker's take: DBS says Singapore office sector near inflection point; upgrades CCT to 'buy'
summary: DBS Group Research has upgraded its recommendation on CapitaLand Commercial Trust (CCT) to "buy" from "hold" due to the Singapore office sector being near an inflection point. The analysts believe the sector will recover faster than expected, with low net incoming supply and record low vacancies mitigating a steeper fall in office fundamentals. They also raised their 12-month target price on CCT to S$1.95 and expect Keppel Reit and Mapletree Commercial Trust to outperform, with price targets of S$1.35 and S$2.25 respectively.

site_title: France confirms 1b euro target for aerospace fund
summary: France is planning to create a 1 billion euro fund to support the country's aerospace industry, which has been hit hard by the coronavirus crisis. The fund, part of an emergency plan to be unveiled next week, aims to protect aerospace firms from foreign takeovers and provide job guarantees. Defence Minister Florence Parly has discussed with President Emmanuel Macron the possibility of bringing forward military orders to boost the sector. The plan seeks to support small suppliers and help them recover from the crisis.

site_title: Stocks to watch: Singapore Airlines, UOB, ST Engineering, HPHT, Banyan Tree
summary: Singapore Airlines raised S$10 billion in fresh liquidity through a rights issue and secured credit facilities. The airline's shares fell 1.1% to close at S$4.33 on Friday. United Overseas Bank maintained its 50% dividend payout ratio amid challenging business climate. ST Engineering disclosed a contained ransomware attack on its US-based subsidiary. Hutchison Port Holdings Trust's distribution decline was due to debt repayment. Banyan Tree undertook cost-saving exercises affecting 10-15% of its global workforce.

site_title: UK firms will need new equity to cope with Covid-19 debt surge: TheCityUK
summary: UK firms may need new equity to cope with the surge in Covid-19 debt, with about a third of the debt being taken on under government emergency programs potentially unsustainable. Companies could struggle to meet financing costs of up to £36 billion by the end of March 2021, on top of existing debt. The sectors most exposed are property, accommodation, and food services, with small and medium-sized firms accounting for half of the total debt. Private capital, including private equity and investment from British insurers and pension funds, could help plug the expected equity shortfall.

site_title: UK to announce laws to prevent foreign takeovers posing national security risk: Times
summary: British Prime Minister Boris Johnson is set to announce laws requiring companies to report attempted takeovers posing national security risks. The legislation would impose mandatory reporting and threaten criminal sanctions, including jail time, for non-compliance. Companies that fail to report takeovers or ignore UK government conditions could also face fines and director disqualification. The move aims to curb the influence of foreign companies, particularly China, and protect national security.

site_title: US adds almost 700 new coronavirus deaths in 24 hours
summary: The US reported 691 coronavirus deaths in the past 24 hours, the lowest in a week, with a total of 110,482 deaths and 1,938,842 cases. Although the number of deaths is high globally, European countries have a higher per capita death toll. Health care professionals worry about a potential surge in infections due to mass demonstrations. The number of deaths has declined from around 3,000 per day in mid-April to 1,000 per day currently.

site_title: Iron ore surges as Vale's mine shutdown fans supply concerns
summary: Vale SA, the world's largest iron ore miner, was ordered by a Brazilian labor court to shut its Itabira complex, accounting for 10% of its output, due to 188 workers testing positive for Covid-19. The halt, until a final court ruling or Vale's control measures are met, has boosted concerns about supply disruptions and surged iron ore futures to US$103 a ton, the highest since August 2019.

site_title: Malaysia to further ease curbs from June 10
summary: Malaysia will ease coronavirus restrictions starting June 10, allowing domestic travel and small-scale social activities while maintaining social distancing protocols. Schools will reopen in stages under the "recovery movement control order" phase, which runs until August 31. The move aims to restart nearly all social, economic, and religious activities.

site_title: Japan bank lending surges at record pace in May as pandemic-hit firms hoard cash
summary: Japan's bank lending surged at a record pace in May, with a 4.8% annual increase to 562.5 trillion yen, driven by cash-strapped companies seeking immediate funding amid the pandemic's impact on sales. This marks the fastest pace of increase since 2001, as the government and central bank's measures to channel money to ailing firms appear to be working. The data suggests a boost to the economy from the measures taken to support struggling businesses.

site_title: SIA snags S$10b in fresh liquidity; boosts health measures on flights
summary: Singapore Airlines (SIA) has raised S$10 billion in liquidity through a rights issue and secured credit facilities to tackle the challenges posed by the COVID-19 outbreak. The airline has also stepped up health and safety measures, including enhanced cleaning procedures, wearing of masks and gloves, and provision of care kits to customers. Additionally, SIA will introduce digital food ordering services and allow passengers to print boarding passes and baggage tags in a contactless manner.

site_title: Art Basel cancels Sept fair
summary: Art Basel has cancelled its September fair in Basel, Switzerland, due to ongoing health and safety concerns related to the coronavirus pandemic. The 50th-anniversary edition, featuring over 250 international galleries, was postponed from June to September. The Swiss Federal Council had delayed its decision on whether the fair could proceed until this month.

site_title: Trump drifts from constitution, former military chief warns
summary: Former US Secretary of State Colin Powell and retired four-star Army General Colin Powell announced they will vote for Democratic presidential candidate Joe Biden, criticizing President Donald Trump for drifting away from the US Constitution. Powell accused Trump of lying and insulting the country, diminishing America's global image. Trump's former Defense Secretary, Jim Mattis, also criticized the President, calling him a "mockery of our Constitution." Powell's comments come after Trump threatened to use active-duty military to quell protests, prompting a confrontation with Pentagon leaders.

site_title: Ascott Residence Trust to join FTSE EPRA Nareit Global Real Estate Index
summary: Ascott Residence Trust (ART) will join the FTSE EPRA Nareit Global Real Estate Index Series starting June 22, marking a significant milestone for the company. This inclusion is attributed to the successful combination with Ascendas Hospitality Trust, which boosted ART's scale and enabled its entry into the global benchmark index. The move is expected to raise ART's profile, broaden its reach among global investors, and increase trading liquidity, ultimately enhancing the company's financial capacity to further enhance its portfolio.

site_title: US Democrats press anti-racism reforms as protests continue
summary: US Democrats are pushing for anti-racism reforms in law enforcement amid ongoing protests sparked by George Floyd's death. Despite President Trump's orders to withdraw National Guard troops from Washington, demonstrations continued across the nation. Democrats, including Representative Val Demings, plan to introduce legislation to make policing more accountable, including easier lawsuits against police and banning choke holds. However, it's unclear if the proposed reforms will pass in the Republican-controlled Senate, with US Attorney General William Barr opposing any moves to lessen police immunity.

site_title: Air New Zealand warns of more job cuts, targets 'healthy profits' by 2022
summary: Air New Zealand has warned of potential job cuts as it aims to return to "healthy profits" by 2022. The airline, hit hard by the coronavirus crisis, plans to reduce its wage bill and cut costs to achieve this goal. Revenue is expected to more than halve in the next financial year, with the company forecasting 13 million customers in 2022, down from 18 million before the pandemic. The airline has already cut thousands of jobs and set aside cash for aircraft impairments.

site_title: North Korea's Kim stresses self-sufficient economy at a politburo meeting: KCNA
summary: North Korean leader Kim Jong Un attended a two-day politburo meeting, discussing economic projects, including the chemical industry and fertiliser production, to further develop the self-sufficient economy. The meeting stressed the importance of increasing fertiliser capacity and constructing residential houses to improve the standard of living. This comes amid economic uncertainty due to the global Covid-19 pandemic and international sanctions. The meeting's focus on economic development is seen as a response to Kim's recent health concerns and limited public appearances.

images.alt_text: North Korean leader Kim Jong Un attended a meeting of the politburo of the country's ruling Workers Party, where economic projects including the chemical industry were discussed, state news agency KCNA said on Monday.

site_title: Rouble's surge gives green light for Russia to slash rates
summary: Russia's central bank may slash interest rates by more than 2 percentage points due to the rouble's surge with oil prices and a slump in consumer demand. This move would give the bank room to cut rates even deeper, preventing inflation from rising above its 4% target. Analysts at major US banks expect this move, citing the currency's rally and decreased consumer demand. The potential rate cut could be a positive sign for the Russian economy, which has been impacted by the coronavirus lockdown.

site_title: Coronavirus pandemic, dire economy and social unrest upend US presidential race
summary: The US presidential campaign is being shaped by three concurrent crises: the COVID-19 pandemic, economic despair, and social unrest. The crises have prompted reflection on racial inequality in America and differing strategies from President Donald Trump and Democrat Joe Biden. The unprecedented strain has become the focal point of the campaign, with both candidates approaching the disasters with distinct approaches. The 2020 presidential election has been reframed by the ongoing crises, with the nation grappling with the consequences of these disasters.

images.alt_text: Three concurrent crises scarring the United States - a deadly health pandemic, economic despair and widespread social unrest - have reframed this year's presidential contest, and prompted national reflection over racial inequality in America.

site_title: UK slave trader's statue toppled in anti-racism protests
summary: Protesters in Bristol, UK, toppled and dumped the statue of notorious slave trader Edward Colston in the harbour, marking the second day of demonstrations against George Floyd's death. The act was a symbol of anti-racism protests, with protesters tying the statue to a rope, stamping on it, and then throwing it into the water.

site_title: Australia extends support to airlines for domestic flights
summary: Australia's government will extend its support for domestic flights through September, covering shortfalls in operating flights and domestic routes for airlines such as Qantas and Virgin Australia. The initial aid, due to expire on June 8, will be extended to ensure the aviation industry can rebuild capacity. The government has already provided over A$1.2 billion in backing, and will also extend financial support for regional airlines until December 31. This move aims to sustain the industry and support airlines as they rebuild capacity.

site_title: Money FM podcast: A special interview with Minister Lawrence Wong
summary: Minister Lawrence Wong discussed the Singapore government's preparations for Phase 2 of COVID-19 recovery in a special interview with Money FM podcast. He emphasized the need for cautious measures and a watchful eye on international news headlines. Meanwhile, globally, China's GDP growth is expected to slow, and policymakers face pressure. Other key developments include a mid-2026 target for Citigroup's global equity index, Thai Prime Minister Thaksin's confidence in his daughter's court case, and the UK economy shrinking for the second month.

site_title: The office isn't dead. It's just convalescing
summary: The article suggests that the concept of working from home may not be a permanent solution for many employees, despite the easing of coronavirus lockdowns. While some companies like Twitter and Google plan to allow permanent remote work, many office jobs require face-to-face interaction and cannot be done from home. The article notes that urban areas with efficient public transport systems, like Hong Kong, make it easier for people to commute to the office, but in crowded cities like Mumbai, suburban working may become more attractive. Ultimately, offices serve as meeting points for social and cultural exchanges, and employees want to return to the office but not necessarily full-time.

site_title: Gold prices up 16% in 2020
summary: Gold prices rose 16% in 2020 amidst a global pandemic. The year began with widespread lockdowns and travel restrictions, but as the second half began, many countries reported a slowdown in the spread of the novel coronavirus. As economies recover, investors are looking for safe-haven assets like gold, which is trading in an equidistant channel.

site_title: China trade surplus surges to record as medical exports jump
summary: China's trade surplus surged to a record $62.93 billion in May, driven by a 3.3% decrease in exports and a 16.7% plunge in imports, largely due to the decline in commodity prices. Exports of medical supplies, including masks, jumped 88.5% and textile products, including masks, rose 25.5%. The record surplus is seen as a positive sign for China's economy, which is gradually recovering, with net exports expected to contribute substantially to GDP growth in the second quarter.

site_title: Opec, allies agree to extend deep output cuts through July
summary: OPEC and its allies agreed to extend historic output cuts through July, aiming to boost oil prices as they recover from the coronavirus pandemic. The 13-member cartel, led by Saudi Arabia, initially agreed to cut output by 9.7 million barrels per day from May to June, and then ease it to 7.7 million bpd from July to December. However, Mexico announced it would not comply, citing its inability to adjust production further, despite agreeing to the cuts in April.

site_title: HSBC's political tightrope act opens up internal fault lines
summary: HSBC has faced backlash for endorsing a proposed Chinese security law in Hong Kong, which has widened internal fault lines within the bank. The move has heightened worries among staff and clients, with British lawmakers criticizing the decision as short-sighted and cynical. In contrast, official Chinese media has warned that HSBC needs to toe the line to maintain access to the Chinese market. The bank's decision has also sparked calls for protests and boycotts, with democracy activists demanding support from the business community.

site_title: BA threatens to fire pilots, fights UK's quarantine rule
summary: British Airways (BA) is threatening to fire its 4,300 pilots unless the union reaches a deal on further job cuts amid the UK's 14-day self-isolation plan for arrivals. The airline, which is cutting 12,000 jobs, sent a letter to the Home Office to block the quarantine, arguing it would disproportionately affect England and be more stringent than the rule for those who test positive for the virus. BA's parent IAG SA and discount carriers Ryanair and EasyJet are considering legal action, which could lead to a lawsuit.

site_title: Ransomware attack on ST Engg's US subsidiary contained
summary: ST Engineering announced that a recent ransomware attack on its US-based subsidiary, VT San Antonio Aerospace Inc, has been contained and is believed to be isolated. The attack was carried out by the group Maze, but no material impact is expected on the company's operations or financials. ST Engineering took immediate action, disconnecting systems, notifying law enforcement, and conducting a rigorous review to ensure the security of its systems and data. The company's US businesses, including VT San Antonio Aerospace, continue to operate normally, with its IT network in Singapore and other businesses unaffected.

site_title: FJ Benjamin navigates the new normal
summary: FJ Benjamin, a Singapore-based retail group and luxury brand distributor, is unlikely to exit the SGX watch list by December 2020 due to the ongoing COVID-19 pandemic. The company's stores have been shuttered for over two months, and mainland Chinese consumers, a significant force in global luxury spending, are also affected. CEO Nash Benjamin stated that it has been "tough" weathering the epidemic, and the company is waiting to reopen. The pandemic's impact on FJ Benjamin's business is expected to be significant, but the company remains on the SGX watch list.

site_title: Construction tech startups eye big break in post-Covid-19 'new normal'
summary: Construction tech startups in South-east Asia, particularly in Singapore, are poised to benefit from the post-Covid-19 'new normal' as the industry shifts towards digitalization. Startups like Novade, VRcollab, and Ackcio are seeing strong interest from contractors for their remote collaboration and automation solutions. Despite financial pressures, some startups believe the pandemic could create an opportunity for them to convert tech-wary contractors into new customers. Angel investors also see a silver lining, suggesting that the industry's need for quick delivery and reduced labor could lead to changes.

site_title: Baltic Exchange Shipping Insights
summary: The Baltic Exchange Shipping Insights report highlights the improvement in the Capesize market, with rates rising to $7,307, driven by strong iron ore demand. The transatlantic market continues to lag, while the Pacific basin saw increased activity. Panamax rates rose, with Kamsarmaxes earning up to $12,750. Ultramax/Supramax rates also improved, with demand from the Indian Ocean pushing rates higher. Handysize rates remained steady, with limited cargo from the US Gulf. Charterers took control, with owners struggling to find cargoes to fix.

site_title: Unity, resilience needed to deal with this generation's 'most dangerous crisis': PM
summary: Singapore Prime Minister Lee Hsien Loong has described the Covid-19 pandemic as the "most dangerous crisis" humanity has faced, calling for unity and resilience to overcome it. The government has a "full agenda" for the next many years, with a focus on strengthening the social compact and improving social safety nets. Lee emphasized the need for Singapore to work with like-minded countries and protect its interests in a more uncertain global economy. Despite the challenges, the Prime Minister expressed confidence in Singapore's resilience and economic strengths, urging citizens to work together to secure a bright future.

site_title: Singapore did not take in 'large flows' of Hong Kong deposits: MAS
summary: Singapore's Monetary Authority of Singapore (MAS) clarified that the country did not receive "large flows" of Hong Kong deposits, contrary to media reports. Total foreign currency deposits in Singapore's banking system stood at S$781 billion, a 20% increase from last year. The growth in deposits came from diverse sources, including domestic, regional, and global factors, such as central bank actions and precautionary savings. MAS stated that media reports focusing solely on deposits in the Domestic Banking Unit (DBU) were "incorrect" and not meaningful due to their small percentage of the total deposits.

site_title: Facing the challenge of economic triage
summary: Singapore's government support for businesses during the pandemic has sparked debate on whether to provide equal support to all businesses or allow structurally unviable enterprises to fail. Experts argue that a "wait and see" approach is necessary, considering the uncertainties surrounding the pandemic's duration, industry impact, and geopolitical situation. Policymakers must balance the need to protect livelihoods with the need to allocate resources optimally to strengthen Singapore's long-term position. Targeted support for businesses that can adapt to the new normal, such as those in technology and digitization, is recommended.

site_title: Malaysia to ease curbs from June 10 to allow domestic travel, social activities
summary: Malaysia will ease its coronavirus restrictions starting June 10, allowing domestic travel, limited social activities, and reopening schools in stages under the "recovery movement control order" phase until August 31. Prime Minister Muhyiddin Yassin announced the decision, citing a drop in infection rates. The move aims to revive the economy while maintaining strict social distancing protocols and safety measures.

site_title: Hong Kong property market proves resilient even as crises mount
summary: The Hong Kong property market has proven resilient despite mounting crises, including the introduction of a security law threatening the city's status as an Asian financial hub. Home prices have risen 1.2% this year, reaching their highest since November 2019, and sales have continued, with 6,885 deals recorded in May. Despite economic contraction and rising unemployment, residents believe property will maintain value due to limited supply and high demand. Experts attribute the market's resilience to its status as a global financial center and its affordability, with the average price standing at HK$15,589 per square foot.

site_title: Feeding the vulnerable and underprivileged during Covid-19
summary: CapitaLand, a Singaporean property company, launched the "CapitaLand #MealOnMe" initiative to support vulnerable groups during the Covid-19 pandemic. In partnership with food charities and local businesses, the initiative has delivered over 30,000 meals and 2,000 food bundles to elderly and underprivileged children. The program aims to provide care and support to those in need, with support expected to continue until October.

site_title: SIA's rights shares, MCBs to hit market on a tailwind of positive sentiment
summary: Singapore Airlines' (SIA) rights shares and 10-year mandatory convertible bonds (MCBs) will begin trading this week, with a strong tailwind of positive sentiment from the global market. The US economy regained 2.5 million jobs in May, and airline stocks soared, including SIA, which jumped 13% during the week. However, the MCBs were largely shunned by investors, with only 59.6% of the S$3.5 billion issued being taken up. SIA's CEO and chairman also opted out of the MCBs. The company has raised S$8.8 billion through the rights issue, which will be used to fund fixed costs, debts, and aircraft purchases.

site_title: Balancing now, and beyond Covid-19
summary: The COVID-19 pandemic highlights the need for organisations to balance short-term recovery with long-term planning and stakeholder-centric approach. Boards must adapt to new risks and opportunities, considering IT resiliency, workforce management, and social responsibility. A stakeholder-centric view can help distil insights and drive actions, while refocusing on purpose and envisioning future scenarios can help businesses remain relevant.
