The pandemic presents a unique opportunity for transformation, requiring leaders to make bold investments and reboot business models to answer future growth demand.

site_title: Singtel associate Airtel staging comeback, raising funds, adding users
summary: Bharti Airtel, a trounced rival of Reliance Jio Infocomm, is mounting a comeback in India's wireless market. The carrier has raised funds, added users, and is in talks with Amazon to buy a stake worth at least $2 billion. Airtel's recovery is seen as a sharp turnaround for billionaire Sunil Mittal after a gruelling competition with Mr Ambani's Reliance Jio. The market assumes Airtel will continue to attract bigger-spending users, posing a rising challenge to Mr Ambani's Jio, which has raised over $10 billion in weeks.

site_title: Malaysia: Even US$3b not enough to settle 1MDB case with Goldman
summary: Malaysia's Finance Minister Tengku Zafrul Aziz has ruled out a US$3 billion settlement with Goldman Sachs over the 1MDB scandal, stating that even this amount is not acceptable. The US bank had previously offered this figure, which is higher than the US$6.5 billion in bond sales at the center of the scandal. Malaysia has charged Goldman Sachs and 17 individuals for allegedly misleading investors over the bond sales. The government is seeking full accountability and justice in the case.

site_title: Fewer director purchases and buybacks; STI surges
summary: The Straits Times Index (STI) surged 7.6% over five trading sessions, ending the 2020 year-to-date decline at 14.6%. Share buybacks decreased to S$1.5 million, with Global Investments leading the tally. Approximately 120 director and substantial shareholder transactions were filed for over 40 primary-listed stocks. Notable acquisitions include Serial System's Derek Goh acquiring 6.7 million shares, and Hedda Juliana im Brahm-Droege increasing her stake in Dutech Holdings to 8.16%.

site_title: Rosneft says no change to dividend policy despite lower state stake
summary: Russia's largest oil producer Rosneft plans to maintain its dividend policy, paying out half of its net profit despite the state lowering its stake in the company to below 50%. Rosneft will continue developing offshore fields in Russia, but not initiate new projects until oil prices recover. The company's decision comes after the state holding company Rosneftegaz relinquished its controlling stake in Rosneft following its exit from Venezuela.

site_title: UOB online programme makes art more accessible
summary: United Overseas Bank (UOB) has launched the UOB Art Explorer, an online visual arts programme aiming to make art more accessible globally. The programme features five initiatives, including tutorials, virtual exhibitions, and collaborations with South-east Asian artists. The bank will provide starter kits to 500 disadvantaged children and showcase over 60 regional artworks by the end of the year, promoting mental well-being and creativity. The initiative's goal is to bridge the gap between art and the community, especially during times of isolation and uncertainty.

images.alt_text: One of the initiatives under UOB Art Explorer is Art at Home, a series of video tutorials that show how to create images such as a three-dimensional apple.

site_title: 383 new coronavirus cases in Singapore, including 14 in community
summary: Singapore reported 383 new coronavirus cases, bringing the total to 37,910, with 14 in the community. The cases include 10 Singaporeans or permanent residents, and migrant workers living in dormitories. The daily average of new community cases has increased to seven, and 24,550 patients have recovered from the disease. The country has reported 25 deaths due to Covid-19, with the youngest victim being a 41-year-old male who died from complications two weeks after being discharged.

site_title: Emerging markets enjoy trillion-dollar week as USD slips
summary: The US dollar's decline has sparked a rally in emerging markets, with the MSCI gauge for emerging-market exchange rates posting its best weekly advance in over four years. The market value of emerging-market assets has gained at least $1 trillion this week, driven by domestic demand and carry trade. Historically, foreign investors have followed this trend, as seen in 2016 when emerging-market equities began a tentative advance after the Federal Reserve's first rate increase in nearly a decade.

site_title: Emirates, Etihad extend temporary salary cuts to Sept
summary: Gulf carriers Emirates and Etihad Airways are extending temporary salary cuts for staff until September to preserve cash during the global coronavirus pandemic. Emirates will extend a three-month wage cut until September 30, with some basic salaries reduced by 50%. Etihad Airways has also extended its salary cuts of 25-50% to September. The airlines have laid off staff and seek government bailouts due to the pandemic's impact on the aviation industry.

site_title: Working together to come out stronger, more integrated, better able to respond to challenges
summary: Asean member states are working together to emerge stronger and better equipped to respond to global challenges and opportunities despite the ongoing pandemic emergency. The EU-Asean Business Council and the Asean Business Advisory Council have issued a joint statement calling for a high-level Special Commission to recommend a recovery plan, which would improve the response to pandemics and ensure Asean's growth and integration. Key actions include eliminating non-tariff barriers to trade, harmonizing standards, and investing in sustainable infrastructure to position Asean for a faster and more sustainable recovery.

site_title: China to strengthen global cooperation in Covid-19 vaccine trials
summary: China plans to strengthen global cooperation in Covid-19 vaccine trials, following earlier collaboration in vaccine development. The country is conducting five separate clinical trials, accounting for half of all such trials globally. Science and Technology Minister Wang Zhigang emphasized the importance of rigorous vaccine development and urged global cooperation, resisting finger-pointing and politicizing the virus. China's President Xi Jinping has pledged US$2 billion in financial support to help deal with Covid-19, particularly in developing countries, and has vowed to make vaccines a "global public good" once they are ready for use.

site_title: US stocks may see more upside on jobs data
summary: US stocks may see further gains if economic data supports a recovery, following a surprise 2.5 million job gain in May and a 13.3% unemployment rate. The unexpected numbers suggest an economic rebound could be near. Airlines, underpriced economically cyclical stocks, and energy stocks surged, with the US Global Jets ETF experiencing its largest weekly gain ever. Despite the optimism, the job report did not substantiate hopes of a V-shaped recovery, and the tech sector declined, with shares of Zoom and Slack falling sharply.

site_title: DBS sets aside S$500,000 in grants for social enterprises
summary: DBS has set aside S$500,000 in grants for 60 social enterprises across Asia, including 13 in Singapore. The grants aim to help these enterprises protect jobs and ease cash flow pressures. DBS will offer low-interest, collateral-free working capital funding to the Singapore Centre for Social Enterprise's network of 360 social enterprises, with loans available up to S$200,000 at rates as low as 2% per annum. The funds can be disbursed within five days of signing and accepting the loan offer.

site_title: Debt repayment led to falling trend of DPU: HPHT
summary: Hutchison Port Holdings Trust (HPHT) attributed its declining trend of distributions to unitholders to debt repayment amid challenging global and macroeconomic events. The trust, which has assets in Hong Kong and China, repaid HK$250 million of its debt in response to uncertainties, resulting in a fall in its distribution per unit (DPU). The group aims to focus on operational efficiency and cost management to increase competitiveness and generate value for unitholders.

site_title: AstraZeneca is said to approach Gilead about potential merger
summary: AstraZeneca has approached Gilead Sciences about a potential merger, the largest healthcare deal on record. The UK-based firm contacted Gilead last month, but no decisions have been made on how to proceed. Gilead has discussed the idea with advisers, but the companies are not in formal talks. AstraZeneca did not specify terms for any transaction. The deal, if pursued, would be a significant move for both companies.

site_title: Greenback up on US jobs data
summary: The US dollar rose modestly last Friday after the Labor Department's employment report showed the jobless rate fell to 13.3% in May, a post-World War II high, and consumer confidence, manufacturing, and services industries stabilized. The US dollar index was up 0.18% to 96.93, and the currency was stronger against the euro and Japanese yen. Analysts attributed the gains to better-than-expected economic data, expectations of US growth, and a steepening yield curve, but noted that uncertainties about the economic outlook and a possible second wave of infections capped the greenback's gains.

site_title: Travelodge's woes pit UK savers against Wall Street titans
summary: Travelodge Hotels, a UK chain of cheap hotels, is undergoing a financial overhaul due to a collapse in revenue during the Covid-19 lockdown. The company plans to cut its rental bill by 38% by December 2021, with shareholders providing £100 million in new debt and equity. Hedge funds Avenue Capital Group and Goldentree Asset Management, as well as Goldman Sachs Group, own a significant stake in the company. The move pits thousands of UK savers and retirees against Wall Street titans, who are also affected by the company's financial struggles.

site_title: Singapore must strengthen social compact, improve safety nets: PM Lee
summary: Singapore's Prime Minister Lee Hsien Loong emphasized the need to strengthen the country's social compact and improve safety nets to cope with the economic and social impacts of the COVID-19 pandemic. He stressed the importance of equal opportunities, good education, healthcare, and housing for all Singaporeans. Lee noted that Singapore's healthcare system is coping well, but the country faces significant economic challenges, including a severe hit to its economy and the need for workers to adapt to new skills. Lee urged Singaporeans to remain optimistic, citing the country's economic strengths and a stable political system, and called for unity and resilience to overcome the crisis.

site_title: Jaguar Land Rover raises 5b yuan loan from Chinese banks
summary: Jaguar Land Rover (JLR) has secured a 5 billion yuan (S$984.9 million) three-year loan from Chinese banks, marking its first debt financing in China. The loan facility will help the company manage cash flow amid the coronavirus pandemic. JLR's China sales have been boosted, accounting for 50% of global sales, and the company expects the luxury car segment to see level or slight growth this year. The loan was arranged by Bank of China, ICBC, and other Chinese banks.

site_title: India, China seek to 'peacefully resolve' border face-off
summary: India and China have agreed to "peacefully resolve" a border flare-up in the Ladakh region, according to a high-level meeting between army commanders. The two nations have been involved in a series of face-offs and brawls along their 3,500-kilometer frontier, which has never been properly demarcated. Thousands of troops from both countries are involved in the standoff. The commanders agreed on an "early resolution" to resolve the situation and ensure peace and tranquility in the border areas, with bilateral relations between the two most-populous nations seen as essential to this outcome.

site_title: Singapore Airlines doesn't plan to cut jobs for now
summary: Singapore Airlines won't cut jobs for now, focusing on recovering from the coronavirus outbreak, according to CEO Goh Choon Phong. The airline has restored some flights and is operating at 6% capacity, but will review possible job cuts. It has raised S$8.80 billion through share and convertible bond sales, cut management salaries by 30%, and is negotiating with aircraft manufacturers to adjust deliveries and payment schedules. Despite its worst quarterly loss ever, the airline will continue to prioritize staff retention.

site_title: 'Never say never' on ECB buying shares: Holzmann
summary: The European Central Bank (ECB) has not ruled out buying shares, despite not currently discussing the idea, according to ECB Governing Council member Robert Holzmann. The ECB recently expanded its stimulus package to combat the coronavirus pandemic, and Holzmann has called for the bank to lower its inflation target and warn against negative rates. He also expressed caution about green bonds, citing market liquidity concerns. The fundamental discussion on ECB strategy will be taken up again as of the summer, with Holzmann open to revising his stance on inflation targets.

site_title: Startups see value in shared working space of physical offices
summary: Startups in Singapore are opting for hybrid office spaces that combine remote work with in-person collaboration, citing the need for creativity and interaction. Despite the success of remote work during the "circuit breaker" period, many startups prefer a physical office space that fosters collaboration and creativity. They have adapted to incorporate social distancing measures, such as Plexiglass barriers and staggered pantry timings, to minimize interaction while maintaining productivity levels. This trend is seen as a response to the limitations of remote work in boosting innovation and creativity.

site_title: S Korea to pump 1 trillion won into Korean Air: Yonhap
summary: South Korea's financial authorities plan to provide 1 trillion won (S$1.16 billion) in liquidity to Korean Air Lines by issuing government-guaranteed bonds by the end of June. The move comes as the flag carrier faces significant debt, including 3.3 trillion won due this year, and the COVID-19 aftermath is expected to continue hindering its operations. This is the second aid package Korean Air has received this year, following a 1.2 trillion won aid package earlier. The funds will be raised through a 40 trillion won fund to support seven key industries, including airlines and shipbuilders.

site_title: Singapore did not take in 'large flows' of Hong Kong deposits: MAS
summary: Singapore's Monetary Authority (MAS) clarified that the country did not receive "large flows" of Hong Kong deposits, contrary to media reports. Total foreign currency deposits in Singapore's banking system grew 20% in April, driven by diverse sources, including domestic, regional, and global factors. Media reports focused on deposits in one accounting ledger, which make up less than 5% of the total, are deemed "not meaningful". MAS attributed the growth to central bank actions, liquidity increases, and precautionary savings amid the Covid-19 economic slump.

site_title: Ransomware attack on ST Engineering's US unit contained
summary: ST Engineering's US unit has contained a ransomware attack that was believed to be isolated to a limited part of its commercial operations. The company took immediate action, disconnecting affected systems, notifying law enforcement, and conducting a review to ensure data safety. The incident is not expected to impact consolidated net tangible assets or earnings per share for the current financial year. The company's IT network in Singapore and other businesses remain unaffected. The incident is under investigation, with leading forensic advisers and advanced tools being deployed to remediate the intrusion and restore affected systems.

site_title: Hong Kong property market proves resilient even as crises mount
summary: The Hong Kong property market has shown resilience despite the introduction of a controversial security law and economic uncertainty. Dozens of buyers lined up for a chance to bid on apartments, with prices starting at HK$6.8 million. Despite a record 7% contraction in the economy, existing home prices have risen 1.2% this year, and the market is expected to continue thriving due to limited supply, high demand, and low interest rates. Experts attribute the market's resilience to its status as a global financial hub and gateway to China.

site_title: The great diamond glut: Miners stuck with gems worth billions
summary: The diamond industry is facing a significant glut, with the world's top five diamond producers holding approximately $3.50 billion worth of unsold rough diamonds, which could reach $4.50 billion by the end of the year. De Beers and Russian rival Alrosa have refused to cut prices, instead allowing buyers to renege on contracts, and have reduced production to control stock levels. The pandemic has devastated the industry, with jewellery stores closing and India's cutting and polishing artisans forced to stay home. The industry is struggling to destock its inventories without undermining the nascent recovery, and smaller diamond producers are offering steep discounts to attract buyers.

site_title: UFC superstar Conor McGregor announces retirement
summary: UFC superstar Conor McGregor has announced his retirement from the sport, citing his decision to end his fighting days. The two-division UFC World Champion, 31, made the announcement on Twitter, thanking fans for the memories. McGregor has a record of 22-4 and held two championship belts simultaneously in 2016. He previously announced retirement in March 2019 but returned to the octagon in January 2020. McGregor's retirement marks the end of an era for the iconic MMA fighter.

images.alt_text: Mixed martial arts (MMA) superstar Conor McGregor announced his retirement from the sport on Sunday.

site_title: British Airways threatens to fire pilots, fights UK's quarantine rule
summary: British Airways is threatening to fire its 4,300 pilots unless the UK's 14-day self-isolation rule for arrivals is lifted. The airline has initiated the legal process to block the rule, which it claims disproportionately affects England and could block its plans to restart services in July. The UK's Home Office has declined to comment on potential legal action. The move comes as the airline industry faces significant job cuts amid the pandemic, with 12,000 positions set to be eliminated across IAG, the airline's parent company.

site_title: Taiwan opposition seeks distance from China after poll defeat
summary: Taiwan's main opposition party, the Kuomintang (KMT), has sought to distance itself from China after a senior official, Han Kuo-yu, lost a recall election in Kaohsiung. Han had visited China and met with its top Taiwan-policy maker, fueling accusations of China's influence. The KMT has reasserted its opposition to Beijing and a "Taiwan first" stance, amid growing tensions in Hong Kong and pressure from China to keep Taiwan out of the World Health Organization. The party's youthful new leader, Johnny Chiang, is reviewing policies to address the public's growing dissatisfaction.

site_title: Apple preparing monthly iPad, Mac payment plans for Apple Card
summary: Apple is preparing to offer monthly payment plans for its products, including iPads, Macs, and AirPods, through its Apple Card credit card. The 12-month interest-free plan will be available for iPads, Macs, and select accessories, while six months of interest-free payments will be available for AirPods and other products. The service aims to spur Apple Card enrollment and boost sales by allowing users to split the cost over time. This follows Apple's existing 24-month no-interest payment plan for iPhones.

site_title: Mexico to sit out extension of Opec+ oil output cuts
summary: Mexico will not participate in the extension of Opec+ oil output cuts, which were agreed to be 7.7 million barrels per day until the end of July. The country had initially agreed to reduce its crude output by 100,000 barrels per day in May and June, and will stick to this agreement. This decision comes after Mexico's energy minister, Rocio Nahle, stated that the country is not in a position to make additional cuts, and that there is no problem with the current agreement signed in April.

site_title: Self-driving sector contends its cars can prevent many more crashes than study says
summary: Companies in the self-driving sector have disputed an Insurance Institute for Highway Safety study suggesting only a third of US road crashes can be prevented by driverless cars. The study analyzed 5,000 crashes and found driver perception errors and incapacitation could be prevented. However, the autonomous vehicle industry claims its cars can prevent a much higher number of potential crash causes, including complex errors from drivers. This contradicts the study's conclusion that driverless cars can prevent only 1/3 of US road crashes.

site_title: China May exports slip back into contraction, imports worst in 4 years
summary: China's exports contracted 3.3% in May, reversing a surprise 3.5% gain in April, due to ongoing global coronavirus lockdowns. This marks the second consecutive month of decline. Imports also fell sharply, with a 7.4% drop, the worst in four years, putting pressure on manufacturers. The somber trade readings may prompt policymakers to roll out more support for the critical sector, which accounts for about a third of the economy, affecting over 180 million workers.

site_title: Volkswagen considering more cost cuts to cope with downturn
summary: Volkswagen is considering additional cost cuts to cope with the economic downturn caused by the coronavirus pandemic. The German automaker discussed potential measures at an internal event, including significantly reducing research and development expenditures, investments, and fixed costs. The main VW passenger car brand must reduce material overheads by 20% to achieve a positive result in 2020, as the group's net liquidity is expected to decline until July. There are no concrete decisions yet, but the company aims to respond to the pandemic's economic impact.

site_title: TikTok lookalike Zynn brings Chinese video app rivalry to US
summary: Chinese video app maker Kuaishou has launched Zynn, a short video app that offers cash rewards to users in the US and Canada for inviting friends to download the app. Zynn, a TikTok lookalike, has become the most popular free app in the US Apple App Store just a month after its launch. The app rewards users with cash for watching videos and inviting friends, a model familiar to users in China where startups have offered similar incentives to grab a larger share of the market. Kuaishou's success will depend on whether the app's main attraction is the money up for grabs or whether payment is a secondary benefit.

site_title: Sweden didn't lock down, but economy to plunge anyway
summary: Sweden's economy is expected to plunge despite not implementing lockdown measures during the coronavirus pandemic, with economists predicting a record decline of up to 10% in GDP. The country's economy was heavily reliant on exports, which were impacted by shutdowns in neighboring countries. Unemployment is expected to soar, with the government predicting a rate of 9% for 2020 and 2021. Sweden's approach, which kept businesses open but urged social distancing and hygiene guidelines, has been deemed unsuccessful in softening the economic blow.

site_title: Art Basel show in Switzerland cancelled over coronavirus worries
summary: The Art Basel show in Switzerland, initially scheduled for September, has been cancelled due to health risks and global travel restrictions amid the coronavirus pandemic. The decision was made after discussions with galleries, collectors, and experts. This marks the latest in a series of fairs and auctions, including the Venice Biennale, to be delayed or cancelled. Art Basel in Basel, Switzerland, drew 93,000 attendees last year and joins other events in postponing or cancelling due to the pandemic.

site_title: Petronas CEO to resign after five years: state media
summary: Malaysia's Petronas CEO, Wan Zulkiflee Wan Ariffin, is expected to announce his resignation after five years in the role. He will be succeeded by an internal candidate. The company declined to comment on the rumors, stating that official announcements would be made at the appropriate time. Wan Zulkiflee led Petronas through a tumultuous period of oil prices, including a historic crash in April due to the coronavirus outbreak.

site_title: Ex-NYC housing czar to build affordable rentals across US
summary: Alicia Glen, former NYC housing czar, is launching MSquared to build affordable rentals in smaller US cities. The firm aims to develop housing for middle-income earners, such as teachers and nurses, in areas where rent has surged. Glen plans to raise $300 million for projects in cities like Denver and Austin, using local government donations and property tax reductions. MSquared's projects could make affordable units available within two years, addressing the US shortage of affordable housing and the issue of high rents in cities like Charlotte and Dallas.

site_title: China's forex reserves unexpectedly rise in May, regulator sees stability
summary: China's foreign-exchange reserves rose unexpectedly by $10.23 billion in May to $3.10 trillion, defying expectations of a decline due to fluctuations in global exchange rates and foreign bond prices. The yuan's weakness due to Sino-US tensions was cited as a factor. Despite this, regulators remain optimistic about China's economic stability, citing the country's large reserves as a sign of its economic potential. The unexpected increase in reserves is seen as a positive development for China's economy.

site_title: Malaysia to double deficit to fund stimulus, says finance minister
summary: Malaysia plans to nearly double its fiscal deficit to 6% of annual economic output this year to fund an economic stimulus package worth RM295 billion. The country aims to narrow the deficit back down to less than 4% over the next three years. Finance Minister Tengku Zafrul Aziz said the government will raise the deficit through domestic borrowings, with a direct fiscal injection of RM10 billion. Malaysia's outstanding public debt now stands at 52% of GDP, and the government is considering raising the public debt ceiling if needed.

site_title: Grubhub receives takeover interest from Just Eat Takeaway, Delivery Hero: CNBC
summary: US food delivery company Grubhub has received takeover interest from European companies Just Eat Takeaway.com and Delivery Hero, according to CNBC. The news sent Grubhub's shares up 5% and comes as the food-delivery space faces increasing demand amid the Covid-19 pandemic. Just Eat Takeaway.com is working with Bank of America as an adviser, while Delivery Hero has been exploring potential transactions to evaluate new opportunities. The move is seen as a long-overdue consolidation in the industry.

site_title: Intesa gets nod for UBI takeover, waives Covid-19 clause
summary: Intesa Sanpaolo has received European Central Bank authorization to acquire a 50% stake in UBI Banca, overcoming a Covid-19 provision that could have allowed it to drop the deal. The ECB deemed the merger would raise provisions against loan losses and reduce UBI's impaired loan burden. Intesa waived the "material adverse change" clause, which could have given it the right to walk away due to the pandemic. The deal is subject to approval from Italian antitrust and market authorities.

site_title: EDBI and SEEDS Capital to dole out S$285m startup support
summary: The Economic Development Board (EDBI) and SEEDS Capital will administer a S$285 million Special Situation Fund for Startups (SSFS) to provide financing support to promising Singapore-based startups. The fund, which will be fully committed or exhausted by October 31, 2021, aims to help high-potential startups sustain growth momentum despite the pandemic. Startups will be assessed on a case-by-case basis and will receive funding on a 1:1 basis with private sector co-investors, focusing on late-stage startups with larger funding needs and early-stage startups with strategic capabilities.

site_title: Half of Americans want meat-free options after industry's crisis
summary: US meat industry crisis has led to a shift in consumer preferences, with 52% of Americans considering plant-based options. A survey found that half of respondents believe the industry prioritizes profits over worker health and animal welfare. The crisis has resulted in worker shortages, price surges, and grocery store shortages. This growing demand for meat-free options may prompt the industry to focus more on plant-based foods.

site_title: PM Lee, other Cabinet ministers to speak in national broadcasts on Covid-19
summary: Prime Minister Lee Hsien Loong and other Cabinet ministers will deliver national broadcasts from June 7 to June 20 discussing post-Covid-19 Singapore's future. The broadcasts cover topics such as living safely with Covid-19, maintaining relevance globally, economic competitiveness, creating opportunities for all Singaporeans, and working together to emerge stronger. The broadcasts will be televised in four languages and also available online through various government platforms, aiming to address the country's long-term economic challenges amid the pandemic.

site_title: Virtual certainty? Bankers ask if success of remote roadshows will last
summary: Companies have successfully launched initial public offerings (IPOs) and seen their shares soar through virtual roadshows during the COVID-19 pandemic. These virtual sessions have allowed companies to save time and reduce costs, with some reporting average gains of 35% in US IPOs excluding those of special purpose acquisition companies. However, bankers question whether virtual roadshows will completely replace physical gatherings when the pandemic subsides, citing concerns about the social interaction and ability to ask questions in person, particularly for startups and younger companies.

site_title: Joe Biden clinches US Democratic presidential nomination
summary: Joe Biden has formally clinched the US Democratic presidential nomination after collecting 1,993 delegates, surpassing the 1,991 needed to become the nominee. This marks the beginning of his general election campaign to unseat President Donald Trump. Biden's nomination comes after a prolonged delegate counting process due to postponed primaries and a deal allowing his last challenger, Bernie Sanders, to continue to accrue delegates. Biden will be formally nominated at the Democratic National Convention in August, setting the stage for a potentially contentious general election.

site_title: China considers 200 billion yuan funding to back troubled banks
summary: China is considering using 200 billion yuan (S$39.4 billion) from government bond sales to help address risks in the banking sector, including re-capitalisation for medium and small-sized lenders. This move aims to alleviate the impact of rising bad loans and policies to give loan holidays to businesses, which are expected to further squeeze the asset quality of the banking sector. The plan is still under discussion and subject to changes, as the exact use of funds remains unclear.

site_title: Pound pushes through US$1.27 for first time since March
summary: The pound reached a 7-month high of US$1.27, its strongest since March 12, despite stalled Brexit trade talks. The currency has gained over 3 cents in a week, driven by a weakening US dollar and market expectations of a better-than-50% chance of a deal. However, Brexit-related risks and a high coronavirus death toll continue to weigh on the pound. A transition arrangement to keep previous rules in place expires at the end of 2020 unless extended, which Britain has ruled out.

site_title: Singapore considers tightening casino rules for customers
summary: Singapore is considering tightening its casino rules for customers to prevent money laundering and financing terrorism. The Casino Regulatory Authority (CRA) has asked casino operators to set a threshold for cash transactions of S$5,000, lower than the current S$10,000 and the global standard of US$3,000 set by the Financial Action Task Force. The move aims to fully comply with FATF standards and is part of a review of the Casino Control Act.

site_title: Malaysia prime minister appoints Petronas CEO to run Malaysia Airlines
summary: Malaysia's Prime Minister Muhyiddin Yassin appointed Wan Zulkiflee Wan Ariffin, CEO of Petronas, as chairman of Malaysia Airlines, effective July 1. Wan Zulkiflee will replace Tengku Muhammad Taufik Tengku Aziz, who will take over as Petronas' group CEO. The appointment comes after Wan Zulkiflee was expected to announce his resignation from Petronas. This move aims to revamp Malaysia Airlines' leadership and operations, following the airline's financial struggles.

site_title: Indian travel firm Yatra scraps merger deal with US-based Ebix
summary: Indian travel firm Yatra has scrapped a merger deal with US-based Ebix, citing Ebix's alleged breach of deal terms. Yatra filed a litigation seeking "substantial" damages. The deal, valued at $337.8 million, was agreed upon in 2019. Yatra also announced cost-saving measures, including cutting management salaries by half, amid the Covid-19 pandemic's impact on its business. Shares of Yatra fell 8% in extended trading.

site_title: Trump administration orders Marriott to cease Cuba hotel business
summary: The Trump administration has ordered Marriott International to cease hotel operations in Cuba, ending a four-year detente that began under former President Barack Obama. The US Treasury Department has told Marriott to wind down its operation of the Four Points Sheraton in Havana by August 31. The move aims to pressure Cuba into democratic reform and stop its military from using tourism revenue to "oppress its own people." This decision is seen as a blow to the US-Cuba detente and may harm Cuba's economy, which is already struggling due to declining aid from Venezuela and the end of Cuban medical missions in Brazil.

site_title: China warns against travel to Australia, citing discrimination
summary: China has warned its citizens to avoid traveling to Australia due to alleged racial discrimination and violence against Chinese and Asian individuals amid the COVID-19 pandemic. The warning comes amid strained relations between the two countries, with China accusing Australia of meddling in its affairs and imposing tariffs on Australian imports. Australia has rejected the accusations, calling them "falsely made" by Chinese officials.

site_title: UBS and Bank of America units clear ECB stress test
summary: The European Central Bank announced that UBS Europe SE and Bank of America Merrill Lynch International Designated Activity Company have passed stress tests, clearing a hurdle for relocation of activities to Europe from Britain. The subsidiaries underwent assessments following Brexit, and the results showed no capital shortfall, allowing the banks to proceed with their European expansion plans.

site_title: Buyout firm Sycamore Partners in talks to buy JC Penney: sources
summary: Private equity firm Sycamore Partners is in talks to acquire JC Penney out of bankruptcy if negotiations with creditors fail. The talks, which involve Wells Fargo and mall operators Brookfield and Simon Property Group, come as JC Penney seeks to restructure its nearly $5 billion debt. The company has filed for bankruptcy protection and is in the process of permanently closing stores and cutting jobs. A deal would require bankruptcy judge approval, and the outcome is uncertain.

site_title: Opec+ agrees to extend output cuts as cheats offer penance
summary: Opec+ agreed to extend its record output cuts for one month, maintaining the 9.7 million barrels per day production level until the end of July. The deal comes after Saudi Arabia and Russia successfully convinced Iraq and other laggards to fulfill their production pledges. Members agreed to implement 100% of their production cuts in May and June, with those who fail to do so making extra reductions from July to September. The move aims to build on the cartel's success in pushing the market into a supply deficit, using a price structure to chip away at the billion barrels of oil stockpiles built up during the pandemic.

images.alt_text: Opec+ agreed to a one-month extension of its record output cuts and adopted more stringent methods to ensure members don't break their production pledges.

site_title: Target's hometown tragedy unearths its struggles with diversity
summary: Target, a Minnesota-based retailer, is grappling with its struggles with diversity after a tragic incident in its hometown, Minneapolis, where George Floyd died at the hands of police. The company has a history of progressive policies but has fallen short in retaining minorities and has only two black executives out of 51 top executives. CEO Brian Cornell has been trying to increase diversity, but the company's record on race is less positive. Following the unrest, Target pledged $10 million to social-justice organizations and community rebuilding, and plans to organize its response through a task force.

images.alt_text: It's called the "Minnesota Paradox": the clash of progressive images and racial divides that roils the Gopher State.

site_title: Vatican arrests Italian in investigation of London real estate deal
summary: The Vatican has arrested Gianluigi Torzi, an Italian middleman, on charges of extortion, embezzlement, aggravated fraud, and money laundering in a London real estate deal. Torzi, who was the Vatican's fiduciary for the $200 million purchase, is the first person to be arrested in connection with the deal. The investigation led to the suspension of five Vatican employees, the resignation of the police chief, and the departure of the former head of the Financial Information Authority. The Vatican has defended using Church money for real estate investments, saying it should be allowed to grow to do more good.

site_title: WeWork Global to invest US$100m in India business
summary: WeWork Global is investing US$100 million in its Indian business, aiming to drive growth in the market over the next 36 months. The investment comes after talks to raise funds from Indian lenders broke down last year, following WeWork's failed initial public offering. WeWork India, operated by Embassy Group, had previously laid off 100 employees due to the COVID-19 pandemic. The investment will be used for focused growth and follows a failed attempt to raise US$200 million in funding from new investors last year.

site_title: Reddit co-founder Ohanian resigns from board, wants a black candidate to take over
summary: Reddit co-founder Alexis Ohanian resigned from the board, seeking a black candidate to replace him amid US protests against racism and police brutality. CEO Steve Huffman said the company would honor Ohanian's request and strengthen its content policy to combat hate speech. Ohanian's departure comes after criticism of Reddit's handling of racist speech and its restriction of access to a Trump-support forum. Huffman acknowledged the company's policy shortcomings and pledged to improve its response to hate and racism.

site_title: Twitter, Facebook disable Trump video tribute to Floyd over copyright complaint
summary: US President Donald Trump's campaign tribute video to George Floyd was disabled by Twitter, Facebook, and Instagram due to copyright complaints. The video featured photos and videos of protests and violence following Floyd's death in police custody, with Trump speaking in the background. California lawyer Sam Koolaq claimed his firm submitted the complaints, but details of the specific copyright image were not provided.

site_title: Silver Lake invests another 45.5 billion rupees in Reliance's Jio
summary: A group led by Silver Lake Partners has invested another 45.5 billion Indian rupees (S$839.8 million) in Reliance Industries' digital arm, Jio Platforms, valuing the company at about US$65 billion. This investment follows Silver Lake's initial investment of 56.6 billion rupees last month, and comes as Reliance aims to slash net debt to zero. The digital unit has raised about US$12 billion in less than six weeks from various marquee buyers, including Facebook and KKR & Co.

site_title: Hong Kong central bank sells HK$8.758b after currency rises to trading limit
summary: The Hong Kong Monetary Authority sold HK$8.758 billion in Hong Kong dollars after the currency reached the strong end of its trading band against the US dollar. The currency had traded closer to the stronger end of the limit in recent weeks despite rising political uncertainty. The aggregate balance is expected to increase to HK$104.525 billion on Tuesday. This sale is part of the HKMA's efforts to maintain the stability of the Hong Kong dollar pegged at 7.75 to 7.85 to the US dollar.

site_title: US bonds falter as blazing stock rally lures investors
summary: US government bonds saw their largest outflow in months as investors sought higher returns amid improving economic data. Yields on the 10-year Treasury rose to 0.96%, their highest since March 20, while the 30-year Treasury bond yield reached 1.76%. The economic data, including unexpected job additions in May, suggests a potential "V"-shaped recovery. Investors are shifting from safe-haven assets to riskier investments, with the S&P 500 index rising 2.8% and consumer confidence stabilizing.

site_title: ST Engineering's US unit hit with criminal ransomware attack
summary: ST Engineering's US unit, VT San Antonio Aerospace Inc, was hit with a ransomware attack by the Maze group, gaining unauthorized access to its network and deploying a ransomware attack. The threat was contained, and operations are believed to be isolated to a limited number of US commercial operations. The company's business continues to operate.

site_title: US will allow Chinese passenger carriers two flights per week
summary: The US Transportation Department has allowed Chinese passenger carriers to operate two flights per week to the US, after Beijing eased coronavirus-related restrictions. This decision cuts in half the four weekly round-trip flights Chinese carriers had previously been allowed, and takes effect immediately. The move comes after the US had planned to bar all Chinese passenger airlines from flying to the US by June 16, and is seen as a defusion of a potential new flashpoint in the US-China relationship.

site_title: 'We were wrong': NFL commissioner regrets stance on player protests, condemns racism
summary: NFL Commissioner Roger Goodell has apologized for the league's initial stance on player protests during the national anthem, acknowledging they made mistakes in not listening to players. He condemned racism in the US and expressed support for protests, saying "black lives matter." This comes amid a backlash against President Donald Trump's call for an end to kneeling protests. The NFL has faced criticism over its handling of diversity and inclusion, including a lack of representation among coaching staffs. Goodell plans to reach out to players who have spoken out against racism.

site_title: North Korea criticises South Korea, threatens to close liaison office
summary: North Korea threatened to close the inter-Korean liaison office, citing South Korea's failure to stop defectors from sending leaflets across the border. The move is seen as retaliation for South Korea's efforts to stop the leaflets, which North Korea considers an insult to its leadership. The liaison office, established in 2018, was a symbol of detente between the two countries. North Korea's actions are part of a cooling of relations, which have stalled due to disagreements over North Korea's nuclear weapons.

site_title: Michael Jordan donates US$100m to racial-equality causes
summary: Michael Jordan and the Jordan brand have pledged to donate US$100 million over 10 years to organizations focused on racial equality, social justice, and education. This donation follows similar commitments from corporations such as Bank of America and Goldman Sachs in response to the George Floyd incident. Jordan's pledge marks a shift in his public image, as he has faced criticism for his reluctance to advocate for social causes. The donation aims to address economic and racial inequality, highlighting the growing corporate effort to address social justice issues in the US.

images.alt_text: Michael Jordan and the Jordan brand, produced by Nike, released a joint statement Friday pledging to donate US$100 million over 10 years to "organisations dedicated to ensuring racial equality, social justice and greater access to education".

site_title: Macron is set to unveil rescue package for French aerospace
summary: France's President Emmanuel Macron is set to unveil a rescue package for its pandemic-hammered aerospace industry, including incentives for less-polluting aircraft, part-time work subsidies, and funding for aviation biofuels. The package aims to support European jet manufacturer Airbus and hundreds of French suppliers struggling due to the coronavirus pandemic. The government will also guarantee some Airbus aircraft orders to avoid cancellations. The move is part of a broader stimulus package worth 40 billion euros to support the economy.

site_title: US sues Chinese firm over half-million 'fake' N95 masks
summary: The US Justice Department has sued a Chinese company, King Year Packaging and Printing, for selling nearly half a million fake and substandard N95 respirator masks to US buyers in April. The company falsely claimed the masks met the N95 standard and were certified by the US National Institute for Occupational Safety and Health. The complaint was filed in federal court in Brooklyn, New York, amid the COVID-19 pandemic.

site_title: Fivetran set for unicorn status with new venture backing
summary: Fivetran, a California-based data integration startup, is in advanced talks to raise new funding from investors including General Catalyst and Andreessen Horowitz. The new round is expected to value the company at over $1 billion, a significant increase from its last valuation of $254 million. Fivetran, which helps businesses integrate data from disparate sources, has seen "explosive growth" with a 75% increase in its customer base to over 1,000 companies and 7,800 users. A term sheet has yet to be signed, with the deal awaiting finalization.

site_title: PG&E preparing US$11b debt financing: investor
summary: California utility PG&E Corp is preparing a $11 billion debt-financing package to exit bankruptcy by June 30, allowing it to tap a state-backed fund to cushion the impact of wildfires. The package, consisting of high-yield bonds and term loans, is part of the company's plan to raise up to $27 billion in funding from future public offerings. PG&E's shares rose over 12% following the announcement, with investors expecting the company to pay down debt despite being slightly overleveraged. The company aims to exit bankruptcy and participate in a state-backed wildfire fund.

site_title: Zuckerberg promises review of Facebook content policies after backlash
summary: Facebook CEO Mark Zuckerberg promised to review the company's content policies after staff walked off the job over his handling of President Donald Trump's posts during protests. Zuckerberg acknowledged that the company should have labeled Trump's post containing a threat of violence and vowed to review policies on discussion and threats of state use of force. He also announced plans to increase transparency and build software to advance racial justice. Zuckerberg acknowledged that the current policy approach may lead to editorializing on content, and other options will be considered.

site_title: Golf: Memorial cleared to be first PGA Tour with fans amid Covid-19
summary: The Memorial Tournament, hosted by Jack Nicklaus, will be the first PGA Tour event to allow spectators amid the Covid-19 pandemic, starting July 16-19 at Muirfield Village Golf Club in Ohio. The event follows five spectator-free tournaments and has received state approval and safety plans from Ohio Governor Mike DeWine. The PGA Tour returns to action next week at Colonial Country Club in Fort Worth, Texas.

site_title: American meat chaos lets Argentina back in the beef game
summary: Argentina's beef exports surged to 1,290 tonnes in April, a 650% increase from a year ago, as US meat processing woes created a supply shortfall. The country had previously negotiated access to the US market under President Mauricio Macri and has since set up distribution networks to supply top-end American restaurants. Argentine beef exports climbed 18% in the first four months to 162,000 tonnes, with China being the biggest buyer. The US market reopening has created opportunities for other countries, including Uruguay and Brazil, to benefit from the shortage.

site_title: Oil climbs 5% on US jobless drop, Opec+ meeting hopes
summary: Oil prices rose 5% on Friday after a surprise fall in the US jobless rate to 13.3% in May, and Opec's decision to bring forward discussions on extending record production cuts. Brent crude futures rose 5.8% to $42.30 a barrel, while US West Texas Intermediate crude futures rose 5.7% to $39.55 a barrel. The US jobless drop and Opec's move lifted fuel demand expectations, with analysts hopeful that supplies could dwindle down as lockdowns ease.

site_title: WHO finally endorses masks to prevent coronavirus transmission
summary: The World Health Organization (WHO) finally endorsed the use of face masks by the public to reduce transmission of the coronavirus, despite initial reluctance. The endorsement comes after a growing compendium of observational evidence showing the effectiveness of masks in reducing transmission. The WHO noted potential disadvantages, including difficulty in communicating clearly and potential discomfort, but emphasized that governments should encourage mask wearing. The organization's stance on respirator masks for healthcare workers remains unchanged, but a recent study found that N95 masks are more effective than surgical masks in protecting healthcare workers.

site_title: Massive apartment on Manhattan's Billionaires' Row sells for US$28m
summary: A full-floor apartment on Manhattan's One57 sold for US$28 million, marking a 41% discount from its original price of US$47.4 million in 2014. The buyer and seller are related, raising questions about the unit's true market value. This sale is the largest discount at the 1,004-foot skyscraper, which has seen a decline in resale values due to a glut of high-end choices and slackening demand in the ultra-luxury market.

site_title: British PM offers to accept EU tariffs on some goods to win trade deal: report
summary: British Prime Minister Boris Johnson is reportedly willing to accept EU tariffs on some UK goods in exchange for dropping EU rules. This move comes as negotiations for a Brexit free-trade agreement stall, with just weeks left to meet a year-end deadline. The UK had previously threatened to walk away from talks if no progress was made, but the coronavirus outbreak has relaxed this threat. EU officials have not immediately welcomed the idea of tariffs, but the UK's chief negotiator, David Frost, made a new offer to the EU.

site_title: 'Dear White People' TV series and 'This Is America' song see surge
summary: Nationwide protests against police brutality have led to a surge in demand for content related to racism and black experiences. Netflix's series "Dear White People" has seen a 329% increase in interest, while the 2019 documentary "When They See Us" has seen a 147% spike. Childish Gambino's song "This Is America" has re-entered the top 50 on Spotify. Several books on race relations, including "How to Be an Antiracist" and "Invisible Man", have sold out on Amazon. Podcasts such as "1619" and "Code Switch" have also gained popularity.

site_title: G-20 pledges more than US$21b to fight coronavirus
summary: The Group of 20 (G-20) rich and emerging economies has pledged over $21 billion to support the global fight against the coronavirus pandemic. The funds will be directed towards diagnostics, vaccines, therapeutics, and research and development. This coordinated effort aims to combat the Covid-19 pandemic, with the pledges being made by G-20 members and invited countries.

site_title: US weighs blacklisting dozens more oil tankers over Venezuela
summary: The US is considering imposing sanctions on dozens of additional foreign oil tankers for trading with Venezuela, targeting around 40 ships, including 25 supertankers. The move aims to sever President Nicolas Maduro's "lifeline" to the US, amid allegations of illicit transactions. Sanctions could be announced soon, potentially disrupting global seaborne trade and sharply raising tanker rates. The US has already blacklisted shipping firms and companies for violating restrictions on doing business with Venezuela, and has warned of further sanctions if the trading activity persists.

site_title: Halted shares of Sembcorp Marine, parent in focus in Singapore
summary: Shares of Sembcorp Marine and Sembcorp Industries remain halted, sparking speculation about a potential deal between the two companies. Analysts at Citi believe an announcement would involve a transaction between the companies. Sembmarine's shares rose 17% on Wednesday, while SCI's shares increased 4.8%. The halt comes after Sembmarine's Brazilian subsidiary entered a US$500 million revolving facility agreement, which could be reviewed if SCI ceases to be the majority shareholder. Both companies declined to comment on the situation.

site_title: California says film and TV production can resume as early as June 12
summary: California officials approved new guidelines to resume film and TV production on June 12, with producers needing approval from local health officials to restart filming. This decision comes after filming was halted in mid-March to curb the coronavirus pandemic.

site_title: Ascena Retail, owner of Ann Taylor apparel chain, mulls bankruptcy filing to manage debt
summary: Ascena Retail Group, owner of Ann Taylor and Lane Bryant, is considering a Chapter 11 bankruptcy filing to manage debt. The company is discussing a potential sale of three brands, including Catherines, while keeping Ann Taylor and Loft. Lenders are exploring a deal where they exchange holdings for a majority stake in the reorganized company. Bankruptcy protection would allow the company to avoid a permanent shutdown and cut borrowings, but the outcome depends on market conditions and store reopenings. Ascena's financial troubles predated the pandemic, with sales sliding and borrowings ballooning to over $1 billion.

site_title: Hertz's possibly worthless stock soars in risky recovery bet
summary: Hertz Global Holdings' shares surged 353% after the company filed for bankruptcy, driven by signs of air travel's rebound and rising used car prices. Investors are taking on significant risk, as shareholders rarely recover from companies filing for Chapter 11. Analysts predict a low chance of full recapitalization and a higher chance of asset-backed securities being made whole. The stock may trade as low as $0.50 or below, according to options market data.

site_title: Zoom stock surge gives little-known early investor a fortune
summary: Taiwanese investor Samuel Chen, a little-known early investor in Zoom Video Communications, has seen his fortune surge to over $1.6 billion after the company's stock quintupled since its IPO last year. Chen's Digital Mobile Venture controls a 1.6 billion-dollar stake in Zoom, and he credits Telenav CEO H P Jin for introducing him to founder Eric Yuan. Analysts are split on the stock's prospects, but some see opportunities in Zoom's cloud-based phone offering and unified communications provider potential.

site_title: Victoria's Secret UK arm goes into administration
summary: The UK arm of lingerie retailer Victoria's Secret has gone into administration, putting over 800 jobs at risk. The company, which operates 25 shops across the UK, blames the economic impact of the coronavirus epidemic for its downfall. Administrator Deloitte stated that the pandemic has had a significant impact on the UK high street and the entire retail industry.

site_title: Economic transformation must speed up for Singapore's survival beyond Covid-19 crisis
summary: Deputy Prime Minister and Finance Minister Heng Swee Keat warned that Singapore's unemployment rate could exceed 100,000 in 2020 due to the Covid-19 pandemic, despite efforts to mitigate its impact. The government's top priority is to save jobs through the SGUnited Jobs and Skills package, which aims to create 100,000 job opportunities in emerging industries. Heng emphasized the need for economic transformation and accelerated growth in technology, innovation, and enterprise to ensure Singapore's survival in the post-pandemic world.

images.alt_text: "In our next phase of growth, we must anchor Singapore as a Global-Asia node of technology, innovation and enterprise," Mr Heng said.

site_title: Fearing violence, France bans George Floyd protests at US Embassy, Eiffel Tower
summary: French police banned George Floyd protests at the US Embassy and Eiffel Tower due to risks of social disorder and health dangers from large gatherings amid the coronavirus pandemic. The ban comes as protests mount globally over Floyd's death in Minneapolis. French government spokesperson Sibeth Ndiaye dismissed comparisons between police violence in France and the US, citing no systemic state violence and incidents being fully investigated and punished. The move follows unrest in the US and previous protests in France, where some law enforcement officials have been accused of disproportionate use of force.

site_title: Wirecard offices searched in probe targeting senior management
summary: German prosecutors searched Wirecard AG's headquarters as part of a probe targeting senior management, alleging "misleading signals" on market manipulation. The investigation is focused on the company's management board, including CEO Markus Braun, and does not target the company itself. Wirecard shares fell 12% after the search, but surged following the company's statement that the issue will be resolved and allegations prove unfounded. The probe follows repeated allegations of accounting fraud and is related to the company's special audit by KPMG, which found internal "shortcomings" and was unable to confirm past revenues.

site_title: Prestigious UK schools push on with plans to open in China
summary: Harrow School, a 450-year-old UK institution, plans to open five schools in China, despite the COVID-19 pandemic. This move is expected to capitalize on the region's growing demand for English-language international schools, projected to double by 2029. Other prestigious English schools are likely to follow, seeking to tap into China's relatively well-managed pandemic response and maturing market.

images.alt_text: In the 2017-2018 school year, Harrow received more than £3 million (S$5.3 million) from its international schools.

site_title: UK seeks to boost post-Brexit ties with Asean partnership
summary: Britain has applied to become a dialogue partner of the Association of Southeast Asian Nations (Asean), seeking to boost post-Brexit ties in the region. Asean has 10 existing dialogue partners, including the European Union, Australia, Canada, Japan, and the US. The UK hopes the partnership will lead to new opportunities in trade, education, science, and security. This move comes as the UK seeks to expand its international relationships after leaving the EU.

site_title: Government committed to rebuilding reserves: Heng Swee Keat
summary: Deputy Prime Minister and Finance Minister Heng Swee Keat stated that the Singapore government is committed to rebuilding its reserves, drawing from past reserves to finance support packages worth S$100 billion to combat the COVID-19 pandemic. The government has drawn S$52 billion from reserves, with no constitutional obligation to restore the funds. Heng emphasized the need for prudent governance and ensuring resources for future challenges, noting that the reserves are a limited resource and should not be taken for granted.

site_title: US: Wall Street rallies to end higher on surprise jobs report
summary: US stocks surged on Friday, with the Nasdaq breaching its all-time closing high and all three major US stock indices advancing 2% or more. The jobs report showed a 2.5 million job gain in May, pushing the unemployment rate down to 13.3%, exceeding analysts' expectations. The S&P 500 and Dow Jones Industrial Average rose 2.62% and 3.15%, respectively, while Treasury yields rose, benefiting interest rate-sensitive banks. The market now turns its focus to the US Federal Reserve's monetary policy meeting next week, where the latest jobs data will likely be discussed.

site_title: Gold sags as 'mind-blowing' US unemployment rate curbs haven demand
summary: Gold prices have declined for the third consecutive week, falling 2.6% to $1,683 an ounce, amid a stronger-than-expected US job market and signs of a faster-than-anticipated global economic recovery. The US unemployment rate fell to 13.3% from 14.7%, boosting investor confidence and reducing haven demand for gold. However, some analysts expect gold prices to recover in the second half of the year due to low yields and negative real rates.

site_title: HP scores US$439m win on Quanta's factories, patents
summary: A federal appeals court ruled in favor of HP Inc, ordering Quanta Storage to surrender its factories, patents, and cash worth $439 million to satisfy a 2019 antitrust judgment. Quanta had failed to post a $85 million bond, leading to the initial order. The appeals court rejected Quanta's claims that the pandemic prevented it from complying with Taiwanese regulations, upholding the original judgment. The ruling allows HP to keep the assets and patents, with the company stating it will ensure Quanta complies with the turnover orders.

site_title: Airbus fails to log any jet orders as airlines hunker down
summary: Airbus failed to secure a single plane order in May due to the global travel slump caused by the coronavirus pandemic. The company handed over 24 aircraft to customers, with Indian budget airline IndiGo taking six planes. Airbus has lowered its build rates by more than a third and is considering further reductions as it adapts to a depressed market. The company has also entered talks with labor groups that could lead to thousands of permanent job cuts. Despite this, Airbus' sales tally for the first five months remained at 299 planes net of cancellations.

site_title: Opec, Russia meet to extend record oil cuts, push for compliance
summary: Opec and Russia meet to extend record oil production cuts, aiming to push for better compliance among member countries. The current cuts, in place since May-June, will taper to 7.7 million barrels per day from July to December. Global oil prices rose nearly 6% on Friday, trading at a three-month high above $42. Iraq agreed to additional cuts, while Nigeria aims to reach full compliance, contingent on meeting its production quotas. The meeting aims to maintain price stability amid the ongoing pandemic.

site_title: Blood pressure drugs linked to lower Covid-19 death risk; two journals retract studies
summary: A new study found that taking blood pressure medications can lower the risk of severe illness and death from COVID-19. Researchers analyzed data from nearly 2,900 hospitalised patients in China and found that those with hypertension who took blood pressure drugs had a significantly lower risk of death compared to those who did not. Two journals, The Lancet and The New England Journal of Medicine, have since retracted studies on COVID-19 treatments due to concerns over data veracity.

site_title: Europe: Stocks rack up hefty gains as cyclicals rally
summary: European stocks surged 2.5% on Friday, ending their best week in two months, as investors bid up shares of banks, automakers, and travel companies amid signs of a recovering global economy. The STOXX 600 index rose 3.8% in the euro zone, with growth-sensitive sectors like oil & gas, automakers, and travel & leisure gaining 4.9-5.8%. Analysts predict another 10% rise by September, driven by business activity and tourist traffic hopes.

site_title: Virtual blockchain summit attendees set to get at least US$1m in Bitcoin payouts
summary: Draper Goren Holm, a blockchain venture studio, is pledging to give away at least $1 million in Bitcoin payouts to attendees of its virtual Los Angeles blockchain summit. This initiative aims to drive adoption of blockchain technology, reminiscent of the early Bitcoin Faucet that gave away tokens as rewards. The event is set to take place later this year, marking a push to stimulate interest in the space.

site_title: Malaysia rolls out RM35b in additional stimulus
summary: Malaysia has unveiled an additional RM35 billion (S$11.4 billion) stimulus package to aid its economy's recovery from the coronavirus pandemic. The package includes RM10 billion in direct fiscal injection, RM5 billion for wage subsidies, RM2 billion for upskilling programs, and RM1 billion for small and medium-sized tourism enterprises. The move aims to put a floor on economic growth, which is expected to dip due to the pandemic's full impact. The combined stimulus packages account for 20% of the country's GDP, following a previous RM250 billion package.

site_title: Miguel McKelvey, co-founder of WeWork with Adam Neumann, to leave company
summary: Miguel McKelvey, co-founder of WeWork, will leave the company at the end of June. This decision comes as the office-sharing startup faces an existential threat due to the COVID-19 pandemic, which has significantly impacted occupancy rates. McKelvey's exit follows a series of top executive departures, including co-CEOs Artie Minson and Sebastian Gunningham. WeWork is undergoing a turnaround plan under SoftBank-controlled management, led by executive chairman Marcelo Claure. McKelvey's departure is part of the company's efforts to shake up its management ranks amidst a tumultuous period since abandoning its IPO.

site_title: Marina Bay Sands casino probed over money laundering controls
summary: The US Justice Department has issued a grand jury subpoena to a former compliance chief of Marina Bay Sands (MBS) in Singapore, seeking records related to potential money laundering breaches in handling top gamblers' accounts. The probe, likely in its early stages, also seeks information on retaliation against whistleblowers. MBS, owned by Las Vegas Sands, has responded by stating it takes any allegations of wrongdoing seriously and has investigated every claim. The US inquiry follows similar probes in Singapore and Las Vegas, where LVS has faced scrutiny over money transfer policies and alleged bribery.

site_title: Optimism over global recovery weakens gold despite weaker dollar
summary: Gold prices rose to a high of $1,761 an ounce in early weekly trading, boosted by a weak US dollar. The dollar index had dropped to a two-and-a-half-month low, fueled by continued unrest in the US. However, optimism over global recovery weakened gold prices, as investors shifted focus to the sector. Despite this, the dollar's decline is expected to drive gold demand in Asia, where dollar asset diversification is on the rise.

site_title: Secondment of construction workers to be reviewed
summary: Singapore to review plans for secondment of construction workers due to firms' needs for their own projects, following feedback from companies. The review aims to optimize manpower distribution and restart construction projects sooner. The Manpower Ministry and BCA will work with the industry to find better solutions. The government also provides support for companies with foreign workers who cannot resume work, including foreign worker levy waivers and rebates.

site_title: Geo Energy fails to get noteholders' nod to ease notes terms
summary: Geo Energy Resources, an Indonesian coal miner, failed to get noteholders' consent to amend the indenture governing its 8% senior notes, which would have given the group more financial flexibility. The company instead offered to buy back the outstanding US$154 million notes at a lower price, with a total gain of US$30.7 million expected from the settlement. The move aims to provide more financial flexibility for the group, which is currently carrying out exploration activities to locate additional coal reserves.

site_title: Singapore building vaccine manufacturing capacity in Covid-19 fight: PM Lee
summary: Singapore is building up its vaccine manufacturing capacity to support the global fight against COVID-19. Prime Minister Lee Hsien Loong announced that the country will offer fill-and-finish contract manufacturing services to vaccine developers, aiming to speed up production and ensure high safety and quality standards. Singapore is also investing in international efforts to combat the virus, contributing $13 million to global initiatives, and leveraging its research expertise to develop new cures and diagnostics.

site_title: Judge slams Ernst & Young for attack on ex-partner during trial
summary: A London judge has criticized Ernst & Young for its treatment of a whistle-blower during a trial, calling the firm's lawyers' behavior "unfair" and "vindictive." The firm, one of the Big Four accountants, was ordered to pay $10.8 million to Amjad Rihan, an auditor who blew the whistle on wrongdoing at a Dubai gold refiner. The judge also said the firm's lawyers made "rancor and ill will" towards Rihan, who was subjected to unfair attacks on his character and integrity. The ruling may lead to further increases in the reward to Rihan.

images.alt_text: A London judge slammed Ernst & Young for its treatment of a whistle-blower during a trial the accounting firm lost earlier this year.

site_title: Oil honchos hit pay dirt as their companies go broke
summary: Oil executives are receiving significant payouts despite their companies filing for bankruptcy. Thirty-five executives at Whiting Petroleum Corp, Chesapeake Energy Corp, and Diamond Offshore Drilling Inc are set to share nearly $50 million in bonuses. This is due to a provision that guarantees bonuses even in bankruptcy, allowing executives to maximize value for creditors. Executives like Whiting Petroleum Corp's CEO Brad Holly received a $900,000 pay raise after filing for bankruptcy.

site_title: Brave new news world
summary: The world has become increasingly polarized, with fake news and misinformation on the rise. The Newseum's closure in 2019 symbolizes the shift from a culture of journalism and truth to one of commodified news. With the proliferation of online platforms, people are consuming news in a superficial manner, often taking in multiple articles simultaneously. This has led to a decline in deep literacy and critical thinking. To navigate this "brave new news world," individuals must take small, careful steps, such as verifying news sources, paying for quality publications, and limiting their exposure to social media and scrolling. By doing so, they can develop the skills to defend themselves against misinformation and cultivate a more informed and engaged citizenry.

site_title: This dead cat has nine lives
summary: The global economy is experiencing catastrophic conditions, including high unemployment, Covid-19 deaths, and trade wars, yet most markets have developed strong uptrends. The US market and Shanghai index have shown resilience, with the Nasdaq leading the way in terms of behavior. Investors are advised to focus on price charts and trend lines, such as trend line A and B, to identify potential entry and exit points. A retreat towards trend line A may provide an opportunity for investors to enter, while a breakout above a certain level may require caution. The key is to quickly recognize when the market is wrong and adjust accordingly.

site_title: Virus boosting demand for flexible offices
summary: Workspace Group, a London-based flexible office operator, sees growing demand for its services despite the coronavirus outbreak. The company has offered 50% discounts and rent deferrals to customers, collecting 70% of rent due this quarter. The shift to flexible offices may push companies to pay a premium for flexibility over long-term leases, potentially benefiting Workspace Group. If firms can survive the initial financial impact, demand is expected to surge, with CEO Graham Clemett stating that the company is well-positioned to capitalize on this trend.

site_title: High yield stocks provide bright spots in gloomy economy: analysts
summary: Analysts say high-yield stocks offer bright spots in the gloomy economy, despite some companies cutting dividends to conserve cash. Among Singapore-listed companies, certain stocks are attractive yield plays, excluding real estate investment trusts (Reits) which face increased risks due to legislated rental waivers. Analysts are positive on SGX earnings and raise target prices, citing a defensive play benefiting from volatility.

site_title: Singapore shares end higher for fifth straight session, up 1.6%
summary: The Straits Times Index (STI) in Singapore ended higher for the fifth straight session, up 1.6% at 2,751.50 points. Advancers outpaced decliners 347 to 140, with about 1.49 billion securities changing hands. The gains followed a muted start to the day after a dip in US shares, and were boosted by strong stimulus support from the European Central Bank and the White House. Key stocks including Jardine Matheson Holdings and Singtel saw significant gains, while Singapore Airlines fell 1.1%.

site_title: Citing Covid-19, Australia bars George Floyd protests
summary: Australian authorities banned nationwide protests inspired by George Floyd's death, citing the risk of new coronavirus infections and tracing participants. Health Minister Greg Hunt said large gatherings would be "impossible to trace" and a Supreme Court injunction was secured to prevent the largest rally in Sydney. Despite the ban, some protesters vowed to carry on, with rally organiser Raul Bassi stating he would "fight for what is true." The decision was made to prioritize public health, with Australia avoiding high infections and casualties since March.

site_title: Video games are the new kings of communication
summary: Video game platforms like Fortnite and Roblox are shifting their focus from gaming to becoming media hubs, offering exclusive movie and music content. Country music star Garth Brooks plans to release new songs within Zynga's mobile games, while Roblox partners with the movie and music industries to host content. These platforms aim to create interactive experiences where players can socialize and consume entertainment, offering extra features unavailable in real-life events. This trend is seen as a long-term opportunity for gaming companies to attract a broad audience and generate revenue through exclusive concerts, virtual merchandise, and season passes.

site_title: Our eyes: Our first defence
summary: Singapore's emergence from the "circuit breaker" period highlights the need for a long-term plan for eye care to prepare for future outbreaks. Eye diseases, such as glaucoma and macular degeneration, can be avoided through early detection and preventive treatment. The COVID-19 pandemic has led to a backlog of eye care cases, with patients delaying medical attention due to healthcare bottlenecks. To address this, ophthalmologists recommend efficient use of downtime, improved clinic infection control, and increased emphasis on eye screening for patients with risk factors. A measured approach to eye care can help restore function and prevent vision loss, enabling individuals to resume their daily activities.

site_title: Govt aware of risk that rental help may prolong exit of unviable businesses: Shanmugam
summary: Singapore's Law Minister K Shanmugam stated that the government's focus on extending rental relief is on supporting viable businesses affected by the Covid-19 crisis, rather than prolonging the exit of unviable businesses. The government aims to protect workers and livelihoods by providing relief to eligible small and medium-sized enterprises (SMEs) that have suffered a 35% fall in revenue. The amendment Bill includes measures such as rental waivers, arrears repayment schemes, and relief for tenants who cannot vacate premises due to Covid-19, while also introducing safeguards to prevent fraudulent behavior.

site_title: Oil trader Winson takes OCBC to court over Hin Leong deal
summary: Winson Oil Trading is suing OCBC Bank over a US$30.4 million payment for a fuel sale to the collapsed Singapore oil trader Hin Leong, which was financed by OCBC. OCBC claims "serious doubts" about Hin Leong's paperwork and cargo backing the finance deal, and does not have to pay Winson. The case comes weeks after a court dismissed an application by Unipec Singapore to stop Credit Agricole from paying Hin Leong. Over 23 banks, including OCBC, are owed nearly US$4 billion by the collapsed trader.

site_title: Keppel O&M, Borr Drilling defer delivery of 5 jackup rigs to 2022
summary: Keppel O&M, a subsidiary of KEPPEL Corp, has entered into a framework deed with Borr Drilling to defer the delivery of five jackup rigs to 2022. This move follows Borr Drilling's announcement to strengthen its liquidity situation by postponing yard commitments and deferring cash interest payments. The rigs will be partially financed by Keppel O&M through seller's credit arrangements, with the total amount totaling around US$415.3 million. This agreement is not expected to impact Keppel Corp's net tangible assets or earnings per share for fiscal 2020.

site_title: EU to start opening external borders from July
summary: The European Union will lift internal border controls by the end of June, with most EU governments expected to do so by June 15. Restrictions on travel to and from other countries will be lifted in July. Meanwhile, China's GDP growth is forecasted to slow, raising concerns for policymakers. The UK economy contracted for the second month, while South Korea's trade chief seeks a 'landing zone' in US trade talks.

images.alt_text: The European Union will only fully open internal borders by the end of June and begin lifting restrictions on travel to and from other countries in July, EU Home Affairs Commissioner Ylva Johansson said on Friday.

site_title: Reits (June 06-07, 2020)
summary: Realtors and investors are closely monitoring the market for Singapore's prime projects, as a Q3 wave of condo launches is expected to test demand above the S$3,000 psf benchmark. Meanwhile, US mortgage rates have climbed after five weeks of declines, affecting the housing market. In the UK, homebuyer demand has rebounded to a six-month high, and in the US, Manhattan rents have reached another record. WeWork has secured new tenants and filled more space at its post-bankruptcy office building in Singapore. These developments indicate a shift in market trends and investor sentiment.

site_title: Four Budgets may help avert 5 percentage point output loss
