summary: Deputy Prime Minister and Finance Minister Heng Swee Keat says Singapore's four Budgets this year may help the country avoid a 5% output loss and S$23.4 billion in losses over 2020 and 2021. The Budgets total S$193 billion, including S$100 billion in response to the Covid-19 crisis, and S$13 billion in the Contingencies Fund. Heng emphasized the importance of national reserves and Singapore's fiscal strategy in enabling a swift and decisive response to the crisis, and cautioned that borrowing could lead to unsustainable debt financing for future generations.

site_title: Diversifying operations and talent pool helps medtech firm find new income streams amid Covid-19
summary: Forefront Medical Technologies (FMT), a Singapore-based medtech firm, has diversified its operations to tap into the growing healthcare innovation market and mitigate risks amid the Covid-19 pandemic. With a S$1.5 million investment, the company expanded its cleanrooms, built automation capabilities, and diversified its talent pool. This diversification has enabled FMT to pivot into the diagnostics space, securing four Covid-19-related projects, including producing 3D-printed nasal swabs. The firm's president attributes its success to Singapore's safe and innovative reputation, as well as the country's ability to attract multinational firms.

site_title: Silence on race no longer an option for corporations
summary: Major US corporations have responded to recent racial events with public statements and pledges, with all but six of the 50 largest companies in the US having made a public stand. Since May 25, when George Floyd's death sparked protests, companies have pledged over $1 billion to support black Americans and address racial injustice. CEOs have spoken out, with some, like Goldman Sachs' David Solomon, expressing horror at the continued attacks against the black community. The reactions have been varied, but silence is no longer an option, with companies recognizing the importance of taking a public stand.

images.alt_text: Black Americans, already ravaged by a fatal virus that is two or three times more deadly in their communities, have spread the protests from the streets to social media, contending that corporate silence is the same as complicity.

site_title: UOB seeks to maintain dividend policy despite Covid-19 woes
summary: United Overseas Bank (UOB) aims to maintain its 50% dividend payout ratio this year despite the challenging business climate due to the COVID-19 pandemic. The bank will review its dividend policy later in the year when more clarity emerges. UOB's Q1 net profit fell 19% to S$855 million, and the bank expects net interest margin to face downward pressure due to interest rate cuts. The bank has set aside sufficient provisions to strengthen coverage and has a healthy and well-diversified loan portfolio.

site_title: US: Wall St jumps on surprise fall in unemployment rate
summary: US stocks surged on Friday after a surprise drop in the unemployment rate, boosting hopes for a faster economic rebound. The Dow Jones Industrial Average rose 2.11% to 26,836.80, while the S&P 500 and Nasdaq Composite also opened higher, reaching fresh records. The unemployment rate drop fueled optimism, despite ongoing tariff uncertainty and split Federal Reserve views.

site_title: Circuit breaker sends April retail sales into sharpest fall in 30 years
summary: Singapore's retail sales plummeted 40.5% year-on-year in April, the sharpest fall in over 30 years, due to "circuit-breaker" measures to contain the Covid-19 outbreak. This decline deepened the -13.3% drop in March and marked the 15th consecutive month of decline. Supermarkets saw a boom, while sales in discretionary items plummeted.

images.alt_text: Singapore's retail sales tumbled 40.5 per cent year on year in April - the sharpest fall in more than three decades - triggered by "circuit-breaker" measures implemented between April 7 and June 1 to contain the Covid-19 outbreak.

site_title: Business formation to stay subdued, cessation to pick up
summary: Singapore's business formation is expected to remain subdued due to the ongoing Covid-19 pandemic, while cessations may increase in the coming months. In April, 3,800 businesses were formed, 33% lower than the annual average from 2015 to 2019. Cessations were comparable to the average of 3,700 in the same month over the past five years. Outward-oriented sectors are expected to be severely impacted, while sectors like biomedical manufacturing and information and communications are expected to continue growing.

site_title: Oil India calls on Singapore experts to handle gas blowout
summary: Oil India has sought assistance from Singapore-based Alert Disaster Control to contain a blowout at one of its wells in the Baghjan oilfield in northeastern Assam. The blowout occurred on May 27 after an uncontrolled gas emission while producing gas from a new reservoir at a depth of 3,729 metres. Oil India suspended operations at the well and experts from Alert Disaster Control are expected to reach the site shortly to handle the situation.

site_title: For every budding baker, there are plenty of hapless home cooks
summary: During the pandemic, many people, especially those who don't cook or prefer simple meals, have taken to cooking as a therapeutic escape or mode of entertainment. However, others, including some who have tried cooking, have found it to be frustrating and unfulfilling. Some have reported disastrous results, such as burnt or charred food, while others have made mistakes like overcooking pasta or underseasoning dishes. Despite these challenges, some individuals have found joy and pride in their cooking attempts, often through social media platforms or online resources.

site_title: Why China may call the world's bluff on Hong Kong
summary: China is imposing its will on Hong Kong, potentially damaging the city's economy and liberties, as part of a new national security law. The move is seen as a calculation by the Communist Party that control and stability outweigh the benefits Hong Kong has provided as a freewheeling financial hub. This comes as China's global economic influence grows, with the world relying on China, with or without Hong Kong, to drive growth. The Chinese government's actions may be seen as a test of the world's willingness to accommodate China's increasing control.

site_title: The demise of the business-to-consumer model
summary: The business-to-consumer model is set to shift to the consumer-to-business model due to the widespread adoption of IoT and AI. With the help of IoT and AI, businesses can collect and utilize data from consumers to create customized products and services, leading to a more personalized experience. This shift will enable consumers to provide feedback to businesses directly, resulting in a near-perfect delivery of products and services. The C2B model will dominate, allowing consumers to participate in the entire value chain, from designing to marketing and sales, and reducing the need for middlemen.

site_title: CapitaLand proposes scrip dividend scheme; opens star attraction at Chongqing mall
summary: CapitaLand proposes a scrip dividend scheme, allowing shareholders to receive cash dividends in new shares, reducing costs. The company plans to retain the cash for growth and expansion, strengthening its working capital. A new article in its constitution will be introduced to facilitate the scheme. Meanwhile, CapitaLand's Raffles City Chongqing mall in China has opened its 250-metre high Exploration Deck Viewing Gallery, which boasts a 270-degree panoramic view of the city's skyline, attracting almost all available tickets during its opening weekend.

site_title: 'No benefit' from hydroxychloroquine for Covid-19: major UK trial
summary: A major UK trial of hydroxychloroquine found the drug has "no benefit" for patients hospitalized with Covid-19, leading researchers to halt the trial. The University of Oxford trial, testing various treatments for the new coronavirus, concluded there is no beneficial effect of hydroxychloroquine on patients hospitalized with Covid-19. The trial will stop recruiting patients to the hydroxychloroquine part immediately.

site_title: Hong Kong: Stocks surge for fifth straight gain
summary: Hong Kong stocks surged for a fifth consecutive gain, driven by optimism over easing lockdown measures and the global economy. The Hang Seng Index rose 1.66%, reaching 24,770.41, while the Shanghai Composite Index and Shenzhen Composite Index also saw gains. The rally comes despite tariff uncertainty and mixed Federal Reserve views.

site_title: Costs of safe management measures will pay off: Chan Chun Sing
summary: Trade and Industry Minister Chan Chun Sing stated that implementing safe management measures at the workplace will incur costs and inconvenience but pay off in the long run, speeding up the reopening of the economy. This will provide more stability for employers and minimize the risk of employee exposure to the coronavirus.

site_title: Hyflux receives notice of termination for Algerian O&M contract
summary: Hyflux received a notice of termination for its operations and maintenance (O&M) contract for the Magtaa seawater desalination plant in Algeria, issued by the project's owner, Tahlyat Myah Magtaa (TMM). The contract, which Hyflux has a 47% stake in, is expected to have a material impact on the group's financial performance for the year ending December 31, 2020. Hyflux Operation & Maintenance Algeria disputes the allegations and will seek advice on enforcement and protection of its rights. The company has 40 days to cure the purported events of default.

site_title: MAS, police launch probe into EHT current, former directors over disclosures
summary: The Monetary Authority of Singapore (MAS) and the Commercial Affairs Department (CAD) have launched a joint investigation into Eagle Hospitality Trust's (EHT) current and former directors over suspected breaches of disclosure requirements. The probe was triggered by a referral from Singapore Exchange Regulation (SGX RegCo) regarding potential breaches of laws and regulations related to EHT's real estate investment trust, Eagle Hospitality Reit (EH-Reit). Trading in EHT stapled securities was suspended after its managers received a demand for repayment of a US$341 million loan, following non-payment of rent by the sponsor and master lessee of EH-Reit's properties.

site_title: Corporate digest
summary: SIA Engineering's shares surged 20 Singapore cents or 9.9% to close at S$2.22 on Friday, following unusual trading activity. The firm confirmed it was in compliance with listing rules and attributed the rally to improved market sentiment for the aviation industry due to border reopenings and flight announcements.

site_title: Koh Brothers lowers final dividend from 0.4 to 0.25 Singapore cent a share
summary: Koh Brothers Group, a Singapore-based construction and property company, lowered its final dividend per share from 0.4 to 0.25 Singapore cent for 2019 due to the severe impact of the Covid-19 pandemic on its core industries. The company cited financial uncertainty and a need to conserve cash flow resources to sustain business operations and meet anticipated challenges. The revised dividend will be tabled at the annual general meeting for shareholder approval.

site_title: Bentley to cut 1,000 UK jobs in recovery plan after virus
summary: Bentley Motors plans to cut up to 1,000 UK jobs, about a quarter of its workforce, to contain costs amid the coronavirus crisis. This move, part of a recovery plan, follows other British auto-industry job cuts. Bentley aims to reduce headcount through voluntary measures but may consider compulsory redundancies. The company also plans to accelerate development of new vehicles to meet stricter emission rules, including hybrid and battery-powered cars. The restructuring is designed to improve long-term profitability and offset the pandemic's impact.

site_title: Govt considered that rental help may prolong exit of unviable businesses: Shanmugam
summary: Singapore's government has passed the Covid-19 (Temporary Measures) (Amendment) Bill, which provides additional rental relief to eligible small and medium-sized enterprises (SMEs) that have suffered a 35% fall in revenue. The relief is intended to support viable businesses that may be felled by the crisis, rather than prolonging the exit of unviable ones. The bill also sets out a repayment scheme for arrears, provides relief for tenants, and caps late-payment interest or charges. Landlords can draw on tenants' existing security deposits to offset accumulated rental arrears, with safeguards in place to prevent fraudulent behavior.

site_title: North Korea expresses support for China's measures in Hong Kong
summary: North Korea's foreign minister expressed support for China's measures in Hong Kong, stating that the issue is China's internal affairs and that external interference violates China's sovereignty. North Korea's comments come after China imposed a new national security law on Hong Kong. The foreign minister also criticized the US for threatening to suppress anti-racism protests, drawing parallels with China's response to the issue. China's ambassador to North Korea expressed gratitude for the support.

site_title: VW board to review internal probe into racist car ad
summary: Volkswagen's management board is reviewing an internal probe into a racist car ad featuring a black man being pushed into a building with the sign "Petit Colon". The internal report has been completed, but its findings will not be released until the management board reviews the matter. The ad was published in 2020, sparking widespread criticism and calls for the company to take action. The outcome of the review is not yet known, but the incident remains a significant issue for the German carmaker.

images.alt_text: Volkswagen has completed an internal report into how it came to publish a racist advert, the German carmaker said on Friday, adding that its findings will be released once its management board has reviewed the matter.

site_title: Thailand to tout 'trusted' tourism in coronavirus era
summary: Thailand is positioning itself as a trusted destination for international tourists as travel restrictions ease, capitalizing on its relative success in containing the coronavirus outbreak. The country aims to rebuild its reputation and attract young, affluent travelers from low-risk countries such as China, South Korea, and Taiwan. Thailand has implemented a health certification system for hotels and restaurants to reassure travelers, and the government plans to launch a campaign later this year to promote the "trust" concept.

site_title: CDW Holdings brings forward dividend 'to support shareholders' amid Covid-19
summary: CDW Holdings announced it will pay out a second interim dividend of S$0.007 per share on June 22, amid the Covid-19 pandemic, to provide support to shareholders. The decision was made due to economic uncertainty and disruptions caused by the pandemic. The company received approval from the Singapore Exchange to postpone its annual general meeting to a date on or before June 30. This move allows shareholders to receive their payouts sooner, rather than waiting until after the AGM.

site_title: SIA Engineering responds to SGX query on unusual trading activity
summary: SIA Engineering's shares surged 9.9% to close at S$2.22 on June 5, 2020, after a query from the Singapore Exchange's surveillance team about unusual trading activity. The company attributed the price movement to improved market sentiments for the aviation industry and the Singapore government's support for the aerospace sector, as outlined in the Fortitude Budget. SIA Engineering confirmed it was in compliance with listing rules and was unaware of any other possible explanations for the trading.

site_title: High yield can be the white knight of the income crisis
summary: High-yield bonds, once considered a less desirable alternative to dividend-paying stocks, are gaining popularity as a reliable source of income during the current income crisis. With the US$2 trillion asset class becoming increasingly accessible, investors are shifting their focus towards high-yield bonds due to their diversified portfolio, global presence, and improved credit quality. The asset class now boasts a BB- credit rating, and its debt is rated CCC, the lowest band, with only 8% of its debt falling into this category. This trend may redefine the cornerstone of a sustainable income strategy.

images.alt_text: High yield boasts significant diversification benefits - it is now a genuinely global asset class with companies representing 85 countries - a long way from the US-dominated ground of years before.

site_title: Asian airlines rally as American Airlines lifts hopes of resumed travel
summary: Asian airlines rallied as American Airlines lifted hopes of resumed travel, with US carriers seeing significant gains. American Airlines increased July flights by 74% and its stock skyrocketed 41%, boosting regional airline shares. Key airlines in the region surged, including Korean Air Lines (18%), Air China (8.4%), Cathay Pacific Airways (5.7%), Japan Airlines (8%), and Qantas Airways (7.4%). The Bloomberg Asia Pacific Airlines Index has advanced 17% since bottoming in late-March, as the coronavirus appears to be largely contained in many countries.

images.alt_text: Korean Air Lines surged as much as 18 per cent, after adjusting for a rights issue, leading advances in Asia Pacific peers. Air China gained as much as 8.4 per cent and Cathay Pacific Airways rose 5.7 per cent in Hong Kong, while Japan Airlines (JAL) gained 8 per cent and Australia's Qantas Airways 7.4 per cent.

site_title: Stalemate after fourth round of post-Brexit talks
summary: The latest round of Brexit trade talks between the EU and UK ended with no breakthrough, with both sides sticking to long-held positions. EU chief negotiator Michel Barnier accused the UK of backtracking on divorce terms agreed last year, while UK counterpart David Frost called for intensified negotiations. The talks will resume in late June or early July, with a focus on key issues like a level-playing field, fishing rights, and a trade deal. The EU and UK have until October 31 to agree on a deal, with the UK set to leave the EU's single market and customs union.

site_title: British Airways parent company considering legal challenge to UK quarantine rules
summary: British Airways' parent company, International Airlines Group (IAG), is considering a legal challenge to the UK's quarantine rules, which are set to deter people from booking holidays and torpedo its planned July return to flying. IAG CEO Willie Walsh said the rules are "irrational and disproportionate" and will review possible action with lawyers. The rules require those arriving in Britain from abroad to stay at home for 14 days, impacting the travel industry's recovery from the coronavirus pandemic.

site_title: Banyan Tree restructures amid Covid-19 hit, lays off 10-15% of global workforce
summary: Banyan Tree Hospitality Group is restructuring amid the post-Covid-19 industry outlook, laying off 10-15% of its global workforce, affecting around 1,100 employees. The move aims to achieve short-term savings and continued efficiency, with transition packages and flexible-employment platforms in place to support affected staff. The company's shares rose 4.08% following the announcement, and it has committed to supporting associates through reskilling and upskilling programs. The restructuring is intended to ensure the company's ability to operate effectively into the future.

site_title: Fortitude Budget: Singapore's fiscal strategy keeps longer-term needs in view
summary: Singapore's Deputy Prime Minister and Finance Minister Heng Swee Keat has emphasized the country's fiscal strategy, prioritizing long-term structural needs despite the Covid-19 crisis. Key investments include healthcare, education, and infrastructure to support an ageing population. The government will consider borrowing for major infrastructure spending, while recurrent spending will be funded through recurrent revenues, including a strengthened goods and services tax (GST) rate increase to 5% by 2025. This approach aims to ensure equitable spending and prudence, with each generation paying for the benefits they enjoy.

site_title: US unemployment rate unexpectedly falls in May
summary: The US unemployment rate unexpectedly fell to 13.3% in May, a drop from 14.7% in April, according to the Labor Department. Nonfarm payrolls rose by 2.509 million jobs, reversing a record plunge of 20.687 million in April. Economists had forecast a jump in the jobless rate, but signs indicate the economic downturn is bottoming, with consumer confidence, manufacturing, and services industries stabilizing at low levels.

images.alt_text: The US unemployment rate unexpectedly fell in May and layoffs abated, the Labor Department said on Friday in a report that showed the latest signs the economic downturn caused by the Covid-19 pandemic was bottoming.

site_title: Malaysia: Shares close lower on Friday
summary: Malaysia's FTSE Bursa Malaysia Kuala Lumpur Composite Index closed lower on Friday, down 5.51 points to 1,556.33, with 615 losers outnumbering 427 gainers. Volume reached 8.67 billion lots worth RM6.2 billion.

site_title: Daily Debrief: What Happened Today
summary: Singapore's Fortitude Budget, which includes S$93 billion in response to Covid-19, totals S$193 billion, exceeding annual budgets in previous years. Retail sales plummeted 40.5% in April, with F&B services taking a larger hit. Business formation slowed, with 3,800 new entities formed in April, 30% lower than the annual average. PepsiCo appointed Singaporean Tan Wern-Yuen as Asia-Pacific CEO, while MAS and CAD launched a probe into Eagle Hospitality Trust directors and officers. The Straits Times Index ended 1.6% higher for the fifth consecutive session.

site_title: Geo Energy fails to get noteholders' nod to loosen notes terms
summary: Geo Energy Resources failed to get noteholders' consent to loosen terms of its 8% senior notes, issued by its wholly-owned unit Geo Coal International. The notes, set to mature in 2022, were tendered by US$20.9 million, with holders receiving US$430 per US$1,000 principal amount. The company's CEO, Tung Kum Hon, said the tender offer aimed to provide flexibility for debt and acquisitions, but the failure to achieve 75% requisite-consent threshold was attributed to the COVID-19 pandemic. Geo Energy's cash balance will be reduced to US$72.3 million after the settlement.

site_title: Singapore shares end higher for fifth straight session, up 1.6%
summary: Singapore's Straits Times Index (STI) closed at 2,751.50, up 44.30 points or 1.6%, for the fifth straight session. Advancers outpaced decliners 347 to 140, with strong stimulus support from the European Central Bank's 130 billion-euro package and expected US economic stimulus boosting sentiments. The STI's upward momentum has faltered slightly, but markets are focusing on the recovery phase.

site_title: Spain perfume firm Puig buys makeup brand Charlotte Tilbury
summary: Puig, the Spanish company behind Paco Rabanne perfumes, has agreed to acquire a majority stake in celebrity makeup brand Charlotte Tilbury for over £1.2 billion. The deal was teamed up with investment firm BDT Capital Partners and will see Charlotte Tilbury retain a minority stake. The acquisition includes popular products such as Magic Cream moisturiser and Pillow Talk lipstick.

site_title: Malaysia announces RM35b in additional stimulus
summary: Malaysia unveils an additional RM35 billion (S$11.46 billion) stimulus package to aid the economy's recovery from the coronavirus pandemic. The plan includes direct fiscal injection, wage subsidies, upskilling programs, and tax breaks for small and medium-sized enterprises. The economy expanded 0.7% in the first quarter, its worst showing since the global financial crisis, and is expected to slip into recession over the next four to six months. The stimulus aims to support consumers and businesses amidst ongoing economic challenges in South-east Asia and globally.

site_title: 95-year-old woman among 11 new community cases in Singapore
summary: A 95-year-old woman is among 11 new community Covid-19 cases in Singapore, all linked to previously confirmed cases. Four other Singaporeans, a 49-year-old PR, and five work permit holders are also among the new cases. The number of new community cases has increased to six per day, while the number of unlinked cases remains stable. A total of 305 more patients were discharged, bringing the total number of recovered patients to 24,209.

site_title: Four Budgets may help Singapore avoid output loss of 5 percentage points or S$23.4b: DPM Heng
summary: Deputy Prime Minister and Finance Minister Heng Swee Keat stated that Singapore's four Budgets for 2020 and 2021 may help avoid a 5% annual output loss or S$23.4 billion. The total size of the four Budgets is S$193 billion, more than double the size of annual Budgets in previous years. The Fortitude Budget sets aside S$13 billion in the Contingencies Funds, reflecting the unprecedented severity and uncertainty of the Covid-19 crisis.

site_title: Fortitude Budget: Govt will not take advantage of low interest rates to borrow
summary: Singapore's government will not borrow to fund current spending due to uncertainty over repaying accumulated debt and the economic outlook. Deputy Prime Minister Heng Swee Keat stated that low interest rates do not guarantee repayment, especially with countries operating in a tighter fiscal space. This decision comes as Singapore sets aside S$100 billion to tackle the Covid-19 pandemic's economic crisis. The government prioritizes fairness to future generations over short-term borrowing opportunities.

site_title: KKR, Ampersand Capital in joint bid for Oxford Immunotec: sources
summary: A consortium of private equity firms KKR & Co and Ampersand Capital Partners has submitted a US$400 million acquisition offer to Oxford Immunotec Global, a medical diagnostics company, for around US$15 per share in cash. The offer comes after the company explored a potential sale to large healthcare peers over the past year, but failed to agree on terms. Oxford Immunotec sells tests to identify tuberculosis and has around 1.7 billion people infected worldwide. The deal is preliminary and has not been confirmed by the company or its partners.

site_title: Plans for secondment of construction workers to be reviewed: Desmond Lee
summary: Singapore's plans to second construction workers to other firms will be reviewed following feedback from industry firms. The government aims to optimize manpower distribution and restart projects sooner. However, some firms require workers for their own projects and cannot afford to second them. The Manpower Ministry and Building and Construction Authority will review and work with the industry to find alternative solutions.

site_title: Europe: Stock markets rebound at open
summary: European stock markets rebounded at the open on Friday, driven by the European Central Bank's stimulus measures. The FTSE 100 index climbed 0.7% to 6,386.46 points, while the DAX 30 and CAC 40 indices rose 1.2% each. The rebound follows recent market volatility and comes as investors focus on US-EU trade talks and the potential for new stimulus measures.

images.alt_text: European stock markets rebounded at the open Friday following the European Central Bank's latest action to stimulate the eurozone economy battered by the coronavirus pandemic.

site_title: Najib to learn fate in 1MDB trial next month
summary: Malaysia's former Prime Minister Najib Razak will learn his fate on July 28 in his first trial over the 1MDB scandal, which alleges he plundered state coffers. Najib denies all wrongdoing and faces seven charges of corruption and money-laundering if found guilty. His lawyers argue he was ignorant of the transactions into his accounts, blaming financier Jho Low as the mastermind behind the fraud. Najib could face a lengthy jail term if convicted, with prosecutors claiming he had full control over SRC International.

site_title: Facebook to apply state media labels on Russian, Chinese outlets
summary: Facebook will start labelling Russian, Chinese, and other state-controlled media outlets on its platform, including Sputnik, Press TV, and Xinhua News, with about 200 pages initially labelled. The company will also block ads from these outlets targeting US users, starting this summer. Facebook will not label US-based news organisations due to editorial independence. The move comes amid criticism over its handling of misleading posts by US President Donald Trump and ahead of the November US presidential election.

site_title: Tokyo: Nikkei closes up for fifth straight session
summary: Tokyo's benchmark Nikkei index closed up for a fifth consecutive session, gaining 0.74% to 22,863.73. This recovery was driven by hopes for economic measures by major countries, offsetting pandemic concerns. The broader Topix index also rose 0.54% to 1,612.48.

site_title: Biden says 10-15% of Americans are 'not very good people'
summary: US President Joe Biden stated that 10-15% of Americans are "not very good people," during an online forum with black supporters. He contrasted this with the "vast majority" of Americans who want to make the country better. This comment echoes a 2016 remark by Hillary Clinton that half of Donald Trump's supporters were "deplorables." The remarks come as primaries approach in the US, with the Democratic National Convention set for August 17.

images.alt_text: Presumed Democratic nominee Joe Biden said Thursday that 10 to 15  per cent of Americans are "not very good people."

site_title: Construction tech startup Hubble raises S$5m from Tin Men
summary: Singapore-based construction analytics startup Hubble has raised S$5 million from Tin Men Capital, its first external fund-raising round. Founded in 2016, Hubble provides software for construction firms to digitalize tasks, including resource deployment and productivity management. The startup's clients include major contractors and government agencies, and its CEO, Lin Shijing, stated that Tin Men's recognition of the opportunity was key to the investment. This funding will help Hubble continue to grow its market adoption and expand its services in the construction industry.

site_title: A US$30b property investor says offices remain a good bet
summary: US$30 billion property investor Karsten Kallevig expects office space to remain in demand despite the Covid-19 crisis, citing the need for social distancing and conference calls. He notes that while some companies plan to let employees work from home, it's unlikely to eliminate the need for office space entirely. Kallevig believes low interest rates will support real-estate prices, and his fund's real estate unit is likely to see returns that fall short of its 7.7% annual average, but still deliver a 3% real return after costs.

site_title: Toyota teams up with five China companies to develop fuel cells
summary: Toyota is forming a joint venture with five Chinese companies, including Beijing Automobile Group and China FAW, to develop fuel cells for commercial vehicles. The venture, United Fuel Cell System R&D, will be based in Beijing and has an initial investment of 5 billion yen. This partnership aims to push deeper into China and the fuel cell market. Analyst Seiji Sugiura notes that China is committing to fuel cells, with Toyota already partnering with Guangzhou Auto and China FAW to develop fuel cell vehicles.

site_title: Keppel O&M, Borr Drilling defer delivery of 5 jackup rigs to 2022
summary: Keppel O&M and Borr Drilling have agreed to defer the delivery of five jackup rigs to 2022. The rigs were originally scheduled for delivery by 2020 and 2022. The companies will use a seller's credit arrangement to partially finance the delivery, with Keppel O&M holding a first lien on the rigs. This move comes after Borr Drilling's announcement to strengthen its liquidity situation.

site_title: GM Cruise trying to poach engineers from struggling rival Zoox
summary: Cruise, a unit of General Motors, is trying to poach engineers from struggling self-driving technology company Zoox Inc. According to an email by Cruise founder Kyle Vogt, the company is willing to recognize the value of Zoox engineers' rewards, as Zoox is potentially about to undergo a major transition. This move comes after Zoox laid off 87 employees in April and was reportedly in advanced talks with Amazon for a potential acquisition. Cruise is seeking top talent, doubling down on its core technology and hiring from other companies, including Starsky Robotics.

site_title: Australia: Shares see best weekly rally in 2 years on recovery hopes
summary: Australian stocks rose 0.1% to a near-three-month high, marking their longest weekly gain since May 2018. The S&P/ASX 200 advanced for a sixth straight week, up 4%, as investors bet on a swift recovery from the coronavirus. The Reserve Bank of Australia and government stimulus reinforced confidence in the economy. Meanwhile, New Zealand's S&P/NZX 50 index fell 0.5% after four sessions of gains.

site_title: Bitcoin diehards revisit roots with virtual conference giveaway
summary: Tim Draper's blockchain venture studio, Draper Goren Holm, is giving away at least $1 million in Bitcoin payouts to attendees of its virtual Los Angeles blockchain summit later this year. The event aims to stimulate mass adoption of cryptocurrencies, which have seen a surge in interest due to Bitcoin's return to $10,000 and the coin's halving. The firm, which expects over 20,000 attendees, is also considering extending the campaign if interest is high. The giveaway is part of a broader effort to bring mainstream adoption to the crypto space.

site_title: Seoul: Shares rise in longest 2020 rally on recovery hopes, post third weekly gain
summary: South Korean shares rose for the sixth consecutive session, closing 1.43% higher at 2,181.87, its highest since February 21, amid signs of global economic recovery from the coronavirus crisis. The Kospi gained 7.50% for the week, its third straight weekly gain, driven by the European Central Bank's stimulus package, yuan's gain, and rising oil prices. Foreigners sold US$60.51 million worth of shares, but overall market sentiment remained positive.

site_title: Fortitude Budget: Govt committed to rebuilding reserves even though no legal obligation
summary: Singapore's government is committed to rebuilding the country's reserves despite no legal obligation, with S$52 billion drawn from past reserves to finance four major support packages worth S$100 billion to combat the Covid-19 pandemic. Deputy Prime Minister Heng Swee Keat emphasized the need for prudent governance and ensuring resources for future challenges, as the country's yearly budget is about S$80 billion and the reserves are a limited resource.

site_title: Hot stock: SIA Engineering gains 9.4%, receives SGX query
summary: SIA Engineering's shares surged 9.4% to a three-month high of S$2.21, with over 2 million shares changing hands. The Singapore Exchange flagged "unusual price movements" and asked the company if it was aware of any explanation. This comes after the aircraft maintenance company's last high was on March 6, when it plummeted to S$2.33. Excluding government support, SIAEC's net profit would have increased by 4.5% to S$168.2 million for the fiscal year ended March 31, 2020.

site_title: Australia: Shares set to snap 4-day rally; US jobs data awaited
summary: Australian shares fell 0.3% to 5,975.4 points, snapping a four-day rally, amid concerns over US jobs data and easing lockdown restrictions. Healthcare stocks declined 3.2% and technology stocks fell 1.9%, while financial stocks rose 0.9%. The benchmark index is on track for a weekly gain of over 6%.

site_title: Pandemic drives Philippine unemployment to record high 17.7%
summary: The Philippines reported a record-high unemployment rate of 17.7% in April, with 7.3 million jobless individuals. The jobless rate increased by 5 million from the previous year, with sectors like recreation and construction experiencing the largest annual drops in employment. The labor force participation rate fell to 55.6%, with females having a lower participation rate at 41.5%. Lockdowns and stay-at-home restrictions contributed to the surge in unemployment.

site_title: Oil trader Winson demands payment from OCBC for Hin Leong deal
summary: Singapore oil trader Winson Oil Trading has taken Oversea-Chinese Banking Corp (OCBC) to court, demanding payment for a sale of fuel to the troubled trader Hin Leong Trading that was financed by the bank. OCBC claims "serious doubts" about Hin Leong's paperwork and cargo backing the finance deal, and a court case is scheduled for July 8. This comes weeks after a court dismissed an application by Unipec Singapore to stop Credit Agricole from paying Hin Leong for a diesel shipment, with Hin Leong facing billions of dollars in debt from 23 banks.

site_title: PepsiCo hires Singaporean Tan Wern-Yuen as Asia-Pacific CEO
summary: PepsiCo has appointed Tan Wern-Yuen as its new Asia-Pacific CEO, effective June 15. Tan, a Singaporean, previously led Walmart China and McDonald's Taiwan, and will oversee operations in APAC, Australia, New Zealand, and China. He aims to accelerate growth by leveraging PepsiCo's scale and creating localized solutions in the region. Tan succeeds Ram Krishnan, who will transition to global chief commercial officer.

site_title: Toshiba expects drop of 15.7% in annual profit, limited coronavirus impact
summary: Toshiba Corp expects a 15.7% drop in annual operating profit to 110 billion yen, down from 130.46 billion yen last year, due to a recent portfolio overhaul and limited impact from the coronavirus outbreak. The forecast beats the average of 13 analyst estimates compiled by Refinitiv at 136.71 billion yen.

site_title: Mega rally in Philippine bonds has room to run along with peso
summary: The Philippine peso and sovereign debt have experienced significant gains, with a 10% return since January, outperforming Taiwan and India. A strengthening peso, proactive central bank, and local lender demand are driving the rally, which follows a 27% gain in 2019. The Bangko Sentral ng Pilipinas' lower reserve requirement ratio and plans for further easing are expected to support further gains, making the nation's debt market a promising investment opportunity.

site_title: Singapore Food Agency to work with fresh food wholesale industry on study
summary: The Singapore Food Agency (SFA) is conducting a study on the future infrastructure needs of the fresh food wholesale and distribution industry, which is expected to be completed by 2022. The study will examine the impact of technological advancements and evolving consumer preferences on business models and infrastructure. The findings will inform the government's review of the industry. Meanwhile, renovation works are underway at Jurong Fishery Port, with a consolidation of Senoko Fishery Port into Jurong Fishery Point planned for 2023.

site_title: Ex-Apple engineers aim to help US hardware makers troubleshoot from home
summary: A California-based startup, Instrumental, founded by ex-Apple engineers, has developed a remote troubleshooting system for US hardware makers. The system uses cameras and artificial intelligence software to analyze manufacturing line images, allowing engineers to spot issues from home. This solution has become more crucial due to the COVID-19 pandemic and travel restrictions between the US and China. Companies like Motorola have been using Instrumental's software for several years and praise its efficiency in monitoring build progress remotely. The system aims to reduce the need for engineers to travel to China for troubleshooting.

site_title: Australia fines Sony A$3.5m for refusing refunds on faulty PlayStation games
summary: A court in Australia has ordered Sony to pay a $3.5 million fine for refusing refunds on faulty PlayStation games. The Australian Competition and Consumer Commission (ACCC) alleged that Sony denied customers refunds after they had downloaded the games or 14 days had passed since purchase. The court also ruled that Sony's offer of store credits instead of cash refunds was unacceptable. This ruling follows a lawsuit filed by the ACCC in May last year, and it marks a significant victory for consumer rights in Australia.

images.alt_text: A court has ruled that a unit of Japan's Sony broke the consumer law by denying customers refunds for faulty PlayStation games and ordered the company to pay a A$3.5 million (S$3.4 million) fine, Australia's consumer watchdog said.

site_title: Good Food Hunting
summary: Singaporean foodies can now enjoy top-notch eateries from Orchard Road to Yishun with Oddle's weekly delivery service. Exclusive concepts Akashi and Sun with Moon offer innovative Japanese dishes, while Mui Kee and Taste Paradise serve traditional Cantonese and Chinese fine dining. Social Place and Fat Cow provide a retro-chic and luxurious experience with dim sum and premium wagyu beef. Tsui Wah and TungLok XiHé Peking Duck offer authentic Hong Kong and Peking duck cuisine. Minimum orders vary, but island-wide delivery starts at S$4.90.

site_title: Japan's Dentsu evacuates Tokyo HQ after receiving bomb threat
summary: Japan's largest advertising agency, Dentsu Group Corp, has evacuated its Tokyo headquarters after receiving a bomb threat. The threat was sent via the company's website, warning of an explosion at the Shiodome headquarters building with a deadline of June 7. The company did not immediately respond to a request for comment. This incident highlights the growing concern of security threats in Japan, particularly in major cities like Tokyo.

site_title: Business formation to stay subdued, cessation may pick up: MTI
summary: Singapore's business formation is expected to remain subdued in the coming months due to the ongoing Covid-19 pandemic. In April, 3,800 businesses were formed, a third lower than the annual average from 2015 to 2019. Cessations may increase, with about 3,800 business closures comparable to the average of 3,700 in the past five years. The pandemic is expected to severely impact sectors like wholesale trade, air transport, and tourism, but others like biomedical manufacturing and information and communications may continue to grow.

site_title: ZoomInfo IPO priced at US$21 per share in largest US tech listing this year
summary: ZoomInfo Technologies priced its initial public offering (IPO) at US$21 per share, raising US$934.5 million and valuing the company at just over US$8 billion. The largest US tech listing this year, the IPO follows a rebound in IPO activity after market turmoil in March and April. However, the company notes that customers in industries heavily impacted by the pandemic may reduce technology or sales and marketing spending, potentially affecting its business. JPMorgan and Morgan Stanley were the lead bookrunners for the IPO, with shares set to begin trading on the Nasdaq under the symbol "ZI".

site_title: Covid-19 urgency meant some sourcing did not go via GeBiz: Indranee
summary: Singapore's government obtained necessary goods and services during the Covid-19 pandemic through emergency procurement, bypassing the default government procurement portal GeBiz. This was done to address the urgency of the situation, allowing for quicker sourcing of essential items such as medical supplies and hotel capacity for quarantine facilities. As the situation improves, more sourcing will be carried out through GeBiz, with agencies still required to assess supplier quotes and comply with audit and review processes. The practice is similar to emergency provisions in other countries.

site_title: Australia to toughen foreign investment laws citing national security
summary: Australia plans to tighten foreign investment laws, citing national security concerns. The new rules, set to take effect in January 2021, will screen all deals involving foreign investors in "sensitive national security businesses" regardless of value. The government aims to give itself more power to review and potentially block investments that pose a threat to national security. The move comes as the country grapples with the economic impact of the coronavirus crisis, with the benchmark stock index losing 16% in value since lockdown measures were imposed.

site_title: MAS, CAD investigating Eagle Hospitality Trust directors, officers
summary: The Monetary Authority of Singapore (MAS) and the Commercial Affairs Department (CAD) are jointly investigating Eagle Hospitality Trust (EHT) directors and officers for suspected breaches of disclosure requirements. The probe follows a referral by Singapore Exchange Regulation (SGX RegCo) and stems from issues surrounding EHT's real estate investment trust, Eagle Hospitality Reit (EH-Reit). Trading in EHT stapled securities was suspended due to a US$341 million loan default by its sponsor, Urban Commons, and a non-binding conditional proposal by Far East Consortium International (FECIL) to acquire a 70% stake in EH-Reit's manager.

site_title: Gap records nearly US$1b in losses on coronavirus-led store closures
summary: Gap Inc reported a quarterly loss of nearly US$1 billion due to store closures caused by the coronavirus outbreak. The company's sales fell 43% to US$2.11 billion, and 55% of its company-operated stores in North America are now open. Affordable brands Old Navy and Athleta saw strong demand, while specialty stores Gap and Banana Republic struggled. Gap plans to prioritize closing underperforming stores and seek rent concessions.

site_title: Hitachi, Toshiba, Miraca to set up line for antigen test kits
summary: Japanese industrial conglomerates Hitachi, Toshiba, and Miraca Holdings subsidiary Fujirebio will jointly set up a facility to produce antigen coronavirus testing kits, increasing weekly production to 400,000. The new line, starting operations by December in Hokkaido prefecture, aims to support Japan's COVID-19 response. Fujirebio's antigen test kits, which can produce results in 30 minutes, will complement PCR tests, which take 4-6 hours. This partnership will help Japan's COVID-19 response and increase global testing capacity.

site_title: China's Dada set to upsize its US IPO amid strong demand: sources
summary: China's online grocery firm Dada Nexus is set to upsize its US IPO, with sources stating the company plans to sell 21 million Depository Shares at US$16 each, raising US$336 million. This comes amid strong demand and follows the successful US listings of JD.Com and Kingsoft Cloud Holdings. US Secretary of State Mike Pompeo has warned investors against "fraudulent" accounting practices of Chinese companies, but investors are brushing off these concerns. Dada's IPO will begin trading on the Nasdaq under the symbol "DADA" on Friday, with Goldman Sachs, BofA Securities, and Jefferies as lead underwriters.

site_title: Abu Dhabi's Mubadala to invest US$1.2b in Reliance's Jio Platforms
summary: Abu Dhabi's Mubadala Investment Co has agreed to invest $1.68 billion in Reliance Industries' digital unit, Jio Platforms, acquiring a 1.85% stake. This deal marks the latest fundraising effort by Reliance, which has sold 19% of Jio Platforms in six transactions, including a $5.7 billion sale to Facebook. The investment highlights Jio Platforms' potential as a dominant player in India's digital economy, with plans to expand into e-commerce through Reliance's retail network.

site_title: Singapore retail sales plunge 40.5% in April amid Covid-19
summary: Singapore's retail sales plummeted 40.5% in April due to the "circuit-breaker" measures to contain the Covid-19 outbreak. Food and beverage services took the largest hit, with takings down 53% year on year. The measures, which limited non-essential services, led to a takeaway or delivery-only basis for most F&B establishments. This decline deepens from a 13.3% decline in March, highlighting the significant impact of the pandemic on the country's retail sector.

site_title: Singapore to build vaccine manufacturing capacity amid pandemic: PM Lee
summary: Singapore is investing heavily in vaccine manufacturing capacity to offer fill and finish contract manufacturing services to vaccine developers. Prime Minister Lee Hsien Loong aims to help companies ramp up production faster and ensure high safety and quality standards. Researchers have developed serological and nucleic acid-based diagnostic tests and are working on therapeutic monoclonal antibodies and a vaccine, with clinical trials underway.

site_title: Japan's household spending falls at record pace as virus stalls economy
summary: Japan's household spending plummeted 11.1% in April, the fastest pace on record, due to the coronavirus pandemic. The decline is expected to worsen the country's recession, with policymakers under pressure to prevent further economic decline. Analysts predict a slow and fragile recovery, citing concerns over job losses and reduced consumer sentiment. The economy is expected to contract by 22% in the current quarter, with a modest recovery in the second half of the year.

site_title: Chinese online mall JD.com files for Hong Kong second listing
summary: China's No 2 online retailer JD.com has filed for a second Hong Kong listing, following NetEase's US$2.70 billion share sale. The company aims to raise at least US$2 billion, amid rising US-China tensions and frosty US capital markets. The twin debuts would be the third major Hong Kong listing by Chinese companies this year, after Alibaba's US$13 billion sale last year. JD.com's Hong Kong listing is being sponsored by Bank of America, UBS Group, and CLSA, and could be launched as soon as next week.

site_title: Housing agency tightens Canadian mortgage rules amid downturn
summary: Canada's housing agency, Canada Mortgage and Housing Corp (CMHC), is tightening mortgage rules starting July 1, making it harder for higher-risk borrowers to qualify for mortgage insurance. Homebuyers will need a higher credit score (above 35%) and a maximum debt service ratio of 35% to qualify. The agency also plans to curb down payment borrowing and suspend refinancing for multi-unit mortgages. CMHC expects housing prices to fall, aiming to prevent new borrowers from getting underwater on their mortgages and curb unsustainable house price growth.

site_title: Malaysia farms face US$3b hit from palm oil worker shortage
summary: Malaysia's palm oil industry is facing a significant US$3 billion hit due to a worker shortage caused by the coronavirus pandemic. The shortage, which could cost farmers 25% of their annual production, is largely due to restrictions on travel for workers from Indonesia, Bangladesh, and India. With more than 70% of plantation workers coming from outside Malaysia, the industry is struggling to maintain production, and growers are considering alternative options such as automation, but this is not a viable solution due to the fragile nature of palm fruit.

site_title: Hong Kong legislature passes national anthem bill amid protests
summary: Hong Kong's legislature passed a national anthem bill that criminalizes disrespect of China's national anthem, with penalties of up to three years in jail and fines of up to HK$50,000. The move comes amid Beijing's tightening grip on the city, following the approval of a national security law that critics say will erode freedoms. The bill orders primary and secondary school students to sing the March of the Volunteers, along with its history and etiquette, and was met with protests and disruptions in the legislature.

site_title: Tokyo: Stocks open lower ahead of US jobs data
summary: Tokyo stocks opened lower on Friday, slipping 0.3% or 56.26 points to 22,639.48, amid investor caution ahead of a key US jobs report. This follows recent rises, which had pushed the benchmark Nikkei 225 index to its highest level in over three months.

site_title: Tesla's Elon Musk calls for breakup of Amazon in tweet
summary: Elon Musk called for the breakup of Amazon in a tweet, citing the company's refusal to allow author Alex Berenson to self-publish a book on its platform. Berenson's book, "Unreported Truths about Covid-19 and Lockdowns," was initially blocked due to unspecified compliance issues, but was later approved after Musk's public support. Musk, who has a history of making provocative statements on Twitter, does not have the authority to break up Amazon. The company has no comment on the matter, stating the book was blocked in error and now available for sale.

site_title: American Airlines soars 41% as plan to add July flights sparks relief rally
summary: American Airlines shares surged 41% after announcing plans to add July flights, sparking relief for the airline industry. The airline will operate 55% of its July 2019 domestic capacity and boost international flights, despite a 45% decline in shares since mid-February. Analysts welcomed signs of leisure demand recovery but warned business and international travel could remain depressed for three years. American will also resume service to European and Latin American destinations in August.

site_title: Malaysia: Shares fall at Friday's open
summary: Malaysia's FTSE Bursa Malaysia Kuala Lumpur Composite Index fell 12.4 points, or 0.8%, to 1,549.4 on Monday, with 392.7 million lots traded worth RM225.4 million. The market saw 249 gainers and 117 losers.

site_title: France to set up 500m euro fund to protect startups: report
summary: The French government plans to establish a 500 million euro fund to protect its startups from foreign takeovers. Public investment bank Bpifrance will manage the fund, which could be increased to 500 million euros from 2021. The fund's mission is to protect national sovereignty by taking minority stakes in strategic companies. This move aims to safeguard French startups and maintain national sovereignty in the face of potential foreign acquisitions.

site_title: Hong Kong: Stocks open slightly higher
summary: Hong Kong shares opened slightly higher on Friday, with the Hang Seng Index gaining 0.09% to 24,388.18, following a four-day rally that added over 6% to the index. China's Shanghai and Shenzhen Composite Indices also rose.

site_title: Netease raises at least US$2.7b in Hong Kong listing, sources say
summary: Chinese online gaming firm Netease raised at least US$2.7 billion in a Hong Kong secondary offering, pricing its shares at HK$123 (S$22.21) each. The company plans to use the funds for international expansion. This deal is part of several large secondary offerings in Hong Kong this year, amid US administration questions about Chinese companies listing in New York. Netease's shares will list on June 11.

site_title: Thailand's headline inflation likely to remain in negative territory in coming months
summary: Thailand's headline inflation declined 3.44% in May, a new post-GFC low, driven by food and housing components. Core inflation was 0.01%, lower than forecast. The economy's reopening is expected to ease downward pressure on prices, but uncertainty and the strength of the Thai baht will keep price pressures weak. Downside risks to growth and inflation persist due to job losses and trade tensions.

site_title: Visitor arrivals to Singapore hit historic low in April
summary: Visitor arrivals to Singapore hit a historic low of 748 in April, a 99% drop from 1.6 million in the same month last year, due to the ban on short-term visitors. The figure represents the first full month since the ban was put in place.

images.alt_text: The number of visitors to Singapore plummeted to a historic low of 748 in April, the first full month since a ban on short-term visitors was put in place.

site_title: Singapore shares rise at Friday's open; STI up 0.1%
summary: Singapore stocks rose 0.1% on Friday, with the Straits Times Index (STI) reaching 2,709.45. Gainers outpaced losers 81 to 34, as 71.2 million securities worth S$93.7 million changed hands. The recent market momentum is attributed to investors' positive outlook despite tariff uncertainty and split Fed views.

site_title: Oxley unit disposes of stake in UK developer Galliard for £30m
summary: Oxley Holdings' wholly-owned subsidiary, Oxley Bright, has disposed of its 18.77% stake in UK developer Galliard Group for £30 million (S$52.9 million). The sale, part of the group's plan to streamline its portfolio, will enhance cash flow. Galliard will cease to be an associated company following the disposal. The sale price was determined by current market conditions, liquidity, and future expansion plans for Galliard. Proceeds will be used to boost the group's cash flow.

site_title: Europe: Stocks pause after rally, ECB stimulus boosts banks
summary: Europe's stock index paused its rally on Thursday, closing 0.2% lower after investors locked in profits. Euro zone banks surged 1.1% after the European Central Bank increased its stimulus program to 1.35 trillion euros. Despite the boost, the Stoxx 600 fell 0.7% led by declines in automakers, utilities, and healthcare stocks. The ECB's move came after a strong week of rallies, with Wall Street's tech-heavy Nasdaq hovering near record levels due to signs of recovery and optimism over a vaccine.

site_title: Opec+ set to extend cuts after breakthrough with Iraq
summary: Opec+ is set to extend production cuts for another month, with a tentative deal reached with Iraq after almost a week of negotiations. The agreement aims to prop up the oil market and prevent a surge in oil supply. Brent crude prices edged higher, nearing $40 a barrel, as the deal is expected to reduce oversupply and create a potential supply deficit of 3-5 million barrels per day. The extension of production cuts is seen as crucial for the recovery of the oil market, with major energy companies like Exxon Mobil and Royal Dutch Shell benefiting from the surge in prices.

site_title: Slack revenue growth fails to impress, shares tank
summary: Slack Technologies reported slower-than-expected quarterly sales growth, with revenue increasing 50% year-over-year. The company withdrew its 2021 billing outlook due to uncertainty from the Covid-19 pandemic. Slack's shares dropped 16% in extended trading, despite beating analysts' average estimate of US$188.1 million in revenue. The company's 2021 sales forecast of US$855-870 million was also lower than expected, citing slower sales from large customers in industries such as travel and hospitality.

site_title: Sembmarine's Brazil unit enters into revolving credit facility for up to US$500m
summary: SembCorp Marine's Brazil subsidiary, Estaleiro Jurong Aracruz (EJA), has entered a revolving credit facility agreement for up to US$500 million with Standard Chartered Bank. The facility is guaranteed by Sembmarine and includes a "change of control" clause that would trigger negotiations with the parties involved if SembCorp Industries ceases to be the majority shareholder of Sembmarine. This comes amid recent court charges filed against two men formerly linked to EJA, and amid broader economic uncertainty in Brazil.

site_title: NBA to return as board approves return-to-play plan
summary: The NBA's board of governors approved a return-to-play plan, paving the way for the league to resume in Florida on July 31 with 22 teams based at Disney's ESPN Wide World of Sports Complex. The plan includes daily testing, eight regular-season games for seeding, and no spectators. The NBA Finals are expected to be completed by October 12, with a provisional start date for the 2020-2021 season set for December 1. The NBA Players Association must sign off on the plan for it to take effect.

site_title: Oil prices steady as market awaits clarity on Opec+ output cuts
summary: Oil prices remained steady on Thursday as investors awaited a decision from top crude producers on extending record output cuts. The Organization of the Petroleum Exporting Countries (Opec) and allies, including Russia, are debating the timing of ministerial talks on a possible extension of 9.7 million barrels per day cuts. Saudi Arabia, Kuwait, and the UAE are not planning to extend additional output cuts, potentially leading to a rise in crude supply next month. The decision has significant implications, with a failure to extend cuts potentially leading to a near-term selling spree.

site_title: Stocks to watch: Singtel, CapitaLand, Mapletree Industrial Trust, SPH, Oxley, Creative
summary: Amazon.com is in early-stage talks to buy a stake worth at least $2 billion in Singtel associate Bharti Airtel. CapitaLand proposed a scrip dividend scheme, and its shares closed down 1.9% on Thursday. Meanwhile, PSC's CEO Sam Goi made a mandatory offer for the rest of the company at S$0.40 per share, and Dutch firm moved to privatize Grand Venture Technology at S$0.94 per share.

site_title: US: S&P, Nasdaq finish lower, ending rally ahead of jobs report
summary: US stocks finished mostly lower on Thursday, ending a rally ahead of the jobs report. The Dow Jones Industrial Average gained 0.1%, while the S&P 500 fell 0.3% and the Nasdaq Composite Index shed 0.7%. Unemployment claims surged to 42 million, and the Labor Department is expected to report a 20% national unemployment rate in May, the highest in 90 years. Stocks rose despite a grim near-term economic outlook, with some companies, like American Airlines and eBay, surging on positive news.

site_title: SMEs' cash flow challenges easing with government relief, DBS poll finds
summary: DBS's survey of 300 Singaporean SMEs found that cash flow issues have eased due to government relief efforts, with 3 in 10 now flagging cash flow concerns as a top issue, down from 7 in 10 in February. Medium-sized SMEs are prioritizing creating new revenue streams, while small SMEs are focusing on access to working capital and income streams. The survey also found that digital transformation and workforce upskilling are not immediate priorities for SMEs, with many citing insufficient knowledge of digital solutions and inadequate employee capabilities as barriers.

site_title: CapitaLand proposes scrip dividend scheme, opens star attraction at China mall
summary: CapitaLand proposes a scrip dividend scheme, allowing shareholders to receive cash dividends in new shares without brokerage fees. The scheme will fund the company's growth and expansion, strengthening its working capital position. The company also opened the 250-meter high Exploration Deck Viewing Gallery at its Raffles City Chongqing shopping mall in China, attracting nearly all available tickets during its opening weekend. The Exploration Deck boasts a 270-degree panoramic view of Chongqing's skyline, making it the highest glass-bottom deck in Western China.

site_title: DBS and Food Bank to create app to streamline food donations
summary: DBS Bank is partnering The Food Bank Singapore to develop an app that streamlines food donations, connecting donors, social service bodies, and logistics providers on one platform. The app aims to facilitate targeted support for the vulnerable, addressing food gaps in Singapore. The app is expected to launch in the fourth quarter of 2020, with DBS financing the development.

site_title: Brazil court accepts charges against 2 men formerly linked to Sembmarine subsidiary
summary: A Brazilian court has accepted charges against two men linked to Sembcorp Marine's Brazilian subsidiary. Guilherme Esteves de Jesus and Martin Cheah Kok Choon face money laundering and corruption charges related to drilling rig construction contracts with Sete Brasil in 2012. The Federal Justice Court of Curitiba accepted the complaint from the Federal Public Ministry, paving the way for a potential trial. This development is a significant step in holding individuals accountable for alleged wrongdoing.

site_title: Temasek leads Tropic Biosciences' US$28.5m Series B funding round
summary: Temasek Holdings led a US$28.5 million Series B funding round for Singapore-based biotech startup Tropic Biosciences, bringing its total funding to US$40 million. The funds will be used to expand its crop focus to include staple crop rice, enhance its technology platform for disease resistance, and accelerate growth through field trials for novel banana and coffee varieties. Gene editing techniques will be used to alleviate climate change impacts on rice production while maintaining nutritional benefits.

site_title: Marina Bay Sands casino under probe in Singapore, US: report
summary: The US Department of Justice is investigating Marina Bay Sands casino in Singapore for potential breaches of anti-money laundering regulations. A grand jury subpoena was issued to a former compliance chief seeking records on "money laundering facilitation" and abuse of internal financial controls. The probe also seeks to establish if there was retaliation against whistleblowers. Marina Bay Sands has denied any wrongdoing, stating it has thoroughly reviewed allegations and will cooperate with authorities. The investigation is the latest scrutiny faced by Las Vegas Sands, which has previously paid millions to settle probes in the US and Singapore.

site_title: Japanese architect pushes for stockpile of virus-safe shelters
summary: Japanese architect Shigeru Ban is pushing for the creation of a stockpile of virus-safe shelters to address natural disasters during the coronavirus era. Ban, known for designing disaster-resistant buildings, hopes the pandemic will lead to less crowded cities and a renewed focus on tackling natural catastrophes. He emphasizes the importance of hands-on contact with materials in architecture, warning against relying solely on teleworking. Ban's proposal aims to prepare cities for future disasters, prioritizing the well-being of residents and the environment.

site_title: What's Up This Week
summary: Tom Hiddleston's National Theatre Live production of Coriolanus is now available on YouTube for a week. Meanwhile, a local fabric manufacturer has produced masks with antimicrobial properties, priced at S$25. Music Matters: Live from Home returns for its second season with homegrown acts, while We Are One: A Global Film Festival offers free online screenings of curated films from around the world. Handmade Heroes has launched a Cocolicious Luscious Lip Mask and Virtual Kisses Care Package, and the Singapore International Festival of Arts (SIFA) is streaming digital content, including a vodcast and behind-the-scenes look into a play about a Japanese ghost.

site_title: US new weekly jobless claims fall below 2 million for first time since March
summary: US new weekly jobless claims fell below 2 million for the first time since mid-March, totaling 1.877 million, down from 2.126 million the prior week. Despite the decline, economists say the stubbornly high number of unemployment claims comes from a second wave of layoffs due to weak demand and lingering backlogs at state unemployment offices. The unemployment rate is forecast to rocket to 19.8% from 14.7% in April, a post-World War II record.

site_title: Singapore shares end higher for fourth day in a row, up 0.3%
summary: Singapore's Straits Times Index (STI) rose for the fourth consecutive day, ending at 2,707.20 points, up 6.81 points or 0.3%. The gain was driven by easing lockdown measures globally and better employment and manufacturing data on Wall Street. ST Engineering was the top performer, rising 2.4%, while ComfortDelGro fell 2.5%. Investors remain optimistic about a speedy economic recovery, despite some risk taking ahead of key economic events.

site_title: Money FM podcast: Singapore's otter success story
summary: Singapore's urban otter population has thrived with 10 families of 80 animals, a rare success story in urban areas. The National University of Singapore's department of biological sciences attributes this to a lack of persecution and the otters' adaptability to their environment. The majority of residents in Singapore want to coexist with the otters, and conservation efforts have been successful in maintaining the balance between humans and wildlife. This unique situation showcases the effectiveness of coexistence in urban settings.

site_title: Tech firms, startups likely to still drive demand for CBD space
summary: Tech firms and startups are expected to continue driving demand for office space in Singapore's central business district (CBD) despite the shift to remote work. According to market watchers, the technology sector will remain a key contributor to office demand due to its accessibility, connectivity, and talent attraction. Despite potential declines in office space demand, tech firms are likely to maintain a presence in the CBD, with some opting for smaller satellite hubs in decentralised areas to optimize space and provide a conducive work environment.

site_title: Patent for Covid-19 cure - is compulsory licensing necessary?
summary: Scientists are racing to find a Covid-19 cure, with 2,739 clinical trials registered globally. Companies are repurposing existing antivirals, such as Chloroquine, Kaletra, and Remdesivir, to treat the disease. Patents for these drugs have been granted, but their territorial nature means they won't affect global availability. Compulsory licensing, a public health emergency measure, may be necessary to counter rising drug costs, but it could discourage innovation. Instead, companies are voluntarily sharing their IP rights, and a global patent pool endorsed by the WHO offers access to every member state at a fair price.

site_title: NTUC's Job Security Council has matched over 10,000 workers with jobs
summary: The National Trades Union Congress (NTUC) has matched over 10,000 workers with jobs through its Job Security Council, with over 1,800 union leaders and staff trained on safe management measures. The council is also raising the funding cap for a training support scheme and introducing a new version for non-unionized firms. Deputy secretary-general Heng Chee How called for enhanced wage offsets, expanded grants, and longer hiring incentives to support older workers amid the Covid-19 crisis.

site_title: Corona Time
summary: Luxury watch brands are responding to the COVID-19 pandemic through charity work and collaborations. Breitling has donated $735,000 from the sale of its Superocean Heritage 1957 Limited Edition II to support healthcare professionals. Independent watchmakers H Moser & Cie and MB&F have collaborated to create new timepieces, a first since the pandemic. Meanwhile, Urwerk has auctioned a gold model, the UR-100 "Fight C-19," to raise funds, with all proceeds going to the cause.

site_title: Widening the appeal, use of mediation
summary: The Singapore Mediation Centre welcomes the call to promote mediation as a means of dispute resolution during the Covid-19 period and beyond. The Supreme Court has launched the SGUnited Mediation Initiative, identifying cases suitable for mediation and referring them to SMC for mediation at no charge to parties. This initiative aims to help litigants resolve disputes quickly and avoid protracted litigation.

site_title: Go beyond fundamentals, technicals for stock selection: Maybank KE
summary: Maybank Kim Eng's head of research, Thilan Wickramasinghe, advises investors to go beyond fundamentals and technicals for stock selection, instead relying on alternative data, company management, and balance sheets. This approach is recommended in the current economic climate. Wickramasinghe made this statement during Maybank KE's Invest Asean conference.

site_title: Mapletree Industrial Trust to replace SPH in STI
summary: Mapletree Industrial Trust will replace Singapore Press Holdings (SPH) in the Straits Times Index (STI) starting June 22, following a quarterly review by FTSE Russell. SPH was also dropped from the MSCI Singapore Index in May. The STI reserve list, comprising Reits with high market capitalization, includes Keppel DC Reit, Suntec Reit, and others. The move aims to accurately represent the investable universe for benchmarking purposes.

site_title: Samsung-Seoul clash escalates over charges against billionaire heir
summary: Prosecutors in South Korea are seeking to jail Jay Y. Lee, the vice-chairman of Samsung Electronics, after his lawyers requested a public assessment of the validity of his indictment. Lee has invoked a 2018 statute to bypass professional prosecutors and appeal to a review committee. Prosecutors are responding by seeking an arrest warrant, which could return Lee to jail. The case involves allegations of bribery and succession, with Lee denying any wrongdoing. The dispute is escalating into a public clash between Lee and prosecutors, with both sides vying for public opinion and a potential impact on the country's independent judiciary.

site_title: April prices of London luxury homes fall most since 2008
summary: London luxury home prices plummeted 2.1% in April, the largest decline since the 2008 global financial crisis, according to Knight Frank's Prime Central London Index. The decline continued in May, bringing prices down over 5% in the past year. Sellers offered wider discounts to secure deals, with an average discount of 5.5% to asking prices. The pandemic and economic turmoil have derailed the market's recovery, but eased government measures may be slowing the rate of decline.

site_title: Covid-19 claims first Singapore Michelin-starred victim
summary: Singapore's first Michelin-starred restaurant to close permanently is Vianney Massot Restaurant, a one-starred fine dining French eatery in Hong Kong Street. The restaurant, which earned its first star in 2019, will close by the end of June due to the COVID-19 pandemic. The closure is part of a string of high-profile restaurant closures in the industry, with more expected before the end of the year. The pandemic's impact on the fine dining industry, with high operating costs and reliance on tourists, is expected to worsen before dining in resumes.

site_title: A post-peak Covid lull doesn't mean a weaker virus
summary: A leading virologist in Italy suggests that Covid-19 may be weakening, with declining cases and deaths, despite the country's reopening. However, experts caution that there is not enough evidence to support this claim, and that the virus's behavior is still unpredictable. Viruses like Covid-19 can mutate, but the rate of change is slower than for influenza, and most mutations do not result in significant changes to the virus's behavior. Until more data is available, the virus should be treated as a deadly threat, and public health measures should remain in place.

site_title: Taiwan eyes NT$40b in foreign tech investment with new scheme
summary: Taiwan aims to attract NT$40 billion in foreign tech investment through a new program, targeting 5G, artificial intelligence, and semiconductors. The government will spend over NT$10 billion in subsidies over seven years to support the investment, creating over 6,300 jobs annually. The move seeks to boost Taiwan's high-tech industry and reduce its economic dependence on China, amid a global supply chain reshuffle following US-China trade tensions.

site_title: Big changes for city centres amid Covid-19
summary: The COVID-19 pandemic is leading to significant changes in city centers worldwide, with more people working from home and companies reducing their office footprints. Major cities are redesigning their central business districts, incorporating green spaces, bike lanes, and new technologies to ensure social distancing. This shift may result in reduced physical office spaces, with some areas becoming less economically viable, and cities exploring alternative uses for former industrial or commercial spaces. Urban planners and city officials are rethinking the design of city centers to respond to changing lifestyles and behaviors, with a focus on decentralizing commercial activity and promoting sustainable development.

site_title: Hawker fare blossoms at Miss Vanda
summary: Miss Vanda, a hawker centre on wheels, offers a unique spin on local Singaporean street food, blending authenticity with controlled irreverence. The restaurant, from Michelin-starred Labyrinth, serves tricked-out versions of popular dishes at reasonable prices, such as chicken "yakitori" and crispy har cheong chicken wings. The menu also features a signature dish inspired by the chef's grandmother, a creamy mushroom sauce over claypot chicken rice. While some dishes may be too rich, Miss Vanda stands out as a strong new concept with solid cooking technique and a courageous approach to pricing local fare.

site_title: Sakae expects growth hit from Covid-19
summary: Sakae Holdings, a sushi chain, expects a growth hit from the Covid-19 outbreak due to weak consumer demand and reduced revenue. The company has been operating takeaway, online ordering, and restaurant delivery businesses since Singapore's partial lockdown in April. Sakae's financial performance is expected to be adversely impacted by the reduced revenue for the period from April 1 to June 30.

site_title: Added reliefs for landlords, tenants positive for S-Reits sentiment: Jefferies
summary: Jefferies Singapore expects the implementation of additional rental waivers and loan covenant relief for landlords to "invigorate the positive sentiment" for Singapore Reits. The new waivers will benefit tenants in commercial properties, while landlords will be able to request payment deferrals. Hospitality Reits are expected to lead the sector, driven by the resumption of business travel between Singapore and China under the Singapore-China fast-lane arrangement. However, concerns remain about the strength of pent-up demand and potential capital calls.

site_title: Japan to allow re-entry for some resident foreigners
summary: Japan has announced that it will allow some resident foreigners to re-enter the country on humanitarian grounds, such as visiting a dying relative or attending a family funeral, after criticism of its policies left many uncertain about their return. The foreign ministry will consider granting permission "depending on the individual situation" with special exceptional circumstances. The country has banned entry from 111 countries, including the US and Europe, but will start loosening restrictions with business travel and expert visits, with tourism likely to follow.

site_title: Earlier, faster reopening raises risk of new Covid-19 cases, says Gan
summary: Health Minister Gan Kim Yong warned that reopening Singapore too early and too quickly could lead to a surge in Covid-19 cases, undoing the "circuit-breaker" measures. He urged patience and cautioned against allowing social gatherings, citing the risk of a second wave of the virus. The government will consider easing restrictions in Phase Two, but only if community transmission rates and dormitory situations remain under control. As of Thursday, Singapore reported 517 new Covid-19 cases, with 15 community cases.

images.alt_text: Health Minister Gan Kim Yong says the number of community cases is likely to rise with the lifting of the circuit breaker.

site_title: Art On The Rebound
summary: An international art show, "They Do Not Understand Each Other," initially scheduled for March 2020 in Hong Kong, has finally opened in Hong Kong, three months late due to travel restrictions.
