The collaboration between Singapore, Japan, and Hong Kong features works by artists such as Heman Chong, Kazuo Shiraga, and Kumi Machida. The show, co-curated by June Yap and Yuka Uematsu, aims to provide solace through art exhibitions during difficult times, drawing healthy attendances in Hong Kong's museums and galleries.

site_title: ECB boosts pandemic stimulus package to 1.35t euros
summary: The European Central Bank (ECB) approved a larger-than-expected stimulus package, increasing bond purchases to 1.35 trillion euros and extending the program to end-June 2021. The move aims to prop up an economy hit by the coronavirus pandemic, with a predicted 8.7% contraction this year and a partial rebound in 2022. ECB President Christine Lagarde emphasized that the economy remains in a "tepid" state, with risks to the baseline projection on the downside.

site_title: Eagle H Trust locked into exclusive talks with Far East Consortium
summary: Eagle Hospitality Trust (EHT) has entered into exclusive talks with Far East Consortium International (FECIL) after abandoning other expressions of interest due to a 90-day exclusivity period. The proposed transaction would see FECIL acquire a 70% stake in EHT's real estate investment trust manager and trustee-manager. The deal is conditional on approval from the Monetary Authority of Singapore and requires the consent of EHT's shareholder and managers. The transaction aims to effect a prompt change of control and greater certainty at the managers' level, with a restructuring committee to be set up to lead and implement the restructuring and recapitalisation of EHT.

site_title: London weighs backing HK against its trade with China
summary: The UK is considering backing Hong Kong's autonomy despite its significant trade with China, which could lead to a collision course with Beijing. The UK has promised to grant work permits to Hong Kong residents and may eventually offer full citizenship. However, most experts believe China will not back down from its imposed security law, potentially leading to a mass migration of Hong Kong citizens to the UK and other countries. The UK's reliance on China for trade, with a £44.7 billion trade deficit, poses a significant challenge, but British politicians and businesses are expected to welcome Hong Kong immigrants, who could bring valuable skills and investment to the UK.

images.alt_text: Foreign Secretary Dominic Raab has said London plans to phase out Chinese telecoms equipment maker Huawei from Britain's 5G networks in three years.

site_title: Getting payment in a cash flow crunch
summary: Cash flow management is crucial for businesses, as it affects their ability to pay suppliers and other stakeholders. However, a significant number of customers fail to pay on time, causing a chain reaction that grinds to a halt. Factors contributing to this issue include a lack of understanding of the importance of financial flow and poor communication. Effective customer management is key to establishing good relationships and encouraging timely payments. Companies should prioritize building strong relationships with their customers to mitigate the risk of delayed payments and ensure a smooth financial flow.

site_title: Suzy Annetta, Editor-in-chief, Design Anthology
summary: Suzy Annetta, editor-in-chief of Design Anthology, shares her journey from growing up in a single-parent household to launching the magazine in 2014. Despite the challenges of the pandemic, Design Anthology has thrived, with a worldwide readership of over 140,000. Annetta believes print will not die, citing its unique tactile qualities and the ability to unplug from digital devices. The magazine's focus on Asian design has been successful, with editions in Australia/New Zealand, UK/Europe, and Asia. Annetta highlights South Korea's product design and Indonesia's architecture as exciting developments, and names Kenya Hara and Neri & Hu as influential architects/designers.

site_title: Australia launches A$680m package for construction sector
summary: Australia has launched a $680 million package, dubbed HomeBuilder, to support the construction sector affected by the coronavirus pandemic. Eligible residents will receive A$25,000 to build or renovate their homes, with a focus on supporting jobs and building family homes. The scheme is restricted to those earning below A$125,000 for singles and A$200,000 for couples, with limits on house values. The government expects 27,000 applications and 14,000 construction job supports, with the package set to start in the second half of the year.

site_title: US jobless claims persist even as Americans return to work
summary: US jobless claims remain high, with nearly 2 million Americans filing for unemployment benefits last week, down from 2.13 million the prior week. Initial claims totaled 1.88 million, the first reading below 2 million since mid-March. Continuing claims increased to 21.5 million, and the labor market continues to show a dichotomy, with layoffs persisting despite Americans returning to work as business restrictions ease. The decline in initial claims suggests the worst of the coronavirus-related layoffs is over, but lingering effects will likely weigh on labor market recovery.

site_title: Virus stole his sense of smell - and changed his wine palate
summary: Dr. Michael Pourfar, a neurologist, lost his sense of smell after contracting COVID-19, which altered his wine palate. Initially, he couldn't appreciate the subtleties of his favorite wines, but as his sense of smell returned, he discovered a new appreciation for bolder, more effusive wines, including Zinfandel and New Zealand sauvignon blanc. He also rediscovered his love for Bordeaux and found satisfaction in good bistro bottles. His experience has changed him, realizing that his altered sense of smell has not diminished his enjoyment of wine, but rather broadened his appreciation for different types of wine.

site_title: HSBC, StanChart shares rise on support for China national security law
summary: HSBC and Standard Chartered shares rose 1.4% and 2.9% respectively on June 4, 2020, after the banks expressed support for China's national security law for Hong Kong, alleviating concerns about potential political crossfire. The move has shored up confidence in Hong Kong as a key market for the banks. HSBC's support comes after former Hong Kong leader Leung Chun-ying criticized the bank for not making its stance clear on the law, and amid global condemnation of the law.

site_title: The Staying Power of Bespoke Design
summary: Local Singapore designers are thriving during the pandemic due to loyal clients who commission bespoke pieces through digital platforms. Jewelry designer Michael Koh sends detailed designs and mock-ups to clients, and they discuss ideas via WhatsApp and Zoom. This long-term relationship helps the designers stay afloat, with some even experiencing an increase in business. The reliance on digital communication has enabled the designers to adapt to social distancing rules and continue working with clients, ultimately benefiting both parties. This shift to online collaboration has been a key factor in the designers' success.

site_title: Eurozone bond yields steady ahead of ECB meeting
summary: Eurozone bond yields remained steady ahead of the European Central Bank's policy meeting, where analysts expect a 500 billion euro expansion of its emergency bond buying program. The meeting's focus will also be on expanding purchases to include "fallen angels." German 10-year yields rose 10 basis points, while Italian equivalents increased 6 basis points. France is set to auction bonds worth up to 11 billion euros. The ECB's decision may influence the market's sentiment towards the EU Commission's 750-billion-euro Next Generation EU Fund.

site_title: Designer Pursuits
summary: During the circuit breaker period, creatives have been finding new ways to express themselves. Architect Rene Tan sketches daily to improve ongoing projects, while baker Tan Sok Tuan combines her love of baking and Miffy characters to create adorable treats. Designer Nathan Yong is working on a screenplay, inspired by his love of film, and creative director Cherin Tan has been cooking twice a day to experiment with new recipes. Meanwhile, musician Pann Lim has been pursuing his hobbies of music and photography, finding inspiration in the comfort of his own home. These individuals have discovered that the pandemic has provided an opportunity to focus on their passions and explore new creative outlets.

site_title: EU considers broadening scrutiny of foreign investments
summary: The European Union's executive has proposed broadening scrutiny of foreign investments in the bloc, targeting sectors such as defense, satellite communications, and nuclear energy. The proposal aims to shield these areas from potential Chinese buyers, amid concerns of state-backed competition and the absorption of EU know-how. EU governments will be required to share details of foreign takeovers in areas like media, transport, and communications starting in October. The move is part of efforts to resist Chinese dominance and increase European investment in China.

site_title: Firms that 'disguise' layoffs could have JSS wage support withdrawn: Josephine Teo
summary: Singapore's Manpower Minister Josephine Teo warned that companies disguising layoffs could have their wage support and work pass privileges withdrawn. She emphasized that employers have a clear obligation to pay retrenchment benefits, even if they are not explicitly stated in the employment contract or collective agreement. The government is also exploring ways to help job seekers, including expanding career centers and partnerships with social services, to ensure Singapore does not let the downturn erode its human capital.

site_title: US$ strengthens; euro falls ahead of ECB meeting
summary: The US dollar strengthened against the euro on Thursday, reversing a week-long decline, ahead of the European Central Bank's (ECB) meeting, where policymakers were expected to step up stimulus measures. The ECB announced an increase in bond purchases and extended the Pandemic Emergency Purchase Programme (PEPP) until June 2021. The euro fell 0.3% to US$1.1202, despite recent gains of 3.6% since the EU proposed a recovery fund. Market analysts expect the euro to consolidate gains and may be limited by positive economic news already priced in by investors.

site_title: Hong Kong legislature passes national anthem bill amid protests
summary: Hong Kong's Legislative Council passed a bill that would criminalise disrespect of China's national anthem, with 41 in favour and one against. The move is seen as Beijing's tightening grip on the city, amid protests. The bill comes as Hong Kongers commemorate the 1989 Tiananmen Square crackdown.

site_title: Marketing in the age of Covid-19
summary: During the COVID-19 pandemic, companies realized that marketing expenses should not be cut, as customers were more likely to cut back on products and services. Successful marketers shifted strategies to cater to current customers and attract new ones. Digital transformation accelerated, with high connectivity and internet usage leading to consumer feedback on business models. Companies must now prioritize consumer-centric approaches to remain competitive. Experts argue for a measured approach and long-term plan for businesses to adapt to changing market conditions.

site_title: Paving the way for an inclusive recovery
summary: The COVID-19 pandemic highlights the urgent need for social investors to step up and protect vulnerable communities in Asia. Key actions include forming unlikely partnerships, leveraging technological innovation, and adopting a holistic approach to address systemic inequalities. Collaboration between capital providers has led to successful initiatives, such as Project Ugnayan in the Philippines and cross-sectoral partnerships in India. Technological solutions, like digital tools for disease monitoring, can revolutionize public services. To bounce back stronger, a collective impact approach is necessary, eradicating inequalities and building resilience through policy changes, process improvements, and values shifts.

site_title: Four strategic priorities for the post-Covid-19 world
summary:
In the post-Covid-19 world, business leaders must adapt their strategies to build resilience. Four key priorities include: 

1. Contingency planning to ensure survival by structuring partnerships strategically and prioritizing reliability over efficiency.
2. Quantifying and anticipating threats through deep qualitative analysis, scenario planning, and technology, including AI and machine learning tools.
3. Building an organisational immune system by fostering a culture of transparency, where bad news is quickly conveyed upwards to prevent collapse from within.
4. Shifting focus from competing with others to contributing to the global community by addressing shared challenges such as climate change, pandemics, and socio-political issues.

site_title: HDB resale volume dips to 30-year low in May, but prices hold up
summary: HDB resale volumes plummeted to a 30-year low in May, with 364 flats sold, a 13.9% decrease from April. Despite the drop, prices remained steady, increasing 0.1% compared to April. Analysts attribute the decrease to the circuit breaker period, which limited physical house viewings. However, prices held steady, indicating no panic selling. Experts predict the worst is over, but expect a lower annual resale volume, with around 17,000-20,000 HDB resales by the end of the year.

site_title: Indian property shares fall as minister dampens hopes for support measures
summary: Indian property shares fell 1.72% on Thursday after Commerce Minister Piyush Goyal advised developers to cut prices and offload inventory due to the shadow banking crisis and tax rule changes. The minister warned that the market won't recover quickly and advised developers to sell their unsold properties to avoid defaults on loans. This comes despite the government's recent efforts to provide relief measures to the real estate sector, including a six-month extension in completion timelines and a credit link subsidy scheme. The Nifty Realty index slid 1.72% compared to the broader market's 0.9% loss.

site_title: Corporate digest
summary: Don Agro International plans to invest S$1.9 million to expand its storage capacity to 95,000 tonnes, aiming to increase yields and profitability. Creative Technology will launch its Super X-Fi products online from China on Friday. mDR has proposed a 100 for 1 share consolidation to increase market interest and reduce volatility. Meanwhile, China's GDP growth is expected to slow, raising pressure on policymakers.

site_title: Hiding in plain sight: Contextualising Singapore's godowns today
summary: Singapore's godowns, once a crucial component of the city-state's entrepôt economy, played a significant role in international trade and globalisation during the colonial period. Built on the quays of the Singapore River, these warehouses were owned and operated by Chinese merchants and served as storage facilities for goods before their distribution. Despite the decline of entrepôt trade, the godowns thrived in the face of disruptive change, and their legacy continues to influence Singapore's logistics industry today. The city-state's strategic location, investments in connectedness, and repurposed warehouses have contributed to its success in international logistics rankings.

site_title: Inovio plans human trials for potential Covid-19 vaccine in South Korea in June
summary: Inovio Pharmaceuticals plans to begin early human trials of its experimental Covid-19 vaccine in South Korea in June, in collaboration with Seoul National University Hospital. The two-stage trial will assess safety and effectiveness in 40 healthy adults, with plans to expand to 160 participants. This is part of Inovio's efforts to develop a vaccine to combat the pandemic, alongside other companies working on around 100 vaccine programmes.

site_title: Abe's approval rating sinks on rising fears of virus second wave
summary: Japan Prime Minister Shinzo Abe's government approval rating dropped to 39.4% in a Kyodo news agency poll, the lowest in two years, amid concerns over a possible second wave of coronavirus infections. The rating fell 2.3 points from the previous poll, with 96% of respondents expressing worry about a second wave. The drop in approval rating comes as the administration ended a nationwide state of emergency just a week earlier.

site_title: Amazon in early talks to buy US$2b stake in Singtel associate Bharti Airtel, say sources
summary: Amazon is in early talks to acquire a US$2 billion stake in Indian mobile operator Bharti Airtel, a move that could give the US tech giant a 5% stake in the company. The talks come as global players are investing heavily in India's digital economy, following Reliance Industries' recent US$10 billion fundraising. Amazon has committed US$6.50 billion in investments in India, primarily for expanding its e-commerce footprint, and has expanded its digital offerings in the country through voice-activated speakers, video streaming, and cloud storage.

site_title: US: Stocks open lower, pulling back after streak of gains
summary: US stocks opened lower on June 4, 2020, amid signs of fatigue in the June rally. The Dow Jones fell 0.2%, the S&P 500 declined 0.4%, and the Nasdaq Composite slipped 0.2%. This came as the US reported another jump in joblessness and the European Central Bank unveiled aggressive stimulus measures.

site_title: Singapore cannot allow Covid-19-led downturn to erode human capital: Josephine Teo
summary: Singapore's Manpower Minister Josephine Teo emphasized the need to enhance the country's human capital to overcome the COVID-19-induced downturn. The government plans to create nearly 100,000 job and training opportunities, and will spare no effort to open up new pathways for jobseekers. Teo urged jobseekers to be open-minded and consider new pathways, and the government will expand its ground presence and digital services to support jobseekers. Despite challenges, Teo cited three reasons for hope, including Singapore's strong tripartism, investment in Continuing Education and Training, and Industry Transformation Maps.

site_title: Blasts From A Celluloid Past
summary: A film historian, Toh Hun Ping, has uploaded old Singapore films from the 1950s and 1960s on YouTube, showcasing the country's rich cinematic heritage. Three standout films, "Ring of Fury" (1973), "My Darling Love" (1965), and "Hang Tuah" (1956), are highlighted for their artistic achievements and historical significance. These classic films, including Singapore's first kung fu film and a Malay melodrama, demonstrate the talents of the local film industry in its early days and offer a glimpse into Singapore's past.

site_title: Malaysia: Shares close higher on Thursday
summary: Malaysia's shares closed higher on Thursday, with the FTSE Bursa Malaysia Kuala Lumpur Composite Index rising 23.31 points to 1,561.84. Volume reached 8.188 billion lots worth RM6.115 billion. Gainers outnumbered losers 634 to 389.

site_title: Businesses welcome Singapore-China 'fast lane'
summary: Singapore and China have launched a "fast lane" travel arrangement, allowing essential business and official travel between the two countries. The initiative, set to begin on June 8, limits travel to six Chinese provinces and requires travellers to undergo swab tests in both countries and adhere to a prior-approved itinerary. Despite stringent requirements, many businesses and trade associations welcome the move as a confidence-building measure, citing its potential to ease supply-chain crunches and protect market share. However, concerns about costs and travel insurance coverage remain.

site_title: Singtel unit prices US$750m 10-year notes at 1.875%
summary: Singtel has priced US$750 million in 10-year notes at 1.875% per annum, with net proceeds to fund its ordinary course of business. The notes, guaranteed by Singtel, will mature in 2030 and are 5.5 times subscribed by investors. Moody's has assigned an A1 rating to the notes with a negative outlook, citing Singtel's elevated leverage and operational challenges from the COVID-19 outbreak. The issue extends Singtel's debt maturity profile and strengthens its liquidity position.

site_title: As air travel resumes soon, flying might never be the same again
summary: Singapore has announced a "fast-lane" travel bubble with six Chinese provinces, allowing for essential business or official trips starting next Monday. Travelers must undergo two swab tests, obtain a letter of sponsorship, and adhere to a pre-submitted itinerary for 14 days. The move aims to ease border restrictions while prioritizing public health and safety. This initiative may pave the way for similar travel bubbles with other countries, including Malaysia, South Korea, and Australia, as the global aviation industry adapts to new norms.

site_title: Dining Goes Virtual
summary: Virtual restaurants are gaining popularity as a cost-effective solution for the F&B industry. Grammi, a new Italian-Mediterranean virtual restaurant, is set to launch on June 8, offering over 40 wholesome food choices for home delivery. Virtual restaurants have been a growing trend internationally, and the pandemic has given it a significant push. Other notable virtual restaurants include Miss Vanda, a Singaporean hawker-style restaurant, and Burrata Joy, a delivery service from the one Michelin-starred Garibaldi. The concept aims to reduce costs by not having to pay for a premium location, renovations, or serving staff.

site_title: Over 100 Scoot cabin crew take up temporary jobs at sensor firm
summary: Over 100 Scoot cabin crew members have taken temporary jobs at ams Sensors Singapore, a sensor solutions firm, due to the COVID-19 pandemic. The employment period is at least three months starting from May 2020. Both companies released a joint statement confirming the arrangement. This move is seen as a way for Scoot to adapt to the pandemic's impact on the airline industry.

site_title: ECB unveils bigger-than-expected increase in crisis bond buying
summary: The European Central Bank increased its emergency bond-buying programme by 600 billion euros, exceeding economists' expectations, to combat the coronavirus recession. The move extends the programme until at least June 2021. This decision follows a series of coordinated spending plans by European countries, including Germany's 130 billion-euro fiscal package, to stimulate the economy.

images.alt_text: President Christine Lagarde and colleagues decided to expand the amount of purchases by 600 billion euros (S$945.9 billion) and extended their duration until at least the end of June 2021.

site_title: World's biggest cinema chain AMC doubts it can go on
summary: AMC Entertainment Holdings, the world's largest movie theater operator, has expressed substantial doubts about its ability to continue operating if cinemas remain closed due to the Covid-19 pandemic. The company, controlled by Chinese conglomerate Dalian Wanda, reported a cash balance of $718.3 million as of April 30 and aims to ramp up cash spending for a summer reopening. AMC expects to report a loss of $2.12 billion to $2.42 billion for the first quarter, citing a lack of films and reduced attendance. The company's 1,000 cinemas and 11,000 screens worldwide are at risk due to prolonged closures.

site_title: Banks prep 2.2b euro debt as eBay classified unit sale proceeds
summary: Banks are preparing debt financings of approximately 2.2 billion euros to back a potential sale of eBay's classified-ads business, valued at around US$10 billion. Two consortia, including Blackstone and Prosus, are in the second round of bidding, with the process set to conclude in early July. The debt financing will likely be comprised of leveraged loans and high-yield bonds, with some bankers considering offering the deal in the US due to limited European market capacity.

site_title: Creative launches Super X-Fi products in China
summary: Creative Technology is launching its Super X-Fi products in China through an online live-streaming event on Friday. The company's CEO, Sim Wong Hoo, emphasized the product's benefits for remote work, learning, and entertainment. Despite the launch, Creative shares fell 2.54% due to unforeseen circumstances. The event marks a strategic focus on China for the company, with Hoo believing it will be a milestone.

site_title: HKEX says many US-listed Chinese firms plan Hong Kong listings
summary: Hong Kong Exchanges and Clearing (HKEX) CEO Charles Li expects many US-listed Chinese firms to list on the Hong Kong exchange this year due to US political pressure over China's national security legislation on Hong Kong. The new law has raised concerns about Hong Kong's autonomy and finance hub status. Following US President Donald Trump's announcement to eliminate special treatment for Hong Kong, these Chinese firms are likely to take advantage of the opportunity to list on the Hong Kong exchange.

images.alt_text: Many US-listed Chinese firms will likely list on the Hong Kong exchange this year, in part because of US political pressure following China's new national security legislation on Hong Kong, the head of the exchange said on Thursday.

site_title: Police fire pepper spray during Hong Kong Tiananmen memorials
summary: Police in Hong Kong fired pepper spray at protesters defying a ban to stage candlelit rallies in memory of China's 1989 Tiananmen Square democracy crackdown. The rallies, which were held in Victoria Park and other locations, were marked by chants of "Liberate Hong Kong" and "Fight for freedom." The European Union and US expressed solidarity with the protesters, while China's Taiwan called for an apology. The incident marked the first time unrest had occurred during the annual Tiananmen vigil in Hong Kong since the ban was implemented.

site_title: mDR proposes 100-for-1 share consolidation
summary: mDR Limited, a MAINBOARD-listed company, has proposed a 100-for-1 share consolidation to raise the theoretical trading price and net tangible asset of each share, aiming to increase market interest and reduce volatility. The move is subject to shareholders' approval at an extraordinary general meeting. Shareholders who receive odd lots of consolidated shares can trade them through the Singapore Exchange's unit share market, but may face disproportionate transaction costs. A circular with details of the proposed consolidation will be sent to shareholders in due course.

site_title: LVMH propels Arnault scion to head up Tag Heuer watches
summary: LVMH has appointed Frederic Arnault, 25, as the new head of Tag Heuer watches, effective July 1. This move follows his previous role in developing the brand's digital activities. Frederic, one of Bernard Arnault's younger sons, joins his siblings in taking on bigger roles within the conglomerate. The appointment aims to revitalize the brand, which faces declining demand among younger clients.

site_title: Taiwan eyes NT$40b in foreign tech investment under new scheme
summary: Taiwan aims to attract NT$40 billion in foreign tech investment over seven years, creating over 6,300 jobs annually, through a new research and development program. The government will spend more than NT$10 billion in subsidies to target investments in 5G, artificial intelligence, and semiconductors.

site_title: Shrinking consumer demand biggest threat to business recovery for Asian businesses: YPO survey
summary: A survey by YPO found that Asian businesses face the biggest threat to recovery due to shrinking consumer demand, with 53% of CEOs citing this as the primary obstacle. Globally, CEOs listed diminished demand, changes in consumer behavior, and government operating restrictions as major challenges. Asian CEOs reported lower difficulties in getting employees back to work compared to their global counterparts. Sentiments of a slow recovery persist, with 49% anticipating negative effects on revenue, 39% on headcount, and 39% on total fixed investment.

site_title: Three firms fined over S$32,000 for rigging Wildlife Reserves Singapore job bids
summary: The Competition and Consumer Commission of Singapore (CCCS) fined three firms, Geoscapes, Shin Yong Construction, and Hong Power Engineering, a total of S$32,000 for participating in anti-competitive agreements to rig bids for Wildlife Reserves Singapore (WRS) tenders from 2015 to 2016. The firms exchanged bid information and coordinated their bids for eight tenders. The CCCS imposed fines of S$19,739, S$7,148, and S$5,211 on the firms respectively, with WRS also barring them from bidding on future projects.

site_title: Singapore shares close 0.3% higher, tracking Wall Street gains
summary: Singapore's Straits Times Index (STI) ended 0.3% higher at 2,707.20 points, tracking Wall Street gains. The index was driven by ST Engineering's 2.4% gain, while ComfortDelGro fell 2.5% and CapitaLand Mall Trust dropped 2.3%. Investors remain optimistic about a speedy economic recovery, despite risk-off sentiment ahead of the European Central Bank meeting and US non-farm payroll figures.

site_title: Support older workers with enhanced wage offsets and hiring incentives, says Heng Chee How
summary: Deputy Secretary-General of the labour movement Heng Chee How has called for enhanced wage offsets, expanded grants, and longer hiring incentives to support older workers amid the economic pressures of Covid-19. He suggested re-channeling the original $80 million transition offset into strengthening the Senior Employment Credit, expanding the Part-time Re-employment Grant to include workers aged 55, and extending the hiring incentive for reskilling job-seekers over 40 for 12 months. Heng emphasized the need to protect older workers from retrenchment and minimize their risk of job loss.

site_title: Companies that 'disguise' retrenchments could have JSS wage support withdrawn: Josephine Teo
summary: Manpower Minister Josephine Teo warned that companies disguising retrenchments may have their wage support and work pass privileges withdrawn. She emphasized that employers have a clear obligation to pay retrenchment benefits, which cannot be sidestepped by calling it something else. However, in exceptional circumstances, retrenchment benefits may be renegotiated or moderated, and norms may be set aside. The Ministry of Manpower has found that poor communication often causes workers to suspect unfair treatment by employers.

site_title: Amazon in talks to buy US$2b stake in Singtel associate Bharti Airtel: sources
summary: Amazon is in talks to buy a US$2 billion stake in Indian mobile operator Bharti Airtel, acquiring a roughly 5% stake in the company. The planned investment comes as US tech giants are placing bets on India's digital economy. This move follows Reliance Industries' digital unit raising US$10 billion from investors, including Facebook and KKR. The talks between Airtel and Amazon are at an early stage, and deal terms could change or an agreement may not be reached. Amazon has committed US$6.50 billion in investments in India, primarily for expanding its e-commerce footprint.

site_title: Hong Kong: Stocks extend gains to fourth day
summary: Hong Kong stocks rose for a fourth consecutive day on Thursday, driven by the easing of global lockdown measures and a decline in concerns over China-US tensions. The Hang Seng Index climbed 0.17% to 24,366.30, while the Shanghai Composite Index fell 0.14%. In contrast, the Shenzhen Composite Index on China's second exchange gained 0.28%. The rally was attributed to investors' positive outlook despite ongoing tariff uncertainty and mixed Fed views.

site_title: Mapletree Industrial Trust to replace SPH in STI
summary: Mapletree Industrial Trust will replace Singapore Press Holdings (SPH) in the Straits Times Index (STI) starting June 22, following the quarterly review by FTSE Russell. The STI reserve list, composed mostly of real estate investment trusts, will replace ineligible constituents. SPH, which was also dropped from the MSCI Singapore Index in May, has expressed resilience and plans to transform its media business and diversify revenue streams. The change will take effect as the next quarterly review of the STI occurs in September 2020.

site_title: Robot dog hounds Thai shoppers to keep hands virus-free
summary: A robot dog named K9 is being used in a Thai mall to dispense hand sanitizer to shoppers, promoting a virus-free environment. The 5G-controlled robot is part of a larger initiative to utilize technology to assist customers. Other robots, such as ROC and LISA, are also being used to check temperatures and provide customer service. The move aims to alleviate fears of a robot takeover and promote the use of technology in daily life, particularly during the COVID-19 pandemic.

site_title: SoftBank US$100m fund to back firms led by people of colour
summary: SoftBank has launched a $100 million fund to exclusively invest in companies led by people of colour, aiming to address the underrepresentation of minority founders in the venture capital industry. The fund, led by Marcelo Claure and Shu Nyatta, will support founders from communities facing systemic disadvantages. This move follows a reaction to protests in the US after George Floyd's death, and SoftBank has also adopted a diversity initiative internally, highlighting its Emerge programme for underrepresented entrepreneurs.

site_title: Germany earmarks 7b euros for hydrogen strategy
summary: Germany's coronavirus recovery stimulus package allocates 7 billion euros for a national hydrogen strategy to reduce emissions by 2030 and 2040, aiming for 5-10 gigawatts of hydrogen capacity. The plan is part of a 130 billion euro economic boost, which also sets fixed prices for the renewable energy surcharge, the EEG, to fund solar and wind power expansion. A fully mapped out hydrogen strategy will be presented shortly, with the goal of making Germany a world leader in hydrogen technology.

site_title: Adidas says China sales back to growth faster than expected
summary: German sportswear firm Adidas reported that sales in greater China returned to growth faster than expected, contrary to its initial guidance of a 40% decline in second-quarter sales. This suggests the decline may be closer to the 40% mark. The company still expects a drop in operating profit of over 100 million euros. Adidas will provide more details with its results on August 6.

site_title: Malaysia, the world's top glove supplier, says no quick end to shortage in US$8b industry
summary: Malaysia, the world's top glove supplier, expects a global shortage of medical gloves to persist into 2021 due to a surge in coronavirus-driven demand. The industry's supply is being fully booked until early next year, with buyers warned to be cautious of scammers promising quick supplies. With demand estimated to jump 11% to 330 billion pieces this year, Malaysia's rubber glove manufacturers association (MARGMA) is closely monitoring worker safety and welfare amid increased pressure to step up production.

site_title: Temasek leads Tropic Biosciences' US$28.5m Series B round
summary: Tropic Biosciences, a biotech startup, has raised US$28.5 million in a Series B round led by Temasek, bringing its total equity funding to US$40 million. The funds will be used to broaden the company's crop focus to include rice, enhance its technology platform for disease resistance and animal welfare, and accelerate field trials for its novel banana and coffee varieties. Gene editing techniques will be used to alleviate climate change's impact on rice production while maintaining nutritional benefits. The company aims to improve food security and address unmet nutritional needs globally.

site_title: Europe: Shares inch lower ahead of ECB meeting, carmakers drag
summary: Europe's stock market fell 0.5% on Thursday, with investors awaiting the European Central Bank's meeting to provide aid for the battered euro zone economy. Automakers and banks led the decline, while shares in Remy Cointreau rose 6.9% after predicting a strong recovery. The ECB is expected to upsize bond purchases by 500 billion euros, but its decision may be delayed due to a deal on European Union-wide fiscal support.

site_title: Australia: Stocks rally for 4th day as stimulus supports rebound hopes
summary: Australian shares rose for the fourth consecutive day, with the S&P/ASX 200 gaining 0.8% to 5,990.8, driven by a new A$680 million stimulus package for home renovations. Despite a recession confirmed by the treasurer, investors remain optimistic about a quicker-than-expected recovery, citing further stimulus measures from central banks. New Zealand's benchmark also rose for the fourth straight session.

site_title: Hong Kong confident dollar peg will endure US-China tension
summary: Hong Kong's currency peg is expected to endure US-China tensions, with the territory's financial chief and the head of the Hong Kong Monetary Authority expressing confidence in the system. Despite concerns over potential capital outflows and US sanctions, China's central bank can provide US dollars, and Hong Kong has a currency swap line with the People's Bank of China. The 36-year-old peg predates the 1992 US-China Policy Act, which allows for the free exchange of US and Hong Kong dollars, and the territory's mini constitution safeguards the free flow of funds.

site_title: Don Agro set to invest S$1.9m to expand storage capacity
summary: Russian agri and dairy firm Don Agro International plans to invest S$1.9 million to expand its storage capacity, increasing overall facilities to 95,000 tonnes from 65,000 tonnes. This will enable the company to store larger amounts of wheat and sunflower seeds for longer periods, potentially leading to greater profitability margins. Construction has begun and is expected to be completed within four months. The investment is part of the company's growth plans, which also include scaling its business through arable land expansion and exploring mergers and acquisitions opportunities.

site_title: South Korea seeks arrest of Samsung heir in succession probe
summary: South Korean prosecutors have requested an arrest warrant for Samsung Group heir Jay Y Lee, suspected of stock price manipulation and audit rule violations in a 2015 merger. Lee faces trial on bribery charges, and if arrested, could return to jail after serving only two years of detention. The move follows an investigation into accounting fraud at Samsung Biologics, which prosecutors claim inflated the company's value by $3.7 billion in 2015. Lee's lawyers expressed regret over the arrest request, and Samsung requested an outside review of the investigation.

site_title: Carnival's Princess Cruises extends suspension of some voyages
summary: Carnival's Princess Cruises has extended the suspension of some voyages in Australia, Canada, and Taiwan due to the ongoing coronavirus crisis. The suspension, which was initially set to end in mid-2020, has now been pushed back to mid-September for four ships. Morgan Stanley analysts predict that sailings will resume in 2021, citing the challenge of structuring social distancing on cruise ships. The suspension is part of a broader industry trend, with cruise lines struggling to recover from the pandemic's impact on their business model.

images.alt_text: Carnival's Princess Cruises on Thursday extended the suspension of some of its voyages in Australia, Canada and Taiwan as ports around the world remain shut due to the coronavirus crisis.

site_title: NTUC raises funding cap for training support scheme, introduces version for non-unionised firms
summary: The National Trades Union Congress (NTUC) has raised the funding cap for its training support scheme from S$30,000 to S$50,000 per firm, and introduced a new version for non-unionised firms with 50 or more union members, providing up to S$8,000 in training support. The move aims to encourage companies to send workers for training, particularly during the COVID-19 pandemic, and pre-emptively match at-risk workers into available jobs. The NTUC Job Security Council has already placed over 10,000 workers in essential services and sectors supporting COVID-19 efforts.

site_title: US airlines gain final approval to drop services to 75 domestic airports
summary: The US Transportation Department has granted final approval to 15 US airlines to temporarily halt service to 75 domestic airports due to low travel demand caused by the coronavirus pandemic. The airlines, which include United, Delta, and JetBlue, will continue to serve all airports with at least one carrier. The move aims to help the industry weather the pandemic, with the airlines receiving $25 billion in government payroll assistance grants. The halt in service will help airlines reduce costs and burn through their cash reserves, which are dwindling rapidly.

site_title: Logistics startup Moovaz acquires SPH's expat publication The Finder
summary: Logistics startup Moovaz has acquired expat publication The Finder from Singapore Press Holdings (SPH) for an undisclosed amount. In the deal, SPH will take a stake in Moovaz and collaborate on regional outreach efforts. Moovaz will take over The Finder's brand assets and the publication's editor-in-chief will join Moovaz as director. The acquisition aims to build an ecosystem of end-to-end logistics and lifestyle services for expatriates.

site_title: UK offers £10b in guarantees for trade credit insurance
summary: The UK government has announced a £10 billion guarantee for trade credit insurance schemes to support businesses affected by the coronavirus crisis. The scheme, which covers an estimated £350 billion of economic activity, will maintain coverage for most businesses and allow them to continue trading and maintain liquidity in their supply chains. The guarantees are available on a temporary basis for nine months, backdated to April 1, and were welcomed by business groups as an important step in firing up the economy as it emerges from the pandemic.

site_title: Citi defies coronavirus with Western European corporate lending push
summary: Citi is expanding its commercial banking operations in Western Europe, Middle East, and Africa, aiming to capture market share from rivals. The US bank plans to hire and launch offices in several countries, focusing on small and mid-sized companies. Despite the coronavirus-induced recession, Citi believes there is an opportunity to grow its business by providing global services to companies that need them. The expansion will help Citi compete with rivals like HSBC and Standard Chartered, which have also been targeting these companies.

images.alt_text: Citigroup is looking to ramp up its commercial banking operations across Europe, Middle East and Africa (EMEA), plugging gaps left by rivals facing fallout from a coronavirus-induced recession.

site_title: First Michelin-starred restaurant to close due to Covid-19
summary: A Michelin-starred restaurant, Vianney Massot Restaurant, in Hong Kong Street, is set to close permanently by the end of the month due to the Covid-19 pandemic. This marks the first Michelin-starred victim of the pandemic. The restaurant, which has already stopped its takeaway and delivery service, follows other high-profile closures in the F&B industry. The closure is attributed to the pandemic's impact on the industry, with investors declining to comment on the matter.

site_title: EHT's sponsor in talks to change control of manager to Far East Consortium
summary: EHT's sponsor, Urban Commons, is in talks with Far East Consortium International (FECIL) to change control of the manager, with FECIL seeking a 70% stake in each manager through a non-binding conditional proposal. The proposal includes an exclusivity period until July 14, 2020, and requires the sponsor directors to relinquish control. The special committee has instructed Moelis to engage with FECIL to ensure the deal serves the best interests of the Reit and its stapled securityholders. Approval from the Monetary Authority of Singapore (MAS) is also required for the change of control.

site_title: Reopening S'pore too quickly could undo 'circuit-breaker' efforts: Gan Kim Yong
summary: Health Minister Gan Kim Yong warned that reopening Singapore too quickly could undo the efforts of the "circuit-breaker" measures, which aimed to slow the transmission of COVID-19. He cautioned against allowing food and beverage outlets to offer dine-in options too early, as it could lead to an increase in cases and require the government to reimpose strict measures. Gan emphasized the need for a cautious approach, citing the example of South Korea, which had to close down schools again due to a resurgence in cases. Singapore is instead adopting a phased approach, with a focus on safe-distancing measures, mask-wearing, and digital solutions for contact tracing.

site_title: 4 new coronavirus clusters in dorms and worksite in Singapore
summary: Four new coronavirus clusters have emerged in Singapore, including three dormitories and one worksite, with 15 new cases announced on June 4. The cases consist of two permanent residents, six work pass holders, and seven work permit holders, all of whom are asymptomatic and had already been placed on quarantine. This marks the highest number of community cases since May 20, with 99% of new cases linked to known clusters. The total number of new cases in dormitories has exceeded one in ten, with 517 cases reported, bringing the country's total to 36,922.

site_title: Seoul: Shares edge up on recovery, stimulus hopes
summary: South Korean shares rose for the fifth consecutive session, with the Kospi index closing up 4.18 points, or 0.19%, at 2,151.18. The gains were driven by hopes of a global economic recovery and further stimulus, but were capped by escalating Sino-US tensions. Foreigners invested US$37.74 million in shares on the main board, while South Korea's current account swung to a deficit in April due to dividend payments and a decline in exports. The decline in Chinese equities also contributed to the trimming of earlier gains.

site_title: Tesla revises Germany plan to have car plant cranking in a year
summary: Tesla plans to revise its German factory plans to address environmental concerns, aiming to start production in about a year. The company has faced criticism over deforestation and water usage related to the plant's construction. New blueprints will reduce the amount of fresh water required and waste water created. An open hearing will take place by early September to review the revised proposal. Tesla's CEO Elon Musk is moving into Germany to challenge Volkswagen and other German carmakers, with the project potentially worth up to 4 billion euros and employing 12,000 people annually.

site_title: IMF chief says some countries may need debt restructuring, not just freeze
summary: IMF Managing Director Kristalina Georgieva suggests that some emerging market countries may need debt restructuring, not just debt freezes, to recover from the coronavirus crisis. The Fund has disbursed $260 billion of its $1 trillion lending power, with 63 countries receiving emergency financing since March. High-debt burden countries may require help going forward, despite some emerging markets weathering the crisis better than others.

site_title: Aston Martin to shed up to 500 jobs in cost cutting drive
summary: Aston Martin plans to shed up to 500 jobs as part of a cost-cutting drive to bring its cost base in line with reduced sports car production levels. The job losses are expected to deliver £38 million in annual savings, with restructuring costs estimated at £12 million. The move comes after the company confirmed Tobias Moers as its new CEO, replacing Andy Palmer. Aston Martin's share price has plummeted 78% over the last year, and the company's first sports utility vehicle, the DBX, remains on track for deliveries in the summer with a strong order book.

site_title: FedEx follows UPS in raising delivery prices in US amid package surge
summary: FedEx has announced plans to raise delivery prices for residential and large packages in the US, following UPS' lead. The price increase, set to take effect on June 8, will add 30 US cents to shippers' volumes and 40 US cents to "SmartPost" parcels handed off to the US Postal Service. The surge in demand due to the pandemic has strained FedEx Ground's network, leading to increased costs and reduced profit margins. This move aims to offset the financial impact of the pandemic-driven package surge.

site_title: HDB resale volume dips to 30-year-low but prices edge up
summary: HDB resale volumes plummeted to a 30-year low in May, with 364 flats sold, a 13.9% decrease from April. Despite the low demand, prices edged up 0.1% compared to April, with buyers paying an average of S$3,000 more than the flats' estimated value. Analysts attribute the drop to the circuit breaker period and the preference for physical house viewings, but note that virtual home tours may become more prevalent. Experts expect the worst to be over as restrictions ease, predicting around 17,000 to 20,000 HDB resales by the end of the year.

site_title: Broker's take: Jefferies says further reliefs for landlords, tenants positive for S-Reits sentiment
summary: Jefferies Singapore analyst Krishna Guha expects further relief measures for landlords and tenants to boost sentiment for Singapore Real Estate Investment Trusts (S-Reits). The government has announced additional rental waivers for small and medium-sized enterprises, providing two more months of base rental waivers for tenants in commercial properties and an extra month for those in office and industrial properties. Jefferies also expects hospitality Reits to lead the sector, driven by the Singapore-China fast-lane arrangement. However, concerns remain about pent-up demand and the potential for business closures once moratoriums are lifted.

site_title: Malaysia's April exports plunge 24%, biggest fall in decade
summary: Malaysia's exports plummeted 24% in April, the largest decline in a decade, due to the Covid-19 pandemic disrupting the global supply chain. The country's trade deficit widened to RM3.5 billion, after 269 consecutive months of surplus. Imports also shrank 8% to RM68.42 billion, exceeding forecast expectations. The government expects exports to improve in the coming months as more industries resume operations.

site_title: India, Australia PMs to hold online summit, seal military logistics pact
summary: India and Australia will seal a military logistics pact at an online summit between Prime Ministers Narendra Modi and Scott Morrison, allowing military ships and aircraft to refuel and access maintenance facilities at each other's bases. The agreement counters China's growing military and economic influence in the region, where India and Australia are locked in a standoff with Chinese troops on their disputed border. The pact is part of a broader strategy to strengthen bilateral ties and security ties between the two countries, amid growing trade frictions with China.

site_title: Tokyo: Nikkei closes up for fourth straight session
summary: Tokyo's benchmark Nikkei index rose for a fourth consecutive session, closing at 22,695.74, driven by optimism over lockdown easing and Wall Street's rally. The index gained 0.36% and the broader Topix index advanced 0.30%. The market opened higher, taking cues from the US stock market, which surged despite rising China-US tensions and economic uncertainty.

site_title: UK leads fall in global trust in government Covid-19 responses: poll
summary: A global survey found that people's trust in their governments' handling of the Covid-19 pandemic has declined, with Britain experiencing the largest drop of 18 points. In the Group of Seven nations, 48% of respondents now approve of their government's response, down from 50% in April. The survey also found that 50% of respondents trust their government to make the right decisions about the pandemic in the future, and 50% would use a contact-tracing app to prevent new infections.

site_title: HSBC, StanChart shares rise in Hong Kong after backing China security law
summary: HSBC and Standard Chartered shares rose in Hong Kong after the banks backed China's national security law, despite criticism from pro-democracy groups. The banks' stance is seen as a move to protect their businesses in Hong Kong, their single most important market. HSBC shares rose 1.6% and StanChart jumped 2.3%. The Hong Kong Finance General Employee Union criticized the move, saying HSBC and StanChart are "betraying Hong Kong people".

site_title: DBS, Food Bank creating app to streamline food donations
summary: DBS Bank is partnering with The Food Bank Singapore to develop an app that streamlines food donations and addresses food gaps for vulnerable individuals and families. The app aims to connect corporate donors, social service agencies, and logistics providers on one platform, reducing food waste and ensuring beneficiaries receive the right quantity and types of food. The app is expected to launch in the fourth quarter and will facilitate real-time requests and donations, reducing paperwork and enhancing data analysis.

site_title: Over 100 Scoot cabin crew take up temp jobs at sensor firm
summary: Over 100 Scoot cabin crew have taken temporary jobs at ams Sensors Singapore to supplement their income amid the Covid-19 pandemic. The arrangement marks Scoot's first cross-industry partnership and allows the airline to retain its frontline talent. Cabin crew underwent an interview and on-the-job training before being deployed to support the manufacturing industry. This is part of Scoot's efforts to upskill its staff, with over 1,900 crew members participating in training programs.

site_title: Air New Zealand set to boost domestic capacity to 55% of normal levels
summary: Air New Zealand plans to increase domestic capacity to 55% of pre-pandemic levels during July and August as travel demand increases. The airline had resumed 20% of its usual domestic capacity when lockdown restrictions ended in May. This boost in capacity is expected to include additional services for the July school holidays. The move follows increased demand from leisure travelers and business travelers.

site_title: Japan to explore 'simplified' Olympic Games: Tokyo governor
summary: Tokyo Governor Yuriko Koike suggests staging a "simplified" Olympics next year due to the impact of the Covid-19 pandemic. The International Olympic Committee and Japanese government have been discussing possible changes, including mandatory coronavirus testing for spectators and limiting movement in and out of the athletes' village. A further delay beyond 2021 has been ruled out, but organizers are considering alternative measures to ensure the Games can take place safely.

site_title: Mexico overtakes US coronavirus daily deaths, sets records
summary: Mexico surpassed the US in daily reported coronavirus deaths for the first time, with 1,092 fatalities attributed to improved documentation. The country reported a record 3,912 new infections, bringing its total known cases to 101,238 and deaths to 11,729. The surge in cases is attributed to a new mortality committee established by the Mexico City government to better identify virus-related deaths. Mexico's government had previously predicted the pandemic would peak in early May and is now reconsidering plans to relax social distancing measures.

site_title: Malaysia's Petronas delivers Myanmar's first LNG import cargoes
summary: Malaysia's Petronas delivered the first liquefied natural gas (LNG) import cargoes to Myanmar in May and June, marking a new consumer for the super-chilled fuel. The two 190,000 cubic meter cargoes were delivered to Yangon, Myanmar, as part of a sales and purchase agreement with joint-venture company CNTIC VPower. This delivery marks a new era in LNG demand growth in Southeast Asia, with Myanmar adopting LNG as a form of cleaner energy, according to Petronas CEO Abdul Aziz Othman.

site_title: Perlis ruler sells stake in F&N unit after land purchase deal scrapped
summary: Malaysia's Perlis ruler, Tuanku Syed Sirajuddin Syed Putra Jamalullail, sold a 30% stake in F&N AgriValley Sdn Bhd to Fraser & Neave Bhd for RM3 million after a land purchase deal for dairy farming and milk production was scrapped. The deal was part of a conditional sale and purchase agreement to buy 4,454 hectares of land in Perlis. The ruler's stake in F&N AgriValley became the sole beneficial owner of the company after the shares sale agreement was completed on June 3.

site_title: Virtu Financial rethinks office space post-coronavirus lockdown
summary: Virtu Financial, a major trading firm, is reevaluating its office space after the COVID-19 pandemic. With 95% of its 1,000 employees working from home, CEO Doug Cifu said the company is considering alternatives to traditional office spaces. A survey found that 75% of employees in the New York area do not want to return to the office, and 35% are open to working from home. Cifu stated that he will not risk employees' health to maintain a large office presence, suggesting a shift towards remote work.

site_title: Hong Kong legislature starts voting on controversial China national anthem bill
summary: Hong Kong's Legislative Council began voting on a national anthem bill that makes disrespecting China's anthem a crime. The move comes amidst the city's commemoration of the 1989 Tiananmen Square crackdown. The bill has sparked controversy and raised concerns about freedom of speech. The voting process is ongoing, with the outcome yet to be determined.

site_title: More than 10,000 workers matched so far by NTUC Job Security Council
summary: NTUC's Job Security Council has matched over 10,000 workers into new jobs since the Covid-19 crisis, citing the need for safe management to enable the economy to reopen and stay open. NTUC secretary-general Ng Chee Meng emphasized the importance of preserving, creating, and matching workers to jobs, and using the crisis to push economic transformation. The council has also provided training and support to businesses, including over 1,800 union leaders and staff on safe management measures, and offered tools to manage costs, such as training programs and absentee payroll support.

site_title: Japan architect Ban urges virus-safe shelters
summary: Japanese architect Shigeru Ban urges cities to plan for natural disasters in the coronavirus era, warning that shelters must be built quickly with infection prevention in mind. Ban, known for designing disaster-relief shelters, has designed shelters with sturdy paper tubes and cloth partitions to reduce density. He argues that hands-on contact with materials is vital for great architecture and that relying solely on technology is insufficient. Ban's team has designed shelters to alleviate the risk of overcrowding in the event of an earthquake or typhoon, a concern he believes has only recently been acknowledged by officials.

site_title: ConnecTechAsia 2020 converted to virtual event
summary: The 2020 ConnecTechAsia event, a gathering of infocomm media and technology professionals, has been converted to a virtual event due to pandemic-related travel restrictions. The three-day event will take place from September 29 to October 1, featuring live keynote sessions, virtual exhibitions, and a 24/7 interactive marketplace. Attendance is expected to be around 30-50% of the original 35,000 delegates, with Informa Markets planning to use the platform for additional content, webinars, and lead generation. The event will resume in a live format next year.

site_title: Cohesiveness will be vital for Asean's post-pandemic economic recovery
summary: ASEAN's post-pandemic economic recovery is crucial, and a High-Level Special Commission is being proposed to develop a comprehensive recovery plan. The plan should address the region's need for a "new normal," including digitization, automation, and supply chain diversification. Key actions include eliminating non-tariff barriers to trade, harmonizing standards, and simplifying customs procedures. Investing in sustainable infrastructure can also create jobs and stimulate growth. ASEAN's young and adaptable population, combined with its geographical location and high internet penetration, make it well-positioned for success with the right enabling environment.

site_title: UBS boosts conviction in Singapore equities' bull market run
summary: UBS upgraded its view on Singapore equities to overweight, citing the country's relatively late entry into a bull market, attractive valuations, and government support. The Straits Times Index entered a technical bull market, climbing over 20% from its March low, with bullish option bets and record flows in an ETF tracking local stocks showing improving sentiment. The market is expected to benefit from exports and oil price recovery, with the government's ability to contain the pandemic and maintain liquidity.

site_title: Grab accelerates expansion of deliveries across South-east Asia
summary: Grab Holdings is expanding delivery services across 50 cities in South-east Asia, partnering with 3,000 stores to deliver groceries, toilet paper, and other essentials. The move comes as ride-hailing businesses, including Uber, saw a 70% decline in global rides during the pandemic. Grab's delivery service is now available in eight countries, including Myanmar and Cambodia, as the company seeks to diversify its revenue streams and combat the downturn. This expansion is part of Grab's pivot to focus on food and goods delivery.

site_title: Severe penalties for abuse of Jobs Support Scheme to get higher payouts: Iras
summary: The Inland Revenue Authority of Singapore (Iras) has warned employers of severe penalties for abusing the Jobs Support Scheme (JSS), which provides 75% of wages for low-income workers. Employers who misrepresent wages, deduct CPF contributions, or engage in other forms of abuse may face up to 10 years' imprisonment and a fine. Iras is monitoring data from multiple sources to identify potential abuses and has set up a team to prevent and detect them. Employers who make incorrect CPF contributions must rectify the errors by June 30 and may be asked to provide declarations or documents to prove eligibility for payouts.

site_title: Malaysia: Shares open higher on Thursday
summary: Malaysia's shares opened higher on Thursday, with the FTSE Bursa Malaysia Kuala Lumpur Composite Index rising 12.32 points, or 0.80%, to 1,550.85. Volume reached 674.61 million lots worth RM355.05 million. The gains were attributed to a positive investor sentiment, despite tariff uncertainty.

site_title: UK car sales almost 90% below normal in May
summary: UK car sales dropped to almost 90% below normal levels in May, with 20,000 new cars registered, up from 4,321 in April. Despite the slight increase, sales remain significantly lower than the 183,724 sold in May 2019 due to coronavirus restrictions. Car showrooms in England reopened on Monday, allowing for some sales, but deliveries to customers continued in April. This decline follows the sharpest drop in British economic activity in April, when lockdown measures were enforced.

site_title: Asia: Markets mixed as rally stalls
summary: Asia markets experienced a mixed day, with some stocks rising and others falling, as investors remained optimistic about the recovery of economies from the coronavirus crisis. The Nasdaq climbed near its all-time high, while the S&P 500 remained less than 10% away from its record. Easing lockdown measures and stimulus packages in Europe and China fueled the optimism. However, China-US tensions and concerns over oil prices weighed on markets, with oil prices slipping back after reaching three-month highs.

site_title: Australia launches A$680m stimulus package for construction sector
summary: Australia's Prime Minister Scott Morrison announced a new stimulus package worth A$680 million, dubbed HomeBuilder, to revive the construction sector affected by the coronavirus pandemic. Eligible residents will receive A$25,000 to build or renovate their homes, supporting jobs and allowing people to achieve a long-held dream. This is Australia's fourth economic stimulus package, aiming to repair an economy in its first recession in 29 years.

site_title: HSBC, StanChart defy UK to endorse Hong Kong security law
summary: HSBC and Standard Chartered, two major British banks, have endorsed a proposed new security law in Hong Kong, defying the UK government's opposition. The move, made on the eve of China's 1989 Tiananmen Square crackdown anniversary, has sparked criticism from British lawmakers and Hong Kong activists. The banks' decision is seen as a strategic mistake, as it may harm their business operations in the city and damage their reputation. The UK government has offered refuge to up to three million Hong Kong residents, while the US has issued an order suspending passenger flights from China-based airlines.

images.alt_text: The two British institutions that dominate Hong Kong's banking system backed Beijing in the standoff over a proposed new security law, joining Jardine Matheson Holdings and some of the city's biggest developers in wading into the political minefield of the former colony's future.

site_title: 3 workplaces told to stop operations for not adhering to safe management measures
summary: Three workplaces in Singapore were forced to stop operations due to inadequate safe management measures, including instructing employees to return to the office despite being able to work from home. The Ministry of Manpower issued 14 composition fines to employers for breaching safe management measures. The ministry reminded employers that working from home should remain the default option for employees who are able to do so, and will take enforcement action if necessary.

site_title: ECB seen beefing up eurozone support as pandemic persists
summary: The European Central Bank is expected to increase its emergency bond-buying scheme by hundreds of billions of euros to support the eurozone economy during the coronavirus pandemic. Analysts predict a boost of 500 billion euros to the 750-billion-euro Pandemic Emergency Purchase Programme, but note that any announcements will be more of a signal than a significant economic stimulus. The ECB will also review its inflation forecasts and consider possible policy moves to address the slowing inflation rate, which may fall as low as zero.

site_title: Australia April retail sales post record slump, backs grim outlook for Q2 GDP
summary: Australia's retail sales plummeted 17.7% in April, the largest on record, amid lockdowns to combat the coronavirus. This historic slump is expected to contribute to the nation's worst economic contraction in the current quarter. Key sectors like cafes, restaurants, and clothing retailers saw significant falls, with department stores also experiencing a decline. The data from the Australian Bureau of Statistics (ABS) suggests a grim outlook for Q2 GDP, with policymakers bracing for the worst economic contraction in years.

site_title: Thai economy to shrink more than expected, jobs to deteriorate sharply: central bank
summary: Thailand's economy is expected to contract more than initially predicted, with a sharper deterioration in jobs due to the coronavirus outbreak. The Bank of Thailand's policy committee cut the repurchase rate to a record low of 0.50% in May, and a new projection is set for June 24. The economy is forecast to shrink 5.3% this year, the largest contraction since the 1997-98 Asian financial crisis.

site_title: Hong Kong: Stocks rally extends into fourth day
summary: Hong Kong stocks rallied for a fourth consecutive day, with the Hang Seng Index rising 1.31% to 24,643.84, driven by optimism over easing lockdowns. China's Shanghai and Shenzhen Composite Indexes also increased, adding 0.29% and 0.35% respectively. Investors are cautiously optimistic despite potential protests in Hong Kong on the anniversary of the Tiananmen Square crackdown.

site_title: Tokyo: Stocks open higher on easing lockdown hopes
summary: Tokyo stocks opened higher on Thursday, extending rallies on Wall Street, as optimism about easing lockdowns in pandemic-hit economies boosted investor sentiment. The benchmark Nikkei 225 index rose 1.29% to 22,904.42, while the Topix index advanced 0.94% to 1,614.13. The gains follow a strong performance on Wall Street, where the S&P 500 and Nasdaq edged to fresh records despite US-China tariff uncertainty.

site_title: US clears private equity as investment option for retirement plans
summary: The US Department of Labor has issued guidance allowing private equity investments to be offered to US retirement plans, including 401(k) plans, as part of diversified investment funds. This move, long sought by the leveraged buyout industry, clears the way for private equity to be included in employee-sponsored defined benefit plans and defined contribution plans, potentially providing strong returns for Americans saving for retirement. The guidance aims to help retirement savers access alternative investments and follows President Trump's executive order to eliminate unnecessary regulations hindering economic recovery.

site_title: Hong Kong to lead Tiananmen mourning despite virus vigil ban
summary: Hong Kong will lead global remembrance of China's Tiananmen crackdown on Thursday, despite a virus vigil ban, with residents lighting candles in neighborhoods across the city. The annual vigil was forbidden due to coronavirus restrictions, but organizers have called for residents to light candles at 8:00pm instead. This year's event marks the 31st anniversary of the deadly crackdown in Beijing, which killed hundreds and is still forbidden to discuss openly in China.

site_title: US records 919 virus deaths in 24 hours: Johns Hopkins
summary: The US recorded 919 COVID-19 deaths in the past 24 hours, bringing the total to 107,099, according to Johns Hopkins University. The country has also confirmed nearly 1.85 million cases. Despite a possible decline in cases, health experts warn of a new surge due to widespread anti-racism protests.

site_title: Smartphone shipments projected to fall a record 11.9% in 2020
summary: Worldwide smartphone shipments are projected to fall 11.9% in 2020, a record annual drop, according to a forecast by research firm IDC. Shipments are expected to reach 1.20 billion, down from 1.40 billion last year. The decline is attributed to the coronavirus outbreak affecting both supply and demand. However, the forecast suggests an upswing in sales and shipments in 2021 as consumers delay purchases rather than forgo them entirely, with the proliferation of fifth-generation wireless services also expected to boost interest.

site_title: North Korea threatens to scrap military deal with South
summary: North Korea threatened to scrap a military deal with South Korea unless Seoul stops activists from flying anti-Pyongyang leaflets over the border. The statement, issued by Kim Jong Un's younger sister, comes amid a deep freeze in inter-Korean ties. Leaflets carrying criticism of Kim's human rights abuses and nuclear ambitions have been flown across the border by defectors and activists. The move follows a recent freeze in communication between the two countries, despite three summits between Kim and South Korean President Moon Jae In in 2018.

site_title: Trump still obese, but free of hydroxychloroquine side effects: White House
summary: US President Donald Trump completed an annual medical check and was found to be in good health despite remaining obese. The White House reported that Trump ended a hydroxychloroquine regimen safely and without side effects, and he remains negative for the coronavirus. Trump weighs 110.67kg, under the definition of obese for his height. His press secretary, Kayleigh McEnany, stated that the president "remains healthy." A medical report was released, but its details were not provided.

site_title: Zoom transforms hype into huge jump in sales, customers
summary: Zoom Video Communications Inc reported a surge in sales and customer adoption, transforming from a niche appmaker to a popular communications service amid the COVID-19 pandemic. The company expects revenue and profit to leapfrog investors' earlier expectations, with sales projected to reach $500 million in the current quarter and $1.8 billion for the fiscal year. With over 300 million participants and 265,400 customers with more than 10 employees, Zoom's strong brand recognition and intuitive technology are expected to help the company outpace the industry and attract paying clients to compete with Microsoft, Cisco, and Google.

site_title: Qantas to boost domestic capacity to 15% of normal by end of June
summary: Qantas Airways plans to increase domestic capacity to 15% of pre-pandemic levels by the end of June, up from 5% currently, as Australian states ease travel restrictions. The airline anticipates more flights in July based on travel demand and potential relaxation of state borders, with the possibility of reaching up to 40% of pre-crisis capacity by the end of July.

site_title: BHG Retail Reit cancels Beijing outlet mall deal on Covid-19 impact
summary: BHG Retail Reit has cancelled its proposed acquisition of a Beijing outlet mall due to the impact of Covid-19 on capital markets and the economy. The decision was made by the Reit's manager and seller Horizon Thrive International, who mutually agreed not to proceed with the acquisition. This move will not affect the Reit's consolidated net asset value or distribution per unit for the current financial year.

site_title: Singtel unit prices US$750m 10-year notes at 1.875%
summary: Singtel's wholly-owned subsidiary, Singtel Group Treasury, priced US$750 million 10-year notes at 1.875% per annum. The notes, guaranteed by Singtel, mature in 2030 and were 5.5 times subscribed by investors. Net proceeds will fund ordinary business activities. The issue is part of Singtel's long-term financing strategy and is rated A1 by Moody's and A by S&P Global Ratings.

site_title: CES global gadget fest on track despite pandemic
summary: Consumer Electronics Show (CES) organisers have announced plans to proceed with the annual gathering in Las Vegas despite the COVID-19 pandemic. The event, scheduled for early January, will feature major brands and top-tier speakers, with additional sessions and presentations streamed online. Precautions will be taken to ensure attendee safety, including routine cleaning, social distancing, and mask-wearing. The show aims to bring together innovators to solve pandemic-related challenges, highlighting its importance in the current situation.

site_title: Lockdown prompts surge in Germans seeking help for alcoholism
summary: A lockdown in Germany has led to a surge in people seeking help for alcoholism. Many, like musician Marco, initially turned to excessive drinking as a way to cope with isolation. However, as the lockdown prolonged, individuals began to reassess their behavior and seek support. This shift is attributed to the prolonged period of confinement, which has highlighted underlying issues and led to a growing need for help. As a result, many Germans are now seeking assistance to overcome their addiction.

images.alt_text: When the coronavirus lockdown started in Germany, all Marco wanted to do was get drunk.

site_title: Stocks to watch: DBS, UOB, OCBC, Singtel, Singapore Airlines, Hatten Land
summary:
Here is a 100-word or less summary of the article content:

Stocks to watch on Thursday include DBS, UOB, OCBC, and Singtel, as banks allow individual landlords to defer loan repayments until December 31. Singtel priced US$750 million 10-year notes at 1.875% per annum. Singapore Airlines shares jumped 4.9% after talks with countries to start fast-lane arrangements post-border restrictions. Other companies include Hatten Land, which deferred bond repayment, and Fraser and Neave, which sold a 30% stake in a unit. Trading halted for Sembcorp Industries and Sembcorp Marine due to a Brazilian court accepting charges against two men linked to Sembmarine.

site_title: Brazil court accepts charges against 2 men formerly linked to Sembmarine unit
summary: A Brazilian court has accepted charges against two men, Guilherme Esteves de Jesus and Martin Cheah Kok Choon, formerly linked to Sembcorp Marine's Brazilian subsidiary. They face money laundering and corruption charges related to Operation Car Wash, a major anti-corruption probe. The charges were filed in February, and no charges were filed against the Sembmarine subsidiary, Estaleiro Jurong Aracruz. The case is connected to drilling rig construction contracts with Sete Brasil in 2012, which remain suspended.

site_title: Snapchat curbs Trump for inciting 'racial violence'
summary: Snapchat has removed President Donald Trump's account from its Discover platform, citing his alleged incitement of "racial violence" and a "legacy of racial injustice and violence in the US". The move comes days after Twitter hid one of Trump's posts promoting violence. Snapchat CEO Evan Spiegel condemned racial injustice and violence in a memo, stating that the company will not promote accounts linked to incitement of racial violence. Trump's campaign manager denounced the move as voter suppression, while Facebook has defended its decision not to interfere with Trump's posts.

site_title: Trump trying to 'divide' America: ex-Pentagon chief Mattis
summary: Former Pentagon chief Jim Mattis accused President Donald Trump of trying to "divide" America and failing to provide "mature leadership" amid nationwide protests over police brutality and racial inequality. Mattis, who resigned in 2018, expressed support for the demonstrators and criticized Trump's decision to use force to clear peaceful protesters near the White House. Mattis stated that Trump is the first president in his lifetime to not try to unite the American people, instead trying to divide them. Mattis also criticized Trump's photo op with military leaders at a nearby church, calling it a "bizarre" and unconstitutional move.

images.alt_text: Former Pentagon chief Jim Mattis issued a stinging rebuke of his erstwhile boss Donald Trump on Wednesday, accusing the president of trying to "divide" America and failing to provide "mature leadership" as the country reels from days of protests.

site_title: Putin declares state of emergency over Siberian fuel spill
summary: Russian President Vladimir Putin declared a state of emergency after a massive diesel spill into a Siberian river, the second-largest in modern Russian history, with over 20,000 tonnes of fuel released. The spill occurred at a power plant near Norilsk, where a fuel reservoir collapsed, and officials criticized the subsidiary of metals giant Norilsk Nickel for failing to report the incident. A national state of emergency was declared, with reinforcements and equipment sent to the site, and three criminal probes launched over environmental violations.

site_title: US suspends flights by Chinese airlines in new spat with Beijing
summary: The US has suspended all flights by Chinese airlines into and out of the US, effective June 16, due to Beijing's refusal to allow American carriers to resume services to China.
