The move comes amid a growing friction between the two countries amid the coronavirus crisis and a two-year trade war. US carriers had suspended flights to China due to the pandemic, but Chinese airlines continued to operate, prompting the US to enforce its Air Transport Agreement.

site_title: US: Dow ends up 2.1%, extending rally on recovery hopes
summary: US stocks surged on Wednesday, with the Dow Jones Industrial Average rising 2.1% to 26,269.89, driven by hopes for an economic rebound. The S&P 500 and Nasdaq Composite Index also advanced, moving closer to their all-time highs. Despite rising tensions with China, investors remained optimistic, shrugging off new Trump threats. The rally was fueled by recovery hopes and sector performances in mining and healthcare.

site_title: Singapore landlords need a post-Covid remake
summary: Singapore's real estate investment trusts (Reits) have grown significantly during the pandemic, with the city-state's Reit mania raising questions about the industry's sustainability. As the pandemic forces a revaluation, landlords are worried about a near-term cash-flow shock and potential destabilization of the financial ecosystem. However, some Reits, like Sasseur Real Estate Investment Trust, have successfully implemented risk-sharing models with tenants, which could be a way forward for the industry. By embracing a more trusting relationship with tenants and carefully curating tenant mixes, Reits may be able to stretch their profits in the post-pandemic world.

images.alt_text: Every third dollar changing hands on Singapore Exchange is because of someone buying or selling units in a real estate investment trust (Reit). But has the city's Reit mania gone a bit too far?

site_title: Oil moves higher, hovers below US$40 as doubts emerge over next step on Opec cuts
summary: Oil prices rose slightly above $40 a barrel, but remained below session highs, due to doubts about an Opec supply cut extension. A recent drawdown in US crude inventories and support from the pact were countered by a surge in US refined product inventories and tepid demand. The uncertainty surrounding Opec's next move weighed on prices, despite a solid build in petrol inventories and a massive build in distillates.

site_title: Germany unveils 130b euro stimulus to kickstart virus-hit economy
summary: Germany's Chancellor Angela Merkel announced a 130 billion euro stimulus package to boost the economy, severely hit by the coronavirus pandemic. The package includes a 15-page document outlining measures such as temporarily slashing value-added tax, providing 300 euros for each child, and doubling a government rebate for electric car purchases to 6,000 euros. The federal government will bear 120 billion euros of the costs. The package aims to kick-start the economy and support families and environmentally-friendly initiatives.

site_title: Europe: Shares rally on improving data, insurers jump
summary: European shares rallied 2.5% on Wednesday, with insurers jumping after AXA announced a dividend payout, and improving global data fueling bets on a faster economic recovery from the coronavirus crisis. Germany's DAX index rose 3.9% to its highest since March 6, with the Stoxx 600 reaching its highest since March 6.

site_title: GSM Building on Middle Road launched for en bloc sale
summary: The GSM Building on Middle Road in Singapore has been launched for en bloc sale with an asking price of around S$98 million and an upgrading premium of S$18.6 million. The building has a 12,003 sq ft land area and a 61-year remaining lease term. It is zoned for commercial use and has proximity to various amenities, including public transport and educational institutions. The tender exercise will close on July 16.

site_title: China-EU summit in Germany postponed due to coronavirus
summary: China and the European Union have postponed their summit in Leipzig, Germany, initially scheduled for September due to the coronavirus pandemic. The decision was made after Chancellor Angela Merkel held phone calls with Chinese President Xi Jinping and European Council President Charles Michel. The EU had aimed to push China to deliver on its promise of equal treatment for European companies, but the focus will now be on addressing the pandemic's social and economic impact. A similar summit in China was also postponed.

site_title: Singapore shares advance at Thursday's open; STI up 1.3%
summary: Singapore shares rose 1.3% on Thursday, with the Straits Times Index (STI) advancing 34.23 points to 2,734.62. The gains were driven by banking stocks, including DBS, UOB, and OCBC Bank, which jumped 2.8%, 2%, and 1.9%, respectively. Other active securities, such as Singapore Press Holdings and ComfortDelGro, also saw significant gains. The positive trend was mirrored in other Asian markets, including Japan's Topix and South Korea's Kospi, which advanced 0.9% and 1.9%, respectively.

site_title: Strategies for the rebound as manufacturing adapts to the new normal
summary: Manufacturers are adapting to the new normal by prioritizing agility and resilience in the face of ongoing global disruptions. Implementing digitally enabled enterprise resource planning (ERP) systems is crucial for improving supply chain visibility, enabling more accurate demand calculations, and diversifying distribution channels. On-shoring, or bringing manufacturing back to local shores, can also benefit the economy by creating jobs and improving product quality. However, this shift may increase costs. Manufacturers must invest in local manufacturing, digital technologies, and employee training to stay competitive in the post-pandemic landscape.

site_title: 81-year-old woman is only Singaporean among 7 new coronavirus community cases
summary: An 81-year-old Singaporean woman is the only local among seven new coronavirus community cases, with 562 foreign workers in dormitories also testing positive. The total cases in Singapore now stand at 36,405, with 99% linked to known clusters. The Ministry of Health (MOH) reported 407 more discharges, bringing the total recovered patients to 23,573, while 334 remain hospitalized and 12,465 are isolated.

site_title: HK NGO takes from five-star hotels to give to the homeless
summary: A Hong Kong-based NGO, Soap Cycling, is recycling and distributing soaps from five-star hotels to the homeless and low-income communities. The organization collects and processes the discarded soaps, creating hygiene kits with surgical masks and hand sanitizer. Since 2012, Soap Cycling has partnered with over 80 hotels and collected 17,545 kg of soap last year. The recycled soaps are sent to charities in Hong Kong and other countries, providing essential hygiene products to those in need.

site_title: Money FM podcast: Building longer-term brand relevance without using the 'C' word
summary: Host Howie Lim discusses consumer behavioural trends during the Covid-19 pandemic with Matthew Crabbe, director of trends at Mintel Asia Pacific. Brands are finding ways to reconnect with consumers without appearing tone-deaf, focusing on long-term relevance rather than short-term gains. Crabbe shares insights on how to reach consumers during this period, highlighting the importance of authenticity and adaptability in marketing strategies.

site_title: Dubai malls, businesses to 'fully operate' from June 3
summary: Dubai's shopping malls and private sector businesses will fully operate at 100% capacity starting June 3, marking the emirate's easing of coronavirus restrictions. This move comes after the emirate shortened its night-time curfew to seven hours and allowed businesses to operate at 50% capacity since last week. The decision aims to resume normal activity while maintaining health and safety measures, including wearing face masks and maintaining social distancing. Dubai is the first Middle Eastern city to drop nearly all restrictions, following the UAE's capital Abu Dhabi, which recently banned travel between regions.

site_title: Charges filed against all four police officers in Floyd killing
summary: Charges have been filed against four Minneapolis police officers in connection with the death of George Floyd, a black man who was killed while in handcuffs. Derek Chauvin, the officer who knelt on Floyd's neck for nearly nine minutes, has been charged with second-degree murder. Chauvin's three colleagues, Tou Thao, J. Alexander Kueng, and Thomas Lane, have been charged with aiding and abetting second-degree murder. The charges come after nationwide protests demanding racial justice and police accountability. The arrest of the officers has been a key demand of protesters, who have largely remained peaceful despite curfews.

site_title: George Floyd's death is a failure of generations of leadership
summary: US policymakers failed to address socio-economic inequality and racism in the 1960s, despite protests and the Kerner Commission's warning of a "spiral" of segregation, violence, and police force. The Economic Opportunity Act of 1964 aimed to empower low-income citizens, but it was undermined by the defunding and dissolution of anti-poverty programs. A new approach to policing is needed, with community involvement and grassroots empowerment, rather than top-down approaches. The "maximum feasible participation" principle, established in the 1960s, provides a blueprint for creating a more egalitarian society.

site_title: South Korea unveils 35.3 trillion won supplementary budget
summary: South Korea unveiled a 35.3 trillion won (S$40.5 billion) supplementary budget, raising the total stimulus to 270 trillion won, as the economy faces its worst growth since the 1998 Asian financial crisis due to the coronavirus pandemic. The budget aims to protect jobs, develop a Covid-19 vaccine, and boost consumption through discount coupons and loans to small and medium-sized businesses. The government is projecting a 43.5% debt-to-GDP level, higher than initially expected, but Finance Minister Hong Nam-ki said the government had no choice but to act due to the economic crisis.

site_title: Kimly expects to complete purchase of two coffeeshops soon
summary: Kimly, a Catalist-listed coffeeshop consolidator, has completed the acquisitions of six food outlets for S$35.5 million and is set to acquire the remaining two for S$20.3 million. The acquisitions were delayed due to Covid-19 disruption. Kimly plans to undergo asset enhancement initiatives, including layout improvements and seating capacity increases. The company expects to benefit from consumers' preference for economical food options and online food deliveries amidst the pandemic's negative economic impact.

site_title: Euro set for seventh day of gains
summary: The euro reached an 11-week high, poised for a seventh consecutive day of gains, as investors seek riskier assets amid hopes for economic recovery and stimulus. The US dollar fell against most currencies, including the Australian, British, Norwegian, and Swedish currencies, amid mass protests against racism in the US. The eurozone's weakest economies are expected to receive debt purchases, supporting the euro's rise.

site_title: Corporate digest
summary: China Everbright Water plans to issue a 1.2 billion yuan note in China, part of a proposed three billion yuan issuance. BreadTalk Group will be delisted from the Singapore Exchange on June 5 after completing a compulsory acquisition. Samurai 2K Aerosol expects lower revenue and net profit for FY2020 due to lower demand and increased marketing expenses. KrisEnergy suspended production at the Wassana oil field due to uncertainties surrounding the Covid-19 pandemic and oil prices. Sanli Environmental secured a sub-contract for mechanical work on the Tuas Water Reclamation Plant. Parkson Retail Asia's shares surged on unusual volume movements, sparking a query from the Singapore Exchange.

site_title: EU resumes Hyundai, Daewoo deal probe, sets Sept 3 deadline
summary: EU antitrust regulators have resumed their investigation into Hyundai Heavy Industries' $1.8 billion merger with Daewoo, with a decision due by September 3. The European Commission halted its probe in March while waiting for information from the companies, citing concerns that the deal could lead to higher prices and affect European shipping companies. The probe was initially launched in December, warning that the combined company would hold a 21% market share.

images.alt_text: EU antitrust regulators have restarted their investigation into world No. 1 shipbuilding group Hyundai Heavy Industries' US$1.8 billion merger with Daewoo with a decision due by Sept 3.

site_title: Starhill Global Reit gets upgrade to 'buy' on attractive valuation: RHB
summary: RHB Research upgraded Starhill Global Reit to "buy" due to its attractive valuation compared to retail peers, but lowered its target price to 63 Singapore cents from 76 cents. The Reit's price-to-book ratio of 0.6 times is lower than its peers and sector average, indicating room for rebound. Analysts expect the Reit's master/anchor leases to provide stability despite the grim outlook for the retail sector, with no expected defaults or delays in rental payments.

site_title: China takes first steps towards Reit market
summary: China is taking its first steps towards establishing a real estate investment trust (Reit) market, providing a new way for mom-and-pop investors to access the country's real estate market. This development could potentially offer exposure to China's real estate market without the need to buy a physical property.

site_title: Singapore leads Asian stock surge on hopes of sharp economic recovery
summary: Singapore's Straits Times Index surged 3.4% amid hopes of a sharp economic recovery, leading Asia's stock markets on Wednesday. The optimism was fueled by better-than-expected economic data in Asia, including China's Caixin services purchasing managers' index rising to 55.0 in May. Global markets also rallied ahead of expected production cuts from Saudi Arabia and Russia, driving oil prices up to nearly $40 per barrel. Despite US-China tensions, investors are downplaying their significance, with analysts predicting a continued bullish trend in Asia.

site_title: European business slump eases in May
summary: European business activity showed signs of easing in May, but a return to growth may take months. The euro zone experienced another contraction in economic activity, although governments have started lifting lockdown measures to contain Covid-19. This marks a slight improvement from previous months, but experts caution that the economy still has a way to go before it fully recovers.

site_title: Singapore-China business travel starts from June 8 with strict curbs
summary: Singapore and China will resume business and official travel between the two countries starting June 8, with strict curbs in place. Travellers will need to be sponsored by a company or government agency, undergo swab tests, and stay isolated for one to two days on arrival. The initial fast-lane arrangement will only include six Chinese provinces and municipalities, with the number of travellers capped. This move aims to enable essential travel and sustain Singapore's economic capacities while containing the COVID-19 situation.

site_title: Australia's GDP falls 0.3% in first quarter, outlook uncertain
summary: Australia's 29-year recession-free run has ended with a 0.3% decline in GDP in the first quarter, largely due to the impact of the Covid-19 shutdown. The nation's economic outlook remains uncertain, with the Reserve Bank of Australia's governor Philip Lowe stating that the recovery will depend on confidence in the health situation and finances. Despite this, consumer confidence has risen for nine straight weeks, and spending data suggests a strong bounce-back in GDP growth in the second half of the year.

site_title: Tiffany shares dive on LVMH review of purchase
summary: Tiffany & Co shares plummeted 8.9% after a report that LVMH's deal to buy the luxury jeweller is uncertain due to concerns over the Covid-19 pandemic, US economy, and growing unrest over riots. LVMH's board members are discussing the proposed deal, citing concerns about Tiffany's debt covenants and ability to cover them. Analysts say the deal's uncertainty could provide a unique strategic opportunity for LVMH, but it's unclear if they will try to renegotiate better terms.

site_title: Dehydrated cleaning products minimise plastic packaging
summary: A Singapore-based team, Team SimplyGood, has developed dehydrated cleaning products that can cut plastic packaging by up to 90%, compared to bottled ones. The #OCBCCares Environment Fund, which supports ground-up projects, has found a way to deploy funding upstream to mitigate climate change issues. The fund will refocus on upstream projects, providing sustainable and strategic support to address gaps in climate change mitigation, rather than community projects.

images.alt_text: Team SimplyGood, helmed by Jeremy Lee and Clewyn Puah makes dehydrated cleaning products in tablet form that can be dissolved in reusable containers (above).
Team SimplyGood, helmed by Jeremy Lee (above, left) and Clewyn Puah (above, right) makes dehydrated cleaning products in tablet form that can be dissolved in reusable containers.

site_title: Acra inspects KPMG's 2011 to 2018 audit of Hyflux
summary: The Accounting and Corporate Regulatory Authority (Acra) is inspecting KPMG's audit work for Hyflux from 2011 to 2018, as part of a larger probe into the water treatment firm's compliance with accounting and auditing standards. Hyflux is under investigation for suspected false and misleading statements and breaches of disclosure rules, with 34,000 retail investors owed S$900 million. The Securities Investors Association of Singapore (Sias) has advised investors to seek their own legal counsel or wait for the right time to initiate legal action. The credibility of Hyflux's board of directors is now in question.

site_title: Gojek may unlock SE-Asian fintech trove for Facebook, PayPal
summary: Gojek, an Indonesian ride-hailing firm, is collaborating with Facebook and PayPal to enhance its payments and food delivery services. The tie-ups signal a shift in how global tech giants are working with local incumbents in emerging markets. Gojek has received an undisclosed sum from Facebook and PayPal as part of its fundraising round, taking its total raised to nearly $3 billion. The company is adding PayPal as a payment option on its app and exploring the implementation of GoPay at PayPal merchants and on Facebook services.

site_title: Singapore PMI rises in May, recovers from April lows
summary: Singapore's factory sentiment improved in May, with the Purchasing Managers' Index (PMI) rising 2.1 points to 46.8, marking the first time this year it rose overall and in the electronics sector. The overall PMI and electronics sector PMI were still in contractionary territory, with economists warning that headwinds persist. Improvements were seen in slower contractions in new orders, new exports, factory output, and employment. However, slower supplier deliveries and deeper contraction in the global supply chain may weigh on factory resumption.

site_title: Personalised services help designers flourish
summary: Local designers and artisans are thriving despite the Covid-19 pandemic's impact on the retail market. Commissioned, bespoke services have helped them recover losses by leveraging technology like WhatsApp and Zoom for remote consultations and progress updates. This adaptability has fostered trust among loyal clients, enabling small businesses to stay afloat. Personalised services have proven crucial for their survival, showcasing the importance of long-term relationships in business.

site_title: Is going for gas environmentally sound?
summary: The debate over the environmental impact of using fossil fuels for the world's merchant fleet continues, with increasing pressure to reduce carbon emissions. The Climate Bonds Initiative aims to mobilize the $100 trillion bond market for climate change solutions. Meanwhile, companies like Tesla and FedEx are investing in electric vehicles and autonomous delivery systems. Japan's carmakers have reduced export prices to offset tariff hits, and EV battery makers are facing pressure to cut emissions. As the world transitions to cleaner energy sources, the impact of fuel choices on the environment will become increasingly important.

site_title: US office towers are still going up, but who will fill them?
summary: The US office tower construction boom continues despite the pandemic, with new buildings scheduled to open in cities like Milwaukee, Nashville, and Salt Lake City. However, the pandemic has darkened the outlook for the industry, with office vacancy rates and demand for space uncertain. Developers are adapting to the new reality, with some incorporating touch-free amenities and walk-through thermal imaging to monitor workers. The pandemic may lead to changes in the way people work and how tenants want offices, potentially reducing the demand for high-end office space and increasing the need for more spacious workplaces.

site_title: Valuetronics posts 10.3% drop in FY20 net profit to HK$178.9m on lower revenue as demand slows
summary: Valuetronics Holdings reported a 10.3% drop in FY20 net profit to HK$178.9m due to lower revenue, mainly caused by slowdowns in customer demand. The company's industrial and commercial electronics revenue fell 13.7% and consumer electronics revenue dropped 21.1%. The group faces the "toughest business environment in its operating history" due to the COVID-19 pandemic and government restrictions. As a result, the company will pay a smaller dividend of 20 HK cents per share, down from 25 HK cents last year.

site_title: SGX firms' Q1 profits skid almost 40%; Q2 expected to worsen
summary: Singapore-listed companies saw a 38.5% decline in total earnings in the first quarter, with 53 firms reporting losses and 102 remaining profitable. The decline was attributed to the COVID-19 pandemic, with sectors like industrials, healthcare, and property experiencing significant drops in profits. Despite this, analysts expect the April-June quarter to be even worse, with earnings downgrades expected due to the prolonged lockdown. The market is expected to decline by 18% in 2020, with banks leading the recovery in 2021, and Reits and developers experiencing a 9% earnings rebound.

site_title: Lam says Beijing will not back down on new security law
summary: Hong Kong leader Carrie Lam stated that Beijing will not back down on plans for national security legislation, despite Britain's criticism. Prime Minister Boris Johnson announced that Britain will give Hong Kong residents the chance to seek refuge in the UK if China imposes the law, which democracy advocates say will erode rights and freedoms. China's government deemed Johnson's comments as foreign interference, while a re-set of relations with Beijing is being considered due to the pandemic.

site_title: Nomura to rethink office space as new CEO seeks deeper cuts
summary: Nomura Holdings Inc, Japan's largest securities firm, is reevaluating its office space usage under new CEO Kentaro Okuda. The review aims to cut costs, following a year-old overhaul targeting 140 billion yen (S$1.80 billion) in cost cuts. Okuda plans to reduce costs further, potentially curtailing global lending and exploring alternative ways to hold seminars, such as video conferencing. The firm's roughly 27,000 employees work remotely from expensive real estate worldwide, prompting a review of its location strategy.

site_title: Legaltech startup Intelllex raises US$2.1m led by Quest Ventures
summary: Intelllex, a legal knowledge-management platform provider, has raised US$2.1 million in Series A funding led by Quest Ventures. The funding round also includes investors Thomson Reuters, Insignia Ventures, K3 Ventures, and an undisclosed Singapore government-backed venture fund. The startup plans to use the capital to expand services in Asia-Pacific and Europe, and develop new products, including applications beyond the legal industry. Intelllex's proprietary AI technology automates document categorization, making its clients' information assets more searchable.

site_title: Work can resume on over 5,400 home renovation projects: BCA
summary: The Building and Construction Authority (BCA) has approved over 5,400 home renovation projects suspended due to the Covid-19 circuit breaker, allowing workers to resume work. Residents in private residential and HDB estates can resume work, while those in dorms must wait for clearance. This decision comes after all applications for the suspended projects were approved, enabling a return to work for thousands of workers.

site_title: More rental help for SME tenants with at least 35% revenue fall
summary: Singapore to introduce additional rental waivers for small and medium-sized enterprises (SMEs) that have suffered at least 35% fall in revenue under the Covid-19 Bill to be tabled this week. The waivers will be shared between the government and landlords, and will be in addition to mandatory waivers already funded by the government. The legislation also sets out a repayment scheme for arrears, provides relief for tenants unable to vacate premises due to Covid-19, and caps late payment interest or charges for certain contracts.

site_title: The oil industry's recovery is now in the hands of politicians
summary: The global oil industry is facing uncertainty, with prices expected to remain subdued for the next 12-18 months due to excess capacity and declining demand. The COVID-19 pandemic, renewable energy growth, and geopolitical tensions have created an uncertain environment for oil prices to recover. Investors should carefully consider the impact of political events, exposure to oil-producing countries, and the speed of recovery in oil prices. The oil crisis may lead to a shift in power dynamics, with Opec's influence waning and conflicts in the Middle East potentially escalating.

site_title: Global companies may shift treasury operations out of Hong Kong
summary: Global companies are considering shifting treasury operations out of Hong Kong due to the US's decision to eliminate special treatment for the city. The move aims to punish Beijing's decision to impose national security laws, potentially affecting trade flows and rates paid by companies in mainland China. Companies such as a leading US retail chain are in talks to relocate treasury operations to Singapore, while Hong Kong's treasury operations remain strong, according to the Hong Kong Monetary Authority. The shift could further threaten Hong Kong's status as a major financial hub.

site_title: Lufthansa posts Q1 net loss of 2.1b euros
summary: Lufthansa reported a net loss of 2.10 billion euros in the first quarter due to write-downs on its fleet and catering business, driven by the coronavirus pandemic. The airline grounded nearly all its aircraft at the pandemic's peak, resulting in a loss before interest and tax of 1.20 billion euros. The group expects a significant decline in 2020 earnings and has approved a 9 billion euro government bailout, which includes a 20% stake and two seats on its supervisory board. This may lead to Lufthansa's removal from Germany's benchmark DAX index.

site_title: Mandate for landlords' rent waivers exception to the norm
summary: The Singapore government has mandated that landlords waive rents for small and medium-sized enterprise (SME) tenants, a move aimed at helping those struggling during the COVID-19 pandemic. This decision is seen as an exception to the norm, as the government has previously relied on market logic and data to address tenant concerns. The Fair Tenancy Framework Industry Committee has proposed a range of recommendations, including variable gross turnover components in rental agreements. The government has also announced additional support for SMEs, including a S$500 million fund to help businesses transform and a Digital Resilience Bonus for those adopting e-payment technologies.

site_title: National Jobs Council to tap tripartite partners: Tharman
summary: Singapore's National Jobs Council, led by Senior Minister Tharman Shanmugaratnam, aims to create over 95,000 job and training opportunities for Singaporeans amid the pandemic and its aftermath. The council, which includes tripartite partners and training providers, will focus on identifying job opportunities, rallying partners, and enabling Singaporeans to take full advantage of these opportunities. Special attention will be paid to middle-aged and mature workers, with the goal of overcoming the jobs challenge and promoting social stagnation. The council's work will align with the Future Economy Council and the Emerging Stronger Taskforce.

site_title: Singapore's derivatives ecosystem continues to chart healthy growth
summary: Singapore's derivatives ecosystem continues to expand with global players setting up regional bases in the country. The Monetary Authority of Singapore (MAS) notes that growth is driven by players from the US, Europe, and China. This expansion is expected to increase the region's influence in the global derivatives market.

site_title: Crude prices retreat after sharp rally
summary: Crude oil prices retreated after a sharp rally, with Brent and WTI prices falling 1.7% and 1.6% respectively, amid reports that an Opec+ meeting may be called off due to disagreements over meeting oil quotas. Despite record production cuts by Opec and allies, experts predict the rally may taper off, with Brent stabilizing around $40 per barrel and global demand recovery taking its own time. A three-month extension of supply cuts could "strongly place oil bulls on the front foot," but market expectations have already priced in most of the positives from the meeting.

site_title: Government, banks offer more relief to cash-strapped landlords
summary: The Singapore government, along with the Ministry of Finance and Monetary Authority, has announced a package of measures to help cash-strapped landlords with their loan commitments, easing cash flow needs. The measures include assistance to landlords who provide relief to tenants, and the government will also assist landlords facing cash flow constraints. This support aims to mitigate the impact of the pandemic on the commercial landlord sector.

images.alt_text: The government may be mandating that commercial landlords help their tenants, but it will also assist landlords who face cash flow constraints as a result of providing relief to their tenants.

site_title: STI rises for third straight day on hopes of economic recovery
summary: Singapore's Straits Times Index (STI) rose 3.4% to 2,700.39, its third consecutive gain, driven by optimism over eased lockdowns and lifted investor sentiment. The STI performance tracked Wall Street's overnight rally. Top performers included ComfortDelGro, DBS, and UOB, while Mapletree Logistics Trust, Jardine Matheson Holdings, and Ascendas Reit were among the biggest losers. Regional benchmarks also ended the day higher.

site_title: Digibank aspirants to show MAS updated proposals
summary: Singapore's 21 digital bank applicants will update their proposals to show their financial strength and resilience amid the COVID-19 pandemic. The Monetary Authority of Singapore (MAS) will assess their ability to manage a prudent and sustainable digital banking business, with financial strength being a key consideration. The applicants, including consortia of entities and solo applicants, will have to demonstrate a path towards profitability based on a five-year financial projection. The MAS will consider all relevant information, including the impact of the pandemic, in making its assessment.

site_title: Comprehensive US-China agreement in best interest of both
summary: A comprehensive US-China agreement is considered beneficial for both nations, despite ongoing trade tensions and disputes over issues such as technology and finance. The Phase One trade agreement's conditions are expected to be met, with China's manufacturing supply chains proving resilient despite the Covid-19 pandemic. However, tensions remain, particularly over the Holding Foreign Companies Accountable Act, which could lead to Chinese companies delisting from US exchanges. A potential transition period and dual-listing trend to Hong Kong's markets may mitigate the impact, allowing companies to find alternative listings.

site_title: Hatten Land bondholders agree to defer repayment for a second time
summary: Hatten Land, a CATALIST-listed company, has secured agreement from its US$25 million, 8-per-cent guaranteed secured bondholders to defer repayment for a second time. The repayment date, originally set for March 8, 2020, has been pushed to July 8, 2020. The interest rate of 10 per cent will apply to the unpaid principal and interest during the extended period.

site_title: US to halt Chinese airlines' access
summary: The US has issued an order suspending passenger flights from China-based airlines, effective June 16, as retaliation for China's ban on US carriers re-entering the Chinese market. The move escalates tensions between the two nations over trade, the coronavirus pandemic, and Hong Kong. US airlines had sought to resume service, but China's leaders recently imposed national security legislation on Hong Kong, preventing US carriers from restarting flights. Chinese carriers will be allowed to operate one flight to the US for each flight granted to American carriers.

site_title: Government and banks to offer more relief to cash-strapped landlords
summary: The Singapore government, along with banks and financial institutions, is offering relief measures to cash-strapped landlords. This includes deferring principal payments on commercial property loans for individual landlords who provide rental waivers or payment rescheduling to their tenants. Landlords can also defer interest payments and extend loan tenures to ease monthly instalments. The measures are available on an opt-in basis and will not affect credit scores.

site_title: UK's Johnson condemns George Floyd killing, calls for 'lawful' protests
summary: British Prime Minister Boris Johnson condemned the killing of George Floyd by US police, calling it "appalling and inexcusable." He emphasized the right to lawful protests but urged people to work with officers amid the COVID-19 lockdown easing. Johnson's comments echoed those of British police chiefs, who appealed for calm and justice. Protests took place in cities across the UK, with hundreds defying virus restrictions. The incident has sparked global outrage and calls for accountability, amidst concerns about racism within policing in both the UK and US.

site_title: Is this the moment for second-best companies and middle powers?
summary: The US-China trade tensions have led to a shift in global trade dynamics, creating opportunities for second-best companies and middle powers to gain market share. Countries like Australia, Canada, and Germany are finding it worthwhile to assume leadership in setting trade standards and developing cooperation frameworks, potentially enhancing their global standing. Despite threats from China, consumers may turn to alternative suppliers, as illustrated by Norway's continued salmon exports to China after a previous incident. This could lead to a more diversified and resilient global trading system.

site_title: CIMB Bank Singapore U-turns on mortgage floor rate hike after customer uproar
summary: CIMB Bank Singapore has reversed its plan to hike its mortgage floor rate from 0.1% to 0.9% due to customer backlash, following a petition from over 100 mortgage customers. The bank will maintain its original floor rate for existing consumer mortgage loans pegged to the Singapore interbank offered rate (Sibor) and Swap offer rate. CIMB CEO Victor Lee attributed the change to the reduction in deposit rates and cost of deposits, and apologized for the inconvenience caused. The bank is now offering alternative fixed-rate packages to affected customers.

site_title: KrisEnergy suspends work at Wassana oil field till further notice
summary: KrisEnergy suspends production at its Wassana oil field in the Gulf of Thailand until further notice due to uncertainties in the Covid-19 pandemic, global economic recovery, and oil prices. The company will cut its workforce in Thailand by approximately 25% and is in discussions regarding the warm-stacking of the mobile offshore production unit. Gross production at Wassana averaged 3,605 barrels per day in the first quarter of 2020.

site_title: Warner Music shareholders raise US$1.9b in upsized IPO
summary: Warner Music Group's shareholders successfully raised US$1.93 billion in an upsized initial public offering, selling 77 million shares at US$25 apiece. This ranks as one of the biggest US listings this year, driven by the renewed strength of US offerings and the emphasis on streaming revenue. The listing signals investors' confidence in the company's ability to adapt to the pandemic and capitalize on the growing demand for entertainment.

site_title: US factory orders extend decline in April
summary: US factory orders dropped 13.0% in April, a decline of 11.0% in March, and 8.0% year-over-year. Economists had forecast a 14% decline. The slump in manufacturing, accounting for 11% of US economic activity, is near its bottom, despite ongoing supply chain disruptions and social distancing measures hindering production. Unfilled orders dropped 1.6% and shipments of manufactured goods fell 13.5% in April. Business investment has contracted for four straight quarters.

site_title: Sanli bags sub-contract for Tuas Water Reclamation Plant
summary: Sanli Environmental's wholly-owned subsidiary, Sanli M&E Engineering, secured a sub-contract from Chip Eng Seng for mechanical and electrical work on the Tuas Water Reclamation Plant. The sub-contract includes engineering, procurement, and construction of MEICA works and is expected to complete in 2025. This win contributes to Sanli's order book of S$293.3 million and is seen as a step towards the group's involvement in the Tuas Nexus project, combining water and solid-waste treatments in Singapore.

site_title: Samurai 2K Aerosol issues profit warning
summary: Samurai 2K Aerosol, a Malaysian aerosol spray paint manufacturer, has issued a profit warning for the year ending March 31, 2020, citing a decrease in total sales volume due to lower demand, increased marketing and distribution expenses, and an unrealised foreign-exchange loss. The company expects to unveil its financial results on or before July 30, with lower revenue and net profit forecasted compared to the prior year.

site_title: US: Wall Street opens higher on recovery optimism
summary: US stocks opened higher on Wednesday as investors remained optimistic about an economic rebound from a coronavirus-led slump. The Dow Jones rose 164.23 points, the S&P 500 gained 18.08 points, and the Nasdaq Composite rose 43.49 points. The gains came despite civil unrest in the country, with investors focused on the potential for economic recovery.

site_title: Saving most vulnerable people from Covid-19
summary: A targeted public health monitoring program, combining PCR tests and serology blood tests, is crucial to protect nursing home residents and healthcare staff from severe COVID-19 infection. In Massachusetts, 38,000 nursing home residents, accounting for 60% of state deaths, require prioritized protection. Implementing a serology-based monitoring system can help identify individuals with protective antibodies, allocate resources efficiently, and inform infection control measures. This approach can also aid in the allocation of COVID-19 vaccines and prepare for future pathogen emergence. By leveraging serology tests, healthcare programs can effectively mitigate the risk of severe infection and save lives.

site_title: Lam says Beijing will not back down on new security law
summary: Hong Kong leader Carrie Lam stated that the central government will not back down on plans for national security legislation, despite Britain's criticism. Prime Minister Boris Johnson vowed to give up to 3 million Hong Kong residents the chance to seek refuge in the UK if China imposes the law, which democracy advocates say will erode freedoms. China's government deemed Johnson's comments as foreign interference in internal affairs.

site_title: US services sector off 11-year trough; still contracting
summary: The US services sector, accounting for over two-thirds of the country's economic activity, experienced a contraction in May with an 11-year low reading of 45.4, according to the Institute for Supply Management. This reading is below the 50-point threshold indicating contraction, and is the lowest since March 2009. The economy contracted at a 5% annualized rate in the first quarter, with a forecasted decline of 40% in the second quarter, the largest since the Great Depression. The labor market is expected to be severely impacted, with a projected 8 million job losses and a 19.7% unemployment rate.

site_title: Singapore PMI improves in May, but still in contractionary mode
summary: Singapore's factory sentiment improved in May, with the Purchasing Managers' Index (PMI) rising to 46.8, up 2.1 points from April. The electronics sector PMI also improved, but both readings remain in contractionary territory for the fourth straight month. Economists note that headwinds remain, with slower contractions in key indexes and supplier deliveries indicating global supply-chain disruptions. The recovery is expected to be gradual, with some sectors showing signs of improvement, but overall manufacturing is likely to remain muted outside of China.

site_title: US private employment falls 2.76 million in May: ADP
summary: US private employment fell 2.76 million in May, according to ADP data, following nearly 20 million job losses in April due to the coronavirus pandemic. The losses were widespread across all sectors and sizes of business, except for education, which saw a modest increase. This data is a preview of the government's monthly jobs report due out Friday. The impact of the pandemic continues to weigh on businesses, according to ADP Research Institute co-head Ahu Yildirmaz.

images.alt_text: Private companies shed another 2.76 million jobs in May following nearly 20 million job losses in April due to the coronavirus pandemic, according to data released Wednesday from payrolls firm ADP.

site_title: CIMB drops mortgage floor rate hike after customer furore
summary: CIMB Bank Singapore has dropped its planned mortgage floor rate hike of 0.9% to 0.1% for existing consumer mortgage loans, following customer backlash. The bank initially announced the hike in response to rising interest rates. The decision reverses CIMB's earlier move and reverts to its original floor rate of 0.1%. The move is seen as a response to customer complaints and pressure from a group of customers who challenged the bank's decision.

site_title: Parkson Retail Asia draws SGX query for unusual trading activity
summary: Parkson Retail Asia has drawn a query from the Singapore Exchange (SGX) over unusual trading activity in its shares, which surged 114.29% on volume of 30.3 million on June 3, 2020. The retailer attributed the surge to no previously announced information and is in a negative working capital position with a loss of approximately S$27.7 million for the nine months ended March 31, 2020. The SGX also queried the group's ability to meet short-term debt obligations and operate as a going concern, to which Parkson replied that it has secured financial support and is trying to generate sufficient cash flow.

site_title: Man behind Sweden's controversial virus strategy admits mistakes
summary: Sweden's top epidemiologist, Anders Tegnell, has admitted that the country's strategy to fight Covid-19 resulted in too many deaths due to a lack of strict lockdowns. Despite this, Tegnell believes a more balanced approach would be better if faced with the same knowledge today. Sweden's death rate is among the highest globally, with 43 deaths per 100,000, and the country's economy is struggling due to its decision to keep society open. The government has announced an inquiry into the crisis, and lawmakers have criticized Tegnell's comments, with some calling them "astonishing."

site_title: Shell weighs sale of US$2b-plus stake in Queensland LNG facilities
summary: Royal Dutch Shell is considering selling a 26.25% stake in its Queensland Curtis LNG plant in Australia for between $2 billion and $3 billion. The sale process, led by Rothschild & Co, aims to be completed in 2020. The facilities, which Shell wholly owns, include liquefied natural gas storage tanks, water, fuel, and power generation systems. The sale follows Shell's efforts to sell assets worth over $10 billion in 2019-2020 and comes as the company seeks to reduce costs amid a historic oil demand slump.

site_title: National Jobs Council to tap into tripartite partners' networks to create job opportunities
summary: The National Jobs Council, chaired by Senior Minister Tharman Shanmugaratnam, has outlined its priority areas to create nearly 100,000 job and training opportunities for Singaporeans amid the Covid-19 pandemic. The council, comprising 16 tripartite partners, will focus on identifying job opportunities, mobilizing training providers, and enabling Singaporeans to take advantage of these opportunities through job creation and retraining. The council will also align its work with the Future Economy Council and Emerging Stronger Taskforce, aiming to support middle-aged and older workers.

site_title: Malaysia: Shares close higher on Wednesday
summary: Malaysia's FTSE Bursa Malaysia Kuala Lumpur Composite Index rose 30.84 points to 1,538.53 on Wednesday, driven by gains. The index saw 562 gainers for every 526 losers, with volume reaching RM7.014 billion.

site_title: US crowds defy curfew to protest Floyd's death, but violence subsides
summary: US protesters defied curfews for the eighth consecutive night, venting their anger over the death of George Floyd, an unarmed black man killed by a white police officer. Despite the curfew, violence subsided in many cities, with clashes between protesters and police reported in Washington, Portland, and New York City. However, 200 arrests were made, largely for curfew violations. The officer involved in Floyd's death has been charged with third-degree murder and second-degree manslaughter, and rallies across the US continue to call for justice and an end to police brutality.

site_title: Daily Debrief: What Happened Today
summary: Key developments include the Singapore government's extension of rental waivers for small and medium-sized enterprises (SMEs) facing a 35% revenue decline, an audit inspection by the Accounting and Corporate Regulatory Authority (ACRA) on KPMG's Hyflux audit, and the launch of the GSM Building at Middle Road for en bloc sale. The Straits Times Index (STI) rose for the third consecutive day, driven by hopes of economic recovery. Additionally, BreadTalk will delist from the Singapore Exchange on June 5, and the government is seeking public feedback on a proposed licensing scheme for Content Moderation Operators (CMOs).

site_title: Singapore stocks set to enter bull market, among last in Asia
summary: Singapore stocks have gained 20% from their March lows, entering a technical bull market, making it one of the last major Asian gauges to do so. The Straits Times Index advanced 3% on Wednesday, driven by optimism over the reopening of the economy and record-low valuations. Despite a worst-ever contraction in GDP expected this year, investors remain positive, citing reopening optimism and US-China relations. The index now trades at 0.9 times estimated book value, a significant increase from its March low.

site_title: Nomura considers having fewer staff at headquarters permanently
summary: Nomura Holdings is considering reducing staff at its Tokyo headquarters to 20% due to the coronavirus pandemic's shift to remote working. The company's CEO, Kentaro Okuda, wants to discuss the need for such a large workforce in the financial district. This move could help Nomura reduce costs, which have been impacted by competition from online stock-trading rivals. The company has already announced cost cuts and is scaling back its retail branches.

site_title: Seoul: Stocks surge; up 50% from March lows as techs lead relief rally
summary: South Korean stocks surged 3% to a three-month high, reaching 2,147, driven by tech giants Samsung Electronics and Hyundai Motor. The Kospi index is up nearly 50% from its March lows, the steepest equity relief rally in Asia. The rally is attributed to government efforts to combat the COVID-19 crisis and economic recovery hopes. Foreign investors bought $167.83 million worth of shares, while domestic investors continue to buy stocks, with investors optimistic about gradual economic improvement next year.

site_title: Europe renews push to slash global tariffs on medical goods
summary: The European Union is pushing for a global deal to eliminate tariffs on pharmaceuticals and medical supplies, aiming to prevent supply-chain disruptions like those caused by the coronavirus pandemic. The EU's executive arm, the European Commission, proposed a policy to end customs duties on essential goods, including antibiotics, vaccines, and medical equipment. This initiative would also give countries less room to restrict international trade in healthcare goods during health crises. The proposal is set to be discussed by EU trade ministers on June 9.

site_title: Acra says it is inspecting KPMG's audit of Hyflux
summary: The Accounting and Corporate Regulatory Authority (Acra) is inspecting KPMG's audit of Hyflux, a water-treatment firm, as part of a larger probe into the company's compliance with accounting and auditing standards between 2011 and 2018. Hyflux owes S$900 million to 34,000 retail investors who bought its perpetuals and preference shares, and its board of directors is under investigation for suspected false and misleading statements. The investigation may have implications for the credibility of the board and its ability to lead the company.

site_title: Malaysia revokes 5G spectrum awarded to telecoms firms
summary: Malaysia has revoked the 5G spectrum awarded to major telecoms firms and a private company due to technical and legal issues, following a process that was not transparent and did not involve a tender. The decision was made by Communications and Multimedia Minister Saifuddin Abdullah, who instructed the Malaysian Communications and Multimedia Commission to review the instruments immediately. The 700 MHz 5G spectrum was initially awarded to local units of Axiata Group, Digi.Com, and Maxis, as well as Telekom Malaysia and private firm Altel Communications.

images.alt_text: Malaysia on Wednesday revoked the 5G telecommunications spectrum it handed out to major domestic telecoms players and a private firm after controversy over the process done without a tender.

site_title: Kimly completes acquisitions of six food outlets for S$35.5m
summary: Kimly, a CATALIST-listed coffeeshop consolidator, has completed the acquisitions of six food outlets for S$35.5 million. The company will also acquire two more coffeeshops for S$20.3 million, pending Housing Development Board approvals. The acquisitions aim to enhance properties with layout improvements, increased seating capacities, and new food concepts to retain and attract customers. Kimly expects to benefit from consumers' preference for economical food options and online deliveries amid the Covid-19 pandemic.

site_title: Business, official travellers must be sponsored by government agency or company under Singapore-China fast lane agreement
summary: Singapore and China have agreed to a "fast lane" for business and official travellers between the two countries, allowing for expedited travel without a two-week quarantine. Travellers must be sponsored by a government agency or company and undergo PCR tests and health declarations. They will also be required to take swab tests before and after arrival, and adhere to a controlled itinerary. The arrangement will initially cover six Chinese provinces and municipalities, with plans to expand to others. Travellers will be expected to cover the cost of tests and medical treatment if they test positive for Covid-19.

site_title: STI rises for third straight day on hopes of economic recovery
summary: Singapore's benchmark Straits Times Index (STI) rose for the third consecutive day, ending at 2,700.39, up 88.76 points or 3.4%. Investors' optimism over eased lockdowns and stimulus measures lifted the market, with Wall Street's overnight rally tracking the STI's performance. Local banks DBS, UOB, and OCBC were among the top performers, while Mapletree Logistics Trust, Jardine Matheson Holdings, and Ascendas Reit were among the biggest losers.

site_title: Hong Kong Tycoon Li's telecom firm weighs US$1b unit sale
summary: Hong Kong telecommunications firm PCCW Global, controlled by tycoon Richard Li, is considering selling its international enterprise unit for up to $1 billion. The sale could attract interest from telecom companies and private-equity funds. HKT, the parent company, has not yet decided on the deal structure. The sale process is at an early stage, with a formal process potentially starting later this year.

site_title: Pope urges US reconciliation, condemns racism and street violence
summary: Pope Francis addressed the US, urging national reconciliation and condemning racism and street violence. He called the death of George Floyd "tragic" and prayed for all those affected by racism and violence. The Pope emphasized that violence is self-destructive and self-defeating, and asked Americans to implore God for national reconciliation and peace. He also called for an end to racism and exclusion, and asked for intercession for those working for peace and justice.

images.alt_text: Pope Francis called for national reconciliation in the United States on Wednesday, saying that while racism is intolerable, the street violence that has broken out is "self-destructive and self-defeating".

site_title: Hyflux subsidiary's ex-HR manager charged with corruption
summary: A former human resource manager of Hyflux subsidiary Hydrochem, Khoo Chen Ee, has been charged with corruption for allegedly receiving S$7,000 in "rewards" from a director of Leeds HR Solution. Khoo, 36, resigned from Hydrochem in December 2018 and intends to plead guilty. The case is part of a broader investigation into Hyflux, which is currently under scrutiny for suspected false and misleading statements and non-compliance with accounting standards.

site_title: Death of reality TV show star in Japan spotlights cyber bullying
summary: A 22-year-old Japanese reality TV show star, Hana Kimura, died from an apparent suicide after being subjected to cyber bullying on social media. Her death has highlighted a rise in cyber bullying in Japan, prompting swift pledges to protect victims. The ruling party is holding hearings to consider legal changes to help victims seek justice, and experts welcome the momentum to update the law. However, concerns remain about the lengthy court process and the need for expedited changes to identify anonymous online abusers.

site_title: Flush with Petrobras settlement cash, Brazilian states step up deforestation fight
summary: Brazilian states are bolstering efforts to combat Amazon deforestation with millions of dollars from a Petrobras corruption settlement, totaling at least 140 million reais. The funds will be used to hire patrol officers, surveillance technology, and other resources to protect the rainforest. This comes as deforestation in Brazil's Amazon reached an 11-year high in 2019, coinciding with a decline in federal environment agency Ibama's budget. The state environmental agencies will act as a counterpoint to the federal government, which has weakened protections for the rainforest under President Jair Bolsonaro.

site_title: Fashion jumps on Black Lives Matter bandwagon after lootings
summary: Fashion brands such as Versace, Saint Laurent, and Gucci have posted messages of solidarity with the Black Lives Matter movement after luxury boutiques were looted in locations like Rodeo Drive and SoHo. The industry faces a public-relations challenge amid store shutdowns and weakened demand, with brands trying to gain credibility despite past racial controversies. Several brands, including H&M and Gucci, have made donations to organizations supporting the movement, but some have criticized the timing and sincerity of their actions.

site_title: 81-year-old woman only Singaporean among 7 new Covid-19 community cases
summary: An 81-year-old Singaporean woman is the only local among seven new COVID-19 community cases, announced on June 3. The total in Singapore now stands at 36,405, with 562 foreign workers in dormitories and six work pass holders linked to known clusters. The Ministry of Health reported a decrease in new community cases, with 12 pre-school staff likely having past infections, and two new clusters confirmed. The government advises against avoiding listed public places and encourages those who visited to monitor their health closely.

site_title: Extra rental waivers for SMEs with at least 35% fall in revenue
summary: The Singapore government has introduced new legislation to provide rental waivers for small and medium-sized enterprises (SMEs) affected by the COVID-19 pandemic. Landlords are required to grant a two-month waiver of base rent for SMEs in commercial properties and a one-month waiver for industrial and office properties. Additionally, SMEs with at least a 35% fall in revenue will be eligible for an extra two-month and one-month base rental waiver, respectively. The government will share the cost of mandatory rental waivers with landlords, and tenants can serve notice on their landlords for a statutory repayment scheme of outstanding arrears.

site_title: GSM Building at Middle Road launched for en bloc sale
summary: The GSM Building at 141 Middle Road in Singapore has been launched for en bloc sale after achieving the minimum consent level. The site, with a 12,003 sq ft land area, is zoned for commercial use and has a balance lease term of 61 years. The upgrading premium is approximately S$18.6 million, adding to the asking price of around S$98 million. The building is located near various amenities, including public transportation hubs and educational institutions, and is expected to close for tender on July 16.

site_title: Australia mulls return of crowds to sporting stadiums as Covid-19 cases slow
summary: Australia is considering allowing small crowds at sporting stadiums as the country's Covid-19 cases slow. The nation's deputy chief medical officer, Paul Kelly, said the move could be possible in the near future due to the successful efforts to contain the virus. With fewer than 20 cases per day, Australia has begun professional sports without crowds, and a national cabinet meeting on Friday will discuss easing social distancing restrictions, including allowing small crowds at stadiums. This comes as Australia's economy has slipped into recession, with the country's GDP contracting 0.3% in the last quarter.

site_title: Over 5,400 home renovation projects in Singapore approved to resume work
summary: The Building and Construction Authority (BCA) in Singapore has approved over 5,400 home renovation projects to resume work after the Covid-19 "circuit breaker" period. All new applications will be approved within two days, and construction workers can resume work immediately if they have completed their 28-day stay-home notice. However, contractors with workers residing in dormitories will need to wait for clearance from an inter-agency taskforce. Workers will still be subject to periodic Covid-19 tests, and any positive cases will require immediate stoppage of work and quarantine.

site_title: Tiffany shares dive after report that deal with LVMH is uncertain
summary: Tiffany & Co. shares plummeted 8.9% on Tuesday after Women's Wear Daily reported that LVMH's deal to buy the luxury jeweler is uncertain due to the US economy's widespread upheaval and concerns over Tiffany's ability to cover its debt covenants. LVMH's board members met to discuss the proposed deal, citing the pandemic's disruption to the US economy and growing unrest. The deal, valued at over $16 billion, was originally seen as a strategic opportunity for LVMH to boost its position in branded jewelry.

site_title: Uber ex-CTO reflects on a rift with Travis Kalanick and how to fix autonomous cars
summary: Uber's former Chief Technology Officer Thuan Pham reflects on his seven-year tenure at the company, which he divided into three "tours of duty." During his time, Pham helped expand Uber globally but left behind a rift with former CEO Travis Kalanick, who he had a falling out with after Pham stayed at the company after Kalanick's ouster. Pham now expresses concerns over the company's autonomous-driving strategy, urging a team-up with more advanced projects like Waymo. He has since resigned and is considering a life after Uber, focusing on personal projects and mentoring entrepreneurs.

site_title: Australia: Shares end near 3-month high as investors eye recovery
summary: Australian shares rose 1.8% to a near three-month high, driven by gains in energy and financial stocks as investors expect an economic recovery from the coronavirus-induced recession. The S&P/ASX 200 index closed at 5,941.60, its third consecutive gain, and is up 30% since hitting a multi-year low. The Reserve Bank of Australia held interest rates at a record low and left the door open for further stimulus. Analysts expect a softer-than-feared economic downturn, citing improved health outcomes and earlier business reopenings.

site_title: Tokyo: Nikkei rallies to over 3-month high; weaker yen lifts auto shares
summary: Japan's Nikkei stock benchmark surged to a three-month high, closing at 22,613.76, driven by a weakening yen and "FOMO" from investors. Automakers like Mazda, Nissan, and Subaru rose 9.1%, 7.5%, and 6%, respectively. The Topix index also rose 0.7%, its highest since February 26, with cyclical sectors performing well. Despite concerns over COVID-19 cases in Japan, the market has shown resilience to negative news, with analysts attributing gains to short-term optimism.

site_title: IndiGo to add new Airbus jets to fleet despite virus
summary: IndiGo, India's largest airline, plans to add new Airbus A320neo jets to its fleet despite the ongoing coronavirus pandemic, which has devastated air travel demand. The airline, which had initially expected a 20% capacity increase, will return its entire fleet of 120 older planes to lessors over the next two years and take delivery of new aircraft. This move is seen as a positive for Airbus, which has reduced its production target and warned of further job cuts. IndiGo's decision is also a rare example of a low-cost carrier keeping growth plans intact, with other airlines deferring deliveries due to the pandemic.

images.alt_text: IndiGo, India's biggest airline, said it will keep adding new aircraft to its fleet even as it can't give any firm guidance on future capacity growth because of the coronavirus pandemic, which destroyed demand for air travel in one of the world's fastest-growing aviation markets.

site_title: BreadTalk to delist from SGX on June 5
summary: BreadTalk Group will delist from the Singapore Exchange (SGX) on June 5, following the completion of its compulsory acquisition. The company suspended trading in its shares on April 21 and lost its free float on April 4. The compulsory acquisition was exercised by BTG Holding, a special purpose vehicle owned by BreadTalk's founder and chairman George Quek, with Minor International owning 99.7% of The Minor Food Group, which in turn owns Primacy Investments, a substantial shareholder of BreadTalk.

site_title: British PM Johnson tells China: we shall not walk away from Hong Kong
summary: British Prime Minister Boris Johnson warned China that the UK will not abandon Hong Kong if Beijing imposes a national security law conflicting with international obligations. Johnson stated that the UK's obligations under the 1984 Joint Declaration, a UN-registered treaty, cannot be ignored. He vowed to honour the UK's commitments and provide an alternative if China proceeds, emphasizing the importance of Hong Kong's freedom. This move comes as Britain's National Security Council agreed to rebalance its relationship with China.

site_title: Insurer AXA to cut proposed dividend payout
summary: French insurer AXA plans to cut its proposed dividend payout to 0.73 euro per share from 1.43 euros, citing the need to preserve cash amid the coronavirus pandemic. The company may consider an additional fourth-quarter payment if financial conditions improve. AXA previously mentioned it could face 500 million euro claims for event cancellations due to the pandemic.

site_title: Formula One unveils eight-race schedule in Europe from July 5
summary: Formula One has unveiled an eight-race schedule in Europe, starting with two behind-closed-doors races in Austria on July 5 and 12. The season, which was disrupted by the coronavirus pandemic, will also feature races in Hungary, Britain, Spain, Italy, and Belgium. The European leg of the season will conclude with the Belgian and Italian Grands Prix on August 30 and September 6, respectively. The season is expected to be completed in December with a revised schedule featuring races in Asia and the Americas.

images.alt_text: The curtailed Formula One season will start with two races behind closed doors in Austria on July 5 and July 12, followed by six other grands prix in Europe, the organisers said on Tuesday.

site_title: Europe: Shares rise on upbeat China data; Renault jumps
summary: European shares rose 0.8% on Wednesday, driven by upbeat China data and a survey showing China's services sector returned to growth in May. The Stoxx 600 held near a three-month high, with sectors exposed to China's economy, such as oil and gas and automakers, rising over 1%. Renault jumped 7.7% after securing a 5 billion euro loan, while AXA rose 5% after halving its dividend. The positive start to the week follows a global rally, with US stocks also reaching fresh records despite trade tensions and civil unrest.

site_title: From five-star hotels to the homeless, Hong Kong NGO recycles soap
summary: A Hong Kong NGO, Soap Cycling, recycles hundreds of thousands of discarded hotel soap bars, distributing them in hygiene kits to homeless and low-income communities. Founded in 2012, the organization has partnered with 80 hotels, collecting 17,545kg of soap last year. The recycled soap is processed into larger bars, packed into kits with masks and hand sanitizer, and sent to charities like ImpactHK. The program has expanded to Myanmar, Singapore, and mainland China, and distributes soap in the Philippines and Cambodia. The initiative aims to reduce environmental impact while providing essential hygiene products.

site_title: GrabPay extends reach with launch of virtual prepaid card in the Philippines
summary: GrabPay, a tech firm, has launched a virtual prepaid card in the Philippines, expanding its reach to 53 million merchants worldwide that accept Mastercard. The card allows users to control their spending and has added security features, including biometric authentication and PIN protection. The launch complements Grab's efforts to promote cashless services and curb the spread of Covid-19, following a Mastercard survey showing 40% of Filipino consumers are using contactless payments.

site_title: Saudi Arabia's non-oil private sector shrinks for third straight month
summary: Saudi Arabia's non-oil private sector contracted for the third straight month in May, with the seasonally adjusted IHS Markit Saudi Arabia Purchasing Managers' Index (PMI) at 48.1. This marks the third time in the survey's history that the headline figure was in contractionary territory, with business conditions deteriorating but at a slower pace than in April. Employment levels and staff costs also shrank, but at a slower pace, amid wage cuts and low demand due to ongoing COVID-19 measures.

site_title: Australia's economy shrinks in Q1, signals first recession in 30 years
summary: Australia's economy contracted 0.3% in Q1, marking its first decline in nine years and signaling the country's first technical recession in 30 years. Household consumption was the biggest drag on growth, with massive falls in spending on various sectors. The country's A$2 trillion economy is facing its worst contraction since the Great Depression. The central bank has cut interest rates and launched a bond buying program to stimulate growth, but the economic fallout is expected to deepen due to the ongoing coronavirus pandemic and devastating bushfire season.

site_title: BlackRock focuses on China credit, oil and travel in Asia
summary: BlackRock, the world's largest asset manager, has outlined its Asia outlook, focusing on China credit, oil, and travel in the region. The fund manager expects a 2022 return to global growth trend and sees Asia as a beneficiary when the recovery arrives. BlackRock likes China's credit spectrum, state-owned businesses, and the real estate sector, while India's quasi-sovereign debt and bonds funding renewable energy present opportunities. Oil prices are expected to rise from the current US$30 range, and price-to-book values in India and Indonesia are at one to two-decade lows.

site_title: Germany's Lufthansa posts Q1 net loss of 2.1b euros
summary: Germany's Lufthansa reported a net loss of 2.1 billion euros in the first quarter due to write-downs on its fleet and catering business. The airline attributed the loss to the coronavirus pandemic's impact on the travel sector. Lufthansa has received a 9 billion euro government bailout, which includes a 20% stake in the airline and the transfer of landing slots to rivals. The airline expects a significant decline in earnings for 2020 and may be removed from Germany's benchmark blue-chip index.

site_title: Google takes down Indian app that removed Chinese ones
summary: Google removed an Indian app, "Remove China Apps", from its app store due to violating company policies. The app, which gained popularity amid calls for a boycott of Chinese apps in India, had over 5 million downloads since late May. The move was made in response to the app's removal of Chinese apps, which Google deemed a violation of its app store policies. The app's removal was confirmed by a Google spokesperson, but no further details were provided.

site_title: MinLaw, IPOS seek public feedback on proposed licensing scheme for CMOs
summary: Singapore's Ministry of Law and Intellectual Property Office of Singapore are seeking public feedback on a proposed licensing scheme for collective management organisations (CMOs). CMOs manage licensing administration and royalty collection for copyright works. The proposed scheme aims to address issues such as members' rights, distribution of licence fees, and dispute resolution. The public consultation will end on June 30. This move is part of efforts to regulate CMOs, which are currently unregulated in Singapore.

site_title: Australia confirms end to longest boom as fires, pandemic destroy growth
summary: Australia's economy has fallen into recession, marking the country's first since the early 1990s, as the COVID-19 pandemic and devastating bushfires led to a 0.3% contraction in the first quarter. Annual growth slowed to 1.4%, the slowest since the 2009 global financial crisis. The recession is expected to worsen in the June quarter, with unemployment predicted to reach 10% by June and stay elevated in 2021. The Australian government has implemented a large fiscal stimulus plan, including a A$60 billion wage subsidy scheme, to cushion the blow to the economy.

images.alt_text: Australia's economy has fallen into recession, the country's treasurer said on Wednesday, after official data showed gross domestic product fell last quarter as entire business sectors were closed to fight the coronavirus.

site_title: Indonesia steps up fiscal spending to keep economy from contracting
summary: Indonesia's finance minister, Sri Mulyani Indrawati, has announced a widened 2020 budget deficit of 6.34% of GDP, exceeding earlier estimates, to support the virus-hit economy. The government's total spending for the National Economic Recovery Programme is expected to rise to 677.2 trillion rupiah, boosting the 2020 budget to 2,738.4 trillion rupiah. The government aims to maintain economic growth above 0% and has set a GDP forecast of between -0.4% to 2.3%. This move aims to keep the economy from contracting.

site_title: As Asia's tropical storm season arrives, grounded airplanes at risk of damage
summary: Asia's tropical storm season is expected to cause unusually high damage to grounded airplanes, with hundreds of aircraft stranded at airports due to the coronavirus pandemic. Airlines and airports are bracing for the risk, with some airports using runways for parking and others securing planes in hangars or sending them to other airports. Insurers face a larger-than-usual risk, with one event potentially causing millions of dollars in damage. The Airports Council International warns that flying planes out of danger may not be possible, and extra precautions such as more tie-downs may be needed.

site_title: Amid pandemic, White House race becomes digital dogfight
summary: The 2020 US presidential race is shifting to a digital-first campaign due to the coronavirus pandemic, cutting off traditional organizing and in-person events. President Donald Trump has an edge in digital infrastructure and social media following, but Democrat Joe Biden is stepping up his digital presence with the help of outside organizations. Digital advertising is expected to reach $1.8 billion, with progressive groups and the Biden campaign working to counter Trump's sophisticated digital operation. The campaigns are also testing online platforms' policies on manipulation and microtargeting, raising concerns about online disinformation and voter manipulation.

site_title: 80 breaches found at purpose-built dorms annually for the past three years: MOM
summary: The Ministry of Manpower (MOM) in Singapore reported 80 breaches annually at purpose-built dormitories over the past three years, with most being minor lapses. About 20 dorms breach licensing conditions each year, out of 43 licensed under the Foreign Employee Dormitories Act. In the past three years, 150 fire safety infringements were found in inspections by the Singapore Civil Defence Force, with 143 resulting in composition fines. MOM can fine up to S$50,000 for breaches, and employers who fail to provide acceptable accommodation can face fines and have their work pass privileges revoked.

site_title: South Korea approves emergency use of Gilead's anti-viral drug to treat Covid-19
summary: South Korea has approved the emergency use of Gilead's remdesivir, an anti-viral drug, to treat Covid-19, citing positive results from other countries. The drug is administered intravenously in hospital and can help reduce the amount of coronavirus in the body, improving patient conditions faster. Remdesivir has shown a modest benefit in patients with moderate Covid-19 and has been approved for use in Japan. South Korea's Ministry for Food and Drug Safety will cooperate with Gilead and other ministries to swiftly import the drug, with guidelines allowing for daily administration of one dose, up to 10 doses for severe symptoms.

site_title: Malaysia awards 5G spectrum to key domestic telecoms firms
summary: Malaysia has awarded 5G spectrum to major domestic telecoms firms, including Axiata Group, Digi.Com, Maxis, Telekom Malaysia, and private firm Altel Communications. The 700 MHz spectrum was allocated through a tender process to cut costs and avoid infrastructure duplication. The move is part of the country's efforts to roll out 5G networks, with the identified pioneer spectrum bands being 700 MHz, 3.5 GHz, and 26/28 GHz. The Malaysian Communications and Multimedia Commission will immediately allocate the spectrum to the companies.

site_title: Pandemic could cost Australian universities US$11b: lobby group
summary: Australian universities face a potential revenue loss of up to US$11 billion due to an indefinite coronavirus border closure, affecting foreign students. The sector, which generates A$32 billion (US$30.8 billion) annually, is pushing for a cash injection to support staff and facilities. The closure has already led to job losses, with over 20,000 academic and support staff jobs at risk. The university sector's dependence on Chinese students has sparked controversy, and some states consider exemptions for foreign students willing to undergo quarantine.

site_title: G-7 finance leaders to hold virus teleconference on Wednesday: Japan's Jiji
summary: Finance leaders of the Group of Seven nations will hold a teleconference on Wednesday to discuss measures to combat the coronavirus pandemic. This is the latest of several teleconferences held since the pandemic spread, pushing the global economy to the verge of deep recession. The meeting comes as China's GDP growth is expected to slow, raising pressure on policymakers.

site_title: Someone just made a big bullish options bet on a Singapore ETF
summary: A record 5,044 iShares MSCI Singapore ETF (EWS) calls were traded on Tuesday, with one trade involving 3,800 November $21 calls at 45 US cents each. The ETF rose 2.1% to close at $19.12. This is the latest sign of increased bullishness on Singapore, as investors flock to the country's shares amid uncertainty over Hong Kong's future. The Straits Times Index has gained nearly 19% since its March low, with the iShares MSCI Singapore ETF gathering almost $330 million since January.

site_title: City centres to see 'radical' redesign amid coronavirus
summary: Cities worldwide are expected to undergo a "radical redesign" as the COVID-19 pandemic accelerates remote working and forces companies to rethink their office spaces. With over 6.3 million global infections, lockdowns have led to a shift away from traditional downtown hubs, with Twitter and Google employees already allowed to work from home indefinitely. Cities may adopt more sustainable, mixed-use developments and repurpose underutilized spaces, prioritizing green spaces, pedestrian-friendly infrastructure, and community facilities to ensure equal access to affordable housing and services.

site_title: US office towers are still going up, but who will fill them?
summary: The US office tower construction boom continues despite the pandemic, with 25-story buildings like Mark F Irgens' BMO Tower in Milwaukee opening in the second half of 2020. However, occupancy rates are lower than expected, with only 15% of the BMO Tower filled, and some developers are concerned about long-term demand. Experts predict that the pandemic may lead to changes in office space, such as more spacious elevators and walkable, mixed-use environments, but projects may be paused until the economic crisis subsides.

site_title: New Zealand could return to normal life as early as next week: PM
