summary: New Zealand Prime Minister Jacinda Ardern may lift all social distancing measures and return the country to normal life as early as next week, provided there are no new cases of coronavirus. Ardern will assess the situation on Monday, considering recent changes to restrictions, after 12 consecutive days with no new cases and just one active case. Under a level 1 alert, there will be no physical distancing requirements, but no immediate plans to reopen the international border.

site_title: 1,081 more US coronavirus deaths in 24 hours: Johns Hopkins
summary: The US has reported 1,081 additional coronavirus deaths in the 24 hours leading up to 8:30pm Tuesday, bringing the total death toll to 106,180 out of 1,831,435 official cases. The US has the most COVID-19 cases and deaths globally, with at least 379,585 deaths worldwide. As the US relaxes containment measures, many major cities have implemented nighttime curfews to combat unrest following the death of George Floyd.

site_title: Italy reopens to tourists from Europe
summary: Italy has reopened to tourists from Europe, three months after the country's coronavirus lockdown, with the goal of reviving its struggling tourism industry. The reopening includes major cities like Rome, Venice, and Milan, but some countries, such as Switzerland and Austria, have expressed concerns about traveling to Italy due to ongoing health measures. Italy's tourism sector, which accounts for 13% of the country's GDP, is heavily reliant on foreign visitors, and the government is urging travelers to come, despite ongoing pandemic risks.

site_title: US firms fear for Hong Kong operations as tensions simmer over Chinese legislation
summary: US businesses are concerned about the future of their operations in Hong Kong due to China's planned national security legislation, which could curb the city's freedoms and fuel ongoing protests. A survey of 180 US firms found 30% were "moderately" concerned and 53.3% were "very concerned" about the laws, which could harm their business operations and lead to a talent drain. Some companies, including HSBC Holdings, have been pressured to support the legislation, while others, like Jardines Group, have published statements in favor of enacting the law to safeguard Hong Kong's national security.

site_title: Airline angst as Spain to sue over virus flight chaos
summary: The Spanish government plans to sue 17 airlines for failing to inform travelers about their right to a refund for flights canceled during the pandemic. Iberia, one of the airlines being sued, denied the allegations, stating that it clearly informs customers of their rights. The lawsuit follows a statement by the consumer affairs ministry, which claimed that airlines' failure to provide refunds constitutes unfair trading and a breach of European law. The move is part of a broader dispute over refunds and vouchers for canceled flights amid the pandemic.

site_title: Australian, New Zealand dollars extend breakneck rally on recovery progress
summary: The Australian and New Zealand dollars extended their rally, with the Aussie rising 0.6% to US$0.6936 and the kiwi dollar jumping 0.6% to US$0.6404. The gains, driven by progress in reopening economies and risk asset recovery, have delivered 3-4% gains in three sessions. Economists revise their outlook for the Aussie, with one analyst predicting it will exceed its pre-coronavirus level of US$0.70 before the end of 2020.

images.alt_text: The Australian and New Zealand dollars on Wednesday extended a rally that has delivered gains of 3-4 per cent in just three sessions as progress on opening economies across the globe boosted risk assets.

site_title: Venezuela govt, opposition agree to seek funds to fight coronavirus
summary: Venezuela's government and opposition have signed an agreement to work together to fight the coronavirus pandemic. The agreement includes seeking funds to improve testing, acquire protective gear, and launch public health campaigns. The move comes as Venezuela struggles with a high number of reported cases and deaths, with critics accusing the government of underreporting cases due to insufficient testing. The partnership with the Pan American Health Organization aims to combat the spread of the virus and provide better healthcare for the population.

site_title: South Korean self-driving startup RideFlux takes on Uber, Tesla and Waymo
summary: A South Korean self-driving startup, RideFlux, has launched an autonomous vehicle on public roads, challenging Uber, Tesla, and Waymo. The modified Hyundai Ioniq has been shuttling customers on a 5-kilometer route, navigating through a busy airport area, and has logged 10,000 kilometers in six months. RideFlux aims to offer ride-hailing services using autonomous cars on 400 kilometers of Jeju's major roads by the end of the year, with plans to introduce fully autonomous vehicles in the next five years.

images.alt_text: In a workshop that blends a corporate office with a tool-packed garage, around 20 South Koreans are looking to take on the multi-billion-dollar giants of Uber, Tesla and Google parent Alphabet with a self-driving car of their own.

site_title: US dollar stumbles as recovery hopes boost Asian FX
summary: The US dollar fell against most Asian currencies as investors sought riskier assets amid hopes of government stimulus and a global economic recovery. The Australian dollar surged to a five-month high, while China's yuan edged higher after a private survey showed the services sector returned to growth. This recovery optimism also boosted shares and fueled expectations for economic growth in the region.

site_title: Hong Kong: Shares open on a high
summary: Hong Kong stocks opened on a high, with the Hang Seng Index jumping 1.28% to 24,303.56. Global markets continue to rise as countries reopen their economies. China's Shanghai Composite Index and Shenzhen Composite Index also increased, with gains of 0.31% and 0.30%, respectively.

site_title: Seoul: Shares hit 3-1/2-month high on rebound hopes, stimulus package
summary: South Korean shares surged to a three-month high on Wednesday, reaching 2,142.01 points, as investors rebounded from worries about the US civil unrest and economic growth. The benchmark Kospi index rose 2.6% with chipmakers Samsung Electronics and SK Hynix leading the gains. The Korean won strengthened to a three-week high, while the yield on three-year treasury bonds fell 0.06 point. A 35.3 trillion won supplementary budget was also unveiled to support the country's economy, facing its worst growth since the 1998 Asian financial crisis.

site_title: Asia: Recovery hope fires fresh rally in equities but concerns remain
summary: Asian markets rallied for a third day on Wednesday as growing optimism about the global economic recovery fueled gains, despite ongoing concerns about COVID-19 surges in Latin America and civil unrest in the US. Stocks in Hong Kong, Tokyo, and Sydney rose at least one percent, while South Korea's government unveiled a $29 billion supplementary budget to boost the economy. Oil markets continued their rally, with Brent breaking the $40 mark for the first time in three months, driven by hopes for an extension of output cuts and improving demand.

images.alt_text: Growing optimism about the global economic recovery pushed Asian markets higher for a third day on Wednesday as investors took heart from a further easing of lockdowns and looked past China-US tensions and civil unrest across America.

site_title: China takes first steps towards launching US$3 trillion Reit market
summary: China has launched a trial of real estate investment trusts (Reits), initially focusing on infrastructure projects like highways and airports. The pilot program aims to provide exposure to the Chinese real estate market for individual investors, with Goldman Sachs estimating the market could reach $3 trillion in value. Retail investors can buy up to 16% of Reit securities, with cornerstone retail investors required to hold at least 20% of their investment for five years. The program aims to alleviate debt strain on local governments and promote economic growth.

site_title: Opec+ edges closer to compromise to extend deepest ever cuts
summary: Opec+ is close to a compromise to extend record-breaking production cuts, with Russia and several nations favoring a one-month extension. Saudi Arabia, however, is still undecided, but the proposal falls within its desired range of one to three months. The cuts, aimed at propelling the oil market, have led to a rally in oil prices, now above $40 a barrel, but still below what most Opec+ members need to cover government spending. The cartel must balance the recovery of fuel demand with the risk of a second wave of infections.

site_title: Digital bank applicants to update MAS on Covid-19's business impact from June
summary: Singapore's Monetary Authority of Singapore (MAS) is inviting digital bank applicants to update on the impact of the COVID-19 pandemic on their businesses. The 21 applicants must demonstrate a sustainable path to profitability and financial strength. The assessment process has been postponed to the second half of the year due to the pandemic. Seven applicants are vying for full bank licenses, while 14 are seeking wholesale bank licenses. MAS emphasizes financial strength and a consistent loss-making trend as key criteria for qualification. The delay in awarding licenses may impact expansion strategies for digital banks.

images.alt_text: The 21 digital bank applicants in Singapore will update the Monetary Authority of Singapore (MAS) from this month on how their business and finances have been impacted by the global pandemic, The Business Times (BT) understands.

site_title: Natural gas may be the next major commodity to trade below zero
summary: Natural gas prices may drop below zero in Europe due to oversupply and low demand, with European gas storage nearing capacity. The lack of a coordinated response from producers and buyers, unlike the oil market, is contributing to the crisis. European markets, particularly the UK's National Balancing Point, are at risk of experiencing negative prices, which could have ripple effects globally. Analysts expect the situation to worsen in August or early September, with some predicting that storage facilities may hit capacity, leading to sub-zero prices.

site_title: Malaysia: Shares open higher on Wednesday
summary: Malaysia's shares opened higher on Wednesday, with the FTSE Bursa Malaysia Kuala Lumpur Composite Index rising 9.79 points, or 0.65%, to 1,517.48. The market saw 406.23 million lots traded worth RM160.61 million, with gainers beating losers 327 to 84.

site_title: China's services sector bounces back into growth, job losses continue: Caixin PMI
summary: China's services sector bounced back into growth in April, driven by a sharp rise in domestic new business, with the Caixin/Markit services PMI rising to 55.0 from 44.4. However, employment and overseas demand remained weak, with employment continuing to contract at a slower pace. The economy shrank 6.8% in the first quarter, and analysts believe it will take months for broader activity to return to pre-crisis levels.

site_title: Gold eases as equity rally boosts risk appetite
summary: Gold prices dropped 0.2% to $1,722.93 per ounce, following a global equity rally fueled by economic optimism and hopes for further stimulus measures. Asian markets are expected to follow the rally, with traders anticipating potential additional stimulus from the European Central Bank. The US dollar fell 0.2% to a two-month low, making gold cheaper for holders of other currencies.

site_title: Twitter signals Trump tweets will stay, even if they break rules
summary: Twitter has defended its decision to label and restrict some of US President Donald Trump's tweets, even if they break the company's rules. The social media platform stated it prioritizes tweets with "highest potential for harm" and provides context to help users make their own judgments. Despite criticism from Trump and other conservative politicians, Twitter has refused to drop Trump from its service entirely, arguing that world leaders' comments should be allowed, even if they violate rules. The company claims it should not determine the truthfulness of tweets but rather provide context.

images.alt_text: Twitter defended its recent decision to label some of US President Donald Trump's tweets, but also said world leaders' comments on the social media service will stay up, even if they break the company's rules.

site_title: Broker's take: RHB upgrades Starhill Global Reit to 'buy' on attractive valuation among peers
summary: RHB Research upgraded Starhill Global Reit to 'buy' from 'neutral', citing its attractive valuation among peers. The Reit's price-to-book ratio of 0.6 is lower than its peer average of 1 and sector average of 1.1, offering room for rebound. The analyst raised no target price, instead lowering it to 63 cents from 76 cents. Starhill Global Reit's units rose 2.8% to 55 cents, trading at a 1.5 cent premium to the new target price.

site_title: Ayala leads A$777m bid for Australia's Infigen Energy
summary: Ayala Corp, backed by the Philippines, has submitted a takeover offer of A$777 million (S$753.4 million) for Australian wind-farm operator Infigen Energy, valuing the company at a 36% premium to its closing price. The bid, made by UAC Energy Holdings Pty, is subject to approval by Australia's Foreign Investment Review Board. Infigen has one of the largest fleets of wind assets in Australia and has surged 37% in shares following the announcement. The takeover would provide UAC with access to capital and renewable energy expertise.

site_title: Stocks to watch: SIA, ST Engineering, SIA Engineering, China Everbright, Valuetronics
summary: Singapore Airlines shares closed at S$4.11 after its rights issue of shares was fully subscribed. ST Engineering and SIA Engineering will receive millions in additional wage support due to the enhanced Jobs Support Scheme. China Everbright Water plans to issue a first tranche of 1.2 billion yuan notes, while Valuetronics posted a 10.3% drop in net profit. CSE Global posted a net profit of S$7.1 million, and Sim Leisure Group's CFO resigned due to a "mismatch of expectations".

site_title: Canadian telcos tap Ericsson, Nokia for 5G gear, ditching Huawei
summary: Canadian telecom companies Bell Canada and Telus Corp have partnered with Ericsson and Nokia to build 5G networks, ditching Huawei due to security concerns. The move follows a Canadian court's setback to Huawei chief financial officer Meng Wanzhou's extradition case. This decision eases the government's review of Huawei's 5G equipment, with analysts saying it will help stimulate innovation and discipline pricing. The partnerships will provide equipment certainty and multiple suppliers, a strategy to safeguard network security.

site_title: Australian central bank may use powers to lower e-payment costs
summary: The Reserve Bank of Australia may use its powers to reduce the cost of electronic payments, as the COVID-19 pandemic increases cash usage and leads to higher costs for merchants. Assistant Governor Michele Bullock said ATM withdrawals declined 30% in April compared to March, and the bank is reviewing retail payments regulation to improve transparency and lower costs. If market forces fail to generate competition, the bank may lower benchmarks for interchange fees, which could benefit consumers and merchants. This move is also seen as a response to the urgent need to consolidate ATM networks due to reduced cash usage.

site_title: Zoom earnings soar as video meets become pandemic norm
summary: Zoom reported a 169% revenue increase to $328 million in the first quarter of 2020, with a profit of $27 million. The company's paying customers grew 354% to 265,400, driven by the pandemic's shift to remote work and socializing. Zoom's shares rose nearly 2% and 3% in after-market trades. The company faces scrutiny over security and privacy concerns, but recently launched a philanthropic foundation and agreed to improve security measures after a New York investigation.

site_title: Negative rate benefits seen limited for Singapore's stock market
summary: Singapore's stock market has seen limited benefits from a decline in interest rates, with the nation's overnight borrowing rate reaching near-zero and one-month swap-offer rate turning negative. Despite this, the economy is expected to contract 4-7% this year due to the pandemic, and the negative implications for the economy and financial system outweigh the appeal of sub-zero rates. The Monetary Authority of Singapore has promised to provide sufficient financial liquidity, but the government has deployed stimulus of S$92.9 billion so far.

site_title: Facebook invests in Gojek in WhatsApp push
summary: Facebook invests in Gojek, Indonesia's ride-hailing and food delivery giant, as part of its effort to expand into emerging markets and partner with WhatsApp. The 10% stake investment aims to build a commerce business around WhatsApp and create a payments feature. Gojek, valued at $10 billion, will deploy fresh capital to expand despite global economic turbulence. This investment follows Facebook's recent $5.7 billion investment in India's Reliance Jio, and aims to bring more people into digital Indonesia through WhatsApp.

site_title: Dubai malls, businesses to 'fully operate' from June 3
summary: Dubai's shopping malls and businesses will fully reopen on June 3, marking the emirate's easing of nearly all coronavirus restrictions. The move comes after the emirate shortened its nighttime curfew to 7 hours and allowed private sector businesses to operate at 50% capacity. Preventative measures, including face masks and social distancing, will remain in place. This is the first Middle Eastern city to drop nearly all restrictions, with Dubai's diversified economy relying on trade, retail, tourism, and real estate.

site_title: US, South Korea agree of funding of Korean workers, Pentagon says
summary: The US and South Korea have agreed that South Korea will fund approximately $200 million to support 4,000 Korean workers who were put on unpaid leave earlier this year. The funding will cover the workers through the end of 2020. However, a broader cost-sharing agreement between the two countries remains unresolved, leading to the initial furloughs. This agreement marks a step forward in resolving the issue, but the two nations still need to finalize their cost-sharing arrangement.

site_title: Sim Leisure says CFO resigned due to 'mismatch of expectations'
summary: Sim Leisure Group announced the resignation of its CFO, Seah Kheng Hong, 45, due to a "mismatch of expectations" regarding his daily roles and responsibilities. Seah submitted his resignation to pursue other career opportunities, with the change occurring less than half a year after his appointment on Dec 16, 2019. The company cited this as the reason for his departure, with no other reasons provided.

site_title: China Everbright Water proposes 1.2b yuan first tranche notes issue
summary: China Everbright Water plans to issue a 1.2 billion yuan (S$236.5 million) first tranche of notes in China on or around June 8, with a 5-year maturity period. The notes have been rated AAA by the Shanghai Brilliance Credit Rating & Investors Service and will be issued to institutional investors in the interbank bond market. The company's registration was accepted by the Chinese interbank market regulator in April, and the notes' fixed coupon rate will be determined through a centralized book-building process.

site_title: Singapore shares rise at open tracking Wall Street gains; STI up 1.4%
summary: Singapore's Straits Times Index (STI) rose 1.4% to 2,649.32 on Wednesday, tracking overnight gains on Wall Street. The gains were driven by investor optimism over stimulus measures and economic reopening. Banking stocks, including DBS, UOB, and OCBC, rose in early morning trade. The most active counters by volume were Rex International and ComfortDelGro Corporation. In the US, stocks continued to climb, with the Dow Jones Industrial Average rising 1.1% and the S&P 500 rising 0.8%.

site_title: Japan's service sector activity shrinks for 4th month in May: PMI
summary: Japan's services sector activity contracted for the fourth consecutive month in May, with the au Jibun Bank Japan Services Purchasing Managers' Index (PMI) rising to 26.5 from a record low 21.5 in April. The contraction was driven by store closures and cancelled events due to the coronavirus outbreak, with more than half of surveyed companies reporting lower activity levels. The employment indicator also shrank at its fastest pace since July 2011, suggesting firms were reducing staffing levels. The government is expected to submit a new stimulus package to offset the pandemic's impact.

site_title: UK mulls 'air bridges' with low-risk countries
summary: Britain is exploring "air bridges" with low-risk countries to exempt them from the country's quarantine measures, which were initially set to apply to all international arrivals from June 8. The Transport Secretary, Grant Shapps, confirmed that these agreements could involve removing self-isolation requirements and safely opening up routes to countries with low transmission rates. The plan aims to limit the spread of Covid-19 and has been welcomed by some businesses and airlines, while others have expressed concerns about the blanket approach.

site_title: Tokyo: Stocks open higher on US rallies, cheaper yen
summary: Tokyo stocks rose on Wednesday as investors took heart from a strong US market and a cheaper yen. The Nikkei 225 index climbed 1.38% to 22,634.11, while the Topix index rose 1.12% to 1,605.42. The rally was fueled by US stock gains, despite ongoing tariff uncertainty.

site_title: Most Americans sympathise with protests, disapprove of Trump's response: Reuters/Ipsos
summary: A majority of Americans sympathize with nationwide protests over the death of an unarmed black man in police custody, with 64% expressing sympathy and 27% not. The protests have deepened the country's crisis, with 55% disapproving of President Trump's response, including 40% strongly disapproving. A separate poll found Joe Biden's lead over Trump expanded to 10 percentage points, with 47% of registered voters planning to support Biden in the November election.

images.alt_text: A majority of Americans sympathise with nationwide protests over the death of an unarmed black man in police custody and disapprove of President Donald Trump's response to the unrest, according to a Reuters/Ipsos poll released on Tuesday.

site_title: Israel says 'successfully' tested ballistic missiles
summary: Israel successfully tested two ballistic missiles, the Long-Range Artillery Weapon Systems (LORA), in the Mediterranean, amid tensions with Iran and its ally Hezbollah. The test involved launching the missiles to 90km and 400km distances. The Israel Aerospace Industries (IAI) stated that the trial was held in the open sea, without revealing further details. The test is seen as a demonstration of Israel's military capabilities and a response to regional threats.

site_title: Google faces US$5b lawsuit in US for tracking 'private' Internet use
summary: Google faces a proposed class action lawsuit in the US for allegedly invading the privacy of millions of users by tracking their Internet use in "private" mode, despite claims by the company that it does not collect data in this mode. The lawsuit seeks at least $5 billion in damages. Google gathers data through various applications and website plug-ins, including smartphone apps, regardless of whether users click on Google-supported ads.

site_title: Activists rip Facebook's Zuckerberg over Trump comments
summary: Civil rights activists have criticized Facebook CEO Mark Zuckerberg for allowing incendiary comments by President Donald Trump on the platform, despite Twitter's efforts to flag or reduce visibility of similar comments. The comments were made after a discussion between Zuckerberg and leaders of rights organizations, who expressed disappointment and concern over Facebook's hands-off policy. The criticism follows protests from Facebook employees and calls for labeling or removing Trump's comments, which warned against voter suppression and violence. Zuckerberg's response, stating that Facebook should enable as much expression as possible, has been met with skepticism.

site_title: Oil up more than 3% ahead of Opec+ meeting and on easing lockdowns
summary: Oil prices rose by more than 3% on Tuesday ahead of an Opec+ meeting and as lockdowns ease. Brent crude settled at $39.57 a barrel, while US West Texas Intermediate crude rose to $36.81 a barrel. Producers are expected to extend output cuts for two months, and the reopening of economies is anticipated to increase demand. Oil inventories fell to 531 million barrels, boosting prices. The Opec+ meeting is expected to take place on Thursday.

images.alt_text: Oil prices climbed by more than US$1 a barrel on Tuesday on hopes that major crude producers will agree to extend output cuts during a video conference expected to be held this week and as countries and US states begin to reopen after coronavirus lockdowns.

site_title: Greece suspends Qatar flights till mid-June after 12 test positive
summary: Greece suspended flights to and from Qatar until mid-June after 12 individuals on a plane from Doha tested positive for the new coronavirus. The plane, carrying 91 people, landed in Athens on Monday. Those who tested positive will be in quarantine for 14 days, while those who tested negative will remain in quarantine for seven days. The civil protection ministry implemented the suspension to prevent further spread of the virus.

site_title: CAD, MAS and Acra launch joint probe into Hyflux and its directors
summary: The Commercial Affairs Department, Monetary Authority of Singapore, and Accounting and Corporate Regulatory Authority launched a joint probe into Hyflux and its directors, Olivia Lum, for suspected false and misleading statements and breaches of disclosure rules. The investigation began last year after a review found reason to suspect offences had been committed over several years. Former and current directors, including Lum, are assisting in the investigation. The probe aims to determine if Hyflux made false statements and failed to disclose material information, potentially harming investors.

site_title: South Korea announces 35.3t won third stimulus budget to fight virus misery
summary: South Korea has announced a 35.3 trillion won (S$40.2 billion) supplementary budget to fight the economic impact of the coronavirus pandemic, bringing the total stimulus to 270 trillion won. The budget aims to support jobs, vaccine development, and consumption, with a focus on small- to medium-sized businesses. The government expects the debt-to-GDP level to rise to 43.5% from 40%, but prioritizes fiscal policies to counter the economic crisis, which has reduced growth forecasts to 0.1% for this year.

site_title: Former President Bush, contrasting Trump approach, says protesters should be heard
summary: Former President George W. Bush criticized President Trump's handling of protests over George Floyd's death, calling it a "shocking failure" on racism and urging protesters to be heard. In contrast, Trump tweeted that authorities used "overwhelming force" to disperse protesters. Bush said it's essential to listen to those hurting and grieving, and to confront America's tragic failures. He also highlighted the need to end systemic racism in society, citing a long series of similar tragedies. Bush's comments reflect a stark contrast with Trump's approach.

site_title: Sweden extradites Chinese 'multi-million-dollar money launderer' to US
summary: Sweden has extradited Qiao Jianjun, a Chinese national suspected of laundering millions of dollars, to the US after a year of rejection of Beijing's extradition request. Qiao, a former Chinese state grain official, is wanted for embezzling 200 million yuan (S$40.6 million) in Henan Province. He was extradited last Friday after a federal grand jury in 2014 first indicted him on charges of money laundering and immigration fraud. Qiao contests the accusations, but his lawyer says the US will now try him for these crimes.

site_title: US: Stocks close higher again despite widespread protests
summary: US stocks closed higher on Tuesday, defying widespread protests, with the Dow Jones Industrial Average gaining 1.1% to 25,742.65. The S&P 500 rose 0.8% to 3,080.82, while the Nasdaq Composite Index climbed 0.6% to 9,608.37. Despite night-time curfews in cities like New York and Washington, investors focused on stimulus measures and economic reopening. Companies like Dicks Sporting Goods and firearms manufacturers saw gains, driven by strong demand for their products amid the coronavirus crisis.

site_title: Valuetronics FY2020 net profit falls 10.3% to HK$178.9m on lower revenue
summary: Valuetronics Holdings reported a 10.3% drop in net profit to HK$178.9 million for FY2020 due to lower revenue from its industrial and commercial electronics segments, as well as a decline in consumer electronics revenue. Revenue fell 16.8% to HK$2.35 billion. The company attributed the decline to a slowdown in demand from customers and the COVID-19 pandemic, which affected production in China and Europe. A final cash dividend of 14 Hong Kong cents per share was recommended for FY2020, in line with the company's formal dividend policy.

site_title: Police stun Americans - by taking a knee with protesters
summary: US police officers are embracing an anti-racism gesture by taking a knee alongside protesters, a move that has surprised and moved Americans. This gesture, popularized by former NFL quarterback Colin Kaepernick, has been adopted by police officers nationwide, including those in New York, Los Angeles, and Washington. The move is seen as a show of solidarity with demonstrators protesting police brutality against blacks and other minorities, and has been met with praise from politicians and protesters alike.

site_title: The heart of finance: Social bonds as a way to improve the world
summary: A new type of financing, social bonds, has the potential to improve the lives of the world's poorest people. In India, a young man struggles to start his own business due to lack of capital from traditional banks. Social bonds, which allow individuals to invest small amounts, could provide an alternative source of funding. This innovative financing model could help entrepreneurs in underserved communities, promoting economic growth and development.

site_title: Carrie Lam accuses US of double standards over riots
summary: Hong Kong's Chief Executive Carrie Lam criticized the US for "double standards" in handling protests, citing the Trump administration's support for sometimes-violent demonstrations in Hong Kong compared to its reaction to similar unrest in the US. Lam said the US is concerned about national security but holds different standards for Hong Kong. The US has passed legislation backing Hong Kong's pro-democracy camp, but President Trump has vowed to revoke special trading privileges and impose sanctions. Lam said there is "no justification" for US sanctions on Hong Kong, warning they would harm US interests.

site_title: France savours return of cafes and restaurants
summary: France reopened its cafes and restaurants on June 2, 2020, marking the country's latest step out of coronavirus lockdown. Customers were required to wear face masks and maintain social distancing, with outdoor seating allowed in some regions. The reopening comes as daily COVID-19 deaths in France have fallen steadily, but contagion risks remain high in the Paris region. The government credits its strict lockdown with saving thousands of lives, but is eager to restart an economy devastated by the measures, with Finance Minister Bruno Le Maire warning of an 11% economic contraction this year.

site_title: XA Network partners Vertex, invests in fund
summary: XA Network, an angel investment circle comprising tech executives, has partnered with Vertex Ventures and invested in the latter's record-breaking $305 million South-east Asia and India fund. XA will provide deep-tech expertise and networks in return, marking its first investment in a venture capital fund. The partnership allows XA to diversify its investments and gain insights from an experienced investor, expanding its portfolio to over 20 startups valued at under $5 million.

site_title: UK PM prepared to change immigration rules if China imposes national security law on Hong Kong
summary: UK Prime Minister Boris Johnson stated that the UK is prepared to change its immigration rules if China imposes a national security law on Hong Kong. This move aims to protect Hong Kong's autonomy and way of life. Johnson's comments were made in an op-ed for the South China Morning Post, emphasizing the UK's commitment to Hong Kong's future.

site_title: Saudi group tipped as buyer of ex-Chevron House retail, banking units
summary: A Saudi group linked to Olayan Group has expressed interest in buying the retail podium and office floors at 30 Raffles Place in Singapore for S$315 million. The entity, which has a diverse portfolio of sectors, is considering the purchase of the Chevron House property. This move comes as the Olayan Group continues to expand its global presence in various industries.

site_title: US scrambles to stem revolt as Trump faces anger for violent crackdown
summary: The US is struggling to contain widespread protests over police racism, with President Donald Trump facing criticism for a violent crackdown on peaceful demonstrations. Cities including New York, Minnesota, and Los Angeles have implemented curfews and police reforms in response to the unrest, which began after the killing of George Floyd. Trump accused protesters of being "scum" and vowed to use "overwhelming force" to restore order, but his words were met with condemnation from leaders, including Joe Biden and German Foreign Minister Heiko Maas. The protests have sparked calls for systemic change and an end to racial discrimination.

site_title: No external talks to sell HK, China businesses, says Bank of East Asia
summary: Bank of East Asia Ltd has stated that it has had no external discussions to sell its Hong Kong or China banking businesses. This comes after a Financial Times report suggested the bank was in talks with financial and strategic investors about the potential sale. The bank had previously agreed to review its businesses, pausing four-year-old legal proceedings. The review was initiated in March amid changes in the lender's leadership and activist investor demands. The bank's statement clarifies its position on the sale of its businesses.

site_title: Non-resident deposits in Singapore jump 44% to record S$62b in April
summary: Singapore saw a record jump in non-resident deposits to S$62.14 billion in April, a 44% increase, as investors sought safe havens amid global market volatility. Foreign currency deposits surged almost four times to a record S$26.97 billion, while Singdollar-denominated deposits rose 10% to S$716.6 billion. Analysts attribute the growth to Singapore's economic stability and safe haven status, as well as uncertainty in the region, including the Hong Kong unrest and trade tensions. The trend is expected to continue, with geopolitics and economic conditions driving investor sentiment.

site_title: US says will investigate nations with digital services tax
summary: The US has announced investigations into digital services taxes imposed by nations including Britain, the European Union, Indonesia, Turkey, and India. The move follows a similar probe into France's digital services tax, with the US claiming these taxes unfairly target American tech firms like Google, Apple, and Facebook. The US Trade Representative office is prepared to take action to defend US businesses and workers, amid a broader trade dispute with China. The investigations aim to determine whether the taxes comply with US trade laws.

site_title: ComfortDelGro cabbies to deliver medicine in new tie-up
summary: ComfortDelGro Taxi has partnered with ALPS, the supply chain arm of Singapore's public healthcare system, to deliver essential medicines to patients with pre-existing conditions. The service, ComfortDelivery, allows cabbies to deliver medicines to patients' doorsteps, increasing the medicine delivery capacity of public healthcare institutions. Fees will be charged to PHIs, with all proceeds credited to cabbies' bank accounts. The tie-up aims to provide cabbies with more delivery job options and increase patient access to medication during the post-"circuit-breaker" period.

images.alt_text: The service will allow ComfortDelGro to provide its cabbies with more delivery job options during the post-"circuit-breaker" period.

site_title: Money FM podcast: A plant-based meat diet benefits the environment
summary: Claressa Monteiro's podcast on Money FM 89.3 features David Yeung, founder of Green Monday and OMNIMeats, discussing the benefits of a plant-based meat diet for the environment. Yeung emphasizes the positive impact on greenhouse gas emissions, water usage, and land use. He cites studies showing that plant-based diets can reduce an individual's carbon footprint by up to 50%. Yeung also highlights the growth of the plant-based meat industry and its potential to drive positive environmental change.

site_title: Ardian raises US$19b for private equity secondaries platform
summary: Ardian, a private investment firm, has raised US$19 billion in commitments for its eighth-generation private equity secondaries platform, the world's largest. The funds will be invested in a fund of funds, creating liquidity for investors. Asian investors, including those from Singapore, South Korea, China, and Japan, accounted for 20% of the funds, with institutions making up 88%. The platform attracted 275 investors from nearly 40 countries, highlighting the maturity of the secondaries market, which is becoming an important source of liquidity for investors amid the Covid-19 pandemic.

site_title: Singapore shares soar on optimism over reopening of economies
summary: Singapore shares surged 2.4% to 2,611.63, driven by optimism over the reopening of economies. The Straits Times Index (STI) rose 60.77 points. Top performers SIA and SATS gained 5.9% each. Overnight rallies on Wall Street and Europe also contributed to the gains. A total of 2 billion shares worth S$2.03 billion changed hands, with gains outnumbering losses 321 to 136.

site_title: US dollar loses safe-haven shine; euro hits 11-week high
summary: The euro reached an 11-week high against the US dollar, trading at US$1.1178, as investors maintain hopes for a global economic recovery. Despite US-China tensions and mass protests, the euro's gain was attributed to central banks' efforts to buy government bonds to protect their economies. The US dollar fell to a three-month low, while the safe-haven Japanese yen also declined. Analysts expect the euro/US dollar to rise further, with some predicting a US dollar weakness of 10% in narrow trade-weighted terms.

site_title: Europe: German stocks rise as cyclicals jump
summary: European stocks rose 1.6% to their highest level since early March, driven by cyclical sectors such as autos, insurers, and real estate. German shares, particularly Volkswagen, Daimler, and BMW, gained between 5.2% and 7.7% on hopes of a stimulus package boosting car sales. The Stoxx 600 index has climbed nearly 34% from its March trough, despite rising US-China trade tensions and civil unrest.

site_title: Plunging cost of wind, solar marks turning point in energy transition
summary: The cost of wind and solar energy has plummeted, making them cheaper to build than running existing coal plants, according to a report by the International Renewable Energy Agency. This shift marks a turning point in the global transition to low-carbon energy, which could aid governments in embracing green economic recoveries from the pandemic. The attractive prices of renewables relative to fossil fuels could also help mitigate climate change.

images.alt_text: Data suggests that the average cost of building new solar photovoltaic and onshore wind power now costs less than keeping coal plants running.

site_title: To beat ABSD, 38 Jervois developer launches fire sale to clear units
summary: 38 Jervois developer, Prominent Land, is conducting a fire sale of its 16 remaining freehold units in the 27-unit boutique condo. Prices have been slashed by up to 24% due to the Additional Buyer's Stamp Duty (ABSD) of 15%, which must be paid by the developer even if only one unit is left unsold. Discounts range from S$275,900 to S$547,320, making the units more attractive, with the lowest transacted price for a 915 sq ft unit in the Tanglin area in the last 2 years. The promotion ends on June 14 with expressions of interest collected during the two-week period.

site_title: Joe Biden to strike careful balance amid escalating racial tensions
summary: US presidential candidate Joe Biden must strike a delicate balance between validating anger over police mistreatment of minorities and condemning violence in response to the ongoing protests over George Floyd's death. Biden aims to advance his campaign's core argument of being an empathetic leader who can bring calm to polarized America. He faces pressure to offer a more forceful policy response to attract activist voters, but must also reassure moderate voters who want order restored to their neighborhoods.

site_title: Sony, Google, Airbnb postpone events due to US protests
summary: US protests against police brutality have led to the postponement of several high-profile corporate events. Sony has postponed its PS5 game console news conference, Electronic Arts scrapped its Madden NFL 21 game introduction, and Google has delayed the introduction of Android 11. Airbnb also postponed CEO Brian Chesky's video message. Demonstrations have turned violent in cities nationwide, with curfews set to deter late-night protests and looting. The events' postponements reflect a somber tone in the country, with companies choosing to stand back and allow more important voices to be heard amidst the unrest.

site_title: SICCI sets up Covid-19 task force to provide crisis support for SMEs
summary: The Singapore Indian Chamber of Commerce and Industry (SICCI) has established a Covid-19 Task Force to provide crisis support for small and medium-sized enterprises (SMEs). The task force aims to help SMEs navigate relief schemes, obtain financial aid, and digitalize. SICCI is also promoting digitalization and internationalization, offering webinars and partnerships with government agencies and Indian organizations to provide funding options. The chamber's efforts focus on helping SMEs survive the pandemic and build resilience for future growth.

site_title: Valuation is in the eye of the beholder
summary: Global equity markets have rebounded strongly despite poor economic data, prompting calls for a downward turn. However, equity valuations are stretched, but not necessarily expensive. The 12-month forward price-to-earnings (P/E) ratio is near historical averages, and excess earnings yield suggests equities are neither cheap nor expensive. A strong economic recovery is expected, driven by fiscal and monetary stimulus, and a potential vaccine for the coronavirus. Earnings growth is key, and forward earnings have reached a baseline, with potential positive surprises supporting further price appreciation.

site_title: Social distancing a tough task when fiery EPL resumes
summary: The English Premier League (EPL) resumes on June 17 after a lockdown, with social distancing measures in place. Despite efforts to minimize close contact, players will face challenges in adhering to the rules, especially during intense matches. The league will be played behind closed doors, with fans watching via television, and some clubs plan to recreate the atmosphere with audience simulation and sound effects. The resumption of the EPL comes at a crucial time, with teams battling for qualification and the title.

site_title: Aerospace firms get some reprieve but the fight's not over yet
summary: Aerospace firms in Singapore have received some relief from the enhanced Jobs Support Scheme (JSS), which provides 25-75% wage support for affected industries. Under the S$33 billion Fortitude package, companies in the aerospace sector, such as maintenance and repair operators, manufacturers, and parts suppliers, will receive higher tiers of wage support. This is expected to benefit companies like ST Engineering and SIA Engineering Company, with estimated additional wage support of S$56 million and S$93 million, respectively. However, the industry's recovery is expected to be long and challenging, with the International Air Transport Association predicting a return to pre-crisis levels in three to four years.

site_title: ANZ to sell NZ asset finance unit to Shinsei Bank for NZ$762m
summary: ANZ Banking Group has agreed to sell its New Zealand-based asset finance unit, UDC Finance, to Shinsei Bank Ltd for NZ$762 million, strengthening ANZ's balance sheet position amid the coronavirus pandemic. The sale provides about A$439 million of capital and releases NZ$2 billion of funding, while Shinsei Bank aims to preserve UDC's operations and grow customer lending in New Zealand. The deal marks Shinsei's biggest overseas acquisition and is part of its efforts to tap offshore markets for growth.

site_title: Why the EU must deliver on its vision for post-pandemic reconstruction
summary: The European Commission has proposed a 750 billion-euro stimulus plan to aid post-pandemic recovery. Commission President Ursula von der Leyen emphasized that this is Europe's moment for recovery, stating it must either go it alone or work together. The pandemic has exacerbated EU vulnerabilities, including the euro zone crisis, migration, and Euro skepticism, intensifying divisions between northern and southern states, particularly between Spain and Italy, and the "Frugal Four" countries. The proposed plan aims to address the economic fallout, with forecasts of a 15% contraction of GDP in the single-currency area.

site_title: Iron ore rise cements Singapore's global status
summary: Singapore has solidified its position as the world's leading hub for iron ore trading, with major mining companies and trading arms of Chinese steelmakers based in the country. The city hosts the iconic Singapore Iron Ore Week conference and has two liquid futures markets for iron ore, with volumes 1.2 and 20 times physical seaborne market volumes. The iron ore market's unique characteristics, including concentrated supply and demand in China, have driven prices to a psychologically important level of US$100 per tonne, despite global commodity trends. This has cemented Singapore's reputation as "the home of international iron ore derivatives".

site_title: Corporate digest
summary: IHH Healthcare's chief financial officer Low Soon Teck is quitting the company, effective August 12. The resignation comes after about four years on the job. No reason was given for his departure.

site_title: UN agency issues health guidelines for airlines
summary: The International Civil Aviation Organization (ICAO) has issued health guidelines for the airline industry, including mask-wearing, temperature checks, and aircraft disinfection. The guidelines, developed by an international task force, aim to minimize the risk of COVID-19 transmission on flights. The recommendations are part of the UN agency's efforts to relaunch air travel amid the pandemic.

site_title: Citi's Covid-19 relief efforts to aid marginalised, migrant workers
summary: Citi has announced three initiatives as part of its 15th Global Community Day, providing Covid-19 relief efforts to marginalized and migrant workers in Singapore. The Citi Foundation will support the YMCA of Singapore with a $150,000 grant to help nearly 900 people. Additionally, the bank aims to aid migrant workers through its partnership with Heritage hotel 21 Carpenter.

site_title: Formalising mediation in Covid-19
summary: The Singapore International Mediation Centre (SIMC) has implemented a virtual mediation protocol for cross-border commercial disputes amid the Covid-19 crisis. However, the Singapore government is urged to promote mediation for domestic disputes and provide a formal mediation process for commercial disputes exceeding a certain threshold amount. The government is also advised to make settlement agreements enforceable in the Singapore courts to provide greater certainty in the mediation process. Singapore has led the way globally with the United Nations' Singapore Convention on Mediation, presenting an opportunity for domestic adoption during the crisis.

site_title: Who has the world's largest economy?
summary: China's total real income surpasses the US for the first time, according to the World Bank's International Comparison Programme (ICP). China's total real income is slightly larger than the US at $19.617 trillion, but its per capita income remains in the middle of the pack globally. The US economy is still ahead when measured by national GDP at actual exchange rates. The ICP's PPP measure is more suitable for comparing standards of living, but not for assessing geopolitical power, which should be based on GDP at current exchange rates.

site_title: No new cases of Covid-19 in Wuhan after city-wide test
summary: Wuhan, China, has reported no new cases of Covid-19 after conducting a city-wide test of nearly 11 million people and identifying 300 asymptomatic carriers. The testing campaign, launched on May 14, aimed to alleviate concerns of a second wave of infections. This marks a significant milestone in Wuhan's recovery from the novel coronavirus outbreak, which began in the city.

site_title: Axington tops offer price in intra-day trade
summary: Axington's shares rose to 21.5 Singapore cents, above Dorr Global Healthcare International's offer price of 20.8 cents, in intra-day trade on June 2, 2020. This represents a 43.45% premium to Axington's last traded price. Dorr plans to acquire 107.2 million shares, valuing Axington at S$33.3 million, and intends to maintain the company's listing status.

images.alt_text: Dorr is owned by entrepreneurs Terence Loh (left) and Nelson Loh (right) , who are cousins and former investment bankers.

site_title: Australia central bank leaves interest rates unchanged
summary: The Reserve Bank of Australia (RBA) left interest rates unchanged at 0.25% and yield targets, citing an abatement of the health crisis that allows the economy to begin reopening. Governor Philip Lowe noted that the depth of the downturn may be less than expected, and the economy is receiving substantial support from fiscal and monetary policy. Despite improved data, the unemployment rate is expected to rise further, and the government and RBA must maintain a positive narrative to avoid sentiment slipping.

site_title: Three key phases of major credit cycle: Map of what's to come
summary: A major credit cycle, potentially worse than the 2008 Global Financial Crisis, is unfolding due to the COVID-19 pandemic's unprecedented disruption to society and markets. The cycle will have three phases: a "processing period" of maximum uncertainty and chaos, followed by a phase of deep value opportunities, and finally, an aftermath with a long tail of opportunities in non-performing loans and special situations lending. Monetary and fiscal stimulus have been critical in keeping markets functioning, but a large default cycle is expected, with huge impairments to credit previously considered safe.

site_title: 4 new Covid-19 cases in community, 3 new clusters identified at dorms
summary: Singapore reported 544 new Covid-19 cases, bringing the total to 35,836, with 99% linked to known clusters. Four new community cases were confirmed, including an 80-year-old woman who was a family member of a previously confirmed case. Three new clusters were identified at dormitories. The number of new community cases has decreased to four per day, while 709 patients were discharged, bringing the total number of recovered patients to 23,166.

site_title: UK leads in coronavirus global response, despite Brexit introspection
summary: The UK, under Prime Minister Boris Johnson, is set to host a major international vaccine conference aimed at raising at least $7.5 billion for global pandemic response. Despite Brexit introspection, the UK has been a leader in the international response to the coronavirus pandemic, with recent actions including debt payment suspensions by the G-20 and the International Monetary Fund. The conference comes as the UN warned of "unimaginable devastation" and the potential for a second wave of the pandemic if countries do not work together.

site_title: United Hampshire US Reit collected 77% of base rents from retail tenants in May
summary: United Hampshire US Reit collected 77% of base rents from retail tenants in May, up from 82% in April, as local governments relaxed lockdown guidelines. About half of retail tenants closed in April have reopened, with some providing limited service. The Reit has seen an acceleration in store reopenings and is in talks with tenants on potential lease extensions. The Reit's aggregate leverage remains at 36.4%, with an interest coverage ratio of 6.2 times.

site_title: Great Eastern offering 1,000 jobs, places for interns and trainees
summary: Great Eastern Holdings is offering up to 1,000 job vacancies, including internships and traineeships, to support job seekers and graduates amid the economic uncertainty caused by Covid-19. The company will launch The Lifeproof Academy programme, providing financial planning and mentorship support. Additionally, it will offer over 200 traineeship positions and more than 100 internship placements. The company's goal is to kick-start the careers of those interested in financial planning and insurance, contributing to the wider economy.

images.alt_text: Great Eastern Holdings is offering vacancies, traineeships and internships to give job seekers, graduates and students opportunities amid the economic and employment uncertainty brought about by Covid-19, it said on Tuesday.

site_title: Startup-builder Antler expands to India
summary: Global startup-builder Antler is expanding to India, starting in Bangalore, led by partner Rajiv Srivatsa. The inaugural India program will run over six months in two phases, focusing on building teams and investing in up to 40 companies within its first year. Antler has a presence in 11 locations worldwide and has invested in over 160 startups. The expansion aims to tap into India's entrepreneurial ecosystem, which offers exceptional talent, high-quality venture capital, and ambitious founders.

site_title: Opera returns to Vienna with hotel 'window concert'
summary: A Vienna hotel transformed its guest bedrooms and courtyard into an outdoor concert hall for a one-night-only opera performance during the city's coronavirus lockdown. The event, held on June 2, 2020, provided a rare moment of joy in the city of music. The hotel, normally deserted, was repurposed to create a unique opera experience. This temporary event was a rare instance of the city's cultural scene coming alive during the pandemic.

site_title: China central bank unveils 400b yuan plan to help small businesses
summary: China's central bank unveiled a 400 billion yuan plan to purchase loans made to small businesses, boosting lending to the real economy. The interest-free reverse repurchase plan aims to develop into a form of quantitative easing (QE). The plan will buy 40% of unsecured loans to small and medium-sized firms with six-month maturities, made between March and December 2020. This move is seen as a response to economic challenges and aims to support the real economy.

site_title: Biden lashes into Trump for fanning 'the flames of hate'
summary: US President Joe Biden criticized President Donald Trump for fueling racial tensions and hatred, likening his language to that of 1960s Southern racists. Biden addressed a backdrop of American flags, stating the country is "crying out for leadership" amid civil unrest. He emphasized the need for healing racial wounds and vowed not to fan the flames of hate, contrasting himself with Trump's divisive rhetoric. Biden's remarks come as his team seeks to highlight the differences between him and Trump on character, empathy, and steadiness.

site_title: SIA rights shares fully subscribed; Temasek to mop up bulk of MCBs
summary: Singapore Airlines' (SIA) rights issue of shares has been fully subscribed, with 2.13 billion rights shares accepted, exceeding 120% of the available 1.78 billion shares. Controlling shareholder Temasek Holdings took up its full pro-rata entitlement of 986 million rights shares. However, the rights issue of mandatory convertible bonds (MCBs) was under-subscribed, with 59.6% of the available S$3.5 billion in principal amount subscribed, and Temasek taking up 40.4% of the unsubscribed amount. The newly issued shares and MCBs will be listed on the Singapore Exchange on June 8 and 9, respectively.

site_title: Architects and engineers suggest possible new ideas for future dormitories
summary: Architects and engineers in Singapore suggest improvements to dormitory designs, including lower bed densities, more space per resident, and better integration with the community to address social stigma. They propose ideas such as tiered beds for social distancing, adaptable spaces, and natural ventilation. The government has announced new standards for Quick Build Dormitories, but experts believe more can be done to address long-term needs. The cost of implementing these changes is still uncertain, with the government studying possibilities for ownership and operations.

site_title: Trump threatens to use troops to crush unrest
summary: US President Donald Trump threatened to deploy the military to end "riots and lawlessness" across the country, following days of violent protests over police brutality. Trump announced plans to send thousands of heavily armed military personnel to Washington D.C. and invoked the Insurrection Act, which could face legal challenges. Democratic lawmakers are alarmed by the move, calling it a threat to Americans exercising their constitutional rights. The president's actions come amid a surge in protests and unrest across the US, with some lawmakers and critics accusing Trump of inflaming tensions and undermining his claim to be an ally of peaceful protesters.

site_title: EU embarks on overhaul of big tech rules
summary: The European Union has begun a process to overhaul its decades-old rules governing big tech companies, including Facebook and Google. The Digital Services Act aims to impose stricter oversight on how these platforms handle disinformation, personal data, and business expansion. The EU is seeking public and government feedback until September 8, with a draft law expected in December. The legislation will face scrutiny from tech giants and EU member states, who are pushing for tougher measures on hate speech and free speech concerns.

site_title: Malaysia: Shares close higher on Tuesday
summary: Malaysia's FTSE Bursa Malaysia Kuala Lumpur Composite Index rose 17.55 points to 1,507.69 on Tuesday, driven by a higher volume of 9.625 billion lots worth RM6.207 billion. Gainers outnumbered losers 596 to 428.

site_title: Latest Trump tantrum targets Big Tech
summary: US President Donald Trump has signed an executive order targeting Big Tech companies, including Twitter, Facebook, and Google, in an attempt to punish them for perceived anti-Republican bias. The move, which changes a federal law, allows the government to probe allegations of political bias and could potentially hold companies liable for posts deemed false or defamatory. However, the order has been criticized for its potential to infringe on free speech and could backfire by alienating Trump's base, which relies heavily on social media. The move is unlikely to win over new voters, who have grown dependent on these platforms during the pandemic.

site_title: Nexon shares hit record high after strong start for Nintendo karting rival
summary: Nexon shares reached a record high after the strong start of its mobile karting game KartRider Rush+, which was downloaded over 10 million times in its first two weeks. The game's success contrasts with Nintendo's Mario Kart Tour, which initially lacked a multi-player option. Nexon's shares rose 1.6% and extended this year's gain to 63%. The company's revenue jumped 80% in Korea, driven by consumers staying home due to the coronavirus outbreak, but fell in China due to PC cafe shutdowns.

site_title: Thailand approves US$9b airport project by Bangkok's skytrain operator
summary: Thailand's Cabinet has approved a US$9 billion airport project in Pattaya, led by Bangkok's BTS Group Holdings, to develop the Eastern Economic Corridor's (EEC) U Tapao airport. The project, valued at 290 billion baht, includes a new terminal, air cargo centre, and aviation repair site. The EEC aims to transform the airport into a tourist hub and economic hub, despite criticisms of a lack of transparency. The project is part of a larger stimulus package to boost Thailand's economy, which has been affected by the coronavirus pandemic.

site_title: Rawabi Vallianz Offshore Services to acquire PT Vallianz Offshore Maritim's debts
summary: Rawabi Vallianz Offshore Services (RVOS) has agreed to acquire approximately US$30 million in debts owed by PT Vallianz Offshore Maritim (PTVOM) to Caterpillar Financial Services Asia and Caterpillar Financial Australia. This debt restructuring deal will be completed with a consideration of not more than 50% of the outstanding amount. The acquisition will release Vallianz from corporate guarantees, allowing the company to deploy its five vessels in the Middle East and North African regions with greater flexibility.

site_title: StanChart appoints Marc van de Walle as global head of wealth management
summary: Standard Chartered appointed Marc van de Walle as global head of wealth management, effective July 6, 2020. Van de Walle, formerly senior managing director and global head of products at Bank of Singapore, will oversee wealth management from Singapore. Current global head of private banking and wealth management, Didier von Daeniken, will focus on private banking from July 6. Van de Walle brings years of experience in banking, including leading global products for Bank of Singapore and OCBC.

site_title: Australia: Shares gain as RBA plays up recovery prospects
summary: Australian shares rose 0.3% on Tuesday, closing at 5,835.10, as the RBA reiterated a less damaging economic impact from the coronavirus crisis, fueling hopes of a speedy recovery. The benchmark has surged 30% since its March low, on a five-week winning streak, driven by Australia's ability to contain the outbreak. Despite lingering US-China relations concerns, the market remains optimistic, with a five-week winning run continuing.

site_title: CSE Global net profit rises 23.1% in Q1
summary: CSE Global, a process control and communications network system integrator, reported a 23.1% increase in net profit to S$7.1 million in the first quarter, driven by higher takings from the Americas and Asia-Pacific regions. Revenue rose 56% to S$131.8 million, while order intake surged 46.6% to S$127.2 million. The company finished the quarter with a robust order book of S$302.7 million, and lowered its net debt position to S$32.7 million. Despite a strong first quarter, the company expects to be negatively impacted by market uncertainties.

site_title: Singapore wealth fund GIC in talks to buy StorageMart stake
summary: Singaporean sovereign-wealth fund GIC Pte is in talks to acquire a stake in StorageMart, the largest privately owned storage company in the world, valued at over US$2.5 billion. StorageMart has about 225 locations globally and has added 549 climate-controlled storage units in its latest facility. The deal, if finalized, would be GIC's latest move in the US property market, following joint ventures with RPT Realty and Tricon Capital Group. Rosewood Investment may also participate in the deal, but representatives for the parties involved have declined to comment.

site_title: WeWork regional MD leaves; firm names new Pacific MD
summary: WeWork has named real-estate veteran Samit Chopra as its new managing director for the Pacific region, replacing Turochas 'T' Fuad who left the company to pursue other interests. Fuad, who oversaw South-east Asia and Korea, will be replaced by Chopra, who will oversee Singapore, Indonesia, Malaysia, the Philippines, Thailand, Vietnam, Korea, and Australia. The move is part of WeWork's efforts to attempt a turnaround.

site_title: CAD, MAS and Acra open joint probe into Hyflux
summary: The Commercial Affairs Department (CAD), Monetary Authority of Singapore (MAS), and Accounting and Corporate Regulatory Authority (Acra) have launched a joint investigation into Hyflux and its directors over suspected false statements and breaches of disclosure requirements. The investigation follows a review of Hyflux's disclosure and compliance with accounting standards from 2011 to 2018. The review raised suspicions of offences committed, and the investigation aims to ascertain lapses in disclosures and non-compliance with accounting standards related to the Tuaspring Integrated Water and Power Project.

site_title: US: Stocks open higher, again shrugging off protests
summary: US stocks opened higher, shrugging off mass protests, as investors focused on stimulus measures and a reopening economy. The Dow Jones Industrial Average rose 0.6%, while the S&P 500 climbed 0.3%. The Nasdaq Composite Index remained flat. Despite economic headwinds and tariff uncertainty, stocks continued their rally, driven by optimism over stimulus and a recovering economy.

site_title: Saudi seeks to raise US$2.3b in Yemen donor conference
summary: Saudi Arabia is hosting a virtual donor conference to raise $2.3 billion in emergency funding for Yemen, amid a coronavirus pandemic and ongoing war. The funds will support humanitarian sectors such as medical, food, and shelter assistance. Britain has pledged $200 million, while UN officials warn of a "fiscal cliff" due to lack of funding, threatening to shut down key programs. The conference comes as Yemen faces its worst humanitarian crisis, with 5.5 million people at risk of losing access to food and clean water.

images.alt_text: Saudi Arabia seeks to raise US$2.3 billion from an emergency donor conference Tuesday to support war-battered Yemen as it faces a coronavirus catastrophe in the sixth year of the kingdom's military intervention.

site_title: Thailand to cut property tax by 90% this year amid coronavirous outbreak
summary: Thailand is cutting building tax by 90% this year to support businesses and individuals during the coronavirus pandemic, reducing revenue by approximately 36 billion baht (S$1.6 billion). The tax will be collected in August. The move comes as Southeast Asia's second-largest economy is expected to shrink by up to 6% this year, the sharpest decline since the 1997-98 Asian financial crisis.

site_title: Thailand approves 290b baht airport project adding new terminal
summary: Thailand's Cabinet approved a 290 billion baht airport project, adding a third passenger terminal at U-Tapao International Airport near Pattaya, as part of the Eastern Economic Corridor. The project, led by BTS Group Holdings, will develop air cargo and aviation maintenance centers. The contract is set to be signed on June 19, with Narita International Airport Corp managing the airport. Officials expect U-Tapao to handle 60 million passengers annually, with plans in place before the coronavirus outbreak.

site_title: Australia's Woolworths to reward over 100,000 staff with shares for virus efforts
summary: Australia's Woolworths Group will reward over 100,000 staff with free company shares for their efforts during the COVID-19 pandemic and bushfire season. The shares will be worth up to A$750 each for full-time employees, while part-time staff will receive a pro-rata share. Casual staff will receive cash bonuses or store discounts. The move comes after Woolworths faced criticism for underpaying workers and comes amid a surge in demand for grocery stores during the pandemic.

site_title: Daily Debrief: What Happened Today
summary: Key developments include: Great Eastern launching The Lifeproof Academy, offering 1,000 agent vacancies; SGX introducing 10 Singapore single stock futures on June 15; Singapore Airlines' rights issue fully subscribed; United Hampshire US Reit collecting 77% of base rents; StanChart appointing Marc van de Walle as global head of wealth management; ComfortDelGro cabbies to deliver medicine in new tie-up; Singapore shares rise 2.4% on optimism over reopening of economies.

site_title: Hong Kong: Shares extend rally
summary: Hong Kong shares rose 1.11% on Tuesday, building on the previous day's 3% surge, as lockdowns eased and China-US tensions receded. The Hang Seng Index climbed to 23,995.94, while the Shanghai and Shenzhen Composite Indexes also increased. This rally comes despite ongoing US trade uncertainty.

site_title: Singapore shares rise on optimism over reopening of economies
summary: Singapore shares rose 2.4% on Tuesday, with the Straits Times Index advancing to 2,611.63, as the city-state's circuit-breaker period ended and more businesses and activities were allowed. The gains tracked overnight rallies on Wall Street and Europe, with risk assets shrugging off political angst. Key performers included SATS, DBS, and ComfortDelGro, while Singapore Exchange and Singapore Press Holdings were the only two STI counters in the red.

site_title: US small business programme handed out virus aid to many borrowers twice
summary: A technical glitch in the US Small Business Administration's loan processing system has resulted in many small businesses receiving Paycheck Protection Programme (PPP) loans twice or more, amounting to potentially hundreds of millions of dollars. The error occurred when borrowers submitted multiple applications with different lenders, which the system failed to detect. At least 1,020 duplicate deposits have been issued, with estimated losses of around $116 million, according to industry sources and Reddit posts. The SBA and lenders are working to identify and recover the duplicate funds.

site_title: Sunniest Spring helps UK hit a new solar record
summary: The UK's sunniest spring on record boosted solar power to a new high of 33% of the country's electricity mix in May, according to Drax Electric Insight's quarterly report. This is a quarter increase over the same period last year and a record high. The abundance of solar generation has led to a record 53 days of coal-free electricity and has caused balancing problems for the network, resulting in negative power prices for several hours. The UK's grid is becoming more flexible, with a greater emphasis on balancing the grid and securing supplies through biomass, gas, and pumped storage power stations.

site_title: German divisions on show over new virus stimulus package
summary: German ministers are meeting to discuss a new economic stimulus package to aid the country's recovery from the coronavirus shutdown. The package's design is a point of contention, with Chancellor Angela Merkel's conservatives favoring tax cuts and business measures, while their junior coalition partners prefer one-off payouts to families and local governments. The proposed auto subsidies have added complexity, pitting regions and industrial sectors against one another in their pursuit of government support. A consensus on the package's details remains elusive.

site_title: SGX to launch 10 Singapore single stock futures on June 15
summary: The Singapore Exchange (SGX) will launch 10 Singapore Single Stock Futures (SSFs) on June 15, in response to growing demand for Singapore-linked equities products. The new contracts will be based on 10 underlying securities, including major banks and companies such as DBS, UOB, and Singtel. The move comes after SGX discontinued most of its MSCI equity index futures and options contracts, which will expire next year. The launch is seen as a next step in broadening SGX's coverage of Asia and deepening its derivatives offerings.

site_title: CSE Global net profit up 23.1% to S$7m in Q1
summary: CSE Global reported a 23.1% increase in net profit to S$7.1 million in Q1, driven by higher takings from the Americas and Asia-Pacific regions. Revenue rose 56% to S$131.8 million, supported by strong-flow revenues and new acquisitions. Order intake surged 46.6% to S$127.2 million, with a robust order book of S$302.7 million at the end of the quarter.

site_title: New Zealand may remove all virus restrictions next week
summary: New Zealand Prime Minister Jacinda Ardern announced that all remaining virus restrictions may be lifted next week, after the country eliminated the virus domestically. With no new cases recorded for 11 consecutive days, Ardern plans to move the country to alert level one, lifting social distancing measures and curbs on mass gatherings, but keeping borders closed. The decision will be made by the cabinet on June 8, ahead of the planned date of June 22.

site_title: South Korea to resume WTO complaint over Japan's export curbs after talks stall
summary: South Korea plans to resume World Trade Organization (WTO) proceedings against Japan over export curbs on high-tech materials, citing stalled talks. The curbs, imposed in response to a 2018 Supreme Court ruling, have led to a sense of crisis within Korea Inc, but imports have not been significantly disrupted. South Korea will continue dialogue with Japan while pursuing the WTO complaint, aiming to prove the illegality and unfairness of Japan's export controls and raise international awareness. Japan's top government spokesman described the decision as "extremely regrettable".

site_title: Japan's Hoshino aims to revive virus-hobbled hotels through new investment fund
summary: Hoshino Resorts, operator of luxury hotels, plans to revive virus-affected hotels through a new investment fund. The fund, valued at up to 20 billion yen (S$261 million), will target hotels seeking new ownership. Hoshino aims to replicate its success in the early 2000s by investing in hotels and traditional inns that have failed. The hotel industry has been hit hard by the pandemic, and the Tokyo 2020 Olympic Games' delay has exacerbated the issue. Hoshino believes the market is due for a correction, and the new fund will capitalize on this trend.

site_title: UK house prices fall by most since 2009 as Covid hits: Nationwide
summary: UK house prices fell by 1.7% in May, the largest monthly decline since 2009, due to the coronavirus crisis. Despite a slight annual increase of 1.8%, the market is highly uncertain, with Nationwide citing a decline in consumer confidence and a six-month wait for potential buyers to make a move. Economists predict a further decline in prices over the rest of the year, with some forecasting a 5% drop by the end of the third quarter.

site_title: Europe: Stocks advance at open
summary: Europe's main stock markets opened higher on Tuesday, driven by easing coronavirus lockdowns and a return to trading after a public holiday in Germany. The FTSE 100 rose 0.4%, the Paris CAC 40 increased 0.8%, and Frankfurt's DAX soared 2.5%. Investors are optimistic about a further loosening of coronavirus measures, which may help shattered economies rebuild.

images.alt_text: In initial deals, the British capital's benchmark FTSE 100 index of major blue-chop companies rose 0.4 per cent to 6,188.10 points.

site_title: UK mortgage approvals slumped to record low in April lockdown-BoE
summary: The UK saw a record low in mortgage approvals in April, with 18,848 approvals, down from 56,136 in March. This is the lowest figure since comparable records began in 1997. Consumer credit figures also showed the largest repayment on record, at £7.399 billion (S$13.03 billion). The decline is attributed to the coronavirus lockdown, where consumers ramped up loan repayments. The Bank of England data highlights the economic impact of the lockdown on the UK mortgage market.

site_title: New York under curfew as looters hit luxury stores
summary: New York City imposed a curfew due to widespread looting and vandalism targeting luxury stores, including Michael Kors and Nike, in central Manhattan. The curfew, initially set to last until 5:00 am, was extended to 8:00 pm on Tuesday. Police made hundreds of arrests and reported "numerous stores" had been hit. Mayor Bill de Blasio criticized President Donald Trump's response to the protests, calling his rhetoric "divisive." The city has seen similar incidents in other US cities, with around 40 cities imposing curfews in response to violent protests.

site_title: Australian PM accepts G-7 invitation during call with Trump
summary: Australian Prime Minister Scott Morrison accepted a Group of Seven (G-7) invitation during a call with US President Donald Trump on June 2, 2020. Trump postponed the G-7 summit, initially set for next month, and invited Australia, Russia, South Korea, and India to join. This move comes as relations between Canberra and Beijing remain strained due to Chinese meddling allegations and concerns over China's growing influence in the Pacific region. Morrison has avoided criticizing Trump publicly and has supported the US in its tougher stance against China.

site_title: Seoul: Shares hit 14-week high on global recovery hopes
summary: South Korean shares reached a 14-week high on Tuesday, closing 1.07% higher at 2,087.19, driven by global economic recovery hopes. Despite concerns over US-China tensions and US protests, the Kospi index rose, with foreigners selling $37.68 million worth of shares. South Korea's economy shrunk 1.3% in the January-March period, while inflation fell below zero for the first time since September 2019. The nation's finance ministry vowed to stabilize financial markets if US-China tensions escalate.

site_title: Indonesia inflation moderates further; rate cut this month on the cards
summary: Indonesia's headline inflation moderated for the third straight month in May, led by a decline in food inflation, with core inflation also edging down. This trend, combined with weak growth and downward pressure on the Indonesian Rupiah, suggests a rate cut by Bank Indonesia is likely this month, according to ANZ Research.

site_title: China buys US soybeans after halt to US purchases ordered: sources
summary: China purchased at least 180,000 tonnes of US soybeans, defying government orders to halt imports, amid rising trade tensions between the two countries. The purchases were made for shipment in October or November, during peak US soy export season. China's decision may threaten progress in meeting goals set in the Phase One trade deal, which China pledged to significantly boost purchases of US agricultural products. The US has directed its administration to eliminate special treatment for Hong Kong, prompting China to counter US attempts to harm Beijing's interests.
