images.alt_text: The purchases, totalling at least 180,000 tonnes of the oilseed, were for shipment in October or November, the peak US soy export season when American soybeans are usually the cheapest in the world.

site_title: Japan has no immediate plan to issue 'corona-bonds': Aso
summary: Japan's Finance Minister Taro Aso stated that the country has no immediate plan to issue "corona-bonds" to cover pandemic costs. Aso said Japan can sell existing bonds without significant disruption, making the idea of issuing corona-bonds not currently being considered.

site_title: Stitch Fix to cut jobs in California, invest in other US states
summary: Stitch Fix plans to cut up to 1,400 jobs in California, with most layoffs expected in September. The company will offer affected stylists the opportunity to relocate to new roles in lower-cost locations, including Dallas, Minneapolis, and Austin, Texas. The company will provide financial assistance, including severance payments, bonuses, and extended healthcare. This restructuring is part of the company's efforts to adapt to changing market conditions and invest in growth opportunities in other US states.

site_title: Singapore's record deposits seen signalling risk aversion
summary: Singapore's bank deposits surged to a record S$27 billion in April, with foreign-currency deposits almost quadrupling and non-resident deposits rising 44% to S$62 billion. Analysts attribute this to risk aversion and inflows from Hong Kong, which has been facing rising tensions. This trend may signal Singapore's status as a private banking hub remains intact despite potential threats to Hong Kong's financial centre status.

site_title: Tokyo: Stocks hit highest in more than 3 months on economic hopes
summary: Japanese stocks reached a three-month high on Tuesday, with the Nikkei index rising 1.19% to 22,325.61 points. The gains were driven by hopes for a global economic recovery and the reopening of countries after coronavirus-related lockdowns. Industrial and technology shares led the advance, with a boost from overnight US manufacturing data suggesting the worst of the sector's slump may be over.

site_title: Great Eastern offers 1,000 vacancies for agents, over 300 for trainees and interns
summary: Great Eastern Holdings is offering 1,000 agent vacancies, over 300 trainee and internship positions to support job seekers amid economic uncertainty. The company will launch The Lifeproof Academy, a financial planning program, to provide support and mentorship. This move aims to provide opportunities for individuals interested in a career in financial planning.

site_title: French economy will contract 11% in 2020, more hard days ahead: minister
summary: French Finance Minister Bruno Le Maire announced that the French economy is expected to contract 11% in 2020 due to the coronavirus crisis. The country's lockdown, which ended on May 11, led to a halt in economic growth for three months. Le Maire stated that more hard days are ahead until the economy recovers next year, and the government is taking measures to support the tourism, aerospace, and building sectors. The government is also seeking buyers for struggling clothing chains to prevent retail bankruptcies.

site_title: Japan allows saliva-based tests to boost coronavirus detection
summary: Japan's government has approved saliva-based tests for the new coronavirus, aiming to boost detection and simplify the diagnostic process. The tests can be given to those with symptoms for up to nine days and will reduce burdens on patients and medical workers. This move follows Japan's low testing capacity, with only 3.4 tests per 1,000 people as of May 20, compared to other industrialized nations. The approval is seen as a step to combat the ongoing pandemic, which has impacted Japan's economy and led to a decline in Prime Minister Shinzo Abe's popularity.

site_title: Virgin Australia administator picks Bain, Cyrus as final bidders
summary: Virgin Australia Holdings' administrator Deloitte has selected Bain Capital and Cyrus Capital Partners as the final bidders for the country's second-biggest airline. Five non-binding proposals were received, including BGH Capital, Indigo Partners, and Brookfield Asset Management. The selected bidders will now proceed with binding proposals to acquire the airline.

site_title: Qatar Petroleum's US$19b LNG vessel order boon for South Korean shipbuilders
summary: South Korea's ailing shipbuilders have received a US$19 billion order from Qatar Petroleum for liquefied natural gas (LNG) ships through 2027, the largest-ever single LNG vessel order. This deal has come at the right time for Daewoo Shipbuilding & Marine Engineering, Hyundai Heavy Industries Holdings, and Samsung Heavy Industries, which are facing a steep market downturn. The agreements signed on Monday will secure more than 100 ships for the three shipyards, providing a much-needed boost to the struggling industry.

site_title: France's cafes, restaurants reopen, but in Paris, only the terraces
summary: France has reopened its cafes and restaurants, with Parisian establishments limited to outdoor terraces due to the ongoing pandemic. The country has lifted its lockdown restrictions, allowing public gatherings of up to 10 people, and beaches have reopened. However, the Paris region and overseas territories remain in a higher-risk category, and the government has urged caution, citing the ongoing presence of the virus. The reopening is seen as a step towards normality, with Prime Minister Edouard Philippe aiming to restart the economy devastated by the lockdown measures.

site_title: Met Opera cancels fall season due to Covid-19
summary: The Metropolitan Opera cancelled its fall 2020 season due to the ongoing COVID-19 pandemic, citing health and safety concerns. The opera house, which had been dark since mid-March, plans to resume performances in December instead of September. Several new productions, including Verdi's "Aida" and Mozart's "The Magic Flute," have been postponed to future seasons, while a premiere of Jake Heggie's "Dead Man Walking" will still take place in April 2021. The health and safety of company members and audience are the top priority.

site_title: 80-year-old S'porean woman is among 4 Covid-19 cases in the community
summary: An 80-year-old Singaporean woman is among four new community cases of Covid-19 announced on June 2. The cases, including three work pass holders and a family member of a previously confirmed case, bring the total number of cases in Singapore to 35,836. The Health Ministry confirmed 544 new cases, with 540 linked to dormitories and no imported cases. The daily average of new community cases has decreased to four in the past week, and 709 more patients were discharged, with 331 confirmed cases still in hospital.

site_title: No 'external discussions' to sell Bank of East Asia's Hong Kong, China businesses
summary: Bank of East Asia Ltd (BEA) has denied having external discussions to sell its Hong Kong and China banking businesses, contradicting a Financial Times report. The bank, which has hired Goldman Sachs to review its businesses, has paused four-year-old legal proceedings brought by activist investor Elliott Management. BEA has a near 8% stake in the bank, which has urged the bank to explore putting itself up for sale. The bank's review is ongoing, with an updated deadline for shareholders set for September 30.

site_title: France's Carrefour expands in convenience stores in Taiwan
summary: France's Carrefour has agreed to buy food retailer Wellcome Taiwan from Asia's Dairy Farm for 97 million euros, becoming the number two player in Taiwan's convenience stores market. The transaction covers 224 stores, a warehouse, and is expected to close by the end of the year. Wellcome Taiwan posted net sales of around 390 million euros in 2019.

site_title: China says sticking to climate pledges despite coronavirus outbreak
summary: China will implement its climate change commitments despite the coronavirus outbreak, with a scheduled progress report on its nationally determined contributions (NDCs) under the Paris climate agreement to be submitted on time. The country aims to peak carbon dioxide emissions by around 2030. This decision comes as China's economy continues to face challenges, including a slowdown in GDP growth.

site_title: Hong Kong leader calls out 'double standards' on national security, points to US
summary: Hong Kong leader Carrie Lam criticized foreign governments for displaying "double standards" in their reaction to Beijing's proposed national security laws, citing US reactions to anti-police brutality protests. Lam warned countries threatening actions against Hong Kong may harm their own interests. The US has removed Hong Kong's preferential treatment in US law, while Beijing's plans for national security laws have sparked protests in Hong Kong. Lam's comments come amid a backdrop of US police brutality protests and curfews in cities nationwide.

site_title: Thai exports to shrink 8% this year, baht climb a concern, say shippers
summary: Thai exports are expected to contract 8% this year due to the coronavirus pandemic's impact on global trade. A recent rise in the baht adds pressure, with the currency trading at 31.55 baht per US dollar. The Thai National Shippers' Council will discuss the issue with the Bank of Thailand to address the strengthening currency. Exports rose 1.19% from a year earlier in January to April, but fell 5% year-on-year excluding gold, reflecting underlying weakness in global trade.

images.alt_text: Thailand's exports are still expected to contract 8 per cent this year as the coronavirus pandemic hits global trade, with a recent rise in the baht adding to the pressure, a Thai shipping association said on Tuesday.

site_title: KKR spends big and fast to avoid mistakes of 2008 crisis
summary: KKR & Co, a global private equity firm, has rapidly deployed $12.7 billion in capital since the COVID-19 pandemic began, making it the most-active private equity house globally. This aggressive strategy aims to avoid repeating its shortcomings during the 2008 financial crisis. By financing deals with equity and tapping into its varied pools of capital, KKR is diversifying away from leveraged buyouts and exploring new opportunities, including public market investments and infrastructure deals. The firm's efforts are seen as a response to the crisis, following a strategy practiced by renowned investors like Warren Buffett.

images.alt_text: When Covid-19 hit the world economy, KKR & Co's management jumped on calls and quickly agreed they'd seen this movie before.

site_title: United Hampshire US Reit collects 77% of base rents from retail tenants in May
summary: United Hampshire US Reit collected 77% of base rents from retail tenants in May, with 82% in April, driven by store reopenings as lockdown guidelines relaxed. Retail tenants comprised 87% of base rental income and about half of those previously closed have reopened. The Reit is also discussing potential lease extensions with tenants. Its leverage stands at 36.4% and interest coverage ratio is 6.2 times, with CEO Robert Schmitt expressing confidence in the Reit's ability to weather the Covid-19 crisis due to its suburban location.

site_title: Hong Kong leader says understands public concerns about security laws
summary: Hong Kong leader Carrie Lam acknowledged public concerns about Beijing's proposed national security legislation, stating that many accusations were unfounded. She urged mutual respect in the city's relationship with the US, following Washington's decision to remove Hong Kong's preferential treatment. The draft legislation has yet to be completed, but Lam's comments suggest an attempt to address public concerns and maintain a positive relationship with the US.

site_title: Sony, Google, Airbnb are postponing events due to US protests
summary: Major tech companies Sony, Google, and Airbnb are postponing events due to US protests over police brutality. Sony postponed a PS5 news conference, Electronic Arts canceled an event for Madden NFL 21, and Google delayed the introduction of Android 11. The protests, sparked by the killing of George Floyd, have turned violent and cast a somber tone in the country. Companies are choosing to stand back and allow more important voices to be heard, instead of celebrating major events.

site_title: In nod to #MeToo, China codifies sexual harassment by law
summary: China has codified sexual harassment by law in a move seen as a nod to the #MeToo movement. The new civil code, approved by parliament, defines actions that can constitute sexual harassment and holds schools, businesses, and organizations responsible for preventing and dealing with it. However, it lacks guidelines for enforcement, and victims are still awaiting redress. The development is a symbolic step, but some lawyers and activists say it offers a nationally recognized enumeration of sexual harassment as a legal offense, paving the way for further changes.

images.alt_text: The reference in the new civil code, approved on Thursday by a session of the National People's Congress, is largely a symbolic step. While it holds schools, businesses and other organisations responsible for preventing and dealing with sexual harassment, it does not lay out guidelines for enforcement.

site_title: Axington shares rise after Dorr's cash offer, briefly push past offer price
summary: Axington Inc's shares rose to 21.5 Singapore cents, surpassing Dorr Global Healthcare International's offer price of 20.8 cents, due to increased volume. The offer values Axington at S$33.3 million, representing a 43.45% premium. Trading activity was driven by married trades, with 110.2 million shares changing hands. The company had previously sold its core business in Malaysia and now operates primarily in Singapore, Laos, and Vietnam.

site_title: Hong Kong finds four virus cases linked to local cluster, RTHK says
summary: Hong Kong reported four new coronavirus cases linked to a local cluster, all residents of the same Sha Tin building as a couple earlier confirmed with the virus. The cases involve the couple's colleagues and a paramedic. Health officials have not evacuated the building, citing no direct contact with the infected individuals. The emergence of hidden local transmission chains is a setback to plans to ease social distancing measures, potentially delaying the reopening of schools and loosening border restrictions with mainland China.

site_title: Mixed fortunes for London shops hit by pandemic
summary: London shops experiencing mixed fortunes as a result of the pandemic lockdown, with some benefiting from customers seeking hard-to-find items and others struggling to stay afloat. The Grain bakery has expanded its offerings to feed the community, while the Chamomile cafe has shut due to safety concerns. The UK retail sales dived 18.1% in April, but most shops will soon reopen as Britain takes its biggest step out of lockdown.

site_title: VW closes US$2.6b investment in self-driving startup Argo AI
summary: Volkswagen has closed its $2.6 billion investment in self-driving startup Argo AI, a Pittsburgh-based company. The deal, announced last July, makes Argo jointly controlled by VW and Ford, which initially invested in the company. VW's agreement includes the transfer of its autonomous driving unit, boosting Argo's employment to over 1,000. The partnership is part of a multibillion-dollar alliance between VW and Ford, announced last year.

site_title: Data surprises mean Australia's economy might not have shrunk in Q1
summary: Australia's economy may not have shrunk in Q1, contrary to initial forecasts of a 0.3% contraction. A record current account surplus and strong government spending added to growth, while companies reported better sales and profits. The Reserve Bank of Australia is hopeful the slowdown won't be as dire as feared, with the central bank expected to keep interest rates at a record low of 0.25%. The data suggests a "small positive print" is possible, but a sharp shock to the labor market is still expected.

site_title: WeWork regional MD Turochas Fuad departs; firm names new Pacific MD
summary: WeWork has appointed real estate veteran Samit Chopra as its new managing director for the Pacific region, replacing Turochas "T" Fuad who departed the company to pursue other interests. Fuad, who scaled WeWork's presence in South-east Asia, will shift his attention to his "next entrepreneurial path". Chopra brings over two decades of experience in the real estate industry, and will oversee Singapore, Indonesia, Malaysia, the Philippines, Thailand, Vietnam, Korea, and Australia. The leadership change comes as WeWork attempts a turnaround following its botched listing attempt in 2019.

site_title: Midnight cowboy steak: French restaurant re-opens after lockdown
summary: A French steak restaurant, "Prison de Bouffay," reopened on June 2, 2020, after an 11-week lockdown due to the COVID-19 pandemic. The restaurant, co-owned by Jean-Pierre Le Bot, welcomed around 100 customers at midnight, marking the easing of lockdown restrictions in France. To ensure safety, staff wore masks, tables were arranged outdoors for better air circulation, and disinfecting measures were implemented. The restaurant's reopening was a welcome sight for customers, who had missed dining out for weeks.

site_title: Sapphire Corp to divest 43.9% stake in Ranken Railway for 280m yuan
summary: Sapphire Corp has agreed to sell a 43.87% stake in Ranken Railway for 280 million yuan (S$55.2 million) in cash to Shandong Hi-Speed Road & Bridge Investment Management. Upon completion, Sapphire will retain a 48.82% effective interest in Ranken, making it an indirect and partial state-owned enterprise in China. This move is expected to increase Ranken's competitiveness in securing contracts in the country and may allow it to secure lower interest rates on external borrowings.

site_title: Boustead Projects, YCH reach settlement over S$2.3m Supply Chain City lawsuit
summary: Boustead Projects and YCH Holdings have reached a settlement over a lawsuit filed in 2018, resolving a dispute over a breach of contractual obligations related to the Supply Chain City project. The settlement was reached without an admission of liability, and the court granted leave to discontinue the lawsuit on June 1. YCH had sought damages of S$2.335 million, while Boustead Projects did not disclose the settlement amount. The agreement allows both parties to move forward without further action.

site_title: Cheap oil is one culprit as American chicken exports diminish
summary: Cheap oil and weak currencies in Mexico and South America are contributing to a decline in American chicken exports. The US is shipping less chicken overseas, with Cuba, a major buyer, reselling oil at a profit and buying poultry instead. Weak consumer demand in China and oversupply in the post-Covid-19 economy are also affecting US meat exports. Prices for chicken legs have fallen to seasonal lows, with exports to Cuba down 35% from the same period in 2019. US shipments are expected to stay slow through June.

site_title: Asia: Markets extend gains on hopes virus crisis is easing
summary: Asian markets extended gains on Tuesday, driven by hopes that the COVID-19 crisis is easing and economies are recovering. The easing of lockdowns in Europe and China's decision not to impose strict sanctions on the US over its Hong Kong security law boosted investor confidence. Despite ongoing US-China tensions and growing unrest in the US, global stocks continued to rise, with the S&P 500 and Nasdaq reaching fresh records.

site_title: Malaysia: Shares open lower on Tuesday
summary: Malaysia's FTSE Bursa Malaysia Kuala Lumpur Composite Index opened lower on Tuesday, down 9.92 points, or 0.67%, to 1,480.22. The market saw a higher volume of 486.25 million lots worth RM240.13 million.

site_title: Some Japanese whiskies aren't from Japan. Some aren't even whiskey.
summary: Japanese whiskey expert Mamoru Tsuchiya warns of a crisis in the industry, citing a significant amount of "Japanese whiskey" not actually made in Japan. Some bottles are filled with imported Scotch or Canadian whiskey, deceiving consumers. This issue threatens the authenticity and quality of Japan's whiskey industry, raising concerns among experts.

site_title: Japan talking with South Korea about export controls
summary: Japan is in dialogue with South Korea regarding export controls on three materials used in semiconductor production, which Japan imposed last year. South Korea requested Japan clarify its stance by May, but Japan declined to comment. The curbs have threatened the South Korean economy and global chip supply chain. No details on potential outcomes or changes to the restrictions were provided by Japanese Trade Minister Hiroshi Kajiyama.

site_title: ComfortDelGro cabbies to deliver medicine in new tie-up
summary: ComfortDelGro Taxi has partnered with ALPS Pte Ltd to allow its cabbies to deliver essential medicines to patients with pre-existing conditions during the Covid-19 period. The service, ComfortDelivery, is available to public healthcare institutions and charges fees based on distance. The company aims to increase medicine delivery capacity and provide cabbies with more delivery job options. This tie-up follows the launch of ComfortDelivery in April, which has successfully onboarded 2,000 taxi drivers for delivery services.

images.alt_text: ComfortDelGro said the medicines will be delivered to patients with pre-existing conditions in need of regular refills during the Covid-19 period.

site_title: Toronto's underground city faces bleak future with bankers MIA
summary: Toronto's PATH, a 30km network of underground tunnels and subterranean plazas, faces a bleak future due to the COVID-19 pandemic. With banks planning to return to offices, the PATH's ability to accommodate workers is uncertain. Narrow halls, pedestrian congestion, and lack of fresh air pose significant challenges. The PATH's ecosystem, which connects major commuter stations, banks, and retail spots, is expected to suffer from bankruptcies among smaller businesses, with some chains remaining shut until people return in larger numbers. The future of the PATH depends on how quickly Bay Street firms return workers to their offices.

site_title: Stocks to watch: SGX, Singapore Airlines, IHH, Sapphire, Boustead Projects, USP
summary: Singapore stocks saw various developments on Tuesday, June 2, 2020. The Singapore Exchange (SGX) announced the launch of 10 Singapore Single Stock Futures on June 15. Singapore Airlines' directors decided not to exercise their mandatory convertible bond (MCB) rights, and registered holders of SIA's short-term DLCs will receive a goodwill payment. IHH Healthcare's CFO resigned, while Sapphire Corp agreed to sell a 43.87% stake in Ranken Railway for S$55.2 million. Boustead Projects resolved a lawsuit, and USP Group reduced its management personnel's remuneration amid the Covid-19 pandemic.

site_title: Traders pin hopes on RBI support after Moody's cuts India rating
summary: Moody's cut India's long-term foreign-currency credit rating to Baa3, citing policy challenges and a deteriorating fiscal position. This move brings India's rating on par with S&P Global Ratings and Fitch Ratings, both of which have a BBB- rating. Traders are seeking RBI support to stabilize the rupee and sovereign-bond markets, fearing foreign outflows and a knee-jerk selloff. The RBI is expected to intervene to curb volatility, with benchmark yields expected to climb by 15-20 basis points.

site_title: Hong Kong: Shares start Tuesday on front foot
summary: Hong Kong stocks opened 0.25% higher on Tuesday, following the previous day's rally, driven by easing lockdowns worldwide. The Hang Seng Index rose to 23,792.24, while China's Shanghai Composite Index remained flat. Global markets, including the US, also saw gains, with the S&P 500 and Nasdaq reaching fresh records despite US-EU trade uncertainty.

site_title: IHH Healthcare CFO quits; PSL Holdings CEO leaves early
summary: IHH Healthcare CFO Soon Teck Low has resigned, effective August 12, to pursue other interests. His direct interest in IHH remains 2.8 million options. Meanwhile, PSL Holdings CEO Lee Chee Tak has resigned early, on May 31, to attend to urgent personal affairs, following initial departure on July 31. No replacement for IHH's CFO position has been announced, and shares of both companies remain stable.

site_title: Trump says to send 'thousands' of troops, police to US capital's streets
summary: US President Donald Trump announced the deployment of thousands of heavily armed soldiers and police to Washington, D.C. to prevent further protests, following days of violent riots and vandalism near the White House. Trump denounced "acts of domestic terror" and vowed to hold protesters accountable, with a focus on organizers. The move comes amid nationwide protests against the death of George Floyd, an unarmed African American man killed by police in Minneapolis.

site_title: ANZ to sell NZ asset finance unit to Shinsei Bank for NZ$762m
summary: ANZ has agreed to sell its New Zealand-based asset finance unit to Shinsei Bank for NZ$762 million, providing A$439 million in capital. The sale marks ANZ's exit from the New Zealand market. Shinsei Bank acquired the unit, which includes NZ$1.5 billion in assets, as part of its expansion into the country's asset finance market. The deal is expected to close in the second half of 2025.

site_title: US records 743 coronavirus deaths in 24 hours
summary: The US reported 743 new coronavirus deaths in 24 hours, bringing the total to 105,099, with 1,809,109 cases, the worst in the world. Globally, at least 373,439 people have died from the virus since its emergence in China in late 2019. States in the US are relaxing confinement measures, but major cities have issued curfews amid violent protests over the death of George Floyd.

images.alt_text: The United States on Monday recorded 743 new coronavirus deaths in 24 hours, according to the Johns Hopkins University tracker, bringing its total to 105,099 since the global pandemic began.

site_title: XA Network partners Vertex, invests in fund
summary: XA Network, an angel investment circle of tech executives, has partnered with Vertex Ventures and invested in Vertex's fourth South-east Asia and India fund, valued at $305 million. The partnership allows XA to provide support to Vertex's portfolio companies through its expertise and networks, while gaining insights from an experienced investor. This marks XA's first investment in a venture capital fund and follows its recent investments in top-tier VC funds.

site_title: Facebook staffers walk out saying Trump's posts should be reined in
summary: Facebook employees staged a walkout, accusing CEO Mark Zuckerberg of failing to adequately police US President Donald Trump's posts, similar to Twitter's approach. The employees, including top managers, took to Twitter to express their concerns and demand action. The walkout, which included dozens of employees, resulted in a shift of Zuckerberg's weekly Q&A session to Tuesday and a statement from Facebook acknowledging the need for change. The protest also led to the end of partnership discussions with online therapy company Talkspace, with CEO Oren Frank stating he wouldn't support a platform that incites violence.

site_title: Tokyo: Stocks open higher despite protests, US-China tension
summary: Tokyo stocks opened higher on June 2, 2020, despite anti-racism protests in the US and simmering US-China tensions. The Nikkei 225 index rose 0.37% and the Topix index advanced 0.41%. The rally was driven by Wall Street gains, with the S&P 500 and Nasdaq reaching fresh records. The positive sentiment was attributed to investors' confidence in the US economy despite tariff uncertainty.

site_title: Distancing and masks cut Covid-19 risk, says largest review of evidence
summary: A large review of 172 studies in 16 countries found that keeping at least 1 meter apart, wearing face masks and eye protection, frequent handwashing, and good hygiene can significantly reduce the risk of Covid-19 infection. The review, published in The Lancet journal, suggests that a distance of 2 meters could be more effective in preventing transmission, and masks and protective eye coverings may add protective benefits. However, the evidence for these measures is not foolproof, and more research is needed to fully understand their effectiveness.

site_title: SGX to launch 10 Singapore single stock futures on June 15
summary: The Singapore Exchange (SGX) will launch 10 Singapore Single Stock Futures (SSFs) on June 15 in response to growing demand for Singapore-linked equities products. The new SSFs will be based on 10 underlying securities, including major banks and companies such as DBS, UOB, and Singtel. This launch comes after SGX discontinued most of its MSCI equity index futures and options contracts in February 2021, citing revenue loss. The move is seen as a step to broaden SGX's equities shelf and deepen coverage of Asia.

site_title: Starhill Global Reit to issue S$100m 3.15% notes due 2025
summary: Starhill Global Reit has successfully issued S$100 million of 5-year, 3.15% notes due 2025. The senior, unsecured notes were oversubscribed with S$225 million from 26 accounts, primarily from fund managers, banks, and insurers. The proceeds will be used to refinance existing borrowings, meet capital expenditure requirements, and cover working capital purposes. The transaction is not expected to impact the Reit's gearing.

site_title: Trump to deliver nationwide address after race protests: White House
summary: US President Donald Trump was set to deliver a nationwide address on June 1, 2020, following days of anti-racism protests against police brutality that turned violent. The White House announced the address amid Trump's criticism for not publicly addressing the crisis.

site_title: IMF backs revised Argentine debt offer, 'limited scope' for more
summary: Argentina's revised debt proposal to international creditors has received backing from the IMF, with the organization stating that the offer is "consistent with restoring debt sustainability with high probability." The proposal, which includes a 45-cent-on-the-dollar payment to creditors, has limited scope for further concessions, according to the IMF. The government has set a Tuesday deadline to finalize a restructuring deal, with creditors likely to accept a deal in the region of 50 cents on the dollar. Argentina's economy has been in recession for two years, with the country owing $324 billion.

site_title: George Floyd death was 'homicide' caused by 'neck compression': official autopsy
summary: An official autopsy of George Floyd found that his death was a homicide caused by "neck compression," ruling out other contributing factors. Floyd, 46, died from cardiopulmonary arrest due to law enforcement actions, despite pre-existing health conditions. The manner of death was determined by the Hennepin County Medical Examiner's office, which emphasized its neutrality and independence from law enforcement.

site_title: Singapore shares rise at Tuesday's open tracking Wall Street rally; STI up 0.7%
summary: Singapore's Straits Times Index (STI) rose 0.7% to 2,567.91 on Tuesday, tracking a Wall Street rally. The index saw gains in various sectors, including banking, logistics, and real estate, with ComfortDelGro, Mapletree Logistics Trust, and Singtel among the top gainers. The rally follows overnight gains on Wall Street, where the Dow Jones Industrial Average and S&P 500 rose 0.4% and 0.4% respectively, amid signs of recovery in Europe and Asia.

site_title: Oil steady; US-China tensions weigh, possible output cuts support
summary: Oil prices steadied on Monday, with Brent futures rising 1.3% to $38.32 a barrel and US crude falling 0.1% to $35.44 a barrel. Rising US-China tensions weighed on sentiment, but reports of Opec and Russia's potential deal to extend oil output cuts provided support. Algeria proposed a June 4 meeting to discuss the curbs, and Bank of America said North American oil shut-ins peaked in May. Economic concerns, including manufacturing data showing struggling factories, also weighed on oil futures.

site_title: US: Stocks end up despite protests, rising China tensions
summary: US stocks rose on Monday despite anti-racism protests and worsening US-China tensions, with the Dow Jones Industrial Average gaining 0.4%, the S&P 500 climbing 0.4%, and the Nasdaq Composite Index advancing 0.7%. Analysts say social violence doesn't typically impact markets, but protests may affect consumer confidence and COVID-19 spread. Markets have shrugged off rising US-China tensions, with signs of a trade detente between the two countries.

site_title: Trump puts G-7 summit proposal to Putin
summary: US President Donald Trump proposed including Russia in an expanded G-7 summit, which he had previously delayed, in a phone call with President Vladimir Putin. The proposed G-7 "with possible invitation of the leaders of Russia, Australia, India, and South Korea" could take place in September. Russia was expelled from the G-7 in 2014 after annexing Crimea. The conversation with Putin was described as "constructive, business-like and substantive." The proposal was met with a lack of further detail from the Kremlin.

site_title: USP key management takes 30% pay cut amid Covid-19
summary: USP Group, a Singapore-based company, has implemented a 30% pay cut for its key management personnel and 10-20% pay cuts for middle management and staff amid the Covid-19 pandemic. The measures, effective from June 1, aim to conserve financial resources and save nearly S$1 million in a year. Other cost-saving measures include a headcount freeze. The company remains committed to exploring new business growth and will provide updates to shareholders. USP has also applied for extensions to announce its full-year financial results and hold its annual general meeting due to the pandemic's uncertainty.

site_title: UN agency recommends health guidelines for airlines
summary: The International Civil Aviation Organization (ICAO) has published health guidelines for the airline industry, recommending measures to reduce the spread of COVID-19. The guidelines include mandatory mask-wearing, temperature controls, and disinfection of aircraft. Passengers are advised to present a health certificate, undergo temperature checks, and travel with minimal hand luggage. The guidelines also suggest limiting physical contact at airports and on planes, and assigning specific toilet stalls for passengers. While the measures are not obligatory, they aim to provide a global reference for aviation COVID-19 related measures and facilitate a safe and sustainable return of air travel.

site_title: Euro, Aussie gain on economic recovery hopes
summary: The euro briefly reached its strongest level since mid-March, while the Australian dollar surged 1.3% to a four-month high, as investors gained hope for economic recovery from the COVID-19 downturn. The euro rose 0.4% and the Aussie gained 20% from March lows, with the dollar falling to its weakest level since March 16. Analysts attribute the rally to improved economic data, including China's marginal factory activity improvement and the US decision not to impose new tariffs on China.

site_title: Infrastructure capability programme kicks off
summary: Singapore's Second Finance Minister Indranee Rajah launched an infrastructure capability development programme for regional government officials, aiming to increase business activity and employment amid economic forecasts triggered by the Covid-19 pandemic. The programme, developed by Infrastructure Asia and the World Bank Group, will train senior and mid-level officials in project preparation, focusing on clean energy and promoting sustainable infrastructure. The initiative seeks to harness Asia's collective expertise and spread the word about Singapore-based solutions to support infrastructure development.

site_title: Thais seek sun and surf as officials re-open some beaches
summary: Thailand has partially reopened some beaches, with authorities easing COVID-19 restrictions for the first time in over two months. Some beaches, such as Pattaya, welcomed visitors who kept a safe distance from each other, while others, like Phuket, remain closed. The move is seen as a step towards reviving the country's tourism industry, which has been severely impacted by the pandemic. Despite the easing of restrictions, concerns about hygiene standards and the potential for a surge in new cases remain.

site_title: Controlling directors make S$0.225 a share cash offer for Dynamic Colours
summary: Singaporean husband and wife duo Goh Seok Eng and Yeo Hock Leng made a voluntary conditional cash offer of S$0.225 per share for Dynamic Colours, valuing the company at S$47.2 million. The offer aims to delist the mainboard-listed resin compounding firm.

site_title: South Korea's GDP shrinks 1.3% in first quarter
summary: South Korea's economy contracted 1.3% in the first quarter, the largest decline since the 2008 global financial crisis. The contraction was slightly less than expected, attributed to the impact of the coronavirus outbreak on consumer demand and economic activity. Private consumption decreased 6.5% during the period, but the country's "trace, test and treat" program helped bring the epidemic under control. The Bank of Korea forecasts a 0.2% year-on-year contraction in 2020, down from a previous forecast of 2.1% growth.

images.alt_text: South Korea's economy contracted slightly less than expected in the first quarter, when the coronavirus outbreak hit consumer demand and economic activity, revised central bank data showed Tuesday.

site_title: Europe: Shares gain as recovery hopes boost cyclicals
summary: European shares rose 1.1% on Monday, reaching their highest level since March 9, as recovery hopes boosted cyclicals. Growth-sensitive sectors, such as travel & leisure, banks, and miners, jumped 2-3% in response to easing lockdown measures. The euro zone's Manufacturing PMI rose to 39.4 from 33.4, indicating a rebound in factory activity. Investors also took relief from US President Trump's decision to leave the Phase One trade deal intact, despite plans to end special treatment for Hong Kong.

site_title: China hits back at US over race protests after Trump criticised HK
summary: China has responded to US criticism over racial protests by accusing the US of "double standards" in dealing with protests at home and in Hong Kong. Chinese officials and state media have highlighted scenes of US violence, looting, and police responses, contrasting them with Hong Kong's situation. Foreign ministry spokeswoman Hua Chunying retweeted a US State Department spokeswoman, adding "I can't breathe" as a reference to George Floyd's death, and state broadcaster CCTV has described US hypocrisy in dealing with minority groups.

site_title: Emergency digital library sued over 'brazen' copyright violations
summary: The Internet Archive, a digital library, has been sued by four major publishing houses - Hachette Book Group, HarperCollins Publishers, John Wiley & Sons, and Penguin Random House - over its "national emergency library" offering 1.4 million digital books without restrictions. The lawsuit claims the library's move is "brazenly" violating copyright laws, despite its efforts to provide public service during the coronavirus pandemic.

site_title: Burned flags and curfews: US cities convulsed by unrest
summary: US cities continue to experience unrest following the death of George Floyd, with protests and clashes with police reported in over 140 towns and cities. Demonstrators faced curfews and police responses, with over 150 arrested in Minneapolis for breaking curfew. In Washington, protesters burned American flags, and in New York, hundreds were arrested, including the daughter of Mayor Bill de Blasio. The cities braced for another night of turmoil, with curfews renewed and National Guard troops deployed in Los Angeles. The unrest has sparked widespread condemnation and calls for calm.

site_title: In times of crisis, central banks need to educate and engage
summary: Central banks need to educate and engage the public, especially during times of crisis, to build trust and confidence. A Banque de France working paper found a correlation between economic uncertainty and a decline in citizens' opinion of and trust in central banks. To address this, central banks are adopting creative communication strategies, such as simplified language, social media, and educational initiatives. Examples include the Bank of England's "vision 2020" and the Reserve Bank of New Zealand's use of cartoons to explain monetary policy decisions. Effective communication can influence trust and reduce the cost of engagement in times of crisis.

site_title: Property firm Capco buys HK tycoon's stake in London rival Shaftesbury
summary: British property manager Capco has agreed to buy a 26.3% stake in London rival Shaftesbury from Hong Kong tycoon Samuel Tak Lee's for £436 million. The deal, valued at 540 pence per share, is a 13.9% discount to Shaftesbury's closing share price last Friday. The acquisition is expected to be completed in two tranches and will be funded through Capco's revolving credit facility. The deal is seen as a shrewd move by Liberum analysts, who consider it a capitalisation on an attractive valuation.

site_title: CIMB customers join forces to fight bank's mortgage rate hike
summary: A group of CIMB Bank Singapore customers, over 40 in number, have formed a collective to challenge the bank's decision to raise mortgage rates. They've created a website, HonestMortgages.sg, to raise awareness and rally other affected customers to contact CIMB to honour their mortgage offer letters.

site_title: Money FM podcast: The do's and don'ts of circuit breaker easing measures
summary: A Money FM podcast discusses circuit breaker easing measures in Singapore, featuring senior partner Justin Chan of Tito Isaac and Co. Chan breaks down the do's and don'ts for Phase 1 and 2, including visiting in-laws and travel restrictions. The podcast aims to provide guidance for individuals navigating the easing measures, which are part of Singapore's COVID-19 recovery efforts.

site_title: Google rejects call for huge Australian media payout
summary: Google has rejected demands for a huge Australian media payout, with its top executive stating that the company earns only A$10 million per year from news-linked advertising, a fraction of the government watchdog's estimated A$6 billion. Google's managing director for Australia, Mel Silva, disputed the watchdog's estimates, citing that news content accounts for only 1% of Google Search actions in Australia, and that the company provides substantial value to news media by driving traffic to their websites. The rejection bodes ill for negotiations between Google, Facebook, and Australian media companies over a mandatory revenue-sharing deal.

site_title: The US should revamp its own democracy, stop preaching to others
summary: The US should revamp its democracy, as its own treatment of black citizens and its handling of the COVID-19 pandemic have sparked widespread unrest. The country is experiencing a "cold civil war" fueled by President Trump's divisive rhetoric, with cities like Minneapolis and New York City descending into chaos. Amidst the chaos, the US should focus on strengthening its democratic foundations, rather than lecturing other countries on their human rights records. The nation's leaders should prioritize fixing its own democratic system before attempting to export its model to others.

site_title: Expenses incurred from working at home qualify for tax deductions
summary: Singapore's Inland Revenue Authority (Iras) allows workers to claim tax deductions for expenses incurred while working from home, such as electricity and telecommunication bills. Expenses must be incurred while carrying out official duties, not reimbursed by the employer, and not capital or private in nature. Taxpayers can claim a deduction for the difference in bills before and after working from home, and must keep records for five years. The taxman also allows an equal apportionment basis among household members if multiple people work from home.

site_title: Reit perp holders risk drops in coupon rate if issuers reset
summary: Reit issuers of perpetual bonds, such as Ascott Residence Trust, are at risk of a 1-1.8 percentage point drop in coupon rates if they choose to skip their first call, a decision made by Ascott after deciding not to redeem existing perpetual bonds and instead resetting their coupon rates. Analysts expect more Reits to follow this approach to conserve cash amid the Covid-19 fallout, with DBS Group Research estimating a potential drop in coupon rates to 2.9-3.2%. This move is seen as a positive for unitholders, preserving gearing capacity and achieving interest savings.

images.alt_text: As analysts expect more Reit issuers of perpetual bonds to follow in Ascott Residence Trust's (ART) footsteps, DBS Group Research on Monday flagged that perpetual holders could face a risk of a 1 to 1.8 percentage point drop in coupon rates if the issuers choose to skip their first calls.

site_title: China's solar giants slash prices as virus curbs demand
summary: China's solar manufacturers are slashing prices due to the COVID-19 pandemic's impact on demand, with costs for components like wafers and cells falling by up to 20% since the start of the year. This could lead to consolidation among smaller players and benefit larger manufacturers like LONGi Green Energy Technology Co and Tongwei Co. Despite the challenges, cheaper prices could spur demand for solar energy when the global economy recovers. New global solar capacity is forecast to be 19% less than pre-pandemic levels.

site_title: Giving up MSCI licensing may hurt but SGX has more strings to its bow
summary: Singapore Exchange (SGX) has decided to let its agreement to carry MSCI equity index futures and options lapse in February 2021, sparking concerns that the move could steer capital towards Hong Kong Exchange and Clearing (HKEx). However, SGX believes the impact will be minimal, estimating a 10-15% reduction in FY21 net profit, and points to its growing multi-asset and borderless strategy, as well as partnerships with other index providers and the acquisition of Scientific Beta, to offset the loss.

site_title: Australia house prices fall in May as shutdowns hit property market
summary: Australian home prices fell 0.5% in May, marking the first decline since June 2019, as the impact of the coronavirus shutdown continues to affect the economy. Melbourne and Perth experienced the largest drops, with prices falling 0.9% and 0.6%, respectively. Despite relatively mild declines, experts warn that the hit to the housing market may be more severe when government assistance packages are scaled back later this year.

site_title: US foes delight in criticising US as protests flare
summary: US cities are experiencing some of their worst riots in 50 years, with dozens of cities under curfews following the killing of George Floyd, an unarmed African-American man. Nations that usually criticize the US on human rights, such as China and Iran, are now criticizing the US record on race, with Chinese officials saying racism in the US is a "chronic disease" and Iranian officials calling for police to "let people breathe." US officials, including President Trump, have responded by criticizing China and Iran for their own human rights records, with some observers suggesting they are diverting attention from their own issues.

site_title: Changing hands
summary: Helen Wong is retiring as OCBC CEO, with Tan Teck Long named as her successor. Sats CEO Kerry Mok received a 30.5% pay hike to S$3.1 million. China's GDP growth is expected to slow, putting pressure on policymakers. Tesla launched in India with a Mumbai event, while Citigroup aims for a mid-2026 MSCI global equity index target of 1,150. Analysts are positive on SGX earnings, raising target prices. Chinese banks face challenges from Beijing's consumer lending push, and Japan's MUFG plans to boost its US securitisation business.

site_title: 60,000 new bed spaces for migrant workers by end-2020
summary: Singapore plans to provide 60,000 new bed spaces for migrant workers by end-2020, with another 60,000 spaces to be added within two years. The new dorms will have reduced density and improved resilience against pandemics. The government aims to house up to 100,000 workers with the new purpose-built dorms. The move comes as the country lifts its circuit breaker measures, with 40,000 migrant workers cleared to return to work. The government has also introduced new access codes and face mask policies to ensure safe resumption of work.

site_title: First Reit units tumble 21.5% after Lippo says it cannot sustain rental support
summary: First Reit (FREIT) units fell 21.5% after Lippo Karawaci (LPKR), its former parent company, announced plans to restructure its leases, making rental support to FREIT "unsustainable" due to the Covid-19 pandemic. LPKR cited a decline in patient volumes and revenues at hospitals leased to FREIT, resulting in significant rental support. FREIT's manager stated it would consider any reasonable proposal from LPKR, but emphasized the need for a mutually agreeable and beneficial agreement.

site_title: OCBC, StanChart to cut savings rates
summary: Standard Chartered and OCBC have announced rate cuts on several savings accounts, effective July 1. Standard Chartered will halve interest payouts on its Jumpstart savings account and Bonus$aver account, while OCBC will reduce interest rates on its 360 savings account. OCBC's 360 account will also stop offering a credit card spend bonus interest. The rate cuts are attributed to the weakening interest rate environment and challenging macro climate.

site_title: Oil prices unchanged ahead of upcoming Opec+ meeting
summary: Oil prices remained unchanged on Monday at US$37.84 a barrel, ahead of an Opec+ meeting to discuss extending record production cuts beyond end-June. The Organization of the Petroleum Exporting Countries is considering the move as global demand remains uncertain. Brent crude prices were unchanged, marking the first day of trading in the August contract. The meeting's outcome will impact the global oil market and influence prices in the coming weeks.

site_title: India's bid for tighter grip on rupee trading is put to test
summary: India is testing its bid to tighten control over the rupee trading market as 12 local lenders, including State Bank of India, began trading in the Non Deliverable Forward (NDF) market offshore. The Reserve Bank of India (RBI) allowed banks to trade in the NDF market in March, aiming to curb volatility and strengthen its regulatory grip. Indian banks expect a cautious start, but may offer competitive pricing using onshore and offshore access, with ICICI Bank starting trading in dollar/rupee contracts in the Singapore market.

site_title: Home's Favourite: from 3 recipes to winning pastries
summary: Home's Favourite, a Singapore bakery, started with three recipes and $30,000 in 1997. Managing director Jason Lee, then 26, pursued his dream of sharing his mother's baked goods. Despite lacking baking experience, Lee developed new products through trial and error, including the signature 100% pure durian snowskin mooncake. The company has since expanded, operating a 2,600 sq ft central kitchen and retail points across Singapore. Lee credits innovation, R&D, and continuous skill development as key to the company's success, and plans to focus on co-branded partnerships and export business in the next few years.

site_title: Conceptual artist Christo who famously wrapped landmarks dies at 84
summary: Conceptual artist Christo, known for wrapping landmarks like the Pont Neuf in Paris and the Reichstag in Berlin, died at 84. Born Christo Vladimirov Javacheff, he used his art to bring people together, requiring cooperation from dozens of landowners, officials, and residents. His works, including the famous Gates project in Central Park, were often decades in the making and considered temporary. Christo's wife, Jeanne-Claude, who collaborated on many projects, died in 2009.

site_title: A manufacturing renaissance can lift Singapore
summary: Singapore's manufacturing sector is poised for growth, particularly in higher-value-added processes, as governments and companies focus on strategic and critical manufacturing. Consultants expect increased support from the government to build resilience and self-sustainability in critical manufacturing activities, such as producing medical equipment and essential food items. Industry experts, including Accenture and SAP, believe Singapore has a strong foundation in advanced manufacturing and can leverage digitalization and Industry 4.0 to drive growth. Former MP Inderjit Singh suggests increasing manufacturing's share of Singapore's economy to 25-30% to boost economic contribution.

site_title: China's manufacturing sector expands in May; unemployment remains high
summary: China's manufacturing sector expanded in May with a PMI reading of 50.7, its highest since January, but demand remains weak, pointing to a slow economic recovery. Roughly 80% of factories have resumed production, but new export orders and imports slowed, and over 50% of companies reported a drop in demand. The unemployment sector remains a concern, with an estimated 70-80 million workers out of jobs. The government has implemented a fiscal package and cut interest rates to stimulate growth, but labor market conditions remain weak, holding back the recovery in consumer spending.

site_title: HK stocks rally after Trump holds fire
summary: Hong Kong stocks rose 3.4% after US President Donald Trump's speech on Friday, which lacked specifics on measures that would directly impact the city. The Hang Seng Index is trading below its price-to-book value, near a record low, after being pummeled by concerns over the economy and US-China ties. China's crackdown on Hong Kong and US farm imports tempered optimism, sending the offshore yuan down 0.2%. The lack of immediate measures from Trump eased investors' concerns about potential sanctions on the Hong Kong economy.

site_title: China halts purchase of US farm imports, threatening trade deal
summary: China has halted purchases of US farm imports, including soybeans, amid escalating tensions with the US over Hong Kong. State-owned companies Cofco and Sinograin were ordered to suspend purchases, while private companies were not instructed to halt imports. The move threatens the phase-one trade deal between the two countries, which was signed in January. China's decision follows President Donald Trump's criticism of Beijing's move to impose national security legislation on Hong Kong, which critics say will crack down on dissent.

site_title: Rex soars 18.7% after deal completion for 2 Norwegian Sea drilling licences
summary: Rex International's shares surged 18.7% after the company announced its subsidiary completed a farm-in deal for a 15% stake in two Norwegian Sea drilling licences. The licences, operated by INEOS E&P Norge AS, are located in water depths of 325 meters. The deal marks a significant milestone for Rex, with exploration drilling planned for early 2021. The farm-in has an effective date from January 1, 2020, and is a standard practice for licence transactions in Norway.

site_title: Covid-fuelled cuts to luxury ad spending worsen magazines' plight
summary: Luxury brands in Europe have significantly reduced their ad spending on magazines and newspapers due to the COVID-19 pandemic, with cuts ranging from 30% to 80%. This has worsened the financial plight of the magazine industry, which is already struggling due to declining advertising income. Luxury brands have shifted focus to digital marketing, and some have expressed uncertainty about returning to print ads in the future. The shift to digital is expected to continue as brands seek more direct and measurable results from their advertising efforts.

site_title: Banks eye permanent telecommuting for some staff
summary: Singapore's major banks are expected to maintain their current work-from-home arrangements, with 70-90% of staff already working remotely. The banks are re-examining banking conventions and considering permanent telecommuting for some staff. As the country eases out of its circuit breaker measures, banks will reopen customer service locations with enhanced safety measures, including face shields, acrylic dividers, and disinfecting coatings. The Ministry of Manpower has recommended adopting working from home as a default option, and some banks are exploring the long-term potential of remote work.

site_title: Fiat Chrysler to list robot-making unit Comau
summary: Fiat Chrysler plans to list its robot-making unit Comau, appointing Paolo Carmassi as CEO. Comau will be spun off after the merger of Fiat Chrysler and PSA, with shares to be distributed to new group shareholders. This move is part of Fiat Chrysler's strategy to separate its various business units.

site_title: Uzbekistan sells hotel stake to Singapore-based firm
summary: Uzbekistan has sold a controlling stake in its iconic Hotel Uzbekistan to Singapore-based Bashan Investment Group for $23.2 million. The state will retain a minority stake, and the company plans to invest nearly $40 million in modernizing the 17-floor hotel over the next year and a half. The sale comes as the country seeks to attract foreign investment and tourists, with many locals welcoming the change, citing the hotel's outdated condition. The building's facade will remain unchanged for the next 10 years.

site_title: Singapore shares climb on the back of a strong rally in Hong Kong
summary: Singapore's Straits Times Index rose 1.6% to 2,550.86 points, following a strong rally in Hong Kong, which rebounded after US President Donald Trump avoided pulling out of the US-China trade agreement. Hongkong Land was the top performer, increasing 8.3% to US$4.07. DBS Group Research upgraded Sembcorp Industries and ComfortDelGro to "buy" with raised target prices, citing undervaluation and opportunity to accumulate on weakness. The market saw 322 advancers and 161 decliners, with 2.18 billion shares worth S$2.11 billion changing hands.

site_title: Pandemic prompts manufacturers to rejig supply chains, operations
summary: Singapore manufacturers are adapting to the pandemic by diversifying their supply chains and operations, with many choosing local suppliers and setting up facilities in more countries to reduce risks. Companies are reducing the number of nodes in their supply chains, diversifying sources, and analyzing changes based on impact to demand, cost, and efficiency. Manufacturers are also prioritizing local labor, technology, and infrastructure, and are exploring digital tools to predict and respond to future disruptions. The Singapore government may need to step in to localise capabilities that are out of reach financially for individual companies, particularly in the biomedical field.

site_title: Sotheby's to stream live auctions in June
summary: Sotheby's will hold its first digitally streamed live auction on June 29, featuring contemporary art and followed by an impressionist and modern art evening sale. The auction will be livestreamed in high-definition, allowing bidders to participate by phone or online. Oliver Barker, a Sotheby's auctioneer, will conduct the auction from London, while specialists in New York, London, and Hong Kong will take bids on the phone. The event aims to replicate the excitement of traditional auctions while incorporating the latest technology.

images.alt_text: An artist's impression showing how Sotheby's plans to hold live auctions remotely beginning on June 29. The auctioneer will take bids from Sotheby's specialists on the phone in New York, London and Hong Kong with the results broadcast to screens in a control centre studio setup.

site_title: SIA directors opt to not subscribe for rights MCBs
summary: MOST directors of Singapore Airlines (SIA) have chosen not to exercise their mandatory convertible bonds (MCBs), despite the airline's proposal to shareholders in April. SIA CEO Goh Choon Phong let his provisional allotments lapse, which included 3.34 million rights MCBs. This decision comes after the airline's larger cash call proposal. The move is seen as a strategic choice, with no direct impact on the airline's financial situation at this time.

site_title: US: Stocks dip as market digests protests, reopenings
summary: US stocks declined in early trading on Monday, digesting the weekend's civil rights protests and the country's reopening from coronavirus shutdowns. The Dow Jones fell 0.6%, the S&P 500 shed 0.4%, and the Nasdaq Composite declined 0.2%. Markets seemed to brush off the weekend's events and continued to reach new records, with the S&P 500 and Nasdaq edging to fresh records despite tariff uncertainty.

site_title: Gilead remdesivir results mixed in moderate Covid-19 patients
summary: Gilead Sciences reported mixed results from a late-stage study of its antiviral drug remdesivir in moderate COVID-19 patients. Patients given a 5-day course of the treatment showed statistically significant improvement, while those given it for 10 days did not. The results, announced on June 1, 2020, are a step down from earlier studies showing a 31% reduction in hospitalization stays. Despite this, the US FDA granted emergency use authorization for remdesivir last month, citing its potential to reduce hospital stays.

site_title: Corporate digest
summary: Keppel Corp's associate company Floatel International will conduct an independent review of its business plan, potentially updating assumptions used in impairment assessments of its vessels. This comes after a competitor, Prosafe, adopted different assumptions leading to a $30.3 million impairment. Heeton Holdings is cutting its final dividend for the 2019 financial year to 0.3 Singapore cents per share due to financial uncertainty amid the Covid-19 pandemic. Clearbridge Health is facing a lawsuit for 1.06 trillion rupiah (S$102 million) from a shareholder over a notarial deed.

site_title: UK's big spending to lift economy and save jobs does little, but deepens debt
summary: The UK government is set to unveil an economic stimulus package in July to combat the recession caused by the Covid-19 pandemic, despite already saddling itself with a massive debt approaching £2 trillion. The package is expected to be delivered sooner than the scheduled autumn Budget, amid concerns over productivity and job losses. The UK's economy has shrunk for a second consecutive month, with the furlough scheme denting productivity and deepening the nation's debt crisis.

site_title: Moon tells Trump he would accept invitation to G7 summit
summary: South Korean President Moon Jae-in told US President Donald Trump he would accept an invitation to join this year's Group of Seven summit, a decision seen as a sign of progress in the face of the global coronavirus crisis. The summit, originally scheduled for late June, has been postponed to September. Trump expressed his desire to invite Australia, Russia, South Korea, and India to the meeting, citing the need for a new system that reflects the current international situation.

site_title: Ex-regional Morgan Stanley Asia COO joins board of robo-adviser StashAway
summary: Former Morgan Stanley Asia COO Sim Hwee Hoon has joined StashAway's board of directors as an independent non-executive director. Ms Sim, with over a decade of experience in major US banks, brings her expertise to the Singapore-based robo-adviser. Her appointment marks the first time an independent director has been appointed to the board, which now comprises six members. Ms Sim previously sat on the board of NTUC Income and was CEO of Morgan Stanley Asia International's Singapore branch. She expressed excitement to join the board, citing her support for StashAway's growth and mission to empower customers.

site_title: The future of infrastructure as an asset class
summary: The infrastructure sector is poised to play a crucial role in post-Covid economic recovery, with multilateral agencies and private sector developers increasingly participating in infrastructure growth. The sector has strong correlations to economic growth and employment creation, and investments in infrastructure can boost private-sector output by a median of $13 and job growth by roughly one million full-time equivalents. Despite the challenges posed by the pandemic, technology adoption, data centre and telecom infrastructure projects have outperformed, and the focus on essential services has helped operating power and utilities continue on a business-as-usual basis.

site_title: WHO seeks good ties with US despite Trump's exit move
summary: The World Health Organization (WHO) expressed its desire to maintain good ties with the US, despite President Donald Trump's decision to cut ties. WHO Director-General Tedros Adhanom Ghebreyesus praised the US's "immense" contribution to global health and urged continued collaboration. In contrast, WHO epidemiologist Maria Van Kerkhove warned that close contact during protests could heighten the risk of spreading Covid-19 disease.

site_title: Covid-19: Do we want to do this again?
summary: A year after the Australian bushfires, the world is experiencing a surprising recovery, with clear skies and waters in previously polluted cities and waterways. The COVID-19 pandemic has also led to a decrease in pollution, as people have reduced their urban activities. However, this recovery raises questions about the sustainability of the environment and the ability of nature to recover from human damage. Experts warn that the world must learn from past mistakes and take action to prevent future catastrophes, as the climate crisis continues to pose a significant threat to global stability and human life.

site_title: US manufacturing stabilising at depressed level, ISM data show
summary: US manufacturing showed signs of stabilization in May, with the Institute for Supply Management's gauge improving to 43.1 from a 4-month low of 41.5. Production and factory employment edged up, while orders rose after a slump. Despite this, weak export markets, high unemployment, and lean capital spending budgets pose significant challenges. The industry is expected to continue recovering, with some growth anticipated in June, according to ISM Chairman Timothy Fiore.

site_title: BT and ST organise star-studded virtual concert
summary: Singapore's BT and ST are organizing a virtual concert, ChildAid 2020 - Virtually Yours, in July to aid underprivileged children. The event features a star-studded lineup, including Nathan Hartono, Benjamin Kheng, Jasmine Sokko, and Jeremy Monteiro, and will be presented as an immersive 360-degree video. The concert aims to raise funds for the Business Times Budding Artists Fund and The Straits Times School Pocket Money Fund, which have aided over 170,000 children. The event marks the 20th anniversary of the latter charity.

site_title: Seizing opportunity in crisis to keep retail interest alive in stocks
summary: Retail investors have rediscovered their appetite for local equities, with a sharp spike in new stockbroking account openings and retail participation in the first quarter of 2020. The COVID-19 outbreak has drawn investors to resume trading, while new players are tempted to try their luck. For the market to remain sustainable, companies, shareholders, and brokers must seize the opportunity and engage in constructive partnerships. Companies need committed shareholders for support, while shareholders should adopt a collaborative mindset and engage with management. Brokers must rebuild relationships with investors, taking advantage of the current low prices and interest rates.

site_title: ECB expected to pump up eurozone support as pandemic persists
summary: The European Central Bank (ECB) is expected to announce hundreds of billions of euros in new bond-buying to combat the pandemic crisis, with analysts predicting a 500 billion euro addition to the existing Pandemic Emergency Purchase Programme (PEPP). The move aims to support the eurozone economy, which is forecast to contract by 8-12% in 2020. The ECB will also review its quarterly growth and inflation forecasts, with inflation expected to fall as low as zero across the year. The announcement comes as European Union governments prepare to discuss a joint response to the crisis, amid concerns over the ECB's powers and the impact of a German Constitutional Court ruling.

site_title: FintruX Network offers smart solutions for startups, SMEs
summary: FintruX Network, a company providing smart solutions for startups and SMEs via blockchain technology, has set up a S$2 million fund to accelerate sustainable financing for small F&B businesses in Singapore affected by the pandemic. The fund partners with F&F Fintech to offer loans and financing solutions to over 60,000 licensed hawkers and food establishments, aiming to reduce vulnerable business owners' reliance on unlicensed moneylenders. This initiative also provides access to FintruX Network's suite of smart solutions, including TruX, to empower small F&B businesses and their suppliers.

site_title: Axcelasia gets S$0.208 per share cash offer from Dorr Global Healthcare Intl
summary: Dorr Global Healthcare International is making an unconditional cash offer of SGD 0.208 per share for Catalist-listed Axington Inc, valuing the company at SGD 33.3 million. The offer price represents a 43.45% premium to Axington's last traded price. Dorr acquired a 66.9% stake in Axington from various directors and shareholders for SGD 22.3 million. The company intends to maintain its listing status and has completed the sale of its core business in Malaysia. The deal is final and no offer price revisions are planned.

site_title: China tells state firms to halt purchases of major US farm products: sources
summary: China has instructed state-owned firms to halt purchases of major US farm products, including soybeans and pork, in response to the US decision to eliminate special treatment for Hong Kong. This move could expand to include additional US farm goods if further action is taken by Washington. China has already cancelled 10,000 to 20,000 tonnes of American pork shipments and suspended bulk purchases of US corn and cotton. The halt could potentially scrap the Phase 1 trade deal between the two countries.

images.alt_text: Large volume state purchases of US corn and cotton have also been put on hold, one of the sources said.

site_title: Directors make S$0.225 per share cash offer for Dynamic Colours
summary: Directors of Dynamic Colours have made a voluntary conditional offer of S$0.225 per share, valuing the company at S$47.2 million. The offer, led by Goh Seok Eng and Yeo Hock Leng, who own 23.15% of the company, is conditional on receiving 90% of total shares and does not intend to maintain listing status. The offer represents a unique cash exit opportunity for shareholders with low trading liquidity, and privatization will allow management to optimize business operations and implement changes.

site_title: 40,000 migrant workers cleared of Covid-19 to resume working, 8 sites picked for new 'quick build dorms'
summary: 40,000 migrant workers in Singapore cleared of COVID-19 infection to resume working after the circuit breaker lifts. Around 60,000 workers will be housed in eight new low-density "quick build dorms" by end-2020. Face masks remain mandatory, but face shields can be used in certain situations. Health Minister Gan Kim Yong stated that face shields are not as effective as masks in reducing virus spread.

site_title: SIA directors opt not to subscribe for rights MCBs
summary: MOST directors of Singapore Airlines (SIA) have chosen to let their rights mandatory convertible bonds (MCBs) lapse without exercising them. SIA CEO Goh Choon Phong and non-executive chairman Peter Seah had let their allotments lapse, but applied to take up their rights shares. Other directors, including Gautam Banerjee and Simon Cheong, subscribed for their rights shares entitlements, while three directors took up neither. The decision may be due to foreign shareholders not being eligible for the rights. The SIA directors act in their personal capacity as shareholders, and their individual investment decisions are not commented on.

site_title: Traders to get S$0.30 per DLC goodwill payment for SIA shorts by June 8
summary: Singapore Airlines traders who held 5x Short Singapore Airlines daily leveraged certificates (DLCs) will receive a S$0.30 goodwill payment per DLC within five business days from June 2. The payment is a gesture of goodwill for Societe Generale's late disclosure about its ex-rights adjustment to the price of the structured products, which caught traders off guard. The regulator is reviewing the situation, but it is widely believed that Societe Generale breached disclosure rules.

site_title: US awards new US$628m contract to boost output of potential Covid-19 vaccine
summary: The US government has awarded a $628 million contract to Emergent BioSolutions to boost manufacturing capacity for potential Covid-19 vaccines under the "Operation Warp Speed" program. The contract, valued at $542.7 million, secures Emergent's manufacturing facilities in Baltimore for 2021, while an additional $85.5 million will be invested in expanding the company's viral and non-viral drug manufacturing capacity. This award is part of the Biomedical Advanced Research and Development Authority's efforts to secure manufacturing capacity for Covid-19 vaccines, with over $2 billion invested so far in vaccine development and funding over 30 projects.

site_title: Music industry pledges anti-racist 'Black Out Tuesday'
summary: Major music industry labels including Atlantic Records, Capitol Music Group, and Sony Music have pledged to halt business on Tuesday, in solidarity with anti-racist demonstrators demanding structural social change and an end to police brutality following the killing of George Floyd. Several celebrities, including Rihanna, Beyonce, and Jay-Z, have voiced anger and solidarity, while others have joined advocacy marches. Donations have also been committed to civil rights organizations, with the hashtag #TheShowMustBePaused being used to emphasize the industry's commitment to change.

site_title: Hong Kong April retail sales tumble 36 per cent as virus hammers demand
summary: Hong Kong's retail sales plummeted 36% in April, marking the 15th consecutive month of decline, due to the COVID-19 outbreak and anti-government unrest. Sales dropped to HK$24.1 billion, a 42.1% decrease in March and 44% in February. The government attributed the decline to the still-severe disruptions of Covid-19 and austere labour market conditions. The retail sector faces significant challenges, with 15,000 stores estimated to close by the end of the year if operating conditions don't improve.

site_title: Daily Debrief: What Happened Today
summary: CIMB customers have created a website (HonestMortgages.sg) to challenge the bank's decision to hike mortgage rates. OCBC will trim the salary credit bonus interest on its 360 account from 1.2% to 0.6% starting July 1. Keppel's Floatel associate will conduct an independent review of the business plan following a major competitor's impairment of US$810.5 million. Two Clearbridge Health units are being sued for 1.06 trillion rupiah (S$102 million) by a shareholder. The STI rose 1.6% to 2,550.86 points, following the announcement of US President Trump's economic plan.

site_title: July issue of Singapore Savings Bonds opens with record low rates: 0.3% for first year, 0.8% per annum on average
summary: The July issue of Singapore Savings Bonds (SSBs) opened with record-low rates, starting at 0.3% for the first year and averaging 0.8% per annum over 10 years. This follows a declining interest rate environment and higher demand for government bonds. The low rates have led to a decline in redemption rates, with an average of 17.8% in recent issues. The low interest rates may also impact the interest in SSBs, with a sharp decline in total amounts applied for recent issues.

site_title: Truckmaker Scania signals lay-offs, has 5,000 more staff than needed
summary: Scania, a Swedish truckmaker owned by Traton, is planning major job cuts due to the coronavirus crisis. The company has an estimated 5,000 more staff than needed globally and is reviewing up to 1,000 white-collar positions at its headquarters. Scania's CEO, Henrik Henriksson, stated that the company will adapt to the new situation, with measures including reducing consultants and reassessing industrial and commercial operations. The company's first-quarter operating profit fell by two-thirds, and it is taking cost reduction measures to adapt to the post-crisis market.

site_title: Govt to build 11 dorms in next 2 years for 100,000 workers; temporary spaces for 60,000 workers
summary: Singapore plans to build 11 purpose-built dormitories for 100,000 migrant workers in the next two years, aiming to improve living conditions and reduce public health risks. Temporary spaces for 60,000 workers will be ready by the end of the year, including semi-permanent "quick dorms". The government is exploring various models for building and operating the new dorms, including a build, own, and lease model. This initiative comes after the government identified the need to address concerns over living conditions in dormitories, where over 90% of COVID-19 cases in Singapore are foreign workers.

site_title: STI up 1.6%, in line with Asian market performance after Trump's announcement
summary: The Straits Times Index (STI) rose 1.6% to 2,550.86 points, in line with Asian market performance after US President Donald Trump avoided pulling out of the US-China phase one trade agreement. Hong Kong's Hang Seng Index jumped 3.3%, while Singapore's top performers included Hongkong Land and Sembcorp Industries, with upgrades from DBS Group Research. The STI saw 322 advancers and 161 decliners, with 2.18 billion shares changing hands.

site_title: Malaysia: Shares close higher on Monday
summary: Malaysia's FTSE Bursa Malaysia Kuala Lumpur Composite Index rose 16.89 points to 1,490.14 on Monday, with a total volume of 10.308 billion lots worth RM6.734 billion. The narrow loss of 64 shares outweighed the 511 gainers.

site_title: Beleaguered Wirecard to proceed with business after insolvency
summary: Wirecard, a German payments company, has filed for insolvency despite its management board's decision to proceed with business activities. The company owes creditors almost $4 billion after discovering a global fraud that led to a significant hole in its books. The Wirecard Bank unit, which holds 1.4 billion euros in deposits, is under emergency management by the German banking regulator. The company's bank will continue to carry out payments to merchants, and it is in talks with regulators and credit card companies to resume operations. An investigation is underway in the European Union.

site_title: Broker's take: DBS upgrades SATS to 'hold', says it is 'on track for long recovery'
