summary: DBS Group Research upgraded SATS to "hold" from "fully valued" with a target price of S$2.64, citing the gradual reopening of the Singapore economy and the company's long-term recovery prospects. SATS is expected to benefit from increased air traffic at Changi Airport, driven by the opening of Terminal 5 and growing non-aviation revenue streams. However, the company faces risks such as cost pressures, currency fluctuations, and a softening Japanese yen.

site_title: BT and ST organising star-studded virtual concert for charities
summary: BT and ST are jointly organizing a virtual concert, ChildAid 2020 - Virtually Yours, in July to support The Business Times Budding Artists Fund and The Straits Times School Pocket Money Fund. The concert features a star-studded lineup, including Nathan Hartono, Benjamin Kheng, Jasmine Sokko, Jeremy Monteiro, and child talents. The event aims to raise funds for underprivileged children and is presented as an immersive 360-degree video experience with surround sound. The concert marks the 20th anniversary of STSPMF and The Straits Times' 175th anniversary, with over 170,000 children aided by the charities.

site_title: Worst may be over for eurozone factories, recovery to be slow: PMI
summary: Eurozone manufacturers appear to have passed their lowest point, with IHS Markit's Manufacturing Purchasing Managers' Index (PMI) recovering somewhat in May after crashing to a 22-year low in April. However, activity remains sharply contracting due to ongoing lockdowns and low demand. The slow recovery suggests a prolonged economic downturn, with many countries in the bloc still grappling with the pandemic's impact. The PMI's recovery is seen as a positive sign, but further growth is expected to be slow.

site_title: Wirecard files for insolvency after US$2b goes missing, CEO's arrest
summary: Wirecard AG, a German payment-processing firm, filed for insolvency after discovering over $2 billion was missing from its balance sheet. CEO arrested amid accounting scandal. Insolvency proceedings leave creditors facing lengthy negotiations, with banks demanding clarity on debt repayment. Wirecard's licenses with major credit card companies, including Visa and Mastercard, are at risk. The company's collapse raises questions about Germany's financial regulator's handling of the scandal, prompting calls for a parliamentary inquiry.

site_title: Bodies left on hospital beds as virus overwhelms Mumbai
summary: Mumbai's public healthcare system is overwhelmed due to India's worsening coronavirus outbreak, with hospital wards filled to capacity and medical care for non-COVID patients suspended. Bodies have been left unattended in hospitals, and patients are forced to sleep on the floor until beds become available. The shortage of beds, ventilators, and oxygen stations for critical patients has resulted in deaths, with some families refusing to claim bodies due to fear of infection. The situation has exposed India's social inequality, with the city's slums being particularly affected, and has raised concerns about the government's ability to cope with the crisis.

site_title: Primark to open all stores in England on June 15
summary: Primark plans to reopen all 153 stores in England on June 15, following the easing of coronavirus lockdown restrictions. The retailer has been trading from 112 stores across Europe and the US, and expects to have 281 stores open by then, representing 79% of its total selling space. While customer queues have been encouraging, cumulative sales are down on the same period last year, with social distancing measures affecting some of its busiest stores.

site_title: Chinese online tutor Zuoyebang raises US$750m in fresh round
summary: Chinese online tutoring startup Zuoyebang raised US$750 million in a fresh funding round led by FountainVest Partners and Tiger Global Management, with other investors including SoftBank's Vision Fund and Sequoia Capital China. The company, founded by Baidu in 2014, has over 50 million daily active users and 12 million paid users. The funding round comes as the Covid-19 crisis spurs investor interest in education technology.

site_title: CIMB customers join forces to challenge bank on mortgage hike decision
summary: A group of over 40 CIMB Bank Singapore mortgage customers have joined forces to challenge the bank's decision to raise the floor of its mortgage rates, citing a significant increase in interest payments due to the bank's new 0.9% rate. The customers created a website, HonestMortgages.sg, to raise awareness and support other affected customers. Despite initial pushback, the bank has not rescinded its decision, and the customers are concerned that this may lead to further exploitation of consumers.

site_title: Singtel's 5G strategy involves building new services, not just network access: management
summary: Singtel, one of two nationwide 5G licence holders in Singapore, plans to move beyond just network access and create new solutions and services with 5G. The company aims to integrate 5G with artificial intelligence, cloud, and data technology to deliver next-generation services. Singtel plans to roll out its standalone 5G network in Singapore from early next year, with coverage goals of half the island by 2022 and the whole country by 2025. The company believes 5G will be transformative for industries and create sustainable economic and social value.

site_title: US agencies to give Congress full data on coronavirus small business loans: letter
summary: US Treasury Secretary Steven Mnuchin and Small Business Administration head Jovita Carranza told lawmakers they will give Congress full access to Paycheck Protection Program data by the end of next week. This move comes after Mnuchin previously resisted calls for transparency. The data will include all borrower names and loan amounts, as well as 75% of the loan dollars approved, and will be sent to the Government Accountability Office. The release aims to help lawmakers guide government aid during the pandemic.

site_title: Hong Kong: Stocks close sharply higher
summary: Hong Kong stocks surged over 3% on Monday, driven by relief that US President Donald Trump held off unveiling severe measures against China over its security law proposal for the financial hub. The Hang Seng Index rose 3.36% to 23,732.52, while the Shanghai Composite Index and Shenzhen Composite Index also gained 2.21% and 3.16% respectively. The rally follows recent US threats to extend its trade war with China, but traders appear to be brushing off the uncertainty.

site_title: Fashion: Trial Run
summary: Luxury fashion shopping has become a challenging experience due to the COVID-19 pandemic. Despite strict social distancing measures, crowds are still present at high-end boutiques such as Louis Vuitton, Chanel, and Dior. To maintain safety, stores have implemented protocols including temperature checks, hand sanitizers, and disposable gloves. Customers must adapt to longer waiting times and physical contact is strictly prohibited. The shift towards online appointments and limited in-store capacity poses challenges for personalized interaction between customers and salespeople, potentially leading to costly mistakes or damaged products.

site_title: Unilever to stop advertising on Facebook, Twitter and Instagram in US
summary: Unilever, owner of brands Ben and Jerry's and Marmite, has stopped advertising on Facebook, Twitter, and Instagram in the US until the end of 2020 due to the polarized election period. The decision comes after Unilever joined a growing list of brands boycotting the platforms over concerns of hate speech and incitements to violence. The move is part of the "Stop the Hate for Profit" campaign, which aims to pressure companies to take a stand against hate speech on social media.

images.alt_text: Consumer giant Unilever, home to brands including Ben and Jerry's and Marmite, said on Friday it will stop advertising on Facebook, Twitter and Instagram in the US until the end of 2020 due to the "polarised election period" there.

site_title: Unilever, rivals mull changes amid global backlash against skin-lightening products
summary: Unilever, the maker of the popular skin-lightening cream "Fair & Lovely", is considering marketing changes amid a global backlash against such products. The company's dominant line of creams has faced criticism for promoting colorism and discrimination based on skin color, particularly in South Asia. Unilever is reportedly discussing potential changes, including rebranding with phrases like "skin detox" and "skin vitality", in response to growing social media pressure.

site_title: California Disneyland delays reopening as virus cases surge
summary: Disneyland in California has delayed its reopening until it receives approval from state officials due to a surge in coronavirus cases in the state. The park was originally set to reopen on July 17. The company cited California's lack of theme park reopening guidelines as the reason for the delay, which follows a record spike in new cases in the state. This decision follows similar delays in reopening at Disney's Orlando, Florida-based Walt Disney World.

site_title: China lawmakers to vote on HK law Tuesday: report
summary: China's top legislative body will vote on Hong Kong's security legislation on Tuesday, potentially handing down a measure that could erode the city's unique freedoms. The proposed law includes life sentences for acts of secession and subversion, sparking criticism from pro-democracy activists and foreign governments. The legislation is part of Beijing's efforts to maintain social stability after last year's protests. If passed, the law could come into effect in time for Hong Kong's July 1 anniversary of its return to Chinese rule in 1997.

site_title: Oil dives over 5% as US crude stocks hit record, Covid-19 cases mount
summary: Oil prices plummeted over 5% due to record US crude storage and rising COVID-19 cases in the US, Germany, and other countries. Brent crude settled at $40.31 a barrel, while US West Texas Intermediate crude fell to $38.01 a barrel. The market is concerned about the prolonged impact of the pandemic on demand, with the International Monetary Fund slashing its 2020 global output forecasts. A stronger US dollar and slump in equities also contributed to the price drop.

site_title: Workers' Party to contest 4 GRCs, 2 single-seat wards
summary: The Workers' Party (WP) announced its lineup for the upcoming Singapore General Election, contesting 4 Group Representation Constituencies (GRCs) and 2 single-seat wards. The party's secretary-general, Pritam Singh, introduced four candidates, including Nicole Seah, a former National Solidarity Party candidate, and Yee Jenn Jong, a former Non-Constituency MP. The candidates aim to bring a fresh perspective to Parliament, with a focus on balance, inclusivity, and addressing the needs of minority groups. WP plans to campaign online due to the pandemic and safe-distancing requirements.

site_title: Stocks to watch: MIT, Keppel Infra Trust, Hong Leong Finance, Accordia Golf Trust
summary: Several companies have announced new developments that may affect trading. Mapletree Industrial Trust raised S$410 million through an upsized private placement, lifting its trading halt. Keppel Infrastructure Trust secured a seven-year S$700 million sustainability-linked loan. Hong Leong Finance launched a Business Loans Campaign to support small and medium-sized enterprises. Accordia Golf Trust distributed S$15.7 million, exceeding initial Covid-19 reserves. Yoma Strategic Holdings proposed a US$76.5 million deal to acquire a controlling interest in Digital Money Myanmar.

site_title: PAP's 5th slate comprises three new candidates from law, banking, aviation
summary: The People's Action Party (PAP) has announced its fifth slate of candidates for the upcoming Singapore General Election, consisting of banker Derrick Goh, aviation expert Poh Li San, and lawyer Raymond Lye. Goh has 27 years of banking experience, while Poh is a former search-and-rescue pilot and first female full-time aide-de-camp to the late President S R Nathan. Lye, a former magistrate and founder of Union Law LLP, aims to promote meritocracy and ensure no Singaporean is left behind. The PAP's fifth slate is part of the party's efforts to engage with Singaporeans and create more synergies.

site_title: Harbouring Hong Kong 'rioters' will harm Taiwan, China says
summary: China's government has denounced plans by Taiwan to help Hong Kongers who decide to flee to the island, calling it a "political plot" to meddle in Hong Kong affairs. China claims providing shelter to "rioters" from Hong Kong will harm Taiwan's people and is an interference in Hong Kong's affairs. Taiwan has set up a dedicated office to help those thinking of leaving Hong Kong, amid Beijing's tightening grip on the former British colony. China denies stifling Hong Kong's freedoms and says national security legislation is needed to return order.

site_title: Singapore wealthy tap insurance for wealth and legacy planning: study
summary: A joint report by AIA and EY found that 70% of high net worth individuals in Singapore use insurance for wealth and legacy planning, with 78% believing it plays a significant role in creating and preserving wealth. This is higher than in other Asian markets, with Singaporeans using insurance for succession and legacy planning at a rate of 75%. Insurance solutions are also being considered for business continuity and long-term wealth protection, with keyman insurance being a popular option among entrepreneurs.

site_title: Singapore NODX falls 4.5% in May on decline in non-electronics exports
summary: Singapore's key non-oil domestic exports (NODX) fell 4.5% in May, its first monthly drop this year, due to a decline in non-electronic shipments. This marks a reversal from four consecutive months of year-on-year growth. Economists predict that exports may bottom out as lockdowns ease and countries reopen their economies. However, concerns remain about the ongoing Covid-19 pandemic and US-China trade tensions, which could impact growth prospects.

site_title: Central banks cut US dollar offers in sign of market confidence
summary: Major central banks in Europe and Asia, including the European Central Bank, Bank of England, Bank of Japan, and Swiss National Bank, will cut their dollar offers to lenders from daily to three times a week starting July 1, a sign of confidence that market tensions are easing despite ongoing economic pain. The move follows massive liquidity injections since the pandemic crisis and a decline in dollar market strains. The central banks remain ready to adjust their dollar liquidity provision as warranted by market conditions.

site_title: US: Dow ends up 2.0% as stocks rally on strong retail sales
summary: US stocks surged 2.0% on Tuesday, driven by strong retail sales data and a 17.7% spike in May sales. The Dow Jones Industrial Average rose 525 points to 26,289.98, while the S&P 500 and Nasdaq Composite Index gained 1.9% and 1.8% respectively. Federal Reserve Chair Jerome Powell vowed to maintain stimulus efforts, but warned that a full recovery is unlikely unless consumers feel confident about the Covid-19 situation. Analysts say the gains reflect a "buy the dip" mentality, with stocks now gaining three sessions in a row.

site_title: Leases for commercial equipment, vehicles to be covered by Covid-19 Act
summary: Singapore's Ministry of Law announced on June 19, 2020, that leases for commercial equipment and vehicles will be covered by the Covid-19 (Temporary Measures) Act, providing temporary relief for contractual obligations due to the pandemic. This move joins other categories of contracts already covered, such as non-residential property and event-related contracts. The new measures aim to support businesses affected by the Covid-19 outbreak.

site_title: Paris Ritz hotel items sell for quadruple the auction estimate
summary: The Paris Ritz hotel auction sold 1,500 items, including historic silver, crystal, and towels, for 1.7 million euros (S$2.64 million), exceeding the pre-sale estimate by four times. The auction, postponed due to the coronavirus epidemic, saw buyers from 25 countries participate, with items like a 12-plate "Marthe service" and Christofle serving trollies selling for 45 and 58 times their estimated values, respectively. This is not the first time the hotel has sold off historic items, as two years ago, it sold 7.2 million euros' worth of furniture.

site_title: Surge in demand for gloves giving rise to new billionaires in Malaysia
summary: Malaysia's glove industry has seen a surge in demand due to the coronavirus pandemic, resulting in four billionaires in the sector, including Thai Kim Sim of Supermax Corp, who has an estimated net worth of US$1 billion. Top Glove Corp, Hartalega Holdings, and Kossan Rubber Industries have also benefited, with their stock prices doubling in 2020. The industry's growth is expected to continue, with global demand for rubber gloves projected to increase 11% to 330 billion pieces this year, with Malaysia accounting for two-thirds of this demand.

site_title: Egypt to reopen airports, resume beach tourism from July 1
summary: Egypt will reopen its airports on July 1 and resume beach tourism, welcoming tourists from countries that have reopened their airspace. The country aims to restore business as usual, with Aviation Minister Mohamed Manar expressing hope for a successful reopening.

site_title: Asian business sentiment plunges to record low on virus effect: poll
summary: Asian business sentiment has plummeted to an 11-year low due to the ongoing COVID-19 pandemic, according to a Thomson Reuters/INSEAD survey. The index fell to 35, its second-lowest reading since the survey began in 2009. Companies cited a worsening pandemic, deepening recession, and staffing and business volume declines as major risks. Economists warn of a prolonged recovery, with the US Federal Reserve signaling a long road to recovery and recessions expected to be more severe this year than forecast.

site_title: Twitter adds option to share spoken tweets
summary: Twitter is introducing a voice tweet feature, allowing users to record and share audio messages up to 140 seconds in length. The feature, currently available for Apple mobile devices, will be tested and rolled out in the coming weeks. Users can tap a "wavelength" icon to record voice tweets, which will be posted as audio files on their timeline. The feature aims to add a more human touch to Twitter, as text can sometimes lose conversational nuances.

site_title: Sweden's Telia In talks with Turkish sovereign wealth fund for Turkcell stake
summary: Telia, a Swedish telecommunications company, is in talks to sell its 24% stake in Turkey's largest mobile-phone carrier, Turkcell, to the Turkey Wealth Fund. The talks are ongoing and may not result in a deal. This move comes as Telia aims to exit Turkey, and Turkcell's shareholders have been locked in a long-running battle over control of the company. The Turkey Wealth Fund, which also owns a stake in Turkey's largest bank TC Ziraat Bankasi AS, is the potential buyer.

site_title: BOE's toolkit may include a bond-buying policy made in Japan
summary: The Bank of England is considering implementing yield-curve control, a policy pioneered by the Bank of Japan, to target specific levels in its government bond buying and reduce borrowing costs. This move could help the UK finance its massive support package to revive economic growth at a low cost. The policy has been debated among economists, with some predicting it may be more likely than negative interest rates. The UK's economy has shrunk a record 20.4% in April, and the central bank is exploring unconventional tools to support the country's coronavirus-addled economy.

site_title: JC Penney wins approval of contentious bankruptcy financing
summary: JC Penney Co has received approval from a federal judge for its $900 million bankruptcy financing package, which provides the retailer with $225 million now and potentially another $225 million next month. The loan is tied to a restructuring deal that allows lenders to force a sale of the retailer if they don't agree on a business plan by July 14. Critics have called the financing "predatory" and a "hold-up," but the judge acknowledged the creditors' risk and the need for a restructuring plan to move forward.

site_title: Citi upgrades Singapore banks to a 'buy'
summary: Citi Research upgraded its call on Singapore banks to "buy" citing a V-shaped recovery in 2021, despite economic concerns. Analyst Robert Kong raised target prices for DBS (29.8% increase), OCBC (40% increase), and UOB (39% increase). Shares of Singapore banks surged on Monday. Citi's economists believe rising interest rates and liquidity from the Fed will prevent a financial crisis, and that the banks' earnings in Q2 will show the "true weakness" of the lockdown period.

site_title: Hong Kong: Stocks rise for third day
summary: Hong Kong stocks rose for a third consecutive day, driven by the easing of global lockdowns. The Hang Seng Index climbed 1.37% to 24,325.62, while the Shanghai Composite Index rose 0.07%. The rally was despite ongoing US-China tensions, with traders brushing off new threats from President Trump.

site_title: Equities to move higher on sustained economic recovery: UBS
summary: Global equities are poised to move higher despite economic data showing a 7% year-to-date decline, according to UBS's Asia-Pacific head Tan Min Lan. The market is forward-looking and will "look past the immediate damage" as economies begin to recover in the third quarter, with sustained growth expected by the first half of 2021. Key investment opportunities include cyclical and value stocks, gold, and active management strategies, with trends such as automation, e-commerce, and cybersecurity also expected to benefit.

site_title: South Korea's May unemployment rate surges to 10-year high
summary: South Korea's unemployment rate surged to 4.5% in May, the highest level in over 10 years, due to businesses slashing hiring amid the coronavirus pandemic. The number of jobs declined 392,000 from a year ago, with small retailers, restaurants, and lodging being the hardest hit. The nation's economy faces challenges as exports tumble and policymakers rely on domestic demand to stimulate growth. A resurgence of virus cases also casts doubt on a swift rebound in consumption.

site_title: Trump can't change G-7 format: EU
summary: The EU's chief diplomat has warned US President Donald Trump that he cannot change the format of the G-7 summit. Trump plans to hold an in-person summit, possibly in September, despite the EU's opposition. The G-7 consists of the US, Britain, Canada, France, Germany, Italy, and Japan. Russia was expelled from the group in 2014 after annexing Crimea from Ukraine, and the EU sees no reason to change the format. The EU's stance is seen as a response to Trump's intention to invite Russia to the summit.

site_title: Eye, robot
summary: Singapore National Eye Centre's medical director, Professor Wong Tien Yin, says COVID-19 is accelerating the healthcare sector's transition to a digital model of care, which could lead to structural shifts in hospital operations. The pandemic has hastened the adoption of digital technology, including teleconsults, electronic records, and AI, allowing for remote monitoring and streamlined processes. This could result in improved productivity, reduced wait times, and a redeployment of manpower. Patients may be able to rely on home-monitoring devices and AI to decide if they need to visit a doctor physically. The transformation could also lead to a leaner staff and reduced physical infrastructure needs.

site_title: Daily Debrief: What Happened Today
summary: Singapore's Employment Pass (EP) holders and S Pass holders may lose their Job Support Scheme (JSS) wage support if their employers disguise retrenchments. Minister Josephine Teo stated that employers must show a plan to fill the vacancy within a reasonable timeframe to avoid having the JSS wage support withdrawn.

images.alt_text: Companies found to have disguised their retrenchments could have their wage support and work pass privileges withdrawn, Manpower Minister Josephine Teo said on Thursday.

site_title: Tata unit to launch digital acceleration centre in Singapore
summary: Tata Consultancy Services (TCS) plans to launch a digital acceleration centre in Singapore, offering up to 100 traineeships to local polytechnic and university graduates. The centre aims to support the recovery of local businesses and build a future-ready workforce. It will provide real-world learning experience and training in cutting-edge technologies, including cloud adoption, AI, and cybersecurity. TCS will invest S$3 million over 12 months, with the potential for well-performing trainees to be hired by the company. The centre is part of Singapore's Smart Nation efforts, with the goal of upskilling and reskilling the workforce.

site_title: France reports 13 more coronavirus deaths, total at 29,155
summary: France's coronavirus death toll rose by 13 to 29,155, with 1,053 people in hospital intensive care units, a decrease from the previous day. The total number of people being treated in hospital for Covid-19 fell by 18 to 12,461, and confirmed cases rose by 343 to 153,997. With probable cases in long-term care homes added, France's total cases are around 190,000, the ninth-highest in the world.

images.alt_text: France's coronavirus death toll, the fifth-highest in the world, rose by 13 on Sunday to 29,155, the government said.

site_title: Brand new ball game
summary: During the COVID-19 pandemic, businesses are adapting their marketing strategies to engage customers and address their concerns. Companies like Carro, a used car marketplace, and PropertyGuru, an online real estate platform, have seen a surge in blog users and sessions by creating informative content on how to navigate the pandemic. Other sectors, such as property developers and lifestyle firms, have turned to virtual tours and online campaigns to connect with customers. Research suggests that investing in marketing during a recession can lead to increased profits and market share. Companies are also focusing on emotional sensitivity, empathy, and creating shared value with their loyal customers. The pandemic has accelerated the digital revolution, with many businesses shifting their focus to online marketing and digitalization.

site_title: Thailand's farm-to-table resilience featured in food export jump
summary: Thailand's food exports surged in April, with the proportion of food-related exports reaching 19.7% of total shipments, the highest in eight years. Despite a 3.3% decline in total exports, the country's agricultural products, such as rice, seafood, and fruit, are gaining popularity overseas. This shift is expected to continue, with food exports potentially surpassing 20% of total exports this year. The trend offers hope for millions of Thai farmers and food producers, who are facing economic challenges due to the COVID-19 pandemic.

site_title: Geely's Polestar plans China showroom expansion to compete with Tesla: sources
summary: Polestar, a premium electric vehicle maker owned by Geely, plans to expand its showroom network in China to 20 locations, with most opening in the third quarter. The move aims to compete with Tesla's locally made Model 3, as showroom strength becomes a key differentiator in China's massive auto market. Polestar plans to deliver the Polestar 2 electric sedans in China from July. The expansion is part of Polestar's efforts to strengthen its presence in the market ahead of new model launches.

images.alt_text: Polestar, the premium electric vehicle maker owned by China's Geely, plans a big expansion of its showroom network in the mainland, sources said, as it prepares for delivery of cars to compete with Tesla Inc's locally made Model 3.

site_title: StaffAny launches app to help SMEs manage reopening measures
summary: StaffAny has launched a mobile app called CICO, which combines the government's SafeEntry digital check-in system with its workforce management solution. The app helps SMEs manage reopening measures, including attendance tracking, temperatures, and health declarations. CICO is free-of-charge for local businesses that sign up by June 30, and StaffAny plans to integrate it with SafeEntry APIs in the future. The app aims to help businesses reopen safely and digitally transform their operations, with co-founder Janson Seah believing the pandemic will be the catalyst for this change.

site_title: Personal finance in the age of social media
summary: Financial advisers in Singapore are turning to social media to reach the younger, more tech-savvy generation, with major insurers reporting a spike in online client engagements. However, concerns arise about the spread of misinformation and cookie-cutter content. Industry experts caution that financial advisers must be careful to provide tailored advice, and that social media content must be emotive and engaging to create an effective call to action. A common three-step social media strategy involves generating interest, inviting prospective clients to webinars, and following up with one-on-one appointments. Despite these challenges, many insurers believe that social media is a useful tool for establishing a brand and presence with existing and prospective clients.

"Many advisers acknowledge that social media doesn't necessarily translate to sales because it takes time to build your brand and following. But it's a very useful tool to help advisers establish a brand and presence with existing and prospective clients." - Daniel Lum, director of product and marketing, Aviva Singapore.
Wong Sze Keed, CEO designate and chief distribution officer of AIA Singapore, says the firm's set of market conduct guidelines is further complemented with a social media monitoring process.

Odd Haavik, Prudential Singapore's chief distribution officer, says the firm does not offer any form of financial or investment advisory to individuals online. Its financial advisers are not allowed to "portray opinions as facts", or share confidential or sensitive information on social media channels, among other guidelines.

site_title: Pandemic antibiotics surge will cause more deaths: WHO
summary: The World Health Organization (WHO) warned that the surge in antibiotics use during the COVID-19 pandemic will lead to increased bacterial resistance and more deaths in the crisis and beyond. WHO Director-General Tedros Adhanom Ghebreyesus said that only a small proportion of COVID-19 patients needed antibiotics, but the inappropriate use of antibiotics will fuel the trend of bacterial resistance. The organization has issued guidelines to limit antibiotic use, particularly in mild and moderate cases of COVID-19.

site_title: Finance chiefs say EU urgently needs to bolster capital markets
summary: A panel of top EU finance chiefs emphasizes the urgent need to deregulate capital markets to boost stock buying, citing the coronavirus recession and Brexit's loss of the EU's financial hub. They advocate for a "capital-markets union" to encourage equity investment, particularly for companies struggling to access funding. This comes as the EU seeks to maintain economic stability amid the pandemic and post-Brexit uncertainty.

site_title: Australian, New Zealand dollars suffer setback, fundamentals still support
summary: The Australian and New Zealand dollars experienced a setback, with the Aussie down 0.5% to US$0.6820 and the kiwi down 0.3% to US$0.6411. Despite the losses, fundamentals remain supportive, including a 25% rise in iron ore prices and Australia's successful virus containment, which has boosted consumer confidence. Analysts at ANZ note that the sell-off may be attributed to a "risk off" sentiment, but fundamental analysts at Westpac remain optimistic, lifting their AUD target to US$0.72 by year's end.

images.alt_text: The Australian and New Zealand dollars nursed heavy losses on Friday as a sudden sea change in risk sentiment snapped a three-week run of sharp gains and knocked both currencies from multi-month highs.

site_title: A booming airline business: shipping pigs to China in 747 jumbo jets
summary: Volga-Dnepr Group, a Russian cargo carrier, has seen a surge in demand for air freight during the COVID-19 pandemic, with sales rising 32% to $630 million in the first four months of 2020. The company has flown over 3,000 breeding pigs to China on Boeing 747 cargo planes to help restore local livestock levels after an outbreak of African swine fever. Volga-Dnepr's revenue is expected to reach $2 billion this year, with the company expanding its geography and shipping medical goods, masks, and hazmat suits to countries affected by the virus.

images.alt_text: Volga-Dnepr Group has flown more than 3,000 breeding pigs to China from France this year. The animals - transported 6,450 miles (10,400 kilometres) in wooden crates in the hold of a Boeing 747 cargo plane - are being used to restore local livestock levels to help mitigate shortages in the world's largest pork market after an outbreak of African swine fever decimated China's hog herds.

site_title: Executive fit
summary: Headhunters now use a range of assessment tools to find the right CEOs, including data mining, AI, and algorithms. Heidrick & Struggles' Alain Deniau says that the CEO of today needs soft skills and cultural fit, as well as the ability to lead with empathy and understand people well. The firm uses digital tools to assess individuals and group dynamics, and has developed assessment tools to evaluate multiculturalism and leadership styles. Deniau envisions a Board that takes on long-term responsibilities, such as ensuring diversity and sustainability. The CEO must define and demonstrate ethics, and the firm aims to develop a "crystal ball" to predict future behavior.

images.alt_text: "You cannot look at today's CEO without looking at the Board. The Board must, now and in the future, be in charge of the long-term implications for the company, the long-term value creation. So we expect the Board to work on diversity, sustainability, long-term digital transformation; to deal with political pressure. A good Board must take over some of these responsibilities to let the CEO concentrate on what has to be done." - Alain Deniau.

site_title: Gold pushes higher as investors prepare for Powell's testimony
summary: Gold prices rose as investors awaited Federal Reserve Chairman Jerome Powell's testimony, with spot gold increasing 0.5% to $1,733.07 an ounce. The Fed's measures, including buying individual corporate bonds, are seen as a commitment to take all possible measures to combat the pandemic. The Bloomberg Dollar Spot Index fell 0.4%, and concerns over new US outbreaks and a weaker dollar also contributed to the gold rally.
